column2: ARMISTICE means a short suspension of hostilities. Not so in France, where the armistice is now well over four years old. Catherine Pomeroy Stewart, in her novel "So Thick the Fog," relates the adventures of the Marquis de Polnay, his wife and five children during the first years of German rule in France.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The armed services now are purchasing fully 90 per cent of all sports and game equipment produced in the United States -- and civilians will have to be content with their present supply yet awhile.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Fourth Air Force of March Field, Calif., made and took advantage of all the breaks but the last one as it lost the opening major football game of 1944 before 50,000 fans in Memorial Coliseum last night.

WHEN an interviewer puts a question to Gary Cooper he may be certain of one thing -- the answer will be to the point and brief, too tantalizingly brief. For Mr. Cooper, unlike most people in show business, is by no means a loquacious person.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 26 -- In a recent speech before the training class of the Kuomintang, Dr. Sun Fo, President of the Legislature Yuan and son of Dr. Sun Yatsen, urged the party to resume its original leftist direction.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 26 -- Breaking the track record by four-fifths of a second, Bon Jour, 6-year-old bay gelding owned by Charles Turner of Toronto, stepped home in first place in the $50,000 added Trenton Handicap at Garden State Park today.

The Hollywood show now being presented under the great name "Wilson" has nothing to do with history. Only in its last half hour it develops two political problems: the League of Nations and Versaillies. The first is given as it should be, but the second is handled in a way that represents a danger in these months of great political decisions.

Further evidence of expansion and new adaptations of joint or centralized buying by retailers in the post-war period, stressing close retailer-manufacturer relationships, was seen last week in the formation of a new buying agency by R.H. Macy Co., Inc., and the May Department Stores Company.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 26 -- Connecticut OPA authorities accused seven Stamford women today of violating emergency price control ceilings in connection with buying of butter from Hartsdale Farms, Inc., a Bronx firm, without giving sufficient ration points.

In an effort to overcome the slump in salvage collections that has marked the summer months Mayor La Guardia and other officials will meet with salvage workers on Tuesday at City Hall to discuss ways of increasing collections, particularly of waste paper, during September.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 26--Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine and nine other high officials of the New York City Police Department inspected Camp Smith and the activities of the First Brigade of the New York Guard today, arriving at noon and staying until evening.

PERHAPS the last person in creation to make any artistic claims for the gay films of Preston Sturges would be Mr. Sturges himself. As a youth, this most recent wonder-boy among the Hollywood magnificoes conceived a titanic revulsion to the fopperies of upper-case Art, due to a large helping of it from his aggressively dilettante mama.

One thing about the zinnia: it doesn't need pampering. Give it a root bed, sunlight and a start, and it will make its own way. It responds to care and cultivation, but it makes few demands. And with half a chance a bed of zinnias will brighten the end of August as few other flowers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- A Pacific Fleet press release:

THE author of this historical novel, which tells of Danish colonial expansion in the eighteenth century, is himself a young Danish novelist, just recently arrived in Sweden after narrowly escaping murder at the hands of Danish Nazis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (U.P.) -- Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee assailed tonight the Senate-approved George Industrial Demobilization Bill as "putting the cart before the horse" in emphasizing unemployment compensation instead of speedy conversion to peacetime production.

The apartment key stamped with the number "7-F" in the handbag of the blond woman whose body was found Friday in a clump of brush beside the main door of Hayden Planetarium in Manhattan Plaza, the victim of a strangler, quickly unlocked the mystery of her identity yesterday.
Mrs. Reginald T. Townsend has gone to the Manoir Richelieu, Murray Bay, Que., for a fortnight.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Four years ago Paris fell to the Germans. The Government of France declared the capital an open city and its citizens grimly watched the gray-clad Wehrmacht moving in without a struggle. This week Paris did not fall to a direct attack by the Allies.

SAIPAN, the Marianas, Aug. 18 (Delayed) -- One of the most unusual individual feats of arms in the capture of Saipan was that of Pvt. George Ruckman, 21 years old of Granttown, W. Va., who killed eighteen Japanese single-handed in a brief fifty-yard walk. Private Ruckman saw only two of his victims before he killed them.

Lieut. Gen. Edmund Hoffmeister, captured commander of the German Forty-first Armored Corps, broadcast from Moscow Saturday to the German people and said that Heinrich Himmler, Gestapo chief, told 150 high ranking officers last spring that he was prepared to deal with internal uprisings and that Adolf Hitler had written off the deaths of millions of soldiers as "only episodes."

AFTER several years of intensive playgoing, somewhat hampered by the fact that I lived in Albany, which made attending the theatre dependent upon what week-ends I could spend in New York and what plays were being shown, I have a few comments and suggestions to make.

Devil Diver made short work of his opposition yesterday at Belmont Park in the $17,650 Wilson Stakes, winning by four lengths as 36,938 persons watched. In with 117 pounds, the Greentree Stable star had heavy backing at 1 to 4 in a race that attracted wagering of hundreds of thousands of dollars.

THE detective in this story is a reporter, and the murderer is his city editor, but the reporter, Lance McCleary, does not know that until the last chapter. The reader has all this information from the beginning. He is told how and why the murders are done and what steps the killer takes to cover up his tracks.

IN the Philippines, up the New Guinea Coast and on the adjacent islands of the Bismarck Sea, Gen. Douglas MacArthur directed some of the most difficult campaigns of the war against Japan in the Pacific. For many months he was hampered by lack of sea transport and support and bedeviled by political charges and counter-charges, some of his own making, that had very little to do with the war.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- One day more and the greatest golf show on earth -- the All-American open -- will have come to an end providing, of course, that there isn't another tie such as has happened in the last two tournaments.

ALGIERS, Aug. 26 -- A newly created organization whose existence has not been announced will soon go to Paris from here. It will be called the Import Committee. Its duties will be to appraise civilian and military needs in France in relation to the supplies already beginning to be imported and to organize their distribution.

News that the American troops passed through Fontainebleau on their triumphal sweep toward Paris must have recalled many a pleasant summer to American students of the Ecole des Beaux Arts and the Conservatoire de Musique, established in the Chateau of Fontainebleau for American students only.

DETROIT, Aug. 26 -- Development of a machine capable of laying an unbroken line of plastics or rubber of any length was announced today by Fred M. Zederan engineering executive of the Chrysler Corporation.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Allied warships operating in the English Channel and Beaufighters of the Royal Air Force Coastal Command have dealt a stunning blow to German merchant shipping and escorting vessels in the last thirteen days, sinking at least fifty and leaving an uncounted number of blazing hulks or beached wreckage.
BOSTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Braves today split a double-header with Philadelphia, winning the second game, 3 -- 2, after bowing in the opener, 3 -- 0.

DETROIT, Aug. 26 -- The Willow Run plant and the aircraft building of the Ford Motor Company at River Rouge will close for lack of parts if strikers at the Highland Park plant do not return to work at once, company officials warned today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 26 -- Opposing the million-dollars-a-mile New England Thruway, individual residents and organizations between Greenwich and Fairfield, along 35 miles of the 46-mile projected road through Fairfield County, are organizing campaigns to kill or at least modify the Thruway plans, which they say will cut property values, lower the grand lists and thereby raise municipal tax rates.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 -- Net working capital of American corporations reached an estimated $43,000,000,000 in the first quarter of this year, setting a new high record and "re-emphasizing the ability of American industry as a whole to reconvert to peace-time production and also to undertake considerable expansion without recourse to outside sources of funds," the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today in its quarterly report on the country's industry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Early last winter a specially picked officer -- a high specialist in his field -- went to Great Britain. There he stripped off his commissioned insignia, donned "Government issue" and thereafter spent several weeks as a replacement private in various Army organizations.

CAIRO (By Wireless) THE diplomatic event which precipitated the torrent of death from the war clouds which had been lowering over Europe during the late Nineteen Thirties was the signature in Moscow on Aug. 23, 1939, of the pact between the Continent's two most open political enemies -- National Socialist Germany and the U.S.S.R.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- In a powerful stretch drive, By Jimminy, with Georgie Woolf aboard, sailed to a six-length triumph in the $80,200 American Derby at Washington Park today to enable Woolf to register his third victory in the classic.

PARIS, Aug. 26 -- Paris has taken the Americans to her heart. An American soldier can't walk a block without having a Parisian -- man, woman or child -- dash up and plant a kiss on his cheek. The GI's are doing all right on the love front, too.
IF America's understanding of China has not kept pace with our good will, we have, at least, a growing choice of interpreters of that country.

UNLESS they have reservations in their pockets, those taking vacations the first two weeks in September are out of luck. For Labor Day, with the possible exception of July 4, is the peak holiday of the year, with all trains and resorts crowded.

Possible economic sanctions that may be imposed upon Japan was the subject uppermost in the minds of textile men in the primary markets last week. The problems of post-war trade and their relation to industry in general and textiles in particular were highlighted in discussions among mill men and exporters in Worth Street.

MAN'S ability to form associations has reached a certain point and then stopped. And at this point, as though to remind him of the difficult further step from which he shrinks, death and destruction on an unprecedented scale have intervened.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The War Shipping Administration reported today the death of Capt. A.O. Lia of Lynbrook, N.Y., master of the tanker Bostonia, who personally sought to stop a gas leak below decks rather than to order any of his crew to undertake the hazardous task.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Col. J.B.L. Lawrence, public relations officer of the United States Army in the European Theatre of Operations, paid tribute tonight to American war correspondents and photographers in a radio address.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- C.E. Wilson, president of the General Moors Corporation, recently has had some difficulty explaining to friends and others that he is not resigning from the War Production Board, and that he is not feuding with the WPB's chairman, Donald Nelson.

THE TIMES Magazine recently gave prominence to an article advocating that a polite type of communism be grafted onto our capitalistic economy; boldly advocating that a much larger use than heretofore be made of what he terms "collectivist economy."

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- In the month since the opening of the Allies' offensive in France, the French Forces of the Interior have won a world-wide reputation for their assistance to the Allies in the great battles from St. Lo and Caen to the Seine and Paris.

IT was not merely Paris which was freed in a memorable week but a city that in so many meanings represented the capital of Europe. The collapse of Germany is now measured in weeks and perhaps enthusiasm does not altogether dictate that verdict in view of the collapse in the Balkans and the speed of the advance in southern France.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Producers of Pennsylvania anthracite were ordered by the Solid Fuels Administration not to supply between Sept. 1 next and March 1, 1945, the old Colony Coal Company of 271 Church Street, New York, Deputy Solid Fuels Administrator Charles J. Potter announced today.

Retail trade was generally good last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. College shop trade was brisk, home departments were active, and coats and suits sold well.

MR. MALCOLM MACDONALD, British High Commissioner in Canada, feels that too few Canadians are aware of the potentialities of their great Northwest and so he has written an account of his two short airplane trips, which swung from Ottawa to the Arctic Ocean.

FURNISHING a room at college may mean merely brightening it up with color -- a gay bedspread, draperies, a few favorite knick-knacks. Or it may call for providing a more ample desk and dresser or an easy chair.
THE Quien Sabe's unlettered crew called Lars Skattebol The Professor because he read books. In an earlier period of maritime history the bitter skipper might have called him Sea Lawyer.
LONDON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:
THE greatest danger facing the United States isn't World War II. It may cost us a million men and two or three hundred billion dollars. But as a nation we're psychologically prepared for it.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in Rumania and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

Many attempts have been made by the Federal Government to tax undistributed earnings of corporations. And various methods have been prescribed in the revenue laws by which corporations have been coerced to distribute earnings and threatened with severe penalties for failure to make distributions.

The elimination of the German Seventh Army as a fighting entity has decided the Battle of France. The survivors of the Normandy battle, and a handful of German divisions north of the Seine can at best fight a series of delaying actions on their retreat into Germany.

In the last issue of Science Drs. David K. Miller and C. Rakete announce that in an icebox culture of tuberculosis germs they discovered a green mold which is probably akin to penicillin and which checks the growth of tuberculosis germs both in culture and in guinea pigs.
PARIS, Aug. 25 (Delayed) (AP) -- The bottom fell out when the Germans came into Paris in June 1940.
A communique, as broadcast yesterday from Chungking in English to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The great Allied victories this week on the military and political fronts gave weight and emphasis to Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's statement that the end of the war in Europe was in sight.
ROME, Aug. 26 (AP) -- A communique:

HOLLYWOOD. SAMUEL GOLDWYN staged his second revolt against what he terms "vicious and unfair film buying prejudice" on Tuesday night when he opened his Danny Kaye picture, "Up in Arms," in a converted dance hall in Reno as a climax to his fight with the T. and D. Circuit, which runs the five movie theatres there.

After the attack on Pearl Harbor, A.N. Spanel of Dover, Del., foresaw that in this war immense bodies of troops would have to be landed on hostile coasts. Many men wounded in such landings while still in the water would be drowned by their heavy packs, he thought, as, apparently, no attempt had been made to deal rationally with the wounded in amphibious operations.
LONDON, Aug. 26 (U.P.) -- The French Forces of the Interior, in a spectacular drive, have liberated Vichy, according to a special broadcast from FFI staff headquarters there today.

Apropos of a column on safety in the hunting field carried here the other day, C.S. Bedell of the Sportsmen's Service Bureau dropped in with some figures purporting to show that a man out a' hunting actually was less liable to accident than he was in his own parlor or, for that matter, riding horseback or playing baseball or football.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Although he sailed fifth in the closing competition of the five-race series, 19-year-old Gerald Driscoll, United States Naval Academy appointee from San Diego, Calif., today won the twenty-second international Star Class yacht championship with a total of 86 points.

THE anonymous author of "Escape From Konigstein" has refused to let himself be discouraged by the undeniable fact that current history is rather more exciting than any dreamed-up adventures. Rather, he has seized upon one of the prime mysteries of the war -- the escape of General Giraud from the Nazis -- and let fact give structure to his fiction.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- The problems of education in the rural areas of the United States were brought sharply to the attention of the Central Westerners this week by some of the country's leading scholars in a conference on the subject attended by 200 educators at the University of Chicago.

AFTER three days of deliberation, the jury stands eleven for conviction against one for acquittal The lone holdout is a young woman, Holly Phillips, who cannot bring herself to believe that Tom Warren is guilty of the murder of Barton Greely, even though all the evidence appears to point that way.

"SUCCESS STORY" might well have been the subtitle of this handsome, massive volume in which Dr. Lombardo has traced the rise of a poor immigrant boy to a considerable position of esteem. In fact, no less a personage than Fiorello H. La Guardia has written a brief but enthusiastic preface for the book.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26--The Earl of Halifax, British Ambassador, appealed tonight for a continued Allied cooperation if the world were to win its way back to anything like secure prosperity in the post-war era. In his talk, the Ambassador said that British Commonwealth war casualties, military and civilian, were nearing the million mark.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 26 -- The entire Germanophile Cabinet of Rumania, including Marshal Ion Antonescu, was arrested by order of King Michael Wednesday night or early Thursday in a one-man stroke, precipitating the about-face of the wealthiest Balkan state after months of secret negotiations between Rumanian emissaries and Allied delegates, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Sidney J. Weinberg, one of the War Production Board's vice chairmen, and a friend of both Chairman Donald M. Nelson and the resigned executive vice chairman, Charles E. Wilson, has resigned his own post with that agency and will return to New York, according to reports tonight.

NOW in its second year of activity, the concert division of USO Camp Shows, an organization which is devoting itself to supplying our fighting men with serious music, reports that business is booming. Since the first concert artist went overseas (that honor belongs to Winifred Heidt, young American mezzo-soprano, who toured the Caribbean area in February, 1943), the men in the services have demanded more concert music.

TIME moves gently up at the beautiful Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park. The rotating seasons leave their imprint, but this is perceptible only in a snail-pace process of weathering, of patinating, of "settling" into the perfect environment provided.

ALTHOUGH it has made no announcement of immediate plans, the New Opera Company has not been spending the summer in idleness. Specifically, it has been spending the summer discussing the L. Bush-Fekete -- Mary Helen Fay play, once called "Tryout in Boston."

IRUN, Spain, Aug. 26 -- Ten thousand Germans encircled by American and French forces around Belin, thirty miles south of Bordeaux, surrendered late this afternoon, French authorities in Hendaye said tonight.

THE dome of alabaster is a white dome indeed and the floor of inlaid onyx is very black. The golden temple door that reaches to heaven is a high door and the blue of the Eastern sky is of surpassing loveliness. Simple statements of fact, these, but together they must spell the anguish of frustration to some future dreamer of Hollywood dreams.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 26 -- Lieut. W. Donald McNeill of the Naval Air Station at Norfolk, national tennis champion in 1940, and Francisco (Pancho) Segura of Ecuador, third in the American ranking, will meet tomorrow afternoon at 2:30 in the final of the fifty-fourth annual invitation tournament at the Meadow Club.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Before 500 guests in St. Mary's Student Chapel, Elyse Knox, film actress, and Lieut. Tom Harmon, Army flier and former University of Michigan All-America football player, were married this morning.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Bulgaria, three days after the withdrawal of Rumania from the Axis, has promised to get out of the war, become a neutral state and to disarm any Germans who remain or may retreat into their country. This announcement was made by the Moscow radio tonight and was followed by a Bulgarian radio announcement that Bulgaria had approached the United States and Great Britain for peace terms.

At Dumbarton Oaks, the 143-year-old Georgetown mansion that has known the tread of many Presidents, the three most powerful of the United Nations started work last week on the most difficult problem of the war -- organizing a lasting peace. Outside the estate military police stood on guard, allowing only those with proper credentials to pass.

MARSEILLE, Aug. 24 (Delayed) -- Marseille was still throbbing with its new freedom today, still crackling along dozens of streets with an exchange of shots between the French Forces of the Interior and collaborationists and still crashing to the thunder of German heavy and light cannon that made La Cannebiere as unhealthy as it was yesterday, as well as that whole section around the St. Charles railway station and the port.

Day after day last week the German communique contained this sentence or a similar one: "London is under heavy V-1 fire." In these short words the darkest chapter in the British capital's history since the bitter months of 1940-41 were recorded. The German rocket bomb, Vengeance Weapon No. 1, was taking heavy toll.

BOSTON, Aug. 26 -- Although the World War and ramifications, particularly in France, stayed very much in New England minds this week, new home front offensives on juvenile delinquency won second place in public attention. The brutal murder of a marine by youthful thugs of both sexes, almost in the shadows of Boston's leading art museums in the Fenway, aroused adults to self-examination for contributory negligence.

Evidence of a growing demand for education on the part of adults is shown in the last year's performance of the University of Kansas extension division. Enrollment in extension classes is growing rapidly, and plans are under way for the establishment of additional centers throughout the State.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States started today "one of the most important referanda in its history" when it sent out questionnaires to its country-wide membership to obtain approval or disapproval of a social security policy.

A new curriculum of international studies, which will provide civilians with training for postwar service overseas as administrators with international relief and rehabilitation organizations, will be offered by Columbia University in the academic year 1944-45, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

He is a shortish, thick-set man in the sixties, with a style of beauty falling perceptibly below the classic. His movements are swift and at times almost violent. He carries two pearl-handled pistols in holsters at his belt and takes a boy's delight in fondling them.

WRITING one's second novel, say some of this year's new novelists, is easier, perhaps, than writing the first one, but more exacting -- there is one's reputation to live up to. Elizabeth Janeway, who wrote her New England story, "The Walsh Girls," in New York, is now in the Connecticut countryside writing a novel of New York.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 26 -- Due to demands of a big majority of the people of Mississippi and Louisiana, it now seems more than probable that the Presidential electors from the two States will cast their ballots for the candidates picked by the people.

Insulin shock therapy for victims of dementia praecox has had excellent results among patients treated at Brooklyn State Hospital, enabling 55 per cent of them to become useful members of the community, the Temporary Commission on State Hospital Problems reported yesterday.

The Dodgers were hitting to the left of them, hitting to the right of them, hitting far away from them and mostly into the stands yesterday at the Polo Grounds, where the Giants suffered a crushing 9-0 defeat before 10,912 fans. So a New York winning streak of four games crashed, even as a Brooklyn losing skein snapped at five.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Seven-hit pitching by the veteran Luke Hamlin, coupled with timely slugging, enabled the Athletics to beat the Red Sox for the third straight time today, 6 to 1.
PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 26 -- A job of literary resurrection that would seem super-colossal even in Hollywood will begin to reach the public as soon as the war is over.

It was not the meteorologist's fault that Normandy was invaded in weather of the kind that General Eisenhower did not want. Pre-war international weather service had been disrupted. Nobody knew exactly what the temperature, humidity, barometric pressure and wind velocity were in distant parts of the earth, and without that information prediction was hazardous.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Whatever new impressions Gov. Thomas E. Dewey might have made on the public concerning his fundamental grasp of, or his particular views on, foreign affairs, he was being credited this week-end with certain strategic political advantages resulting from the manner in which he and his advisers handled his latest excursion into the subject, especially in its last phase.
BROWNSVILLE, Texas, Aug. 26 (AP) -- After ninety-seven years Fort Brown, for which this border city was named, will be abandoned Sept. 25 as a surplus military installation.
PARIS, Aug. 26 (AP) -- A great exodus began from Paris to the countryside today with thousands of persons searching for food on surrounding farms.

THIS is, perhaps, the most opportune time to make preparation for the planting and transplanting of evergreens, both conifer and broad-leaved. For all practical purposes they have now completed their top growth.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- By the margin of three runs walked over the plate by Jim Lynn, third of their six pitchers, the Cubs lost a wild game to Cincinnati, 10 to 7, today. Bucky Walters, who had troubles of his own, stuck it out for his nineteenth victory against six defeats.

PAUL WHITEMAN'S new musical series, featuring vest-pocket symphonies especially composed for the Blue network, is scheduled to start Tuesday, Sept. 5, from 11:30-12 P.M. For the premiere, the featured work will be Igor Stravinsky's "Scherzo a la Russe."

IN the eight years which followed the end of the Civil War, the period known as Reconstruction, a great many things of lasting importance occurred. To some people they seemed good, to others bad; tempers flared, demagogues filled the air with platitudes and generalities, the newspapers and journals of the day angled their news even as ours do today, and behind the scenes the men of power manipulated their hidden strings.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26 -- For the first time on the West Coast in this war civilian employes have been dismissed from their war-plant job at the direction of an officer of the armed forces, and the machinery of the Federal Government has been put in motion to bar him from employment by any concern in the country holding Government contracts.

LIKE the experienced traveler who takes no more luggage than he can carry, the wise gardener today tries to bring the upkeep of his property down to his working capacity. This means, among other things, finding attractive yet fairly self-sufficient plantings for those small, inconvenient corners that can otherwise be unduly trying.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

The continued successful operation of the first six new C-2 freighters, which were converted into "reefers" early last year for transportation of frozen meat to Allied forces abroad, has resulted in a Maritime Commission order for similar conversion of six more vessels, it was announced last week by Llewellyn Williams, vice president of the York Corporation, holders of the contract.

TODAY the world thrills to the rapid liberation and the fast approaching freedom of France from her chains -- and the world includes the musicians thereof. The musicians have even, it may be said, a special interest in the matter. They are aware of its bearing upon the revolutionary developments of a century of their art and the expression of the greatest hero that art has known -- Beethoven.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Sunday, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A communique:...

MARGERY SHARP, in spite of a certain modern levity, is in the tradition of genteel British novelists (usually female) in whose writing the aim of all young maidens is matrimony, foreigners are suspect and unstable and the best of all social orders that of Great Britain.
ROME, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The battle of southern France entered its final phase today as the Americans slashed deeply up the Rhone Valley in a race to cut off the fleeing German forces below Lyon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- After the director of Selective Service made his remarks in Denver last Monday, capital newshawks were heard selling their papers with the cry: "Two million GI's to be released when Germany is defeated!"
STOCKHOLM, Aug. 26 -- Out of Germany this week came a certain Swedish traveler who has earned the reputation of being a keen observer. This in a nutshell is what he said about the Reich:

SHALL we pronounce the first vowel of economics as in eel or as in ell? Should gibberish have a soft or hard g? What about the sound of e as in sacrilegious? These and many similar questions recur to those of us who would mind our speech lest it mar our fortune. But we are not likely to find answers to them from radio commentators, especially if we seek uniformity of pronunciation.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Chinese forces besieging the main Japanese Yunnan Province bastion of Tengyueh have made advances in the southern section of the city, the Chinese High Command announced tonight, after Japanese counter-attacks against positions inside the city were repulsed.
PARIS, Aug. 25 (Delayed) (8:20 P.M.) -- The final unconditional surrender of Paris was signed at 6 o'clock tonight in a bare, dingy baggagemaster's office in Montparnasse railroad station in Paris.

One of the leading series of dog shows of the autumn season is that which will begin next Saturday at the fair grounds in Allentown, Pa. Three organizations have combined to repeat the successful triple-header of last fall, beginning with the third annual show of the Bucks County Kennel Club.

We should not favor the immediate unconditional surrender of Germany. We should not strive hard for early victory. We are fighting over a cause. The war should be continued until that cause has been removed. The cause as far as our participation is concerned is to teach the Nazis the futility of the use of force for aggression and tyranny.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- The damage to paintings in a part of Italy, where virtually every town contains some priceless work of art, has been unexpectedly small, the War Office announced tonight. The major art centers have for the most part escaped serious harm, but innumerable works, especially frescoes in smaller towns, have suffered.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 26 -- Rumania's collapse as an Axis adherent and the apparent imminence of similar developments in Bulgaria have suddenly and swiftly altered the strategic picture of the war in southeastern Europe, menacing Hitler with loss of many more troops and, furthermore, facing him with the deprival of his greatest remaining sources of raw materials; above all, oil.

Kitchen departments in department and furniture stores as well as appliance establishments into which a customer may invite her family for an evening meal prepared by herself under the supervision of a "store cook," were predicted yesterday for the post-war period by H.E. Warren, advertising manager, Edison General Electric (Hotpoint) Appliance Company.

Claims against railroads for breakage and loss of goods in transit probably will reach about $60,000,000 before the end of the year, as compared with an aggregate of $42,000,000 in 1943, it was estimated yesterday by Albert L. Green, special representative, freight claim division, Association of American Railroads.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26 -- Demands for post-war programs beyond the backslapping and wishful thinking variety became louder this week as President Roosevelt called upon West Coast shipyard workers for speed in building victory attack transports for amphibious operations in the Pacific while Allied armies were pouring across France.

GREAT LAKES, Ill., Aug. 26 -- Tiny Keo Nakama, Ohio State University's Hawaiian star, annexed his second free-style title, and youthful Joe Verdeur of Philadelphia easily retained his breaststroke crown in the second round of the National A.A.U. outdoor swimming championships tonight.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Supreme Headquarters warned the people of Alsace and Lorraine and Luxembourg today they now were in the rear area of military operations and soon their territory "may become a theatre of war."

DETROIT, Aug. 26 -- A pair of mighty home runs by Rudy York, six-hit pitching by left-hander Frank (Stubby) Overmire and Mark Christman's two-run error spelled a 5-to-0 victory today for the Tigers over the league-leading Browns, who suffered their third successive shut-out.

ONE of the most complex and urgent problems certain to arise in the post-war period is that of India's political future. The people of India have demanded freedom from British rule. In response the British Government has put forward the Cripps offer of 1942, which, it contends, gives India the free choice of dominion status or complete independence.

ROME, Aug. 26 (AP) -- RAF Mustangs of the Mediterranean Allied Air Force yesterday shot up four trains on the Zagreb-Banova Jaruga rail line in Yugoslavia -- at least two of which were loaded with Nazi troops -- and strafed a motor convoy near Arta, Greece.

AT the beginning of Aldous Huxley's new novel his hero, a very young poet with the face of a Della Robbin angel, is standing on the steps of a public library. At the end, much older and wiser, he is quoting from his notebooks long passages beginning, "Read Aeschylus on the subject of Nemesis," or "Must look up what Spinoza says about pity."
OUR combat plane was flying high rough a clear, light blackness. Over the "intercom" the navigator said, "We are exactly at the northern edge of Paris."

LIEUT. COMDR. NEVIL SHUTE, in his latest novel, returns to his favorite element, working his miracles of the air with the sure and steady hand of a practical magician. He takes off for his epic flights from the firm base of experience.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Government announced today that the selling price of cotton owned or controlled by it has been increased 50 points, or one-half cent, a pound in a move to help to bring market prices nearer the parity-price goal sought by Congress.

THE American sweet tooth is proverbial -- in fact, our appetite for sweets of all sorts is said to exceed that of any other nationality. Up until the war per capita consumption of sugar was averaging 100 pounds a year, and though rationing may have cut this quantity it has not materially changed our tastes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- When the Federal Government filed an anti-trust suit this week accusing powerful railroad interests of coercion and collusion in arranging freight and passenger costs the public became newly aware of a controversy whose roots extend back more than half a century.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- With increasing frequency, America's new giant Superfortresses of the air are bombing Japan. Last Sunday's twin mission -- an attack by day and a second raid by night -- dramatically highlighted the role B-29's will play in the strategic destruction of Japan's ability and will to fight.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Communique 140:

Peter van den Toorn, managing director of the Holland-America Line, endorsed yesterday the recent proposal by Basil Harris, president of the United States Lines, which called for a series of shipping conferences between Great Britain and United States steamship operators to iron out problems that might arise in the post-war period.

A brief dispatch from Rome identifying the commanders of the American fleet units that participated in the successful attack on the Riviera coast of France shows again how far-flung are the activities of the United States Navy in this war and how interrelated they are.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 26 (AP) -- With a large delegation of officials and newspaper men from Washington present, the Liberty ship Jesse Cottrell, named for the late correspondent for The Nashville (Tenn.) Banner and other newspapers, was launched at Bethlehem-Fairfield shipyards today.

THE word "hopeless" is often applied to contracts arrived at through over-optimistic bidding, but perhaps there is no such thing as a hopeless contract. The late Comdr. Winfield S. Liggett once made a grand slam when his opponents held the ace of trumps (they revoked on the first trick).

The Australian Constitution is, on paper, much easier to amend than our own. It provides that an amendment can be submitted directly to the voters if approved by an absolute majority of both houses. The amendment is adopted if approved by a majority of the voters in a majority of the States and also by a majority of all the voters.

Lieut. Gen. William S. Knudsen, director of Army Air Forces Materiel and Services, will address an all-day contractors' terminations conference tomorrow at 10 A.M. at the Hotel Wadorf-Astoria. He will discuss "War Contract Readjustment and the Future of American Industry."

In response to a request from Representative S.O. Bland, chairman of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee, Vice Admiral Emory S. Land, War Shipping Administrator, announced yesterday a series of seven recommendations for legislation that amount to an equivalent of the "GI Bill of Rights."

NOT long ago there was a little ceremony at New City, the county seat of Rockland County. A number of men and women received their citizenship papers and took their oaths to support the Constitution of the United States. And the presiding judge made a short but unforgettable speech to these new shareholders in our democracy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Four great decisions mark the foreign policy of the United States: the purchase of the Territory of Louisiana from France, the pronouncement of the Monroe Doctrine, the extension of our obligations to the Asiatic waters of the Western Pacific after the Spanish-American War, and our rejection of the League of Nations.

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 26 (AP) -- A series of aerial lashings of seven Japanese-held Pacific islands, topped by a forty-seven-ton bomb attack on Iwo Island in the Volcano group, 689 miles south of Tokyo, was reported by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz today.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- Governor Dewey declared today that New York's war ballot law was a proved success and said that those who sought to scuttle the system had failed. He included the Democratic party in that category.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- Although the Labor Day week-end will climax the summer season in this resort section, plans to continue the entertainment of sizable throngs of vacationists during the month of September have reached the stage where municipal officials will continue their summer programs.

MOST of those who give any consideration at all to essayists probably think of them as the mildest and most harmless of the literary tribe. The good essayist lives in a pluralistic universe. He has tendencies but rarely dogmas.

LIKE the Old Apple Lady of this story Nura takes children into lands that have never been mapped, but into which they can slip as easily as did Peter Rabbit into Mr. McGregor's garden. So it is with her pictures in which the round outlines and the bright colors of reality are overlaid with a dreamy air of fantasy.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 26 (AP) -- An eight-inning single by Thurman Tucker, scoring Leroy Schalk from second base, provided the winning margin as the White Sox won a free-hitting, 6-to-5 decision from the Indians today, evening the series at a game apiece.
TINIAN, Mariana Islands (Delayed) -- "These are Kiska's beaches," said the officer who had been in the Aleutians campaign, "but this time the Japs are here."

A long-standing need of the western New York area will be fulfilled with the establishment by the University of Buffalo of a four-year program in mechanical engineering. The program, announced by Chancellor Samuel P. Capen, will begin with the opening of the university's fall term on Sept. 27.

A COMPLETE show for a five cent entrance fee! Including all the elements of a box-office hit -- lovely girls, villains, dear old ladies, men in uniform, children, and a big fashion show. The program changes every day, every hour. You never know what is going to be offered. It is an everlasting surprise.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 26 -- Taking an early lead, Crispin Oglebay's Price Level led all the way to win the featured $5,000 added Jeanne d'Arc Stakes by a length at Narraganset Park today.

LONDON, Aug. 26 (Reuter) -- The sixth wartime football season opened in England and Wales today. Clubs began in optimistic mood despite player difficulty and in the south the additional threat of robot bombs.

ANY book on contemporary social politics which reaches a mass audience and persuasively defends a point of view is an important book. "Modern Political Philosophies" meets both these tests. The book will be read not simply because it is inexpensive but because it is written simply, clearly and with a reassuring appearance of objectivity, even of finality.

LAST spring when the theatre glanced into its crystal ball the rosy radiance therefrom was enough to burn the eyes. It would be a fine summer, said Broadway. Travel restrictions and pleas by the Mayor should keep New Yorkers from Cape Cod, Maine and Vermont, although vast multitudes of war workers would be able and anxious to come down week-ends from Bridgeport.

BUFFALO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State chairman, predicted today that the Democratic national ticket will do better this year, with Governor Dewey as the Republican Presidential nominee, than in 1940, when Wendell L. Willkie headed the Republican ticket.

TO some observers such a struggle as the Battle of France is ultimate, indescribable chaos; to others it conveys a series of ordered pictures -- men and tanks and planes and guns moving like well-drilled puppets across hedgerows and through forests, down roads and across rivers, according to some gigantic, well-ordered plan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Fritz Mandl, former Austrian munitions manufacturer, now operating in Argentina, and former husband of Hedy Lamarr, film actress, has been "blacklisted" as being associated with Axis economic interests, the State Department disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The War Production Board had a new chairman this week in the person of J.A. Krug.

WITH THE SEVENTH ARMY, in Southern France, Aug. 26 -- After nearly four years of thinking of France in terms of General Charles de Gaulle, Gen. Henri-Honore Giraud and the French exiles, it comes almost as a shock to realize that France is not Algeria or Morocco or exiled in London.

I would like to compliment Dorothy Gordon on her article on juvenile delinquency. I am 16 and naturally the subject of delinquency is an important one to my friends and me. Dorothy Gordon's piece is the first one that I have read that really got to the core of the issue.

LONDON, Sunday, Aug. 27 -- Russian troops yesterday reconquered Bessarabia, reaching the Danube waterway from the Prut River down to the Black Sea, while other Soviet forces struck westward into the Carpathian Mountains in pursuit of an enemy fleeing toward Hungary and leaving behind scores of thousands of captives and great quantities of war material.

A new curriculum to train workers in the rehabilitation of the handicapped will be opened this autumn in Ohio State University's School of Social Administration. According to a survey made by the National Council on Rehabilitation, Ohio State is the first university to organize and identify as such a long-term integrated course of this nature.

LONDON, Sunday, Aug. 27 -- In a long-sustained strategic air assault, that began with a blistering attack by nearly 1,400 British bombers before dawn on industrial towns deep within Germany, United States heavy bombers concentrated yesterday on five important oil plants in the Reich.

WEATHER conditions in late summer ordinarily favor the development of mildew which is, typically, a white growth over the surface of the plant. The name applies equally to the disease and the fungus which causes it.
ALBANY, Aug. 26 (AP) -- James C. Watson, president of the New York State Council of Retail Merchants, urged pupils today not to quit their studies to take full-time jobs in stores.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Their offensive machinery moving in full swing, the Yankees tonight battered their way still closer to the top in the American League flag race by crushing the Senators, 10 to 3, before a ladies' night gathering of 12,788.

LOUIS WALDMAN was a 17year-old immigrant from the Ukraine, who went to work on the East Side for $2 a week. He followed a well-known path. He learned English in the free night schools, lived under the gloom of the elevated in Allen Street, sweated his days out and went on strike in the garment factories.

Employes in the Sanitation Department who resigned their jobs to enter war industries will not be taken back, although many have applied for reinstatement, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday at exercises held in City Hall Plaza to mark the awards of medals and citations to sanitation workers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Republican leaders joined Socialists today in contending that the White House was responsible for the War Department's turnabout ruling that President Roosevelt's Aug. 12 speech at Bremerton, Wash., was not "political."

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- Oats developed independent weakness today on the Board of Trade on general commission-house selling induced by a lowering of the Canadian equalization fee from 21 to 15 cents a bushel on grain for shipment west of Fort William, Ont., and from 21 to 20 cents east of that Canadian port.

CANNES, France, Aug. 25 (Delayed) -- This is not like Toulon or Marseille. There is no street fighting and there are no crowds of young people patrolling the streets with arms.

Russian War Relief workers were more than pleased to see, in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Aug. 13, the story cabled to you by W.H. Lawrence, describing the use of, and need for, the relief supplies Americans have shipped to our Soviet allies through Russian War Relief, Inc.
PARIS, Aug. 26 -- Describing Paris today is like trying to paint a desert sunset in black and white.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Ralph A. Bard, Under-Secretary of the Navy, charged today the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation with "a desire to incite a controversy between the workers and the Navy Department" by refusing to make payments to the company's employes already approved by the War Labor Board.

They must be, she says, because all the procedures on which she once boned up so diligently aren't of the slightest use now that she has a job and the only times she sees Bill on weekdays are at breakfast and at dinner time.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- With the production of most fruits, vegetables and flowers near peak levels despite the recent drought, a Westchester County Victory Garden Harvest Show will be conducted Sept. 6, 7 and 8 in the armory here by the County Horticultural and Agricultural Association.

With the possibility of a butter shortage looming larger, it was learned yesterday that the War Food Administration had indicated its readiness to aid hospitals unable to obtain butter through regular channels.

As news from the European battlefronts gets better and better, retailers become more selective in their buying and more watchful of their inventories, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

DR. WILLIAM WARREN SWEET has written here an epitome of his researches in church history. He makes no pretense that this study is a complete history of revivalism, nor that it presents a full summary of the subject. Yet in the body of his text he draws mature conclusions which go beyond his self-imposed limitations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The State Department stated today that Japan's peace envoys in the immediate pre-Pearl Harbor period never raised any question about the disposition of American naval forces. The department issued this statement in comment on assertions made by Representative Magnuson of Washington, who told The Seattle Post-Intelligencer there were reports in Washington and on the Pacific Coast that "the Japs made a 'patsy' out of the State Department."

HARDLY a man is now alive who clearly remembers seeing the first St. Louis National League baseball team take the field in 1876, on the very grounds on which today's high-flying Cardinals entertain when at home. And many who can recall certain successors of those pioneers would probably prefer not to, for National League ball was a long time in achieving its latter-day eminence in the Mound City.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- London and southern England went through the second straight day without a robot bomb attack, the longest quiet interval since the assaults began in mid-June, and there was some cautious hope that the Germans had abandoned their launching bases across the Channel as a result of terrific Allied aerial bombardments and the outflanking of Nazi lines east of the Seine River.

A ten-point program to accommodate veterans and essential defense workers whose formal education has been interrupted by the war has been announced at the Junior College of Connecticut at Bridgeport. The purposes of this plan are to provide opportunities for those persons to resume their education quickly, to avoid duplication of former studies, and to aid them in accomplishing their objectives in minimum time.

As the European war enters its final stages and military orders decline, the sharp rate of increase in earnings of industrial manufacturers is slowing perceptibly. The combined net income of $721,554,752 for the 331 companies under review in the first six months of the current year has narrowed to the moderate increase of 4 per cent from the half-year net of $691,355,626 in 1943.
LONDON, Aug. 26 -- The Yugoslav Government in Exile cut its last official tie today with Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch, Serbian officer who has been the center of much of Yugoslavia's internal strife.

"NO BRIGHT BANNER" deals with serious subject-matter and is as pertinent to the times as the daily newspaper, but as a novel it has grave defects. The question it asks occurs in most current fiction: how does a man feel and what does he grow to feel about the America he is asked to fight for?

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 26 (U.P.) -- Reinforced Japanese troops have hacked their way into the Kwangtung Province city of Limkong in a new drive northward from the base of Luichow Peninsula opposite Hainan Island, a Chinese communique said today.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Sunday, Aug. 27 (AP) -- An eighty-five-ton bombing attack on Palau, guarding the central approach to the Philippines, was reported today by Gen. Douglas MacArthur.

THE Museum of Modern Art announces its exhibition plans for the season of 1944-45, which will be upon us in no time at all now. Apparently the Museum of Modern Art is going to be more active than ever.

ALTHOUGH collectors have known for some time that a series of stamps for interim use in liberated France was prepared at the Bureau of Engraving and Printing in Washington and sent abroad, the War, State and Postoffice Departments have denied requests for details.

Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was of moderate volume yesterday, and prices, after showing initial declines of 3 to 8 points, hardened and closed at the best marks for the day, net unchanged to 4 points higher than on Friday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- President Sveinn Bjornsson of Iceland and Villajalmur Thor, Foreign Minister, held a news conference today at which they made it clear that their country has no intention of granting permanent military bases to the United States.

WHEN the Tucker family moved to the country Tim, Andy and Bunty were sure they were going to have a dog. There was even a dog house waiting. But Mr. Tucker, busy with his garden, was curiously evasive about their chief desire.

Last week the American Red Cross properly took credit for having sent by airplane to European battlefronts 500 pints of whole blood -- the first of a series of still larger daily shipments. This does not mean that 100,000 pints of plasma will not be required weekly but it does mean that volunteer soldiers will no longer be the sole donors of whole blood when only that will do.

The Nazi empire has been shrinking during the past week even faster than it expanded in 1940. The fruits of two bold strokes in France -- General Bradley's break-through into Brittany and General Patch's landings on the Mediterranean shore -- were being reaped. Generally speaking, the Germans south of the Seine River are either pocketed in a few resistance centers or are trying to get out.

Today is the eighty-fifth anniversary of the completion of the Drake well, near Titusville, Pa., the first oil-producing well and the beginning of the oil industry. Under private ownership and operation the petroleum industry since has expanded through American genius with a magnitude excelled by few if any industries, and today it is vital to the world's industrial and commercial activity, in revolutionizing which it played a leading role.

LONDON, Aug 26 -- It is a hungry Paris that has thrown off the yoke of the German conquerors. For the past fortnight the Germans have not given much thought to anything except their own escape and supplies.

Assets of the Associated Gas and Electric system, once advertised as a "billion-dollar utilities empire," have shrunk to not more than $115,000,000, Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell held yesterday in approving a reorganization plan sanctioned four months ago by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Allied troops, driving the enemy back south along his route of conquest in northern Burma, have advanced more than twenty-two miles down the Mandalay railway from their base at Mogaung, a communique announced today.
BROOKLYN-BORN Bridget Veronica Kelly, known to the nation as Patsy, rushed into Room 400, RCA Building, Rockefeller Center, twenty minutes late. She apologized in the voice that is peculiar to Patsy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- President Roosevelt ordered today the liquidation of the Division of Central Administrative Services of the Office of Emergency Management, an experimental Federal organization designed to do "housekeeping" for civil war agencies quickly formed.

FROM its practical inception less than twenty years ago, the international short-wave radio has represented a power which even now has not been fully evaluated in terms of world relations: the power to invade in a matter of seconds the privacy and minds of peoples around the globe.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sunday, Aug. 27 -- British infantry carved out two bridgeheads across the Seine at Vernon and Louviers yesterday and smashed northward for a distance of several miles into the chaos of a mass German withdrawal eastward between the Seine and the Somme.

RICHARD BEER-HOFMANN, the last poet of the great Austrian generation of Hofmannsthal and Schnitzler who still towers up in our war-torn time, can hardly be called a prolific writer. His voice was seldom heard, yet the few times it spoke it revealed a great priest of the word whose poetical stature reminds us of the awe-inspiring faces of the seers biblical and classical times.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 26 -- Ninety-three sick and wounded American soldiers who have served overseas, most of them in the Pacific area, arrived here at the Army's beachfront England General Hospital this week for treatment and convalescence.

SWITZERLAND'S annual "National Fete" series comprises four stamps this year, and one of them commemorates the battle of St. Jacob on the Birs five centuries ago. Above a picture of this Swiss town "St. Jacob an der Birs 1444" is inscribed on the 10-centimes plus 10c gray-black and red.

With the final and reasonably speedy defeat of Germany's military power now assured, the representatives of the Allied Powers assembled at Dumbarton Oaks are confronted with the problems involved in formulating a preliminary draft of armistice and final peace terms.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP)--The upheaval in the War Production Board's high command resulted tonight in expressions of Congressional concern lest it hinder both war output and reconversion, and a declaration by Senator Johnson, Democrat, of Colorado, that the WPB chairman, Donald M. Nelson, was being "ditched" permanently.

Associated Press Correspondent OUTSIDE PARIS, Aug. 25 (Delayed) -- What is believed to be the first American vehicle to enter Paris today was driven by Capt. Sachal Bollas, 36, of Los Angeles, Calif., who was born in Paris, and had not been there since 1927.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 26 -- In a ring-around-the-rosie air, which for an hour seemingly had no more idea of settling down than a confused bird, sixty-eight starting craft, a big Saturday fleet, set sail this afternoon in the special series regatta of the Port Washington Yacht Club.

Caution was noted in buying activities in the past week, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

GENERAL HEADQUARTER, Southwest Pacific, Aug. 27 -- Five uncaptured Japanese soldiers saw Judith Anderson play a scene from "Macbeth" when the Broadway actress, now touring the Southwest Pacific as head of a group of entertainers, played Biak Island three days ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 27 -Alan Mowbray has been named by Twentieth Century-Fox to portray George Washington in the fantasy, "Where Do We Go from Here?," to be put into production tomorrow. The studio has exercised its option on Clifton Webb for another year.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 27 -- The honors in the final grass tennis tournament preliminary to the national went to Francisco (Pancho) Segura today, and the little Ecuadorian, with the greatest two-handed drive the game has known, stands forth as the man to beat in the championships starting on Wednesday at Forest Hills.

Frank C. Ferguson, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, announced yesterday that an examiner of the Interstate Commerce Commission had recommended cancellation of so-called all-commodity rail rates representing a reduction of 45 to 50 per cent on mixed freight shipped in carload lots from the North Atlantic region to the South.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- With Hungary apparently next in line to feel the weight of the Red Army offensive, now moving rapidly through Rumania, the Hungarian Council in Great Britain called on its fellow countrymen tonight to cease fighting.
ROME, Aug. 27 -- Polish troops of the British Eighth Army have driven across the Metauro River on the Adriatic coast and are within nine miles of Pesaro.

LONDON, Monday, Aug. 28 -- Powerful formations of Lancaster heavy bombers of the Royal Air Force rained high-explosive and incendiary bombs early yesterday on Koenigsberg, capital of East Prussia and supply depot for the German Nineteenth Army Group facing the Red Army 100 miles to the east.

ROME, Aug. 27 (AP)--In the dawn bombings on D-day along the French Riviera, Lieut. Col. Gilbert T. Mullins of Pagosa Springs, Col., cut loose two 500-pound bombs from his Thunderbolt at a string of boxcars--and thereby kept a promise made nearly two years ago.
AVIGNON, Aug. 26 (Delayed) -The welcome accorded to the French and the Allies here and in the surrounding territory amounts to probably the greatest mass expression of gratitude on record.

Sveinn Bjornsson, president of the Republic of Iceland, arrived here from Washington yesterday afternoon aboard an Army plane for a brief visit to this city. Mayor La Guardia headed a delegation of city officials who welcomed the visitor as he alighted from the plane at La Guardia Field, Queens.

EDMONTON, Alta., Aug. 27 -- The United States Army's abandonment of the Haines Cutoff, a road between the Alaskan Highway and the coast, has raised a question in the Northwest as to the fate of similar projects when their war urgency has ceased.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UP) -- Representative Charles A. Halleck, Republican of Indiana, urged tonight further Congressional inquiry into the Office of Price Administration's "apparent determination to ignore Congressional mandates" in administering price control.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 27 -- Ninety-seven craft, the largest number in any regatta this year out on Long Island Sound, except during Larchmont race week, took part today in the sixteenth championship series contests, which were held by the Port Washington Yacht Club.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- Increased offerings of Canadian oats at lower prices have affected the domestic market and brought in considerable commission-house selling of futures despite the fact the latter are selling at a good discount under both domestic and imported cash grain.

PARIS, Aug. 26 (Delayed) (Reuter) -- For all the wild gaiety today -- reminiscent of pre-war days -- and the great, warm welcome to American and French liberators, hunger and sorrow stalk the streets of Paris.

After the wild poetry of its liberation, Paris today is facing the prose of practical problems. This is as it must be. No one need lament that the exultation which sent delirious crowds into the streets has to be succeeded by a more sober mood which, if all goes well, will send them back to their daily occupations.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 27 -- One of the seven Stamford and Riverside housewives, against whom the Office of Price Administration has brought injunction proceedings for alleged purchase of butter and meat without ration points and above ceilings, said today they were victims of discrimination.

PARIS, Aug. 27 -- Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain, Pierre Laval and former Premier Edouard Herriot were arrested by the Gestapo and taken to Germany a few days before American and French forces entered Paris, a reliable informant said today.

ROME, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A communique:

A realty investor acting through M. L. Hess, Inc., and Henry Shapiro has bought from the Radar Realty Corporation the four-story building at 165 West Forty-seventh Street, on a plot 20 by 100.4 feet. The seller was represented by Scribner Miller, lawyers.

LONDON, Aug. 27 (U.P.) -- A German light cruiser was destroyed and fourteen merchant vessels and a destroyer were heavily damaged by sixteen American Thunderbolt fighter-bombers that slipped through the clouds Friday to bomb and strafe Brest Harbor the Ninth Air Force revealed today.

Still with only frail clues to the murder of Mrs. Phyllis Lyons Newmark, who has found beaten and strangled under shrubbery near the main door of the Hayden Planetarium on Friday, police yesterday through her husband made a public plea for her woman companion on a tryst that apparently preceded the slaying to come forward and aid in solving the mystery.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- For the greater part of last week the stock markets continued their seemingly strange behavior of weakening steadily as the war news became better and better. This paradox is not so strange as it may appear. For months, indeed for years, the markets have been discounting the return to peace.

ABOARD A BRITISH AIRCRAFT CARRIER, off the west coast of Sumatra, Aug. 27 (Reuter) (Delayed) -- A two-wave air strike by fleet air arm Barracuda bombers in the Padang area at breakfast time today extensively damaged, and possibly destroyed, the biggest cement works held by the Japanese outside Japan -- at Indarung, eight miles east of Padang, and heavily damaged shipping and installations at Emmahaven.
Five new films are scheduled to arrive in midtown theatres this week. They are:

Notwithstanding German surrender of Paris, despite Allied victories elsewhere in western Europe and evident abandonment of Nazi affiliations by Rumania and Bulgaria, last week's stock market declined. On Friday transactions fell to 599,240 shares, the smallest full day since July.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 27 (AP) -- The College All-Stars and the Chicago Bears tomorrow stage their final dress rehearsals for their football tangle at Dyche Stadium Wednesday night before an expected capacity crowd of 50,000.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Monday, Aug. 28 -- Strong American forces were pouring eastward between the valleys of the Seine and Marne yesterday in a major offensive that appeared to be directed to the east and northeast.

Since Hugh Russell Fraser in his letter to you, published in your issue of Aug. 22, reflected upon the quality of teaching of American history in Pittsburgh, I hope you will allow me an opportunity to reply.
PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The dropping of forty-two tons of bombs on Iwo in the Japanese Volcano Islands by American Army Liberators was reported today by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz.

Both houses of Congress have passed bills providing for the disposition of surplus war supplies and plant and equipment, and the matter now goes to conference. In view of the lightning speed with which events are marching to their inexorable climax in Europe, prompt action by the conference committee is imperative, so that final action can be taken this week.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 27 (AP) -Agents of the Defense, Navy and Finance Ministries are investigating an attempt to ship to Yucatan a great quantity of dynamite, listed and marked as other merchandise, Navy Ministry officials disclosed yesterday.

" 99 Park," headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc.,* offers a partial list of free amusements available today, through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- Continued small receipts of hogs and announcement the Government had ordered packers to set aside a percentage of their choice cuts of pork stimulated the demand for cured meats last week and small lots of product moved at ceiling prices.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- With candidates for only three of the thirty-five Senatorial seats to be filled in November still remaining to be selected, it is evident that that body will be greatly changed without taking the elections into account.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- The Government's rate for loans on the 1944 wheat crop, combined with a buying of cash grain by the Commodity Credit Corporation at one cent a bushel under the loan figure, continues effectively to check bearish sentiment in wheat futures.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- National banks on June 30 had total assets of more than $70,000,000,000, Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency, announced today. His report covered the 5,042 active national banks in the United States and possessions.
LONDON, Aug. 27 -- The Paris radio listed the casualty figures of last night's raid as 108 persons killed and 719 injured and 290 houses destroyed and 250 damaged.

Those who are willing to confess to a certain age may remember the doubts raised about the talking motion picture when it first came in. It was assumed by some, momentarily at least, that the silent movie might continue to have a place on the screen and that the talkie would not wholly displace it.
PARIS, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A new French Government is being set up rapidly here even as snipers continue a desultory fire.

That unrivaled baseball piece, "The Giants and the Dodgers in Two," had its final presentation of the season yesterday at the Polo Grounds and the results were highly gratifying from a strictly Giant angle.

Uncontrolled and wasteful expansion of urban communities in the last century will curb their future growth, Dr. Homer Hoyt, director of economic studies for the Regional Plan Association, Inc., declared yesterday. He announced that he would direct a new course in urban problems at Columbia University.

IF the war had not intervened it is quite possible that Leslie MacMitchell of N.Y.U. now would be zooming over the track in time not too far distant from the ever-beckoning four-minute mile. The young man was coming along at a tremendously fast pace when he traded in his Violet uniform two years ago for one of a trim Navy blue.

Mayor La Guardia announced in his Sunday broadcast yesterday that City Markets Department inspectors would be posted at every Gristede Bros. store today to serve summonses if the store refused to deduct two cents a dozen from the price of eggs bought by customers supplying their own cartons.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 27 -- As a result of the heat wave, the shortage of manpower and the necessity for repairs to equipment, the rate of production of steel ingots in the nation dropped last week two points to 94 per cent of rated capacity.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 27 (AP) -- After a stinging 14-6 defeat in the firsts game of a double-header clocked at 2 hours and 38 minutes, the Cardinals battled another 2 hours and 4 minutes in the nightcap to manage only a 1-1 ten-inning draw with the Pirates when the game was called because of darkness.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Communique 141:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- About 300,000 more workers are needed by war industries turning out thirteen "key" types of vitally needed equipment, according to a summary on production and manpower issued today by the Office of War Information.

The National Urban League announced yesterday from its headquarters, 1133 Broadway, the start of a new community project to help improve race relations and avoid post-war racial conflict. Financed by the General Education Board, the project is one of the league's efforts to eliminate racial friction from post-war reconversion and redevelopment programs of American industrial centers.

PANAMA, Aug. 27--Political unrest in Guatemala appears to be increasing with the preparations for the Presidential elections and arbitrary arrests by the Government, according to newspapers received here.
LONDON, Aug. 27 (UP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

PARIS, Aug. 27 -- Liberated Paris -- that part of it that went to bed -- got up this morning after the wildest Saturday night in years to touch off another frenzied demonstration in greeting Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and his British, French and American staffs.

Continuing the technique of the conference of twenty-six Republican Governors at St. Louis, radio speeches by nine of these Governors will start the campaign for the party's national ticket, Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National chairman, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Fifteenth Air Force Flying Fortresses and Liberators from Italy drove through heavy flak and attacked two synthetic oil refineries at Blechhammer in Silesia today. Reports from Rome said about 750 heavy bombers and a huge fighter escort made the attack, the second at Blechhammer this month.

Berwin Co, in 957 Park Ave; Percy Douglas, in 550 Park Ave, through Douglas Gibbons Co; John Kimball, in 520 E 86th St, through Douglas Gibbons Co; Lucius Pond Ordway, in 40 Central Pk South -- Culver, Hollyday Co, brokers.

On the assurance that politics and diplomacy would not be discussed, Wendell L. Willkie spoke briefly at a mass meeting last night at Town Hall at which 850 Chinese and Americans celebrated the 2,495th birthday of Confucius. The meeting was sponsored by the China Institute of America.
PAWLING, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- Governor Dewey devoted much of today to further work on his September campaign speeches, but made time to attend Sunday services in Christ Church with his family.

LONDON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Representative Frances P. Bolton of Ohio said today that in her month-long survey of fifteen American hospitals in Britain she had found conditions "very fine with the morale of both patients and staff high now" but that she would lay before the War Department what she considered was a need for an increase in medical personnel in the European war theatre.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Equal time on the Army's short-wave radio facilities would be made available upon request each week to all qualified political parties for rebroadcast of "political addresses" to American armed forces overseas, the War Department said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The Yankees appeared to have taken another big stride toward the top of the American League ladder today and for a brief period actually had elevated themselves to within two and a half lengths of the uppermost rung, when suddenly something gave way and their latest advantage slipped out of their grasp.

Mayor La Guardia's weekly broadcast yesterday from City Hall touched seventeen topics, ranging from an appeal to parents of working children to send them back to school in the fall to an expression of his opinion that the anti-trust suit brought by the Government against a group of banks and railroads was a bit of useless litigation that would cost $1,000,000 or more, to be paid ultimately by the public.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Aug. 27--Allied carrier-borne aircraft, with heavy support of the far-ranging Eastern Fleet, have smashed again at Japan's industrial installations near Padang, chief city on the west coast of the island of Sumatra in the Netherland Indies.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Red Sox broke a five-game losing streak and jumped back in the thick of the pennant fight four games behind St. Louis when they took a double-header from the Athletics today, 8 -- 5 and 7 -- 2 before 30,146.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A Pacific Fleet announcement:

BOSTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A single by Whitey Wietelmann which scored Frank Drews from second base in the tenth inning with the score tied 4-all gave the Boston Braves a 5 to 4 victory over the Phillies in the second game of a doubleheader today. Philadelphia won the first contest, 8 to 5.

Out of Sing Sing a little more than a year, John J. (Mickey) McLoughlin, one of the old Hudson Duster gang that flourished on the West Side docks two decades ago, made the rounds of his favorite bars last week. He spent freely.

History courses are indispensable in the teaching of citizenship in America, members of a panel on "Education for American Citizenship" agreed yesterday afternoon. The discussion was broadcast over WEAF.

More than 100 persons attended a memorial service for Mme. Draja Mikhailovitch, wife of the Yugoslav leader, conducted yesterday at the Serbian Cathedral of St. Sava, 15 West Fifteenth Street. Mme. Mikhailovitch's death after two years of internment in a Nazi concentration camp was announced in London on Aug. 16.

Another gracious French city has been restored to France. Avignon is an enchanted place. Time seems to stand still there, as on the figures of a frieze. Petrarch and Laura and Rienzi have been there. St. Catherine of Siena pleaded there with the Pope to return to Rome.

E.H. Dixon has been elected president of the Electric Power and Light Corporation, and N.C. McGowen has been made president of the United Gas Corporation, an important Electric Power subsidiary, it was announced yesterday. The new officers succeed J.H. Gill, former president of both companies, who died several months ago.

Neisner Brothers, Inc., reports a net profit of $306,615 for the first half of 1944, comparing with $289,083 in the 1943 period. After providing for preferred dividends, the profit was equal to $1.25 each on 204,891 common shares, against $1.15 a share a year ago.

DETROIT, Aug. 27 (U.P.) -- After a stormy three and one-half hour meeting today with 1,500 striking employes of the Ford Motor Company's Highland Park plant, officers of Local 400, United Automobile Workers (CIO), announced that the workers would return to their jobs on the midnight shift tonight, but said that the return would be an "infiltration" process lasting several days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (U.P.) -Anglo-American-Soviet delegates to the Dumbarton Oaks world security talks prepared tonight, after a week-end of relaxation, to consider during the second week of their conference some of the issues arising from various proposals by the three big powers for keeping the peace.

GREAT LAKES, Ill., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Keo Nakama of Ohio State University won the 800-meter freestyle race tonight in the closing competition of the National A. A.U. outdoor swimming championships, giving him a triple for the three-day meet.
PARIS, Aug. 27 -- Among the targets hit by the German planes were a hospital, a paper warehouse and wholesale wine centers.

BRITISH HEADQUARTERS in France, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Twenty-five German generals and one admiral have been killed, wounded, captured, replaced or have just disappeared in western France since D-day, June 6, it was announced late today.
KANDY, Ceylon, Aug. 27 (UP) -- A communique:

NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Harold R. Moskovit, president of the Affiliated Young Democrats, Inc., of New York, asserted here today at a Democratic rally that "the pre-war isolationism" of the Republican party was "riding hard to sweep the country on to the road of new isolationism." He added:
