Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically from Bucharest and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

After declining steadily in the first half of last week, the cotton market staged a recovery in later dealings on developments in Washington with respect to the efforts being made to assure domestic cotton growers parity for their staple. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 5 points above to 2 points below the level which prevailed at the close of the previous week.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Transportation between Shanghai and Kobe, Japanese seaport, is now being conducted mainly with large wooden boats that take twenty-seven days for a journey that pre-war express liners did in thirty-six hours, a Chinese report said today.
ROME, Aug. 27 (AP) -- French troops smashed the last enemy resistance within the city and port of Toulon today and captured the fortifications of the Six-Fours district southwest of the city.

DETROIT, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Two explosive six-run innings in a row put the American League-leading Browns back on their feet in the second game of a doubleheader against the Tigers today, the Brownies hammering five Detroit pitchers for a 17-to-2 runaway after bowing, 5 to 3, to Hal Newhouser, who corralled his twenty-first victory in the opener.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 27 -- The outlines of the Soviet Union's post-war policy in Eastern Europe, which has been a source of much speculation in the Western world, is becoming increasingly clear as the rapidly shifting Balkan picture develops strategically.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (U.P.) -The Office of War Information, in its report on the situation today, gave this summary of the country's production and manpower requirements in the war industries:

With employment of women in New York State already the highest in history, 25,000 additional women must enter or return to the labor market here before the end of the year if war production is to be maintained, Joseph B. O'Connor, acting regional director of the War Manpower Commission, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The system of Canadian air bases and landing strips for which Canada has agreed to pay the United States $76,811,551 cost this country $90,683,571, American Aviation Magazine says in its current issue.

ROME, Aug. 27 -- The "path of liberation" in Italy is a path of fantastic desolation. In France it is different. Except in Normandy the Germans in France have not shown anything like the resistance they have put up and still are putting up here. Indeed, the chances are that France will come out of the war with fewer physical wounds than any occupied country.

VERSAILLES, France, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Beautiful Versailles Palace, where the 1919 peace was signed, is a picture of neglect today with its gardens overgrown with weeds, but it is structurally intact.

After leading the congregation in prayer for success of the Dumbarton Oaks conference, the Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Prince, guest preacher at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, 122 West Sixty-ninth Street, declared in his sermon, yesterday morning that the church, while having no assigned part in planning for world security, should make it clear that any successful new world order "must rest on spiritual foundations.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Celon, Aug. 27 (U.P.) -- A young American doctor is credited by Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten with saving the sight of his left eye when the Supreme Commander was injured while on an inspection tour of the north Burma front last March, it was disclosed today.

We read of French patriots, members of the French Forces of the Interior, liberating towns or citizens in every section of France below Paris. This is the resistance, known to Americans as the underground. But what is the resistance? How is it organized and how does it operate?

PROCESSED FOODS (various canned or bottled vegetables, fruits, fruit juices, soups, baby foods, jams, jellies and other special products, and certain dried beans.) Blue stamps A8 through Z8, also A5 through F5 in War Book 4, good indefinitely at 10 points each. Frozen fruits and vegetables and dried fruits now point-free.

China House, a cultural center for Chinese students and their American friends, was dedicated yesterday at a ceremony that also honored the 2,495th birthday of Confucius. Dr. H.H. Kung, vice premier of China and a seventy-fifth lineal descendant of the Chinese sage, formally accepted the house in his capacity as president of China Institute in America.

There are so many of us these days, perhaps particularly those of us who are in the newspaper business, who are all the time hearing things that are definitely hush-hush. One gets a bit of information by accident or because an old friend who trusts you is in an expansive mood.

The New York Hospital, 525 East Sixty-eighth Street, last year cared for 66,848 patients, of whom 89 per cent were unable to meet the full cost of their medical care, according to the annual report of the institution made public yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -The British Board of Trade's index of commodity prices for July at 167.1 reached a new wartime high, comparing with 166.1 on June 16, a year ago. Aggregate increaseI since August, 1939, now 70 per cent, foods and tobacco being up 781 per cent and industrial materials, up 66 per cent.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 27 (AP)--Battling to remain within striking distance of the league-leading Orioles, the Bears today were held to an oven break by Syracuse, losing in the overtime eighth by 5--3 after taking the measure of the Chiefs, 8 to 6.

LONDON, Monday, Aug. 28 -- An avalanche of Russian tanks and motorized infantry poured into the rich Ploesti oil region in the heart of capitulated Rumania yesterday, after having shattered the Galati Gap defenses between the Danube and the Carpathians and captured thousands of Germans trying to escape to Hungary.

An investing group acting under the name of the P.M.S. Realty Corporation, Peter C. Lust, president, has acquired the four-story apartment house with forty suites at 117-19 Fourth Street, in Mount Vernon, Westchester County, from Mollie Weingarten, through Max B. Cane and Louis Cooper, brokers.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Japanese troops in a sudden renewal of fighting on the Honan Province front north of Hankow and the Yangtze have fanned westward from the Peiping-Hankow Railway and have reached points about thirty miles northeast and twenty-five miles east of the important highway and river junction of Miyang, the Chinese High Command announced today.

Fresh from a vacation of nine weeks, the original cast of "The Voice of the Turtle," comprising Margaret Sullavan, Elliott Nugent and Audrey Christie, resumes its highly successful engagement tonight at the Morosco, where it left off on June 24 as far as the public is concerned.

LONDON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- DNB, German news agency, in a broadcast of Tokyo dispatches, said today that "the town of Manila is being evacuated," but the context of the broadcast indicated the evacuation was limited to civilians unnecessary to strictly necessary functions of the Philippine capital.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The air cargo system developed by the United States with the cooperation of other United Nations brought 22,000,000 pounds of imports to this country, including vital supplies from far corners of the earth during the first six months of this year.

A deep and quiet fervor, more impressive than open jubilation, marked services of thanksgiving for the liberation of Paris at two of the religious centers of the French colony in New York yesterday. There was an overflow attendance at both churches and at one worshippers stood in the street with bared heads to participate

The Northern Pacific Railway reported yesterday operating revenues of $13,352,274 for July, an increase of $648,081 over the same month last year. Net railway operating income was $1,976,617, a decline of $823,139. For seven months ended July 31 gross revenues were $88,429,100, comparing with $79,476,273 in 1943.

The weary, battered German soldiers retreating through France to the Siegfried Line, behind which lies their Fatherland, are retiring from defeat through confusion to what soon may be chaos. This time they are not falling back, as they did in 1918, on a Germany little touched by the devastation of war, but on a homeland that has been and still is being battered from the skies as German territory never was ravaged before.

In one guise or another, fresh fruit may be served at any course of a meal. It may appear as an appetizer, in soups of Scandinavian varieties, as an accompaniment to meat, in bread, salads and desserts.These recipes, tested in THE NEW YORK TIMES kitchen, call for fruitsI that are now in season.

Van Alstyne, Noel Co. head a group which will offer today 141,054 shares of the Buffalo Bolt Company's $1 par value common stock at $6 a share. The company will use the proceeds from the sale of 78,834 shares to replenish working capital expended in the last four years for permanent improvements.
The headlines yesterday told again, as they did all last week, the story of the disintegration of a false idea, the gradual crumbling of Hitler's "New Order" in Europe.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Roy Cullenbine's ninth-inning home run gave the Indians a 1-to-0 victory over the White Sex and clean sweep of today's doubleheader. The Tribe won the first game, 4to3.

Although the list of approved items that next of kin may send to American prisoners of war has not been extended for Christmas gift boxes, families packing their boxes have a choice of seventy-four items recommended by the home service of the American Red Cross.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)--The War Department's announcement on radio broadcast time was as follows:

That municipal, State and Federal health authorities will have to concern themselves more and more with the distribution of medical care for the masses both the reformers and the conservatives in medicine now recognize. There is a justified fear that if this comes to pass, official medicine will be dominated by bureaucrats, and that it will not keep pace with the laboratories and the clinics of medical schools.
Last week's operations in the Pacific forecast the shape of things to come.

LONDON, Aug. 29 (Reuter) -- Vernon Bartlett, British Member of Parliament and writer for The London News Chronicle, this morning charged that Moscow had refused a joint British and American request for bases to supply arms to Warsaw.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 -- Edward H. Cashion, counsel to the Corporation Finance Division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, warned in an opinion made public today that there should be no when-issued trading in the new debentures and common stock provided for in the plan of reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric Holding Company system until final confirmation of the proposal by the Federal District Court in New York.
CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The 1944 world series will begin in St. Louis on Wednesday, Oct. 4, and efforts will be made to confine attendance strictly to home town fans.

A window display of properly wrapped Christmas boxes, arranged by the Army Postal Service, opened a week of talks and demonstrations yesterday at the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, Pershing Square Information Center, to teach civilians the correct procedure for mailing gift boxes to servicemen overeas.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 28 -- The chief members of the erstwhile Vichy Government were reported today to have been returned from Mulhouse to Belfort, where the Germans are making special defense preparations, pending the outcome of discussions between the French collaborationist leaders and Berlin on the fate of Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain.

David Sullivan, president of Local 32-B, Building Service Employes Union, in an examination before trial yesterday in Supreme Court, contradicted statements made by James J. Bambrick last Tuesday, in a suit brought by five members of the union, who accused Sullivan and Bambrick, a former president of the local, of conspiracy and diverting $300,000 of the local's funds.

Couturier touches, involving the use of velvet and satin, in new fur fashions, with the resulting achievement of a pencil-slim silhouette, distinguished the collection presented yesterday by Maximilian at 20 West Fifty-seventh Street.

ROME, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Speeding the Germans' disorderly flight and driving them into the blazing guns of the cut-off force just above Montelimar was another American column pounding up the Rhone Valley from Avignon, some forty-five miles down the river.

Sveinn Bjoernsson, President of Iceland, will be received officially at the City Hall today, but it is no conventional and formal welcome that awaits him in this city and this country. He is the head of the new republic into which a thousand-year-old people has flowered.

Prof. Harry A. Over-street has in the current number of The Saturday Review of Literature an article entitled "Images and the Negro," which should be of considerable interest to a former editor of The Saturday Review.

LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 29 (AP) -- United States Eighth Air Force fighters yesterday made their heaviest strikes since D-day on enemy railroad junctions and equipment in all-day attacks ranging over the Franco-German border, Belgium and the Netherlands. Fifteenth Air Force heavy bombers from Italy kept up the attack on Nazi oil sources with blows at targets in Austria and Hungary.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Tests on the curative effects of music on psychiatric patients are being conducted at Walter Reed Hospital, the Office of War Information announced today.

ALBANY, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The names of President Roosevelt and Senator Truman will be on New York State's war ballots as American Labor and Liberal party candidates for President and Vice President, under a ruling issued today by Supreme Court Justice Francis Bergan.

Anxious to be in a position to acquaint the general public with the strides made in dehydration during the war, many dehydrators of foods already are laying plans for promotional campaigns to start soon after the end of the war in Europe.

LONDON, Aug. 28 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav Partisans reported today the capture of important chrome mines at Rovane, in Macedonia, and said that all the eastern Serbian area between the Morava and Timok Rivers was "on the eve of liberation."

A banking syndicate headed by White, Weld Co. and Shields Co. was the successful bidder yesterday for an issue of $12,000,000 Mississippi Power and Light Company first mortgage bonds, receiving the award on its offer of 103.52 for the bonds, naming an interest rate of 3 1/8 per cent.

Every full moon since March, 1941, British planes have landed in the vast hinterlands of France, keeping a brief and dangerous rendezvous with members of the French underground. They brought radios, cameras and other highly important spy weapons.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- A national campaign for physical fitness, caused by the discovery that more than 4,000,000 men could not meet the physical and mental standards of selective service, was started today at a meeting of Army and civilian medical experts in the headquarters of the American Medical Association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- An appeal for intervention to prevent the "extermination by the Germans of the population of Warsaw" has been sent by the Polish Government in exile in London to Allied and neutral Governments and to the Vatican.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The migratory labor pattern by which the fruit and vegetable crops of the Eastern seaboard have been harvested traditionally for the big city markets was saved this year from being a war casualty by cooperation between Northern and Southern States, according to C.W.E. Pittman, senior agriculturist of the Extension Farm Labor Program, Department of Agriculture.

The arrest by the Buenos Aires police of Arnaldo Cortesi, THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent in Argentina, and his detention for eleven hours without charges show clearly the ever-present danger of rule by a military government that has no mandate from the people, recognizes no law except that of its own preservation and acts on any momentary whim of its members.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- Cheered by the latest war news, the stock markets here opened the week on a cheerful note and fresh gains were recorded in many sections. Gilt-edge securities developed a stronger tone, but prices in the foreign bond section were inclined to be irregular.

PARIS, Aug. 28 -- Dr. Pasteur Vallery-Radot, new French Minister of Health, said today that he had dismissed Dr. Alexis Carrel from his position and intends to modify "deeply" the Carrel Institute in Paris. [The Paris radio, heard by The Associated Press, said Dr. Carrel had been discharged as head of the Vichy Government-created Foundation for the Study of Human Relations.

Holders of Consumers Power Company first-mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, due 1967, have been notified that the company will redeem on Nov. 1, 1944, all of these outstanding bonds at 105 3/4. The redemption will be made at the City Bank Farmers Trust Company.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Keen competition among six airplane transport companies for the route between the Pacific Coast and Hawaii put the potential postwar fare below $100 today.

Two of the busiest days in the history of local golfing circles have been arranged for Sept. 16 and 17 when the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association will sponsor a program of tournaments to be held at approximately 100 clubs in Westchester, Long Island and Fairfield County in order to raise funds to build a small course for convalescents at Halloran General Hospital on Staten Island.
LONDON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Robot bombs fell in London and South England around noon today, breaking a lull of more than thirty hours, but the attacks were limited and short.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 28 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

PARIS, Aug. 27 (Delayed) (AP) -- The bodies of eight young French resistance fighters, slain by German troops who captured them on the first day of the mass uprising of Paris, were dug from a common grave today in the courtyard of Caserne barracks in the Place de la Republique.

Three persons, arrested when police raided the Jewish Ladies Day Nursery, 1695 Washington Avenue, the Bronx, on Aug. 12, pleaded guilty in Bronx Magistrate's Court yesterday to being common gamblers and were paroled by Magistrate William A. Farrell for sentence Thursday.

CHUNGKING, Aug. 28 (U.P.) -- In far southwest Kwantung, Chinese troops have destroyed part of the Japanese who had smashed into Limkong, four-way road junction, in what appeared a possible new drive north toward Kweilin, in Kwangsi, to coincide with the enemy push toward that base from the east in Hunan Province.

ROME, Aug. 28 -- Making a sharp swing west, an American force has planted itself on the last heights over the Rhone Valley at Montelimar and for almost a week It has been threatening the left flank of the German Nineteenth Army and inflicting heavy losses on elements attempting to break through to the north, it was revealed today.

Sixty detectives worked on the Phyllis Newmark murder mystery yesterday with apparently no tangible result. The case seemed no nearer solution than on Friday forenoon, when Mrs. Newmark, who lived at 127 West Seventy-ninth Street, was found strangled in the bushes near the Hayden Planetarium steps.

Selective buying was the rule as the semi-annual New York Gift Show opened yesterday at the Pennsylvania and New Yorker Hotels. A much more cautious attitude with respect to ersatz merchandise was shown by buyers who, however, were confident of an active Christmas retail trade.

Factory operations in the shirt and pajama industry during the first six months of 1944, compared with the like 1943 period, were at about 70 per cent, according to a survey by the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers.
PARIS, Aug. 28 -- The commander of the American forces that helped to liberate Paris officially delivered the city to Lieut. Gen. Joseph-Pierre Koenig, military commander of Paris, at noon today.

Like everyone, I wondered about the word "maquis." No one bothered to explain, or even inquire, its origin. I dimly supposed it might come from se maquiller, to disguise one's self. But the always indispensable Petit Larousse gives a clue that is worth communicating.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Russia was credited with starting and continuing the negotiations that brought Rumania to the Allied side in the war and with opening the dealings with Bulgaria, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said at a press conference today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- J.A. Krug, acting chairman of the War Production Board, today urged full production on Labor Day in all war plants producing critically needed military supplies.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 28 -- Rear Admiral Harold G. Bowen announced tonight that he was reporting to James Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy, "full compliance" of machinists at the 104 uptown machine shops seized since Aug. 14 by the Navy at President Roosevelt's order in a dispute over overtime work.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 22 per cent for the week ended Aug. 26, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the previous week the bank had reported a decrease of 8 per cent under the 1943 week.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 28 (AP) -- On the last lap of a tour of New England for "the education of Henry Wallace," the Vice President spent two hours here today as guest of Herman Koppelmann, Democratic candidate for Congress from the First District.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Theodore M. Matson, director of the Yale bureau for street traffic research, declared today that heavy responsibilities in the post-war period rest upon those governmental and traffic control specialists charged by law with the development of this nation's highway system.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 28 (AP) -- A back-to-work movement today found almost 3,500 men in the coal pits of central and western Pennsylvania, but more than 4,200 still were idle because of demands for company recognition of a mine supervisors union.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, KANDY, Ceylon, Aug. 28 (U.P.) -- Striking at points nearly 100 miles apart, special British and Indian harassing forces operating far behind Japanese lines in the Chin hills of western Burma have killed more than 100 of the enemy and wrecked numerous vehicles in their latest series of lightning thrusts.

PHILADELPHIA Aug. 28 -- A straight redemption plan eliminating all of the exchange features of a previous proposal for the elimination of the 7 per cent and $6 cumulative preferred stock of the New York Power and Light Corporation has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, it was disclosed today.

The State War Ballot Commission reports that applications for ballots have been received thus far from some 400,000 members of the armed forces who are residents of New York, and Governor Dewey hails this as proof that the State has taken adequate steps to "safeguard for its men and women in uniform their constitutional right to a full ballot."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The Office of Price Administration formally provided today for substantial price increases in combed and carded cotton yarns to make them conform to restrictions in the Stabilization Act of 1944.
LONDON, Aug. 28 -- The United States Army Claims Office is transferring its activities to the Continent.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Tuesday, Aug. 29 (AP) -- A communique:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- A Pacific Fleet announcement:
ROME, Aug. 28 (AP) -- A communique:

William Kogen, a student at the University of Michigan but competing unattached, last night won the metropolitan senior 100-meter free style championship in the swimming meet held in the Astoria pool.

Egg dealers here reported yesterday that Mayor La Guardia's radio crusade to compel Gristede Brothers to deduct 2 cents a dozen from the price of eggs bought by consumers supplying their own cartons had started a boom in the egg sales of that chain of stores.

Col. Edgar W. Garbisch, district engineer of the United States Army Engineers, will turn over to Army postal authorities for occupancy Friday the new Army Postoffice Concentration Center, a massive one-story building containing 500,000 square feet of floor space, located on the site of the former Madison Square Garden bowl in Long Island City, Queens.

Charging the League of New York Theatres with "prejudice and discrimination" because it denied him the right to act as his own manager but permitted four other members (William A. Brady, Brock Pemberton, Lester Meyer and Jules Leventhal) to do so, Michael Myerberg, producer of the Pulitzer Prize play, "The Skin of Our Teeth," and owner of the Mansfield Theatre, has resigned from that group.

"Till We Meet Again," a Paramount film starring Ray Milland, will have its local premiere this morning at the Rivoli. The topical drama, which is set in occupied France, was produced and directed by Frank Borzage. Among the featured players are Walter Slezak, Lucile Watson, Vladimir Sokoloff and Konstantin Shayne.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28--China has proposed to the United States and Great Britain the creation of an international police force to act under the Executive Council of an international security league to prevent and repel future aggression, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Returning from a week-end visit to New York, the Russian, British and United States delegates to the Dumbarton Oaks Conference resumed their conversations today with a meeting of their steering committee, while the questions of secrecy and of the relations between the "big four" and the smaller countries in the proposed world organization were raised in the Senate.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- By breaking par when he registered a 69 on his last round, Byron (Lord) Nelson of Toledo today annexed top honors in the All-American open for the third time in the four-year history of the three-ring golf circus that George S. May runs at the Tam o'Shanter Club.

HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 28 -- RKO-Radio has named Marcy McGuire and Glenn Vernon for the leads in the forthcoming "Riverboat Rhythm," a musical with a story about rival showboat and night club entertainers at a river port. The picture will be produced by Nat Holt, former Western district manager for the company.

The latest figures on Regulation V and VT loans made public by the Federal Reserve Board show a total authorized credit volume of $8,046,672,000 at the end of June, against $7,797,400,000 a month before, a new high mark. Actual borrowings at June 30 were only $2,046,672,000, comparing with $2,033,579,000 a month before.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
No matter how safe highways may be made by engineering, or how nearly accident-proof cars themselves may be, the real key to the future of street and highway safety lies in better qualified drivers.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 -- The Standard Gas and Electric Company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today an amended plan of reorganization designed to overcome the objections that led the SEC to reject an earlier proposal on May 31.

ONE of the most significant developments in the history of sports was the announcement by the War Department last week that the Army is about to launch a tremendous program of competitive athletics for our soldiers all over the world. Oddly enough, it hardly created a ripple of excitement. Yet the bare fact that untold millions of American boys will engage in organized sports is a very momentous event.
Mrs. Vera S. (Tom) Bragg scored a double at Belmont Park yesterday, including the featured Hurricana Handicap, in which Transformer was first and by the surprising margin of four lengths.

SEATTLE, Wash., Aug. 28 -- An eleven-point program for post-war reconstruction on a basis designed to provide maximum employment and economic stability was presented by Chester Bowies, OPA administrator, in an address today before the Seattle Chamber of Commerce.

PARIS, Aug. 28 -- After a couple of days looking around a Paris that has been reborn, this correspondent would like to go on record as saying the city is still the style center of the world -- war or no war.

ROME, Aug. 28 -- A warning to Italy not to "fall into the clutches of the Fascist totalitarian system in any guise in which it might present itself" was contained in Prime Minister Churchill's farewell message to the Italian people. It was coupled with the warmest professions of friendship, encouragement and hope that are going to make a profound impression here.
GENERAL HEADQUARTER, Southwest Pacific, Tuesday, Aug. 29 -- Four Japanese freighters were destroyed or damaged in another Allied air raid on Celebes, headquarters announced today.

Obviously showing deep concern over the growing backlog of Army Air Force termination cases resulting from tardy presentation of claims by industry, ranking officers of the War Department began yesterday a "contract readjustment training program for contractor personnel" with a warning that the end of the war in Europe would mean a cut of 33 per cent in the aircraft industry's contracts.

It is paradoxical that Rumania is now in a better international position than Poland, even though Poland has, from the very beginning, been the most faithful ally and Rumania the most loyal to Adolph Hitler. King Michael, who collaborated with the Nazis and the Iron Guards, is better off than the democratic Prime Minister Mikolajczyk of Poland.

PARIS, Aug. 27 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Tortures inflicted by the Germans on Allied internees that "paralleled the Spanish Inquisition" were described today by escaped Allied women internees who have reached Paris for medical care.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (U.P.) -- John J. McCloy, acting Secretary of War, denied today that there was any White House dictation in the Army's quick reversal of its ruling granting the Socialist party broadcasting facilities to answer President Roosevelt's Bremerton (Wash.) address as "political."

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 28 -- The Grand Circuit came to the Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The major league of harness racing began a two-week run at the local course and a gathering of 4,482 turned out for the opening program. The handle was $190,589.

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 28 (AP) -- A two-ply raid by American warplanes on Saturday against Onnekotan Island in the northern Kuriles and strikes against Japanese bases in the Marianas, south of Tokyo, and in the Central Pacific were announced today by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- In the Polish armored division's first major engagement in France, a fierce six-day battle, during which it took the full brunt of the assault from units of two fanatical Nazi Elite Guard corps, Polish tanks, on Aug. 21, sealed Allied victory in Normandy, it was announced tonight.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Fritz Mandl, former Austrian munitions magnate, declared today he had no connection with the Argentine Government and said his inclusion in the United Nations' blacklist came as "a fantastic surprise."

ALBANY, Aug. 28 -- Acting in behalf of 22,000 employes of the mental hospitals in the State, the Association of State Civil Service Employes made a demand today on the Salary Standardization Board and John E. Burton, budget director, that the classifications and salary allowances made to these employes by the Legislature be carried out.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Senator A.B. Chandler, Democrat, of Kentucky, asserted in the Senate today that British objections to a report on India by William Phillips led to the diplomat's recent resignation as political adviser to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.
In reference to your historical background of Dumbarton Oaks, I should like to make a correction.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, Aug. 29 -- The dead rest easier in the cemetery on the hill above the quiet Marne, for the Americans are back in Chateau-Thierry land are driving the Germans before them as their fathers did twenty-six years ago.

The cotton problem will be one of the most important and perplexing economic questions that the nation will have to face after the war, in the opinion of the Guaranty Survey, published monthly by the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Morton Cooper won his one hundredth game of his major league career tonight when a home run by pinch-hitter Ken O'Dea in the ninth inning defeated the Reds, 3 to 2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The House Rules Committee paved the way today for taking the heavily revised "conservative" George industrial demobilization bill to the House floor tomorrow under a resolution designed to permit "liberal" programs that were rejected by the Senate and the Ways and Means Committee to enter into contest with it.

BUFFALO, Aug. 28 -- Air passenger travel will increase sevenfold and air express thirty-fold within five years of the end of the war, with passenger fares at 3.5 cents a mile and express at 30 cents a ton-mile, according to findings of a survey made for the Curtiss-Wright Corporation by Dr. D.H. Davenport of its business research staff.

The drying-up process in the stock market accelerated yesterday to such an extent that volume dwindled to the smallest in more than three months. A narrow, listless movement prevailed throughout the session, with prices fractionally mixed at the close.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- If members of the reputed Nelson and Wilson factions within the War Production Board do not work together from now on, heads will fall, J. A. Krug, newly appointed acting chairman of WPB, told the Senate War Investigating Committee today.

The annual pamphlet report of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company for the year 1943, delayed by contract negotiation, disclosed yesterday a net profit of $4,947,045 after provision of $16,732,000 for taxes and $1,000,000 for contingency reserve.
The American Jewish Conference submitted yesterday to Secretary of State Cordell Hull a memorandum containing an eight-point proposal on the punishment of war criminals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Canned California sweet cherries will sell at retail for about two and a half cents more for the popular-sied can than last year, the Office of Price Administration made known today in announcing "ceiling" prices for processors covering the 1944 pack.

New York City's youth will answer Mayor La Guardia's appeal that they behave themselves, made in his regular weekly broadcast last Sunday, with a self-prepared manual of behavior, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Elias Lieberman, associate superintendent of schools in charge of junior high schools.

Frustrated by their own sluggishness, the Yankees spent a miserable afternoon at the Stadium yesterday, winding up on the wrong end of a 7-4 score that enabled the Red Sox to gain second place, three and a half games behind the Browns.

ROME, Aug. 28 -- Fully a year ago Adolf Hitler laid his plans to make every German city a Stalingrad, according to a German correspondent considered one of the best informed of those who remained behind when the Allies took Rome.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- Grain prices fluctuated nervously within moderate limits today on the Board of Trade. Brokers paid little attention to favorable news from the European war front and the belief prevailed that only sensational developments abroad would become a major market influence again.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Communique 142:

Baltimore County, Md., will be in the market on Sept. 26 with a new issue of $2,000,000 of Metropolitan District, fourteenth issue, bonds, for which bidders have been asked to name an interest rate not exceeding 5 per cent. The bonds, to be dated Oct. 1, 1944, will mature serially from Oct. 1, 1945, to 1984.
LONDON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

The Government has started an anti-trust suit against the railroads and the representatives of Wall Street. The railroads have done a swell job during the war and are still doing more than seemed humanly possible. On the contrary, the Government has instituted no suit, during the last two and a half years, against striking unions or against those who retard production.

Your recent editorial "To Tie or Not to Tie" merits a grateful response from tomato growers. Worth-while suggestions should come from experts, I suppose. However, I have found to my own satisfaction the answer to your question.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- A formation of RAF Lancaster heavy bombers in a daring twenty-minute operation to support the Red Army on the East Prussian front mined and blocked the Stettin Canal on the night of Aug. 16, while a major Bomber Command attack was made on the port of Stettin, the British Air Ministry reported today.

In your editorial of Aug. 26 you say: "Some landlords are refusing to re-decorate apartments for new tenants. * * * OPA now promises an all-out drive to correct this situation. Where tenants are required to redecorate at their own expense as a condition for renting, OPA will prosecute."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The House Committee on Campaign Expenditures began its investigation today of the two political action committees headed by Sidney Hillman in a calm, peaceful atmosphere and ended late this afternoon in a heated and angry colloquy between the witness and Representative Ralph E. Church, Republican, of Illinois.

PARIS, Aug. 27 (Delayed) (AP) -- An unknown patriotic Frenchman started a second revolution, this time against the hated Nazis in Paris, and Commandant Roger Stephane helped carry it through to victory.
GRENOBLE, Aug. 26 (Delayed) -- In this area one discovers why American veterans of the Italian campaign so admire the French.

The steady rise in the number of women enrolled at the Columbia University School of Law probably will continue after the war, although the percentage of women students may go down as more veterans return to finish their law training, Prof. James P. Gifford, assistant to the dean, predicted yesterday.

LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 29--Red Army forces, ripping deeper into Germany's crumbling Balkan empire, invaded Hungarian-annexed Transylvania yesterday in a twenty-seven-mile march across the Carpathian Mountains, while the Soviet flood...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28--The prepared text of the statement Sidney Hillman, chairman of the CIO Political Action Committee and the National Citizens Political Action Committee, before the Special Committee of the House to investigate campaign expenditure follows:...
PARIS, Aug. 28 -- The Paris bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES was reopened today in its old quarters at 37 Rue de Caumartin for the first time since America entered the war.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- A working model of a new television station designed for construction in large and small communities was exhibited today by the Austin Company, Cleveland, at the convention of the National Association of Broadcasters here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Preston Lockwood, president of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation, told Navy officials today that the company did not propose to meet its back wage claims, totaling $1,500,000, until it was certain that it could also pay all its back taxes and have, in addition, a net working capital of $800,000, it was learned tonight.

Ice cream much like the memorable pre-war variety -- smooth-textured and rich -- can be made at home with a preparation called Virginia Dare Ice Cream Powder. The product, which is among the best of its kind that this department has tried, contains rennet and vanilla among other things, and is used in combination with light cream and sugar.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Chinese forces have posed a new threat to the tenuous Siang River supply line of the Japanese in Hunan Province in successes that, if exploited successfully, might change the entire Hunan situation in favor of the defenders and frustrate the Japanese aim of conquering the whole Canton-Hankow rail route across China, the High Command said tonight.

In final preparation for what Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican national chairman, calls "a sort of a kickoff" in the Presidential campaign today, the Republican party added new weight yesterday to its coaching staff, dispatched another scouting party to the Midwest and tossed the ball around on a side issue.

A group headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Hemphill, Noyes Co., will offer today the unsubscribed portion of 70,000 new shares of Carrier Corporation $50 par value 4 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock at $50 a share.

For more than a year we have followed with interest your vigorous and convincing appeals for the salvage of waste paper. We would like to cooperate in your campaign -- if we could dispose of the paper accumulated.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The Congressional Medal of Honor has been awarded to two more infantrymen, Pvt. First Class William J. Johnston, 26 years old, of Colchester, Conn., and Staff Sgt. Jesse R. Drowley, 24, of Luzerne, Mich.
LONDON, Aug. 28 (U.P.) -- Sources here reported today that the German robot bombs were spreading more death and destruction around their launching sites in France than in Britain.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad Company and the Utica, Chenango Susquehanna Valley Railway Company made joint application today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to merge the properties of the latter company into that of the Lackawanna.

LUBLIN, Poland, Aug. 28 -- Edward B. Osubka-Morawski, chairman of the Polish Committee of National Liberation, disclosed to foreign correspondents today that his group was willing to offer to Mr. Mikolajczyk the portfolio of Premier if he and three of his colleagues from the London Government in Exile would join the Polish Committee to form a provisional government for Poland.

Success in reconversion from a wartime to a peacetime economy will resolve into a "battle of the last three feet," the counter distance separating retail sales clerks from the public, C. William Green, New York regional manager of the Committee for Economic Development, declared yesterday in an address at the semi-annual meeting of the National Luggage Dealers Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Federal officials have asked the National Safety Council to continue "at a maximum level of efficiency" its campaign to prevent accidents in the interest of wartime manpower conservation, William A. Irvin, chairman of the council's board of trustees, announced yesterday.

Bass fishing might be expected to benefit from the war. With millions of young Americans away in foreign parts far from their beloved lakes and streams, it might be expected that the fish would increase and multiply so greatly that the average catch of the few oldsters who can manage to go fishing would grow enormously.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- The Polish underground affiliated with the Government in Exile in London has asked Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk to insist upon Anglo-American backing of any bilateral agreement that may be concluded with Russia to settle Russo-Polish difficulties, it was learned tonight.

DETROIT, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Production of aircraft engine parts at the Highland Park plant of the Ford Motor Company, halted by a strike last Friday, was resumed today with the return of most of 8,000 employes involved in the stoppage. The tie-up, for a time, threatened to affect 50,000 other workers in Ford plants in this area.

Paper production is on a "hand- to-mouth" basis in many metropolitan mills, where wastepaper is the leading raw material, a survey showed yesterday. Purchasing agents for several mills said that shutdowns have already been necessary, while others admitted that lack of wastepaper may momentarily stop their machinery.
LONDON, Aug. 28 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 28 -- Stephen Knight of Hartford, Connecticut Office of Price Administration enforcement officer, denied today that there has been discrimination in Federal court actions to restrain seven Stamford and Riverside housewives from black market buying.
After starting 4 to 7 points up with spurts of realizing during the day, cotton prices closed steady yesterday at advances of 15 to 17 points on active months on the New York Cotton Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP)-- E.L. Olrich, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, today denied recent charges by Mayor La Guardia of New York that surplus war property is being sold "at junk prices."

When his alma mater, the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine, recently conferred on him the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws, Maj. Gen. Paul R. Hawley, one of the Army's highest medical officers, made much of the fact that 97 per cent of our wounded are restored to health.

This memorable month -- the August of record-breaking heat, as well as of the liberation of Paris and the beginning of the end for Europe's oppressors -- may go down in history as significant in another way. For Congress has agreed, according to late reports, to dispose of 75 to 100 billions of surplus war property, immediately on the conclusion of peace, and to apply the receipts against the national debt.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- The Moscow radio, quoting the Bulgarian News Agency, said tonight the Germans had begun withdrawing troops from Bulgaria. The radio said the withdrawal would "be completed within a few days."

DENVER, Aug. 29 (AP) -- A new tax program for Federal, State and local governments to eliminate "overlapping and duplication * * * in our present system" was proposed today by Arthur R. Kaiser of Chicago, tax specialist, in a speech prepared for the National Association of State Chambers of Commerce.

By the simple process of "picking them off the edges" as tightly massed formations of Japanese planes attempted to get by his fighter screen to attack United States task forces off Saipan June 19, Lieut. Alexander Vraciu Jr., the Navy's No. 1 ace, destroyed six enemy dive bombers in eight minutes of combat, he revealed yesterday in an interview at 90 Church Street.

Now is the time for all good independents to come to the aid of the candidate they have been independently supporting since the memory of man runneth not to the contrary. It is the season when the voter opens his morning mail and finds appeals from all sorts of Independent Committees.
Flour, clothing and soap -- and, in Paris, foodstuffs of all sorts -- are among the greatest needs of the civilian population in the areas of France freed by the Allies.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in English from Chungking and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Polish Press Bureau said today that the Germans were removing troops, tanks and guns from Praga, eastern suburb of besieged Warsaw, to the west bank of the Vistula River which flows through the capital.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The War Production Board ruled today that producers of capital equipment, including machine tools, precision measuring and testing instruments, electric motors and generators and other general industrial equipment, need no longer obtain its permission to begin production on unrated orders.
An easier tone developed yesterday in the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange and final prices were virtually at the lows of the day with net losses of 16 to 22 points.

PARIS, Aug. 29 -- Georges Carpentier, who fought Jack Dempsey in 1921, sat tonight in his darkened Lido Club, one floor below the Champs-Elysees, trying to forget the four terrible years just past. The realization that the Americans had finally arrived and Parisians could once again speak their own minds and live their own lives seemed to bewilder him.

Fines totaling $1,025 were assessed against Gristede Brothers and suspended sentences were imposed upon forty-one employes of that food chain by Magistrate Charles E. Hirsimaki in Yorkville Court yesterday after the defendants had pleaded guilty to violations of Office of Price Administration regulations.

DETROIT, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Driving in five runs with a single, double and his fifth home run, Paul (Dizzy) Trout notched his eighth straight pitching victory for the Tigers today, blanking the White Sox, 7 to 0, on nine hits. Trout also achieved his fifth shut-out and his twenty-second triumph against nine defeats.

Col. John Hay Whitney, scion of one of the nation's oldest and wealthiest families, last night was reported to have been captured by the Germans "somewhere in France" while riding in a jeep with four other officers. His secretary said that, while there had been no confirmation from the War Department, she was inclined to believe the report was true.

ROME, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Polish forces driving up the Adriatic coast of Italy have captured the village of Fano, six miles from Pesaro, and are pushing forward within three miles of the Germans' Gothic Line outposts in that sector, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Appeals for the rescue of the Jewish people of Europe were presented to the White House, to Congress and to the British Embassy today by Jewish and Greek Orthodox Church leaders.

The Emery Thompson Machine and Supply Company has purchased the former sub-station of the Consolidated Edison Company on Inwood Avenue in the Bronx. Situated on the west side of Inwood Avenue 345 feet south of 170th Street, the building extends through to Cromwell Avenue and fronts 200 feet on each thorough- fare.

CHUNGKING, Aug. 29 -- Although the Chinese Government's post-war security plans have not been made public here some indication of what they may be is contained in unofficial proposals of the People's Foreign Relations Association, which is partly composed of Government officials.

Prices on the stock market attained yesterday a slightly bug irregularly higher level. Stepped-up activity in some of the low-price motor shares helped the list in the final hour, but trading in the earlier hours was listless and narrow. Switching operations accounted for a slight increase in business on the Stock Exchange, where transfers reached 619,760 shares, against 554,300 on Monday.

LONDON, Aug. 29 (U.P.) -- American anti-aircraft batteries were revealed today to be playing an active role in the defense of southern England against flying bombs, and their marksmanship was praised by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- President Roosevelt will make his first political speech on Sept. 23 at a dinner here of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. AFL, he said today at his news conference. adding that he was too busy to make "a swing around the country" in the campaign.
KANDY, Ceylon, Aug. 29 (UP) -- A communique:

WITH THE CANADIAN FIRST ARMY, at Freneuse, Aug. 28 (Delayed) -- Almost in sight of the historic city of Rouen, scene of the martyrdom of Joan of Arc, Canadian forces were pouring across the Seine River at two points near here today against heavy machine gun and mortar fire.

LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Royal Air Force heavy bombers struck at Germany in great strength during the night, concentrating upon Stettin and Koenigsberg, while Mosquito bombers hit Berlin and Hamburg, the British announced officially today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 23: Decreases of $122,000,000 in loans, $334,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, $107,000,000 in balances with domestic banks, $818,000,000 in United States Government deposits, and $270.000.000 in deposits credited to domestic banks; and an increase of $506,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted.

The Yankees and Red Sox, their eyes glued on the pennant, dealt each other some fearful blows at the Stadium yesterday with the result that by splitting the double-header they did neither the one nor the other a bit of good.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Wednesday, Aug. 30 -- More than seventy-five Allied bombers and fighter-bombers struck the heaviest blow of the war against the enemy base at Amboina, former great Netherland naval center in the Netherlands Indies, in a 188-ton attack on Monday that left the target area a mass of flames, it was announced today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- Although the pumpkin is still green on the vine, the football season, already partially opened, will get its first big prod tomorrow night when the Chicago Bears, champions of the National League, clash with the College All-Stars in Dyche Stadium, Evanston.

Receiving the city's welcome at City Hall, Dr. Syngman Rhee, first President of Korea and now head of the Korean Government in exile at Chungking, appealed yesterday afternoon for additional arms and munitions for the Korean Army in China "so we may participate, to the greatest extent possible, in the defeat and destruction of Jap militarism."

In the collection shown yesterday in the showrooms of Chez Ninon at 785 Fifth Avenue, Mme. Lyne, the French designer responsible for the clothes, stressed slenderness of line and refinement of detail, expressed in the use of tucks and folds to contribute to the silhouette.

Women are doing more of the "organizing" for this election than in any previous year, Mrs. Charles W. Tillett, vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, declared yesterday in an interview at the Hotel Biltmore. Preliminary reports show a great increase in the number of women serving as precinct and county leaders and running for office on the party's local and state tickets, she said.

Reduction of employment ceilings in New York State will be effected to meet the increased demands for essential war production, Joseph B. O'Connor, acting director of the regional War Manpower Commission, announced yesterday upon his return from a conference of area directors in Syracuse.
The tentative plan for a Council, Assembly and Permanent Court of International Justice to deal with justiciable issues in the proposed world organization is practically a revived League of Nations.

From Harlem to Broadway is the journey taken by "Anna Lucasta," arriving tonight at the Mansfield with a cast of Negro performers. Early this Summer the Philip Yordan script, dealing with "a young Negress and her attempt to rejoin her family circle in a small Pennsylvania town after several years of unconventional living along the Brooklyn waterfront," was nurtured for nineteen performances by the American Negro Theatre.

Elsewhere on this page we publish a letter from Wendell Berge, the Assistant Attorney General, taking issue with our editorial on the suit filed by the Department of Justice a few days ago against forty-seven railroads and two banking houses.

LUBLIN, Poland, Aug. 29 -- Col. Gen. Michal Rola-Zymierski, supreme commander of the Polish Army, estimated today that more than 200,000 Warsaw residents had been killed by the Germans since the inadequately armed Polish Home Army, loyal to Gen. Kazimierz Sosnkowski, commander of the forces of the Polish Government in Exile, began its uprising in the Polish capital on Aug. 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- A report that the post of war mobilization director, now held by James F. Byrnes, would be waiting for Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chairman, when he returned from his mission to China, were dismissed by President Roosevelt today with the statement that he disapproved of speculation.

Duell, Sloan Pearce won the Council on Books in Wartime's drawing to determine the publisher of "Mediterranean Sweep: Air Stories From El Alamein to Rome," which will be published in November. The air history of the Mediterranean campaign, told in fifty stories, was written by Major Richard Thruelsen, co-author of "Target: Germany," and Lieut. Elliott Arnold, author of "The Commandos.''
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- A Pacific Fleet announcement:

BOSTON, Aug. 29 -- In more ways than one the clubbing of Manager Mel Ott and Ernie Lombardi wrought havoc with burly Nate Andrews and the Braves today as the Giants submerged Bob Coleman's team, 4 to 2.

Charles Lawless, 23 years old, of 329 West Eighty-fourth Street, a counterman since he was dishonorably discharged from the Navy two years ago, was booked as a material witness last night in the investigation into the murder of Mrs. Phyllis L. Newmark.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -The United States Government recognizes the Polish Home Army as a combat force and has warned Germany that she will be held responsible for reprisals against it, the State Department announced tonight.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 29 -- At a Cabinet meeting this morning the Chinese Central Government accepted the resignation of Gen. Sheng Shih-tsai as Governor of Sinkiang Province. General Sheng will come to Chungking to serve as Minister of Agriculture and Forestry.

While American troops were marching up the Champs Elysees yesterday to be reviewed by General de Gaulle, in honor of their return visit after a quarter of a century, further and even more decisive victories seemed to be ahead in northern France. Patton's armored columns, moving like cavalry and hitting like infantry, were swinging wide around Paris in what may be a new and gigantic encircling movement.

Bluefish have been reported at various points along the Atlantic coast from time to time this summer, but since the dearth of these fish in recent seasons has relegated them almost into the legendary class, no one has become very excited.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Infantile paralysis cases throughout the country, already at the highest level since the epidemic of 1916, continue to mount, and the United States Public Health Service says "the peak is not yet in sight."

Filing in Federal court here of a civil complaint asking an injunction against continuation of an alleged monopoly in the sale of wood alcohol was announced yesterday by Charles Fahy, acting attorney general of the United States. Similar charges had been made in a criminal indictment handed up by a Federal grand jury on April 5, but in yesterday's action the Ford Motor Company, not previously accused, was added to the list of defendants.

The rasping, bulldog voice of Prime Minister Churchill remains the most eloquent in Europe. In his stocky, muscled figure, cigar in mouth, still stands the leading people's advocate. As few other men of history he has the ability to cut through the fog of language to the heart of a problem and express it in terms that anyone can understand.

GRENOBLE, France, Aug. 25 (Delayed) -- German formation of 946 troops surrendered today to a 24-year-old American lieutenant, Clarence E. Coggins of Poteau, Okla., whom they had captured a short time before.
Lieut. Comdr. Dudley S. Knox, USNR, and Mrs. Knox have come to the Plaza from Washington, D.C.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- President Roosevelt has set wheels in motion to obtain a detailed economic measurement of the country's productive effort.
LONDON, Aug. 29 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

PARIS, Aug. 29 -- Slowly, very slowly, Paris is struggling back toward normal life. The hysterical happiness with which Parisians greeted the French and American troops coming to their rescue last Friday as passed. The people are happy, more deeply happy than at any time since 1918, but now they are quiet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The text of a statement issued today by Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Under-Secretary of State, explaining the secrecy policy adopted for the Dumbarton Oaks Security Conference was as follows: ...

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- The future goal of the United States is "to maintain at all times the finest air force in the world," Robert A. Lovett, Assistant Secretary of War for Air, told the war-time conference of the National Association of Broadcasters today.
ROME, Aug. 29 (UP) -- A communique:

Allow me to take exception to a statement in your Washington story about the visit of the Icelandic President, that Iceland "was a part of Denmark until June 16." This is not so. Iceland has not been a part of Denmark since Dec. 1, 1918, when Denmark acknowledged her as "an independent and sovereign state."

LUBLIN, Poland, Aug. 27 (Delayed) -- I have just seen the most terrible place on the face of the earth -- the German concentration camp at Maidanek, which was a veritable River Rouge for the production of death, in which it is estimated by Soviet and Polish authorities that as many as 1,500,000 persons from nearly every country in Europe were killed in the last three years.

Passengers who have been delayed in landing at La Guardia Field and other busy airports while the plane circled aloft will soon have cause to bless a particular Saint, according to a demonstration put on by American Airlines at La Guardia Field yesterday.

Faced with the necessity of recruiting in the third quarter approximately 85,000 workers for war plants, the New York State office of the War Manpower Commission expects to grant but few certifications which will enable manufacturers to return to the production of civilian items,

Rapid strides of the Allied forces in liberating France and other European areas have spurred preliminary planning by retail buying groups, foreign traders and other business interests for the return of their representatives to Continental Europe as soon as possible after the end of hostilities, it was learned here yesterday.

The indefatigable "friends" of cotton are still on the job. The Senate has approved a rider to the Surplus Property Disposal Bill raising the loan rate on cotton to 95 per cent of parity. Three years ago the loan rate was set at 85 per cent of parity for basic agricultural commodities.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- Under the guns of the German Army, Hungary's faint-hearted puppet Government was deposed today and a clique of generals installed in its place, presumably with the intention of making a final fight beside the Wehrmacht for the terrtories looted since 1938 from neighboring countries.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 29 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. Arriving simultaneously at the Globe and Gotham Theatres will be "Wing and a Prayer," a topical drama produced by Twentieth Century-Fox dealing with an aircraft carrier and her aviators.

President Sveinn Bjoernsson of the newly formed Republic of Iceland stressed the growing friendship between his people and those of the United States in ceremonies at noon yesterday in Mayor La Guardia's office at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The main difficulty of the blind in overcoming a general attitude of unbelief in their ability to do a job, Lawrence Q. Lewis, Executive Director of the National Society for the Blind, told the House labor subcommittee which opened hearings today on the status of the handicapped.
LONDON, Aug. 29 -- Prime Minister Churchill returned home this evening after an absence of nearly three weeks in Italy where he undertook a number of talks with Italian, Greek and Yugoslav leaders.

Good Thing, a filly by Discovery from Little Sleeper, at last vindicated the apt and humorous name given her by Navy Lieut. Alfred G. Vanderbilt, when she dashed home first at Belmont Park yesterday as the outsider in a field of five.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- simplified method for redemption of war bonds, effective Oct. 2, was announced today by Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- As his last official act before leaving for New York on Thursday, Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the War Production Board, who resigned last week, will preside over a meeting of the Committee on Post-War Research, which has completed a plan for pushing research in military matters after the war.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 990, against 815 last week and 806 in the like period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 449, against 376 last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The War Production Board today ordered further cutbacks in aluminum production amounting to approximately 30,000,000 pounds of aluminum ingot per month. This will reduce total output to slightly less than half of the peak 188,000,000 pounds a month reached early last winter.

Julius Kayser Co. issued yesterday their annual report to stockholders covering the fiscal year ended with June, revealing net earnings of $1,168,355 after all charges, including $1,727,200 provision for Federal and Canadian income taxes. The result is equal to $3.16 a share and compares with $1,035,419 or $2.79 a share, earned in the previous year, when $1,382,000 was provided for taxes.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Communique 143:

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- With buyers in today's stock markets inclined to wait for further war developments, business quieted down today. There was little selling, however, and changes of prices, particularly among the industrial shares, were small.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The whittled-down Senate bill carrying what remains of the basic legislative program for industrial demobilization was denounced on the House floor today as providing an "ersatz" plan for the reconversion of men and machines to a peace economy and was defended by a majority of the Ways and Means Committee, which cut the measure, as covering all that could "properly, wisely and safely" be done at this time.

GUAM, Aug. 17 (AP) (Delayed) -- Guam is destined to become a small Pearl Harbor from which the winning blow against Japan can be struck, Maj. Gen. Henry L. Larson of the Marine Corps said today at his first press conference since taking command of the island's defenses and development.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Lieut. Comdr. H. Massie Smoot, assistant naval inspector of ordnance, told the Senate War Investigating Committee today that of 300 bomb-sights manufactured during three mouths last year at a new plant at Elmira, N.Y., "about half" had to be sent back for repairs or rebuilding.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- President Roosevelt directed Secretary Stimson tonight to take over and operate the strike-bound facilities of the International Nickel Company, Inc., at Huntington, W. Va., where a stoppage of work by 2,500 operators was held to have interfered with the production of vitally needed steel alloy metals and rotating steel bands for large artillery shells.

By a vote of 2,118 to 772 employes of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation selected last night the Transport Workers Union as their collective bargaining agent, defeating John L. Lewis' District 50, United Mine Workers of America, in a State Labor Relations Board election.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 29 -- Acting on what labor circles here said was confidential information received from various Latin-American countries, Vicente Lombardo Toledano, president of the Confederation of Workers of Latin America, today issued a statement in which he accused Argentina of fostering the setting up of Fascist governments in the Western Hemisphere.

Confident that cost analyses and surveys being undertaken by the Office of Price Administration will result in an upward revision of cotton yarn prices, cotton spinners of certain counts may continue to withhold their production even though the new OPA ceilings have been confirmed, it was learned in Worth Street yesterday.

CHATEAU-THIERRY, France, Aug. 29 (AP) -- American troops, fighting over the rolling green battlefields where doughboys and marines immortalized themselves in 1918, occupied Chateau-Thierry and went past Belleau Wood in a smash that swept across the Valley of the Marne to the approaches of Reims today.

Oysters return to market on Friday, which marks the start of the first "R" month since April. Unfortunately, the shellfish are expected to be no more plentiful than they were last year, when, according to the Long Island Oyster Growers, the shortage resulted in a nation-wide crop only 40 to 50 per cent of normal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Details of how 30,000,000 wage-earners and salaried workers will be able to avoid computing their 1944 income taxes through the use of a new withholding receipt were given today by the Treasury.
A military funeral will be held tomorrow at 10 A.M. at the Fort Totten funeral chapel for First Lieut. Waldo B. Gellard, who was killed in a plane crash at Stormville, N.Y., on Saturday.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Browns unleashed an eleven-hit attack to defeat Cleveland, 8 to 3, tonight and increase their American League lead to four games.

If the Dodgers had exclusive rights to the Phillies throughout the season, they and not the Cards would be leading the National League. The figures, following a 12 -- 1 victory over Freddy Fitzsimmons' lads at Ebbets Field yesterday, show that Brooklyn has captured thirteen of seventeen from Philadelphia for a .765 mark and not even the Cardinals have a better average.

Sixteen members of the armed forces are included in the field of thirty-two in the men's singles who will start play today in the combined national tennis championships at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens.

JOSEPH DRISCOLL, a far wandering war correspondent for The New York Herald Tribune, will have to celebrate the publication today of his "Pacific Victory: 1945"* in a city much preoccupied with another victory. At present he is filing his dispatches from Paris. After spending a long session with our forces in Alaska and gathering there the material that he put into his "War Discovers Alaska," Mr. Driscoll spent a year with the Pacific Fleet.

A group of underwriters headed by the First Boston Corporation will offer formally today $5,992,000 State of New Mexico highway debentures, due from 1946 through 1957 and bearing coupon rates from 2 3/8 to 3 1/4 per cent. The bonds will be priced to yield from 0.65 for the early maturities to 1.55 per cent for those due in 1957.

Maj. C. Stewart Comeaux, formerly in the office of the Chief of Ordnance, United States Army, has resumed his duties as secretary-treasurer of the Institute of Makers of Explosives and the Sporting Arms and Ammunition Manufacturers Institute, 103 Park Avenue.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 29 -- Monty Woolley and Gracie Fields will be teamed by Twentieth Century-Fox in "Waltz Me Around Again, Willie," a musical with a background of Chicago in the early 1900's, to be produced by William LeBaron and directed by Lloyd Bacon.

FOLKESTONE, England, Wednesday, Aug. 30 (AP) -- This southeast coast town shook and the earth rumbled for several seconds just before midnight, and speculation immediately ranged from a prosaic demolition of a munitions dump in France to the possibility that the Germans were testing their long-threatened "Vengeance Weapon No. 2."

Economic "planners," who vision a practically unlimited backlog of consumer demand for the post-war period, are overlooking the fact that well-paid employes of today, anxious to buy unobtainable items with surplus cash, probably will change their minds if they are among the list of unemployed after the war, Lew Hahn, general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, declared yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Tie-breaking rallies in the late innings by the Athletics won both ends of a twilight-night double-header with the Senators tonight, 3 -- 1 and 11 -- 4. Frank Hayes furnished the deciding punch in both contests. The box scores:

Home decorators who have been paying collector's prices for repainted Victorian furniture under the impression that they were acquiring heirloom antiques may be sorely disappointed a few years hence to discover that the resale value is no more than that of second-hand furniture, experts in this field warn.

ROME, Aug. 29 -- In a statement to the press a few days ago, Marcelo Soleri, Minister of the Treasury in the Bonomi Cabinet, lamented that everything is lacking in Italy today but paper money. The money situation here is a nightmare in itself. It worries responsible people in the Allied commissions as well as the Italian Government even more, if possible, than the shortages of food.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The chairmen of the United States, British and Soviet delegations at the Washington Conversations on International Organization announced today that they had reached "general agreement" on the structure and aims of an international league to maintain peace and security.

PARIS, Aug. 28 (Delayed) -- Although the Allies never bombed Paris proper, the Germans were in constant dread of an air attack there and built elaborate shelters for their officers in or near some of the best hotels in the city. Some of the largest of these were at the Majestic, where they had their general staff headquarters, the George V and the Plaza.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Ted Wilks, the National League's leading pitcher, gained his eleventh consecutive victory and his fourteenth of the year tonight as the Cardinals blanked Cincinnati, 3 to 0.

MOSCOW, Aug. 29 -- The State Investigating Committee of German Atrocities, headed by the Leningrad journalist Nikolai Tikhanoff, reported today that the Nazis put a booby trap in the grave of the beloved Russian poet, Alexander Pushkin.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- An outstanding issue of the 1944 Presidential campaign is the CIO political action committee's "stranglehold on the New Deal party," Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National Chairman, said today.

ROME, Aug. 29 (U.P.) -- American heavy and medium bombers, with some help from British and French planes, achieved complete destruction of France's greatest naval base at Toulon, where at least ten submarines were found sunk at their moorings, a survey of Allied bomb damage, inflicted while Toulon was in Nazi hands, showed today.

PARIS, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Past the Arc de Triomphe and down through the avenues where their fathers had walked a generation ago, the men of a great American infantry division marched today. There were cheers and laughter, but it was a solemn moment when Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley and Lieut. Gen. Joseph-Pierre Koenig laid a wreath on the tomb of France's Unknown Soldier.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- State tax collections for the fiscal year ended June 30 have climbed to a new high total of $5,386,000,000, which is 5.8 per cent greater than the previous high of slightly more than $5,094,000,000 for 1943, according to figures released today by the Census Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Smashing of the power of German monopolistic concerns on the ground that after two wars they still constitute "a definite menace to the future peace of the world," General Biddle told a Attorney Senate Military Affairs subcommittee today that peace terms should call for means of curbing them.

In view of several hundred persons who scurried into hallways and crowded stores on upper Madison Avenue, a 13-year-old Harlem boy, firing a home-made pistol, exchanged shots with two patrolmen last-night before he was shot in the left side.

The Governors of California, Illinois and Connecticut, loosing the first heavy fire in the Republican party's Presidential campaign, pictured President Roosevelt last night as a candidate whose nomination for a fourth term was "dictated by the New Deal High Command and carried into execution by the bosses of the big city New Deal machines, Kelly and Hague and Flynn and Hannegan."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- A country-wide campaign based on the slogan "Can you spare a worker?" devised by the Michigan Manufacturers Association, will be undertaken by the War Manpower Commission as part of its effort to find skilled workers for the production of war goods in which critical shortages exist.

While Anne O'Hare McCormick has written "No one else was present at his [Churchill's] long conversation with the Pope, so no word of what was said leaked out," the correspondent of The United Press, along with other news items, told us that the Pope also "was said to have expressed the desire to muster all Catholics in Italy into the now dominant Christian Democratic party."

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Cubs, off to a seven-run first inning, broke a seven-game streak with a 15-to-4 rout of Pittsburgh today, but the Pirates gained an even split of a double-header before 11,649 when Frankie Gustine's four hits helped them to a 5-to-4 victory in the nightcap.

An apartment building of nineteen stories and penthouse, to accommodate ninety families and to contain a storage garage, is planned at 71 Riverside Drive and 315-21 West Seventy-ninth Street at a cost of $850,000, according to plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings by Edward J. Hurley, architect, for the Seaman's Bank for Savings, owner of the plot.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- Rye and oats developed a decidedly heavy undertone in the late trading today on the Board of Trade. Prices held within narrow limits until about forty-five minutes before the close of the session. Commission house selling developed thereafter and scattered liquidation was in evidence and found support lacking.

PARIS, Aug. 29 -- Victorious American troops of the Fifth Corps rolled through Paris today in a triumphal procession while the people of the liberated capital quit working, fighting and rebuilding to cheer them.

Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic national chairman, charged yesterday that Governor Dewey's rejection of proposals to simplify "his elaborate, red-tape-bound soldier voting system" has resulted in a situation in which New York will lag far behind neighboring States in getting out the service vote.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 29 -- Four plenipotentiaries are expected here tomorrow from Turkey to conclude the long series of secret negotiations that will eliminate Bulgaria as an enemy belligerent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Secretary Stimson said today that there was no basis for a rumor that United States citizenship was being promised to Italian prisoners of war in this country in return for their loyalty.

As American boys fight on the old line of the Marne battles that might never have had to be fought if the United States had given its full support to the old League of Nations, the outlines of a new League begin to appear in Washington. Yesterday the heads of the British, Russian and American delegations to the security conference at Dumbarton Oaks announced agreement on three points which they will recommend to their Governments.

The regional War Labor Board penalized a union yesterday by depriving it of six weeks' retroactive pay in a labor dispute because it had called a strike during negotiations and in violation of labor's no-strike pledge. The union is Local 843 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, which waged a strike against seven breweries in the Newark, N.J., area last June.
