One of the fundamental reasons for the rule for compulsory competitive bidding for new issues of public utility securities promulgated by the Securities and Exchange Commission some years ago was to reduce the issuing company's cost of borrowing in the investment market and to obtain, theoretically at least, the highest possible price for its securities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The women of this country are more interested in international affairs than ever before and have a better opportunity than ever before to influence international affairs, according to Dr. Helen Dwight Reid, who has just taken charge of the international relations program of the American Association of University Women.
LONDON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The campaign in western and northern France already has cost the Germans at least 325,000 men on the basis of incomplete tabulations.

ROME, Aug. 29 -- The fifteen-day battle for southern France had virtually ended in an Allied victory tonight as American troops completed the destruction of 15,000 Germans trapped in the lower Rhone Valley and French forces opened a new drive southwest toward the Spanish border.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Wednesday, Aug. 30 (AP) -- A communique:

Postmaster Albert Goldman urged yesterday that New Yorkers begin saving strong twine and heavy paper and start packing Christmas parcels for overseas service men and women immediately and be ready to mail the packages on Sept. 15, when the Yule mailing month opens.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has called for redemption on Oct. 2 its outstanding fifteen-year sinking fund convertible 3 1/2 per cent debentures due on Oct. 1, 1952, at 103 1/2 and accrued interest Payment will be made at the company's stock transfer department.

A nation-wide syndicate headed by White, Weld Co. will offer today $12,000,000 of Mississippi Power and Light Comany 3 1/8 per cent first mortgage bonds, due in 1974, at a price of $104.4877 to yield 2.90 per cent.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- The regular pre-season meeting of the National Football League was held today in the league headquarters, with representatives of all the clubs present, including Boston, which is returning after a long absence.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday mobilized the forces of the Police and Sanitation Departments, as well as the teaching staffs and pupils of the city's public schools, to cooperate with the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office in an intensive waste-paper salvage drive to begin immediately after Labor Day.

Although appliance manufacturers have been "talking down" new designs for the post-war period on the plea that full attention should be given to the war effort, they give every indication that they are all set with such designs and will be ready to produce and market them as soon as they get the "go signal" from the Government, it was pointed out in advertising circles yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Supported by far-ranging American planes, Chinese forces today captured Suchowtang, on the Canton-Hankow railway, fifty-five miles north of the enemy-held bastion of Hengyang, and increased their threat to Japanese communications along the vital Siang River, main supply line for Hunan Province, the Chinese Command announced.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Aug. 29 (U.P.) -- British forces, driving south along the Mandalay railway, reported today the capture of strategically important Pinbaw, twenty-six miles from Mogaung, while bombers of the Eastern Air Command roared out of India to disrupt traffic on the new Moulmein-Bangkok railroad.

AMERICAN "Y" FORCE HEADQUARTERS on Salween Front, Aug. 28 (U.P.) -- American liaison soldiers who fought with Chinese guerrillas on the far northern flank of the Salween front for six months have reported to headquarters near the Burma Road after marching more than 1,500 miles through rugged mountain ranges on the China-Burma border near Tibet.

PARIS, Aug. 28 (Delayed) (AP) -- Six men, members of the all-powerful Central Committee of the Paris Liberation Movement, directed hundreds of thousands of Parisians in the revolt against the Nazis. They gathered in a candlelit cellar on Aug. 19 and gave the order from which flared the final, vengeful revolt of a city four years under the German yoke.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- Lieut. Gen. Kurt Dittmar, German radio commentator, admitted tonight that the defeat of Germany was drawing closer and, in perhaps the strongest peace note yet voiced by a German propagandist, he implied that Germany would like to talk compromise terms on a basis somewhere short of unconditional surrender.

Strains of "I Don't Want to Go Home" broke out on the lower level of Grand Central Terminal yesterday as 266 Girl Scouts arrived from Camp Andree in Pleasantville and Camp Brady in Towners, closing their summer camping season two days earlier than scheduled, to abide by wartime travel regulations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The devastating blows struck the Japanese by carrier task forces in the last year were just "a sweet summer zephyr" compared with the punishment which the Navy's air arm, backed up by other weapons, is now prepared to deliver, Vice Admiral Aubrey W. Fitch declared tonight on the eve of the thirty-first anniversary of naval aviation.

A West Side garage building has been acquired by a dairy company which plans to improve the structure for a new pasteurization plant. Several midtown and West Side apartment houses also were reported yesterday to have passed into new hands.

BRITISH HEADQUARTERS near the Seine, Aug 29 (AP) -- Allied troops killed or captured 122,000 Germans in the general Falaise entrapment, British Second Army headquarters said today, and still more thousands of Germans will be added to the toll from the disorganized enemy retreat across the Seine.

The French Republic will be restored to take its place, by the labors of its people, among the great powers, Gen. Charles de Gaulle pledged yesterday in a speech in Paris, in which he paid tribute to the city's resistance, the valor of the French Forces of the Interior and "the Allies' armies whose irresistible offensive made possible the liberation of Paris and is making certain the liberation" of all France.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- The Bulgarian Government, hastening to get out of the war, began today to surrender territory that in any case the Allies were expected to demand as a condition of Bulgaria's surrender.

The French Republic will be restored to take its place, by the labors of its people, among the great powers, Gen. Charles de Gaulle pledged yesterday in a speech in Paris, in which he paid tribute to the city's resistance, the valor of the French Forces of the Interior and "the Allies' armies whose irresistible offensive made possible the liberation of Paris and is making certain the liberation" of all France.

LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 30 -- Russian land and naval forces, combining a sixty-five-mile advance overland and an eighty-two mile amphibious leap down the Black Sea coast, captured the great Rumanian port of Constanta yesterday, while other Red Army troops drove to the outer fringes of the Ploesti oil fields and seized control of the great Ploesti-Constanta oil pipeline.

The secret of the moral strength of the French resistance is difficult, I think, for Americans to understand. The Norwegians, the Czechs and Poles, the Russians, the Yugoslavs and the Greeks all understand. They know the Germans.

ROME, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Plans for reconstruction of Cassino -- theatre of some of the war's most bitter fighting -- have been approved and 125 one-family houses will be erected soon at the devastated town, the Allied Control Commission for Italy announced today.

The cables have brought news that in Washington Senator Kenneth McKellar is urging that the United States obtain (1) all islands in possession of or mandated to Japan as of Dec. 5, 1941; (2) all islands in the West Indies now in the possession of European nations, and (3) the Galapagos Islands off Ecuador in South America.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, Aug. 31 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's four Allied armies have driven two salients deep into northern France, and the withdrawal of the German armies from that area is now regarded as inevitable by Allied staff officers.

During recent weeks Poland has been in the news first as a battleground, second as the object of controversy between the Polish Government in Exile, with headquarters in London, and the Polish Committee of National Liberation, formerly in Moscow, now in liberated Lublin.

David A. Schulte, president of Park Tilford, Inc., has paid to the company $264,828 in cash representing "profits" on his trading in shares of the company between Oct. 21, 1941, and May 31, 1944, his counsel reported yesterday to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Following discussions with high railroad officials and the Office of Defense Transportation, the American Management Association has decided to continue its conference program, attended by 13,000 persons last year, it was learned yesterday.

I have read your editorial "Post-War Military Research." During World War I, I had an especial assignment in Europe which brought me into close contact with much of the military research of the Allied nations. LONDON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Smashing through blazing defensive fire, Nazi flying bombs struck London and southern England in periodic salvos today. As Allied armies racing for Belgium captured more of the enemy's launching sites and our bombers hammered others in northern France, the Nazi-controlled Oslo radio asserted Hitler's V-1 weapon was portable and could be shifted for operation to all parts of Europe.
The long-standing petition of New York City real estate owners for a 10 per cent increase in housing rents was denied yesterday by the Office of Price Administration.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UP) -- Dr. Ramon Grau San Martin, President-elect of Cuba, arrived here today by plane for an official visit at the invitation of President Roosevelt.

Maintaining its record pace, "Dragon Seed," the Metro adaptation of the Pearl Buck novel, which begins its seventh week at the Radio City Music Hall today, will have been seen by 894,600 persons for a gross business of $737,000 in its first six weeks, according to an estimate made by the management yesterday.

Plans for a new housing unit for 167 families to be erected after the war in the Tudor City development on the East Side were announced yesterday by Irving Broun, president of the Fred F. French Investing Company. It will be twelve stories high and occupy a plot 241.4 by 131.8 feet at the southwest corner of Prospect Place and East Forty-first Street.

Martial Jean Paul Singher, baritone at the Metropolitan Opera House, is wondering if it is a criminal offense to sing in his own apartment. He spent three hours yesterday attempting to take legal possession of a five-room apartment at 124 East Eighty-fourth Street before he was finally successful-- but not before he signed a statement saying that he never would sing in it.

Decision to add only two new colors in women's shoes for the coming spring season was reached yesterday, despite elimination of color restrictions by the War Production Board, at a meeting of representatives of the Tanners Council of America, the National Shoe Retailers Association, the National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers Association and the Textile Color Card Association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- A suit seeking to break up what the Government describes as an international cartel agreement to divide markets and fix prices in the distribution and sale of machinery for separating, cleaning and grading of grain was filed by the Department of Justice in Minneapolis today.

PARIS, Aug. 30 (U.P.) -- The furniture was being dusted and new name plates were being hung out at many of the old American business places in Paris today. Others remained empty, with German signs still standing as reminders of the enemy occupation.

Under expanded interest, the stock market crept forward moderately yesterday, although the pace slackened toward the close and best gains were reduced somewhat. There was a smattering of investment demand, but the bulk of the transfers still centered in low-price issues.

ALBANY, Aug. 30 -- Justice Francis Bergan in the Supreme Court today heard arguments on a novel question, the outcome of which will determine whether the nominations made by the American Labor Party and the Liberal Party of President Roosevelt and Senator Harry S. Truman will stand.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 -- Stamey Hiller Jr., a 19-year-old Berkeley inventor, who at the age of 12 established a $100,000-a-year business in making miniature racing automobiles, demonstrated today a helicopter of his own design, on which he had worked for three years.
LONDON, Aug. 30 -- After ten months' work the United Nations War Crimes Commission has ready a preliminary list of German war criminals whose surrender the Allies will demand.
LONDON, Aug. 30 -- Returning voluntarily to Germany, 600 men, women and children, all German nationals, will leave an internment camp on the Isle of Man tomorrow night for repatriation.

The semi-annual report of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, released yesterday by P.W. Litchfield, board chairman, reveals an increase of 10.5 per cent in net sales, to $404,707,818 from the $366,269,545 volume for the first six months of 1943.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- For the third straight year, the Army-Navy football game, one of sports' super-spectacles in peacetime days, will be held down this season to a home-town show.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 30 -- Bulgaria's armistice delegation arrived in Cairo early this evening to receive surrender terms from those Allied powers with which their Government is still in a state of war.

SCRANTON, Pa., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Lieut. (jg) J. Donald Reifsnyder, USN an attorney and social leader, shot and killed himself today a short time before he was to have reappeared before a Federal grand jury investigating the affairs of the Federal district court.

To commemorate the town of Distomo, Greece, whose 1,100 men, women and children were killed by Nazi machine guns June 10, the Committee for the Rebirth of Distomo was formed yesterday to seek a community in the United States that will adopt the name.

Irregularity developed yesterday in the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange, and final prices were 3 to 7 points lower on the day. The near contracts were relatively firmer than distant months.

PARIS, Aug. 30 (U.P.)--Dr. Marcel Petiot, whose crimes were broadcast by the Germans during their occupation of Paris, probably was the super-Bluebeard of all time, gendarmes of the Clichy district said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The United Mine Workers Journal in an editorial today blamed unnamed labor leaders as being "too cowardly to press forward for labor gains," and charged that President Roosevelt was "smart enough to trick the simple minds of the misleaders of labor into believing that the world will go to hell unless the full pattern and design of the present Administration as regards all things is accepted in toto by labor."

PARIS, Aug. 30 (U.P.) -- The four-year occupation of France by the Germans has brought about the almost total collapse of whole sections of French industrial and economic life, and a gigantic effort will have to be made to restore them and to place France again on a healthy economic basis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Confidence that victory over the Germans will be won within the next four months was voiced tonight by Under-Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson in a report to the nation on his observations at the French and Italian battlefronts.

The Duchess of Windsor was scheduled to enter Roosevelt Hospital last night to undergo an operation for appendicitis, probably today, following a final consultation of her physicians yesterday afternoon, it was announced by a spokesman for the Duke of Windsor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The War Production Board lifted its restrictions today which have been standardizing models and fuel types of domestic cooking appliances and heating stoves, but warned simultaneously that the relaxation of these specifications would not result in "dressed-up" products.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Sales of wholesalers, on the basis of reports from 2,752 establishments, were approximately at the same level in July as for the same month a year ago, it was reported today by the Census Bureau.

OGDEN, Utah, Aug. 30 (AP) --Slingin' Sammy Baugh still has that old-time magic in his arm -- and he has a top-notch receiver to boot.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Aug. 30 (U.P.) -- Troops of the British Fourteenth Army have blasted their way to the upper Chindwin River in West Burma to gain their first major objective in that area and totally wipe out the temporary advantage gained by the Japanese since they launched their ill-fated invasion of India last March.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- August production of combat aircraft will fall about 400 units behind schedule, just as July did, but the output will be sufficient to supply all needed craft to the armed services, Charles E. Wilson, retiring executive vice chairman of the War Production Board, said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 30 -- In a casting switch involving two studios, Gregory Peck will go to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the lead with Greer Garson in "The Valley of Decision" and John Hodiak, who had been announced for that part, will return to Twentieth Century-Fox for the Major Joppolo role in "A Bell for Adano."

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Thursday, Aug. 31 -- Along the entire line from New Guinea to the Philippines, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's Army and Navy bombers tore at Japanese shipping, coastal installations and troop concentrations with unrelenting fury.

The national junior and girls' champions figured in the two most interesting matches in the combined men's and women's national championships yesterday as the sixty-third annual tournament started at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, with a large representation from the armed forces.

The turf veteran was studying the Racing Form and the Briton, oddly enough, was reading a London newspaper.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Five thousand beauty kits to be sent to Red Cross workers overseas were presented today by Mrs. Constance L. Huhn, president of the George W. Luft Company, to the American Red Cross. The satchels will be shipped to all war zones served by the Red Cross.

Issued today by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company is a new 104-page booklet that contains 455 tested recipes, hints on budgeting one's money for food, ideas on avoiding failures in making cakes and pastry, and suggested short-cuts in meal-getting.

The four-story forty-eight family apartment house at 234-36 Hawthorne Avenue, Yonkers, N.Y., has been sold by the trustees of Series 34-F to the Alpha Management Corporation at a reported price of $125,000 cash. A loan was made on the property by the East New York Savings Bank.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Cubs beat Pittsburgh twice today, 12 to 5 and 6 to 3, before 17,438 fans. Dom Dallessandro of Chicago, Vince DiMaggio and Babe Dahlgren of the Pirates hit homers during the five and one-half hour double-header.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 -- An amended plan for reorganization of the Portland (Ore.) Sophie of Saks-Fifth Avenue opened the couture season of New York yesterday afternoon in the Salon Moderne, with a diversified collection that included styles ranging from tailored suits to formal evening gowns.

OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., Aug. 30 -- Opening the Republican national campaign in Maine, Representative Everett Dirksen of Illinois charged tonight that President Roosevelt was seeking reelection under false pretenses.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30--The War Labor Board voted unanimously today to refer to President Roosevelt for action the refusal of an affiliate of the United Mine Workers to call off strikes of supervisors in seven Pennsylvania coal mines.

BOSTON, Aug. 30 -- Under the paralyzing influence of two home runs, the Giants bowed to the Braves today by 4-to-2.

A group of investment bankers headed by Dick Merle-Smith will offer today for public subscription an issue of $47,000,000 of Kansas City Terminal Railway Company first mortgage serial bonds, dated Oct. 1, 1944, and maturing from 1948 to 1974.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 (U.P.) -- Gov. Earl Warren revealed tonight he had rejected a speech suggested to him by Republican national headquarters that denounced Sidney Hillman and the Congress of Industrial Organizations' Political Action Committee for promoting a fourth term for President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- A survey of the economic aspects of the Allied invasion of Normandy, made public yesterday by Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., reports that Allied forces have spent but a relatively small part of their pay in France, with the result that prices in liberated areas have been "notably downward."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Proposals for extending unemployment compensation payments to all Federal employes and the increasing of the amounts of weekly benefits paid during the reconversion period emerged today as the principal causes of impending fights as the House prepared to act tomorrow on amendments to the battered Senate bill containing the basic program for industrial demobilization.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- President Roosevelt presented six Congressional Medals of Honor today at the largest ceremony of its kind held in the White House since the war began. A substantial increase -- slightly more than forty-five tons over last week -- in the regular Wednesday collection of waste paper throughout the city by Department of Sanitation trucks was reported last night by Commissioner William F. Carey. His final figures were 345.1 tons, compared to 299.8.

ROME, Aug. 30--British and Polish troops of the British Eighth Army were within two miles of the Gothic Line today. After having pushed back the German First Parachute Division, they dug in solidly in the last high ground before the Foglia River.
