Eisenhower, reporting on what he called "this great victory" in northern France, told the War Department today that German casualties in the swirling battles up to Aug. 25 had been more than 400,000, with two whole armies and the main strength of two more decisively beaten.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Southern Pine Association is the winner of the annual contest for cooperative services to business men by trade associations conducted by the American Trade Association Executives, Secretary of Commerce Jesse Jones announced today.

LAMAR, Mo., Aug. 31 -- Formally accepting the Democratic party's nomination for Vice President from the steps of the Barton County Court House here in the little town of his birth, Senator Harry S. Truman warned the American people tonight not to change Presidents in the "midstream" of efforts to secure a lasting peace.

TRENTON, Aug. 31 -- In the presence of many fellow-convicts, sixty-two inmates of the New Jersey State Prison here were honored today for having served as human "guinea pigs" in medical experiments for the control of tropical fevers which have incapacitated many men of the armed forces in the war.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Although business in today's stock markets was on the quiet side, there were one or two bright spots. The best feature was renewed Cape buying of Kaffir shares, the rise being accentuated by the small market supply of shares on this side.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- A Berlin broadcast announced today German rejection of British and American warnings against treating the Polish Home Army "contrary to the laws and customs of war" and said these Poles were rebels without protection of The Hague Convention.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on Aug. 26 were 905,724 cars, the Association of American Rairoads announced today. This was 18,278 cars or 2.1 per cent more than for the preceding week, 1,667 cars or 0.2 per cent more than for the corresponding week yast year and 6,319 cars or 0.7 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WITH UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY in France, Aug. 31 -- Our drive is sweeping on at a breathless, incredible rate. Never in all warfare have troops advanced so swiftly and with such power. The Germans wanted a blitz war and now they have it.

Allied victories have assisted in the work of evacuating refugees and have had an effect not only on neutral and occupied countries but upon the Axis satellite nations as well, according to Joseph Schwartz, European chairman of the American Joint Distribution Committee, who arrived here yesterday after an eight-month trip abroad.

This month stocks of butter will be the smallest they have been, according to the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, which forecast yesterday supplies of food that will be available to civilians during September. Beef of superior quality and large fresh eggs will be short, also, though virtually all other products -- lower grade beef, small-sized eggs, produce, poultry and fish -- will be plentiful.

ALBANY, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Establishment of a more adequate program of physical training for youth is "a statutory obligation that cannot be overlooked," George D. Stoddard, State Education Commissioner, declared today in a letter to school superintendents and principals.

Bobby Permane closed his career as an apprentice jockey in a blaze of glory by riding three winners yesterday at Belmont Park, where 18,956 watched the racing and bet $1,899,802. The blond lad, who had piloted his first victor a year ago yesterday, lost his apprentice allowance of five pounds because of the expiration of that time and today he will compete as a full-fledged jockey.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Mrs. Pilar H. Lim, former president of the National Federation of Women's Clubs in the Philippines, was today sworn in as the one woman member in the eighteen-member Filipino Rehabilitation Commission, which includes three members of President Sergio Osmena's Cabinet in the Filipino group and three Senators and three Representatives in the American group.

While property owners were considering a possible appeal from the decision of the Office of Price Administration turning down their plea for a 10 per cent blanket increase in housing rents in New York, Mayor La Guardia hailed the decision as a victory for the city administration and for the city's 2,000,000 rent-paying families.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- The New York Football Giants, forty-one strong (?), reported to Coach Steve Owen today as their training camp was opened in this picturesque setting. Gathering his men around him, which rates as quite a trick, even when Stout Steve is in shape, the veteran mentor lost no time at all in emphasizing that "every job on this club is open."

When Gustav H. Jensen started working for Lord Taylor at the age of 13, he told himself, "By jingo, I'll keep this job." Yesterday, in the offices of the store for which he has worked continuously for sixty-five years and where he is now collection manager, 78-year-old Mr. Jensen received from Walter Hoving, president of Lord Taylor, a gold watch as a token of his long service.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 31 -- Germany is stated by Excelsior today to be planning the creation of what the newspaper terms a "seventh column" charged with the task of rebuilding the Reich after the war.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 31 -In the second break in the ranks of the Rhode Island Political Action Committee, nine of twentyone members have resigned from the PAC committee of the industrial trades union of Woonsocket. The nine said their action was motivated by fear that the movement would harm labor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Acting Secretary Patterson held his press conference today in an auditorium of the fifth floor of the Pentagon not customarily visited by War Department correspondents, with the result that even some of the Pentagon veterans had trouble finding it.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 31 -Mrs. Julia Columbo's life ended last night -- and with it one of the tenderest deceptions ever enacted in this capital of make-believe.
LONDON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The condition statement of the Bank of England for the week ended Aug. 30 showed an increase of u1,573,000 in note circulation.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 31 (U.P.) -A five-run barrage in the fourth inning tonight, highlighted by Joe Buzas' homer with two on, enabled Newark to defeat Baltimore, 6 -- 3, and move within a game and a half of the league leaders. A crowd of 6,134 paid to watch the first of a five-game series on which the pennant hinges.

Once more this ancient and illustrious city has passed out of the hands of the German savages. In September, 1914, bombardments which fired the scaffolding and roof of the cathedral stirred the anger of civilization. In 1917 and 1918 the rose window and the Angel spire were destroyed.

Initial reports on back-to-school merchandising are favorable, with volume rising sharply during the last ten days. College shops have been busy, but the greater acceleration has been noted in children's and junior departments. Many retailers are particularly stressing the coordination of items and colors in "pig-tail" and 'teen age groups.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- With some steel plants down to less than a week's supply of coal, President Roosevelt today ordered Secretary Ickes, as Solid Fuels Administrator, to seize ten Pennsylvania coal mines owned by two companies.

LONDON, Friday, Sept. 1 -- At least 120 Nazi flying-bomb launching ramps already have been neutralized by the Allied advance in northern France, it was reported today, but continued sporadic attacks on the London area indicated that the Germans were using new sites, possibly in Belgium.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Office of Price Administration issued a new price regulation for furs today, establishing dollars-and-cents maximum prices over Australian and New Zealand rabbit skins, and hatters' fur cut from these imports.

At noon today on the station platform of the Seaboard-All Florida Railway in Miami, Fla., one of the largest public auctions of railroad properties in recent years will take place. As a result of foreclosure proceedings the assets of the Seaboard-All Florida, the Florida Western Northern Railroad and the East and West Coast Railway will be sold to the highest bidder.

The nullifying effect of Selective Service regulations on the quota arrangement by which a limited number of qualified students were to complete their education as chemists is the subject of a disturbing report by a committee of the American Chemical Society.

" Their shoes," writes the trained observer, speaking for the combined American press, "would make any American woman weep with envy. Platform soles are the thing and they are usually in bright reds and greens, while other colors usually accept the print of the dress."

LONDON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Slovakia fell rapidly under the control of Czechoslovak armed forces today, and a German DNB broadcast, announcing a Cabinet shake-up in the Nazi puppet state of Croatia, indicated the possible spread of revolt to that country.

Consolidated net income of the American Power and Light Company and its subsidiaries amounted to $3,057,045 for the three months ended with June, compared with $3,660,761 for the June quarter of 1943. Operating revenues for this year's period increased to $34,005,569 from $32,220,534 for similar three months a year ago.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Communique 145:

The Duchess of Windsor underwent a successful operation for appendicitis yesterday morning at Roosevelt Hospital, and was resting satisfactorily last night, it was announced in a bulletin issued by Dr. Joe R. Clemmons, the hospital's director.

The Board of Estimate, at a special meeting at City Hall yesterday, authorized Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick to purchase the tentative awards made by the courts to residents of Queens whose property has been condemned by the city for improvement of the new municipal airport at Idlewild.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Purchasing missions from a number of allied and friendly nations will no longer be able to exercise veto powers over shipments of American goods to their homelands, according to an order today of the Foreign Economic Administration, effective Oct. 1.

Maj. Alexander H. (Zan) Carver of Philadelphia, Flying Fortress and Liberator pilot on furlough from the Pacific area, experienced his biggest thrill since sinking a submarine when he eliminated one of the favored group yesterday in the national championship at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

The Literary Guild's October selection is a first novel about Montreal, called "Earth and High Heaven," by a Canadian author, Gwethalyn Graham. Lippincott will publish it Oct. 4. The Guild's November selection is the latest Jalna book by Mazo de la Roche, who began her series in 1927 with "Jalna," winner of the $10,000 Atlantic Monthly fiction award for that year.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- As the Allied armies swept northward tonight, Belgian officials who will act in liaison with them were on twenty-four-hour call in London, with their plans completed, their baggage packed and transportation arranged for them.

Three more Republican Governors will speak by radio tonight in the second of a series of such broadcasts to serve as a prelude to Governor Dewey's opening campaign address at Philadelphia on Sept. 7. The fifteen minute program will be carried from 10:30 to 10:45 on the network of the National Broadcasting Company and will be heard through 139 stations.

Mayor La Guardia confirmed yesterday a report that the Police Department had served notice on the Copacabana night club, 10 East Sixtieth Street, to show cause why its license should not be revoked because of the character of its ownership and management.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Short covering and millers' buying of wheat gave the grain markets a firm undertone today on the Board of Trade, although liquidation continued in September oats, which sold at a new seasonal low. Failure of many of the rumors circulated late yesterday to be confirmed overnight, combined with a belief that the urgent selling had about run its course, had considerable influence on sentiment.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- A gain of 5 per cent for July in the sales of independent retailers, compared with the same month last year, was reported today by the Bureau of the Census. Cumulative sales to date were 5 per cent over sales for the first seven months of 1943.

Consumer response to August fur events has been disappointing in most sections of the country, reports in the industry here agreed yesterday. Volume slipped substantially behind a year ago, with reorders reaching the trade being chiefly for lower-end garments.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Strand the attraction will be "Arsenic and Old Lace," Warner Brothers' adaptation of the long-run Broadway comedy, starring Cary Grant. Produced and directed by Frank Capra, the picture's supporting cast includes Raymond Massey, Peter Lorre, Priscilla Lane Jack Carson and James Gleason.

ROME, Aug. 31 (AP) -- From "near Lyon" an Associated Press correspondent reported having seen three railroad-car loads of American Red Cross supplies -- plainly marked -- that had been looted by the fleeing Germans. He said smashed and torn cartons of food and medical supplies were scattered over a wide area.
LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery, favorite soldier of the average Briton, has been promoted to the highest rank in the British Army, that of Field Marshal, by King George.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed increase in holdings of Government securities and note circulation for the system as a whole to be $259,813,000 and $173,767,000, respectively, while the ratio of reserve declined to 54.5.

The reopening of New York City's schools will not be postponed, although the peak of the polio-myelitis epidemic has not yet been passed, a spokesman for the Department of Health reported yesterday. The number of cases in the city is said to be very low compared with other parts of the State and in comparison with other epidemic years.

A new kind of Never-Never Land was discovered yesterday. After exploring the paragraphs of War Production Board limitation order L-85, which regulates the yardage going into women's wartime clothing, it was found that the twenty-six-inch-long woolen garments displayed Wednesday by Sophie of Saks Fifth Avenue were neither jackets -- "a jacket cannot be longer than twenty-five inches" -- nor coats -- "a coat cannot be shorter than thirty-three inches."
LONDON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Hungary, new keystone of Adolf Hitler's southeastern defenses, seemed on the edge of a crack-up today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A Pacific Fleet announcement:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Oregon-Washington Railroad and Navigation Company, operated under lease by the Union Pacific Railroad Company, made application today to the Interstate Commerce Commission to sell $54,750,000 of refunding mortgage bonds, Series A, and $17,444,000 of refunding mortgage bonds, Series B, a total of $72,194,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -The President's recent trip to the Pacific, his Scottie dog "Fala," and Representative Clare Boothe Luce's guest columns for Walter Winchell came in for sharp comment today in the House during a set-to between Democrats and Republicans.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Chinese forces have crushed enemy defenses five to seven miles northeast of the Yangtze River port of Ichang in diversionary drive to prevent the Japanese from sending reinforcements to the Hengyang front, it was announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- An all-out effort to recruit 4,000 Army nurses during September "to help care for heavy casualties being suffered on all fronts" was announced today by the American Red Cross.

Most readers, I am sure, will feel that Albert A. Volk's proposal to continue bombing the Germans after they are ready to surrender is too drastic. A people which has countenanced such cruel and barbaric practices as the enforced labor of subject populations, the execution of hostages, the extermination of Jews in Poland and the indiscriminate massacre of civilians as at Lidice, scarcely deserves our sympathy.
August passed last night, and the heat is over for the season, except for possibly a brief spell now and then, in the opinion of the Weather Bureau.

Holders of 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock of the Gotham Hosiery Company, Inc., have been notified that the company will redeem on Nov. 1 all this stock at $110 a share plus an amount equal to dividends at the rate of 7 per cent from Aug. 1, 1944, to Nov. 1, making a total redemption price of $111.75.

WITH BRITISH TROOPS, Before Amiens, Aug. 31 (AP) -- British tanks cruising the country east of the Seine are fanning out at such speed that it no longer is possible to keep abreast of their progress. At a forward headquarters this morning the staff was setting out again to establish a new position for the third time in forty-eight hours.

Although trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the lightest since May, the volume was the largest since 1936 for a corresponding month. Transactions for August, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, were 20,752,920 shares, compared with 28,219,705 shares in July, and with 14,251,976 shares in the same month a year ago.
Following is the text of Senator Harry S. Truman's address last night as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

ALBANY, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Declaring the "Poles have lived up to the gallant tradition of their history" in opposing the Nazi armies, Governor Dewey today proclaimed tomorrow as "Tribute to Poland Day" and urged all citizens of the State to join in its observance.

Net profit of the Borden Company and its domestic and Canadian subsidiaries during the first six months of this year amounted to $4,325,000 after provision of $1,500,000 for special contingencies, taxes and other charges, T.G. Montague, president, reported to stockholders yesterday in a semi-annual statement.

IN the reign of Henry VI in the year 1432, one year after Joan of Arc was burned to death in the market-place of Rouen, an elderly English woman began to dictate her autobiography. The priest who set down her words wrote and spelled "so ill," Margery Kempe thought it best to start all over again four years later with a new amanuensis.

Associations in the work clothing field have been assured by the Office of Price Administration that it will cooperate fully with them as industry representatives in the future, and that every member of the work clothing industry advisory committee will be consulted before issuance of further amendments or regulations affecting the industry, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- The American Federation of Musicians' ban on recordings was described as "a made-work plan based on no real need" by Sydney Kaye, special counsel for the National Association of Broadcasters, in an address before the association today.

ROME, Aug. 31 -- French armored columns, in an eighty-two-mile thrust through southwestern France, drove to within forty-seven miles of the Spanish border today, while American troops captured Valence in an eleven-mile advance up the Rhone Valley and rolled on toward Lyon for a final showdown battle with the battered remnants of the German Nineteenth Army.
Sufficient price-fixing orders appeared late yesterday in the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange to steady prices, and these at the close showed net gains of 1 to 5 points.

CHINESE HEADQUARTERS on the Salween Front, Aug. 31 (U.P.) -- Japanese troops, pushing up the Burma Road from the Mangshih area, are throwing desperate attacks against two Chinese road blocks in an effort to smash through to the aid of their beleagured garrison at Lungling, hub of the enemy's Salween defense system.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- On the eve of the fifth anniversary of the World War, which started on Polish soil, the Government in exile made comprehensive proposals today for settlement of its long-festering dispute with the Soviet Union. Prime Minister Stanislaw Mikolajczyk described the dispute as a test case for future world peace.

The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago has called a special meeting of stockholders on Oct. 5 for the principal purpose of approving amendments to the present mortage in order to permit a further simplification of the capital structure of the utility and its affiliates. It will be a final step in a iprogram begun in 1937, the letter I says.
The British radio yesterday quoted late dispatches reporting that units of the forces of Marshal Tito had reached the vicinity of Belgrade and that the thunder of guns was resounding in the city.

LONDON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Hundreds of British heavy bombers and American Marauder mediums ripped German ammunition and flying bomb fuel dumps in the Channel coast area today in the path of encroaching Allied land armies, and also struck twice at tiny Cezembre Island whose German gunners are preventing the Allies from using St. Malo harbor in Brittany.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Another "holiday" period in which distillers will be free to devote their output to potable spirits rather than alcohol for war use is possible "in the not too distant future," Dr. Walter G. Whitman, head of the War Production Board's Chemical Bureau, said today.

Of dubious farces there seems no end -- although, of course, after Labor Day it may be different. Into the Cort Theatre, which had a full share before, there came last evening the latest in the series, "Sleep No More." Like may another in recent seasons, and no doubt back through history, it tries to pretend that turbulence is humor, and wit is arrived at by the constant reiteration of a couple of jokes.

Dr. Ramon Grau San Martin, President-Elect of Cuba, is a guest at the White House. Sunday we shall see him in this city. He will be inaugurated on Oct. 1. He is a distinguished physician, Professor of Anatomy in the National University. He was inexperienced in politics when he became Provisional President in September, 1933, though he had been an active opponent of the Machado dictatorship.
LONDON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Flying

The Senate version of the surplus disposal bill provides that no Government agency shall manufacture or produce articles with Government-owned plants in competition with private industry. This is a sound principle. The bill's restrictions on Government operation, however, apply only to the Federal Government.

A scholarship fund to provide tuition and maintenance for men and women students in practical nursing was announced yesterday by the Committee for the Recruitment and Education of Practical Nurses, 250 West Fifty-seventh Street. The grants will be distributed on the basis of need to candidates between the ages of 18 and 50, with an elementary chool education or its equivalent, and who are citizens or in possession of their first papers.

LONDON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Author P.G. Wodehouse, who made five broadcasts over the German radio during his internment in the Reich, was quoted in a dispatch from Paris today as having said that he believed he had made "a terrible mistake," but meant no wrong.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31--A powerful coalition of House Democrats and Republicans, out-maneuvering and out-voting the "liberal" forces, passed by a voice vote late today the much whittled-down Senate bill carrying the basic legislative program for industrial demobilization and post-war readjustment.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 31 -- Disbandment of Atlantic City's civiliaan police corps of 350 was announced today by Police Capt. William Mulloy on the heels of charges that regular policemen have refused to "cooperate" with the volunteer officers in law-enforcement duties.

Your editor's note to Christopher Morley's letter this morning, in which you say, "The Maquis are named * * *," continues an American usage which shows our misunderstanding of the word. "Le Maquis" is a collective singular without a plural, like our word "the underground."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Seasonally lower prices for apples and potatoes together with declining markets for live poultry and eggs brought the Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of commodity prices in primary markets down 0.1 per cent during the week ended Aug. 26.

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- Probably anticipating that the shops of Paris would not always be at her disposal, the wife of Reich Marshal Hermann Goering visited the fashionable establishments here just two weeks before the city was liberated and had four dresses made.

The world today is too busy with more important matters to give much attention to the culinary art. However, we all hope the time is soon coming when it will again take its justifiably important place in our lives and in anticipation of that happy day it may not be too early to draw attention to a serious situation now existing.

The great battle that is now reaching its triumphant climax in northern France as the beaten armies of Hitler stream toward the approaches to Germany has been the most successful major campaign in our military history.

Crown Princess Martha of Norway attended a gala performance of the operetta "Song of Norway" last night in the Imperial Theatre, 249 West Forty-fifth Street. Arriving from her summer residence in Green Farms, Conn., she was met at the theatre by an honorary guard of seamen from the Norwegian Navy Gunnery School on Travers Island, Pelham.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Dry beans, fruit butters and prune juice were in effect removed from rationing today as the Office of Price Administration reduced the ration values of these three items to zero points.

The President's War Relief Control Board in Washington, it was learned yesterday, has reversed its attitude of last December and has certified the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee, a left wing organization, as eligible for membership in the National War Fund.
LONDON, Aug. 31 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Swelled by the largest railroad financing since March, 1936, new bonds offered publicly here in August totaled $189,263,000, for twenty new issues, the largest amount for any month since April, 1942, when $261,352,000 in twenty-six issues were marketed.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Friday, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Catalina flying boats damaged or sank a Japanese destroyer and four merchantmen in another raid at heavily hit Celebes Island, headquarters announced today.

HEADQUARTERS OF UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCES, Pacific Ocean Areas, Aug. 31 -Lieut. Gen. Millard F. Harmon, whose appointment to the newly created position of commander of Army Air Forces in Pacific Ocean Areas was announced today by Pacific Fleet Headquarters, told correspondents this afternoon that mass bombings of Japan on a scale as large as the 1,000-plane attacks on Germany are probable, "if Japan holds out long enough to make it necessary."

When Eugene Ormandy, conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, arrived here yesterday from his three-month tour of Australia, he disclosed that Gen. Douglas MacArthur had set a definite date for a Victory concert in Manila. Mr. Ormandy said the general had invited him to conduct the Manila Symphony Orchestra at this concert, and that he had accepted.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 -- The staff of the Public Utilities Division of the Securities and Exchange Commission was accused today by three attorneys of participating in secret negotiations in the recapitalization proceedings of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation for the purpose of "muzzling" the common stockholders and deprivng them of their rightful portion of the proposed one-stock structure of the huge holding company.
PARIS, Aug. 31 (U.P.) -- Dr. Alexis Carrel, world famous physiologist who served as a health official in the puppet Vichy regime, denied today charges that he collaborated with the Germans.

LONDON, Friday, Sept. 1 (AP) -Yesterday's parade of big Russian tanks and guns down the broad Calea Victorei, Bucharest's main thoroughfare, came three years and six weeks after Rumania made the fatal mistake of joining the Germans in their June, 1941, attack on Russia -- a step that has cost the Rumanians more than 300,000 men, either captured or who perished on the vast Russian steppes leading far back to Stalingrad.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- United States forces alone lost 3,000 airplanes and more than 900 tanks in supporting the operations in France, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower revealed today in cabling an urgent plea across the Atlantic for an unbroken flow of war materiel.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Relieving Stubby Overmire in the seventh, Dizzy Trout scored his twenty-third victory of the season tonight as the Tigers defeated the league-leading Browns, 4 to 3.

To encourage the design of heating facilities that may be easily and inexpensively converted from one fuel to another, the Bituminous Coal Institute is sponsoring a competition opening today in which prizes will be awarded for the most practical and attractive architectural designs for basements and chimneys capable of using any fuel.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Lieut. Glenn Dobbs of Tulsa University, stationed with the Second Air Force at Colorado Springs, was voted the most valuable player with the All-Stars in last night's charity game won by the professional Chicago Bears, 24 to 21, on a fourth-period field goal.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Friday, Sept. 1 -- The Battle of France is nearly over, and the Battle of Belgium is about to begin.

We may take it for granted that Senator Truman's long-considered and carefully prepared address last night, accepting the Vice-Presidential nomination, offers a sure clue to the type of campaign which the Democratic party will make in the fall election. This campaign will subordinate domestic to international issues.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Nearly 250,000 workers will have to join the labor force of the cotton-textile industry by Nov. 1 if a dangerous slump in production is to be halted and essential requirements for cotton products are to be met, the War Manpower Commission stated today.

A cut in bus service in Manhattan and the Bronx before the end of this month was threatened yesterday when the Office of Defense Transportation ruled, in effect, that bus operators in these boroughs would get no more new tires until the truck tire shortage became less critical in other communities that depended more heavily on buses for essential transport.

With the addition this week of 55,000 drug stores and 10,000 general merchandise stores, it was announced yesterday by Arnold Friedman, chairman of the paper conservation division of the Periodical Publishers National Committee, that altogether 240,000 retail stores throughout the country have signed the War Production Board's pledge to conserve paper bags and to ask customers to carry packages unwrapped.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The fifth anniversary of Hitler's attack on Poland arrives just after General Eisenhower has made public the results of the fighting in northern France between June 6 and Aug. 25. In "this great victory." as General Eisenhower truly calls it in his report to the War Department, the Germans have lost over 400,000 men in killed, wounded and prisoners of war.

OF the thousands of spectators who will be in attendance at the national tennis championships this week-end, no one will watch the play more keenly than Walter Pate, the captain of the American Davis Cup team. He was ambushed at Forest Hills yesterday and gently prodded into discussing tennis in general. Before he had finished, however, Mr. Pate was waxing lyrical about J. Donald Budge, his favorite character.

Approval by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service of a change in zoning suggested by Conservation Commissioner John A. White is regarded by the Conservation Department as a boon to New York State woodcock hunters.

Because of the need for schooling its members in the proper psychological attitudes toward the war wounded, the Navy Wives Club of America is requiring all its affiliates to devote at least one session to studying the subject.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The State Department announced today that Robert D. Murphy, who performed important diplomatic roles in connection with the North African and Italian invasions, had been assigned to the staff of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower "as a political adviser with the personal rank of Ambassador in the machinery that will be set up for the military government of Germany."
MOSCOW, Friday, Sept. 1 -- Soviet troops entered Bucharest, the capital of Rumania, yesterday after defeating the enemy grouping south of the Ploesti oil fields.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Thomas B. Cromwell's 4-year-old colt Ogma returned to the races after a five-month rest today and won the Jockey Guild Purse at Narragansett Park.

FLORENCE, Italy, Aug. 30 (Delayed) -- Florence is no longer the Florence that the world has known for 400 years, and this is the shocking surprise that anyone gets on coming to the city after its "liberation." No previous accounts that this correspondent had read or heard prepared him for the discovery that the heart of Florence is gone.

Chevy Chase, Inc., manufacturers of toiletries and cosmetics, to RayHirsch Company. Trade publications, direct mail and dealer help material. Leading fashion, women's and motion picture magazines will be included in 1945.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 31 (AP) A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique

ROME, Aug. 31 (U.P.) -- On a line running nearly 16 miles inland from the Adriatic to Monte Calvo on the Foglia River, Eighth Army units, including Polish, British, Indian and Italian formations, steadily moved northward to make contact with the enemy in Gothic Line fortifications the Germans have claimed to be "impregnable."

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Ranging from the Equator to the Bering Sea, American Army and Navy fliers during the first three days of this week continued small raids to harass the Japanese around their empire perimeter.

Holdings of Government securities by banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $259,813,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, thereby hitting a new high record, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Holdings of Treasury bills rose $276,413,000, giving the banks of the system $10,121,000,000 of the $15,600,000,000 outstanding, but New York City banks did not participate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Appearing before the same House Campaign Funds Investigating Committee which on Monday heard Sidney Hillman defend the activities of the Congress of Industrial Organizations Political Action Committee, Robert M. Gaylord, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said today that the NAM was "not political," did not support or contribute to the election of candidates and would not, even if the Corrupt Practices Act permitted it.

Men's and boys' clothing manufacturers are determined to fight the trend among smaller retailers seeking to place orders without binding signatures, Harry A. Cobrin, secretary of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the United States of America, declared yesterday.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 31 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, supreme commander of the Allied expeditionary forces in France, forecast the invasion of Germany today when he declared that the American and British armies in France must follow the Germans into the Reich to defeat them decisively and completely.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 31 -- Joan Bennett, who has the second leading feminine role in Twentieth Century-Fox's "Nob Hill," will be retained by the studio for the romantic lead in the Monty Woolley-Gracie Fields musical, "Waltz Me Around Again Willie" William Eythe has been scheduled for the second spot in Fox's "Colonel Effingham's Raid," which he will do after his appearance in "Czarina," the Tallulah Bankhead picture.

LINDEN, N.J., Aug. 31 -- As a result of an ordered cutback in production of Wildcat fighter planes for the Navy, Harold Lowe, president of Local 595, United Automobile, Aircraft and Agricultural Implement Workers of America, CIO, announced today that he had requested the aid of Federal and State officials to avert a threatened "disastrous upheaval" in employment at the Eastern Aircraft Division plant of General Motors here.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 31 -Miss Margaret Nichols of the Hudson River Country Club, women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association duration champion, won the group's one-day tournament with a round of 44, 39 -- 83 at the Siwanoy Country Club today.

ROUEN, France, Aug. 30 (Delayed) -- This medieval city of churches, with memories of war before the birth of Christ, has suffered again, and its ancient Cathedral of Notre Dame, the walls of which once stopped arrows from crossbows, has now felt the blasts of high explosives rained from the air.

The Monarch, or Milkweed butterfly, seen in great numbers this week in New Jersey, is a stout-hearted fellow who fits the tempo of the century. Not only is he the strongest flier and most famous traveler of the Lepidoptera, but he subscribes to the modern flair for bright colors in all phases of life.

Determined to push their pennant prospects to the limit, the Yankees more than made hay while the sun shone at the Stadium yesterday. To the cheers of 17,893 they took two games from the Senators and advanced to within two games of the Browns, when the league leaders lost last night.

The war in Europe entered its sixth year today with the German Army in retreat to the national frontiers it crossed so confidently in 1939 to overrun Poland as a preliminary to an attempt at the conquest of all Europe.

When Mike Todd has important news to impart he gets on the phone himself and effervesces. It was his pleasure yesterday to confirm the signing of Jeanette MacDonald for two seasons to appear in his forthcoming operetta, untitled at present, containing an original score by the late Victor Herbert.
BUCHAREST, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Russian Army entered Bucharest from the east and northeast today and moved through to the west, the direction of the Bulgarian frontier.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A large delegation of Negro ministers stood in silent prayer today at a Senate subcommittee meeting for consideration of a bill to establish a permanent Fair Employment Practices Commission.

There was much to challenge the eye in the custom-made collection that Jay Thorpe presented for review yesterday morning. A return to grande dame fashions was notable. This was evident in daytime and evening costumes. (It is interesting to observe that New York is taking its formal evening wear seriously for the first time since our entry into the war.)

The stock market remained yesterday in its confined area with an irregular drift throughout the session. There were scattered bids for stocks in the conversion category, but moderate heaviness weighed on the industrial division. The market thus closed August with prices little altered in the month and about between the highs and lows.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Aug. 31 (U.P.) -- The Allied command announced today that British Fourteenth Army troops pushing south into the monsoon-swept Chin hills of western Burma, had scored new gains on the road to the enemy base of Tiddim.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Aug. 31 -- The American parade in Paris was more a matter of necessity than ceremony, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower explained to American and British correspondents here today.

GRENOBLE, France, Aug. 31 -The attack in a coordinated fashion, made against our troops at Briancon, near the Italian border, which caused a temporary falling back, may be the last organized resistance in this area, as daily German vehicles, moving here and there in a frantic effort to nose out some means of escape, become short of fuel and their crews and following units of infantrymen approach a point of exhaustion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Combining to insure that a policy of "regulated competition" governs the granting of post-war permits for international air routes by this country, seventeen American airlines today announced appointment of Alexander B. Royce, a New York lawyer, as permanent chairman of an airlines committee for United States air policy.
ROME, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A communique:

Your editorial of Aug. 20 "To Make Democracy Strong" appears to accept the totally unproved theory, which has gained some credence in this country, that proportional representation was at least partly responsible for Mussolini and Hitler and tends in general to a multiplication of parties and a parliamentary ineptitude which paves the way for popular disgust and dictatorship.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 31 -- Dismantling of United States war agencies in Brazil is already beginning.

ROME, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Polish troops in two days of fierce fighting with infantry and tanks have stormed and captured the German Adriatic stronghold of Pesaro, an outpost of the Gothic Line, and with British help have forced crossings of the Foglia River along a 16-mile front inland from the sea, Allied Headquarters announced today.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Saturday, Sept. 2 (AP) -- A communique:

H.F. HEARD, whose scholarly, ascetic, bearded face would easily qualify him for a role in the movies as a prophet or a mad scientist bent on transferring the souls of apes to men and vice versa, is an English writer now living in California. He is the author of several superior and originally horrible detective stories, and under another signature, that of Gerald Heard, he is the author of several works of philosophic speculation.

The census is an important and useful institution, but one hopes some day it will add one more item to its agenda. How many little wooden plank bridges are there in the United States, spanning creeks and brooks? And beside how many of them is there a passage for team and wagon which can be used in summer when the water is low?

BY his very nature a horseman -- or even a horse player -- has to be an incurable optimist. Unless hope was forever welling within him he never could withstand the disappointments and the heartaches which are infinitely more numerous than the dreams which sometimes come true.

Supreme Court Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan reserved decision yesterday on a motion by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan to transfer the extortion trial of Joseph S. Fay and James Bove, labor leaders, from Supreme Court back to the Court of General Sessions.

PARIS, Sept. 1 -- The round-up of collaborationists and those suspected of having been too friendly with the Germans continued today. Already there are some 3,000 or 4,000 suspects interned in the Velodrome d'Hiver, a bicycle-racing arena. They all are awaiting trial.

Some of the big ones have not got away this season. Word came yesterday that three exceptional fish, one of world-record proportions, no less, had found their way into fishing contests, where they probably will bring prizes and certainly a modicum of fame to their captors.
GRENOBLE, France, Aug. 30 (Delayed) -- At the present moment these liberated parts of France appeared to have been given over to expressions of joy.

The last of the three Saturday closings of the New York Stock Exchange and other leading securities markets in the United States and Canada will be in force today. Next week, however also will witness a short week in financial circles, since the major security and commodity markets in the two countries will be closed on Monday in observance of Labor Day.

Gen. Sir Bernard Law Montgomery's promotion to the highest rank in the British Army has been so amply and nobly earned that it will be welcomed and applauded by the armed forces and the civilians of all the United Nations. To the people of his own country he is an idol, though nobody can be more remote from the conventional "dashing" warrior.

Persons with a historic bent may be reminded today of Horace Walpole's famous comment on the England of the elder Pitt in 1759: "It was necessary to ask every morning what new victory there was, for fear of missing one." In France alone, one sector of a worldwide front, dramatic detail follows dramatic detail with dreamlike swiftness.

Charles Margolis, specialist for the Foreign Economic Administration, who in January, 1943, took charge of a mission to purchase cinchona bark-in Colombia, was arrested yesterday and held in bail of $3,000 on a Federal charge of having solicited a bribe.
The text of the message broadcast by Pope Pius XII, as reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Emphasis placed on the need to obtain additional cotton textile workers by the War Manpower Commission will prove a vital factor in increasing production in the last quarter, Worth Street commission men familiar with the situation stated yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 1 -- The Bagrianoff Government of Bulgaria fell today just as its emissaries in Cairo had begun to discuss an armistice with the Allied powers, and for the moment the situation remains exceedingly confused, with the surrender talks temporarily broken off and reports of rioting in Bulgaria itself leading some observers to believe that a revolution, possibly of an agrarian nature, may break out.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- On the threshold of his eighty-fourth birthday Gen. John J. Pershing is in France again in heart and spirit, if he cannot be in body.
Pavot is among eleven juveniles in the $50,000 Hopeful Stakes today at Belmont Park, where the long Saratoga Association meeting will end with an attendance expected to reach 35,000.

In one of the busiest weeks of the year, railroad financing for the second successive week featured flotations of new securities here this week. Five new issues of bonds aggregating $65,222,000 were offered publicly, of which $47,000,000 represented a railroad loan, $12,000,000 a public utility issue and $6,222,000 three tax-exempt issues.

Three more Republican Governors, in the second of a series of broadcasts for the Republican national ticket, stressed last night support of President Roosevelt by Sidney Hillman's Congress of Industrial Organizations Political Action Committee and its alleged alliance with Communists as a prime reason for defeating the President for re-election and electing Governors Thomas E. Dewey and John W. Bricker, Republican nominees for President and Vice President.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- Election of the Dewey-Bricker ticket and a Republican House of Representatives was pictured as certain today by Herbert Brownell Jr., National Chairman, after a six-hour session of the party's national executive committee which reported to him on the most extensive surveys to date.

Continuing the expansion in volume noted with the arrival of cooler weather, retail trade here last week was active. Gains of department stores, it was estimated, ran 15 per cent or more ahead of the like week last year. Back-to-school merchandise was in particularly strong request.

Topics of The Times of Aug. 27 is skeptical as to prospects of hastening German collapse by propaganda. In the last war the Fourteen Points "were accepted by the Germans after they were beaten in the field. When the German generals knew that the war was lost they told the German political heads to get busy; whereupon the Kaiser's Ministers became suddenly aware of the Fourteen Points."

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- With astonishing frankness the German staff of the Brussels radio admitted in a series of messages to the Belgian people tonight that the capital was on the eve of liberation and promised that it would not be pillaged.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the nomination of Harold Maurice Kennedy of New York to be United States district judge for the Eastern District of New York. He will succeeed the late Judge Marcus B. Campbell.

After two days of comparative lull, the tempo of the competition in the national tennis championships accelerated alarmingly at Forest Hills yesterday, with the favorites challenged dangerously throughout the afternoon.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The names of six correspondents suspended for reported violation of censorship regulations in Paris were made public tonight by Supreme Headquarters, which said that investigation of their cases was continuing.
LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The stock markets finished the week quietly today. Gilt-edged stocks were dull and foreign bonds were irregular.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Housewives will save about $15,000,000 a year in the prices they pay for butter as a result of a campaign started last June to eliminate illegal "upgrading," the Office of Price Administration reported today.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 1 -- How Wendell L. Willkie came to leave the Democratic party is told in a "column" he wrote for John Temple Graves of The Birmingham Age-Herald, which will print it tomorrow.

FLORENCE, Sept. 1 -- One of the weirdest, saddest battles of the war continues to be fought in Florence. It will be remembered that the city which is -- or was, for it will never be the same again -- the flower of the Renaissance lies in the valley of the Arno in an amphitheatre of terraced hills, embroidered with gardens and sunburnt villas.

A high police official verified yesterday a report that orders had been issued by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine and Chief Inspector John J. O'Connell requiring each of the city's 1,500 detectives of all ranks, including the assistant chief inspector in charge of the bureau, to keep a uniform and a complete set of equipment in the station house of the detective district to which he is assigned.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 1 -- Shirley Temple will be starred in the picture version of the F. Hugh Herbert play "Kiss and Tell." David O. Selznick will lend her for the part to an autonomous company producing the film at Columbia, and including Mr. Herbert, George Abbott, who produced the stage play, and Sol Siegel, representing the studio-distributing company.

Their names are: Masaki Fujikawa, Shinei Nakamine, Denis Masato Hashimoto, Grover Kazutomi Nagaji, Kenji Kato, Tsugiyasu Toma, all killed in action against their country's enemy. Irving M. Akahosi was cited for his conduct during "a daring mission" at Anzio.

ALBANY, Sept. 1 (AP) -- A license issued by the State Harness Racing Commission to a single association may be construed as covering a single meeting even though the dates assigned to the meeting are not consecutive, Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein ruled today.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The spark Hitler struck five years ago when he drove his legions into Poland was consuming the German leader in its fire today -- an anniversary marked less by the words and ceremonies of the Allies than by the deeds of their armies.

With the theatrical season gathering its traditional Labor Day momentum, two new plays will make their premieres next week. On Tuesday night, the Barrymore will be lighted by "East Stop," a melodrama by Irving Kaye Davis, with Minnie Dupree, Catherine Doucet, Seth Arnold, Eda Heinemann and Enid Markey in the cast.
ROME, Sept. 1 -- German troops of the Nineteenth Army were fleeing north and northeast from Lyon on all roads today as French and American forces pushed up both sides of the Rhone River.

In respect to the Labor Day picnic, which is a tradition in many households, the New York State Emergency Food Commission offers counsel that should expedite the preparation and make the meal attractive and delicious.

John B. Turk, 33 years old, who was suspended from the chairmanship of the Downtown Rationing Board in Manhattan and later pleaded guilty to charges of having conspired to defraud the Government of his own impartial services, received a prison term of a year and a day yesterday from Federal Judge Shackelford Miller Jr.
The report of the Diamond Match Company covering operations for the six months ended on June 30 yesterday disclosed a net profit of $1,053,449 after all charges including taxes of 2,199,245.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Babe Dahlgren's two-run double, followed by Frankie Gustine's single, gave Pittsburgh a 3-to-2 victory over the Cardinals before 17,030 in a series opener tonight. Fritz Ostermueller scattered eleven hits to pitch his twelfth victory.

PARIS, Sept. 1 -- An American woman shopping in Paris today would find nothing but disappointment wherever she went, for behind the tempting-looking window displays the shops are practically empty, coupons are required and prices for what little is on sale are fantastic.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- J.A. Krug, acting chairman of the WPB, appealed to his staff of vice chairmen and rectors of bureaus and divisions today to "stay on the job" of completing the work of WPB, which, he added, was "not necessarily a long job."

CINCINNATI, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Cubs thwarted Bucky Waiters' attempt to gain his twentieth victory tonight, beating the right-hander and the Reds, 3 to 2. Paul Erickson, who took over in the fourth after starting pitcher Bill Fleming had been removed for a pinch-hitter, was credited with the victory which enabled Chicago to wrest fourth place from the Giants.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Soviet Government has not only agreed to permit a Japanese vessel to pick up American relief supplies at a Soviet Pacific port but has agreed "generally to meet" certain conditions imposed by the Japanese, the State Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept 1 -- Gen. George C. Marshall has told Army planners that the post-war American Army must consist of the smallest possible professional organization, with citizen-reserves, because the large standing army had "no place among the institutions of a modern democratic State."

Too ludicrous for words was the baseball exhibition between the Yankees and Senators at the Stadium yesterday. The Senators, guilty of less floundering than the pennant-contending home team, finished on top, 10 -- 7, after more than two-and-a-half hours of up-again-down-again diamond warfare in which the silliest things happened.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Office of Price Administration moved to halt a slump in the production of essential work gloves today by authorizing increases in both manufacturers' and wholesalers' ceiling prices.

At least three projects are under way or in preparation to provide air commuter service in the metropolitan area. Though Pickair Seaplane Service of Ossining had announced the start of a seaplane service for commuters as far as Poughkeepsie this week-end, it was said at the company's offices yesterday that actual service had been delayed and that activities were being confined to test hops and construction of ramps and other terminal facilities.

ROME, Sept. 1 -- The battered German Nineteenth Army, ordered to get out of southern France as best it can, was reported evacuating Lyon tonight as four American and French armored columns pushed northward on a sixty-five-mile front, one reaching to within forty miles of Lyon.

VERDUN, France, Aug. 31 (Delayed) -- Over the same white clay through which their fathers fought in 1918. American troops moved today into historic Verdun, encountering none of the fierce fighting the Germans displayed in World War I.

Evidently the Association for Longevity of Small Mouth Bass held a convention at the bottom of Lake George following your editorial on bass fishing of Aug. 29 to discuss ways and means of combating the vicious propaganda directed against their well-being in your paper.
LONDON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Some 750 flying Fortresses and Liberators roaring up from Italy attacked German supply or escape arteries in Hungary and Yugoslavia today.
PARIS, Sept. 1 -- The august Academie Francaise, seat of French culture in which membership is regarded as the highest distinction for writers, artists and scientists, held its own purge yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept, 1 (AP) -- Joe Haynes, White Sex right-hander, singled with two out and the bases filled in the twelfth inning tonight to beat Al Smith, Cleveland southpaw who went the route against him, 5 to 4, before 10,025. A poor throw and wild pitch by Smith figured in the winning run after he had weathered six other errors by the Indians.

NASHVILLE, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Byron Nelson's putting stick chilled on him today on the eve of the $10,000 Nashville Invitational Golf Tournament. Odds-on favorite in the 72hole event, opening tomorrow for a three-day run, he cruised around the Richland Club course in a lackadaisical par 71, while his contemporaries were seizing honors in the preliminary pro-amateur competition.

ROME, Sept. 1 -- Eighth Army forces have smashed their way into the Gothic Line beyond the Foglia River in the Adriatic sector and at one point near Montecchio penetrated German defenses to a depth of 1,000 yards. At two other points wedges were driven into that last great defensive system south of the Po Valley, where many a war has been fought to its finish.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- Liquidation developed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade after a showing of firmness early. All deliveries of oats, July wheat and rye and December and May barley sold at new seasonal low prices, with the close about the bottom.

ROME, Sept. 1 (AP) -- British troops attacked hard behind a rolling aerial barrage laid down by waves of fighter-bombers to penetrate the Germans' Gothic Line defenses at three points near the Adriatic coast, Allied headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull said in reply to a question at his news conference today that he could recall no offers by the Germans to surrender to the Allies within the last two weeks.

Holiday-happy crowds, ignoring the appeal of the Office of Defense Transportation to keep the available space on trains and intercity buses clear for members of the armed forces and war-essential travelers, streamed from the city yesterday for the Labor Day weekend.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- A powerful combination of Russian diplomacy and Russian military victories won a new success in the Balkans tonight when the Bulgarian Government headed by Ivan Bagrianoff resigned and Bulgarian armistice talks in Cairo were suddenly suspended.

The war surplus disposal bills passed by both houses of Congress provide for the use of the proceeds from such sales to reduce the national debt. The Treasury is opposed to this provision on the ground that it "could not and would not accomplish its apparent objective, i.e., to reduce the public debt below what it would be in the absence of its enactment."

GUAM, Aug. 15 (Delayed) -- Retreating Japanese forces beheaded at least fifty-one native Chamorros -- all members of a forced labor battalion and some of them former members of the United States Navy -- in one of the most bestial episodes of the Pacific war, it was established officially today as Navy authorities sought to determine the fate of 2,000 to 3,000 other missing natives.
Hugues Le Gallais, the Minister from Luxembourg, and Mrs. Le Gallais have arrived from Washington and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 - Secretary Hull said in an address of welcome to Dr. Ramon Grau San Martin, President-elect of Cuba, who is here on an official vist, that the paramount post-war problem was "the establishment of regimes that will work toward general public welfare." He said this was the "ultimate objective of national and international action."

WITH UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY IN FRANCE, Sept. 1 -- The Germans retreating into Belgium are leaving a trail of burning granaries behind them. Today I counted a dozen blazing barns in a half-hour jeep ride back from the front line. Their French owners told me that Germans on motorcycles had thrown hand grenades into them just before they had fled from our advancing forces.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 1 -- A jet propulsion aircraft engine, a method of storing dried blood for group testing prior to transfusion and an advancement in hormone chemistry are among the 553 inventions listed in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

Natacha Rambova, widow of Rudolph Valentino, is the co-author, with James H. Smith, of a book called "Technique for Living," which Duell, Sloan Pearce will publish next Friday. The book describes ways to relax and to get rid of "war nerves."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Braves swept both ends of a double-header tonight, 3 -- 2 in ten innings and 7 -- 4. The Phils took a 2-0 lead in seven frames of the twilight opener, but Boston tied it at 2 -- 2 in the eighth before a downpour delayed play for forty-seven minutes.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, Sept. 2 (U.P.) -- Liberator bombers of the Far Eastern Air Force battered the Japanese airdrome at Cape Chater, on Timor Island, with forty-five tons of explosives Thursday, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.
LONDON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- In the Vah Valley runs the important railroad from Bratislava to Zilina and two smaller lines to northern and southern Moravia.

The GI Bill of Rights provides in part that "Men who were under 25 years old when they entered the service are deemed, under the law, to have had their education interrupted. Men who were over 25 must offer proof that education was interrupted. The total period of education is limited to four years.

FLORENCE, Italy, Sept. 1 -- Politically, Florence is already shaping up along more drastic radical lines than Rome or the south of Italy, Ihave found after a two-day visit to this city which still is living in a sort of No Man's Land between two conflicting foreign armies.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 -- In one of the stormiest parliamentary sessions held in recent times, Herminio Ahumada, President of the Chamber of Deputies, today was removed from his post because of the tenor of his replies to the annual report that President Manuel Avila Camacho made to the nation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The delegates at the Washington conversations on international organization have under consideration a proposal to create a "United Nations Commission for Europe," which would "direct and coordinate" the various Allied armistice and relief commissions soon to be operating on the continent, it was learned today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Chungking in English to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The Germans subjected the Dover area of southeast England -- the "hell's corner" that has been under siege of Nazi guns on the French coast since 1940 -- to one of its worst bombardments of the war early today. They hurled about 100 shells into the little coastal towns, causing extensive damage and casualties.

Disinclined to maintain a long position over the week-end holiday, traders sold cotton futures yesterday in sufficient volume on the New York Cotton Exchange to bring about a net decline of 13 to 19 points on active months.

LONDON, Saturday, Sept. 2 -- Russian troops, advancing thirty-five miles south from liberated Bucharest, yesterday reached the border of Bulgaria and captured the Rumanian Danube River oil port of Giurgiu.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Minneapolis, St. Paul and Sault Ste. Marie Railway, known as the Soo Line, today officially ended seven and a half years of bankruptcy with a newly formed corporation taking over the road.

There has been an easing in the bristle supply situation recently, according to brush manufacturers, due to the continuing policy of the Government in releasing merchandise to the trade from the Defense Supplies Corporation's stockpile. It is pointed out, however, that all requirements are not being met, even though the supply position is in much better shape than was the case a few months ago.

Spokesmen for the American Labor Party and several Congress of Industrial Organizations unions issued Labor Day statements yesterday expressing organized labor's thanks to the members of the armed forces and calling for the re-election of President Roosevelt as the best means of insuring a lasting peace.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 19.5 per cent during August, climbing to a new high record for the month despite the extreme heat during most of the period, according to a monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

New York fashions, having stood firmly on their own feet for the last four years, will not lose out when Paris creators resume their showings, it was predicted yesterday by representatives of various branches of this city's largest industry.

UNITED STATES FIFTEENTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, Italy, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Fleets of Flying Fortresses have made a spectacular mass evacuation to Italy of 1,126 American and British airmen who had been shot down and interned in Rumania during the last year.

ROME, Sept. 1 -- On the fifth anniversary of the beginning of the war, Pope Pius XII, with his eyes on the coming peace and the future social order, made an earnest defense of the right of private property in a speech broadcast this evening.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Selective Service reported to Congress today that the armed forces, estimated at an over-all 11,417,000, could be kept at full strength without changing current draft policies, barring military reverses.

The Very Rev. Frederick W. Beekman, for the last twenty-six years dean of Holy Trinity American Episcopal Cathedral in Paris, will return to France to reopen his cathedral by the first plane of ocean liner on which he can get passage as soon as the application he has filed with the authorities in Washington is approved.

Monday being Labor Day, tomorrow will be observed in the city's churches as "Labor Sunday," with many sermons on post-war labor problems. Members of the Association of Catholic Trade Unionists will attend a mass at 12:15 P.M. on Monday in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

There is one odd circumstance about nearly all the books and magazine articles and speeches and pictures and plays dealing with Woodrow Wilson. Men today have radically modified their views about the Versailles Treaty, but they continue to fall into old habits of speech when they speak of the men who made the treaty.

America's farmers have accomplished what many people believed to be impossible. For three successive years they have fought for high food production goals. Each year they have made a new record despite manpower shortages, machinery lacks and weather troubles.

The 2,200-ton superdestroyer Pierce, named after the late Lieut. Commdr. John Reeves Pierce who was lost with the submarine Argonaut early in the Pacific war, was launched yesterday evening at a ceremony at the Bethlehem Staten Island yard.

The Catholic War Veterans added their protest yesterday to those of the Knights of Columbus and other Catholic organizations against the proposed plan to have business concerns support a national advertising campaign which, its sponsors say, might "stamp out venereal disease" through spotlighting the subject with widespread publicity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Transfer of war work from plants that may readily be reconverted to civilian production to such specialpurpose plants as Willow Run, will be encouraged by the War Production Board wherever such a transfer does not impede war production, officials said today.

The Forty-eighth Street Cinema, formerly an exclusive showcase for Swedish films, will be reopened today, offering a revival bill composed of "The Private Life of Henry VIII" and "Catherine the Great." Today and Monday, when the Sue Hastings Marionette Show will give matinee performances for children, the film program will not begin until 5 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -The Presidential campaign, thrust into the background in the House while the members worked on post-war bills, burst into prominence today as soon as the legislative tasks had been given their first going-over.

Gertrude Stein, the author, has been found safe at her chateau in the mountains of southeastern France, a Columbia Broadcasting System correspondent, Eric Sevareid, reported from France last night. He said she had just finished a new book.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Bernard M. Baruch, Presidential adviser and co-author of Administration blue-prints for industrial reconversion, indicated today that he viewed the George bill, as whittled down by the Ways and Means Committee and passed by the House yesterday, as "certainly inadequate."

LONDON, Sept. 1 (UP) -- Belgian patriots, active in sabotaging German communications since the Allied drive began nearing Belgian frontiers, have blown up the big strategically placed Yvoir-Cinay tunnel, ten miles south of Namur, and bottled up northbound German railway transport, it was learned today.

CLEVELAND, Sept. I (UP) -- The strike committee of the Mechanics Educational Society of America threatened today to close down all MESA plants in Detroit, Toledo and Cleveland to enforce demands at the strike-paralyzed Cleveland Graphite Bronze Company.

Faced with a three-day closing produced by the final Saturday shut-down of the Stock Exchange and the observance on Monday of Labor Day, the stock market carried over yesterday its hesitancy of late August into the new month. There was some bidding again on the Stock Exchange in the issues of companies rated in the quick conversion division, and this alone permitted an irregularly higher closing.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Newark Bears climbed to within a half game of the Baltimore Orioles tonight by trouncing the league-leaders, 14 to 3, behind a savage sixteen-hit attack and five-hit pitching by Frank Hiller.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- A majority decision by the National War Labor Board, refusing to scale down the amount of retroactive payments as directed by a regional board, was announced today, along with an attack on the ruling by the industry members in a dissenting opinion which declared that to grant the union members in the case full retroactive payment was "tantamount to tacit approval of the sympathy strike and subsequent slow-down."

Public officials proclaimed yesterday Poland's right to freedom as a result of her five-year struggle against Germany and declared that her future status as a nation will be a test of the treatment of small nations at the peace conference.
BOSTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Red Sox beat the Athletics, 4 to 3, today as Joe Bowman chalked up his eleventh victory.

Stating that he was writing on behalf of pottery manufacturers of the United States, J.G. Kaufmann, publisher of China and Glass, yesterday made public a letter of protest to Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, against the advertisement advocating the use of chipped teacups by American housewives as a patriotic act.

City Treasurer Almerindo Portfolio sold at public auction yesterday the liquor stock of La Vie Parisienne, 3 East Fifty-second Street, a night club against which the city pressed a claim for $13,461 in unpaid sales taxes and penalties. The sale took place at the building of the Manhattan Storage and Warehouse Company, Eightieth Street and Third Avenue.

CHUNGKING, Sept. 1 (U.P.) -Seven Japanese divisions, smashing forward on an eighty-mile front, have launched a huge offensive toward the big Kwangsi Province base of Kweilin and severe fighting is raging far to the west and southwest of Hengyang, where the drive started, it was reported today.

The hunt for cotton goods in almost every category continues, and this merchandise remains on a strict (and small) allotment basis. the report pointed out.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 2 (U.P.) -- The Brazilian Aviation Ministry announced today that Pan American Airways' special license to carry passengers and air cargo between points inside Brazil would be terminated as of Jan. 1, 1945. Pan American has been operating in Brazil since 1934.

Adult education has always been the Cinderella -- a time-expired Cinderella -of the learned pedagogues and a misguided public. There are hundreds of millions in public money for kindergarten, primary and secondary schools, for colleges and universities. There are besides enormous endowments from private sources, concentrated particularly on the college and the university.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -President Roosevelt said tonight that "a tower of strength" has fallen with the death of former Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 2 -After a trip through twelve far Western and Mountain States, Miss Marion Martin, assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee, said today that the Pacific Coast would be in the Dewey-Bricker column by Election Day and that independent voters of the country would insure the success of the Republican ticket.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 2 -Russell Hudson's Pick Up broke Miss Brookdale's string of five successive victories tonight by beating J.B. White's 6-year-old mare in the Imperial, a mile pace feature on the Grand Circuit program at Roosevelt Raceway.

Palma of Richmond declared yesterday at St. George that the State Public Service Commission was "high-handed" in ordering a hearing on Sept. 22 to receive amended plans for the Grant City-Oakwood Heights grade-crossing elimination of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railroad and at the same time refusing to divulge the plans to his engineers.

Donald McNeill of the Norfolk Naval Air Station yesterday, and for the second time in his career, Parker gained the final round of the national championship.

AN idea that occurs to everyone sooner or later is that it might be possible to create a whole new hedge by taking cuttings from one favorite shrub. This is an easy thing to do with most shrubs, and if started now the cuttings will be ready to set in place next spring.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS in the Southwest Pacific, Sept. 2 -When Gen. Douglas MacArthur's men go ashore in future operations in the drive toward the Philippines and the China coast they will be backed by a fleet of floating hospitals, ships that can be pushed up on a beach no more than forty-five minutes behind the first wave of assault troops.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Sidney Hillman's appearance before the House committee investigating campaign expenditures raised some questions which will probably be discussed again and again before the Presidential campaign ends.

NASHVILLE, Sept. 2 -- Byron Nelson, nerveless tee titan of Toledo, fashioned a seven-under-par 64 at Richland today to take the first round lead in the $10,000 Nashville invitation golf tournament.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in the Southwest Pacific, Sunday Sept. 3 -- In the greatest raid on the Philippines since the war began, formations of Liberators smashed three airfields at Davao, Mindanao's principal port, destroying thirty-seven planes on the ground and one in the air.

Five years ago today -- Sunday, Sept. 3, 1939 -- the storm of war broke over Europe, ending the uneasy peace that had persisted since the guns were silenced by the armistice singed in the forest of Compiegne on a November day in 1918.

RICHMOND, Sept. 2 -- A sensation has been caused by a series of pronouncements from leaders of the Byrd political organization in favor of repeal by the Virginia Legislature and people of the poll tax. Representatives Clifton Woodrum of Roanoke, and Dave Satterfield of Richmond, have just advocated this step, which was urged last week by T. McCall Frazier, another Byrd spokesman.

ROME, Sept. 2 (AP) -- United States Fifteenth Air Force Liberators hammered rail communications and fighters strafed Nazi transport jamming the highways in Yugoslavia today as the German armies apparently began a mass flight out of the Balkans.
PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 2 (AP) -Aerial blows against Japanese island strongholds over a wide Pacific front were reported in an American Fleet Headquarters press release today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -Representatives of five political parties and the Army, meeting in New York today, reached a "general agreement" for the rebroadcasting of political speeches to troops overseas, the War Department said.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The bizarre story of Tyler Kent, young diplomatic code clerk at the United States Embassy in London who, Scotland Yard discovered, passed large quantities of secret documents to the Germans through the medium of the daughter of a Russian Czarist Admiral, was placed on the record today by the Department of State.

The War Food Administration is beginning a study of the war food stock piles and the future food requirements of England and Russia, it was learned yesterday. The departure for those two countries of Lieut. Col. Ralph W. Olmstead, deputy director of the office of distribution, WFA, to shape food policy was hailed in food trade circles as "an intelligent approach" to the problem of disposing of food surpluses and organizing a food production program.

With buying of back-to-school merchandise an outstanding feature, retail trade here was active last week. Percentage gains were said to be somewhat smaller than in the previous week, but nevertheless the average increase for department stores was estimated at 15 per cent or more over the like week last year.

PARIS, Sept. 1 (Delayed) -Three landmarks known to almost every American who has visited Paris since World War I were not used by the Germans in their four years of occupation and were unscathed in the fighting and bombing that preceded the expulsion of the Germans from the city.

A ONE-MAN show of sketches by Phil May currently provides a special attraction at the Bal Tabarin in West Forty-sixth Street. While the available wall space is rather scant, it suffices, since these sketches -- which the artist calls "pen-pressions" -are often of thumbnail dimension.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 2 -- The War Labor Board is without authority to suspend a State law, the Jefferson County Court of Misdemeanors ruled today, declaring that a worker was not obliged to belong to a union against his will. This is provided for in Alabama's labor code under the Bradford Act.

THE problem of the service man's wife, and what she can do with those empty hours on which she is so heavily overstocked, is solved in a thorough if somewhat specialized way in "The Gals They Left Behind." Just inherit a ramshackie Maine farm, the message runs, and live in it the year round.
PARIS, Aug. 31 (Delayed) -Parisians have been too busy celebrating their liberation and welcoming their American liberators to do much serious political thinking these past few days.

ALBANY, Sept. 2 -- Temporary employes promoted in the New York State Civil Service in the present war emergency are legally entitled to the same salaries as those applying to permanent promotions, Attorney General Goldstein decided today.
SELOIGNES, Belgium, Sept. 2 -- Laughing, cheering and weeping Belgians decked American tanks, trucks and jeeps with garlands of flowers as they entered Belgium today.

DURING the current season of the Mexican Symphony Orchestra, which comes to a close on Sunday, Sept. 17, Carlos Chavez, founder and conductor of the orchestra, has achieved a long-standing ambition in presenting for the first time this summer in Mexico City the complete cycle of the nine symphonies of Beethoven.
