Dr. Ernest M. Hopkins, president of Dartmouth, yesterday accepted the chairmanship of the board of Americans United for World Organization. His acceptance was immediately endorsed by Wendell L. Willkie and Mrs. J. Bordan Harriman, and a list of vice chairmen was made public covering most sections of the United States representative of many diverse shades of political opinion and economic activity.

Pan American Airways announced yesterday that three of its crews had made world records for over-water flight during July. Capt. Olas S. Abrahamsen, on July 22, flew a Coronado of the Naval Air Transport Service from an unnamed base in the British Isles to La Guardia Field in seventeen hours, forty-five minutes flying time, bettering by twelve minutes the record made by American Export's Vought-Sikorsky clipper earlier in the month.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 2 -Completing twelve days of training at Camp Smith here Wednesday, units of the First Brigade, the Fifty-first, Sixty-ninth and Seventh Regiments of the State Guard, broke camp with the assurance of their commanding officers that the tour, marked by high morale and achievement, had been satisfactory.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Acting upon recommendations made by Col. Bradley Dewey, Rubber Director, whose resignation became effective yesterday, President Roosevelt formally abolished the Office of Rubber Director today and directed the transfer of most of its authority to the chairman of the War Production Board. J. A. Krug, acting WPB chairman, said later that a rubber bureau has been set up within WPB under direction of James F. Clark, an assistant to Colonel Dewey.

WITH THE AMERICAN FIRST ARMY, Sept. 2 -- American troops crossed into Belgium at 11:07 o'clock this morning. The first men actually to begin the liberation of another European country were in a reconnaissance group. They were closely followed by strong supporting forces.

The newly formed National Foundation for the Care of the Advanced Cancer Patients, Inc., a non-sectarian group, will open a campaign tomorrow to raise $1,800,000 to provide beds and care in established institutions at low cost for incurable cancer patients.
CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 2 -- Joe W. Brown's Brownie drove to an impressive two-length victory in the $10,000-added Princeton Handicap at Garden State Park today before 19,796 fans.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- General liquidation of grains was resumed today on the Board of Trade. Opening prices were off sharply, and the selling movement continued until near the close of the market when aggressive short covering in anticipation of events in the double holiday caused a strong rally. 1/2 to 2 1/2 cents. For a man of destiny he struck me as remarkably lacking in definite visual character. His points -- mustache and forelock -- were distinctly synthetic aids to notice, which, if removed, would leave an appearance hard to remember.

With the situation growing more acute daily due to increasing shortages, the needs of American hotels for furnishings and equipment have risen 25 per cent above what they were in February of this year, it is estimated by the American Hotel Association, representing 5,500 hotels throughout the country.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- A new Bulgarian Government designed to take the country out of the war was formed tonight under Constantin Muravieff, long a leader of the Peasant party, as Premier and Foreign Minister.

I cannot let such an attitude as the one on Germany expressed by James Warburg in THE TIMES Magazine go unchallenged. No doubt it was written in the interest of peace and tolerance. But underneath the guise of such "high thinking" selfish interests may walk.

JOHN SINGLETON MOSBY, Bristol, Virginia, lawyer, opposed to secession, enlisted in the Confederate Army as a private in the Washington Mounted Rifles and emerged at war's end a full colonel, "his name * * * a synonym in the South for brave deeds and daring escapades; a byword in the North for fear and hatred and chagrin."

With Dixie Walker leading the hit parade at Ebbets Field yesterday, the Dodgers continued their unkind treatment of the Giants, beating them for the second straight time, 8 -- 4, before a crowd of 12,441 and running their modest winning streak to four games.
VERDUN, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Waves of German heavy bombers, dive-bombers and fighters blasted and strafed Verdun for an hour last night, setting parts of the city aflame.
Before an astonishing crowd of 32,435, biggest of the season at Ebbets Field, the Giants and Dodgers wound up their season's business yesterday by splitting a double-header.
Heavy buying of housing properties on the East Side was indicated by deals reported over the week-end.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The league-leading Browns, faced with the prospect of toppling from the first-place perch they have held since May 31, snapped a four-game losing streak today and defeated the Tigers and the league's best pitcher, Dizzy Trout, 4 to 1.

ABERDEEN, Md., Sept. 3 -- Some of the secret weapons which have been dealing death and destruction to the enemy on all battlefronts or providing the means of moving equipment to our troops were exhibited today at the proving grounds here.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 -- Asserting that the election of Governor Dewey as President would rupture "national unity," the general executive board of the United Office and Professional Workers of America. CIO, urged tonight the re-election of President Roosevelt and the gathering of $50,000 from the members of the union for a campaign to be conducted in cooperation with the Political Action Committee of the CIO.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Recruiting of members of the Women's Army Corps for specific jobs and first assignments for duty at specific stations will be discontinued Nov. 1, the Army's Sixth Service Command announced today.

The eleventh performance on Saturday night marked the end of "Lower North" at the Belasco. The closing of the Martin Bidwell comedy-drama of Navy life was sadly announced yesterday by Max J. Jelin, lessee of the house and producer of the play.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Cubs won from the Reds today, 5 -- 1 and 6 -- 2, in their final appearance here. The opener was featured by a first-inning triple play by Chicago, while the second game was highlighted by Bill Nicholson's thirtieth home run -- one more than his last year's total.

There is no question that leisure is a good thing. It doesn't follow, however, that all so-called leisure-time activities are beneficial. As an example, consider the rather futile results of the physical education programs in many schools.

Seven, including Alex Barth, have been named for the $10,000 added Aqueduct Handicap, the feature today when the Queens County Jockey Club begins its fall meeting at the Aqueduct course. Eight races are scheduled, with a 1:15 post time for the first, and the proceeds will go to war charities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- A $3,375,250,000 road-construction program, one of a series of plans being fashioned in Congress to combat post-war unemployment, was put on the list by Administration leaders today for pre-recess action in the Senate.

The discovery by a Mayo Foundation pathological anatomist at the University of Minnesota that the keeping of a diary may have some practical use after all, is not exactly the sort of thing that is likely to turn the world upside down while it is busy watching France, but it may bear some reflection anyway.
The text of a statement issued by the Soviet Foreign Commissariat on Finland's request for peace, as broadcast by the Moscow radio last night and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 2 (Delayed) -- One subject that neither Propaganda Minister Goebbels nor Germany's leading military commentator, Lieut. Gen. Kurt Dittmar, talks about is the suspicion that Rumania's defection was achieved with the connivance of the Wehrmacht generals and abetted by the whole German Legation at Bucharest.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Cleveland's Indians backed Steve Gromek's four-hit pitching with timely hitting to earn a 4-to-1 victory over the White Sox today in a game marked by an altercation between Manager Jim Dykes of the Sox and his starting pitcher, Bill Dietrich.

Last week's stock market moved only fractionally and as a rule on light transactions. Monday's business was 554,300 shares, smallest since May 16, before invasion of northern France. Full compilation for August shows stock trading the smallest since May, but 45 5/8 per cent above August, 1943, and largest for the month since 1936.

Despite world-wide expectation of a speech by Adolf Hitler containing a sensational announcement, which was forecast on Saturday in German diplomatic circles in Portugal, radio listening posts here failed to pick up any broadcast by the Nazi leader or reference to one in Berlin news broadcasts.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Harvesting of the new corn crop is progressing in Texas and will get under way in Oklahoma in a week or so. Small amounts of new grain already are being fed to livestock in Iowa, Illinois, Missouri, Kansas and Nebraska in areas where there is a shortage of old grain.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- Belgium's hidden army came into the open today to help the Allied Expeditionary Forces sweep the Germans out of the Low Countries back onto the Reich after four years of occupation, and underground forces in the Netherlands received a stand-by order from Prince Bernhard, who was appointed their commander by Queen Wilhelmina.

The Trustees of Series C-2 have sold the six-story apartment building on a plot 150 by 100 feet at 3971 Gouverneur Avenue, in the Bronx, to a client of Julius S. Wikler, attorney. The property is assessed at $220,000 and was sold through I. Kenner, broker. Oscar Mann was the attorney for the sellers.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Jersey City and Syracuse divided a double-header today, the Little Giants winning the opener, 7 to 5, with the Chiefs coming back to win 4 -- 2, in eleven innings.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3 -- With cooler weather and major repairs completed at some plants, the steel ingot rate last week snapped back 2.5 points to 96.5 per cent of capacity. Indications are that the rate this week will be as high.

PARIS, Sept. 2 (Delayed) -- Not far from the Paris city hall lies a section of old Paris where there is a very special reason for thanksgiving tonight. It is that little quarter including the Third, Fourth and Fifth arrondissements where most of the capital's Jews reside.

WHEN Dorothy Adams first went to a dinner party in the home of her future in-laws in the ancient city of Cracow she found herself introduced to Polish ways at once. "What is your idea of God?" said a voice just at her side. "You are my partner for dinner. Will you take my arm?"

LONDON, Monday, Sept. 4 -- Russian troops, sweeping westward across Rumania for a junction with the Partisan armies of Marshal Tito, yesterday smashed to within 138 miles of Yugoslavia, while other Red Army forces climbed into the Transylvanian Alps to within thirty-six miles of the Rumanian city of Brasov.

The problem of returning displaced persons to their homelands will be one of the major questions to be discussed at the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Conference in Montreal on Sept. 15, said Dr. Karl Evang, Surgeon General of the Norwegian Government in Exile, who was among eight transatlantic passengers who arrived last night at La Guardia Field on a Pan American Airways clipper.

After a show of strength in initial dealings, prices of cotton turned easier last week and continued to weaken throughout the period. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed for the week net losses of 15 to 31 points, with the greatest recession in the distant July delivery.
BOSTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Athletics exploded with four runs in the fifth inning, including a disputed homer by Bill McGhee, to gain a 5-to-1 victory over the Red Sox today before 22,000.

The Canadian free dollar moved lower last week, selling down to 89.62 cents, on Wednesday, from an opening price on Monday around 90.06 cents. Amounts involved were small, dealers said, attributing the easier tone more to the lack of business than to any particular incident in the financial picture. There was a modest upturn at the week's close to 89.75 cents, a loss of 5/16 cent from the preceding week.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 3 (U.P.) -- Three of the four Japanese columns advancing south and west along the Hengyang-Kweilin railway in Hunan Province punched out new gains yesterday, while the Fourteenth American Air Force hammered their supply lines.

MONS, Belgium, Sept. 3 -- Mons has been pinched off by American armor and is ours, but all around this city heavy German forces that have been cut off by the tremendous American thrust are fighting furiously in efforts to break out to the east and continue their retreat.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Sept. 3 (U.P.) -- Indian troops, slogging their way through high water along the Myitkyina-Mandalay railway thirty miles southwest of Mogaung, have occupied the village of Kyagyigon, pushing to within three and one-half miles of the enemy base at Hopin, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's communique disclosed today.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- The stage is almost set for the final, three-sided air assault on Germany that will be the heaviest aerial operation in history. Possession of several score first-class airfields in France and Belgium will give the Allies the springboard needed to reach the heart of the Reich with every form of high explosive and fire contained in bomb or rocket.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 3 -- German troops in Finland will be withdrawn to Norway as soon as possible, the Berlin correspondent of the Stockholm Tidningen said in a dispatch today. The correspondent also said the reaction in Berlin was characterized more by disappointment than by rage.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- In all predictions at this early stage as to the election outcome in November, Democratic leaders in the Middle West reflect the conviction that a strong Republican trend is running in their territory and that local Democratic forces, with a few possible exceptions, appear powerless to counteract this with their own resources.

The Lohmeier Building at 332-40 Claremont Avenue, in Jersey City, N.J., now under lease to the Western Electric Company, has been bought by the Orient Realty Company of Hoboken for investment. J.I. Kislak arranged the sale for the West Side Building and Loan Association, in voluntary dissolution.
VERDUN, Sept. 3 (Delayed) -The center of Verdun was in ruins today after a German night bombing that brought back the scenes of 1916, when artillery almost annihilated this ancient fortress town.

ARRAS, France, Sept. 3 -- The dash of Lieut Gen. Miles C. Dempsey's British Second Army through Amiens, Arras and Vimy Ridge will produce some day a thousand sentimental essays. In two days these 1944 Britishers raced over battlefields that held and bled their warrior fathers for more than two years during World War I.

Foreseeing a "concerted assault on the American organized labor movement as soon as the war is over," Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, in a Labor Day statement yesterday called upon the warring factions of the trade union movement to unite to meet the "reactionary onslaught" if labor in the post-war world is not to become a "debased commodity."

LONDON, Sept. 3 (U.P.) -- About 500 American Flying Fortresses with strong fighter escort bombed the area of Ludwigshafen, German rail and chemical factory center in the upper Rhinelantl, today, as well-informed observers predicted the month would be the most devastating in air war history for Germany.

MOSCOW, Sept. 3 -- A sign that the Red Army's drive into Czechoslovakia cannot be far away was given today in a Moscow press conference held by representatives of the Czech Government in exile in London, who have arrived hero as members of the commission that will administer liberated Czech territory by agreement with the Soviet Government.

All signs point to an impending struggle on the plains of northern Italy as disastrous and conclusive for the Germans there as the Battle of France was for their countrymen now reeling back across the Fatherland frontier. After a six-week lull the Allied front before the Gothic Line has flamed once more into action, and General Alexander's forces are launching heavy assaults against both ends of that vaunted defense system.

LONDON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Russia blasted any dreams of bargaining for peace in the Balkans today by calling Bulgaria to account for aiding in the exodus of Germans and repeating accusations that Turkey was maintaining a double dealing neutrality.

An appeal to management and labor to "cooperate whole-heartedly in a vast program for worldwide peace and prosperity" was issued yesterday in a Labor Day message by the Federal Council of Churches. The message warned that any tendency toward a "narrow isolationism or economic imperialism" on the part of industrial leadership would constitute a "betrayal" of our fighting men and would contribute to another world war.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3 (AP) The coal mine supervisors' campaign for recognition of their newly-organized union, which has led to strikes closing sixteen Pennsylvania mines, is spreading this week into West Virginia, with strike votes scheduled at forty-four mines there.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES in Belgium, Sept. 2 (Delayed) -American troops swept from France into Belgium at widely separated points on the border today. This evening they had advanced miles into Belgium territory and were making rapid progress toward liberating the second German-occupied country on the Continent of Europe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The nation's pulpwood-supply situation is showing "encouraging" trends, but current receipts, while higher than those of a year ago, are still insufficient to meet present and anticipated requirements for military and essential civilian items, the Forest Products Bureau of the War Production Board reported today.

Government officials have reported that the end of the war in Europe would mean a 35 per cent cutback in war production. In the current issue of the Survey of Current Business, published by the Department of Commerce, S. Morris Livingston presents a series of estimates showing the effect upon our economy of a one-third reduction in the output of combat munitions.
LONDON, Sept. 3 -- With the capture or abandonment of hundreds of launching sites in France, flying bombs have stopped falling on England.

The spearpoint of any international effort to enforce peace should be an international air force, reported under consideration at the Dumbarton Oaks conference, according to a statement for the Commission to Study the Organization of Peace made yesterday by Clark M. Eichelberger, its director.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- These Labor Day messages were issued tonight by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Philip Murray president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations:

Snowsuits and leggings will be about three times more plentiful this year than last, unless manpower shortages prevent fulfillment of special production programs, manufacturers said yesterday.

ROME, Sept. 3 -- The Allies liberated all Lyon except isolated pockets of German rear guards today as an American spearhead swept thirty-six miles beyond that third largest city of France to a point within 144 miles of a junction with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's northern forces. Headquarters announced that the Germans had evacuated all southern France from the Lyon area to the Atlantic, 300 miles west, including the great port of Bordeaux.

In a Labor Day message broadcast yesterday in the Army Hour on the National Broadcasting Company network, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower. Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, expressed the gratitude of the armies under his command for labor's contribution to victory on the production front and declared that now as never before it was essential to keep uninterrupted, the stream of military supplies to tile fighting lines.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Monday, Sept. 4 -- The Battle of Germany is about to begin. Three Allied armies have wheeled into line from Sedan to Tournai and are thrusting powerful armored forces toward the German frontier and the Siegfried Line.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Chinese troops, occupying enemy strongpoints within the encircled fortress city of Tengyueh in Yunnan Province, found the first cases of Japanese suicides on the Salween front, headquarters of Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Juan Francisco de Cardenas, Spanish Ambassador, asserted in a statement today that "no one has ever contemplated providing a hiding place in Spain for the enemies of the Allied countries."

The new fall clothes colors in the pink-to-purple tones -- the pinkish blues and beiges, the mauves, magentas, fuchsias, and plums -- undoubtedly will present a problem to many women when they start their fall wardrobe shopping this year, beauty authorities agree.

ROME, Sept. 3 -- As surprising as finding Florence still a battleground much worse damaged than reports indicated are spectacular evidences of the devastating struggle waged for the country between Rome and Florence. This is the part of Italy where the enemy made the quickest retreat, and no accounts published at the time prepared one for the panorama of destruction left in the wake of what was supposed to be a comparatively easy battle.

LONDON, Sept. 3 (U.P.) -- A new patriot uprising against the Germans in Poland has developed as Polish quarters reported today that underground troops in Radom, fifty-seven miles south of Warsaw, had risen in full strength. The Radom underground was said to be cooperating with Russian troops driving from the east toward the city.
PARIS, Sept. 3 -- The Folies-Bergeres opened here last night to a packed house of United States Ninth Air Force engineers, and they all liked it better than somewhat.

On all sides the political and military front of the Axis has begun to crumble at an accelerative rate. In the east, Roumania, Bulgaria and Finland are either dropping out of the war or turning on their former "ally." The Nazis have suffered the irreparable loss of the Ploesti oil fields.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UP) -- President Roosevelt told Dr. Ramon Grau San Martin, President-elect of Cuba, that he hopes to visit that island republic as President or otherwise, it was disclosed tonight after Dr. Grau had ended an official visit here and left for New York

Bishop William T. McCarty, Military Delegate to the Armed Forces of the United States, paid tribute yesterday to the Catholic Women's Union on its twenty-fifth anniversary and to the Catholic Central Verein on its forty-seventh anniversary.

Attacking "unfounded anti-labor propaganda," John L. Childs, State chairman, and Joseph V. O'Leary, State secretary, of the Liberal party, in a Labor Day statement yesterday stressed labor's "impressive contribution to victory" and the right of returning veterans and demobilized workers to post-war jobs and security.

BETHPAGE, L.I., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Four marines -- two men and two women -- registered world records today as Quantico marines swept to practically all the championships in the fall pistol tournament sponsored by the National Rifle Association at the Grumman Gun Club.

Attendance at the 11:45 o'clock mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral was the first event in the program of Dr. Ramon Grau San Martin, President-elect of Cuba, and his official party of Cuban and American diplomats who arrived from Washington at 6:55 A.M. yesterday for a six-day visit in New York.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 3 -- Reports of strong opposition in the House of Representatives in Washington to the Bankhead loan boosting amendment to the Surplus Disposal Bill as approved by the Senate, more favorable war

LONDON, Sept. 3 (AP)--Five great waves of American war planes, under orders from Supreme Commander Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to bomb Brest until the last remnants of the German fanatics holding the French Atlantic port were killed or surrendered, blasted the city's fortifications and defenses today and tonight with more than 1,700 tons of exploding steel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- With sittings scheduled despite the Labor Day holiday, the international conversations for the organization of a world security body tomorrow will enter their third and what is expected to be their final week. There are to be meetings tomorrow of the full subcommittees on security and organization, and work is going to be pushed rapidly throughout the week.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3 (AP) -- America will operate at near its present wartime boom pace within six months after the war ends, H.G. Batcheller, president of the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, predicted today in a message to the company's 4,500 employes in the armed services.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3 (AP) -- A new life saving harness, the Navy disclosed today, enabled the rescue recently of a disabled aviator by a Navy blimp off the southern California coast and apparently solved one of the principal problems of saving marooned personnel in sea areas too far removed for the use of shore-based crash boats or too rough for seaplanes to land.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- A radio operator-air gunner of the Army Air Forces, who asked to be thrown out of his crippled Fortress to lighten the plane while the crew was fighting off enemy attacks over Bremen, has received the Medal of Honor.

The paper salvage situation in Bronxville as outlined by Anna Steese Richardson is one from which this town suffered until the beginning of this year. At that time all salvage operations were divided among groups on the basis that those who did the collecting got the entire proceeds.
Price increases for a large number of commodities caused the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices to rise from the previous week's level of 113.01 to a new all-time high of 113.18.

Commenting on the opening of the campaign for the election of Governor Dewey, Republican nominee for President, by six Republican Governors, Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic National Chairman, said yesterday that none of these Governors in their radio speeches had discussed the real issues of the camapign.

LONDON, Monday, Sept. 4 (AP) -- A. Reuters dispatch from Stockholm said it had been announced officially in Helsinki, Finland, that the Finns and Russians had agreed that fighting would cease on Finnish-held sectors of the Eastern Front at 8 A.M. today.

The travesty of gasoline rationing has long been apparent. On any day or night can be seen thousands of cars driving and parked in the city and surroundings, all bearing A, B and C stickers. Old cars filled with youngsters out for a joy ride, all, I suppose strictly war workers and on essential driving.

The question of the trials of the war criminals will soon occupy public attention. The civilized world will, of course, grant full protection to the defendants -- that is, accord them the presumption of innocence and impose on the prosecutors the duty of establishing guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.

FORT ONTARIO, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- Four hospitality houses and a community center furnished and equipped by B'nai B'rith for the refugees at the emergency shelter established by the United States Government at Fort Ontario were dedicated today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- By a mere breath, of which there were few out on Long Island Sound today, Arthur Davis brushed his International sloop Patricia past Corny Shields' Arleen right on the finish line to win by a split second.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 3 -- Zoe Elliott, whose "Eighth Army Band March" is gaining popularity in British and American military camps, revealed today that he had received word from Field Marshal Sir Bernard L. Montgomery, former head of the Army, to which the song is dedicated, that the march is "first class."

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 3 -- Dr. Karl Clodius, head of the German Trade Commission, who has bullied the Balkan nations since before the war, is being held captive in Bucharest, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- General Marshall's idea for a compact post-war Army with a professional nucleus but a trained citizen reserve, is expected to receive its first formal consideration on Capitol Hill on Tuesday.

PROCESSED FOODS (various earned or bottled vegetables, fruits, fruit juices, except prune juice; soups, baby foods, jams, jellies and other special products. Blue stamps A8 through Z8, also A5 through L5 in War Book 4, good indefinitely at 10 points each. Frozen fruits and vegetables, fruit butters and dried beans and fruits now point-free.

The traditional army of wheat harvesters that moves with the ripening season from Texas to the Canadian border has received 500 new recruits. Some months ago the War Food Administration allocated to Massey-Harris, farm machinery manufacturers, engines and steel to build 500 self-propelled combines.

If a householder has no electric stove, or if the one he has is beyond repair, and if the house is adequately wired for an electric stove, he might have a chance -- but probably a slim one -- of buying one of the 18,420 new electric ranges that the War Production Board recently authorized five manufacturers to turn out during the last half of this year.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 3 -- For the seventeenth time Champion El Wendie of Rockland took the highest honor possible in a dog show. This afternoon the notable fawn boxer bitch was placed first in the final judging at the eleventh annual exhibition of the Lehigh Valley Kennel Club, held on the Allentown Fair Grounds.

Acquisition of wealth as the controlling aim of American life was condemned by the Rev. Dr. Bernard Iddings Bell of Providence, R.I., in a sermon yesterday morning at Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway at Wall Street.
LONDON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- An American-driven bulldozer diverted a river of flaming gasoline recently and saved a southwestern English village after a twenty-one-hour battle, it was disclosed tonight.

Another warm day was promised by the weather man for today as yesterday's temperatures, which reached an official high in the city of 89 degrees, sent more than a million New Yorkers to the beaches and parks. At La Guardia Field where 4,100 persons passed through the turnstiles at the observation deck, the thermometer registered 91 at 4 P.M.
ARRAS, France, Sept. 2 (Delayed) -- French patriots are rendering invaluable assistance to the British troops as the latter race steadily toward Belgium.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- An intensive campaign was announced today by the transportation division of the War Production Board to save at least one day in the freight car turn-around for the rest of the year. The campaign was undertaken to get the cooperation of shippers and receivers to meet in the coming months a transportation situation that is expected to be "the most critical in the war."

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Pirates today became the first team to sweep a four-game series with the Cardinals when they took both ends of a double-header, 6--5 and 8--2, before 34,395, largest crowd of the year here.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Detachable rockets, capable of assisting a heavily laden plane into the air from a short runway, have been developed by the Army Air Force Technical Service Command, it was announced here today by Col. Nelson S. Talbott, commanding officer.

A method of mixing cake has been devised by General Mills, Inc., that takes only four minutes as compared with the customary fifteen to twenty. In addition to saving time, it also cuts down on dishwashing, for only one bowl need be employed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, accused the House of Representatives today of failure to provide for "the human side" in the reconversion bill which it passed on Friday.

A UNITED STATES AIR COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, England, Monday, Sept. 4 (U.P.) -- United States Eighth Air Force Thunderbolts, harassing the German retreat across Belgium, which pilots say has developed into a motley race of everything on wheels, strafed a twenty-mile-long convoy east of Louvain yesterday while Belgians waved and cheered from the roadside.

LONDON, Sept. 3 (Reuter) -- Today's communique from Gen. Jean-Gabriel Cochet, commander of the French Forces of the Interior in southern France, quoted tonight by the Algiers radio, reported that French patriot forces had crossed the Alps and penetrated Italian territory.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Riding a torrid scoring streak, that bids to carry him to a new national record for 72-hole competition, Byron Nelson of Toledo fashioned a 4-under-par 67 over the Richland course today to stretch his lead in the $10,000 Nashville invitation golf tournament.

In his third recent purchase in the section, Samuel Knepper, operator, has acquired the fourteen-story and penthouse apartment building for seventy-two families at 370 Riverside Drive, northeast corner of 109th Street, from Pasquale Ferri.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- The stock markets here have thrown off in some small measure the heaviness and inactivity that gripped them for a time because of the war's excellent progress and the consequent fears about the transitional peace period.

MOSCOW, Sept. 3 -- A bizarre tale was told today to foreign correspondents of how a Rumanian Communist in Bucharest, sought by the Gestapo, had slipped into the royal palace under cover of the blackout night after night to conspire with young King Michael on ways to pry Rumania away from the Axis and place her at the side of the United Nations.

The present requirement of a two-thirds vote by the Senate for ratification of treaties "might easily lead to almost irreparable damage to the prosperity and happiness of the American people as well as to the great movement of international cooperation to establish and maintain world peace," according to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.
CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 3 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles won the women's national tennis championship for the third year in succession and the "foreign threat" in the men's singles was spiked yesterday at Forest Hills with the defeat of Francisco (Pancho) Segura of Ecuador by William Talbert of Indianapolis.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 3 -- Greece's civil war, which has been intermittent between rival patriotic factions of guerrillas, was probably ended today when five representatives of the left wing and Communist-led Eam came from their mountain hideout in Greece and were sworn in as members of Premier George Papandreou's Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The President's Committee on Fair Employment Practices and the War Policy Division of the United Automobile, Aircraft and Agricultural Implement Workers (CIO) have signed a working agreement designed to speed "the elimination of un-American discrimination."

Incorporation papers for the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York as the agency to operate a comprehensive plan of medical and surgical care for all persons living or working in the city and earning not more than $5,000 a year were filed on Thursday with the State Board of Social Welfare and the Superintendent of Insurance, Mayor LaGuardia announced yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Proposals for setting up air service to the West Indies, Central and South America and across the Atlantic to Northern and Central Europe, Russia and points in Asia are made in applications filed with the Civil Aeronautics Board by the Moore-McCormack Steamship Lines.

PLEASANTVILLE, Sept. 3 -- How to compete with the high school siren who wears "a long platinum bob, a tight black dress and black gloves with rings on the outside" was the topic for discussion today at the Girl Scouts teenage conference in session at Camp Macy, where juvenile and adult leaders are planning a national program of activities for Scouts of the senior age group.

Determined now to go all out in an effort to bag a pennant which weeks ago seemed irretrievably lost, the Yankees yesterday catapulted themselves right onto the very necks of the American League front runners as they vanquished the Senators in both ends of a double-header before a roaring crowd of 44,689 onlookers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Any setting aside of the plans for an international monetary fund by the recent Bretton Woods conference would bring general discouragement in the field of post-war international relations, the Foreign Policy Association declared in a report today.
Here is a suggestion that might serve to coordinate the proposals now before the conference at Dumbarton Oaks on enforcing peace.
Five new films are scheduled to arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

When a telegram from his family in Brooklyn informed Pfc. Louis Colella, 28 years old, on Saturday that his mother, Mrs. Filippa Colella, was dying -- could not survive forty-eight hours -- he was in despair. To get to her bedside from Atlantic City, where he was convalescing in an Army hospital from a hand wound received at St. Lo, he needed an immediate furlough.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 3 -- RKO has bought the screen rights to the late Eric Knight's comedy fantasy, "The Flying Yorkshireman," and will star Barry Fitzgerald in the role of the north country Englishman who learned to fly without mechanical aid after being converted to the mind-over-matter theory by a famous Los Angeles woman Evangelist.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- Fred Wright and his guest, Ted Schluter, unattached, who took a three-stroke lead in the first round of the Leewood Golf Club's annual member-guest tournament yesterday, saw their margin whittled by a stroke this afternoon when Nick Mertens and Charlie de Lucca of Gedney scored a net 62 for a two-round count of 131.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (U.P.) -- Edd Johnson, 38 years old, a war correspondent for The Chicago Sun, has been cited in a letter from Lieut. Col. John J. Deane for his conduct under fire on the day of the American landing on the south French coast.
May I correct some of the statements contained in a letter in your Aug. 28 issue from Charles A. Davila, former Rumanian Minister to the United States.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Phils came back today to win by 5 -- 0 after bowing to the Braves, 2 to 1.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Demand for lard has become general, but with an unusually small make and comparatively little unsold product in the hands of packers, a tight situation has developed and most sales last week were at ceiling prices. Loose lard is quoted at $12.80 bid a 100 pounds.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- As the influence of the holiday season wanes, clearer evidence emerges of what bankers believe to be a definite and probably lasting downward trend in circulation of currency of the Bank of England. Last week's rise of 1,500,000 in note circulation compared with nearly 4,000,000 last year, and throughout the holiday season this year the expansion has been at a smaller rate than in the same period last year.

MOSCOW, Sept. 3 -- The story of another German death camp, situated at Sobibur, Poland, smaller than that at Maidanek but which, nevertheless, is estimated to have been the execution site for "hundreds of thousands of persons," was published in today's Komsomolskaya Pravda, organ of the Young Communist League.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in the Southwest Pacific, Monday, Sept. 4 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's aerial spearhead in the Philippines offensive has driven the Japanese air force from southern Mindanao, it was announced today in a communique telling of a record 130-ton bomb attack on Davao's airfields and port installations.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 3 -- The Bulgarian armistice negotiations have halted while the two-man Bulgarian delegation here sits idle. No one, including themselves, knows whether the new Sofia Government expects them to continue the parleys or wants to send new envoys or plans to give up the whole thing as a bad job.

ROME, Sept. 3 -- The British Eighth Army considerably widened its breach in the Gothic Line today against the desperately battling Germans, who were putting up what may prove to be their last stand in Italy. As the campaigns in France and the Balkans have shown, the Germans have no reserves and, once their front-line forces have been smashed, a battle becomes a pursuit.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- An appeal to women war workers to stay on the job in critical labor-shortage areas to release men for heavy work in production bottlenecks was made today by Miss Margaret A. Hickey, chairman of the Women's Advisory Committee of the War Manpower Commission.
LYON, France, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Doughboys entering Lyon today were greeted with hysterical joy by the city's 600,000 residents.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- General liquidation in oats, rye and barley was on last week on the Chicago Board of Trade, with July oats selling at the lowest price reached by any delivery of that grain since February, 1943. General improvement in the feed grain situation was responsible for the selling that uncovered stop-loss orders.

NEWARK, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Salvaging the finale of a five-game series in which first place was at stake, the Baltimore Orioles blanked Newark, 4 to 0, in the second game of a twin bill today before a crowd of 14,895, after the Bears captured their fourth straight in the opener by a 7-3 count.

George Norris was one of the last of the elder statesmen. Probably no Senator in his time left a deeper impress on a changing America. He stood like a rock dividing the liberal and conservative streams of thought in this nation, diverting much of it into the channels through which he wished it to flow.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Ceiling prices for leading grains, other than corn, are virtually a thing of the past, and brokers on the Board of Trade express the belief that it will take a considerable change in conditions to restore wheat, oats and barley to the maximum quotations set by the Office of Price Administration.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 1 (Delayed) -- How the Rumanians feel about their country's fighting on the Allied side was expressed today by Alexander Cretsianu, Rumanian Minister to Turkey. Mr. Cretsianu said:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Rejoicing in the increasing prospect of victory and pride in the part which American labor has played to bring the result stood out in Labor Day messages from war and labor leaders of the country on the eve of the golden jubilee Labor Day.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- President Roosevelt's executive order authorizing Secretary Ickes to seize and operate certain coal mines follows:

Frank C. Ferguson, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, announced yesterday that railroad storage rates on water-borne freight at Portland, Me., have been adjusted upward, effective Sept. 15, to equalize railroad storage charges in effect in New York and other North Atlantic ports.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The Dumbarton Oaks Conference has reached general agreement on the basic principle that force must be made available to the proposed league executive council to prevent and repel aggression, it was learned today.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Byron Nelson of Toledo strengthened his claim to the title of kingpin of modern golf today by capturing the $10,000 Nashville invitation tourney with a seventy-two-hole score of 269, fifteen under the Richland Club's par.

Member savings and loan associations of the Federal Home Loan Bank System made home loans during the first half of 1944 amounting to $624,336,000, an increase of 37 per cent over the corresponding period last year, James Twohy, governor of the system, reported yesterday. This represents the greatest lending activity of member associations for any six-month period since the system was established in 1932, he said.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Tuesday, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Communique:

On the beaches of England, Wales and Scotland, workmen these days are rolling up the barbed-wire barricades that have been there since the fall of 1939, that were reinforced the following summer when France fell, that many believed might still be needed so short a time ago as last spring.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Delivery of pulpwood to mills in July totaled 1,512,000 cords, a gain of 10.5 per cent over the same month of the previous year but 3 per cent below receipts of July, 1942, the forest products bureau of the War Production Board reported today.

PERHAPS you missed reading about it. This reporter found it hidden away in a corner of only one newspaper and possibly most folks overlooked it entirely. But it was a might significant item, one that may have wide repercussions in the future.
CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 4 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
Thank you so much for publishing the letter from Edward Manley Hopkins. In these times of so much sadness it is refreshing to read something that gives a good laugh, and I am still laughing.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Establishment of emergency refugee shelters immediately in Palestine and Latin American countries was urged today by the Agudath Israel Youth Council of America at closing sessions of its annual convention.

PARIS, Sept. 4 -- Some idea of the temper of Paris during the struggle for its liberation can be gained from the following text of a sermon preached a week ago Sunday in a Paris church. To a congregation made up largely of people who had spent the previous night fighting the Germans behind barricades, the clergyman said:

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Detroit's pennant-bidding Tigers slipped to two and one-half games behind the new league leaders, the Yankees, today when Ed Lopat's four-hit southpawing checked them, 6 to 3, after they had routed the White Sox, 12 to 2, in the first game.
WASHINTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 113:

The necessity for redoubling rather than relaxing efforts directed toward the conservation and salvage of waste paper to keep pace with our swiftly advancing armies and their lengthened supply lines was urged upon householders yesterday by officials of the salvage drive.

Seeking to scotch reports that the medical societies in the city are still opposed to his health-insurance plan, Mayor La Guardia issued a special statement yesterday asserting that the plan not only had the support of the profession, but that "details" of the plan would be discussed "real soon" with the medical societies.

ROME, Sept. 4 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. Alexander M. Patch's Americans and Gen. De Lattre de Tassigny's French scarcely paused for the job of liberating Lyon as they drove north to close the gap, now little more than 140 miles wide, between the Allied armies in southern France and those above Chaumont in the north.

Twice within a week the German air force struck back in retaliation for the day-after-day bombing of Germany and of the German armies fleeing the battlefronts. The first attack was on the Paris suburbs the night of Aug. 26-27 and the morning of the 27th. On the night of Sept. 1-2, German bombers attacked Verdun, until then little scarred by this war.

LONDON, Sept. 4 (U.P.) -- Polish quarters in London today announced that General Bor's forces would continue their "almost hopeless" fight against the German forces in Warsaw, after having asserted earlier that the fighting had been halted and General Bor had withdrawn from the capital.

MOSCOW, Sept. 4 -- Without any known formal agreement, the Soviet Government and the Polish Committee of National Liberation are proceeding, at least on an informal basis, to put the Curzon Line in effect as the boundary between the two countries, it was disclosed today.

CHICAGO, Sept 4 -- The radio has done more to destroy faith in nutrition research than any other element in American life, C.A. Elvehjem, professor of biochemistry at the University of Wisconsin, told the Harris Foundation Institute at the University of Chicago today.
BRUSSELS, Sept. 4 -- Belgium's capital was in a state of delirious pandemonium today after its liberation late last night by armored units of a famous British division.

WASHINGTON, Sept 4 -- Federal seizure of four more Pennsylvania soft coal mining properties where supervisors affiliated with District 50 of the United Mine Workers of America struck for recognition of their union was ordered by President Roosevelt today on the ground that the labor troubles would impede the prosecution of the war.

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 4 -- Pacific Fleet forces severely punished the three principal Japanese bases in the Bonins and Volcano Islands by air and sea bombardment over the three-day period from last Wednesday through Friday with carriers, cruisers and destroyers operating against targets within 600 miles of Tokyo.

In the wake of war come huge problems of civilian welfare. Families are dislocated. Vast numbers of children with fathers in the fighting forces and mothers in war industry require care that they can no longer get at home. Thousands of aged and infirm people whose needs in peacetime would be met by their younger relatives are now neglected.

PHILLPHIA, Sept. 4 -- President Roosevelt called upon the United Office and Professional Workers of America (CIO) today at the opening of their fifth constitutional convention to lend every assistance in strengthening "national unity for a speedy victory, a durable peace, full production and full employment."

CINCINNATI, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Cardinals took all the winnings permitted by the weather today, defeating the Reds, 3 to 0, in the first half of the holiday double- header on Ted Wilks' five-hit pitching.
LONDON, Sept. 4 -- Although business in most sections of today's stock markets was on the quiet side the encouraging war news had a hardening effect.

From now until the war ends, the country will be waiting and meantime making what preparations and adjustments it can for the termination of hostilities without relaxing in the work and effort still needed, according to the September review of economic conditions by the National City Bank of New York.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 4 -- For the second time in three days of dog shows, that remarkable black cocker spaniel dog, Champion Non-quitt Nola's Candidate, today won top prize in the second annual exhibition of the Anthracite Kennel Club.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 4 -- The whirling Allied victories in Europe and the Pacific look particularly unreal today. For news of the most immediate consequence here is that the Japanese have resumed one of their most decisive offensives. Not since the fall of Hankow in 1938 have they undertaken an offensive with such far-reaching potentialities.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Chungking and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- So far-reaching has been the defeat imposed on the Germans in France that some authoritative military observers now doubt seriously that the enemy will be able to make any prolonged defense at the Siegfried Line or Westwall. Those holding this opinion advance the following points:

BOSTON, Sept. 4 -- Secretary Frances Perkins advanced today a four-point post-war program including extended social security, a quick return to the short workweek, a revival of collective bargaining and a steady increase in the production and distribution of goods.

LONDON, Sept. 4 (Reuter) -- The puppet Slovak Government is about to be dismissed by the Germans, according to private reports from Bratislava and Berlin reaching Czechoslovak Government quarters here.

MOSCOW, Sept. 4 -- Pravda, official organ of the Communist party, today sharply attacked William C. Bullitt, former, United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union and France, as "a bankrupt spy" who sympathized with Adolf Hitler, staked his career on a German victory over Russia and continues to carry on "dirty anti-Soviet work" in the columns of Life magazine.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The National War Labor Board held a Hearing of several hours today on a dispute which, according to its members, should never have come to it. A dispute over wage rates for four molders Which brought a strike of 400 men making critically needed valves for naval vessels.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Sugar stocks held by primary distributors in the United States have fallen to less than 1,000,000 short tons despite heavy receipts of raw sugar from Cuba and Puerto Rico during the first half of the year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 4 -- The Finnish Parliament, the Diet, met in secret session tonight and was expected to approve the instructions drawn up by President Mannerheim's Government for the peace delegation that is going to Moscow.

M'COOK, Neb., Sept. 4 (U.P.) -- George W. Norris fought for the common person and best interests of humanity throughout his long career, Dr. Bryant Drake, president of Doane College of Crete, Neb., said here this afternoon at a funeral service for the distinguished former Senator from Nebraska.

An urgent call for help came from General Patron's Third Army the other night, according to a headquarters announcement. In response ten tons of maps were flown to the indicated area and dropped by parachute. The Third's armored columns had been moving so fast that they had run off the edges of the maps they had.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Jersey City and Newark swapped shutouts before 5,545 today, the Little Giants winning, 2 -- 0, after the Bears had triumphed by the same score.

Vice President Henry A. Wallace, defeated for renomination at the recent Democratic National convention, will make his first speech for President Roosevelt in this campaign on Sept. 21 at Madison Square Garden, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Extension of home rule for Puerto Rico was urged by President Roosevelt in a letter sent today to Representative C. Jasper Bell, Democrat, of Missouri, chairman of the House Committee on Insular Affairs.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 4 -- "Free labor is winning this war," A.F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, declared in a Labor Day statement and added that despite war-induced hardships, including "inequities between wages and the cost of living," the American worker "has not only retained, but in some instances has extended his basic right to engage" in collective bargaining through his own representatives.
CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Before a record crowd of 42,000, Equifox, 7-year-old son of the turf's immortal Equipoise, streaked to a two-length victory in the $59,050 Washington Park Handicap today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 -- Anemic Giant batting averages found a stimulant today in Phillies' pitching as Mel Ott's band battered Freddy Fitzsimmon's modified hurling staff for thirty-two solid blows, but the best the Giants could get was a stand-off.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The faltering Browns yielded their long-held first-place position in the American League standing today by splitting a double-header with Cleveland while the Yankees won two games to reach the top rung, one-half game ahead of the Browns.

Tonight Irving Kaye Davis' play, "Last Stop," will have its delayed premiere at the Barrymore and the Davis family will then be rooting for two attractions. Mrs. Davis is Elsa Shelley, author of "Pick-Up Girl," resident at the Forty-eighth Street since May 3.

The title of your thoughtful editorial in THE TIMES of Aug. 23, "Whole Blood by Air," emphasizes with the words "by air" a point not brought out in the content of the piece. The fact that whole blood can be flown overseas is notable first, of course, because new laboratory processes keep unseparated blood effective after it is taken from the donor.

The six-story, forty-eight-family apartment house on a plot 100 by 96 feet at 140-71 Ash Avenue, in Flushing, has been sold through Farber-Wittman, Inc., and Paul P. Zinner to an investing client of Dover Realty, Inc.

About 150,000 war ballots, representing the first batch to be sent to service men from Greater New York under the State Soldier Voting Law, will be placed in the mails tomorrow and Thursday by the New York City Board of Elections, Commissioner David F. Costuma, secretary of the board, disclosed yesterday.

Man and boy-wonder, Frankie Parker came East annually from Milwaukee and California for more than a dozen years in fruitless quest of the national tennis championship. Mercer Beasley, his coach, suffered in silence with him as he endured the slings and arrows of outraged form experts sitting in judgment on a forehand that was never the same from season to season.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 4 -- High style for high school girls will be the same this year as last and the year before that -- sweaters and skirts, long bobs with an occasional pompadour and "loafers," "shanks mares" or "jesters" as footgear, according to preferences expressed by senior Girl Scouts at a conference on clothes today.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- Austria as well as Germany is to be occupied by the Allies when Germany is defeated. But the occupation is to be of a different kind from that of Germany, since it was decided at the Moscow Conference last year that Austria is to be reestablished as an independent state.

At a time when the American Medical Association protests in its Journal a threatened reduction of 25 to 30 per cent in 1945 of students entering classes at medical schools, a survey of fifteen leading medical colleges in seven cities shows only a slight increase in enrollment of women at nine schools.

A "very severe" surface earthquake struck the Atlantic coast from eastern Canada to at least as far south as Norfolk, Va., at 12:34:53 A.M. today and the tremors were felt as far inland as Wisconsin. Two distinct shocks were recorded by leading seismic observatories and long after the earth had settled surface waves were registered on the delicate instruments.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Union leaders estimated not more than one-fourth of the regular shifts reported for work at the two Cleveland Graphite Bronze Company plants tonight. Earlier the company warned that continuance of the five-day-old strike might limit American aerial operations in Europe and Asia.
LONDON, Sept. 4 -A liberation message, broadcast by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower. Supreme Allied Commander, to the peoples of Belgium, Luxembourg, the Netherlands and Norway, was released today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- The attitude of machine tool builders on prospects of the industry vary widely, with some optimistic over business in the post-war period and others pessimistic, but they generally agree that post-war planning is still too indefinite actually to let them know where they are going, a check of the leaders here last week revealed.

CHUNGKING, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Japanese spearheads plunging along the trackless stretch of the Hunan-Kwangsi railway are only about forty miles from the coveted air base at Lingling near the Kwangsi border in a sudden drive that portends a renewed attempt to split China in two, the Chinese High Command indicated tonight.

As the Allied tornado sweeps into Germany the barometer is steadily dropping in the Pacific. Storms there that drove the enemy out of the Solomons, the Marshalls, New Guinea and the Marianas are followed by bombing of the Bonins and the Philippines, and the air is still heavy with foreboding.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 4 -- Luther S. Ayer of 606 Park Avenue, who, with his wife, entertained at dinner yesterday a man who gave his name as Lieut. William G. Poston, whom they had met Saturday night through a friend, reported to police today that after his departure, they missed jewelry valued at $1,500 and $100 in cash which had been in a bureau drawer.
BRUSSELS, Sept. 4 (UP) -- To cheers that drowned the shots still being fired by knots of isolated Germans, British troops entered Brussels today.

BOSTON, Sept. 4 -- With Ben Chapman starting them off right by hurling a neat three-hitter, the Dodgers went on today to sweep the twin bill with the Braves, 4 -- 1 and 6 -- 4 -- a highly satisfactory performance for the Brooks, but not at all pleasing to the 11,394 Hub fans who witnessed the double debacle.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- Gen. Kasimierz Sosnkowski, whose removal from command of the Polish armies has been proposed by the Polish Government in exile as a concession to Soviet demands, denied today that the Poles were responsible for not coordinating the costly Warsaw uprising with the Red Army plans.

LIKE most of the front-line war literature, Charles Wertenbaker's "Invasion" has a hard time competing with the raw facts set forth in the daily newspapers. But in this account of the Normandy campaign, from its inception up to the capture of Cherbourg, Mr. Wertenbaker justifies a quick rewriting of yesterday's dispatches by delving into the personalities of the generals who planned and executed the whole intricate maneuver.

DETROIT, Sept. 4 -- Senator Harry S. Truman, Democratic nominee for Vice President, brought President Roosevelt's fourth term bid here to the heart of the country's industrial empire with a promise and a warning to the millions of American workers who paused today to celebrate their accomplishment in fashioning the tools with which Allied victories are being won on battlefronts the world over.

Republican Congressman Calvin D. Johnson should really have at least a nodding acquaintance with his subject when he discourses on the situation in India in relation to Britain, in which case I am sure his natural honesty would inhibit him from making the fantastically inaccurate statements in his resolution reported Aug. 30.

Though drapery and upholstery fabrics are currently listed among the hardest to find of decorator's materials a new exhibit opening today at Macy's suggests "architecture with fabric" in lieu of major construction work to correct rooms with bad proportions, or window that are too short, too tall, too broad or too many.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, Sept. 5 -- The flood tide of the Allies' military might has swept northward across Belgium into the Netherlands and eastward to the German frontier, where it is rushing on the outer defenses of the Siegfried Line.

Deploring capitalist and communist propaganda that sought to set labor and trade unions apart from the fighting forces, the Rev. John P. Monaghan declared yesterday that the nation's workers had been belittled and misjudged.

A.N. McFarlane has been appointed manager of sales of the chemical division of Corn Products Refining Company, with Dr. Henry L. Cox named general manager W.B. Newkirk, formerly director of research and development, has been made assistant to Dr. Cox.

ROME, Sept. 4 -- A clear hint that Italy's six-party Government cannot last much longer was contained in a speech by Pietro Nenni to the Socialist Party Congress in Naples yesterday afternoon, the text of which reached Rome today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 4 -- Warner Brothers plan to co-star Joyce Reynolds and Robert Hutton, the romantic leads of "Janie," in "The Time Between," a story by Gale Wilhelm about the romantic adventures of an Army flier on furlough.

The New York Stock Exchange will admit to dealings tomorrow Texas Pacific-Missouri Pacific Terminal Railroad of New Orleans 3 3/8 per cent Series A mortgage bonds due in 1974 and certificates of deposit for the capital stock of the New York, Lackawanna Western Railway Company.

LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 5 -- Russian troops, resuming their drive to free Warsaw, smashed through powerful German fortifications yesterday and advanced to the Narew River, last enemy defense line on the northern approaches to the Polish capital.

Between alarms, New York City's firemen are reading more and better books, according to the New York Public Library. Circulation of books in firehouses by the library has increased 300 per cent over the number of two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today an agreement by the Colagte-Palmolive-Peet Company to discontinue use of advertisements which the Commission said "misrepresent the composition, properties and effectiveness" of certain soaps, dentifrices and shaving creams.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Contending that the ban on the use of "Government standards" in establishing ceiling prices for canned fruits and vegetables makes enforcement of price controls "impossible," Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, asked Congress today to end the restriction that is contained in the Appropriations Act of 1944 controlling OPA funds.

Expenditures for repair and maintenance of homes, exclusive of farm residences, during the first six years after the war will break all records, with a total volume exceeding $6,000,000,000, according to a forecast prepared by the Producers Council, national organization of manufacturers of building materials and equipment.

Drums beat out hot rhythm in Times Square so successfully yesterday that at the end of a two-hour afternoon rally $33,000 worth of war bonds were sold to a Labor Day crowd that exceeded in size any attending similar rallies previously.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 4 -- While the Federal Government seized eight more western Pennsylvania mines operated by four companies today, nearly 300,000 tons of bituminous coal were lost because of Labor Day absenteeism and strikes involving supervisory employe bargaining right demands.

Brussels broke into a wild frenzy of rejoicing yesterday as the last badly mauled German columns fled, while the Allies marched in and Belgian troops paraded in the city for the first time in four years, according to descriptions broadcast last night by the Belgian national radio and reported' by the Federal Communications Commission.

ROME, Sept. 4 -- The situation in Italy with regard to food, public health and mortality has become so alarming that Brig. Gen. William V. O'Dwyer, Chief of the Allied Control Commission's economic section, left Rome today on a dash back to Washington to place facts and figures before President Roosevelt.

Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for United States Senator, will open today his campaign for the seat now held by Robert F. Wagner, Democrat, when he begins a tour of several up-State counties. On the trip, Mr. Curran, who is New York's Secretary of State, will make a number of informal talks.
LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Just before daybreak today the Germans loosed another barrage of flying bombs at London and southern England, ending a four-day lull in the robot attacks.

ARRAS, France, Sept. 3 (Delayed) -- A stalwart German lieutenant was deeply chagrined today when a 16-year-old French Maquisard, prodding him with a rifle, led him into a British field headquarters near the Belgian frontier.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- President Roosevelt said tonight in a statement issued at the White House:

PARIS, Sept. 4 (U.P.) -- The French "Provisional Government" ordered the arrest of many prominent collaborationists tonight and it was revealed that police had unearthed a French branch of the Gestapo accused of murdering more than 1,000 persons and kidnaping Gen. Charles de Gaulle's niece.

LYON, Sept. 4 -- The retreat of German forces in a general northerly direction began Friday, and the last elements to leave this city moved out last night after all twenty-eight bridges across the Rhone and Saone, with the sole exception of the Wilson Bridge, had been completely destroyed.

In its latest report on the working capital of American corporations, the Securities and Exchange Commission "re-emphasizes the ability of American industry as a whole to reconvert to peacetime production and also to undertake considerable expansion without recourse to outside sources of funds."

If you are wondering what to include in a Christmas box to be sent overseas to a service man or woman, we suggest as one of the items a pound or two of lebkuchen. These are the delicious cookies associated with the Yuletide throughout the middle of Europe, and they are baked to a T by Mrs. Paula Freund in her small establishment at 1087 St. Nicholas Avenue, between 164th and 165th Streets.

The Office of Price Administration is to be commended for denying the thoroughly unjustifiable claim of landlords in this city that a 10 per cent rent rise is necessary. It was also highly gratifying to see this action taken despite the activities of a well-financed lobby working in behalf of the real estate owners.

The British radio yesterday quoted a report issued by Gen. Gabriel Cochet, Chief of Staff of the French Forces of the Interior, as saying that fighting continued in the Eastern Alps and that 2,000 Germans had been taken prisoner in the Ardeche and Loire Departments.
PAWLING, N.Y., Sept 4 -- Governor Dewey revealed tonight that he would participate, with the other Republican Governors, in a series of joint radio broadcasts during the Presidential campaign.

ROME, Sept. 4 -- Powerful Canadian forces of the Eighth Army had the vital Adriatic coastal city of Rimini almost within their grasp tonight after a slashing attack carried them across the Conca River and gave them a solid bridgehead two miles deep within less than seven miles of the important terminus of the Po Valley highway.

The late Heywood Broun, and no doubt many others before him into the dim mists of time, used to say of a certain type of play on the Broadway stage that even if it was good he wouldn't like it. There are a great many of us who feel the same way about national policies, domestic or foreign, of which we disapprove from the start.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Cubs took a 6 -- 3 decision from the Pirates before 18,175 today but the Bucs gained a 4 -- 3 verdict in the second game called by darkness in the sixth.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 4 -- There were eighty-six sailing craft in the Larchmont Yacht Club's final summer regatta out on Long Island Sound today, the eighteenth on the championship list series. Varying breezes muddled much of the competition.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Allied troops advancing into western Burma in pursuit of Japanese forces retreating from India are approaching Tiddim after clearing the highway of the enemy for a distance of almost 100 miles south of Imphal, headquarters announced today, adding that only limited rearguard resistance was being encountered in the continuing advance.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 4 -- Finland's three years of war with Russia ended with a dramatic cease-firing order today, and guns of both sides all along the 500-mile front from the coast near Viborg to Salla subsided into silence.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 4 -- A planned national economy, with Government, industry, labor and agriculture collaborating, was urged today by Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, as providing "common security and prosperity in the difficult days" of the postwar era.

The wholesale markets were active last week, with many buyers on hand placing additional orders for fall and holiday merchandise. Retailers are not worrying particularly about a recession in consumer buying before the end of the year, according to a summary of activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

"99 Park," headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc.,* offers a partial list of free amusements available today through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- Commemorating the triennial of the Cromwellian Soldier's Bible the University of Chicago Press will publish tomorrow "Soldiers' Bibles Through Three Centuries," a monograph by Harold R. Willoughby of the Disciples Divinity House.

Nelson Bengston, who helped to set up the payroll savings plan for War Bond purchases in lower New York State and who until recently was deputy State Administrator of the Treasury Department's War Finance Committee, has been appointed finance director of the National Citizens Political Action Committee, Sidney Hillman, chairman of the committee, announced yesterday.

With arraignment of four alleged counterfeiters of gasoline ration coupons, local Federal authorities announced yesterday that they had made the largest seizure of its type ever recorded in this area.

ROME, Sept. 4 (U.P.) -On the west coast American troops of the Fifth Army had reached points ten miles south of the Gothic Line anchorage north of Viareggio. The Americans were closing in on Lucca, capital of an ancient Italian State, and it was seen probable that the city would fall without heavy resistance.

"Wilson," Twentieth Century-Fox's film story of the first World War President, will start its sixth week at the Roxy tomorrow, thereby becoming the first screen attraction to play more than five weeks at the 5,886-seat house. With the beginning of the sixth week for "Wilson," the Roxy also marks the completion of seventeen and a half years of continuous operation.
DALLAS, Tex., Sept. 4 -- Neiman-Marcus Company predicted the ten best costumes of the year as edited under the eye of its fashion standards at its annual fashion exposition this evening.
The city of Florence is reported to have been mercilessly ravaged by the fleeing Nazis. Florence is identified, of course, with Niccolo Machiavelli (1469-1527) and Dante Alighieri (1265-1321).

To serve sixteen groups of cooperating retail grocers managing their own warehouses, a corporation will be formed at a meeting of a special committee of the New York State Food Merchants' Association, to be held Sept. 13 at the Hotel Pennsylvania, A.F. Guckenberger announced yesterday.

The Liberal party made public yesterday telegrams it had sent to President Roosevelt and to Governor Dewey urging them to use their influence with Congress to obtain immediate passage of a bill creating a permanent Fair Employment Practice Commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The appeal by Herbert H. Lehman, director general of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, for 15,000,000 pounds of clothing for distribution in the liberated countries of Europe has been taken up by churches, parishes and synagogues which will conduct a nation-wide collection campaign in the week of Sept. 24.

Eric Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, declares that "a super-social security system is already here" in an article defending all phases of insurance published in the Casualty and Surety Journal for October, issued today.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 4 (AP) -- With Slinging Sammy Baugh in fine form, the Washington Redskins broke a deadlock in the fourth quarter tonight to defeat the Green Bay Packers, 20 -- 7, in an exhibition game before 40,000 sweltering fans, including 18,000 service men.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in the Southwest Pacific, Tuesday, Sept. 5 -- Long range Army Liberators and Navy Catalinas have tightened what amounts to an air blockade on Mindanao, sinking or severely damaging twelve freighters Sunday and Saturday north and south of that key Philippines island.

In the United States and Canada people pay $1,716,000 every weekday, plus $3,160,000 every Sunday, for their newspapers, the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, tells retailers throughout both countries in a new series of mailing cards released today for member newspapers.

ST. LOUIS. Sept. 4 (AP) -- American skies in six years are expected to be filled with nearly half a million private planes, the Aero Medical Association of the United States was told today at the opening session of its annual meeting.

Assurances that there will be no layoffs in Navy Yards throughout the country after the defeat of Germany were given yesterday by Rear Admiral James M. Irish of the Executive Office of the Secretary of the Navy in reply to rumors that there would be a cutback in production for the Navy such as the Army has indicated for some of its procurement programs when hostilities in Europe end.
ROME, Sept. 4 (UP) -- A communique:

JERUSALEM, Aug. 21 -- Bible-lovers in the United States will no doubt be thrilled to know that preparatory work has begun on the Garden of the Prophets and Sages in the land of the prophets of old. This garden, unique of its kind throughout the world, will have all the flowers, plants, shrubs and foliage mentioned in the Scriptures, the books of the Talmud and Jewish literature.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 4 -- The Swedish Red Cross has completed arrangements for the exchange this week at Trelleborg and Gothenburg of 2,345 Allied war prisoners, including 239 Americans, for a similar number of German war prisoners.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Senators came to life with a sixteen-hit attack to beat the Red Sox, 9 -- 2, after losing by 11 -- 7 before a crowd of 9,206 today.

Before a record Aqueduct crowd of 50,159, and on the track's greatest betting day, Alex Barth drove hard through the stretch yesterday to victory over his opposition, and also over the jinx which has found him second in four $50,000 races during the last couple of months.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- National income reached a new high annual rate of $158,000,000,000 and national production a new high annual rate of $196,000,000,000 in the first half of 1944, the Department of Commerce announced today.
DETROIT, Sept. 4 -- The prepared text of Senator Truman's Labor Day speech here tonight before a group of American Federation of Labor leaders was as follows:

After speaking to many French sailors and civilians who had left France after the German occupation, I am inclined to think that the American attitude toward Marshal Petain is entirely at variance with the opinion held of him by many Frenchmen. Laval is damned unqualifiedly, but Petain is regarded as a true patriot who stood by his guns and did the best he could for France.

ROME, Sept. 4 -- French and American troops raced northward up both banks of the Saone River tonight in pursuit of German forces fleeing from the great French communications center of Lyon, in which the last enemy resistance had been stilled.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- With a promise of a "forthcoming intensification of operations in the Far East" American and British production officials reported today that the industrial capacities of this country and the British Empire have combined since "the black days after Dunkerque" to turn out supplies and weapons of war at the "prodigious rate" of nearly four times that of the Axis powers.
The following awards for valor were announced yesterday by the armed forces:

Expressing general agreement with the proposals that have been approved by the Dumbarton Oaks conferees, the Americans United for World Organization, Inc., urged yesterday that the United States delegates stand steadfastly for a democrative world organization in which the great powers will not dictate, but in which instant action can be taken when war threatens.

BOLBEC, France, Sept. 4 (U.P.) -- An undetermined number of flying bomb launching bases, some not yet completed and others long used in the Nazi robot offensive against England, have been captured in the British-Canadian thrust from Rouen to Dieppe and toward Le Havre.
