SUPREME HEADQUARTERS. Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Communique 149:

The nine-story and penthouse apartment building at 108-10 East Ninety-first Street, 54 by 100 feet, has been acquired by an investor through Farber-Wittman, brokers. The assessed valuation is $255,000.

PARIS, Sept. 4 -- Once again the legendary Paris taxis have come to the aid of an army. In 1914, when the Germans threatened at the Marne, thousands of taxis rushed troops to the front; today they are in the war again -- this time rushing American military personnel on official business in and around the city.

BERNE, Switzerland Sept. 4 (U.P.) -- Nazi authorities are hauling the grain, potatoes and vegetable harvests out of Alsace in full expectation that the Allied armies will arrive in a few days, while German SS patrols engage in a frantic hunt for Canadian parachutists reportedly, dropped in the Mulhouse area Friday night, reports from Basle said today.

Net profit of the Reynolds Spring Company for the nine months ended with June amounted to $315,736 after taxes and all charges, equal to $1.11 each on 284,300 common shares outstanding, the report disclosed today. In the comparable period of the previous year the profit was $240,734, or 83 cents each on 290,000 shares then outstanding.
LONDON, Sept. 4 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Bertin and recorded by The United Press:

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4 -- Protesting that they had "no heroes aboard," more than 300 members of the Second Marine Corps Division, veterans of Guadalcanal, Tarawa, Saipan and Tintan, were greeted on their return to the mainland today for thirty-day furloughs after two and a half years overseas.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, as president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, has added his voice to those who are advocating an amendment to the Federal Constitution to provide for ratification of treaties by a majority vote in each of the two houses of Congress instead of by a two-thirds vote of the Senate alone.

In the case of a lieutenant in the Army Air Corps stationed in New Guinea we are finding that it is necessary for six complete mail trips to be made before his final vote is received. Even with the best mailing facilities, from two to three weeks are required for each trip.

Closing a spectacular home stand with a dramatic flourish, the Yankees yesterday thundered into the lead in the American League's fantastic pennant race by crushing Connie Mack's sagging Athletics in both games of the holiday double-header at the Stadium while in distant St. Louis the stumbling Browns could do no better than break even with the Indians.

SOMEWHERE IN THE PACIFIC, Sept. 4 (UP) -- Forced to parachute 12,000 feet during a raid on a Japanese position in the Pacific, Ensign Donald C. Brandt, of Cincinnati, Ohio, saved his life by clinging to the periscope of a submerged United States submarine, which towed him two miles to safety, a delayed Marine Corps dispatch disclosed today.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 4 -- With labor, management and the Government cooperating, the end of the war will signal the start of the greatest period of prosperity in the nation's history, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, predicted today.

G. George Niebank, president of the Bank of Jamestown, Jamestown, N.Y., and president of the New York State Bankers Association, announced yesterday the appointment of committees for 1944-45, including two special committees named for terms of one year each to deal with problems arising out of the wartime economy.

Hoping to achieve a style of writing suggestive of the rhythm of modern jive and boogie-woogie, Alan Kapelner wrote a novel called "Lonely Boy Blues," to the accompaniment of scores of phonograph records. The book has nothing to do with music, but is a story of life in present-day New York.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 4 -- German troops have commenced the evacuation of southern Greece and the Aegean Islands and are gradually withdrawing their forces northward to Salonika, it was learned here today.

LONDON, Sept. 4 (U.P.) -- About 500 American heavy bombers attacked targets in northern Italy today but in western Europe rain and low clouds kept Allied air operations almost at zero, giving the fleeing German ground forces some respite.

SINCE William McFee retired from a long and highly successful career as a ship's engineer he has found time to write more than a score of books. Most of them have been novels with a seagoing background; and many of them have been told through the medium of a pivotal character talking at great length to a group of patient listeners.

Owners of 75.03 per cent of the shares of the Western Union Telegraph Company voted yesterday complete discretionary powers to the board of directors of the company as to the means of refunding $25,000,000 of 5 per cent bonds due in 1951, despite active opposition by a handful of stockholders to the issuance of convertible bonds.

It would be nice to come right out and say, "Well, this is that bluefish year you've been waiting for; go to it, boys," but sitting on a limb is risky business and so it is better to wait a while. However, a few items are offered as evidence, with conclusions left to those interested.

A Tokyo broadcast said yesterday that Japan's Munitions Ministry had effected two large-scale mergers of the country's synthetic oil producers to meet "a crying need for urgent action regarding the production of synthetic oil."

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The revitalized Japanese drive in Hunan Province, generally believed aimed at splitting China in two in preparation for the expected eventual American landings in eastern China, made further progress today.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday near the lows of the day at net losses of 11 to 15 points on active months.

Emphasizing the Republican determination to do everything in their power to win New York's forty-seven electoral votes, Republican State headquarters announced yesterday that Herbert Brownell Jr., the national chairman, would take part with Edwin F. Jaeckle, State chairman, and Thomas J. Curran, candidate for Senator, in a series of regional meetings with Republican county leaders starting next week.

The calendar for flotations of new corporate issues in the next few weeks continues to be augmented each day, and almost all the new material under way is scheduled to be sold in competitive bidding. Underwriting firms are experiencing the busiest period in many months as they appraise the markets and prepare bids for the forthcoming issues.

The sergeant pushed the button, the record changer moved and the music came out Bach, Karl Philipp Emanuel. Two hundred soldiers gathered yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Service Men's Center, 9312 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, sat back and listened contentedly as the first juke box for classical records flooded their ears with soothing melody.

Paul Whiteman, jazz band conductor, speaking at a luncheon yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria in connection with the thirteen contemporary composers' weekly concerts, "Music Out of the Blue," now being broadcast over the Blue Network under his direction, declared that the purpose of the series was to find another "Park Avenue Fantasy" or another "Rhapsody in Blue."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Senate and House conferees eliminated today from the bill for disposal of surplus war property provisions for giving medical and educational supplies and equipment to states, municipalities and tax-supported and non-profit institutions.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- For the third successive business day prices of leading grains went today to new low levels for the season. The only exception was September wheat, which was affected by liberal buying of cash wheat by the Commodity Credit Corporation.

Washington, Wednesday, Sept. 6 -- More than a million men will be discharged from the Army at the end of the European war, but the other 6,700,000 plus will be kept at their posts or will be employed in the war with Japan, it was learned this morning.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- A royal decree proclaiming a limited state of siege in the Netherlands, drawn up exactly a year ago to meet the present emergency, was signed by Queen Wilhelmina and made effective today. It provides for the administration of the country by Netherland military authorities responsible to the civil government.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 5 (UP) -- A parole for Samuel B. Crane, former major league baseball player whose perennial champion has been Connie Mack, manager of the Philadelphia Athletics, was approved today by Gov. Edward Martin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (U.P.) -- Representative Samuel A. Weiss (Democrat, Pennsylvania) protested in the House today against restrictions on attendance at the Army-Navy football game and said the decision to play it at Annapolis instead of a major metropolitan city "just doesn't make sense."

LONDON, Wednesday, Sept. 6 -- Russian troops, in the first major breakthrough on the Warsaw battle front, yesterday smashed about twenty miles through rapidly crumbling German defenses to reach positions north of the Polish capital, while Soviet forces in Rumania raced forward seventy-six miles to within fifty-two miles of Yugoslavia.

Ladenburg, Thalmann Co. and White, Weld Co. head a group of investment firms which will offer today 60,000 shares of Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company $5 cumulative prior preferred stock of no par value. The stock will be priced at $67.375 a share.

There is no conceivable turn that the war can take that will lessen the responsibilities of the American Red Cross during the coming year and in many respects these obligations will be heavier rather than lighter, Basil O'Connor, national chairman of the organization, said last night in a talk over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Unhappy in the strange surroundings of second place, the Browns are relying on the return of Bob Muncrief and an advantage in the stretch-drive schedule to put them back on top of the American League.
ROME, Sept. 5 (UP) -- A communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Wednesday, Sept. 6 (U.P.) -- Allied aircraft sank or damaged thirty-seven more Japanese barges and cargo vessels, including thirteen troop-laden barges and small craft, in attacks against the Philippines, Halmahera and the Netherlands Indies Sunday night and Monday, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

Sgt. Charles Robinson, a member of THE NEW YORK TIMES staff covering Police Headquarters for about seven years prior to his departure for the armed services on Feb. 17, 1943, has been missing in action since Aug. 21, according to word received from the War Department by his wife at their home at 2386 Walton Avenue, the Bronx.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- With Southpaw Hal Newhouser pitching a six-hit shut-out for his twenty-third victory, the Tigers gained a half-game on all pennant rivals tonight by beating the White Sox, 6 to 0. The victory moved Detroit within two games of the league-leading Yankees and within a game and a half of the second-place Browns.

ROME, Sept. 5 -- Great interest is taken in Allied circles here in the Pope's broadcast on the fifth anniversary of the war. Particular attention has been given to the concluding passages referring to world organization. The Pontiff has exchanged views with so many Allied leaders since Rome's liberation that it would not be surprising if his thought was colored by their ideas of the future.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- The exchange rate for Belgian currency in relation to the British pound sterling has been fixed at 176.50 Belgian francs to the pound, and from this it can be deduced that the provisional exchange rate between the Netherlands guilder and sterling will be 10.691 guilders to the pound.

Starting on his eighteenth consecutive year as Brooklyn College football coach, Lou Oshins, just returned from a good-will tour of Mexico, welcomed thirty enthusiastic candidates at the Kingsmen's opening practice session yesterday on the Flatbush gridiron.

Acting on further reports of black market operations in the building and building supply field, New York officials of the War Production Board announced last night that they were "out to stop" this bootleg activity as quickly as possible and were redoubling their efforts to clear up the situation.

The designers at Henri Bendel's dipped into history books and museums for some of the handsomest costumes seen in their collection for fall and winter. And to make them, they dipped into their stock of silk velvets, which must have come from shelves well-filled in pre-war days.

The report of the Burroughs Adding Machine Company, issued yesterday for the six months ended on June 30, shows a net income of $1,810,691, equal to 36 cents a share on 5,000,000 shares of capital stock outstanding. This compares with $1,784,913, or 35 cents a share, earned in the first half of 1943.

The Tokyo radio reported yesterday that Adolf Hitler had asked the Allies to stop bombing German cities and had threatened that if they do not accede to his request he would release a German secret weapon that "will utterly annihilate the Allies."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept 5 -- Ginger Rogers, Lana Turner, Walter Pidgeon and Van Johnson have been announced as the principal members of the cast for "Week-end at the Waldorf," the forthcoming Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer picture of "Grand Hotel" pattern which will have as its locale the Waldorf-Astoria, New York.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 5 -- War criminals and traitors will not receive asylum in Sweden, Gustav Moeller, Minister of Social Affairs, said today.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine has sent a confidential five-page order to all commanding officers in the Police Department giving instructions on the maintenance of order and the elimination of traffic hazards on V-day, it became known yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- A revolt by stockholders of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad was indicated today over reported plans of the road's directors at a meeting on Friday to elect Holly Stover of Washington, a coal man, president to succeed Charles T. O'Neal, who would be made chairman.

The stock market was thrown back yesterday for its sharpest reversal in about two weeks when selling on a fairly broad scale emerged in the final hour. This weakness when pressure centered mainly on the steels and aircrafts followed four hours of fairly steady prices, although it was evident that followers of the market had returned from the extended recess still in an uncertain mood.

Maj. Gen. Robert Courtney Davis, who had a soldier's burial at Arlington Cemetery yesterday, was not yet 68. Few men have worked harder or to better purpose. From West Point he passed through the grades to major general. He took part in the campaign against Santiago de Cuba, in the battle of El Caney, and in the Philippines in various engagements against the insurgents.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Medical schools and colleges should engage immediately in a recruiting campaign to get women students enrolled to help fill short classes, Dr. Martha Eliot, assistant chief of the Children's Bureau, urged today in an official statement.

Give a man a pile of logs, a sawbuck the right height, a sharp crosscut saw and a partner with a sense of rhythm in a strong right arm, and he can enjoy himself and cut a lot of fireplace wood. He can't keep it up all day, maybe, but he can keep at it quite a while if he has periodic pauses to puff his pipe and survey the results of his labor.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Admitting mistakes in German strategy with a frankness that seemed to indicate that the Wehrmacht has not yet been completely cowed by the Nazi party, Lieut. Gen. Kurt Dittmar told the German people over the radio tonight that "we are beaten by the weapons we have forged."

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, Sept. 6 -- Three Allied armies are deploying for an assault on the Siegfried Line. Karlsruhe, Stuttgart and Ludwigshafen, three of the principal communications centers behind that section of the line opposite the American Third Army were hammered yesterday by hundreds of heavy bombers of the American Eighth Air Force.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The condition statement of weekly member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 30, the Federal Reserve Board announced today: An increase of $697,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and a decrease of $683,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

LONDON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- With Red Armies driving toward the Hungarian plain along the mainline Bucharest-Budapest railway and newly at war with Bulgaria, Hungary's worried official reaction tonight, as filtered through Berlin, was determination "to fight on nevertheless" as a German ally.
LONDON, Sept. 5 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

CINCINNATI, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Two pitchers threw shut-out victories tonight to become twenty-game winners as the Cardinals and the Reds divided a twi-night double-header. Mort Cooper, aided by two home runs, took the first game, 4 to 0, and Bucky Walters, Cincinnati's dependable right-hander, hurled the second to give the Reds a 4-to-0 triumph.
LONDON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Department store sales in this city last week were 9 per cent above those in the corresponding week of 1943, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the week ended Aug. 26 the increase was 22 per cent over a year ago.

An unsigned wireless from Lublin, printed in your issue of Aug. 30, speaks of Colonel General Rola-Zymierski as "Supreme Commander of the Polish Army." Quite untrue. He is merely the head of Polish forces recruited in Russia, and financed and directed by Moscow as a divisive wedge against Poland's unity.
New Yorkers resignedly complied with blackout regulations last night, in another of the quarterly air raid drills ordered by the War Department last January.

Your editorial "The Maidanek Horror" seems a regrettable departure from THE TIMES' tradition. Usually you are an enviable example of lucidity and balanced judgment. But this editorial begs several questions which are still moot, and lumps together matters which have no common meaning.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Flying bombs sent over southern England early this morning broke an eighty-hour period of quiet. This afternoon the familiar phrase "London yesterday was again under V-I fire" reappeared in the German communique.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Americans have put aside $100,000,000,000 in savings in the last four and a half war years, from the end of 1939 to June, 1944, according to estimates released today by the Department of Commerce. One-half of this total was accumulated during the last eighteen months, the period when war production really went into high gear.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Jumping into an early lead, Hanid, a Donna Ray Stable's entry, today won the featured $2,000 Middletown Purse at Narragansett Park.

The post-war Federal tax plan for high employment proposed by the research committee of the Committee for Economic Development would in effect remove the corporation income tax, but one of the difficulties of administering the plan would be to prevent corporations from accumulating unneeded surpluses, Beardsley Ruml, a member of the research committee and treasurer of R.H. Macy Co., said yesterday at a press conference held in New York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Rodolfo Garcia Arias, Argentine charge d'affaires, said today that "versions or suppositions" that Argentina might become a refuge for German leaders after the war "are totally unfounded."

The publication date of "Hard Facts," the new novel by Howard Spring, who wrote "My Son, My Son!" has been postponed from Sept. 11 to some time in November, the Viking Press announces. The change was the result of the book's being named the December selection of the Literary Guild.

Perhaps it was an earthquake that jarred the town, but followers of the fortunes of the Yankees insisted all day yesterday that it was their favorites who had caused all the disturbance. Dissenters are respectfully referred to the Athletics.
HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 5 -- A Finnish peace delegation headed by Premier Antti Hackzell is expected to go to Moscow tomorrow.
OTTAWA, Sept. 5 -- The Canadian Cabinet met today in the first full meeting since the parliamentary session ended on Aug. 14.
KANDY, Ceylon, Sept. 5 (UP) -- A communique:
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Communique 150:

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Gen. Kazimierz Sosnkowski, chief of the armed forces of the Polish Government in Exile, who is already in the Russians' bad books, got himself into trouble with the British today by his order of the day deprecating the Allies' aid to the underground army of Warsaw.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 5 -- Continuing its series of precautionary measures of defense, made even more imperative by the Allies' further progress toward the Belfort gap, the Swiss Federal Council ordered increased mobilization of its first-line frontier troops today "in preparation for all eventualities."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- A rounded post-war tax program which proposes to overhaul the present Federal tax structure with the idea of dividing the burden about equally between business and individuals, and raising sufficient revenue to permit "significant Federal debt reduction" was presented today by the research committee of the Committee for Economic Development.

The apartment leasing situation in New York is tighter today than ever before in the history of realty statistics, with vacancies in modern buildings almost non-existent and with a number of would-be residents reported kept away from the city by inability to find suitable living quarters.
My attention was forcibly arrested by the timely and significant discussion in Topics of The Times of Aug. 30 anent the labeling as "psychoneurotic" of certain men rejected for military service.

Some retailers have found that under present conditions there is good opportunity to permanently develop apparel departments carrying size ranges that previously have had relatively little promotional significance, it is pointed out by the Industrial Council of the Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.

Twenty-seven hundred copies of a questionnaire designed to determine the attitude of Congressional candidates on United States foreign policy were sent yesterday to 435 Congressional districts by the Women's Action Committee for Victory and Lasting Peace.
MOSCOW, Sept. 5 -- The Soviet Government tonight declared war on Bulgaria.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The Women's Army Corps is spending $2,200,000 for recruiting advertising between July and Nov. 1.
LONDON, Sept. 5 -- The stock markets here were more active today, buyers being influenced by the continued good war news.
School officials expect a drop of 44,700 students in all branches of the system in the city, the Board of Education reported yesterday. The new school year will begin on Monday.

LONDON, Wednesday, Sept. 6 (U.P.) -- Two massive sweeps over Germany were carried out yesterday by the Eighth Air Force fighters that destroyed 143 German planes on the ground and twenty-eight in the air.

North American Aviation, Inc., in its annual report of operations covering the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, 1943, released today, shows consolidated sales increased to $509,139,649 from the 1942 volume of $253,226,119.

Eyes sparkling with curiosity and faces cheerful with the thought of living in a bomb-free America, sixty young attractive war brides, the largest number to be brought here from the British Isles, arrived yesterday afternoon on a Navy transport. Several hundred Navy personnel also were aboard.

An elaborate conspiracy to smuggle morphine and opium from the Bahama Islands into this country in a fleet of their own boats was charged yesterday to seventeen men who were named in a sealed indictment that was opened by Federal Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in the District Court in Brooklyn.

Election of Governor Dewey as President was urged last night by the Republican Governors of New Jersey, Michigan and Washington in a joint nation-wide radio broadcast.
ALBANY, Sept. 5 -- Members of a commission which is to make a study of medical care for those unable to provide it were announced today by Paul E. Lockwood, secretary to Governor Dewey.

The Regional Office of Price Administration announced yesterday that it had obtained injunctions against twenty-seven wholesale distributors in Manhattan and Brooklyn to roll back the price of soda pop and save consumers thousands of dollars.

Only one place in the world is fit for the new World League, now in preparation -- Geneva. None of the "Big Four" would give way to the other three, so only one of the small countries could be chosen for the League's seat.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 5 -- The decisions reached by the European Advisory Commission in London concerning the eventual armistice with Germany have been communicated to the French Provisional Government and to the seven other Governments directly interested in German affairs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Slashing all formalities, the War Department gave orders today for the seizure of the two strike-bound plants of the Cleveland Graphite Bronze Company under instructions from President Roosevelt.

Committees of laymen will be encouraged to help rehabilitate returning members of the armed forces in parishes of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, according to the Rev. Dr. Frederick R. Knubel, who yesterday succeeded the Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler as president.

The Distinguished Service Medal "for exceptionally meritorious service to the Government in a position of great responsibility" was presented yesterday to Maj. Gen Irving J. Phillipson, former commanding general of the Second Corps Area (now the Second Service Command) at a ceremony on Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island.

Because manufacturers of upholstered furniture are using the same men and machines for war work that they did for peacetime goods, the industry is in an excellent position to resume production when reconversion becomes an actuality, it was reported yesterday at a meeting of the Upholstered Furniture Manufacturers Association at the Biltmore Hotel.

Army and Navy officials yesterday warned householders that their failure to cooperate whole-heartedly with the city's fall paper salvage drive, just opened, can still delay victory for our armed forces, notwithstanding the great military successes being won presently in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Charges that the Office of Price Administration was used as an instrument by which the Rotary Club of Bernardsville, N.J., could pay off a grudge which some officers and members held against him, were made to a House committee here today by Benjamin Getzoff, a Bernardsville innkeeper, and former owner of one of the largest meat and grocery establishments in the township.

Finland's ordeal by fire is over, one hopes for all time. One may have the poorest opinion of the governmental folly that chose to side with Hitler when the choice had to be made; and which persisted in clinging to Hitler's coattails long after the masses of civilized mankind were arrayed on the other side.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 5 (U.P.) -- A Finnish communique charged today that Russian troops, in violation of an armistice agreement, had continued their attacks and carried out "infantry movements that were not clear in most sectors of the southern front until 8 A.M. today -- twenty-five hours after the Finns had, they said, ceased fire.

Coat of Arms and Fox Brownie won the feature races yesterday at Aqueduct, where there was a lull following the record-breaking totals of Labor Day. The attendance was 17,308 and the wagering $1,498,755.

The First National Bank of New York received yesterday the award of $950,000 of Buffalo (N.Y.) general improvement bonds on a bid of 100.032 for an 0.80 per cent interest rate. The bonds, dated Sept. 15, 1944, are to mature on Sept. 15, 1945 to 1949.

With official indication that the Provisional Government of liberated France will not sanction private trading until a new government is elected, "which may take fram six months to a year," foreign traders stated yesterday they feared a pattern of government monopoly over trade will be established for all liberated areas.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, it was learned today, has initiated an investigation to determine whether the Transamerica Corporation of San Francisco, through its control of the Axton-Fisher Tobacco Company, has engaged in fraudulent acts and practices prohibited by the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

As determined a little horror as has drifted to Broadway in quite a time bobbed up at the Barrymore last evening under the perhaps prophetic name of "Last Stop." It concerns the residents of an old ladies' home. Scratching into their lives for a macabre sort of comedy, which alternates with maudlin sentimentality, it succeeds in making very little sense.
LONDON, Sept. 5 (U.P.) -- An all-out offensive against German communication lines and supply routes throughout Yugoslavia was reported today by headquarters of Marshal Tito's Partisan forces.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The Navy stated today that only about one-half of the 18,000 pre-aviation students, now enrolled in colleges under the V-12 training program, will be chosen for aviation training.

"99 Park," headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc.,* offers a partial list of free amusements available today, through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A. M.; evening tickets after 4 P. M.
FOURTEENTH ARMY AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS in China, Sept. 5 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Another "great debate" on this country's participation in a League of Nations started in the Senate today. And, like that other fateful discussion twenty-five years ago, this one began with acrimonious charges and counter-charges that the executive branch of the Government was planning to throw away American sovereignty and assume the constitutional right of Congress to declare war.

The National-American Wholesale Grocers' Association will protest the latest effort by Price Administrator Chester Bowles to use United States Government grades as a basis for OPA ceiling prices on canned fruits and vegetables, it was learned yesterday.
LONDON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (U.P.) -- The manpower situation, far from being eased by production cutbacks, is so critical that 200,000 workers are needed to maintain the arms production asked by Gen. Dwight Eisenhower, Paul V. McNutt, head of the War Manpower Commission, declared tonight.

WITH THE HOME FLEET ABOARD A BRITISH AIRCRAFT CARRIER, off Norway (delayed) -- The Fleet Air Arm, in the words of a wing leader, "blasted hell out of the Tirpitz and all adjacent targets" in its latest attacks on the German battleship in her hideout in Alten Fjord, Norway.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Miss Margaret McCallum's consistent Reztips, who turned in a corking second to Brownie in Saturday's Princeton Handicap, won the feature Tioga Purse, an allowance dash of six furlongs that topped today's card at Garden State Park.

BRISSAGO, on the Swiss-Italo Border, Sept. 5 (U.P.) -- German commanders in northern Italy met secretly yesterday at the Villa Carbinati at Cernobbio and drafted plans for the German evacuation of the Italian Peninsula, a report from the Italian partisan station fat the frontier post of San Bartolomeo di Valmara said today.

ROME, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Canadian forces of the British Eighth Army dealt bluntly today with reinforced German armor that attempted to liquidate the Allies' bridgehead across the Conca River near Rimini, knocking out a score of enemy tanks and leaving the battlefield littered with German dead as they beat off a series of counter-attacks.

WITH AMERICAN THIRD ARMY, Advancing on Germany, Sept. 5 -- Bivouacked in many towns and fields where American and Allied troops fought in the closing months of World War I, the United States Third Army now is before the Moselle River.

Plans for new buildings to cost nearly $3,000,000 were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings in Manhattan. Some of these were post-war projects and others were designed to take advantage of present zoning rules in anticipation of approval by the city this fall of stricter site and height regulations.

Yesterday in Macy's grocery department, at the invitation of the demonstrator, we had our first taste of rice bonne. This is a dehydrated preparation manufactured by the Dry-Pack Corporation, which also makes some excellent dried soups that have been reported in this column.

Pershing Hall, headquarters of the American Legion in France, was undamaged in the invasion and the German evacuation, according to word received here yesterday by Jack S. Specter, special liaison officer for the Paris Post of the American Legion.

Real estate bond prices showed an average improvement in August for the twenty-sixth consecutive month, according to the Amott-Baker Realty Bond Price Averages. August's gain of 0.2 per cent, however, was considerably below the 1 per cent advance in July and the average monthly increase this years of 2.2 per cent, but it brought the year's gain to date to 17.6 percent.

Mauricio Hochschild, wealthy South American mine owner, who was kidnapped in Bolivia in July and held captive for seventeen days, declared here yesterday that he had never plotted against the current Bolivian regime and said he hoped to help Bolivia adjust its post-war social and economic problems.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull vigorously defended Robert Murphy and Samuel Reber today in an unusual statement that took cognizance of their criticism by "two or three editors." They have just been appointed political advisers to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Wednesday, Sept. 6 (UP) -- A communique:

Some of the gala atmosphere of former openings was apparent at Bergdorf Goodman's late yesterday afternoon at the semi-annual function at which clothes designed and made in its studios and workrooms are paraded before its president, Edwin Goodman, and the entire staff.

Rather than compete with an adverse set of notices, "Sleep No More" closed on Monday night at the Cort, after its seventh performance. It had opened last Thursday. The intake for the brief engagement of the "wacky new mirth-quake" was said to have been $2,500, against an estimated expenditure of $35,000 by the producer, Clyde Elliott.

The lady who has been superintendent of binding for the circulation department of the New York Public Library is taking a rest after thirty-six years with that institution. Through her initiative the Public Library, it is stated, became a pioneer in the use of bright colors for rebinding its books.
LONDON, Sept. 5 -- The first of what may be a series of premature reports of Germany's capitulation was broadcast this morning by the Brussels radio.

Lincoln is credited with the remark, "I have not made events; events have made me." Without the French Revolution, there would probably have been no Napoleon with imperial ambitions; and without the last war, Hitler would probably never have been heard of. This still leaves us wondering how leaders are chosen.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 5 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek summed up the present situation in China in a speech before the third plenary session of the Peoples Political Council in Chungking this morning.
Maxie Shapiro, 136 1/4, East Side, beat Lew Maxwell, 136 1/4, Newark, N. J., in the feature eight-round bout at the Queensboro Arena last night before 4,000 fans.

DENVER, Sept. 5 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt warned today that necessary readjustments of Federal personnel after the war "must not be used as a cloak to destroy vital public services developed through many years of painstaking care."
ROME, Sept. 5 -- Intense diplomatic activity is going on in the Vatican these days. It is giving rise to a renewed crop of reports of peace feelers and even efforts at capitulation.

American ship operators are maintaining a schedule of 1,400 "war cargo" sailings a month, or one every 30 minutes, the War Shipping Administration said yesterday, disclosing that almost 27,000,000 long tons of dry cargo have been shipped out of this country in the first six months of this year.

From Canada to Virginia the eastern seaboard shook early yesterday morning. Though this city was hardly aware of anything unusual there were tales of dishes that tumbled and pictures that swung. It was not a major quake -- merely "severe," in loose terminology.
Earth tremors that shook the eastern seaboard from Canada to Virginia at 12:39:01 A.M., eastern war time, yesterday centered about sixty miles southeast of Ottawa, Canada.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5 -- Wendell Willkie gave to the United Office and Professional Workers of America (CIO) today six suggestions for guarding and extending the rights of labor in the United states following the war.

The flying bomb or robot used against southern England is "Hitler's last and most dastardly attack," Lord Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, declared yesterday afternoon at a preview exhibit of the V-1 on the mezzanine of the International Building in Rockefeller Center.
Spencer Trask Co. made yesterday a successful special offering of 10,000 shares of Eastern Airlines, Inc., capital stock on the New York Stock Exchange at 39 7/8 with special commission of 60 cents.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 5 -- Foreign Minister Ezequiel Padilla today came out in support of a "world government" in which the great powers at first should have guarantees that their security did not depend on the will of the small nations.

An important addition to the Grand Central zone's business space appears to be in sight as the result of the purchase of the property adjoining the seventy-seven-story Chrysler Building on the east by the W.B. Chrysler Building Corporation, wholly owned by the estate of the late Walter P. Chrysler.
MARTINCOURT, France, Sept. 4 (Delayed) -- Have you ever seen a town murdered? This one was a few hours ago by German soldiers.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Another heavy air attack on the German battleship Tirpitz by British naval forces resulted in fighting off northern Norway in which nineteen German vessels were sunk or damaged, the Admiralty announced tonight.

In extending an official welcome to Cuba's President Elect, Dr. Ramon Grau San Martin, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday at City Hall that there can be "no quotas in a good neighbor policy." Speaking particularly of sugar, one of Cuba's principal crops, he hit directly at subsidization of America's sugar beet industry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The War Production Board announced another special program today to aid in the production of essential civilian wearing apparel made from cotton knit goods. Called "Knit Goods Program No. 4," the new project is aimed at assuring adequate production of fourteen items of civilian clothing in specified sizes.

PAWLING, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- Having completed eleven days of speech-writing at his Quaker Hill farm, Governor Dewey packed his bags tonight for a campaign tour which will cover 6,700 miles and take him into twenty-one States.

PARIS, Sept 5 (AP) -- Leon Rollin, director of the Agence Francaise de la Presse, born in the days of Paris' liberation, has advised Kent Cooper, executive director of The Associated Press, that the agency expects to become an independent national news agency modeled after the AP's precedent in cooperative gathering and dissemination of news.

Two new projects that the Near East Foundation has scheduled for the Balkan nations have received the "blessing" of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration and will begin as soon as the war permits the UNRRA to enter the area, it was disclosed yesterday by Edward C. Miller, executive secretary of the foundation.

THE photographers swarmed into the Yankee dressing room after the Labor Day double-header which had seen the New Yorkers vault blithely over the Browns into first place in the sizzling American League pennant race.

LONDON, Wednesday, Sept. 6 -- The United States Eighth Air Force struck yesterday the first of tremendous air blows the Allied Supreme Command is ready to throw into support of the land battle for Germany.

Eighty-nine cases of poliomyelitis were reported in the city during the three-day week-end from Saturday through Monday, it was announced yesterday by the Department of Health. On the preceding two-day week-end -- Saturday and Sunday -- sixty-three cases had been reported.

ROME, Sept. 5 -- The Catholic Communist movement, which has aroused much controversy among Catholics, even to the point of condemnation by the Pope and the Vatican organ, the Osservatore Romano, changed its name today to the party of the Christian Left.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Charges that for personal reasons of friendship and mutual interest in "independent" broadcasting, James Lawrence Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, furthered the sale of a radio station in Florida to the disadvantage of the owner and the profit of the purchaser, were made today before the Special House Committee investigating the commission, and were denied by Mr. Fly.

ELIZABETHTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, told a gathering in this picturesque Adirondack community tonight that the American way of life was threatened unless Thomas E. Dewey was elected President and candidates like himself were sent to the Senate.

This is to express strong approval of the editorial "The Soldier's Ballot" in THE TIMES of Aug. 29. This and previous editorials on the same subject have pointed out clearly the injustice being done by Mr. Dewey to members of the armed forces, the merchant marine, the Red Cross and other war organizations.

"Double Indemnity," a melodrama starring Fred MacMurray, Barbara Stanwyck and Edward G. Robinson, will have its local premiere this morning at the Paramount. Jean Heather and Tom Powers appear in supporting roles in, the Paramount picture, which was directed by Billy Wilder.
The attitude of the French resistance movements toward Gen. Charles de Gaulle will probably condition the whole political future of France.

A spokesman for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower instructed foreign workers in Germany yesterday to desert their jobs at the first opportunity and almost simultaneously the Soviet-sponsored Free Germany National Committee called for a general strike in the German armaments industry.

Mayor La Guardia opened yesterday John Wanamaker's new branch for men, The London Shop, at 59 Liberty Street, in a brief ceremony before company officers and staff members by cutting a ribbon. The store, housed in the street floor level and basement in the building of the New York State Chamber of Commerce, was at one time the site of a bank.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Sweeping plans for shifting industry from war to civilian output when Germany falls with "immediate and drastic" elimination of virtually all controls from all but military production needed to defeat Japan were announced by the War Production Board tonight with the unanimous approval of the Army, Navy and other major war agencies.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the Associated Electric Company's sale of the properties of the Missouri Southern Public Service Company to the New-Mac Electric Cooperative, Inc., for $170,000 cash.

The liberation of Europe marches so swiftly that the communiques, dictated by an understandable military caution, do not keep up with the facts. Under the circumstances it is natural that the public should be impatient and that its hopes and wishful thinking should race ahead of the fastest-moving armored columns.

WASHINGTON, Sept 5 -- The country's aircraft plants, geared for still mightier offensives against Germany and Japan, have turned out about 1,500 heavy, four-motored bombers a month since the end of June, bringing the total to an estimated 15,000 produced in the last twelve months, the War Production Board revealed today.

Shirt manufacturers and makers of other cotton garments, are wondering why there is a disappearance of staple cotton goods after production, "which usually reappears only on offers of black market premiums," according to Max J. Lovell, counsel and director of the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers, who declared yesterday that a Congressional investigation of the problem is called for to assure the public larger quantities of moderately priced garments.
LONDON, Sept. 6 -- The long-awaited plan for the demobilization of the British armed forces is expected to be among the first pronouncements of the Government when Parliament reconvenes on Sept. 26.
Large apartment houses on and near Park Avenue were among East Side properties reported in new ownership yesterday.

In the War Department's announcement yesterday of its plan for "a partial and orderly demobilization" of the Army following the defeat of Germany, however near at hand or still distant that event may be, there is no comfort for Japan. To be sure, some troops now in the European zone will at once be designated "surplus."

WASHINGTON, Sept 6 -- As Allied armies were pushing toward the portals of Nazi Germany, President Roosevelt today summoned three important members of his Cabinet to the White House for a conference that was believed to be related to the military occupation of Germany.
LONDON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Bulgaria, frantically4truggling to' get out of the war, seemed on the edge of an internal upheaval as the Moscow radio urged the population to "take fate in your own hands."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The three-cornered debate in the Senate yesterday over the powers of the American representative in the Council of the proposed World Security League threw an interesting and important light on one highly controversial detail of the Administration's plan for the organization of that League.

To counteract a little-publicized rider to the Surplus Disposal Bill which would set up a two-price system for cotton exports, the Cotton-Textile Institute of New York, Inc., has submitted to the conference committee which now has the bill, a set of amendments for control of imports of foreign made goods and export of raw cotton and finished textiles, it was learned in the trade yesterday.

One year of universal military training after this war has been suggested. I cannot see the necessity for such a long period, since many soldiers were sent into combat in this war after only thirteen weeks of training, and some after only six weeks.

An underwriting group headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co. will offer today $65,000,000 first mortgage twenty-year 3 1/4 per cent bonds, series E, of Armour Co. The bonds, dated Sept. 1, 1944, will be priced to the public at 102 1/4 per cent and accrued interest.

LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 7 (UP) -- Royal Air Force heavy bombers smashed heavily by daylight late yesterday at Emden, nearest haven for German vessels attempting to flee the French Channel ports, and American fighters shot up and wrecked a Nazi transport in western Germany.

MALONE, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- Continuing his campaign swing, Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, asserted here today that organized labor had as great a stake in the outcome of the November election as any other group in the country.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Automobiles for civilians within three months after Germany is beaten was held out today by J.A. Krug, acting chairman of the War Production Board as a distinct probability under the reconversion plans announced by the WPB last night.

Antwerp is one of the shining Allied prizes of the war. The Belgian port on the Scheldt is worth more in terms of supply for the assault on Germany than perhaps any other city we have taken. It is some 200 miles nearer the German frontier than Cherbourg, the one open port on which we have chiefly depended in the Battle of France, and ten times as large.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- A mission headed by Laurence Duggan will be Sent to Brazil by the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration to discuss Brazil's active participation in the world-wide war relief program, it was announced today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 6 -- A swift junction between Marshal Tito and Red armies, advancing from Craiova in Rumania past Turnu Severin into northeastern Yugoslavia and across Bulgaria into Macedonia and the Morava Valley is anticipated. Marshal Tito's Partisan units have been slowly penetrating eastward in Yugoslavia, fighting Chetniks, Bulgarians and Germans.

During the five-year war period, Jews in 4,200 communities throughout the nation have contributed $82,000,000 to the United Jewish Appeal for Refugees, Overseas Needs and Palestine to save Jews in Europe, it was announced yesterday.

DETROIT, Sept. 6 -- Michigan, with its nineteen electoral votes, promises at this time to become one of the major battlegrounds in the Presidential campaign, largely because of the determined effort of the CIO Political Action Committee to register and turn to the Roosevelt-Truman ticket the large migrant war-worker vote, estimated at more than 400,000 in Detroit and 500,000 in the State as a whole.
MOSCOW, Sept. 6 -- The magazine War and the Working Class today published an article entitled "Japanese Notes," by Grigori Ivanoff, in which there are two interesting items:

Importers who had planned to broaden their activities as soon as shipping and overseas market conditions permitted, have found it possible to carry new commodities due to limitations of the War Production Board's import control order M-63, traders reported yesterday.

ROME, Sept. 6 -- The gravity of the food and health situation in Italy convinces many of the Allies' officials here that a revision in the program and administration of relief is urgently necessary. They argue that, if large-scale rioting and social disintegration occur in the first country placed under Anglo-American control, the blow to the democracies' prestige would have repercussions throughout Europe.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 6 (AP) -The United States Naval Academy announced today that it would follow the four-year competition ruling of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, thereby making half a dozen Navy stars eligible for another season on an already well stocked football powerhouse.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 6 -- With total defeat moving upon Hitler's Fortress Germania, the latent uprising of some 12,000,000 foreign workers in the Reich may have already begun, some German reports tonight indicated.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- A majority of the representatives of various counties and sportsmen's organizations in New York State were in favor of doing something about the pheasant season, either curtailing it or reducing the bag limit, at a public hearing held in the Assembly chambers today by the State Conservation Department.
The Police Athletic League provided a special holiday for the youth of the city at Coney Island yesterday, celebrating the fourteen- year-old organization's "Annual Day."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Seventeen items were eliminated today from the list of rationed processed foods under the announced policy of the Government to lift wartime restrictions as quickly as possible.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Britain's blackout, generally agreed to be the most depressing of her many wartime restrictions and a cause of many accidents, is to be almost banished on Sept. 17, when double summer time ends, it was disclosed today.

The Office of War Information says that service men overseas enjoy receiving Christmas gifts of candy, which prompts us to suggest sending some home-made varieties of the kind that will stay fresh under all sorts of conditions. Such old favorites as fudge and penuche will not fill the bill; rather we recommend Christmas nougat, vanilla caramels, uncooked fruit and nut confections, and chocolate creams.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The Army made public today its "just and impartial" plan for demobilizing more than 1,000,000 soldiers when Germany is defeated, but simultaneously Secretary Forrestal announced that the Navy was expanding and could not demobilize until Japan fell.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Operating business machines will probably be the best post-war opportunity for many women now on the assembly lines, according to Ford T. Shepherd, executive assistant for management of the Management-Labor Policy Committee of the War Manpower Commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The prosecution moved forward slightly in the mass sedition trial today when it put before the jury the testimony of Mrs. Bonnie Jane McLaughlin that she attended eleven meetings of the "Friends of Progress" in Los Angeles between November, 1941, and March, 1942, and heard three of the defendants assail Jews and Communists.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- While the Polish Government in Exile was trying today to make its peace with Russia, a group of sixteen Polish private citizens, including the widow of Gen. Wladislaw Sikorski, former Premier of the exiled Government, circulated reports that the Red Army was disarming and in some instances interning the Polish underground forces in liberated territory that the Russians acknowledged to be Polish.

The Office of Price Administration's investigation into rising prices of cigars and the appearance on cigar stands of some new brands in alleged circumvention of price control was endorsed yesterday by the Cigar Manufacturers Association of America, Inc.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 -- Modification of sentence for five northern Negro soldiers, formerly stationed at Dale Mabry Field, Fla., and now in the Tallahassee Federal Correction Institution for "joining a mutiny, failure to suppress a mutiny and assault on a non-commissioned officer," was disclosed today by David Levinson, civil liberties lawyer and counsel for the five men.
Lynette Perfumes, Inc., to the M.H. Hackett Company.

"Meet the People," which arrives at Loew's State, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The musical comedy, which was produced by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, stars Lucille Ball and Dick Powell, and includes Bert Lahr, June Allyson, Rags Ragland, Virginia O'Brien and Vaughn Monroe and Spike Jones and their bands among its supporting players.

Your columns are customarily so judicial that it was a shock to read on the front page of THE TIMES this morning the headline "Americans Destroy Army That Set Out to Rule the World." This is unfair both to the British forces, which, as General Eisenhower recently pointed out, faced the heaviest German armor, and to the people of London who after years of fortitude and endurance are still in the front line.

The belief that after the war "people in the whole world are going to get freedom and democracy such as they have never had before" was expressed yesterday by Dr. Ramon Grau San Martin, President Elect of Cuba, at a luncheon given in his honor at the Union Club, Park Avenue and Sixty-ninth Street, by Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corl0oration.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 6 (AP) -- An order sought by the Securities and Exchange Commission, directing the Axton-Fisher Tobacco Company to produce its records and documents since Jan. 1, 1941, has been entered in Federal District Court here.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Sept. 6 -- Despite Germany's disaster, Japan has not yet put out any peace feelers and there is reason to believe the Japanese Government hopes for a diplomatic victory that will prevent the total defeat that it is now obvious her arms cannot prevent in the long run.

Security and commodity markets throughout the country suffered severe inroads yesterday as a result of broad and intense liquidation. Prices on the stock markets were thrown hack from 1 to 3 points and the averages returned to the levels of early June in the worst crack-up since early last November, while some of the grains in Chicago retreated the limit permitted for a single session.
PEARL HARBOR. Sept. 6 -- One of the Navy's favorite institutions, the Officers Club, has disappeared from the Pacific in accordance with an order from the Bureau of Personnel in Washington.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, Sept. 7 -- Mud-stained infantrymen of the American Third Army have fought their way across the Moselle River in face of fierce German fire to strike the first blow in the assault on Germany.

LONDON, Sept 6 (U.P.) -- Hungary announced tonight that she had opened hostilities against Rumania and that the Hungarian Home Army had received orders to defend the Transylvania frontier on which Russian troops, supported by Rumanians, are poised.

Danger lurked along the speedway -- a roped-off section of East Sixteenth Street between Avenue A and Avenue B. For the winners of events in the "Anything on Wheels Derby" there were war stamps. But for the losers there was nothing but skinned knees and knuckles, bruises and bumps.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 6 (UP) -- Donald M. Nelson and Maj. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley, on a special mission for President Roosevelt, arrived at a Chungking airport today. They will be received by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- President Roosevelt moved to end a fourteen-month-old labor dispute today by directing the War Department to seize two plants of the Hughes Tool Company, in Houston, Tex., makers of oil field machinery.

OTTAWA, Sept. 6 -- The largest convoy ever to set sail, with more than 1,000,000 tons of cargo, crossed the Atlantic and arrived at British ports shortly after D-day, making a "safe and timely delivery which reflected great credit on all those concerned," according to the British Admiralty, it was announced here today.

With the increased tempo in the European war pointing to a quick military victory, a change in the availability of yarn supplies is imminent, according to yarn merchants in Worth Street yesterday. Cotton textile goods for civilians would be benefited immediately by this change, it was indicated.

WITH AMERICAN FIRST ARMY TROOPS on the Road to Germany, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Doughboys have breached the enemy's defenses before the border of the Reich, and tonight it can be said that the battle for Germany has begun.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Japan's air forces will be tougher to handle in the coming phases of the Pacific war, Navy Secretary James V. Forrestal said today, because they are now concentrated and the Japanese have improved the quality of their planes.
LONDON, Sept. 6 (U.P.) -- Diamond experts predicted today that reopening of the huge Antwerp jewel market within possibly three months would lower the price of all diamonds.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Thursday, Sept. 7 (AP) -- A communique:

ROME, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Rimini is at the Adriatic terminus of a P. Valley highway that runs northwest through Bologna into the heart of the northern Italian industrial regions. Lucca, captured by American patrols in the Fifth Army's thrust near the western end of the line, is an important communications center with a normal population of 82,000.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Roger Cramer, 38-year-old veteran of sixteen major league seasons, continued his batting spree by hitting a triple and a single tonight to lead Detroit to a 3-to-2 victory over the White Sox.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 6 -- Frank J. Murray of Orange, special investigator for Gov. Walter E. Edge into charges against four members of the State Board of Tax Appeals, opened today a public hearing at which alleged discrepancies in board-approved valuations on similar properties in Hoboken were introduced in evidence.

After a day marked by injuries to two jockeys -- Howard Cruz, who went down in a hurdles spill that caused his mount, Navarin, to be destroyed, and Conn McCreary -- the crowd of 19,202 that attended yesterday's racing at Aqueduct saw the Brookmeade Stable's Sun Herod, ably ridden by Bobby Merritt, race to a length triumph in the thirty-fifth Babylon Handicap.
Fira Benenson's collection, in which crepes and satins are used lavishly, was shown yesterday in the Salon de Couture at Bonwit Teller's.

ALBANY, Sept. 6 -- Supreme Court Justice Francis Bergan dismissed today the petition of John J. O'Connor, former Representative, who sought to have the Presidential nominations of the American Labor party ruled off the ballot.

Fact was once more imitating fiction when the father and sisters of Russ Columbo succeeded in keeping the young man's death a secret from his mother over a period of ten years till the very end of her own life.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Dealings in most sections of today's stock markets were on the quiet side. Kaffirs, however, again provided a good feature. Buying from the Cape continued and prices advanced, Blyvoor reaching a new high and the shares of smaller companies also receiving attention.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Delegates at the "Washington Conversations on International Organization" appear to be coming to the conclusion that America's role in keeping the peace will be determined not at Dumbarton Oaks on the Georgetown hill but in the United States Senate on Capitol Hill.

ROME, Sept. 6 -- As the Allies gradually break their way through to the Po Valley preparatory to the final drive to clear Italy of the Germans, urgent calls are being issued by the Allies and the Italian leaders for a final intensification of the resistance movement.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Loss in action of the submarine Robalo, commanded by Lieut. Comdr. Manning Marius Kimmel, son of Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel, was reported by the Navy today.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND, Kandy, Ceylon, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Allied patrols probing far below captured Mogaung in north Burma are heading steadily toward Hopin and reorganized Japanese defenses along the Myitkyina-Mandalay railway, a headquarters communique said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- A Pacific Fleet announcement:

LONDON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- No peace plea has yet been made to the United Nations by Germany, a spokesman for the British Government stated emphatically tonight. He made the statement, he said, to dispose of recurrent rumors that Germany has been seeking opportunities to open talks with the Allies.

A man of mellow culture and a skeptical turn of mind, he sits in his editorial eyrie behind a stack of World Almanacs that must be at least seven feet high by this time.

A tentative schedule of offerings of new securities, subject of course to last-minute changes, concentrates sales in competitive bidding of no less than seven major corporate issues on two days this month. Underwriters are preparing to bid on some $138,000,000 in new issues on Sept. 18, consisting of $42,000,000 of Brooklyn Union Gas Securities; $55,000,000 of Oregon-Washington Railway, $31,500,000 of Narragansett Electric and $10,000,000 of Birmingham Electric.

The first newsreel films of the actual liberation of Paris will be shown in local theatres today, with all of the five major companies devoting the whole of their biweekly releases to the subject. The films, which were made by service photographers and by a civilian newsreel camera man who was in Paris with the resistance forces before their liberation, arrived in this country last week-end.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 6 (AP) -The Newark Bears tightened the International League pennant race tonight by whipping the Jersey City Giants, 8 to-l, whilethe pacesetting Orioles lost to Syracuse in the opener of a twin bill in which the nightcap was washed out.

SOUTHERN FRANCE, Aug. 30 (Delayed) (AP) -- In the tiny town of Tanaron shortly after dawn on Aug. 15, southern France's D-day, a parachute sergeant was in a bad fix. He and fifteen men had been dropped ten miles from their assigned landing zone, cut off and surrounded.
Police Sergeant John Anderson was behind the desk at the Bergen Street Station at 10:30 A.M. yesterday when an elderly man entered, and said: "I couldn't keep this, my conscience would bother me."

War ballots were mailed yesterday to 16,800 members of the armed forces from Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx as the New York City Board of Elections began the task of getting ballots to service personnel who request them. As of yesterday 298,000 applications had been received at the board's offices, 400 Broome Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- A post-war program under which Federal assistance would be given to all families with incomes below $1,500 to assure adequate diets and clothing, has been put before the agricultural subcommittee of the House Special Committee on Post-War Economic Policy and Planning, by Claude R. Wickard, Secretary of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- An estimate of 3,500,000 to 4,000,000 workers to be laid off in industries in thirty days after the day of German's surrender has been prepared by the War Manpower Commission, it was reported today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved lower yesterday in sympathy with grains and stocks, and final prices were 6 to 14 points net lower on the day.

"Industry is to be allowed in its own way, according to the availability of markets, men, materials and plants, to do the swiftest and most effective job possible of restoring production, making whatever people want and affording maximum employment, just as quickly as possible."

HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 6 -- The Finnish peace delegates headed by Premier Anth V. Hackzell are leaving Helsinki at 11:30 o'clock tonight for Moscow. They will go by train to the Russian border, by automobile from there to Leningrad and then by plane to Moscow.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 6 -- In a broadcast address to the Argentine nation tonight President Edelmiro Farrell asserted that, in the present state of affairs the armed forces would remain the instrument and executor of the Government's revolutionary program.

The board of directors of the Western Union Telegraph Company voted on Tuesday afternoon to direct officers of the company to formulate a plan to invite competitive bids for the refunding of $25,000,000 of 5 per cent bonds due in 1951, the company announced yesterday.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 6 -- A new process in the manufacture of synthetic rubber whereby the capacity of the country's synthetic rubber plants could be increased by 40 per cent, adding about 400,000 long tons of rubber annually to the national production, was announced today by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company.
Governor Dewey leaves New York City today on his first formal campaign trip.

The eleven-story loft building on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 109 West Twenty-sixth Street has been sold by Sidney Kreitman to a syndicate represented by Glekel Drimmer, attorneys. It is assessed at $135,000 and was bought for cash over a first mortgage of $121,000 held by the Bowery Savings Bank, Nehring Brothers were the brokers and Norman Siegel was the attorney for the seller.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (U.P.) -- To each of five political parties eligible to use Army short-wave radio facilities for rebroadcast of political speeches to troops overseas will be allotted two half-hour and three quarter-hour periods for such purposes, it was revealed tonight.

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 6 (AP) -- American warplanes slashed anew into the island stepping stones south of Japan and made their first attack since May 19 on Marcus Island, 1,200 miles southeast of Tokyo, in widespread actions announced today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -On direction of President Roosevelt, the Interior Department took possession tonight of fifteen more bituminous coal mines tied up by strikes of supervisory employes.
PARIS, Sept. 6 -- Visitors newly arrived in Paris from London are shocked at first by the grip that the black market has on this city.

Openings of men's wear woolen and worsted lines for the spring 1945 season will be along more informal lines than at any time during the war period, mill executives said yesterday, with strict allotments to be made, particularly on worsteds.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- D.V. McClure's Gold Princess, a 5-year-old mare who carried 110 pounds, today scored a major surprise by winning the $17,100 Modesty Handicap, feature of the next-to-last day of the Washington Park race meeting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The Department of Justice has been preparing an anti-trust proceeding against certain New York investment banking firms for alleged restraint of trade, but the suit is not expected to be instituted before Election Day.

Officials of Local 153 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, American Federation of Labor, promised the regional War Labor Board at a hearing here yesterday that they would urge ninety striking plaform workers of the Hoffman Beverage Company in Newark, N.J., to return to work today pending the board's reconsideration of a recent decision denying a wage increase.

Sweden joins Switzerland in announcing that right of asylum will not be given those war leaders "who by their actions have defied the conscience of the civilized world or betrayed their own countries." In the same week the Spanish Ambassador to Washington and the Argentine Charge d'Affaires there denied reports that asylum was being prepared in their respective countries or would be given the bloody-handed Nazi and Fascist leaders and their collaborators.

The embarrassing situation in which Franco's militarist and dictatorial regime now finds itself has made it necessary for his Ambassador in Washington. Senor Cardenas, to do some explaining. According to him, Franco's regime has nothing in common with National Socialism, "which is condemned by the church, while Spain's own regime is essentially based on Christian principles."

ALBANY, Sept. 6 -- Interest on bonds of the State Dormitory Authority is exempt from Federal income taxation, Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein ruled today in a formal opinion for the State Education Department. The authority was created this year to provide housing for students at State colleges for teachers.

Indications that purchasing commissions of the Soviet Union are preparing for a possible curtailment in the number of items made available to them under lend-lease arrangements and a consequent increase in cash purchases were reported yesterday by exporters attending a meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The dissemination of horse racing information is not essential to the winning of the war, the Office of Price Information ruled yesterday in denying the appeal of a Brooklyn distributor of "dope sheets" from his local rationing board's refusal to grant him a C gasoline ration.
CHUANGKING, China, Sept. 6 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Force communique:

A minister's wife who is the only Wac chaplain's aide in the Second Service Command, Private Helen Laky of Fort Monmouth, N.J., was chosen Wac of the Month yesterday. At the public relations office of the command, 90 Church Street, she told how she helps service personnel from her experiences in the first World War, when she was an interpreter and translator.

PARIS, Sept. 6 -- Representative Frances Bolton, Republican, of Ohio, who has arrived in Paris after a tour of army hospitals in France, said tonight that she had one message to carry back to the American people as a result of her trip: that they must donate more fresh blood.

MOSELLE VALLEY, France, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Making their first real stand since the Allied breakthrough in Normandy, the Germans engaged the United States Third Army tonight in some of the heaviest fighting of its drive across France.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The resignation of L.R. Boulware, Vice Chairman of the Office of Operations in the War Production Board, was accepted "with great reluctance" by WPB Acting Chairman J.A. Krug today, who straightway reappointed Hiland G. Batcheller, himself a former WPB official and Mr. Boulware's predecessor.
CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Bellwether made a showing of his opposition to win the featured Knotts Purse at Garden State Park before 12,850 today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 (AP) -Ike Williams of Trenton, N.J., won a 10-round split decision tonight over Sammy Angott of Washington, Pa., former National Boxing Association lightweight king, in a punch-packed bout before 11,568 fans at Shine Park.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Kiyang, guarding the route to the Lingling airbase near the southern Hunan Province border, has fallen to the swift new Japanese drive, the Chinese High Command announced tonight. The new enemy attempt to split China apparently was in full swing.
ROME, Sept. 6 (UP) -- A co,r;uniqud: 'r

AN AMERICAN HOSPITAL, in England, Sept. 6 -- The Americans are inching forward toward Brest in one of the bit terest battles of the war in France. Deeply entrenched and ordered to hold "at all costs," a conglomerate force of infantry, parachutists, marines, sailors, German port officials and artillerymen is clinging tenaciously to the last big German stronghold in France.

A consolidated net income of $4,984,895 for the six months ended on June 30 is reported by the Greyhound Corporation in its semi-annual statement, released today. The income, which after all charges and Federal taxes, is equal to $1.76 a share on the 2,784,395 shares of common stock outstanding.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Within the past forty hours arms have been sent from the Soviet Union to the Slovak patriots who are holding escape routes through their country against four German divisions, and British and American help has been promised them, it was announced here today by Jan Masaryk, Czechoslovak Deputy Prime Minister.

CHICAGO, Sept 6 (U.P.) - President William Harridge of the American League predicted tonight that almost 100 per cent of the circuit's players currently in the service would doff their uniforms and resume their pre-war stardom once hostilities ceased.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Governor Dewey and Secretary Hull expressed gratification over the conversations on peace last month between Mr. Hull and John Foster Dulles, Governor Dewey's representative, in an exchange of letters made public by the State Department tonight.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES in the Moselle Valley, Sept. 6 (U.P.) -- When dawn broke this morning after a night battle across the Moselle, both sides still were firing heavily, but the Americans could not take their gaze off a dam across the river just left of the center of Pont-a-Mousson.

LONDON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Counting on a speedy liberation of the Netherlands by Allied armies, the Netherlands Government in Exile officially took leave of Britain today before returning to the homeland.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Gov. Coke Stevenson of Texas conferred for an hour today with President Roosevelt and then met Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic national chairman, for talks which were potentially of political significance.

The story in your issue of Sept. 2, about Mr. Willkie's fight with Newton Baker for a straight-out platform endorsement of the League of Nations at the Democratic convention in 1924, must stir painful memories in all who, like myself, watched that fight sympathetically from a distance, and who agree with Mr. Willkie that Mr. Baker's speech on that occasion is one of the great orations in American history.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Thursday, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Navy Catalina planes sank three small Japanese freighters off Mindanao, southern Philippines, Monday night and Tuesday morning, headquarters announced today.

Diners who make a practice of poring over the menu before ordering their meals may have to forego that pleasure for a while, it was disclosed yesterday, as employes of twelve New York menu printing concerns went on strike.

Social equality "is what you have among friends" and cannot be made a matter of legislation as can citizenship rights, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared yesterday in discussing a letter she wrote to Mrs. Catherine Stallworth of Evergreen, Ala., in which she was quoted as denying that she advocated social equality between Negroes and whites.

LUBLIN, Poland, Sept. 5 (Jewish Telegraph Agency) -- A Jewish relief committee to organize aid for all surviving Jews in the liberated part of Poland has been established here. It is headed by Dr. Shloima Herszenhorn, who is also the head of the Jewish department at the Polish Committee for National Liberation.

HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 6 -- Betty Field has been signed by David Loew for the lead of "Hold Autumn in Your Hand," which goes into production tomorrow for United Artists with Jean Renoir directing. Miss Field replaces Frances Dee, who withdrew from the cast after her husband, Joel McCrea, was supplanted by Zachary Scott.

LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 7 -- The Red Army has smashed across the Danube into Yugoslavia to join with the Yugoslav Partisans, Marshal Tito's radio station broadcast early today shortly after the nightly Russian communique had announced the capture of Turnu Severin, on the Rumanian bank of the river.

American Red Cross headquarters here and in Washington denied yesterday the rumor that delivery of prisoner of war packages to American prisoners of war in German camps had been stopped. In Washington it was said that no word had been received either directly through the International Red Cross or indirectly that "temporary shipments are held up," as reported in a Swiss broadcast recorded by the Columbia Broadcasting System.
A communique, as broadcast in English to North America from Chungking and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

BEAR Mountain, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- Following 'a strenuous double workout for the New York Football Giants today at the Interstate Park Coach Steve Owen revealed the probable "varsity" team that will play a No. 2 squad Friday noon at Camp Shanks.
LONDON, Sept. 6 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
The Sofia, Bulgaria, radio announced last night that all German troops in Bulgaria had been interned.

ROME, Sept. 6 -- French troops pursuing German forces trying to escape from southern France have swept through Chalon-sur-Saone and tonight they were believed to be approaching the communications center of Dijon, thirty-eight miles north.

The research committee of the Committee for Economic Development, a private organization composed mainly of leaders in business and industry, has brought forward a proposed postwar tax plan that deserves the most serious study. In many ways it is an outstanding contribution to the subject.

As a result of the growing scarcity of apartments in New York and increasing numbers of calls for help from prospective tenants, a city-wide system of housing assistance probably will be set up soon as a unique addition to municipal service, it became known last night.
