SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 6 -- The coming Allied assault on the Siegfried Line, Germany's last formidable defense system in the west, will be a stiffer and longer battle than those of the last three weeks, although there is no doubt that the enemy position can and will be broken.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- As the Army announced the methods it would use in demobilizing part of its strength after Germany is defeated, there were indications to day that the number of men released immediately would be small.

Milgrim's new custom-made collection, which was displayed yesterday, lays its strongest accent on the tunic. It was seen in two- piece costumes and simulated in crepes as well as woolens. Then there were overskirts or apron effects, descending into a point at the front or slightly draped in the manner of a polonaise and falling in a loose panel at the back.

The American Red Cross and the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies share equally the residuary estate of Mrs. Ida C. Friedlander, widow of Louis Friedlander, who died Sept. 1, under her will, filed yesterday for probate in Surrogate's Court.

MOSCOW, Sept. 6 -- War and the Working Class reviewed favorably today a NEW YORK TIMES Magazine article by C.L. Sulzberger [The Pact that Shook the World, Aug. 27], with emphasis on those passages saying that the western powers had mistakenly failed to collaborate with the Soviet Union before the outbreak of the present war and urging the Allies not to repeat this mistake after victory.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- Grain markets broke badly today on the Board of Trade as the result of the heaviest liquidation in many months. May and July wheat, December and July rye and May oats broke the permissible limit of 5 cents a bushel under the weight of offerings and several other deliveries came within a small fraction of a cent of the maximum decline permitted for one day.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 6 -- Under a blinking sun, almost obscured by lazy and lowering clouds, and light winds that made it anyone's guess as to whether the moon would peep above the shore line before the distant sails fluttered over the finish line, the initial regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's twelth annual Race Week was held today in what a statistician might have figured an 80 per cent calm.

The first two recipients of the Twentieth Century-Fox annual literary fellowship awards for young writers in the armed forces are Lieut. E. Sheppen Geer, USNR, and Lieut. (jg) Martin Dibner, USNR. The fellowships, each of $1,500, are being offered to those who submit winning outlines of book manuscripts, which they have one year to complete.

As the rate for improvement after the war with an apartment house for 250 families, a plot containing more than 23,000 square feet at the southeast corner of Broadway and Ninety-sixth Street through to Ninety-fifth Street has been sold by the B.F. Keith Corporation to William Barkin and Samuel Greenberg, builders.

A new and tiny millinery establishment was opened yesterday afternoon. It had a very Latin Quarter air for it was situated high in a "done-over" house at 26 East Fifty-fifth Street and boasted of a large studio window. This is the establishment of de Lil, who has made a reputation for herself under the name of Lil Picard.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- The prepared text of the address of Senator Robert F. Wagner before the State Industrial Union Council today was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- An assertion that a secret trade agreement between Carl Zeiss of Jena, Germany, and the Bausch Lomb Optical Company of Rochester, N. Y., operated to the advantage of the German military machine in the years between the two World Wars was made today by Wendell Berge, Assistant Attorney General in charge of anti-trust cases.

The legend of the Wandering Jew and the far-from-legend that is Hitler form the chief ingredients of "The Day Will Come," which opened last evening at the National. As a play it is confused, a mixture of would-be realism and fantasy, and neither successful.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Swinging through the dairy farm area of New York State today, Thomas J. Curran expressed confidence to two large audiences that Thomas E. Dewey, the Presidential candidate, and he, as Republican nominee for the United States Senate, would carry New York State by large majorities, because the old-fashioned Democrats in the larger cities were supporting them.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull charged at his press conference today that Argentina was the headquarters of the fascist movement in the Western Hemisphere.

Abuse of the principle of free speech over the radio for purposes of propaganda and defamation is becoming increasingly frequent. Radio broadcasting as a means for the communication and transmission of ideas is measureless in the number of persons it reaches and in the power it possesses to influence public opinion.

Official intent to disclose the actual owners of certain New York City night clubs was indicated yesterday in two separate proceedings -- one involving the Casablanca, which formerly operated at 161 East Fifty-fourth Street, the other the Copacabana, 10 East Sixtieth Street.
A communique, as broadcast from Chungking yesterday in English to North America and reported by United States Government monitors:

ROME, Sept. 7 (U.P.) -- Swiss reports, not confirmed by headquarters, already put the Americans at Pontarlier, five miles west of the Swiss frontier and twenty-eight miles due east of Arbois. A German communique said the Americans had gained a "temporary" foothold on the north bank of the Doubs at Baume-les-Doubs, fifty-nine airline miles southwest of the German frontier.

The New York State Public Service Commission yesterday authorized the Brooklyn Union Gas Company to send out invitations for bids on the company's proposed offering of $30,000,000 of bonds and $12,000,000 of debentures.

SAMPSON, N.Y., Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers scored a 25-14 victory over Lieut. Comdr. Jim Crowley's Sampson Naval Training Center football team today. The professionals put on a sensational running and passing show witnessed by more than 10,000 bluejackets.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of commodity prices at the primary market level rose 0.1 per cent during the week ended Sept. 2. At 103.6 per cent of the 1926 average the all-commodity index is the same as for the corresponding week of last month and less than 1 per cent higher than at this time last year.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Large Japanese forces streaming south along the lower reaches of Hunan Province have advanced within twelve miles of the big United States air base at Lingling and have sent one column in a swift thirty-five-mile surge in an attempt to outflank it on the west.

Three new day-care centers for children whose mothers work will be opened this month to meet the steadily increasing demand for nursery and after-school supervision for youngsters, Miss Helen M. Harris, executive director of the Mayor's Committee on Wartime Care of Children, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The War Production Board today released an estimated 500,000,000 board feet of certain lumber stocks for sale to homeowners, farmers and other non-priority consumers. The released stocks are of a type which have accumulated in distributors, yards and are not adaptable to war uses.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Louisiana is opposed to the Memphis Natural Gas Company's application for permission to double its pipelines from Monroe, La., because the State needs to preserve its natural gas reserves, an official of the Louisiana Public Service Commission said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Most of the War Manpower Commission's controls will be removed when the war against Germany ends, Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, indicated today.

Increased buying credited to southern mills, brought about a recovery yesterday in cotton futures prices, and the market on the New York Cotton Exchange gained 10 to 11 points net and closed near the best levels of the day. Starting 2 points higher to 2 points lower than Wednesday's final quotations, the market declined under southern selling to net losses of 3 to 15 points soon after the noon hour.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept 7 -- The time has come for New York State to revise its present system of welfare services, Assemblyman Harold C. Ostertag, chairman, told the six-county regional conference of the State Committee on Welfare and Relief here today.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Governor Dewey asserted today that he did not believe any labor leaders could deliver labor's votes to any candidate.

GOETEBORG, Sweden, Sept. 7 -- The war's second exchange on Swedish soil of invalid war prisoners and noncombatant civilians began this afternoon as 682 Germans landed here off the Swedish liner Gripsholm from New York and 1,670 American and British soldiers arrived from Germany at the south Swedish port of Trelleborg.
Several town houses on the East Side passed to new control in transactions announced yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- Whatever their American compatriots may attempt, British dress designers have no illusions about capturing post-war pre-eminence in women's smart clothes from Paris, which is now back in the running.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Senate and House conferees on the bills providing for the disposal of an estimated $100,000,000,000 worth of surplus war property agreed today to assign to the Surplus Property Board the task of classifying millions of acres of land which is to be sold or leased during the reconversion and post-war periods.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- President Roosevelt received a check for $2,219,669.30 this afternoon from Nicholas Schenck, chairman of the Motion Picture Committee of the March of Dimes. Mr. Schenck was accompanied to the White House by Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

As a formula to take care of post-war pricing problems, the Office of Price Administration has approved the use of "renegotiation discounts," it was learned yesterday. These discounts will reflect fluctuating volume and its resultant effect upon costs and prices.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 -Thomas E. Dewey, opening his campaign for the Presidency in Convention Hall here tonight, used as his keynote the theme that, while the people of America were winning the war on the battle-fronts, the New Deal, always defeatist in nature, had lost faith in the American people and was offering nothing but the dole, at home, after the battles were won.

Wall Street observers returned from the Detroit area report that the motor industry there is readying itself for the dash back to civilian production, although armaments output is not to be made to suffer meanwhile. Where possible, machines are being relocated, storage space is being cleared and changes in the design of plants are being worked out so that X-day may see action rather than deliberation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Prospective railroad security issues, particularly those of the Great Northern for $100,000,000, the Chicago, Burlington Quincy for $40,000,000 and lately those of the Gulf, Mobile Ohio for $10,000,000, are invoking a new procedure to obtain more favorable bids, it was indicated today by a representative of the Burlington before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- There were 22,400,000 women not in the country's labor force in February, 1944, who were not primarily responsible for care of children and might therefore be regarded as available for employment, according to a sample survey issued yesterday by Director J.C. Capt of the Bureau of the Census, Department of Commerce.
FORT DEVENS, Mass., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Even greater emphasis will be put upon pre-induction training in New England secondary schools the coming year, Maj. Gen. Sherman Miles said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The forces of resistance in Czechoslovakia, including Slovakia, which have begun active operations with the approach of the armies of liberation, were formally recognized by the United States today as a legally constituted army and Germany was warned to treat them according to the rules of war.

The Society of the Sisters of Charity of St. Vincent De Paul, Mount St. Vincent-on-Hudson, New York City received a legacy of $50,000 under the will of Mrs. Clara J. Corbett, who died at Port Jefferson, L. I., on Aug. 21, last, it was disclosed in a petition for probate filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

Stymied by the scarcity of actors capable of shouldering the central role in "Henry VIII," Billy Rose finally decided yesterday to postpone the Shakespearean spectacle for which Robert Edmond Jones had designed fourteen sets. Mr. Rose had counted on bringing the revival to the Alvin early in November.

Losses in addition to those of Tuesday and Wednesday were suffered yesterday in the stock market before support in the afternoon produced some leveling off of the liquidating force. The attempt at recovery, was generally Selective, however, since some of the industrial shares failed to appear during the come-back, while the best demand centered in low-price and quick cohversion issues.

The regional War Labor Board issued yesterday what was said to be a precedent-setting decision establishing the principle of pay to bakery employes for time spent changing clothes where the change is obligatory because of a company requirement, a condition of employment or a local law or ordinance.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

MADRID, Sept. 7 (U.P.) -- A diplomat just arrived from France told today of the death of German Minister Manfred von Killinger in the Bucharest legation when, after he learned that Rumania had declared war on Germany, he ran amok with a machine gun, killing attaches and girl stenographers.

Promising that he would "never dictate laws of a personal character," Dr. Ramon Grau San Martin, President-elect of Cuba, also declared yesterday morning at a press conference in the Hotel Plaza that dictatorships in the Western Hemisphere are only temporary and will disappear because they "do not represent the will of the people, and their rule can only be imposed for a time by force."

CHICAGO, Sept. -- 7 Although the grain markets fluctuated in an extremely nervous manner today on the Board of Trade, heavy short covering developed on the breaks and resulted in a strong rally after July wheat and all deliveries of rye and barley had sold at new low prices for the season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- What Federal officials felt was "a new dodge" by John L. Lewis to evade the sanctions of the War Labor Disputes Act was started today when foremen, employed in a mine seized by the Government after a strike, "resigned" and thus prevented production workers from entering the pit, cutting off production as effectively as if a strike were still under way.

An Independent Citizens Committee for Roosevelt and Truman is being organized with the active assistance of local and State Democratic officials to carry the brunt of the campaign in New York State for the Democratic national ticket this year, it was disclosed yesterday.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 7 -- Ten to twelve farms in Berkshire County have been obliged to auction off dairy stock in the last six months because of inability to get sufficient labor, Jesse Fairfield, chairman of the county war board, said today.

If given the opportunity to vote in a free election the people of Argentina unquestionably would express a public opinion "which is frankly and decidedly friendly to the United Nations," fourteen members of the Bar Association of the State of Tucuman have declared in a statement that reached this country through underground channels and was released here yesterday by the National Lawyers Guild.

Francis H. Ludington has sold his forty-acre farm on Furnace Woods Road, in the Town of Cortlandt, Westchester County, to Mrs. Anna Schutz. The property includes a six-room dwelling, guest cottage, garage, barn and a two-acre spring-fed lake.

ALBANY, N. Y., Sept. 7 (AP) -- The names of 435 winners of State war service scholarships were made public today by the State Education Department. A second examination will be held soon for the remaining 765 scholarships established by the 1944 Legislature.

The Department of Sanitation showed no respect for the Police yesterday in the annual baseball game at the Yankee Stadium, and when the last precinct was heard from the Sanitation nine had the guardians of the law well under control, winning by a score of 10 to 3.
LONDON, Sept. 7 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
LONDON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England for the week ended yesterday reported an increase of 3,778,000 in note circulation.

" Soul of a Monster," a melodrama produced by Columbia, will open this morning at the Rialto. Rose Hobart, George Macready, Jim Bannon, Jeanne Bates and Erik Rolf head the cast of the film, which was directed by Will Jason for producer Ted Richmond.
ROME, Sept. 7 (UP) -- A communique:

ROME, Sept. 7 -- French and American forces now control what is officially described as "a substantial segment of eastern France" between the Saone River and the Swiss frontier and thus appear in a position to drive and harry the retreating enemy columns making for Germany.

The Book-of-the-Month Club will distribute, as a special gift to each of its more than 600,000 members, a pamphlet edition of Harold Moulton's and Louis Marlio's "The Control of Germany and Japan," a forthcoming publication of the Brookings Institution. The gift is being made.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (U.P.) -- It took two Navy planes and a destroyer to rescue Marine Capt. George H. Franck, former All-American and professional football player, after his fighter plane was shot down off Wotje, Japanese-held base in the Marshall Islands, the Navy revealed tonight.

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 7 -- Pacific Fleet carrier planes made the third sea-borne strike of the war against Palau, major Japanese naval base in the western Carolines on Tuesday, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz's headquarters announced today.

In connection with meeting the maturity on Nov. 8 next, of $71,000,000 of its notes held by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the Baltimore Ohio Railroad is understood to be considering a plan for a readjustment of virtually its entire debt structure.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 7 -- In contrast to the lifeless initial session out on the water for the opening regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's Race Week, there was a northwester today that piped between fifteen and twenty-two miles an hour in the bay and up to thirty in blasts out on Long Island Sound.

LONDON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Reich Plenipotentiary for Total War, conscripted beleaguered Germany's school children and Red Cross workers for war service in the "fight for our very lives" today as Nazi propagandists pleaded with soldiers to fight a desperate delaying action to thwart an Allied victory before winter.
Following is the text of Governor's address in Philadelphia as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Brazil today enters her 123d year as a nation. It was on Sept. 7, 1822, on the plain of Ypiranga, near Sao Paulo, that Prince Regent Dora Pedro proclaimed the independence of Brazil from Portugal. A few months later he was crowned Emperor. The corruptness of his father's court in Lisbon and of the Cortes had led to the break.

New York City banks reporting to the Federal Reserve System for several weeks have had their reserves zigzagging back and forth from excess to deficiency. For the week ended on Wednesday their reserves mounted $8,000,000 but requirements rose $48,000,000, so that they ended with a deficiency of $30,000,000, against an excess of $10,000,000 at the close of the previous week.
References to the Republican party as the "youth" party were described last night by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt as a "catch phrase invented to get over the hurdle of their candidate being young."

The article by Edwin L. James in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 3, while recognizing the general competence of John Foster Dulles in the field of international affairs, takes Mr. Dulles to task for his failure to recognize, in March, 1939, the possibility of a Japanese attack upon the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UP) -- House Republicans, focusing further political attention on the Pearl Harbor attack, today blamed President Roosevelt for the success of the Japanese raid and accused the Administration of withholding the "real story" for reasons of "political expediency."

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- A report in digest form of what sportsmen from various New York State counties said at yesterday's public hearing on the scarcity of pheasants and what should be done about the season follows:
Mr. and Mrs. Julian S. L. Humphrys, who were at Mayfair House after spending the season in Edgartown, Martha's Vineyard, have gone to Saratoga Springs.

Hilda, a Doberman pinscher member of the K-9 Corps, "stole" the annual pet show held yesterday by the Children's Aid Society at its Lower West Side Center, 219 Sullivan Street, where Hilda was guest of honor.

Total deposits in 9,549 State-supervised banks reached a high record of $57,650,981,000 on Dec. 31, 1943, an increase of $8,378,333,000 over the year before and a rise of 58 per cent during the five-year period from 1938, according to the thirteenth annual report of the State bank division of the American Bankers Association.

Marketers will find butcher shops better stocked today than they have been in some time. Both veal and lamb are more plentiful, and mutton and beef of lower grades are abundant, according to welcome reports from the War Food Administration, the New York Council of Wholesale Meat Dealers and the Meat Trade Institute.

WEST POINT, Sept. 7 -- Maj. Gen. E. Leitao de Carvalho, chief of the Brazilian delegation of the Joint Brazil-United States Defense Commission, presented the Cross of the Brazilian Order of Military Merit, on behalf of the Minister of War of Brazil, to the corps of cadets at retreat parade this afternoon.

WITH AMERICAN ARMORED COLUMN at Namur, Belgium, Sept. 6 (Delayed) -- Enemy resistance has tightened along the line of the Meuse. But with Namur firmly held by our armor and infantry, other American forces pushed across the Meuse farther south last night and this morning.

The Public Service Commission took under advisement yesterday, after a hearing at 233 Broadway, proposals made by the Long Island Lighting Company in response to the commission's recent recommendations as to changes in the company's pending plan of financial reorganization.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 7 (AP) -- New work stoppages growing out of soft coal mine supervisors' demands for union recognition tonight had closed twenty-three pits in Pennsylvania and West Virginia, New strikes closed the Kent 1-2 operation in Indiana County, Pa., employing 600 men, and the Koppers mine at Grant Town, W. Va., making 850 more idle.

WHAT undoubtedly is the strangest baseball league ever formed is now operating with considerable success. Military secrecy prohibits identifying the teams too precisely or revealing how extensive the set-up is but Abner Doubleday's brain child has gone off in a new direction. Word of this arrived yesterday on receipt of a letter from Lieut. C. Harrison Meyer, who writes from Somewhere in Russia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- A majority opinion of the National War Labor Board today defended its action in awarding back pay amounting to $450,000 to employes of Montgomery Ward Co. as putting that organization on a level with others which have appeared before the board.

HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 7 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has named Joan Blondell for the lead opposite William Bendix in "Two-Faced Quilligan," a story of a bigamist who pretends suicide to eliminate one of his personalities. Herbert C. Lewis wrote it.

FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 7 --Operation of the Army's demobilization program, announced by the War Department yesterday, was observed on a reduced scale by newspapermen today on a tour of the Fort Dix separation center. The separation and classification school, under the direction of Maj. Charles B. Roeder, trains 100 officers and enlisted men every five weeks to staff separation centers to be established throughout the country.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Friday, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A new smashing raid on Netherland Celebes, with destruction of fifteen grounded Japanese planes, and patrol activity that brought a second Philippine city under allied bombsights were announced by headquarters today among intensive aerial strikes.

ROME, Sept. 7 -- Powerful American armored forces from southern France swept up the Doubs Valley east of Chalon-sur-Saone today in a smash that carried within seventy miles of Belfort Gap -- the lone area along the entire lower German frontier where there are no mountains to protect Hitler's Reich.

ROME, Sept. 7 -- American troops closed in tonight on the big communications center of Pistoia and other outposts of the Germans' Gothic Line defenses northwest of Florence, still fighting a dogged foe on Italian soil a year after Italy quit the war.

HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 7 -- A quick decision in the Moscow peace talks was predicted in Helsinki Cabinet circles today. Both sides were believed determined to iron out all problems in the shortest possible time.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Dr. Harold G. Moulton, president of the Brookings Institution, and Dr. Louis Marlio, a French industrialist and economist who served on League of Nations committees, made public today a study which declared that economic controls without the backing of mobile force would be next to useless in preserving peace.
Operations of the W.T. Grant Company during the six months ended on July 31, resulted in consolidated net earnings of $1,263,998 after all charges, including $3,150,000 provision for taxes.

New York owners and agents of residential properties, as represented by the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee, decided yesterday to carry to the Emergency Court of Appeals its petition for a 10 per cent blanket increase in housing rents over the present ceiling as fixed by the Office of Price Administration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- At least one great question remains to be settled by the delegates at the "Washington Conversations on International Organization": What happens if one of the "Big Four" peacemakers makes war?

ROME, Sept. 7 (U.P.) -- A United Press war correspondent reported from an Eighth Army command post that six warships lay off Rimini and pumped medium caliber shells into coastal and land batteries around the city, while between rain squalls fighters and bombers of the Desert Air Force rained bombs on enemy positions and strafed communications and troop movements.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 -- The Dodgers lost a ball game to the Phillies tonight under the Shibe Park lights, blowing an early three-run lead to do it, but there were only 3,566 witnesses to this minor ignominy. The score was 7 to 5.

The stamp of individuality was evident at the Hattie Carnegie showing yesterday afternoon. The chic little tailored suits were typical of Hattie; this year there were many in high shades; pockets and detail of cut were so unobtrusive as to be scarcely noticeable.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 7 -- Turning in identical nines of 39 and 41 for cards of 80, the defending champion, Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont and Miss Maureen Orcutt of Ridgewood today tied for the lead at the halfway mark in the revised women's New Jersey Golf Association medal play championship.

To train boys and girls in the fundamentals of aviation, the Air Forces and the Army, as well as to supply a steady stream of well-selected and prepared candidates for Air Force crews, the Greater New York Cadet Training Group of the Civil Air Patrol will sponsor a new basic two-year course in city high schools, Capt. L.G. Lederer, executive officer of the body, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Total assets of insured commercial banks, amounting to $122,647,000,000 as of June 30, were higher than on any other reported date in the history of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Leo T. Crowley, chairman, announced today.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Ed Heusser bested Fritz Ostermueller tonight as the Reds edged the Pirates, 2 to 1, in the first game of their battle for second place in the National League.

KANDY, Ceylon, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Allied air forces, sweeping the skies over Burma almost at will, have begun widespread long-range attacks on the exposed Japanese lines of supply, a communique announced today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Friday, Sept. 8--Three Allied armies are wheeling eastward through northern France and Belgium in the first phase of the battle for the Siegfried Line.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Department store sales showed an increase of 16 per cent for the week ended Sept. 2 as compared to the like period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Browns, ousted from the American League lead Monday after more than three months' occupancy, fought their way back into a tie for first place with the idle Yankees tonight by rallying for three runs in the ninth inning to defeat the White Sox, 5 to 4.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- Bulgaria tonight apparently achieved the unenviable distinction of becoming the first country to be at war with both Russia and Germany as a culmination of her frantic efforts to get out of the war with as many of her ill-gotten spoils as possible.

A little over a month after General Bradley's tanks broke out of Normandy the campaign in Western Europe is today approaching its major crisis. The combined operations of the Allied armies in the North and General Patch's divisions driving from the South have cost the Germans perhaps 600,000 men, nearly all of France, most of Belgium and part of the Netherlands

As fascism the political philosophy that places the state above the individual -- is being overturned in Europe, Secretary Hull reiterates the warning that its poison has been planted in this hemisphere. The headquarters of the Fascist movement in the New World, he says, is in Argentina, from which country are spread false reports and rumors tending to disrupt inter-American relations and breed discord, an old Fascist custom.

PARIS, Sept. 7 -- In Paris the purge of collaborators and so-called collaborators continues. Daily there are new arrests of high officials, doctors, editors, police officers and, in some cases, their wives.

DALLAS, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The money-bags twins of the fairways -- Byron Nelson and Harold (Jug) McSpaden, who between them this season have gathered in close to $60,000 on the war bond trail -- finished with 2-under-par 69s to lead the field today in the second annual Texas Victory open tournament's first 18 holes.

To enable a certain amount of development of new markets by exporters, the Foreign Economic Administration has set up a "contingency quota" amounting to 10 per cent of total shipments to an area for exporters who never traded in such areas in established base periods, L.L. Horch, assistant regional director for the agency, reported yesterday.

Bill Voiselle sought and earned his nineteenth victory of the season as he pitched the Giants to a 9-3 victory over the Braves in the final arc-light struggle of the year at the Polo Ground last night. It was an easy triumph for the freshman ace, but it should have been even easier.

Frederick Brown, operator, has purchased the two six-story apartment buildings known as the Park Lane at 263 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, from the Balkan Building Corporation. The buildings, assessed at $300,000, cover a plot 110 by 192 feet, extending through to Lincoln Place and are situated near the Franklin Avenue I.R.T. subway station.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 7 (AP) -- A ninth-inning error and a wild pitch gave the Cardinals their fourteenth straight victory over the Cubs tonight, 3 to 2. St. Louis came from behind with two runs in the last inning.
PARIS, Sept. 6 (Delayed) (AP) -- The de Gaulle regime announced today that 1,496 Frenchmen were killed and 7,552 were wounded at the Paris barricades during the battle for liberation of the capital.

Employment in the steel industry moved higher in July for the second successive month after nearly two years of decline, averaging 571,500 persons for the month, comparing with 569,800 in June, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The nation's gasoline supplies last week dropped 819,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the week they amounted to 79,921,000 barrels, compared with 80,740,000 a week earlier and 70,552,000 a year ago.

As Emperor Hirohito himself sounded a grave note by declaring that "increasingly fierce" Allied blows had produced a "more intense" war situation, Premier Gen. Kuniaki Koiso -- addressing the eighty-fifth extraordinary session of the Diet -- warned the Japanese people to expect intensified American air raids on their mainland and not to overlook the "possibility" of a "landing on our home soil."

The collection of "service charges" from guests who make interstate calls on hotel telephones will have to be stopped soon, according to a decision handed down yesterday by Federal Judge Stephen W. Brennan in a suit brought by United States Attorney James B.M. McNally against the operators of thirty-three New York hotels.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- The post-1918 mistake of supplying Europe with food and finished goods, but not with the raw materials she needed to rehabilitate her industry, will not be repeated after this war if the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration can prevent it, a press conference held by that organization was told today.
Hunt Stromberg Productions, Hollywood, to Ruthrauff Ryan, Inc.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 7 -- (AP) -- Communique 152:

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- The best feature today in otherwise quiet stock market was a renewed strength of Kaffirs. With London giving support to heavy Cape buying and with stock in short supply, prices advanced. Blyvoors reached a new high and Venterspost was in keen demand on reports of good developments.

PARIS, Sept. 7 -- The sudden liberation of France has left the country in a situation similar to the Directoire period of French history. In these circumstances Gen. Charles de Gaulle and his Government, largely imported from Algiers, are trying to settle down and sort themselves out.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (U.P.) -- More than 900 Japanese prisoners of war, arming themselves with baseball bats and mess knives, made a mass escape attempt from a prison camp in Australia last month, and 231 were killed or committed suicide and 108 were wounded, Premier John Curtin of Australia announced today in a statement released through the Australian Minister, Sir John Dixon.

LONDON, Sept. 7--The second Battle of London has ended in victory--a victory that was in the making even before Allied armies overran the flying-bomb bases in France and Belgium, reducing to impotent pinpricks the effects of Hitler's vaunted Vengeance Weapon Number One.

Mrs. Cordell Hull, president of the Woodrow Wilson Birthplace Foundation, announced on Wednesday establishment of a fund to keep up the manse in Staunton, Va., in which Woodrow Wilson was born. For this purpose $50,000 has already been given. It is hoped to double this sum so that the income may provide for the keep.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Another rigorous double practice occupied the New York Football Giants today as Coach Steve Owen continued to drive his charges for the intersquad exhibition game tomorrow at Camp Shanks, where some 25,000 service men will be on hand.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Friday, Sept. 8 (UP) -- A communique:

The freeing of Brussels after four years of German occupation was celebrated here yesterday by 1,000 members of the Belgian colony who gathered in the Iridium Room of the Hotel St. Regis to hear plans for the rebuilding of their ravaged country.

WASHINGTON, Sept 7 -- A thorough inquiry into every phase of the newsprint problem was promised today by Representative Lyle H. Boren, Democrat, of Oklahoma, who is chairman of a House Committee on Newsprint and Brand Names.

WITH FRENCH FORCES IN SOUTHERN FRANCE, Sept. 5 (Delayed) (AP) -- Now that Marseille and Toulon are 200 miles behind the Allied vanguards, it may be disclosed how outnumbered French troops -- forced to attack the fiercely defended seaport areas before they were ready -- killed or captured 53,500 Germans in cleaning up the region at a cost of only 1,000 casualties.

Anne O'Hare McCormick, mourning, as we roll do, the needless destruction of the bridges, palaces and the old river-front of Florence, calls this city "the setting of the greatest efflorescence of human genius that ever occurred in one place at one time." Has Mrs. McCormick never heard of Athens? Or are we to infer that the architects, statesmen, sculptors, poets, dramatists, philosophers, warriors of Athens were inferior to those of Florence?

Jimmy McDaniels, Pacific Coast welterweight who established himself as a local favorite by stopping Aaron Perry three weeks ago, will appear in the headline bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. He will box Ralph Zannelli, Providence (R.I.) veteran, in a battle listed for ten rounds.

Ahmisk, carrying the colors of Isidore Bieber and saddled by Hirsch Jacobs, captured the $5,775 Harbor Hill Steeplechase at Aqueduct yesterday, where 18,870 persons wagered $1,764,223 on the eight races and the daily double.

The heaviest calendar of price control cases on record in the Magistrates' Courts shaped up for next Monday when the Office of Price Administration announced yesterday that summonses, returnable at that time in Criminal Courts Building, 100 Centre Street, had been issued to 248 service establishments.

Anne O'Hare McCormick, mourning, as we roll do, the needless destruction of the bridges, palaces and the old river-front of Florence, calls this city "the setting of the greatest efflorescence of human genius that ever occurred in one place at one time." Has Mrs. McCormick never heard of Athens? Or are we to infer that the architects, statesmen, sculptors, poets, dramatists, philosophers, warriors of Athens were inferior to those of Florence?

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Forces, Sept. 7 -- The German garrisons clinging desperately to Brest, Le Havre and the Channel ports are playing their part in general German strategy of delaying the main assault on the Reich itself.

Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, will be host next week to four groups of women from Queens, Richmond, Westchester and Manhattan, who have been invited to meetings in his Empire State Building office to form county consumer advisory committees.

WASINGTON, Sept. 7--Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson added weight today to the growing belief in military circles that the end of the European war is not far off when he asserted at his press conference that the "effective forces left at the disposal of the enemy seem insufficient for the task of prolonged defense."

About two and one-half tons of waste paper were collected last night at a roof party of the Madison Square Boys Club, 301 East Twenty-ninth Street, one ton being the yield of the sale of admissions to the party of 500 club members and their guests, and of the swap of 2,500 pounds of member-grown potatoes for stacks of paper.

Formation of Religious Associates, an organization headed by the Rev. Dr. Dwight J. Bradley to cooperate with the National Citizens Political Action Committee and other groups backing the re-election of President Roosevelt, was announced yesterday by the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Further evidence that Ralph A. Horton, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., sold his radio station WFTL to George B. Storer, of Detroit, president of the Fort Industry Company, in the mistaken belief that only by doing so could he save his interest in it was presented at today's hearing before the Special House Committee investigating the Federal Communications Commission.

Every human being has a pretty high notion of his own relative importance in the world. But what some people fail to see is that the valuation they put on themselves is not necessarily the highest nor best.

A BASE HOSPITAL, Somewhere in England, Sept. 7 -- For the last five days I have been in the hands of the United States Army Medical Department, tagged and classified after having been wounded at 8 o'clock Saturday night in a tiny French farmyard near Brest.
The Bulgarian Cabinet decided Thursday that "all prisoners of the Allied Powers are to be freed and sent to their respective countries," the Sofia radio has announced.

The board of directors of the Pepsi-Cola Company voted unanimously on Wednesday to recommend for consideration by the Stockholders an amendment to the certificate of incorporation so as to effect a three-for-one split-up of the company's stock.
CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 7 (AP) A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Fifty-five well babies are living in municipal hospitals because they have neither homes nor foster homes to go to, Miss Sophie van S. Theis, executive secretary of Foster Homes for Children, disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Friday, Sept. 8 -- The German radio said last night that Russian troops driving swiftly across Bulgaria had reached Dimotika, twenty-six miles inside Greece at a point on the Turkish frontier, while Allied headquarters in Rome announced that a new combined offensive against German communications in Yugoslavia had cut the only major railway line by which some 200,000 Nazis in the southern Balkans might escape.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- If the impending meeting between the President and the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom has been shifted from London to Quebec, as is being freely asserted, then it will be held on the very fringes of the American Presidential campaign and this fact just possibly could impede post-war Anglo-American unity.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- Factory sales of mechanical coal stokers for the first seven months of this year totaled 17,702 units of all sizes and types, according to figures released today by the Stoker Manufacturers Association, compared with 18,581 during the same period last year.

A purse of $50,000 in folding money has been made up to start "Mama's Bank Account" on the way. The limited partners having a stake in the venture and the investment of each follow: Arthur Willi ($25,000), Howard S. Cullman ($10,000), Eleanor K. Reinheimer ($3,000), Adele R. Levy, Ruth Field and Milton Biow ($2,500 each), Al Greenstone and Marjorie H. Ewing ($1,250 each), Dorothy F. Rodgers and Benjamin F. Feiner Jr. ($1,000 each).

Sir Thomas Beecham, opera and orchestra conductor, and his wife, the former Margaret Betty Thomas, British concert pianist, went through a second marriage ceremony late yesterday afternoon before Supreme Court Justice Samuel Null in his chambers at the County Court House.

ALBANY, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Twenty thousand more volunteer workers must be recruited in the next two weeks if New York's fruit and vegetable crops are to be harvested and processed without loss, T. Norman Hurd, director of the State War Council's Farm Manpower Service said today.

Concerned over the growing number of protests they are receiving about sharp increases in commercial rents here, city officials expressed fear that unless the leasing situation was "brought back under control" it would result in the exodus of important manufacturers and business houses from New York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The American Federation of Labor intensified today its refusal to cooperate with the Congress of Industrial Organizations by declining to have a representative at the opening session of the National Post-War Conference at Spring Lake, N.J., because the conference had invited the CIO to send delegates.

State war ballots were mailed yesterday to an additional 20,959 members of the armed forces from New York City as criticism of the slowness in dispatching ballots here began to develop. In at least three up-State counties, according to reliable reports, ballots already have been mailed to all servicemen whose requests have been received to date.

PARIS, Sept. 7 -- Word has reached the Government here that the American advance in the north of France was so rapid that the coal mines around Lens, Bethune, Marie and Courrieres in the region of Lille have been recovered almost intact, it was disclosed today.

DETROIT, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Tigers, making hay behind Paul (Dizzy) Trout's three-hit pitching, whitewashed the Indians, 3 to 0, today to shave their distance back of the league leaders to a single game.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Representative J. William Fulbright of Arkansas, author of the resolution through which the House gave the first formal Congressional expression for post-war collaboration among the United Nations to maintain peace, offered a resolution today calling for international agreements to guarantee freedom of the press and radio as an aid in preventing future wars.

DETROIT, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Ford-operated Willow Run bomber plant which has been producing a four-engined B-24 Liberator bomber every working hour, was closed this afternoon for the second time today by labor disputes. About 30,000 workers were made idle by the stoppages.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- In a decision filed here today in a $777,745 damage suit arising from the crash of the Yankee Clipper at Lisbon, Portugal, on Feb. 22, 1943, Supreme Court Justice Frank H. Coyne refused to declare unconstitutional the rules of international air transportation established at the Warsaw Convention of 1929 and ratified in this country five years later by Presidential proclamation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- James F. Byrnes, director of war mobilization, said this afternoon that production of critical Army supplies in August showed increases of 5 to 17 per cent over July. But even after these increases, he added, production was "far behind requirements."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture forecast today for this year a cotton crop of 11,483,000 bales and said the indicated yield for the acre would establish a new high record of 273.4 pounds.

In a stormy session before the regional War Labor Board yesterday, the United States Gypsum Company, of which Sewell L. Avery, head of Montgomery Ward Co., is chairman of the board, refused to comply with a national WLB directive involving 120 employes in its Jersey City plant on the ground that it was both "improper and illegal."

On the China-Burma-India circuit "you can't be glamorous," confessed Ann Sheridan of the movies in an interview yesterday at the United Service Organizations Camp Shows office here after returning from an eight-week tour in that area.

The Childs Company and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $527,417 in the first seven months this year as compared with $355,657 earned in the corresponding period a year ago, the report of the trustee showed yesterday. The gross volume of business for the seven months ended with July totaled $11,721,717, against $11,430,447 last year.

Charles Edward Wilson, who resigned recently as vice chairman of the War Production Board in a row with Donald M. Nelson, chairman, was re-elected yesterday president and a director of the General Electric Company at a meeting of the board of directors.

PARIS, Sept. 7 (Delayed) -- For the first time men of the United States Eighth Air Force are able to pick their way through the ruins created by their own bombing and to assess its worth on the spot. It's been a good, sound piece of destruction, judging by the evidence examined so far.

Pope Pins XII has set aside Oct. 22 to be observed as annual "Mission Sunday" in the 115 dioceses of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States, it was announced yesterday by Mgr. Thomas J. McDonnell, national director of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, at the national office, 109 East Thirty-eighth Street.
Andrew E. Chute of the Foster-Wheeler Corporation, has been elected president of the Junior Chemical Engineers of New York City.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 8 -- Picking the puffs of a fairly strenuous northwester as they congealed and then split, Arthur Knapp sailed the International sloop Bumble Bee to victory today in the third session of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's Race Week.

MEMPHIS, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A Federal Power Commission hearing on a Memphis Natural Gas Company application to enlarge its facilities from here to Monroe, La., continued here today with the principals informed of possible new legislation in the natural gas field.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The War Production Board today further increased the supply of lumber available to non-priority consumers by announcing that mills in the Western pine region now may ship Douglas fir and larch lumber to distributors on uncertified and unrated orders.

BOSTON, Sept. 8 -- The Yankees' perch on top of the American League hung at a perilous angle a number of times today, but in the end things righted themselves in almost miraculous fashion as the McCarthymen scored two runs in the twelfth, staved off a bewildering Red Sox rally in the last half of the same round and triumphed, 7 to 6, in the opening clash of a four-game series.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Men already in class 1-A and new 18-year-olds can more than supply the needs of the armed forces for the rest of 1944, Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, draft director said today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, Sept. 9 -- Liberators and Mitchells escorted by Lightnings made another big raid on Mindanao, following which Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced "our air forces now dominate the southern Philippines."

The total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $589,232,839 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average price per share of all listed stocks on Aug. 31 was $35.40 compared with $35.07 at the end of July.

In connection with the competitive on Tuesday of $100,000,000 of Great Northern Railway bonds, a glance at what the company has accomplished in the way of reduction of funded debt during the past twelve years is noteworthy.
ROME, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A communique:

A resolution urging the Dumbarton Oaks conference to make specific provision for the peaceful settlement of international disputes was forwarded yesterday to Undersecretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Pr. by Mrs. Norman de R. Whitehouse, national chairman of the Women's Action Committee for Victory and Lasting Peace.

The Rev. Donald Harrington, for the last five years minister of the People's Liberal Church, Chicago, will formally become colleague to John Haynes Holmes, the minister of the Community Church, when that congregation resumes its regular Sunday 11 A.M. worship on Sept. 24 in Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 8 -- The aim of the peace-makers at the close of this war must be broader than the prevention of future aggression by Germany and Japan, Thomas E. Dewey declared tonight in his second major campaign address, devoted entirely to foreign affairs.

To announce the post-war availability for civilian use of its "flying-A" gasoline, the Tide Water Associated Oil Company will release the first of a series of advertisements in 175 Eastern newspapers and trade journals beginning Monday. The initial advertisements will be 745 and 996 lines. Lennen Mitchell, Inc., is the agency.

An American can only view with incredulity the state of mind which twice has led Japanese prisoners to attempt mass escapes in impossible situations. On Feb. 25, 1943, several hundred in a New Zealand prison camp attempted a mass break. Forty-eight were killed and sixty-three wounded.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Ken Miller limited Baltimore, leading the International League by one percentage point, to four hits tonight to give Jersey City a 4-to-3 victory in a spirited battle. The home club tied the score with two runs in the seventh and won on Buddy Kahn's error with the bases loaded in the eighth.
A communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

For descending into a flaming ammunition hold to extinguish a fire that momentarily threatened to blow up the Liberty ship Samuel Parker, Comdr. Nikolai C. Storkersen, USMS, received yesterday the Merchant Marine Distinguished Service Medal in a ceremony at War Shipping Administration headquarters, 45 Broadway.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 -- The reorganization plan of the $300,000,000 United Gas Corporation was approved today without exception by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which also filed with the district court in Wilmington, Del., an application for approval and enforcement of the plan.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Sept. 8 -- Adding a fine 76 today at the Forest Hill Field Club to the 80 she scored yesterday at the Upper Montclair Country Club, Miss Maureen Orcutt of Ridgewood regained the Women's New Jersey Golf Association medal play title she surrendered in 1942 to Mrs., William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont.
The text of Governor Dewey's address last night before the National Federation of Women's Republican Clubs as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES follows:

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- Announcement that the Canadian export tax on oats had been reduced 4 to 6 cents a bushel late Thursday led to general liquidation in oats and barley futures today on the Board of Trade. September and December deliveries of the two grains broke to new seasonal low prices and the close was about the bottom.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Any further Federal appropriation for the treatment of poliomyelitis should go to the grants-in-aid program for crippled children under the Social Security Act, Dr. A.L. Van Horn, of the Children's Bureau, said today in testimony before the Kelly subcommittee to investigate aid to the physically handicapped.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- Under the impact of the Allies' victory drive the Axis organization in Yugoslavia was reported tonight to be falling apart, with a general rising in Serbia, a revolt in Croatia and the disintegration of the Bulgarian occupation forces.

A Brooklyn Bond Bowl gridiron clash, sending the newly named Brooklyn Tigers, more familiarly known as the Dodgers, against an all-star service "squad, will be staged under the lights at Ebbets Field on the night of Oct. 2, it was announced yesterday at a United States Treasury Department luncheon held at Toots Shor's.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for United State Senate, insisted tonight that provision must be made in the post-war program for the needs of the small business man and the white-collar worker. He promised to take an active part in legislation that would aid their cause if elected to office.

The 330 Hudson Street Corporation has sold the five-family apartment house at 330 Hudson Street, Hoboken, N.J., to the Helen Realty Corporation and the four-family building at 709 Washington Street, Hoboken, to Emil Canarozzi and Mary Sperano. J.I. Kislak, Inc., broker in both transactions, also reports the sale in Hoboken of the one-family dwelling at 1302 Bloomfield Street for the Hoboken Land and Improvement Company to Gustave Moeller.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- The first of the normally constituted governments of Europe to return to its homeland from the refugee capital of London reached Brussels and began functioning immediately today. The principal members of the Government were the same men who were in office when the Germans attacked in 1940.

ROME, Sept. 8 -- In a magnificent suite of rooms in the Palazzo Venezia, where Mussolini held forth and the Fascist regime dissolved in the fateful all-night session of July 24, 1943, there is now being held a breath-taking exhibit of masterpieces of Renaissance painting.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- Backed by the force of the Red Army, Russia's iron-fisted diplomacy has won a bloodless victory against Bulgaria, which formally made public tonight her declaration of war on Germany.

The King of the Sea, that celebrated fish restaurant at 879 Third Avenue, near Fifty-third Street, started out eight years ago with two tables and a counter accommodating sixteen stools. Since then it has expanded gradually till now the establishment consists of the original room plus large new quarters adjoining that were opened yesterday.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 8 (AP) -- New Saratoga records were established at the pari-mutuel windows and at the turnstiles at the recently concluded racing meeting held at Belmont Park, the State Tax Commission reported today, pushing season figures toward a new high for the entire State.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (U.P.) -- Indirectly answering the criticism of Britain's India policy by United States Ambassador William Phillips, the British Information Service said today that Prime Minister Churchill had never stated that the Atlantic Charter did not apply to India.

When September is edging away from August and bad company she soon mellows into the bland days beloved of the enthusiasts of baseball. In the last war the season ended on Sept. 2. This year the devotees of the diamond are luckier; the armed forces and civilians have a long and fertile subject for debate and wager.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- There was still "a desperate need" for increased production of some items, Paul V. McNutt, Chairman of the War Manpower Commission, old the Senate War Investigating Committee today, but virtually all manpower controls would end when he war in Europe was over.

ROME, Sept. 8 -- Eighth Army forces in the Adriatic sector smashed German counter-attacks supported by tanks just south of San Savino in a bitter battle. British artillery and tanks turned the tide of the fighting, in which the Germans suffered extremely heavy losses, mostly in killed.

The current loan exhibition of work by American artists at the Museum of Non-Objective Painting has been extended until Oct. 14. On Saturday and Sunday afternoons brief informal talks are given by Ralph Scarlett and John Sennhauser, who are among the painters represented in the exhibition.

The gasoline coupon black market, which remains a high hurdle in the path of increased A and B rations for motorists, has again pegged its prices and has come more completely under the control of professional criminals than ever before, it was learned yesterday.
Business is booming at the Father Knickerbocker canning plant in Orange County.

WITH AN AMERICAN ARMORED COLUMN, east of Namur, Sept. 7 (Delayed) -- German opposition along the Meuse River where it turns south from Namur crumpled like an egg shell in less than a day under the brisk attacks of American armor and infantry Our main columns began surging forward at full speed again yesterday afternoon and today are far along on the march to Germany.

I resent with utmost passion the cheap sentimentality of Herbert L. Matthews in that recent article from the South of France in which he lauds the "valiant Germans" for their death-stand in a hotel there, blithely over-looking the fact that in this process these men unnecessarily killed Mr. Matthews' fellow-countrymen, or the soldiers of his allies.

Three new films will open today at midtown theatres -- "Storm Over Lisbon," a topical melodrama featuring Vera Hruba Ralston, Richard Arlen and Erich von Stroheim, at the Republic Theatre; "Enemy of Women," purportedly "the private life" story of the Nazi Propaganda Minister, Paul Joseph Goebbels, and featuring Donald Wood, H.B. Warner, Sigrid Gurie, Ralph Morgan and Gloria Stuart, at the Victoria Theatre; and "1812," a Soviet historical drama, at the Stan ley Theatre.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 8 -- Evelyn Keyes has been chosen by Columbia for the feminine lead in its forthcoming Technicolor fantasy, "A Thousand and One Nights." The film will be directed by Alfred E. Green, who gives up his assignment on "Eadie Was a Lady," the Ann Miller picture, to Arthur Dreiffus.

While new reports were coming in yesterday to Mayor La Guardia and other city officials telling of increases in commercial rents, suggestions were received from several sources for prompt public hearings to "get at the facts" in the business leasing situation here.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Browns today lost their hold on a tie for the American League lead when they were defeated by the White Sox, 9 to 5. The Browns now are in second place, trailing the New York Yankees by one game.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 8 -- According to the Chinese military spokesman, the Japanese forward units in the drive toward Kweilin number 60,000 to 70,000 men from the Third, Thirteenth, Thirty-seventh and Fortieth Divisions, which escaped the severest fighting in the Hengyang campaign in June and July.

WITH AMERICAN THIRD ARMY, in France, Sept. 8 -- Before noon today the American first troops had crossed the Moselle River in the Metz area. Late this afternoon they were reported to have established a firm foothold on the east bank of the river and additional troops were joining them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Branch offices of Japanese trading companies were used extensively by the Nippon government for gathering information in the United States which would be of military value to Japan, according to testimony presented by the Department of Justice to a subcommittee of the Senate's Military Affairs Committee investigating international cartel agreements in which American companies were involved. Military aircraft data and methods of producing 100-octane gasoline were involved.

Spurred by cooler weather and "back-to-school" purchasing retail sales last week gained about 20 per cent over the like 1943 week, according to department store executives. It was pointed out that all departments were active, and that in some instances purchasing was on a level with the Christmas buying period.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Forces, Sept. 8 (UP) -- United States heavy bomber fleets, in direct support of the American and Russian armies closing in on Germany from the west and south, battered the Wehrmacht's vital supply sources in the Rhineland and its crippled communications in Yugoslavia today.

ALLIED NAVAL HEADQUARTERS, London, Sept. 8 (U.P.) -- Although the Germans launched a series of secret weapons, including human torpedoes and explosive motor-boats against Allied cross-Channel shipping, more than a million men were landed in France in the first twenty-eight days of the invasion of northern France, high naval authorities disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Gen. H.H. Arnold, commanding the Army Air Forces, told the presidents of aircraft manufacturing companies today that American leadership in aviation was dependent upon their industry's being "strong, progressive and imaginative."

CAMP SHANKS, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- The New York Football Giants, preparing for the forthcoming National League championship campaign, thrilled a large turnout of service men today at Camp Shanks as the Blues routed the Reds, 25 -- 12, in an intra-squad game that saw Coach Steve Owen using his entire roster of thirty-six candidates.

A signed card containing a prayer for victory and peace and the return of loved ones in the armed forces now overseas will be the admission to the third annual patriotic services of the New York Archdiocesan Union of the Holy Name Society to take place at the Polo Grounds, Eighth Avenue and 155th Street, Sunday, Oct. 8, at 5 P.M. The prayer follows:

The stock market leaned yesterday to the recovery side but without sufficient backing to prove that the reversal of trend from the previous sessions was conclusive. Gains in the majority of the issues were fractional and scored on comparatively small dealings, for, with three exceptions, the most active stocks ended lower.

Strong efforts will be made by the fur industry in the immediate future to have the 20 per cent excise tax eased on the ground that the 20 per cent tax actually is returning less revenue to the Government than the 10 per cent levy.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 8 -- Mrs. Job Taylor 2d of 430 East Eighty-sixth Street, New York City, was a prisoner in Suffolk County Jail here tonight on charges of grand larceny. She is accused of having stolen and sold jewelry worth $27,750, including a $25,000 star ruby clip owned by Mrs. E.C. Stollenwerck of 14 East Seventy-fifth Street, New York City.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- A charge of conspiracy in the sale of a radio station was made today against James Lawrence Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, at a hearing of the House committee which is investigating his agency.

New financing continued large this week, but unlike the two preceding weeks, when railroad offerings accounted for the bulk of the new bonds, it was confined almost entirely to the industrial field. Three new issues of bonds aggregating $65,370,000 were offered for public subscription, compared with five, totaling $65,222,000, last week.

The Upholstered Furniture Manufacturers Association, the members of which do 90 per cent of the $20,000,000 annual business in the upholstered furniture manufacturing industry in New York, is considering a "pool" buying plan, it gas learned yesterday.
LONDON, Sept. 8 -- Decisions on three pressing issues of war and peace are anticipated at the forthcoming meeting between President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill. They are:

PARIS, Sept. 8 -- The Germans failed to loot any of the great French art collections, so far as can be ascertained at present. The great French museums, the Louvre, Cluny and Carnavalet, are still closed to the public today and their collections remain in various chateaux of France where they were taken for safety in 1940 and where, so far as is known in Paris they were unharmed by the occupying Nazis.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 8 (U.P.) -- United States War Production Board Chairman Donald M. Nelson and Maj. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley, here on a special economic-political mission for President Roosevelt, held a series of conferences with Chinese Government officials today.

A felonious assault charge against Laurence Lloyd of 983 Park Avenue, advertising executive, was dismissed yesterday in Felony Court after Mrs. Louise Munn, former screen actress, named as complainant, called the charge "a gross injustice."

Searching for an understanding of the common ground that underlies all sciences and knowledge rather than the differences that keep scientists, philosophers and theologians apart, so that knowledge can better serve mankind, a hundred eminent scholars opened yesterday in the Men's Faculty Club, Columbia University, 400 East 117th Street, the fifth annual Conference on Science, Philosophy and Religion in Their Relation to the Democratic Way of Life.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 8 -- Egyptian political leaders are drafting post-war claims on the grounds that Egypt should be repaid for the inconveniences she suffered during the war in North Africa. They will demand that aspirations for complete independence should be honored.

BY nature the American fan is a restless individual, never quite satisfied with the rules of any sport as he finds them. Perhaps his yen for change is honest enough. After all, our Constitution has been amended some twenty-odd times and nothing stands still in this land of ours.

OTTAWA, Sept. 8 -- The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration has already spent $12,000,000 in Canada, and it is expected that this amount will increase materially in the next few weeks, Brooke Claxton, M.P., parliamentary assistant to the President of the Privy Council, said today.
The defense of Marshal Petain by John D. Flynn in your letter columns should not go unanswered.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Members of the American Retail Federation, composed of several score national and State associations, were urged today by several speakers to keep their minds on the idea of encouraging a high level of productivity in the post-war period as the best means of maintaining their own business existence.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- Directors of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad elected today Holly Stover as president to succeed Charles T. O'Neal, who was elevated to chairman of the board. Mr. Stover, who for many years has been widely known in the coal industry, is the Government's manager of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railway and is vice president of the Gulf, Mobile Jo Ohio Railroad.

With the War Production Board and the National Housing Agency studying possible means of relieving the acute housing shortage in New York, realty experts expressed optimism yesterday over the prospect of early action by the Federal agencies to revise some of their regulations and policies governing private construction work to permit modernization of outmoded houses and the splitting up of large vacant apartments.

An eighteen-inch bazooka shell brought back from North Africa by a United States soldier exploded shortly after noon yesterday in a basement apartment of a six-story building at 1979 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, injuring five young Bronx boys, two of them critically.
A communique, broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 8 (AP) -- After Newark had broken a 2-all deadlock with a run in the thirteenth, Syracuse came back with two runs in the home half of that frame to grab a 4-to-3 victory. The Bears are still a percentage point behind Baltimore in the race for the International League championship.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 8 -- The large and long-established American air base at Lingling in central China fell yesterday before a strong Japanese force streaming down the Hunan-Kwangsi railway in a drive intended to help establish an overland military route from Manchuria to Singapore.

Mrs. Phyllis Lyons Newmark talked with two sailors at the Mall in Central Park just before midnight Aug. 24, the night before she was found strangled near the Hayden Planetarium, and then walked away with them uptown, a new witness told the police last night.

To discern whether the "Great Lakes special" on a drugstore menu is really a pre-price-control western egg sandwich at a fancier price, the Midtown War Price and Rationing Board, 1775 Broadway, has obtained the part-time, voluntary assistance of a "well-known" chef, said to earn $30,000 a year, it was learned yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 8 -- Speaking to the press this evening Foreign Minister Orlando L. Peluffo denied each and every one of the accusations against Argentina made by Secretary of State Cordell Hull yesterday.

Rationed shoe inventories as of July 31 are expected to show about 175,000,000 pairs in retailers' hands, compared with about 220,000,000 pairs as of last Sept. 30, according to industry information regarding the survey conducted by the Office of Price Administration. OPA figures are expected to be released next week, at which time the agency also will inaugurate a new survey of the number of outstanding unused shoe coupons.

In your issue of Sept. 4 Albert Hirst expresses the conviction that it will not be possible to punish the overwhelming majority of war criminals for lack of proof, because they will be entitled to the presumption of innocence and witnesses will have disappeared or will have been murdered and documentary evidence destroyed.

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., has acquired an issue of $3,000,000 city of Tacoma, Wash., light and power revenue bonds on a bid for a combination of interest rates which gave a net interest cost to the city of 1806 per cent.

I David Sullivan, president of J Local 32-B, Building Service Em*J ployes International Union, Amer-J ican Federation of Labor, receivedJ a setback yesterday when SupremeJ Court Justice Ferdinand PecoraJ declined to grant an injunction re-J I straining the executive board of J the international from reviewing charges by members of the local that the union leader had received "kickbacks" from professional men and had taken money from employers to "call off picket lines."

WASHINGTON, Sept 8 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 2 were 898,450 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 7,274 cars or 0.8 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 2,625 cars or 0.3 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 10,490 cars or 1.2 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- President Roosevelt and members of his official family answered in various ways today assertions made last night in Philadelphia by Governor Dewey, Republican Presidential candidate.

In this war there are likely to be two armistice days, one when the last German army surrenders and one when the Japanese lay down their arms. There are two ways to celebrate the first of these occasions, which will be bought, as the second one will be, by wounds, death and sorrow.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- The mortality rate among the children of France has increased by 25 per cent since before the war, and food and medical supplies must arrive in the affected areas within a short time to prevent a still further increase, Gen. Adolphe Sice said here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- President Roosevelt said today that the United States and Great Britain had already shipped supplies, including fuel, valued at $100,000,000 into Italy, but said that the need for additional aid in that country was acute.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Social services of the resistance movement, organized under occupation "to look after the poor and helpless and to mitigate the harshness of enemy rule," would facilitate post-war rehabilitation "enormously," Miss Mary Craig McGeachy, UNRRA welfare director, predicted today at a press conference following her return from London.

First Fiddle, often mentioned in the first flight of the handicap division, has this afternoon what looks like an easy race at Aqueduct in the $15,000 added Edgemere Handicap. He is in with 127 pounds against only four rivals of mediocre opposition.

ROME, Sept. 8 -- German rear guards, who for several days had put up no determined resistance to French and Arnei, lcan forces,surging northward to cut off' enemy retreat ' 'from soutl'ern Finance through the .Belfort-Gap into Germany, have made a stand against American troops ' at Besancon, :French garrison town on the Doubs River, Allied Ieadquarters reported today.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- The main center of interest in today's stock markets was again the Kaffir shares. With renewed buying from the Cape and more local support, fresh rises of prices were seen. Venterspost again was wanted on persistent reports of a rich strike on company's property shares rising another sixteenth.

ON BOARD THE DESTROYER O'BANNON, in New Guinea Waters, Sept. 8 -- The fourth Presidential citation to be awarded to a destroyer in the Pacific since Pearl Harbor was conferred today on the 0'Bannon for a year's outstanding service, from Oct. 7, 1942, to Oct 7, 1943.

American 90 mm. anti-aircraft guns, aimed and fired by M-9 electric directors that automatically calculate the height and forward speed of an approaching target, with set shell fuses to explode at given points, have played a major part in ending the robot bomb menace in England, Dr. Clarence A. Lovell, Bell Telephone Laboratories Research engineer, disclosed yesterday.

James Montgomery Flagg presented to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt the original of a campaign poster he designed for the President during a brief ceremony yesterday morning at headquarters of the Independent Voters Committee of the Arts and Sciences for Roosevelt in the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- A "large task force" of B-29 Superfortresses, operating by daylight from their China bases, today attacked important industrial targets at Anshan in Japanese-dominated Manchuria with good results, Twentieth Air Force Headquarters here announced in a communique late this afternoon.

Walter Hoving, chairman of the national board of the United Service Organizations and president of the Fifth Avenue Association, was appointed yesterday by Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican national chairman, as assistant manager of the Republican national campaign.

WASHINGTON, Sept 8 -- The Russian phase of the "Washington Conversations on International Organization,'' which was expected to end this week-end with a draft agreement, will continue next week, for the expected agreement on all points has not yet been achieved.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- President Roosevelt was reported to be contemplating a universal military training program for youth in the post-war years which will combine this basic training with a combination of some features of the old Civilian Conservation Corps and more formal education helping to fit youth for future years.
A communique, as broadcast from Chungking in English to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange eased momentarily yesterday on the bearishly interpreted Government estimate of the cotton crop, but the trend was reversed in the late trading on short covering and final prices were 3 to 5 points net higher on the day for the active months.

Mayor La Guardia interrupted a honeymoon yesterday to award a $100 war bond to the 5,000,000th paid visitor to the Empire State Building observation tower, 1,240 feet above Fifth Avenue at Thirty-fourth Street.
CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A communique from Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters:

A UNITED STATES SUPERFORTRESS BASE IN WESTERN CHINA, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The largest force of Superfortresses yet employed bombed Anshan in Manchuria and the surrounding Japanese industrial empire today, concentrating on chemical and explosives factories. No planes were lost.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- President Roosevelt had a sixty-minute conference with the "Big Four" of United States military and naval strategy, presumably as a prelude to the next meeting with Prime Minister Churchill, which the President has hinted is imminent.

Efforts of all agencies planned to help returning veterans -- from the largest Federal bureau to the smallest "ladies aid" -- must be coordinated on a national basis if discharged service men are to have proper guidance, Dr. Willard Waller, Associate Professor at Columbia University, declared yesterday.

Into the V-1, his vaunted robot plane, Hitler packed his last wild hope of victory. We know now that this hope, sedulously spread among the German people, was vain. Duncan Sandys' thrilling report of London's defense against this weapon reveals that it was failing even before the Allied invasion cleared the rocket-launching coast.

In a recent review in Time magazine of Dr. Martin Gumpert's new book, "You Are Younger Than You Think," published by Duell, Sloan Pearce, the reviewer mentioned the author's views against May-December marriages. Shortly after the review appeared, Dr. Gumpert received a telephone call from a worried reader.
