WHEN I went to grammar school in a New England city we learned the Three R's by rote and drill and didn't worry very much about social significance. In the Bull Moose year of 1912 we lined up politically according to the reason or the prejudice of our parents, with no clear understanding of the issues involved.

Expressing "deep gratitude for all the courtesies shown me" and his admiration for "all the splendor of this nation," Dr. Ramon Grau San Martin, President-elect of Cuba, left La Guardia Field yesterday morning en route to Havana after a visit of nearly two weeks in the United States.

PARIS, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower stood today beneath the Arc de Triomphe, symbol of French military prowess since Napoleon, and presented a commemorative liberation plaque to the French people.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Navy said today that it was prepared to use jet-assisted take-offs, which it demonstrated to a group of correspondents at a naval air base several months ago, for carrier airplanes and flying boats.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Twentieth, Air Force communique 11:

MOSCOW, Sept. 8 -- The story of the rehabilitation of the Donbas, the Soviet Union's former prime industrial area, in one year after its liberation from German rule was told today in a letter to Premier Stalin from 710,086 workers in the area.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- July exports of merchandise from the United States amounted to $1,198,000,000, the third highest monthly total in the country's history, the Bureau of the Census reported today. This figure represents a drop of approximately 6 per cent from June and a decrease of about 16 per cent from the record high total net in May.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Evidence that an acute shortage of cotton goods persists despite efforts by the Government to speed production was presented by the Labor Department today in a report showing that cotton clothing, textiles and household articles made of cotton continued in short supply as late as July in twenty- one large cities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Conferees on the bills providing for the disposal of an estimated $100,000,000,000 of surplus war property, including $15,000,000,000 of plants and equipment, agreed today on provisions designed to protect small business from discrimination in the sale or leasing of any of the property.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 -- The Dodgers stayed out of the National League cellar tonight, but only after a bitter battle with the Phillies under the Shibe Park lights, the decision not coming until the ninth inning. Then the 4-3 triumph for the Brooks was in considerable doubt when the Phils got the tying run as far as second base with only one out.
Jimmy McDaniels had little trouble defeating Ralph Zannelli of Providence in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

PLANDOMZE, L.I., Sept. 8 -- Up-State golfers, used to elbow room, found the tree-lined fairways of the Plandome Golf Club a little more than they had bargained for when they attempted to qualify in the club's annual member-guest invitation tournament today.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Conciliation meetings have been arranged to iron out differences in two labor disputes which closed the Fairfield Steel Works of the Tennessee Coal. Iron and Railroad Company and the Bessemer plant of the Pullman-Standard Car Manufacturing Company causing nearly 2,000 war workers to be idle.

AT THE FRENCH-SWISS FRONTIER, Sept. 8 -- The battle for the Belfort Gap began today with a preliminary Allied artillery barrage and an all-day series of air attacks. Three Allied motorized columns were approaching, with the most advanced within ten miles of the city of Belfort.

Emily Cunningham Myles, 18 years old, daughter of Robert C. Myles, an attorney of Roslyn, L.I., and Gertrude Poyneer Sheppard, 20, both of 18 East Sixty-fourth Street, appeared in Felony Court before Magistrate Frederick L. Strong yesterday on grand larceny charges.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 8 - Several developments in metal chemistry, a method of preparing wheat germ for use in baking and a shutter for high-speed aerial cameras are among the 511 inventions listed as patented in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Sept. 9 -- The Soviet High Command reported last night that the Red Army had crossed the Bulgarian border early Friday and in less than twenty-four hours had driven eighteen to forty-one miles, capturing the two important ports of Varna on the Black Sea and Ruschuk on the Danube.

Noting that the high educational standards set by the Army and Navy will be the standards for civilian employment after the war, Superintendent of Schools John E. Wade urged yesterday that all boys and girls of high school age leave their jobs and return to school on Monday.

ROME, Sept. 8. -- Osservatore Romano took today the occasion of polemical argument with the Communist Unita over the fate of Warsaw to deny again that Moscow was seeking an accord with the Vatican. It likewise pointed out that while it had published the charge that the Russians deliberately had halted outside Warsaw to permit patriots to be massacred it also had published full reports on the whole situation from all sources, including Russian.

LONDON, Saturday, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Gen. Fedor I. Tolbukhin's Third Ukrainian Army crossed into Bulgaria from Rumania in a drive aimed at swiftly crushing 250,000 Germans in neighboring Yugoslavia and Greece.

A letter on this page day before yesterday deplored a front-page headline of two days earlier which, in the writer's opinion, seemed to claim for our American forces sole credit for smashing the German Army.

DALLAS, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Golfdom's automaton, lean-faced Byron Nelson, clipped par again today to move into a class by himself at the halfway mark of the Texas Victory open, his card for 36 holes reading 69, 69 -- 138.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 8 -- Delemont and Moutiers, two railroad stations ten and twenty kilometers inside. Switzerland, respectively, to the east of the Porrentruy pocket, were subject to heavy low level machine-gun attacks by seven Allied pursuit planes shortly after 9 o'clock this morning.

The New York Life Insurance Company has sold the twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at 378 West End Avenue, southeast corner of Seventy-eighth Street, to the 378 West End Avenue Realty Corporation, Joseph Reinschreiber, president, which plans to alter the eleven-room apartments into small suites.

Milling throngs of French so cluttered up the roads leading to Paris that American - equipped French armored forces had an extremely difficult time entering the capital, Paul Manning, WOR radio commentator and war correspondent, said yesterday.

Things are not quite the same in the United States Court House on Foley Square since the Government acquired those 17,000 pairs of nylon stockings. There is a predatory gleam in some of the feminine eyes, while some of the men wear a hunted look -- they know where the nylons are buried, and the girls know they know.

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 8 -- United States carrier forces prowling the far Central Pacific bombed and strafed the Japanese bases at Yap and Ulithi in the western Carolines on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. These new strikes announced by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz's headquarters today follow closely attacks on the Bonin, Volcano and Palau Islands.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 8 -The Special People's Tribunal in Berlin, that is investigating the plot on Hitler's life July 20, is continuing its deliberations, and while the proceedings are secret this week's illustrated newspapers published details of the arrest of Dr. Karl Goerdeler, former Mayor of Leipzig, who is suspected of having been the political brains of the military putsch against the Nazi regime.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The resignation of Douglas H. Allen as president of the Rubber Development Corporation, effective Oct. 1, was disclosed today by Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator, who named Francis A. Truslow, vice president of the corporation, as his successor.

Your editorial on the Monarch butterfly was enjoyable but ignored an interesting aspect of its story. Why does it dance with such blithe abandon? Perhaps it is because birds have learned to leave it strictly alone because of its exceedingly disagreeable taste.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, Sept. 9 -- Veteran infantry and armored divisions of the American First Army are smashing through German forces covering the approaches to the Siegfried Line in eastern Belgium.

The team of Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse, who as writers, producers and actors have carved a considerable niche for them selves on Broadway with such permanent fixtures as "Life With Father" and "Arsenic and Old Lace," has purchased for January production "The Hasty Heart," a new play by Capt. John Patrick.

I set out a grapevine and a couple of fruit trees a few years ago, and by now I am wondering what the generals and commentators mean when they talk of "fruit withering on the vine"; of victories dropping "like ripe peaches into waiting hands," and so forth.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- President Roosevelt singled out the cartel problem at his news conference today as one of the most important which must be met in the next few months.

Michael Hughes has purchased the five-story ten-family apartment house at 1909 Andrews Avenue, the Bronx, from the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, which recently acquired the property through the purchase of a deed in lieu of foreclosure.

CONGRESS is nursing grievances it does not air. Almost any Senator or member of Congress -- unless he belongs to the inner circle -- knows that a lot is going on in which he has no part. The complaint may be just or unjust; it varies from member to member; yet it is reality itself to the man who feels it.

CAMP CARSON, Col., Sept 9 (AP) -- Packaged rations have passed the test in keeping up the good health and morale of 900 soldiers and officers in what the Army believes is the largest ration experiment in military history.

The "second front" in the war, in which capitalist America is cooperating with socialist Russia to overcome the Axis menace to world security, must be followed by a "second front" in Soviet economic reconstruction if enduring peace is to be achieved, Dr. Oscar Lange, Professor of Economics at the University of Chicago and editor of Econometrica, believes.

Luther Huston in THE TIMES MAGAZINE says that Lord Halifax has traveled 40,000 miles in the United States, and that this is "more than any other British Ambassador except Lord Bryce." Mr. Huston has clearly forgotten Lord Lothian, Lord Halifax's predecessor, who had certainly traveled far more widely here.

TORONTO, Sept. 9 -- None of the Maple Leafs will be affected by the National Hockey League ruling barring players deferred from military service for other than physical disability, Frank Selke, Toronto manager, said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- At the risk of "diverting the attention of the people from the tremendous task to which we must devote all of our efforts if we are going to contribute our part to the victory," James F. Byrnes, War Mobilization Director, made public today a report on what the Administration had done to prepare for the end of the war in Europe.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 -- Californians intent on making it economically impossible for persons of Japanese descent to earn a living here after the war have failed, for lack of enough signatures, to get an initiative measure on the November ballot intensifying the State's alien land law.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- As a first step toward the eventual lifting of controls over the production and distribution of rayon yarns, the WPB today amended its rayon yarn order M-37-D. The amendment simplifies procedures for obtaining reserved domestic yarn, eliminates the necessity of filing forms by which yarn consumers obtained their requirements, and revokes reporting procedures.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace completed a series of brief, informal conferences with municipal officials and civic leaders in three West Virginia cities today as part of a survey of post-war employment problems in this and near-by States.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Alied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Communique 154:

LONDON, Sunday, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Marshal Tito's Partisan armies, fighting toward the Danube, stormed into the river and highway town of Zajecar in eastern Serbia yesterday in a drive carried within six miles of the Bulgarian border, the Free Yugoslavia radio announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Government, implying suddenly that "X-day," that day when Germany falls, might be expected at any time, but promising nothing, announced this week its progress for directing industry back to a peacetime economy, free of the shackles, the controls and, too, the incentives that put production almost four years ago on a total war standard.

THE first edition of this book, which Harold J. Laski perhaps rightly called "the most illuminating treatise on American government since the late Lord Bryce's," was apparently prepared between the first election of Franklin Roosevelt as President and his inauguration.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The story of a "forgotten convoy" which spent eight months in Arctic north Russia was told today by the War Shipping Administration.

IF anyone has had any doubts about the literary taste of the rising generation this book should reassure them. It represents the collective taste of thousands of girls who have read and sung these poems and ballads with Miss Ferris, and it is just as sound a selection as any advocate of the good life could wish.

THE newest index of the nation's manpower situation is the fact that the Forty Plus Club is now advertising for members. The club has virtually run out of members twice in the past six months, and its leaders are happily dismayed to find that its tactical position continues topsy-turvy, with more jobs available than it has members to fill them.

WITH THE ALLIED ARMIES IN FRANCE. IT is a gray morning in northern France. The command car, dust powdered, pulls up at the prisoner of war cage. Rolls of barbed wire have been strung around a meadow. The cage thus formed has been similarily subdivided into several smaller cages -- one for officers, one for non-corns, one for enlisted men, and one where the tents for the interrogators have been set up.

The final eighth of a mile, and a twenty-three pound weight difference, decided the victory at Aqueduct yesterday in the $16,250 Edgemere Handicap when the Havahome Stable's Strategic drove on to win from the 7-10 favorite, First Fiddle, by a length and a half.

Dr. Miland E. Knapp of the University of Minneapolis had a kind word to say about the Kenny treatment for infantile paralysis at last week's meeting of the American Congress of Therapy. He finds theft when treatment is started early, in the acute stage of the disease, very few patients develop deformities and very many recover the use of paralyzed arms, legs and other muscles.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 9 -- The Foreign Ministry announced tonight that Argentina had decided to withdraw from the Emergency Advisory Committee for the Political Defense of the Continent, which has been sitting in Montevideo, Uruguay, under the chairmanship of Alberto Guani, former Uruguayan Foreign Minister, since April, 1942.
Continued shrinkage of butter supplies available for civilians has caused some sections of the trade to demand an increase in ration points from 16 a pound to 20.

Regulation of prices is the one control which all textile exporters want retained after the war, it was emphasized last week in authoritative sources. Export licensing and other restriction of the Foreign Economic Administration should be eliminated without delay, they said, not only for the benefit of the traders but because it would afford the quickest way for all foreign countries to obtain their fair share of American textiles.

BUSINESS in the studios is pretty quiet just now except on the "Caesar and Cleopatra" set, where work goes on at feverish pressure, since Claude Rains is due back in Hollywood by October, and Vivien Leigh is what the columnists describe as "infanticipating." Most of the other units are away on location, shooting what they can before the English autumn clamps down on outdoor activities.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 9 -- This week's military and political events have made most Germans realize that "Festung Europa," more or less overnight, has become "Festung Germania." The Nazis' midweek appeal to Germans to meet the Allied onslaught by partisan warfare and the application of a scorched earth policy brought home the nearness of enemy troops to the Reich borders as nothing else has.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Spokesmen for the heads of seventeen aircraft manufacturing companies, following days of conferences with Army, Navy and Government officials, expressed confidence today that the military chiefs could submit to Congress at any time detailed plans for post-war air forces, that would assure the continued healthy growth of the industry.
A communique, broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

HOLLYWOOD. GLENHALL TAYLOR has taken over the production reins of "Sherlock Holmes" from Ned Tollinger, who is producing the Burns and Allen show. Denis Green and Bruce Taylor are the new writers of the "Holmes" stories, which no longer will all be set in London.

HOLLYWOOD Invades Broadway! Cinema Blitzes Drama! Write your own headline, but the story remains the same. And that story is that the 1944-45 theatrical season will go down in the annals as the year of the Great Invasion.

DESPITE the fact that the dispute between the recording companies and the Musicians Union remains unsettled, and despite the fact that a settlement still appears to be months away, both Columbia and Victor have been engaging concert artists in preparation for the day when record manufacturing will be resumed.

WITH THIRD ARMY. Advancing on Germany, Sept. 9 -- Fighting as determinedly and skillfully as if it were the Rhine itself, and not the Moselle River, they were defending, the Germans on the sector from the southeastern tip of Luxembourg to a point south of Nancy continued today to slug it out with the attacking American Third Army.

LEBANON'S promised "Commemoration de l'Independence" series comprises 25-piastres rose, 50pi green, 150pi blue and 200pi brown for postage use, these illustrating Government buildings; and, for air mail, 25pi green, 50pi orange, 200pi violet, 300pi olive and 500pi olive-brown, picturing a plane above places or citadels in Bchamoun, Rachaya and Beirut.

KONRAD HEIDEN expects to take two or three years to complete his sequel to "Der Fuehrer" (the Book-of-the-Month for last February), in which he stopped with events of 1933. He is working an Cape Cod and in Boston Libraries. . . . One third of actor Roland Young's autobiography, illustrated by caricatures of his friends, has arrived in manuscript at Houghton Mifflin.

CURRENT discussion about what to do with Germany and Japan after the war largely misses the point: It Is too much preoccupied with fighting the present war over again in the future, and springs from the heart rather than the head.

Twenty-four new courses concerned with current and post-war problems will be offered by the Hunter College Evening and Extension Division during the fall semester. Among the courses which will prepare students for post-war service are Music Therapy, Reading and Writing of Standard English Braille, and Methods and Materials in the Nursing Arts.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- Out of an entry of more than 600 dogs in the twenty-sixth annual exhibition of the Tuxedo Kennel Club, held today on the polo field of the Westchester Country Club, a fawn boxer carried off the beautiful president's trophy, offered and presented by Mrs. David Wagstaff of Tuxedo Park.
LONDON, Sunday, Sept. 10 (U.P.) -- The new Bulgarian Cabinet, as announced by Sofia, is:

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- Training activities of the State Guard units last week at Camp Smith here were marked by command post exercises conducted on the reservation under the direction of Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commander of the guard.

CONFRONTED with the stirring events of the present crisis, probably only the student of military history is interested just now in the events of a war of over a quarter century ago. However, the subject-matter of this article, of World War I origin, bears directly upon present and coming events.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- For July, income payments to individuals in this country amounted to $12,892,000,000, which is 9 per cent higher than the $11,846,000,000 disbursed in the same month of last year, Secretary of Commerce Jesse Jones has announced.

Start of fall trade in the week found department stores moving into high volume operation again at a pace 20 per cent above a year ago. The increase for the previous week was officially 9 per cent. August fur sales proved disappointing here as elsewhere and the industry is moving for modification of the 20 per cent tax.

LAUREL, Md., Sept. 9 -- Bobanet, an upset winner of the Walt Whitman Stakes at Garden State Park on Labor Day, came back with another triumph in the thirty-second running of the $10,000 added Eastern Shore Handicap at Laurel Park today.

CAMP SHELBY, Miss., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Spud Chandler, last year's Yankee world series star and now a private with the Sixty-fifth Infantry Division here, received an engraved wrist watch today as the "most valuable" American League player in 1943.

New York State's 1944 move against "strike suits" is almost back where it started. The Law Journal of Sept. 5 contained the decision of Supreme Court Justice Edward A. Koch declaring that Section 61-b of the General Corporation Law was unconstitutional.

GRACE MOORE, Metropolitan Opera soprano, was much pleased by the recent story about the use of her villa near Cannes on the French Riviera by the Maquis. The dispatch from France said the villa, Casa Lauretta, had been a relay station for French patriots fleeing from the Gestapo.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- About $38,000,000 worth of surplus war property was disposed of by five authorized Government agencies between May 15 and Aug. 15, W.L. Clayton, Surplus War Property Administrator, stated today. Remaining inventories on Aug. 15, he added, were $313,000,000, made up of a sizable quantity of slow-moving aircraft and gliders, as well as plants and real estate.
WITH AMERICAN THIRD ARMY, across the Moselle River, Sept. 9 (U.P.) -- Perhaps one of the most fantastic stories of the war is being unfolded in this sector.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- Liquidation was on again today in oats, rye and barley futures on the Board of Trade. All deliveries of oats except July sold at new low prices for the season, as did September and December rye and all deliveries of barley.
LIEGE, Belgium, Sept. 9 -- While our forces continue today their swift march eastward toward Germany, the mopping up of Liege has been virtually completed.

The barrels of flying bazookas, which the Army Air Forces have installed on the Thunderbolt and other types of fighter planes, are made of a special paper plastic developed by General Electric and the Byron Weston Company. The particular plastic used is light and fire-resistant to the launching blast.

The resurgence of college football in 1944 from its depressed position in 1943 and 1942 and a coast-to-coast resumption in 1945 were pictured by Asa Bushnell, Commissioner of the Eastern Intercollegiate Football Association, in a paper read yesterday before officials at the Hotel McAlpin.

DALLAS, Texas, Sept. 9 -- Byron Nelson hurried along with a 70, his third sub-par round of the Texas Victory open, today and it was enough to keep him out in front at fifty-four holes, but closing in was the man with a chest like a blacksmith and golf drives to match -- Harold (Jug) McSpaden.

RICHMOND, Sept 9 -- South Carolina is swinging into line with North Carolina, Virginia and Maryland in the formulation of plans for providing better and more comprehensive medical care for all its people. The South Carolina Medical Association has just announced a ten-point program to this end.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- Sidney Hillman, chairman of the CIO Political Action Committee and of the National Citizens Political Action Committee, today assailed Governor Thomas E. Dewey's position on international and national affairs, attacked his record as Governor and declared that this record should be a clear guide for labor and all progressive voters as to what could be expected from Mr. Dewey in the event of his election as President.

The "war of words" -- more officially known as "psychological warfare" -- has had a considerable role in the battle of France and will be of increasing importance as the Germans approach more and more closely to inevitable defeat.
Concerning the article "Adventure Rides in the Bus" in THE TIMES MAGAZINE, here is my own personal explanation of why people mass themselves at the front of the bus:

BROCCOLI, brussels sprouts and cauliflower are crops with which the second-year Victory gardener speculated to his present gain, for they will be at their best from now on, when the mainstays on the vegetable lists are almost gone.

ROME, Sept. 9 (AP) -- In seeking to prevent an Allied break-through into the Po Valley and a possible envelopment of the whole Gothic Line, the Germans fought savagely today to hold the gateway city of Rimini against British Eighth Army forces.

IN the days of his "Post Impression," which the author of "No Mean City" wrote when a member of The Evening Post staff, he signed his name to those excellent Saturday pieces. When many of The Evening Post men left Vesey Street for Times Square Mr. Strunsky was among them.

That flash of orange flame in the woods is a sour gum tree doing its best by early September. In these parts some of the sour gums showed color on a few leaves as early as three weeks ago, hastened by the drought. Give them another two or three weeks, however, and they will be firing woodland and hillside with the brilliant orange-red which only they can achieve.

The admirable editorial in THE TIMES of Sept. 6 marking the exit of Finland from the war summarized and appraised her situation with knowledge, good sense and sound principle that gave it an air of finality. This dismal episode that profited none and destroyed much is now closed, and Finland's misfortunes can no longer be so readily used as fuel to stoke the hate-Russia campaign.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- President Roosevelt considered world economic problems that will arise from the war with a Cabinet committee today as part of his preparation for his forthcoming meeting with Prime Minister Churchill in Quebec.

TO one innocent bystander, this "informal encyclopedia of knots" seems the knot book to end all knot books. Into its 600 double-size pages, describing "every practical knot -- what it looks like, who uses it, where it comes from, and how to tie it," have gone Clifford W. Ashley's forty-year "education in knots" and eleven years of actual writing.

The Priestley Medal, highest honor of the American Chemical Society, has been awarded to Dr. James Bryant Conant, president of Harvard University, it was announced here yesterday by the society, which opens its 108th meeting tomorrow at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Recent reports from Paris say that French couture is recovering from its dim-out and that soon it will return to its pre-wartime activities with formal showings as of old. New York hails the news and offers its warmest congratulations to the gallant couture.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- J. Edgar Hoover, FBI Director, said today that automobile thefts had increased 26.6 per cent during the first six months of 1944, compared with the first half of 1943, and that 64.5 per cent of the thefts were committed by youths under 21.

Paris--head and heart of all France--began to settle down last week to the sober task of reconstruction. The wild days of joy and hasty vengeance were over. Executions were ending. The Government, ordering the arrest of such collaborationists as Jacques Doriot, leader of the fascist French Popular party, and Joseph Darnand, chief of the Vichy Militia, officially frowned on such antics as shaving the heads of women camp followers.

THE first consideration in slam bidding is the solidity of the trump suit, with emphasis on the high cards held. When the object of a bid is merely to reach game, length is just as good as high cards: 8-7-5-3-2 is as good support for partner's suit as Q-10-6-4. When the object of a bid is an ultimate slam contract, the long, low trump holding should be subjected to some doubt.

IN spite of airmail, V-mail and soldier franks, America has returned to spiritualism as a speedy and exciting means of wartime communication. Between February and June, 1944, one New York department store alone has sold more than 50,000 ouija boards to credulous and incredulous customers.

The Babcock Wilcox Company, manufacturer of steam power-plant and related equipment, reported yesterday for 1943 a net profit of $3,066,809 after all charges, including taxes of $10,804,000 and a provision of $1,500,000 for contingencies.

THE affairs of the man Botts, salesman for the Earthworm Tractor Company, are not merely a super-success story wrapped up in comedy. Botts has the basic appeal of Mickey Mouse. He is the dauntless little runt who gets pushed around, taken for a sucker, humbled and ridiculed, only to emerge triumphant through sheer force of audacity.

The semi-annual report on the activities of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, made public yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Harold H. Kelley, director, showed among the large volume of services to active merchant seamen of all nationalities a total of 168,922 lodgings provided and 640,731 meals served in the first six months of 1944.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 9 -- Maine, which holds its State election on a date separate from that of the rest of the country, is expected to elect Horace A. Hildreth, Republican, as Governor, Monday, probably by a large majority over Paul A. Jullien, Waterville insurance man, the Democratic nominee.

Mayor La Guardia denounced New York University and the real estate holding company of Trinity Church yesterday as rent gougers that are asking exorbitant increases in rentals of commercial properties under their ownership or control.

AT least ninety-five out of every 100 lawns need repairing this fall. Summer drought has killed many, and others, less seriously damaged, must be repaired in order to combat weed encroachment. Adverse lawn weather has prevailed for over a year.

Maj. Gen. Kenryo Sato of the Japanese War Ministry, in a Tokyo broadcast, announced that a new air attack was launched yesterday against Anshan, industrial city in southern Manchuria, by about ten American aircraft, The Associated Press reported.

GENEVA, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- Completing a five-day up-State campaign tour, Thomas J. Curran attacked the New Deal Administration here tonight as failing to aid New York farmers, particularly during the recent drought. The Republican Senatorial candidate declared that the needs of farmers would continue to be ignored in Washington unless he was sent to the Senate to succeed the Democratic incumbent, Robert F. Wagner.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Only 500 salable hogs were received today, not enough to make a market, and prices were nominally steady, with the quotable top $14.75. The day's report of the livestock markets here by the war Food Administration follows:

BOSTON, Sept. 9 -- The wheels of progress in the American League pennant race, so far as the Yankees were concerned, came to a grinding stop today as the McCarthymen went tumbling down to defeat before the Red Sox, 7 to 1, in the second game of the current series before a crowd of 14,132.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- The White Sox defeated the Browns, 2 to 1, in the fourteenth inning tonight to drop the visitors into third place, a game behind the leading Yankees and a half game behind the Tigers. Chicago scored the deciding run after Jack Kramer, veteran right-hander, had forced the struggle into overtime with a homer for the St. Louis run and scoreless pitching for twelve straight innings.

An EducatiOnal Counseling Service to help the war veteran correlate his liberal arts program with practical career objectives has been set up at Middlebury College. Special advisers are available to organize the student's work in order that he may direct his training with respect to time in the most economical fashion; he will be helped to adapt the liberal arts curriculum as closely as possible to his vocational goal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9--The possibility that the end of the war in Europe may not come on any one particular day was officially acknowledged today in a joint statement by the Office of War Information and the War and Navy Departments that warned that more peace rumors may be expected to follow those that have already appeared.

Ready-to-wear manufacturers' associations are hopeful that initial "exploratory" meeting will begin within the next two weeks with officials of the National Retail Dry Goods Association to discuss a uniform order and confirmation blank, it was learned during the week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- While discussions among the British, United States and Russian delegations at Dumbarton Oaks were being prolonged by differences over the status of the smaller countries, Washington diplomats representing the lesser powers were keenly interested today in the outcome of this deadlock on the world security organization.
BOSTON, Sept. 9 -- Widening liberation of Europe and publication of plans for the discharge of service men have made New England think more seriously of post-war rehabilitation this week.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 -- The fact that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey is making four major addresses on the West Coast during his seven-speech tour fits in perfectly with Coast opinion that here, indeed, is an area needing intensive cultivation by the Republicans before Election Day.

BOYS and girls, like the rest of us, need to feel that they are in there pitching. Leaders of children's groups contend that a job is never too hard or too boring if the youngsters feel that it is really important.

LONDON, Sept. 9--Bulgaria, rapidly ridding herself of the men who tied the country to Germany during the last four years, got her second new Government in two weeks tonight and an armistice in the four-day-old war with Russia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Secretary Forrestal pinned the Legion of Merit today on George R. Tweed in recognition of his almost two years of hiding from the Japanese on Guam and providing valuable information to American forces which recaptured the island.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 9 -- Russian influence in southeastern Europe, embracing, roughly, that area from Trieste to the Carpathians and the Danube delta, is today at a zenith never before attained in the complicated history of that area.

The decision of Mrs. Crystal Bird Fauset, former Democratic member of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives, to support Governor Dewey for the Presidency constitutes "sensational evidence of a very marked change in Negro opinion on political matters," Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican national chairman, declared yesterday in announcing she would make a series of speeches for the Dewey-Bricker ticket.

IT is another great advantage of a democratic system that almost any viewpoint on the nature and problems of the coming peace can obtain a hearing. The four books under consideration constitute a symposium in the sense that each is dominated by a somewhat different leading idea.
DETROIT, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Tigers, roaring down the September stretch after their first American League pennant since 1940, belted the Indians, 15 to 6, today before 9,529.

ROME, Sept. 9 -- President Roosevelt's statement on the necessity of sending more food and supplies to civilian Italy was prominently displayed in all newspapers here today. Although the only one that had commented so far did so unfavorably, there can be no doubt that the statement was received by most Italians with great satisfaction.

MRS. KENNETH HORAN has hitched her story to a wagon and as for the proverbial star -- that will no doubt be beckoning out in Hollywood. Mrs. Horan's latest novel, "A Bashful Woman," concerns itself primarily with a family saga and assiduously and self-consciously with the story of the birth and growth of the automobile industry from the horseless wagon days up to the present.

THE screen version of Lloyd Douglas' novel, "The Robe," to go before the cameras early in 1945, will cost approximately $4,000,000, according to budget estimates just completed. This is twice as much as Producer Frank Ross originally planned to spend on the picture when he acquired the screen rights a year ago and made a deal with RKO-Radio for joint financing and distribution.

LONDON, Sept 9 -- Notice was given in the House of Commons today that the British Government would be asked to explain to Parliament Britain's role in the dispute between the Polish Government in exile and the Soviet Union.

AMID all the distractions of war a Congressional campaign was under way. It was October, 1918. The Germans had sued for peace. But the voters, as Mr. Schriftgiesser notes, had their minds filled with such worries as wartime taxes, food restrictions -- or so they regarded them -- and post-war unemployment. Republicans and Democrats wrangled over prohibition, woman suffrage and the farm problem.

Credited with the destruction of 101 enemy planes in aerial combat and 104 on the ground and the sinking or damaging of thirty-eight Japanese ships, including three aircraft carriers, personnel of Navy Air Group I has been returned to this country for rest and rehabilitation, the Navy disclosed yesterday.

MR. RISTER is certainly one of the outstanding historical searchers in the field of the American West, particularly the southern half of that West. His usual approach has been to take a certain specific historical current and give it factual outline, holding himself rather strictly within boundaries.

PREPARING for a post-war world, the National Association of Travel Officials announces a tentative program for its annual meeting at the Hotel Sherman, Chicago, scheduled for Nov.15-16. Members who have been doing considerable research on various phases of after-the-war travel will present their findings at the sessions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The CIO, looking ahead to the end of the war with Germany and many workers returned to a forty-hour week, called today for the same pay for forty hours work as has been paid for forty-eight during wartime.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Sunday, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Today's communique:

MONTREAL, Sept. 9 -- Tommy Gorman, general manager of the Canadian Arena Company, today described as "a miserable plot to break up a great hockey team" a National Hockey League regulation barring any player deferred from military service for other than physical disability.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 9 (AP) -- John L. Lewis asserted today that record production gave promise of plentiful domestic coal supplies this winter, but parried questions on subjects which, he said, would be debated before the United Mine Workers biennial convention, which opens Tuesday.

The completion of arrangements for the American Merchant Marine Conference and the eighteenth annual meeting of the Propeller Club of the United States, which will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Oct. 18, 19 and 20, were announced yesterday by Lieut. Comdr. Arthur M. Tode, USNR, honorary president of the club.

BIG JOHN OSNATO finds it difficult, after twenty-eight years on the New York City police force, to adjust to rural life. He moves awkwardly among the corn rows and the broccoli on his little farm in Reeders, near Stroudsburg, Pa., and he fondles the new calf as if it were a Great Dane, which is not practical husbandry.

LONDON, Sunday, Sept. 10 -- Russian troops raced thirty-seven miles across Transylvania to within 226 miles of Budapest, capital of Hungary, yesterday, while Berlin reported that Soviet forces had opened a massive new offensive in southern Poland in the region of Cracow directed toward the heart of highly industrialized German Silesia.

IN the first of the two stories in this volume Archie Goodwin, who is now a major in the Army, goes to work on Nero Wolfe, dissuades him from his idea of training to be a soldier and persuades him to take on a job for which he is better fitted.

IT takes more than a collection of the newest gadgets to make a handy kitchen -- as many a housewife comes to realize when she finds herself beating an egg with a fork or toasting a slice of bread over the fire because it's quicker than hauling out her streamlined appliances.
MUCH him been written about "the plight of the small liberal arts colleges"; little has been written, however, about the plight of those few civilian students lucky enough still to be going to them.

HAVING tasted the joys of theatrical production through a limited (in time) partnership with Billy Rose, Ben Marden is about to step out on his own. He is assembling an organization and is looking around, and he has cut himself off from his normal, or night-club, field.

Some of the arguments presented by James P. Warburg in his article in THE TIMES MAGAZINE are so wrong that they deserve to be refuted. His basic premise is that all Germans are not "bad." He seems to be fighting windmills, which is a favorite technique of the "soft" peace advocates -- because the foremost defenders of the "long occupation" theory do not assume that all Germans are "bad."

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 9 -- Following intensive strafing by carrier fighters in conjunction with heavy bombing by Gen. Douglas MacArthur's Liberators, cruisers and destroyers of the Pacific Fleet moved close to the Palau Islands Wednesday and shelled installations. Carrier bombers continued the air strikes, which began Tuesday and did extensive damage to military installations on the major islands of the group.

ROME, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Two Allied columns coming up from southern France struck today within twenty-five miles of Belfort, whose fortifications bar the way through a mountain gap into the plain before Germany's frontier on the Rhine, thirty miles east.

I WRITE this at a moment when events along the "doodle bug" coast are moving at a tremendous pace. It is possible that London has already received her last flying bomb. It is also possible that she may yet have to stand up to some last minute display of Nazi frightfulness.

The Aero Medical Association met in St. Louis last week and discussed some of the new and difficult medical problems that must be faced when fliers ascend to heights of 35,000 and 40,000 feet. Among the more serious problems are those presented by healed tuberculosis scars of the lungs and by the "chokes," an asthma-like affliction.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9--Following is the text of the report made to the President by James F Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization:

Charles Reilly, 42 years old, who said he had been earning $110 a month until Friday, when he lost his job as superintendent of the apartment building at 1708 Webster Avenue, the Bronx, was being held last night at the Bathgate Avenue Station after policemen had found four children from 1 to 10 years old abandoned in a three-room cold-water flat at 1687 Carter Avenue, the Bronx.

By way of chilling Harry Feldman's bid for victory No. 12 at the Polo Grounds yesterday the Braves poured five runs over the plate in one rampant inning and submerged the Giants. The count was 6 to 4.
OWOSSO, Mich., Sept. 9 -- Thomas E. Dewey's home town turned out en masse with three bands tonight to greet the Republican Presidential candidate.

THESE two photographs of the same woman tell more dramatically than words the way in which make-up can, if properly used, bring out good features. The make-up in this case was done by the expert, Eddie Senz.

BEFORE Pearl Harbor and the Japanese conquest of southeast Asia there was a notable dearth of books on India and the American public remained largely ignorant of the Indian situation. Since the Cripps mission and its failure, however, there has been a profusion of books designed to interpret India's problems for Americans.

As a result of numerous individual surveys showing general unpreparedness by industry for termination, financing and credit companies are now carefully investigating the preparations which are made by companies for "contract cancellation time" before entering into financial arrangements with such companies, controllers reported last week.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- For the second time since his arrival in Paris, Gen. Charles de Gaulle has made changes in the French "Provisional Government," apparently to give a voice in its counsels to the resistance and political leaders inside France.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sunday, Sept. 10 -- Allied vanguards are moving steadily forward in the battle of frontiers, despite desperate reinforcement and realignment and savage counter-attacks by the Germans.
BOSTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Two new plastics have been made from the plasma of Red Cross blood donors by Harvard Medical School's Department of Physical Chemistry.

It seems to be Lieut. Gen. Kurt Dittmar's task to prepare the German public for bad news, at the same time buttering it up to make it as palatable as possible. "We are being beaten," he said over the radio last week, "by the weapons we have forged." Strictly speaking, this is untrue.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in Australia, Sept. 9 -- On one fairly typical day this week our planes left sinking ships, ruined runways and exploding dumps behind them in the following normally tranquil archipelagos: Philippines, Celebes, Moluccas, Kai Islands and Palau as well as at Timor. In addition they attacked isolated Japanese forces in Dutch and British New Guinea and on New Britain, New Ireland and Bougainville.

A warning of the danger of serious racial disturbances after the war unless the Negro in industry receives equal treatment from labor unions and employers, made by Malcolm Ross, chairman of the President's Committee on Fair Employment Practice, and demands for greater tolerance between the great religious faiths marked yesterday's session of the Conference on Science, Philosophy and Religion in Their Relation to the Democratic Way of Life.

Recovery in the final few minutes of trading on the Stock Exchange gave the stock market a firm tone at its Saturday close and wiped out some of the small losses that had appeared in the early part of the dull session.

Memories from the heroic past fleck the mighty flood of victory now swirling toward Berlin. France and the Low Countries are an age-old battleground, but the two great wars of all time were decided there within the memory of the living. Almost every town and village taken brings some sharp recollection of former days of valor.
Thank you for the article by Helen Hayes. It is timely, needed, and true.

ON a night late in June the American Negro Theatre invited a few of its downtown friends to see the production of a new play. Harlem was hot as only Harlem can be when the air is breathless. The reviewers, screen representatives, agents who went into the basement theatre of the library on 135th Street had the sensation of stepping forlornly into a furnace.

FORCED landings at sea by land planes -- and even by sea planes that weren't meant to ride out long spells of rough weather -- are so much a part of this war that in particularly "busy" areas both Britain and the United States maintain regular rescue services and provide special instruction in "ditching" procedure for pilots and crews.

MOSCOW, Sept. 9 -- The rapid clearing of German troops from Bulgaria implied in the Sofia Government's declaration of war on the Reich and the Red Army's swift advance down the Black Sea coast raised today the question whether Allied supplies for the Red Army now fighting in the Balkans might be materially speeded by convoys going through the Dardanelles and the Black Sea.

ROME, Sept. 9 (U.P.) -- Hit by 123 rocket projectiles, the former liner Rex lay on her side in Trieste harbor tonight, burning fiercely and apparently abandoned by German engineers who had reportedly planned to sink the vessel to block the mouth of the harbor.

PARIS, Sept. 9 (U.P.) -- The Commissioner of the Interior announced today the arrest of Rene Fonck, France's greatest flying ace of the First World War, and Rohan Chabot, director of the French Red Cross, on charges of collaborating.

The article on the ups and downs of the mustache in American life made me chuckle no end. An anthropologist from Columbia University is quoted as saying that our contemporary mustache wearers must be regarded as nonconformists, in bold defiance of style and convention.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- The advance of the Allied armies in western Europe has brought the problem of relieving liberated Europe to a head with unexpected suddenness. Hardly had our Army and the French civilian authorities met the more urgent needs of the Paris population by flying in foodstuffs and relief supplies than Brussels was freed and the problem is moving on to Amsterdam and Rotterdam.

We owe to this class the chairs we sit down on, the clothes we wear, the houses we live in; and, indeed (when we come to think of it), we probably belong to this class ourselves.
In preparation for the shock of post-war competition, food distributors are improving their credit position and are building surpluses, according to a canvass of the trade last week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Holland M. Smith of the United States Marines, commanding general of American forces that drove the Japanese from Saipan, reported today he had been "forced" to relieve Army Maj. Gen. Ralph Smith, who commanded Army forces during that operation.

The Moscow radio has again appealed to the Spanish people to oust the Falange party and the regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franco and thus prevent their country from becoming "the home of Hitlerites condemned by the justice of the anti-Hitlerite coalition."

RADIOWISE, autumn is here when those sustaining shows go back where they came from and the evening hours once again are given up to the stars who make us tear off the boxtops or, at least, listen a little more regularly.

SINCE business issues are bound to have a leading place in the discussions throughout the Presidential campaign now under way, it proved disappointing to some business men to hear Governor Dewey in his opening address try once more to fasten the label of "depression" upon the whole period from the collapse in 1929 to 1940.

IF the sole function of a horror story is to horrify, this volume can be safely recommended to all addicts of clear conscience and strong stomach (though "safely" may not be quite the right word). Mr. Wandrei, described on the jacket as "a tall thin man of St. Paul, Minn.," has published two books of poems and contributed to Esquire, Argosy, Weird Tales and The Minnesota Quarterly.

Schools and colleges begin the new school year, the third year of the war, challenged by current questions and future uncertainties. Among the more pressing and persistent problems born of the war is the continued teacher shortage.

A SHY little girl and a shy old lady don't sound like a recipe for a happy summer and Penny's visit to Great-Aunt Pene lope didn't start off very well. If Penny, miserably homesick, hadn't started to run away, been beguiled by a home-made circus and frightened by a cow she might never have known how nice a person Aunt Penelope really was.

IT was a short, pointed letter from a private. It seems that he was driving his jeep along Route 7, on the way to Sparanise one afternoon, when two soldiers waved at him. Could The Stars and Stripes lost and found department please find out who those two soldiers were?

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 7 (Delayed) -- A handsome young King, the tires of his automobile screaming as he whipped out of the palace driveway and drove off into the night, exchanging shots with the enemy --

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Representatives of management, labor and the public, who for three days have been in closed session at the National Post-war Conference here, issued tonight a statement that it had been decided that the test of United States foreign trade policy is whether it means more or fewer jobs.

Although Paris has been liberated less than a fortnight, buyers last week were already wondering how soon the Parisian influence will be felt in fashions, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

The British radio's military correspondent, Lieut. Gen. Waisson, said yesterday that the purpose behind the operational blackout of fighting-front news from Allied Supreme Headquarters was to keep Germany fighting in "this last battle" like a "blind man with one hand tied behind his back."

But to get the record straight at the outset, it should be explained that the actor's estimate of the actor is a purely objective one based on accumulated, and rapidly mounting, evidence.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Governor Dewey's foreign policy speech was applauded today by Chairman Connally of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, who declared that advocates of an international peace organization welcomed support of the Republican Presidential nominee.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 9 -- Sale of the facilities of the Eastern Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Camden and Atlantic Telephone Company, which furnish telephone service in portions of Camden, Cape May and Gloucester Counties, to the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company for $1,615,113 was approved today by the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners.
BUFFALO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Seventeen-year-old Theodore Maher of Riverside, Conn., was declared champion at the close of the National Lightning Class Association's two-day regatta today.

Chester I. Barnard, president of the United Service Organizations, emphasized yesterday that, no matter how sudden the impending armistice with Germany might be, there would be no sharp reduction in the need for USO service to the armed forces.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 9 -- S.M. Johnston, Alabama lawyer who resigned as a Presidential elector because he felt that he could not vote for Mr. Roosevelt in the electoral college, started the South to thinking.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The National League's only remaining battle, for second place, tightened perceptibly today as the Reds took their second straight game from the Pirates, 3 to 2, cutting the Pirates' lead over them to four games.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 9 -- Delayed at the start for 2 hours and 15 minutes today, the fourth session of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's race week was finally run off, to the relative satisfaction of almost everybody concerned.

The Metropolitan Golf Association, after a successful season of one-day tournaments and the renewal of its championship, has released its revised handicap list which contains about two hundred more names than appeared last June.

NOW that the film biography "Wilson" has shown here for more than five weeks and continues to draw full-house business at the vast Roxy Theatre, it is safe to concede that the public has elected it a hit and has nullified any anxiety which its canny producer may have felt.

FALL is in the offing, and the start of cooler weather will mean a revived interest in baking. To save sugar and shortening one might explore the potentialities of sweet yeast dough, which may be converted into coffee cakes, buns and all sorts of good things. A basic recipe follows, together with directions for using it to advantage.

The House of Representatives of the Japanese Diet, acting swiftly on a request by Premier Gen. Kuniaki Koiso for a supplementary budget of 31,000,000,000 yen, last night gave its rubber stamp approval to the huge expenditure following a short period of formal questioning on Koiso's administrative policy.

" To determine whether a law or an attitude is just," said Tolstoy, "it is sufficient to imagine it applied to a child. I should wish in this letter to measure the present tragedy of Warsaw against just such a human standard.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- A walkout of nearly 600 union workers at the Dodge Chicago plant, makers of the B-29 Superfortress, ended today after a soldier who had been wounded in Italy pleaded with the workers to go back to their jobs.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- A plan to enlist the services of food brokers all over the nation in moving accumulating surpluses of canned foods came a step nearer today with the release of a sample contract which the War Food Administration is proposing to brokers. While the contract has not yet reached its final state, it indicates the lines which WFA officials may take.

LONDON, Sept. 9 (Canadian Press) -- A crowd of 45,000 watched a Combined Services team trounce a Northern Ireland side, 8 -- 4, at Belfast today, while the second largest crowd -- 24,000 -- saw Liverpool and Manchester City battle to a 2-2 draw in an English League North soccer game.

The march of the armies of the United Nations through Europe to the borders of Germany, liberating or threatening to liberate in its path, cities and countries which have substantial amounts of dollar bonds outstanding here, has awakened widespread interest of late in the market for those obligations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Acting on orders of the President, the Army announced tonight it was taking over the plant of the Twentieth Century Brass Company in Minneapolis.

TONIGHT will see the opening of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo in its second season at the City Center. On the first bill will be one of the two novelties scheduled for the fortnight's engagement. This is George Balanchine's choreographic setting of Stravinsky's "Danses Concertantes," with scenery and costumes by Eugene Berman.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- Central Western business leaders greeted with praise and criticism the War Production Board's announcement this week that controls over civilian production would be virtually eliminated after Germany's defeat.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Pacific press release 552:

Tomorrow an estimated 860,000 New York City school children return to their classrooms. Elsewhere across the United States more than 40,000,000 students already have been at their books or are making preparations to return this month to their studies in elementary schools, high schools, colleges and universities.

THE first edition of this book was published early in 1944. Its aim was to provide a general guide to all those who come in contact with occupied territories and to analyze the economic problems which follow in the wake of a war of movement.

The woman who police believed would lead them to a solution of the two-weeks-old murder of Mrs. Phyllis Lyons Newmark succeeded yesterday only in tangling further the contradictory skeins enveloping the victim's movements on the night before she was found strangled in a clump of brush behind the Hayden Planetarium on Aug. 25.

FOUR more U.S.S.R. stamps illustrating medals presented for gallantry in battle have been received by J. H. Stolow. On a 15-kopecs red is pictured the emblem of the Order of the Great Patriotic War, the Soviet name for the present conflict, and the design of the emblem features the familiar hammer-and-sickle device.
JAMES J. JOHNSTON was discovered gleefully rubbing his hands and delightedly scanning a sheaf of newspaper clippings.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Signator, who races for Herbert Woolf's Woolford Farm of Kansas City, finally found a band he could defeat at Hawthorne today. The 6-year-old son of Insco captured the Speed Handicap, a six-furlong race, which enriched his owner by $6,225.
ST. LOUIS, Sept.9 (AP) -- The Cubs broke loose with a bang tonight to break a jinx and defeat the Cardinals, 6 to 1, for the first time in sixteen meetings this season.

WITH AMERICAN CAVALRY, Southeast of Nancy, France, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Mechanized American cavalrymen, largely from Brooklyn, the 'Bronx and New Jersey, described during a lull in "kraut picking" today how they wiped out a German armored column of SS troops with Indian-style tactics.

AS one of the features of its twentieth anniversary issue, The Saturday Review of Literature asked a large number of the country's literary commentators to nominate the leading American novelist and the leading novel of the last twenty years.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 9 -- The question of bail for Mrs. Job Taylor 2d, who is being held in the Suffolk County jail on charges of grand larceny, will be discussed Monday in a conference between District Attorney Fred J. Munder and her attorneys.

A GROUP of shrubs, uncommon in our gardens, yet valuable for bloom this month, consists of bush clovers (Lespedeza). A few are hardy here in the North and are more or less alike in having trifoliolate leaves and large clusters of small red or purple pea-like flowers.

WHAT may perhaps be regarded as the first exhibition of the new season opened Friday at the Brooklyn Museum. The show consists of some 600 prints, blocks and photostats arranged in ten groups on the second floor and together the work presents a cross-section of the monumental output of some 20,000 prints by the Mexican artist Posada.

PLANDOME, L.I., Sept. 9 -- After three teams had led the qualifying parade in the Plandome Golf Club's member-guest tournament, only one remains in the running for honors going into tomorrow's semi-final round.
Business was not very active yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and prices eased to close at net losses of 3 to 9 points.

Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York, Republican Presidential candidate, headed west last week on his first speaking trip of the campaign. The task he had set himself seemed clear. Veteran political observers agreed that President Roosevelt was still favored by the majority of voters, though not by as large a margin as at this stage in previous election years.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Japanese, driving down the Hunan-Kwangsi Railway, have entered the town of Tungan, ninety miles from Kweilin, a Chinese communique announced today, and a fresh enemy threat loomed from Indo-China.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, ALLIED EXPEDITIONARY FORCE (By Wireless). TWO days before the start of the American offensive west of Saint Lo on July 25, the offensive from which the great victories of August and September stemmed, headquarters of the First American Army hummed with activity. Staff officers hurried from tent to tent, gazing thoughtfully at secret maps on which the projected operation was outlined.

BOMBAY, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi and Mohammed Ali Jinnah, seeking to solve political differences between the Hindus and Moslems, today began discussions that may pave the way for India's independence.

The Tokyo radio said yesterday that more than 500 "enemy ship-based aircraft" raided Palau on Friday while other carrier planes bombed and "enemy battleships and cruisers shelled" the Yap group of islands, about 350 miles to the northeast of Palau.

In presenting in this column suggestions for the pattern of a post-war tax plan no claim is made to originality as to concept of taxation. All the principles embodied in these proposals have been discussed herein over a period of years and from time to time have been urged upon Washington as worthy improvements in our income-tax system.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 9 -- The Battle of Germany, the decisive battle of the war in the west, is about to begin.

PARIS, Sept. 9 -- Paris, which in this as in so many respects undoubtedly reflects all France, is visibly and enthusiastically pro-American today as it has not been since 1918 and as it may not always be in the future.

SOMETHING in the nature of an at least semi-permanent public tribute to the aims and accomplishment of Alfred Stieglitz has been arranged at the Philadelphia Museum, where selections from the Stieglitz collection have been on view this summer.

IF you have a child of the picture book age who, in spite of your most zealous care, is suspicious of ghosts, he or she should certainly know Georgie. No one could be scared of Georgie, the most amiable little ghost who ever creaked a stairboard or squeaked a door.
OTTAWA, Sept. 9 -- Princess Juliana will probably look back on her four-year exile in Canada as the time when, despite all her anxieties, she enjoyed the greatest personal freedom and informality.
ROME, Sept. 9 (AP) -- A communique:

IF we are to understand the nature of the French resurrection flaming in the headlines we must begin to remember Paris as something more than a lovely tragic ghost. Nostalgic reminiscences of recent haunted years have left our eyes a little misty, our memory confused with chestnut trees, moonlit nights in the Bois, champagne cocktails at the Ritz and sad-eyed filles de joies waving us good-by.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Sept. 9 -- When Governors Dewey and Bricker and Senator Truman officially shoved off into the national campaign this week they set sail on as deep a sea of public apathy as any crew of Presidential and Vice-Presidential candidates has been called upon to navigate in many years.

Rutgers University has created a research council, the aims of which are to expand existing research programs and to encourage cooperation in research between departments in the university and organizations outside of the university, and to make available to scholars and the general public the results of research done at the university.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Buck Newsom pitched and batted the Athletics to a 3-1 victory over the Senators tonight. Roger Wolff was Newsom's victim, mostly through faulty fielding.

PARIS (By Wireless). THE terrasse of Cafe Vieil on the Boulevard des Capucines. . . . I am sipping cold beer -- there aren't any aperitifs; the Germans have drunk them all up. It's the hour just before lunch and the sidewalk cafes are crowded. Most of the people are French, but here and there are small groups of American officers or tables shared by GI's and their new-found French friends.

A new weapon against the black market in gasoline, now being tried out in Philadelphia, will be used soon in New York and elsewhere to uncover filling stations that make use of counterfeit or illegally diverted ration coupons, it was learned yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 9 (AP) -- A devastating third-quarter attack, which rolled up a pair of touchdowns and moved the ball to the one-line at the close of the period, paved the way for Baldwin-Wallace to capture its 1944 football inaugural at the expense of the University of Rochester today, 33 to 19.

OMAHA, Sept. 9 -- The V-day problem of the Middle Western farmer embraces considerably more than the readjustment of production to a peace market basis and of prices based on surpluses rather than on shortages. For one thing, on the farms and in the small town centers of farm community life they are wondering about the return of their men from the armed services and the re-employment of them.

WASHINGTON, Sept 9 -- The first three weeks of the Dumbarton Oaks security conference may not have disclosed all the subtle differences among the United States, Britain and Soviet Russia on how to keep the peace, but they have done a great deal to clarify and sharpen the viewpoints of the Senate and the Administration on this all-important subject of future security for all nations.

With the police issuing a strong request yesterday to holders of dangerous war souvenirs to turn them over immediately to the Police Department, which would ask no questions, the Bomb Squad engaged all day in the hazardous task of picking up bazooka rockets and various types of small, deadly war items that were suddenly relinquished by owners.

Named chairman of the labor division of the Democratic national campaign committee for a fourth time, Daniel J. Tobin, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, largest union in the American Federation of Labor, revealed yesterday that he is prepared to work with the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations for the re-election of President Roosevelt.

ARNOLD SCHOENBERG, who celebrates his seventieth birthday next Wednesday, reaches the proverbial three-score and ten never more fully possessed of the attributes that have made him one of the most dynamic and important contributors to the musical progress of the time.

NETWORK executives are beginning to admit to some real concern over what may be one of their major post-war problems -- the discovery and development of enough new microphone talent to feed television and an expanded broadcasting service when peace comes.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 9 (U.P.) -- Sister M. Jeanette, O.P., the pharmacist of the Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, Queens, N.Y., has been named first recipient of the Dr. J. Leon Lascoff Memorial Award.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- With Congressional and public opinion seemingly lining up behind the proposals for compulsory military training -- or universal military training, as the Army prefers to call it -- War and Navy Department leaders are giving extremely serious consideration to working out an efficient and truly democratic plan.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Salute to autumn here takes the form of increased activity on country club greens, an additional number of bicycle riders greeting the dawn on the eight mile Boardwalk and fishing piers crowded with anglers. Ocean piers adopt week-end program schedules this week with dancing to name bands and vaudeville billed at the Steel Pier, in addition to movies and the indoor zoo.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 9 (AP) -- A crowd of 21,061 on hand for the closing of Garden State Park's fifty-day race meeting was thrilled by one of the finest races of the meet today as the Cain Hoy Stable's Good Morning and the Longchamps Farms' Mrs. Ames staged a bitter duel throughout the mile and a sixteenth of the Vineland Handicap, with Good Morning dropping her head down for the decision right at the wire.

LONDON, Sept. 9 (U.P.) -- Norwegian patriots informed the Norwegian Government here today that the Germans were moving large numbers of troops out of Finland and into eastern sections of Norway.
LONDON, Sept. 9 -- What parts of Germany British and American troops are to occupy has become one of the most speculative questions for decision before the long-term future of the Reich is decided.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Sept. 9 -- The New Zealand Labor Government, which has accepted the Atlantic Charter with its pledge to build freer international trade, nevertheless plans to continue its present system of import control "as long as it is in the interests of the people so to do," Finance Minister Walter Mash said in the House of Representatives last night.

Between 800,000 and 1,000,000 veterans of the present war may study eventually at educational institutions of their own choice under the provisions of the Service Men's Readjustment Act of 1944 (GI Bill of Rights), the Office of War Information said recently in a report on what the bill gives veterans and what it means to higher education in this country.

EDGAR SNOW'S latest book recounting his experiences and observations on wartime visits to the Soviet Union and Asia is important not only because it is a well-written and intelligent job by an author with a wide reputation for his energy and honesty. It is still more important because of the conclusions it draws, which, whether you agree with them or not, are timely, forthright and provocative.
OTTAWA, Sept. 9--The secrecy that enwrapped all the major decisions of the previous Quebec conference will be even stricter this...

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Sept. 9 -- Governor Bricker of Ohio opened his campaign as the Republican candidate for Vice President here tonight with a slashing attack on the New Deal and a charge that the CIO Political Action Committee was seeking to "buy" a fourth term for President Roosevelt "with money extracted from the honest and patriotic workers of this country."
NOW that France is once again a free nation you can look forward to a resurgence of French films here this season on a scale unparalleled since the lights went out in Paris four years ago last June.

From Canada to Virginia the eastern seaboard shivered and twitched early on Tuesday morning last week. Sleepers in Ottawa, Montreal, Toronto, New Haven and New York were awakened. Dishes rattled, chandeliers swung, blinds banged against windows. The police and the newspapers were kept busy answering questions about an explosion.

WITH THE AMERICAN FIRST ARMY, in Belgium, Sept. 10 -- Forward elements of the American First Army are now at the German border.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10 -- Associate Justice Frank Murphy of the United States Supreme Court declared tonight that the tides of race conflict and bigotry were rising higher every day and proposed a six-point program to combat the former.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Corn made moderate progress toward maturity last week, although record low temperatures for this early in the season were reported at numerous points, and light frost occurred in some sectors of Wisconsin. However, the latter occurred in an area where little corn is raised.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 10 -- With the vote on the loan-increasing plan still delayed in the House and war news continuing with prospects for an early peace, cotton futures remained under water almost all last week.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Although trading in corn futures has been resumed on the Kansas City Board the Trade, it is expected that operations will get under way on the Chicago Board of Trade for several months, if then. The new corn crop is not yet made, and although farm feeding is expected to be reduced considerably, whether farmers will sell cash grain freely or not remains to be determined.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 10 -- Clint Stromberg has announced plans for a picture based on the military career of Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr. The film, to be titled "Blood and Guts," will have Charles Bickford in the starring role of the colorful American officer.

During the last week price increase for a large number of commodities outweighed price decrease and caused the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices to rise to the new high level of 113.27.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 10 (AP) -- The first step toward understanding the functions of social agencies is knowledge of the community needs which created them, Mrs. Natalie W. Linderholm, consultant on agency policies of the Greater New York Fund, today old the Training Institute of the Family Welfare Association of America.

The city's voluntary health insurance plan has been incorporated, and the incorporators include leaders in business and the professions and of representative organizations. When a board of directors composed of physicians and citizens is formed the time to invite subscriptions will have arrived.

Despite reports of a depleted and shattered Luftwaffe, the Germans "still have the best damned aircraft equipment and design right now," two aircraft engineers declared yesterday on their return from Europe aboard an American Export Airlines flying ace.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Senators beat the Athletics by 2 -- 1 and 8 -- 2 today before 8,057.

CHARLESTON, W.Va., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Mine supervisors at fourteen additional West Virginia soft-coal pits voted today to strike immediately, increasing to more than 10,000 the number of idle at thirty- one mines because of demands for company recognition of their union.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Producers of colored combed and carded yarns are not eligible for the price increases recently provided for producers of combed and carded yarns in the gray, the Office of Price Administration said today.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Reds sent 'em away happy today as they captured the second game of a double-header with the Pirates, 2 to 0, before 17,343 in the last home appearance of the season. Lefty Arnold Carter allowed Pittsburgh six hits, but in the first contest Bucky Walters, ace of the Reds' pitching staff, suffered his eighth defeat when the Pirates found him for a dozen hits and won, 7 to 5.

LONDON, Monday, Sept. 11 -- Russian troops attacking on a 225-mile front yesterday penetrated eighteen miles into Hungarian-annexed Transylvania in their accelerated drive to knock Hungary out of the war, and a Moscow dispatch said they were closing fast on Cluj, capital of the big plateau province and rail heart controlling Axis defenses.
LONDON, Sept. 10 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press.

WITH THE AMERICAN THIRD ARMY Along the Moselle, Sept. 10 -- Our forces continued crossing the Moselle River in this sector south of Metz this morning under the cover of United States Ninth Air Force fighter-bombers and a heavy smoke screen laid down by chemical warfare technicians.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Small plants should be permitted to reconvert promptly to civilian production as war orders are finished or terminated, without waiting for large plants to fill their contracts, Maury Maverick, chairman of the Smaller War Plants Corporation, said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- An American proposal that all nations join to guarantee world freedom of news as one means of preserving future peace has been drawn up here and may be submitted soon to other members of the United Nations.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Fifty thousand persons attended the opening of the New Jersey State Fair here today. George A. Hamid, director of the exposition, said it was the largest opening day crowd in its history.

A syndicate of investors bought from David S. Meister, operator, the six-story apartment house for eighty-four families at 611 Argyle Road, in Brooklyn. The house is on a plot 198 by 100 feet and is assessed at $320,000.

The war situation in Europe finds retailers cautious and loath to place orders as far in advance for spring lines as was the case a year ago, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

ON BOARD THE DEWEY SPECIAL TRAIN, En Route to Des Moines, Sept. 10--Thomas E. Dewey and his advisers were warned, during their stay in Mr. Dewey's native State, against over-confidence concerning the November result.

LONDON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The United Nations' radio at Algiers said tonight that Dr. Ante Pavelitch, Quisling dictator of Croatia, German puppet State in northwestern Yugoslavia, had been arrested by revolutionaries and handed over to Marshal Tito's Partisans.

Another continuing readership study will be made by the Advertising Research Foundation, it is announced by William G. Palmer, chairman of the board of directors, Which will be devoted to a measurement of transportation, or car card, advertising.
