NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 10 -- It took a 943-mile telephone call and $3 for reporters at Newark Police Headquarters last night to locate the sister-in-law of Pvt. Earl Estes of Missouri, who lives approximately 943 paces from the headquarters press room.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 10 (Reuter) -- Increasing numbers of German soldiers fleeing from the Aegean Islands are reaching the Turkish coast daily. The evacuation of the islands by German troops is now in progress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10--More than 1,000 spectators, including Navy men of all ranks, saw the wartime role of Navy doctors portrayed in the graphic work of artists sent to many theatres of war at a special exhibition which opened today at the National Gallery of Art.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Sept. 10--Steve Owen was pondering today the astonishing accuracy of a remark once uttered by Doc Barrett, Columbia trainer and gridiron philosopher. "Aw," said the Doc, "these modern teams consist merely of two football players and a lot of heavy eaters." The Doc has a very discerning eye for good trenchermen, since he himself has been known to polish off several hearty meals with practically no provocation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Plans for the immediate disposal, through regular sales channels, of 30,000 surplus Army vehicles were announced today by the Office of Surplus Property of the Treasury Department.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Relief pitcher Orval Grove's eleventh-inning triple, scoring Jimmy Webb, gave the White Sox a 3-to-2 victory over the Browns in the second game of a double-header today after the Brownies had taken the opener, 6 to 2.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- The brighter the news, the duller the markets, is how brokers here sum up the present position of the stock markets. According to the officially recorded number of transfers, business has improved considerably, but this activity is traceable largely to the South African mining market, which has come back into favor while other groups still are languishing.
Five new films are slated to arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

Mayor La Guardia and Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, welcomed back to the "best school system in the world" yesterday the 858,340 boys and girls who will answer today the opening roll-calls of all classes under the jurisdiction of the Board of Education.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich, Sept. 10 -- A substantial movement to rescind the union's no-strike pledge confronted delegates to the convention of the United Automobile Workers, largest CIO affiliate, as they assembled here today for the opening session tomorrow.

PARIS, Sept. 9 -- The American flag was hoisted over the American Embassy this afternoon for the first time in four years when Selden Chapin, charge d'affaires, arrived to reopen the building on the northwest corner of the Place de la Concorde.
PARIS, Sept. 9 (Delayed) -- French workers -- no one knows how many thousands of them -- are striving to gain a substantial measure of control in the industries employing them.

Millions of gallons of water cascading from a pipeline believed to have been broken as a result of the earth tremors that shook the city last week, flooded three sub-street floors of the Reconstruction Hospital, 100th Street and Central Park West, yesterday, causing damage estimated at $100,000 to medical supplies and irreplaceable therapeutic equipment.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Chinese battled today to stave off a grave threat from Japanese who had surged down the Hunan-Kwangsi railroad, menacing the important center to Kweilin, but the High Command said none of the invaders had yet punctured the Kwangsi provincial border.
HAGERSTOWN, Md., Sept. 10 -- The war's first airplane designed exclusively to carry military cargo, the C-82, was successfully test flown at the Fairchild Aircraft plant today.

James Cassidy, National Broad-casting Company reporter with the American First Army in Belgium, witnessed yesterday the first shelling of Germany by American forces in this war. The shells were fired from Verviers, Belgium, ten miles from the German border.

Detractors of the Modern, who complain that it lacks warmth and homey charm,' will have a hard time proving their point to anyone who sees the new modern rooms at Abraham Straus. With designs in furniture and wallpapers still "frozen," and the range of choice in fabrics and floor covering dwindling daily, the store's decorators sensibly refrained from attempting the spectacular and concentrated on color with results that are pleasantly cheerful but not over-stylized.

It was the last visit of the season for the Braves at the Polo Grounds. And despite the fact it was that rarity in this baseball age, a single game on the Sabbath, there were 13,782 fans present. The weather was ideal. A warm sun, tempered by a lazy breeze, beat down on a scene of pastoral beauty, and stands that were three-quarters empty.

PANAMA, Sept. 10 -- "Our colleague, Prensa, of Buenos Aires, sounds off in a peeved tone in commenting on Secretary Hull's most recent rebuke to Argentina," says an editorial in the Star and Herald today.

With a weaker team than the[ one that tied a picked New YorkI eleven on Decoration Day, the RAF soccer players from the Air[ Navigation School of PIamilton, Ont., failed against the combina-I tion representing the New Yorki Americans and Brookhattans of the American Soccer League in the return match at Starlight Park before 5,500 fans yesterday.

Miss Marion Martin of Bangor, Me., assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee, predicted yesterday on her return from a cross-country organizing trip that the Republican party would carry Maine's State election today "by over 50,000 votes."

Fifty thousand residents of Manhattan, Staten Island and the Bronx may receive instruction in City College evening session extension courses, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Robert A. Love and Dr. Walter A. Knittle, co-directors of the program.

HALIFAX, N. S., Sept. l0 0J)-Prime Minister Churchill, arriving here today en route to his conference with President Roosevelt, told a we'/coming crowd that never before since the war began have the skies been brighter.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- A currency protection branch, patterned after the Treasury Department's Secret Service, has been set up in the Office of Price Administration to fight counterfeiting of ration coupons.

DETROIT, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Tigers and the Indians divided a double-header today before Detroit's largest crowd of the season, 52,691 paid, Cleveland taking the second game, 7 to 4, on Steve Gromek's seven-hit pitching. Detroit held the American League lead for two hours on Hal Newhouser's four-hit 5-to-0 triumph in the first game.

Net losses of 10 to 16 points occurred in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange last week following declines of 15 to 31 points in the preceding week. Prices moved irregularly throughout the period. The decline started about the middle of the preceding week.

OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 9 -- Tastier and more varied rations are in store for American combat soldiers, Brig. Gen. Milton O. Boone, commanding general of the California quartermaster depot, said today in stating that combat ration "C" had been improved with an increase in the variety of meats and several other changes.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Communique 155:

The city that once boasted enough space to hold any man's army, now strains at the seams of its skyscrapers as an available apartment becomes as rare as a white-walled tire. The situation is desperate and the city is taking action.

LONDON, Sept 10 -- The liberation of Antwerp opens a new and possibly somewhat unsettled future for the diamond trade. It is estimated that before the war Antwerp was responsible for cutting 80 per cent in value of the world's diamonds and that it employed about 23,000 workers.
Alvan D. Peabody has been elected head of a new rural market development department of the electric appliance division of the Westinghouse Electric Manufacturing Company.
LONDON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Allied military authorities in Rome tonight confirmed a broadcast statement from. Marshal Tito's headquarters that no Allied land forces were operating in Yugoslav territory.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Chungking in English to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Reflecting the growing belief that peace in Europe is only a matter of a few months at most, grain markets have been going through the process of readjustment from a war to a peace economy, with the result that prices have declined sharply.

The letter of Donald Lines Jacobus in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 1, proposing the drafting of Germans as laborers in the rebuilding of their devastation, expresses the feelings of many others, practical or impractical as the idea may be.
LONDON, Sept. 10 (UP) -- A United State Strategic Air Forces in Europe announcement:

John Hersey's best-selling novel about the American occupation of a Sicilian town, "A Bell for Adano," has sold more than 95,000 copies since publication Feb. 7 and is now in its tenth printing. French, Portuguese and Swedish language rights to the book have been sold.

WITH UNITED STATES SEVENTH ARMY, in Southern France, Sept. 9 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Some details of the four-year passive fight in which French war factory owners, managers and workers slowed down work for the Nazis but sought to maintain production at the exact level that would keep the Germans from transferring machinery and workers to Germany were recounted two days ago beside the smoking ruins of the great Schneider-Creusot steel and armaments plant.

These are hectic and rather bewildering days to the orthodox military strategists and their armchair disciples on the air and in editorial sanctums. The war simply refuses to behave as well-mannered wars should. It will not fall into the traditional pattern, much to the confusion if not disappointment of old-time observers.

Fervent prayers for victory, a just but firm peace and the eradication of every vestige of religious or racial bias in this country as well as in the post-war world were uttered yesterday afternoon at an Interfaith Citizens Rally attended by 5,000 persons in Randalls Island Stadium presided over by Mayor La Guardia.

LONDON, Monday, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Nearly 5,000 Allied bombers and fighters from Britain and Italy blasted Nazi targets, from the Channel to Germany and Austria, yesterday in one of the heaviest all-day assaults since the invasion of the Continent.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 10 -- The newspaper Nacion this morning, as did Prensa yesterday, protests against what it calls the new method of carrying on diplomatic discussions by means of declarations to the press and is careful to register its opinion that this innovation was introduced by Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Troop A of the Eighth Cavalry, which killed Japanese numbering twice the size of its own force while taking a jungle strong-point in the Admiralty Islands campaign last Spring, has been cited for battle honors by President Roosevelt.

From early morning until late last night the Police Department's bomb squad and emergency trucks sped through the five boroughs, collecting dangerous war souvenirs from the present and the first World War.

Sidney Meyerson of Brooklyn has purchased the Ernst Mayer farm of 150 acres on Bishop Flat On the main highway between Mount Kisco and Armonk, in Westchester County, and will subdivide it into two to ten acre plots. A John Gatenellow was the broker.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 -- The Yankees' slender hold on first place in the seething American League pennant race appeared on the verge of giving way today when one decisive blow by Oscar Grimes righted things once more for Manager Joe McCarthy.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that city officials would confer tomorrow with real estate interests in an attempt to work out a method for helping "desperation cases" to find places in which to live. At the same time he renewed his discussion of the commercial renting situation, declaring that the city faced the loss of a big corporation, Sears, Roebuck Co., because of the increase in rents.

PARIS, Sept. 10 (U.P.) -- Julio Hernandez, president of the Spanish National Union, said tonight that Spanish republicans in France were in touch with an active underground movement in Spain and that "our immediate aim is to overthrow the Franco government and the Falange."

EDGAR SNOW knows more about modern China than nearly any other correspondent, as he has ably demonstrated in his "Red Star Over China" and "The Battle for Asia." He is a journalist blessed with more than the usual quota of physical energy, intellectual curiosity and aggressive determination. He will go anywhere, no matter how remote, and suffer any discomfort and inconvenience, no matter how unpleasant, to get his facts.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Recent declines in the prices of oats and barley for future delivery border on the sensational and reflect a rapid improvement in the feed-grain situation. This is partly a result of decreased supplies of livestock on farms and partly a result of increased pressure in Canada to sell oats here.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 10 -- Five prisoners escaped from the Nassau County Jail here at 9:10 o'clock tonight after assaulting one keeper and threatening two others with a pistol to get keys that eventually took them to freedom over a fifteen-foot wall at the rear of the building.

Asserting that most members of the armed forces "neither know much nor care about Christianity," the Rev. Bernard Iddings Bell of Providence, R.I., urged yesterday that the church turn its efforts to winning the returning veterans. Dr. Bell preached at the morning service in Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street .

The Hudson City Savings Bank sold the apartment building at 125 Kensington Avenue, in Jersey City, N.J., to Gilda Glass and Gwendolyn Stock, who will occupy two of the suites. J.I. Kislak was the broker in the sale of the building, which was the old Otto Wittpenn homestead and was converted into apartments some years ago.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 10 (U.P.) -- An Atlantic tempest attended by winds of hurricane velocity now is 400 miles north of San Juan, P.R., according to a United States Weather Bureau warning issued here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Revision of the tax structure to encourage private industry to take the lead in maintaining an adequate post-war national income was emphasized in a report filed with the House of Representatives today by its special committee on Post-War Economic Policy and Planning.

ROME, Sept. 10 -- French troops have struck within sixteen miles of Belfort and are engaged in bitter fighting against Germans defending the gap leading into the Black Forest of southwestern Germany, Allied Headquarters announced tonight.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 10 -- Although it could do no better than finish fifth today, Bumble Bee, owned by W.H. Stanley, took the honors in the International class competition, of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club race week, which ended its five-day session today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10--Sitting on the outside and eagerly waiting to learn what is going on at Dumbarton Oaks is France, which aspires to resume her place among the great powers at the earliest possible moment.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 117.6 on Aug. 29, compared with 118.0 a fortnight before, 118.1 a month before, 114.3 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

In sessions devoted to group tensions as social, religious and intellectual problems, speakers at the Conference on Science Philosophy and Religion drew yesterday a grave picture of the future but found some hope for slow progress in easing frictions between minorities, nations and hemispheres.

We are told that vintners have found it more profitable under ceiling prices to bottle their wines for individual consumers rather than to sell them to large industrial users, who as a consequence have been hampered by a shortage of domestic sauterne, burgundy and other well-known types.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Monday, Sept. 11 (UP) -- A communique:

Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, told the seventy-two graduates of St. Vincent's Hospital School of Nursing yesterday morning that the need for nurses all over the world was the greatest in history. In addition to being a work of mercer and of spiritual satisfaction, he said, the career of nursing also offered fine opportunities to young women for self-advancement.

A broadcast Japanese Imperial Headquarters communique yesterday identified an airfield near Chengtu, 175 miles northwest of Chungking, as the base from which B-29 Superfortresses had raided Anshan, in Manchuria, Friday, and asserted Japanese planes attacked the big planes as they were landing at the base Friday night.

After the Labor Day holiday on Monday, last week's markets declined with much rapidity. On Wednesday Stock Exchange transactions rose to 1,470,200 shares, the first million-share day since Aug. 18 and largest since July 17. The TIMES' average price of stocks fell on Wednesday 21-3 points since the week began, reaching a figure not touched since June 10, when the invasion of France had just begun.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- A special committee of the American Bar Association, which opens its annual meeting here tomorrow, will declare in favor of a world organization having power to use "armed force" to prevent "incipient aggressions or acts of war," the president of the association, Joseph W. Henderson of Philadelphia, said tonight.
THE TIMES of Aug. 27 published a letter from the social studies director of the Pittsburgh public schools regarding my reference to the status of American history in that city.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Demand for all choice cuts of pork products continues fairly aggressive, but offerings here are small and the bulk of trading is at ceiling prices. Owing to the lack of desirable cuts, more activity is being shown in pig livers and other products.

HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 10 -- The population of the Finnish capital was startled and puzzled today by an air raid alarm fifteen minutes after a train bearing the German minister, Wipert von Bluecher, and his legation staff of sixty-odd on their way to the Reich via Sweden.

LONDON, Sept. 10 (U.P.) -- Marshal Tito Announced tonight in an order of the day that his Yugoslav Partisans, driving to meet the advancing Russian Army, had captured the important communications center of Zajecar, in eastern Serbia, five miles from the Bulgarian frontier, and had taken 1,000 Germans prisoner.

ALBANY, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The State Post-war Public Works Planning Commission announced tonight the approval of 105 projects for peacetime construction in twenty-eight communities at an estimated cost of $5,594,887. The State's contribution to the outlay was set at $101,630.73.
ROME, Sept. 10 -- Heavy rain, powerful German counter-attacks and bitter resistance in other places are holding back the British Eighth Army today in its Adriatic drive.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, Sept. 11 -- A Japanese tanker of 10,000 tons -- the size used by the Japanese for fleet purposes -- attempted to run our aerial blockade of the southern Philippines and met disaster.

The final battle for Germany has begun. The great pursuit that set such a glorious climax to the battles of France and Belgium after the victory of Normandy has virtually come to an end. Fierce fighting is raging again along the whole western front, from Belfort opposite Switzerland to Breda in the Netherlands.

The report of the Director of War Mobilization on the Government's plans for returning to a peacetime economy (or at least, after the defeat of Germany, to something less than a total war economy) is admirable in many ways. Mr. Byrnes tells us that with the defeat of Germany the requirements for war materials and supplies will be reduced by approximately 40 per cent.

Tonight's premiere is the postponed "Down to Miami" at the Ambassador. Written by Capt. Conrad Westervelt, USN, retired, the comedy has a latter-day version of the "Abie's Irish Rose" theme, embellished with a Miami Beach background.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Morton Cooper became the first pitcher in the National League to win twenty-one games today as the Cardinals won the second game of a double-header from the Cubs, 4 to 2. The Cubs won the first game, 9 to 0, behind the three-hit pitching of Paul Erickson.

For Americans to think that this is a Christian nation just because they call on God to bless their national dreams and ambitions would be "a blasphemous business," the Rev. Dr. Russell F. Auman, pastor of St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street, warned yesterday.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- In the rays of a setting sun, a Doberman pinscher paraded at the Westchester Country Club today. Deep liver in coloration, he was in marked contrast to the white attire of his owner-handler. It was the final scene at the twenty-seventh annual show of the Westchester Kennel Club, held on the polo field here.

Governor Dewey's opening campaign speeches "reveal that he has found no weak points in the armor of his opponent," Frank Kingdon, chairman of the New Jersey League of Independent Voters for Roosevelt, declared yesterday, adding that the Republican candidate is "failing utterly in his attempt to charge the responsibility of the depression to the Roosevelt Administration."

MOSCOW, Sept. 10 -- Premier Mechislav Gedvilas announced today that the Soviet Republic of Lithuania, through its own commissariat of foreign affairs, planned "to strengthen our ties with the United States, where 1,000,000 Lithuanians -- one-fourth of all our people in the world -- have found a home."

OTTAWA, Sept. 10 (Canadian Press) -- Dominion Observatory officials reported today that moderately severe earth tremors, described as after-shocks of the tremors that caused extensive damage in the Cornwall, Ont., district, had been recorded last night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The greatest obstacle to our post-war economic success is the threat of cartel control of the principal industries of the world, according to Wendell Berge, Assistant Attorney General of the United States, in charge of the Anti-Trust Division, in whose book, "Cartels: Challenge to a Free World," is about to be published.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Sept. 10 -- The police here are on the lookout for a sailor who, after escaping Saturday night from the Navy disciplinary barracks on Harts Island and swimming two miles across Long Island Sound to Kings Point, supposedly looted the shorefront home of H.C. Marks, head of the Howard clothes shops.
Vogel Rotkin, operators, have purchased 666 East 233d Street, in the Bronx, a six-story building containing eight stores and sixty-seven apartments, from the builders, through L.V. Hoffman Co.

In the famous valedictory address which he delivered at Johns Hopkins in 1905 the late Sir William Osler declared that "the effective, moving, vitalizing work of the world is done between the ages of 25 and 40 -- these fifteen golden years of plenty, the anabolic or constructive period, in which there is always a balance in the mental bank and the credit is still good."

Appointment of Francis W.H. Adams, New York attorney, as Democratic finance chairman for the State of New York was announced yesterday by Edwin W. Pauley, treasurer of the Democratic National Committee.

The problem of readjusting Jews who will not be capable of reintegration in Europe after the war is one of the most important questions facing Zionists today, Maurice Samuel, author, told 500 members of the New York Junior Hadassah yesterday in the Hotel Astor.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Exploding a three-touchdown rally in the fourth period, the Fort Warren Broncos defeated the highly favored Brooklyn Tigers of the National Football League, 21 to 20, today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 -- The highest proportion of Government securities compared with corporate securities offered within a single month was reported for August, the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today.

Among the major problems of post-war planning, deserving equal attention with matters of business and government, is development of the nation's spiritual resources and preservation of its religious ideals, Mgr. William A. Scully said yesterday at a solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

LONDON, Sept. 10 (U.P.) -- The six weeks' battle for Warsaw continued today in the rubble-strewn center of the city as the Patriot leader, General Bor, reported that fighting had reached "the limit of human endurance."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- A post-war program of lower taxes on individuals in low and middle income brackets was among the recommendations today of the House Economic Planning Committee.

PARIS, Sept. 9 (Delayed) -- Allied bombing assaults on vital German war industries in the outskirts of Paris literally drove the Germans underground. Even more astonishing than plans for factories tucked away in caverns has been the discovery that the Nazis were working on them last May, apparently confident the war would run at least another two years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, giving his views on radio problems in a copyrighted interview in the current issue of "Broadcasting," declared his opposition to any censorship by the Federal Communications Commission and urged a revision of the law to limit it to technical regulation.

ROME, Sept. 10 (AP) -- More than 1,000 American airmen evacuated from Bucharest to Italy after they had been freed from Rumanian prison camps, gathered at an embarkation port yesterday, where fifty-three of them received awards.

LOCUST VALLEY. L.I., Sept. 10 -- Society of the North Shore colonies crowded the Piping Rock Club show grounds today to watch more than 100 junior horse owners and riders stage the Helping Hand Horse Show, a charity event combining the Brookville Charity Horse Show and the Glen Head Junior Show with its own program for the duration.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept 10 -- With the election of Horace A. Hildreth, Republican nominee for Governor, in tomorrow's State election regarded as virtually certain, interest here centers in the contests for representatives in the first and second Congressional Districts where the Democratic candidates are backed by the Maine United Labor Committee, an affiliate of the CIO Political Action Committee.

A story that reads like the most approved brand of "Ruritanian romance" has come out of Bucharest -- only it happens to be true. It is young King Michael's personal account of the overthrow of Antonescu and Rumania's exit from the Axis. In it all the fictional elements of glamour, romance, comedy, dramatic suspense and rapid action blend perfectly.

QUEBEC, Sept. 10--Prime Minister Churchill arrived at Halifax, N.S., today to take part in a second momentous Quebec conference with President Roosevelt. Meanwhile the stage had already been set in this fortress city of New France, and the air...

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 -- Although Ben Chapman followed his usual policy of driving in at least one run to back up his pitching today, not enough of the rest of his mates could deliver at the right time, with the result that the Dodgers split a double-header with the Phillies, winning the opener, 8 -- 4, and losing behind Chapman, 3 -- 2.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. l0 (AP) -- From Tuxpan, on the Gulf Coast, to Manzanillo, on the Pacific, came reports today of whole towns washed away, thousands of people left homeless and marooned by rising waters and crops devastated by floods from torrential rains that have been falling throughout the past three or four days.

HEADQUARTERS SEVENTH ARMY AIR FORCE, Central Pacific (Delayed) -- Four American airmen recently took part in an experiment. They spent five days out on the Pacific aboard a rubber raft with only meager rations of rock candy and water and later physical check-ups showed they could take it.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Monday, Sept. 11 -- The American First and Third Armies were hammering the Germans back into the Siegfried Line yesterday, while the British Second Army was smashing through hastily organized German forces north of the Albert Canal and was moving steadily toward the northern end of the line.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 10 -- Street fighting and shooting affrays are taking place in Athens as the Balkan situation gradually emerges from chaos. Patriot groups and quisling security battalions have been clashing in the Greek capital since late August.
LONDON, Sept. 10 -- In liberated western European countries American economic missions like that in London, headed by Philip Reed, are to be created.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo officially opened the dance season, considerably earlier than it is accustomed to opening, last night at the City Center with the usual sold-out house and the standard quota of bravos and flowers.

We all have been reading with great joy the wonderful news about the jubilant Paris crowds. Will this exaltation ever be surpassed? It could only be when our boys return to New York bringing with them not only victory, as in Paris, but a new and genuine peace.

GOETEBORG, Sweden, Sept. 10 -- Some 2,600 Allied war prisoners, exchanged here for a similar number of Germans, started this morning on the last lap of their trip homeward after a more or less long stay in camps in the Reich.

DALLAS, Tex., Sept. 10 (AP) -- The birdies sang again today for Byron Nelson, the kingpin of golf's summer trail, and he had a par-smashing round of 68 to win the second annual Texas Victory Open with a score of 276, leaving the last of the field far in the lurch.

A tale of the wholesale extermination of Warsaw Jews was told yesterday by an eye-witness, Miriam Berg, 19-year-old refugee who spent four years in the city's ghetto and six months in a Warsaw prison camp where she was interned with her father, sister and American-born mother.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10 -- Operational difficulties last week were responsible for a half-point drop in the national ingot production to 96 per cent of rated capacity. Early indications are that the rate this week may be stepped up at least a point.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (U.P.) -- Secretary Forrestal said tonight that the Navy planned 600,000 new inductions this fiscal year to bring its strength to 3,389,000 by July,1945.
ROME, Sept. 10 (UP) -- A communique:

BALTIMORE, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Washington Redskins showed the Chicago Bears how the T formation should be played today in a National Football League pre-season exhibition at Baltimore Stadium, sinking the world champions, 21 -- 7.
CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 10 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., Sept. 10 (AP) -- America's vast productive capacity, if left free from Government controls, will provide an antidote to threats of post-war inflation and unemployment, Whipple Jacobs, president of the Belden Manufacturing Company, Chicago, said tonight.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the pubic which will mature within twelve months amount to $45,598,032,175. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, non-interest-bearing discount bills and notes as follows:

A high-wing airplane to carry thirty passengers or five tons of freight at 250 miles an hour for a range of 500 miles has been designed by the Glenn L. Martin Company as one type of post-wart plane sought by the Air Transport Association, according to The Martin Star, published by the concern.
WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES in France, Sept. 7 (Delayed) (AP) -- The speed of the American Seventh Army's drive toward Germany from the south is making it an endless nightmare for communications men.

ROME, Sept. 10 -- Europe is even more optimistic than America of the early end of the war. Europeans have lived so long under the spell of German military power that when they see the Wehrmacht in retreat everywhere they are certain its last hour is striking.

PARIS, Sept. 10 -- The Government announced by Gen. Charles de Gaulle last night -- the adjective "provisional" is already beginning to be dropped -- is regarded in political circles as representing a big step, but not the final step, toward the creation of a Cabinet that can claim the support of most of the country until elections have produced an Assembly and a Government that can be called fully representative.

Science, which needs the originality of youth to keep pace with its opportunities for service to mankind, is suffering from "too many old men at the helm" Dr. Thomas Midgley Jr., president of the American Chemical Society, reported yesterday on the eve of the opening of the society's 108th meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- President Roosevelt is expected personally to make a decision granting some appeasement from the wage freeze of the Little Steel formula, according to informed Government circles.

Although New York City coal dealers are entering the new heating year with virtually no inventories, they asserted yesterday that the solid fuel situation was better than last year because of better distribution.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 11 -- Restrictions on the use of dollar currency by Australians has considerably impeded the flow of American books to Australia since the war began, but it has been possible to procure a limited number through orders placed with Australian booksellers who can obtain import licenses.

Curfew laws designed to keep boys and girls under 16 years of age off the streets and out of public places after 10 P.M. unless they are accompanied by their elders or are on a "legitimate errand" were urged by the New Jersey State Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday.
ALBANY, Sept. 11 (AP) -- New York State's infantile paralysis epidemic is on the wane, health officials have agreed.

Several new instances of boosts in commercial rents were cited yesterday by Joseph Platzker, chairman of the Mayor's Committee on Rents, who declared that "the situation is really desperate." Mr. Platzker will submit to Mayor F.H. La Guardia today a compilation of complaints, including more than a hundred he received over the week-end, from commercial tenants who have paid, or have been asked in pay, increases in rent.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 11 -- Dr. William A. Sawyer, medical director of the Eastman Kodak Company, Rochester, N.Y., urged conferees at today's session of the Ninth Institute on Industrial Relations, sponsored by the National Association of Manufacturers, to place more emphasis on guarding the health of key supervisors, personnel and higher executives.

Yesterday was the last day for members of the New York Stock Exchange to report on their own trading in the shares of low-price motor stocks. The Exchange expects to require another two or three days to round up the reports of those who make a practice of being late.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 11 -- Supporters of John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, this afternoon invaded a caucus called by Ray Edmundson, his rival for the presidency, and broke up the meeting which had begun to discuss the long-standing, contentious question of district autonomy.

The premiere of "Maisie Goes to Reno," scheduled for Thursday at Loew's State, has been postponed, it was reported by the management. The current film attraction, "Meet the People," will continue for a second week.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- Into each life some rain must fall. Army is very likely to have one of the best football teams in the country this season but -- Lieut. Col. Earl Blaik shudders every time he thinks of it -- Navy will have a better one.

PARIS, Sept. 11 -- In spite of the Nazis, in spite of Vichy, in spite of material shortages, the French school system remains substantially as it was before the Germans took over. Busy with "other things," the Nazis intervened directly only in the matter of history textbooks, which they "purged" of any reference to German war guilt or German atrocities during World War I.

MOSCOW, Sept. 11 -- Soviet scientists reported today that frontline doctors, often working under artillery fire, had succeeded in restoring life to twelve of fifty-one severely wounded soldiers on whom new methods of respiration by forcing air directly into the lungs and introduction of blood into an artery leading to the heart instead of a vein were used after all outward signs of death had become evident.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 (AP) -Refinancing of the Gulf States Utilities Company of Beaumont, Tex., by an issue of preferred stock can be accomplished at the present time "on the most favorable basis in the company's history," Richard N. Benjamin of New York, secretary of the company, said today at a hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission on Gulf States plan to issue 120,000 new preferred shares.

One of the busiest days ever experienced in the new Criminal Courts Building developed yesterday when 620 defendants, mostly small food retailers, appeared in Municipal Term Court charged with violations of OPA regulations. Court attaches explained that the rush was occasioned by reopening of the court after the summer recess.
LONDON, Sept. 11 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Two ruddy-faced sailors, one tall and the other short, were the object of a police search yesterday as suspects in the murder of Mrs. Phyllis Lyons Newmark, whose body was found in the bushes behind the Hayden Planetarium.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 11 (AP) -- The question of whether the four-man State Racing Commission would grant the North Jersey Racing Association a license to build and operate a horse-racing track with pari-mutuel betting in Mountain View, Passaic County, remained unsettled today when a vote on the subject resulted in a tie.

Five 6-month-old puppies born on April 3 to a German shepherd war heroine at Fort Lincoln, N.D., and declared "surplus" by the War Department, received a howling welcome yesterday at the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals, 350 Lafayette Street, their first stop in their return to civilian life.

DALLAS, Tex., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Quarreling Democrats of the Lone Star State today rejected preliminary efforts at compromise and headed for an open fight at tomorrow's State convention over whether the party's twenty-three electors would be bound to vote for President Roosevelt and Mr. Truman.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Pope Pius XII sent a message of compassion tonight to Poland by means of a broadcast from the Vatican radio. The message, addressed to President Wladislaw Raczkiewicz of the London Polish Government in exile, was delivered at a crucial juncture in Poland's relations with the Great Powers.

The International Minerals and Chemical Corporation reported yesterday a net profit of $2,016,037 for the fiscal year ended June 30, equal to $3.11 a share for the common stock, comparing with $2,081,738, or $3.23 a share, in the preceding year.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Tuesday, Sept. 12 (UP) -- A communique:

WITH demobilization already looming as the great political problem of the moment, Dixon Wecter's "When Johnny Comes Marching Home"* is a book for the hour. It is a reassuring book, for Mr. Wecter has discovered that war seldom changes the direction of the American citizen-soldier's life. Mr. Wecter bases his conclusions on a rigorous and wide-reaching study of the aftermath of three great wars, the American Revolution, the Civil War and the first World War.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Goldman, Sachs Co. and Piper, Jaffray Hopwood will offer today to the public 75,000 shares of Pillsbury Mills, Inc., $4 cumulative preferred stock of no-par value. The stock will be priced at $100 a share.

WASHINGTOA7, Sept. ll -- %he Distinguished Flying Cross to First Lieuts. Andrew 2. De Melik, 150 East Fifty-second Street, New York, Frank E. Walker, 1530 Franklin Street, Hillside, N. J. Second Lieut. Emil S. Aason, 106 Aionhegan Street, Clifton, N.' J.; (reported missing in action) Staff Sgt. John W. Grap, 212 Oak Place, Plainfield, N. J.

Leopold Stokowski held additional auditions yesterday at the New York City Center for replacements and extra players for the New York City Symphony, which will begin its season on Monday, Oct. 9, at 8:30 P.M. Membership in the orchestra, which gave its first four concerts last season, is open to anyone who is musically qualified, the conductor said.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Japanese forces pushing down the Hunan-Kwangsi railroad apparently have crossed the border into Kwangsi Province and reached Chuanhsien, sixty-seven miles from Kweilin, center of the South China defense systems, a report from Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell indicated tonight.
Retirement of eighty-one men from the Police Department was approved yesterday by the trustees of the Police Pension Fund at their monthly meeting in Police Headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Senate and House conferees on reconversion legislation appeared today to be so bogged down that unless the deadlock is broken tomorrow they will request their respective chambers for instructions.
CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 11 (AP) -- A United States Fourteenth Air Force communique:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Government moved toward speedier production of civilian goods today with the issuance of General Regulation No. 2 by the Office of Contract Settlement, which provides machinery for war contractors to obtain 75 to 90 per cent of their costs and contract price within thirty days after the contract is terminated.

HAVANA, Sept. 11 -- President-elect Ramon Grau San Martin will take office Oct. 10 with the strong support of the Cuban people, but with a sizable opposition bloc in Congress, figures available to the Supreme Electoral Tribunal on final results in the June 7 elections revealed today.
KANDY, Ceylon, Sept. 11 (UP) -- A communique:
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Communique 156:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Whether their views were to be recorded secretly or in the open, those who have been closely observing the inwardness of political planning during the last twenty years or so would probably cast a large majority for James' A. Farley as first among his compeers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (U.P.) -- Chairman Robert E. Hannegan of the Democratic National Committee denied today that he had been instructed by President Roosevelt to "clear everything with Sidney" Hillman in behind-the-scenes maneurering at the National Convention in July.
QUEBEC, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The meeting between Prime Minister Churchill and President Roosevelt is either the eighth or eleventh -- depending on how you count.

Extravagantly draped turbans of fur and opulent fabrics were endorsed by the three designers who showed at the revue luncheon given yesterday by the Millinery Stabilization Commission in the Cotillion Room of the Hotel Pierre. The exhibitors, Peg Fischer, Laddie Northridge and Braagaard, demonstrated the feeling of release so prevalent in the collections this fall, although the rules regulating fabrics were adhered to.
MOSCOW, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Bereza -- which in English means birch tree -- won the twentieth consecutive running of the Russian Derby yesterday before 170,000.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 14 per cent last week over the like week of 1943, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The gain for the preceding week was 9 per cent.

An unusual Christmas present for service men overseas is the so-called photo pack, newly on sale at Gimbels. The sender of the gift supplies the store with a personal picture, either of himself or a member of his family or anyone else he wishes.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 -- This is the time of year, it would seem, when some enterprising entrepreneur ought to corner the market in crying towels and seek out the college football coaches of the land.

In every election a considerable number of eligible voters do not vote. In 1940, out of 80,000,000 possible voters there were 31,000,000 who do not vote. It can only be assumed that those who do not vote have not yet acquired an understanding of their social responsibilities, of their rights and duties under a democratic system.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- Charges that decisions of the United States Supreme Court "reflect the governmental philosophy and political purpose" of the Roosevelt Administration, that the court has "created a state of uncertainty" in interpretations of the law and that it is losing the "high esteem" of the people were made in a resolution offered today at the opening of the convention of the American Bar Association.

An encouraging factor in the liberation of western Europe is the prompt return of Belgium's exiled Government to Brussels and its equally prompt acceptance by a cheering populace. This should operate as a strong influence toward stability in a trying period of transition.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 11 -- B.G. De Sylva announced today that his first autonomous production for Paramount will be a comedy starring Bob Hope, and that his second will be a Bing Crosby musical. He plans to put the Hope film into production late in January following the comedian's co-starring appearance with Paulette Goddard in "My Favorite Brunette."

ALONG THE MOSELLER RIVER, Sept.11 -- Operating over territory they know as well as a West Point cadet knows the battlefield at Gettysburg, fanatical German cadets from an officers' training school near Metz are now fighting like demons from strong old fortifications on the west bank of the Moselle north of Metz.
ROME, Sept. 11 (UP) -- A communique:

While it was listed on the staid pages of The Playbill as a comedy, "Down to Miami" probably was a hallucination. All this season the faithful have wondered whether every other new play was not the worst in years -- a search that now can be ended officially.
PARIS, Sept. 11 -- There are still Germans in Paris -- nobody knows how many. But one responsible estimate is that they number more than 100,000.

The 21,705 who visited Aqueduct yesterday to bask in the shade of the grandstand and watch the rest of the world (and some of its horses) go by, could scarcely believe their eyes when they saw one favorite after another parade under the wire a winner.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull today issued a warning to Austria that the time has almost run out when she will be able to demonstrate her fitness to have her independence restored when Germany has been defeated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- An effort to return to the United States Tyler Kent, convicted in a British court of violating the British Official War Secrets Act while a member of the American Embassy staff in London, was begun in the Supreme Court today by his mother, Mrs. Ann H.P. Kent of this city.

One of vaudeville's stanchest admirers, Paul Small, doesn't mind organizing a variety bill whenever the proper talent is available. As a matter of fact, he always seems to be preoccupied with that section of the amusement industry and it has turned out to be quite a lucrative hobby.

A cursory sampling of opinion among New York's school-age population on the first day of classes yesterday revealed that they returned to their desks with resignation, if not with glee. In the words of one elementary school youngster who nostalgically eyed the adjoining playground as he entered the school gates:

Secretary of the Navy Forrestal, addressing the newly formed Navy Industrial Association at the Waldorf-Astoria last night, emphasized what should be obvious but which cannot be repeated too often, that to maintain peace after war we must have power capable of keeping would-be international ruffians in check.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Invitations to more than fifty countries to attend an international conference on civil aviation to take place in this country beginning Nov. 1 have been issued by the United States Government, it was revealed by the State Department today.

Pressure on the stock market lifted noticeably yesterday and under the mildest of prodding the list staged a general recovery, paced by the aircraft issues. The market occupied an advantageous position after the descent of last week, and the possibility that this reaction had provided a technical tonic induced some short covering.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- The chief interest in today's stock markets again was centered in Kaffirs. The Cape gave fresh support at the opening and some further gains were recorded. Later some profit-taking set in and the market turned easier.
LONDON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- Extension of the New York Central Railroad's Putnam division from its present "inconvenient" terminus at Highbridge in the Bronx to some point in central Manhattan was urged unanimously today by the Westchester County Board of Supervisors.
LONDON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Thousands of evacuees streamed into the British capital Sunday despite Government pleas to stay put and warnings the robot raids danger was not over.

QUEBEC, Sept. 11 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill arrived here today to open their second Quebec conference, thirteen months since the conference of August, 1943, at which they planned the final defeat of Germany. This time, their spokesmen made clear, they would plan the knockout blow against Japan.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- Prospective farm legislation became today the dominating influence in the grain markets, which were as strong as they were weak last week. Wheat advanced 3 1/8 cents a bushel and rye 3 cents before the bulge was checked by profit-taking and a resumption of commission house pressure.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Sept. 11 (AP) -- British Fourteenth Army Troops have opened an offensive against the Japanese in the long dormant Arakan sector in lower Burma and heavy fighting is in progress, it was announced today.

Hosiery manufacturers have asked the Office of Price Administration for price relief only to the extent of added yarn costs resulting from the Bankhead amendment, it was learned in the trade yesterday. Spokesmen for the industry asserted that early action on the part of OPA in granting the request would induce the largest amount of bidding by hosiery manufacturers on Government orders.

WITH AMERICAN FIRST ARMY at the German Border, 2 P.M., Sept. 11 -- The Germans fought back obstinately today with their backs to their own frontier. Our armored troops and infantry entered the town of Eupen, however, at 1:15 o'clock this afternoon after having fought all morning.

QUEBEC, Sept. 11 -- Prime Minister Churchill held up a troopship carrying American soldiers several days so that he could get aboard to travel to Halifax on the first leg of his journey to the conference with President Roosevelt, a spokesman for Mr. Churchill said today.

LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 12 -- The United States Eighth Air Force won a major victory yesterday, destroying at least 175 Nazi planes in a blow that may prove as decisive in the Battle of Germany as the Royal Air Force's destruction of 185 enemy planes on Sept. 15, 1940, was in the Battle of Britain.

A banking group headed by Putnam Co. of Hartford, and Chas. W. Scranton Co. of New Haven, will offer to the public today $10,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage 3 per cent bonds, series I, of the Connecticut Light and Power Company.
PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 11 -- Republican candidates for Governor and three Congressional seats swept the field in Maine's State election today.

LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 12 -- Russian troops in one of the fiercest struggles of the war yesterday drove to within three miles south of Lomzha, gateway to lower German East Prussia, and Moscow announced officially early today that Red Army patrols had crossed from Lithuania into that imperiled Nazi Province.

Mortgage bankers are awaiting the promulgation of the regulations which will put the home, farm and business purchasing programs of the G.I. Bill of Rights into effect. These regulations were expected to have been announced the first of this month, but those close to the situation say they may not be forthcoming before the first, or maybe the middle, of next month.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Oliver Farm Equipment Company has been called for Oct. 3 to vote upon issuance of new convertible preferred stock, a two-for-one split-up of the common stock, a change in name to the Oliver Corporation to provide for broadened activities and acquisition of the assets of the Cleveland Tractor Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The American, British and Russian delegates at the Dumbarton Oaks security conference have changed their draft plans to guarantee that the smaller powers will be consulted whenever they are asked to put any substantial amount of force at the disposal of the proposed World Security Council.
ROME, Sept. 11 -- Contact was established today between the American Seventh and Third Armies.

The owners of big Fifth Avenue apartments which are now going begging -- despite an acute housing shortage -- and landlords with similar properties elsewhere in the city would like to split these apartments into smaller quarters, which might be offered to newcomers and others with a wartime housing problem on their hands.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Reassurance that Allied airmen are being briefed daily on the exact locations of prison camps in Germany, in order to avoid the bombing of our own men, was given yesterday by Miss Sadie Lucinda James, American Red Cross prisoner of war consultant for the North Atlantic area.

Nearly 5,000 members of the American Chemical Society opened a five-day meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday and heard reports on new chemical processes that promise to make life more pleasant after the war.

In answer to a cabled appeal from the Mayor of Warsaw, Mayor La Guardia broadcast yesterday a plea for weapons, ammunition and supplies for the people of Warsaw, who sprang into open revolt against the Nazis five weeks ago when Russian armies drew near the city gates.
Four of the air lines of the United States yesterday bought from Douglas Aircraft, or indicated their intention to buy, a total of 108 four-engine transport planes.

Mrs. Marjorie Johnson Carter of Los Angeles, daughter of Nunnally Johnson, film writer and producer, and Gene Fowler Jr. of the Army, son of another well-known screen author and former New York newspaper man, obtained a marriage license here yesterday in the Municipal Building.

Your correspondent G. Nye Steiger's point in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 8, that President Roosevelt was as guilty, if not more so, as John Foster Dulles in misjudging Japan's intentions to attack the United States is hardly borne out by the evidence.

Sandals -- "barefoot" sandals reminiscent of childhood days and a sophisticated type more reminiscent of fabled Rome -- were a highlight of the new Delman collection presented yesterday at Bergdorf-Goodman.

A Washington dispatch to this newspaper reports that "according to informed Government circles" President Roosevelt "is expected personally to make a decision granting some appeasement from the wage freeze of the Little Steel formula." It is indicated that this might be done some time between now and election, possibly around mid-October.

LAUREL, Md., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Mrs. S.M. Pistorio's Quillon, claimed from the Christiana Stable at Garden State for $6,000, earned part of his purchase price by winning the Allabasi Handicap, featuring the Monday program here today.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Dr. Robert F. Hyland, who took three stitches in closing a gash in outfielder Stan Musial's chin, said the Cardinals' leading hitter probably will remain out of the club line-up for a week or ten days.
The letter forwarded to you by Reginald Purbrick, a Member of Parliament, concerning the Phillips resolution has been called to my attention. I therefore make the following answer.

Sidney Robinson, who operated the Piping Rock Club on Saratoga Lake at Saratoga Springs in the summer of 1941 and 1942, and who also is vice president and part owner of the Copacabana, night club at 10 East Sixtieth Street, denied yesterday that there was any gambling on the premises he leased in Saratoga.

BOOMBAY, Tuesday, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi told a prayer meeting last night, after several days' conferences with Mohammed All Jinnah on a possible division of India into Moslem and Hindu States, that, if the two did not agree, "the hopes of millions of our countrymen will be dashed to pieces."

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Mrs. M.J. Wolfson's Smart Bet scored his fifth consecutive triumph on New England tracks when he won the Swansea Purse by three and a half lengths today at Narragansett Park. It was his fourth victory in a row on this oval.

Placing himself definitely on record as favoring a year of universal, compulsory military training for all American youth over the age of 18, James Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy, appealed last night for the post-war maintenance of sea power and air power adequate to enable us to fight any future enemies at times and places of our own choosing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -Unusually abundant rains in August improved national crop prospects so materially that production this year likely will be within 2 per cent of the 1942 record crop and above production in any other year, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 11 -- Pacific Fleet carrier and surface forces commanded by Admiral William F. Halsey attacked Mindanao Island in the Philippines Friday for the first time and sank or damaged eighty-nine Japanese vessels of various categories, not including combat ships, destroyed sixty-eight enemy planes and swept five airfields and three ports with destruction from the air.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 114:

The women who lunched on the roof at the St. Regis Hotel yesterday got a pretty fair idea of the way they can and will look this fall and winter from the clothes displayed there by The Tailored Woman, Fifth Avenue specialty house.

Asserting that the report on plans for the return of the nation to a peacetime economy made by James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization, contains the "first break in the clouds on reconversion pricing," business men here said yesterday that the report put it up to the Office of Price Administration and Congress to make the next moves.

SIDNEY, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- Helen Hayes, the actress, speaking on the first day of a three-day campaign tour in behalf of the Congressional candidacy of Augustus W. Bennet of Newburgh, declared here tonight that Mr. Bennet's opponent, Representative Hamilton Fish, had been "a failure" in Congress.

LONDON, Sept. 11 (U.P.) -- Russian representatives were engaged today in simultaneous peace negotiations with three erstwhile enemies -- Finland, Rumania and Bulgaria -- and fuller collaboration between the Red Army and its new Balkan allies is expected to be one of the major results.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 11 -- From now on the problems of the peace to come and its maintenance in the post-war world "should be the business of every citizen, whatever his calling," Dr. Isaiah Bowman, president of Johns Hopkins University, declared here tonight in his address as retiring president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, at the opening general session of the association's first annual meeting since 1940.
ROME, Sept. 11 -- The Fifth Army has taken the offensive and swept up high ground to the immediate approaches to the Gothic Line.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11 -- Wendell Berge, Assistant United States Attorney General in charge of anti-trust cases, began here today a series of West Coast addresses on the future activities of his office.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 11 -- A vacancy created in the Cabinet last Aug. 25 when the Minister of Justice and Public Instruction, Dr. Alberto Baldrich, resigned was filled today with the appointment of Dr. Romulo Etcheverry Boneo. Since Dr. Baldrich's resignation the post has been filled by Minister of Foreign Affairs Gen. Orlando L. Peluffo.
William Miller Collier, former Ambassador to Chile, Mrs. Collier and Mrs. George H. Mason have come to the Biltmore after spending the Summer in Newagen, Me.
The Associated American Artists Gallery, 711 Fifth Avenue, opened with champagne yesterday afternoon an exhibition arranged to celebrate the organization's tenth anniversary.

Courses in consumer education dealing with current and post-war problems will be presented under the joint sponsorship of the New York City Civilian Defense Volunteer Office and the Board of Education beginning on Sept. 20 and 21, Mrs. Nathaniel Singer, director of the CDVO consumer services division, disclosed yesterday at City Hall.

The 1,059 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $101,581,322,714 par value on Aug. 31, had a total market value of $102,328,885,992, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. On July 31 there were 1,065 issues, aggregating $101,559,186,057 par value which had a total market value of $102,284,657,208.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Luxembourg's liberation was hailed today by President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

War plants and other companies that have been authorized to extend the working schedule of employes beyond the limit provided by law have found that their efficiency is impaired if they work more than forty-eight hours a week, Mrs. Emily S. Marconnier of the State Department of Labor said last night at the New York Women's Trade Union League.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept 11 -- A second group of Germans convicted of plotting to assassinate Adolf Hitler and overthrow the Nazi regime was hanged in Berlin today after a trial that proceeded as expeditiously as the one that consigned eight prominent military leaders, including a Field Marshal General, to the gallows a month ago on the same charge.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Representative Harness, Republican of Indiana, declared today "there appears to be an abundance of evidence" that seventy-two hours before the attack on Pearl Harbor, Dec. 7, 1941, the Australian Government had advised Washington a Japanese aircraft carrier force was headed toward Hawaii.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration, on the advice of leading educators, tonight guaranteed to pay tuition of at least $10 a month, $30 a quarter or $40 a semester for the college education of war veterans.

Obviously ill at east, Col. Donald J.M. Blakeslee of the Eighth Air Force, holder of the Distinguished Service Cross with Oak Leaf Cluster, the Distinguished Flying Cross with seven clusters, the Air Medal with three and the Silver Star with one, as well as the Presidential Unit Citation and a British Distinguished Flying Cross, faced cameramen and reporters at an interview in the Sherry-Netherland Hotel yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- Corporation taxes were condemned as "evil" by Beardsley Ruml, treasurer of R.H. Macy Co. and chairman of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, in an address today before the wartime conference of the controllers congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo last night gave a long and varied program as the second offering of its current season at the City Center. Opening with "Swan Lake" and closing with last season's new "The Red Poppy," it contained also Balanchine's "Danses Concertantes," set to Stravinsky's music of that name, which had its premiere the night before, and Agnes de Mille's "Rodeo."
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, Sept. 12 -- Germany has been invaded.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 11 -- Sparked by an individual 68 by Wiffy Cox, home club pro, the combination of Bert Edwards and Cox cut eight strokes from par to win the amateur-pro of the Long Island P.G.A. with 33, 32 -- 65 at the Hempstead Golf Club today.

GENERAL STILWELL'S HEADQUARTERS, China, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell estimated today that virtually the entire garrison of 2,000 Japanese died in the three months siege of Sungshan, the fall of which opened the Burma Road to trucks as far as beleagured Lungling.

Sales of leading mail-order and chain-store companies in August increased 13.6 per cent over the same month of 1943, the largest gain thus far this year, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES covering thirty-one companies.
An expanded program of entertainment and recreation for the Army overseas was announced yesterday by Brig. Gen. Joseph W. Byron, director of the Special Services Division of the Army Service Forces.

Starting his second week of campaigning up-State, Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for Senator, reported yesterday that he had been cheered last week by manifestations of Republican unity and enthusiasm for the whole ticket.

A new water-main break occurred late yesterday afternoon at 100th Street and Central Park West about forty feet from the break in the pipe that late Saturday night flooded three basements in Reconstruction Hospital Emergency crews working on the first break had to abandon their task to take care of the new leak, which threatened another inundation of the hospital basements.

Your earthquake editorial refers to Malone, N.Y., as the origin of that unseemly convulsion of Mother Earth. As a resident of that community it appears to me that to make us a pinpoint on the map otherwise unidentified is doing us an injustice.

Samuel S. Schneierson, manufacturer and active in philanthropic and educational fields, has been appointed head of the 1944 appeal of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, it was announced yesterday.

For readers interested in finding out why an author came to write certain stories, how much he was paid for them, and which he considers his best, MacKinlay Kantor gives his answers to such questions in "Author's Choice," published yesterday by Coward-McCann.

WITH AMERICAN TROOPS in the Maginot Line, Sept. 11 -- Striking across Lorraine, American doughboys captured a big segment of the Maginot Line today after taking the fortress city of Aumetz, the first town that Hitler had proclaimed to be a part of Germany.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The War Production Board, in one of its most decisive actions to check the shortage of military cotton textiles, today ordered held for Government use stocks of four types of cotton duck in excess of 500 yards stocked by all dealers, including transport companies, manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers.

A Greater New York committee, headed by Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr., which will work on recruiting for the Women's Army Corps, was announced yesterday by Mrs. Oswald B. Lord, chairman of the civilian advisory committee for Wac recruiting for the Second Service Command.

Production of many types of merchandise now missing in chain drug stores will be resumed faster than many think, once Germany is defeated, R.E. Skillern, president of the Associated Chain Drug Stores, said yesterday in an interview here. Mr. Skillern, who presided at the opening of the three-day wartime conference of the organization at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, reported that thus far, however, no easing of merchandise shortages, particularly in metal lines, has developed.

DES MOINES, Sept. 11 -- At a press conference today Governor Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for President, accused the Roosevelt Administration of failing to prepare for war and of delay now in planning for reconversion to peace.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Ray Mueller, Cincinnati's versatile as well as durable catcher, drove in four of the Reds' first five runs with a triple and double today and then singled and scored the winning run on Eddie Miller's long fly in the tenth inning as the Reds took the opener of a series from the Cubs, 6 to 5.

If the meeting of Mr. Roosevelt and Mr. Churchill at Quebec coincides with the opening of a political campaign in the United States, the primary responsibility for this timing must reside with General Eisenhower and the troops which he commands. The war in western Europe has developed with tremendous speed.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in English to the United States from Ckungking and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

The diversified groups of scholars who comprise the Conference on Science, Philosophy and Religion in Their Relation to the Democratic Way of Life, after three days' discussion of papers on unity and difference in the modern world, announced yesterday unanimous agreement on two basic principles affecting man's struggle for peace and happiness.

A problem that has long been calling for a definitive settlement is this question of the so-called least common denominator. It keeps turning up every little while in the most unexpected places. The last occasion was a few days ago in David Lawrence's column in The Sun.
The cotton futures market was quiet yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange but it made net gains of 6 to 16 points and closed near the best levels of the day.

Mme. Chiang Kai-shek was admitted yesterday morning to the Harkness Pavilion of the Presbyterian Hospital Medical Center for diagnostic study, it was announced by the hospital. She was accompanied by her sister, Mme. H.H. Kung, and her niece, Miss L.T. Kung.

Pursuing a policy in effect since Pearl Harbor, Best Foods, Inc., again will feature the Government's wartime nutrition program in its six fall and winter advertising campaigns, it was announced yesterday at the opening session of the semi-annual three-day meeting of the company's top executives in the Waldorf-Astoria.
Dom Amoroso, 134 1/4, Jersey City, and Bo Harris, 132 2/4, East Side, fought a draw in the feature eight-round bout before a crowd of 4,000 last night at the Queensboro Arena.

The Jamestown, R.I., Bridge Commission has signed contracts for the refunding of its $1,808,000 of 4 per cent bonds that will result in an estimated saving in interest of more than $680,000 during the life of the new bonds, it was announced yesterday by Charles H. Brooks, vice chairman and general manager of the commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Discontinuance of the resale price maintainance policy for two types of films used by amateurs has been ordered by the Federal Trade Commission in findings against the Eastman Kodak Company of Rochester, N.Y., which were made public today.

Greetings from President Roosevelt, Vice President Henry A. Wallace and members of the Cabinet to the Jews of the United States on the occasion of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, which begins next Monday, were made public yesterday through the Jewish Telegraphic Agency.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 6: Decreases of $229,000,000 in holdings of United States Government obligations and $911,000,000 in United States Government deposits, and increases of $372,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted and $187,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.
Dr. Wei Tao-Ming, the Chinese Ambassador, and Mme. Wei have arrived from Washington and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.
The supply of butter in the New York City area has become so tight with slumping production that many retailers are limiting customers to a ration of two ounces.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- As the second Quebec conference convenes to consider the disposition of British and American forces for the Far Eastern war no foundation can be found in London for the persistently whispered belief in America that Britain is not interested in the coming major campaign against Japan and intends to shift the major burden of it to United States forces.

The Association for the Aid of Crippled Children of 580 Fifth Avenue will come into a very large bequest, possibly exceeding $10,000,000, within the next few months as the result of the death on Sept. 4 of Mrs. Annie Kirk Belding, widow of Milo M. Belding, a silk thread manufacturer.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Wednesday, Sept. 13 -- The air attack up the reached a new crescendo Sunday and Monday with record assaults by Gen. Douglas MacArthur's land-based bombers upon the Celebes and a record number of strikes on the Ceram-Buru area with Halmahera also coming in for a heavy pounding.

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Commissioner John H. Fahey of the Federal Home Loan Bank Administration cautioned today against expectation of a widespread upsurge of home building immediately after Germany's downfall, but said house construction would tremendously aid full re-employment after the war and for many future years.

Setting no fixed goal or quota in an attempt to raise as large a sum as possible, the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies announced yesterday at a pre-campaign "leadership" luncheon, held at the Hotel Astor, that its objectives this year were to provide not only for present needs, but for post-war responsibilities as well.

Lewis Spencer Morris, as executor, has sold to a client of Joseph Howard Katz, lawyer, the threestory buildings with stores at 915919 Eighth Avenue with an "L" through to 305 West Fifty-fourth Street. The assessed valuation is $200,000.

Apparently unmindful of such a thing as a budget, Billy Rose mounts the rostrum this morning to announce the engagement of Benny Goodman for "The Seven Lively Arts," due at the Ziegfeld on Dec. 7. With the help of three or four confederates (Mr. Rose rates them as "great standouts"), the killer-diller and his clarinet will dispense the latest and liveliest in the world of swing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- German infiltration of American industry was so effective in the years before World Wars I and II that the groundwork is ready for resumption of domination by German firms in the post-war era in preparation for World War III, Department of Justice representatives testified today before the Senate Military Affairs Committee on Demobilization.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull and a bipartisan subcommittee of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee discussed today what both regard as the central question of America's future foreign policy: how to reconcile the need for swift collective action against future aggressors with the constitutional prerogative of Congress to declare war.

ROME, Sept. 12 (UP) -- American Seventh Army troops, their left flank already linked with elements of the American Third Army from the north, have thrust far past Dijon and within nineteen miles of the highway city of Langres in their swift advance designed to catch or cut off German units still fighting their way eastward toward the Belfort Gap, Allied Headquarters disclosed tonight.
CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 12 (AP) -- A Fourteenth, United States Air Force communique:
ROME, Sept. 12 -- The envelopment of the Gothic Line along its whole length began today as both the Fifth and the Eighth Armies made contact in many places along the entire front.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- President Roosevelt nominated today Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley, commander of the Twelfth Army Group in France, for the permanent rank of major general and named Admirals Chester W. Nimitz, commander of the Pacific Fleet, and Royal Ingersoll, commander of the Atlantic Fleet, for the temporary rank of admiral.

QUEBEC, Sept. 12 -- Speculation here as to who will be named coordinating commander in chief of the forces in the Pacific war areas, holding a post similar to that of General Dwight D. Eisenhower's in Europe, has led to the formation of a fairly general opinion that whoever is chosen will be an American -- and a sailor.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 12 -Samuel Goldwyn has announced that after completing "The Wonder Man" he will star Danny Kaye in "Fancy Free," a comedy about a military policeman who gets involved in romantic complications during the liberation of Paris.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Heavily favored by a crowd of 7,500 persons, Mrs. H.P. Bonner's Reaping Glory today scored his second consecutive victory of the meeting when he won the $1,800 Fairhaven Purse at Narragansett Park.

Manager Mel Ott looked up from his seat in the Giants' dugout at the Polo Grounds yesterday and found himself surrounded by thirty-two ball players, including a lot of fellows named Joe just returned by Jersey City, and had nothing for any of them to do.

PARIS, Sept. 12 -- Before a crowd of approximately 3,000 persons Gen. Charles de Gaulle made his debut in Paris today as a political speaker and as the head of the "Provisional Government," stating his program in general terms.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The question of which group, the low-bracket wage-earners or corporations, deserves quicker relief from wartime tax burden was debated today before members of the National Tax Association, with Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the board of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, championing the cause of the corporations and J. Raymond Walsh, research director of the CIO, speaking for the low-income group.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,786, against 486 last week and 1,564 in the like period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 1,002 against sixty on last Tuesday.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 1 -Although it is done without ration books, the day's marketing for a Chungking housewife is just as complicated a process, and perhaps a little more arduous, than is the daily marketing for the American housewife.

Sixth Deputy Police Commissioner William M. Kent resigned in a huff late Monday and brought suit to collect the difference between a $4,500 pension on which he was retired as a deputy inspector and the $6,000 that ordinarily goes to retiring chief inspectors and deputy commissioners promoted from the ranks, it was learned yesterday.

For the first time retailers and other outlets will be put into individual classifications when competing for prizes totaling more than $100,000 for clever store displays in advertising the Sixth War Loan campaign which will be started in November, it was revealed yesterday at a meeting of merchants, display experts and pres representatives in the Hotel Biltmore.

THAT sizzling American League pennant race has been in a state of suspended animation for the past couple of days and, except for the Yankees against the Athletics tonight, won't come to life again until this week-end. Meanwhile the three main contenders are not unlike a groggy fighter who is grasping for the ropes and wondering from which direction the next blow will come.

WITH THE AMERICAN FIRST ARMY, In Germany, Sept. 12 -- The German border was penetrated this afternoon for the second time in twenty-four hours by armored elements of the American First Army.
