After the thrust late yesterday near Trier a second spearhead drove into Germany today from Eupen, a Belgian border city, after a slogging battle begun at daybreak.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- The people's army of Warsaw, which is in revolt against the German garrison, has been fighting with the aid of 100 tons of British arms, including 3,000,000 rounds of ammunition delivered by British-controlled aircraft from the Mediterranean area, the Polish Government disclosed tonight.

Both the Department of Sanitation and the Board of Transportation have a substantial amount of equipment laid up because of a lack of heavy-duty tires, it was learned yesterday. A serious situation in the Department of Sanitation will develop by Winter if tires are not made available, it was said.

LONDON, Wednesday, Sept. 13 -- More than 4,000 Allied bombers with fighter escorts probably several thousand strong from bases in Britain and Italy seared the Reich from the Ruhr to the border of Czechoslovakia yesterday, concentrating largely on oil plants in the great campaign to force the collapse of the German war machine.

Erich Leinsdorf, conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra and former conductor of the Metropolitan Opera Company, has received an honorable discharge from the United States Army, effective last Thursday, it was learned here yesterday. It was understood, according to The Associated Press, that the cause of the discharge was a minor foot disability.

Etta Deutsch, executive director of the Central Location Index, Inc., an agency for information concerning dislocated Europeans, estimated yesterday that all data required might be obtained within two years.

To relieve what he and real estate interests agreed was a "critical shortage" in housing here, Mayor La Guardia created yesterday a new municipal agency to help "desperate" newcomers and families of service men to find suitable living quarters in the city.
American guns were thundering on German soil yesterday, but assault upon the German Westwall is still in its preliminary stages.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Following heated debate before the House of Delegates, ruling body of the American Bar Association, approval was given today to a resolution calling for creation of a world court backed by an international organization and executive council to preserve peace.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Office of Price Administration loosened today its price restrictions on two categories of sales, the first authorizing higher price ceilings to exporters and the second permitting wholesalers to adjust their maximum levels under application of State Fair Trade Acts.

Stimulated by legislative developments in Washington, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange became more active yesterday and gained 17 to 21 points net, closing near the best levels of the day.

Joe Adonis, Brooklyn racketeer, was pictured yesterday as a favored "customer" of the Piping Rock Restaurant in Saratoga Springs. He received no dinner check after enjoying the costly cuisine and spent every night in the week in what was described as the gambling casino in the rear of the restaurant playing gin rummy with an entertainer rather than roulette, dice, chemin-de-fer or bird cage.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 12 -- In what was to have been a practice round for the nineteenth United States Senior Women's Golf Association championship, starting tomorrow at the Westchester Country Club, the association attempted a Scotch foursome event in the rain today.

OSSINING, N.Y., Sept. 12 -- Affable and smiling, James J. Hines, former Tammany Hall district leader, was released this morning from Sing Sing Prison after he had served three years, ten months and twenty-eight days of a sentence of four to eight years for having protected the policy racket of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer.

At the seventy-eighth National Encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic, now in session in Des Moines, but fourteen veterans are present. At the meeting in Milwaukee last year there were twenty. Of the posts in New York County there is but one survivor.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Cardinals, in a late season slump which has seen them win only four of their last thirteen games, lost a double-header to the red hot second-place Pirates tonight. The scores were 5 to 3 and 6 to 5.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Sept. 12 -Playing in a pouring rain -- the first precipitation in these parts since the senior golfers held their summer tournament at near-by Essex County in early August, Stanley Park of Glen Ridge today carded a 41, 42 -- 83 at the Essex Fells Country Club to lead the field in the first day of the New Jersey State senior's annual championship.

After visiting two political headquarters here yesterday, Representative Clinton P. Anderson, chairman of the House Committee on Campaign Expenditures announced yesterday that a spot check of contributors to the Citizens National Political Action committee would be made to learn if coercion was used to get funds and that the Committee for Constitutional Government, Inc., had refused to supply a list of contributors.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Grain markets fluctuated erratically today on the Board of Trade, feed grains declining early under selling induced by a bearish construction placed on the report issued late yesterday by the Department of Agriculture showing the second largest yield of grain on record.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 12 -- A bill of complaint aimed at voiding "permanent agreements" between five locals of the International Association of Bridge, Structural and Ornamental Iron Workers, AFL, and Northern New Jersey contractors was filed in Chancery Court here today by the Associated Contractors of Essex County.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Four specific proposals for relaxing corporate taxation in the reconversion period were advanced today in a report made public by the Business Committee of the National Planning Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Overriding bipartisan opposition, the Senate voted, 35 to 18, today to begin consideration of a bill proposing a Federal contribution exceeding $2,000,000,000 toward a $3,375,250,000 post-war highway program.

A second story of the sea by A.D. Divine, author of "Firedrake," will be published on Sept. 29 by Dutton. Called "Navies in Exile," it tells how the navies of Europe's conquered countries became an integral part of the Allied war machine. The book is illustrated with photographs. Mr. Divine writes also under the pseudonym David Rame.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Pouncing on a convoy of escorted Japanese merchant ships, apparently Burma-bound across the Andaman Sea, rocket-firing British Beaufighters scattered the ships over hundreds of square miles of ocean in a twenty-three-hour fight, Allied Headquarters announced today.

Governor Dewey in his Philadelphia speech bases his optimism for post-war jobs on his presumably reliable consumer research showing that we will need "a million homes a year, 6,000,000 automobiles, 3,500,000 vacuum cleaners, 7,000,000 clocks, 23,000,000 radio sets, 5,000,000 refrigerators, 10,000,000 electric irons, 3,000,000 washing machines."

VALENTINE, Neb., Sept. 12 -Thomas E. Dewey today hailed the results of the election in Maine as a definite indication of his own election, along with a Republican Congress, in November. Seated on the lawn of former Governor Sam R. McKelvie's ranch twenty miles from here, in the sand-hills area of Nebraska's cattle country, the Presidential nominee fairly beamed as he gave the reporters the exact results, and his interpretation of them.

Staff Sgt. Robert D. Leon, 22 years old, who had completed sixty-two missions as a gunner with the Twelfth Air Force before he was wounded on a bombing mission over Italy last October, captured a burglary suspect on Sunday morning at 651 West 188th Street, testimony yesterday in Felony Court revealed.

High speed short-order cookery by electronic "megacycle heat" was forecast yesterday as a postwar development for lunch counters, restaurants and hotels by Vernon W. Sherman, manager of the industrial electronics division of the Federal Telephone and Radio Corporation, in an address at the wartime conference of the Associated Chain Drug Stores at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 12 -- Rain marred the opening of the 102d annual Mineola fair at the Fair Grounds here today, holding the attendance down to a handful and causing the abandonment of opening day ceremonies.
LONDON, Sept. 12 -- The British Empire was defended by Miss Ellen Wilkinson, chairman of the British Labor party, before today's opening meeting of the all-Empire labor leaders' conference here.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 12 -- This war, which has caused the flowing of more rivers of blood than ever before in human history, has also led to the greatest progress in our knowledge of this vast ocean of life, its multiplicity of constituents and the mechanism of its many systems, according to Prof. Edwin J. Cohn of Harvard.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 12 -- A lot of news finds its way into the United States Naval Academy from all points of the compass. By cable, short wave, telephone, the press and other vehicles of transmission Rear Admiral John R. Beardall, academy superintendent, and his staff have a pretty good knowledge of what is happening all over the globe, usually well before the information is available to the public.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 12 -Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for United States Senator, told a luncheon meeting here today that if President Roosevelt were re-elected in November the control of the Democratic party would pass into the hands of Sidney Hillman, Earl Browder "and those top New Dealers who despise our Constitution."

One of the most impressive success stories of the day is that of C.E. Wilson. Until a little while ago he was holding down a job at Washington, D.C., at the very moderate wage, not to say the scandalously low wage, of $1 a year.

The fourteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 544 East Eighty-sixth Street, in the Gracie Square neighborhood, has been sold to an investing client of Pease Elliman, brokers. Originally erected as a cooperative building, this house contains thirty suites ranging in size from five to fifteen rooms.

In the opinion of this writer, the Mainbocher collection presented yesterday was the most beautiful this designer has made since his arrival in this country. It had more subtle charm than many seen in his salon in Paris. Perhaps this is due to the fact that it was created with a purpose in mind.

August was the second month since 1937 in which steel production had slipped below that of a corresponding month of the year before, the first month in which a decline occurred being December, 1943, it appears from an American Iron and Steel Industry report of 7,469,800 net tons of output last month.

PARIS, Sept. 12 -- In one of the first American magazines seen in Paris in four years there is a cartoon in which a Kentucky mountain woman says, "If you want something just ask for it. I'll tell you how to do without it." This might have been the theme song of every Parisian housekeeper during the years of the German occupation.

The speed and relative ease of the Allied advance across France have something of the quality of a miracle for laymen and, strangely enough, their astonishment seems shared by many military men and war analysts.
Revival of diamond cutting in Antwerp offers no major threat to the diamond market here or its price structure, according to a canvass of the industry in the city yesterday.

Because of a leg injury suffered by Frederic Franklin on Monday, there were two important changes in the cast in last night's performance of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the City Center. Yurek Lazowski stepped into his role in "Le Beau Danube" and James Starbuck took his place in "Rodeo."
1. In a letter from Representative Calvin D. Johnson published in your issue of Sept. 12 there appears the following passage:

It seemed more or less appropriate that the first major test of the rule of compulsory bidding for railroad securities should bring together the leading underwriting firms in the long controversy over the principle of bidding for corporate securities.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 12 (AP) -Charles P. Taft, director of the State Department's Office of Wartime Economic Affairs, declared today that it was "essential for our national interest to have a strong England," and that "we must find ways to help" the British solve their financial problem.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -Navy communique 542:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Acting on information that "recruitment of nurses has slowed up along with the growing belief that the war in Europe is about over," Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, instructed the agency's procurement and assignment service today to ask hospitals and physicians throughout the country to assist in recruiting nurses.

In your editorial "Mr. Dewey a Philadelphia" you stated with respect to Secretary Stimson's promise of demobilization that "with regard to this last point we differ from one argument in Mr. Dewey's speech. He (Mr. Dewey) holds that 'the occupation of Germany and Japan should very soon be confined to those who voluntarily choose to remain in the Army when peace comes.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Wednesday, Sept. 13 (UP) -- A communique:

Despite mist and rain at Aqueduct yesterday, Breezing Home, a 4-year-old son of Espino and Marching Home, sustained the form players by a one-sided victory in the featured Stony Brook Handicap at six furlongs.

Endorsing a whole change of mood in fashion, a sense of elegance not felt for many years, Bloomingdale presented yesterday a collection that included clothes for a variety of occasions. Stressing elaborate embroideries, exciting colors and sculptural draping, each costume was made up of component parts including the right hat, the right bag, the right jewels.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Mounting indications -- the size of the Maine majority for candidates opposed by the CIO-PAC is the latest -- that Sidney Hillman and his political activities may prove to be one of the President's heaviest liabilities in the quest for a fourth term were doubtless responsible for the statement in Chicago yesterday by Robert E. Hannegan, chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

"Ninety-nine Park," headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc.*, offers a partial list of free amusements available today through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.

Since it is the autumn, the season for reviving vaudeville again is at hand, and to keep this agreeable franchise intact, another show has come out of the West, "Star Time," which arrived last evening at the Majestic. To say that it is an evening with Lou Holtz is to give due credit to the demon of the one-time Palace, but it also is necessary to say that as variety, "Star Time" lacks sprightliness.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The United States submarine Gudgeon, which last year won the Presidential unit citation for its prowess against the Japanese in the Pacific, is overdue and must be presumed lost with her skipper and crew of about sixty-five, the Navy Department reported today.

WITH BRITISH SECOND ARMY, North of Bourg-Leopold, Belgium, Sept. 12 -- Advance British armored patrols that crossed the Escaut Canal yesterday had penetrated several miles into Netherland territory today, but this district far behind them still resembled the front line because there was much mopping up of resistance pockets to be done.

Drawing deductions from the Maine election is the prerogative of every free-born American citizen and the special delight of party statisticians, who can usually be relied upon to find something brightly optimistic for their side, even in the face of the most adverse vote.

The fight against tuberculosis has received impetus from the discovery of a special method of infecting rats and mice with the disease, it was reported yesterday before the American Chemical Society, which is holding a five-day meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
LONDON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Plans for thirty new homes to cost $270,000 were filed yesterday for sites owned by the Vinmont Land Corporation at Mosholu Avenue, 254th and 255th Streets, and Henry Hudson Parkway and adjoining private roads, in the Bronx. The post-war project involves dwellings costing from $8,500 to $9,500, according to the plans as presented by Robert C. Weinberg, architect.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Forces, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Communique 157:

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 12 -- Sidney Hillman, chairman of the CIO Political Action Committee, challenged today assertions that the PAC was one-sided politically and defended labor's right to take part in politics.
Because of the serious coal shortage, householders in the New York City area were advised yesterday to forego "luxury heat" in October and not light their furnaces before Nov. 10.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (U.P.) -Senator David I. Walsh, Democrat, of Massachusetts, chairman of the Senate Naval Affairs Committee, long-time opponent of overseas service for Navy women, predicted tonight that the Senate by the end of the week would approve sending Waves anywhere in the Western Hemisphere.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Third District, in its first decision construing terms of the amendment to the Selective Service Act which requires employers to reinstate returned veterans to their jobs, ruled today that a medical director for an industrial corporation is an employe within the meaning of the law and entitled to his old job after discharge from the armed forces.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 12 -- President Roosevelt and Philip Murray, head of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, appealed today to the convention of the United Automobile Workers to reaffirm the no-strike pledge as the movement for repeal of the pledge threatened to stampede the 2,300 delegates.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -Maj. Gen. Patrick Hurley and Donald M. Nelson took with them to China 380 pounds of books, instruments and other cultural items chosen by the State Department for distribution to institutions in that country, it was announced today.

LONDON, Wednesday, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Russian troops, driving ahead forty miles in southern Transylvania, yesterday burst into the broad Mures River valley leading to the Hungarian plains before Budapest and captured the communications center of Deva, 208 miles southeast of the Hungarian capital.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Maine Republicans, confident over their smashing State election victory, today expressed hopes of giving Governor Dewey a majority greater than the 7,000 accorded Wendell Willkie in 1940.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Shoving over three touchdowns in the first period, the Philadelphia Eagles trounced the merged Pittsburgh Steelers and Chicago Cardinals, 22 -- 0, in a charity football exhibition tonight at Shibe Park. Despite an all-day rain, a crowd of 20,000 turned out for the contest sponsored by Philadelphia Inquirer Charities, Inc.

SINCE the Japanese began their "China incident" at the famed battle of the Marco Polo Bridge in 1937 and he was caught between the lines of fire, Jack Belden has been immersed in war. Probably no correspondent of our time has seen so much of war for so many years, so continuously, so intimately, as has this young reporter from Brooklyn.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, Sept. 13 -- Veteran divisions of the American First Army have now smashed across the German frontier in two areas, while the British Second Army, in a swift, decisive move to the north, has wheeled into line on the Americans' left flank and presented another invasion threat to the Ruhr.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 12 -- Charging that President Roosevelt, during the 1943-44 coal wage negotiations, had "publicly kicked every coal miner in the country in the face." John L. Lewis warned some 2,700 delegates to the United Mine Workers of America convention today that they would get "some more" of that treatment in April if they voted him "into office in November."

Pastel felts, blue, pink, champagne and white contributed to the general air of femininity that pervaded the hat preview held yesterday at the Pierre by the Millinery Stabilization Commission The exhibitors at the luncheon show, the second in a series of three, included Hattie Carnegie, Mme. Reine and Walter Florell.

ROME, Sept. 11 -- The Italian campaign has been fought against three enemies -- the Germans, the terrain and the mosquito. Yesterday this correspondent went down to the mouth of the Tiber with Col. Paul Russell, chief of the malaria control branch of the Allied Control Commission, to see one of the battlefields where the Germans enlisted the mosquito as an ally in their bitter fight against the Allied armies and the Italian people.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Credit must play a major role in post-war merchandising, Edward N. Allen, president of the Sage-Allen Company, Hartford, Conn., and president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, today told members attending a meeting of the Controllers Congress here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Conferees seeking to reconcile differences between the war demobilization bills adopted by the two branches of Congress temporarily abandoned their efforts today. The House conferees will seek further instructions from their colleagues before again meeting with the Senate group.
Communique 1, issued by the Bulgarian Armed Forces, as broadcast domestically Monday night from Sofia and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora signed yesterday a show-cause order restraining William L. McFetridge, president of the Building Service Employes International Union, and the executive board of the International from making a decision on charges against David Sullivan, president of Local 32-B.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (U.P.) -- The American Red Cross alerted tonight chapters along the Atlantic coast from Virginia southward for hurricane relief.

A few days ago Representative Fulbright offered a resolution in the House calling for international agreements to guarantee freedom of the press and radio as an aid in preventing future wars. This has been promptly followed by Mr. Taft's resolution in the Senate and by the framing of a State Department proposal which may be submitted soon to other members of the United Nations.
MOSCOW, Sept. 12 -- In the latest copy of the Russian periodical Bolshevist, a Soviet writer, Prof. Z.B. Atlas, advocates a world return to the gold standard.

The surrender of Le Havre to British troops marks the beginning of the end of German resistance in the French ports. The few thousands left in the doomed garrison tried to carry out the orders of their High Command to fight to the death. But their ranks were broken by 5,000 tons of bombs and they could not hope to halt the final thirtysix-hour assault from sea and land.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Christmas boxes to the total of 1,250,000, packed by Red Cross volunteers, are now ready to ship overseas.

LONDON, Wednesday, Sept. 13 -- The Moscow radio announced today that an armistice had been concluded with Rumania. Russia, Great Britain, and the United States acted on behalf of all the United Nations.

CHICAGO, Sept. l2 -- Trading in corn for future delivery will be resumed on Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Directors of the Exchange today authorized trading in December, May and July contracts with a ceiling price of $1.18 1/4 a bushel.

The American Kennel Club held its quarterly meeting of delegates yesterday at the club offices in this city. There was a large attendance and considerable enthusiasm was shown in the informal report of President Dudley M. Rogers.

Two banking syndicates, both headed by the First Boston Corporation and G.H. Walker Co., won yesterday at competitive sale the award of $10,600,000 of first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds due 1969 and 350,000 shares of common stock of 10 par value of the Empire District Electric Company.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 12 -- Representative Hamilton Fish charged here today that Helen Hayes, the actress, was distorting and misrepresenting facts in an effort to promote the election of Augustus W. Bennet, Mr. Fish's opponent in the Twenty-ninth Congressional district.

If there is a service man or woman overseas to whom you want to send something special for Christmas, you might inspect the array of unusually attractive holiday boxes at Alice H. Marks, 6 East Fifty-second Street. This establishment, which specializes in gifts of all kinds, including china, glassware and fine foods, has assembled half-a-dozen or more assortments ranging in prize from $4.50 to $15 each.

LAUREL, Md., Sept. 12 (AP) -Shako, owned by S.W. Labrot Jr., proved an easy winner of the Morvich, best offering on today's program. Shako, an eligible for the $7,500-added Richard Johnson here Sept. 27, won by five lengths under the handling of A. Snellings.
LONDON, Sept. 12 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower tonight warned the civilian population of the Rhineland and the Ruhr to keep away from war danger areas.

A proposal that an adequate hospital be built for downtown Manhattan was made yesterday at ceremonies marking the reopening of the Downtown Hospital and Pan-American Clinic. Closed since July 13, the institution was renovated at a cost of $60,000.

REIMS, France, Sept. 11 (Delayed) -- The spacious, well-equipped airport of this city, among the best in France and once the proud possession of Reich Marshal Hermann Goering's Luftwaffe, is today the picture of utter desolution and just another graveyard of German aircraft.
PARIS, Sept. 12 -- Here, as in Algiers, Communists are emerging as the only active opposition to the de Gaulle government, even though they are represented by two Ministers in that government.

MOSCOW, Sept. 12 -- Agrarian reforms under which large estates, except those belonging to the Roman Catholic Church, will be broken up to provide peasants and agricultural workers with about twelve and a half acres each, with each farm privately or cooperatively operated without collectivization, are being effected immediately by the Polish Committee of National Liberation in an effort to distribute available land by Dec. 20, it was disclosed today.
LONDON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- A United States Air Forces in Europe communique:

Prices of aircraft shares, bolstered by the low-price motors, negotiated yesterday a further selective recovery on the stock market. The slight rebound was hampered, however, by the slowest day's business since mid-May, as transfers on the Stock Exchange dwindled to 546,560 shares, compared with 571,940 shares on Monday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 12 -- Continuance of home canning on a large scale, expansion of nutrition information services and enlargement of the tax-supported school lunch programs were advocated here this afternoon at a nutrition meeting sponsored by the Westchester County War Council, the American Red Cross and the State Emergency Food Commission.

To prevent surplus stocks of raincoats from falling into the hands of speculators, the stocks should be used for filling the needs of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration and lend-lease, according to a statement yesterday by directors of the National Rainwear Manufacturers Association, which opened offices in the Empire State Building.

A nation-wide syndicate of investment bankers headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. won yesterday the award of a total of $100,000,000 of Great Northern Railway Company general mortgage bonds at competitive bidding.
ROME, Sept. 12 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- With the exception of gilt-edge issues the easier trend in the stock market here was unrelieved today. Bolstered by the reinvestment of profits taken in the industrial market, several gains of one-sixteenth in this group were recorded.

No further changes in the rules governing the Eastern Intercollegiate Football Association will be made for the coming season, it was decided yesterday at a meeting of the executive committee. Deliberations during the summer resulted in six rules adjustments being taken under consideration, five of which were adopted officially yesterday and the sixth again endorsed and recommended for use.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, Sept. 12 -- Battleships of Admiral William Halsey's Third Fleet shelled Palau yesterday, joining carriers, cruisers and destroyers in the intensive air and sea attacks against the Japanese stronghold in the western Carolines that began a week ago.

"Wilson," Twentieth Century-Fox's screen biography of the first World War President, which enters its seventh week at the Roxy today, has played to approximately 750,000 persons during its first six weeks, according to an estimate by the management. "Wilson" will terminate an eight-week stand at the Roxy on Tuesday, Sept. 26, after which it is slated to begin an engagement at the Victoria.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Limitation of the numbers of commercial broadcasting stations that can be in a "single ownership" was hinted by James Lawrence Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, at today's hearing before the special House committee investigating that agency.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Japanese in their drive to guard the China coast against expected American landings, have captured the important Chekiang provincial seaport of Wenchow and now hold about two-thirds of the Province, the Chinese acknowledged tonight.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 12 -After six days in Chungking, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, and Maj. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley were still unable today to discuss the specific nature of the mission here assigned to them by President Roosevelt.
MIAMI, Sept. 12 -- A great Atlantic hurricane was centered about 400 miles east of Stuart, Fla., at 11:30 tonight, the weather bureau said. Stuart is about 35 miles north of Palm Beach.
LONDON, Sept. 12 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by the United Press:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -A movement to foster world-wide freedom of news as one means of preventing future wars gained impetus today with the introduction of a Senate resolution calling for a Congressional declaration.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 12 -- Faced with the growing danger of a serious incident as the battle grows hotter in the Belfort Gap. the Swiss Federal Council, in an extraordinary session this morning, decreed the lifting of blackout restrictions throughout the country, effective as of tonight.

Regulations for the new "T" loans, designed to assure adequate financing to war contractors during the period of contract termination, have been announced by the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System. The loans are to be made by private financing institutions, chiefly commercial banks, and guaranteed to the extent of 70 to about 95 per cent by the Federal Reserve Banks.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 -Hans Bergmann, 28 years old, a native of Austria, alighted from a taxicab in midtown Philadelphia last night and handed a penciled note to a traffic policeman on duty at a street corner. The note read: "I .am an escaped German prisoner and I would like to give myself up."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 -- The Standard Gas and Electric Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to the company's divestment plan, providing additionally for disposal of its interest in the Wisconsin Public Service Corporation.

IT comes as a shock when an athlete dies long before the allotted span. Gus Sonnenberg was only 44 years of age when he died the day before yesterday, a victim of the mysterious disease of leukemia. Gus will be remembered by sports fans on two counts, first as one of the truly great tackles of this generation when he performed for Dartmouth and secondly as a wrestler.

There was poise and dignity and an adroit application of the style trends in the custom-made collection that Stein Blaine displayed yesterday afternoon. It was a comprehensive showing in which handsome furs took their place along with daytime and evening dresses.

VALENTINE, Neb., Sept. 13 -- Thomas E. Dewey injected himself into the Quebec conferences between President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill today by demanding that "greater scope and recognition" be given the talent of Gen. Douglas MacArthur in the course of picking the military command for the drive on Japan.

For the first time New York City school officials have adopted a program to end the indirect system of employing custodial workers. This will ultimately place the 3,000 workers under the protection of civil service. By action of the Board of Education yesterday, the direct civil service plan will be tried experimentally in "at least one school."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- A fast and powerful new Spitfire, hurtled through the air by a five-bladed propeller that gives it fighting strength at 40,000 feet and higher, came off the British Air Ministry's secret list tonight.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 13 -- There are four major enemies of mankind against which relentless wars must be waged in the post-war era with the same determination as we are now fighting on the battlefront, Dr. Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard Observatory, and president of the Society of Sigma, declared here tonight at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, Sept. 13 -- A fierce air battle is raging over the heart of the Philippines, where carrier planes from Admiral William F. Halsey's Third Fleet boldly attacked Cebu, Negros and Panay Islands Monday.

An incomplete survey of the changing character of home-front information campaigns by the War Advertising Council in cooperation with the Office of War Information and other Government agencies already has shown that at lease two important programs can be dropped in whole or in part and that several new ones can be started, the council announced yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Prime Minister Antli V. Hackzell of Finland is expected to return to Helsinki from Moscow within twenty-four hours, bearing Russian armistice terms. An authoritative Finnish source said the terms probably would be presented to Parliament tomorrow for approval.

Richard W. Lawrence, general chairman of the New York War Fund's appeal, which will start next Wednesday, announced yesterday formation of the men's advance gift division. The chairman is Robert L. Garner, financial vice president of the General Foods Corporation.

PARIS, Sept. 13 -- A new program for the resuscitation of the French press, differing from that adopted by the Committee of National Liberation in Algiers, is now contemplated by the "Provisional Government," it was learned tonight.

The First Boston Corporation and G.H. Walker Co. head two banking syndicates which will offer today $10,600,000 of first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds due in 1969 and 350,000 shares of common stock of $10 par value of the Empire District Electric Company.

Fathers go in the Army, mothers go to work and children begin to stutter. War tension in homes accounts for much of increased attendance at the fall sessions of the Kindergarten Speech Clinic at the National Hospital for Speech Disorders, 61 Irving Place, according to the medical director, Dr. James Sonnett Greene.

Uncertainty regarding legislation to permit Government loans on cotton up to 95 per cent of parity and continued favorable war news brought in yesterday sufficient liquidation in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange to make a barely steady tone, and final prices were 11 to 13 points net lower on the day.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 13 -- After stormy debate lasting nearly five hours, the convention of the United Automobile Workers, largest affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the most important single labor factor in the country's war production, defeated today a resolution calling for immediate repeal of the no-strike pledge.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Sept. 13 -- A 35-foot putt for a birdie 3 at the seventeenth hole today put Arthur Drake, eight-handicap golfer from Baltusrol, in the lead at the conclusion of the second rain-swept day of the New Jersey State seniors' annual championship at the Essex Fells Country Club.

The praise offered by your correspondent to the telephone service at Kingston might with equal justice be extended to the entire United States. It is the eighth wonder of the world to me that, no matter what city I call, or call from, the service is everywhere the same and everywhere excellent.

ALONG THE MOSELLE with the United States Third Army, Sept. 13 -- The Germans along the Moselle are fighting just as furiously and skillfully as they have since our first attempt to cross the river a week ago, but the weight of Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's army is slowly but surely pushing them back. Their stand along the high-banked river now appears to be only a matter of days.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Germany's check-rein on American industry through an exercise of patent rights was sufficiently powerful to have retarded the Navy in obtaining Diesel engines for various types of vessels, the Senate Military Affairs subcommittee on war mobilization was told today by James B. Adams of the Justice Department's Economic Warfare Section.

Confronted with a challenge whether the New York State Public Service Commission has jurisdiction over financing operations of the Western Union Telegraph Company, Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the commission, ordered yesterday an inquiry into the proposed issuance of $24,603,000 of debentures by the nation-wide telegraph system.
LONDON, Sept. 13 -- The millions of foreign workers in northwestern and southern Germany were instructed today by General Eisenhower to desert German factories immediately and go into hiding.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- In his proposals for the organization of world peace Prime Minister Churchill will act in accordance with the spirit and principles of the League of Nations, but will clothe those principles with the necessary authority, he assured Viscount Cecil of Chelwood in an exchange of letters in honor of Lord Cecil's eightieth birthday tomorrow.

National Democratic Chairman Robert E. Hannegan and National Republican Chairman Herbert Brownell Jr., in statements to the National Conference of Christians and Jews yesterday pledged to keep racial and religious controversies out of the election campaign.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden conferred today with the Polish Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, presumably in preparation for his journey to the Quebec conference, where it is understood in Polish quarters that a solution will be sought for the long-standing Russian-Polish disagreement.
The Duke of Windsor paid a courtesy call yesterday on Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine and the headquarters personnel at 240 Centre Street.
LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Attracted by the recent decline buyers came into many sections of today's stock markets here and in consequence prices moved generally in favor of holders.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- President Roosevelt will make a second campaign address the night of Oct. 5, after arrangements have been made for 125,000 Democratic precinct meetings throughout the country to listen in via radio, Robert E. Hannegan, national chairman, announced here today.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- Describing Representative Hamilton Fish as a "silly man," Helen Hayes, the actress, called for his retirement as a "discredited political leader" before an audience of 500 at the final meeting in the Rialto Theatre here of a three-day campaign tour on behalf of Augustus W. Bennet of Newburgh, Mr. Fish's opponent in the Twenty-ninth Congressional District.

The placing of orders by three major airlines with the Douglas Aircraft Company for four-engined airliners to cost more than $50,000,000 shows the confidence of the air-carriers in the post-war outlook. American Airlines, United Airlines and Pan American Grace Airways, among them, have bought ninety-three DC-4's and DC-6's.

The three-story building on a lot 20 by 75 feet at 34 West Thirty-fifth Street has been sold by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to Webb Knapp, Inc., who also purchased the adjoining sevenstory Oakdale Hotel on a plot 40 by 98.9 feet at 36-38 West Thirty-fifth Street.

QUEBEC, Sept. 13 -- Representatives of Australia and New Zealand have been invited to Quebec so as to remove any suspicion among the peoples of those Pacific dominions of the British Commonwealth that they were being in any way slighted or kept in the dark about the plans that are being made here for the defeat of Japan.

QUITO, Ecuador, Sept. 12 -- The Constitutional Congress today passed a motion permitting anti-Fascist propaganda, with an explanation by Congressman Medina, who presented the motion, that the people of Ecuador were anti-totalitarian and that the attempt of the Foreign Minister to curb criticism of the present attitude of certain American countries was incorrect.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Pounding out nineteen hits, the rampaging second-place Pirates won their second double-header in two nights from the league-leading Cardinals tonight, 7 to 3 and 10 to 5. With nine consecutive conquests of St. Louis, Pittsburgh cut the Cardinals' lead to thirteen and one-half games.

A droll comic of considerable renown, Frank Fay will make a radical departure from type in his next stage appearance. Yesterday, Mr. Fay, who has been active in radio, vaudeville and Broadway musicals, was announced for a straight part in Brock Pemberton's presentation of the Mary Chase comedy, "The Pooka," listed to arrive here in mid-October after a whirl out of town.

The United Service Organizations-Camp Shows, devoted to supplying entertainment to our armed forces, announces the formation of the largest musical show to date, "Porgy and Bess," for overseas presentation. The George and Ira Gershwin-Dubose Heyward operetta will employ sixteen players.

A purchase and quick resale featured East Side realty activity yesterday when Albert Klein bought the fourteen-story apartment house at 1136 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Ninety-fifth Street, from the 1136 Fifth Avenue Corporation and resold it to a syndicate of investors represented by Jerome L. Greene, attorney.

With the Weather Bureau in Washington extending its hurricane alert to include the coastal area from Cape Hatteras to Block Island, the police of New York were advised last night by the local Weather Bureau to be on the lookout for strong winds and high tides, and orders were immediately given to all precincts, particularly those in outlying sections, to take all measures possible for the protection of life and property in the circumstances.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Administration won its fight to return Leland S. Olds to the chairmanship of the Federal Power Commission today when the Senate voted without a roll call to confirm his renomination for a five-year term. Opponents could not muster sufficient strength for a record vote.

Plans for an expanded program of gas utility industry research, national advertising and genera promotion involving an expenditure of $1,400,000 a year for three years were approved yesterday by the executive board of the American Gas Association.

ROME, Sept. 13 -- Pietro Nenni, Socialist leader, said in the Avanti today that the Socialist party would be willing to take power, and that when Milan had been freed the time would come for another solution of Italy's government than the present six-party rule under Premier Ivanoe Bonomi.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
LONDON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:
LONDON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Japanese troops, posing another threat to Kweilin in Kwangsi Province, have driven far northwest of Canton in South China to within nine miles of the Kwangtung-Kwangsi border, a communique from Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters revealed tonight.

PARIS, Sept, 13 (U.P.) -- The French policy is to open the door to news agencies of all friendly nations, Andre La Guerre, director of the foreign press services of the Commissariat of Information, said today.

Declaring that a sound pricing policy during the reconversion period is the key to many post-war problems, James G. Rogers Jr., deputy administrator of the Office of Price Administration, warned yesterday that "an unstable price structure can put us off to a poor start and interfere with getting peacetime production in full swing."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The War Department announced today the names of 233 sick or wounded Army officers and enlisted men, former prisoners of war of Germany, who are on the way to the United States on the Swedish motorship Gripsholm, following an exchange of prisoners at Gotesburg, Sweden.

LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 14 -- Russian troops, breaking through German defenses on a thirty-five mile front in a new offensive in southern Poland, reached the border of Czechoslovakia yesterday, while other Soviet forces captured the German fortress of Lomzha, guarding the southern approaches to East Prussia.

TRENTON, Sept. 13 -- Part Two of the State Supreme Court ruled unconstitutional today a law requiring boards of education to provide free transportation for children attending parochial and other private, non-profit schools if the service is given to public school children.

DALLAS, Tex., Sept. 13 (U.P.) -- Pro-Roosevelt Texas Democrats rode roughshod over all opposition today to oust fifteen Presidential electors who had stated that they would not cast their votes for a fourth term for the President.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Franklin D. Roosevelt and Thomas E. Dewey have decided that this is a good year to save $10,000 on the inauguration of the next President.

ROME, Sept. 13 (AP) -- A three-pronged Allied Seventh Army drive was aimed tonight at the Belfort Pass, southwestern gateway to Germany, as the Seventh and Third armies completed a junction in force near Chatillon, closing the major enemy retreat routes out of southern and western France.

Edward T. McCaffrey, National Commander of the Catholic War Veterans, replied yesterday to Dr. J.H.J. Upham, president of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, in a letter to the War Advertising Council, declaring that the Catholic War Veterans had not protested against education to prevent venereal disease, but only against the kind of education proposed, which is "false, misleading and indecent."

A possible parallel between tested methods for the handling of disputes in the field of labor relations and somewhat similar arrangements for dealing with disputes in the field of international relations may not have occurred to some of your readers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- Retailers were told today by Lew Hahn, general manager of the National Dry Goods Association, that an amended general price maximum order would be preferable to the new system of price controls re putedly in preparation by the Office of Price Administration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- A warning that unless controls covering the whole list of urgent civilian needs are retained and strengthened during the reconversion period, washing machines may emerge as juke boxes, vacuum cleaners as slot machines, and small boys' pants as ladies' luxury items, was voiced today by Caroline F. Ware, chairman of the National Social Studies Committee of the American Association of University Women.

Several weeks ago in outlining to stockholders the details of a $25,000,000 refunding operation, the management of the Western Union Telegraph Company took special care to explain the favorable features of issuing convertible debentures.

DENVER, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, chief of the Veterans Administration, said today that thirty-two of every 100 discharged veterans of the second World War have filed claims for disability pensions and that two-thirds of the adjudicated claims have been allowed.
BRUSSELS, Sept. 13 -- The Belgian Parliament will meet next Tuesday for the first time since this country was occupied by the Germans.

When the nights are crisp and frosty and the first thin silvery sheet of ice forms on the watering trough in the barnyard, comes the time to stack the beans. The splotches of yellow foliage in the clumps of gray birches along the pasture wall match the color of the dried, frost-seared rows of beans.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Communique 158:

LAUREL, Md., Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Longchamps Farms' Baby Dumpling, winner of four races at Garden State, today found the muddy track here to his liking and won the Glen Wild Purse with speed in reserve.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The opposition to the American Security Plan inside the Senate, which so far has been voiced in private, is now coming out in the open and is centering around Senator Robert M. LaFollette Jr., Progressive, of Wisconsin.

QUEBEC, Sept. 13 -- The second Quebec Conference of President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill came into focus today as a definite preliminary to another meeting of the Anglo-American leaders with Marshal Joseph Stalin of Soviet Russia.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in English from Chungking to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 115:

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has commitments with the United States Navy Department for construction at its shipbuilding yards running into 1947, Eugene G. Grace, president, announced yesterday in a message addressed to employes.

PARIS, Sept. 13 -- This is our kind of war now. With a supply line stretching more than 500 miles from the Normandy beaches to the German frontier, all the skills peculiar to peacetime America are being called into play to keep soldiers at the front supplied with gasoline, bullets and food.
ROME, Sept. 13 (AP -- ) A communique:

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Thursday, Sept. 14 (U.P.) -- Allied aircraft, free of any enemy air opposition, have again struck Japanese airdromes in the southern Philippines, the Moluccas, Palau and the Netherland Indies and have sunk or damaged at least five cargo vessels, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

Ever since D-day the war in the west has been primarily the business of the ground forces. It was the infantry that stormed ashore on the beaches of Normandy, clung to the beachheads sometimes by the skin of its teeth, fought the grim war of the hedgerows, and had to withstand the desperate German counter-attacks.
Veterans of World War II are finding that there are many benefits to which they are entitled. I think the are grateful to the American people who are footing the bills.

The new fashion trends point to a return of big hats for the women of America, and tall buildings for the streets of New York. Taking these two in the order of importance, we find it stated in behalf of the new elaborate headgear that the style engineers anticipate a post-war vogue for the lady type.

A group of investment firms headed by the First Boston Corporation will offer today 34,692 shares of 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value of Northern Indiana Public Service Company at $103.50 a share. The shares were awarded to the banking group at competitive sale on Monday on a bid of 101.79.

Preliminary plans for ten new apartment buildings in Manhattan to cost more than $3,000,000 were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The proposed houses will contain a total of about 700 suites.

Retailer objection to the proposed new pricing regulation designed to supersede the General Maximum Price Regulation took definite form yesterday in a resolution adopted unanimously by the Retail Council of the Office of Price Administration at the end of a three-day meeting at the Hotel McAlpin.

Applications for world series tickets will be accepted, starting today, by the Yankees, it was announced yesterday by President Ed Barrow. Of course, the Bronx Bombers, a mere half-length on top at the moment and shortly to invade the perilous West, may not make it, but in such an event refunds will be made.

Within the framework of the War Production Board's preparations for V-E day, the agency has established liaison with the State Department and the Foreign Economic Administration for coordinated relaxation of export and import controls, foreign traders reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- A three-run homer by Rookie Frank Secory gave the Cubs a 3-to-2 victory over Cincinnati in the second game of a double-header today.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- The greatest and longest sustained air offensive of the war continued today as 600,000 incendiary bombs and probably 3,000 tons of high-explosives ravaged the Germany on which, Marshal Hermann Goering promised five years ago, not a bomb would fall.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 13 -- President Roosevelt was praised as "the savior of humanity" at the convention of the United Mine Workers today when discussion of the merits and demerits of the Democratic Administration opened.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 -- Both the staff of the public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation denied today charges that they had engaged in secret negotiations to produce the proposed reorganization plan of the holding company that is now pending before the commission.

Line rather than dimension was emphasized in the collection of costume-made millinery presented yesterday at Saks-Fifth Avenue. Creating with the premise that hats should both flatter and suit the life and personality of the wearer, the two designers, Tatiana du Plessix and Josephi, showed new versions of the small hat as well as an exciting group of the larger hats so much in the fashion picture for fall.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- Three proposals for the post-war international organization of courts were approved today by the delegates to the convention of the American Bar Association and the association's governing body, the House of Delegates.
The text of the Allied-Rumanian armistice agreement, as broadcast from Moscow reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 13 (AP) A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

The Federal Public Housing Authority has leased the entire fourth floor and one-half of the sixth floor at 38 Park Row from M. L. Hess, Inc., managing agent for the Seamen's Bank for Savings, through William A. White Sons, brokers.

KANDY, Ceylon, Sept. 13 (U.P.) -- Allied units have carved out new gains at opposite ends of the tortuous, rain-swept Burma front, a communique disclosed today, as the Thirty-sixth Indian Division completed occupation of Hopin, in North Burma, and troops of a Gurkha regiment seized another strategic height in the Mayu Hills, on the Arakan front, far to the southwest.

The Very Rev. Hubert H. Welsh of the Eastern Mission Band of St. Joseph's Province, Order of Preachers, known as the Dominican FaLhers, was honored at a solemn high mass of thanksgiving yesterday morning in St. Catherine of Siena's Roman Catholic Church, Eastern Shrine Church of St. Jude Thaddeus, 407 East Sixty-eighth Street.

A dry skim milk called Starlac, which costs around 6 cents a quart when reconstituted with water, is about to be introduced generally in groceries in New York City, according to an announcement by the manufacturers, the Borden Company.

"99 Park," headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc.,* offers a partial list of free amusements available today, through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M.

ON Saturday a new name will appear over this column, the name of Francis Hackett. Most people will remember Mr. Hackett as the author of the warm, pulsating biography, "Henry VIII." Those whose memories go back to the days when The New Republic was the latest thing on the publishing horizon will recall Mr. Hackett's incumbency as literary critic for that magazine.

A motion picture, "We Too, Receive," produced for the National Council of the Episcopal Church by Cathedral Films, Hollywood, based on fact and depicting the rescue by Christian natives of a wounded Yankee airman shot down in the Southwest Pacific by the Japanese, was shown yesterday afternoon at the Preview Theatre, 1600 Broadway.

A jury of five men and one housewife in Queens Municipal Court yesterday awarded $50 to Mrs. Myra Rintel of 65-41 Saunders Street, Forest Hills, in her suit against Emerich Gross, a meat concessionaire in the branch of the Queens Food Exchange at 96-36 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Rumania has pledged to fight on the Allied side until final victory over Germany, to pay $300,000,000 worth of reparations to Russia, to restore all United Nations property and to adhere to the 1940 frontier that gave Russia Bessarabia and northern Bukovina, the Soviet Government announced tonight in broadcasting the terms of the Rumanian armistice.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- With the press and radio telling of American advances into Germany, Gen. John J. Pershing, Commander in Chief of the AEF in France in the First World War, celebrated his eighty-fourth birthday today in his quarters at the Walter Reed Hospital here.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- For the connoisseur of Scotch whisky, Harry L. Lourie of Washington had a cheerful message today:

Bucking driving rain and deep going, Brownie yesterday captured the $11,000 Bay Shore Handicap as 10,724 persons watched the mighty Western invaders, Occupation and Three Dots, finish two, five in a field of six.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- In discussing the prospective armistice with Germany, Secretary of State Hull expressed the opinion at his press conference today that France should be consulted with respect to phases of the post-war German situation and said he assumed she would be.

New York State's breeding stock of pheasants will be safeguarded for next year by the decision to cut in half this fall's open season and to reduce the total bag from six to four cock birds. Intensive field surveys and public hearings at Albany and Rochester and a preliminary canvas of more than 700 clubs in the State prompted the decision, announced by Conservation Commissioner John A. White.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 13 -- Sylvia Sidney, who has been away from the screen for more than three years, has been signed by William Cagney Productions for the lead with James Cagney in the forthcoming "Blood on the Sun." The picture, to be based on Garrett Fort's melodrama of Tokyo before the war, is scheduled for production within six weeks.

Some 10,000 readers in the East Bronx will have to get along next winter without their usual public library books or travel several miles to get them, because the library's book wagon is a war casualty.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 13 -- The "scarlet letter of public hostility" will be the fate of the industrial manager who attempts to discharge his obligations to returning veterans according to the mere letter of the law, in the opinion of Walter B. Weisenburger, executive vice president of the National Association of Manufacturers.

ROME, Sept, 13 (AP) -- The Allies driving for the core of the Gothic Line have reached the threshold of two main passes leading through the Apennine barrier guarding the approach to northern Italy and the Po Valley.

The City Planning Commission announced yesterday, after another public hearing on its proposal to impose additional restrictions on the height and bulk of new buildings throughout the city, that its report would be ready for consideration by the Board of Estimate by Nov. 1.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, Sept. 14 -- The assault on the Siegfried Line has started on the front of the United States First Army, and the American Third and British Second Armies are smashing through the German defensive screen guarding the southern and northern approaches to Germany.

QUEBEC, Sept. 13 -- Secretary of State Hull informed President Roosevelt today that his department was preparing "definite policy proposals" for curbing international cartels and suggested an early meeting with the Chief Executive "to present to you in more detail, plans for discussions with other United Nations in respect to the whole subject of commercial policy."
LONDON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

PARIS, Sept. 12 (Delayed) -- Combined Allied air forces hit the French railroads so hard in their successful drive to cripple the enemy's communications that our own needs on the same lines now cannot be satisfied. This result was expected, however, and will not deter the bombers from executing an identical program farther afield in the Reich.

LONDON, Sept. 13 (U.P.) -- German propagandists, revealing a fear that President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill, while in Quebec, intended to appeal to the German people to repudiate nazism and to surrender, opened a campaign today to offset it.

The House and Senate War Mobilization and Reconversion Bill conferees are deadlocked on the question whether or not Federal employes are to be covered by unemployment compensation. The Senate bill provides for such coverage; the House bill does not. Undoubtedly the adoption of this provision would be attended by administrative difficulties and would involve some costs.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 13 -- Four full American armies -- two more than Gen. John J. Pershing had in the last month of World War I, are on the Western Front, it was disclosed today with the announcement that the United States Ninth Army had taken a place beside the First, Third and Seventh.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- With a shrieking of air raid sirens and the unfurling of the French flag, New Rochelle hailed today the liberation of its mother city, La Rochelle, the historic French coastal community midway between Brest and the Spanish border.

Speed, equitable use of normal trade channels and discouragement of speculation were stressed in a seven-point program for disposal of Government-owned surplus foods made public yesterday by the regional advisory committee through Francis L. Whitmarsh, president of Francis H. Leggett Co. and chairman of the committee.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 13 -- A report from Sofia, Bulgaria, to the Swiss Telegraphic Agency tonight said that Dobri Boshiloff, former Premier, was arrested late last night, together with "a number of other prominent pro-Axis politicians," and would be brought before a special tribunal to stand trial for "war guilt."

The report of United Wall Paper Factories, Inc., for the year ended on June 30, which will be mailed today to stockholders, shows a net profit of $526,907, after all charges including Federal income and excess profits taxes of $862,266. For the year to June 30, 1943, net income, after taxes of $484,027, was $394,792.

John Farrar, editor of Farrar Rinehart, Inc., since its inception in 1929, former vice president and then chairman of the board of directors, has withdrawn from the firm. Mr. Farrar, who has just returned from overseas, was on leave of absence for the last year while serving with the psychological warfare branch of the Office of War Information in the Mediterranean theatre,

In contrast to the attitude of the German wounded picked up early in the war by American Field Service volunteer ambulance units, enemy wounded no longer exhibit an arrogant confidence in victory, Maj. George F.J. King, AFS veteran of more than four years' service, said yesterday.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Thursday, Sept. 14 (UP) -- A communique:

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 13 -- While the war in Europe is going rapidly in our favor the war in the interior of China is going rapidly against us. Driving southwest from Hengyang toward Kweilin, Japanese divisions have reached Hwangshaho at the Kwangsi Province border.

At the end of seven days of mailing war ballots to members of the armed services, the New York City Board of Election last night had sent out 126,420. Applications for ballots from service men whose homes are in the city totaled 376,155. Ballots mailed yesterday totaled 15,730.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Permanent cancellation of increases in freight rates for the country's railroads, originally authorized by the Interstate Commerce Commission in March, 1942, but held in abeyance by three suspension orders, the last of which will expire at the end of this year, was asked today by twenty organizations, predominantly State railroad and public service commissions, in a petition placed before the ICC.

Yugoslav partisans, closing in on the Vardar-Morava Valley, main escape route for Nazi forces in Greece, have occupied Kavadar, some fifty miles southeast of Skoplje, and the towns of Vranje, Vranjska Banja and Vladicin Han, about the same distance to the northeast of that strategic rail junction.
TRENTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- A six-point program for easing problems existing between Negroes and whites was approved today by the two-day Central New Jersey Interracial Clinic at its closing session.

OLEAN, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- Thomas J. Curran. Republican candidate for United States Senator, urged here tonight that when the war was over women should take an active part in the peace negotiations. The large attendance of women at up-State gatherings he had attended, he said, showed that they had a keen interest in the coming election and also in the peace plans.

Tule Lake in northern California, where Japanese considered dangerous to the United States are kept, was described yesterday as a "headache" by Harold S. Fistere, relocation supervisor of the War Relocation Authority for the Middle Atlantic States.

A series of special activities in celebration of the 100th anniversary of the founding of Congregation Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, was announced at its temple yesterday. They will start today and continue until April 6, 1945, the anniversary date of the official organizing.
A communique, as broadcast in Serbo-Croat yesterday by the Free Yugoslav radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The stock market bogged down yesterday in its effort at recovery as bearish thinking over the problems of reconversion of industry produced general selling. The action of the list confirmed opinions that the rallies of Monday and Tuesday had failed to return any degree of confidence.

SAMPSON, N.Y., Sept. 13 (AP) -- Lieut. Comdr. Jim Crowley's Sampson Bluejackets could do nothing against the New York Giants' stout forward wall and dropped a 13-0 decision in an exhibition football game today.

The Netherlands Information Bureau and Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, announced here jointly yesterday, according to The Associated Press, that the Royal Netherlands Government is completing arrangements with a group of fourteen banks and trust companies in this city for an interim credit of $100,000,000 for reconstruction purposes.

War ballots mailed to service men in distant war theatres only thirty days in advance of Maine's State election last Monday were received, voted and returned in time to be counted, Senator Owen Brewster, Republican, of Maine reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The long-pending bill to permit foreign service for the Waves was passed by the Senate today with only about ten minutes of discussion immediately after it was favorably reported by Chairman Walsh of the Senate Naval Affairs Committee.

Two days of rain were bound to reduce the regular weekly collection of waste paper by Department of Sanitation trucks and Commissioner William F. Carey therefore was not apologetic in announcing that 349 tons were salvaged yesterday, compared with 381 tons on the previous Wednesday.
LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Marshal Tito announced in a special communique early today that his Yugoslav Partisan troops had made contact with the Red Army.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 13 (AP) -- A storm, which descended upon northern New Jersey yesterday morning and has continued since with intermittent lulls and showers growing to cloudburst proportions tonight, piled up a record precipitation at Newark Airport weather bureau by 8:30 P.M. today of a total of 6.31 inches for the two-day rain.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- The grain trade is set tonight for resumption tomorrow of trading in corn futures on the Chicago Board of Trade after an absence of business since June 25, 1943, when trading was suspended at the request of the Government.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Use of radio communications to direct the operations of freight trains in large Government steel-loading plants and arsenals has increased the use of locomotives in such operations from 20 to 25 per cent, the Federal Communications Commission was informed today.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- The bitter T of Lieut. Col. Earl Blaik is overdue for some sweetening. After trying for two years to come in on a single wing and a prayer against Notre Dame, the head coach of Army football went over to the T formation last fall as a measure to combat superior manpower, but with the same unsatisfactory result.
Mr. and Mrs. C. Frederick Frothingham of Tuxedo Park are at the Ritz-Carlton.

High style, in the opinion of Macy's experts, divides itself into six classes. "Forward and backward," "hassock heads," tunics," "capes," "sky-high" and "covered up." Each was fully illustrated at a review of styles from Macy's Little Shops yesterday morning.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall, the newcomer will be "Casanova Brown," starring Gary Cooper and Teresa Wright. This is the first film to be made by International Pictures, Inc., and was produced and written for the screen by Nunnally Johnson.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Criticisms by an admiral of some national defense policies and administrative acts of James Lawrence Fly, as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission and the Board of War Communications, were officially made public for the first time at today's sessions of the special House committee investigating the FCC.

Lilly Dache, Sally Victor and John-Frederics were the designers represented at the last of a series of luncheon fashion shows held at the Pierre yesterday under the auspices of the Millinery Stabilization Commission.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- A special committee to develop post-war plans for the American Red Cross, which has been tremendously expanded during the war, was appointed today by Basil O'Connor, chairman.

It is pleasant to let the imagination dwell on the kind of cities and suburban areas that may take shape during a coming period of peace. The national genius that built so successfully for war ought to do as well in building the homes of the people. But it does require planning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The conversations on post-war foreign policy between Secretary of State Hull and Mr. John Foster Dulles ended with a conviction at the State Department that, on the structure of a world organization to maintain peace, the official Democratic and Republican positions are almost identical.

LONDON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The existing British-Argentine meat agreement is expected to be extended provisionally when it expires Sept. 30, and Britain has hinted at a four-year post-war contract along similar lines, giving Britain distribution rights to Argentina's surplus meat, it was learned today.

The extent of the gasoline black market in the New York metropolitan area, long a matter of silence or vagueness in official circles was computed yesterday at from 90,000 to 150,000 gallons, and possibly more, a day.

The gift of an oil research and development company to the American Chemical Society, providing it with an annual income of $1,000,000 for research in the fields of science relating to the oil industry, was announced last night by Dr. Thomas Midgley Jr., president of the society.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The Office of Price Administration removed today the disputed "highest price line limitation" from its price control over women's and children's outer wear at both the retail and wholesale levels, substituting historical, category mark-up."

The gasoline supply dropped an additional 345,000 barrels last week, but was still 8,558,000 barrels larger than a year ago, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The new total is 79,576,000 barrels, against 79,921,000 a week before and 71,018,000 a year ago.

Vehement protests from two service men condemning campaign literature they had received from the Democratic political organization in Jersey City were made public by the men's families yesterday. Both protests were contained in letters, one coming from a first-class petty officer in the Navy, now in New Guinea, and the other from a Marine corporal stationed in Columbia, S.C.

According to advices received here yesterday by officials of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, the company's properties in Paris, comprising two factories and a laboratory, were not damaged in the battle for France.
CINCANNATI, Sept. 14 -- John L. Lewis won an overwhelming victory over insurgent delegates on the autonomy issue at the convention of the United Mine Workers of America today.

A free world press and uncensored publicity of war preparation can only be effective if such publicity is practiced at home by the countries willing to subscribe to such a pledge. The authorities in all the strong nations have undoubtedly always had the fulles knowledge of such war preparations but they have censored or suppressed such news.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS. Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Communique 159:

Charitable and religious institutions share in $730,148 of the estate of Mrs. Caroline Phelps, widow of Herbert Wilson Phelps, who died a resident of the Sherry-Netherland Hotel on Dec. 15, 1941, leaving a gross estate of $1,383,207 and a net estate of $1,201,311.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 14 -- Twentieth Century-Fox now has been assured of a screen sequel to "Claudia" with the signing of Robert Young and Dorothy McGuire, the leads in the original, for co-starring parts in a film, "Claudia and David," detailing new adventures of the Rose Franken characters.

Marshal Tito, demanding the "amendment of past injustices such as the Versailles and other treaties," has laid claim for Yugoslavia to Italian Istria and declared that "we could not be reconciled" to being "kept outside" at the peace conference, the Free Yugoslav radio said last night in a broadcast reported by the Federal Communications Commission.

With residents of exposed island and beach communities evacuated to the mainland, cottages battened down and cabanas lashed to trees with wire and rope, Long Island communities rode out a gale last night while the lashing wind, driving sheets of rain before it, tore off doors and gables in some sections, uprooted trees and tore down power lines.

Tickets for the "Brooklyn Bond Bowl" football game in which an all-star service team from Camp Kilmer will meet the Brooklyn Tigers at Ebbets Field on Monday night, Oct. 2, will be available beginning tomorrow, it was announced by the Treasury Department yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 -- A Federal grand jury today accused a British corporation and another owned 90 per cent by Germans through a Netherland "dummy" company of having controlled since 1929 by means of a cartel arrangement the production and marketing of virtually the entire world's supply of borax, obtained almost exclusively in California.

In New England, State and municipal authorities made early preparations for the arrival of the storm. In the afternoon Gov. Leverett Saltonstall of Massachusetts broadcast an appeal to shore dwellers to evacuate their homes before 9:30 P.M., and he asked those who lived inland to remain indoors.

ISTANBUL, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Reports reaching here today indicated that the Germans were evacuating the Island of Rhodes, largest in the Dodecanese. The Germans were estimated to have more than a division on the island. Germans on the Greek mainland appeared to be concentrated at Salonika and Larissa, the reports added.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday ordered Edgar Bromberger, Commissioner of Investigation, to conduct an "immediate" inquiry into the charges made by Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman of the City Council, that the New York City Housing Authority had been a party to "rent gouging" in connection with leasing of store space in the Queensbridge Housing project in Long Island City.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- More than 2,000 civilian women will be sent to Hawaiian Air Depot of the Seventh Air Force to work as technicians, mechanics, clerks, and in many other capacities, according to the Air Service Command, which has taken on the task of recruiting and training them.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The War Department has asked Congress to authorize the elevation of two officers to the ranks of "generals of the Army," and action is expected on Monday.

Governor Dewey's remarks at his Nebraska press conference about the Pacific war, and particularly about General MacArthur's part in it, are not helpful, if what is needed is a clear understanding by the American people of the nature of the war we have been fighting.

Plans for a fifteen-story commercial building at 314 West Forty-second Street through to 319 West Forty-first Street were filed yesterday by Joseph Lau, architect, for Maude A.K. and Edith M.K. Wetmore, the owners. The proposed structure will be more than 200 feet high and will cost $750,000.

ADVANCE ALLIED AIRBASE in Southern France, Sept. 12 ( Delayed) -- While fighter-bombers continued to take off to strike targets inside Germany, a motley collection of warplanes circled this field today in a traffic jam, impatiently awaiting tower orders to land.

A quota of 4,000 nurses for the Army Nurse Corps must be met by Oct. 1, in addition to 2,000 between Oct. 1 and Jan. 1, and another 4,000 by next June, Maj. Edith Aynes, Army Nurse Corps, said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Publicity Club of New York, held at the Belmont Plaza Hotel.
Town houses and small apartment buildings on the East Side passed to new control in realty deals announced yesterday.

War-swollen pay envelopes and the critical shortage of modern living quarters in New York have created an "unprecedented" situation in the residential projects operated by the New York City Housing Authority, with thousands of families remaining in these publicly financed buildings despite the fact that their incomes long ago passed the original maximum limit for eligibility of tenants.
