Senator Robert F. Wagner, who is seeking re-election this year, denounced last night Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's charge that President Roosevelt had prolonged the depression as a "blatant distortion of the facts." The depression was caused, he declared, by Republican policies, notably those adopted by former President Herbert Hoover whom he described as Mr. Dewey's mentor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Hearings on alleged irregularities in the ownership and control of certain radio stations by Arde Bulova, head of the Bulova Watch Company, were opened today by the special House committee investigating the Federal Communications Commission.

In response to an appeal from former Governor Herbert H. Lehman, director general of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, religious groups of all faiths will participate in a national campaign for collecting used clothing to send overseas, beginning Sept. 24.

Four rain-swept horses raced into the stretch neck and neck yesterday at Aqueduct as the Belle Harbor Purse made up in keenness what it lacked in numbers for the benefit of 14,147 persons huddled in the stands. The stretch run split the four somewhat, but at the end it was the narrow margin of a head which decided the issue in favor of the Angpet Stable's Sirlette, paying $9.50 for $2.

The Nevada Apartments, a seven-story and penthouse building containing stores and apartments in the triangular block bounded by Broadway and Amsterdam Avenues, West Sixty-ninth and Seventieth Streets, facing Sherman Square, have been sold by the Mutual Life Insurance Company to Bella Mantell Morris, operator of a chain of apartment hotels.

The annual report of Stokely Brothers Co., Inc., disclosed yesterday a net profit of $2,227,200 equal to $2.87 a common share for the year ended on May 31, 1944. This compares with $1,080,535, or $1.45 a common share earned in the preceding fiscal year.

With trading slowed up awaiting legislative action on cotton loans next week, the futures market on the Cotton Exchange here held yesterday within a narrow range and closed 1 point lower to 8 points higher on the day for active months.

It was a genuine pleasure to watch the panorama of ready-to-wear styles that de Pinna assembled and spread before the press for review yesterday morning. Along with the matron, the young woman and the debutante came the junior, providing a refreshing picture.

Mature, well-seasoned football material is a scarce commodity on the college campus this year and for some coaches it's a real shock to find themselves working with undersized squads almost totally deficient in college experience.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Two fast Chicago Eastern Illinois passenger trains crashed head-on in a heavy fog three miles north of here early today, killing twenty-seven persons and injuring about forty others. Of the dead, twenty-four were overseas Air Force veterans, many wearing Purple Heart decorations.
Charles S. Reed 2d, recently appointed United States Consul at Barcelona, Spain, and Mrs. Reed have come to the Waldorf-Astoria from Washington.

On Wednesday the 13th Gen. John Joseph Pershing, to his old soldiers Black Jack or J.J.P., was 84. If his picture tells the truth, his years are favorable witnesses. Should we call his always distinguished face grave or austere? He sits straight as ever. He has the broomstick back of the West Point cadet he was.

A motion picture in color illustrating each step in the enameling of a copper bowl was the highlight of the reception and exhibition held last night at the Craft Students League of the Young Women's Christian Association at 745 Tenth Avenue.

The board of directors of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., yesterday elected B. Brewster Jennings to be president and chairman of the executive committee and Harold F. Sheets to be chairman of the board. Mr. Jennings succeeds as chief executive John A. Brown, who died last Saturday.
LONDON, Sept. 14 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

MOSCOW, Friday, Sept. 15 -- Polish and Soviet troops, led by Polish-born Marshal Konstantin K. Rokossovsky, yesterday captured Praga, important Warsaw suburb and fortress considered vital to the German defenses of the Polish capital, from which the Soviet troops now are separated by the wide, swift-flowing Vistula River.

Roy T. Hurley has been elected vice president of the Bendix Aviation Corporation, Ernest R. Breech, president, announced yesterday. To Mr. Hurley has been assigned the problem with which the corporation is confronted in the reconversion and immediate post-war period.

Before the representatives of eighty national, trade and governmental groups making up its membership, the American Standards Association was presented with the Distinguished Service Award of the Army Ordnance Department at a luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- A new allotment of 100,000 tons of carbon steel and 25,000 tons of alloy steel was granted today by the War Production Board for the manufacture of civilian goods during the fourth quarter of this year under the "spot authorization" procedure, Priorities Regulation No. 25.

Galen Drake, in 405 Park Ave; Cord Meyer, in 40 E 66th St; Eugene A. Sherpich, in 455 E 57th St; Mrs. John Peale Bishop, in 15 W 55th St; Frederick F. A. Pearson Jr, in 333 E 68th St -- Douglas L. Elliman Co, broker.
A communique, as broadcast yesterday from Tokyo to Asiatic areas and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

QUEBEC, Sept. 14 -- Anthony Eden, Britain's Foreign Secretary, arrived here unexpectedly tonight to touch off speculation encompassing the whole of the political possibilities in the European situation.

"Blondes always want to wear blue to bring out the blue in their eyes, but I give them orange if the part demands it," said Stewart Cheney, stage designer, in an interview yesterday in which he explained the use and purpose of visual effects in the theatre.

Fourteen nuns, Franciscan Missionaries of Mary, who will leave the United States soon to serve in Australia, received last night the blessing of the Very Rev. Matthias Faust, delegate general for North and Central America of the Order of the Friar's Minor, at farewell services for them in the Church of St. Francis of Assisi, 135 West Thirty-first Street.

Candidates for Congress from New York State show a higher percentage of agreement on foreign policy than on any domestic issue, the New York League of Women Voters reported yesterday on the basis of returns to a questionnaire in which their views were sought on six major problems likely to rise in the next session.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 14 -- Charles Cook, secretary of the State Board of Tax Appeals, testified today before a State investigator that a majority of the board members had voted a $100,000 tax assessment reduction on the apartment building in Jersey City in which Mayor Frank Hague resides.

ROME, Sept. 14 -- The battle for the Gothic Line now is raging across almost the whole of the Italian front from the Adriatic south of Rimini to the mountain range north of Lucca and Pistoia. It has every appearance of the decisive struggle of the Italian campaign, fought not for villages or towns but for hills and ridges, dugouts, pillboxes and machine-gun nests.

ALBANY, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The State Health Department has investigated the outbreak of poliomyelitis in Erie County and other parts of the state "as thoroughly as possible," Dr. James E. Perkins, director of the department's division of communicable diseases, said today.

As American troops smashed toward the outer works of the Westwall yesterday and British troops drove toward the Schelde-Meuse Canal, smaller battles of considerable import were still continuing hundreds of miles behind the front lines.

Crops of domestic cabbage -- the early fall variety -- have been reduced considerably in most sections, and especially in Eastern areas, the War Food Administration reports. In New York the largest single producing district in the country, hot dry weather and insects have taken their toll of the harvest.

LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Newspaper World, a leading weekly publication for the British newspaper profession, endorsed today the resolution of Representative J. William Fulbright, Democrat, of Arkansas, asking the United States Congress to declare itself in favor of international agreements guaranteeing worldwide freedom of news exchange.

It is a token of the tremendous change in the war situation wrought by Allied triumphs on all fronts that all interest is now centered on final victory in Europe and the surrender of the main enemy, Nazi Germany. The capitulation and change of sides by Germany's former satellites arouse only passing notice.
ROME, Sept. 14 (AP) -- A communique:

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 14 -- The convention of the United Automobile Workers, largest affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, voted down today, 5,075 to 4,694, a resolution reaffirming the no-strike pledge after having defeated a repeal resolution at yesterday's session. A few hours later, however, the convention reversed itself, and by a show of hands voted to retain the pledge, pending a mail referendum within ninety days of the union's 1,000,000 members.

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 14 -- Carrier aircraft under Admiral William F. Halsey's command have "crippled" Japanese air forces, shipping and ground defenses in the Central Philippines in a three-day attack lasting from dawn Monday to sundown yesterday, a Pacific Fleet communique said today.

"One-carrier" international airline service between the New Jersey-New York district and key points in Latin America, designed to reduce transit time, to eliminate double and triple handling of freight and to fight off the postwar bids of foreign-flag carriers, is being championed by the Port of New York Authority.

Six of the largest oil companies of the country have transferred to the American Chemical Society the ownership of the Universal Oil Products Company, a property with a value that lies between $10,000,000 and $15,000,000. The income of about $1,000,000 a year is to be spent for research in petroleum chemistry, chiefly by grants to universities, and any discoveries or inventions that may result will be available to the public without payment of any kind.

Immediate emergency relief and assistance must be given to the Jews of Europe who now are in such a serious plight that they cannot wait for the planned programs of aid by various governmental agencies to go into effect if they are to be saved, Dr. Joseph D. Schwartz, European chairman of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, asserted yesterday.

A Federal court order forbidding the owner of a five-story building at 948 First Avenue to continue remodeling the structure in violation of the War Production Board's Conservation Order L-41 was obtained yesterday by John B. Creegan, assistant United States Attorney.

PARIS, Sept. 13 (Delayed) -- Of the three highest republican authorities still living in France, only Jules Jeanneney, President of the Senate, was chosen to sit in the de Gaulle Government. Albert Lebrun, President of the republic, was not chosen, nor was Edouard Herriot, President of the Chamber of Deputies.

Agreeing with Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, that price control is more necessary now than ever before, men and women representing four groups of Westchester County organizations met yesterday with the OPA chief in his Empire State Building office and formed themselves into a consumer advisory committee for their county.

Anticipating a quickened reconversion with a consequent increased consumer goods output as the European phase of the war nears an end, the Norge division of the Borg-Warner Corporation will attempt to focus consumer attention on its distributors and dealers throughout the country in its fall newspaper and outdoor advertising campaign, it was announced yesterday.

Trained disaster workers of the American Red Cross were stationed at strategic points along the northeastern seaboard yesterday, while Red Cross chapters from Delaware to Maine were ordered to be on the alert to give needed assistance to sufferers from the hurricane.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Governor Dewey, extending "my heartiest greetings and sincere good wishes" at the beginning of the Jewish New Year, next Monday, declared today "The people of Jewry have the consolation that from each successful trial that they have undergone, they have emerged stronger."

TWENTY years ago there died in France at the age of 80 one of the indisputably great French writers, Anatole France. In his younger days he was one of many distinguished French men of letters, for then France was rich with creative genius, but in his old age he was alone upon the literary heights, the last of the giants.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Durable Ray Mueller caught his 135th consecutive game of the season for Cincinnati today as his team lost the second game of a double-header to the Cubs, 4 to 2, after winning the first, 3 to 2, in 13 innings.

Amid the strident tones of war and hate and race and class which fill the world today the voice of reason can still be heard. It spoke last week at Columbia in the fifth annual Conference on Science, Philosophy and Religion in Their Relation to the Democratic Way of Life.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Senate Roads Committee today rewrote the post-war highway bill to slash proposed Federal contributions by more than a half-billion dollars and require States to match Government payments on a 50-50 basis.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- After an uncertain start the stock markets here developed today a more cheerful tone and leading industrials, which had eased at first on lack of support, rallied on the appearance of fresh buyers. Earlier Cape sales in the Kaffir market were readily absorbed and prices showed some gains.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed increases in holdings of Government securities and note circulation for the system as a whole to be $377,157,000 and $77,899,000, respectively, while the ratio of reserve declined to 53.3.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Friday, Sept. 15 -- With strong naval and air support Gen. Douglas MacArthur sent troops ashore today on Morotai Island, northernmost of the Halmahera group, only 300 miles from the Philippines.

All sorts of changes affecting incoming shows were made yesterday. For instance, "Champagne for Everybody," now in Philadelphia, will shut down for repairs there tomorrow night. The pre-Broadway tour of the Laszlo Vadnay-Max Lief comedy, in which Eddie Nugent, Eva Condon, Will Geer and Helen Parrish are appearing under the auspices of Robert Ritchie and Alex Yokel, was to have continued next week in Boston.

First Lieut. James K. Levy, who served with the American Air Force in the African, Sicilian and Italian campaigns, was killed in action over the island of Elba on June 10, according to word received here by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Levy of 2 East Sixty-ninth Street and Essex, Conn. He was 23 years old.

Persisting in an attempt to play a double-header at Ebbets Field yesterday despite a soggy outfield and hurricane warnings, the Dodgers were rewarded by a ninth-inning triumph over the Braves in the one game completed and an ascent from seventh into sixth place.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Installation of an old guard Communist as President of the pro-Soviet Polish Provisional Government in Lublin created a new point of difference today between the Polish Government here and the Lublin regime.

The American League's spectacular pennant race, which has been hanging in mid-air since last Sunday, experienced another twenty-four hours of "arrested motion" yesterday when for the second successive evening the Yankees had their night game with the Athletics in Philadelphia rained out.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- A judiciary subcommittee of the Senate reported favorably today to the full committee, without amendment, the House-approved Walter bill, reaffirming the intention of Congress to exempt the insurance business from the provisions of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Department store sales showed an increase of 14 per cent for the week ended on Sept. 9, compared to the corresponding date last year, it was announced today by the Federal Reserve Board.
Leaving havoc in its wake along a 500-mile path, the most destructive hurricane since the disaster of 1938 battered the Atlantic Seaboard from Cape Hatteras north to Long Island yesterday.

WARSAW, N.Y., Sept. 14 -- Ending his first up-State campaign swing, Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, told a dinner audience tonight that four more years of the New Deal would mean a continuance of the extravagance of the twelve-year Democratic Administration.
IN GERMANY, Sept. 14, 5:53 P.M. (AP) -- Doughboys of the United States First Army, supported by tanks, broke through the first line of the Siegfried defenses today and drove on deeper into Germany.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- Selling orders predominated in the corn pit on the Board of Trade here this morning when trading in that grain for future delivery was resumed after a lapse of around fifteen months. May opened at $1.07 1/2 to $1.05 a bushel, or far below trade expectations.

Declines ranging from 10 to 35 per cent under May levels were recorded yesterday at the sale of Hudson's Bay Company furs held by Lampson, Fraser Huth. The top prices and percentage of decreases for the furs offered were white fox, $37, decline 10 per cent; otter, $25, 20 per cent; fisher, $94, 35 per cent; marten, $115, 10 per cent; lynx, $60, 10 per cent; skunk, $2.90, 20 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- A Senator who is disposed to agree to a post-war security treaty, in which our member on the proposed Council may vote to use American armed force quotas against war threats, and without prior recourse to Congress in every instance, is voicing a familiar complaint about administration tactics in dealing with this issue.

Preparations for corporation income tax payments and for crop movements, and the fact that the Government took more cash out of New York banks than it disbursed here caused a fairly heavy outflow of funds from New York City in the week which ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Board of New York reported yesterday.

How to combine two new rayon stocking shades with a variety of street and evening ensembles was illustrated yesterday by the Gotham Hosiery Company in a marionette fashion show at the Hotel Pierre. Styled the "Gold Stripe Revue," portrait marionettes by Remo Bufano pirouetted in a dozen costumes specially created by American designers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The possibility that the Little Steel formula under which wartime wages have been frozen since 1942 may be upset arose here today with the filing of reports by two panels set up by the National War Labor Board to hear union demands for increased hourly wage rates in the steel industry.

Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic National Chairman, charged yesterday that Republican campaign speakers were "directly injecting racial prejudice" into the national campaign and called upon Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National Chairman, to repudiate them.

The stock market encountered increasing difficulties yesterday as further selling pushed the list back to the lowest levels since June. The supply at the opening of the market proved too difficult to overcome, but the pressure lightened thereafter to permit off-setting of some of the losses. Values at the close were generally reduced by fractions, although there were cases of much heavier inroads.

Japanese determination and ability, which he observed as a fugitive on Guam for two and one-half years, have convinced George R. Tweed, Navy warrant radio electrician, that the impending collapse of Germany will not mean a quick end to the Pacific war, according to a statement which he made yesterday at the Navy Public Relations Office, 90 Church Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Gradually increased production of peacetime goods even before Germany falls completely was promised today by J.A. Krug, acting chairman of the War Production Board, as protection for civilians if the European war should upset current forecasts and extend into the Winter months.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Average commodity prices at the primary market level during the week ended Sept. 9 remained unchanged from the preceding week. The all-commodity index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, at 103.6 per cent of the 1926 average, was 0.4 per cent below the level of four weeks ago and 0.8 per cent higher than at this time last year.

ROME, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Italy-based Allied warplanes teamed with American Eighth Air Force bombers shuttling from Russia in a devastating attack on German communications and industries in south central Europe yesterday and last night.

Plans for a new publication, "United States Quarterly Book List," an up-to-date, complete guide to books published each year in this country, are being announced by the Library of Congress in Washington. The list will be prepared by the Library as part of the Inter-American program of the Department of State, and sent to libraries, cultural institutions and newspapers in each of the American republics.
CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 14 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it had ordered the Southgate Brokerage Company, Inc., Norfolk, Va., to cease accepting commissions on purchases for itself of food and other merchandise.

The hurricane swept the New Jersey coast last night from Atlantic Highlands to Wildwood, south of Atlantic City, causing havoc to boardwalks, hotels, homes and shipping and disrupting electric, telephone and railroad service.

The Fidelity Union Trust Company sold the building containing four retail stores and four apartments at 284-288 Sixteenth Avenue, Newark, N.J., to Morris Lennett. Michael A. Stavitsky Co. were the brokers.
LONDON Sept. 14 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England reported an increase of 815,000 in note circulation to a new high record of 1,150,604,000.

FORCE HEADQUARTERS, on the Salween Front, Sept. 14 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops today captured the ancient walled city of Tengyueh in Yunnan Province in the first major success of their offensive to join forces with Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's North Burma armies and open a land route from India into blockaded China.

A suggestion to housewives to use all their blue ration tokens before surrendering blue stamps in the purchase of processed foods was made yesterday by Daniel P. Woolley, regional head of the Office of Price Administration.

PARIS, Sept. 14 -- The campaign of Right, as well as Left, organizations in favor of more vigorous action against collaborators seemed to gain momentum today. The Government is taking cognizance of it by promising more regularized arrests and quick trials.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Tentative proposals for an international organization to maintain peace and security have been submitted to President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Marshal Stalin by the delegates at the "Washington Conversations on International Organization," and pending their acceptance of these proposals the Dumbarton Oaks conference will recess for a few days.
G E N E R A L HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Friday, Sept. 15 (AP) -- A communique:

HELSINKI, Sept. 14 -- On the day before Finland's zero hour of Friday at midnight -- the deadline set by Moscow for the evacuation of the Wehrmacht from the country -- the Finns in Helsinki are most anxious about northern Finland, from which, it is feared, German troops will not have had time to withdraw completely before the deadline arrives.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Friday, Sept. 15 -- Two more American armored columns have smashed across the German frontier and sunk their teeth into the Siegfried Line. The American First Army is now fighting its way through Germany's last man-made barrier on the west at three points on a seventy-five-mile front from Aachen to Trier, while farther south the American Third and Seventh Armies plunged forward toward Metz and the Belfort gap.
While our gallant armies in Italy are steadily pressing northward the United Nations are confronted with vital issue of psychological warfare-the problem of South Tyrol.
Jules Podell, Copacabana night club manager, spent an uneasy day in license proceedings before Deputy Police Commissioner Cornelius O'Leary yesterday.

"Ninety-nine Park," headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc.*, offers a partial list of free amusements available today through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.; evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.

On all sides it is agreed that the most pressing task which confronts this nation after the war is to provide jobs for the wage-earners. Many people go further, sometimes it sounds like a majority of those who are giving serious thought to the problem.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Treasury made public today its revised and simplified income-tax Form 1040, which is designed to eliminate involved annual computations for an estimated 20,000,000 taxpayers who are not eligible to use the much simpler withholding receipt form.

It was with great pleasure and interest that I read the two viewpoints on the uprising in Warsaw in the Sept. 10 issue of THE TIMES. I should, however, like to correct some of the inaccuracies in Mr. Pope's letter.

In your encouraging editorial "The Man Over 40" you gave the welcome assurance that "because a man has reached the age of 40 the time has not arrived to clear off a place for him on the shelf of desuetude." And you added some of the many achievements of the great minds that had passed their fortieth year.

LONDON, Sept. 14 (UP) -- Yugoslav Partisans, in a smashing double blow aimed at isolating the Germans by land and sea, have captured the large Dalmatian Island of Brac and two key trans-Balkan railroad towns near the Bulgarian border, Marshal Tito announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Following is the text of the War Labor Board panels' "over-all summary" of findings on the steel wages:

BILLINGS, Mont., Sept. 14 -- In a reversal of his previous stand against rear-platform appearances, and extemporaneous remarks, Thomas E. Dewey delivered three fighting addresses in his tour of the West today, and in his final one tonight, to a crowd of thousands at the railroad station here, predicted that the Democrats would know they had been in a fight before the election was over

MOSCOW, Sept. 14 -- Agreements providing for the voluntary transmigration of hundreds of thousands of Polish and Soviet citizens affected by the Curzon Line boundary, or those desiring to move from one country to their homeland for other reasons, have been signed by the Polish Committee of National Liberation and the Governments of the Ukrainian and White Russian Soviet Socialist Republics, it was disclosed tonight.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., were the successful bidders yesterday for two issues of railroad certificates of indebtedness aggregrating $7,680,000. The sales were marked by unusually close bidding on the part of several investment firms and commercial banks.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (U.P.) -- Japan reported today that giant new American B-34 Superliberator bombers, in action for the first time, had attacked the northern Kurile Islands and said that heavy raids by carrier-borne planes continued in the Philippines.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- The Germans announced tonight the death of Ernst Thaelmann and Dr. Rudolf Breitscheid and claimed they were victims of bombs that fell during an American air attack Aug. 28 on the Buchenwalde concentration camp at Weimar, where the two men had been held for years.

Bill Voiselle, both the ace and the workhorse of the Giants, yesterday coasted to a 12-1 victory over the Phils at the Polo Grounds and became the first Giant hurler to win twenty games since Carl Hubbell and Cliff Melton turned the trick in 1937.

It will be four years next week since a strutting little man in Rome ordered his troops to march across the Albanian border into Greece. Almost six months later, on Palm Sunday of 1941, Hitler, using the same fascist system of striking first and then announcing his intentions, joined the attack with the then mighty German Army.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Chungking in English to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 14 -- No agreement between the Central Government and the Chinese Communists has been reached, according to Dr. Wang Shih-chieh, one of the two Government representatives in the negotiations that have been going on for four months.

RYE, N.Y. Sept. 14 -- Mrs. Edward Stevens of Round Hill led Mrs. Ruth R. Young of Knollwood by one stroke at the half-way stage of the revived women's United States senior golf association championship, which opened on the Westchester Country Club's rain-soaked south course today after a day's delay because of inclement weather.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio, Republican candidate for Vice President, declared tonight that the New Deal "has adopted the basic doctrines of Nazism and Fascism."

As the full fury of the drenching rains and record winds passed New York soon after 9 P.M. An incomplete checkup at 2 A.M. today showed that at least ten persons had been killed by live wires and about twenty others had been hurt seriously, but not critically, while property damage had been confined to innumerable minor items.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the Ohio Edison Company's plan of recapitalization providing for the sale under competitive bidding of $30,962,000 of first mortgage bonds due in 1974 and 120,000 shares of $100 par value preferred stock.
GENERAY MacARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, Somewhere in New Guinea, Friday, Sept. 15 (UP) -- A special communique:

The intention and urgent necessity of the National Citizens Political Action Committee to maintain a public status independent of the political organizations of the Congress of Industrial Organizations was expressed last night by speakers at the initial meeting of the New York section of the NCPAC, held at the Commodore Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 115:
CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

"Bride By Mistake," a comedy romance produced by RKO starring Alan Marshal and Laraine Day, will have its local premiere this morning at the Palace. Marsha Hunt, Allyn Joslyn, Edgar Buchanan and Slim Summerville are among the supporting players.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Advising against any controls of newsprint supplies that might infringe upon "the basic principle of freedom of the press," a House Interstate Commerce subcommittee recommended today that "no attempt should be made to ration printing paper by dictating what uses may be made of it."

TRENTON, Sept. 14 -- Mechanical baseball games are not gambling devices, the New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals ruled today in affirming a Chancery Court order restraining John B. Keenan, director of public safety of Newark, from confiscating many such devices from Stirling Distributors, Inc., of that city.

Presenting a ten-point reconversion program because "these days you can't get anywhere without a point-full program," Maury Maverick, chairman of the Smaller War Plants Corporation, declared yesterday that Government control of business must continue if a capitalistic form of economy is to be maintained.

Robert W. Bryant, formerly sales manager for various automotive concerns, and T.R. de Quelin, formerly New York district manager of the De Soto Motor Corporation, have been made New York district managers of De Soto.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- The defenses of the last two barriers halting the advance of the Allies' armies into Germany -- the Siegfried Line and a large part of the Rhine River -- have just been photographed for the first time in three years by a tactical reconnaissance group of the United States Ninth Air Force under the command of Col. George W. Peck of Detroit.

An agreement between the Civil Affairs Division of the War Department and the Belgian War Relief Society of the United States of America on the distribution of relief to Belgium was disclosed yesterday by Maj. William Wickham Hoffman, president of the society.

The city of Portland, Ore., plans in the near future to enter the market with an offering of $12,000,000 of sewage disposal plant bonds, maturing in three to twenty-three years, it was learned yesterday. It is planned to invest the funds to be received from the sale of such an issue in Government bonds until the plant can be built.

A newly isolated pituitary hormone that regulates the production of antibodies with which the human body resists the invasion of disease, and the laboratory production of a powerful natural substance that can clot blood almost instantly were described yesterday before the American Chemical Society at its meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CHUNGKING, Sept. 14 (U.P.) -- Japanese troops streaming southwest along the Hunan-Kwangsi Railway toward the American air base at Kweilin have plunged to within about twelve miles of the town of Chuanhsien, in northeastern Kwangsi, and severe fighting is raging along both sides of the Siang River north and northeast of Chuanhsien, the Chinese High Command reported tonight.

President Roosevelt's strength with the electorate dropped sharply after the liberation of Paris, according to Fortune Magazine's latest survey covering the week ended Aug. 26 which was made public yesterday. The poll indicated that the President was backed by 49.3 per cent of the people, Governor Thomas E. Dewey by 44.4 per cent and that 6.3 per cent had not made up their minds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Army announced tonight that it had reached a written agreement with five political parties -- Democratic, Republican, Socialist, Prohibition and Socialist-Labor -- whereby each will receive equal time for rebroadcast of political speeches by short wave to troops overseas.

The Department of Justice yesterday reached the climax of four years of investigation with the opening of indictments in Federal courts in Manhattan and Brooklyn and Newark, N.J., accusing 174 men and women of concealing their affiliation to the Nazi party.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Gestapo Chief and Home Army Leader Heinrich Himmler announced tonight a strengthening of the Berlin police command only a few hours after the broadcast of an unconfirmed French radio report that a small group of rebels had "routed an SS [Elite Guard] formation" in a peace riot and then fled into hiding before the arrival of reinforcements.

MOSCOW, Sept. 14 -- Religious education among youth may now be carried on in the Soviet Union, it was asserted here by Georgi Grigorievich Karpoff, head of the Soviet Council on Greek Orthodox Church Affairs. The only rule the Soviet Government insists upon, Mr. Karpoff said, is that religious instruction must not violate the basic principle of separation of church and State.

The New York Board of Trade announced yesterday that on the day of Allied victory in Europe the people of New York City "should express reverence and thanksgiving." This suggestion is contained in a resolution adopted by the board's directors after it was recommended by the organization's mercantile section.

The Western Union Telegraph Company disclosed yesterday before the New York State Public Service Commission that it does not intend to issue convertible debentures in connection with its proposed $25,000,000 refunding program. The issue will be straight twenty-year debentures aggregating $24,603,000.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- By an almost unanimous voice vote, the American Bar Association, whose membership includes 32,000 of the country's lawyers, defeated today a resolution assailing the United States Supreme Court.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 14 -- One of the army's amphibious tanks with a bulldozer attachment would have had no difficulty traveling the length of Long Island during the hurricane, but for all other vehicles the roads virtually were impassable, a motorist reported tonight as he reached this village at 10 o'clock.

PARIS, Sept. 14 -- "We want a lot of newspapers in France and many papers that criticize the Government," said Henri Teitgen, Minister of Information, in a talk with Allied correspondents today. He continued:

An 18-year-old mother, who admitted to fifty burglaries while her husband served overseas with the Army, was arraigned in Brooklyn Adolescent Court yesterday afternoon, where Magistrate John F.X. Masterson ordered her held in $10,000 bail for an examination on Wednesday.

KUMMING, China, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The deterioration of Chinese resistance on the eastern front and the swift development of the Japanese threat to the big Allied air center of Kweilin are forcing a redisposition of American air power and a change in the basic strategy of the Battle of China.

Five Northeastern States counted their dead at twenty-seven and placed property damage unofficially at upward of $50,000,000 as the Caribbean-born hurricane that lashed New York City and its environs Thursday night blew itself out into the North Atlantic last night in diminishing fury between Cape Breton Island and Newfoundland.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade were unsettled today. Short covering developed in September oats and disclosed a lack of offerings, and the price ran up 2 1/2 cents a bushel before profit-taking checked the advance.

MARYKNOLL, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- Fourteen Maryknoll Sisters in the Kaying area of South China who were obliged to flee from their various mission convents during the Japanese attempts to take the Hankow-Canton railroad have congregated in their convent at Tungshek and are continuing their mission labors along the border near Fukien and Kiangsi.

The lengthy fact-finding reports of the War Labor Board on steel wages seem for the most part to be careful and workmanlike. As the central facts have already been matters of record, however, the factual findings do not contribute anything essentially new. One or two general points, however, are worth noting.

War workers, school children and others inconvenienced yesterday by a slow-down strike of 250 drivers employed by the Comprehensive Bus Company and the East Side Omnibus Corporation were expected to find service back to normal today following adjustment of differences between the Transport Workers Union, Congress of Industrial Organizations, and the companies last night.

Taking of an inventory of the merchandise stock in every retail pharmacy in the country on Jan. 1, 1945, as the first step in post-war planning was urged yesterday by Paul C. Olsen of the faculty of the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy and Science and Rutgers University College of Pharmacy in an address at the closing session of the convention of the Federal Wholesale Druggists Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 15 (AP) -- A dead heat for first and a new track record of 2:03 1/2 by Time Table marked two of the heats of the Reading Futurity for 3-year-old pacers in the Grand Circuit harness races at the New Jersey State Fair today.

In his article in THE TIMES of Sept. 12, "Austria Is Warned to Earn Freedom," your Washington correspondent stated that "a considerable nucleus of the old Socialist and liberal groups of Austria resisted Anschluss." The statement is true in regard to the Socialist workers, who, together with their Catholic colleagues, tried with all means at their disposal to resist the Anschluss.

The New York County Medical Society urged Mayor La Guardia yesterday to give the medical organizations of the five counties an opportunity to confer with him on the working details of his Health Insurance Plan of New York.

Bridgeport, Conn., awarded yesterday to Chas. W. Scranton Co. and Wood. Struthers Co. an issue of $388,000 of refunding bonds on a bid of 100.029 for the bonds bearing interest at the rate of 0.75 per cent. The bonds will mature from Sept. 15, 1946, to 1954.
Byrne Bauer has been appointed sales and promotion manager of the Plaza Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The Union Pacific Railroad rejected today a suggestion by Oliver E. Sweet, director of the Bureau of Finance of the Interstate Commerce Commission, that it make a commitment to impound sufficient funds to provide for bonds maturing in 1946 and 1947 and amounting to $156,191,500.

HELSINKI, Sept. 15 -- A new act in the Finnish drama with many scenes was unfolded today. Semi-official Helsinki judged that a virtual state of war has existed between Finland and Germany since last night as a result of a German attack on Finnish-held Suursaari Island, strategically important stronghold in the Gulf of Finland halfway between the Finnish and Estonian coasts.

While Mayor La Guardia was taking prompt steps yesterday to oust a market tenant from one of the City Housing Authority projects on the basis of a study of charges of "rent gouging," the current rent inquiry appeared likely to broaden into a city-wide investigation embracing all leasing contracts made by municipal agencies with private interests.

Under increased hedge selling and uncertainty about the outcome of legislation in Washington, the futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned slightly easier yesterday and closed unchanged to 7 points net lower on the day.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 15 (U.P.) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower took command of Lieut. Gen. Alexander M. Patch's American Seventh Army today, thus assuming formally the direction of all Allied forces operating against the Germans in western Europe.

Last month, for the first time this year, the aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange declined. The decrease was not important -- only 44,086 shares -- but it was interpreted as a possible reversal of a long-term trend. The decline in aggregate short interest was from 1,327,641 shares on July 31 to 1,283,555 shares on Aug. 31.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Reds, scoring two runs in the tenth inning, defeated the Pirates, 5 -- 3, tonight, to win the first tilt of a five-game series -- the last of the season between the two squads fighting for second place.

VITTEL, France, Sept. 13 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- American troops liberated 361 American citizens and 1,700 others from an internment camp in this famous French spa after they had spent a nightmarish two weeks within range of a battle between German troops and the French Forces of the Interior.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- United States and British Air Forces dropped 34,154 tons of bombs on the Germans during the war's longest sustained air offensive from Sept. 8 to Sept. 14 -- and the great majority of the bombs fell on the soil of the Reich itself.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 15 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops have joined forces across the seventy miles of rugged jungle and mountain terrain separating the Ledo Road terminus at Myitkyina from a spur of the old Burma Road at captured Tengyueh, thus paving the way for opening a desperately needed land supply route into China from India, it was disclosed today.

Stockholders of the Cook Paint and Varnish Company at a meeting yesterday in Kansas City, Mo., approved proposals recommended by the management designed to enable the company to carry out a post-war expansion program, if desired.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 15 -This city had not recovered tonight from the effects of last night's storm, and damage to utilities and dwellings is expected to be far in excess of the havoc caused by the 1938 hurricane when the final reckoning is made. The blow of that year resulted in a $1,000,000 property loss.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 15 -- The text of the report of the Resolutions Committee of the United Mine Workers, criticizing President Roosevelt and praising Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, as adopted today:
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 -- Temple last year was one of the few football teams to give it the old college try without benefit of a Navy or Marine units.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 15 (U.P.) -- Tank-supported Japanese forces, knifing southwest of fallen Chuanhsien in northeastern Kwangsi Province, are within sixty-two miles of the Allied base of Kweilin and the double-edged enemy offensive to split China is less than 150 miles from achieving its goal, it was disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Three Army Air Force fliers, taking an A-20 Havoc airplane head-on into the hurricane which struck the Atlantic coast Thursday, have made two important discoveries for the future of aviation and meteorology, it was disclosed here yesterday.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Presidential electors named by the Texas Democratic convention last May -- including fifteen who indicated that they would not vote for President Roosevelt -- were accepted today by Secretary of State Sidney Latham as the official party list, but pro-Roosevelt forces, who have named a substitute list of electors, immediately said that his action would be challenged in court.

Approximately 25,000 taxpayers called in person and 150,000 pieces of mail were received up to 5 P.M. yesterday at the Custom House and its annex at 2 Broadway for the payment of the third quarterly installment of the 1944 Federal income tax due today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur, who landed with American troops at Morotai Island north of Halmahera, declared today that "our campaign is now entering upon its decisive stage" and "defeat now stares Japan in the face."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 117:

Allocation of fluid milk to take care of the needs of small independent handlers who recently have complained of insufficient milk to supply their customers will be discussed at a meeting of industry representatives next Tuesday afternoon.

Among the authors, critics and journalists who will conduct a series of lectures, from mid-October to mid-April, at the Institute of Arts and Sciences, Columbia University's public lecture platform, are Lillian Smith, Carl Van Doren, Emil Ludwig, Martin Flavin, who wrote "Journey in the Dark"; Sinclair Lewis, Ilka Chase, Orville Prescott, book reviewer for THE NEW YORK TIMES, and Ray Joseph, author of "Argentine Diary."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Senators climbed on a left-handed rookie, Clem Dreisewerd, for three runs in the first inning tonight, a lead which helped them triumph, 5 -- 2, over the Red Sox. Micky Haefner went the route for Washington.
PARKERSBURG, W. Va., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Governor Bricker of Ohio accused President Roosevelt tonight of "selling out his party" to the CIO Political Action Committee.

ROME, Sept. 15 -- The long contested Coriano-San Savino Ridge in the Adriatic coast area south of Rimini has fallen at last to the Eighth Army. At another point Canadians after hard fighting established a bridgehead across the Marano River and drove to within one mile of the Rimini airfield.

Announcement by the Association of Junior Leagues of America. Inc., of a new venture in children's radio -- a series of radio dramatizations of books for boys and girls, produced for the first time for electrical transcription, no doubt will be welcomed as warmly by fathers and mothers as by the youngsters for whom the programs are planned.

The use of "black light" to detect fungus infection of the scalp was reported by Dr. Maurice J. Costello and Dr. Louis V. Luttenberger in a recent issue of the New York State Journal of Medicine. Known as the Wood light, it has a filter that absorbs the visible rays of light but allows some of the ultra-violet rays to be transmitted.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- Young Americans could skip through ten years of school in just six years if lighting conditions in classrooms were improved, according to a paper read before a technical conference of the Illuminating Engineers Society here today by Dr. Darrell B. Harmon, education co-ordinator of Texas schools.

WASHINGTOH, Sept. 15 -- The Office of War Information mailed letters to eighteen newspaper, press association and radio editors tonight, asking whether they wished the agency to carry on its news service ticker views of Axis nations on the forthcoming Presidential election.

The A.R.C. Building Corporation has purchased the brick business buildings at the southeast corner of Kings Highway and Coney Island Avenue, known as 1102-14 Kings Highway and 2053-65 Coney Island Avenue, in Brooklyn, from the Schulte Real Estate Company.

LONDON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Germans declared today that a new secret weapon -- radio-controlled "explosion boats" -- had sunk thirty-six Allied ships and damaged fifteen others in the English Channel in recent weeks.

Maintaining through counsel that he was not called in good faith, Frank Costello, the gambler, refused to testify before Deputy Police Commissioner Cornelius O'Leary yesterday in license revocation proceedings against the Copacabana night club.

Reporting on operations of the American Bantam Car Company for its fiscal year ended on June 30, F.H. Fenn, president and chairman, informed stockholders yesterday that deliveries of war materials were approximately 150 per cent greater than those of the previous year.

After what must have been a record nine-day air and sea bombardment, the invasion of Palau is under way. It may be the most difficult assignment yet given a United States Task Force in the Pacific. Palau is second only to Truk, if that, as a Japanese sea and naval base in Oceania.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Postponement of contemplated layoffs to meet a 50 per cent cutback in production at the Wright Aeronautical Corporation plant here was announced today by the company, after a report last night by Representative Gordon Canfield of Paterson that the Army Air Forces would use the Paterson plant to supplement production at the Wood-Ridge plant, where no reductions were ordered.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 15 -- Having disposed temporarily of the no-strike pledge issue after two days of heated debate by a compromise making continuance of the pledge contingent upon the results of a referendum of the union membership, the convention of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, turned its attention today to other controversial issues affecting control of the organization.

My father and I feel that you have a most understanding naturalist on the editorial board. We have read with interest and pleasure his astute comments on such personalities in nature as the swallow, the catbird and the ant.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The American Gas and Power Company's proposed sale of its interest in the Bangor (Me.) Gas Company for $122,500 will be considered at a hearing Sept. 29, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Senator Connally, Democrat, of Texas, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, moved tonight to speed Congressional action on a resolution advocating United States leadership in fostering world-wide interchange of independent news as one means of preserving future peace.

Advances in the study of how plants use energy from the sun, one of nature's most fundamental mysteries, and findings on a Far Eastern preventive for hardening of the arteries were reported yesterday at the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the American Chemical Society in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

So-called "socialites" must stand before the bar of justice the same as ordinary defendants, Magistrate Charles E. Ramsgate ruled in the Felony Court yesterday when, on the motion of a lawyer, he sent shoplifting charges against Emily Cunningham Myles, 18 years old, and Gertrude Poyneer Sheppard, 20, who have prominent kin on the North Shore of Long Island, to the grand jury for action.
James J. Walker, former Mayor of New York, has leased a large apartment in Capt. Vincent Astor's building at 120 East End Avenue through Douglas Gibbons Co., Inc.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 (AP) -- A prediction that the British Empire will be the largest market for United States exports after the war, as it was before, was voiced today by Thomas H. Wilson, chief of the British Empire unit of the Commerce Department.

BOSTON, Sept. 15 -- Cape Cod and the old whaling town of New Bedford emerged today as the most battered area in New England along the path of the Atlantic hurricane, which roared out to sea after levying destruction from the Carolinas to Prince Edward Island.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 15 -- The military and political situation in the Reich is such that the war in Europe probably will end within two months, a highly placed observer just arrived from Berlin said today. That it will last through the winter is entirely out of the question, he is convinced.

A blueprint for the morning meal is presented in "Eat a Good Breakfast," a new leaflet that has been issued this week by the United States Department of Agriculture. The publication is prompted in part by the fact that the efficiency of many persons suffers because, out of haste or habit, they eat too lightly the first thing in the day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Production of super-bombers and development of super-bomber bases is gaining momentum, and the Army Air Forces already has blueprinted its plans to make Japan -- once the European war is liquidated -- feel "the full weight of air power on a scale beyond anything they have imagined," Lieut. Gen. Barney M. Giles asserted today.

With American troops grinding deeper into the Siegfried Line, the German Foreign Office circulated Friday for foreign consumption a dispatch declaring that such gigantic "steel and concrete" fortifications -- German as well as others -- had proved a failure against modern tactics and weapons.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 15 -- The United Mine Workers' convention condemned President Roosevelt and his Administration today in a resolution, adopted by an overwhelming vote, which virtually endorsed the candidacy of Governor Dewey, although specifically disclaiming that it was so doing.
CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 15 -- For the first time the problem of the relations between the central Government and the Chinese Communists has been discussed openly under Government auspices.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Communique 160:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- President Roosevelt today ordered the seizure of nineteen strike-hampered soft coal mines in West Virginia and Kentucky, bringing to sixty-four the total number of bituminous mines taken over by the Government since Aug. 31.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 15 -Rhode Island estimated its hurri cane losses today at approximately I $1,000,000, only a fraction of the $100 000,000 toll in the late 1938 blow, and, in the words of Gov. J. toward NIcGrath, "thanked Almighty God that there was no loss of life." The State's death toll from the hurricane six years ago: :was 262 lives.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, Sept. 16-- Tanks and doughboys of the American First Army reached Stolberg, six miles east of Aachen and less than thirty miles from the outskirts of Cologne on the Rhine yesterday and, according to a late report from the front last night, American infantry broke through the main Siegfried Line.
The following books of a religious or inspirational nature recently have been published:

A recent editorial in THE TIMES, "Looking Back to Solferino," interested me especially because, though the Red Cross is the greatest humanitarian effort since the founding of Christianity, very few people know how and by whom it was founded.

While power and light and communications facilities suffered considerable damage in this area as a result of the hurricane, the extent and seriousness of the outages by no means compared with those of the hurricane of 1938. Telephone damage was most severe in New Jersey, Long Island, the Bronx, Westchester and southern New England, with electric power and light facilities similarly affected in the same areas.
VESOUL, France, Sept. 15 -- American forces pushing on the Belfort Gap met increased resistance today.

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 15 -United States Marines landed yesterday in the Palau Islands and are closing in on the airport on Peleliu Island after repulsing several Japanese tank attacks. A communique from the headquarters of Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, late today told of the gains.

KORNELIMUENSTER, inside the Siegfried Line defenses, Germany, Sept. 15 -- The German people gradually are emerging from their hypnotic state under the Nazis, and their initial hostility toward the invading Americans has given way to a genuine feeling of gladness.

Like the babbling brook, racing apparently is going on forever, in view of what happened yesterday at Aqueduct as the aftermath of the hurricane. Things were out of whack except for the ability of the horses to run and of the racegoers to bet, but with those two items all right the sport went blithely ahead.

There was a noticeable increase of activity yesterday along Shubert Alley as several Broadway producers marked out production plans for the months of October and November. From the offices of Blevins Davis came word that "Rhapsody," the Fritz Kreisler operetta, would make its local debut on Oct. 30 at the Century Theatre.

QUEBEC, Sept. 15 -- Among the military men who have been in close conference here this week studying the problem of how to defeat Japan, there has been no easy optimism about early and complete victory.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Sept. 15 -- An example of interfaith cooperation came to light today in the wake of the hurricane in the story of six Episcopalian monks who labored tirelessly through the storm to keep the spark of life in a 12-year-old girl at a Catholic hospital here.

The purchase by the William Waldorf Astor estate of a large plot at the southwest corner of Sixth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street was announced yesterday. The properties, known as 1387 to 1399 Sixth Avenue, give the buyer frontages of 100 feet on Fifty-seventh Street and 134 feet on the avenue and have a total assessed valuation of $807,000.

Governor Dewey does not actually do any farm work on his farm at Pawling, but he knows all about it from youthful experience, according to speakers on the "Dewey's Neighbors" broadcast over the network of the National Broadcasting Company last night from Pawling and Owosso, Mich.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Saturday, Sept. 16 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, Sept 15 -- The general tone of today's stock markets was good, and the recent moderate recovery in industrials was held. Diamond mining shares provided the brightest feature as yesterday's rally on reports from New York that there would be a big demand for diamonds in America after the war continued, and in active dealings some useful gains were seen.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 15 -- Philip Murray, president of the CIO, predicted that the "Little Steel" wage formula would be broken because of labor's demands.

QUEBEC, Sept. 15 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill will end their second Quebec conference tomorrow, the sixth day since they arrived here for military talks that broadened to cover a wide range of political as well as military subjects relating to the global war.

New York's Fleet Post Office to handle Christmas boxes for Navy men was open and ready for business yesterday on Pier 51 as the mailing period for men in the Navy, Marines, Coast Guard and, Merchant Marine began. For one month, until Oct. 15, mail handlers will sort and route holiday gifts that are expected to fill 300,000 mail sacks, each holding an average of 15 parcels.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 15 -- A wildcat strike today of 1,000 electrical employes demanding bonus incentive pay curtailed production of tank-landing invasion ships at the Dravo Corporation's Neville Island shipyard.

Almost without a blow yesterday the old capital of Lorraine was taken by the tanks and infantry of the First American Army. This is a considerable military gain and heartening to all the friends of freedom as a herald of the restoration to France of the two "lost" provinces of which she was twice robbed by the Germans.

The Jewish people of this country and their co-religionists throughout the world, including those in the armed forces, will begin at sundown tomorrow the observance of Rosh ha-Shanah, marking the 5705th year of the Hebrew calendar.
Your editorial comment on the Nazi threat of underground warfare highlights an issue that has been obscured by the tremendous speed of military events.

Voting is the "primary duty of Christian citizenship," declared a statement issued yesterday by the executive committee of the Federal Council of Churches in America at the headquarters, 297 Fourth Avenue.

The State Standard Building Code for places of public assembly was criticized yesterday as being "about twenty years behind the times" by members of an advisory committee appointed by Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi to study revision of the regulations.

CHICAGO, Sept 15 -- Winthrop W. Aldrich, president of the Chase National Bank of New York, called today for scrapping the Bretton Woods currency stabilization and international investment bank proposals and suggested as a substitute the negotiation of international agreements for the removal of trade barriers and the establishment of a stable dollar-sterling exchange rate.

Tommy (Rocky) Graziano, 151 pounds, East Side, fought an eight-round draw with Frankie Terry, 155, Brooklyn, at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The contest headed the opening card of the season and attracted 3,201 spectators, who paid $4,624.

LONDON, Saturday, Sept. 16 -Russian and Polish troops drove retreating German forces back toward the Vistula River on a fourteen-mile front north of captured Praga, Warsaw's eastern suburb, yesterday while hundreds of Soviet big guns opened up on the Polish capital in preparation for a mighty assault to liberate the city.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, SATURDAY, Sept. 16 -- Sweeping forward against light opposition, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's infantrymen captured their primary objectives, Pitu airdrome and Dorobu township, on the southwestern end of Morotai Island, which lies eleven miles above the northern tip of Halmahera.

The issue in this campaign is not between the Republican party and the Democratic party, but between the Republican party and the Hillman-Browder axis, Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, Republican nominee for United States Senator, declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Cubs edged out Morton Cooper, 2 to 1, today to extend the Cardinals' losing streak to five games, their longest slump of the season, but then the Chicagoans kicked in three runs to help St. Louis snap the streak, 3 to 2, in the second game of a double-header.

The Home Owners Loan Corporation has sold the eight-room dwelling at 68 Hartsdale Road, Elmsford, N.Y., to Marguerite Volavy through William J. Sherry, broker. The same broker sold for Joseph Hall the one-family house at 275 St. John's Avenue, Yonkers, to Charles J. Tate.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 15 -- A method of preserving butter over long periods of time, a process for obtaining pure Vitamin K, and several developments in the field of synthetic rubber are among the 501 inventions to receive patents this week, as reported in the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15--With Germany's defeat regarded as imminent, the National War Labor Board is giving thought to its responsibilities of preventing wage cuts when war production cutbacks are ordered, William H. Davis, NWLB chairman, told reporters today.

New bond financing in the New York market this week was the heaviest in more than two-and-a-half years. Paced by the flotation of $100,000,000 of Great Northern Railway bonds, the total of new offerings amounted to $131,870,000, comprising seven issues, the largest volume to reach the market in any one week since the period ended Jan. 23, 1942, when $152,835,000 in bonds were marketed.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Backed by Vern Stephens' home run and nice hitting by his team-mates, Denny Galehouse pitched the Browns to a 5-1 victory over the White Sox tonight.
HAVANA, Sept. 14 (delayed) -More than 200 officers of the United States Army Air Forces are being extensively feted on their visit to Havana as guests of the Rotary Club.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Donald M. Waesche of Teaneck, president of the State Board of Tax Appeals, said today an investigation of Jersey City properties which he made convinced him that assessments there approved by a four-member majority of the board were "far in excess" of actual values.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP)--Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, said tonight that if Thomas E. Dewey "in his beagle-like snuffing about for votes" has any criticism of the Jackson Hole National Monument in Wyoming, he should direct it at Calvin Coolidge, Herbert Hoover and John D. Rockefeller Jr.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -Government assurance was given today that there will be no reduction in ceiling prices of live hogs before June 30, 1945.

The hurricane on Thursday, causing stores to abandon the night opening, affected retail sales figures here this week. Estimates yesterday indicated that the average for department stores will run about even with to 2 or 3 per cent under the like week of last year.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Sept. 15 -- Allied Headquarters in New Guinea is a jungle town, artificially created, well over a thousand miles north of Brisbane, Australia, where Gen. Douglas MacArthur had his regular headquarters previously.
The New York Stock Exchange firm of Deery White will dissolve on Sept. 30.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Manufacturers of knitted outerwear have reported that "extensive expansion'' of civilian styles and models of knitted outerwear would be impossible so long as shortages in labor and yarns exist, the War Production Board announced today.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 15 -- Purification of two of the elusive components of the blood which play an important role in fighting infectious diseases was reported today at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed during August totaled 841,490 bales of lint and 12S,063 bales of linters, compared with 724,167 of lint and 136,726 of ]inters in July this year, and 843,187 of lint and 107,975 of inters in August last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Further revelation "at this time" of information supplied by officers of the armed services to the special House committee investigating the Federal Communications Commission was suspended today by Representative Louis E. Miller, Republican, of Missouri, for "protection of the officers involved."

ABOARD AN ARMY CATALINA OVER MOROTAI ISLAND, Sept. 15 (Delayed) -- Johnny Doughboy strode on toward the Philippines today by establishing himself in force on Morotai Island, some 300 miles south of Mindanao, in another amphibious operation that, from the air, appeared to be unopposed.

Proudly displaying the Purple Heart, a momento of Pearl Harbor and service ribbons of both World Wars, the U.S.S. Nevada has arrived in New York Harbor after five months in the Atlantic and Mediterranean theatres, which included every major European engagement involving sea support.

" A service of thanksgiving to Almighty God for His gift of victory in the battle which reached its climax on Sept 15, 1940," will be held tomorrow at 4 P.M. in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The service was arranged at the request of the Most Rev. William Temple, Archbishop of Canterbury, and will take place in conjunction with similar services in every part of the free world.

BILLINGS, Mont., Sept. 15 -After conferring with representatives of the sheep industry in the last two days Thomas E. Dewey criticized the Federal Government for collecting too large a stock pile of unprocessed wool, while depriving the general public of wool products.

MOSCOW, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Polish Committee of National Liberation's semi-official news agency, Polpress, said tonight that a widespread series of assassinations had greeted the committee's military mobilization, and it accused the London-commanded Polish Home Army of preparing for civil war.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 15 -- Universal has named Alan Curtis for a co-starring role with Turhan Bey and Susanna Foster in "Frisco Sal," a musical with a background of San Francisco's Barbary Coast to be put into production Tuesday. Curtis, who has just finished the lead with Gloria Jean in "The Fugitive," will play a sympathetic heavy.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Sept. 15 -- August F. Kammer of Baltusrol today regained the Hew Jersey State seniors' championship when his 159 total for thirty-six holes, scored Wednesday and yesterday over the Essex Fells Country Club links, withstood an attack by the last day's competitors.

WITH UNITED STATES INFANTRY, southeast of Aachen, Sept. 15 -- Fellows walking on two feet carrying bayonets and working mostly with hand grenades walked all the way through the Siegfried Line today and got out into open country beyond where American tanks are following them this evening.

Lewis S. Greenleaf Jr., regional manager for the War Production Board, announced yesterday that of the 100,000 tons of carbon steel allocated for the manufacture of civilian goods, 16,0000 tons has been assigned for use in the New York region.
A communique, as transmitted yesterday by the German Transocean Agency in English to the Far East and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- A memorandum urging "appointment of qualified women to participate in planning and negotiations for the projected general international organization" has been sent to Secretary Hull by the National Committee on Economic and Legal Status of Women of the American Association of University Women, meeting here this week.

Authorization to manufacture 35,000 aluminum household trays in the fourth quarter of this year was given to Farber Shelvin, Inc., 375 Kent Avenue, Brooklyn, in the second "spot authorization plan" approval in this region, Lewis S. Greenleaf, regional director for the War Production Board, announced yesterday.

In a pistol duel between a Negro and two detectives in Ann's Red Rose Tavern at 1185 Boston Road, the Bronx, the Negro's wife was shot to death, when caught in the crossfire, the two detectives were wounded seriously and the Negro, who is a prisoner in Morrisania Hospital, was wounded critically.
