WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The Office of Price Administration will price new civilian goods made after the defeat of Germany as nearly as possible at levels prevailing in 1942, when most plants were converted from peacetime production to war work, Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- House and Senate conferees reached an agreement late tonight on a bill to set up an organization for the disposal of surplus property estimated at $100,000,000,000 in value.
ROME, Sept. 15 (AP) -- A communique:

An order declaring an emergency under which all butchers and grocers of Nassau and Suffolk Counties and the Flushing and Rockaway sections of Queens may sell perishables such as meat, butter and cheese without requiring ration points, a result of the hurricane, was issued yesterday by Daniel P. Woolley, Regional Office of Price Administration head.

OCEAN BEACH, L.I., Sept. 15 -- Seventy-five sturdy dwellers on highly vulnerable Fire Island rode out last night's hurricane at Ocean Beach Inn to the tunes of a rollicking songfest despite a power failure that plunged this comunity into darkness at the peak of the storm.

BOSTON, Sept. 15 -- In line with the tradition that everything unusual involves the Dodgers and Braves let it be recorded that today's game at Braves Field had to be put off because there were neither Dodgers nor Braves on hand to play it.

From the Conservation Department yesterday came the announcement, certain to be greeted with whole-hearted approval by partridge hunters, that the open season on ruffed grouse will run forty-three days, as it did last year and bag limits will be unchanged.

LAUREL, Md., Sept. 15 (AP) -- William Helis' Alfios, the favorite, romped to a four-length triumph in the Oxon Hill Purse today. The Glen Riddle Farms' Soldier Song was second, five lengths in front of the Flamingo Farms' Baby Darling.

As disaster relief forces of the American Red Cross swung into action yesterday to shelter, feed and rehabilitate victims of Thursday night's hurricane, Harold P. Gilmour, acting director of disaster service for the North Atlantic area, declared no serious health problems had been reported and that local chapters were completing surveys of property damage on which to base the rehabilitation program.
Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National Chairman, declared yesterday that the charge that Republican campaign speakers were injecting "racial prejudice" into the campaign was unwarranted.

Ralph H. Tapscott, president of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., yesterday promised lower rates for consumers of the Consolidated Edison system upon completion of a proposed merger of five operating subsidiaries into the parent company to form a single operating set-up.

A new fall campaign for "All-Fabric Tintex Tints and Dyes" has been started by Park Tilford through the Charles M. Storm Company, Inc. The appropriation is 72 per cent above that of last fall and the largest in the history of Tintex for a comparable period.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 9 were 825,593 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 72,497 cars, or 8.1 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, 8,717 cars, or 1.0 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 11,056 cars, or 1.4 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Knit dresses continue to be comfortable and easy to pack, but something new has been added. This year's crop contains many style notes such as two-color combinations, interesting stitch detail, slot seams and smart jumper effects.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 -- The Giants bagged one-half of a freak "double-header" with the Phils before 3,210 fans tonight at Shibe Park, mainly because the "first game" was a one-inning hold-over affair.

HASTINGS, Neb., Sept. 15 (U.P.) -- An explosion which was heard about 125 miles away killed at least three Navy men, injured fifty-six Navy and civilian employes and demolished one of the main buildings of the Naval Ordnance Depot early today.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- The Westchester Country Club closed both its courses today as a result of last night's storm and members of the United States Senior Women's Golf Association, gathered for their national championship, disbanded without being able to finish the event, which was revived this season after a two-year lull.

Though the fury of the hurricane that swept up from the West Indies was exceeded by that which devastated New England in 1938, it will go down in meteorological history. After the worst had happened, we read the usual tales of lives lost, property damaged, electric lighting systems crippled, trains stalled.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- General of the Armies John J. Pershing, who observed his eighty-fourth birthday on Wednesday, has suffered a severe physical setback, the War Department announced tonight.
LONDON, Sept. 15 -- Reconstruction Minister Lord Woolton disclosed today that 107,000 homes had been destroyed beyond repair in London alone by the German airplane and robot attacks since 1940.

Lucien Cart, 19-year-old Columbia University student, pleaded guilty to first degree manslaughter yesterday in General Sessions in the fatal stabbing of David Kammerer, 33, a one-time teacher of English and physical education at Washington University, St. Louis.

PARIS, Sept. 15 (U.P.) -- Francois de Menthon, Justice Commissioner, outlining proceedings that his department would undertake against traitors and collaborationists, said today that Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain and all members of the Vichy Cabinet had been ordered arrested and that he would suggest that a special high court be created to try Marshal Petain.

With customary courage and good sense Gen. "Ike" Eisenhower goes full out in praise of American labor for its contribution to the war effort. In a Labor Day broadcast he said: "From this battlefront American fighting troops send their grateful thanks to the workers of America for having made this the best-equipped force in history."

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 15 -A toll of three persons dead, $2,000,000 loss to apple, tobacco and other crops and other losses were counted up today in Connecticut as factories, utilities and householders set to work to repair damage suffered in last night's hurricane.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 -- The proposed $12,000,000 refunding program of the Gulf States Utilities Company, a subsidiary of the Engineers Public Service Company, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Many leading chain stores and independent merchants were in the position yesterday of being unable to comply with the revised MPR 330 issued on Wednesday by the Office of Price Administration and effective on next Monday, it was learned here.

The stock market recovered some confidence yesterday as losses of the two previous sessions were bridged, although the reversal of form failed to attract any increase in business. The most substantial additions were made by the aircraft issues, where bidding proceeded at an accelerated pace and gains were increased as the day progressed.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 15 (AP) -Robert E. Hannegan, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, declared tonight that Governor Dewey's attacks on the New Deal were based on the principle of "when in doubt, prosecute."
CLEVELAND, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Tigers blasted four pitchers for a 9-1 victory to split a double-header in Municipal Stadium tonight. The Indians won, 4 -- 3, in the twelve-inning twilight opener.

Women of all ages in many Latin-American countries are "psychologically" in the war and are extremely interested in international post-war problems, as indicated at numerous women's meetings held recently in Chile, Brazil, Uruguay and Argentina, it was reported yesterday by Miss Margaret E. Forsyth, new director of the foreign division of the Young Women's Christian Association, who returned Thursday from several months' tour of these nations.

THERE has been some murmuring lately about the week-to-week quality of newsreels, and a good many folks of our acquaintance have manifested discontent. The newsreels, they say, have failed to picture the true proportion of war's events and have gone on repeating trivial happenings that have been stock news items for years.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 16 -- The Berne correspondent of the Swedish newspaper Morgentidningen, citing a "reliable German source," said today that Adolf Hitler had asked an intermediary to ask Russia for peace.

PARIS, Sept. 15 (Delayed) -- The French "Provisional Government" will ask the Allies to include in the terms of the armistice with Germany a provision for the extradition of those high French officials who are in Germany, Francois de Menthon, Commissioner for Justice, announced today.

ELEVENTH ARMY AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, Alaska, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The story of a thrill-packed escape from the Alaskan wilderness after they had been blown out of their airplane 20,000 feet above land was related here today by six crewmen from a Liberator bomber that had been listed as missing since Sept. 3.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Red Sox pushed across ten runs in the last two innings to wallop the Senators, 11 -- 5, tonight and keep alive their American League pennant hopes.

LAST week in THE NEW YORK TIMES there was told the story of radio's search for performers, writers and directors, under the heading of "Tomorrow's Talent." If I may, I should like to suggest this postscript, for, believe it or not, talent is in search of radio.

Ever since 1942 when the nation's purchasing power began to exceed the supply of goods and services available for purchase, the Administration has been walking a tightrope. Pulling it one way was the necessity of stabilizing wages and prices to prevent the excess-purchasing power from bidding prices up the inflationary spiral.

CONTRARY tremors ravage the cove invited to appear as a guest star on "Information, Please." The bid to compete in wisdom and waggery with Fadiman, Adams and Kieran is so flattering that it reduces the candidate to a semi-swoon. The prospect of a triumph among the illuminati caresses the victim's ego until he purrs like a dynamo.

Federal officials opened the way yesterday for widespread remodeling of large apartments and outmoded tenements under a liberalized wartime program that is expected to help materially in relieving the critical housing shortage in New York.

LONDON, Sept. 16 (U.P.) -- The Germans began sabotaging Finnish harbors and mine fields and mining shipping lanes tonight, precipitating scores of clashes. Stockholm dispatches reported another German invasion fleet was moving toward Porkala, twenty-five miles southwest of Helsinki.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16 -- The Browns took over first place in the tight American League pennant race tonight by walloping the White Sox, 9 to 0, behind Jack Kramer's one-hit pitching. Their margin is a half game.

Here is the story of the Army's role in the first two years of war told in 482 of the thousands of magnificent photographs made by Signal Corps photographers.
THE popularity of horseback riding is increasing, according to reports from both riding academies and sporting goods stores, and dude ranch operators are having a busy season.

ONE doubts if any other literature can count as many abortive or truncated careers among its novelists as our own. Our literary history of the last few decades is strewn with the wrecks of talent and genius. Seldom has there been a steady growth toward mastery of craftsmanship which has been accompanied by a corresponding growth in maturity of attitude.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora signed an order yesterday requiring Frank Costello, gambler, to show cause why he should not be held in contempt for refusing to testify Friday before Deputy Police Commissioner Cornelius O'Leary, in the proceeding before him to revoke the cabaret license of the Copacabana night club.

THE fall sessions of classes in gardening at near-by educational institutions have been announced. Included among them are day and evening lecture series designed for the layman, and longer courses for professional gardeners.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The National Gallery of Art placed on exhibition today a group of paintings and drawings portraying the United States Coast Guard in offensive action against the enemy, done by members of the Coast Guard Combat Artists Unit.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 16 -- New light on the mechanism involved in the regeneration of lost limbs in tadpoles and related species, and the discovery of a method that brings about regeneration of lost organs even in adult frogs, leading to the hope that "this new knowledge may provide a basis for the inducting of limb regeneration in higher animals."

IT was once traditional, in writing jocularly of contract bridge, to describe trumping partner's ace as a heinous crime. It has since become known, however, that in many cases it is proper to trump partner's ace. In fact, if a player is seen to trump his partner's ace he is probably an expert, not a beginner.
ROME, Sept. 16 (AP) -- A communique:

RICHMOND, Sept. 16 -- The recently announced plan of the war mobilization director, James F. Byrnes, for reconversion of industry after the war has been of especial interest in the Upper South where this problem is particularly important.

Three alternative courses of action by the Office of Price Administration were seen in retail quarters here last week following the objections voiced unanimously by the OPA Retail Council to the dual pricing chart and cumulative mark-up control embodied in the eighth draft of an order designed to supplant the General Maximum Price Regulation.

Haydn Pearson's "Argument for Military Training" in THE MAGAZINE struck me as a particularly fine example of the realistic approach and clear-minded analysis of this important subject. Leaving out all frills and nonessentials, he concentrates on the three basic reasons in favor of a year of military training for our youth in peacetime, namely: (1) preparedness as a means of national security; (2) the physical benefit to the individual, and (3) the value of discipline.

BOSTON, Sept. 16 -- A Dodger team made up mostly of junior varsity youngsters split a double-header with the Braves today, winning the opener, 5 -- 4, and dropping the nightcap, 4 -- 2, before a mild turnout of 2,944 fans.

Although they are sharply divided as to the merits and total academic benefits of the accelerated three-year college program, a majority of college and university presidents report that they will return to the traditional four-year schedule after the war ends. Those institutions that offered summer session courses in normal times will continue to do so, but for the most part the compulsory three-year pattern, now in effect in many parts of the country, will disappear.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Spokesmen for the United Mine Workers of America indicated today the union would ask coal operators, or the War Labor Board, for a new contract within twenty-four hours after any decision to revise the "Little Steel" wage formula upward is announced.

BOSTON, Sept 16 -- Shortage of venture capital, willing to take risks in rehabilitation, continues to plague those responsible for post-war planning despite pioneer work of various official commissions. State and Federal Government projects are plentiful but an alarming reliance upon public treasuries for needed funds in private industry is apparent as a legacy of the last twelve years.

MOSCOW, Sept. 16 (AP) -- There is a growing feeling among Russians that the Americans and British may take too easy an attitude toward the Germans after the war.

Describing the condition of Italian people as "desperate" and beyond the scope of private relief agencies. Justice Juvenal Marchisio, president of American Relief for Italy, Inc., appealed yesterday for recognition and help to Italy as a fighting ally by the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration Council at Montreal.

He devotes the first quarter of his book to an outline of his work as courthouse beat man for The Tulsa (Okla.) Tribune, to his eager struggle to get into the Marine Corps as combat correspondent despite defective eyesight, to the agonies of boot training and to the brush-off treatment he got from hardshell marine regulars.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- American forces smashed into the gateway of the Philippines this week by their double-barreled, coordinated invasions of Morotai and Palau. While these momentous military moves, preludes to our return to the Philippines, were taking place.

China had no representative at the Quebec conference, but the sad state of that nation must have been high upon the agenda of the meeting. The military fortunes of China are at their lowest ebb. Her economic and political situation continues to deteriorate. Yet it is from China, most strategists agree, that our final blows against Japan must be struck.

OFF PELELIU ISLAND, Palau, Sept. 14 (Delayed) -- For three raucous days this heavy cruiser in company with other warships of the Pacific Fleet has stood off the beaches of Peleliu and sent a thundering bombardment into blockhouses, pillboxes, gun emplacements and every form of defense installation visible or suspected.

GARY, Ind., Sept. 16 (AP) -- David J. McDonald of Pittsburgh, secretary-treasurer of the CIO-United Steel Workers and one of six labor leaders who recently toured European war fronts, told delegates from 132 locals of the union's District 31 today "the preponderant production of American steel workers turned the tide of war in our favor."

FALL planting of small fruits is becoming more popular, although spring has long been the traditional season for this work. A few of them should not be started now, but most varieties of grapes, blackberries, red raspberries, currants, gooseberries and blueberries are so hardy that there will be no unusual hazard from fall planting.

A homicide at New Paltz, N.Y., yesterday morning led the police here to the discovery at 3 P.M. of the bodies of a woman and her two children in their second-floor apartment at 82-10 Rockaway Boulevard, Ozone Park, Queens.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 16 -- A gangling freshman end twice outreached and outran desperate owa Pre-Flight Seahawk defenders today to give the University of Michigan a 12-7 victory in the season's football opener for both teams.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Bucknell stampeded the Muhlenberg Mules today, 24 to 7, in the season's football opener. Early-season jitters, which caused five fumbles, four converted into touchdowns, counted heavily in the result.

A CONFLICT of no small consequence is brewing between the producers in Hollywood and the nation's theatre owners on the issue of over-long pictures, those two hour-plus marathons which have become so common.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 16 -- Yale's search for a backfield to put behind its biggest line in years was rewarded today in a full-length supervised scrimmage with Holy Cross on Thompson Field.

The American Constitution was adopted on Sept. 17, 1787, by a majority of the fifty-five delegates from twelve States which had begun their deliberations in Philadelphia on May 12 of that year. It is peculiarly fitting this year that Governor Dewey has issued a proclamation naming today as "Constitution Day" and urging that patriotic exercises be held in honor of the event.

BULB planting in general, and this year the planting of daffodils and other narcissus in particular, takes precedence over all other fall activities in most gardens. We have come to expect the American-grown narcissus, particularly daffodils, to be of the finest quality.

On a six-and-a-half-acre site that seven months ago was cluttered with dilapidated garages, small commercial buildings and tenements, one of the largest playgrounds in the city was opened yesterday in Harlem at Lenox Avenue between 143d and 145th Streets, with only coal bunkers between it and the Harlem River.

In cooperation with the War Production Board, the nation's Girl Scouts are planning a long-term salvage program to replace their periodic salvage drives. Mrs. Paul Rittenhouse, national director, announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, Sept. 16 -- With the Red Army at Warsaw's gates, apparently preparing to cross the Vistula River. the state of quasi-civil war that has broken out in sections of Poland threatens to further impair relations between the Soviet-sponsored Polish National Committee and the Polish regime in London.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration ordered tonight sharp increases in point values for those processed foods which were still rationed in a companion move to elimination of points on a wide variety of other canned foods. Both the higher points and removal of many items from rationing are effective Sunday.

Post-war tax proposals of the Committee for Economic Development are based on a national income of $140,000,000,000. The committee made clear that it does not predict this figure, using it merely for convenience. Other tax plans, such as that sponsored by Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and treasurer of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., all assume high national incomes.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 16 -- Fleet-footed Marvin Jenkins dismayed his former shipmates by dashing sixty-five and eighteen yards for Harvard touchdowns as the Crimson opened its informal four-game football schedule with a 19-12 victory over Tufts today before a 12,000 crowd at the stadium. Jenkins, famed as a trackman while pursuing his Navy V-12 course at Tufts, was transferred to Harvard in midsummer.

THIS is the story of Oliver Morosco, a man who flashed comet-like across the Broadway sky in the early years of the Nineteen Hundreds. A task done candidly and with affection, it is written in the form of an autobiography by his wife and a friend, with details from Morosco's own notes and comments, with convincing enough result.
WITH the advancing season, the list of both returning and new programs continues to grow, this week being represented by drama, comedy, music and literature. In the following order:

ENEMY planes are observed circling over a spot in the desert, and the Fortress Commander at Alexandria fears that the Germans, aided probably by spies in Alexandria itself, are planning some coup. He sends for Capt. Dan Dupree, a South African Intelligence officer, to find out what is going on.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Sept. 16 (U.P.) -- Troops of the British Fourteenth Army have crossed the upper Chindwin River, thus narrowing to less than 115 miles the gap separating Allied drives closing in on the Japanese in the heart of Burma from the north and west, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's communique revealed today.

Donitas First and Best Effort each captured a $25,000 stake as Aqueduct closed its fall meeting yesterday, but it's safe to say that Jockey Ted Atkinson felt he possessed that which was greater than gold for he rode five winners, including the two stake winners.

WITH Rumania and Bulgaria out of the Axis orbit, Italy a co-belligerent, France liberated and other lands being one by one wrested from the Nazis, the question at the moment uppermost in American collectors' minds is how soon Washington will permit philatelists to acquire the many European stamps which have been released in enemy and enemy-occupied countries during the war years.

BILLINGS, Mont., Sept 16 -- There are close to seventy reporters covering the Dewey campaign train, which wound its way slowly and somewhat mysteriously across the continent this week. Most of them are experienced in covering national campaigns, some are not.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The War Production Board today issued Interpretation No. 2 to Conservation Order M-385, the textiles-for-civilian items order, to clarify the definition of the terms "dresses" and "men's shirts" and to explain operation of the equitable distribution clause of the order.

EXPECTATIONS of an early peace in Europe have renewed interest here in overseas distribution of Hollywood's pictures, as indicated by recent developments. The Overseas Branch of the Office of War Information has announced that seven major producing companies are cooperating on a Hollywood radio program to be broadcast daily from London in French.

The New York War Fund, representing the twenty-two National War Fund member agencies and nine New York City war service organizations, will open its 1944 'one-for-all, once-a-year" appeal Wednesday night with a dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

THIRD ARMY HEADQUARTERS, France, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Wallendorf, first German village captured in the American First Army sector northwest of Trier, was set aflame Thursday and every building burned because of persistent sniping.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16--While the United Nation's mighty armies are pouring over Germany's borders enroute to Berlin, public officials and civic, business and church leaders in the central West are in the midst of making plans for V-day when the Nazis are conquered.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 16 -- On the platform of a prizefight arena in this city, John L. Lewis is playing his favorite role, thundering defiance at his enemies, adding to their number and threatening the financial overlords of the nation with his wrath.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- To the British nation, slightly punch-drunk from overwork and the nerve strain of living under guns for more than five years, the news from Quebec tonight came as a reminder that, even when Germany is defeated, there is still another war to win on the other side of the world.

As the nation's butter production slumps to near a twenty-year low and the local supply becomes tighter, New York City's municipal hospitals have been compelled to switch from butter to oleomargarine.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 16 -- Paperboy, 6-year-old owned by the W-L Ranch of movie producers Harry Warner and Mervyn Le Roy, staged a motion-picture finish today while winning the $25,000 added Narragansett Special by a length at Narragansett Park. Closest to him at the finish was the Millbrook Stable's Alex Barth, who beat Max Marmorstein's Castleman for second in a photo finish.

THOUGH such developments may seem rather acutely prompt, the new local art season presented us with quite a bit of stir and preambling bustle last week. In the last year 1,500,000 sick and injured were cared for in and by the voluntary, non-profit hospitals of New York City, it was revealed yesterday by James S. Adams, chairman of the sixty-sixth annual United Hospital campaign, as he made plans for the city-wide fund drive which begins on Sept. 25.

While both importers and exporters showed an increasing interest in re-establishing contact with French foreign traders, well-informed exporters stated last week that French authorities have indicated trade with that country will not be returned to private channels until the United States releases French funds frozen here.

THE major part of Dr. Rodzinski's programs for the New York Philharmonic-Symphony season of 1944-45 has been arranged. The list of works, with certain of their dates of performance open to change, constitutes one of the most interesting and best-balanced repertories that we have seen in years.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Bill Trotter, veteran Browns' and Washington right-hander, was greeted by a three-homer barrage as he made his National League debut with the Cardinals today, and the blows gave the Cubs a 9-to-5 victory.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The returns from the Maine State election, private reports to Democratic national headquarters from agents in the field, open resentment by powerful units of organized labor and the belief that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey is about to make a strong attack on Sidney Hillman and the CIO-PAC have combined to make Mr. Hillman and his political group activities a major issue in the Presidential campaign.

A new blood clotter is announced by Drs. Walter H. Seegers, Eugene C. Loomis and J.M. Vandenbelt of Parke-Davis laboratories. It is prothrombin, a constituent of human blood which has been isolated in pure form after six years of effort. Activated prothrombin is so powerful that an amount the size of an aspirin tablet can clot a pint of blood solid in a few seconds.
IN 1919 there was a saying in the AEF that the war would last a hundred years, "five years of fighting and ninety-five of winding up the barbed wire."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16--Instructions of the Soviet Government to its delegation at Dumbarton Oaks, the absence of which caused a recess in the first phase of the conversations, have failed to clear away the obstacles to an agreement among the three chief powers.

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 16 (U.P.) -- The Japanese Premier, Gen. Kuniaki Koiso, attempting to bolster home-front morale, said that Japan was preparing to "launch a great offensive in the near future to crush Britain and the United States," and Tokyo revealed another shake-up in the Japanese Naval High Command.

To meet a need shown by last year's NEW YORK TIMES survey, which revealed a widespread lack of knowledge of American history, City College is introducing a new course in "American Life, Literature and Culture" this fall at the School of Business and Civic Administration.

Until police intervened yesterday, Cono Cesario, 35 years old, of 626 East New York Avenue, Brooklyn had worked out what seemed to be a novel and moderately profitable way of mixing business with pleasure.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 16 -- The people of this part of the Deep South are interested more in ending the war and in the peace plans to follow this than they are in politics. With a total registration of 680,000 in Louisiana, only about 250,000 voted in the primary held for Congressional Representatives last Tuesday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 16 -- President Seymour of Yale University warned today that the belief that "this war can be finished without unutterable effort and sacrifice" was "a peculiar danger, not less than the dangers through which we have already passed."

LONDON, Sept. 16 (U.P.) -- Despite the overwhelming evidence that Germany has lost the war, Adolf Hitler and others of the Nazi hierarchy apparently hope to hold out during the winter with a view to making London pay such a high price in blood through revenge bombs that a negotiated peace would be possible next spring, informed observers said tonight.

Except for the effects of the tropical hurricane, which eliminated the Thursday night opening of department stores here, retail trade was active during the week. The loss of the Thursday evening volume, however, pulled down sales totals. Estimates indicated that department store volume might run even with to about 3 per cent under the comparative 1943 week.

New York City added another to its long list of "firsts" when the Lillian Z. 2d, a floating machine shop for marine repairs, was commissioned yesterday at its East Twentieth Street pier by the Zalud at its East Twentieth Street pier Mobile Marine Corporation, prime contractors to the United States Maritime Commission in the conversion of ships to war use.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Newark won the opening game of its semi-final play-off round with Toronto tonight, handing the Leafs a 5-to-1 setback behind Ken Holcombe's brilliant three-hit twirling. A crowd of 4,075 watched the game, played after four consecutive postponements because of rain and hurricane damage to Ruppert Stadium.

BARI, Italy, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Strong elements of Yugoslav Partisans pushing northward west of the Morava River against scant opposition have enveloped Valjevo, captured near-by Slovac and taken Lajkovac, the latter only thirty-four miles southwest of Belgrade, it was learned here today.

MISS FOLEY'S collection of American short stories of the year is a representative cross-section, both in content and in source, of the sort of story our literary magazines are publishing. THE New Friends of Music, which begins its season of sixteen Sunday afternoon chamber music concerts Nov. 5, in Town Hall, will devote its programs for the forthcoming series chiefly to works of Mozart. The offerings also will include compositions of leading French composers from Rameau to Ravel. Ensembles participating include the Gordon, Lener, Budapest and Pro Arte string quartets and the Albeneri Trio.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 16 -- The Allies are apparently developing an aerial and naval effort to hamper the Germans' northward withdrawal in Greece, according to indications tonight after the war's heaviest bombing of the Athens airdromes and the disclosure that the tightening Royal Navy blockade in the Aegean Sea has destroyed 78 per cent of the Germans' available shipping tonnage as they attempt a hopeless evacuation.

Important new discoveries of early American literature have been brought to light and evaluated for classroom study, under a textbook project of the Catholic University of America, according to an announcement by Benedictine Sister Mary Theresa Brentano, of the university's committee for the revision of English curricula.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 16 -- Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for United States Senate, told a gathering here today that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey was well equipped to be President of the United States because of his achievements in Albany.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sunday, Sept. 17 -- A threatened upset of the conservative balance of power in the executive board of the CIO United Automobile Workers was averted early today with the re-election of Walter P. Reuther as vice president of the union.

The People's Symphony Concerts will present a series of six Artists Recitals and a series of six chamber music concerts at the Washington Irving High School during the coming season. Participants in the Artists Recitals comprise Erica Morini and Efrem Zimbalist, violinists; Raya Garbousova, 'cellist, and Egon Petri, Robert Goldsand and Erno Balogh, pianists. This series opens Oct. 7 and closes March 3.

ROME, Sept. 16 (AP) -- British and German tanks were locked today in a great battle within three miles of the Adriatic stronghold of Rimini, whose fall would let the Eighth Army into the Po Valley to roll up the Gothic Line from behind.

ONIONS are breaking records this year, the United States Department of Agriculture says. The crop has been estimated to be 51 per cent greater than that of 1943 and 47 per cent in excess of a recent ten-year average.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16 -- A campaign which originated in southern California and seeks to have the voters at the November election eliminate the closed shop from this State's industrial scene has sharply divided employer groups and is giving concern to union leaders.

A check for $24,000,000, one for $17,000,000 and twenty ranging in amounts from $5,000,000 to $10,000,000 representing payments of the third quarterly installment of the 1944 Federal income tax were among the 250,000 pieces of mail received at the Custom House and its annex, Capt. William J. Pedrick, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Second New York District, announced yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Sept. 16 -- The tremendous distances involved in the Pacific war -- distances which act as a brake on getting in position for a direct attack on Japan itself -- were emphasized this week when Gen. Douglas MacArthur moved into Morotai, the northernmost isle of the Dutch Halmaheras, and Admiral William F. Halsey landed simultaneously on Palau.

MONTREAL, Sept. 16 -- L.B. Pearson, Canadian Minister to the United States, was elected chairman of the second session of the Council of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration at its opening plenary meeting this afternoon.

BOSTON, Sept. 17 -- On a single by Eddie Basinski that drove in the only Brooklyn earned run of the day, plus some strikeout relief hurling by Art Herring, the Dodgers today contrived a 3-2 night cap victory to split a doubleheader with the Braves and retain sixth place by 1 percentage point.

Six have been named for the $10,000 Fall Highweight Handicap as Belmont reopens today and, for an added attraction, Pukka Gin, erstwhile Kentucky Derby favorite, is scheduled for a return to competition in the Freeport Purse.

LONDON, Monday, Sept. 18 -Under fire from German batteries on Warsaw's cliffs, Russian and Polish troops yesterday launched a frontal assault on the Polish capital across the quarter-mile Vistula River from Praga, the German High Command said last night.

The annual report of Lehn Fink Products Corporation for the fiscal year ended June 30 shows a net profit of 697,845, equal to $1.75 a capital share, comparing with $778,037, or $1.96 a share, in the previous year.
Formation of the women's division of the Citizens Committee for Universal Military Training was announced yesterday by Mrs. Ernesta Barlow, chairman of the organizing committee.

Kathleen Winsor's novel of the Restoration period in England, "Forever Amber," which Macmillan is promoting with enthusiasm, has a first printing of 50,000 copies and will go through a second and third printing before publication, which is scheduled for Oct. 16.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 17 -- Agreement by the House Conference Committee to seek approval of the Bankhead amendment to the Surplus Disposal Bill, whereby cotton loans would be raised to 95 per cent of parity and sale of surplus cotton in foreign markets at the prevailing world price level accounted for a stiffening of cotton future prices early last week on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange.

On a twelve-acre site in a longneglected section of Harlem overlooking the Harlem River the Metropoltian Life Insurance Company is planning to erect a modern park-like residential community for 1,200 families.

More than $600,000,000 in new corporate securities is in sight for public offering over the course of the next six weeks or so, promising the most active period in the investment market since before the war.

Recent developments have thrown an encouraging light on the picture of aviation in the post-war years. Last week the airlines expressed their faith in the future with a $50,000,000 order for huge new Douglas transports. Alfred Marchev of Republic Aviation and Joseph Gueting of General Aviation see a silver lining in the clouds that surround the future of private flying.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Congestion has developed in September oats as the result of a concentrated holding attributed to processors while a cash house with northwestern connections is said to be short. There have been fairly liberal deliveries of cash oats on September contracts, but they went into strong hands and had no effect as a price-making influence.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Small receipts of hogs, combined with a fairly aggressive demand for lard and meats, have resulted in a tight situation in the market for pork products. Although it is possible to obtain some meats in lots of 4,900 pounds, which command a premium of 3/4 cent a pound over carlot sales, the bulk of the business is at the ceiling level.
SYDNEY, Sept. 17 (Reuter) -- Sydney University is establishing the first chair of American History in Australia as a further step to the creation of a school in Pacific studies.

BEAUGENCY, France, Sept. 17 -- All day long German forces of occupation from the Loire south to the Pyrenees have been converging on this ancient town to surrender their weapons to the United States Ninth Army. By midafternoon 15,000 were in the pens and another 3,000 to 5,000 were expected to be rounded up before nightfall.
J.H. Satcher has been appointed executive general agent of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company with offices at 618 Woodward Bulilding, Washington, D.C.

ANTWERP, Sept. 17 -- How an 11-year-old Belgian boy stopped the Germans from blowing up the last bridge over the Rupel River near Boom and thus made possible the continued British advance may become a legend as famous as that of the little Dutch boy who plugged a dike with his thumb to save Holland from the sea.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Cubs closed their home season by shading the Cardinals twice by identical scores of 2 to 1 before 41,822 today. The last seven innings of the opener were played in the rain.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (U.P.) -Public members of the War Labor Board sought tonight to apply a brake to what was termed the "high enthusiasm" of wage-earners that they would receive general pay increases if the "Little Steel" stabilization formula was modified.

The citizens of New York are more interested in small nations with great hearts than in large nations whose hearts are black, Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, declared yesterday, at exercises held in the Council chamber at City Hall to celebrate the 700th anniversary of the Luxembourg freedom charter.

KUNMING, China, Sept. 17 -The United States Fourteenth Air Force has destroyed and virtually abandoned its air bases near Kweilin, provisional capital in invaded Kwangsi province, it was disclosed today, in the face of a grave Japanese threat not only to that city but also to the whole structure of the American military effort in this country.
Mrs. Anne C. Roberts, who has been with Lord Taylor as merchandise manager of first-floor accessories for eight year, has resigned.

Active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 8 to 37 points last week with the more distant deliveries having the more pronounced strength. The market was mainly under the influence of developments in Washington with respect to legislation for raising the loan rate on cotton and for authorizing export sales of surplus commodities at world competitive prices.

Last week, stock averages declined again, recovering at the week-end. They went below the preceding week's low level, and were some 6 1/2 points under the highest of mid-July, selling in mid-week at the lowest average since June 9.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Detroit's Tigers surged into the American League leadership today by sweeping a double-header from the Cleveland Indians on a pair of brilliant pitching performances by Stubby Overmire and Rufus Gentry.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- The first direct blow for the liberation of Holland was timed to come simultaneously from underground and from airborne troops of Lieut. Gen. Lewis H. Brereton's newly formed army of the sky.

A new and mighty Allied army sweeping from the sky entrenched itself yesterday on the German border behind the enemy fighting line in Holland. Never before has an entire army been carried through the air with men, guns, tanks and supplies complete. This vast aerial armada surpassed in size and power any similar undertaking in the history of war.

Barring unfavorable occurrences we do not foresee, the active domestic demand for goods, supplemented by a huge export demand, promises to make our traditional form of economic organization function to the general satisfaction once the period of transition from war to peace is safely passed.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Browns dropped out of the firstplace position they had held since last night when they split today with the White Sox. The Browns won the first game, 5 to 1, but lost the second, 8 to 2.

DETROIT, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Paced by Melvin Bleeker, rookie halfback, who scored two touchdowns, the Philadelphia Eagles whipped the Detroit Lions, 27 to 7, today in a National Football League exhibition game before 13,702 fans.

KATHERINE ANNE PORTER is one of the most highly regarded literary artists in this country. Up until last week she had published only two volumes of short stories, "Flowering Judas" and "Pale Horse, Pale Rider," but on the strength of those two small books alone she had won herself a critical prestige so great that her often announced and often postponed novel has been one of the legends and disappointments of repeated publishing seasons.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he would ask Governor Dewey to call a special session of the Legislature to enact measures to control commercial rents. Such legislation, the Mayor declared, was needed at once to protect the city from "irreparable damage" as a by-product of "rent gouging" by lessors of lofts, factory space and other commercial floor areas.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 17 -Jennifer Jones will be starred by Hal B. Wallis in his first Paramount picture "The Love Letters." The actress will have the role previously announced for Ann Richards. The picture, an adaptation by Ayn Rand of an English novel by Chris Massie, is scheduled to begin production Oct. 15 under the direction of William Dieterle.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Monday, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Allied objectives on the perimeter of Morotai Island, invaded Sept. 15, have been reached, today's communique reported. Meanwhile, a tight Allied air cover was maintained, and Bombers crashed a record of 290 tons of bombs on adjacent Halmahera Island, concentrating upon already blasted Japanese airdromes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The grave plight confronting the Japanese Empire and the Japanese Navy was brought into sharp for fus tonight with the disclosure that American sea and air forces had sunk at least 2,004 enemy ships since Pearl Harbor in the greatest strangulation blockade in history.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 17 -The team of Jack White and Pat Circelli of Metropolis won the annual member-pro golf tournament at Bonnie Briar today with a net best-ball round of 33, 31 -- 64, leading by three strokes.

Continued scarcities were reported last week in the apparel and piece goods markets, with buyers following up on orders placed previously and at the same time endeavoring to place new business, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Murray Hill Estates, Inc., representing Lipkin Bros., operators, bought from the Poughkeepsie Savings Bank the taxpayer on a plot 62 by 130 feet at 532-36 St. Mark's Avenue, corner of Franklin Avenue, in Brooklyn. Gus Frey, broker, arranged the sale for cash over a purchase-money mortgage of $12,000.
The Yankees closed their home season at the Stadium yesterday, slamming the door with such violence that they all but shut themselves out for any possible world series return.
LONDON, Sept. 17 (Reuter) -- A Polish Home Army fighting in War saw communique, as reported by the Polish Telegraph Agency:

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Newark took a commanding lead of two games to none in their International League semi-final playoff round today by shading Toronto, 3 to 2, in eleven innings before 4,855 fans.

Although it is to experiment in only a few schools at this time, the Board of Education is to be commended for the beginning it has made to end the system under which school buildings are placed in rite control of custodian engineers. For many years leading educators, citizens' groups and various commissions have urged that New York City end this practice.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -Secretary Hull said today that he would back any practical measure to give international recognition to the principle of news freedom.

To help Navy men and their families cope with the increasingly critical housing shortage in the metropolitan area, Rear Admiral William R. Munroe, commandant of the Third Naval District, appealed to patriotic New Yorkers yesterday to make available their vacant rooms and apartments to Navy personnel stationed here.
The letter from Representative Calvin V. Johnson that you published Sept. 12 is very curious, to say the least of it. He apparently is not aware of, or disregards entirely, the following facts:
SPOKANE, Wash., Sept. 17 -Governor Dewey's first Pacific Coast speech, which is to be delivered tomorrow night over a country-wide radio network from Seattle, will be on the subject of "Labor."

The last official barrier to widespread conversion of large apartments and old tenements into badly needed living quarters was removed here yesterday when Charles S. Ascher, regional head of the National Housing Agency, designated New York as an area of "critical housing shortage."

Nation-wide reports from real estate offices indicate a decided upswing in the purchase of part-time farms. City and town dwellers of both the white-collar and industrial worker groups are buying homes and acreage on the roads which radiate from centers of population.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Increases aggregating about 10 per cent over present mill level ceilings for all fine cotton goods priced under individual construction ceilings, including box-loom, clip-spot marquisettes, were announced today by the Office of Price Administration.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 17 -Suddenly a breath of fresh air has begun to rush through the stagnant miasma of Chungking. Newspapers and the people have begun to express at least something of what is on their minds.
The German-controlled Copenhagen radio reported last night that bomb blasts had wrecked important industrial objectives in the Jutland cities of Aalborg and Aarhus yesterday afternoon.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Pirates closed their home season by dividing a double bill with the Reds today before 19,823 fans.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -Pacific Fleet communique 120:

LONDON, Sept. 17 (U.P.) -- Field Marshal Sir Bernard L. Montgomery said tonight in a broadcast to his troops that the German enemy had suffered such immense losses in the west that "it is becoming problematical how much longer he can continue the struggle."

An aspect of the farm labor problem which is rarely mentioned in the news is a question of health -- the overworked farmer. The stress is always on the drop in production through lack of labor, or praise for continued production in the face of lack of labor.

The Age of Success Human nature is so happily constituted that it is impossible to be discouraged for long, even when our scientists, as did Dr. Thomas Midgley Jr. recently and the late Sir William Osler previously, tell us that men over 30 or 40 are not good for much except the leftover jobs that the young fellows can't do better.

Cutting the late rowen is a pleasant fall task on the farm. There's a sense of urgency in regular haying season; during hot July days the farm family stretches every sinew to get the crop quickly under cover. But when rowen time comes, there's a different spirit over the land.

PELELIU ANCHORAGE, Sept. 15 (Delayed) -- United States assault forces stormed Peleliu today against what appears to be one of the fiercest defenses yet encountered in the war against Japan. Under a terrific barrage from rocket-firing landing craft, destroyers, cruisers and battleships, wave on wave moved slowly onto the island's western beach and tonight they were clinging tenaciously to a stained beachhead about 700 yards deep.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 1 -- During Wen Ying-feng's first year in a cotton spinning factory the Japanese came from the east, threatening the city of Shasi, in Hupeh Province, where she worked. The factories in Shasi decided to move up river.
WITH AMERICAN TROOPS Before Schneidemuehl, Germany, Sept. 17 (AP) -- This town, northwestern suburb of Stolberg, east of Aachen, is being torn apart today by our big guns and fighter bombers.

BATH, Me., Sept. 17 (U.P.) -- A fighting ship bearing the name of a fighting man was launched here today when the 2,250-ton destroyer Frank Knox, honoring the late Secretary of the Navy, slid down the ways before a distinguished gathering of high-ranking Navy officials and guests.

A modern Greek tragedy moved toward its close yesterday with the arraignment in Queens Felony Court of Peter Demetrakoupoulos for the fatal stabbing of his wife, Mary, in their home at 82-10 Rockaway Boulevard, Ozone Park, Queens, in retribution for her killing of their two daughters.
ROME, Sept. 17 (AP) -- A communique:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 -Strange things happened to the Giants today at Shibe Park; things that had to be seen to be believed. Included were no fewer than five errors, four wild pitches, a passed ball, a hit batsman and a man being picked off first.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Government support continues to absorb a considerable part of the surplus spring wheat pressing on the market and results in decreasing hedging pressure to a point where it is almost non-existent. September deliveries in leading markets have been showing considerable strength and they were selling recently well below the price that the Government would pay for cash grain stored in elevators.
PARIS, Sept. 17 -- Soon -- perhaps in a few days -- this "City of Light" will have electricity again on a fuller scale than the half-hour daily now available.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 17 -- American airmen shot down over Bulgaria and captured were beaten with pistol butts by the Bulgarians, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (U.P.) -The War Department has begun divesting itself of 22,322,540 acres, an area almost the size of New England, which it acquired to house, train and equip its armies of 7,000,000.

DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 17 -- Ben J. Field of Great Neck, L.I., had the second great dog show thrill of his sporting career today when his liver and white pointer, Champion Tempo, was named best in show at the second annual exhibition of the Interstate Kennel Association at the Ox Ridge Kennel Club today.

ROME, Sept. 17 (AP) -- In a desperate effort to prevent an Allied break-through into the Po Volley the Germans were hurling big. Mark V and Mark VI tanks at Canadian and Greek troops of the British Eighth Army who were reported today to be only two miles from Rimini, eastern anchor of the Gothic Line in northern Italy.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 17 -- The nationalist organ Cabildo, blacklisted by the United States, reappeared this morning and in its explanation why it had suspended publication for one day -- yesterday -- reveals that the nationalist press buys its newsprint directly from the Argentine Government. In one Government office a special official is charged with distributing locally produced newsprint to the blacklisted press.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17 -- The steel ingot rate for the nation last week sagged 1 1/2 points to 94.5 per cent of rated capacity. Indications are that steel-making activity this week will be on a par with a week ago. The drop last week was attributed to repairs and also to the fact that some makers of ingots and semi-finished steel for other plants found these supplies in excess of the demand.

Visible evidence of the damage done by the hurricane that struck the New York area Thursday remained in many parts of the city yesterday as 533 pieces of equipment from the Department of Sanitation sought to clear the streets of fallen trees and power wires, and augmented utilities crews worked on round-the-clock shifts to restore electric light and telephone services.

The Columbia University Department of Psychiatry will open a psychoanalytic and psychosomatic clinic for training and research next month at the Columbia-Presbyterian Vedical Center, Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, dean of the faculty of medicine, announced yesterday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Jefferson Caffrey, United States Ambassador, left this morning by plane for Washington, where he said he had been "called for consultation."

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 17 -- The romantic and violently independent mountainous area of southern Syria known as Jebel Druz, inhabited by an estimated 60,000 tough, hard-fighting members of the Druz tribe, has decided to relinquish its statutory autonomy and merge with Syria, which received its independence following its liberation from the Vichy French in 1941, according to a Damascus message released by the Arab News Agency.

UNITED STATES NINTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS in France, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Lieut. George W. Stucky, Thunderbolt fighter pilot who crossed the Siegfried Line in a jeep, returned to his headquarters today and said:

BEACHHEAD ON MOROTAI, Sept. 16 (Delayed) -- American troops who poured ashore yesterday on Morotai under the eyes of Gen. Douglas MacArthur pushed forward this morning in a drive to extend their lines around the base of Cape Gila and occupy all the flat land in the southern part of the island, where installations may eventually be built for bombing the Philippines from a range of about 300 miles.

OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 17 -Marine Pfc. Vito A. Cassara, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vito Cassaro of 2025 East Seventy-second Street, Brooklyn, N.Y., is recovering in the Naval Hospital here from wounds received on Saipan. But he said today that he probably would be dead had it not been for Lieut. Col. Evans F. Carlson, marine raid leader, "than whom they don't come any better."

Thirteen months after their first conference at Quebec, at which were laid the plans for the great campaigns in western Europe that have brought the Allied armies to the "holy soil" of Germany, President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill and their chiefs of staff have met again in the same historic city to lay the plans for the defeat of the last enemy -- Japan.
Fordham University conferred yesterday upon Dr. H.H. Kung, Vice President and Minister of Finance of China, the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 17 -- Rather than risk a strong easterly wind and raging water, most of the Long Island Sound skippers kept their sailboats idle today. Their decision, plus the fact that many boats suffered damage in the recent hurricane, resulted in only eighteen craft getting under way in the Y.R.A. championship regatta at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 17 (AP) -- A state of war exists between Finland and Germany, and a formal declaration may come almost without notice, the Finnish press declared tonight.

LONDON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Eight American Congressmen, critical of what they termed the Army's stalling tactics, have appealed directly to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for permission to visit France. If it is refused, they say, they will ask why visiting labor leaders have received preferred treatment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -The destroyer Warrington and two Coast Guard patrol craft sank at sea during last week's Atlantic hurricane, the Navy reported tonight. It added that reports indicated heavy loss of life on the destroyer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- As Allied airborne forces drop into the Netherlands and the liberation of the country nears, the Netherlands Government in exile, it was understood here today, has been completing plans for the rapid resumption of its former place in the political world.

"Coppelia," with Alexandra Danilova in the central role, was the chief feature of last night's program by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, which yesterday began its second and last week at the City Center. This is one of Miss Danilova's best parts, and she was in good form, especially in the first act.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Sweden is ready to resume shipments to the United States of newsprint and wood pulp for making other paper at nearly pre-war rates as soon as Nazi domination of the sea lanes from Sweden can be ended, and ships become available, Sweden mill executives say.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 17 -- A slender man with a pair of grappling-hooks for hands and four men with a penchant for rules conspired to make the Brooklyn Tigers' National Football League debut for 1944 an inauspicious one today as the erstwhile Dodgers were downed, 14 -- 7, by the Green Bay Packers at State Fair Park.

The invasion of Mindanao in the Philippines, probably in the near future is clearly forecast, by last week's successful invasion of Morotai in the Halmahera group south of Mindanao, and of Palau, the Japanese island fortress, 600 miles to the east.

KEARNY, N. J., Sept. 17 -Charles Edison, former Governor of New Jersey, paid tribute to the ate Lewis Compton, Assistant Secretary of the Navy from Feb. 9, 1940, to Feb. 13, 1941, at the launching today of one of two 'pocket cruisers" at the United States Steel Corporation's Federal shipyard here.
A Partisan communique, as broadcast yesterday by the Free Yugoslav radio in Serbo-Croat and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears, National Football League champions, came from behind today to defeat the New York Giants, 20 to 10, in an exhibition game before 20,981 shirt-sleeved spectators.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (U.P.) -The rush for air routes in Latin America will get a public airing beginning tomorrow when the Civil Aeronautics Board opens hearings on applications for air service to South and Central America, Mexico and the Caribbean.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Germans could put barely 200 planes into the air against 4,200 Allied aircraft thrown against the Germans on D-day for the invasion of southern France, the War Department reported today.

PARIS, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York held services today in the Cathedral of Notre-Dame, which he described as "the heart and soul of France," before an overflow attendance of American soldiers.

ROME, Sept. 17 -- The Italian press played down the anniversary speech of Marshal Tito wherein he claimed for Yugoslavia "Istria and Slovene coastal areas" and denounced objections of "people in countries that were at war with us a short time ago" to the Yugoslav demand for amendment of "past injustices such as Versailles and other treaties."

Lightning -- in the form of a plainclothes policeman -- struck twice in an apartment in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn Saturday night and early yesterday morning. Twice the alleged culprits, arrested on charges of disorderly conduct, were freed.

The Swedish radio reported last night that a preliminary count of the votes cast in the election for the Lower House of Parliament showed that the country's major political party, the Social Democratic, had lost nineteen seats but retained undisputed control of the Chamber with 115.

LONDON, Monday, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Luftwaffe was able to send up only scattered and futile opposition yesterday to the vast aerial armada of transports and gliders that landed an Allied liberation army in the Netherlands.

Bishop William T. Manning officiated at a service commemorating the Battle of Britain at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday afternoon and predicted that "the Nazi terror" was approaching its end. Five thousand persons attended the service of thanksgiving "to Almighty God for His gift of victory in the Battle of Britain."

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Monday, Sept. 18 -- Thousands of Allied airborne troops landed in the Rhine Delta of the Netherlands yesterday in the wake of a thunderous bombing by American and British heavy bombers, and armored divisions of the British Second Army raced into the Netherlands to join the airborne units in a coordinated effort to turn the right flank of the Westwall.

Children would rather climb on broken-down walls and crawl through sewer pipes than stick to formal playground equipment, as everybody knows who has watched them play. Recognizing this, the community planning and landscape division of the New York City Housing Authority has devised a series of designs on which children can use their imaginations, have fun, and play in safety.

The agricultural commodity market during the past week was fairly active, with price declines somewhat more pronounced than the price increases. The combined weight of these price changes caused the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices to drop moderately from 113.27 to 113.05.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- A contest over proposals to enroll soldiers and sailors now on active duty developed today on the eve of the American Legion annual convention.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Grain markets have been fluctuating in such an erratic manner recently that many traders express the belief that reconversion from a war to a peace basis has been about completed, and the fact that prices have recovered part of the recent loss in the face of continued favorable war news leads to the view the break might have over-discounted developments to date.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- The British Treasury, officials said tonight, is negotiating with the Governments of western Europe for a resumption as soon as possible of trade relations between their countries and Britain.

Charging that several motionpicture houses in Algiers had refused to show the Allies' films of the liberation of Paris, a spokesman for the French Commissariat of Information said yesterday that the armies fighting in France would not understand that in North Africa "the struggle against the Republic continues with such impudence without being punished."

Most food companies with well-established brands are planning larger advertising campaigns after the end of the European war in anticipation of keener competition from many other products which probably will be advertised and promoted extensively, according to Gordon C. Corbaley, president of the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc.
Three new films are scheduled to arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

Your dispatch of Sept. 11, from Washington, concerning Secretary Hull's statement on Austria, must have occasioned considerable amazement to persons familiar with Austrian problems. The statement that "a considerable nucleus of the old Socialist and liberal groups of Austria resisted Anschluss" is not only historically false but also dangerous to future political settlements in central Europe.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 17 -- Walter P. Reuther, head of the union's General Motors division, was declared today to have been re-elected a vice president of the United Automobile Workers, affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, following an all-night count of the vote cast yesterday in the liveliest contest of the convention.

ADVANCE HEADQUARTERS, Troop Carrier Command in Europe, Sept. 17 -- General Brereton and all his staff officers were highly elated tonight at the success of the unit's first exploit. General Brereton and Maj. Gen. Paul L. Williams, commander of the Troop Carrier Command, flew in with the airborne troops to observe the results at first hand.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -A six-run splurge in the second inning helped the Senators edge out the Red Sox, 7 -- 6, today.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- Tentatively, hesitantly and to the accompaniment of an air raid alert the total blackout that has enveloped this country for more than five years came to an end tonight in London. Other cities, towns and hamlets on these islands also shared the lifting of the blackout, and only the more unfortunate coastal areas remained shrouded in the blackness, with little hope of relief until the war has ended.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- The good recovery last week in the markets here is arousing comment whether the tide has definitely turned or the rise was only a temporary respite as a natural reaction after a week's fall. The underlying influences remain -- uncertainty about the immediate post-war period and the desire for liquidity of funds pending a clear view of the outlook.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 17 -- Sensational allegations concerning conditions within Germany were made today in a report that purports to sum up the observations of three men who have been in Germany in an official capacity for a nation that has just broken with the Reich.

Despite a record-breaking withdrawal of meats from cold storage in August, meat stocks in cold storage on Sept. 1 totaled 740,299,000 pounds. This was 15,500,000 pounds more than was on hand at the corresponding period last year and 168,400,000 pounds larger than the average 1939-43 holdings.

ATLANTA, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Coming operations in the Pacific "will dwarf anything completed" in that war area thus far, Lieut. Gen. Alexander A. Vandegrift, commandant of the United States Marine Corps, said today.

The city is prepared to carry out a $400,000,000 construction program in 1945 if Congress acts at once to meet half the cost, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast. The Mayor disclosed that his annual capital budget message to the City Planning Commission, delivered to that body without fanfare last Friday, certified that the city might safely incur debt up to $300,000,000 for capital projects in 1945.

Something new in the way of a mail-order market that should prove especially valuable for those with large households recently has been organized at 139 Belmont Avenue, Newark, N.J. Called the Consumers Food Products Service, it specializes in selling canned meats by the case, which in most instances represents twelve or twenty-four tins, depending on the packer.
LONDON, Sept. 17 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (U.P.) -Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts, House Republican leader, said tonight that the people regarded the war in Europe as nearly over and would elect a Republican House in November "to direct the return to peace-time economy."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Cessation of the war in Europe should reduce military consumption of gasoline sufficiently to allow more gasoline for civilians, the Petroleum Industry War Council, which represents the off industry in the office of the Petroleum Administrator for War, said today.

THE name of Bold Michael McTigue, a broth of a boy from County Clare, crept into this space the other day, making its entrance by the back door, so to speak. Jimmy Johnston had been discussing boxing in general when he detoured for a dissertation on Bold Michael. 'Tis no way to treat a man. Begorrah, he deserves more than an off-hand mention.
MOSCOW, Sept. 17 -- One of the war's saddest stories came from Poland today in dispatches of Soviet correspondents who are advancing with the Red Army near Warsaw.

PARIS, Sept. 17 -- Before an applauding crowd that filled the Salle Pleyel today, hitherto unknown leaders of the Movement of National Liberation, comprising seven resistance groups, proclaimed the intention of the resistance organizations to continue their activity even though liberation has now been achieved.

After a long absence due to illness, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, pastor of St. Nicholas Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, returned to his pulpit yesterday morning and preached on "Life's Compensations."

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 17 -Army troops of the Eighty-first (Wildcat) Infantry Division landed on Angaur, southernmost of the Palau Islands, on Saturday and joined two beachheads that they established on the north and northeastern shores of the island.

Last week there was a United Press dispatch in your paper regarding King Leopold of the Belgians which rather favored the side of his critics of May, 1940, when he was accused of surrendering without consulting his allies.
LONDON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- A new British armored weapon described as a sort of super-tank was taken off the secret list today with the disclosure it spearheaded the initial D-day landing operations.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- In the whole south of France, notably in the regions around Bordeaux and Poitiers, the underground regime remains side by side with the provisional civil authorities named by Gen. Charles de Gaulle to act for the "Provisional Government," according to information reaching French officials here by messengers sent to Paris by the southern authorities.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 15 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- An 18-year-old Bulgarian Partisan waving a rifle herded Prince Cyril, regent and uncle of the boy King Simeon II, by night to the Government Building to sign papers legalizing the Bulgarian National Front Government of Premier Kimon Georgieff, it can be told today.

The report of the American Cable and Radio Corporation and subsidiaries for the first six months of this year, issued yesterday by John L. Merrill, chairman, shows a consolidated net income after operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $1,264,369, compared with $862,507 in the first half of 1943. Gross revenues were $10,131,369, against $7,984,466.

BUSBACH, Germany, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Sixty-two Nazi party officials lived in this town of 5,000 people, but when the American Army came looking for them today not one of them was left. To a man they had gone east -- and their families with them.

Winthrop W. Aldrich, Chairman of the Board of the Chase National Bank, suggests as a substitute for the plans advanced at the Bretton Woods conference the negotiation of international agreements for the removal of trade barriers and the establishment of a stable dollar-sterling exchange rate.

Max Gordon will offer tonight his first production of the new season, "While the Sun Shines," a comedy by Terence Rattigan, at the Lyceum Theatre. George S. Kaufman has staged the work, an importation from London, where it is now having a successful run at the Globe Theatre.

The New York poultry trade, which for a week has reported an impending importation of 1,000,000 to 2,000,000 pounds of poultry from Argentina, learned yesterday that it had been too conservative in its estimates.

The benefits and advantages offered by the GI Bill of Rights Law appear recently to have influenced many men over 30 who have draft deferment to volunteer for military service, it was revealed yesterday by Col. Arthur V. McDermott, city director of Selective Service.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the Arkansas Power and Light Company's recapitalization plan providing for the issuance of 1,070,000 shares of new $12.50 par value common stock to its parent, the Electric Power and Light Corporation.

When the time for rehabilitation in the war-disrupted Netherlands arrives, a small group of women of Dutch descent who have given up jobs and family ties here to go to the aid of their former countrymen will be among those on hand to assist in the job.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 18 (U.P.) -- A naval battle between German and Finnish warships in which the Finns sank two U-boats off the Aaland islands, blocking the Gulf of Bothnia between Sweden and Finland, was reported tonight.

Speedy relief from "nonsensical control" that was declared to be bringing calamity upon the fur industry was asked yesterday by Sydney H. Murley, president of Lampson, Fraser Huth, largest fur auction company in the world, in an open letter to Price Administrator Chester Bowles.

To the two Canadian teams in the National Hockey League will go the honor of serving as hosts in the opening games of the 1944-45 season, according to the schedule released yesterday. The campaign will get under way on Saturday, Oct. 28, when the world champion Montreal Canadiens will entertain the Boston Bruins and the Toronto Maple Leafs will have the New York Rangers as their guests.

The 157th anniversary of the signing of the Constitution of the United States was observed yesterday at noon with a simple ceremony on the steps of the Sub-treasury Building, Wall and Broad Streets. Two thousand persons attended the celebration, which was held under the auspices of the New York Chapter of the Sons of the American Revolution.

Compared with the reconquest of the Philippines, driving Japan from the Palau Islands may seem to some armchair observers merely a necessary but small preliminary operation. Actually it is an undertaking which will require the full exercise of our amphibious strength.

In the letter by the Rev. Thomas A. Michels, published in your issue of Sept. 15, we are told that in Austria "most of the liberals -- in the European sense of the term -- were not only not opposed to nazism but favored it openly or cryptically."

Delmar S. Harder has resigned as general manager of the Fisher Body fabricating plants, effective at the close of the European phase of the war, it was announced "with regret" yesterday by T.P. Archer, vice president of the General Motors Corporation and general manager of the Fisher Body division.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of $30,000,000 of Brooklyn Union Gas Company general mortgage bonds in a sale marked by extremely close bidding. The group bid 101.10 for the issue as 3 1/2s.

CUSTER made his last stand in the wild and woolly West and that's just about where the Yankees will make theirs. Our battered heroes, heads bloody but unbowed, square off against the Tigers at Detroit today and -- it's painful to have to admit it, mates -- the Yanks seem headed for the same fate which met up with Custer.

The disciples of Freud have reason to rejoice that Columbia's faculty of medicine is to establish a Psychoanalytic and Psychosomatic Clinic -- the first of its kind in this country. For a generation they have been complaining of the medical profession's hostility. The physicians cannot be wholly blamed.
ROME, Sept. 18 (AP) -- An Allied naval task force, including aircraft carriers, has sunk eight enemy ships in the Aegean Sea off Greece, it was announced today.
PARIS, Sept. 18 -- The Quebec conference left a bitter taste in French mouths.

ROME, Sept. 18 -- The plan to create an all-Italian organization to direct and deal with Italy's immense and urgent relief problem took shape today as Premier Ivanoe Bonomi announced the formation of the National Agency for the Distribution of Relief Supplies to Italy.

The third volume of Douglas Southall Freeman's "Lee's Lieutenants," to be published on Oct. 9 by Scribner's, runs 825 pages. It brings to an end Mr. Freeman's history of the Army of Northern Virginia, which he tells in 900,000 words.

LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Germans said last night that one of the war's greatest battles was raging in the forest and lake regions of Latvia and Estonia, with the Russians hurling more than 500,000 men into action in an effort to crush two Nazi Baltic armies on the flank of a Soviet salient pointed at East Prussia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- An independent investigation by Congress of the Pearl Harbor disaster was demanded in the House today by Representative Harness, Republican, of Indiana, and a member of the Military Committee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The Port of New York Authority bid today for a major role in post-war inter-American air traffic by recommending to the Civil Aeronautics Board authorization of nine "basic routes" between New York and various Latin-American points.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 18(AP) -A search for men to work in secrecy on the manufacture of tetraethyl lead at the Deepwater plant of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. is being conducted by the company in cooperation with the War Manpower Commission, State Manpower Director Thomas F. Costello said today.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 -- David Mdivani, former husband of Mae Murray, married bliss Virginia Sinclair, daughter of Harry Sinclair, oil man, at 1 A.M. in Las Vegas, Nev., friends in Beverly Hills learned today. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Frederick Lovett, pastor of the Las Vegas Baptist Church.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- Russian troops, in the first Allied bag of major Axis war criminal suspects, have arrested ten Rumanian and German military and political leaders in Rumania, including former Premier Ion Antonescu and Dr. Karl Clodius, Germany's ace economic expert in the Balkans.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 18 -- New Jersey's copy of the Bill of Rights, one of the ten in existence, has been found again, Sidney Goldmann, State librarian, announced today.
