A large-scale refunding program by the Pacific Gas and Electric Company is expected to augment the amount of securities scheduled to reach the new investment market in the near future. It was reported yesterday that Pacific Gas and Electric is planning to enter into arrangements with Blyth Co., Inc., and associates for the refunding of about $115,000,000 of first mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds due in 1961.

LAUREL, Md., Sept. 18 (AP) -William Helis, New Orleans sportsman, received some interest on his heavy turf investment today when Rick's Raft was an easy winner of the Haste Purse, a test of six furlongs at Laurel.
LONDON, Sept 18 -- Although the general tone of today's stock markets here was firm, business in most sections was quiet.

New professional football leagues are dropping out of the skies like paratroops over Europe these days. The latest is the Trans-America, whose formation was announced yesterday by John F. (Chick) Meehan, former Syracuse, New York University and Manhattan College coach.
The two-year hiatus in New York University football ended yesterday when Coach Jack Weinheimer sent forty candidates through a two-and-one-half-hour drill on Ohio Field.

The National Association of Bedding Manufacturers is planning to revive "National Bedding Week" as early as practicable with the copyrighted slogan "Invest in Rest," through newspaper advertising and publicity and other media, it was said yesterday, in the furniture field.

With one of its biggest opening-day crowds in history -- 32,800 -Belmont Park began the fall racing season yesterday with Ariel Lad capturing the $10 850 High-weight Handicap in a bristling finish. Clocked in 1:08 2/5 for the six furlongs, he was within one-fifth of a second of the track record.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 18 -- Fifteen of the twenty-three members of the April Hudson County grand jury will be cited tomorrow for contempt for ending their term without being dismissed formally by a Common Pleas court judge, it was announced today by Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper, acting county prosecutor.

The sixty-sixth annual United Hospital Campaign for $1,554,931 to cover services rendered free or at less than cost during the last year will be opened at a dinner on Monday in the Hotel Commodore, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- The Republican and Democratic Vice-Presidential candidates, respectively Governor Bricker of Ohio and Senator Truman of Missouri, today carried the appeals of their parties for veterans' votes to the platform of the convention here of the American Legion.

Aachen, better known to most of us as Aix-la-Chapelle, Charlemagne made the northern capital of his empire. His father, Pippin, built a palace there before him. The town owes its splendor to the son. He loved the place. In his time it was the center of a learned and cultivated society.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- The police questioning of Pierre Boni and Henri Lafont, who gained notoriety for their part in the French Gestapo under the Germans, is making the Parisian press bubble with excitement.

An employer-financed social security plan that will cost unionized hotels in the city an estimated $750,000 to $900,000 annually and will provide benefits for 25,000 hotel workers was announced yesterday by Edward P. Mulrooney, impartial chairman of the hotel industry.

The United States Trust Company has sold the five-story tenement building at 47 Clinton Street to a client of Louis Schlessinger, attorney. Assessed at $32,000, the property was sold for cash above a first mortgage of $12,800 held by the Greenwich Savings Bank. P. Zaccaro Company was the broker.

Mrs. Gloria Steinberg, 31 years old, confessed yesterday that she had slain her son, David, 9, with a Boy Scout axe she had bought him recently. She had been driven to kill the boy, she told the police, because he had been uncontrollable and had precipitated frequent bitter clashes between her and her husband.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The Transportation Board of Investigation and Research today recommended in a report to Congress the elimination during the post-war period of several taxes on transportation facilities.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 18 -- The convention of the United Mine Workers assured John L. Lewis today an uncontested election for a four-year term as president by upholding his ruling which eliminated Ray Edmundson of Springfield, Ill., his only opponent, from the ballot.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- With Soviet consent the supplying of arms and food to the beleaguered underground garrison of Warsaw was stepped up considerably today when United States Eighth Air Force heavy bombers from Britain started a shuttle delivery service to the Polish patriots in the city.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Furniture makers have asked the War Production Board to ease its restrictions on models and patterns to enable their plants to maintain a higher level of employment during the period of reconversion to peacetime output, it was announced today.

Urging New Yorkers to "give once for all," the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office opened yesterday its New York War Fund campaign at the Pershing Square Information Center with a half-hour program in behalf of the peoples of China, France, Belgium and the Netherlands.

MONTREAL, Sept. 18 -- As the Council of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration voted today to consider an expansion of its operations by extending aid to Italy, Director General Herbert H. Lehman warned that relief might have to be contracted because of delay by member Governments in contributing to the fund.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Japanese forces were advancing tonight toward Kweilin, key city of Kwangsi Province, in a campaign that threatens to split China in two and wreck the entire American military set-up in the country.

William E. Russell, general chairman of the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee, declared yesterday that the increase in rents in Government developments "goes far beyond the moderate increase" which is requested by his committee.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Jerome A. Gottschalk, research engineer, today told 200 foremen and management officials attending the Western plant management conference of the National Metal Trades Association at Genoa City, Wis., that every concern and every industry must establish sound practices and procedures for the employment of returning veterans and other workers.

The Pantepec Oil Company of Venezuela, C.A., reported yesterday for the six months ended with June, a net profit of $509,250 in contrast to the net loss of $122,965 sustained in the first half of last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -The Senate Foreign Relations Committee delayed action today on a resolution calling upon the United States to take the lead in urging untrammeled international exchange of independent news as a means of promoting world peace.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, announced tonight that Gen. Douglas MacArthur will command the campaign to reconquer the Philippines, in a message sent here to the national convention of the American Legion.

BOSTON, Sept. 18 -- Back in the National League cellar, a spot with which they aren't unfamiliar, the Dodgers headed home tonight to wind up their campaign with thirteen games against the strength of the West.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The House this afternoon accepted as final the report submitted by its conferees on the complex legislation for disposal of surplus war materials, which had been under debate with a Senate group for the past three weeks.

PELELIU ISLAND, Palau, Sept. 16 (Delayed) -- The young hospital corpsman who came alongside yesterday afternoon with his gruesome cargo has gone. He fell exhausted into a sick-bay bunk and after a long sleep returned to his outfit.

WITH UNITED STATES MARINES, on Peleliu Island, Palau, Sept. 17 (Delayed) (Via Navy Radio) (AP) -One marine tank [destroyed eight Japanese tanks in/ thirty minutes of fighting today in a battle that apparently has destroyed the remainder of Japanese armor on Peleliu.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Tuesday, Sept 19 (U.P.) -- Carrier-based planes of the Southwest Pacific Command attacked Halmahera Island airdromes for the first time Saturday, intensifying the offensive to neutralize the bases and prevent any attacks on United States positions on Morotai Island, it was announced today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, Sept 19 -- Hard-hitting armored forces of the British Second Army joined Allied airborne battalions in the Netherlands yesterday and the combined forces stormed north across the great Netherland water barriers, threatening Amsterdam and Rotterdam on the west and the northern end of the Siegfried Line on the east.

Manpower shortages and priorities on Government orders for the armed forces, rather than the deliberate stock-piling of unprocessed wool, have caused temporary shortages of woolen garments for the public, representatives of local wool manufacturing companies declared yesterday, challenging a statement made recently by Governor Dewey.

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 18 -- New enemy counter-attacks have been repulsed on Peleliu and Angaur Islands in the Palau group and the American forces have made good gains in both places, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz's communique said today.

GOETEBORG, Sweden, Sept. 18 -- News of Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain and Pierre Laval and members of his Vichy Cabinet from Germany was brought here today by Argentine diplomats on their way home from the Reich.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Fat Freddy Fitzsimmons again will manage the Phillies in 1945, General Manager Herb Pennock announced today. Fitz already has signed his contract.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull gave assurances today that the names of Adolf Hitler and his arch-crimi nal associates would be found on the list of those marked for punishment by the United Nations War Crimes Commission.
LONDON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Marquess of Hartington, husband of the former Kathleen Kennedy, daughter of former United States Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy, was killed in action in France Sept. 10.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Sept. 18 -- Bert Edwards of Rockville took the honors in the Long Island P.G.A. amateur-pro tourney on the Rockville links today. He posted a 66 with Wiffy Cox, Hempstead pro, and duplicated this score with Willie Klein of Wheatley Hills to lead the field.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission.

ABOARD A CARRIER FLAGSHIP, off Mindanao, Sept. 17 (Delayed) (Via Navy Radio) (UP) -- Admiral William F. Halsey, leader of the Third Fleet and commander of the Palau invasion and accompanying air blows against the Philippines, said today that more trouble was in store for the Japanese and that he would like to go to Yokohama among other places.

Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican national chairman, predicted yesterday afternoon that there would be a definite labor swing to Governor Dewey as a result of last night's speech on labor problems in Seattle. He also warned that the New Deal had set the stage for some new gesture to labor before election day.

Prompted by the fact that thousands of tons of green tomatoes go unused each year, the Michigan State Experiment Station has been exploring the possibilities for preventing such wastage. It has found out that the tomatoes can be pickled in a variety of ways, as one would cucumbers; in fact, they can even pinch hit for that vegetable when it is scarce.

While scanning a photographic display at the entrance to The Associated Press Building at 50 Rockefeller Plaza, Thomas Hughes, night photo editor of the wire service, was mugged and badly beaten at 11 o'clock last night by three men who fled with his wallet containing $8 and valuable papers.

Stockholders of the Tubize Rayon Corporation will be asked to vote, at a special meeting on Oct. 20, on the creation of a new issue of preferred stock in an authorized amount of $10,000,000, of which $7,000,000 initially will be sold and outstanding, the company announced last night.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 18 (UP) -- Communique 163:

WASHINGTON, Sept 18 (U.P.) -- Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau was accused today by Robert E. Stripling, chief investigator of the Dies committee, of impeding the committee's inquiries into the income sources of organizations which the group looks on as Communist, Nazi or Fascist.
PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, Sept. 18 -Members of the American Legion and of the radio audience:

The extermination of the Nazi regime has begun. An Allied proclamation broadcast to the German people has announced that General Eisenhower, as supreme commander and military governor, has assumed executive, legislative and judicial authority in occupied Germany and has established an Allied Military Government whose principal task, next to guarding the security of the Allied armies, will be the destruction of National Socialism.

The statistics concerning the starving population of Italy, as published in THE NEW YORK TIMES Sept. 5, are heartrending. One person out of two is tuberculous; one baby out of two is dying. It does not require much knowledge of arithmetic to understand these figures; it does not need much heart to feel compassion and a desire to help.

A banking syndicate headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co. received yesterday the award of $54,750,000 refunding mortgage 3 per cent bonds, Series A, of the Oregon-Washington Railroad and Navigation Company on a bid of 102.098.
The American Red Cross issued the following statement here yesterday:

Representatives of eleven New York and New Jersey counties will confer in New York on Sept. 22 under the auspices of the Regional Plan Association and with the cooperation of the Port of New York Authority to plan for airports in the metropolitan area after the war, the Regional Plan Association announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 18 -- Lynn Bari has been chosen by Twentieth Century-Fox for the second lead in the forthcoming comedy "Bon Voyage." She will have the part previously chosen for Anne Baxter, who, instead, starts tomorrow in the Tallulah Bank-head picture "Czarina."
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in English to North America from Chungking and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- Wildly enthusiastic men, women and girls of a Netherland frontier village -- loath to part with their liberators -- escorted troops of the American First Army across the border into Germany holding umbrellas over their heads to protect the soldiers from the drizzling rain, according to a Reuter correspondent.

Faced with the threat of a clash over labor's no-strike pledge, delegates to the ninth annual convention of the United Rubber Workers of America, Congress of Industrial Organizations, heard Philip Murray, CIO president, deliver yesterday a strong defense of Sidney Hillman, chairman of the CIO's Political Action Committee, and denounce critics of the PAC as "evil men" bent on spreading "diabolical lies."

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 18 -- The County Supervisors here today authorized the County Board of Assessors to propose a compromise with representatives of the J.P. Morgan estate at East Island so that the assessed valuation of the property now reportedly owned by Philip Publiker will be reduced from $727,940 to $465,000.

With designs in furniture drastically limited under a War Production Board order dating back to early 1943, designers of furniture for post-war production have been guarding their sketches under lock and key. The few clues to future trends in furniture design come from custom-made pieces appearing now and then in exhibits.

Senator Elmer Thomas, Democrat of Oklahoma, estimated yesterday at a visit to Democratic national headquarters here that the United States would need a military establishment of three to four million men immediately after the war and that it would continue to need at least 2,000,000 in service for "five, eight or ten years" after victory.
LONDON, Sept. 18 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden returned to London today from the Quebec conference and gave the War Cabinet a detailed report of the conclusions reached there.

Reversing the usual order of things, the showing at the St. Regis yesterday at the luncheon hour began with a bridal procession. It was unconventional in more ways than one, for the designer, Helene Lyolene, elected to use her favorite blouse and skirt theme for bride and bridesmaids.

WITH AMERICAN THIRD ARMY on the Moselle River, Sept. 18 (U.P.) -- A group of American infantrymen lay hopelessly trapped in the thick woods west of Metz, with the nearest German machinegun nest twenty-five yards away. Some of their number had been killed; their wounded lay beside them.

Rosh ha-Shanah services were attended by hundreds of thousands of Jews in the temples and synagogues of the metropolitan area yesterday, the second day of the observance of the opening of the year 5705 of the Hebrew calendar. Orthodox Jews will continue their observance until this evening. Reform congregations closeed theirs last night.
Following is the text of Governor Dewey's address in Seattle, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

With their home schedule completed, the Yankees last night pointed their noses toward the West, where during the next fortnight the American League's spectacular pennant race will be fought to a decision.

Pointing to the withdrawal of seven medium-size and smaller tobacco manufacturers from business because of inability to cope with rising leaf-tobacco prices while the Office of Price Administration maintained rigid ceilings on cigarettes and other tobacco products, a newly formed association of small tobacco manufacturers called yesterday for a prompt adjustment of OPA policies.

ROME, Sept. 18 -- Canadian and Greek troops of the British Eighth Army were pressing toward Rimini today in the face of fierce resistance that showed no signs of diminishing, while American planes dropped bombs on the enemy not more than 500 yards ahead of them.

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today the appointment of Maj. Gen. Francis P. Mulcahy, former commander of Marine Fleet Aircraft on the West Coast, as commanding general of Marine Aircraft of the Fleet.

Cash and United States Government securities held by eighty-six members of the National Association of Investment Companies on June 30 amounted to $124,000,000, representing 9.5 per cent of combined total assets of $1,298,000,000 on that date, compared with $101,600,000 cash and Government bonds on Dec. 31, the association announced yesterday.

The Thunderbolt, Army fighter plane made by Republic Aviation at Farmingdale, L.I., is about to enter its third phase oil battle usefulness with the production of a long-range model for use against the Japanese, the company announced yesterday in its house organ, Republic Aviation News.

Federal assistance for the city's post-war construction program would be "completely justified," Mayor La Guardia declared in his 1945 capital budget message to the City Planning Commission, made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The pinacle of Government employment, except in the State Department, has usually meant a chief clerkship at the end of active service and then retirement on meager pay. In normal times these limitations have prevented innumerable men and women of appropriate ability from making a career of Government service.

MOSCOW, Sept. 18 -- Soviet support for the Polish Committee of National Liberation's claims to German-held Silesia, East Prussia and Pomerania was reiterated today in a War and the Working Class editorial. It said that the territory must be taken from Germany to weaken her and thereby to increase the future security of Poland, Czechoslovakia, the Balkans, France and the Soviet Union -- in fact all Europe.

The transition from war to peace will be a time of sharp dislocations and hurried reorganization. Great as will be the rejoicing over victory and high as will be the hope of building a better world, millions of Americans will face grave uncertainties. So also in still greater degree will the peoples of other countries, whatever their present relation to the war.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 18 -- Appointment of Jose Echaniz, Spanish-American pianist, to the faculty of the Eastman School of Music was announced today by Dr. Howard Hanson, director of the school. Mr. Echaniz will take up his new duties here next week.
By coincidence I read this evening two items which fit together like the parts of a puzzle. The first comes on Page 242 of Hallett Abend's excellent new book, "Treaty Ports." I quote:
A.G. Chaffer, formerly assistant manager of the General Electric Company's South Lowell works, has been appointed sales manager of the household refrigerator division.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 18 -- Until the Allies set up an administration in Berlin representing the United States, Britain and Russia, the Allied Military Government under Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will operate in the areas occupied by the Anglo-American armies and will make the destruction of national socialism its chief objective, it was announced tonight.

ROME, Sept. 18 -- The former vice director of the Regina Coeli prison, Donato Carretta, was killed by a wild mob of 7,000 Romans today in a most vicious and brutal fashion while 200 Carabinieri and other Italian police looked on without lifting a finger.
ROME, Sept. 18 (AP) -- A communique:

The sumptuousness of the season's fashions was displayed at Altman's yesterday afternoon in seven tableaux presented in the Charleston Gardens. The creations of the designers emphasized color brilliance, jeweled richness and furred luxury.
MONTREAL, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Director General Herbert H. Lehman gave to the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation conference today his summation of the basic needs of war-wrecked countries.

Sept. 18, 1931, is an important date in contemporary world history. On that evening Japanese Army troops masquerading as guards of the South Manchuria Railway attacked the Chinese Army barracks and Chinese Government buildings in Mukden. In two days they had seized control of two of the three eastern provinces of China.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- A proposal for a food allotment plan to get some 2,100,000 tons of war-accumulated surpluses into the homes of low income groups was revived in Congress today.

The Ballet Theatre has announced the complete schedule of its forthcoming season at the Metropolitan Opera House from Oct. 8 through Nov. 5. At the same time, the newly organized Ballet International Incorporated has made official the date of its opening at the International Theatre (formerly the Park) at Columbia Circle as Oct. 30.

SOFIA, Sept. 17 (Delayed) (Reuter) -- The Bulgarian Government has reached a provisional agreement with the local Greek authorities in Thrace by which the Greeks will carry on the local administration throughout the area and Bulgarian troops will remain to safeguard the territory.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Tuesday, Sept. 19 (AP) -- A communique:

Comdr. Abram Weiss of the United States Navy has sold the building formerly occupied by him as doctor's offices, at 2302 Palisade Avenue, Weehawken Heights, N.J., to Charles Scheuerle. Commander Weiss, who spent days on a raft after his ship was torpedoed, is now stationed in Florida.
LONDON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- A broadcast cast communique from the Polish Patriots in Warsaw:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Conflicting views on the Government's role in dealing with post-war health were heard today when representatives of medicine, labor and industry began their testimony before the Senate's subcommittee on war-time health and education which opened a second three-day session here today.

The city of Minneapolis, Minn., will be in the market on Oct. 3 with two new issues aggregating $2,260,000. The financing will consist of $1,960,000 of refunding bonds, for which bidders are to name a rate of interest not exceeding 5 per cent, and $300,000 of public relief bonds, not exceeding 6 per cent.
HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 19 -- in a two-hour sitting today the Finnish Parliament was informed of Moscow's peace terms.

SEATTLE, Sept. 18 -- Thomas E. Dewey laid the blame for labor troubles during wartime at the door of his White House opponent, in a major address delivered here tonight and broadcast by radio all over the country.

WITH UNITED STATES NINTH AIR FORCE, France, Sept. 18 (Reuter) -- American fighter-bombers equipped with rockets that are in action in western Europe are using a new type of missile that offers the great advantage of a high ratio of fire control for the pilot.

In one of the most listless sessions of this year, activity in the stock market was centered yesterday almost entirely in the aircraft section. Trading was almost at a standstill on several occasions and volume on the Stock Exchange dwindled to the lightest in more than four months with transfers at 344,855 shares, compared with 642,280 shares n Friday.

"The Impatient Years," a Columbia comedy-romance starring Jean Arthur, Lee Bowman and Charles Coburn, will open this morning at Loew's Criterion. The story is about a returned soldier and his bride, whom he had known only four days when he was shipped overseas for eighteen months.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 17 -- Under the same blanket of air cover that made the first phase of the operation an unqualified success hundreds of United States Eighth Air Force bombers and First Allied Airborne Army gliders poured reinforcements, ammunition and heavy equipment into the Netherlands today.
LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Heavy Bombers of the Royal Air Force attacked the German North Sea port of Bremerhaven last night, the British Air Ministry announced today.

The peak of the 1944 epidemic of infantile paralysis for the nation as a whole apparently has been passed and the incidence of the disease is now tapering off, according to the latest reports received by the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, Basil O'Connor, its president, declared yesterday.

Corwin A. Fergus, formerly deputy general manager of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, becomes vice president on Oct. 1 of the Institutional Securities Corporation, a real estate and mortgage investment corporation wholly owned by the savings banks of New York State.

Pushing its campaign to end irregularities in the retail coal business in New York City, the Solid Fuels Administration for War announced yesterday that it had compelled eleven unequipped and two equipped dealers to remove from householders' cellars 204 tons of anthracite coal delivered in excess of the 50 per cent rule.
CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Following is the text of Gen. George C. Marshall's address to the American Legion:

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 18 -- Artemus L. Gates, Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Air, witnessed the war's first naval air attack on the Philippines from the deck of a carrier that steamed for three days within sight of Mindanao, he revealed here today.

Designation by the National Housing Agency of New York City as a critical housing shortage area, thereby permitting the remodeling and conversion of existing structures here, was hailed yesterday by realty men as a move which will contribute considerably to easing the acute housing situation, particularly in small apartments.

Price legislation issued during the occupation of the Netherlands by the Germans is to be maintained "for the time being" and the prices of services and movable property "must remain as they were on Sept. 4," the Netherlands military government told inhabitants of the Netherlands yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Veterans in Walter Reed General Hospital, who are fighting for a return to normal civilian life after losing an arm or a leg in combat overseas, have two simple "dont's" for people who meet them on the street.

ON THE MOROTAI BEACHHEAD, Sept. 19 -- Naval planes and patrol boats fought a dramatic battle deep in enemy waters for the life of one of our pilots shot down at sea and finally won it with less than a minute to spare.

On the basis of a report now being prepared by the Foreign Economic Administration, Belgium is expected to be the first liberated country to resume foreign trade through private channels, officials of the agency stated yesterday. The report is being prepared under the direction of M.S. Szymczak, member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, who headed a commission to study Belgian problems with the Belgian Government in London.

A full four days after the hurricane New York City authorities estimated last night that it would be three weeks before streets were cleared of fallen trees, essential repairs to city property completed and normal city routine restored.

Prospects for a higher lending rate on raw cotton and political pressure to lift cotton prices accelerated short-covering yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. This with some outside buying, led the futures market to close 2 points lower to 9 points higher than on Saturday on active months.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- The existence of a Polish underground army in France, 20,000 strong, was disclosed today by its leader, Alexander Kowalkowski, who has come into the open after having worked secretly in France during the occupation.

How many men has General Eisenhower already in the field against Germany, or stored away in that capacious manpower bag from which every little while he draws forth one more Allied army? Now it is the famous American Third, and then the American Seventh, and then the British Second, and then the Canadian First, and then the American First and the American Ninth, and, up to the moment of writing, the First Allied Air Army.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP) -- From undergraduate days at Yale, Clifford Webster Barnes employed his two hands unstintingly in the busii ness of practical philanthropy-and often expressed the wish that he "had seven more" to use in his manifold tasks.

The United Press carried on Sept. 13 a London dispatch that quoted the Moscow radio as having said that a Slovak National Council had been formed in Russia to carry on the government of freed Slovak territory until a legal government could be established by a democratic election.

WITH AMERICAN AIR-BORNE FORCES IN HOLLAND, Sept. 18 -- The air-borne troops of Lieut. Gen. Lewis H. Brereton's sky train army made contact with a British armored patrol in the Netherlands today, some twenty-four hours after their landing in this canal-laced country behind the German lines.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The War Production Board set aside today a reserve of 37,000 tons of steel and proportionate quantities of other materials, which will be drawn upon during the fourth quarter of this year for the manufacture of seventeen groups of critically needed civilian articles, from alarm clocks to mechanical refrigerators.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- The French Academy, whose four vacancies it may fill at its October meeting, has informally asked Gen. Charles de Gaulle if he will permit his name to be proposed as one of the forty "immortals."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -A recommendation that the Commodity Credit Corporation announce its intention to take over all 1944 cotton still in the hands of producers on next Aug. 1 at full parity price was made today to Fred M. Vinson, Economic Stabilization Director, by Southern Senators, represented by Senator Bankhead of Alabama.

Jaeckel's, known for its furs, has made the entire street floor of the shop at 8-10 East Fifty-seventh Street into a new ready-to-wear department. In air-conditioned surroundings, customers will find an extensive selection of dresses, suits, coats, sportswear and accessories.

Congratulations from Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower on the "speed and brilliance" with which French troops broke German resistance at Toulon and Marseille were made public yesterday in an order of the day issued by Maj. Gen. Jean de Lattre de Tassigny, commander of the French Army in the south.

Your editorial in THE TIMES of Sept. 14 helped to clarify the status of Federal employes with relation to social security payments on their separation from their positions during the demobilization period, which is one of the major controversies in the pending demobilization and reconversion measure now before the Congress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The House refused today to approve Senate proposals to pay travel costs back home for migratory war workers and provide unemployment compensation for about 3,100,000 Federal workers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull hailed the invasion of the Netherlands today and praised the Netherlanders for their fortitude during their four years of fighting and confident waiting for liberation.

Operating revenues of eighty-six Class I roads in August are estimated at $665,343,151, or 2.3 per cent more than the $650,600,932 for August, 1943, according to the Association of American Railroads. This estimate, it was pointed out, does not touch upon trends in the operating expenses, taxes or final income results.

The Federal Housing Administration anticipates a "very tremendous volume" of applications for building conversions under the new ruling which eases the restrictions on structural changes. None of the applications has yet been received, and the officials do not expect them before the end of the week.

Gustav Augstein has purchased the twelve-family apartment house at 2167 East 177th Street, the Bronx, from Vincent Ambrosino. The property is assessed at $28,000 and is situated on a plot 52 by 103 feet. P.C. D'Onofrio Company was the broker in the transaction.

One long-established Childs restaurant in the Times Square area will have to depart, while another will be permitted to remain, according to rulings handed down yesterday by Federal Judge Edward A. Conger. The one just west of the Times Tower on Seventh Avenue between Forty-second and Forty-third Streets is to remain.
LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Calling for the election of Thomas E. Dewey as President, Gov. Leverett Saltonstall of Massachusetts declared here yesterday that the only issue of the campaign was that of providing jobs in private enterprise for all those able to work.

One of the greatest threats to a successful development of postwar export markets will be the adoption of a policy by manufacturers of satisfying fully domestic needs during the reconversion period without setting up immediate quotas for export shipments, W.C. White, vice president of the Alcoa Steamship Company, told a meeting of the Sales Executive Club yesterday in the Hotel Roosevelt.
ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Forward passing from any point behind the scrimmage line will be permitted in seven of Cornell University's nine football games this fall.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 19 -- John L. Lewis and the convention of the United Mine Workers ignored today a Government appeal for a no-strike pledge for the duration of the war and castigated a group of Government officials and the Roosevelt Administration for a "rotten deal" to the Clerical, Technical and Supervisory Employes Union, an affiliate of the miners' organization.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Taking the lead at the start, H.H. Hagag's Ball Player today won the $2,500 Lake Pearl Purse by three lengths at Narragansett Park.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Communique 164:

If the American proponents of a world security organization do not find some way by which their plan would preserve the constitutional power of Congress in respect to the use of American armed forces in any specific case, we are likely to find ourselves in an impasse which would spell disaster to the one enterprise which offers hope for the maintenance of future peace.

LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Acting Prime Minister Ernst von Born, broadcasting the terms of the armistice signed with Great Britain and Russia today, called this "one of the hardest days in our history" and questioned whether the nation could survive.

A contribution of $25,000 for the establishment of a trust providing for two annual awards of $500 each to the best supporting male and female performers of the season has been made by Clarence Derwent, veteran actor, director and producer, to Actors Equity Association, which has accepted administration of the fund.

HELSINKI, Sept. 19 -- From the lips of Acting Premier Ernst von Born, Finns tonight heard the worst -- or nearly so -- for the Finnish Cabinet Minister, in a late evening broadcast breaking the news to his countrymen, dwelt only on the highlights of the twenty-three-point Russo-Finnish armistice signed in Moscow today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A majority and a minority report, by Democratic and Republican members, respectively, of a House investigating committee, declared today in the first case that President Roosevelt had only performed "his duty" when he ordered seizure of montgomery Ward's Chicago mall-order house last April, whereas the dissenting opinion asserted that the action was unconstitutional and a "pattern for complete dictatorship."

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 967, which compared with 1,786 in the preceding week and 1,350 in the similar period of last year, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Ernie Pyle's invasion book, "Brave Men," has been named the December selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club. Holt will publish the book on Nov. 20. The Book-of-the-Month Club has also named Glenway Wescott's new novel, "The Children of Wrath," as a reserve selection.

OHAIN, Belgium, Sept. 19 -- There are some people who think that a country cannot keep a secret, but here is a whole sprawling farm community that kept one from the Germans for more than four years. Living in its midst is the secret, a Jewish family that it was hiding.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 (AP) -- City Solicitors of Cincinnati, Ohio, and Covington, Ky., appeared today at a hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission and made known the interest of those cities in acquiring two subsidiaries of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation which the commission may order the company to dispose of.

To persuade the public to buy at least twice as much goods as it did before the war in order to provide jobs for the larger working force that will be available is the post-war challenge to advertising, William J. Moll, an executive of Geyer, Cornell Newell, Inc., told a meeting yesterday of the Advertising Club of Washington, D. C.

MONTREAL, Sept. 19 -- The council of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration received official assurances today that the military authorities will turn over European relief to the UNRRA as soon as possible when military considerations permit, and that adequate supplies of food, cotton and wool for clothing, and resources for rehabilitating the agriculture and industry of the liberated countries will be available.
ELKHART, Ind., Sept. 19 (AP) -- The sheer drama of an airman's last days adrift in the Pacific on a life raft.

A bid to arrange for the movement into world markets through regular channels of the cotton trade the stocks of the staple purchased in recent years by the United States Government will be submitted to cotton merchants from all over the South by John Scatterty, president of the New York Cotton Exchange and a committee of its members at a meeting to be held in the Peabody Hotel in Memphis, Tenn., on Friday.
ROME, Sept. 19 -- The Italian Government will make its second attempt to try the former police chief of Rome, Pietro Caruso, tomorrow morning.

No clearer, more realistic appraisal has been made of what already has been done in the Pacific and what remains to be done before Japan is brought to unconditional surrender than that by Admiral Nimitz in his radio address from Pearl Harbor to the American Legion convention in Chicago.

THE referees in the National Football League are business-like gents who zealously enforce every rule in unsmiling fashion. However, being competent is not enough, it seems. Stout Steve Owen, for one, prefers the less predictable mental maneuvers of operatives like Jim Durfee and Tom Thorp, who tooted whistles back in the old days when the professionals were struggling, to get a foothold in public esteem.

In his attack on the Administration's labor policy Governor Dewey was effective and fully justified in one charge. This was that the Administration has smothered labor relations under a welter of "more than twenty-five Federal agencies pulling in opposite directions." This charge he documented by some telling illustrations.

WOOD-RIDGE, N. J., Sept. 19 -- More than 40,000 Wright Cyclone engines to power the B-29 Boeing Superfortress within the next fifteen months were called for today from the Wright factory here by Col. J. M. Gillespie, Deputy Chief of Engineering and Procurement of the Air Technical Service Command, Dayton.
Following is the text of Governor Dewey's speech in Portland, Ore., as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sex knocked Jess Flores out of the box with a pair of three-run innings in mid-game tonight and defeated the Athletics, 6 to 3. Johnny Humphries went a nine-hit route for his seventh victory.

At a moment when the Battle of the Rhine is developing into a decisive engagement for the conquest of Germany and when Russian forces are converging upon the Polish and Latvian capitals, Finland has decided to sign an armistice with Russia and Great Britain and to wage an undeclared war against the retreating German troops.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 19 (AP) -- A report from Haelsingborg, on the Swedish coast across from Denmark, said Danish constabulary fought today in defense of the royal palace and killed at least fourteen Nazis, but were subdued by light artillery. The Danes were forced to surrender, this report said, and a number of Danish police officers fled to Sweden.

LIDO BEACH, L.I., Sept. 19 -- A 500-foot strip of beach between here and Point Lookout was transformed into a tiny Pacific island today and quickly became "American-held" territory as 1,500 sailors "wrested" the land from its sixty-five "Japanese" defenders in invasion maneuvers that concluded a three-month course of training for future amphibious blows against Japan's dwindling island empire.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Wednesday, Sept. 20 -- The Japanese again unsuccessfully attempted to attack newly won American positions on Morotai in the Halmaheras at dawn Sunday, two enemy planes trying to swoop down on our shipping, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's communique said today.

In an appeal to President Roosevelt twenty-six leading citizens of Harlem urged yesterday that he request the War Department to abandon its plan for segregating battle-weary Negro troops returning home for rest under the rotation furlough system.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The United States accorded full recognition of the independence of Syria and Lebanon today through the appointment by President Roosevelt of George Wadsworth of New York as Minister to the two republics.
LONDON, Wednesday, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Air-raid sirent howled in London again during the night as the Germans struck at southern England with their flying bombs for the third successive night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Plans were being circulated in United States and British war production quarters today calling for the reconstitution of the Combined Production and Resources Board into an agency for determining policy the reconversion of industry to on peacetime production at the end of the European war.
A communique, as broadcast in English from Sofia yesterday and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
Mrs. Henry Drummond-Wolff and her daughter. Miss Carolyn L. Holcombe, have arrived from Newport and are at the Savoy-Plaza.

While public and private agencies were still laboring to clear away the wreckage and debris left behind by last Thursday's hurricane, a report spread in the metropolitan area yesterday that another big blow was on its way, but the report was scotched almost as quickly as it started by prompt action of the Weather Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- President Roosevelt directed Secretary Ickes to take over nine more bituminous coal mines today. This raises to seventy-three the number of soft-coal pits that have been seized by the Federal Government since the beginning of the dispute over bargaining rights for supervisory employes who have been organized by the United Mine Workers of America.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- A specially selected group of Royal Air Force Lancasters attacked the battleship Tirpitz with six-ton bombs as she rode at anchor in a remote Norwegian hide-out shortly after noon last Friday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 19 --Lieut. Gen. Kurt Dittmar, radio spokesman for the German High Command, declared in a broadcast tonight that "the fronts have moved close to the boundaries of the Reich and the result is apparent in the race now being run between the Anglo-Americans on the offensive and the Germans with their counter-measures, upon the outcome of which everything now depends."

ROME, Sept. 19 -- All Rome buzzes with shocked, frightened comment on the outburst of mob violence yesterday which resulted in the gruesome murder in the Tiber of Donato Carretta, Fascist vice director of the Regina Coeli prison and chief state witness in the trial of Pietro Caruso.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Wednesday, Sept. 20 (AP) -- A communique:

PELELIU ISLAND, Palau, Sept. 19 -- Against determined mortar and gun fire, indomitable Marine division are pushing slowly up the slopes of Peleliu's "pillbox range" this afternoon to establish positions that will give them the first high ground on which to set some of our large supply of artillery.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board declared today that after the war people must buy more consumer goods and services than they ever did if the United States were to maintain a stable economy.

An award of a $1,000 war bond to be made by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company to the real estate broker or salesman responsible for the most original or ingenious transaction of definite benefit to some section of New York City during 1944 was announced yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the Real Estate Board of New York in the Hotel Commodore.

A.N. Williams, president of the Western Union Telegraph Company, announced yesterday that the company had deferred its proposed $25,000,000 refunding program because of the question of jurisdiction raised last week by the New York State Public Service Commission over the issuance of Western Union securities.

PARIS, Sept. 19 -- The Commission for Education asked the National Council of Resistance today to study the question of the transition from Vichy's education laws to the republican system and to propose to the Government the policy to be followed.
The 1944 campaign of the New York War Fund to finance thirty-one war-supporting agencies will begin officially tonight at a dinner in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WHICH is the true socialism, a hare-brained community of eccentric idealists at a Brook Farm or a leviathan state with a regimented industry, a huge army and a secret police? Who is the more representative Socialist, a kindly gentleman like Norman Thomas or the iron ruler of all the Russias? What is the real meaning of such well-worn phrases as production for use and economic planning for the general welfare?

A study of practical nurse placement registries in the State preliminary to setting up a model registry here was approved yesterday by the Committee for the Recruitment and Education of Practical Nurses at its initial fall meeting at 250 West Fifty-seventh Street.
A communique from headquarters of Marshal Tito as broadcast in Serbo-Croat by the Free Yugoslav radio yesterday and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Four New Yorkers, members of the armed guard aboard the ammunition ship El Coston when she was sunk in collision with a tanker in a convoy last February, received commendations for "conspicuous courage and devotion to duty" from Vice Admiral Randall Jacobs, chief of naval personnel, it was announced here yesterday.

For many years a quiet investor in numerous theatrical undertakings, Marcus Heiman announces now that he will assume the mantle of a Broadway producer early this season with the presentation of Channing Pollock's new play, "Tangled Web."

An investment banking group headed by Shields Co. will offer today to the public a new issue of $10,500,000 of first and refunding mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds, series D, of the Gulf, Mobile Ohio Railroad Company. The bonds, dated Oct. 1, 1944, and due Oct. 1, 1969, are to be priced at 98 3/4.

In a move which exporters stated "showed close adherence to the Foreign Economic Administration's policy of relaxing trade controls," the Belgian Congo Purchasing Mission yesterday notified traders of a sweeping elimination of controls over shipments to that market.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Navy communique 543:

Paramount's "The Frenchman's Creek," a romantic adventure filmed in Technicolor and starring Joan Fontaine and Arturo de Cordova, will have its premiere this morning at the Rivoli. An adaptation of the the novel by Daphne du Maurier, the picture, which is set in the seventeenth century, was directed by Mitchell Leisen and includes Basil Rathbone, Nigel Bruce.
ROME, Sept. 19 (AP) -- A communique:

TORONTO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Behind the effective four-hit pitching of 17-year-old Don Johnson, the Newark Bears tonight advanced to the final round of the International League play-offs by defeating the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3-2.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Federal investigations took a turn toward setting a course on post-war health problems toward State aid experiments as leading health experts continued their testimony today before the Senate's subcommittee on wartime health and education.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Tentative offers to purchase the M.W. Kellogg Company of New York, a $23,000,000 privately owned industrial engineering and contracting concern, have been made by the Pullman-Standard Car Manufacturing Company it was reported today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- Utilization of Westchester County's Crugers Point Park, a 251-acre tract along the Hudson River south of Peekskill, as a site for a $1,000,000 war veterans' hostal would receive "favorable consideration" from the county if the Federal Government paid at least $125,000 for the land, County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach said today.

What makes a "bad" child? A "good" child? What does one do about "discipline," when children tell lies, when they ask about sex -- or when they never ask? These questions are discussed in a new manual issued by the Child Study Association of America, Inc., 221 West Fifty-seventh Street, in cooperation with the American Association of University Women.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 19 -- RKO-Radio has borrowed Robert Young from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to star with Dorothy McGuire and Herbert Marshall in the screen remake of Sir Arthur Wing Pinero's play "The Enchanted Cottage." He goes into the part from which Alan Marshall withdrew because of illness. Production will begin in two weeks.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 19 -- Gov. John W. Bricker said here tonight that a Republican victory in November would assure a post-war America in which creative genius would be rewarded and the inventive ability of the people would be used to produce work and "the security of productive jobs."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today amendments to the reorganization plan of the Southern Union Gas Company, a former holding company now operating as a gas utility in western Texas and New Mexico.

The appeal for living quarters for Navy men stationed in and around New York City has brought a fine response in rooms but there is still a great need for apartments, Mrs. Mark Hollander, in charge of the Housing Bureau of the New York City Women's Council of the Navy League, declared yesterday.

Magistrate Jenkin R. Hockert in Flushing Court at three intervals yesterday morning called the names of Joseph and Anna Volpe, principals in a domestic disagreement. Finally, at 1 o'clock he declared the case "dismissed for nonappearance of either party," unaware that Joseph, 69 years old and father of seven children, had slain his 58-year-old wife with a pistol a few hours earlier and then attempted to take his own life.
PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 19 -- Governor Dewey's Presidential campaign special was wrecked at Castle Rock, Wash., sixty miles north of here, at 11:45 this morning, Pacific Coast time.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 19 -- A plan for further reducing the mortgage debt of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad Company and for eliminating its 1947 maturity was approved here today by the board of directors of the company.

Last-minute efforts to scrape the German manpower barrel and raise forces sufficient to halt the Allied drive onto German "holy soil" are doomed to defeat, a study of the German press and recent underground reports reveal.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- A majority of employed women are willing and many are eager to return to their homes after the war, Mrs. O.H. Hahn of Omaha today told the American Legion Auxiliary, holding its annual convention here.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 19 -- No man is indispensable to America or to the world. Governor Dewey declared tonight in a direct challenge to the Democratic stand that President Roosevelt must be reelected to a fourth term.

No insurances concerning the termination of the war or its date are being issued at Lloyd's, the large British insurance organization, O.D. Duncan, general counsel for Lloyd's in the United States, announced yesterday in reply to reports that such insurance on the end of the war in Europe was being written.

One of the most popular dishes in southern Italy, especially in the vicinity of Naples, is pizza -- a pie made from a yeast dough and filled with any number of different centers, each one containing tomatoes. Cheese, mushrooms, anchovies, capers, onions and so on may be used.

MOSCOW, Sept. 19 (U.P.) -- The Flying Fortresses from Britain that yesterday dropped "scores of tons of ammunition, food and medical supplies" to Polish patriots in Warsaw and continued on to Allied bases in Russia made the flight with the loss of two bombers and two escort fighters, the Eastern Command. United States Strategic Air Forces, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Communist Political Association, which succeeded the American Communist party, now has about 80,000 members who contribute 25 cents to $2 a week, creating an estimated annual income of $150,000 to $170,000, Earl Browder, its president, said today in testimony before the House Special Committee investigating campaign expenditures.

Aiming at a post-war factory sales volume in excess of $200,000,000, compared with a pre-war figure of approximately $75,000,000, the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation is offering its car dealers the highest discount in the industry, H.C. Doss, vice president of the company and general sales manager of the Nash Motors division, disclosed yesterday.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in English to North America from Chungking and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

BEFORE METZ, Sept. 18 (Delayed) -- The hilly, heavily wooded area on the west bank of the Moselle River northwest of the ancient fortress city of Metz, where fanatical "last stand" Nazis are manning several old forts and numerous heavy, sunken pillboxes against attacking American infantrymen, is a roaring hell of heavy artillery and mortar fire by night and a constant hail of machinegun and rifle fire by day.

Operations of the Timken-Detroit Axle Company in the fiscal year ended with June resulted in a net profit of $4,908,142 after all charges including $13,600,000 provision for taxes and $500,000 for post-war contingencies, Willard F. Rockwell, chairman of the board, reported to stockholders yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Scoring six runs in the first half of the eleventh inning after two were out, the Senators won the opener of a three-game series with the Browns tonight, 6 to 0. The loss put the second-place Brownies one and a half games behind pace-setting Detroit.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The biggest haul to date by American submarines was announced today by the Navy, which said twenty-nine more Japanese vessels -- including three warships -- had been destroyed.

The A.M. Napier Company has sold the twelve-story and penthouse building at 63 Vesey Street, southeast corner of Greenwich Street, to a client of A.J. Goldstein Co., brokers in the transaction. Except for the street floor, the building is entirely occupied by the Regional Accounting Office of the United States Army.

LONDON, Wednesday, Sept. 20 -- Three mighty Soviet armies, seizing more than 2,800 towns and settlements, have launched an all-out blow to break the Germans' grip on the Baltic States and one tank and infantry force has fought to within seven miles of Riga in a twenty-five-mile drive through German defenses, Moscow revealed last night.

As a result of last week's hurricane the Fishery Council reported yesterday that there was not even a moderate supply of a single salt water variety of fresh fish at Fulton Fish Market. This is the first time in many months that there has been such a dearth of fish.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, Sept. 20 -- The whole right flank of German defensive position in northern Europe is crumbling under the assaults of three Allied armies.

PARIS, Sept. 19 -- Leather was one of the rarest materials in France from the beginning of the occupation. The French, in equipping their army in 1939, had used a great part of the existing stocks and the Germans requisitioned the rest.

WITH THE UNITED STATES THIRD ARMY, in France, Sept. 19 (U.P.) -- Edward W. Beattie Jr., United Press war correspondent, and Wright Bryan, managing editor of The Atlanta Journal, were captured by the Germans last week and are believed to be in Germany, it was disclosed today.

The weather man gave the Dodgers another knockout blow yesterday, when they still were groggy from their experiences getting to Boston and in that city. So yesterday, originally an open date, remained open when the rescheduled contest between the Pirates and the Dodgers at Ebbets Field was called off.

The "vertical envelopment" of the Netherlands' waterlines continued yesterday as more Allied airborne troops landed north of the systems of rivers and canals that form the northern flank of the principle Westwall defenses.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Featherweight champion Willie Pep of Hartford celebrated his twenty-second birthday tonight by stopping Charley (Cabey) Lewis, Cuban-born New Yorker, in 1:52 of the eighth round of a scheduled non-title ten-rounder. Pep weighed 127 and Lewis 128.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 19 -- Despite an attempt to have the entire grand jury list of 150 names thrown out on the ground that "it includes many persons politically opposed to the Democratic organization of Mayor Frank Hague," the September term of twenty-three Hudson County grand jurors was sworn in today before Chief Justice Thomas J. Brogan of the New Jersey Supreme Court.

Senator Harry S. Truman, Democratic candidate for Vice President, will arrive in New York today to go over arrangements for his campaign itinerary with officials of the Democratic National Committee and to discuss campaign strategy and tactics.

The first of the Government's popular-appeal, small-denomination discount bonds will mature on March 1 next year. Holders of those securities, which back in 1935 were called "savings bonds," find it hard to realize that almost ten years have elapsed and that they are to receive the full face value of the bonds next March.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Chinese said tonight they had driven the Japanese back forty miles and recaptured the Hunan Province town of Taohsien, ninety miles east of Kweilin, but that other Japanese columns were reported only forty miles northeast of Kweilin, where the Fourteenth United States Air Force recently blew up and abandoned most of its extensive installations.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES IN GERMANY, Sept. 19 -- In the face of uproar and danger and in spite of the Nazi party's orders to evacuate, the great majority of the German civilian population are remaining in their homes. Apparently they have greater fear of the unknown fate that awaits those who flee deeper into Germany.
Mrs. Rose Cohen, 73 years old, was roasting a seven-pound duck in her oven at 3 P.M. yesterday for guests to celebrate the end of the Jewish new year holiday.

Two issues of obligations of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company will be offered today to the public: $30,000,000 of general mortgage sinking fund 3 1/2 per cent bonds due in 1969 by a group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and $12,000,000 of 4 per cent sinking fund debentures due in 1969 by a syndicate headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and the Mellon Securities Corporation.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- After five years the Zionist campaign for the creation of a Jewish Army achieved token success tonight when the War Office announced that a Jewish brigade group would be formed from Jewish Battalions recruited in Palestine.

ROME, Sept. 19 -- American forces of the Fifth Army achieved a notable success yesterday when they captured three dominant heights well within the German defense system and gained the advantage of terrain.

Denying that the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations harbors any ambition to capture "the Democratic party or any other party," Sidney Hillman, PAC chairman, attacked yesterday Governor Dewey's labor record and challenged the sincerity of the Republican Presidential candidate in his appeal for labor support in his speaking tour of the heavily industrialized West Coast.

A report on rent gouging on commercial loft space, citing 250 cases of increases demanded for 1945 in 200 buildings in Manhattan and Brooklyn and charging that in the garment center, where all space is rented, some owners were starting wholesale evictions, was made public yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

Your editorial "Mr. Dewey on MacArthur" is such a sober, objectively reasoned essay that it is to be hoped the Governor may find time to read it and take its lesson to heart. As you so clearly state, if he disagrees with the Allied strategy of beating Hitler first, it is his "right and privilege to challenge the wisdom of the whole basic policy."

Efforts of the farm bloc in Washington to get parity prices for the cotton farmer stimulated yesterday heavier trade covering in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange, and final prices were near the best levels of the day and up 9 to 19 points net.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora handed down yesterday a decision enjoining the executive board of the Building Service Employes International Union from trying David Sullivan, president of Local 32-B of the union, on charges preferred by members. The court held that the executive board lacked jurisdiction to try the president of a local.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- A committee of the American Legion, holding its national convention here, completed the draft today of a resolution calling for an international organization to keep the peace by force if necessary, soon after Secretary Hull invited the organization's cooperation in mobilizing public support for a program to prevent future wars.

The stock market broke out yesterday from its two-week stalemate and, as the list was lifted from its recent resistance level, prices rose fractions to more than a point. The break-through came suddenly in the second hour under the leadership of the pivotal industrial issues, but thereafter trading lagged and top increases of 2 points were reduced.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- James H. Steinman, director of the War Production Board's printing and publishing division, agreed with Representative Boren of Oklahoma tonight that no reduction of newsprint quotas for the fourth quarter of this year would be necessary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 13, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

Women have failed to form a "united front" to fight the many discriminations against their sex and, despite "sops" to their feelings, neither the Republican nor the Democratic party has as yet offered them a helping hand in standing up for their rights, according to Elizabeth Hawes, formerly a fashion designer and now on the educational staff of the United Automobile Workers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The War Production Board moved today toward further utilization of materials and facilities freed from war work by authorizing the manufacture of 30,000 domestic-type oil burners and simultaneously increasing the program for electric water heaters from 12,500 to 30,000 units during the fourth quarter of 1944.

Preparations for a drive for usable clothes for overseas distribution through the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administion were started yesterday for the 374 parishes of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York at a meeting of priests at Cathedral High School for Girls.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- President Roosevelt gave orders today for an immediate planning by the Government agencies for the demobilization of their civilian war machine, with its 3,000,000 of personnel.
LONDON, Sept. 19 -- Business in today's stock markets generally was quiet, and with little support from buyers and some selling in progress, prices tended to ease.
LONDON, Sept. 19 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 19 -- Advancing slowly against rifle and machine-gun fire from pillboxes and entrenched positions, the First Marine Division has captured a small town on Peleliu Island and made slight gains on the eastern and northeastern fronts while on Angaur, six miles to the south, Army troops have occupied two-thirds of the lightly defended island.

The Museum of Modern Art will open to the public today an exhibition of work by Soviet children. It is installed in the Young People's Gallery on the third floor, and was arranged in collaboration with the art committee of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship, Inc. About a hundred water-colors and drawings have been assembled and these are to remain on view through Nov. 19.

In most industrial operations the annual payroll far exceeds the annual interest charges plus profits. It is one of our national boasts that wages in the United States are the highest in the world -- not only hourly rates but also annual earnings. And never have these boasts rested on firmer evidence than at present.

LAUREL, Md., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Battling to a dead heat, E.C. Eastwood's Challamore and the Glen Riddle Farm's Soldier Song provided the chief thrills here today. The two rivals were all out at the end of a mile and seventy yards in the Greenbelt Purse, the day's feature race.
"Risk" capital must be encouraged if the nation is to avoid post-war inflation, according to the consensus of seventeen leading industrialists polled by the Life Insurance Companies in America.

WITH THE BRITISH SECOND ARMY, in Valkenswaard, the Netherlands, Sept. 18 (Delayed) -- Under the protection of British guns that were blazing away at the enemy, the populace of this trim little Dutch town shouted, cheered and sang today in celebration of its liberation, which took place last night.

A communique from the General Headquarters of the French Forces of the Interior for the Southwest and Center Regions, as broadcast yesterday from Toulouse and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 19 -- It's hard to tell about a bear. Ordinarily there isn't much harm in him, but he has been known to rear up and take an awful swipe at anyone taking too many liberties with him.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Secretary Hull indicated today that it would not be fair to expect the United States, Great Britain and Soviet Russia to reach full agreement quickly on all points under discussion at the Dumbarton Oaks security conference.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- The German's extermination of some 500,000 leading members of pre-Nazi German political parties to prevent the formation of any alternative Government under the Allies' control is possible during the coming weeks or months, authoritative circles here believe.

More than $17,750 of a campaign quota for $275,000 assumed by the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York for its fund-raising appeal opening on Oct. 3 has already been raised. Mrs. Cleveland E. Dodge, Y.W.C.A. campaign chairman, revealed yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Indians unleashed a fifteen-hit attack against three Boston pitchers tonight to defeat the Red Sox, 8 to 2, in the opener of a three-game series.

Ray Kilthau, Cherry Valley, won the seniors' championship of the Long Island Golf Association with a gross score of 79 over the Pomonok Club course in Flushing yesterday. J.B. Perkins, Garden City Country Club, was the net winner, with 83-11 -- 72.

S.W. Antonville, formerly vice president at Chicago in charge of Midwestern operations of the United States Plywood Corporation, has been transferred to the corporation's New York headquarters to assume the newly created post of director of sales.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Earl Browder, in defense of communism, told a House committee today that the Chinese war effort would continue to go "downhill" until the Allies recognize that the Communists represent that nation's most potent force against the Japanese.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- The around-the-clock hammering of Germany by the Allied air fleets was resumed today as American heavy bombers followed up a burning assault on Bremerhaven before dawn by the Royal Air Force with attacks on five transport and industrial centers that are key supply points behind the Nazis' Western Front.

Terence Rattigan's new comedy, "While the Sun Shines," can be cut into as even segments as it is possible to find in the theatre. Two-thirds of it are generally amusing and one-third, the last, as they show it to you at the Lyceum, is not so good.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Reports of disturbances in Brazil were denied today by Dr. Carlos Martins. Brazilian Ambassador, and Secretary of State Cordell Hull.
TORONTO, Sept. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Maj. Connie Smythe today announced that he would not accept the presidency of the National Hockey League, offered him at a league meeting two weeks ago.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 19 -- The Germans decreed a new state of siege in Denmark, "of a police character only," at noon today following battles between German forces and members of the Danish police force, who were resisting seizure and internment.

DETROIT, Sept. 19 -- The Yankees, launching their final pennant bid in the West today, hurled themselves resolutely in the path of Steve O'Neill's Tigers. But for all the impression they made upon the enemy they might just as well have executed a more prudent detour.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- When the Senate yielded to the House in its refusal to extend to Federal employes the unemployment benefits bestowed on other civilian war workers in the reconversion bill, an estimated saving of $1,200 millions was effected.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Senate took two major steps today toward post-war adjustment by accepting the reports of its conferees on measures to set up an Office of War Mobilization and Reconversion and to dispose of surplus property to an estimated value of $100,000,000,000.

In Copenhagen and elsewhere in Denmark yesterday Danes rioted against the Nazis, who brought artillery to bear on the uprising which now apparently has quieted down. This was a revival of resistance that, if intermittent from necessity, was the expression of the great majority of Danes and frequently flamed into violence.
Danny Bartfield, 139, East Side, outpointed Joe Amico, 141, Philadelphia, in a hard-fought eight-round bout before a crowd of 3,500 fight fans at the Broadway Arena last night.

A dinner tonight will open the second annual "one-for-all, once a year" drive of the New York War Fund for $17,200,000 to finance its member agencies. This is a unique campaign embracing the appeal of most of the accredited war and service organizations in the nation at large and the New York area, except the American Red Cross, which conducts a separate drive.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Some confusion over the date of Thanksgiving Day, which was thought ended when President Roosevelt restored the holiday to its traditional time in 1942 has cropped up because there are five Thursdays in November this year.

Partial relief from the provisions of amended General Order 31 has been granted employers by the War Labor Board, which will aid retailers in meeting the difficult problem of obtaining seasonal employes for the fall and Christmas rush period, it was learned here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Grain traders are paying much more attention to possible developments in Washington designed to hold up the price of agricultural products than for some time past, and a belief that steps will be taken to prevent a broad decline after the collapse of Germany, temporarily at least, offsets the favorable character of the war news.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 19 (AP) Titan Hanover today established a new world record for 2-year-olds on a half-mile track when he won the $5,000 stake for trotters of his age, feature of the five-day Grand Circuit harness race meet.

LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- A "Congressional invasion" of France was arranged today by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, after nine members of the United States House of Representatives told the supreme commander they believed that they were being blocked from the trip by lesser military authorities.

Gov. Leverett Saltonstall, who is running for the Massachusetts Senate seat now held by Sinclair Weeks, declared yesterday on a visit to Republican National Headquarters that Governor Dewey would do "a doggone sight better" in the Bay State this year than Wendell Willkie did four years ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Republican charges that the Democratic majority in the Senate had sidetracked the Equal Rights amendment because of pressure by the Congress of Industrial Organizations and its Political Action Committee were denied today by Senator Alben Barkley, majority leader.

Disclosing for the first time its elaborate plans for linking every continent by air in the post-war era, Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that it had filed applications with the Civil Aeronautics Board for two new trans-oceanic routes and for extensions of its pre-war routes that would provide an American-flag airway around the world.

Through the years, starting from 1866, favorites in the Jerome Handicap have not always fared well, but yesterday was an exception when Occupy, carrying the John Marsch colors and the hopes of most in a crowd of 23,575, drove first over the line at Belmont Park.

An indictment handed up in Federal court yesterday accused six old and trusted employes of a shipping concern of having perpetrated a racket that often was successful during World War I, but seems to have less chance in this one. The six men were caught through an investigation occasioned by the return of 200 mailed statements of the earnings of supposed employes.

Sales of Alice Duer Miller's "The White Cliffs," published in 1940, have set a record for any single book of verse, according to T.R. Coward, president of Coward McCann, which published the book. In the United States 275,507 copies have been sold, and the poem has had thirty-four printings.

Post-war expansion of cooperative merchandising will depend largely upon the policies adopted by private enterprise manufacturers, particularly those relating to the prices of their products, Colman O'Shaughnessy of the Stanley Tool Company said yesterday at the discussion luncheon held by the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Sheraton.

WITH ALLIED AIRBORNE FORCES in the Arnhem Area, the Netherlands, Sept. 20 (U.P.) -- Fighting is continuing bitterly throughout this area. There have been moments when our position looked very sticky, but you would never know it from the faces of our men.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill's Quebec declaration of friendship for President Roosevelt was described tonight by Representative Dirksen, Republican, of Illinois, as a "fourth term speech."
WITH AIRBORNE TROOPS in the Arnhem Area, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Wireless signals from the relieving force are now loud enough for us to distinguish them. They promise good news.

Housewives became aware yesterday of a new shortage in sugar as some grocers had none on their shelves and others refused to redeem more than one of the five sugar ration stamps that now are valid for five pounds each.

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY AT EINDHOVEN, Sept. 20 -- Eindhoven, scene of many Allied air raids, suffered a furious enemy air attack last night, less than twenty-four hours after its liberation by American paratroops and British forces who linked up in this vicinity Monday.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, Sept. 20 -- Organized resistance has ended on Angaur, southernmost of the two islands in the Palau group invaded last week, Pacific Fleet headquarters announced this morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Senator Barkley said today that a Foreign Relations subcommittee would meet tomorrow to consider a resolution putting Congress on record as favoring international agreements for the free interchange of independent news.

In sharp contrast to termination payments at the beginning of the year, the New York Ordnance District is now approving payment of approximately 90 per cent of the amounts called for in claims submitted by war contractors, Capt. R.N. Norwood, Ordnance Corps, United States Army, stated yesterday.

Father Divine has issued a proclamation to "all adherents to My Doctrine of Americanism, Democracy, Brotherhood and Christianity and to all sympathizers with me politically" instructing them not to register or vote in the coming Presidential election, it was learned yesterday.

With adequate supplies of milk for the New York City market during this year's short season assured through a voluntary agreement among handlers, the War Food Administration opened hearings yesterday on proposals to guarantee all dealers access to enough milk to meet the demands of their customers.
