BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 20 -- Likened by Superior Court Judge Kenneth Wynne to Theodore Dreiser's "An American Tragedy," the slaying of Josephine Medina, 17 years old, of 556 West 126th Street, New York City, reached its climax today when William B. Sanders, 18, of 3603 Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx, New York City, was sentenced to life imprisonment after pleading guilty to murder in the second degree.

Staten Island may mean just a ferryboat ride to some, but to 10-year-old Arnold Linn it was paradise. The lad, who was picked up Monday in Grand Central Terminal and for several hours later bewildered police concerning his identity, was called for yesterday by an aunt at the Lebanon Home, 156th Street and Cauldwell Avenue, the Bronx, where he was a guest.

Optimism regarding the fuel oil supply for the approaching cold season was expressed yesterday by J.D. Collins, district director of the Petroleum Administration for War. He told 300 members of the petroleum industry that "the fuel oil situation is not going to be tough at all."

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek has accepted a set of recommendations submitted by Donald M. Nelson and Maj. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley designed to bring more of China's currently available industrial power to bear on the war effort, it was announced tonight.
LONDON, Sept. 20 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

A concentrated investigation of the toy industry, both manufacturing and merchandising, has been started by the Office of Price Administration to secure proper pricing in time for the Christmas shopping season, it was learned yesterday.

Hyman Karlin, 49-year-old president of the Equitable Trading Corporation, was sentenced yesterday to thirty days in jail and he and the corporation were fined $100,000 by Federal Judge James P. Leany. The fine was the largest yet imposed here in an Office of Price Administration case.

Roy B. White, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company, announced yesterday that a plan of adjustment affecting some $652,000,000 of the company's debt and extending the maturity of $427,000,000 of its bonds had just been adopted at a meeting of the board of directors.

The importance of eye make-up in connection with fall millinery was stressed yesterday at a combination eye cosmetic and millinery show given by Peg Fisher, millinery designer, and Aziza Cosmetics at a cocktail tea in the Persian Room of the Hotel Plaza. Ten shades of Aziza eye shadow and mascara were used to match either the color of the hat or its trimming.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- A three-power accord among Russia, Great Britain and the United States for the long-term occupation of Germany is reliably reported to be nearing realization under the impetus of mounting United Nations military successes on both the eastern and western fronts in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Senate approved today, almost immediately on receiving them, nominations by President Roosevelt of Ambassadors to the Netherlands, Belgium and the Governments-in-Exile of Yugoslavia, Poland and Norway.

The ceiling price on Grade A eggs, which has risen steadily for six weeks, will go up an additional cent a dozen today. The new weekly fruit and vegetable price ceiling chart for New York City, issued by the Office of Price Administration, lists the various sizes of Grade A eggs at 7 cents a dozen more than they were on Aug. 9.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Communique 165:

An all-New York company of the Women's Army Corps will be formed during the first two weeks of October to honor Lieut. Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, commander of our forces in the Philippines who has been a prisoner of the Japanese since the fall of Corregidor in May, 1942, it was announced yesterday.

Following is an unofficial translation from the Russian-language version of the text of the Finnish armistice terms broadcast domestically by the Moscow radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Thursday, Sept. 21 (AP) -- A communique:

Mrs. Kenneth M. Read, whose husband died last month at his summer home at Prousts Neck, Me., was found dead in her apartment at 988 Fifth Avenue yesterday morning. The police listed the death as a suicide, adding that she had ended her life by twisting a heavy leash around her neck.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians pushed across two runs in the thirteenth inning to edge out the Boston Red Sox, 11 to 10, today.

After the radio has been lying dead for ninety-six consecutive hours, a hurricane casualty along with the electric lights, the pump, the refrigerator and the stove, even the commercial jingle about Splasho has lost its former terrors.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- The American Legion, in national convention here, adopted today without debate or dissent a resolution endorsing an international police organization for world peace after the conclusion of this war. At the same time the Legion asserted that the association must be one of "sovereign nations."
LONDON, Sept. 20 -- With dealers continuing to be cautious, today's stock markets were quiet. Some junior rail stocks attracted buyers, both Great Western and Southern advancing.

Forest fires, the damage they cause and the terrible toll they take of bird and animal life, only because someone was careless or thoughtless, are a subject familiar to sportsmen. Often, they have heard, read about and discussed this totally needless waste.
ROME, Sept. 20 (UP) -- A communique:

Oppenheim Collins emphasized clothes keyed to meet the daily demands of a busy life in its fashion show yesterday. The costume look was stressed in fashions for functional workadays as well as those for glamorous evenings.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Sept. 20 -- The 10,000th Thunderbolt fighter plane rolled off the production line of the Republic Aviation Corporation here today at colorful ceremonies attended by thousands of workers, high ranking Army officials and prominent civilians.

PELELIU BEACH, Sept. 20 -- Here on Beach White 2 [Navy code designation of a particular beach], surrounded by the traces of our advance and the enemy's bitter stand, the wounded and heat stricken come down, and sometimes the dead come, too, for often there is no telling whether a man is dead or alive.

There is one military question above perhaps all others that should be kept out of politics. That is when and in what numbers men can be brought home from the fighting fronts, either on furlough or to stay. It should be kept out of politics for the reason that it affects morale, one of the most important factors in the waging of war.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The campaign of organized labor to get rid of wartime restraints on increases in wages won new ground tonight when a War Labor Board panel declared that the "Little Steel" formula could be broken to keep earnings abreast of the cost of living.

For the first time in many years the New York State Federation of Labor, largest State unit of the American Federation of Labor with a membership of 1,500,000, has failed to endorse Senator Robert F. Wagner for re-election.

ONLY the other day Walter Lippmann was deploring that few histories written since 1919 give an "adequate account" of the argument of President Wilson's opponents -- "men like Theodore Roosevelt, Root, Knox, and even Lodge." Well, the word "adequate" is like a duffle bag: you can put anything into it, from a bolster to a tommy-gun.

The American Labor party made public yesterday its twelve-point State program for the re-election of President Roosevelt. Simultaneously, Hyman Blumberg, State secretary, announced that the party was distributing 750,000 registration and enrollment pamphlets throughout the State.
" Today," said Branch Rickey in a pseudo-jovial manner just before his Dodgers went out to tangle with the Pirates at Ebbets Field yesterday, "we are going up. We can't go any farther down."
We shall emerge from World War II more than ever the world's creditor on financial account.

DETROIT, Sept. 20 -- The increasingly enfeebled efforts of the Yankees to keep themselves in the running for their fourth straight American League pennant practically developed into a rout today as Steve O'Neill's clawing Tigers, behind their second mound star, Dizzy Trout, flattened the fading champions for the second successive afternoon.

Opening a drive for $17,200,000 for the support of thirty-one national and local war service agencies serving our own fighting men and women and our allies, more than 1,200 volunteer campaign workers of the New York War Fund and distinguished guests attended a dinner and a stage presentation in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night.
In a recent letter to THE TIMES from Hugh Russell Fraser two inaccurate statements were made which ought to be corrected.

LONDON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Allies' day and night aerial campaign to prevent the Nazis from moving troops or supplies to the Siegfried Line or into the Netherlands continued in full swing today along 100 miles of Germany's western frontier.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- Speculative sentiment, after having been decidedly bullish recently, changed today after an early upturn in the grain markets and, although prices rallied from the low wheat futures on the Board of Trade closed unchanged to 1/2 cent a bushel lower than yesterday.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Sept. 20 The Roosevelt administration was accused tonight by Governor Bricker of Ohio of withholding facts of the "disgraceful Pearl Harbor episode" because of the harm which the telling of the full story might do to the fourth-term campaign.

The total day-session enrollment at New York City's four public colleges -- City, Hunter, Brooklyn and Queens -- was announced yesterday as 17,595 by Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education. This is 334 above the total registration at the municipal schools one year ago.
LONDON, Sept. 20 -- The Germans made two crucial mistakes in Normandy that cost them the war, Field Marshal Sir Bernard L. Montgomery said in Belgium recently, it was disclosed today.
ROME, Sept. 20 -- The trial of Pietro Caruso and his private secretary, Roberto Occhetto, began at 8 A.M. today in the heavily guarded Corsini Palace, two blocks from the Regina Coeii prison.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, Sept. 21 -- American and British troops are slowly breaking stubborn German resistance in three great battles in three countries, battles on which the duration of the war in the west depends.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 20 -- The State-wide drive to obtain ratification of the proposed new constitution for New Jersey at the Nov. 7 election moved into high gear tonight as Gov. Walter E. Edge charged 600 busines, civic, agricultural and industrial leaders of the State with the task of enlisting votes for the proposal.

The distinguished service award of the Army's Ordnance Department was presented yesterday to the American Iron and Steel Institute at a brief ceremony in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Maj. Gen. G.M. Barnes, chief of research and development of the Ordnance Department, presented the award to Walter S. Tower, president of the institute, in the presence of the institute's board of directors and guests.
BOSTON, Sept. 20 -- A year ago Boston College gave the game of football back to the boys.

Five troupes of major league baseball stars will head overseas shortly after the world series to entertain soldiers in front line battle areas under the auspices of the USO Camp Shows, it was announced yesterday through The Associated Press.
AN AMERICAN COMMAND POST IN THE NETHERLANDS, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Major Generals -- even in America's fast-moving armies -- don't usually shoot it out personally with German armed columns.

CINCINNATI, Sept 20 -- John L. Lewis, their president, and delegates to the convention of the United Mine Workers of America rejected today as an "insult" a query by Secretary Ickes, who wanted to know whether the coal miners' chief proposed "to live up to your long-vaunted role of abiding by your contracts.***"

It should be common knowledge by now that Mrs. Yolanda Mero-Irion did a grand job last season in reviving "The Merry Widow" for the New Opera Company. With all its splendor and gaiety, the famous operetta is returning on Saturday night, Oct. 7, to the City Center.

A testimonial dinner to Ferdinand C. Smith, Negro secretary of the National Maritime Union, Congress of Industrial Organizations affiliate, was given last night at the Hotel Commodore, on the eve of his departure on a campaign tour to speak for the re-election of President Roosevelt.

A strong appeal for reaffirmation of the no-strike pledge for the duration of the war was made at yesterday's session of the convention of the United Rubber Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations affiliate, at the Park Central Hotel, by Sherman H. Dalrymple, president, after delegates from Akron, Ohio, had attacked it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--The United States, Soviet Russia and Great Britain have devised a formula for the solution of their difficulties over the formation of an international security organization, it was reported tonight.

ALONG THE MOSELLE, Sept. 19 (Delayed) -- The situation along the Moselle from Nancy in the south to Thionville in the north was virtually unchanged today. Before Metz there was little or no change in the positions, although there was both infantry fighting and artillery dueling all day.

Don Federico Henriquez y Carvajal was 96 years old on Sept. 16. He was born in the city of Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, the oldest city in the New World, "The Cradle of America," and has lived there his entire life.

A bevy of pretty girls piroutted on the circular platform set up in the center of the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday in the latest jeune fille styles, hand-picked by Josephine Hughes for the Jeune Fille department of Hattie Carnegie.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Thursday, Sept. 21 -- Heavy bombers again have struck at the Philippines in one of the largest attacks to date, more than fifty planes unloading 120 tons of bombs in the Davao area, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's communique said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Thirty-eight States are signatories to a petition filed today in the Supreme Court of the United States requesting a rehearing in the case of the Southeastern Underwriters Association on which a decision was handed down last June 5, declaring that insurance is interstate commerce and therefore comes under the jurisdiction of the anti-trust laws. New York State filed a similar plea on Sept. 14.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 124:
CHUNGKING, China, Sep. 20 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
The battered divisions of the Third Reich of Adolf Hitler and the great armies of the Allies were locked in a bitter, swaying death grapple yesterday on three great fronts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The fourth quarter newsprint supply for United States consumption will be 819,000 tons, the same as in the third quarter, the War Production Board said today, adding that it will consist of these monthly deliveries: Canada, 200,000 tons; United States, 60,000 tons, and Newfoundland, 13,000 tons.

The haunting strains of Sibelius' "Finlandia" were heard over the Helsinki radio Tuesday night as Acting Premier Ernst von Born concluded his summary of the armistice terms Finland has had to accept from Russia. The full text, as broadcast from Moscow yesterday, does not lessen the first impression of severity.

A fine for all persons who do not exercise their right to vote, modeled after the Australian plan, was suggested yesterday by Henry J. Kaiser, the shipbuilder. Mr. Kaiser is chairman of the newly-formed Non - Partisan Association for Franchise Education, Inc., which held its first meeting yesterday.
ROME, Sept. 20 -- Both sporadic violence, which is becoming a commonplace in the provinces, and Sicilian separatism broke into national prominence today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- A Republican hint that the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee might look into the political activities of Mayor Edward J. Kelly of Chicago developed tonight after the disclosure that pro-Roosevelt campaign letters accompanied soldier vote applications mailed from that city.

The Australian Government has paid American exporters approximately $5,000,000 in clearing claims or cargoes diverted to Australia at the outbreak of the war, S. Laney, Australian Customs Representative, disclosed yesterday. Of the original 4,700 claims all but 800 have been settled, and the latter are the subject of current action, he said.

Senator Harry S. Truman, Democratic nominee for Vice President, charged yesterday that Governor Dewey had exceeded "the limits of veracity" in his speech at Portland, Ore., Tuesday night in which, the Senator said, the Republican nominee for President pictured a dream of himself in the White House with a Republican Senate and House of Representatives.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) -- After being shut out for six innings, the White Sox reached Russ Christopher for six runs in the seventh inning tonight and defeated the Athletics, 6 to 1. Third Baseman Grey Clarke singled twice in the big inning.

JOLLY CHOLLY GRIMM stretched a languid leg over the side of a chair and relaxed. The weatherman had given his Cubs a day off and the best left-handed banjo player ever to enter the major leagues was punching the conversational bag with his usual gusto. Then someone in the room mentioned Cotton Tierney and the Chicago manager bolted upright.

LONDON, Sept. 20 (UP) -- Germany, desperately challenging Russia and Finland alike to enforce their agreement to expel the German Army from Finnish soil, said tonight that German troops were already fighting the Red Army in northern Finland and threatened to devastate the country to slow any Russian advance.

ROME, Sept. 20 -- The Fifth Army has cut a six-mile gap in the Gothic Line north of Florence, and headquarters declared today that the whole enemy position" guarding the Po Valley and industrial northern Italy was in jeopardy.

The needs of a post-war world of peace and abundance were discussed by speakers from diverse fields and of varying political backgrounds at the opening yesterday at Christ Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, of a two-day forum on "Building a Better World."

Governor Dewey scored a fair point and an effective one when he took the Administration to task for the "quarreling, dissension and disunity" which have so often marked its three terms in office. He spoke only of the open and acrid dispute between Vice President Wallace and Secretary Jones over the corporate affairs of BEW and the long series of vendettas that has featured the career of WPB.

Perhaps there are not many families who will be able to stage a setting for the day "when Johnny comes marching home" that would measure up to the group of rooms with that label that opened yesterday at Lord Taylor. But probably most families would like to if they could.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- President Roosevelt declared his "whole-hearted pleasure" over our recognition of the independence of Syria and Lebanon in a statement given out by the White House today The action was taken yesterday.

An account of how two men received exempt 4-F draft classifications from Local Board 20, in Manhattan, by reason of a single hernia, was given by a witness yesterday at the Federal Court trial of Murray Cohen, 28-year-old restaurant owner.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- The British Government will publish shortly a plan for compulsory military service after the war, it was reported tonight, and at the same time it will satisfy an increasing public demand by raising the pay of all members of the British armed forces.

EUGENE, Ore., Sept 20 (U.P.) -- Governor Dewey, in a platform speech to a depot crowd of 3,000 here, said today that this country must "go forward with the most complete house-cleaning" in its history by changing Administrations and electing a Republican Senate and House.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora reserved decision yesterday on a motion by Frank Costello, slot-machine operator and gambler, to vacate a subpoena requiring him to testify at the Copacabana night club license hearing before Fourth Deputy Police Commissioner Cornelius O'Leary.

A cotton eport plan providing "internal subsidies" to exporters which they immediately can pass along to foreign purchasers is needed if the United States is to hold a competitive position in world markets, according to downtown textile exporters yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Browns, battling to stay in the race for the American League pennant, defeated the Senators tonight, 5 to 2, as Jack Kramer won his fifteenth game of the year. The second-place Browns still trail Detroit by one and a half games.

ON BOARD DEWEY SPECIAL TRAIN, Sept. 20 -- Governor Dewey departed today from Portland for San Francisco, where he will make his third major Pacific coast speech at 11 P.M. tomorrow (Eastern War Time). The talk will be broadcast over a nation-wide network.

LONDON, Sept. 20 (U.P.) -- Flying bombs winged into southern England and the London area tonight in the second such attack within twenty-four hours as official sources renewed warnings for evacuees from the southern areas to delay homecomings until the Government had announced that it was safe.

MONTREAL, Sept. 20 -- Herbert H. Lehman, as director general, revealed today that the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration expected to spend at least $1,000,000,000 in 1945 for supplies and services for the peoples liberated from Axis occupation. This is one-half of its total potential resources.

Montgomery ward Co., Inc., had a net profit of $7,981,736, equal to $1.39 a share of common stock in the six months ended on July 31, according to the statement issued yesterday to stockholders by Sewell Avery, chairman of the board. In the corresponding period of last year the company cleared $7,305,193, or $1.26 a common share.

UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Sept. 20 -- German troops manning what is left of the Siegfried Line have been ordered to hold at all costs and are fighting a battle of desperation. Prisoners now falling into the hands of our forces include good quality troops recently brought from the Eastern Front and ragtag and bobtail scrapings from the bottom of Hitler's manpower barrel.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 20 -- The most spacious anchorage in Europe came under the Allies' control today when the garrison of Brest, which once numbered more than 20,000, finally capitulated after six weeks and four days of siege by American forces.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 20 -- John Wayne will be starred by RKO in "The Invisible Army," screen story of American and Filipino underground activity in the Philippines. The story, by Aneaus MacKenzie and Richard Landau, will be produced by Robert Fellows, and, according to the studio, will have War Department collaboration.

The City Vacancy Listing Bureau opened yesterday in the Pershing Square Information Center with a fairly good rush of business and one of the applicants got quick results. He is S.M. Koenigsberg. an employe of the Securities Exchange Commission, who is being transferred fore Philadelphia to New York City.

The Battle of the Rhine, which the Germans themselves characterize as "decisive," is proceeding with extremely heavy fighting. With Allied progress through the Westwall moving slowly and at heavy cost, this last great barrier to an Allied advance into the heart or Germany can only be converted from a German defensive position into a trap for its defenders by the Allied offensive in the Netherlands.

War effort advertising in daily and Sunday newspapers throughout the country during June aggregated $8,254,036, it was announced yesterday by the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association. This brought to $55,541,144 the value of such advertising since Aug. 1, 1943, when figures first were compiled.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- A broad gauge post-war health program, designed not only to provide needed medical care and attention for the people of the nation but to prevent illness and the causes of illness, was presented by Mayor La Guardia of New York, and indorsed by experts and lay speakers at today's final hearing before the Senate's subcommittee on wartime health and education.

The general outline of armistice terms for Axis countries was agreed upon by the Allies some time before the surrender of Italy; it was applied to her, adding some particular conditions, and signed by Marshal. Badoglio on Sept. 8 and Sept. 29, 1943. During and after the pourparlers of the armistice it was not considered that Italy had immediately to declare war on Germany.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- A house naval sub-committee urged an immediate and independent investigation of the Pearl Harbor disaster today while Senators engaged in another heated argument on the subject.

Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, warned last night in a speech broadcast over Army short-wave facilities to American troops overseas that there is grave danger that the United States and its Allies may lose the peace even as they are winning the war.

Paramount will produce sixteen "important feature films" during the coming year, it has been announced by Henry Ginsberg, vice president in charge of production and studio operations. The pictures, he stated, will be exclusive of films to be made by the Hal Wallis, B.G. De Sylva and William Pine-William Thomas independent production units.

Daily average gross crude oil production for the country last week was 4,745,500 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute, a gain of 56,100 over the preceding week. For the four weeks ended last Saturday the average was 4,690,000, against 4,375,750 for the corresponding period of 1943.

When the late Wiley Post in his single-motored Winnie Mae completed the first solo round-the-world flight from New York to New York in July, 1933, he predicted that some day circumnavigation of the world by air would be a commonplace. Now Pan American Airways has filed applications with the Civil Aeronautics Board for a post-war extension of its international lines that would bring true Mr. Post's dream.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Constitutional Educational League, Inc., refused today to give the House Campaign Expenses Committee a record of its finances, contending that the organization was nonpolitical.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- A hint of the overwhelming sea power the United States and Britain are massing for use against Japan is contained in the 1943-44 edition of Jane's Fighting Ships, distributed to the press tonight for publication tomorrow.

If the joint application by Mayor La Guardia and the New York City Tunnel Authority for the manufacture of 790 tons of bolts, washers and nuts is approved promptly by the War Production Board, the Authority will be ready to resume construction of the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel in three months, or as soon thereafter as the necessary manpower becomes available, Commissioner William H. Friedman said yesterday.

New York City's observance of National Dog Week was concentrated into two hours of rapid-fire action yesterday afternoon at the lower plaza of Rockefeller Center. Dogs of scores of breeds participated in a parade of champions. Retrievers delivered to hand ducks from land and water, while there was a demonstration of obedience training by members of the New York City class.

Vice President Henry A. Wallace will make his first speech for the re-election of President Roosevelt in Madison Square Garden tonight at a meeting sponsored by the Independent Voters Committee of the Arts and Sciences, which will be the first big meeting of the campaign in New York City.

A powerful spurt just before the end of the two-mile journey won for Elkridge the $5,925 Broad Hollow Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday, while many among 17,132 persons cheered his progress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Analyses of twenty-one different types of family problems caused by war disruptions, with a plan for action in each, have been prepared by Mrs. Lydia A. Lynde, parent education specialist, Extension Service, Department of Agriculture, for discussion in home demonstration clubs throughout the country.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically from Sofia and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 20 -- Thirsty-eight men, all from New Jersey, were indicted today by the Federal grand jury on charges of illegally producing alcohol. The indictments resulted from a six months' investigation by the Alcoholic Tax Unit of the Treasury Department.

A promise that housing developments under the supervision of the New York City Housing Authority would revert to their low rent and low income character when the war is over, or sooner if accommodations are available in privately owned properties, was made yesterday by Edmond B. Butler, chairman of the authority.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 20 (U.P.) -- Japanese cavalry have fought their way to a point nineteen miles north of embattled Kweilin and a second spearhead approaching through rugged terrain to the east is within twenty-three miles of the city, according to dispatches from United States Fourteenth Air Force headquarters at Kunming.

A weakened technical condition in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange, following recent heavy covering by the trade, resuited yesterday in a decline of prices and at the close quotations were 3 to 14 points net lower on the day.

WASHINGTON, Sept 20 -- American and other Allied troops entering Nazi Germany from the west are carrying new military marks, like the military lira used in the Italian invasion. An announcement regarding the new currency, including the dollar and pound exchange rates fixed for it, is expected momentarily from Allied headquarters overseas.

ROME, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Allied air and naval forces have loosed a mounting attack against strained Nazi transport and airfields on Crete and have blockaded the island to prevent escape of the German garrison, Allied communiques announced today.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday for the first six months of this year a consolidated net income of $4,310,457, compared with a net of $2,220,584 in the first half of 1943. Results of certain of the corporation's important subsidiaries were not included in the consolidated statement.

The New York State Board of Social Welfare and Robert E. Dineen, State Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday approval of a certificate of incorporation for the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, which was conceived by Mayor La Guardia as a means of providing health and medical insurance for all persons living and working in New York City who do not earn more than $5,000 a year.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 -- Three large plants of SKF Industries, largest ball bearing manufacturers in the mountry, were virtually paralyzed today by a wildcat strike involving about 3,500 workers.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND, Kandy, Ceylon, Thursday, Sept. 21 (U.P.) -- British carrier planes of the Eastern Fleet air arm have bombed the Japanese-controlled railway-maintenance center at Segli, northwestern Sumatra, it was announced today.

PARIS, Sept. 19 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Marquise de Polignac, the former Nina Crosby of New York, who married into the wealthy French champagne family, sat on a cot in the Drancy stockade today and said that she welcomed arrest as a way to clear her name of rumors that she was a collaborationist.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Bucky Walters won his twenty-second victory of the season tonight as the Reds annexed the second game of a twilight double-header from the Phils, 6 -- 4, after the Phils took the opener, 3 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today that he had known in advance of the provision in the armistice with Rumania for the return of Transylvania to Rumania, "subject to confirmation at the peace settlement."
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Chungking in English to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

Despite forebodings, railroads have little to fear from other forms of freight competition after the war, according to a study on the outlook for railroad securities just released by the New York Stock Exchange firm of Baker, Weeks Harden.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Sept.20 -- By a voice vote after brief discussion, the House approved today the conference report on reconversion legislation which was adopted yesterday by the Senate, thus clearing the calendar for a probable recess of Congress tomorrow until after election.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- An allocation of 2,659,848 tons of wood pulp has been authorized for the manufacture of 4,358,460 tons of paper and paperboard during the fourth quarter of the year, the War Production Board announced today. The new grant is approximately what it was for the previous quarter, it was said.
A Headquarters announcement, as broadcast domestically yesterday from Tokyo and recorded and translated by the Federal Communications Commission:

What is said to be the first complete line of aircraft products, accessories and supplies distributed by a single concern, backed up with a complete merchandising program, will be offered to private fliers by the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company at airports in all parts of the country, it was announced yesterday.

Administration policy for the reconversion period is apparently being based upon two conflicting theories concerning the nature of our post-war problem. Some agencies in Washington are acting on the assumption that the post-war period will be characterized by inflation; others are assuming it will be a period of deflation.
Sadao Iguchi, spokesman of the Japanese Board of Information, denied yesterday that Japan was seeking peace with Britain and the United States and that Germany was seeking peace with Russia.

THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 18 contained a very interesting report about the 1,800 priceless paintings from the Rijks Museum of Amsterdam which have been found in safety in an air-conditioned sandstone cavern on the out-skirts of Maastricht.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 20 -- The University of Chattanooga at its summer commencement conferred honorary degrees tonight upon three distinguished Americans, Associate Justice Wiley Blount Rutledge of the Supreme Court, Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and Mrs. Sulzberger.

The stock market furthered its recovery yesterday but the gains were selective and activity was on a reduced scale. The upturn in group movements was spotty, with gains most prominent in a long list of unrelated issues. Business on the Stock Exchange contracted to 696,080 shares from 714,890 on Tuesday.

LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 21 -- A fourth huge Soviet army has joined the battle for the Baltic States and has advanced forty-four miles through crumbling German defenses to within sixty-two miles of the Estonian capital of Tallinn, Moscow revealed last night.

PARIS, Sept. 20 -- Though the Allies have brought more than 12,000 tons of foodstuffs into Paris and the distribution of meats, fats, milk and vegetables has substantially increased by comparison with the starvation ration of the Vichy regime, the average Parisian now gets barely 1,000 calories daily, or less than half the amount needed, Paul Giacobbi, Commissioner for Foods, said today.

General MacArthur's precursors have arrived over Manila in the form of American carrier planes, and eleven Japanese ships are on the bottom and 205 enemy aircraft are masses of wreckage. Thus is Japan reminded of that Sunday in 1941 which brought a peaceful nation into war.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Polish circles in London today welcomed the appointment of a new United States Ambassador to Poland, but they placed no great faith in the implications of the appointment that had been suggested by commentators in the United States.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Jeff Heath's pinch two-run homer and two of three Boston errors handed the Indians a 5-to-2 victory over the Red Sox today. Oris Hockett's four-bagger in the eighth provided the Tribe with its last tally

With his speech last night at San Francisco it seems to us that Mr. Dewey just about completed the process of running for the Presidency on the domestic platform of the New Deal. This process, of course, was pretty well under way before Mr. Dewey reached California, or even before he entrained for the West Coast.

Alternating periods of weakness and strength cropped out yesterday in the stock market with a resumption of the recent cautious trading. Emphasis was on the lower side, although good bidding appeared in a selected list of specialties. Business on the Stock Exchange continued to lighten as transfers dropped to 560,920 shares, against 696,080 shares on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission agreed today to reopen its hearings on freight rate increases after the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners and twenty State commissions asked that the increases, which have been held in suspension by the ICC, be eliminated permanently.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- J.A. Krug, acting chairman of the War Production Board, gently chided the American people today for what he termed "thinking in terms of next year's automobile instead of this year's war." He backed up his reproof with a reminder that urgent munitions programs were falling behind schedule because of manpower shortages.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Congress formally adjourned this afternoon until Nov. 14, barring an earlier summons back into session by their leaders.

In a letter released yesterday, clarifying the official position on bonuses, the National War Labor Board revealed that it has not, in fact, limited Christmas and year-end bonuses to 4 per cent of the annual payroll, against 10 per cent last year, an impression which was conveyed by its brief release on Tuesday.
Following is the text of Vice President Henry A. Wallace's speech, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Theodore Roosevelt Jr. was awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor posthumously today "for gallantry and intrepidity at the risk of his life above and beyond the call of duty" in the invasion of France.

Three reasons why the present international conflict can be made the "last world war" were outlined yesterday by Dr. Hu Shih, former Chinese Ambassador to the United States, at the close of the two-day forum on "Building a Better World," at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- A number of inquiries have come to this department, of which the following is typical:

Jockey Ted Atkinson, who had five winners in a row last Saturday, had the opposite kind of racing luck at Belmont Park yesterday when he was beaten aboard the favorites of both features, those losers being his twenty-third and twenty-fourth in succession since his victorious sweep.

ATLANTA, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Railroads must prepare quickly to guarantee "adequate transportation" for increased industrial needs of the post-war South, industrial and railroad representatives were told today by J.J. Kornfeld of New Orleans, chairman of the Southeast Shippers Advisory Board.
LONDON, Sept. 20 --Business in today's stock markets here was on a light scale but the general tone was firmer as a result of the latest war news.

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 21 -- Carrier planes from Admiral William F. Halsey's Third Fleet struck at Japanese airfields near Manila and elsewhere on Luzon Island yesterday, carrying the war back to the heart of the Philippines for the first time since Corregidor fell.

MOSCOW, Sept. 21 -- A strong attack by Edward B. Osubka-Morawski, chairman of the Polish Committee of National Liberation, upon Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, Premier of the Polish Government in Exile in London, was received with general approval by delegates to the first meeting of the Polish Peasant party in liberated Poland, the Soviet press reported today.

The Air Technical Service Command at Wright Field, Dayton, is the world's biggest industrial organization. Its customers are the gallant men who fly and operate Army Air Force planes in every part of the world. Through it they are supplied with every needed weapon, almost exclusively by air, with speed which is well-nigh miraculous.

Czechoslovak textile mills, with the exception of those that were scrapped early in the war, have suffered little damage, underground sources have informed Czech representatives here, and they will be able to produce for their own nationals as soon as the war is over if staple is made available.

Despite charges of illegality and hints of "rigged" specifications, the Board of Estimate approved yesterday the form of contract for the paving of three of the huge concrete runways to be constructed at the new Idlewild Airport in Queens.

Prince Charles of Belgium yesterday took the oath as "Regent of the Realm" to serve in the absence of his brother, King Leopold III, now a prisoner of the Germans, the Brussels radio said last night. The ceremonies were attended by members of the Government, diplomatic corps, Governors of Provinces and Members of Parliament, the broadcast said.

"Hurricane" apples -- those blown from the trees during the tropical storm of last week -- are to be found in city markets this morning in such quantities that they virtually amount to a surplus. To avoid waste, the War Food Administration asks householders to make generous purchases of the fruit -- bruised only slightly, if at all -- for eating, cooking and preserving.

Establishment of a trust fund by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to finance five annual post-doctorate fellowships in physical science was announced yesterday by Walter S. Gifford, president of the company.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Banks in this city increased their deposits, cash resources and holdings of Government securities in the third quarter of this year, according to figures disclosed today in response to a call issued by the State Auditor for the condition of State banks as of Sept. 18.

The Independent Citizens Committee working for the election of Carmine Marasco, Democratic candidate for the Kings County bench, listed one Louis Principe as a member of its executive group, but it failed to check up on the fact that Mr. Principe was a lifelong Republican interested in the election of the Republican candidate, Nicholas H. Pinto, and that Mr. Principe had died on May 17.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Fair progress was made today on the Board of Trade in evening up September grain contracts. September wheat held within narrow limits and closed unchanged. Liquidation developed in oats and the price was off 3 1/4 cents a bushel at one time, although trading was relatively light.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed increases in holdings of Government securities and note circulation for the system as a whole to be $132,761,000 and $58,715,000, respectively, while the ratio of reserve declined to 52.9.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- During the week ended Sept. 20 member bank reserve balances decreased $81,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $329,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks, $63,000,000 in money in circulation, $6,000,000 in Treasury cash and $5,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, offset in part by increases of $321,000,000 in reserve bank credit and $2,000,000 in Treasury currency.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (U.P.) -- Secretary Forrestal told a news conference that United States shipyards must turn out five assault vessels every two days in the period immediately ahead. Assault shipping was the most urgent item in the Navy's production program, he said.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 21 -- In a direct appeal for the support of Southern voters, Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio declared tonight that the only way for the Democrats "to take back their party" was by casting their ballots for the Republican ticket in this, "the year to stand up and be counted."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Reds annexed both ends of a double-header tonight against the Phils, taking the arc-light game, 8 to 4, after winning the twilight opener, 5 to 3, in twelve innings.

Job placements by the United States Employment Service of the War Manpower Commission set a new high record in this State in August, with 170,159 placements, representing an increase of 4 per cent over the previous record of 163,698 established in July, it was reported yesterday by Joseph B. O'Connor, acting regional WMC director.

Aside from the beauty of the fine furs that Gunther exhibited yesterday in the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel at the luncheon hour, the detail of workmanship attracted attention. Persian lamb in a full-length cape and a long coat was manipulated in such manner that it made scrolled folds placed just below the shoulder line.

Consumer education was hailed yesterday as the "core of the school" by Dr. Edward Reich, coordinator of consumer education for the Board of Education, in initiating the consumer education course sponsored jointly by the Board of Education and the New York City Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, for which he is serving as coordinator.

"The Big Noise," which arrives at the Rialto, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Laurel and Hardy are starred in the Twentieth Century-Fox comedy, which was directed by Mal St. Clair and which includes Doris Merrick, Helene Reynolds, Arthur Space and Esther Howard among its supporting players.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. defended today the policy by which the Government has financed the war mainly by floating securities of short maturities.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The British draft will be maintained as long as the war with Japan lasts, the Government announced tonight in a White Paper on details of the 'age and service" formula adopted for whatever demobilization of the nation's armed forces may take place after Germany is defeated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 16 were 892,358 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 66,405 cars, or 8 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 10,408 cars, or 1.2 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 10,741 cars, or 1.2 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.
The following letter has been received by THE NEW YORK TIMES from Raymond C. Maley, New York correspondent for the Sydney (Australia) Morning Herald:
Despite the presence of a Lincoln, Grand and Morgan on the squad, Columbia gets ready for its dip in the 1944 football pool with considerable trepidation.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday at Burbank, Calif., that it was negotiating a Regulation V credit of $175,000,000 through fifteen commercial banks to meet current needs and those caused by termination of contracts.
LONDON, Sept. 21 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from, Btrlin and recorded by the United Press:

Senator Claude Pepper of Florida, whose appointment as chairman of the Foreign Language Committee of the Democratic National Committee had just been announced, charged yesterday that Governor Dewey, Republican nominee for President, had made "a purposeful appeal to a large nationalistic and racial group in this country to get their votes."

ABOARD A BRITISH AIRCRAFT CARRIER OFF SUMATRA, Sept. 18 (Delayed) (AP) -- Sumatra's main railway installations have just been worked over by planes of this swift carrier task force, and pilots who whipped over the Netherlands East Indies possession unopposed, declared it a "dead island."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UP) -- War casualties of the United States armed forces now exceed 400,000.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 21 (AP) -- Three members of the board of directors of Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, including Paul A. Schoellkopf, chairman, resigned today in order, they said, to devote their time to the reorganization of the company's western New York affiliate, the Buffalo, Niagara and Eastern Power Corporation, Mr. Schoellkopf will continue as chairman of the board of B.N. and E. and as president of the Niagara Falls Power Company.
WASHINGTON, Sept 21 (UP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 127:
KANDY, Ceylon, Sept. 21 (AP) -- A communique:
DETROIT, Sept. 21 -- The United Automobile Workers (CIO) has prepared a maternity clause which the union is trying to have included in every UAW contract.
LONDON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Note circulation as reported by the Bank of England in its weekly condition statement showed a slight decrease for the week ended Sept. 20.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The surplus property bill just enacted by Congress was denounced as inadequate and its repeal or substantial amendment within a year was predicted by Mayor La Guardia at a hearing today before the special Senate committee investigating the National Defense Program.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Pacific Fleet communique 126:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- A rise of 9 per cent in weekly department store sales for the week ended Sept. 16, as compared to sales of the corresponding week of last year was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board.

Suggestions for three clauses for a uniform confirmation on orders placed by retailers, drawn up by a subcommittee, will be considered today at a meeting of the Conference of Apparel Credit Men to be held in its clubroom at 1440 Broadway.

ROME, Sept. 21 -- Pietro Caruso, police chief of Rome, who typified in Italian eyes all that was hateful in fascism, will be tied to a chair and shot in the back. Roberto Occhetto, his younger private secretary, will live in a prison under a thirty-year sentence.

Proposals for the State-wide application of the Multiple Dwelling Law to improve existing housing facilities and to prevent any great exodus of tenants from this city to adjacent areas were made yesterday at a hearing called by the State of New York Joint Legislative Committee to Recodify the Multiple Dwelling Law.

WASHINGTON, Sept 21 -- An extensive study of the steel industry by economists of the Office of Price Administration indicates that manufacturers will be able to bear the cost of a susbtantial rise in workers' wage rates if a high level of production is maintained through the period of reconversion, it was learned today.

"Next time you go shopping with a man who is buying himself a hat, be sure he picks out a color that is becoming to you," advised Helene Garnell, millinery designer, while she transformed a man's battered felt into a dashing feminine cloche yesterday afternoon at Loeser's.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 -- Governor Dewey outlined tonight his idea of the "American way" to meet the country's domestic problems. That way, he said, must lie between New Deal regimentation and the reaction of uncontrolled business.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Communique 166:

WITH THE EIGHTH ARMY IN RIMINI, Italy, Sept. 21 -- Greek troops hoisted their flags on the main postoffice of Rimini today and the last German hope of holding the Eighth Army away from the Po Valley lay crushed in the desolate ruins of this once-beautiful resort and port city.

Surrounded on all sides by victorious armies and vengeful populations, forsaken by virtually all his allies and satellites, Adolf Hitler, the man who set out to conquer the world, is fighting his last battle. Into it he is pouring the life-blood and the last physical and moral resources of the German people, emulating in a different sense the maxim of another absolute ruler, "After us the deluge."

Twelve and a half dollars a room is the basic rent in the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's new housing project for Harem. It is taken for granted that the great majority of the tenants, if not all, will be Negroes.

The Joseph J. Gabdi Organizaon was the broker in the sale of the doctor's office in Weehawken Hghts, N. J., for ComdL Abram Wsa. iow attioned in Fda, Comd Weiss plans to open larger quarters in Weehawk-I en after the war.

THE tank factory had been bombed out of Duesseldorf and built again many miles distant in a country district where it was cleverly camouflaged in a wood. There thousands of German laborers, most of them over 40, toiled at pitiful wages for twelve hours a day in two shifts making machines of war for the glorious armies that were fighting for the Fatherland in Africa and before Stalingrad.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept 21 -- The savings of individuals and unincorporated businesses in the United States amounted to $8,800,000,000 in the second quarter of 1944, increasing total liquid savings to a high record of $130,000,000,000 as of June 30, or an increase of about 100 per cent in the two and one-half years since Pearl Harbor, the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today in its quarterly savings study.

Leopold Stokowski, in an informal meeting yesterday with representatives of the outstanding women's organizations of this city, revealed several additional works which are being contemplated for presentation in the coming season of the New York City Symphony, of which he is musical director, and which will open Oct. 9.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Average commodity prices in primary markets have remained unchanged since the last week in August. The all-commodity index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, at 103.6 per cent of the 1926 average, was at the same level as in mid-August and 0.7 per cent higher than at this time last year.
ROME, Sept. 21 (UP) -- A communique:

DETROIT, Sept. 21 -- With an effort born of despair, the Yankees today turned upon their tormentors and by sinking the Tigers, 5 to 4, in ten innings, kept alive their slender thread of hope in the American League flag race.

Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, will deliver the opening address of the industrial relations conference of the American Management Association next Wednesday morning at the Hotel Pennsylvania, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- A Government information service which would operate in foreign capitals after the war, supplying news to and about the United States, was forecast today by Robert Sherwood, Director of Overseas Operations for the Office of War Information, as an outgrowth of the OWI's function during the war.
Tami Mauriello will be in the star bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. The popular Bronx heavyweight will tackle Lee Oma of Detroit in a clash listed for ten rounds

ALBANY, Sept. 21 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National chairman, and Edward F. Jaeckle, State chairman, held a closed session this afternoon with the chairmen of twenty-one up-State counties to discuss the Presidential campaign.
The key to the battle of time yesterday was still the little Dutch city of Arnhem and the crisis is now.

Acquaintance with American products gained by the population of the Belgian Congo during the war will result in a new and larger market for American exports and capital in the post-war period, Dr. Max Horn, counselor of the Belgian Congo Government, declared yesterday.
The New York Stock Exchange membership of Gregory C. Hunt has been transferred to Adrian Ralph Kristeller.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 21 -- Loretta Young has been named for the co-starring lead with Gary Cooper in the untitled western picture which the latter will produce for International. "Home Is The Sailor." the Eric Hatch novel in which Miss Young was to appear for the company, has been postponed until spring or early summer.

The thirtieth annual Flower Show of the American Dahlia Society opened yesterday in the Ball Room of the Hotel Pennsylvania with a display that equaled those of better-growing years. Earlier in the week officers of the society had considered canceling the show because of the hurricane.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Friday, Sept. 22 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, Sept. 21 (U.P.) -- Heads of both the American Chamber of Commerce and the American Red Cross today emphatically denied allegations published by The London Daily Mail that American business men were being allowed to go to Paris, in the guise of Army officers, to transact private business, while British business men were unable to get permits to visit the French capital.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, driving himself furiously, suffered a breakdown in health recently and was confined to his camp for several days, but is in excellent condition again, Merrill Mueller, National Broadcasting Company correspondent, reported yesterday in a pooled broadcast from Paris.

Plans for the conversion of the home of the late Felix Warburg at 1109 Fifth Avenue into a museum of Jewish historical and cultural objects were filed yesterday at the Department of Housing and Buildings.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (U.P.) -- The Chicago Daily News announced tonight that it will support Gov. T.E. Dewey for President.

Supreme Court Justice Benedict E. Dineen after lengthy examination directed Mrs. Catherine Fromm, superintendent of an apartment building at 520 West 183d Street, yesterday to relinquish custody of Patricia Ann Marron, 16 months old, to her parents who left the child with Mrs. Fromm eleven months ago.
Following is the text of Governor Dewey's address as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Direct mail advertising has been cut almost two-thirds since 1941 and currently is using less than 2 1/2 per cent of all commercial printers' paper, according to figures released yesterday by the Joint Committee on Government Relations of the Commercial Printing Industry.

ROME, Sept. 21 -- The first open published demand that the Allied Control Commission leave Italy and let the Italians "administer our misery alone" was made by Pietro Nenni, secretary of the Socialist party, in today's Avanti.

Automobiles manufactured in 1947 will travel twenty-two miles on a gallon of gasoline, and the 1949 models will go as far as twenty-five miles on a gallon, Albert J. McIntosh, economist for the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, predicted yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 21 -- The French Government expects soon to begin a campaign against the black market and to strive for provisional equilibrium between prices and wages. In so doing it will tackle a major immediate social problem of France -- a problem created by the inflation that resulted from German exactions.

Deeper into the National League cellar sank the Dodgers yesterday as the Pirates took both ends of a double-header at Ebbets Field, 10 -- 4 and 14 -- 6. The two debacles gave Pittsburgh a clean sweep of the series and a record of eighteen triumphs in the season's twenty-two games between the clubs

Clutching bunches of broccoli, carrots and beets, baskets of kohlrabi, corn and tomatoes, and sheaves of swiss chard, 100 East Side boys and girls who are members of the Educational Alliance Gardening Clubs brought their year's crops to be piled high on the harvest table yesterday, topped with the symbol of their victory garden -- the American flag.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Sir Owen Dixon, the Australian Minister, said tonight that he had no pre-Pearl Harbor information that any Japanese task force was about to attack any American territory or take any warlike measures against this country, and had never said so.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 21 -- Prenatal influence in cancer was discussed today by forty authorities in the first of a series of five sessions, organized by Dr. C.C. Little, director of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory, and it was the consensus that cancer is not inherited as such, that is as a disease.

After a two-day debate the convention of the United Rubber Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations affiliate, with a membership of 200,000, reaffirmed yesterday by a vote of more than two to one the no-strike pledge for the duration of the war "without qualification or reservation."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Jefferson Caffery, former ambassador to Brazil, was appointed by President Roosevelt today as "representative of the United States, with the personal rank of Ambassador, to the de facto French authority now established at Paris."

As a result of complaints by Navy and merchant sailors that they had to pay up to $45 in some stores for $28 uniforms, the Office of Price Administration filed injunction suits yesterday in Federal Court against nineteen manufacturers and wholesalers of uniforms doing a nation-wide annual business of $20,000,000.

Production of insulating board for Government use has dropped about 50 per cent since 1942, it was revealed yesterday by Stuart A. Ralph, president of the Insulating Board Institute, Chicago, following a meeting of that organization at the Hotel Biltmore here.

McKesson Robbins. Inc., showed consolidated net profit of $5,161,069 for the fiscal year ended with June, according to the annual report to stockholders issued yesterday by William J. Murray Jr., president. The profit for the previous fiscal year was $5,097,370.

The recent address delivered by Winthrop W. Aldrich represented the studied views of Mr. Aldrich on the Bretton Woods conference negotiation on international agreements. The American people now have the authoritative views of the banking world.

The Board of Estimate made available yesterday to the Park Department and the Presidents of four boroughs a total of $375,000 to be used to repair damaged done to trees and sidewalks by the recent hurricane. The funds will come from accruals and various surplus funds and will be augmented, if necessary, by additional appropriations.

With nurseries in five local hospitals now closed because of outbreaks of diarrhea among newborn babies, Dr. Samuel Frant, director of the bureau of preventable diseases in the New York City Department of Health, admitted yesterday that incidence of the disease here has been "rather more than normal" since June.

PEARL HARBOR, Sept 21 -- Marines fighting in the rugged limestone ridge on Peleliu Island were able to achieve only minor gains yesterday while planes presumably from carriers bombed other islands in the Palau group.

UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Sept. 21 -- The disappearance under ominous circumstances last night of three American military police just outside the American-held town of Roetgen has emphasized the difficulty of the security problems facing our troops in Germany and along its border.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Disapproval of "any policy based on hysterical fear of possible future surpluses and accompanying price decreases rather than on existing supply" was voiced in a press conference today by the Executive Committee of the Consumer Advisory Committee of the Office of Price Administration.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Cardinals clinched their eighth National League pennant and their third in a row today by coming from behind twice to defeat the Braves, 5 -- 4, and 6 -- 5 in ten innings. Southpaw Harry Brecheen, who pitched a total of seven innings during his two relief assignments, drew credit for both victories.

By referring to its committee on general welfare a resolution calling for an investigation of all phases of "rent gouging," the City Council paved the way yesterday for a sweeping inquiry into charges that the "gouging" practices are prevalent in publicly as well as privately owned premises.

PARIS, Sept. 20 (Delayed) -- One of the greatest petroleum distributing systems the world has ever seen pumped gasoline, high-grade aviation fuel and Diesel oil from Cherbourg to the battlefront as it advanced across France and is now ready to push on into Germany.
Lieut. Nelson W. Aldrich, USNR, and Mrs. Aldrich have come to the Chatham from Marblehead, Mass.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept 21 -- Communities that delay the completion of plans for post-war construction projects face a revocation of State grants for drafting the plans, James C. Harding, Westchester County Commissioner of Public Works, said here today on returning from conferences in Albany with the State Post-War Planning Commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- In a message rushed to the Congress before it began its recess today President Roosevelt urged "careful and early" consideration of legislation which would spread Federal establishments patterned after the Tennessee Valley Authority throughout most of the country west of the Mississippi River.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The War Production Board announced today it had reduced by 3,333 tons the allocation of carbon steel for the manufacture of domestic heating and cooking stoves during the fourth quarter of 1944 with the explanation that the supply of that metal was still "acute."

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 21 (U.P.) -- Resurgent Chinese forces, battling desperately to block twin Japanese offensives aimed at splitting embattled China from north to south, have blasted the enemy back out of Yungming, seventy miles east of Kweilin, and checked another strong force driving down the Hunan-Kwangsi railway, forty-five miles northeast of Kweilin, a Chinese communique asserted today.

The sixteen reporting New York City banks which are members of the Federal Reserve System continued last week to sell Treasury certificates, bills and notes in order to straighten out their reserve positions, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday for the week ended on Wednesday.

In his first formal speech of the campaign Vice President Henry A. Wallace declared last night that the problem of the campaign was not one of indispensability but that the only issue confronting the American people was which of two men, President Roosevelt or Governor Dewey, Republican nominee for President, could better handle the following two problems:

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Dr. William H. Johnson, superintendent of Chicago schools, was injured slightly tonight when a dynamite bomb exploded behind his house at 1,228 Farwell Avenue, causing damage estimated at $1,500 and jarring the area within a radius of two blocks.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Optimistic reports on the progress of the war were given reporters here today by both Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War, and James V. Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 21 -- About the time that the football season will he getting into full swing for colleges throughout the country, the end of the campaign will come for Harvard. The Cantabs play Boston College on Oct. 7 and after that the curtain falls, unless additional games can be arranged for November following the examination period for the Navy V-12 trainees.

BARI, Italy, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Military censorship has relaxed one of its most rigid, restrictions so that public recognition may be given Maj. Linn M. Farish of Woodland, Calif., the courageous officer who outfoxed the Germans for twelve months in the Balkans only to die in a plane crash.
ROME, Sept. 21 (U.P.) -- Fifth Army forces today scaled five Emilia Province mountain peaks in an advance toward Futa Pass and probably the decisive battle of the Gothic Line is about to develop.

DALLAS, Tex., Sept. 21 (AP) -- Federal Judge William H. Atwell enjoined the War Labor Board and the Petroleum Administration for War today from seizure of the Humble Oil and Refining Company's plant at Ingleside, near Corpus Christi.

LONDON, Friday, Sept. 22 -- Russian troops racing across the top of Estonia at a mile-an-hour clip yesterday drove to within forty-eight miles of Tallinn, Estonian capital, as another powerful Red Army swept down the western slopes of Rumania's mountain chain and reached the great Hungarian plain only forty- eight miles from Szeged, Hungary's second city.

PARIS, Sept. 20 (Delayed) -- The Germans fled from Paris in such haste they carried out no important demolitions, but they did leave many thousands of tons of high explosives behind them. Lives have already been lost as a result of booby traps and there is a possibility that a concealed charge, may some day touch off a major explosion.

George Romney, managing director of the Automobile Council for War Production, charged last night, in an address at a dinner of the National Industrial Conference Board at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, that the "failure of the Government up to now to authorize preparatory activities for partial reconversion already has lengthened the period of unemployment that will occur during the partial reconversion period if the war in Europe ends before December."

A group headed by Blair Co., Inc., and Maxwell, Marshall Co. will offer today $2,000,000 of Textron, Inc., fifteen-year 5 per cent convertible debentures with detachable warrants for the purchase of common stock. The debentures will be priced at par and accrued interest from Sept. 1, 1944.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, in the Southwest Pacific, Friday, Sept. 22 -- Bombers of the Far Eastern Air Force, continuing attacks against tightly drawn Japanese communications, sank or damaged more than a dozen enemy vessels in a series of blows ranging from Truk to the Philippines and struck heavily at Japanese island airdromes and supply depots.
CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 21 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

The women and children still alive in Warsaw can be saved through immediate relief action, a group of exiled citizens of that city declared yesterday in a statement urging the organization of a special emergency committee of Americans.

A new record was set yesterday at City College when Rene Gnade, 36-year-old refugee student, began attending classes for the fifteenth consecutive year. Mr. Gnade, who entered the College of Liberal Arts and Science in 1929, earned the degree of Bachelor of Science last June and is now taking advanced courses in organic chemistry and qualitative analysis requisite to his admission to the Veterinary School at the University of Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The United States and Great Britain, on the basis of decisions taken at the Quebec conference last week, are drafting a post-armistice directive to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower that will result in the strictest possible control of German industry and the ruthless elimination of all elements of the Nazi party.

MONTREAL, Sept. 21 -- Dean Acheson, assistant secretary of State and member of the council of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, announced today that the United States proposal for relief to Italy does not provide for the shipment of food supplies to that country, except for the "displaced" persons of other nationalities, mostly Yugoslavs, who were in Italy.

It was a dark day to begin and when the Cubs shelled Bill Voiselle for seven runs in the first inning of the first game, it did not get any lighter yesterday at the Polo Grounds. In the end, literally and figuratively, it should not have been much darker, for Chicago bagged both ends of the double-header, just about ruining whatever chance the Giants had to finish in the first division.

It is easy to become sated even with death when someone else is doing the dying. It is easy, when our own lives are not in danger, to become complacent over the hazards others are facing for our sakes. It is easy to forget after years of war that there once was peace and will be again.

Thomas B. Costain, author of the recently published historical novel, "Ride With Me," is taking an extended leave of absence from his post as an associate editor of Doubleday, Doran to devote himself to the completion of his next book, a historical novel of the thirteenth century in England and China.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- James F. Byrnes, director of War Mobilization, ordered Government agencies today to put into effect at once procedures deigned to aid in an orderly reconversion of industry by providing both management and labor with advance information relating to war-production cutbacks.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 21 -- The Government this evening closed the noon newspaper Momento Argentino and arrested its editor. The reason for the measure is that the newspaper today printed a message from Berlin stating that an anti-United States movement had broken out in Brazil and that President Getulio Vargas had been ousted.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 21 -- The Allies' penetration of the Rhineland and the successful landing of Anglo-American airborne troops in the Netherlands have brought the question of compulsory evacuation of densely populated areas to the forefront of German military consideration.

Facilities in New York City for the rehabilitation of men rejected or discharged by the armed forces for neuropsychiatric reasons are "far short of needs," and only a small percentage receive psychiatric care, according to a report made public yesterday by the New York City Committee on Mental Hygiene of the State Charities Aid Association.

More than 179 persons visited the City Vacancy Listing Bureau in the Pershing Square Information Center yesterday, the second day that the bureau has been open. This was an increase over the 136 who had called there on the previous day.

ST. LOUIS, Sept 21 (AP) -- The Browns moved a half game behind the first place Tigers tonight by defeating the Senators, 9 to 4. Nelson Potter was credited with the victory, making his season's total 17, against 7 defeats. Emil (Dutch) Leonard was charged with the loss.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Chungking in English to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

Two of the recent newcomers to the Roaring Forties will wind up brief engagements tomorrow night. Reluctantly bowing out are "The Day Will Come," at the National, and "Last Stop," at the Barrymore. The first will have tarried for twenty performance, while the latter will have attained the twenty-three mark.

Revealing a zest for combat that a man half his age might be proud of, Lieut. William C. Fleming, 45-year-old bombardier who recently completed fifty-seven missions with the Italy-based Twelfth Air Force, expressed the hope yesterday that the Army might consider favorably his request for service in B-29 Super-Fortresses.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 17 (Delayed) -- The present Fatherland Front Government has no intention of establishing a Communist regime in Bulgaria, Anton Yugoff, Communist Minister of Interior in the Georgieff Cabinet, reiterated today.
Increased hedge-selling brought about yesterday a slightly easier cotton futures market, and prices on the New York Cotton Exchange finished at or near the lows of the day, 9 to 12 points net lower.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull, tersely pointing up one aspect of a hard peace for Germany, said today that a lot of Germans were going to be shot when the war was over.

The reconversion legislation which has now gone to the President meets some of the more pressing problems that directly affect labor. It provides a guarantee for the State unemployment funds. Wisely it preserves the State unemployment insurance plans that have long been established, and voids the extravagant alternatives that had been suggested.
I remember reading about a booklet that was issued to our boys before they landed in Africa on how to act in strange lands. This seemed like a very sound idea.

FRANK MENKE, the sports statistician and historian, recently contributed an out-of-the-ordinary turf tale to the Overseas Edition of The Sporting News Since this publication goes only to the G.I Joes all over the world and is not for sale, this reporter is taking the liberty of letting the civilians back home in on the story.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- President Roosevelt has returned from his war conference at Quebec with Prime Minister Churchill and devoted much of today on drafting of the political speech with which he will open his campaign for a fourth term on Saturday night.

The sound of the axe echoes through the woodland and the sawmen are busy clearing, cleaning, salvaging, trying to make the best of the hurricane's damage. That damage varies from district to district even from street to street in the towns, but few sections in this area escaped it completely.

Revealing a zest for combat that a man half his age might be proud of, Lieut. William C. Fleming, 45-year-old bombardier who recently completed fifty-seven missions with the Italy-based Twelfth Air Force, expressed the hope yesterday that the Army might consider favorably his request for service in B-29 Super-Fortresses.

In a move designed to prepare now for better post-war promotion of all phases of the bituminous coal industry, the Bituminous Coal Institute recently held a meeting in Cleveland where advertising, publicity an sales executives made suggestions for the furtherance and betterment of the program, it was announced yesterday.

The National Citizens Political Action Committee and its parent group, the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, are backing, either openly or informally, two Republican candidates for the United States Senate and one for the House of Representatives, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The Office of Price Administration today ordered increases ranging from 1 to 5 per cent in manufacturers' price ceilings of several cotton knitted heavyweight undergarments to bring maximums into line with specifications set forth in the Stabilization Extension Act.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 22 -- Samuel Goldwyn has sold his screen play of the Edward Chodorov stage play "Those Endearing Young Charms" to RKO Radio, where it is planned for immediate production by Bert Granet, starring Laraine Day.

Mrs. Muriel Bachant of 1627 University Avenue, the Bronx, mother of five-months-old triplets, whose husband, Pvt. Herbert Bachant, was reported Thursday to have been killed in action in France, disclosed yesterday that her appeal for help in caring for her children has been answered.

ALSACE-LORRAINE, France, Sept. 22 -- The German High Command threw in fresh forces of armor today against the American Third Army's steel tentacles probing toward the Reich and a furious tank struggle went into its fourth day.

Fear that Mayor La Guardia has left the private flier and the small airport out of his post-war aeronautical plans for the city was expressed last night at a meeting of representatives of more than a majority of the counties in the metropolitan area called to develop a regional airport plan for presentation to Congress through the Civil Aeronautics Administration.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
