WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 George P. McNear Jr., president of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad Company, now in the possession of the director of the Office of Defense Transportation under an executive order of the President, appeared today in person to argue before division four of the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to borrow $100,000 by the issuance of promissory notes to cover that amount.

It is an ironic but also a very human situation that the two American citizens who stand the poorest chance of winning a popularity contest in any Soviet publication are Herbert Hoover and William C. Bullitt.

A caravan of armored trucks and jeeps that had been in service through the African, French and Italian campaigns rolled into Times Square yesterday to display examples of 3,000 war vehicles now in metropolitan ordnance shops awaiting 500 mechanics and helpers to repair them.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22 -- The chief engineer of the Dnieprostroi Dam disclosed today that the Germans had made a desperate unsuccessful effort in the winter of 1943 to completely blow up the great dam across the Dnieper River at Zaporozhye, which the Russians themselves had partly destroyed in August, 1941, as part of their "scorched earth" policy when Soviet troops were falling back before the then mighty Wehrmacht.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 22 -Sixteen members of the Hudson County grand jury, April Term, were publicly rebuked today by Common Pleas Judge Horace K. Roberson at a hearing on contempt of court proceedings against the jurors.

BOSTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Braves took the final game of their three-game series with the Cardinals, 11 to 2, today with Nate Andrews hanging up his fifteenth victory. Boston collected fourteen hits off three pitchers, featured by a five-run outbreak in the fifth inning.

Lloyd G. Hertzler, formerly sales manager of the vacuum cleaner division and more recently with the morale program of the General Electric Company's Bridgeport plant, has been appointed sales manager of the company's home laundry equipment division.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 22 -- The statisticians dominated the discussions today on parental influence in cancer at the conference which is being held here under the auspices of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory with leading authorities on cancer participating.

Frank Costello, gambler and slotmachine operator, was ordered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora to testify before Deputy Police Commissioner Cornelius O'Leary in the license revocation proceedings against the Copacabana night club, and was held guilty of contempt "in a technical sense" for his refusal to testify.

The reconversion of manufacturing facilities in this city from war to consumer goods production, already begun, soon will augment the short supply of vacuum cleaners, wire coat hangers, metal Venetian blinds and other civilian goods, it was learned yesterday.

Primarily because of a shortage of cardboard containers, only 341,000 children in 245 of the city schools are receiving milk at 2 cents a half pint, compared with the 590,000 youngsters in 433 schools who were being served at the end of last term, it was learned yesterday.

The joint legislative committee to investigate commercial rents in New York City will begin public hearings o Oct. 5 at 10 A.M. in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street, Assemblyman D. Mallory Stephens of Brewster, N.Y., announced last night.

Negotiations between Brock Pemberton and operators of the Forty-eighth Street Theatre were concluded yesterday whereby the former's production of "The Pooka," Mary Chase's comedy, will open at that playhouse on Nov. 1. Rehearsals begin next week under Antoinette Perry's direction.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Justice Department said that Mrs. Raissa Berkman Browder, wife of Earl Browder, a Communist leader, had returned to this country from Canada on a visa.

Four, including Bolingbroke and Devil Diver, are named for the $15,000 added Manhattan Handicap, mile and one-half fixture today at Belmont Park, where all receipts will be donated to war charities. It will be the seventh war relief day on New York tracks this season and is expected to add $100,000 to a fund already past $750,000.

Active bidding in the beverage and aircraft issues produced yesterday a better tone in the stock market, although interest in the list generally continued to slacken. Despite the enlargements of value in these groups, the market remained semi-static.

A five-man committee to investigate statements that Ferdinand Smith, national secretary of the Nationalk Maritime Union, is an alien and consequently ineligible to office under the union's constitution was named yesterday by Joseph Curran, NMr president.

The recommendation that penalties be imposed on landlords and accrue to the benefit of tenants for violations of the Multiple Dwelling Law was made yesterday at the close of the public hearing conducted by the Joint Legislative Committee to Recodify the Multiple Law, held in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-second-Street.
A communique, as broadcast yesterday from Ckungking in English to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

BANGOR, Me., Sept. 22 -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio declared tonight that the words of Sidney Hillman were proof of the fellowship and alliance which now exists between Earl Browder "and his Communists and Hillman and his Political Action Committee."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration is on record with an apology for sending an Ohio farmer's wife 30,000 words about turkeys without including the information she had requested -- ceiling prices.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -A group of anti-Roosevelt Democrats called together by Senator Smith of South Carolina organized a "National Agricultural Committee" today to fight a fourth term for President Roosevelt.

A brilliant red dahlia, twelve inches in diameter, was judged yesterday to be the largest and most perfect bloom in the thirtieth annual Flower Show of the American Dahlia Society, which ended a two-day display at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.

Flotations of new bonds contined large this week, the total again exceeding $100,000,000, but falling below the two and one-half year weekly record figure made last week. Five new issues of bonds aggregating $109,250,000 were offered publicly here, against seven for $131,870,000 a week ago and a single issue of $1,250,000 in this week last year.

PARIS, Sept. 22 -- In the initial measure toward restarting French industry, Robert Lacoste, Minister of Production, has ordered that firms that had been working for German accounts should work in the same proportion for the French state.

Frank Munk, author of "The Legacy of Nazism," published in 1943 by Macmillan, is leaving for England to assist in establishing a training center there for overseas workers for the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration.
CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 22 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- In expectation of large-scale selling of Government-owned aircraft when hostilities cease, W.L. Clayton, surplus war property administrator, outlined today regulations to govern sales of this equipment by the disposal agencies, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Foreign Economic Administration.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 22 -- Housewives on their first factory jobs have walked away with most of the awards won by women for suggestions to increase production of Curtiss Helldiver dive bombers, according to officials of the Curtiss Wright Corporation here.

Reflecting the sharp increase in new financing in recent weeks, most of it for refunding purposes, the total of outstanding bonds called for redemption in the next two months before maturity dates has mounted this month and now exceeds $200,000,000.

The Japanese Domei agency and the Japanese-controlled Manila radio said yesterday that the attacks by United States carrier planes against the Manila area of the Philippines continued Thursday and Friday. They stated that the new strikes were concentrated "on harbor facilities and also the airfield."

ROME, Sept 22 (AP) -- The American column that reached within a mile of the Futa Pass, where the Germans are believed to have installed some of their most formidable defenses, were pushing along strategic Highway No. 65. Rain and low visibility precluded air support for the attacking Americans.

Red Cross home nursing classes are being organized in the financial district with the support of twenty-eight leading banks, companies and other institutions. The New York chapter of the American Red Cross is assisting in organizing the classes and supplies registered nurses as instructors.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 22 -- A plant hormone preparation, a free-flowing explosive which will detonate even after prolonged immersion in water and a method of purifying pyrethrum are among the 506 inventions reported in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

The silk shirt of World War I has been succeeded by the sports shirt in World War II, to the detriment of regular dress shirt supply, according to men's wear buyers now in the market seeking replacements on the latter for the fall and holiday selling seasons.

Six-year-old Joseph Jezik Jr. was back home last night, tired, still clutching a live turtle, and satisfied about fulfilling his wanderlust. But how Joseph reached Stamford, Conn. -- "trolley and train" were his words -- without any money and without being the cynosure of curious eyes, was still something of a mystery when he went to sleep at his home, 406 East Seventy-second Street.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, Sept. 23 -- Firing until the Dutch houses that they were using as strong points crashed about them, British and Polish airborne troops were reported to be fighting grimly to hold their "patch of hell" in the Arnhem area last night until British armor, plowing north from Nijmegen, could relieve them.

A departure from the customary procedure in corporate financing, particularly in a sale of new securities by competitive bidding, took place yesterday when the Gulf States Utilities Company accepted one of two offers made by banking groups to assist it in making an offer of an exchange of shares.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -Cities on the East, West and Gulf coasts, from New York to Los Angeles would become air gateways to Latin America under plans of twenty-one airline and steamship companies being outlined to the Civil Aeronautics Board.

Vira Service has purchased from the estate of Edward P. Gunther the service station on the triangular plot at Hudson Boulevard, Fourteenth Street, Fifteenth Street and Kerrigan Avenue, Union City, N.J. Originally developed as a service station by the late Mr. Gunther, the station later was operated by Eckel Brothers and then by the Shell Company.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- On the eve of their important National Football League opener against the Green Bay Packers, the champion Chicago Bears announced tonight that sharpshooting Sid Luckman, star quarterback, had signed a contract for the full 1944 season and will rejoin the club here tomorrow.

In Topics of The Times the writer states that the matter of the age at which a man does his best work is an intriguing question and that the record is full of examples where productive power continues without diminution until 75 or 80.

Reminiscent of "Friday payroll" field days for organized thugs in the Twenties, a hold-up wave struck the city yesterday with four major robberies, all carried out in daylight, netting armed stick-up men a total of $43,000.
I feel much interested in Pearl Buck's letter in the Sept. 19 issue of your paper.
ROME, Sept. 22 (AP) -- A communique:

The eight-story Palace Hotel, at 132 West Forty-fifth Street, has been sold by Minnie Sobel to an investing client of Emanuel Goldberg, attorney. It is on a lot 35 by 100 feet, between Broadway and Sixth Avenue, and is assessed at $135,000.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Although business in today's stock markets was restricted somewhat by the week-end, the general tone was cheerful and support was given to various industrial issues. There were buyers for chain-store shares and prices improved.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- President Roosevelt and Governor nor Dewey have written the Senate Campaign Expenditure Committee on contributions and expenditures in connection with their campaigns.
KORNELIMUENSTER, Germany, Sept. 22 -- Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York celebrated his first mass in Germany since 1932, in the thirteenth century Church of St. Kornelius, here today.

PARIS, Sept. 22 -- In the historic room of the Foreign Ministers in the Quai D'Orsay, Foreign Minister Georges Bidault, who a few weeks ago was a hunted leader of the underground, called upon the Allies today to recognize the de Gaulle Government de jure without further delay and to admit France into the councils of Allied powers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Investigators for the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee will be sent to Texas soon to inquire into the part being taken by Senator O'Daniel "and his organization'' in the election campaign, Chairman Green, Democrat, of Rhode Island, said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- In-plant feeding has proved its worth during the war and will be continued in many plants as a peacetime measure, industrial owners and managers have told the Industrial Feeding Division of the War Food Administration.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 22 -- Under an agreement between the Swiss Bankers Association and the Swiss National Bank, American dollar and British pound notes have been taken off the trading lists of Swiss Bourses, thus closing virtually the last loophole in Europe through which illegally seized Allied nations, banknotes might have been traded by the enemy and converted into "freer" valuta.

Within a month consumers in New York City will have the opportunity to buy California fruits and vegetables that have been harvested only a day or so before they are put on sale. At least, this is the expectation of American Airlines, Inc., which is setting up a complete air-freight service system, the first of its kind.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced yesterday that it had arrested on Thursday a man it had been seeking since Jan. 27 for violation of the National Stolen Property Act. He was Joseph Mason Warren Miller, 42 years old, who made something of a splash last June in real estate circles here by purchasing the former J.P. Morgan estate on East Island, at Glen Cove, L.I.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 -- Governor Dewey proposed tonight an immediate broadening of the present Social Security system to provide pensions for all. Addressing a large audience in the Coliseum, and a nation-wide radio network, the Republican Presidential candidate demanded increased Social Security of all varieties "forthwith."

Supreme Court Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan denied yesterday a motion by District Attorney Frank Hogan to transfer the extortion trial of Joseph H. Fay and James Bove, labor leaders, from Supreme Court back to the General Sessions.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 -- The Presbyterian Church in the United States of America reported today the largest annual net membership increase in nearly a quarter of a century and the largest total membership in the 238 years of organized Presbyterianism in this country.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- France's Tricolor flew again today over the French Embassy here when the premises, vacant since the Vichy representative was removed to internment at Hershey, Pa., Nov. 17, 1942, were reoccupied by the French.
ROME, Sept. 22 -- The Battle of the Po Valley, which has long been regarded as the inevitable site of the ultimate Battle of Italy, has definitely begun.
HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 22 -- Cornell has all but been crowned on paper as king of the Ivy for the 1944 football season. But let the Ithacans beware, and Yale and Penn, too.
HELSINKI, Sept. 22 -- Eleven Russian members of the Allied Armistice Commission arrived today. They were headed by Pavel Dimitrievitch Orloff, Soviet Minister to Finland after the 1939 winter war.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 22 -- The long rivalry for domination of local Arab politics between Palestine's two leading Moslem families, the Husseinis and the Nashashibi clan, whose leader is a former Mayor of Jerusalem, Ragheb Bey, Nashashibi, has again defeated efforts to create a central Palestinian Arab body that could be represented at the Arab intergovernmental talks opening Monday in Alexandria, Egypt.
Following is the text of Governor Dewey's address, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The best argument, in principle, for "TVA" developments on the Missouri, Arkansas and Columbia Rivers, recommended by the President in a special message to Congress, is the record and present status of the Tennessee Valley Authority. On the Tennessee a coordinated system of dams has lowered flood crests all the way to Cairo, has made possible a growing amount of river freight traffic and has produced power of vital importance for war and for peace.

INSIDE GERMANY, Sept. 22 -- The Germans are fighting in their Siegfried Line with all the stubbornness of the Normandy hedgerow battles and they seem determined to make this the major stand in defense of the Fatherland.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 22 -- A considerable part of the Greek mainland and several important Ionian and Aegean islands have been liberated and placed under the authority either of local representatives of the Papandreou Exile Government, now in Italy, or of officials of patriot and Andartes bands. The liberation of these areas follows a combination of German withdrawals and guerrilla assaults.

A renewal of commission-house buying and considerable local covering steadied the cotton futures market yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, where final prices showed net gains of 1 to 8 points. Prices held within a comparatively narrow range all day.

I was interested in the editorial on "That Cricket" in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 17. Your writer states that "the cricket's customary tempo is eighty beats to the minute," which indicates that he has usually timed crickets only when the evenings have become cool.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The temper of American policy toward defeated Germany has already been set by President Roosevelt, it was learned today on unquestionable authority. It is definitely a very "hard" policy.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, in the Southwest Pacific, Saturday, Sept 23 -- American and Australian fighters, ranging over Japanese island defense lines from the Philippines to Timor, sank or seriously damaged fourteen enemy vessels and forced others ashore, while continuing blistering attacks on enemy airdromes.

ROME, Sept. 22 -- At 2:08 P.M. today, under a blue sky of the Roman countryside, Pietro Caruso was shot in the back, expiating bravely those terrible crimes he had committed in the name of fascism. Justice at the end was quick and merciful.

The former J.P. Morgan town house, at Madison Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, was dedicated yesterday afternoon as a Lutheran Church House by the Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the United Lutheran Church in America.

With early fall trade already off to a good start in most sections of the country, retail volume in the final quarter of the year is likely to rise to new peaks regardless of an early end of the European phase of the war, according to views expressed yesterday in merchandising quarters here.

MONTREALL, Sept. 22 -- The policy committee of the council of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration adopted three resolutions today providing for $50,000,000 for "limited" help to Italy; aid for allied nationals, German Jews and other anti-Nazis found in enemy territory and control of epidemics therein, and a uniform standard of relief for all liberated areas.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- President Roosevelt indicated today that he did not intend to order or request that Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel and Maj. Gen. Walter C. Short, commanders at Pearl Harbor when the Japanese struck on Dec. 7, 1941, be court- martialed before election.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 22 -- In a middle wave broadcast, audible only in some parts of western Sweden during the night, a person claiming to be a German general said he had taken Germany's fate "in my own hands" to lead the beaten army back to the homeland to spare it from being uselessly sacrificed in civil war.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 22 (U.P.) -- Japanese columns streaming into southeastern Kwangsi Province against weak Chinese resistance have captured Wuchow, largest city on China's West River, and Jungyun, sixty-five miles to the southwest, in a double-barreled drive that has rolled 140 miles west of its launching point at Canton, it was disclosed today.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Communique 167:

Mrs. E. Correll, in 290 Park Ave; Frank Bryant, in 580 Park Ave; Alden Hatch, in 1 East End Ave; Maj. Milton Underwood, in 10 Gracie Sq; Francis Blossom, in 40 E 62d St; John F. Reeder, vice president of Young Rubicam, in 45 E 85th St; Mrs. K.H. Ostermann, in 17 E 97th St; Mrs. Ronald Kinnear of Albany, N.Y., in 160 E 48th St -- Douglas L. Elliman Co, brokers.

LONDON, Saturday, Sept. 23 -The Red Army captured the Estonian capital and naval base of Tallinn yesterday, opening up the Gulf of Finland to the Soviet Baltic Fleet, whose airmen sank three transports choked with Nazi troops attempting to escape from the port.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 22 -- Under-Secretary of the Navy Ralph A. Bard cautioned tonight against underestimation of the strength of the Japanese and predicted that the task of defeating them would become increasingly difficult as fighting got nearer to their homeland.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Asserting that "the day of shouting and flag waving is a long way off," John D. Rockefeller Jr., in a speech on behalf of the national war fund tonight at the University of Minnesota outlined a four-point program in war and peace "to bring to fruition the results of the struggle."

LONDON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Twelve hundred American heavy bombers blasted deep into central Germany today from bases in both Britain and Italy, hitting the industrial city of Kassel, the Munich area and other targets, while Allied fighters continued their assault along the flaming battlefront despite thick cloud conditions.

Charles, Count of Flanders, younger brother of King Leopold III of Belgium, before the war a major in the air service, has come back from active service in the underground forces to take the office of Regent The Government-in-Exile, a strictly constitutional body, has thus complied with a constitutional provision.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Saturday, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A coTnrnniqg :

The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday approved the world featherweight championship bout between Titleholder Willie Pep and Challenger Chalky Wright, scheduled for Madison Square Garden on Friday night. The approval was conditional, accompanied by the proviso that Wright carry out a previous agreement to box Jackie Wilson in Washington.

The countryside would lack part of its interest and activity without the busy chipmunk. Tamias is a cosmopolitan sort; he's perfectly at home in the farm dooryard or along the edges of the woodland. He delights in scampering along the uneven tops of weather-grayed stone walls and the top rail of hemstitched-pattern split fences.

The name of the city of Arnhem, in the Netherlands, on the north bank of the north branch of the Rhine, is written in letters of fire and blood today. Arnhem is, or was, a beautiful city in a lovely region. It had many pleasant parks and many tree-shaded avenues. Around it were meadows and forests of beech and oak, kept up with the Dutch neatness which permits no disorderly underbrush.

Vice President Henry Wallace declared yesterday, at two separate press interviews, that he was supporting the entire Democratic ticket and that his failure to mention the name of Senator Harry S. Truman of Missouri, Democratic candidate for Vice President, in his speech at Madison Square Garden Thursday night, was not intentional.

Officials of the Dubuque Bridge Commission, Iowa, have invited bids on Oct. 10 for an issue of $2,800,000 of first mortgage bridge revenue bonds, for which bidders are asked to name one rate of interest for the entire issue. The bonds, dated Nov. 1, 1944, will mature on Nov. 1, 1964, and are to be optional for call from time to time at premiums.

WITH ALLIED AIRBORNE FORCES in the Arnhem Area, Sept. 22 (5 P.M.) -- The British Second Army already has linked up with one isolated airborne force here and is getting nearer to our positions. Already many shells from the Second Army's guns are landing among the Germans behind us while in front of us there is firing from something we hope is the Second Army's armored cars.
O.H. Sandman in today's issue of your paper points out that the Board of Transportation, by cutting its service by one-half on Sundays, saves $71,000 a year.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 22 -- The plan of the New York Cotton Exchange to establish an "export" futures contract won today the approval of Southern members and representatives of the trade at an all-day meeting here presided over by John Scatterty, president of the New York Exchange.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 -- The staff of the public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, already accused of participating in secret negotiations in connection with the proposed reorganization plan of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, was charged today by the same accusers of having also a double standard -- "one for big financial interests which now agree with it, and another for the little individual stockholders who may disagree."

BOSTON, Sept. 22 -- The right of married women to hold municipal jobs in Massachusetts was upheld today by the State Supreme Judicial Court, which ruled unconstitutional the dismissal of six married women employes of Somerville.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Sept. 22 -- The armed services' requirements after V-E-day will mean numerous cotton cloth procurements in addition to those contracted for at the time, Maj. Gen. Edmund B. Gregory, Quartermaster General, stated here today.

WITH BRITISH SECOND ARMY IN NIJMEGEN, the Netherlands, Sept. 21 (Delayed) -- The huge and important highway bridge over the Rhine River, one principal military route to Germany, has fallen intact to the Allies as a result of fierce fighting in which American paratroops did signal work.

Retail trade continued active here this week, with consumer demand for early fall merchandise increasing. Department store volume was estimated as ranging 8 to 10 per cent over the like week last year.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Free-for-all pacers and trotters featured the closing of the Grand Circuit meeting today. King's Counsel, owned by the Baker Stables of St. Charles, Ill., and driven by Harry Fitzpatrick, took the pace.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the Central Vermont Public Service Corporation's issuance and sale of 37,856 shares of $100 par value preferred stock to refinance a like number of shares of $6 dividend series no-par value preferred stock.

CHICAGO, Sept 22 -- Large-scale unemployment after the war will result in the Government's entry into business on a vast scale unless business takes the risks involved in planning greatly expanded production and employment, James M. Cleary, Chicago advertising executive, declared today at the twenty-second annual conference of the National Industrial Advertisers Association.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 128:

Tami Mauriello had plenty of rocky going before he stopped Lee Oma of Detroit at Madison Square Garden last night. The Bronx heavyweight, a top-heavy favorite to win, was on the road to dreamland several times until he put over a crushing right and left to the jaw to put Oma down for the full count in 1:41 of the eighth round.

MAYBE you never even noticed it, but the college football season opened last week. It sneaked in mighty furtively, too; almost as if it was afraid someone would tap it on the shoulder and shout, "Hey, you, where do you think you're going?" Be that as it may, however, it's here and nothing can be done about it.

BOSTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Gov. Walter E. Edge, Republican, of New Jersey, declared tonight that President Roosevelt's re-election would not "change a single strategic plan of the United Service leaders, but his defeat will contribute much to ending a dictatorship in domestic affairs."

ROME, Sept. 22 -- Europe is as riddled with questions as with shell holes. It is a volcano of simmering uncertainties. As an American reporter moves over the rumbling ground -- more firmly than the natives, because he walks on leather soles -- the one thing that strikes him most is that his role is reversed.

Like the baseball season itself, the Giants are slowly folding. And their chances of finishing in the first division are on the wane, too. Mel Ott's harassed band spent yesterday at the Polo Grounds trying to make some headway against the fourth-place Cubs, but without success.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Forces, London, Saturday, Sept. 23 (U.P.) -- The text of Release 113, covering activities of the Allied Military Government in Germany:

Harry S. Fischer has purchased for occupancy from the Brooklyn Trust Company the eighteen-room house and more than twenty acres of land on Westchester Avenue, south of Purchase Street, in Harrison, N.Y. Cullen Dykman represented the seller and Joseph J. Fischer the purchaser.
A communique, as broadcast by the Free Yugoslav radio in English last night and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The summer of 1944, which established five heat records in the New York area and set a new mark for wind velocity, bowed out officially at 12:02 A.M. today after a day of sunny skies, cool breezes and normal temperatures.

There is nothing in the price control law, as enacted by Congress, which makes it a violation for a prospective tenant to offer a bonus to a building employe in an effort to obtain an apartment, Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of OPA, declared yesterday in answer to a letter from the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 22 -- Although their position in the American League pennant race had become increasingly difficult during the afternoon with the twin victories recorded by the Tigers, the Yankees kept their faint hopes still glimmering tonight as they trounced the Indians, 7 to 3, in the opener of a three-game series.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns moved one game behind the league-leading Tigers in the tight American League pennant race by defeating the Athletics, 4 to 2, tonight.

Expecting 3,000,000 Negro votes to be cast in the coming Presidential election, a National Non-Partisan League, a Negro organization, has been formed and will work in seventeen States for the re-election of President Roosevelt, it was announced yesterday by John H. Sengstacke, publisher of The Chicago Defender and honorary chairman of the new organization.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- President Roosevelt urged today that electricity be carried to about 7,000,000 farms and rural homes which have not yet received these facilities under the REA program.
PARIS, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Ten Congressmen, who complained recently that the Army was keeping them from taking a look at the United States war effort in France, arrived here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- President Roosevelt disclosed today that in the Quebec discussions relating to the future of Italy two programs received paramount consideration, and he indicated that he and Prime Minister Churchill were working on plans to make them effective.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Shipyard unions today added their weight to the labor pressure upon wage ceilings, with an AFL union intimating that there may be strikes unless wages are raised. John P. Frey, president of the AFL metal trades department, in a shouting demand upon the War Labor Board, insisted that the Government "honor" a 1942 wage contract or we will take matters into our own hands and use our own judgment."

Average hourly earnings of all wage-earners in manufacturing industries rose in July, according to the National Industrial Conference Board, to reach a new all-time high point of $1.072. This figure, which includes overtime and other monetary compensation, marks the latest peak, according to the Board, in an upward movement which has lasted for eleven years.

Virtue brought its reward yesterday to Mrs. Pauline Wiedermann of 322 East Eighty-sixth Street, a charwoman. She received $100 from the owner, Mrs. Mary Esses of 2151 Sixty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, for finding a diamond ring worth $1,500.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, Sept. 23 -- The first steps toward purging Germany of nazism have been taken by the Allied Military Government, which follows close behind combat troops onto German soil, Supreme Headquarters announced today.

A class of thirty dogs received gilt-seal diplomas last night in commencement exercises in the New York Guard Seventeenth Regiment's Armory, Park Avenue at Thirty-fourth Street, after completing the first ten-week obedience course of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

DETROIT, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Tigers came from behind twice today to capture a double-header from the Red Sox, 7 to 4 and 8 to 6, before a crowd of 12,282 paid, increasing their American League lead to one game over the second-place Browns and three and one-half over the third-place Yankees.
HONOLULU, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Virgil Trucks, former Tiger pitcher, hurled a neat four-hitter today as the Navy blanked the Army, 5 to 0, in the opener of a seven-game Army-Navy baseball series.

Under the stress of farm labor shortages the age provisions of child employment are not being observed, J.E. Sidel, field worker for the National Child Labor Committee, reported in a survey made public yesterday, based on visits last month to up-State farms.

The Commission on a Just and Durable Peace issued a statement yesterday reiterating its desire for a peace based on spiritual principles, but cautioned against any international provision for the use of force that "even in appearance" would be a device through which the strong nations could impose their will upon the weak.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- Bill Goldbeck and Dr. Andrew Virtuoso, of the home club triumphed on a match of cards in the Westchester P.G.A. pro-amateur best-ball event at the Mount Kisco C.C. today.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 21 (Delayed) -- Bulgarians are disturbed because they have not yet received the Allies armistice terms. The Government has not yet been asked to send a new delegation to negotiate an armistice.

Vice President Wallace's speech in this city was a valuable contribution to the Democratic cause by a man who might have felt a sense of grievance in being unceremoniously dropped, as he was, from the Democratic national ticket. Much that he said, perhaps the greater part, was not partisan.

Sales of the Quaker Oats Company in its fiscal year ended on June 30 rose to the record volume of $142,647,173 from $122,178,665 transacted the year before, R. Douglas Stuart, president, declared in the annual statement issued yesterday.

Manila is more than a city and a capital. It is a symbol. Declared an open city by General MacArthur in the early days of the Pacific war, it was ruthlessly attacked by Japanese bombers in contravention of international law. For over two years Japanese soldiers have swaggered through its streets, pillaged its treasures and cuffed its inhabitants, bragging that the Americans never would come back.

United States Attorney James B.M. McNally is resigning his Federal post, it was learned yesterday, and in a few days will begin his campaign for the Supreme Court bench in the First Judicial District -- Manhattan and the Bronx -- for which he is a candidate of the Democratic, American Labor and Liberal parties.

Services of thanksgiving will be held on V-E day in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, as follows: 11 A.M., a service of worship lasting one hour, which will include an address by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell; from noon until 5 P.M., brief services every fifteen minutes, conducted by Dr. Bonnell or the associate pastor, the Rev. Ralph B. Nesbitt.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- President Roosevelt told his news conference today that he was still working on the speech with which, at a dinner of the International Teamsters Union, AFL, he will open tomorrow night his campaign for a fourth term.

LAUREL, Md., Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Christiana Stables, enjoying much success at Laurel Park, added another winner to a long string when High Command drove to a two-length triumph in the Hereford Purse today.

Vito Scaminaci and Bartolo Ferrigno were having red-point trouble yesterday, but theirs was not the usual headache of making their coupons go farther. They were disturbed by an over-abundance of them -- 300,000 points' worth.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- The $1,000,000 County Center here that Westchester "leased" to the Navy Department last spring for conversion into a war factory may be used only for storage or be returned to the county before the lease even emerges from Washington and without one piece of war material being produced, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- President Roosevelt's expression of personal interest in the cartel problem in his recent letter to Secretary Hull, has resulted in the speeding up of an Administration decision with regard to the whole cartel problem, and especially on what to do about German cartels.
LONDON, Sept. 22 (UP) -- A communique, as broadcast today from Berlin:
LONDON, Sept. 22 (UP) -- Military and political developments in the Balkans mounted to a climax today as three Yugoslav Partisan columns struck to within twenty-five miles of Belgrade.

SINCE the wanderings of Barnaby and O'Malley were first trapped into book form we mortals have pursued them vainly, calling names like fantasy, satire, whimsy (perish the thought), hoping to arrest them in an attitude to which we can pay suitable tribute. We might just as well try to fasten the Nobel Prize on a rainbow.

CINDERELLA has turned up in strange company in our time; in Mr. McFee's current story of the sea she calls herself Rosita Ross ( nee Rossman ) a telephone operator from the Bronx enjoying her first luxury cruise in the pre-deluge summer of '29.

Declaring that there could be no compromise with communism, Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, Republican nominee for United States Senator, yesterday again attacked Sidney Hillman, chairman of the CIO Political Action Committee, and Earl Browder, Communist, and asked the voters of Queens if they wanted the Hillman-Browder combination to be a dominating influence in the nation if President Roosevelt should be re-elected.

A very small force acting impartially on behalf of all nations to enforce a known and agreed rule of law, and exercised at an early stage of an aggressor's activities would prevent wars. It would have suppressed the participants in the Mukden incident. It would have stopped the small German expedition into the Rhineland.

Reporting that citizens of all faiths in all parts of the United States had expressed appreciation of the pledges of Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National Chairman, and Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic National Chairman, for a campaign free from racial or religious prejudice, Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, made public yesterday a further appeal for a "clean" campaign.

Rationing is harder on dogs and cats than it is on their owners. When Washington decreed that meat could be obtained only by stamps, a problem was presented. That problem was considered by the War Food Administration and the National Research Council, which turned it over to the Department of Physiology and Biochemistry at Rutgers College, New Brunswick, N.J.

In both political camps last week it was clear that eyes were on the calendar. Nov. 7 was drawing closer. It was time that political axes began to cut wood, that political boilers be stoked, that a full head of steam be built up. The woodlot was the whole country and toilers for both sides were busy at the gleaning.

NOBODY has openly accused Gilbert Peabody of murdering his aunt, Adeline Tillsit, nor has anyone definitely stated that Aunt Adeline was murdered. But whispers are going about -- and Gilbert's wife, who has to bear the brunt of it while Gilbert is at the war, wants to bring the accusation into the open and fight it.

IN "The Road to Serfdom" Friedrich A. Hayek has written one of the most important books of our generation. It restates for our time the issue between liberty and authority with the power and rigor of reasoning that John Stuart Mill stated the issue for his own generation in his great essay, "On Liberty."

Delegates to the ninth annual convention of the United Rubber Workers of America, Congress of Industrial Organizations, endorsed yesterday the re-election of President Roosevelt and went on record for "modernization" of the "Little Steel" formula to permit wage increases commensurate with the actual increase in the cost of living.
SUMMER WELLES, who last September resigned as Under-Secretary of State, will begin a new series of weekly commentaries from 10 to 10:15 P.M. Wednesdays over WOR and Mutual, beginning Oct. 11.

WITH the opening next month of the game bird season in most eastern States, the gunner who is both naturalist and sportsman will again prowl the woodlands in search of woodcock and ruffed grouse, the latter known in northern New England as "pa'tridge."

Sales of the Davison Chemical Corporation in its fiscal year ended on June 30 rose $3,816,229 over those in the previous year to $25,448,492, but earnings before taxes of $2,500,632 were only slightly higher than those of $2,460,366 the year before, the report of Chester F. Hockley, president, disclosed yesterday.

WHEN it comes to Seabees, William Bradford Huie, formerly of The American Mercury and now a lieutenant (j.g.) in the Navy's Construction Battalions, makes no pretense of being unbiased. Right at the start of "Can Do!" -- a racy handbook detailing the fabulous accomplishments of the Seabees, and considerably more rewarding than its title would indicate -- he says, "this narrative is a good-humored entry in the who's-winning-the-war argument.

New applications for aid in obtaining living quarters will not be accepted this week at the New York City Vacancy Bureau in Pershing Square. The staff, meanwhile, will concentrate on finding homes for the 746 persons who have applied for aid since the service was opened Wednesday, Joseph Platzker, deputy commissioner of the Department of Housing and Buildings, said last night.
