Following is the text of President Roosevelt's speech before the Teamsters Union as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

HOW does an aviation cadet feel in the clutches of a discrimination reaction test? What does he think about on his first night flight? And what are his thoughts when, as a bomber pilot, he sets out on his first mission over France?

Gradual building up of their open-to-buy position to take advantage of the gradual return of better goods to the wholesale markets with the end of the European war is being planned by many retailers, a survey here last week disclosed. Emphasis on this policy was described as a logical development arising from present merchandise inventories.

STOCKHOLM (By Wireless). I HAVE just come out of Berlin. Whoever knows the city from before the war would have the greatest difficulty in recognizing the present collection of ruins in Germany's prosperous pre-war capital. The resemblance to the old city is almost nil.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23 -- The Browns did it again tonight and stayed one game behind the leading Tigers in the American League pennant race by defeating the Athletics, 3 to 1.
BOSTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Secretary Morgenthau is studying the taxation for Federal revenue of the wagers placed at race tracks throughout the country in pari-mutuel betting, he said today.

The floodwaters of nazism's bitter inland sea are in these days withdrawing on all fronts. A series of maps projected on a motion-picture screen would be necessary to tell the story of the advance and recession of this savage flood. Only two years ago this week Hitler's empire included more of Europe than the Roman emperors ever held, more than Napoleon ever firmly grasped.

Intensified consumer interest in the quality, performance and value of textile products has resulted in a marked increase in the use of yarn identification labels. A check of suppliers of well-known brands of cotton and rayon yarns disclosed that last week, although the availability of yarns for civilian use has not increased, the demand for labels has grown to a great extent.

In extreme contrast to the temperature, the Dodgers were hotter than a firecracker under the Ebbets Field lights last night as they romped wildly around the bases to beat the Cubs, 12 -- 3, and emerge from the National League cellar by one percentage point.
Ethelbert Smith confessed that in his idle moments he has lately been playing with the idea of writing a novel about people after the war, say about the year 1960.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- The major question before the annual convention of the American Bankers Association, which will be opened on Monday in the Stevens Hotel here, is the position to be taken by the bankers on the conclusions reached on the international monetary proposals considered at Bretton Woods.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Prime Minister Stanislaw Mikolajczyk of the Polish Government in Exile today informed President Wladislaw Raczkiewicz that his Cabinet had decided that Gen. Kazimierz Sosnkowski, commander of the regime's army, must either resign or be removed. Because Mr. Raczkiewicz promised the late Prime Minister Wladislaw Sikorske in 1939 that he would be guided by the advice...

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 23 -- Cornell's Big Red football team tonight registered the first victory it has ever scored in Archbold Stadium, beating Syracuse's inexperienced eleven, 39 to 6. A crowd of 20,000 attended.

A motorist in a speeding car ran down and injured four men, one critically, early yesterday to avenge a punch in the nose, the police charged as they arrested Constantino Coste, 33-year-old furrier, of 23-06 Twenty-first Avenue Astoria, Queens, on a complaint of felonious assault.

Eighty-seven Spars, the first group of women received in a Hospital Corps training school of the Coast Guard, were graduated yesterday at Columbia University's College of Pharmacy, 115 West Sixty-eighth Street.

ROME, Sept. 23 (AP) -- American forces have smashed through the center of the Gothic Line and are looking down on the Po Valley, it was disclosed tonight, while the British Eighth Army on the east coast, fighting out to the Po plains, has pushed the Germans out of strategic road and rail positions.

Tax revenues for the fiscal year 1944 of Federal, State and local governments in the United States totaled more than $55,000,000,000, a world record, according to estimates and compilations that are being carried on at the Tax Institute, an organization of tax economists, accountants and administrators.
BOSTON, Sept. 23 -- The text of Gov. John W. Bricker's speech today read as follows:

Autumn and the Pirates hit the Polo Grounds simultaneously yesterday and fashioned a frosty afternoon for the Giants, as well as some 3,749 die-hard fans who sat shivering in the stands. Getting hot only long enough to slip unexpectedly into an eighth-inning tie, the Giants finally were clubbed into submission in the thirteen inning, 6 to 4.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The White Sox defeated Washington, 5 to 4, tonight to move into sixth place in the American League, ahead of the Athletics. Bill Dietrich went the route for his sixteenth victory.

JUDGING from an increasing number of stories of the far North it would seem hard not to write a good book about that frozen locale. This is one of the best of them. Cpl. Zack Denny of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, heading across the Mackenzie district to the sea on the trail of reindeer rustlers, is puzzled when he finds a stranger in a shelter cabin.

TO one kind of reader, who sees "with," not "thro" the eye -- Blake's phrase -- Jean Stafford's "Boston Adventure" will seem unsatisfactory, and he will wonder what kind of adventures she really had and why she did not write about those.
AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 23 (AP) -- A new party which will file its own slate of Presidential electors was organized today by a group of anti-Roosevelt Democrats in a closed convention.

The Rev. Dr. Israel Goldstein, in his sermon yesterday morning at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street, west of Broadway, said that the recent announcement by the British War Office that a Jewish brigade would be formed "is a belated but nevertheless welcome token of recognition of the Jewish part in the war effort, particularly the contribution of Jewish Palestine."

THE last of Sergei Rachmaninoff's four piano concerti has been committed to records and released by Victor, with the great Russian pianist-composer-conductor as soloist (Album DM-972, four twelve-inch records). As a recording it is no great shakes, but as a musical document it is both interesting and important.

AFTER an ambitious spurt a fortnight ago, the new local art season has ambled rather than sped toward the full-scale activity that ere long may be expected to develop. There were only eight openings last week, comment on which appears on this page today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 -- West Coast newspapers had two stories vying for first-page apace this week, the war and Thomas E. Dewey. The war got the banner-line display in most cases, but Governor Dewey's campaign down the 1,300-mile coastline between Seattle and Los Angeles was the domestic development that kept the Coast's attention for the moment.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Danny Litwhiler went on a batting rampage against his former teammates to lead the Cardinals to a 6-2 victory over the Phillies today. Litwhiler hit a single, triple and home run, driving in four runs. His fourteenth homer of the season came in the seventh with two on base.

PARIS, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Reports by travelers today said Spanish Republicans who fled their country in 1939 when Generalissimo Francisco Franco won the civil war are striking back by seizing his consulates in a number of French cities.
Topcoats were hurriedly taken from storage yesterday, the first day of autumn, as the mean temperature in the city registered 8 degrees below the normal 65 for the day.

The scrap iron and steel market is demoralized at present because of the virtual cessation of steel-mill buying for the last four to six weeks. Because of this condition, certain outstanding dealers in the trade are urging early consideration of the establishment of a "futures" market in scrap steel.

AFTER two winters of fuel skimping -- first on oil, then on coal -- most householders have come to appreciate the advantages of a heat-worthy house, properly insulated, weatherstripped, fitted with storm windows. But the average fuel consumer still has much to learn, say heating experts, about the efficient operation of the heater itself to get the maximum amount of heat from every ounce of fuel burned.

Damien Parer, 33 years old, Paramount News war correspondent, has been reported by the Navy Department as having been killed in action by enemy machine-gun field fire on Sept. 17 while filming front-line operations at Peleliu Island, east of the Philippines, Paramount News announced here yesterday.

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in the Southwest Pacific, Sunday, Sept. 24 -- Far-ranging planes of the Far Eastern Air Force and Navy air patrols, continuing strikes against Japanese communications, sunk twelve additional Japanese vessels ranging from supply-laden barges to small freighters on Wednesday and Thursday, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's communique today announced.

ABOARD THE DEWEY SPECIAL TRAIN, Sept. 23 -- Governor Dewey headed eastward today, on the homestretch of the 8,000-mile coast-to-coast trip which he started on Sept. 7. He has one more major address, in Oklahoma City, on Monday.

TIME and hard work are needed to repair the damage brought to home grounds and gardens by the recent storm. What to do and when and how to do it and results to be expected are to be judged by the experiences of 1938.
LONDON, Sept. 23 (UP) -- A communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

"NIGHT UNTO NIGHT" takes a young wife whose husband has been killed in war almost before her eyes and paints her anguish in the prismatic colors of slick-paper romance. It takes a courageous and brilliant man who foreknows his own doom, and surrounds his destruction with the plot ingenuities and scientific flourishes of a detective story.

Over many individual steel plants fly pennants signifying Army-Navy E and Maritime M awards. Now, however, the steel industry as a whole, as represented by the American Iron and Steel Institute, has been honored by the bestowal of the Ordnance Distinguished Service Award.

Hand-picked industrial shares advanced yesterday to new highs for the year on the New York Stock Exchange. The rest of the market was firm and quiet, with volume for the two-hour session 311,910 shares, against 275,240 shares at the previous week-end.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Post-war planning for the country's agriculture is geared to one basic objective, continued full use of the tremendous productive capacity of American farms, according to top officials of the Department of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A fact-finding panel of the War Labor Board made a report today on issues in a dispute between the General Motors Corporation and the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, CIO.

CONCURRENTLY with the opening of the New York War Fund campaign American philately, functioning through a volunteer committee of collectors, dealers and writers, inaugurated a movement last week to raise part of the $17,200,000 which the New York War Fund seeks.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 23 -- Byron Nelson, record-breaking top-money winner of the season, teamed with Edmund H. (Eddie) Driggs Jr., metropolitan amateur golf titleholder, to defeat Harold (Jug) McSpaden and the P.G.A. president, Ed Dudley, by 2 up, in a benefit exhibition match at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today before about 1,200.
Ruth Cranston's article, "The Myths of the League Battle" in THE TIMES Magazine, contains confusion of fact so misleading that it amounts to public misinformation.

WASHINGTON, Sept 23 (U.P.) -- Chester Bowles, director of the Office of Price Administration, described today as "routine," "preliminary," "confidential," and inconclusive a report yesterday by economists of the OPA in which conclusions were drawn that the steel industry could absorb wage increases without raising prices.

When Adolf Hitler built the Siegfried Line he wove into it the natural defenses of the mountains and rivers of the Reich's western border, the stout walls or fortress cities, the steel and concrete of complex tank barriers, the firepower of large and small guns in heavy emplacements.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Harried officials in the Veterans Administration and half a dozen other Federal agencies now hope to complete within a few weeks regulations governing loans under the Service Men's Readjustment Law.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Relations with the Farrell regime in Argentina, which the United States steadfastly refuses to recognize, constitute our chief political problem in South America, but as the European war is proceeding into its final stages this is not our only problem.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Storm-tossed perennials, especially chrysanthemums, should be restaked and tied. . . . Other battered perennials which have finished blossoming may be cut back as in preparation for winter. . . . Grapes should be picked and used as soon as ripe, for they cannot be stored successfully. . . . Newly rooted sections of climbing roses and other plants layered in early summer can be cut off and transplanted.

THE automobile industry in a thoroughly documented statement last week, made plain its belief that the American public is being misled grievously about reconversion and that when millions of unemployed are walking the streets in search of jobs the true course of current development will come as belated and sad knowledge.

LONDON, Sept. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Huddersfield Town today retained the distinction of being the only unbeaten team in England's major soccer with a thrill-packed victory that topped a full program witnessed by an aggregate of more than 300,000 for thirty-nine games.

The demand in the better and medium price coat and suit market was mainly for gabardine suits last week, especially black types, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Sept. 22 (Delayed) Chats with soldiers in New Guinea indicate that a considerable percentage are uninterested in the Presidential elections and that many will not vote.

ARTUR RODZINSKI is beginning his forthcoming Philharmonic-Symphony season with two novelties, a survey of programs for the first two weeks shows. The initial concerts on Oct. 5 and 6 will include the first performance of a revised version of John Alden Carpenter's "Sea Drift," which the composer completed just a year ago.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 23 -- Although the scoreboard offered no encouragement, what with the Tigers hammering the Red Sox inning after inning, the Yankees continued to hold grimly to their slender American League flag hopes today as they won their second straight game from the Indians, 7 to 2.

THIS collection consists of the statements of Secretary Stimson, made mostly to the press, from four days after Pearl Harbor until two days after the invasion of France. These plain and colorless statements afford a quick resume of the progress on all battlefronts from December, 1941, to June, 1944, with particular reference to the accomplishments of our own troops.

A TEMPORARY exhibition of paintings and small sculpture by European and American artists is being held at the Buchholz Gallery, which has just reopened in enlarged and redecorated quarters. The sculpture includes small bronzes by Despiau, Renoir and Lechaise and characteristic pieces by Lipchitz and Flannagan.

LONDON, Sunday, Sept. 24 (AP) -- American and British planes swarmed out across the Channel from Britain yesterday in direct support of Allied ground forces on the German border and in the Netherlands and other American planes struck at the Reich from the south.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Disputes at sixty-seven Government-operated coal mines were handed over to a special coal panel of the War Labor Board for investigation today. Secretary Ickes, operating the mines, requested the action.

The Central West produced last week a pioneering step in higher education when 800 prospective students at the University of Chicago completed a three-day placement test which would admit them irrespective of their high school credits or previous educational training.

As the Philippines again figure prominently in the news, many an American in his fifties or sixties may be thinking back to Admiral George Dewey, the Battle of Manila Bay, Aguinaldo, Funston and -- perhaps as important as anything else -- the little army of American school teachers who went out after the end of the "insurrection."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Establishment of a commission for children and young people in the Office of War Mobilization and Reconversion to curb juvenile delinquency was recommended in the report made today by the Pepper subcommittee on Wartime Health and Education.

PARIS, Sept. 23 -- The French Government has asked a neutral nation to take over the protection of French prisoners of war in the same way the Swiss look after American and British prisoners, who, for this reason, fare better than the French, French officials here said yesterday.

A MEMBER of the Polish underground has informed Roy Publishers that Sofia Kossak -- who was interned, under another name, in a concentration camp in Poland for underground activities -- has escaped after seven months' imprisonment.

DR. ALBERT SHAW has to his credit a very long and distinguished career as an editor and author. Sixty years ago he received his Ph.D. degree from Johns Hopkins University, and it is appropriate that the very same university where the Albert Shaw lectures on diplomatic history have been given since 1899 is now publishing a volume by him.

THE artistry of Ethel Barrymore at long last has come to radio's door. Now the uncounted who are listeners can share regularly the treat of hearing one of the theatre's great ladies give lilt and wing to mere words and lift from the dramatist's cold pages the characterization that makes for a performance.

MIAMI, Sept. 23 -- The last class in Pan American Airway's school for aerial navigators will graduate next Saturday and the school will be closed. In four years it has trained almost 5,000 Army, Navy and Royal Air Force cadets, with 1,500 having been decorated for gallantry according to last reports available.

GENERAL EISENHOWER'S ADVANCED ARMY POST in France, Sept. 23 -- Exuding quiet confidence, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower declared today that Germany's military situation was hopeless. The length of the European war depends, he continued, on two main factors: First, how long the Germans can stand the terrific pounding that they are taking from the west, south and east, and, secondly, how long the Gestapo remains in control of the Reich.

Are the networks serious about developing new talent or will it be the old story? John Royal certainly knows talent if anybody does, but will he be able personally to de velop talent? Then who is going to do it? And how is the talent to place itself in position to be developed? Ask any aspiring and gifted youngster who has been "through the mill" of auditions and what comes after that happened.

Some of the objectives sought to be brought about by the post-war tax plan outlined in this column in recent weeks are: To encourage the investment of venture capital in new industry; to raise sufficient revenue to meet a not unreasonable post-war budget; to create a simplified and sound tax system.

THE aviation field has produced two books which nicely complement each other. Between them they cover the field in time and present extent so adequately that few settlers of bets can afford to be without them. From John P.V. Heinmuller's "Man's Fight to Fly" you can learn almost anything of the thrust into the air from Leonardo da Vinci on.

THE publication of the proceedings of the Writers' Congress held last October in Los Angeles may prove an important event in American cultural history. For the screen, radio, publicity, song writers and cartoonists of the nation have made a solemn declaration of their responsibilities and, in effect, served notice on the entertainment industry that they are about to take over Hollywood.

"AIRBORNE operations on the scale on which we will conduct them are the forward pass which will open up the whole war." Lieut. Gen. Lewis Hyde Brereton bit off the words so that they seemed to march forth in platoons rather than issue in sentences. He leaned forward in his chair to give further emphasis to them.

FROM Buenos Aires comes word that the postal administration will issue 3-centavos and 5c stamps (respective quantities, 10,000,000 and 20,000,000) to commemorate the Fourth National Eucharistic Congress to be held there in October.

LONDON, Sept. 23 (Reuter) -- Robert Boothby, Member of Parliament, chairman of the Monetary Parliamentary Policy Committee, declared today before a conference called to coordinate opposition to any return by Great Britain to the gold standard that their immediate object was to stop the Bretton Woods "racket."

IN contrast to the crop of 1943, this season's apple harvest is a big one -- a fact that worries' producers almost as much as it pleases them. Normally at this time in the fall the fruit that cannot be marketed immediately goes into storage; this year, however, storehouses are so full of supplies accumulated for the Government that there is little space left for new entries.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- Talk of inflation came to the fore today as a price-making influence in grains on the Chicago Board of Trade and general short covering by professional traders and through commission houses developed. Closing trades were about the top.

A detective force brought to full strength by cancellation of leaves and days off moved swiftly yesterday to bring to book the perpetrators of Friday's outbreak of four hold-ups that yielded $43,000 to armed bandits.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 23 -- Under the influence of chill winds an Airedale terrier came back to his best form today and gained the honors in the sixth annual bench show of the Suffolk County Kennel Club, held on the grounds of the Crescent Club.

Burs are ripening. Walk along a roadside or across the fields and you will know it all too well. Half an hour's walk can provide half an hour's work getting them off your clothes, to which they cling with hooks and spurs and barbs and spines. But they are worth looking at as you pluck them off, simply as examples of nature's ingenuity.

DR. SERGE KOUSSEVITZKY remarked during a recent interview that one of the most serious problems facing young composers today is what he bluntly termed "money." Dr. Koussevitzky did not go into details on the subject, but, as an intensely practical musician and one who has watched the growth of so many young artists, he knows whereof he speaks.

Another adventure in Americana will come to Broadway soon in the shape of "Bloomer Girl." This newest musical excursion into American history goes back to 1861 for the story of the early stages of women's fight for freedom.

ACCORDING to Mr. Ardrey, the world began in a factory on the outskirts of a town called Indian Pass in the West Texas desert. But he doesn't mean the world you mean. The film "Wilson" took the American public into the past for a look into the future.

The observance here on Wednesday of Victory Fleet Day, dedicated this year by the War Shipping Administration to American steamship operators for their management and operation of this country's vast wartime merchant fleet, will include a parade and a ceremony on the steps of the Custom House, under the auspices of the WSA and the American Merchant Marine Institute, Frank J. Taylor, president of the institute, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Senator Ferguson of Michigan expressed the view today that the findings of the special Army and Navy boards investigating the Pearl Harbor disaster should be made public as soon as their reports were completed.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 -- In 1932 Franklin D. Roosevelt outlined, in broad terms, the economic philosophy of the New Deal in his famous speech at the Commonwealth Club, in San Francisco. Thursday night Thomas E. Dewey, speaking in the same city, outlined his creed.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sunday, Sept. 24 -- After six anxious days and nights the battle for the bridgehead to northern Germany across the Lek River, northernmost arm of the lower Rhine in the Netherlands, showed prospects of success last night.

It is of the utmost importance in this election, when every man's vote is a more sacred heritage than at any time in our history, that the public be not misled by false assertions by either candidate.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Communiqe 168:

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 23 -- A discussion of cancer families was the main feature of today's conference of specialists assembled here, with Dr. Frank E. Adair of the Memorial Hospital, New York, telling of the appearance of cancer in women who were daughters, sisters or nieces of cancerous mothers and maternal aunts.

MONTREAL, Sept. 23 -- Another resolution was adopted today by the Policy Committee of the Council of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration to authorize relief and repatriation for German Jews, and others of enemy nationality, and stateless persons who have been deported, or forced to leave their homes by the enemy because of race, religion or anti-Nazi activities and who are found in liberated territory.

Although a substantial number of colleges and universities are still in serious financial difficulty, the low ebb in civilian enrollments has been reached and a slight upturn has begun. Fall registration in various sections of the country has shown an increase in freshmen and women students, and a return to the campus of many thousands of discharged service men.

A RATHER earnest young lady from Boston. Dorothy Adams, went to Poland to attend a conference of the League of Nations and met Jan Kostanecki, a handsome economist. Presently, while studying at the London School of Economics and trying to write about that prickly problem, the Polish-German Silesian boundary, she met Kostanecki again.

ELECTION songs by the hundreds, composed by professional and amateur tunesmiths, have been pouring into Republican and Democratic party headquarters. One hails Thomas E. Dewey as "Our Yankee Dewey Dandy"; another offers this lyrical voting advice: "Follow Through With Roosevelt."

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, made public yesterday a letter to him from Samuel H. Varonek, field director of the American Red Cross, stationed with the Seventy-sixth Infantry Division at Camp McCoy, Wis., saying that he had been informed by the New York State War Ballot Commission that he would have to return to New York to vote and appealing for help.

Retail trade was brisk last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Children's departments were crowded.

ANN RICHARDS, press agentry's potential candidate for the title "Miss Steel of 1944," probably would have been an Aussie pin-up girl had she not had a one-track mind, so to speak. As it was, Miss Richards of Sydney, Australia, had one and only one central idea.

Compulsory military training and restricted immigration during the war period were urged yesterday by the twenty-third biennial convention of the General Society of the war of 1812 at the Hotel Biltmore. Later, the delegates, from several eastern States, attended a special memorial ceremony for those who died in their country's service and those who served during the war of 1812.

RICHMOND, Sept. 23 -- Two notable steps toward better county government in Virginia were taken this week when the Virginia League of Counties voted unanimously to support a clinic at the University of Virginia for the improvement of county government in the State and when Warwick County voted to adopt the County-Manager system.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Hill and jungle fighters of the British Fourteenth Army have driven to a point just seven miles above the important Japanese base of Tiddim in Burma, capturing the town of Tongzang and chasing a cut-off Japanese rear guard into the jungle, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's headquarters announced today.

THE post-war railroad dining-car patron may expect the comfort, luxury and service of a smart hotel dining room, according to plans for a new diner announced by Pullman-Standard. The outstanding innovation of the new car is its floor plan, which calls for tables to be placed diagonally with seats at a 45-degree angle to the side of the car, permitting unobstructed movement by both waiter and patron.

Citing plant clearance as a major reconversion problem which, if unanswered, would contribute to a "long time-lag" in getting industry back to peacetime production, the automotive industry called last week for the adoption of procedures that would make possible prompt decisions on the disposal of termination inventories.

A continuous-injection molding and extruding machine, the only one of its kind known to this department, and capable of laying an unbroken seamless tube of plastic or rubber from New York to San Francisco, has come out of the work of Walter P. Cousino, 45-year-old engineer of the Chrysler Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt proclaimed today Oct. 11 as Pulaski Day and Oct. 12 as Columbus Day, and paid tribute to the Poles, "who were the first to take up arms against our common foe," and "the superb faith and resolution" of Christopher Columbus.

MORE than two hundred years ago, when sails and horses' legs still furnished rapid transportation, an English gentleman wrote: "Could I transport myself with a wish from one country to another, I should choose to pass my winter in Spain, my spring in Italy, my summer in England and my autumn in France."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The American diplomatic and consular office in Paris, which functions as the office of our representative to the French Committee of National Liberation, is being staffed by the larger part of the American mission in Algiers as well as by some foreign-service officers now on duty in the State Department and at other posts.

READERS to whom the name M.P. Shiel is a password to a delirious and astounding world will only need to be told that "Sleep No More" contains a fine Shiel of good vintage. "The House of Sounds," which Mr. Derleth has winnowed out of England, where it has lain for fifty years, is as wild and gorgeous a tale as "Purple Cloud" devotees could hanker for.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The new National Agriculture Committee, composed of anti-Administration Democrats whose purpose is to get out the farm vote against President Roosevelt, ended today a two-day conference here by passing a resolution urging farmers "to smash the vicious control of the New Dealers" in the November elections.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- President Roosevelt told the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers of America in the opening political speech of his campaign for re-election to a fourth term tonight that the Republican Old Guard was trying to pass itself off as the New Deal and he gave reasons why this could not be.

IN the Navy, where matters both great and small must all receive attention, it is equally important, according to the time and place, that a man possess his full allowance of socks and shoes and "buttons, bone, white," as that a Task Force commander have, in his turn, a proper proportion of battleships, carriers, cruisers and destroyers before embarking on a combat mission.

In regard to Dr. James Bender's article on "General American" in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine, why does he consider standard English to be a modern genteelism? Some of it doubtless is. I remember my grandmother protesting warmly against the "pedantry" of saying "hwat" for "what."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- At the beginning of another wartime autumn the fuel outlook, if a few shades brighter than it has been for the last two or three winters, appears, from the official point of view, no brighter than a battleship gray.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States warned American communities today against the "socialism" which might result if they make the mistake of "bringing pressure to bear on the Federal Government" to continue operation of Government-owned war plants beyond the time when they were needed for the war program.

AN innovation in the handling of full-length war news films will be tried out by Twentieth Century-Fox with the release of "The Fighting Lady." The film, photographed over a period of fifteen months by a Navy camera crew, was edited into story form by Producer Louis de Rochemont and will be sold by Fox to theatres just as any other of the company's pictures.
OTTAWA, Sept. 23 -- The Canadian picture has in this past week presented a number of curious contrasts.

WHEN our betters get up in meeting to "deplore" the "let-down of discipline," the chances are that they go on to fond recollections of the beatings they received as children. "I was whipped as a child, thank goodness," an eminent headmaster of a boys' school in this country was quoted as saying the other day.

WHAT is the nature of this war? Is it a battle between rival imperialisms, the sated and the hungry; a moral struggle between the children of light and the children of darkness; or a universal civil conflict in which new political and economic systems are being born in blood?

Air commuting on the Hudson, planned for Sept. 15, was postponed by the hurricane, according to Charles S. LoPiccolo, manager of Pickair Seaplane Base and the Hudson River Air Lines, who said yesterday that almost all of the shore equipment, installation of which was completed the day before the storm struck, had been wiped out at a loss of $25,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Gasoline stocks are now at virtually pre-war levels, but only about half the supply can be spared for civilians, Ralph K. Davies, deputy petroleum administrator, said today. In 1941, before the war and heavy military demands, about 90 per cent of storage stocks went to motorists and other civilian users.

GREAT LAKES, Ill., Sept. 23 -- Great Lakes' bustling Bluejackets, sparked by Jim Youel, former Iowa star, surged to two last-quarter touchdowns to spoil the debut of Purdue's Boilermakers, 27 -- 18, before 25,000 sailors today.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- The complete defeat of Germany is now in sight. Already the problems of what to do with Germany after she has surrendered unconditionally are beginning to replace the plans for military operations in the minds of Allied leaders.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Loss of six small United States naval craft -- two minesweepers, an LST, landing ship tanks, and three torpedo boats -- in action in the Mediterranean was announced by the Navy today. They were the minesweepers 21 and 24, LST 282 and PT boats 202, 218 and 555.

THERE may possibly be two schools of thought regarding Fredric March's proposal, as mentioned in the Sunday TIMES of Sept. 10, that an annual Academy award be made for the outstanding juvenile characterization of the year.

There is something about the mustache that the able Dr. Marion Smith overlooked -- only a man can grow one. And here lies the kernel of the argument. The man who decides to sport lip adornment asserts his masculinity and desire to tyrannize over the home.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Whether Germany can be defeated this year depends in large measure on one factor over which the Allies have absolutely no control -- the weather. The weather can be predicted and provided for and its ill effects can be palliated by devices of modern war but it cannot be changed.

Mrs. Kermit Roosevelt, widow of Major Kermit Roosevelt, son of former President Theodore Roosevelt, has joined the women's division of the Democratic National Committee and will campaign actively for the re-election of President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Marvin Jones, War Food Administrator, announced tonight that the WFA would buy from farmers at parity prices all cotton of the 1944 crop for which a loan scheduled had been announced and which might be placed in acceptable storage.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Sept. 23 -- The next of kin of nineteen Army Air Forces men received yesterday afternoon the decorations of soldiers who had won them for acts of heroism. The medals were presented by Lieut. Col. Warren G. Nichols in Post Theatre No. 2.
ROME, Sept. 23 -- Warrants for the arrest of seven high Fascists were issued by Count Carlo Sforza today in his capacity as High Commissioner for the Punishment of Fascist Crimes.

I am delighted that Mr. Hulings has made the position so clear. The Democrats did indeed vote almost solidly asainst the treaty with reservations, the Republicans almost solidly for it. Any seeming confusion in this matter occurs because to vote for the Senate resolution on the treaty i whieh was the treaty with reservations) was actually to vote against the Leaffue; to vote against the resolution was to vote for the League.

Fleet Admiral Karl Doenitz, Commander in Chief of the German Navy, called on German workers yesterday to support Adolf Hitler with "fanaticism" because his leadership will "eventually" result in victory, the DNB agency reported.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Sunday, Sept. 24 (AP) -- A communique:

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 23 (UP) -- American air attacks have set afire the enemy-held West River port of Wuchow in southern China had ripped a span from the strategic Yellow River railway bridge near Chengchow, more than 800 miles to the north, in blows aimed at crippling twin Japanese offensives grinding toward a juncture in Kwangsi Province.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 23 -- A strike of 600 foremen and sub-foremen at the Dravo Corporation shipyards, which completely stopped the production of war vital invasion craft, ended tonight less than eighteen hours after it began and 6,000 company employes who were idle because they had no supervisors, began to return to work.

PEARL S. BUCK'S novel "China Sky," which, during the last three years, has been on and off RKO- Radio's production schedule more times than anyone around the studio likes to remember, now is well on its way toward completion.
PARIS, Sept. 23 -- "The whole center of Le Havre is a pile of ruins," said Herman du Pasquier, president of the port authority of Le Havre, who was in Paris today.

TROLLIUS, one of the most beautiful of all spring-flowering perennials, is easily grown from seed, provided it has proper treatment. The blossoms on graceful two-foot stems could double for large buttercups, single or double.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- While the Chamber of Commerce of the United States demanded today that access to liberated areas be granted American business men so they might establish trade contacts "as promptly as possible," Allied Supreme Headquarters announced that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Supreme Commander, had prohibited transportation of business men to "forward zones."

The discontinuance of butter set-aside in October should tend to check the downward spiral of consumer supplies, the Market News Service, Office of Distribution, War Food Administration, forecast yesterday in its weekly dairy market review.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 -- The Fourth Naval District said today that 2,500 shipyard workers were needed immediately from Pennsylvania, Delaware and New Jersey to alleviate a manpower shortage in West Coast shipyards.

Dorothy Parker, author, and Clifton Fadiman, conductor of the radio program "Information Please," will be the principal speakers at the official opening meeting of the women's division of the New York War Fund at 11:30 A.M. Tuesday in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel Madison Avenue and Forty-sixth Street.
IT has been said that the country of smiles is China. This is not altogether true. There is another country where people smile and laugh, even through their tears. That country is France.

In THE TIMES Magazine a list of words was given to test pronunciation knowledge. I am interested in the pronunciation that is given to the word oleomargarine and I would like to know what has happened to the principle that the letter "g" before "a" is hard with the one exception of the word gaol.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Senator Bailey, Democrat, of North Carolina, a frequent critic of New Deal measures and opponent of the CIO Political Action Committee, disclosed today his intention to "stay in the Democratic party."

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- A strong suggestion that American policy inclines toward removing the capital of Germany from Berlin as a step toward the drastic decentralization of the post-war German Government was given today by an exceptionally well informed diplomatic source.

BALLET THEATRE will present a total of thirty-two ballets and divertissements in its forthcoming season at the Metropolitan Opera House. The single new ballet scheduled is Balanchine's "Waltz Academy" to music of Rieti, with decor by Oliver Smith and costumes by Alvin Colt, which will have its premiere on Oct. 11.

The charge that the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, headed by Sidney Hillman, is the vehicle by which the Communists hoped to penetrate into the Democratic party was made and denied in a discussion last night on the "People's Platform" program, broadcast from radio station WABC and the network of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

TO the lay tennis enthusiast, who probably thinks of his favorite tennis star as an upright citizen who spends most of his waking hours keeping in top physical shape by various strenuous pursuits of an athletic nature, Mr. Richmond Barrett's novel of the ga-ga, hard-drinking personnel of the amateur tennis championship clique may come as something of a disillusionment.

WHEN you read about Barbara Loomis (or rather her prototype) in peacetime she was beautiful, desirable -- and usually in love with some worthy but poor and/or dangerously employed young man. Beset by Horrible Examples -- their nail polish chipped, their figures gone -- Barbara's predecessors chattered through their dilemma in the smartest of clothes, clubs and catch phrases.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The campaign thus far conducted by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey in his quest for the Presidency impresses a number of politicians here who wish him success as not sufficiently distinct from the Democratic position to attract the votes that must be transferred if there is to be a change in the Government.

Alien merchant officers and seamen who served on Allied merchant vessels and subsequently "jumped" their ships in American ports to obtain work ashore are the targets of a drive by the Immigration and Naturalization Service. These men when apprehended get the choice of returning to ships of their nationality or deportation, according to War Shipping Administration announcement.

ALBANY, Sept. 23 -- An increase of more than 100 million gallons of motor fuel was consumed in the first seven months of this year, Rollin Browne, President of the State Tax Commission, reported today. Consumption of beer and "hard liquor" also increased, but cigarette sales fell off 5 per cent, as shown by the returns made to the Tax Commission.

I wish to express my hearty approval of Malcolm Vaughan's article "Beauty and Art" in THE TIMES Magazine. Modern art actually does not appeal to me. However, I don't voice my opinion on it because I realize that the reason I don't like the modern version is that I don't understand it.

LONDON, Sunday, Sept. 24 -- Russian troops, driving a fifty-mile wedge across Estonia to the sea, yesterday captured the Riga Gulf port of Paernu, split the disintegrating German Baltic armies in two and sealed off a substantial Nazi force in northwestern Estonia.

IN 1939 Mrs. Enit Kaufman, a Czechoslovak by birth, an American by choice, and a "psychological portrait painter" by profession, came to the United States from the barbarism of nazified Europe. With her first look at America -- on a drive up the Hudson River "with the cliffs of New York skyscrapers in front of me, the burning white light behind them" -- she was thrilled.
BOSTON, Sept. 23 -- Governor Bricker of Ohio urged here today the use of force if necessary to maintain world peace.

THOUGH many women and their hairdressers blame unsuccessful permanents on the state of health of the subject at the time the permanent is given, dermatologists say that this theory is completely without foundation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- When Henry A. Wallace appeared Thursday night among the main speakers at the Roosevelt-Truman rally in Madison Square Garden in New York City, the fact was accepted in political quarters in Washington as a definite sign that the retiring Vice President had made up his mind on numerous political questions, including his own future.

THE "quack" with whose murder this story deals is Nathaniel Wall, a bonesetter of the little English village of Stalden. The villagers do not look upon him as a quack, for they know that he has been extraordinarily successful in treating their ailments.

Based on the reports of the past few days, officials at the Fish and Wildlife Service are of the opinion that the recent hurricane did not have too great an effect on local fishing. A number of Sheepshead Bay boats have been out and returned with good catches of porgies.

"ANNA LACUSTA," the hit at the Mansfield, owes its success to the American Negro Theatre, and the A.N.T. owes its own genesis to Frederick O'Neal, a young St. Louis actor who came to Harlem some years ago to develop a dream on a larger stage than the Midwest could afford.

The race-track axiom that a good jockey "must have a clock in his head," that is, be a judge of pace and time, had a sensational illustration at Belmont Park yesterday when Devil Diver won the Manhattan Handicap in buggy horse time -- time so slow that many observers thought the automatic timer was out of whack.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 23 -- Although finishing third in today's final special regatta of the season with Minkie II, C.H. Vanderlaan annexed the Noyes Memorial Trophy for high standing among the Atlantic Class boats of the Long Island Sound Y.R.A.

THERE are, and there always have been, in the world, countries that men call great and countries that men call small. The fact that, since man has existed and dwelt in society, the pages of history have dealt with great and small nations is proof that both find their justification in the deep and permanent needs of humanity.

Let it be said without equivocation that there is an art in country living. The art is important, both for those who must earn a living and for those who can plan a program that is either entirely free or partially free of the necessity of remunerative work. The first element in leading a countryman's life successfully is, peculiarly enough, the identical element that determines successful city living.

Cotter, before whom he was arraigned on a charge of illegal possession of "approximately 4,500,000 point value food ration stamps."

WITH AMERICAN FOURTH INFANTRY DIVISION in Germany, Sept. 22 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- American doughboys, huddled in log-roofed shelters in the Schnee-Eiffel Forest where the sun seldom breaks through, are concentrating tonight on the extremely tough problem of how best to remain alive in a little section of the world where even the trees can kill.
WITH AMERICAN FIRST ARMY, in Germany, Sept. 23 -- The Germans are feverishly preparing defenses east of the Rhine River in anticipation of the day when the fighting will move deeper into Germany.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 23 -- The State Supreme Court upheld today the right of pro-Roosevelt Democrats to have their new slate of Presidential electors printed on the State ballot instead of the anti-Roosevelt list which the Secretary of State was ready to certify.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- President Roosevelt's Cabinet committee on German peace policy has split wide open, it was learned today, over a plan sponsored by Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. for completely destroying Germany as a modern industrial state and converting it into an agricultural country of small farms.

BREST, France, Sept. 20 (delayed) (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Troy Middleton, commander of the Eighth Corps of the United States Ninth Army, announced today that 36,389 Germans were captured at Brest, the second largest prisoner bag of the war.

SOMEWHERE IN FRANCE (By Wireless). IN the Valley of the Orne, not far from the sixteenth-century city of Argentan, a unit of the American Third Armored Division uncoiled its column of tanks and struck down a road with piston-like power. They rumbled along unopposed.
American Indian Day was celebrated yesterday afternoon by the American Indian Council, Inc., with a tribal program at the bandstand on the mall in Central Park.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- With the Congress of Industrial Organizations and communism being stressed by Republicans as paramount issues, the Illinois Senatorial campaigns of Scott W. Lucas, Democratic incumbent, and Richard J. Lyons, his GOP opponent, are looming large on the political scene in the Central West.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Bucknell's co-captain, Gene Hubka, carried the ball 176 yards in 28 attempts today as the Bisons rolled over Muhlenberg, 14 -- 0. It was Bucknell's second victory over the Mules on successive Saturdays.

BOSTON, Sept. 23 -- Politicians throughout New England, a region so preoccupied lately with war and hurricanes that it has not yet warmed up its election spirit, have started once more to wonder about future tactics of the CIO's Political Action Committee.

WASHINGTON, Sept 23 -- President Roosevelt has instructed Secretary Wickard and Brig. Gen. Hines, administrator of veterans affairs, to make a canvass of the problem of placement of discharged service men on farms and ranches and to report at an early date.

Consuming industries will oppose any efforts made by importers designed to bring to an end international cattle hide control under the Combined Raw Materials Board, according to views expressed in the week by spokesmen for the related interests.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 -- With American individuals having on hand the unprecedented amount of more than $130,000,000,000 in cash, bank deposits and Federal Government securities, the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today its plan for declaring an "open season" on unscrupulous promoters and salesmen who may be casting a hungry eye toward this vast hoard of liquid savings.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 23 (AP) -- The University of Rochester, employing long runs and taking advantage of errant enemy forward passes, romped to a 27-7 victory over Union College today.

DETROIT, Sept. 23 -- Paul (Dizzy) Trout pitched a six-hitter today for his twenty-sixth victory as the Tigers defeated Boston, 8 to 2, and eliminated the Red Sox from the American League pennant race. The victory enabled Detroit to hold its one-game lead over the second-place Browns.

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 23 -- The First Marine Division on Peleliu made new gains yesterday that flanked the strong Japanese hill defenses, and an apparent enemy effort to reinforce the garrison was smashed by our naval and air forces, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz stated in a communique today.

Thomas and August Seaman of Ridgewood.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A Caribbean air service, featuring lower-priced cabin class seats, a base rate of five cents a mile and a flat $5 fare from Key West to Havana, was proposed today to the Civil Aeronautics Board.

BOSTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Al Javery scored his eighth victory, scattering six Cincinnati hits, today as the Braves took the first of a three-game series with the Reds 4 to 0.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A work stoppage among members of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen halted production today at the Corrigan-McKinney plant of Republic Steel Corporation, which employs 3,500. SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, Sept. 23 -- The news that Great Britain is obtaining 100,000 tons of oil a year from hitherto secret deposits within her own borders was released today by the Government, and a party of newspaper men were permitted to visit the site.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 23 -- With its head coach on lend-lease to a Philadelphia war plant and all except three members of last year's varsity in the armed forces, Holy Cross is playing football under as big a handicap as any of the strictly civilian teams, despite the fact that it has a naval unit.

Teachers' colleges over the country expect increases varying from 10 to 60 per cent in the size of their freshmen classes this fall. ST. LOUIS, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Refusing to give up in the red-hot American League pennant race, the Browns came from behind in the ninth inning today to defeat the Athletics, 3 to 2. The victory kept St. Louis one game behind the league-leading Tigers.

A program of songs by Negro composers was given at Town Hall before a good-sized audience yesterday afternoon by Dayse Regina Harding, Negro soprano. William B. Yeager, who has been president of the International Utilities Corporation since July, 1941, announced yesterday that he was reigning his post with the company since the reorganization of the public utility holding company is now virtually completed.

IN less than a week the Pittsburgh players will assemble to vote on how they'll divide their second-place (or so they hope) share of the world series money. But the Pirates went to work on the Doc in their Polo Grounds dressing room yesterday and soon had him squirming a little uncomfortably.

The city's celebration of V-E-day, marking the victorious end of the European phase of the war, must not be marred by drinking or disorderly and destructive demonstrations, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast, delivered from his home at Gracie Mansion.

The Liberal party's State committee made public yesterday a letter to Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, Republican nominee for United States Senator, protesting his certification of Liberal party candidates on the sixth line of the ballot as "prejudicial and discriminatory'' and announcing an intention of appealing to the courts for a better position.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 24 (AP) -- A new discovery about matter, that organic substances have a phosphorescent state which will give scientists a basis for attacking the riddle of molecular structure, was reported by Dr. G.N. Lewis, Professor of Chemistry at the University of California.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 24 -- For the nineteenth time the noted boxer, Champion El Wendie of Rockland, captured the highest award in a dog show, scoring in the final open-air competition of the 1944 season, the twenty-second annual bench event of the Westbury Kennel Association, held on the Phipps polo field today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 -- Continued small receipts of hogs is resulting in light production of pork and lard and some warehouse men say that unless conditions soon change they will be practically out of their holdings within a short time. A considerable percentage of the business in meats last week was in lots of less than 5,000 pounds, with ceiling prices prevailing generally.

Cooler weather brought a quickened pace to retail business last week and led to additional pressure for deliveries in the wholesale markets, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

PARIS, Sept. 23 (Delayed) -- The Minister of War and members of the National Council of Resistance agreed today that in the future censorship would apply only to strictly military information whose publication might affect security or discipline in the Army, according to a statement issued tonight.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- The campaign against international cartels initiated by President Roosevelt last week has received a surprising amount of support from various sections of English public opinion during the past few days -- surprising, that is, in view of the enthusiasm shown by British industry for cartelization and the complacency with which the English courts have regarded the fruition of their ambitions.

In an address to Czechoslovak pilots in Britain President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia said: "This is probably the last time I shall see the Czechoslovak Air Force in England," the London radio reported yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Buffalo took a 3-to-2 edge in games over Baltimore today in the International League semi-final play-off series when Walter Wilson outpitched Red Embree to take a 4-2 decision before a record local crowd of 32,913 in Municipal Stadium.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- Poland's exiled President Wladyslaw Raczkiewicz, tried today to drive a hard bargain with his Cabinet. They have demanded unanimously that he oust Gen. Kazimierz Sosnkowski as Commander in Chief of the Polish forces, on the ground that this extreme Nationalist has repeatedly caused the Government embarrassment not only with the Soviet Union but with its British and American Allies.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 24 (U.P.) -- Dr. Clarence Cook Little, director of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory for Cancer Research, stated today that cancer was acquired by human beings through a combination of hereditary and environmental influences.

DETROIT, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Tigers clung to their one-game edge over the Browns today by beating the Red Sox for the fourth straight time, 9 to 5. Hal Newhouser, permitting one hit in the first five innings, coasted to his twenty-seventh triumph.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 24 -- David O. Selznick has announced that he will move up the start of production of J.E. Marquand's best seller, "So Little Time," from the spring to December. Dore Schary will produce the film for Selznick's Vanguard Company.

Drain Jr. for $1,650,000.

WITH THE BRITISH, near Arnhem, Sept. 23 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Tireless British infantry struggled through to the Arnhem area today after a forced march, fighting and advancing until they came out at the Lek, then launched themselves across the river to bring succor to their dauntless airborne comrades at Arnhem.

ABOARD DEWEY SPECIAL TRAIN, Sept. 24 -- Governor Dewey gave notice today that following the example set by President Roosevelt last night, he will take off the gloves and make the campaign a real fight. On Saturday night the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo presented the second of its scheduled premieres at the City Center, George Balanchine's choreographic setting of Richard Strauss' music for Bourgeois Gentilhomme," with scenery and costumes by Eugene Berman.

NAPLES, Sept. 24 -- General headquarters of this war theatre is the capital of a mobile state. It has all the characteristics of a seat of government -- departments, bureaus, cabinet meetings and a vast clerical staff -- and the same atmosphere of concentrated power and diluted responsibility.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Monday, Sept. 25 -- British Second Army patrols slipped across the Lek River Saturday night to relieve the trapped airborne forces in the Arnhem area and, thanks to American airborne reinforcements, beat back furious German efforts yesterday to cut across the avenue of attack, stretching north through the Netherlands to the river's southern bank.

LONDON, Sept. 24 (Reuter) -- The Moscow radio tonight broadcast an article in Pravda criticizing the recent broadcast speech by Baron Ernst von Born, who was acting Premier and is now Minister of Justice in the new Cabinet, and demanding that Finland should fulfill the armistice terms.

Freeman Lewis, vice president of the Blakiston Company and director of the Triangle Book and New Home Library series, has announced his resignation, effective next Monday, Doubleday, Doran reports. Mr. Lewis thereafter will be associated with Marshall Field as consultant in book publishing.

Strong price increases for a large number of commodities, particularly farm products, brought the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices up from the previous week's level of 113.05 to a new all time high of 113.52.

Saying that Abraham Lincoln, who freed more than three million slaves, gave the Negroes full rights of citizenship, denied in some States today, Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, Republican nominee for United States Senator, declared yesterday that while the Negroes of America had been the subject of political exploitation for many years, the party of Lincoln had not done the exploiting.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 24 (U.P.) -- The Swedish Government's decision to close Swedish territorial ports in the Gulf of Bothnia and Baltic Sea west to the Falsterbo Canal represents, to all practical purposes, the most important swing from neutrality to a policy favoring the Allies Sweden has made since the start of the war, informed quarters agreed today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Smashing performances in France have proved the effectiveness of the Army's new tank destroyer, the speedy M-18, the War Department indicated today.

The summer's attendance at Park Department beaches -- Rockaway, Jacob Riis Park and Orchard -- was estimated at 31,856,175, compared with an estimated 29,749,525 last summer, the department announced yesterday. In addition, 1,954,726 persons visited the twenty-six pools operated by the department, compared with 1,996,707 who found relief from hot weather in them last year.

LONDON, Monday, Sept. 25 -- The Red Army smashed twenty-five miles inside Czechoslovakia and also crossed the pre-war Hungarian frontier yesterday in a big pincers movement aimed at knocking Hungary out of the war, while in the north, Soviet naval forces captured the Estonian seaport of Baltic Port [Paldiski].

ROME, Sept. 24 -- The Fifth Army has driven on over the mountains and last night it was only fifteen miles from Bologna. Futa Pass, the strongest German position in all Italy, has fallen, while, on the Adriatic side, the Eighth Army was beginning to fan out beyond Rimini in the Po Valley.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 24 -- A plea to the educators of America to speak against a return to isolationist policies when the lessons of this war are no longer fresh was made today by Lieut. Gen. Alexander A. Vandegrift, commandant of the Marine Corps, at commencement exercises for thirty-one graduates of John Marshall College here.

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 24 -- Japanese naval strength in the Philippines has been dispersed and the enemy's air force there has been "broken," Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, declared in a communiqu today announcing a strike in the Manila area on Thursday, the second in two days, by carrier planes of Admiral William F. Halsey's Third Fleet.
CHUNGKING, China, Monday, Sept. 25 (AP) -- A danger that the Japanese might be outflanking Kweilin, key city of northern Kwangsi Province, was indicated by the High Command in an announcement today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The White Sox extended their spurt to six straight victories today by beating Washington, 9 to 3 and 2 to 0. The defeats sent the Senators away from Chicago without a victory in 11 games here.

BUFFALO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Vice President Wallace said tonight that "some people say President Roosevelt is a tired old man, but I think his mind is still pretty good. The great fear of certain reactionaries is that his mind is awful good."

An appeal for the re-election of President Roosevelt and the election of a Congress that would give him full support in his foreign and domestic policies was made yesterday by Senator Harley M. Kilgore, Democrat, of West Virginia.

LONDON, Monday, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Hundreds of Allied planes blasted German ground positions in the Nijmegen-Arnhem area in the Netherlands yesterday and in the Nancy sector United States Ninth Air Force Thunderbolts assisted in repulsing strong tank-led enemy counter-attacks, despite near-gales and rain in both regions.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (U.P.) -- An intensified drive to get out the vote Nov. 7 is expected by political observers in the wake of President Roosevelt's political speech Saturday night.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Cleveland's Rams brought out an unheralded aerial attack that caught the Pittsburgh-Chicago eleven flatfooted to hand the Steeler-Cardinal team a 30-28 defeat in a National Football League game before 20,968 today.

A 19-year-old youth who had imbibed too freely Saturday night appropriated a city-owned bus on the Third Avenue line in Brooklyn at 3:30 A.M. yesterday and, with two sleepy sailors as passengers, drove fifteen blocks before he was caught by a radio car crew.
WITH BRITISH AIRBORNE UNITS in the Arnhem Area, Sept. 24 -- German shelling of our little stronghold is more vicious and continuous. It seems they are bringing up batteries of 88's.

At the close of trading on Saturday on the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts from October through May showed on the week gains of 1 to 15 points and July had made a new improvement of 27 points.

Developed originally for hospital curtains and black-out curtains in Government offices an ingenious new fixture is now available for home decorators. It promises to remove many curtain - hanging headaches. Specifically it does away with the nuisance of removing and replacing dozens of rings or hooks every time draperies are cleaned or of having to use a valence or cornice to hide the bare section of rod when curtains are drawn apart.

Preparing for a possible widespread use of the spot authorization plan, under which certain manufacturers are allowed to resume production of civilian items, some sales managers are restudying their advertising and sales plans, sales executives stated yesterday.

In your editorial "Rumania's Armistice" you derive considerable satisfaction from the fact that twelve Rumanian divisions are fighting on the Allied side, and you suggest that the Rumanian armistice terms are justifiably more lenient than those imposed upon Italy because Rumania is now in the United Nations' camp "with all her forces," whereas the Italian King, Badoglio or the Italian underground was unable to deliver so much at the time of the Italian surrender.
PISTOIA, Italy, Sept. 24 -- This provincial capital, captured more than two weeks ago, appears to be a deserted city.
ROME, Sept. 24 -- Important territorial claims were put forward today on behalf of Greece by the Greek Minister of Information, George Cartalis, in a press conference here.

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 24 -- The revised box score of total damage inflicted on the Japanese by the Halsey-Mitscher naval forces from Aug. 30 through Sept. 21 in sweeps over the Bonin and Volcano islands, the Palau group and the Philippines, as announced today by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 24 -- Assets remaining of five New Haven banks which failed in 1931 will be liquidated immediately if applications filed by State Banking Commission and State Receiver Richard Rapport with the State Superior Court are granted.

BOSTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Cincinnati swept a war relief double-header today by defeating the Braves, 1 -- 0, behind the three-hit pitching of Arnold (Lefty) Carter. The Reds took the first game, 2 -- 1, for Harry Gumbert's fourteeth victory.

Kenneth Downer, employed by the Otis Elevator Company of Yonkers until he left in 1942 to become a foreign representative of United Seamen's Service, distinguished himself at his post in the southwest Pacific, according to a cablegram received by Douglas P. Falconer, executive director of the service, and announced yesterday.

A quick turnover of a property on the West Side was made when James H. Cruikshank, operator, resold the four-story rooming house at 43 West Sixty-ninth Street which he purchased ten days ago. The building, which contains sixteen rooms and eleven baths, occupies a lot 20 by 100 feet and is assessed at $25,500.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 24 -- Four Finnish divisions, battling their former comrades in arms, have captured part of Suomussalmi in northeastern Finland from the Germans and are continuing to make progress in ejecting an estimated 100,000 Austrians and Germans from the area, a Helsinki military communique said today.

All of us would like to do more than we are doing to bring victory in this war for freedom. All of us yearn to express in some tangible way our thanks to the brave men and women who toil and suffer for us in order to bring the victory nearer. There is one sure way to give more of ourselves and to make our gratitude felt.

Instead of calling for further tariff reductions it would seem more logical to consider the effect on our post-war national economy of the drastic reductions already made, Bertrand W. Hall, secretary of the American Tariff League, said yesterday in commenting on the recent statement of Winthrop Aldrich on the Bretton Woods currency plan.

Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, declared last night that the two major political parties were making their campaigns on the basis of personalities instead of concerning themselves with principles and programs that would bring peace and plenty.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 24 -- Memphis cotton men are of the opinion that the announcement Saturday by Marvin Jones, head of the War Food Administration, that the Commodity Credit Corporation will buy the 1944 cotton crop from the farmer at parity may result in the closing of the futures exchanges, disruption of the spot markets and curtailment of mill activities.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 24 -- The German press and radio are seizing on assertions of "flagrant differences of opinion among the Allied nations" as allegedly shown by the American press on the subject of "the harness of the armistice terms imposed on Finland" "disagreement leading to disintegration of the unity of the Allied nations."

For his "contribution to the cause of public service and humanity" United States Supreme Court Justice Frank Murphy was chosen yesterday to receive the annual award of the League of Fraternal and Benevolent Organizations of the Jewish Education Committee of New York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (U.P.) -- The old adage that woman's place is in the home was contradicted tonight by a Women's Bureau survey which showed that since Pearl Harbor more than 6,500,000 women had joined the country's working force, with more than half coming from home housework.
Mr. and Mrs. Harold T. Moore have come to the Carlyle from Tiny Timbers, their place in Wynnewood, Pa.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 117.7 on Sept 12, compared with 117.6 a fortnight before, 118.0 a month before, 114.4 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

Mr. Roosevelt's first speech of the campaign did not discuss Dumbarton Oaks, or American policy toward Germany, about which many unofficial reports are being circulated, or any other of the major questions which must soon be faced and settled in the field of international policy.

The second of the three alleged actual participants in the $12,300 hold-up of a messenger for Sutro Brothers Co. in the Equitable Building last Friday was arrested at 1 o'clock yesterday morning in Greenwich Village.

NEWARK, N.J, Sept 24 -- Pierre van Paassen, author and war correspondent, urged here today that Jews in the United States set up "an American society of professional squawkers and activists within the Zionist movement to raise a mighty voice in a demand for belligerency for Palestine."

Additional appropriations totaling $1,582,380 to meet emergency needs that have arisen since the budgets for the last quarter of 1944 were approved, were announced yesterday by the National War Fund. The fund already has approved budgets of $26,683,001 for the work of its twenty-two member agencies in the three months beginning next Monday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (U.P.) -- William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, defended tonight WLB approval of night shift differentials for the copper industry in Idaho, Montana, Utah, Nevada, Colorado and New Mexico against industry members, charges that the WLB action abandoned its policy against any new pattern of employment practices.

YENAN, China, Sept. 23 (Delayed) -- After flying from Chungking for three hours the pilot picked up a gray pagoda among the brown loess hills. Then we dropped down in a narrow river valley, landing amid a huge cloud of dust on the short airfield in Yenan, the capital of Communist China.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (U.P.) -- The War Production Board reported today that the lumber output in July dropped to 2,843,765,000 board feet, 6.7 per cent below June, because of shortages of manpower and equipment.

Mayor La Guardia appealed to New Yorkers in his regular Sunday broadcast yesterday to use butter sparingly because of the "tight" supply situation. He pointed out that discontinuance of Federal Government buying in October should ease the situation, with perhaps further tightness in November when production slumped.

A reorganization of Denmark's police force by the Germans, restoring power to police superintendents under previous German regulations and placing the organization of the police in the hands of city and district officials, was announced yesterday by the Danish radio.
Somerset Importers, Ltd., has been appointed exclusive United States distributor of the Alta Vineyards Company products.

Prior to the liberation of France the United States policy of nonrecognition of the French Committee of National Liberation could be explained on the ground of France's inability to express herself while under German occupation. Today, however, General de Gaulle emerges as the uncontested leader war-torn France and he is daily giving new evidence of his undeniable ability as head of the Government.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Sept. 24 (AP) -- The North Carolina Preflight Cloudbusters tore apart the Cherry Point Marines' defenses for three touchdowns in the third period for a 27-to-14 victory before 8,000 fans today.

A Greenwich Village rooming house fire at 6 A.M. yesterday caused the death of one woman and injuries to two firemen and routed twenty persons into the street in their nightclothes. Miss Irene Gallagher, 40 years old, was burned to death in her top floor apartment of the three-story dwelling at 142 West Thirteenth Street.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 -- Yard goods probably will continue to be a comparatively rare item on retail store shelves long after the European phase of the war is ended, mill representatives and store-buyers declared last week. Emphasis was placed on the shortage of cotton goods, with indications that that item may be among the last to reappear because of its importance in the Japanese war areas.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 130:
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept 24 -- The Arab unity conference on the future area of the Islamic world lying between the Iranian border, the Red Sea and North Africa is scheduled to open in Alexandria tomorrow.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- On the grounds of a chateau at Coye-la-Foret, about thirty kilometers from Paris, children, whose parents have been killed in the resistance movement in Paris or deported to Germany, are learning to play again. The horrors that knitted their little brows are gradually fading from their memories under the influence of kindness and freedom.

Although she is the owner of a pleasant home at 51-57 Gorsline Street, East Elmhurst, Queens, Mrs. James T. McLaughlin is obliged to live with her two young children and her mother in a cramped apartment, and probably will have to put up with the situation at least until Jan. 31 under a ruling yesterday by Municipal Court Justice John F. Scileppi.

PHILIP WYLIE, until recently principally known to fame as the author of pleasant tales of fishing, in The Saturday Evening Post, looks upon the modern world in much the same spirit as Jeremiah did upon Jerusalem. It must be admitted in Mr. Wylie's favor that a world given over to slaughter and horror is no nice spectacle.
Air power helped to tip the scales of battle again last week, as it has done so often in this war.
ANKARA, Turkey. Sept. 24 (AP) -- Bulgarian troops are now fighting beside the Russians under Marshal Feodor Tolbukhin, Foreign Minister Petko Stainoff said today.

The Catholic minority of the United States can "do America a great service by stating clearly that peace must be based on law, truth, justice and fraternal charity," the Rev. Thomas A. Donnellan, assistant chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Reading in bed has long been one of mankind's best pleasures, and it seems remarkable that so little progress has been made in improving it. The theory of our architects and home furnishers seems to have been that bed and book and possibly an ill-conceived lamp were enough, a notion that is ridiculous.

Since they went off the ration list a week ago, jams and jellies once more are finding their way back to prominent positions on grocers' shelves. Recently we found some rather unusual varieties -- along with a good assortment of ordinary kinds -- at Wisconsin Farms, delicatessen at 224 East Eighty-sixth Street (between Second and Third Avenues).
