LAKE PLACID CLUB, N.Y., Sept. 24 -- Samuel H. Packer, vice president of Lake Placid Club, was found dead in the garage of his lake shore estate, Interlaken, at midnight last night. Mr. Packer was found by a son, Kendrick, 17. He was 55 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Maximum prices that processors and primary distributors may charge for dried apricots, peaches, pears, prunes, and raisins of the 1944 and later crops were announced today by the Office of Price Administration.

Reading in bed has long been one of mankind's best pleasures, and it seems remarkable that so little progress has been made in improving it. The theory of our architects and home furnishers seems to have been that bed and book and possibly an ill-conceived lamp were enough, a notion that is ridiculous.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- The recent recovery in the stock markets here proved, as many had anticipated, merely a flash in the pan, although while it lasted it certainly encouraged hope in some quarters that it might be the forerunner of something more substantial and more lasting.

LAKE PLACID CLUB, N.Y., Sept. 24 -- Samuel H. Packer, vice president of Lake Placid Club, was found dead in the garage of his lake shore estate, Interlaken, at midnight last night. Mr. Packer was found by a son, Kendrick, 17. He was 55 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Maximum prices that processors and primary distributors may charge for dried apricots, peaches, pears, prunes, and raisins of the 1944 and later crops were announced today by the Office of Price Administration.

The Gothic Line, last German barrier on the ridgepole of the Apennines, is smashed. Victorious Allied troops are pouring across two-thirds of its wreckage into the open plains of Lombardy. The enemy is reported in disorganized flight through the valley of the Po, pursued by death in the air and on the ground.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Cardinals took two well-pitched games from the Phillies today, with Ted Wilks hurling a 1-0 shut-out after Mort Cooper went sixteen innings to win the opener, 4 -- 3.

A captured German telephone log, which lists all the conversations held by the Chief of Staff of the German Seventh Army since D-day, reveals among other things that Hitler demanded that the Allies should be annihilated by the evening of June 6, Absie (the American Broadcasting Station in Europe) reported Sunday.

Our airborne invasion of Holland was unquestionably a magnificent feat beautifully executed. We have ample reason for pride in Lieut. Gen. Lewis H. Brereton and other leaders who planned the operation and of the men who carried it out with such speed and precision.
MOSCOW, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Kremlin today learned of all the decisions on the Far Eastern war reached by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill at their Quebec conference.
CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 24 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 24 -- Season championships were decided on a wholesale basis in the final Yacht Racing Association regatta of 1944, under the auspices of the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club today. Sixty-three sailboats started in just about the finest racing weather of the season. A brisk wind, due east throughout, lightened from 11 miles to about 5, then picked up again.

PARIS, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Agence Francaise de Presse, official news agency, said last night that Louis Renault, 77, motor magnate and one of France's leading industrialists, had been jailed in the Fresnes Prison. Accountants of the Renault firm were quoted as saying that from 1940 to 1943 it made $120,000,000 worth of war materials for the German Army.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 2 -- An eight-hour day, with one day off in ten, is the usual schedule for women workers in this vicinity, according to a survey made by the women's department of the Chinese Association of Labor.
Seven new films, including importations from Mexico and France are scheduled to arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers, scoring twice in the last five minutes of play, broke a deadlock and defeated the Chicago Bears, 42 to 28, in a wild, bruising National Football League game today before 24,000.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 -- Secretary Ickes told the American Slav Congress today that President Roosevelt's reconversion plans had succeeded at least to the extent of converting Mr. Dewey into a New Dealer.

BOSTON, Sept. 24 -- A program of rescue and rehabilitation for thousands of suffering European Jews, which will cost $20,000,000 in 1944 was outlined today by Louis Broido, executive vice president of Gimbel Bros., Inc., of New York, at the New England conference of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee today.

On a couple of vagrant hits that spun around third base, the Giants yesterday broke their nine-game losing streak before a gathering of 13,778 at the Polo Grounds when they beat the Pirates in the first game, 5 to 4. However, they lost the nightcap in ten innings, 3 to 2.

The Dodgers yesterday walloped the Cubs, 10 -- 3, in the first contest and almost swept the three-game series in the nightcap before the Bruins nosed them out, 4 -- 3. A crowd of 12,568 was at Ebbets Field.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 24 -- The Yankees' last lingering rays of pennant hopes virtually flickered out on this frost-bitten afternoon as they succumbed to the wiles of the veteran Mel Harder and dropped the final engagement of their series with the Indians, 4 to 1.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- The French Forces of the Interior were made a part of the French Army and subject to military discipline today by a decree of the Commissariat of War, thus partly solving a problem that has been discussed for three weeks by the Government and the Council of National Resistance.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers, scoring twice in the last five minutes of play, broke a deadlock and defeated the Chicago Bears, 42 to 28, in a wild, bruising National Football League game today before 24,000.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 -- Secretary Ickes told the American Slav Congress today that President Roosevelt's reconversion plans had succeeded at least to the extent of converting Mr. Dewey into a New Dealer.
The text of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's speech as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES follows:
Rube Melton tried manfully to hang up his tenth triumph at Ebbets Field yesterday but non-support finally gave the champion Cardinals a 3-1 victory, with all the enemy runs unearned.

The forthcoming Sixth War Loan Drive which is scheduled to begin in November will tax the ingenuity of the advertising industry, according to New York advertising men yesterday. With the defeat of Germany almost in prospect, the incentive to purchase bonds will be reduced greatly.

Plans for alterations to New York Hospital to cost $400,000 were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings by the Society of New York Hospital, 525 East Sixty-eighth Street. The plans call for rearrangement of the wards, private rooms, laboratories and offices.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Thirty-three more industrial facilities have won the Army-Navy production award -- the E pennant -- for excellence in the manufacture of war materials.

The five-story mansion of the late Harold I. Pratt at the southwest corner of Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street has been presented to the Council on Foreign Relations, it was announced yesterday. The gift was made by Mrs. Harriet Barnes Pratt as a memorial to her husband, who was a member of the council for many years prior to his death in May, 1939.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The War Department announced today the temporary promotion to colonel of these lieutenant colonels: Lauson H. Stone of 41 Garden Place, Brooklyn, N.Y., and John V. Brown of Maplewood, N.J.

A gay new addition to the smart West Fifty-seventh Street "fashion row" is Jay Thorpe's Casual Shop, which opened yesterday morning. It adjoins the main building, with an entrance one door to the east, at 20-22 West Fifty-Seventh Street. The first impression on entering is of high color. The walls are paneled in corrugated wood in red, green and yellow, into which are set frames of natural pigskin.

WITH AMERICAN SEVENTH ARMY, in France, Sept. 25 (AP) -- German SS troops have sealed the Franco-German frontier, prohibiting further German units on this side of the border from retreating into Germany, according to information gleaned from prisoners captured in the central sector of the front today.

WITH UNITED STATES AIRBORNE TROOPS Near Nijmegen, Sept. 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- Under the direction of a fearless young Netherlander who parachuted in with an American general, the Dutch underground has played a major role in this division's operations and in the battle of the Nijmegen bridge.

The Theatre Guild's road constituents have been clamoring for "Oklahoma!" since last season, and rightly so, because it was promised them. To keep peace in the family the Guild decided yesterday to halt the Chicago duplication next Jan. 6 after a run of 532 performances over fifty-nine weeks.

A shortage of necessary materials is delaying the conversions of dwellings in the local area. About twenty to twenty-five applications have been received by the Federal Housing Administration, but action on them cannot be taken until new regulations governing the use of critical materials have been received from the War Production Board in Washington, Thomas G. Grace, State director of the FHA, said yesterday.

Reflecting the War Production Board's relaxation of control orders, "the first marked break in the allocation of new machinery for the plastics industry" has been made, plastic molders reported yesterday. The first allocation of new injection molding machines in the fourth quarter, it was pointed out, approved applications for sixty-eight machines, as compared with eleven in the preceding quarter.

The commander of the uniformed police in Queens, Deputy Chief Inspector James F. McGoey, and one of his chief assistants, Inspector John P. Challan, head of the Fifteenth Division, which embraces the Queens South Shore, have successfully applied for retirement, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine announced yesterday. Inspector McGoey's retirement became effective last midnight and that of Inspector Challan at midnight last Saturday.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 25 -- Impressed by the benefit they had derived by discussing the cancer problem as a group, and convinced that cancer research in widely separated fields would make more rapid progress if it were planned and organized, the forty scientists who attended the last four sessions held by the Conference on Parental Influence in Cancer adopted a procedure which resembles a charter with fourteen points.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, cautioned the Government and the OPA against any move to abandon price control as soon as the war in Europe is won in a statement today.

The Gardner School, one of the oldest private schools for girls in New York City, has taken new and larger quarters in two buildings it has leased at 5 East Eighty-eighth Street and 1071 Fifth Avenue, M. Elizabeth Masland, principal, announced yesterday.

A $100,000,000 bank credit group was organized yesterday by twenty-three banks in this city to provide an additional source of bank credit for small and medium-sized businesses in the reconversion and post-war periods. It is the first such credit group to be organized under the program recently adopted by the Post-War Small Business Credit Commission of the American Bankers Association.

WITH THE BRITISH SECOND ARMY at Nijmegen, the Netherlands, Sept. 24 (Delayed) -- The story of the British paratroopers who landed in the Arnhem area a week ago today and tried in vain to wrest a footbridge from the Germans was told here late last night when four of the survivors reached the British lines.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Representatives of all levels of the food industry, production, manufacture and distribution, began a three-day conference with Office of Price Administration officials today in an effort to devise a food pricing policy for use after the fall of Germany.

The recent letter of Miss Catharine Masters, president of the United Tenant Leagues, approving rent increases in housing projects, which in some cases amount to 100 per cent, indicates that tenants on the whole are in sympathy with rent increases, despite the fact that the OPA recently turned down a meager 10 per cent increase asked by New York owners.
Officials of Middlesex County, Mass., will be in the market on Oct. 3 with an issue of $250,000 temporary loan notes. The obligations, dated Oct. 6, 1944, will become payable on April 25, 1945.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 25 -- Governor Dewey lashed back tonight at President Roosevelt, in return for the latter's speech of Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- A future as an official roving "business man ambassador" seemed likely for Donald M. Nelson tonight, but whether this would be coupled with continued active chairmanship of the War Production Board was unrevealed.

Our correspondent at Pistoia reported yesterday that a third of the town was destroyed by the Germans, but that most of its art treasures are thought to have been preserved. It is a gracious walled town. Where else than in Italy could such another be found? It had been a city state with a long stirring history.

The Kansas City Southern Railway Company has called a special meeting of stockholders for Oct. 31 to approve the acquisition of the properties of seven subsidiaries, all of the capital stock of which is now owned by the railway.

The Francisco Sugar Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday in the annual statement covering the year ended with June net profit of $1,584,904, equal to $4.52 a share. This compares with net profit of $260,082, or 74 cents a share, earned in the previous fiscal year.

A former garage worker who had stolen a Mauser pistol keepsake from his erstwhile boss was arrested yesterday as the grudge slayer of Juan Mercado, 28 years old, of 165 East 112th Street, Sunday morning, after a quarrel over the playing of a juke box in a bar at 1775 Lexington Avenue, where Mercado had been celebrating the impending opening of his own tavern in the neighborhood.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Attorney General Biddle today denied that either the newly formed National Citizens Political Action Committee or the Congress of Industrial Organizations Political Action Committee had violated the law on political contributions.

The local office of the War Food Administration, 150 Broadway, declared yesterday that it could offer little hope for increased supplies of butter for civilians in this region before the end of the year.

Supplies of sole leather for civilian shoes may be increased by 10,000,000 pairs during the last quarter of this year as a result of military cutbacks and an expected, decrease in the allotments to the repair industry, shoe manufacturers and tanners declared yesterday.
LAUREL, Md., Sept. 25 (AP) -- In a brilliant driving finish, F.A. Piarulli's Prissy Miss beat the Rupaca Farm's Layaway by a nose in the Rockville Purse at Laurel today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 25 -- Harvard opened the doors of its Medical School to women today for the first time since the school was founded 162 years ago.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- The Figaro will publish tomorrow what it presents as an eyewitness story of the destruction of the village of Maille in the Department of Indreet-Loire in Tourraine and the slaying of 125 persons or virtually the whole population, by Germans on Aug. 25.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- France, through her diplomatic delegation in Washington, has submitted for the approval of the Foreign Economic Administration a proposition for the purchase of locomotives to put the battered French railway system into operation again, it was learned today.
Oct. 1 -- New York's traditional "moving day" -- will bring delays, disappointments and confusion this year to countless families, a survey indicated yesterday.

The stock market almost closed yesterday the breach opened in the last three weeks as prices scored the second best recovery of the month. Supplied with a favorable background by the sharp spurt in the commodity exchanges, where the major staples jumped the limit permitted for a single session, strength rotated from one group to another throughout the day in the share list and produced gains of a point and more.

ROME, Sept. 25 -- The investigation of the assassination of the anti-Fascist, Carlo Rosselli, in France in 1937 is developing into one of the biggest international scandals of the past decade, it was learned today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Tuesday, Sept. 26 (AP) -- A communique:

A group of underwriters headed by Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., will offer today a portion of 120,000 shares of Gulf States Utilities Company's $4.40 dividend preferred stock, subject to the exchange rights of present preferred stockholders under an offer that will expire on Oct. 4.
SEATTLE, Sept. 25 (AP) -- "Usability" of China's new lifeline, the Ledo Road, was disclosed today by The Post-Intelligencer.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Taking the lead in the far turn after running third, Mrs. Sam Orr's Chance Yen today won the $2,000 North Shore purse at Narragansett Park.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Sept. 26 -- A Navy Black Cat," one of the old slow-flying Catalinas that in recent weeks have maintained a constant night patrol over Philippine waters, scored an impressive triumph during the week-end, hitting a seaplane tender and two destroyer escorts in a single bombing run, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's communique today announced.

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 25 -- The marines on Peleliu pushed their spearheads along the western shore Sunday to new positions within a mile of the northern end of the island, by-passing the strongly held ridge where the battle has been stalemated, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz's communique said tonight.

All persons who have not donated blood for the wounded overseas should visit the Blood Donor Center, at 2 East Thirty-seventh Street, Basil O'Connor, new national chairman of the American Red Cross, suggested yesterday, on his first official visit to the New York chapter's center.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Office of Price Administration moved today to eliminate the differential between the East Coast and the rest of the country in validity dates for "A" gasoline ration coupons.
ROME, Sept. 25 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Eric A. Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, declared at a fall conference of the National Association of Home Builders today that "local spirit and local initiative" must spring-board our expanding economy after the war.

An exhibition of decorative textiles from all over the world, designed to inspire a greater appreciation of the hand skills of contemporary artists and encourage them to new endeavors, opened yesterday afternoon at America House, 485 Madison Avenue.

MONTREAL, Sept. 25 -- Herbert H. Lehman said today that he hoped to visit Moscow as soon as possible to supplement the work of the special mission which the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration was sending there at the invitation of the Russian Government.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Communique 170:

The suffering caused by the war and hopes for an early and permanent peace will be reflected in Jewish synagogues and other places of worship as services at sundown this evening usher in Yom Kippur, the traditional Jewish Day of Atonement.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The country's war plants turned out munitions that cost $5,430,000,000 during August, and raising the month's total to 97 per cent of its scheduled program, the War Production Board reported today.

There is every reason to believe that credit requirements of the post-war period may be met without difficulty, whatever they may be, according to the October issue of The Guaranty Survey, business review of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The joint chiefs of staff have concluded finally that the capital, for the first time since Pearl Harbor, is safe from enemy air attack.

Murray Cohen, 28-year-old owner of four "Marco Polo" restaurants, was convicted yesterday of conspiring to evade the draft with the benefit of another man's hernia. A jury in Federal court returned its verdict to Judge John Holland in an hour and fifty-five minutes.

The need for continuing without interruption or lessening of the home and war services of the nonprofit hospitals of the city, was stressed at the sixty-sixth annual United Hospital Campaign launched last night at a dinner in the Hotel Commodore.

Cotton futures advanced widely yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange on heavy mill, trade and speculative buying brought on by the announcement that the Federal Government, through the War Food Administrator and the Commodity Credit Corporation, would purchase raw cotton at parity levels.
Mrs. Henry Coster Emmet has returned to the Plaza from Castine, Me., where she spent the summer.

To initiate a ticket-selling campaign for the annual White Elephant cocktail party and tea dance on Oct. 26 in the main ballroom of the Plaza, Mrs. Henry J. Taylor, chairman of arrangements, and Mr. Taylor will give a reception tomorrow afternoon at their home, 960 Fifth Avenue, for members of a men's committee headed by L. Boyd Hatch and Winthrop Smith.

John Steinbeck's new novel, "Cannery Row," will be published in 1945 by Viking. His "Of Mice and Men" will be the first play to be presented at the French National Theatre in Paris when it is reopened after having been dark for many months.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- Tomorrow is going to be a wonderful day for milady, because she no longer will have to sit under a hair dryer in a beauty shop to simmer and bake her complexion while her pin curls dry, predicted hairdressers today at the silver anniversary convention of the American Cosmeticians National Association.
LONDON, Sept. 25 -- The "delicate problem" of the French Forces of the Interior is being solved, Lieut. Gen. Joseph-Pierre Koenig, their commander, declared today.

CAMP McKALL, N.C., Sept. 25 (UP) -- Army airborne maneuvers, a large-scale demonstrations of startling new techniques following months of training for more than 8,000 paratroopers, gliders and transport troops, were completed here today with seventy-one casualties -- thirteen dead and fifty-eight injured.
After reading the latest reports of the advancing Allied armies into Germany it is evident that a class of snipers are boys of ages 9 to 15.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 -- An involved intra-system series of transactions in the holding company system of the NY PA NJ Utilities Company was proposed today for consideration by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Mr. Dewey's speech at San Francisco states that economic security must accompany political freedom. "We must find a way to have both." This brings to mind the endless pages in the Congressional Record wherein the Republicans with all but unbroken ranks have done their best to crush all hope of economic security.

The Postoffice Department this year is faced with the tremendous task of handling 80,000,000 to 90,000,000 Christmas packages going to American fighting forces overseas, Postmaster General Frank C. Walker yesterday disclosed at the formal dedication of the new $3,500,000 branch of the New York Port of Embarkation Postoffice in Long Island City, Queens.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- F.A. Lange's Double Brab and the Happy Hour Farm's Impenetrable shared honors today in the two best races at Hawthorne.
Yesterday's communique as broadcast from Chungking in English to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Chinese troops are engaging two Japanese columns apparently attempting to envelop Kweilin in flanking movements, the High Command announced today as bitter fighting was reported all along the Chinese battlefront.

MONTREAL, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Thousands of Norway's most prominent citizens are being rounded up by the Germans and shipped to Germany as hostages, the Norwegian Ambassador to the United States, Wilhelm Morgenstierne, said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Cubs swept a doubleheader from the Phillies tonight, taking the nightcap, 4-1, after going ten innings for a 7-6 victory in the opener. Only 1,611 fans watched the proceedings.

DETROIT, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Russ Christopher, lanky Philadelphia right-hander, tamed the Tigers on four hits today as the Athletics captured the opener of a three-game series, 2 to 1, before a crowd of 5,881.

" Delinquent Daughters," a drama about juvenile delinquency, and a Western, "West of the Rio Grande," compose the week's new double-feature program, starting today, at the New York Theatre. . . . "The Impatient Years" today enters its second week at Loew's Criterion.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- As large creditors of the Federal Government, banks are in a vulnerable political position, Dr. Marcus Nadler, Finance Professor at New York University, warned the American Bankers Association today. In an address to the national bank division he said that they were in danger of being made victims of unorthodox financial methods intended to ease the load of the war-swollen Government debt.

Buddy Kerr, up-and-coming shortstop of the Giants, stepped to the plate with none out in the ninth and the score tied at 2-all yesterday, slammed Ed Heusser's first offering against the left field scoreboard and with this home-run wallop handed the Reds a 3-2 setback before 982 paying customers at the Polo Grounds.

The Board of Higher Education reinstated last night Seymour S. Leikind, tutor in chemistry suspended at Brooklyn College on March 16, 1944, after he had charged that "official efforts" were directed toward concealing communist activity at the school.
A total of $58,962,000 in new securities of two public utility corporations was sold yesterday to investment banking groups at competitive sales.

The Third Fleet's attack on the northern Philippines, on only the first two days of which the official communiques have reported, continued through Friday and Saturday, according to Radio Tokyo. Admiral William F. Halsey apparently is not going to leave the area until his fliers and his ships have destroyed every worth-while target they can find.

Lack of electric power eleven days after the hurricane has greatly inconvenienced most households in Suffolk County and some in Nassau, but, it was learned yesterday, the handicap proved positively exasperating to Charles Hendrickson, chief of the volunteer firefighting force in the town of Syosset on the North Shore of Long Island.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed an increase of 15 per cent over the like week last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Serve Bank of New York. For the preceding week, sales had shown a rise of 1 per cent.
LONDON, Sept. 25 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 25 (AP) -- The State's anti-Roosevelt Democrats, who officially list themselves as "Texas Regulars," today filed with the Secretary of State here a state of Presidential elector nominees for the general election ballot.
When a newly arrived Navy ship resounds these days with bugle blasts and orchestral strains of "The Sidewalks of New York" its crew awaits the voice of Mayor La Guardia saying:
At San Francisco Mr. Dewey set out to prove that we can have both political freedom and economic security. He developed the fact that we are fast losing both under the New Deal.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, Sept. 26 -- Still another attempt by crack German SS troops and tanks to block off the Allies' spearhead pointing north through the Netherlands toward the Westphalian Plain was swept aside yesterday.

THERE was once a time when literature could be divided into neat compartments. You could tell a poem because of the rhymes or the strong beat of a regular meter. You could tell a novel from a biography because the first was an imaginary story, although it could make use of factual material, and the second was an account of a man's life confined to ascertainable facts and legitimate interpretation of them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- In his twenty-second seizure order involving management-labor disputes that have become deadlocked before the War Labor Board, President Roosevelt directed Secretary of War Stimson today to take over and operate the Farrell Cheek Steel Company at Sandusky, Ohio.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Sweden's decision to prohibit German shipping in certain of her most accessible ports has been received with gratification by the United States Government. Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today after a conference with the Swedish Minister, W. Bostrom.

Two thousand persons, representing a hundred Greek-American societies here, held yesterday afternoon a memorial meeting in Madison Square Park to mark the Nazi destruction of Distomo in Greece. Led by Archbishop Athenagoras of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America, they prayed for the early liberation of Greece.

At Hearns, 20 West Fourteenth Street, a new delicacy department was opened yesterday. Unusual foods, canned and glassed, comprise the stock, which serves as a supplement to the more down-to-earth wares sold in the main grocery section.

The Corning Glass Works announced yesterday the purchase of a substantial interest in the Vidreria Santa Marina of Sao Paulo, leading glass company in Brazil. In 1943 the Corning company made a similar contract with Argentina's foremost glass concern, Cristalerias Rigolleau of Buenos Aires.

A new argument against any word of criticism of Soviet Russia has made its appearance; or if not exactly new, it has been heavily stressed of late. It takes the form of saying that every censorious word uttered in this country against Russia helps to prolong the war by whipping up German hopes of a rift in Allied unity.

BOSTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- After scoring another run for a 13-8 victory while completing a game suspended here after eight innings on Aug. 1, the Pirates today dropped the regularly scheduled contest to the Braves by 5 -- 4 in thirteen innings.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 25 -- Humphrey Bogart has been named by Warner Brothers to star with Bette Davis in the screen version of the Owen Davis-Donald Davis play "Ethan Frome" after Miss Davis does "Stolen Life" and Mr. Bogart completes "The Big Sleep."

E.C. Barringer, president and executive secretary of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel, Inc., trade organization of scrap iron dealers, announced yesterday in Washington that the institute's special committee to consider trading in scrap iron futures has taken a unanimous position against such a market.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- All but out of it as they dejectedly trekked their way out of Cleveland last night, the Yankees, with a heroic effort, virtually chinned themselves back onto the outer rim of the American League flag race today by wrenching two games away from the White Sox.

The Worcester Royal Porcelain Company, Inc., and A.N. Khouri Brothers, now at 19 East Forty-seventh Street, have purchased from Frederick Brown the five-story commercial building on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 234-36 East Forty-sixth Street.

BILLY SOUTHWORTH'S main worry at the moment is to obtain hotel reservations in St. Louis for his family during the world series. The usually efficient Billy the Kid slipped up on that little item because he was so busy trying to help out friends in the same predicament that he overlooked taking care of himself. Otherwise, though, the Cards are ready for the post-season classic.

A petition, signed by the principal and twenty-five teachers of Flushing High School, objecting to the banning of the Lord's Prayer at student assemblies, has been prepared and is to be sent to the Board of Education, it became known yesterday.

The War Department has completed plans for the disposition of all prisoners of war who are rescued from the enemy and returned to military control, Lieut. Col. Joseph B. Kavanaugh, chief of the American Section, Prisoner of War Information Bureau of the Office of Provost Marshal General, said yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Ed Klieman shut out Washington with four singles tonight as the Indians defeated the Senators, 6 to 0.

First of the trade organizations to rally to the support of investment bankers in rebuttal of Department of Justice attacks against long-standing practices in the underwriting of new securities, the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., made public yesterday letters sent to members of Congress as a result of action by its board of directors.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 25 -- The possible return of former King Carol to the throne of Rumania was being discussed today in diplomatic and Rumanian circles as a result of conversations that were understood to be taking place between the Russian Ambassador, Constantine Oumansky, and the former monarch.

Marvin Jones, War Food Administrator, announced Saturday night that the Government would buy from farmers at parity prices all cotton of the 1944 crop for which a loan schedule had been announced and which might be placed in acceptable storage. He announced a similar program for wheat.

Theft of two carbines by a pair of merchant seamen forced two soldiers to go ashore on the Normandy beach in June without their weapons, Robert Mitchell, assistant United States attorney, charged yesterday. He arraigned the seamen, Edward Berton Henry, 25 years old, of Lynn, Mass., and Glennroy Gee, 21, of Cincinnati, Ohio, before United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- In part reversing an earlier action, the Office of Price Administration ruled today that manufacturing retailers of women's and children's outerwear garments and fur coats and men's and boys' tailored clothing will be subject, on and after Nov. 24, to the controversial highest price line limitation which was removed from these items of apparel on June 30.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Having pigeonholed the original Beveridge Plan for social security from the cradle to the grave, Prime Minister Churchill's Coalition Government offered Britain today "something just as good."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Without denying, the reported split in President Roosevelt's Cabinet committee on a peace policy toward Germany, Secretary of State Cordell Hull today declared the question was still under study and that the "higher officials" of the governments concerned would make the final decision.
Sunday's communique, as broadcast from Sofia yesterday and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The President's opening speech frankly addressed to his re-election interest was, by the normal political tests, a success. His hearers, who included some of his chief campaign directors, were sincere when they expressed the belief that Mr. Roosevelt had swept away all doubts of his physical capacity to carry on for another four years and had turned the Democratic campaign from defense to attack.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 25 -- Larry Burke and Pat Cici of the home club scored 34 -- 33 -- 67, four strokes under par, to win the one-day amateur-pro of the Long Island P.G.A. at the Salisbury golf links today. Cici shot an individual 71.
HELSINKI, Sept. 25 -- The concession of the Porkkala Peninsula imposed by Moscow on Finland may force the Finns to move their capital from Helsinki to Aabo.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 25 (AP) -- A wave of killings was reported sweeping German-occupied northern Italy today, where the newspaper Regime Fascista exhorted Blackshirts to avenge the execution in Rome of Pietro Caruso.

LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 26 (AP) -- About 2,000 American planes, including more than 1,200 Flying Fortresses and Liberators, hammered home yesterday Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's warning to foreign workers to leave German plants or face the gravest danger.

PARIS, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Porfirio Rubirosa, Dominican diplomat and husband of screen actress Danielle Darrieux, is in serious condition in a hospital here from a gunshot wound in the kidney, reported inflicted the night of Sept. 22 as the couple and friends were driving home from a nightclub.

LONDON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The British Government made public today its social security plan to provide unemployment and sickness insurance, health service, widows' pensions, retirement pensions, family allowances, orphan's allowance, motherhood grants and death grants.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The American, British and Russian Governments have decided to be satisfied, for the time being, with 90 per cent agreement on the kind of international security organization they wish to see established and to take up at "the highest level" the other 10 per cent at some future date.

At the start of his eleventh year in office, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine declared yesterday that crime, "with the exception of a few outbreaks, is really on the decrease." Mr. Valentine, nineteenth New York Police Commissioner, has served longer than any of his predecessors.

WITH THE FRENCH ARMY on the Belfort Front, Sept. 24 (Delayed) -- Warning that the hardest fighting still lay ahead inside Germany, Gen. Charles de Gaulle told French Army commanders and civilian leaders today that the end of the European war must not be expected before next spring, "contrary to hopes too hastily conceived."

LONDON, Sept 25 (U.P.) -- The battle for Belgrade was under way tonight as Yugoslav Partisans smashed into the capital's outskirts while other patriot forces captured the vital Bosnian military and communications center of Banja Luka and British commandos tightened the noose around the German Adriatic garrisons by seizing Solta Island.

One of the metropolitan season's biggest racing days is in store for today's racing fans at Belmont Park where the Lawrence Realization and the Futurity Trial head the program which also includes the Nesconset Handicap for Class D horses.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The fighting Browns climbed into a first-place tie with Detroit tonight in the American League pennant race as they defeated the Boston Red Sox, 3 to 0, behind the brilliant two-hit pitching of Nelson Potter.

LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 26 -- Red Army forces virtually completed the liberation of the Estonian mainland yesterday, sealed the German escape port of Haapsalu in a thirty-two-mile advance and crashed through the new German "winter line" east of Riga, Latvian capital. Riga was threatened by if our armies seeking to conclude the Baltic campaign. [I-Ielsinki, Finnish capital, Continued on Page 11, Colmn 1

Those men you see crippling through Grand Central Terminal and Pennsylvania and Long Island stations these mornings probably are not victims of an automobile accident, the gasoline situation being what it is. They are sufferers from the hurricane, second degree.

With the critical situation of the "lost divisions" at Arnhem still in doubt despite some reinforcements, the Allied flanking movement through the Netherlands into northwestern Germany is acquiring new momentum in what is virtually an Allied Schlieffen plan in reverse.

The proposal to make "V-E Day" one of solemn thankfulness and commemoration has been warmly endorsed, and naturally so, by Mayor La Guardia and spokesmen for the Catholic, Protestant and Jewish faiths. Places of worship will be kept open throughout the day, and in each, according to its ritual, prayers will be offered in gratitude to God and to the living and the dead who have by their sacrifices made the victory over nazism possible.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 25 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, disclosing tonight that some of the millions of foreign workers in Germany had been organized into resistance groups and were being supplied with arms, called on these "organized cells" to take "immediate action according to the prearranged plan."

Estimating that there will he 50,000 personal aircraft in the New York metropolitan area within five years of the war's end, Joseph Geuting Jr., chairman of the personal aircraft council of the national Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce, told a luncheon meeting in the Waldorf yesterday that so far the city of New York made no provision in its post-war plans for the necessary "air parks," "air harbors" and "flight stops."

PELELIU, Palau, Sept. 21 (delayed) -- This is the story of two brave men -- two Americans on Peleliu. One is dead and will be buried in the Marine cemetery and the other is presumably back in there hauling out wounded since for some reason he prefers carrying stretchers at the front to his own work as chief pharmacist's mate at the beach station.
LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Although the stock market today opened the week on a quiet note, generally the tone was firm.

FLORENCE, Sept. 25 -- Since military government was established weeks ago under Brig. Gen. Edgar Erskine Hume, the Fifth Army's senior civil affairs officer, considerable progress has been made toward bringing life back to Florence under conditions more difficult than in any city of comparable importance and size.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Supreme Court of Pennsylvania today was asked to decide if State courts have authority to set aside a National Labor Relations Board collective bargaining election, because of alleged fraud in balloting, and if they have the right to nullify a resultant employer-union contract.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Foreign Economic Administration, reporting on its first year as the country's economic warrior, declared today that its operations had been in large part responsible for the industrial weaknesses of Germany and that an intensification of similar economic intelligence was being thrown against Japan.

Laurent Hendrikus Johannes Brackx, 49-year-old native of the Netherlands and naturalized United States citizen, who has been under surveillance by the Federal Bureau of Investigation since 1940, was arrested yesterday and accused of having come here on commission of the Italian Government to spy out the secrets of radar.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Control in Germany and in former occupied countries of companies which collaborated with the Axis' "effort to gain world domination" has been accepted by the Governments of the United States and Britain, a State Department spokesman said tonight.
CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 25 (AP) A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- After the 39-6 defeat Syracuse took from Cornell last Saturday night in the Archbold Stadium, there wouldn't seem to be very much for the Orange to expect except a crescendo performance by the anvil chorus of the downtown quarterbacks. In war as well as peace, the local tobacco shop experts function in full strength, and that is the only normal aspect of the football situation here.

Moviegoers who gulped at the devotion of the maid, Fidelia, in "Since You Went Away" may be enlightened when they see the room Sloane's decorators designed for her in "The House of Years" that opened yesterday in new fall dress.

LONDON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- German propagandists today rose in frenzied denunciation of the Morgenthau plan for a "hard peace," and it appeared that Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden or even Prime Minister Churchill might choose the subject for an early speech in Parliament.

FIFTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Sept. 18 (Delayed) (AP) -- The United States Fifth Air Force's ninety-nine fighter "aces" have shot down 777 Japanese aircraft in combat, but it is becoming increasingly apparent that the "ace" business is headed toward a depression because of a scarcity of Japanese.

WEST HARTLEPOOL, County Durham, Sept. 25 (Reuter) -- The hands, feet and face of a British merchant seaman who has just reached home after escaping from a German prisoners of war camp bear witness to a sickening story of Nazi cruelty.

LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Flying bombs came over the east coast of England during last night to continue the enemy's attack for the tenth straight night. The missiles raced in from an east-northeasterly direction, indicating that they were launched from German aircraft in the region of the North Sea.

MOSCOW, Sept. 24 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- As Germany plunges deeper into the gloom of defeat Moscow is gradually brightening, and the rhythm of normal life is beating stronger in the Soviet capital every day.

Thoughtful revision of wage scales and working conditions in those service industries in which women workers have traditionally outnumbered men, would ease competition for post-war jobs in other industries, Frieda S. Miller, new director of the Women's Bureau in the United States Department of Labor, declared here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The House Campaign Expenditures Committee today postponed until tomorrow action on a recommendation of its counsel that it institute contempt proceedings against Edward A. Rumely for refusal to turn over records of contributions made to the Committee for Constitutional Government, founded by Frank Gannett, New York State newspaper publisher.

President Roosevelt will make at least two campaign speeches in New York State before election day, Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic national chairman, indicated yesterday. One will be in New York City, probably in the last week before the election, and one up-State, according to present plans.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Robert Sherwood, Director of the Overseas Branch of the Office of War Information, resigned today to permit himself freedom in campaigning for the re-election of President Roosevelt.

ROME, Sept. 25 (AP) -- American troops of the Fifth Army, smashing beyond the core of the Gothic Line, were fighting forward tonight less than twelve miles from the Bologna-Rimini highway, the main escape route for the German forces still battling desperately northwest of Rimini.
Yesterday's comnunique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
A special communique, as broadcast in English by the New Yugoslav Wireless and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

After being shut out of 1944 allotments for the Indian market by what they call "cartel-like arrangements," independent auto parts manufacturers face a similar lot next year because of a proposed extension of lend-lease buying for that area, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill, in a joint statement issued here and in London today, declared that the Italian people had demonstrated their will to be free, to fight on the side of the democracies and to take a place among the United Nations for peace and justice.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 -- A plan for reorganization of the Mobile (Ala.) Gas Service Corporation, a subsidiary of the Consolidated Electric and Gas Company, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Commissioner Chester C. Du Mond of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets told delegates to the conference of the North Atlantic Section of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers yesterday that lowering the cost of production of farm equipment would revolutionize their production in this area after the war.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept 26 (AP) -- The Phillies and the Cubs exchanged lambastings in a double-header at Shibe Park tonight, with the home club pounding out a 10-1 victory after the Cubs had taken the opener, 15 -- 0.

Gov. Edward Martin of Pennsylvania reported yesterday at a joint press conference with Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National Chairman, that the Republicans would get a larger share of the workingmen's vote in the Keystone State this year than at any time since 1932.

BOSTON, Sept. 26 -- Plans under which returning service men and women may receive credit for experience and study in the armed forces if they desired to continue their formal education were outlined today before more than 100 educators from New England and the Middle Atlantic States.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Grain futures, which closed at the top yesterday, up 5 cents a bushel from Saturday's finish as the result of buying based on a Government program to purchase wheat at parity prices, reversed their course today on the Board of Trade.

Aiding the Women's Army Corps drive to form an all-New York company in honor of Lieut. Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, commander of the American forces on Bataan and Corregidor and now a prisoner of the Japanese, Mayor La Guardia issued a proclamation yesterday at City Hall fixing Oct. 1-15 as the official recruiting period.

Most colleges and universities are planning to go back, after V-day, to the traditional four-year curriculum with two semesters a year and the long summer vacation. This allows, of course, for the old summer session.

Plans for a widespread program of education designed to prevent loss through fraud of the huge sayings now in the hands of the public, estimated at $130,000,000,000, were formulated yesterday at the conclusion of a two-day meeting of representatives of the National Association of Better Business Bureaus at the Hotel Lexington.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Complete disruption of futures tradings in agricultural commodities is threatened if the Administration insists on offering to buy such commodities as cotton and wheat at full parity prices, and the Office of Price Administration retains these 100 per cent parity prices as its ceilings, Maurice Mandeville, president of the National Association of Commodity Exchanges and Allied Trades, Inc., declared today at a meeting of resident directors.

The Virginian adds its name to the growing list of railroads that are expected to undertake major refunding operations in the next few weeks. According to reports yesterday, the company plans to enter the market with a new issue, the proceeds from which will be used to retire the outstanding $60,000,000 of first and refunding 3 3/4s, due in 1966, which are callable at 106.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- This city is the national laboratory of politics, and the chemists of that trade were busy today making tests of the political situation as it may have been affected by the President's first campaign speech and the reply of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey. The findings of a majority of the experts as reported to this correspondent were as follows:

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Browns remained tied for first place in the American League by defeating the Red Sox tonight, 1 to 0. In one of the most spectacular pitching battles of the season at Sportsman's Park, Sigmund Jakucki, 32-year-old rookie from a Houston shipyard, beat the veteran Mike Ryba and posted the second St. Louis shut-out of Boston in two nights before 18,655 spectators.

SAPULPA, Okla., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Sapulpa and central Oklahoma turned out 15,000 strong today to welcome home Mrs. Thomas E. Dewey. Governor Dewey became Mr. Frances Hutt for the day, husband of Sapulpa's most distinguished daughter, and Mrs. Frances Hutt Dewey stole the show.

The possibility of Federal action on commercial rent gouging increased yesterday as Senator Robert F. Wagner, after a conference with manufacturers here, announced that on his return to Washington the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, of which he is chairman, would open hearings "on the whole problem" of commercial rent ceilings.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 26 (AP) -- A woman was reported on the way today from Memphis to claim custody of 11-year-old Harry Feldern Jr., whose father, Harry Feldern, 58, died yesterday on a downtown street from a heart attack after buying the youth a cameo ring for his birthday present.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- American merchant ships will cease picking up cargoes at Argentine ports on northbound runs on Oct. 1, the State Department said today. The ban will also prevent the ships from taking on Argentine cargoes at such transshipment points as Montevideo, Uruguay.

Women trade union members, housewives in women's civic groups and Government representatives from both local and Federal agencies must cooperate after the war in solving such problems of community welfare as health, housing and employment for women, Miss Frieda S. Miller, new director of the Women's Bureau in the United States Department of Labor, said yesterday.
DETROIT, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Paul (Dizzy) Trout, making his twenty-seventh victory of the season his seventh shut-out, blanked the Athletics, 6 to 0, today.

The War Advertising Council, Inc., a non-profit organization representing all phases of advertising that was set up to further the war effort, announced yesterday that it had advised the United States Public Health Service that it could no longer assist in obtaining sponsors for the present educational advertising campaign against venereal diseases.

LONDON, Sept. 26 (U.P.) -- Accounts of the Germans' casualties when they tried to invade Britain in the fall of 1940 and were defeated when Royal Air Force planes turned the Channel waters along the European coast into what the Germans involved called a hell of flames by dumping oil on the sea and firing it with incendiary bullets, were given by responsible Belgians last week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Senator Burton K. Wheeler, Democrat of Montana, who was a leading opponent of President Roosevelt's foreign policy before Pearl Harbor, started tonight his campaign against the Administration's plan to create an international security organization before the end of the war.
There are those who are now saying that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey is not offering anything specific or constructive in his program of progress for the country.

Appalled by the inequities and injustices of capitalist civilization, they veer toward totalitarian statism; and, horrified by the tyranny of totalitarianism, they drift back to capitalist democracy.

As religious and civic leaders in Queens rose to the defense of the Flushing High School petition protesting what was felt to be a directive banning recitation of the Lord's Prayer in public schools, Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday that no such ban existed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The success of women as nurses on the battle fronts was cited today by Senator Claude Pepper of Florida, chairman of the Subcommittee on War-time Health and Education, as evidence that, given the opportunity, women could greatly lessen the shortage of physicians.

American industry faces one of its greatest trials in its public relations approach to the problems of reconversion and post-war production, Paul Garrett, vice president of General Motors Corporation, declared last night at the New York Athletic Club, at a dinner where he and Eric A. Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, were honored for their work in the field of public relations.
LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Publication of the Government's all-embracing social security plan caused a sharp drop in insurance shares today but a rise in the spirit of large sections of the British public.

An exhibition called "American Battle Painting: 1776-1918" opened with a private view yesterday afternoon at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. It opens to the public today and will continue through Nov. 12.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 26 -- Arriving four hours before she was scheduled, the Swedish repatriation liner Gripsholm tied up at Pier F, American Export Line, here at 11:30 A.M. today, bringing home 219 wounded and seriously ill American officers and enlisted personnel who had been prisoners of war in Germany.
The Continental lotors CorpoI ration showed a net income of $5,074,757 for the nine months ended on July 31. according to the statement of operations issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Post-war plans of the Maritime Commission for development of the merchant marine contemplate the shipping of 50 per cent of United States exports in United States ships, a House subcommittee on post-war economic policy and planning was told today, but that goal would not be realized without a continuation of construction and operating subsidies.

The War Shipping Administration released yesterday details of the story of this country's first Liberty ship, the Patrick Henry, which was launched in Baltimore on Sept. 27, 1941, as the first unit of the nation's wartime emergency fleet.

DETROIT, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The United Automobile Workers (CIO) Union made public today a letter from an Army Air Forces representative paying tribute to a union leader who left a sickbed to stop a strike and died shortly afterward.

Three new films will open in midtown theatres today. At the Roxy the new attraction will be "Greenwich Village," a Twentieth Century-Fox musical romance filmed in Technicolor. Heading the picture's cast are William Bendix, Carmen Miranda, Don Ameche, Vivian Blaine and the dance team of Tony and Sally De Marco.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 26 (AP) -The Senators enjoyed a field day at bat today as they walloped the Indians, 8 to 3, reaching five Tribe pitchers for fifteen blows. Every Senator chalked up at least one hit except Pitcher Emil Leonard.

In view of the present shortage of butter, as well as its high point value, a ration-free product being introduced today at Abraham Straus in Brooklyn is especially timely. It is a vegetable spread, which, though not a substitute for butter, may be used effectively in place of it in many instances.

ROME, Sept. 26 -- British troops yesterday crossed the Rubicon River, which was our own and the Allied symbol of new hopes for a speedy end of the war, but despite that, it must be stated that it was a day of stubborn resistance and heavy counter-attacks.
HONOLULU, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Army faces the task of winning four straight when the "service men's world series" resumes tomorrow after Navy's twelve-inning 4-to-3 victory yesterday, its third in a row.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- A score of American Federation of Labor leaders, headed by George Meany, secretary-treasurer; Matthew Woll, vice president, and John P. Frey, president of the Metal Trades Department, warned the National War Labor Board today that unless the board requested President Roosevelt to set aside the Little Steel formula, wages during the reconversion period would be decided by the play of economic forces, with resultant "strikes, strife and economic chaos."

The original manuscripts of Charles Dickens' novel, "Our Mutual Friend," and of Edgar Allan Poe's "Murders in the Rue Morgue" will be placed on sale at public auction next month, together with other important literary and historical autographs, it was announced yesterday by the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

BOSTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Scoring in each period, the Philadelphia Eagles defeated the Boston Yankees, 28 -- 7, as National League football returned to Boston tonight after a seven-year lapse. A paid crowd of 19,815 witnessed the game, which was the regular season's opener for both teams.

Although the Madison Square Garden Corporation spent between $85,000 and $100,000 for repairs during the first quarter beginning June 1, the loss normally sustained during the summer months was $10,000 less than in the same period of last year, Ned Irish, acting president, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday.

Conditions imposed by Gunder Haegg, Arne Andersson and Haakan Lidman make it appear unlikely that they will come to this country from their native Sweden, it was learned yesterday. WASHINGTON, Sept 26 -- A circumstance interesting Federal financial officials is that while British critics of the monetary fund approved at Bretton Woods say it represents a return to "the gold standard," the most vocal critics in the United States have been saying that it bears too little resemblance to such a standard.

The British Government has brought forward its social security plan. Like the Beveridge plan, it is designed to insure everybody against all the common hazards of life. It will provide unemployment and sickness insurance, health service, widows' pensions, retirement pensions, family allowances, orphans' allowances, motherhood grants and death grants.

Kurt Dittmar, German High Command radio spokesman, said tonight that there were still "hopelessly corrupt personalities" in the German Army, especially in its rear forces and administrative branches, and that these "must be annihilated wherever they show themselves."

LONDON, Sept. 26 (U.P.) -- In the House of Commons today Prime Minister Churchill paid tribute to the "Heroism and tenacity of the Polish Home Army and the population of Warsaw, who after five years of oppression fought for nearly two months to contribute all in their power to the expulsion of Germans from the capital of Poland."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Wednesday, Sept. 27 (U.P.) -- Allied planes lashed out at numerous targets on the path to the Philippines on Sunday and Monday, attacking Ceram with sixty-five tons of bombs and sinking five small vessels, damaging four and hitting numerous other enemy craft, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Joseph B. Keenan, former assistant attorney general, told the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee today that he regarded Senator Nye, Republican, of North Dakota, as "a man with dangerous political views" and he hoped Nye would be defeated in the fall election.

LONDON, Wednesday, Sept. 27 -- Three mighty Soviet armies, racing toward Riga as the Germans hastily began to evacuate the shell-torn Latvian capital, converged on the city from the north, northeast, east and southeast yesterday and seized more than 500 towns and settlements in Latvia and Estonia.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Lieut. Gen. Ben Lear, commanding the Army Ground Forces, has issued a pamphlet to all units stressing the importance of conserving and safeguarding materiel and supplies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Earl of Halifax, British Ambassador, conferred today on behalf of King George honors, decorations and medals on twenty-four Americans and foreigners for acts of heroism and distinguished services during the war. One woman was on the list.

Cotton prices eased yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The close was 15 to 17 points net lower and virtually at the lows of the day. Uncertainty about the working details of the Government program to buy and sell cotton at parity led to liquidation.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Adios won both heats of the free-for-all pace at the Grand Circuit harness races today in 1:58 1/4 for each mile to set a world record for a two-heat race and also to lower the season race record.

The newest of this country's wartime pennants, the War Shipping Administration's War Service Flag, will be hoisted aloft in seventeen cities today, the home ports of our ship lines, in the third observance of Victory Fleet Day, which is dedicated this year to the American steamship companies for their accomplishment in operating our vastly expanded American Merchant Marine.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The War Production Board, in an effort to end duplication of function by different regulations, today revoked two limitation orders controlling the manufacture of fountain pens, mechanical pencils and pen nibs.

ROME, Sept. 26 -- Premier Ivanoe Bonomi averted a governmental crisis today when he insisted he would stay in office only if all six major Italian parties locally supported him. A banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. won yesterday the award of an issue of $2,000,000 of Baltimore County, Md., Metropolitan District bonds on a bid of par for a combination of interest rates which afforded the county a net interest cost for the funds of 1.561 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- For the fourteenth consecutive year, immigration fell below the 100,000 mark and was substantially less than the legal quota, Attorney General Francis Biddle said today.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- The Government's white paper on social insurance caused traders to knock down the prices of industrial insurance shares in today's stock markets. At the reduced prices the market became steadier, the shares coming on offer being readily absorbed.

Unfortunately, our American election is not just a domestic event. It involves our relations with the whole world. Unless we have personal contact with Europeans, we Americans have no conception of the relations of this year's Presidential election to world politics.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Prime Minister Churchill was welcomed and cheered in the streets of London and in the halls of Parliament today when he returned to Westminster. But he found that members of the House of Commons and the House of Lords were concerned about plans that were being made for the punishment of war criminals, the treatment of vanquished Germany and the international organization for the maintenance of peace.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Communique 171:

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Although their position seems to become hourly more hopeless, the Yankees nevertheless clung grimly to their slender hold in the waning American League pennant race tonight by trouncing the White Sox for their third straight victory of the series.
PAWTUCKET, R. I., Sept. 26 (AP) -- E. H. Carson's Golden Thorn made his first start since June a winning one today when he took the Lowell Purse at Narragansett Park.

Brilliant and inept by turns, the Dodgers finally let the ineptitude triumph and dropped their second straight to the champion Cardinals at Ebbets Field yesterday, 8 -- 7, a setback that also represented the Brooks' eighteenth humbling by the champs in twenty-one games.

LONDON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- For the second successive day about 1,200 heavy bombers of the United States Eighth Air Force smashed at targets in Germany, dropping more than 3,500 tons of high explosives and incendiaries on Nazi war plants and railway yards jammed with Army supplies without encountering any Nazi fighter opposition and running through spotty flak.
LONDON, Sept. 26 -- The military correspondent of The Times, London, writes as follows:
LONDON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

KATONAH, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- Kenneth Ives, New York real estate broker, died today at the Four Winds Sanitarium here. Dr. Amos O. Squire, County Medical Examiner, ruled he had committed suicide while mentally disturbed.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The battle for Kweilin, strategic Allied base in southern China, took another serious turn tonight as a Japanese column approached Kungcheng, forty-seven miles southeast of Kweilin.
LONDON, Sept. 27 -- The stock markets here displayed today a certain amount of uncertainty, buyers holding off pending delivery of Prime Minister Churchill's statement on the war.

Clyde King, 20-year-old North Carolina collegian, gave himself and 5,514 Brooklyn fans a bit of a thrill yesterday when he registered his first major league triumph and scored it over the class of the National League, the champion Cardinals, by 3 -- 2 at Ebbets Field.

Two new Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer films will arrive in Brodway theatres this morning. They are "The Seventh Cross," an adaptation of the Anna Seghers novel, starring Spencer Tracy and Signe Hasso, at the Capitol, and "Maisie Goes to Reno," latest chapter in the series starring Ann Sothern, at Loew's State.

ALBANY, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals was asked today to grant a reargument of the appeal of Charles H. Mullens, former Assistant Deputy State Controller, and William Solomon, former Tammany leader, whose conviction on charges of taking bribes for diverting State printing contracts was reversed by the court last April.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Unmistakable evidence has come to the campaign managers of the two major party candidates that a great many people in this country object, in time of war, to types of electioneering they tolerate or even enjoy in peacetime.

A lunch-hour crowd of several thousand yesterday heard Vice Admiral Emory S. Land, War Shipping Administrator, call the American steamship operators "the most abused of all war industries" -- one that had been commandeered and had since done its wartime job in excellent style.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- In the event that the Tigers and the Browns wind up in a deadlock for first place when the American League pennant race ends next Sunday, the championship will be determined by a single play-off game in Detroit next Monday.
KANDY, Ceylon, Sept. 27 (AP) -- A commonique:

The ideals and methods of liberal education, linking the past with the present, must dominate in vocational training or men will become machines, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday at the opening exercises of the university's 191st academic year.

Warning it would be fatal in the post-war period for plans of little business to conflict with those of big business or for manufacturers', wholesalers' or retailers' groups to work at cross-purposes, Knox Ide, president of the American Home Products Association, yesterday urged the formation of an industry council representing all trade and professional elements in the drug field.

Investment demand for the $48, 962,000 in new securities of the Ohio Edison Company, which were offered formally to the public yesterday by Morgan Stanley Co. and associates, was reported by the bankers as highly satisfactory. The offering consisted of $30,962,000 of first mortgage 3s due in 1974, priced at 102 1/2, and 180,000 shares of $4.40 preferred stock, priced at $103 a share.
Allen E. Dale, formerly with McKesson Robbins, Inc., has been appointed director of sales promotion for International Distributors.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (U.P.) -- The Treasury has tentatively set Nov. 20, the beginning of Thanksgiving week, as the date for the start of the Sixth War Loan drive, with a goal of about $14,000,000,000.

Spoofing isn't tolerated in Germany, and so certain recent German remarks about Hitler can hardly be regarded as other than hostile propaganda. Somebody, probably a "capitalistic hyena," lets loose a story that this unique "combination of theorist, organizer and leader" is subject to fits of blind rage in which he amuses himself by "chewing rugs."

Homemakers who have heeded the advice of the coal and oil authorities and faced the fact that neither fuel will be overly plentiful this winter, probably will have completed any major jobs of insulation and attended to the seasonal conditioning of their heating units by now.

Stoles, worked in a variety of furs, held the spotlight at a showing yesterday by Dein-Bacher given on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Expressed in mink, persian and silver or blue fox, several versions were shown over street and evening costumes.

Ordinarily one of the largest and most important cauliflower crops in the East is that grown on Long Island in the vicinity of Riverhead. From the Long Island Cauliflower Association, however, comes a discouraging report on this year's production.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Momo Flag, carrying the colors of Adelard Lamoureux, set a world's record for the seldom-used distance of two and one-sixteenth miles in winning the seventh and last endurance handicap at Narragansett Park today.

Brazil declared war against Germany Aug. 22, 1942. She had a regular army of 100,000 and three times that number of reserves. None the less, in September, when 300 vacancies in the Special Army Officers Reserve Corps were to be filled, thousands of candidates appeared in Rio de Janeiro and spent two or three nights camped on the street.

LONDON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Nazi Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop, once an architect of the new order in Europe, marked the fourth anniversary of the Axis tripartite alliance today with a dour broadcast implying hopes merely for a stalemate.

LAUREL, Md., Sept. 27 (AP) -- War Jeep, a $4,700 yearling who has become one of the season's leading 2-year-olds, made a quick trip to Laurel to win the $7,500 added Richard Johnson Handicap today. Shipped from New York for the race, Mrs. E. Graham Lewis' colt coasted home four lengths in advance of the Pentagon Stable's The Doge in the event, first run in 1912.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox dealt a powerful blow to the American League pennant hopes of the Browns tonight by downing St. Louis, 4 to 1, behind the four-hit pitching of George Woods and Red Barrett.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Chungking in English to North America and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

I would like to register my protest against the judgments made by Mr. Herbert Matthews in his account of the attack by a Roman mob against one of the official fascist terrorists who had been put on trial. As a close eyewitness of this summary act of vengeance Mr. Matthews' feelings were naturally lacerated: what happened before his eyes was terrible to behold and he reacted as any other humane man would.

A further drain of 354,000 barrels was made last week on the nation's gasoline stocks, but supplies of light and heavy fuel oils were increased, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the week gasoline stocks amounted to 78,372,000 barrels compared 4th 78,726,000 a week earlier and 69,095,000 a year ago.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 27 -- State and local officials, at a conference this afternoon with Federal lending agency representatives, learned that there was no hope for direct grants to aid seashore municipalities in rehabilitating public facilities wrecked in the recent storm.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Samuel Okin of New York, an attorney whose outbursts at proceedings concerning the Electric Bond and Share Company system before the Securities and Exchange Commission at one time led to his ejection from a hearing by a policeman, was barred today by the commission from participation in all the system's cases and denied the privilege of appearing personally in future cases until further notice.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (U.P.) - Airborne armies, with perhaps the highest rate of casualties among the armed forces, will soon have a complete medical and surgical unit -- the 130th Evacuation Hospital -- first mobile hospital to be transported by air.

ROME, Sept. 27 -- Italy considers herself at war with Japan and will fight beside the Allies to the end, Visconte Giovanni Venosti, Under-Secretary of Foreign Affairs, told the foreign press today in a conference called to express Italy's satisfaction at President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill's declaration.
PARIS, Sept. 27 (AP) -- After a hiatus of almost two months caused by the invasion and liberation furor, French horseracing will be resumed on Oct. 6 by authorization of the Minister of Agriculture.

HOW is America to cope with bureaucracy? In 1944 this is no idle question. There isn't a smoking car or a Pullman in the country where some afflicted business man is not simmering with revolt at the way his nose has been wiped by Washington. He has been compelled to toe a line because some whippersnapper of a bureaucrat has decreed it on high.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- In the first application of Title VIII of the Revenue Act of 1943, the Army and Navy Departments have taken drastic action to cut back to what was described as a "fair and reasonable" basis prices charged by the Lord Manufacturing Company of Erie, Pa., on rubber engine and instrument mounts required by both the Army and Navy.

LONDON, Sept. 27 (U.P.) -- A British Army captain, descended from thirteen generations of earls with a fighting tradition dating back to Flodden Field in 1513, has resigned his commission and risked sacrificing his army career because, he said, he could not lead men into battle and to death "shouting a war cry which I regard not only as foolish but as one of the outstanding examples of criminal neglect in British Empire history."

With each succeeding year Zoe de Salle's designs have grown more distinctive until this season they have reached a high in the expression of her individual technique. She shows broad, rounded shoulders with deepset armholes and sleeves of the dolman type.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Thursday, Sept. 28 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Tuesday's American Superfortress attack on Anshan, steel-producing center in Japanese-held Manchuria, and other targets in Manchuria and enemy-occupied China, was a "splendid military operation" in which none of the big B-29 bombers was lost in action, War Department officials announced today.

An abnormally heavy demand for sugar, attributed partly to the recent hurricane, lack of cold storage space and this year's large fruit crop, has left various sections temporarily short of sugar, brokers and dealers reported yesterday. Little prospect of relief was seen until the middle of next month or the early part of November, when the new beet crop would appear on the market.

The United States Steel Corporation has called for redemption on Nov. 1 the $27,500,000 of its serial debentures that remains outstanding, at the stipulated prices with accrued interest to that date, payable at the office of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- Reconversion of agriculture from a war time to a peacetime industry is the most acute problem confronting farmers today, Clifford R. Hope, representative from Kansas, today told delegates to the annual meeting of the American Meat Institute, and processors and distributors of agricultural products will be directly affected by any Government programs influencing reconversion.

EILENDORF, Germany, Sept 27 -- All day long the guns and mortars speak across the fields and neat little towns, and each day American infantrymen inch forward a little in the great battle of the Siegfried Line, which has not been won and is in reality only beginning.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- A mild rush to sell grain futures at the opening of the Chicago Board of Trade today carried prices off 1/2 to 3 cents a bushel, barley leading, but on the break there was a good class of commission house buying and some support, based on the belief that at least some inflation would be certain if the "Little Steel" wage formula was broken.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Opening of Houston and Galveston, Tex., as new gateways for air traffic to Latin America from the western United States, was proposed to the Civil Aeronautics Board today by the Braniff Airways Corporation.

The Allied Stores Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday in an operating statement covering the three months ended with July a consolidated net profit of $1, 517,520, equal, after preferred dividends, to 70 cents a common share.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- Still clinging grimly to a forlorn hope, the Yankees maintained their slender mathematical hold in the American League pennant race today by capturing the series final from the White Sox, 7 -- 2, thereby making a clean sweep of the four-game series.
