While the Allied armies continue their weary advance toward the valley of the Po, President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill have properly recognized, in their statement of Tuesday, that "first and immediate considerations in Italy are the relief of hunger and sickness and fear."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau appeared today to have lost his fight with Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson and Secretary of State Cordell Hull for an American Government decision in favor of reducing Germany to an agricultural status after the war.

MOSCOW, Sept. 27 -- The Soviet press commented sharply today on reports that the names of Adolf Hitler, Hermann Goering, Henrich Himmler and Rudolf Hess are missing from United Nations' list of war criminals drawn up in London and pledged that the Red Army and the Soviet people would make certain that these men were punished after the war for the atrocities they organized throughout Europe.

The battle of the steamship companies to enter the air transportation field was focused last night on the Hawaii operation by Sydney G. Walton, vice president of the Matson Navigation Company, fresh from hearings before the Civil Aeronautics Board in which three airlines and his steamship company seek flight routes between the Pacific Coast and Hawaii once the Japanese are beaten.

Marshall Field and Richard L. Simon of Simon Schuster confirmed yesterday reports that they have been discussing the possibility of Mr. Field's acquiring an interest in Simon Schuster and its highly profitable subsidiary, Pocket Books, but they said that no agreement had been reached yet.
LONDON, Sept. 27 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
PARIS, Sept. 26 (Delayed) -- A wide difference of opinion exists between the Allies' and the French authorities on the question how many Germans remain at large in the Paris area.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 -- Vice President Wallace urged organized labor in an address at Cramps shipyard today to support the candidacy of President Roosevelt in the interest of post-war jobs, but only if "hard-boiled" thinking led the workingman to the same conclusion.

Shortly after he unfolds "Snafu," the Louis Solomon-Harold Buchman comedy, at the Hudson Theatre on Oct. 25, George Abbott, Broadway's chief purveyor of droll entertainment, will commence preparations on still another comedy.

Your Mexico correspondent, Mr. Cianfarra, reports that ex-King Carol is negotiating with Constantine Oumansky, the Russian Ambassador, his return to the throne "if the Rumanian people freely decided that they wanted him back as their ruler."

As a result of appeals published in the newspapers, hundreds of persons have offered rooms to Navy officers and enlisted men, Rear Admiral William R. Munroe, commandant of the Third Nacal District announced yesterday. In a statement made at district headquarters, 90 Church Street, he said, however, that the plight of men with children continues grave.

Removal of WPB Limitation Order L-85, regardless of when it occurs, would not affect the coming spring and summer apparel style trends, according to a statement issued last night by members of the Fashion Originators Guild of America.

BOSTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Although outhit, 12 to 7, the Braves took the deciding game of their three-game series with the Pirates today, 4 to 3. It wound up the season's Pirate-Brave competition, with Pittsburgh on the high side of 13 to 9 victories.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--An air transport link between the Marianas and Admiralty Islands in the Pacific -- over the heart of the Japanese-held Carolines--has been established by the United States Seventh Air Force and has been used to transport passengers and high-priority freight.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- Maurice Valrimont, spokesman for the Committee of Military Action of the National Council of Resistance, said today that he expected very soon a new government decision much more favorable to the French Forces of the Interior than the decree signed on Saturday to incorporate those forces into the regular army.
CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 27 -- One of the worst droughts in the history of the State is sweeping southern and southwestern New South Wales.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- While the abilities of the Allies to defeat Japan unconditionally are unquestioned, because of their immense superiority in materiel, this country's military and civilian experts believe it may take years after Germany's defeat to conquer the Japanese, the Office of War Information reported today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 -- The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals denied today a rehearing of its decision that Harry Bridges should be deported to his native Australia as an undesirable alien.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- The French Government revealed today that it had decided to take over the coal mines in the north and the Renault motor-car plant near Paris and to confiscate profits derived from trading with the enemy, the black market or illicit deals in gold or foreign exchange during the German occupation.
The New Jersey Council, sponsor of that State's annual Governor's fishing tournament, tells how some of the fresh-water entries got where they are, namely, in the running for tournament prizes.

UNITED STATES COMMAND POST ON SIEGFRIED LINE, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Shivering with cold, sixteen American soldiers who helped to crack the Siegfried Line stood under birch trees today and received Distinguished Service Crosses for heroism in storming Normandy beaches 113 days ago.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Senator Truman, Democratic nominee for Vice President, said today that after the defeat of Germany and Japan "We will have the greatest responsibility any country ever had."

WITH THE ARNHEM AIRBORNE FORCE, Tuesday, Sept. 26 (Delayed) -- This is the end. The most tragic and glorious battle of the war is over, and the survivors of this British airborne force can sleep soundly for the first time in eight days and nights.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Philip Murray, president of the United Steel Workers of America, affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organization, closed his argument today before the National War Labor Board on the steel workers wage demands with an insistence that such wage adjustments would have no inflationary effect.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (U.P.) -- Secretary Forrestal presented today a Presidential unit citation to a Navy combat demolition unit which landed under heavy fire on one of the Normandy beaches with the first wave on D-day, despite 53 per cent casualties, cleared lanes for troop landings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Representative Church said today he had sent to the Army and Navy boards investigating the Pearl Harbor disaster an affidavit signed before a notary by Frank C. Hanighen of Washington. He read to the House Sept. 21 a similar affidavit he said was signed by Sidney C. Graves.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Another step toward swifter termination of war contracts was taken by the Office of Contract Settlement today with the issuance of General Regulation No. 3 providing for settlement agreement between the Government contracting agency and the war contractor "in advance of actual termination."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 133:

As it becomes more difficult to purchase spot cotton in the South in the open market, hedge selling in the cotton futures market dwindles somewhat, and prices on the New York Cotton Exchange rose yesterday 2 to 10 points net on active months.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- Members of Parliament showed clearly today that they hope that when Prime Minister Churchill reports to them tomorrow on the progress of the war he will speak in his role as a statesman rather than as a strategist.

SALEM, Mass., Sept. 27 -- Representative George J. Bates of Massachusetts, Republican member of the Naval Affairs Committee, said today he had word from a high authority that information thus far developed by the War and Navy Departments as to the Pearl Harbor attack did not "justify" the court-martial of Lieut. Gen. Walter C. Short or Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Under-Secretary of State, told reporters today that the United States, British and Russian delegates at Dumbarton Oaks had reached very wide agreement on the kind of international security organization which they wished to recommend to their Governments.

HELSINKI, Sept. 26 (Delayed) -- The Finns have asked the Russians to prolong for two and a half months the period in which they are to demobilize their Army because they consider the time insufficient if they are actively engaged in the expulsion of the Germans still remaining in northern Finland.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept 27 (AP) -- Titan Hanover set a new world mark for a two-heat race for 2-year-old trotters today in winning the $6,529 American Stake in mile heats of 2:02 3/4 each.

Frank Gannett, a trustee of the Committee for Constitutional Government, issued yesterday a statement declaring that the officers and trustees of the committee stood squarely behind Dr. Edward A. Rumely, its executive secretary, in his refusal to turn over the records of contributors to the House Campaign Expenditures Committee.

BOMBAY, Sept. 27 (AP) -- A breakdown in talks between Mohandas K. Gandhi and Mohammed Ali Jinnah, which were begun in an effort to solve the political differences between the Hindus and Moslems, was announced today.

The Germans are sick and tired of the war and they want to get it over with, even if it means defeat, at least fifteen of the 218 wounded and sick American soldiers who were prisoners of war in Germany declared yesterday when interviewed at the Halleran General Hospital on Staten Island.

Recognizing clearly that the strongest point in Mr. Roosevelt's bid for re-election is his war leadership, Mr. Dewey has sought on various occasions to emphasize that the next Administration will be primarily "a peace Administration." But Germany, as the news tells us plainly, has not yet been beaten. Germany may last through the winter.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, Sept. 27 -- All of Peleliu Island except two small pockets in the hills is now under American control, bringing the bitter battle of the central Pacific campaign almost to an end.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- President Roosevelt has the support of a large majority of the labor newspapers in the country while only one labor publication has come out in favor of Governor Dewey, the Federated Press, a daily news service for labor, reported today in disclosing the result of a poll of member papers covering thirty-one States.
DETROIT, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Left-hander Hal Newhouser, achieving his twenty-eighth victory for the Tigers, shut out the Athletics by 4 to 0 today on five hits.

Dealing another blow against the crumbling walls of Hitler's fortress, Allied seaborne and airborne troops, backed by air and naval forces, have launched an invasion of the Balkans across the Adriatic from Italy. These forces are now operating on a wide front which appears to stretch from southern Albania to northern Yugoslavia -- a distance of some 400 miles.

ROME, Sept. 27 -- American troops of the Fifth Army battled today to regain mountain positions from which heavily reinforced German units forced them to retreat in a savage attack, while British Eighth Army forces on the Adriatic coast reached a point more than seven miles north of Rimini and approached an important Po Valley highway junction eight miles northwest of the coast.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Bears were almost blasted out of the Park tonight in the first game of the final International League play-offs as the Orioles scored a 14-3 victory before a crowd of 12,773.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Indians defeated the Senators, 6 to 4, today in the final game of the season between the clubs.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Coming from behind in the eighth inning today, the Cubs walloped Bill Lee for three runs to tie the Phillies, 3 -- 3, and then added two more in an extended eleven-inning game to beat the Phils, 5 -- 3, at Shibe Park.

WITH THE BRITISH SECOND ARMY, in the Netherlands, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Between 1,700 and 1,800 survivors of an original force of approximately 8,000 British airborne troops trapped at Arnhem escaped across the Lek River, leaving some 1,200 wounded behind, a senior British staff officer disclosed tonight.

ROME, Sept. 27 -- Justice Juvenal Marchisio, president of American Relief for Italy, Inc., who arrived in Rome two days ago, had a forty-minute talk with Pope Pius today. Myron C. Taylor accompanied him.

KUNMING, China, Sept. 26 (Delayed) (AP) -- Despite the Japanese successes in southeastern China, Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, commander of the United States Fourteenth Air Force, said today the enemy never would be permitted to derive much benefit for north - south communications through China.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- W. Randolph Burgess, president-elect of the American Bankers Association, today described the Bretton Woods monetary conference proposals as "complex" and "unclear," and announced that the association had adopted a resolution directing its special activities committee to make a thorough study of the proposals.

The Communist-supported administration of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, third largest affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, was returned to office yesterday with the re-election at the union's convention of Albert J. Fitzgerald of Lynn, Mass., as president and Julius Emspak of New York as secretary-treasurer.

A UNITED STATES SUPERFORTRESS BASE, West China, Sept. 27 (AP) -- A dozen Japanese medium bombers raided this Superfortress base last night in a "peanut-sized" retaliation for the attack on enemy industry yesterday at Anshan in Manchuria.

LONDON, Sept. 27 - Although Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has welded his Allied forces into one smoothly working fighting machine, there is as much difference between the arrangements and facilities for correspondents in the British and the American sectors as if they were in different wars.

The story of the British First Airborne Division is finished. As a division it no longer exists. Its dead lie in the woods west of Arnhem. Its disabled wounded are in German hands. About two thousand of its original eight or nine thousand fighting men have been "withdrawn" to safety.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, Sept. 28 -- The Germans have boastfully written an end to a new epic in British military history, the gallant but forlorn stand of the First Airborne Division at Arnhem, but drawing no confidence from this fortuitous triumph they have begun to haul tens of thousands of men out of the western Netherlands.

Arthur Posnansky of Bolivia, anthropologist and archaeologist and director of the Cultural Mission of the Government of Bolivia to the United States, is the author of a three-volume work, "Tihuanacu, the Cradle of American Man."

Another southern row over Democratic Presidential electors flared up yesterday (this time in Louisiana) just as party leaders were breathing easier over court settlement of the long electoral triumphs in Texas.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific, Sept. 27 -- Flying deep into the occupied Netherlands Indies, Allied planes based in Australia for the first time hit the Batavia area in Java in a strafing attack on enemy buildings there Sunday.
ROME, Sept. 27 (UP) -- A communique:

Argentina has taken action cutting off leather exports, according to importers here, who stated yesterday that no information is available as to how long the curbs will last. At the present time the United States Government has on hand in Argentina more than 5,000 tons of leather purchased there and ear-marked for shipment to Russia under lend-lease, which is being held up by the curb, effected through non-issuance of export, licenses.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Officials of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters have pledged a fund of about $150,000 to aid in the re-election of President Roosevelt.

ROME, Sept. 27 -- A new trial in the assassination of Socialist Deputy Giacomo Matteotti in June, 1924, is going to be held in Italy, it was decided today. The High Commission for the Punishment of Fascist Crimes requested the annulment of the original trial, which whitewashed the assassins, and it was granted by the Supreme Court of Cassation, according to this afternoon's newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -James F. Byrnes, director of War Mobilization, said in a radio address before the National Press Club today that the task after the war would not be industrial and economic demobilization but mobilization for peace.

Common sense ought to be a complete antidote for Secretary Morgenthau's fantastic propasals about Germany. Compared to the Secretary the man who burned a barn to kill a mouse is a piker. Mr. Morgenthau would destroy the economic utility of a continent to gain revenge upon a few hooligans.

Bonds in the aggregate amount of $4,266,000 were sold yesterday by the El Paso Housing Authority, Texas, and the Wilmington Housing Authority, N.C. Of the total, $2,597,000 was sold as Series A bonds to a banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co., while the remaining $1,669,000 will be sold to the Federal Public Housing Authority as Series B bonds.

Fifty-eight baggage cars of soldiers' Christmas parcels have accumulated in Long Island City, Queens, and thirty more cars are en route, taxing the facilities of authorities to process the mail for shipment overseas, it was disclosed yesterday as the War Manpower Commission sent out a call for 3,000 full-time workers to help solve the bottleneck.

Twenty-four weary, unshaven defendants appeared before Magistrate J. Roland Sala in Bay Ridge Court yesterday morning as the aftermath of a routine gambling raid a few hours earlier on a loft building at 339 Bridge Street, Brooklyn.

EN ROUTE WITH DEWEY TO ALBANY, Sept. 27 -- The October phase of the Presidential campaign was being notched up today as Governor Dewey sat back "between rounds" to survey the results of his 6,700-mile trip to the Pacific Coast and back.

The working of a moral law through "the juridical organization of the international community" is the principal hope of lasting peace, the Rev. John Courtney Murray, Professor of Philosophy at Woodstock College, Maryland, declared yesterday in his address at the annual Votive Mass of the Holy Ghost in St. Andrew's Church, Duane Street and Cardinal Hayes Place.

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY Before Arnhem, the Netherlands, Sept. 26 (Delayed) -- The men of the British First Airborne Division came back, what was left of them, during the night from their Arnhem bridgehead, limping, hungry and fighting utter exhaustion to keep on their feet.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Communique 172:

LONDON, Sept. 27 (Reuter) -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today that the reports from Sir Alexander Cadogan, head of the British delegation to the security conference at Dumbarton Oaks, showed that much useful and indispensable preliminary work had been accomplished at the conference in a friendly and cooperative atmosphere.

Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic National Chairman, yesterday charged Edwin F. Jaeckle, Republican State Chairman, with "a rank exhibition of racial discrimination" in denying renomination to Representative Joseph Mruk of Buffalo.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 27 -- Only nationalist newspapers commented today on the United States' decision to declare Argentina out of bounds for American merchantmen, but they do so rather discordantly.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The record of Congress in preparing for the post-war period was offered today by Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney of Wyoming, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, as a reason for the re-election of "a Democratic Congress" in November.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- A fact-finding panel reported today to the War Labor Board that most textile workers in New England, New York and Pennsylvania were unable on the basis of present earnings to support families on a minimum "WPA" budget, and that their wages were "sub-standard."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (U.P.) -British jet-propelled fighter planes have gone into action with success against German robot bombs and further development of the craft, still cloaked in secrecy, is under way, it was announced today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Foreseeing a transportation shortage that will prevent the prompt return of service men from Europe after Germany is defeated, the War Department is planning the establishment of vocational training courses to be given abroad to soldiers who can be spared from the war with Japan and the policing of Germany, Col. Lawrence Westbrook, assistant director of the department's planning division, disclosed yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 27 -- Addressing several hundred Elite Guard officers charged with the direction of foreign labor camps, Robert Ley, German Labor Minister, called on them today to use "without stint that iron hand of discipline you have used so judiciously in the past" to maintain order at all costs among the 12,000,000 foreign workers in Germany.

LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 28--Breaking through the lake and river barriers to Riga, the Russians drove within twenty-three miles north of the Latvian capital yesterday and tightened their ring to thirty-five and thirty-one miles east and southeast, capturing more than 200 communities from the German defenders, who were throwing in their last desperate reserves.

WASHINGTON Sept. 27 -- The Navy Department has given top priorities to the production of assault transports and assault landing ships for use against Japan, Secretary Forrestal said today at a press conference.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- Although the German consulate in Tangier has been closed and its entire staff withdrawn, the British Government is not satisfied with the way in which the Spanish Government is dealing with the expulsion of other German agents in the Tangier zone and Spanish Morocco, according to Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretary, in reply to a question in the House of Commons today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- President Roosevelt received a firsthand report today from Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, on the trip to China from which he has just returned.

The Men's Fashion Guild of New York was formed yesterday by a group of manufacturers of sports wear and furnishings to develop greater style appeal in men's wear and to promote the New York market. At a meeting at the Empire State Club in the Empire State Building David A. Church of Edmund T. Church Company, Inc., was elected president.

Leading from start to finish of the long two and a half miles, the top-weighted Rouge Dragon yesterday captured the $8,900 Brook Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont before 28,988 persons, most of whom were highly pleased since the M.A. Cushman color-bearer was the public choice.

It took Mayor La Guardia just three minutes yesterday to swear in Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine for a third five-year term. The brief ceremony, held in the Mayor's office at City Hall, was attended by members of Commissioner Valentine's family and about fifty high officers of the Police Department.

One of the saddest traits in human nature is the spirit of faction, as they used to call it in the eighteenth century. Here at home the Founding Fathers were much concerned over what factionalism might do to their infant Republic.

LONDON, Sept. 27 (U.P.) -- During today's Eighth Air Force attacks across the Siegfried Line the weather over northwestern Germany was stormy, with hail and rain alternating and extreme cold at high altitudes. Thick clouds blanketed Europe and furious air battles were fought entirely out of sight of the earth in the sub-stratosphere cold.

The stock market moved narrowly yesterday in one of the dullest sessions of the year, with prices mixed at the close. There were scattered major alterations in values, but fractional changes again predominated. Speculative enthusiasm was further chilled by the forecast of a long war against Japan and the stern defense being made by the Nazis on the German border.

ALBANY, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Municipal Electric Utilities Association of New York State called today for legislation to prohibit the New York State Public Service Commission "from instituting electric rate proceedings of its own motion."

In an appropriate farewell to the Giants for the 1944 campaign, Bucky Walters, with the assistance of Steve Mesner, notched his twenty-third victory of the season yesterday at the Polo Grounds, to become the National League's top pitcher.

ON BOARD THE DEWEY SPECIAL TRAIN, Sept. 27 -- With Governor Dewey traveling eastward for arrival in Albany tomorrow morning with no formal speeches scheduled, an interesting event aboard the train today was the release of a poll of the correspondents on various aspects of the campaign.

LONDON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- A broad plan to govern the economic life of Germany for an indefinite period through Allied control commissions has been formulated in the midst of a controversy within the European Advisory Commission on the question of the country's industrial demobilization, it was learned tonight.

SAMPSON NAVAL TRAINING CENTER, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- With the professional side of the schedule at an end and a couple of scrimmage games with Syracuse and Colgate behind them, the Sampson Bluejackets are now in process of getting ready for formal intercollegiate competition.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- Stanley W. Church, Mayor of New Rochelle, announced today that he had received notification this morning from the Office of Price Administration in Washington that Chester A. Bowles, the national administrator, "does not feel that rent control in Westchester County is warranted at this time."

ROME, Sept. 27 -- Allied forces have invaded Albania and the Adriatic Islands of Yugoslavia on a wide front, it was announced today, in what was believed to be the opening blow of a gigantic pincers drive against Germany's crumbling Balkan empire in coordination with the Red Army to the east and northeast.

WITH THE BRITISH SECOND ARMY AT NIJMEGEN, Sept 25 (Delayed) -- A twenty-two-year old British paratrooper, who landed near Arnhem, was captured with comrades by the Germans and escaped, told today how they and their captors had argued over the responsibility for the bombing of cities.

Seventy-one men were caught in police gambling raids in mid-Manhattan early yesterday when plainclothesmen broke into four establishments, one on Broadway near Fiftieth Street, as a result of letters received by Mayor La Guardia.
HONOLULU, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Navy sluggers pounded out a 10-5 victory over the Army today for their fourth straight triumph and the championship of the "service men's world baseball series."
George Oliva, formerly assistant advertising manager of the National Biscuit Company, has been named advertising manager, succeeding A. W. Sherer.

The essential need of mankind's return to God and to the moral law as the road to salvation from war and social ills was the theme of sermons preached yesterday in temples and synagogues on the occasion of Yom Kippur, Day of Atonement.

BEFORE METZ, Sept. 27 (AP) -A bridge leading to the mile-long and moated Fort Driant, key to the fortresses on the west bank of the Moselle guarding Metz, was seized by United States Third Army troops today after an air attack this morning and an all-day artillery barrage.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The finance division of the interstate Commerce Commission today granted authority to the Oregon-Washington Railroad and Navigation Company, wholly owned by the Union Pacific Railroad Company, to issue not exceeding $72,194,000 of refunding mortgage bonds, consisting of $54,750,000 of Series A and $17,444,000 of Series B, interest 3 per cent.

KANDY, Ceylon, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Japanese forces have broken off contact with the Fifth Indian Division, Admiral Lord Louis Mount-batten's headquarters announced today, and it was believed the enemy had abandoned his strategic base at Tiddim, withdrawing to a mountain fighting line on the Kennedy Peak in the Fort White area.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Robert E. Stripling, chief investigator for the Dies Committee, charged in a report to the committee today that the CIO Political Action Committee was a by-product of communism. It was dominated by members of that group and affiliates who sought to gain control of a major political party and, through it, to wreck the Government, he asserted.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28 -- The Browns and Yankees, the former theoretically at least, still a pennant contender, the other pursuing little more than a forlorn hope, found themselves stalled completely today in their frantic chase of the Tigers when rain washed out the opening clash of their final four-game series.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 27 (Delayed) -- Germany's reaction to Sweden's ban, effective today, on foreign shipping in her Baltic ports and territorial waters, which is tantamount to a cessation of all Swedish exports of iron ore and other commodities to Germany, will be limited to a sharp note charging a breach of neutrality.

NIJMEGEN, the Netherlands, Sept. 27 (Delayed) -- This once prosperous city of 100,000 persons was liberated a week ago but it remains within the range of German 88-mm. guns that keep firing at the big bridge over the Rhine River in a thus-far-unsuccessful attempt to destroy the structure and cut the main British communication line leading northward toward Arnhem.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- Two hundred and fifty thousand women are working in the transportation industry of the country, 112,000 of them with Class 1 railroads, said Miss Cornelia Edge, assistant head of the personnel supply section in the Office of Defense Transportation at Washington, in an address today at the first session of a two-day conference of women railroad executives.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower told the people of Germany today that his Allied armies were coming "as conquerors but not as oppressors," with the purpose of eradicating the Nazi party and German militarism. General Eisenhower's first proclamation to the Germans said the Allies intended to abolish "cruel, oppressive and discriminatory laws" and to try all military and party leaders, Gestapo men and others suspected of war crimes and atrocities.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 28 -- Two thousand or more Allied heavy bombers pounded German targets within the last twenty-four hours in the latest nonstop air offensive to strangle German communications and reduce the war industries, according to Allied communiques today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept 28 -- Mike Turnesa of Knollwood, a late finisher, tied Clarence Doser of Scarsdale for the Westchester Professional Golfers Association championship with 140 for thirty-six holes at Bonnie Briar today.

The Albert D. Smith Company, dry goods converting and commission house, has signed a long-term lease through the Charles G. Edwards Company for the ground-floor space in 81 Worth Street, formerly occupied by H. Slater Sons.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The emergency program for maternity and infant care is to be broadened to include health services as well as care during illnesses for children of servicemen unedr 1 year of age.

Surplus medical stocks will be sold through regular trade channels in an "as is" condition at prevailing prices, Albert W. Frey, deputy director of the Treasury Department, yesterday informed the concluding session of the wartime conference of the National Wholesale Druggists Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Furniture manufacturers shipped a larger dollar volume during August than in any other month of the year or during the preceding year, according to a survey issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants. August, 1944, shipments were 4 per cent more than for the like month a year ago, and were 24 per cent more than July, 1944, shipments.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The stock markets, although generally firm in tone, today remained quiet. One exception was Kaffirs, which showed improvement on the news that an agreement which includes a five-year wage truce had been reached between South African gold producers and the white miners.

OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 28 -- An autopsy today failed to establish the cause of the death of Aimee Semple McPherson here yesterday after taking a sedative and the authorities then ordered an inquest Oct. 6 and a chemical analysis of her stomach.

Some of New York's most distinguished designer names were assembled in a fashion showing by Saks Fifth Avenue in the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel yesterday at the luncheon hour. These artists were represented by some of their best accomplishments of the season, setting the pace for New York's ready-to-wear market.

A Greater New York women's division of the National Citizens Political Action Committee was formed yesterday afternoon at a meeting of women leaders called at the Hotel Shelton by Freda Kirchwey, vice chairman of the national group.
ROME, Sept. 28 (UP) -- A communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, in New Guinea, Friday, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Attacking a seven-ship convoy, an American patrol plane sank a 10,000-ton Japanese transport and badly damaged another smaller troopship in the first Allied strike over the Sulu archipelago, southwestern Philippines, it was reported today by headquarters.

A class of 130 Army, Navy and civilian students was graduated yesterday from the New York University College of Medicine, and seventy-six men and women from the Division of Nursing at exercises held in the Gould Memorial Library on University Heights.

The explosion of a 5,000-gallon ammonia tank in the basement of Balch Price Co., furriers, at Fulton and Smith Streets, shook the heart of downtown Brooklyn's shopping district at 2:30 P.M. yesterday and caused injuries to seventeen persons, eight of whom required hospital treatment.

Mayor La Guardia made a hurried trip to Washington yesterday, leaving La Guardia Field at 9:17 A.M. and returning to his desk at City Hall about 3:30 P.M. He disclosed that he had sought help in getting an earlier start on resumption of work on the Brooklyn-Battery tunnel project.
LONDON, Sept. 28 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

Shake hands with Gertrude Niesen! She has just been promoted to stardom in "Follow the Girls" by producer Dave Wolper. In return for the compliment, the star has agreed to remain in the hit musical for a year beyond her present contract or until June, 1946. In case a film commitment should materialize she can leave the show after next June by giving Mr. Wolper sixty days notice.

The charge of rent gouging was hurled yesterday at Joseph P. Kennedy, former Ambassador to Great Britain, at a hearing held by the general welfare committee of the City Council, attended by more than 500 persons, most of them tenants of lofts, stores and other commercial space.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The question whether the Germans ever attempted an invasion of Britain in 1940 and 1942 was raised in the House of Commons again today when Prime Minister Churchill was asked if he was now in a position to state the facts.

With "American Battle Painting: 1776-1918" duly installed at the Museum of Modern Art, the Brooklyn Museum now offers a show relating to the present war. It is installed in a gallery on the fifth floor of the museum, opens to the public today, and will remain through Nov. 12.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- Rain and cold weather with a forecast for frost in parts of Iowa and Wisconsin and light country offerings of new corn gave the market for that grain a firm undertone today, and prices advanced 1 1/2 cents a bushel from the early low mark on the Board of Trade and closed about at the top with gains of 1/2 to 7/8 cent.

MOSCOW, Sept. 28 -- A grim and horrible story of how advance Red Army units reached a German concentration camp near Kloga, Estonia, while four huge funeral pyres containing the bodies of an estimated 2,000 recently killed persons, including men, women and children, still were smoldering was told today in the newspaper Izvestia, which renewed the Soviet pledge that retribution will be sought in Berlin.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 28 -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace told the convention of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, CIO, at its opening session here today that the re-election of President Roosevelt was the "doorway to the future," including full employment, and that "if you don't go through that doorway you are going to have to wander like the children of Israel in the wilderness."

Giving a graphic picture of the serious plight of the Jewish people in Europe, Dr. Joseph J. Schwartz, European chairman of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, in an address before a large audience of Jewish leaders last night at the Hotel Astor asserted that "emergencies on a scale staggering the imagination" will unfold when relief workers enter the liberated countries.
Wednesday's communique, as broadcast domestically yesterday by the Nazi-controlled Hungarian radio and reported by the Federal Communication Commission:

MISSOURI VALLEY, Iowa, Sept. 28 (AP) -- At least six persons were killed and between sixty and seventy persons were injured tonight when a Chicaog Northwestern passenger train and a freight train crashed on the outskirts of Missouri Valley, the railroad's division dispatcher at Boone reported.

PISA, Italy, Sept. 27 (Delayed) -- Shells probably from cannon on mounted railroad cars on a few isolated sidings, in any case the largest the Germans are believed to have in this theatre, were coming into Pisa last night, wreaking additional damage on the city, which already had suffered more than most.

Trampled beneath the feet of huge contestants, San Marino has suffered the traditional fate of the innocent bystander. Now the toy republic rises from the dust of battle, brushes itself off and declares war on Germany. The Germans, it is true, have gone with the wind.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Two former CIO local union officers told a Dies subcommittee today that their official connection with the union was severed because they refused to engage in political activity or accept Communist leadership.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Some of the delegates at the Dumbarton Oaks conference and Administration leaders in the State Department and on Capitol Hill are reaching tentative conclusions about the security problem and its relation to Soviet Russia.

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 28 -- Attacking the Visayas group of islands in the Central Philippines Sept. 23 (West Longitude Date) carrier planes of Admiral William F. Halsey's Third Fleet sank twenty-two ships, damaged forty-three others, of which fifteen probably were sunk, sank or damaged twenty to thirty small craft and destroyed thirty-six more planes besides bombing and strafing six islands.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Higher prices for grains and for fruits and vegetables caused the Bureau of Labor Statistics index of commodity prices in primary markets to rise 0.1 per cent during the week ended on Sept. 23.
KANDY, Ceylon, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Japanese rearguards still block the road to the Japanese supply base of Tiddim in the Chin Hills of Burma, headquarters announced today.
LONDON, Sept. 28 (U.P.) -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Churchill's speech in the House of Commons today:
CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 28 (AP) A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- American planes in the European skies are in general about as good as, or better than, the planes of the enemy.

BOSTON, Sept. 28 -- The Most Rev. Richard J. Cushing, Auxiliary Bishop of the Catholic Archdiocese of Boston since 1939, has been appointed by Pope Pius XII as Archbishop of Boston, succeeding the late William Cardinal O'Connell.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a plan whereby the Pennsylvania Gas and Electric Corporation would donate to the Petersburg and Hopewell Gas Company all the capital stock of Old Dominion Gas and Electric Corporation.

A dead heat for first place, always the handicapper's dream, yesterday enlivened the running of the $10,000 added Vosburgh Handicap, a memorial to the late Walter Vosburgh who for many years was the handicapper on the New York tracks.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Retreating Germans blew up bridges and burned villages as Finnish troops, seeking to drive them out of northern Finland, crossed the Iijoki River and advanced toward Olhava, on the Bothnian Gulf, a communique reported today.

PARIS, Sept. 27 (Delayed) -- The coal miners of northeastern France are threatening to strike unless they receive a 50 per cent increase in wages. A joint mission of American Civil Affairs Officers and French labor leaders is attempting to settle the dispute.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Frank Sinatra had tea with the President today and joined with him in a little chat about the art of making girls swoon.

LAUREL, Md., Sept. 28 (AP) -- W.L. Brann's Gallorette, a candidate for the Maryland Futurity on Oct. 4, won the Morgil, a test of six furlongs which drew five Futurity eligibles and three others at Laurel today.

In a speech supporting Norman Thomas, Socialist nominee for President, and broadcast to troops overseas, Brig. Gen. H.C. Holdridge, retired, declared last night that neither Democrats nor Republicans could solve the problem of reconstruction, but were committed to a policy of "plowing under abundance in order to create a world of artificial scarcity."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The ration price for creamery butter will be raised from 16 points to a record high mark of 20 points a pound on Sunday to balance a slump in production and a sharp increase in the nation's consumption of fluid milk, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

Nine additional manufacturing companies in the New York metropolitan area have been authorized to resume civilian goods production under the "spot" authorization plan of the War Production Board, the regional office here announced yesterday.

Annual safety awards to five air lines operating in Latin America were presented yesterday by the Inter-American Safety Council at a luncheon at the Metropolitan Club. Perfect safety records for 1943 were the basis of the awards. J.T. Wilson, president of the council, made the presentations.

With rumors from the South that farmers are being told to hold their cotton until after the Government's purchase plan has been announced, waves of short covering orders for cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange sent prices upward again yesterday to net gains of 11 to 22 points.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A compromise between the severe Treasury plan for the virtual de-industrialization of Germany after the war and those who favor a more moderate method of preventing the enemy from arming again was anticipated today as it became known on high authority that President Roosevelt probably would summon his three-man Cabinet Committee to meet with him at an early date.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- A solution of the struggle within the Polish Government over the status of Gen. Kazimierz Sosnkowski, Commander in Chief of the Polish armed forces, was reached today after six days of almost continuous discussions between President Wladislaw Raczkiewicz and Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Eight maritime States among the United Nations have accepted an agreement in London for a merchant shipping pool to continue for six months after the end of the global war. The agreement of principles was signed by spokesmen of the participating governments last month and was made public today by the State Department.

The Union Securities Corporation and W.C. Langley Co., with associates in Boston and New York, have agreed to purchase controling stock interests in the Goodall Worsted Company and Sanford Mills, both at Sanford, Me., at $55 a share and $40 a share, respectively.
LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Prime Minister Churchill mentioned the United States Presidential election once in his address to the House of Commons today, and then with a smile.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Robert Hanes, Winston-Salem, N.C., former president of the American Bankers Association, declared today that bank credit would be available to "every competent man, firm or corporation that needs bank credit for some constructive purpose that serves the private enterprise economy of this country."

Sidney Hillman accused the Republican party yesterday of an unwillingness to face the real issues of the 1944 Presidential election and the adoption instead of a campaign of slander and vilification, modeled after Nazi propaganda techniques, in an effort to divide and confuse the electorate and thereby gain advantages.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Office of Contract Settlements, in an effort to clear plant space for civilian production as soon as possible after war work has been ended, issued today its fourth ruling on terminated war contracts, which provides that a contractor may either buy government-owned equipment in his plant or have it removed within sixty days after the request for its removal, unless required further for war orders.
LONDON, Sept. 28 (Aneta) -- A Netherlands royal decree today called for restoration of the country's national news agency as an organization independent of the Government.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 28 (AP) -- The "job of making peace" will not be accomplished immediately following the war's end, but will "be the work of years," Assistant Secretary of State Adolph A. Berle Jr. said tonight at the fifty-first annual meeting of the Savings Banks Association of New York.
Under the dismal skies of yesterday the Dodgers blew a five-run early lead to Bill McKechnie's Reds at Ebbets Field and wound up losing the first of the final four-game series, 10-6.

DETROIT, Sept. 28 -- Plans of James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization, and the War Production Board to cut war production 35 to 40 per cent after V-E (Victory in Europe) Day to release manpower and materials to supply civilian needs would give no immediate help to the automobile and other industries which were converted wholly to war output, leaders of the automotive industry said here today.

Confused thinking characterized the trading on the stock market yesterday and although meager progress was made toward recovery the close was generally mixed. Prime Minister Churchill's warning that the European war might continue into 1945 produced no definite market reaction.

Cabildo, most rabid of the pro-Nazi newspapers that have sprung up in Buenos Aires in recent years, denounces Secretary of State Hull as being responsible for a drop in quotations of Argentine state securities on the Buenos Aires Exchange. The charge is not important.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Further details of plans to provide educational courses and practical job training for soldiers serving in the Army of occupation or waiting for ships to bring them home after Germany's defeat, were made public today by the War Department.

Mrs. Helen Hay Whitney, owner of the Greentree Stable of race horses and widow of Payne Whitney, financier, named her son, Col. John Hay Whitney, Army airman, and her daughter, Mrs. Joan Whitney Payson of Manhasset, L.I., executors and principal legatees in her will filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

Owing to the change in the European food situation, large quantities of meat and other foods will be put on the market here for home consumption in the next six or eight months, Mortimer E. Greif, attorney for the regional office of Price Administration, declared yesterday.

THE boxing business these days is very much like the old gray mare. It ain't what it used to be. Manpower shortages have been acute and preliminary boys have sprouted into headliners overnight. The beachcombers from Jacobs Beach have been on a starvation diet for so long that they undoubtedly will wolf down the tasty dish Uncle Mike Jacobs sets before them at the Garden tonight.

A number of subjects came up at the first fall meeting of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association in White Plains that gave an indication of what metropolitan district sportsmen were thinking about as the new season approached.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 28 -- Armed uniformed members of the notorious Jewish political extremist group named Irgun Zvai Leumi, which has been directing terrorist assaults against the Palestine police since the beginning of this year, again struck at several police stations last midnight, inflicting casualties on the police and suffering casualties themselves.

With this dispatch I wind up a full year of work as a press columnist. At my own request, and despite the generous urging of the syndicate and individual editors, the column is being discontinued. I shall of course, continue to write from time to time for the newspapers and periodicals, but I am dropping the burden of a regular column.

Successful test removals of O. D. coloring from woven and woolen! goods has aroused considerable interest in textile markets. If such operations can be extended to cotton and rayon fabrics, the problem of selling millions of yards of surplus textiles will be eased, it was pointed out..

CHUNGKING, Sept. 28 (U.P.) -- A Japanese column in southeastern Kwangsi Province, storming forty-five miles west of Wuchow in two days, plunged to within about five miles of the American airfield at Tanchuk, as the enemy scored important gains along the entire southern wing of their double-edged offensive driving toward a juncture in Kwangsi, it was revealed tonight.

James A. Farley, former national chairman of the Democratic party, who has not gone beyond a bare statement of support for President Roosevelt in the coming elections, reiterated yesterday that he remains a Democrat, but once again stopped at that point.

With the exception of fresh fruits and vegetables, supplies of many foods will be more limited in October than they have been for some time, according to predictions of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company.
A communique broadcast Thursday by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Tales of hair-raising parachute leaps from burning planes at altitudes of 100 feet, crash landings in enemy territory and heated indictments of the poor and insufficient food at prisoners-of-war camps were among the experiences described yesterday by thirteen Army airmen who were freed after the collapse of Rumania.

ROME, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The possibility of increased Allied pressure on the imperiled Germans in the Balkans, where airborne and seaborne troops already are striking at Nazi escape routes In Albania, was indicated today in an announcement that the two main Greek guerrilla forces had come under orders of Gen. Sir Henry Maitland Wilson.

After an ownership of several weeks, the ten-story and penthouse apartment building at 19 East Ninety-eighth Street has been resold by W.E. Parsley to an investing client of Rossbach Associates, brokers, who arranged the recent sale of the property for the Marks estate.
Lippy Leo Durocher yesterday received a new vote of confidence from Branch Rickey, Dodger president, in the form of a one-year contract to pilot the Brooklyn club again in 1945.

Mr. Churchill has delivered another of those eloquent reports of his on the issues of war and peace which, if they do not always contain startling news, at least permit men to view events from the mountain top of world statesmanship and to readjust their perspective accordingly.

Just back from a talk with President Roosevelt in Washington, Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic National Chairman, last night called upon organization Democrats throughout the country to work for the largest possible registration and vote to make certain the re-election of President Roosevelt, warning that the only danger of defeat of the President was in party apathy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Speaking for thirty-one steel companies, Roger H. Blough, general counsel of the United States Steel Corporation, told the War Labor Board today that these companies did not have the ability to pay the wage increase of 17 cents demanded by the United Steel Workers Union without a substantial increase in steel prices.

James F. Byrnes, the Director of War Mobilization, declares that present controls on prices, wages and rationing must be kept at this time, and that the line against inflation must be held until the danger of inflation has passed. He adds that the relationship between wages and prices must continue to be kept stabilized.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Purchase of the Mosque Theatre Building at 1020 Broad Street by the Bremer Broadcasting Corporation was announced today by Irving Robert Rosenhaus, executive vice president and general manager of radio station WAAT.

Earl Browder, laying down the Communist line at a mass meeting in Madison Square Garden last night, declared that the election of Governor Thomas E. Dewey to the Presidency would be "an American invitation to Europe to plunge immediately or soon into the most devastating civil war."

Although they did not improve their reserve position -- the reserve deficiency rising from $15,000,000 to $20,000,000 last week -- New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased their loans and investments for the first time in some weeks, according to the figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Fewer laws than we now have, "wisely enacted and vigorously enforced," were suggested yesterday morning by Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, to reduce the confusion in most minds resulting from their multiplicity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 23 were 898,667 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 6,309 cars, or 0.7 per cent more than for the preceding week, 8,644 or 1.0 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week of last year and 1,240 cars or 0.1 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years.

A backlog of more than $10,500,000,000 in new construction has piled up in the States east of the Rocky Mountains and awaits the availability of men and materials after the war, according to the F.W. Dodge Corporation, which yesterday announced the results of a special study of the subject for the building industry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A critical shortage of cotton textiles, which has shown itself particularly in poor variety and low quality of cotton clothing, was predicted today by the Office of War Information from facts available at government agencies that "the current tight supply of cotton goods" would continue "from one to two years after the fall of Germany."

A familiar and unworthy device for introducing racial and religious issues into a political campaign is to accuse an opponent of doing so and then assume a holier-than-thou pose. Democratic National Chairman Robert E. Hannegan resorted to this device when he charged that Edwin F. Jaeckle, Republican Chairman for New York State, had refused to endorse Representative Joseph Mruk of Buffalo for renomination because Mr. Mruk is a Catholic of Polish descent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UP) -- Secretary Ickes, whom Governor Dewey has promised to fire if he is elected President, wrote today that such action would not be necessary because he would resign "effective, if, as, and when the incredible comes to pass and you become the President."

Henry Marsh, 42 years old, who operated several concerns at 36 East Twenty-first Street, in which he dispensed love potions, especially a concoction he called "dragon's blood"; mystic amulets and other contraptions he promised patrons might bring health and prosperity to them, paid a $500 fine yesterday in Special Sessions to avoid going to the penitentiary for six months.

The other day in an editorial you took Mr. Dewey to task for a certain statement he made concerning the possible breaking of the Little Steel formula. Specifically, you question the choice of the words "to which they are justly entitled." Apparently you question the soundness of this view.

Cass Canfield, president of Harper Brothers, Bennett Cerf, president of Random House, and Harry Scherman, president of the Book-of-the-Month Club, issued yesterday a joint statement that their concerns have arranged to purchase the long-established reprint house of Grosset Dunlap, one of the largest in that field.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The War Department announced today a plan for discharge of enlisted men who did not meet minimum physical induction standards and for whom no appropriate assignment was available.

BOUND BROOK, N.J., Sept. 28 -- Twenty-three war workers employed in one department at the Calco Chemical Division of the American Cyanamid Company here were under treatment for trichinosis today, following a picnic at which undercooked pork sausage was served.

Robert Real Estate, Ltd., has sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $230,000 the six-story brick apartment building at 480 East 187th Street, southwest corner of Laurel Hill Terrace, to the Sentley Realty Company. The building is on a plot 127 by 114 feet and was sold through Allan Robbins, broker.

LONDON, Sept. 28 (U.P.) -- Russia announced tonight she had received permission from Marshal Tito's forces to send an army into Yugoslavia to attack Hungary from the south, and that shaky German satellite, already buffeted by a mighty Soviet-Rumanian advance from the east, reportedly was asking for peace terms.

What amounted to the junior varsity of the Cardinals opposed the Giants yesterday at the Polo Grounds, but Billy Southworth's reserves proceeded to blank the home team, 2-0, before a crowd of 1,819 fans, including 456 service men.

VAN WYCK BROOKS, the little gray critic with the college boy haircut, follows his literary star with a serene composure that seems all unmindful of the storms of controversy that sometimes swirl about him. In his younger days he wrote of Emerson, James and Mark Twain with considerable acerbity toward the bareness of the American cultural scene.

Willie Pep, Hartford fighter who holds the featherweight championship of the world, will risk his crown tonight when he tackles Chalky Wright of Los Angeles in the star bout of fifteen rounds at Madison Square Garden. The clash has aroused widespread interest, and Promoter Mike Jacobs is confident that a crowd of 15,000 fans will be on hand.

ALBANY, Sept. 28 -- Governor Dewey returned today from a twenty-one-State tour which covered 8,545 miles and received a report from Herbert Brownell Jr., national chairman, that his campaign drive across the country and back had brought hundreds of thousands of independent and Democratic voters into the Republican fold.

By a law approved Dec. 26, 1941, Thanksgiving "for Federal purposes" comes on the fourth Thursday of November. Each State is free to conform or fix its own day as it pleases, but a general agreement on the date is desirable. The six New England Governors agreed last December to follow the Federal example.
LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The War Office disclosed tonight that the Germans had captured the general commanding the British "Red Devils" in the Arnhem pocket but that he had escaped.

Nine criminal informations and an indictment were handed up in Federal Court yesterday as the result of action taken by United States Attorney James B.M. McNally on the basis of investigations conducted by the War Production Board.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 28 -- The Foreign Office announced tonight that Argentina had informed Britain that war criminals would be barred from this country and would be prohibited from depositing funds or acquiring property here.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Friday, Sept 29 -- Three Allied threats to gateways of Germany at Arnhem, Aachen and Metz, hourly gaining magnitude in German eyes, have produced a state of alert along the whole 450-mile western front, where hot local fighting for favorable positions continued yesterday between the opposing armies.

The West of Central Park Association has elected Paul B. Owens, assistant vice president of the Dry Dock Savings Institution, and Joseph B. Hodgkins, manager of the New York Telephone Company, as directors for two years and appointed John S. Burrell of the Union Dime Savings Bank as chairman of its city planning committee.

Joseph (Joe) Gould, one-time manager of former heavyweight champion James J. Braddock and now a captain in the Army Service Command, has been placed under arrest at Camp Shanks, N.Y., pending trial on charges that he conspired to defraud the Government by accepting money to influence the award of contracts for the manufacture of Army equipment.
LONDON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England issued today reported an increase of 4,082,000 in note circulation to a new record high.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 28 -- Jack Carson, who recently finished the lead with Rosalind Russell in "Roughly Speaking" at Warner Brothers, has been named by the studio for the principal male role with Bette Davis in "Stolen Life." The picture will be produced by Jack Chertok and directed by Curtis Bernhardt.

EINDHOVEN, the Netherlands, Sept. 27 (Delayed) -- Since Allied airborne troops dropped on the Netherlands Sept. 17 and British armored forces pushed across the Meuse-Schelde canal, about 500 square miles of the Netherlands has been liberated, and experienced Allied troops expressed belief today that the country had suffered as much as, if not more than, any in western Europe under German occupation.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- A Grand Jury investigation begun here May 17 into an alleged $250,000 shortage in the funds of Local 60 of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union, AFL, has resulted in its first indictment, District Attorney Elbert T. Gallagher disclosed today.

The first Soviet novel, dealing with the impact of the Five Year Plan on the everyday life of the Russian people, to be authorized for publication outside the country is "Road to the Ocean," by the novelist Leonid Leonov. L. B. Fischer lists it for early November publication.

Sentiment for reopening the whole question of rezoning New York in anticipation of widespread building activity after the war developed yesterday at a conference in the office of Edgar Nathan Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, and resulted in a concerted demand by realty and civic groups for a public hearing on a new zoning program offered by City Planning Commissioner Irving V.A. Huie.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Governor Bricker of Ohio, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, said today that he would make at least twenty-eight speeches during the first six days of a 9,250-mile four-week western campaign tour starting Monday.

WITH AMERICAN TROOPS in Alsace-Lorraine, Sept. 27 (Delayed) -- In an abandoned factory only two miles from German positions American troops of a frontier regiment gathered today for an afternoon of entertainment.

Yom Kippur services were held this year on German soil at a point immediately behind the front of the American First Army. To describe this assemblage of approximately one hundred members of the Jewish faith on the most solemn day in their religious calendar we have at our disposal any number of words.

Bishop William T. Manning issued yesterday to the 370 members of the clergy in the Episcopal Diocese of New York, of which he is the head, a prayer he has written to be offered in the churches on V-Day and so long as the war lasts.

PHILADELPHiA, Sept. 28 t)-The Louisville Gas and Electric Company of Delaware, parent of J the Louisville Gas and Electric of , Kentucky. dll file a plan of liquidation with the Securities and Exchange Commission within two! weeks, George C. Matthews, vice president of the Standard Gas and Electric Company. said today.

Both the Democratic and Republican national platform fail to face the Negro problem realistically, Wendell L. Willkie charges in the current issue of Collier'a magazine, in advocating equal rights for 13,000,000 Negro citizens.

I read in THE NEW YORK TIMES that "the American Legion wants to deport all refugees after the war to reduce unemployment." A worthy resolution, indeed, of those who once fought to make the world safe for democracy!

LONDON Sept. 28 (AP) -- In the first detailed Soviet comment on post-war plans for defeated Germany, Tass reaffirmed today that the Tripower European Advisory Commission proposed three separate zones of occupation, but denied there was any plan under discussion for cutting Germany into small States.

Reporting on operations of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., for the six months ended on July 31, Bernard F. Gimbel, president, informed stockholders in a statement for publication today, that sales rose 16.9 per cent to $84,442,414 from the $72,264,728 volume for the corresponding period a year ago.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Americans should regard the return of war veterans as a "marvelous opportunity rather than a problem,'' Homer B. Clarke, president of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks, declared today.

The Koppers Company is expected to undertake a major refunding program soon and work on it is understood to have progressed to a point where a registration statement covering the issuance of $23,000,000 of bonds may be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission within the next few weeks.

LONDON, Friday, Sept. 29 -- Russian troops fought their way nearly three miles inside Czechoslovakia yesterday through the Lupkow Pass from Poland, and Budapest said other mobile Russian forces attacking on a 100-mile front had punched out gains in southeastern Hungary.
LONDON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Savage sky battles were fought over Germany again today as the German Air Force sought to stem the mass Allied aerial assault that carried through its fourth consecutive day.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Friday, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A communique:

Brooklyn's drive to raise $225,000, the borough's quota in the sixty-sixth annual United Hospital Campaign, was started yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel St. George by 1,000 leaders headed by John Cashmore, Borough President.

SANDS POINT, L.I., Sept. 28 -- The seventh rest center in the United States to care for merchant seamen was dedicated today when the seventy-two-acre estate of the late Mrs. Christian R. Holmes, "The Chimneys," was turned over to the United Seamen's Service and the War Shipping Administration, who will jointly operate the place for the benefit of seamen who suffer convoy fatigue or from enemy action.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -The War Food Administration ended rationing and distribution control today over all farm machinery and equipment except corn pickers, but WFA officials said the action did not mean that any more machinery would be immediately available to farmers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Labor's Combined Victory Committee has been summoned to confer with President Roosevelt at the White House at noon tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The appointment of Raymond Brugere to the general secretaryship of the Quai d'Orsay is, to date, the most significant step taken by Georges Bidault, the new Commissioner for Foreign Affairs. It foreshadows a resolute policy based on the assumption that France deserves to receive, now and not later, the status of a great power and to be treated accordingly.
Yesterday's Polish Home Army communique, broadcast to Europe in Polish by the British radio and reported by the Federal Communication Commission:
HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- For the sixteenth successive year Andy Kerr will send a Colgate football team into action Saturday, when the Maroon opens its season at Rochester.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The text of Secretary of State Hulls statement on war criminals:
LONDON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2S -- The State Department said late tonight that it had received no official confirmation that Argentina had sent a note to Great Britain on the Axis war criminals.

John Osnato, retired detective and former acting lieutenant of the New York Police Department, was honored last night at a dinner given by his former associates on the Italian Board of Guardians at the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn. He retired from the Police Department last June and now is living on his farm at Reeders, Pa.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Davey Crockett accepted the surrender of the Toulon arsenal and 500 German troops during the Allied invasion of southern France.

It has been with keen interest that I have followed THE TIMES editorials dealing with the forthcoming national election. As a normally independent Democratic newspaper you have evidenced a commendable desire to subordinate newspaper partisanship to a clear, honest and succinct presentation of the facts, the issues and the statements of the candidates and their respective parties.

ROME, Sept. 28 -- Two Jesuit fathers were today ordered to widely separated provincial parishes by their superior in Rome after a political demonstration by members of the congregation Sunday in the fashionable church of San Roberto Bellarmino on the Piazza Ungheria.

William M. Leiserson, professor at Johns Hopkins University and former chairman of the National Mediation Board, declared last night at the conference of the American Management Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania that there was fear in organized labor of a concerted anti-union drive by the larger hiring concerns such as followed the previous war.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday that he had sold $25,000,000 of New York City revenue bills to a group of twenty-five banks at an interest rate of 0.50 per cent. The bills will become payable on Oct. 27, 1944.
ROME, Sept. 28 (U.P.) -- The Canadians who took Bellaria made a new crossing of the Rubicon near its mouth. The Germans left many demolitions behind in this area.
WASHINGTON Sept. 28 (AP) -Pacific Fleet communique 134:

Oblivious to the lunch-hour hustle in the heart of Manhattan, several hundred Victory gardeners yesterday scrutinized the varied produce on exhibit in New York's first citywide harvest show. They also listened happily while horticulturists praised the fruits of local yards in dedicating a three-day display in Pershing Square Information Center.
LONDON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

The fabric identification program between the Pacific Mills worsted division and the Joseph Feiss Co., Cleveland, men's clothing manufacturers, will be presented to retailers on Oct. 16, when a line of summer suits will be shown made of a new specialty fabric, it was announced yesterday by Felex S. Mayer, president of Joseph Feiss.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Familiar signs point to the abandonment by the President of Secretary Morgenthau's Carthaginian post-war plan for Germany, which was briefly in the ascendant here and got much encouragement at Quebec.

A group of commercial banks headed by the National City Bank of Cleveland was the successful bidder yesterday for an issue of $2,200,000, of Chesapeake Ohio Railway equipment trust certificates dated Oct. 1, 1944, and maturing in ten equal installments beginning on Oct. 1, 1945.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Communique 173:
