" Frenchman's Creek" has played to the highest attendance and gross business in the twenty-seven-year history of the Rivoli during the first week of its stand, ended Tuesday night, it was announced yesterday by Charles M. Reagan, vice president in charge of distribution at Paramount.

Stockholders of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company have been notified that a hearing on the offer of settlement in the stockholders' derivative action known as Baumgold, etc., vs. Bailey and Others, will be held on Oct. 30 before Supreme Court Justice Frank E. Johnson in the Kings County Court House.
ALBANY, Sept. 28 -- The Right Rev. G. Ashton Oldham, Episcopal Bishop of Albany and president of the World Alliance for International Friendship, is going abroad to visit American troops.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons in his war report today that much of the British battle fleet already was gathered in the Indian Ocean for the war against Japan, guaranteeing the Allies naval superiority in the Pacific of "the most complete and decisive character."

The first necessity in the punishment of war criminals is to catch the criminals. Likewise, the first necessity in catching the more important of such criminals is that there shall be for them, in Kipling's words, no "thoughtful islands where never warrants come."

ROME, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Seven strategic Italian towns have been occupied by Allied troops advancing up both coasts of the peninsula and in the rugged central sector where Americans were only twelve miles from an important German escape route, Allied headquarters reported today.

Delegates to the tenth annual convention of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, meeting at Manhattan Center, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, adopted unanimously yesterday a resolution calling for the reemployment of servicemen at their old jobs without loss of seniority, and demanded that veterans be hired at their old jobs "regardless of any consideration."

A pretty good case can be made out that fishermen are the most prodigal spenders in sports. Frank G. Menke, painstaking historian of things athletic, makes just such a case in his most recent book, "The Encyclopedia of Sports."

The three-story building at 91 Tompkins Avenue, Brooklyn, containing a store and two five-room apartments has been sold by Alliger, Rather Co. to Joseph La Capra. The property is assessed at $10,500. Isidore Eisenberg was the broker.

BOSTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Nate Andrews kept seven Chicago hits well scattered while pitching the Braves to a 5-1 victory today in the opening game of their final 1944 series. Since Manager Charlie Grimm did not accompany the Cubs here, Coach Roy Johnson ran the team.

Everybody is now asking, and answering, when will the war end. There is another question which people will be asking and answering after the end of hostilities. When did the war end? The answer to the second question is by no means as obvious as some might think.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Office of Price Administration does not contemplate any move to bring Westchester County under rent control at present, it was stated today by Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, after a survey of rent increases in the area.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- The outburst of approval provoked yesterday by the Government's decisions to take control of the coal mines and the Renault plant, which two Ministers said were steps toward socialization, was sharply modified today by critical comment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Commodity Credit Corporation, under its program of buying 1944 cotton from farmers at parity, will pay 21.90 cents a pound for middling 15/16-inch staple in October, it was announced tonight, and, beginning on Oct. 2, it will offer its owned and pooled stocks for sale at 22.40 cents a pound.

Meeting yesterday to consider further possible changes in the State building code standards, the advisory committee appointed by State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi adopted a recommendation that the statute defining "places of public assembly" be amended to include virtually all places where 100 or more persons gather, including churches or edifices owned or occupied by religious organizations.

LONDON, Saturday, Sept. 30 -- Russian troops yesterday opened a new drive against the famous Tatar [Jablonica] Pass across the Carpathian Mountains and extended their front along the Czechoslovak border to 170 miles, apparently in preparation for a great drive across Czech territory to envelop Hungary from the north.

LONDON, Sept 29 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden described to the House of Commons today how this country hoped to collaborate with the Soviet Union and the United States to keep Germany and Japan from disturbing world peace again.

In the excitement caused by the tense struggle for top honors in the American League, perhaps too little attention has been paid to the contest for second place in the National circuit. Anyway, after the Reds had routed the Dodgers, 10 -- 2, at Ebbets Field yesterday, it suddenly dawned on some persons that the Cincinnati outfit was only a half-length behind the Pirates.

President Roosevelt hailed America's free press yesterday on the occasion of National Newspaper Week, Oct. 1-8, in a statement published in Editor and Publisher, newspaper trade journal. His message follows:

The start of Swiss watch movements to this country following the opening up of Europe indicates to many retail jewelers that the supply situation not only will be relieved but that pace levels will decline, according to market information yesterday.

Ethel Merman has withdrawn from the impending "Sadie Thompson,'' the musical version of "Rain," in which she was to have starred. This was made known last night in a joint statement released in behalf of A.P. Waxman, the producer, and the musical comedy player.
New York's second air line to Florida will open on Sunday with the arrival at La Guardia Field at 5:15 P.M. of National Airlines' first Lockheed Lodestar from Jacksonville.
PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 29 -- Two small islands north of Peleliu in the Palau group were invaded by units of the First Marine Division on Wednesday in quick smashing assaults.

The Giants had to squeeze themselves into a ninth-inning tie at the Polo Grounds yesterday in their battle with the Cardinals. Then they had to squeeze Steve Filipowicz into the catcher's paraphernalia when the available supply of backstops was exhausted through strategy's stern demands.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, Sept. 30 -- Hot local fighting flared up yesterday on both sides of the corridor through the southern Netherlands into which Lieut. Gen. Sir Miles C. Dempsey has been pouring the whole of the British Second Army for an ultimate strike across the Rhine.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 -- Standard Power and Light Corporation and its subsidiary, Standard Gas and Electric Company, filled today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a joint declaration providing for a compromise of claims against Standard Power and its eventual dissolution.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The CIO United Packing House Workers of America said today that Chicago stockyards workers probably would strike on Oct. 16 unless the company meanwhile complies with a War Labor Board order.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 29 -- One of the important questions discussed today at the National Urban League's "self-examination" session had to do with industrial relations now and after the war among Negro and white workers and management.

The Most Rev. Amleto G. Cicognani, Apostolic Delegate to this country, is the author of "The Priest in the Epistles of St. Paul," one of 100 books in various fields of literature recommended on the fall list of the Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee, announced yesterday. The list follows:
ROME, Sept. 29 (UP) -- Allied I forces have made new landings inI Albania and dropped paratroopers at several points in Greece, reportsI from Ankara and Sofia said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- President Roosevelt denied today that there was any basic difference between members of his Cabinet Committee on Policies toward Germany as he made public a Victory in Europe Day program for the Foreign Economic Administration.

ST. LOUIS Sept. 29 -- Under a leaden sky the Yankees faded out of the flag race today, but in passing contrived to keep things seething both here and elsewhere in one of the most spectacular pennant battles the American League has known in years.
In pushing prepared cereals housewives are hampered by a lack of adequate, uniform labeling.

The War Production Board is prepared to issue an order which will remove "practically all" restrictions on the use of glass containers, it was learned yesterday. At a meeting of the Glass Container Association in the Hotel Biltmore, members stated that issuance of the order was expected over the week-end.

Eighteen well-known civic and trade associations announced yesterday that they had formed an organization to be known as the Citizens Zoning Committee to oppose the city rezoning plan now before the City Planning Commission on the ground that it would be "detrimental to the growth of New York for many years to come."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- President Roosevelt virtually confirmed reports today that Mayor La Guardia is to be commissioned in the armed services and sent to Italy in an administrative capacity.

At 5 o'clock this morning the Bronx was scheduled to suppress trouble in the Catskills. Company F of the Eighth Regiment, New York Guard, was under orders to board trucks and start for Liberty whence word had been received of "grave civil disorders." The troops were to carry all the equipment necessary to control the toughest mob.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, Sept. 30 -- Allied armies pressed the Germans back last night at opposite ends of the 460-mile western front -- at Arnhem, where the enemy blew approaches to the Lek River bridge to balk pursuit through the Netherlands, and in mountain strongholds eleven miles west of France's Belfort gateway to southern Germany.

LANSING, Mich., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Articles for two new corporations bearing the name of the Fisher Brothers were filed here today, setting out their purpose to design, manufacture, sell, repair and deal in airplanes, automobiles "and any and all automotive products."

" Dangerous Journey," the latest full-length film compilation of the jungle explorations of Armand Denis and his wife, Leila Roosevelt, through Africa and Asia, will begin an engagement today at the Gotham Theatre. The film is being distributed by Twentieth Century-Fox and the narration is spoken by Conrad Nagel.

The largest policy bank in the city received a shattering blow late yesterday afternoon when Deputy Chief Inspector Michael J. Murphy, in charge of the Police Department's Confidential Squad, and forty aides made six simultaneous raids in Harlem.
New bond financing this week aggregated $59,734,000, representing seven issues, compared with $109,250,000 for five emissions the week before. A year ago this week the market was devoid of offerings.

The skunk isn't at all a bad chap to know. His reputation, based on smell, does not do him justice. Anyone who has seen a mother skunk lead her brood of little ones in single file across a lawn at dusk, each tiny fellow with his tail held aloft like a banner, has seen one of the most appealing sights in nature's museum.

Statistics show the death rate from tuberculosis in the State of New York to be fifty persons per 100,000 population. This is more than three times as great as that of Iowa and nearly twice the rate of Michigan and Minnesota. Why?

" World-wide Communion Sunday" will be observed tomorrow by Protestants in churches all over the globe, in Army camps, on naval vessels and at battle fronts. Millions will partake of the Lord's Supper. This will be the fifth consecutive year of such united observance, sponsored at home by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America and abroad by the World Council of Churches with the cooperation of the International Missionary Council.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29 -- Vice President Wallace, speaking in a roped-off street in near-by New Kensington after being barred from that city's high school auditorium, said tonight that the United States was just getting started toward a politically democratic system of government.

DETROIT, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The last-place Senators, splitting a double-header today with the Tigers before 17,606 fans, knocked out Paul (Dizzy) Trout in four innings of their 9-to-2 nightcap victory after the Bengals had taken the opener, 5 to 2.

The hope that the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration or other qualified agency will work out a satisfactory plan to take care of refugees unable or unwilling to return to their former homelands was expressed yesterday at a joint press conference of the World Jewish Congress and the American Jewish Conference.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt reiterated today that he had no plans for political speeches beyond his scheduled Oct. 5 radio address to Democratic party workers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- A delegation representing nine national organizations interested in consumers' problems called on War Food Administrator Marvin Jones today with a statement urging him not to take meat off rationing and not to scrap the rationing system.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- In a general overhauling of its regulation setting ceiling prices for staple work clothing the Office of Price Administration today postponed from Sept. 25 to Nov. 1 the date for the preparing and filing of records pertaining to the wholesale percentage used in computing producers' maximums.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 -- Clare Boothe Luce, Republican Representative from Connecticut, denounced the Roosevelt Administration tonight for what she called a "fondness for secrecy in the handling of our international policy," and warned that such conduct is "the fatal road to national disunity and disaster."

The service men of this city will have to do without that batch of cookies blonde Marian Johnson had been planning for them. The management of her "Be Kind to Service Men" campaign has been suspended since last Thursday night, when Mrs. Johnson was arrested for wearing a costume that too nearly resembled that of a Wac.

It loses no opportunity to attack him personally. Recently a Government-sponsored animated cartoon movie was issued ridiculing Mr. Hull.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- A crowd of devout Frenchmen gathered before the famous statue of Georges Clemenceau in the Champs Elysees this morning to celebrate the centenary of his birth. Parisian newspapers emphasized that the anniversary of the savior of France in the last war comes on the eve of another victory.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine will promote sixty-one members of the force, filling vacancies in the officer ranks from sergeant to deputy chief inspector, at ceremonies at 11 o'clock this morning in the office of Mayor La Guardia at City Hall.

Willie Pep retained his featherweight championship of the world in his fight with Chalky Wright, veteran from Los Angeles, at Madison Square Garden last night. The agile Hartford boxer, thanks to a lightning left to the face and a pair of sturdy legs that kept him generally out of range of his rival's punches, took the unanimous decision in the fifteen-round contest.

KEARNY, N.J., Sept. 29 -- Work on invasion craft being constructed at the yards of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company here and at Port Newark, N.J., has been cut 50 per cent by a wildcat strike of 142 crane operators, Walter C. Hemingway, vice president and general manager of the yards, declared in a statement today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Field Marshal Sir Bernard L. Montgomery declared tonight that the First British Airborne Division "did not fail and all is well elsewhere" in praising its gallantry in the battle of Arnhem.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, in the Southwest Pacific, Saturday, Sept. 30 (U.P.) -- Allied aircraft sank or damaged twelve small Japanese ships and five barges Wednesday night and Thursday in extensive sweeps over the Philippines, Makassar Strait and enemy bases in the Netherlands East Indies, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 -- A registration statement covering the proposed issuance and sale of $180,000,000 of first mortgage 3 per cent, Series L, bonds, $155,000,000 of which are to be offered publicly, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Commonwealth Edison Company, Chicago.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Business in today's stock markets was on a limited scale and movements of prices were small. Insurance shares were steady and one or two improved on a little buying. Industries generally were quiet.

In an action-packed, hour-and-a-half press interview Gerald L. K. Smith, Presidential candidate of the America First party, topped some persuasive talking yesterday -- most of it designed to clear his party of its anti-Semitic stigma and link it with "the Dewey high command" -- by bodily ejecting John Roy Carlson, author of "Under Cover."

The Rev. Dr. Alfred C. Snead will leave tomorrow night on his first preaching mission of the fall as foreign secretary of the Christian and Missionary Alliance, with headquarters at 260 West Forty-fourth Street. Dr. Snead, who has under his care 416 missionaries in eighteen countries, will speak at a missionary convention of the Alliance in Akron, Ohio, for three days and then will go to Scranton, Pa., to preach through Oct. 8.

Mrs. McCormick's poignant observations from Rome in THE TIMES today give food for thought. They must be pondered over by every right-thinking American who wants to see a free world living in peace. They once more point up the confusion, the bewilderment, the disorder that must follow in the wake of liberation if the conditions obtaining in Italy are duplicated elsewhere.

In a last-minute rush to buy butter before its ration poet value advances from 16 to 20 after midnight tonight, New York City consumers formed lines yesterday at butter counters of many retail stores throughout the city. Food merchants who had butter limited sales to one-quarter or one-half pound a customer.

An investigation of the basic prices and importation costs of foreign foods as of April, 1943, will be made by a special committee of the food importers division of the Association of Food Distributors of New York, it was decided at a meeting of the group yesterday, Jose M. Calderon, one of the chairmen of the division, announced.

Reversing its previous position, the Board of Education is asking the courts to declare unconstitutional the license No. 1 eligible lists and is seeking to throw out the names of the 2,500 teachers who are still unappointed, it became known yesterday.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 29 (U.P.) -- The Canadians at Calais have granted the Germans a twenty-four-hour truce beginning at 2 P.M. today for the evacuation of civilians, and meantime the Germans are preparing desperately for what is expected to be a bloody last-man defense of the port.

Sales of the Aircraft Accessories Corporation for the fiscal year ended April 30 increased to $38,758,829 from the $24,972,469 volume for the previous year, R.C. Walker, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- After technically occupying the $1,000,000 County Center here since May 15 but never actually making use of the building, the Navy Department canceled today its $60,000-a-year lease on the structure -- a lease that never emerged from Washington in final written form -- and returned the occupancy to Westchester County.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden disclosed today that Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten, Allied Commander in Chief in southeast Asia, was in London -- obviously to discuss offensive plans against Japan.

There was sufficient hedge selling yesterday in the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange to bring about a slightly easier tone, and prices declined 3 to 9 points net. All futures months for the current crop though May sold within a 4-point range from 21.99 cents a pound to 22.03 on the close.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Triple-threat Jimmy Wilson was almost the whole show tonight as Temple University opened its football season with a 34-12 victory over Swarthmore before 8,000 at Temple Stadium.

LONDON, Sept. 29 (U.P) -- United States Ninth Air Force headquarters in France said today that its pilots had disabled at least eleven locomotives, destroyed or damaged twenty-nine rail cars and cut tracks in twenty-nine places during the day.

Some thirty specialists made history at the cancer conference held at Bar Harbor under the auspices of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory. It was not the first time that authorities on cancer discussed their problems, but it was the first time that a plan of research was adopted in the form of a fourteen-point charter designed to bring about cooperation where there has been only chaos.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 29 -- Several developments in vitamin chemistry, an improved transmission wire for rural electrification projects and a method of detecting unwanted ethylene in citrus storage rooms are among the 504 inventions listed as patented in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

The Capital National Bank o Sacramento received yesterday th award of $900,000 of tax antlclpaCalif., Sacramento City unifieo Calif., Sacramneto City unified school district, at 0.24 per cent, plus a premium of $3. The notes will become payable on Dec. 29, 1944.

The editorial "Mr. Dewey's Foreign Policy," in THE NEW YORK TIMES, should be read by every voter. It sets forth with clarity and utmost fairness the issues before the American people. Historians will commend it as an outstanding example of the highest standard of American journalism -- character and integrity in the throes of a political campaign during the world's greatest crisis.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Russian phase of the Dumbarton Oaks Security Conference ended today with an official announcement that "a large measure of agreement" has been reached, and China entered the discussions with the warning that peace in the future depends on the "certainty, definiteness and promptness" with which force is used to prevent and repel aggression.

Word that Robert Viscount Stuart, second lieutenant of the Ninth Lancers, British Eighth Army, died of wounds received in action on the Gothic line in Italy, was received by his grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Solomon R. Guggenheim, and made public here yesterday.

The return of the evening coat logically follows the trend toward formality that pervades the fashion scene for fall. New ideas have been developed in silhouettes and fabrics that make the evening wrap an important adjunct to the evening costume as opposed to the fur coat that performed day and night duty.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Allentown-Bethlehem (Pa.) Gas Company asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to approve its arrangements to finance the purchase of gas manufacturing properties and distributing facilities in Berks and Northampton Counties from the Metropolitan Edison Company, Reading, Pa.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 29 -- Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican, in a statement to The St. Paul Pioneer Press tonight, said that he would not campaign for Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, the Republican Presidential candidate, "at this time."

The presidents of five national engineering societies, whose collective memberships provided much of the technical guidance in America's war mobilization, presented yesterday a scientific four-point program designed to take the ability to wage war out of Germany's post-war industrial economy.

The Christmas wishes of service men for their families and friends back home already are arriving from overseas in the form of orders at the Procurement Branch of the Army Exchange Service. Offices of the branch at 25 West Forty-third Street, took stock yesterday of order blanks received to date and found they had topped 150,000

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Japanese forces have broken into Paoking and are being engaged by battle-weary Chinese in street fighting, while another invader column to the south plunged ahead twenty miles to within thirty-five miles of the Kwangsi capital of Kweilin, the High Chinese Command announced tonight.
SUPREME HEADQUAATERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Communique 174:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- President Roosevelt refused today to make any promises or commitments to spokesmen for organized labor who sought so convince him that the National Wage Stabilization Policy as embodied in the "Little Steel" formula, should be revise to provide higher wages.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 29 -- The Nationalist newspaper Fronda, commenting on the fire that destroyed the Argentine tanker San Blas at Ensenada. Mexico, advances a novel theory in an editorial entitled "This Smells of Sabotage."

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- President Wladyslaw Raczkiewicz of Poland has agreed to relieve Gen. Kazimierz Sosnkowski of the post of Commander in Chief of the Polish armed forces and will name Gen. Tadeusz Komorowski [General Bor] as his successor.
The big push of the third intercollegiate football season of the war will start today.

The Army's GI Santa Claus found himself swamped when the Army Embarkation Postoffice in Long Island City turned over to officers at the Port of Embarkation 30,000 sacks of mail containing a half-million packages addressed to servicemen serving on the many battlefronts, it was announced yesterday by Postmaster Albert Goldman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- A request for a consumer representative on the Surplus Property Board was made today by Dr. Kathryn McHale, general director of the American Association of University Women, in a letter to President Roosevelt who will soon appoint this three-member board.
Columbia's eleven will meet Union at Baker Field today in the metropolitan intercollegiate football opener. The start is set for 3 P.M.

Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for United States Senator, last night denounced the New Deal Administration for its acceptance of the support of Earl Browder, Communist leader. Mr. Curran, who now is Governor Dewey's Secretary of State, addressed the members of the Kings County Republican Committee at a meeting in the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn.

In your editorial of Sept. 28 you raise the question of Mr. Dewey's foreign policy. That is a fair question and one which I believe that Mr. Dewey as candidate for President should answer to the best of his ability.

Nation advertises can obtain space in the vast majority of newspapers although some metropolitan dailies are not always able to give them as much as they asked on specific dates or within a given period of time, according to a survey just made by the Association of National Advertisers among 732 newspapers throughout the country.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Reports that the War Food Administration and Office of Price Administration were considering advancing ceiling prices on cash wheat and readjusting price differences between Chicago, Minneapolis and Kansas City led to general buying of grain futures today on the Board of Trade.
" Vive la France" day was celebrated in Greenwich Village yesterday as artists set up their brightly colored paintings on fences, walls and doorsteps in preparation for evening and week-end crowds.

WEST HARTLEPOOL, England, Sept. 29 -- Michael McPartland, torpedoed British seaman who spent four years as a German prisoner after his ship "Gracie Field" had been sunk off Montevideo in July, 1940, exhibited his disfigured fingers today to support his charges that his captors had tortured him.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 29 -- The Senate today ratified the settlement between the United States and Mexico in connection with the expropriation of United States oil companies here in 1938.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept 29 -- After heated debate in which a substantial bloc of delegates demanded immediate repudiation of the no-strike pledge on the ground it tied labor's hands in its fight for trade union objectives, the convention of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, CIO, voted by 650 to 50 today to reaffirm the pledge "until the war has been finally won, both in the West and in the East."

LONDON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The existence of another -- and still un-used -- German secret weapon, the V-3 rocket with a blast area of about two miles -- was reported today among American Third Army troops advancing upon Germany.

ALBANY, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Plans for pooling personnel resources to handle post-acute and convalescent care of this year's infantile paralysis victims, who are expected to reach a total of 5,800, were reported today by the State Health Department

CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 29 -- Arthur S. Drakeford, Air Minister, told the House of Representatives today that the Government had been forced to the conclusion that its proposal for an international air authority to operate international trunk routes would fail because of "the national ambitions of certain countries to become predominant in air commerce."

Henri Morin de Linclays, director of the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique, or French Line, in this country since 1933, sat tight yesterday in the line's old office at 17 State Street and challenged the assertion by representatives of the French Government in London that he was "out" as custodian of the line's affairs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A charge that CIO local union treasuries are being tapped for political purposes without the consent of the local members was lodged today with a Dies subcommitte, which decided to refer the matter to the Attorney General.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt previewed "The Army at War" art exhibit yesterday afternoon in the Jules Laurents Studios at 2291 Broadway, and found the 150 paintings depicting the life and work of the armed forces so "very interesting" that she hoped many Americans would have an opportunity to see them.

ALBANY, Sept. 29 -- Governor Dewey, in a statement today dealing with National Newspaper Week, Oct. 1 to 8, declared that the suppression of a free press in Continental Europe was a lesson "not without some application to our own country."

LONDON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Marshal Tito's forces, battling Germans, Yugoslav puppet troops and Gem Draja Mikhailovitch's Chetniks, are "standing on the approaches to Belgrade," a Free Yugoslav broadcast said tonight.

LUXEMBOURG CITY, Sept. 28 (Delayed) -- Occupying a richly but tastefully furnished and appointed ground floor room, specially reserved in the stately white stone Arbed Building for the infrequent visits of Heinrich Himmler, Lieut. Col. Edgar A. Jett, former soft coal salesman of Boston, now virtually is running the Duchy of Luxembourg.

ROME, Sept. 29 -- American troops of the Fifth Army in one day's fighting yesterday got over the crest of mountains on the road to Bologna. They took Mount Bastione, Mount Oggioli and Mount Canda, which means that the Germans have lost the Radicosa Pass and lost it so quickly that it is obvious they are not able to stand so well as they were in days gone by.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Phil Hannah, secretary-treasurer of the Ohio State Federation of Labor, AFL, described today abolishment of hiring discriminations as the first requirement of a postwar program for Negroes.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 -- The United Corporation denied today in a letter to the Securities and Exchange Commission the charge brought by three attorneys headed by Alfred J. Snyder of Philadelphia that the staff of the Public Utilities Division of the SEC had participated in secret negotiations in connection with the preparation of the recapitalization plan of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporaton.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Indians and Athletics played eighteen innings of baseball today, but only one victory was recorded, with Philadelphia taking the first half of a double-header, 4 to 2.

The first phase of the Dumbarton Oaks Conference has not ended with every "t" crossed and every "i" dotted on a plan which will infallibly put a stop to war forever. It has ended, however, with far more progress than was made by any international conference prior to Armistice Day, 1918, and with better-justified hopes than those that were raised by the Versailles Conference of 1919.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Saturday, Sept. 30 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Dr. Harry A. Millis, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, declared in a statement today the board's "determination" to see to it that employes were assured an opportunity to vote in collectivebargaining elections free from any illegal interference.

OTTAWA, Sept. 29 (Canadian Press) -- The first Canaries official estimate of Canada's 1944 wheat crop is placed at 447,700,000 bushels compared with 293,700,000 bushels in 1943, the Dominion of Statistics reported today.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Bankers have shown a tendency to rely "a little too much" on the Government but soon should depend again on their own initiative, Leo T. Crowley, head for the Foreign Economic Administration and chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said today in an address at the forty-third annual meeting of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks.

WITH AMERICAN FIRST ARMY, Near Stolberg, Sept. 29 -- Yard by yard, hardy veterans of some of the finest divisions in the United States Army are widening the breach in the Siegfried Line in one of the bitterest battles of the war. This is exacting strenuous fighting, the like of which has not been seen since Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley broke the German positions around St. Lo.

Joseph Buerckel, whose death in his easy forties was reported yesterday, has been in penumbra for some time but he was one of Hitler's most trusted and energetic aides. As Reich Commissioner for the Saar he took charge of the plebiscite in 1935. The expected and carefully engineered result threw Germany into fits and set millions of legs parading.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 29 -- Lucille Ball has been cast by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the second feminine lead in the Katharine Hepburn-Spencer Tracy comedy drama 'Without Love." It will be her first non-musical part for M-G M, to whom she has been under contract for more than two years.

Sixteen, including unbeaten Pavot, are named for the Futurity Stakes, which will gross above $77,000 if all start today at Belmont Park, where one of the best programs of the season will be offered by the Westchester Racing Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The United States has submitted a proposed agenda to the more the fifty countries invited to the International Civil Aviation Conference to be held in this country late this year, the State Department said today.

" Good painting can also be good decoration, and is far more likely to be of lasting quality than the so-called 'decorative' stuff often suggested for home interiors," contends Bertha Schaefer, decorator, who held a private preview of selected works of contemporary American artists at her new studios, at 32 East Fifty-seventh Street yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 29 -- Ernest Urdarianu, Chamberlain and closest political adviser of former King Carol of Rumania, said today that Carol would leave Mexico permanently for Rio de Janeiro "within some time."

The building at 1026-28 South Orange Avenue, corner of Smith Street, Newark, N.J., containing three stores and four apartments, has been sold by Paramount Realty Company of Newark to the 1010 South Orange Avenue Corporation through Morton Howard, broker. The two corner stores have been leased by Mayfair Baby Land, now located at 1010 South Orange Avenue.

Retail trade continued active here this week as consumer demand for fall apparel accessories and home items began to approach its peak. Department store volume was estimated as 10 to 12 per cent ahead of the like week of 1943.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 (AP) The Phillies won today as Ken Raffensberger shut out the Pirates, 3 -- 0, on seven-hit pitching.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Eligibility lists of three teams and umpire assignments for the world series were announced today by Baseball Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- President Roosevelt charged the Argentine Government today with repudiation of "solemn inter-American obligations" and declared he was following with "increasing concern" the development of "Nazi-Fascist" influence and methods in that country.

It developed yesterday that in addition to the plan to issue $23,000,000 of bonds for refunding purposes, the Koppers Company, which always has been controlled closely by the Mellon interests of Pittsburgh, may permit the public to become part owner of the company.

On the same day that Mr. Churchill was paying such high tribute in the House of Commons to the excellent training for war which the United States Army has received, an announcement came from Washington of the plans being worked out for the post-armistice training of the same men for a life of peace.

The stock market perked up yesterday in the final hour when bidding in the rails spread to an assorted list of specialties and produced gains of a point and more. Previous to the closing period, the session had been drab, with activity limited to special situations along with the aircrafts and sugars.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The report that Hungary is suing for peace with Russia is believed here to be correct. A spokesman for the Hungarian Council in Great Britain said tonight that he believed negotiations were going on between representatives of the Soviet Government and Hungarians who would be able to commit their country to laying down its arms.

The nine-story office and showroom building at 37-39 East Twenty-eighth Street has been sold by Jacob Freidus and Samuel E. Aaron for cash over a first mortgage of $55,000 held by the New York Life Insurance Company. It is assessed at $110,000, and was sold through M.A. Blate, broker.

LONDON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Flying through rain and low clouds that grounded heavy bombers, hundreds of American and British medium bombers attacked the Siegfried Line and enemy road and rail channels today in the fifth day of a non-top aerial offensive.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 29 -- President Roosevelt's statement to the press about Argentina, coming as it did only twelve hours after the Farrell Government had announced that it would deny sanctuary to any fleeing Axis war criminals, caused deep surprise and not a little consternation in Buenos Aires official circle today.

ARMY vs. North Carolina -- Ah, a glimpse of daylight at last! If they were all as easy to guess as this one, pigskin prophesying never would be classed as a hazardous occupation. The Kaydets have one of the nation's powerhouse teams and the Tar Heels already have been beaten. That makes it simple. Two or three careless votes for Army.

Business and industry can keep Government participation in their labor affairs at a minimum by doing their utmost to reach agreements with employes and not "dropping the whole bundle into the lap of the Labor Board" James Tanham, vice president of the Texas Company and a member of the National War Labor Board, declared yesterday at the industrial relations conference of the American Management Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
PARIS, Sept. 29 -- One version of the mysterious truce with the Germans during the uprising in Paris was given in the weekly the Action, appearing here today.
ABOARD CARRIER FLAGSHIP OFF LUZON Sept 22 -- We have just fought and won the second battle of Manila Bay.

DETROIT, Sept. 29 --Two days of discussions and offering of exhibits by leaders of the automobile industry of the problems facing them in the reconversion from war production to peacetime output closed here today with a warning that excessively optimistic reports regarding progress made thus far in transition may hinder the complete prosecution of the war.
LONDON, Sept. 30 (UP) -- A communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

Last week Gov. Thomas E. Dewey returned to Albany. He had completed his three-week, 8,500-mile swing around the country, had made nine major speeches, had set forth the main premises on which he would wage the Republican fight for the Presidency. President Roosevelt had made his first frankly political speech, a speech which was partly a statement of Democratic policies and partly an answer to charges leveled at his Administration by Governor Dewey.

IN a season of reproductions, the present volume of short stories is of the genuine, hand-painted variety. As a writer Mr. Freund possesses a most essential and enviable attribute -- the ability to translate philosophical and moral ideas into story ideas.

REGARDLESS of all the pretty little legends to the contrary, Cassandra still is the prophetess of Broadway. The movies in their infinite mercy and technicolor, the columnists and writers for smooth paper magazines, have combined to set up the wrong impression.

THE business of the firm of Cool Lam is picking up, and all because Donald Lain is back with a medical discharge from the Navy. The first client who appears after his return has a problem which appears to be simple enough but which develops complications galore.
Through the adaptation of a "visual control board" to its termination procedures, the Wright Aeronautical Corporation has quadrupled the speed with which it can handle contract terminations.

BILLY ROSE is lining up another one of those heavy batteries with which to hammer the town. Jerome Kern is writing music and Oscar Hammerstein 2d will do the book and lyrics for an operetta which probably will follow "The Seven Lively Arts."

THAT title is a lot lighter than Colonel Gregory's little book. He knows helicopters. He has faith in them. But through his own years of trial and error in rotary wing aircraft, he knows, too, the infinite growing pains this revolutionary type of aircraft must go through before, if ever, there is one in every garage.

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- While refusing to comment formally on the story of the Paris truce given yesterday in the newspaper Action, which charged that an attempt to wreck the rising had been made, informed persons who were in Paris and involved in the Resistance strategy here at that time discussed the background of the mysterious cease-fire order today with this correspondent.

THIS is a valuable book. So many sins have been committed in the name of Impressionism that it is a good thing to have between popular covers (if $5.95 can be called popular) a clear statement of what Impressionism is -- "merely the expression, impossible to assess, of a certain epoch, preceded and followed by other modes of expression."
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 30 (AP) -Minnesota's line play ad running attack were too much for a green Nebraska Cornhusker eleven today and the Gophers romped to a 39-to-0 victory in their annual game.

The New York State Liquor Authority announced yesterday that it had adopted a new policy barring issuance of permits that allowed New York holders of distilling company stock dividends to convert their dividends into whisky.

THAT a rebellion against the excesses of bureaucracy is rising in America is attested by the fact that in the last few months a number of books, of which this by Professor von Mises is the latest, have appeared devoted wholly to the subject.

LORD BYRON died at Missolonghi in 1824 in the struggle for Greek independence. Lord Dunsany, when the Germans invaded Greece over a century later, was occupying the Byronic Chair at the University of Athens.

Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney of Wyoming, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, declared yesterday that Governor Dewey had "displayed his ignorance" and shown irresponsibility by repeating a remark of Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey head of Selective Service, that "we can keep people in the Army just about as cheaply as we can create an agency for them when they are out."

ADVANCED ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, the Southwest Pacific, Sept. 30 -- A new and major threat to overstrained Japanese shipping now has made its appearance in the Southwest Pacific with Gen. Douglas MacArthur's mid-September jump from New Guinea into the old "Spice Islands," the Halmahera group lying 300 miles south of the Philippines.

GREAT LAKES, Ill., Sept. 30 (U.P.) -- Matching speed and fighting freshmen against power and experience, Illinois battled a veteran Great Lakes' football team to a 26-26 tie today before 25,000 service men and women.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Commissioner K.M. Landis holds out little hope that major league baseball teams can resume training in Florida next spring.

The conference which was held from Sept. 21 to Sept. 25 at Bar Harbor, Me., on parental influence in cancer by about thirty specialists may well be a milestone. It was not the first time that authorities on cancer had discussed their problems as a group, but it was the first time that they agreed on a plan of research.

RHODODENDRONS, which have been widely used for home planting during the past decade, are sometimes regarded as hard to grow. Even though the locality is suitable for these distinguished flowering shrubs, many people feel that theirs are not so handsome looking as they could be if they were at their best.

Under a "compromise" reached yesterday between the Copacabana night club, 10 East Sixtieth Street, and city officials, the current cabaret license of the night club was revoked, the club conceded the validity of the city's claim for $37,371 in sales and business taxes, and the connection of Frank Costello, slot-machine entrepreneur and erstwhile dabbler in Tammany politics, which was not admitted by the Copacabana management, was "completely terminated and severed."

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 30 -An official announcement from Sofia received here tonight reported that the three regents -Prince Cyril, Bogdan Philoff and Peter Gabrovski -- who had been under house arrest since the coup d'etat, had been handed over to the Russians for deportation to Moscow, where they will stand trial.

CHINA ASTER is one of the most important flowers in many gardens during late summer and early fall. It is regrettable, however, that in recent years many gardeners have been unsuccessful in growing annual asters because of the ravages of a disease known to pathologists as Phytopthera cryptogea.
Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican national chairman, said yesterday that "you don't see many regular Democratic leaders defending the New Deal these days," and added that some were in open revolt.

Confidence in the outlook for early spring apparel merchandising was bolstered considerably last week by the action of practically all of the style groups in the women's garment field in assuring retailers that, regardless of the dropping of L-85 by the War Production Board, the styles to be shown beginning around the middle of this month would be "authentic" and would hold for the entire season.

Incorporation of Stock Exchange firms will return tomorrow to the stage of open discussion, when it will be considered by the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, opening a two-day meeting of its board of governors in the Biltmore Hotel.

Jule Marshall, the Larchmont man whose avocation is hunting deer with bow and arrow during the seasons in Westchester County and Michigan, spent part of the summer at Twitchell Lake, Big Moose, N.Y., watching beaver. He looked over some old beaver dams and also watched these remarkable engineers busy at their trade on a new one, but what interested us most were some recollections of previous beaver observations.

KEARNY, N. J., Sunday, Oct. 1 -- With production crippled in both its local and Port Newark, N. J., yards by a wildcat strike of 142 crane operators which, company spokesmen say, has virtually halted work on troop ships, naval assault craft, destroyers, cruisers and LSM (landing ship medium) naval vessels, the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company suspended operations in both its plants at midnight until Monday morning.
AMERICAN COMMAND POST IN GERMANY, Sept. 30 (AP) -- First Army correspondents saw for the first time today the full text of one of the most unusual orders of the entire war.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- The important role the American farmer, now possessed of a "tremendous total" of accumulated cash, will play in the country's post-war reconversion period is being stressed by agricultural observers in the Central and Middle West.

PERHAPS the scales do not indicate it, but the suit you wore last spring may, when you put it on this season, tell you that your waistline is not as slim as it was. If, throughout the summer months, the muscles that control the shape and form of the waistline area are allowed to become slack through lack of use, thickness and flabby bulges are the inevitable result.

EVERY so often, Jack L. Warner, executive producer at the Warner Brothers studios, comes out with comments very pertinent to the progressive development of films. A few nights ago he was speaking to the Screen Writers Guild in Hollywood on a subject of vital interest to all thoughtful film folks today -- that is, the stern, responsibilities of motion pictures in the post-war world.

ADVICES wirelessed from Stockholm to THE NEW YORK TIMES tell how Paul Joseph Goebbels, the Nazi Minister of Propaganda, has begun using what purport to be postage stamps as convincing "evidence" that what he has steadfastly maintained is really true -- first, that Europe is being "sold out" by the United States to Stalin and, second, that Stalin and President Roosevelt are dividing the British Empire behind Churchill's back.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -Mark-ups used by retailers in determining their ceiling prices on North Atlantic and Pacific fresh fish and seafood items are being increased by an average of one cent a pound on many species, the Office of Price Administration said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The attempt of the American, British, Russian and Chinese delegates at Dumbarton Oaks to draft recommendations for an international organization to keep the peace has raised again the ancient constitutional question of the right of the Senate to enter into treaties which may obligate us to wage war when the Constitution specifically says that the whole Congress "shall have the power to declare war."

NOW that the last of the three plays which make up its present repertoire has been staged I can say that the Old Vic company's present season at the New Theatre is the high spot of the war for the serious drama in London.

A Manhattan clergyman says the emphasis upon the importance of politicians, left-wingers especially, is one of the factors responsible for present-day difficulties. Yes, Dominie, but let's be charitable. Politicians are only human, they do the best they can, and most of them never quit trying.

LONDON, Sunday, Oct. 1 -- Russian troops invading Yugoslavia in a drive aimed at sealing off 200,000 Germans in the lower Balkans have seized a sixty-mile bridgehead on the Yugoslav side of the Danube River opposite Rumania and captured a score of villages, Moscow announced officially last night.

MOSCOW, Sept. 30 -- Reporting a steady deterioration in the Japanese military situation, the Communist party newspaper Pravda said today that Japanese propagandists were attempting to hearten their people, fearful of an Allied invasion, by recalling that a Thirteenth Century invasion armada from Mongolia was wiped out by a typhoon, which is cited as historical proof that their country was invulnerable to direct attack.
