THAT autumn affords splendid opportunities to increase soil fertility is not so widely appreciated as the fact that intelligent fertilization is one of the main principles of good gardening. In order to get the best out of soil, it is necessary to put into it the required plant foods and supplies of humus.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 30 -- Representative Clare Booth Luce, Republican, of Connecticut, tonight defended her remarks about "GI Jim," the American veteran killed in this war, made in a speech at the Republican National Convention last June, declaring that the victims of the war should be kept in mind constantly by the survivors as martyrs to the failure of the Roosevelt Administration to prevent the rise of the dictators who caused the war.

BOSTON, Sept. 30 -- Support of Governor Dewey in New England has grown remarkably during the last few weeks. His hard-hitting, practical campaigning has encouraged faint-hearted Republicans who believed last spring that any fight against Mr. Roosevelt would be futile.

The first phase of the 1944 Presidential campaign came to an end last week with the return to Albany of Thomas E. Dewey. That return followed by five days the emergence from international conferences and the general running of the National Government and the war of Franklin D. Roosevelt, political candidate.

APPREHENSION of Hollywood's employe groups over the problems of the returning soldier and jobs came to the surface at a meeting last week of the Screen Writers' Guild, called to "face a critical problem of the immediate future."
Gertrude Berger in THE TIMES Magazine gave some interesting highlights on the history of a phenomenal game in "The Ouija Comes Back."

The all-New York company of the Women's Army Corps to honor Lieut. Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, commander of our forces in the Philippines who has been a prisoner of the Japanese since the fall of Corregidor in May, 1942, will open for enlistments today.

THE music of Czechoslovakia's most distinguished composer has been heard on orchestral programs in America from time to time during the past ten years; since the outbreak of war and Martinu's arrival in this country his music has been performed with increasing frequency, to meet with considerable success.

THAT Winslow Homer is a painter of first consequence in our native panorama need no longer be argued. He is one of the few truly outstanding figures of his period. Usually considered one of a trio with Eakins and Ryder, he can as easily belong, as I have frequently pointed out, in a quartet in which Ralph Blakelock is also bracketed.

THESE are busy days for John Corigliano, who begins his second season as concertmaster of the Philharmonic-Symphony Thursday evening. Mr. Corigliano joined the orchestra in 1935 as assistant concertmaster, but he didn't assume the first desk until last year, when the post became vacant.

THE Viking Portable Shakespeare (6 3/4"x4 1/4"x1") contains the complete Kittredge text of four tragedies: "Hamlet," "Macbeth," "Romeo and Juliet," "Julius Caesar;" three comedies: "A Midsummer Night's Dream," "As You Like It," "The Tempest," and the Sonnets (627 pp); those passages from other plays that every schoolboy and some politicians, know(57 pp); most of the songs (9 pp), and a keyword index to quotations for impatient people with poor memories (18 pp in small type).

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Japanese forces, storming down from the northeast, have fought their way to positions approximately thirty miles northeast of the big American-Chinese base of Kweilin and have reached the American advance air base of Tanchuk, 130 miles south of Kweilin, the Chinese command announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -Julius A. Krug, chairman of the War Production Board, said today that a WPB "task force" had prepared a tentative program under which on V-E Day (Victory-inEurope Day) the WPB would revoke 350 of its 500 industrial control orders.

JUST about a week from today, Oct. 7, to be exact, Diana Lynn will be 18 years old. This, to the rising young Paramount star, will be known as "L"-day, "L" for Liberation, and the possibilities will be enormous.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- There is plentiful evidence that the Republican campaign management is much encouraged by the effects of the President's first openly political speech, one of which was the vigorous reply of the party candidate, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey. There is abundant evidence also that the oratorical exchange has given to the Republican management more hope than before of a successful election outcome.

The twenty-third annual specialty exhibition of the Cocker Spaniel Breeders Club of New England will be held in Boston Friday and Saturday, Oct. 20 and 21. President Joseph E. Redden announces that this year's show will be given as a testimonial to O.B. Gilman, former president, who, for a quarter of a century, has worked for the advancement of the American cocker spaniel.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 30 (AP) -- The University of Tennessee came back into the nation's football picture today, displaying a fast set of backs who outran the University of Kentucky, 26 -- 13.

Jennings Perry in his article about the South says, "Practically no southern woman of poll-tax age ever casts the ballot." Has he statistics for this? In the years I voted in Alabama and in South Carolina I met many women casting their ballots.

BY this time the phrase is pretty well worn out and dreadfully frayed around the edges. But baseball men still say it in tones of such profound reverence that they practically tip their hats when they speak. The expression in all its stark triteness is this: "Anything can happen in a short series" -- although some of them pronounce it "serious."

With no let-up in the public's desire for merchandise, fall retail business is reaching its peak much earlier than usual and reorder requests therefore are particularly heavy, according to the market report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

WAR has strange and unpredictable by-products. You wouldn't think offhand that one of these would be the development of a great new batch of operagoers, but it is. Thousands upon thousands of American men and women in uniform who have never seen an opera in the United States will return home from this madhouse with experience of, and perhaps fondness for, opera.

THE final harvesting of herbs is down on the calendar for any really dry day now. In most cases, one or two cuttings have already been made, at flowering time, of leaves used in cooking. But this pleasant work must be finished some time before frost kills the tender annuals and bites the tips of some of the hardier plants.

VIEWED simply as a romantic chronicle, the career of John C. Fremont and his beautiful wife, Jessie Benton, is one of the most compelling tales in all of American history. It has what the Hollywood scenarists call "everything": a passionate love interest, episodes of Western adventure and heroism seldom surpassed, scenes of Washington intrigue, business transactions that interested two continents, and a Civil War chapter of absorbing suspense.

Present indications, based on advance reservations received for the American Merchant Marine Conference and the eighteenth annual meeting of the Propeller Club of the United States, point to heavy attendance during the conference to be held in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Oct. 18, 19 and 20, with maritime industry leaders from all parts of the country taking part.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Direction 2 to Conservation Order M-73, by which the sale or delivery of snowsuit cloth was prohibited except on a rated order, has been revoked, the War Production Board announced today.

For five years internal revenue agents have been instructed, in the course of their examinations of taxpayers' records, to make special reports upon corporations which have not distributed at least 70 per cent of their net earnings, as required by Treasury ruling TD-4914.

GEN. DWIGHT D. EISENHOWER is the principal architect of the Allied victory in the west. The calculated and icy efficiency of Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley and Field Marshal Sir Bernard Montgomery's tactical skill have at times obscured the brilliance of the Supreme Commander who has played a major role in the planning and execution of the Allied campaigns in France, Belgium and Germany.

Action by the Argentine Government last month in announcing export control under license of hides and leather and other commodities is regarded by some importers here as indicating the beginning of a trend in international trade that may carry with it serious implications for world distribution of needed materials.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 30 -Navy's dream of a golden era this fall when the yard is filled with glittering stars from other football sectors received a rude awakening today when North Carolina Pre-Flight's determined band of warriors emerged a 21-14 winner in the middies' opener.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sunday, Oct. 1 -- The United States Seventh Army, fighting through snow sweeping out of the Vosges Mountains, wheeled up to two foothill passes yesterday and were only nine miles northwest of the gateway city of Belfort to challenge the Germans along the chain of peaks blocking the southern route to the Rhineland.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Basil O'Connor, chairman of the American Red Cross, will leave soon for Europe by air to inspect Red Cross operations with United States troops in France and Great Britain, it was announced today at national headquarters.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Communique 175:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Labor's resentments came into fairly sharp focus this week at the War Labor Board hearings, where both AFL and CIO urged abolition or modification of the "Little Steel" formula.

IN 1884 a botanist appeared before the Royal Society with an armful of charts and a paper in three parts and proceeded to riddle the prevailing notions of the Manchester School of Economics. He was Patrick Geddes, scarcely known outside of his native Scotland.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- A military academy for training women commissioned officers is proposed by Representative E.E. Cox, Democrat, of Georgia, ranking majority member of the Rules Committee, in a bill the text and purpose of which he announced today.

Retail trade here continued active last week. Consumer buying of fall apparel and accessories is climbing toward its peak for the early season. Department store volume was estimated as ranging from 10 to 12 per cent ahead of the like week of 1943.
LANCASTER, Pa., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Coach Jordan Olivar's Villanova Wildcats scored their second football victory of the season today, conquering Franklin and Marshall by 14 -- 6 on a rain-soaked field.

Charles Alan's "Ode to Nature," published in THE TIMES MAGAZINE, has caused me to write a challenge to the pleasantness of city life which he seems to like so much. You might call it "Sonnet: Seen in a City."

ROME, Sept. 30 -- Whenever there are revelations of Fascist crimes there is more excitement abroad than here in Italy. This week, for instance, it was revealed that the late Count Galeazzo Ciano, Mussolini's son-in-law and Italian Foreign Minister, himself ordered the assassination in France in 1937 of the anti-Fascist Carlo Rosselli.

SOMEWHERE in China stood the Village where Head Man Chou once ruled his neighbors and his family with an iron hand. "The Phoenix and the Dwarfs" is the story of what Japanese bayonets and new social trends have done to Chou and his two sons, to the Village and to rural life in general.
CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 30 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sunday, Oct. 1 -- With their consciences relieved of the lives and safety of some 20,000 civilians, Canadian forces drove into the town of Calais yesterday after the French port's defenses had been drenched with bombs and shells in a final effort to liquidate the German garrison holding out there under Hitler's express orders.

I disagree with the thesis of Haydn Pearson, in a recent issue of your magazine, that compulsory military training will be necessary if we wish to prevent a repetition of the catastrophe that has befallen our generation. The newspapers praise Russia's destruction of the breeding place of militarism and the conscription system and at the same time tell you that men are working on plans to transplant that very system in your home town.

Tinhorn gamblers and their associates make the largest contribution to juvenile delinquency in the city, and the Police Department mill continue in its efforts to drive them out of the community, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday at exercises held in the Board of Estimate chamber at City Hall, marking the promotion of sixty-two members of the department.

Brooklyn Tech, a leading schoolboy eleven here last season, opened its campaign with a 13-12 victory over Abraham Lincoln on Lincoln's gridiron yesterday. Al Veling's point after a touchdown on a line plunge was the margin after his team had scored twice in the first period.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 30 -- For the second time this year Jewish commercial and residential sections of Jerusalem are under day and night curfew, following yesterday morning's fatal shooting of Assistant Police Superintendent T.J. Wilkin, who was killed as he was walking to his office at police headquarters.

ROME, Sept. 30 (AP) -- When and if Mayor La Guardia arrives here he will find himself already satirized in "Cantachiaro," an Italian musical comedy that has been drawing capacity crowds for two months.

RICHMOND, Sept. 30 -- Plans for taking care of the returning service men are shaping up in this section, and in Richmond a committee headed by Dean George Modlin of the University of Richmond is attempting to coordinate the multitude of agencies now seeking to have some part in the task.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 30 (U.P.) -- Dartmouth and Holy Cross fought a battle of aerials to a 6-6 tie today before 8,000 football fans who journeyed to Memorial Field for the thirteenth contest of this 41-year-old New England gridiron rivalry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -Americans were told by many spokesmen last week that they had better pull in their belts an extra notch and prepare for a winter and possible spring campaign against Germany, and for at least eighteen months of war against Japan after Germany's defeat.

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 30 (UP) -- The Tokyo radio said today that a civilian evacuation of Manila had begun following devastating raids last week by Admiral William F. Halsey's third fleet and smashing American invasions of the Palau Islands on the southeastern threshhold of the Philippines.

The strategic problem in the defeat of Japan has always been two-fold -- reducing her ability to fight, getting close enough to her homeland, or wherever her main strength is concentrated, to defeat her forces in the field. Last week the nation was given a glimpse of the progress of that strategy and of what lies ahead.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Sept. 30 (AP) -- A bone-crushing offensive brought Penn State a decisive 58 -- 13 victory over Muhlenberg today as the Nittany Lions rolled 462 yards on the ground for their first victory of the 1944 football season.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30 -- The American League pennant race, now down to its final one-game dash to the tape, still was tied in a handsome bowknot late today as Luke Sewell's Browns turned back the Yankees for the third straight time, 2 to 0.

JOHN and Ward Hawkins, two brothers from Portland, Ore., who are now in the Army, show signs of becoming the smoothest literary doubles team since Nordhoff and Hall. The Hawkins brothers run to muscular heroes -- loggers, pilebucks, members of the black gang -- and to tough dialogue. But they really know the trades they write about, and there is nothing phony or literary in their toughness.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- The German radio reported tonight that Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain, Chief of State of the defunct Vichy Government, had fled to Germany before the Allies' army approaching Belfort, leaving Fernand de Brinon as chief of a "French Government committee for the protection of the national interest."

EVEN while the first battle of Germany moves to a climax, the second battle is developing -- the political battle. Probably this second battle is still far from its crisis, but the fronts are becoming clearer.

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- "I had never before understood the French Revolution quite so well as on Aug. 26 last when I watched the crowds greeting Gen. Charles de Gaulle in the Champs Elysees," said a French historian to this writer a few days ago.

The American Economic Review, official organ of the country's economists, made public yesterday an article that will appear in its forthcoming issue, initiating a discussion by American economists of the significance of the recent revision of Soviet economic theory.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Newspaper publishers have strongly urged the War Production Board not to revoke print paper controls on V-day in Europe but to retain the controls "until every newspaper in the United States is assured of an adequate supply of newsprint," the WPB said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- With large-scale reconversion tied willy-nilly to the progress of the war, extensive resumption of civilian goods production appeared more distant this week than it had for many months.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The War Labor Board stated today that the Fair Employment Practices Committee concedes to WLB the authority to deal with questions of racial discrimination in handling labor disputes.

Yields of Victory gardens will be displayed in many of the 116 medical and social welfare agencies affiliated with the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies in the observance of Succoth, the traditional harvest holiday, which begins tonight at sundown and continues until Monday of next week.
ST. OMER, France, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The last civilians of the from 17,000 to 20,000 fleeing Calais passed this way today under the threat of a battle about to open in their streets, yards and homes.

DETROIT, Sept. 30 -- Left-hander Hal Newhouser, carving his twenty-ninth pitching triumph, set down the Senators with eight hits today as the Tigers gained their seventeenth victory over Washington, 7 to 3, to hold their share of first place with the Browns.

Although the War Food Administration has ended butter set-aside requirements for October, members of the trade estimated yesterday that unfilled set-aside obligations amounted to 30,000,000 pounds. As dealers in arrears will continue to make reservations for the Government, the butter shortage is expected to continue for the rest of the year.

Last week the war in Europe took on a new aspect. The season was changing; the kind of fighting was changing. The headlong sweeps that earlier had marked the Allied campaigns in both east and west were now coming up against the main strength of the foe, entrenched in the strong natural defenses girdling the inner citadel of the Reich.

Manufacturers of branded lines of underwear have made appreciable gains in production and sales in the last two years despite serious shortages in materials and labor, it was learned last week from manufacturers in the trade. Their position has been so strengthened that maintaining volume sales in the post-war period, even with the return of a buyers' market, should prove no serious problem, it was stated.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

September came to an end yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange wish prices higher on the day and mixed on the month. The day's trading saw aircraft shares in the lead of a general moderate recovery movement.

THE French State of Marshal Petain is dead without ever having lived an independent life. Officially, the Third Republic, never having ceased to exist. continues, but President Lebrun has not returned to the Elysee Palace, and it will take more than a decree of the Provisional Government to bring the Third Republic to life again.

Rabbi Israel Goldstein, in a sermon in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street, near Broadway, declared yesterday that "The American people must get out of the mood of relaxation which has come over some of them as a result of the recent succession of victories on the war fronts."

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 30 -Two Buenos Aires nationalist organs, Cabildo and Federal, joined hands today in accusing President Roosevelt of having falsified the truth in his statement Friday that Argentina had not discharged her international commitments.

WITH the European war nearing its final phase it is no particular secret that many in Washington and elsewhere believe that people on the home front, particularly along the Eastern seaboard, are not as aware as they should be of the nature of the enemy that confronts us across the Pacific.

HOLLYWOOD. AN Army captain by the name of Clark Gable went to see a movie called "Lost Angel," about a child wonder who rattled off Chinese and dabbled in the Napoleonic campaigns. The child wonder was Margaret O'Brien.

DIAMONDS by millions of carats have given new precision to the war tools of the United Nations. The use of industrial diamonds has so expanded that stones which would ordinarily sparkle in a jeweler's window have "put on overalls" and joined their rougher brothers in grinding machines, dies and cutting tools.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The General Motors Corporation told the National War Labor Board today that there should be no change in the country's established wage policy at this time to avoid the peril of inflation.

Since last Sunday there has been a decisive advance in plans and preparations for peace and at the same time a realization that peace may not come as soon as many of us had expected. The first phase of the conferences at Dumbarton Oaks has ended with an encouraging extent of agreement among the United States, Great Britain and Russia.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, made a plea to regard the European situation as a whole, at a conference of the Vassar College Community Church today. He urged a curb for the resentment that would lead Germany to rearm eventually in spite of temporary control of her military and industrial resources.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Michigan State College boomed back into the football wars today after a one-season layoff by overpowering the University of Scranton (Pa.) 40 to 12 before 7,000 spectators.

An unsettled situation not conducive to aggressive post-war business activities nor to complete post-war employment has resulted from the manner in which Federal tax laws have been administered, according to a country-wide survey of the National Association of Manufacturers.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sept. 30 -- Canadian troops and British war planes opened a crushing attack on Calais at the stroke of 12 today, after a 24-hour truce during which 20,000 civilians trudged from the bomb-torn port, leaving behind 4,000 Germans ordered to fight to the last man and cartridge.

A laboratory system designed to measure the specific odor, taste and visual properties of foods and beverages, and also the preferences of the typical consumer, is described in a report to the American Chemical Society by E.C. Ziegler and E.H. Scofield, two chemists who specialize in the study of wine and spirits.

THERE is a mouth-filling word that everybody stumbles over in Italy whether they try to say it in English or in Italian. It is "defascistization," or, in Italian, "defascistizzazione." The word is not only hard to say; it expresses something that is terribly hard to do, and thereby hangs one of the gravest dangers for the future of Europe and the world.

MOSCOW, Sept. 30 -- Edward B. Osubka-Morawski, chairman of the Polish Committee of National Liberation, sharply attacked Lieut. Gen. Tadeusz Komorowski [General Bor], newly appointed commander in chief of armed forces loyal to the Polish Government in London, today as "a criminal against the Polish people."

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- After four years of long-range shelling from German guns in the Pas-de-Calais area the English coastal towns of Dover, Deal and Folkestone, that have become known as "Hellfire Corner," were today officially considered "liberated," following the capture of the last remaining guns at Cap Gris Nez.

NIJMEGEN, The Netherlands, Sept. 30 -- The Netherland medical profession gave the Germans a strong dose of very distasteful medicine during the early days of the occupation, according to a story told today by a local doctor.

PEARL PRIMUS, who is probably one of the best known young dancers in the field, has curiously enough never given a Broadway performance. That is now to be rectified in a big way, for beginning on Wednesday evening of this week and running through the evening of Oct. 14 she will dance nightly at the Belasco Theatre under the management of Max J. Jelin.

Activity in the field of new corporate financing is at the highest level at which it has been in many years. Seldom, if ever in recent financial history, have investment bankers been called upon to distribute, or investors to absorb, a greater volume of new securities over a period of two and a half months than that which was offered to them in September and planned for the market during October and early November.

In reply to a telegraphed inquiry from THE NEW YORK TIMES, seventeen of thirty-three Democratic candidates for the Senate this year and two of twenty-nine Republican candidates have said they favor a Constitutional amendment authorizing treaty ratification by a simple Senate majority or a majority in the two branches of Congress.

THE American has a pronounced tendency to use nicknames and slang expressions. Every job, trade, profession, sport and hobby has developed a jargon all its own. Here is some of the slang of the detective story industry as aired by "Sez You," the "slanguage" quiz heard over the Blue Network.
ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 30 (AP) -Cornell's football forces rolled to a 26 -- 0 victory over Bucknell in their home opener before 7,000 on Schoellkopf Field today, scoring a touchdown in each period.

I was very much interested in the recent article on "General American" speech, by James F. Bender, in which he described and discussed the sectional characteristics of fair speech. I am a New Yorker, but have lived and worked in Boston for several years and have had a number of friendly arguments about New England speech in and around Boston as influenced by the Irish brogue.
LONDON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Pavot's foot was bloody, but his head unbowed as he sped on to victory by two lengths yesterday in the world's richest juvenile race, while 35,386 persons at Belmont Park cheered him on in his gallant effort. The champion colt, who never has been defeated, is through for the season with the outer wall of his hoof ripped from coronet to heel.

PETER DE VRIES, author of "But Who Wakes the Bugler?" and "The Handsome Heart." has turned to satire in his latest novel, "Angels Can't Do Better." Its amusement value relies on its schoolroom setting and its involved account of a young college professor, attempting to combine actual practice with theory in his classes on political science, trying to overthrow a corrupt political machine.
New York last night was winding up "the quietest moving season in its history" with no sign of the bustle and confusion usually associated with Oct. 1.

ONCE again durable Desmond Shannon does his stuff while the official police and the FBI look on in awe-struck admiration. He has two jobs on his hands. One is to help the police apprehend the murderer of Theodore Armisted, shot in his own home while a cocktail party is going on.

A UNITED STATES NAVAL AIR STATION, Hawaiian Islands, Sept. 30 (AP) -- "Jato" for Tojo, the American fliers call it -- an important new aerial weapon recently announced by the Navy -- is about to go into use against Japan.

An automobile ferry service linking Key West, Fla., with islands of the West Indies and connecting Cuba with Mexico is being planned as a post-war project by the Gulf Atlantic Transportation Company of Jacksonville, Fla., Harold G. Williams, president, announced here yesterday.

Charles V. Halley Jr., former Transportation Commissioner and long active in Bronx Democratic politics, has been named chairman of the Dewey-Bricker-Curran Citizens Committee in that borough, it was announced yesterday. Campaign offices have been opened at 149th Street and Third Avenue, 233d Street and White Plains Avenue, 165th Street and Ogden Avenue, Westchester Square and 183d Street and Third Avenue.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- The London Daily Mail's allegations that American business men had been making their way to Paris in uniform to get in on the ground floor of French trade revival are likely to provoke at most a teapot tempest. The possibilities for export trade to France on any regular commercial basis in the near future are not bright.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 30 -For more than three periods, a stubborn Coast Guard Academy team threatened to make football history in the Yale Bowl by becoming the first Connecticut rival to defeat the Elis in seventy-two years of varsity football, but a last-quarter surge won for Yale, 7 to 3.
ROME, Sept. 30 (AP) -- A communique:

Reversing a trend that began when this country entered the war and jobs became plentiful, the high school enrollment has stopped its downward spiral. Fewer boys and girls are leaving the classroom to go into industry. For the first time in three years the tremendous exodus of students from the nation's secondary schools has been checked.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 30 -- Notre Dame's Irish, striking with unexpected speed and power, today served notice they'll again be very much in the running for the mythical national collegiate title they won last year as they smothered the University of Pittsburgh's Panthers under a barrage of aerials and a varied running attack, 58 -- 0.

FOR an undisclosed purpose a certain labor union has ordered, direct from the publisher, 1,000 copies of "Labor Baron," James Wechsler's not very sympathetic portrait of John L. Lewis. . . . Even though listed as a mystery, "Hue and Cry" (a Jefferson House November publication, to be distributed by Morrow) appears, at first glance, to be of political import: the author is Thomas B. Dewey.

FIVE or six years ago a young woman named Margaret Halsey spent a year in England and recounted her experiences in a demure little book called "With Malice Toward Some." in which she landed one deft punch after another on all the more open and vulnerable spots in the British way of life.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 30 (AP) -Predicting full employment for United States citizens after the war if all groups cooperate, Vice President Wallace said tonight:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -French disappointment, as expressed in Paris newspaper comment, that the Quebec conversations and other recent international negotiations have not brought recognition of the French Provisional Government is not shared in political circles here, which feel that much has been done in recent weeks to clear the way for the desired objective.

LAST week this department touched upon the contributions to literature which are likely to come as a result of the tremendous impetus the war has given to flying. I mentioned some of Selden Rodman's remarks on the subject in his introduction to "The Poetry of Flight," but I did not refer to his suggestion that through contact with the air it is possible that poetry may achieve a great revival.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 -The University of Pennsylvania football team wasted no time in getting around to recording an upset in the young gridiron season. The youthful Quaker eleven, facing a favored Duke machine, treated the Southerners quite inhospitably and handed them a decisive 18-7 setback today.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 30 -The pass that wasn't there won a football game for Indiana today as Michigan, prepared for Bob Hoernschmeyer's aerials, saw its line ripped by Fullbacks George Sundheim and Harry Jagade in a 20-to-0 upset victory for Indiana.

One of the main factors back of the OWI forecast of eighteen more months of war with Japan is undoubtedly the present situation in China. It would be untrue to say that it couldn't be worse, for it gives every prospect of growing worse before it can be made better.

HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 29 (Delayed) -- The question of identifying Finnish war criminals is a matter to be settled later, Pavel Orloff, political adviser to the Allied Control Commission in Helsinki, said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -Play-by-play descriptions of the world series games will be broadcast to troops in all overseas theatres by the Armed Forces Radio Services, it was announced today by the War Department.

A CABLEGRAM received from Moscow by J. H. Stolow says the U.S.S.R. is issuing two stamps to mark the seventy-fifth anniversary of the birth of Sergey Chaplygin (1869-1942), aeronautical scientist. Chaplygin dedicated his life to mechanics, hydro-aeronautics and mathematics and belonged to the Academy of Sciences.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 30 (AP) -- A pair of ground-eating scoring drives plus a 68-yard return of a pass interception provided the margin of victory as the University of Rochester rolled to a 20-13 victory over favored Colgate today.

Many specially designed fashions will be shown at the Third Edition-1944 "Fashions of The Times," which will get under way for an eight-performance presentation on Oct. 24 at The Times Hall, 244 West Forty-fourth Street. The show, in which leading New York textile manufacturers and designers will cooperate with THE NEW YORK TIMES, will stress fabrics and will continue for four days with matinee and evening performances.

ROME, Sept. 30 -- The first statement on Italy's financial situation, which was published today, showed that fascism and the war had left this country with a public debt of a little more than 650,000,000,000 lire.

NIJMEGEN, The Netherlands, Sept. 27 (Delayed) -- Thus far something like 800 men and women have been arrested in Nijmegen as collaborators. They are being held in the city jails pending trial before special Netherland courts that will be established within a few days.

LIBERTY, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- The theoretical suppression of supposed civil disorder by Company F, Eighth Regiment, New York Guard, became so realistic here this afternoon that plans for a further problem tomorrow were modified.

Support of President Roosevelt and Senator Harry S. Truman was pledged unanimously yesterday by delegates to the fourth biennial convention of the New York District, State, County and Municipal Workers of America, who at the same time attacked Governor Dewey for failing to take proper care of workers in "his own backyard."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- President Roosevelt accepted the resignation of Donald M. Nelson today as chairman of the War Production Board and set down specifications for a new job for Mr. Nelson which the President described only as "a high post of major importance" in connection with "laying the groundwork for post-war economic cooperation with other nations."

THE list of long-awaited household items included in the "spot authorization" program initiated by the War Production Board on Aug. 15 as a blueprint for industry's conversion to civilian products sounds like the American housewife's letter to Santa Claus. Almost anything might be made by a manufacturer who can present the necessary qualifications.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, citing issues raised by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, asserted tonight that national unity could not result from the Presidential campaign "if one of the high candidates for office continues untruthfully and unfairly to impugn the motives of the High Command that directs our war effort."
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Brown put on a touchdown parade at Brown Stadium today in pinning a 44-to-0 defeat on Tufts.

SCHENECTADY, Sept. 30 -- How the development of the jet propulsion airplane turbine was kept a secret in this country for two and one-half years, with scarcely more than a hundred persons within a manufacturing organization of 190,000 employes knowing about it, was told here today by the General Electric Company.

ROME, Sept. 30 -- One of the few art monuments of Pisa still standing on the southern bank of the Arno River is the exquisite little Gothic Church of Santa Maria della Spina. All around it houses are in ruins, but it somehow escaped damage.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 30 -- The rank and file of the Democratic party in Louisiana has won its fight for instructed electors.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 -- Declaring that President Roosevelt had been a "rabid isolationist" prior to 1938. Clare Booth Luce, Republican Representative from Connecticut, charged today that the country had been "lied instead of led" into the present war by its Chief Executive.

SHORTAGE of electric power is delaying the reopening of 325 motion picture theatres in Paris, but elsewhere in France American and British films are being enthusiastically greeted by Frenchmen. The situation in Paris is unique. Up to last week only three newsreel houses were open in the city and they were turning away crowds starved for sight of honest film. Nothing to compare with it has ever been seen in Paris.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The supply problem in the war against Japan is three times that of the war in Europe, James V. Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy, said here today.

Though plastic surgeons who are now treating airmen who have been disfigured by bullets, shrapnel and burns fear that too much is expected of them in the way of complete restoration, they admit that they have made progress. Here are some of the modern plastic surgical methods, now being used at East Grinstead, England, where the Queen Victoria Hospital is training American surgeons.

PAU, France, Sept. 29 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- French authorities in southern France are daily discovering new evidence of atrocities committed by the Germans before their evacuation, official sources throughout the Biarritz-Toulouse region reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Coffee rationing will again be necessary unless Government agencies succeed in efforts to increase shipments of coffee to this country, the Office of Price Administration said tonight, adding that a decision will be made within twenty-four hours.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 30 -Brazil recently set up a commission to study post-war reconstruction as it will affect Brazil internal economy. This body has been directed by the Brazilian Foreign Office. Nimitz, the new Great White Father to thousands of Micronesians.

THE San Francisco Opera Association, which opened its four-week season Friday in San Francisco, will give twenty performances in that city, three in Sacramento, six in Los Angeles, one in San Jose and one in Pasadena. Works listed comprise "Aida," "Lakme," "Manon." "The Tales of Hoffmann," "Martha," "Carmen," "Faust." "Salome," "Masked Ball," "Falstaff," "La Boheme," "Lucia di Lammermoor" and "Forza del Destino."

Members of a deputation of the Protestant Episcopal Church who will leave soon for England to confer with the Archbishop of Canterbury on problems of Episcopal and Anglican missionaries after the war, called yesterday morning at the office of Presiding Bishop Henry St. George Tucker, 281 Fourth Avenue, headquarters of the Protestant Episcopal national council, to complete plans for the trip.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 30 -Army's 1944 Model T struck like seven forks of lightning in its unveiling today in Michie Stadium and the cadets ran and passed a spirited but outclassed North Carolina eleven dizzy in a 46 -- 0 scoring jamboree.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 30 -- Any boundary adjustments after the war between Greece and Yugoslavia will be made in bilateral conferences held in the most friendly spirit and only after the final European peace negotiations, this correspondent was informed today by Demetrios Pappas, Greek charge d'affaires in Egypt.

DOVER, England, Sept. 30 (AP) -- In their joy, the people of Folkestone remembered to thank their liberators. Six bishops will take part in the celebration of the 100th anniversary of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis of Assisi, 135 West Thirty-first Street, beginning at 8 P.M. Tuesday and continuing through Sunday. There will be solemn mass at 10 and a service at 8 P.M. each day. ,The observance coincides with the feast of the church's patron saint.

PARIS, Sept. 29 (Delayed) -- The French railroads are slowly shaking off the effects of the Germans' occupation and the Allies' bombing, Maj. Gen. Frank E. Ross, chief of transportation for the United States Army in this theatre, said today.

BOSTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Labor troubles curtailed activities today at two New England shipyards.

A White House conference on rural education, called by the National Education Association and the White House, to discuss means of improving the schooling received by millions of farm children, will get under way Tuesday evening and continue through Thursday. It is expected that a "charter for rural youth" will be prepared that may set the standards for farm education for many years to come.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 30 -- United States armed forces have under way an extensive rehabilitation and job-counseling program to help prepare veterans for return to civilian life, according to an address by Maj. Samuel P. Roach today at the industrial relations session of the conference of the National Urban League.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Sunday, Oct. 1 -- A single Navy Catalina bomber destroyed four Japanese freighters totaling 8,500 tons and sank six loaded barges in Darvel Bay, Borneo, on Thursday night as Allied bombers struck enemy shipping routes off Surigao, northern Mindanao, and throughout the East Indies, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

ROME, Oct. 1 -- Good news came from the Italian Partisans' headquarters in northern Italy today to coincide with the announcement that the Swiss had recognized the patriots' provisional government in the Ossola Valley south of Switzerland.

Frank A. Howard, president of the Standard Oil Development Company, a research organization of the Standard Oil Company (N.J.), announced on Saturday in Elizabeth, N.J., to a party of some 2,800 employes and their families celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the company that he had resigned, effective on next Friday. He will be succeeded by R.P. Russell, executive vice president of the company since 1937.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 1 -- Canadian Army infantry and heavy guns began today to close a ring around the Netherlands islands to which the Germans are clinging to deny Allied armies the use of Antwerp, one of the greatest ports in the world.

BOSTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Al Javery won his tenth victory of the season today as the Braves defeated the Chicago Cubs, 7 to 6, in the second game of a double-header at Braves Field after dropping the first contest, 4 to 3.
ROME, Oct. 1 (AP) -- A communique:

In Bright sunshine and before a crowd of 6,961 loyal Flatbush fans, the Dodgers made their farewell of 1944 at Ebbets Field yesterday a reasonably pleasant one by nosing out Bill McKechnie's Reds, 6 -- 5. Neither team had anything to gain or lose in the contest, since a first-game triumph of the Pirates over the Phillies had made certain the Reds couldn't finish higher than third nor the Brooks lower than seventh.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 1 (U.P.) -- American marines and Army forces have "secured" four islands in the southern Palaus with the exception of two small pockets of fiercely resisting Japanese and have killed more than 10,000 enemy troops in the eighteen-day campaign, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz said today.
HONOLULU, Oct. 1 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz called for increased war production today in a statement terming Hawaii and the West Coast the "forward echelon of America's arsenal of democracy."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- "Chambers of commerce and trade associations across the land, representing hundreds of thousands of business men, believe in social security,'' said Eric A. ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 1 -- A comprehensive program for reconversion, expansion and maintenance of American shipbuilding on a level that would provide work after the war for most of the 1,722,000 now employed in it was made public here today in a report by officials of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, for presentation to its convention tomorrow.

PARIS, Oct. 1 (AP) -- All French journalists will have to be licensed by the government starting in April, 1945, the Agente Francaise de Presse disclosed tonight in its summary of the newly published Government press ordinances.

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- With German-banned books restored -- and books glorifying Germany and Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain eliminated -- several million French children will return tomorrow to elementary schools freshly arrayed with the republic's tricolor and portraits of Gen. Charles de Gaulle, head of the French Government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Basil O'Connor, chairman of the American Red Cross, announced here today the appointment of a special medical and health committee composed of eleven men, prominent in their respective fields, to survey current Red Cross medical and health operations and to recommend plans for the post-war period.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- President Roosevelt, who conferred with a group of CIO and AFL officials Friday, will continue his discussion of labor problems this week with another group of labor leaders. Chiefs of four railway unions and one machinists' union have been asked to meet Wednesday with the President, it was learned today.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Green Bay's Packers spotted Detroit a touchdown today, but drove back to overwhelm the Lions, 27 to 6, for their third straight National Football League victory.

LONDON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- All American and Royal Air Force heavy bombers were grounded today because of weather on this opening day of October, traditionally a bad month in Allied air operations. The weather had improved tonight, however.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Bob Estalella's three-run, tenth-inning homer broke up a scoreless tie and sparked the Athletics to a 5-to-0 triumph over the Indians in the second game of a double-header today. The Athletics won the first game, 5 to 2.

DOVER, England, Oct. 1 -- The people of Dover seemed dazed today with the full realization that they could come and go as they pleased without the constant dread of long-range shells from across the strait. They had had more than 2,000 shells fired at them in four years and this was the first Sunday since Aug. 12, 1940, that they could be assured of a normal existence.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 1 -- Edward G. Robinson has been signed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to be starred with the child actress, Margaret O'Brien, in "Our Vines Have Tender Grapes," the George V. Martin novel of a Wisconsin farming family. Jackie Jenkins, who made his screen debut as the youngest member of the family in "The Human Comedy," and Frances Gifford also will be seen in the film.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The board of directors of the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad have authorized the purchase of $3,500,000 of Diesel locomotives, steel passenger and freight cars and steel rail, L.C. Sprague, president, said tonight.

LUXEUIL, France, Sept. 30 (Delayed) (AP) -- The mysterious modern "Scarlet Pimpernel" of the French Commandos, who has led an incredible existence since D-day for southern France, has been identified as Major Henri d'Astier de la Vigerie, brother of a former member of the French Committee of National Liberation in Algiers.

NAPLES, Oct. 1 -- Waiting in a military airport for the weather to clear is an adventure in uncertainty, but it is also an excellent way to learn how vital to modern war, how carefully patrolled, are the aerial highways. We were at the Rome airfield at dawn two mornings ago to start a roundabout trip north, but so far we have traveled no farther than Naples.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 1 -- Led by the more distant positions as early peace hopes chilled with the announcement of the Commodity Credit Corporation's plan to buy 1944 cotton at parity prices, cotton futures moved sharply last week to new highs for the season on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange.

An attractive collection of antiques -- from sources as divergent as colonial mansions, Victorian parlors, farmhouse kitchens and Old World palaces -- went on display yesterday afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel and will continue through Friday evening.

Exports from the United States are continuing at record levels, and on the basis of figures for the first seven months of 1944 may reach the huge total of $15,000,000,000 this year, the National City Bank of New York reported yesterday in its monthly letter.
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 1 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
The Philadelphia Nationals lost their American Soccer League engagement with the Brookhattans at Starlight Park yesterday, 6 to 5.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- The building industry will probably be free of most of its restrictions three months after the end of the European war, builders said today in analyzing the results of the recent conference of the National Association of Home Builders.

Few persons have thought of brass as a material for decorative accessories lately, except in terms of heavy andirons and fireplace tools or early American candlesticks. Nevertheless its warm yellow glow may do more than anything else would to brighten up a dark corner and it makes a rich foil to furniture of dark polished woods.

Marie Louise Wagner, soprano, gave her first local recital in nine years last night in Town Hall. A mature singer with a carefully trained voice, Miss Wagner displayed a sure grasp of style and penetrating insight as interpreter throughout a program devoted largely to German Lieder by Beethoven, Schumann, Schubert and Brahms but also containing the aria, "Divinites du Styx" from Gluck's "Alceste" and a group of English songs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Office of Price Administration has revised its controls over the use of suger in meat, fish or poultry packing and processing to lend flexibility to the amounts of sugar to be consumed in specific products.

THOSE who like to toy with words are forever intrigued by the structural composition of the word setup. By a slight transposition of letters setup becomes upset. The first full Saturday of the football season saw plenty of the supposed setups rock back the mighty in major upsets.
Hyman Blumberg, State secretary of the American Labor party, announced yesterday a program of radio speeches as part of its campaign for the re-election of President Roosevelt. The schedule follows:

In his regular Sunday broadcasting, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that he thought the butter situation had been "bungled up locally by the OPA but there is no use crying over coupons over the counter."

Charles M. Switzer, director of cellophane production at E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. since 1935, has been named director of the company's nylon production, effective Oct. 1. Dr. Elmer K. Bolton, chemical director of the company, has been elected to receive the Perkin Medal of the Society of Chemical Industry, American Section, in recognition of his outstanding accomplishment in the field of industrial research.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- The Presidential campaign of 1944 -- second in the nation's history to be held in time of war -- will swing into its final and crucial thirty-five-day stretch tomorrow with the temper of the farm States of mid-America furnishing the principal hope of the Republicans that their candidate, Governor Dewey, might stop the fourth-term aspirations of President Roosevelt.

The New York District, State, County and Municipal Workers of America brought its fourth biennial convention to a close last night at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, after unanimously renewing a no-strike pledge for the duration of the war.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The combined Chicago-Pittsburgh eleven came from behind to defeat the New York Giants, 17-16, today in a thrilling exhibition that was mostly Johnny Grigas.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels has opened a new propaganda campaign to bolster German morale. The High Command is pictured as believing the luck of the war will change again in German favor.

Retail activities during the past week were good, but deliveries are generally poor, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Women's suit orders were placed for November and December deliveries, it is pointed out, but deliveries are worse in the balance of the ready-to-wear markets.
SOFIA, Sept. 29 (Delayed) (Reuter) -- The Bulgarian Minister of Propaganda, Dimo Kazasoff, today announced a new provisional regime in western Thrace and eastern Macedonia.
Three new films are slated to arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Communique 176:

BALTIMORE, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Shoving across six runs in a wild eighth-inning rally, the Baltimore Orioles squared their International League series with the Newark Bears today at two games apiece, with a 7-3 victory before 29,667 hysterical fans.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 1 -- About 1,500 persons, divided between whites and Negroes, attended today's sessions of the National Urban League, held in the Shiloh Baptist Church, at which Lester B. Granger, executive secretary of the league, received an award from the Committee to Abolish Racial Discrimination, of the Congress of Industrial Organizations (CIO).

LILLE, France, Oct. 1 -- In a speech today in this capital of the industrial north of France, Gen. Charles de Gaulle, for the first time, explicitly committed himself and his Government to the creation of a new economic system in France -- a system of planned economy under the direction of the Government, as he described it.
HONOLULU, Oct. 1 (AP) -- A barrage of home runs gave the Army its first victory over the Navy today in the "service men's world series," a 5-3 verdict in the finale of the seven-game tournament.

A plea to communicants to offer daily prayers for priests because they are subject to human frailties while being God's helpers was made made yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral by Mgr. Joseph F. Flannelly, the administrator.

Mayor La Guardia told 4,000 persons yesterday at La Guardia Field, at the opening of service between New York City and Miami by National Airlines, Inc., that aviation was making such rapid strides that within a few years New Yorkers would be able to week-end in London or Paris in the same manner as they took a jaunt into the country now.

Reflecting the announcement by the War Food Administration of its plan for assuring parity prices to growers, cotton prices in the domestic market advanced sharply at the outset last week, with an upsurge of 69 to 100 points, or $3.45 to $5 a bale, on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (U.P.) -- As soon as conditions permit, the Battle Monuments Commission proposes to restore memorials and national cemeteries in Europe of the first World War, which have suffered from neglect, rather than destruction, in the present conflict.
The Catskills once again are safe for the hotel trade. An official communique issued from the field of maneuvers at 12:15 P.M. yesterday reported that "alien saboteurs have been dispelled."

Retirements of bonds in September before maturity declined to the smallest monthly total since May and were below the figure for September, 1943. At $145,480,000, the month's redemptions compared with $198,610,000 for the preceding month and $226,750,000 for the corresponding month a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 -- Gerald L.K. Smith, Presidential candidate of the America First party, told more than 800 at a rally tonight that President Roosevelt and Governor Dewey were "low-heeled traitors" who had "hitched their horses behind the barn and are driving them off together."

Although the volume of business on the New York Stock Exchange last month dropped to the second smallest of the year, trading in September was the largest for that month since 1939. Sales exceeded the million-share mark in two sessions, the largest of which was 1,477,770 shares on Sept. 7, while on Sept. 18 trading declined to 344,855 shares, the second smallest of the year.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 1 -- A nine-foot putt for a birdie three at the seventeenth hole by Dr. Charles J. Robinson, Wheatley Hills enabled him and George Meredith to defeat Harry Carroll and Tom Strafaci, Plandome, 2 and 1, in the final of the annual member-guest tourney at the Garden City Club today.

In all British hearts Dover is "forever England." The old city above its white cliffs is the rampart of the realm, "the key to England." Beneath its ancient turf, relics of the Romans, the Saxons and the Normans lie at peace. Before the war untroubled merchantmen and watchful destroyers steamed in and out of the harbor, for it was chief of the Cinque Ports that guard the nation.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- The prospect that a winter campaign will be necessary to defeat Germany has made it certain that the present Conservative-Liberal-Labor coalition Government in Britain will endure until next spring or even summer.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- James F. Byrnes, War Mobilization Director, stated today that there is no necessity for rationing coffee now.

War Mobilization Director James F. Byrnes is quoted in today's paper as stating that "the hold-the-line policy has been bent, but on the whole the line has held, and Government should continue to hold it until the dangers of inflation are past."

Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican national chairman, announced yesterday that the October drive for the election of the Republican national ticket would begin tonight with a speech by Gov. Earl Warren of California at Minneapolis in a week of campaigning that would reach its climax in Governor Dewey's speech Saturday night at Charleston, W. Va.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Proposals for seizing, naming trustees for and restoring to operation under their rightful owners all industrial properties plundered by the Nazis are set forth in a pamphlet report issued today by the Committee on International Economic Policy.

The post-war outlook for the private electric power and light industry in this country, as a whole, is that during the period of readjustment there will be no great amount of idle capacity, the commercial planning committee of the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday in the first of a series of post-war studies on generating capacity and electric sales.

The General Platoff Don Cossack Russian Chorus, Nicholas Kostrukoff conductor, which made its debut in this city in Carnegie Hall late in 1940, gave a most enjoyable concert at its first appearance at the New York City Center yesterday afternoon before a large and appreciative audience.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 1 (U.P.) -- Finnish soldiers striving to drive the Germans from north Finland were reported battling strong garrisons today in the streets of Kemi and Torneaa along the northern shores of the Gulf of Bothnia, and advancing northward along a 115-mile front.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- J.A. Krug, chairman of the War Production Board, declared today that the Government could not grant now the request of automobile manufacturers for priority on machine tools to give the industry a fast start on passenger cars after the German collapse.

OPTIMISTS who have been making wagers that the European hostilities will cease before snow flies were no doubt considerably discouraged by Prime Minister Churchill's remarks about 1945 before the House of Commons last Thursday. But since they were only backing hopes and Mr. Churchill, although he was speaking from better sources of information, was only estimating probabilities, there can be few indeed with any firm convictions about so conjectural a matter.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Miss Margaret Osborne of San Francisco today won the women's Pacific Coast tennis championship by defeating Miss Louise Brough of Beverly Hllis, 8 -- 6, 3 -- 6, 8 -- 6. Miss Brough was the defending titleholder.

PARIS, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Pablo Picasso, famed painter whose works were termed "degenerate" by the Nazis and removed to the top floors of galleries in German museums, has emerged from the retirement he imposed on himself during the German occupation and will show about fifty paintings arid sculptures in the Paris autumn salon, which opens Saturday.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 1 -- Eight American and Canadian hospital executives were advanced to fellowship in the American College of Hospital Administrators at the eleventh convocation of the college here this afternoon.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- Examination of an unexploded flying bomb by British air experts has established hitherto unknown facts. The distance traveled by the bombs is controlled by a small windmill in the nose whose revolutions are recorded by an electrical counter.

Declaring that the war casualty lists had created added interest in the question of immortality, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, said in his sermon yesterday there were ample indications in the New Testament that bereaved persons may expect to recognize and have renewed fellowship with loved ones in an after life.

Trust Robert Reud to steer his theatrical course by the stars. A practitioner of astrology, it is no secret that he consults the firmament for guidance before, during and after launching a production. According to his calculations, tonight is a propitious time to introduce the postponed farce, "The Odds on Mrs. Oakley," at the Cort.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 1 (U.P.) -- An all-time record for Japanese ship sinkings in one week was set during September when bombers of the United States Fourteenth Army Air Force sank 28,000 tons of Japanese ocean-going vessels, probably sank 1,700 tons more and damaged 4,300 tons during the week of Sept. 21-27, according to a communique from Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters.

One million volunteers, one-tenth of the estimated number now busy at wartime activities, will be needed for community service after the war, it was predicted yesterday by Mrs. Winthrop Pennock, executive director of the Association of Junior Leagues of America, and Miss Violet M. Sieder, secretary to the Committee on Volunteer Services for Community Chests and Councils, 155 East Forty-fourth Street.

We have a great many Americans of Italian descent in this country, and in the normal course of events we are certain to meet a few of them at least. The recent years have been a little embarrassing for them, even though their sons were in our Army and Navy, fighting perhaps against their own kin on foreign soil.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1 -- Baseball fans of the Mound City, skeptical almost to the very last, finally turned out en masse today and threw themselves into a paroxysm of joy as Luke Sewell's Browns brought to this metropolis its first American League pennant in history.

ROME, Oct. 1 -- The Luftwaffe struck an all-time low in the Mediterranean theatre by sending only fourteen fighters against the Fifteenth Army Air Force in September. The figure was announced today. All fourteen were shot down.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- The struggle between Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk's exiled Polish Government in London and the Soviet-sponsored Committee of National Liberation for political control of Poland approached the exploding point today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The White Sox and Red Sox took only 2 hours and 48 minutes playing time to divide their season's final games today. Rookie Rex Cecil won the opener, 3 to 1, for Boston, and Johnny Humphries, veteran Chicago right hander, took the afterpiece, 4 to 1.

Wendell L. Willkie sent complimentary telegrams yesterday to the two Republican candidates for the United States Senate who indicated unequivocally in a NEW YORK TIMES poll that they favored a constitutional amendment providing for ratification of treaties by a majority vote of the Senate instead of the two-thirds vote now required.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Senator Truman of Missouri reiterated today his belief that millions of dollars were wasted in construction of the big Sunflower ordnance plant at DeSoto, Kan., but had no comment on the Government's withdrawal from a multi-million dollar informer's suit against contractors who built the plant.

Only six of the thirty-two major current information campaigns dealing with important home front problems will be terminated at the end of the war in Europe, according to a survey made by the War Advertising Council in cooperation With the Office of War information.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 1 -- The United States Fourteenth Air Force announced today that it had evacuated and destroyed its air base at Tanchuk, in southeastern Kwangsi Province. It was the second time in two weeks that Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault's airmen had been forced to abandon and blow up a strategic operation center imperiled by the Japanese offensive.

In general, the commodity market was relatively inactive during the past week. The changes that did occur caused the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices to drop from the previous week's all-time high level of 113.52 to 113.45.

For the nineteenth consecutive year New York's rodeo-minded will have ample opportunity to "yippee" and "ride 'em, cowboy," becoming Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden and for twenty-five nights and fourteen matinees thereafter.

Jocularly asserting the "it's tough for an Army man to give anything to a sailor," Mayor La Guardia presented yesterday to Robert Pearson, electrician's mate 3d class, several prizes including $150 in cash for being the millionth service man to enter the National Catholic Community Service Center, 17 East Fifty-first Street.
ALBANY, Oct. 1 (AP) -Approval of fifty applications from twenty up-State communities planning post-war projects, to cost an estimated $5,720,457, was announced today.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 1 -- While the principal democratic newspapers keep silent, the nationalist press continues attacking President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull for their policy toward Argentina. Today's editorials, like yesterday's, are liberally spiced with charges of bad faith and aim chiefly at rejecting the accusations of fascism brought against Argentina.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Trading in oats on the Board of Trade here was relatively light last week, except early in the period, when the market was affected by strength in wheat and advanced sharply. Short covering was the main influence; as soon as the buying let up, the market eased.

Walnuts hang in green clusters against the sky, now that the leaves have begun to thin out, and butternuts can be seen there on the dark branch. Among the hickories there is a steady patter of hulls as the squirrels work their way from limb to limb, making the most of a particularly good yield of hickory nuts.

The Reynolds Metals Company has arranged a $25,000,000 regulation VT credit through the Bank of Manhattan Company as agent for a group of banks to provide or replenish working capital for war production. The credit carries 2 3/4 per cent interest.

In an effort to reach 12,000 industrial nurses in this country, a nation-wide membership drive has been opened by the American Association of Industrial Nurses. Headed by Catherine R. Dempsey, R.N., and organized in 1942, this marks the first campaign for increased membership undertaken by the association, which comprises a membership of 3,500.

Preaching his first sermon as a regular staff member of the Community Church of New York, the Rev. Donald Harrington, associate minister, declared yesterday in Town Hall that among the basic causes of the present world tragedy was "an ertreme discrepancy between man's achievements in the physical sciences and the social and psychological sciences."
LONDON, Oct. 1 -- A spokesman for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower told the Austrians in a broadcast tonight "to prepare for the arrival of the Allies."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Ending one of their most successful months in a blaze of Japanese destruction, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's flying forces ranged from Celebes to the Philippines, damaged or sank three Japanese ships, set fire to airdromes and destroyed a number of parked planes, today's communique announced.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Monday, Oct. 2 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (U.P.) -The War Labor Board tonight directed regional boards and industry commissions to withhold approval of voluntary wage-progression schedules which raise an employe to the top of his rate range in less than twelve months for unskilled, eighteen months for semi-skilled and twenty-four months for skilled jobs.

NIJMEGEN, The Netherlands, Sept. 30 (Delayed) -- Working in such secrecy that even members of their families and many of their intimate friends remained in ignorance of their activities, a 30-year-old merchant, a student and a clerical worker have been publishing and distributing what they proudly call "an illegal paper" for one year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Little change was shown in the lard and hog products market last week, with offerings remaining small and reflecting the limited movement of hogs while the demand was active, but sales were restricted by lack of offerings.

A denunciation of self-exaltation, which he said applied also to political parties and to nations who will meet about the peace table, was made yesterday by Canon Edward N. West, sacrist of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Edward V. Loughlin, leader of Tammany Hall, made public yesterday a letter to the Tammany assembly district leaders, urging them to make every effort for a large vote for President Roosevelt, Senator Robert F. Wagner and the rest of the Democratic ticket.

In reply to a telegraphed inquiry from this newspaper, seventeen of thirty-three Democratic candidates for the Senate this year and two of the twenty-nine Republican candidates declare that they favor a constitutional amendment authorizing treaty ratifications by a simple Senate majority or a majority in the two branches of Congress.

KANDY, Ceylon, Oct. 1 (U.P.) -- Resuming their penetration of the Arakan sector in southwestern Burma, British troops battered down "slight" Japanese opposition and captured a hilltop position southeast of Maungdaw, while farther north, other Allied units scored gains in their advance on the enemy base of Tiddim in the Chin Hills, a communique announced today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Bears, minus Sid Luckman but apparently rejuvenated after their defeat by the Packers last week, handed the Redskins a 28-0 defeat before 22,017 in a National League exhibition today. The running of Ray McLean, substitute halfback, and the receiving of George Wilson were the high spots in the Chicago victory.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Monday, Oct. 2 (U.P.) -The famed Bayeux tapestry, the 850-year-old embroidered pictorial of the conquest of England by William the Conqueror -one of Europe's most prized art treasures -is safe in a lead box in the sub-basement of the Louvre in Paris, it was learned today.

The schedule of art events for the week includes twenty-five shows. The Whitney Museum will place on view tomorrow oils and water-colors by Winslow Homer, chiefly from private collections, in connection with the publication of a book on the artist by Lloyd Goodrich, research curator at the museum.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 1 -- When the "Great White Fleet" under Rear Admiral Robley D. (Fighting Bob) Evans and Rear Admiral Charles S. Sperry sailed around the world in 1908, there was started a process and a tradition that came to its latest culmination last week somewhere in the waters of the Western Pacific.

Mayor La Guardia's broadcast from City Hall yesterday was not the "farewell address" expected by many of his radio audience and even by some members of his official family. There was no hint that he would soon leave for Italy. with the rank of brigadier general, to serve as a member of the Allied Military Commission by appointment of President Roosevelt.

The Allied Military Government in Italy, although faced with a difficult and complicated situation, has made much progress in little more than a year, according to an article by Col. Charles Poletti, Commissioner of the Rome Region for the AMG, which will appear in tomorrow's issue of The Civil Service Leader.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 1 Saul Lantzis, chairman of Fenway Golf Club's tournament committee, saw to it that the club's annual member-guest tournament was safely under way this afternoon, then trailed the assembled thirty-four members and thirty-three guests, comprising sixty-eight best-ball teams, to the scoreboard in near-darkness with the winning card of 35, 34 -- 69, made in company with Dave Scope of the Metropolis.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles and the Cleveland Rams, unbeaten National Football League rivals, played a 7 -- 7 tie today in an exhibition game before 14,753 fans. The Rams scored in the opening period as Tom Colello, a Canisius graduate playing on a familiar field, starred.

SAMPSON, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- Eight thousand bluejackets, representing virtually all Protestant denominations and twenty countries, assembled in a drill hall at the Naval Training Center here this morning and participated in the biggest World Communion Sunday service in the Navy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (U.P.) -Representative Richard B. Wigglesworth, Republican, of Massachusetts, said tonight that station WWDC, Washington, had reportedly provided Democrats with commercially sponsored radio time to urge President Roosevelt's re-election, a seemingly "clear violation" of the Hatch and Corrupt Practices Acts.

ROME, Sept. 29 (Delayed) -- Of Greece's estimated population of 7,000,000, 500,000 persons have tuberculosis. Two and a half million suffer from malaria because the measures previously taken against its spread have been rendered impossible under German rule.

From the France for whose liberation he gave his life, came a stirring tribute yesterday to Brig. Gen. Theodore Roosevelt Jr. at memorial services at the French Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit (Eglise du Saint Esprit), 109 East Sixtieth Street. General Charles de Gaulle, President of the Provisional Government of the French Republic, said that General Roosevelt's sacrifice would not be forgotten by the French people.

A two-cent tax on all transit fares within the city, to be paid by riders on rapid transit, street car and bus lines, whether publicly or privately operated, was proposed yesterday by the City Club of New York. Such a tax, the club declared, would provide additional revenue of $68,000,000 a year to meet the annual subway deficit of $41,000,000 and provide funds for necessary improvements.

ROME, Oct. 1 -- The death of Princess Dora Ruspoli, one of the best known hostesses in Rome, was announced by her family today. Princess Dora, who was well known to the American colony of Rome, was visiting her sick chauffeur in a poor quarter of the city Sept. 27.

Little, Brown has announced that James Oliver Brown has been appointed editorial representative of the company in New York, where he will take up his duties today. Mr. Brown was associated for a short time with The Publishers Weekly, and before that was a captain in the Army.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -The end of August found the Postoffice Department with a surplus of $6,495,203, in contrast to a deficit of $12,979,868 correspondingly a year before, Frank C. Walker, the Postmaster General, announced tonight.

Fifty thousand persons packed the Central Park Mall yesterday for a civilian's view of GI entertainment. Mayor La Guardia told the audience, many of whom sought vantage points for a glimpse of Hollywood and Broadway stars, to "kick in" with support for the New York War Fund, sponsors of the show, in its current drive for the USO and thirty other member agencies.

SUPRME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 1 -- Canadian troops captured the bomb-torn port of Calais today, along with the German commander, Colonel Schroeder, who was unable to rally his motley army for the last-man defense ordered by Adolf Hitler.

The electric power and light industry, following the devastating effect of the recent hurricane on the Atlantic seaboard's power facilities, is taking steps to avert a recurrence of the operating handicaps whereby some 1,750,000 customers found themselves without electricity for periods ranging from a few hours to seventeen days.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Although trading in corn futures on the Chicago Board of Trade has not come up to the expectations of operators since it was resumed two weeks ago, this is said to be due to the lack of supplies of cash corn at terminal markets and the refusal of brokers to operate freely until there is a balance wheel of liberal hedges in the market.

ROME, Oct. 1 (AP) -- British Eighth Army troops have captured Savignano, ten miles inland from the Adriatic on the Rimini-Bologna highway, after several days of bitter fighting, and have thrown the Germans back at some points from their strong Fiumicino River line, Allied Headquarters announced today.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- Stock market activity here continues at an extremely low level. The current daily official business markings are around only 4,000, compared with 6,000 last week, which was accounted a very poor record. It is the old complaint of post-war uncertainties cramping the initiative of investors.

CHEVY CHASE, Md., Oct. 1 -- Out of the keen competition of the finale of the annual National Capital Kennel Club show Miss Anna Katherine Nicholas of New York today picked as best of show and best American-bred the fawn boxer bitch, Ch. El Wendie of Rockland.
Former Gov. Alfred E. Smith, critically ill in Rockefeller Institute Hospital, showed "real improvement" yesterday, his personal physician, Dr. Raymond P. Sullivan, announced.

Football will be king at Ebbets Field tonight. A crowd of 32,000 fans is expected to welcome the gridiron sport back to the Dodgers' ball yard, where the Brooklyn Tigers of the National League will clash with a Service All-Star eleven in a game that is calculated to attract $3,500,000 into the Treasury Department coffers through the sale of War Bonds.
Today we take time out to look back on the past season and to review some of the outstanding stores and products discussed in this column since the beginning of the summer.
Possibly the North Carolina Pre-Flight Cloudbusters had no intention of springing a "sleeper" on the Naval Academy.
