I read with pleasure your brief dissertation on "That Cricket" on the editorial page of the Sunday TIMES recently. Your treatment of Gryllus neglectus was interesting reading and shot through here and there with threads of humor -- a pleasing quality all too rare these days.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Pirates clinched second place in the National League pennant race today by winning the opener of a double-header with the Phillies, 9 to 1, but bowed, 7 to 1, in the second game at Shibe Park. when Manager Frank Frisch filled his line-up with rookies.

Calais, the Continental spearpoint aimed at England, which was also Hitler's first objective in his war against the west, is again in Allied hands. Despite Hitler's express orders to hold out to the last man, and the German commander's professed willingness to do so, the German garrison as such had no stomach to die for the Fuehrer and gave up when their officers' authority broke under the final Allied assault.

It is important that Pennsylvania's new State law, designed to correct the neglect of American history in the high schools, should not be made the subject of erroneous statements as to its historical origin and need.

Re-election of President Roosevelt for speedy victory in war and enduring peace and full post-war employment was urged yesterday by Vice President Henry A. Wallace in a speech from Reading, Pa., broadcast to 4,000 Negroes at a rally in the Golden Gate Ballroom, West 142d Street and Lenox Avenue.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- With light airs in contrast to the blow of yesterday, the second regatta of the post-season series of racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club was held today, and W.H. Stanley's International sloop Bumble Bee and J.H. Gould's Class S craft Allons won over ten and one-half miles of easy sailing.
PROCESSED FOODS (canned or bottled fruits, some juices, tomatoes, catsup and chili sauce) -- Blue stamps A8 through Z8, and A5 through R5, good indefinitely, at 10 points each.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- A peace formula for Germany under which her industrial monopolies would be broken up and stock ownership distributed among workers and returning soldiers was proposed tonight by Senator Kilgore, West Virginia Democrat.
They wrapped the 1944 baseball championship season yesterday at the Polo Grounds and put the Giants in camphor in fifth place.
Succoth, the Jewish Feast of the Tabernacles, which began at sundown on Sunday, was marked yesterday with numerous sermons, most of them dealing with the war.
LONDON, Oct. 2 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 2 -- David Newcombe, president of the Wright Aircraft Supervisory Association, consisting of the foremen and some other minor executives employed at various plants of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation in this area, today announced that he had persuadded members of his association to return to work following their absence from their jobs since last Friday.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 2 (U.P.) -- About 2,200 American heavy bombers and fighters, sighted but avoided by German fighters, attacked three main railway and industrial centers of western Germany through broken cloud today with a loss of less than 1 per cent of the estimated striking force.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Edward Hopkinson Jr. of Drexel Co., financial advisers to the Philadelphia Electric Company, said today at a Securities and Exchange Commission hearing on the utility's application for exemption from competitive bidding that the proposed $130,000,000 bond issue could be sold nationally under a private arrangement.

At the precise moment when Nazi propaganda began to talk about the military "miracle" which had enabled Hitler to "stabilize" the western front and thus avert immediate defeat, the American First Army has struck one of the hardest blows of the war. After two weeks of preparation, and a heavy aerial and artillery bombardment, it has crossed the Wurm River in the neighborhood of Geilenkirchen and cut the Aachen-Duesseldorf railroad.

Page Estate, Inc., has sold the five-story garden-type apartment house at 1997-1999 Hughes Avenue, the Bronx, assessed at $210,000, to Walclar Realty Corporation, headed by Abraham Klorman. Jack S. Glasser represented the purchaser.

To remove the "lingering doubts" of "some people who ask whether the cruelties of the Gestapo are really as bad as they are painted," the British radio broadcast today an eyewitness description by a Canadian Broadcasting Corporation correspondent of a concentration camp at Breendonck in Belgium, where he said hundreds were tortured and killed during the German occupation.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Oct. 2 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt visited wounded airmen in the old and new cantonment hospitals here today. As she went through the wards she stopped at the beds to ask the men how they felt and what battles they had been in and wished them speedy recovery.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Chinese Government has presented to the United States and Great Britain at the Dumbarton Oaks security conference a detailed plan for the creation of international machinery to remove or mitigate the causes of war.

The six-story loft building at Ninth Avenue, southeast corner of Fifteenth Street, has been sold by the Hiljer Realty Corporation to the 62 Ninth Avenue Corporation. On a plot about 51 by 100 feet, directly opposite the Port of New York Authority Building, the property is assessed at $110,000. J.F. Cahill Co., Inc., brokers in the transaction, have been appointed managing agents.

The four-story eighteen-family apartment house at 459-61 Linden Boulevard, Brooklyn, assessed at $44,000, has been sold by Fannie Goldberg to Samuel Rosenblum. Charles E. Goldberg was attorney for the seller and Julius Schapper for the purchaser.
George W. Clausen, formerly with Hibbard, Spencer, Bartlett Co., has been appointed assistant merchandise manager, Aldens Chicago Mail Order Company's home furnishings division.

Increased interest was attracted yesterday to the stock market, but only minor improvement resulted as the list went into the last quarter of the year. The aircraft division was the principal trading vehicle, although the gains were spotty and best additions were not generally held through to the close.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Because the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration proposed to distribute through its own machinery the food and supplies it was prepared to grant to Yugoslavia, the Yugoslav Committee of National Liberation has refused the offer, the Free Yugoslav radio said today.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 19 per cent last week over the comparative week last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported a gain of 14 per cent over 1943.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 2 -- The British First Airborne Division, which made the heroic ten-day stand behind the German lines at Arnhem, quit its position only after two-thirds of the division had been killed, wounded or isolated and it was apparent that it could not possibly hold out for twenty-four hours.

"99 Park," headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc.,* offers a partial list of free amusements available today, through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M. Evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.
Developments of the last few days underline once more the President's vacillations and vagaries in the administrative field.

One of the most interesting union publications which I have had the good fortune to see is a recent Report on Unrest and Dissatisfaction made by a Special Research Committee of the International Brotherhood of Papermakers.

An American soldier fighting in France and this city's Missing Persons Bureau formed a long-distance partnership in man-hunting that proved of service yesterday to a French woman by locating her husband, whom she had not been for nearly four years.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 138:

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- Mrs. Richard Hellmann of the Scarsdale Golf Club led Miss Margaret Nichols of Hudson River, Westchester-Fairfield "duration" champion, by a stroke to win the association's one-day event held in high winds over the south course at the Westchester Country Club today.

Censored in New Haven and Boston, "Men to the Sea" arrives at the National this evening with still the important cuts restored," according to Dave Wolper, producer. Herbert Kubly, a reporter of The Herald Tribune staff, is the author of the play, his first on Broadway.

Describing himself as a leader of an extensive underground movement in Argentina, Felix Cernuschi, Professor of Theoretical Physics at the University of Tucuman in that country, declared in an interview yesterday in the office of The Nation, 20 Vesey Street, that he also represented a group about to form in Montevideo, Uruguay, a "liberation junta" that hoped to be recognized "by all democratic countries as our provisional government in exile."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Eric A. Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, and Robert M. Gaylord, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, urged the National War Labor Board today to favor continuance of wartime wage and price stabilization policies until the end of the war.

ROME, Oct. 2 (AP) -- German resistance officially described as "very strong" had brought the Allied drive for Italy's industrial north to a virtual standstill tonight along the last mountain rim guarding the broad Po River Valley.

To compound a warning: "Don't bet on the races and don't write plays about them -- unless, of course, it is "Three Men on a Horse." Harry Segall has tried his hand, with "The Odds on Mrs. Oakley," and this morning after the night before at the Cort he must be wandering around without his shirt.

Attendance at the spring opening of volume shoe manufacturers at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday was about double the figures reached at the April displays, but buying activities, while very strong on rationed types of shoes, were tempered in so far as the non-rationed types were concerned.

Plans for a thirteen-story industrial building on the site of the old St. John's Park Terminal were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings by Victor Mayper, engineer, for the Hudson-Varick Corporation, subsidiary of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, Inc.

In your editorial "Doctors and the Mayor" you have offered detailed criticism of an editorial appearing in the Journal of the Medical Society of the County of New York on Sept. 16 which seems to be based on intimate knowledge of the Mayor's plan not available to the public.

Two new productions have been added to the repertoire of the New York City Opera Company for the forthcoming season, Laszlo Halasz, the conductor, announced yesterday. Puccini's "Manon Lescaut" and Johann Strauss' "The Gypsy Baron" will be heard, besides five operas presented last season.
Mr. and Mrs. Frederick T. Frelinghuysen are at the Ritz-Carlton.

A syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. and Glore, Forgan Co., as joint managers, will offer today $10,000,000 of 3 per cent debentures and 50,000 shares of 4 1/4 per cent cumulative preferred stock of the Greyhound Corporation.

The four leading contenders for Ivy League supremacy will come to grips in two of the main attractions on the intercollegiate football program this week. Three local games are offered, with the return of New York University to the gridiron after an absence of two years.

Harry L. Hopkins, close friend and adviser of President Roosevelt and once a symbol of the Government-spending panacea in the President's intimate circle, called for repeal of the excess profits tax, re-establishment of the corporate income tax credit for dividend recipients and readjustment loans for small business in outlining yesterday a program for the post-war economy.

As all Americans know, there are newspapers and there are newspapers. In the United States we have many kinds of newspapers. But what we do not have is a Government press, newspapers that depend on official favors for existence.

Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic national chairman, conceded yesterday that the Democratic National Committee might have distributed some copies of a guide for campaign orators containing attacks on Col. John J. Bennett Jr., the 1942 Democratic candidate for Governor in New York, and on James A. Farley and Edward J. Flynn, two of Mr. Hannegan's predecessors as national chairman.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- Brushing aside suggestions that the $1,000,000 County Center beside the Bronx River Parkway here be maintained as an income-producing property now that cultural and recreational activities have been moved from it, the Westchester Board of Supervisors voted 32 to 5 this afternoon to return the operation of the building to the County Recreation Commission.

WITH THE BRITISH SECOND ARMY, North of Nijmegen, the Netherlands, Oct. 2 -- Bringing back reports of having destroyed or damaged seven German tanks, of having accounted for a considerable number of enemy casualties and of having held its ground in the face of furious enemy artillery and mortar fire, a seasoned British battalion relaxed today after having been in one of the hottest spots of the big German counter-attack now going on.

The temporary injunction against the W.T. Grant Company in the action brought by the Office of Price Administration charging violation of the highest price line limitation of the orginal MPR-330 was vacated yesterday in a decision handed down by Federal Judge D.J. Leibell in the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York.

While owners of the larger night clubs in midtown and Greenwich Village represented themselves as welcoming the drive of Mayor La Guardia, conducted through the Police Department, to root out gamblers and racketeers even though it might mean a delay in obtaining their own cabaret licenses, the Mayor yesterday took the unusual step of "calling on the carpet" two detectives who had testified in the Copacabana case.

The abundance of apples -- particularly of the "hurricane" variety -- supplies excellent reason for home-canning the fruit and also for serving it as often as possible. In addition to the familiar dishes such as apple pie and baked apples, you might try for the sake of variety an apple meringue pudding.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Gov. John W. Bricker, proposing a "thorough house cleaning" in Washington, asserted tonight that the Federal Government payroll had been expanded under the present Administration from 560,000 employes to "the staggering total of almost 3 1/2 million."

The Manumit School, a progressive co-educational school for children 7 to 15 years of age which has been operated for twenty years near Pawling, N.Y., has purchased the eighty-acre estate known as Brice House on the Hulmeville-Cornwall Heights Road, in Bensalem Township, Bucks County, Pa.

ALBANY, Oct. 2 -- Governor Dewey will deliver a nation-wide radio speech from the Executive Mansion tomorrow night on the subject of taxation, Paul E. Lockwood, secretary of the Governor, announced today. The broadcast will be over the Mutual network from 8:45 to 9 P.M., Eastern war time.
Twilight Tear returned to competition yesterday for the first time since her sensational string of victories was snapped last August, and raced right back into her winning ways.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- A thirty-page pamphlet, "Calling All Women," made public today by a new group, the Matriots Foundation, Inc., has for its purpose "changing the predominant masculine domination of civilization and government" in the interests of peace.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 2 -- Sidney Hillman, chairman of the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, challenged today Representative Martin Dies, chairman of the House Committee for Investigation of Un-American Activities, to bring him before the committee to answer charges of Communist domination of PAC and alleged illegal financing of the organization.

BOWLING GREEN, Ky., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Governor Bricker, Republican candidate for Vice President, declared today the Democrats' own nominee for Vice President had said the Roosevelt Administration was responsible for "inadequate over-all planning and delay in determining basic policies" of the war program.

The public school curriculums are being extensively revised to promote democratic practices in daily living, both in and out of school, it was announced yesterday by Superintendent of Schools John E. Wade, who reported the extension of the Board of Education's program to combat racial and religious prejudices among the city's children.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- A special program for the manufacture of low and popular priced maternity supports and maternity and nursing brassieres to alleviate an existing shortage was announced today by the War Production Board.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Twenty-nine full shares, three half shares and six cash awards were voted by the Browns in a club meeting today on the split-up of their world series pot. All the regular players, Manager Luke Sewell, Coaches Fred Hofmann and Zack Taylor, Trainer Bob Bauman and Secretary Charley DeWitt come for full shares.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Senator Taft of Ohio said tonight that President Roosevelt's whole effort is to divert attention from domestic problems "because he knows the people have turned against Washington bureaucracy, regulations, Government waste and the other trappings of a totalitarian State."

ROME, Oct. 2 -- A mysterious attempt was made last night to disinter the body of Pietro Caruso, executed police chief of Rome. The reason for this morbid attempt is not known because the ghouls eluded the watchmen who disturbed them.

Concerns soliciting business on British cotton materials are doing so at their own risk and will be unable to effect deliveries for many months after the war in Europe ends, M. Stanley Brown, United States representative of the Cotton Board of Manchester, England, asserted yesterday.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, Oct. 3 -- American infantry has bowled forward two miles into Germany in a new assault, forcing wedges into the Westwall in a small sector north of Aachen that was so saturated with bombs and shells in a preparatory bombardment yesterday that at least one German-held village vanished from the skyline.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Expanded industrialization of Mexico and certain South American countries is reported among the major projects to be put in the hands of Donald M. Nelson in his future role as Presidential emissary for "post-war economic cooperation with other nations."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- A story of how fists flew in the Statler Hotel after President Roosevelt made his opening campaign address to the Teamsters' Union was told today by a young Navy lieutenant.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 2 -- Three teams finished in a deadlock for first position at 69 in the amateur-pro event at the Huntington Crescent Club today. The annual metropolitan P.G.A. championship will open here tomorrow with eighteen holes and conclude with thirty-six holes on Wednesday.
MEMPHIS, Oct. 2 -- A large portion of the Mississippi delta's near-record cotton crop may go to waste this year because of the shortage of pickers, the Commercial Appeal reported today.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Roy Zimmerman, Newark first baseman, slammed a triple in the eleventh inning tonight, scoring Bill Rabe, who had singled, then came home himself on a fly to defeat the Baltimore Orioles, 7 -- 5, and give the Bears a 3-to-2 lead in the International League play-off finals before 18,723 fans.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 2 -- Local programs to provide better housing for Negro families were urged today by Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, at the conference here of the National Urban League.

Add to the list of films opening this week, "Music In Manhattan," a comedy with music produced by RKO, which will arrive at the Palace on Friday. Anne Shirley, Dennis Day and Phillip Terry head the film's cast, with Raymond Walburn, Jane Darwell and Charlie Barnet and Nilo Menendez and their bands in supporting roles.

WITH UNITED STATES THIRD ARMY, on the Moselle River, France, Oct. 2 (U.P.) -- Ghosts of men, a handful of infantry came out of their foxholes on Hill 386 today. They had made a three-week stand that is worthy of history.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 2 -- Retorting to Prime Minister Winston Churchill's statement to Parliament last week that China had received "lavish American help," a spokesman for the Chinese Military Council charged today that United States' aid to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's armies had been pitifully inadequate and described the strength of the United States Fourteenth Air Force in China as "so small it would hardly be credited if it could be disclosed."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Army Air Forces have lost more planes in the United States than on combat missions on all fronts, Gen. Henry H. Arnold, AAF commander, revealed today in announcing that as of Sept. 28 American airmen had dropped 1,000,000 tons of bombs on the enemy.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP) -- For the first time since he became baseball commissioner in 1920, Kenesaw Mountain Landis will miss a world series, at which his characteristic slouch on the third-base rail perennially had been the delight of photographers.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull reached the age of 73 yesterday with some unfinished business still ahead of him. He has to help liquidate a great war and organize a lasting peace. Success is in the laps of the gods. This much, however, Secretary Hull's countrymen may take for granted: he will undertake the work that remains to him in the spirit of unselfish devotion to his country's good.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 -- Pullman, Inc., yielding to an order of the Federal District Court here for a complete and perpetual divorcement of the company's railroad-car building from its sleeping-car business, filed today a plan offering the latter system to a proposed new company and certain individual railway lines for $81,325,222.

The rate at which the conversion of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's 3 per-cent debentures due in 1956 has progressed this year is reflected in the decrease in the total amount of this issue now outstanding. On Sept. 26, the listed debentures aggregated $169,043,000, a reduction of approximately $27,000,000 in three months.

Because Oct. 15, the announced deadline for mailing Christmas packages to men and women in the armed services overseas, falls on a Sunday and post offices will not be open that day, the Post-office Department made known yesterday that the final date for sending such parcels will be Oct. 14.

MOSCOW, Oct. 2 -- Protestant and other non-Orthodox groups in the Soviet Union have created associations to deal with the newly formed Soviet Council on Affairs of Religious Cults, according to its chairman, Ivan Vasilievich Polyansky.

France again belongs to the French. But the treasures of art which French civilization created or assembled belong to the world as well. So it is reassuring to learn from an Allied Supreme Headquarters Commission of Inquiry that some of the greatest of these treasures are intact and will soon be restored to the public.

A nation-wide effort to enlist the aid of industry and labor in the control of venereal diseases was started last night at the "Industry vs. VD" meeting of the American Social Hygiene Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The meeting was held in connection with the second wartime public health conference and the seventy-third annual business meeting of the American Public Health Association, which opens today.
HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 2 -- Barbara Hutton, Woolworth heiress, and Cary Grant, movie actor, announced today that they had become reconciled after a separation which began when he left their home in August.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 2 -- The "National Committee," headed by Fernand de Brinon, "accepted" the reins of what was claimed as the French Government yesterday in Sigmaringen, Germany, near the Swiss frontier, where Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain is said to be a prisoner, eyewitnesses reported today.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- Municipal elections to choose City Councils in Paris and other cities will be held fairly soon -- far in advance of the national election, which must await it he return of prisoners from Germany -- authorized quarters said tonight.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- With 550 guests registered for their dinner tonight, the New York State Division of the Daughters of the American Revolution opened its forty-ninth annual conference here today. Sessions will continue for three days.

The war has heightened public consciousness of the need and value of public health nursing, speakers declared at a meeting last evening of the New York City membership committee of the National Organization for Public Health Nursing at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 2 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California told a Republican rally at the Lyceum Theatre here tonight that the "corrupt" city political machines of a few large urban centers had rushed to the support of President Roosevelt's fourth-term bid either through hope of reward, or for "fear of consequences if Tom Dewey is elected."
Football's whys and wherefores got a thorough going-over yesterday when the Football Writers held their first meeting of the year at Toots Shot's with an overflow attendance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Bulgaria's reluctance to withdraw her troops from Greece and Yugoslavia was mentioned by Secretary of State Cordell Hull at his news conference today as one possible reason for delay of the Allies in concluding an armistice with Bulgaria.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 2 -- Murmurings of a return to prewar luxuries and an end to all sacrifice on the home front endanger the fighting spirit of American forces overseas, Brig. Gen. Robert L. Denig, director of public relations for the Marine Corps, told 200 New Jersey editors and publishers here tonight.

The action of the executive board of the American Academy of Pediatrics in advising withdrawal of support of the United States Children's Bureau and its emergency maternity and infant care program for families of service men was sharply criticized in a letter in the September issue of the Journal of Pediatrics, published yesterday.

As supplies of butter in New York City grew tighter and as Philadelphia consumers formed lines yesterday to buy butter even at twenty-point ration value, New York City food purveyors continued to offer oleomargarine at half retail price to push sales of this substitute.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Dr. Edward A. Rumely, who refused to give the House Campaign Expenditures Committee a record of contributions to the Committee For Constitutional Government, was indicted today under a law against "willful default" in production of subpoenaed documents.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Democratic nominee for Vice President, Senator Truman of Missouri, announced today dates on and places where he will speak in an intensive campaign that will take him to the Pacific Coast. He also made a nation-wide political broadcast tonight.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- Predetermination of a number of factors involved in final settlement of war contracts was offered today as a means of speeding up the book work involved in concluding war work. Courtney Johnson, assistant to the chairman of the board of the Studebaker Corporation, told of the plan to members of the accounting profession gathered at the thirteenth annual meeting of the Controllers Institute of America being held here.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Communique 177:

The Gulf Oil Corporation reported yesterday in its semi-annual statement covering operations for the six months ended with June, a net profit of $21,414,517 after all charges, including $7,896,051 income taxes and $2,500,000 reserve for contingencies, which includes an amount in respect of refunds which might result from renegotiation.

The Free Yugoslav radio said yesterday that the daughter of Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch, leader of Chetnik units in Yugoslavia, had run away from her father because she considered him a "traitor" and reported to the forces of Marshal Tito in Serbia.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 2 -- Perhaps no better example of how even a brief period of time can bring about a remarkable shifting of values in baseball can be found than the one that comes to light as at the moment we see the game's outstanding academic minds striving to ponder the relative merits of the Cardinals and Browns as these two St. Louis entries prepare for their forthcoming World Series clash.

THE law of diminishing returns is an insidious thing. It applies to a wide variety of fields, including authorship. Any author can write a mediocre book; no author, no matter how eminent, can maintain a consistent level of excellence. And if his books tread rapidly upon each other's heels, it is inevitable that a poor one soon will appear to lower the average level.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (U.P.) -- The German Government, hard pressed for foreign exchange, obtained $25,000,000 to $35,000,000 from the United States before Pearl Harbor through a secret agreement with five American banks for the sale of "blocked" German marks to Nazi sympathizers in this country, according to the Department of Justice.
LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Business generally was quiet in all sections of today's stock markets here.

ROME, Oct. 2 -- Thirty-nine of seventy-two requested marriage annulments were granted by the Tribunal of the Sacred Roman Rota during the juridical year just ended. Mgr. Giulio Grazioli, dean of the Rota, said in a report read to the Pope today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (U.P.) -- Senator Harold H. Burton, Ohio Republican, who, with Senator Joseph H. Ball, Minnesota Republican, and two Democrats, sponsored the B2H2 peace resolution, took issue tonight with Senator Ball's decision to refrain from campaigning for Governor Dewey "at this time."
I am among millions of people who tune to the radio occasionally to find some soothing music while relaxing with a book in the hand.
After opening 1 to 3 points lower, the market for cotton futures turned easier yesterday and closed at about the lows of the day and 10 to 15 points net lower on the New York Cotton Exchange.

DETROIT, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Jack Zeller, general manager of the Tigers, announced tonight that Steve O'Neill, who led the Bengals to within one game of the American League pennant, has signed a one-year contract, his third, to manage the club in 1945.

LONDON, Tuesday, Oct. 3 (U.P.) -- The Soviet offensive which had rolled across eight frontiers in the last four months apparently came to a temporary halt yesterday, with Moscow reporting no important changes along the 1,300-mile Eastern Front, although Yugoslav Partisans and Bulgarian troops scored gains in the battle of the Balkans.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Chungking in English to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Supreme Court met today preparatory to considering a docket of more than 500 cases. The short session was devoted almost entirely to admission of lawyers to practice.

WITH THE AMERICAN FIRST ARMY, In Germany, East of Heerlen, the Netherlands, Oct. 2 -- After a violent bombardment by scores of the heaviest guns and hundreds of medium bombers and fighter-bombers, a bombardment that shook the sodden earth for ten miles around, a strong force of American infantrymen rose from their foxholes and poured across the Wurm River into Germany to begin a new and inherently important assault on the Siegfried Line this morning.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Senator Truman tonight called for the reelection of President Roosevelt "to the biggest job in the world" because of his proved leadership and experience.

Concentration of this country's air transportation facilities in one company to represent the United States in the field of international airways after the war is essential if we are to compete successfully with the other nations, David E. Grant, foreign counsel for Pan American Airways, said yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Two underwriting groups, both headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., were the successful bidders yesterday for two new issues of public utility bonds, aggregating $61,500,000. The competition in both sales among several syndicates was unusually keen for issues of this size.

Getting ready for today's official opening of his campaign for re-election, Senator Robert F. Wagner challenged yesterday Thomas J. Curran, his Republican adversary, to make an issue of his voting record in the Senate.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 2 (U.P.) -- American marines and Army forces are engaged in mopping up a few "fanatical" enemy troops holding out on the Peleliu and Angaur Islands in the Palaus as they complete the campaign which has given them firm control over the southern Palaus and three potential airfields within bombing distance of the Philippines.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Royal Air Force Beaufighters destroyed five more German aircraft over Aegean Islands during the night, bringing total enemy losses to sixteen within the last six days, a Middle East air communique announced today.

LONDON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Germans were reported from Cairo today to have given up three islands off the southern tip of Greece in the face of British commando attacks, while other advices told of Allied forces driving into Greece from the northwest and of Partisans fighting in the vicinity of Athens.

The threat that the Association of Theatrical Agents and Managers, American Federation of Labor, would immediately take "oppropriate steps" against the Metropolitan Opera Association unless it hired a union press agent house manager and company manager, it was indicated yesterday, would be held temporarily in abeyance for at least five weeks.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- December wheat developed independent strength today on the Board of Trade as the result of heavy buying attributed to mills, presumably reflecting large sales of flour that followed an announcement over the week-end by the Defense Supplies Corporation that the subsidy on wheat for flour had been increased by 4 to 10 1/2 cents a bushel.

The Whitney Museum, 10 West Eighth Street, opened with a private view yesterday afternoon its exhibition of twenty-four oils and thirty water-colors by Winslow Homer. This was arranged in connection with Lloyd Goodrich's book on Homer, brought out for the Whitney Museum, of which Mr. Goodrich is research curator, by Macmillan.

Before a crowd of 31,880 persons, including many wounded service men, the Brooklyn Tigers, the renamed Flatbush entrant in the National Football League, made their home debut under the lights at Ebbets Field last night. The occasion was the Brooklyn Bond Bowl game -- $3,500,000 worth of bonds were sold -- and the opposition was supplied by a combination of All-Star service men.
LONDON, Tuesday, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Allies' chances of trapping an Axis force originally estimated at 200,000 men appeared lessened today.

ON CYTHERA ISLAND, Greece, Sept. 16 (Delayed) -- British Commandos started landing on this island, five and a half miles south of the Greek mainland, at 10 o'clock last night from ships of the Canadian and British navies and for four hours they streamed ashore in the first liberation of Greek territory since the Germans swarmed through the Balkans in the spring of 1941.

Banks in this city and throughout the nation began yesterday to cash in war bonds for properly identified citizens who presented them for redemption, in accordance with the plan recently announced by the Treasury. In this city comparatively few persons took advantage of the new service, a survey indicated, but some Midwestern communities reported heavy redemptions.

For the first time since 1938 the American Institute of Graphic Arts, 115 East Fortieth Street, will show in New York and later throughout the country an exhibition of fifty outstanding prints by American artists.

Third-quarter condition statements of many of the larger banks and trust companies, which made their appearance yesterday, while showing no uniformity in trend in all items, did reveal some marked changes from the June quarter in some of the principal items.

Adoption of the zoning plan amendments now before the City Planning Commission would handicap future construction, reduce the city's tax income and increase business costs here, without a corresponding benefit to the public interest, it was contended yesterday afternoon at a meeting under the auspices of the Citizens Zoning Committee at its headquarters, 233 Broadway.

ROME, Oct. 2 (U.P.) -- The Fifteenth Air Force made about 1,000 sorties yesterday, the greatest single day's effort in more than a week, and the majority of these flights were by light bombers and other tactical aircraft in support of ground troops.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- To make possible a revival of her export trade, Britain will shortly begin to restrict her orders under lend-lease to food, petroleum and munitions and at the same time revise her 1941 White Paper pledge in the agreement with the United States.
ALLIED HEADQUAETERS, New Guinea, Tuesday, Oct. 3 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- In a further move to simplify and expedite the industrial reconversion program, President Roosevelt by Executive order today transferred from the Secretaries of War and the Navy to the chairman of the War Production Board the authority to determine when each of an estimated $6,000,000,000 worth of privately owned war-production facilities was no longer necessary to the war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Census Bureau monthly reports on the production of the women's and children's clothing industry now are being supplied to Government agencies and soon will be regularly published.

Some time in the not too distant future -- it may be and ten years from now and it may be sooner -- there will be published a new novel which will score an enormous popular success. Naturally, this piece of fiction will be followed by a great many others from other hands dealing with the same theme and in the same temper.
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 2 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- When the time comes to redraw the map of Europe, Britain probably will advocate not only the allocation of German territory east of the Oder River to Poland but the conversion of the Rhineland into a demilitarized zone under international control.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, in the Southwest Pacific, Tuesday, Oct. 3 (U.P.) -- Allied bombers struck at Japanese airdromes and shipping at the Philippines and Celebes and Amboina Islands Saturday and Sunday, sinking or damaging ten enemy vessels, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

ST. LOUIS. Oct. 2 -- Mound City fandom, coming out of the stunning surprise which had engulfed it at the moment the twice incredible Browns surged forward to snatch their first American League pennant, settled down today with astonishing decorum to await the opening of baseball's first all-St. Louis world series.

A campaign described as second only to the war loan drive in scope will be launched Nov. 1 to reeducate consumers and grocers concerning the value of ceiling price lists in keeping down inflation, J. Sidney Johnson, director of trade relations of the Office of Price Administration, announced yesterday.

American Woolen Company, in opening its spring lines of women's fabrics for coats, suits and dresses yesterday, stated that all numbers are being produced in sixty-inch widths with the exception of two gabardines, which are made on men's wear looms, and a few suedes, which are still being offered in 56 and 58 inch widths.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Although official Polish circles here have refused to comment, there will be an answer in tomorrow's Polish Daily, which reflects the opinion of the Government-in-Exile here, to the attack by leaders of the Polish Committee of National Liberation against Lieut. Gen. Tadeusz Komorowski [General Bor] newly appointed Commander in Chief of the Polish armed forces.

UNITED STATES TWELFTH ARMY GROUP HEADQUARTERS, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley, field commander of American troops cracking down on Germany, pitched in today to help a youthful admirer back home get a new dog.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 3 (AP) -- A four-run homer by Stan Benjamin in the fifth, followed by another round-tripper off Howard Moss' bat, gave Red Embree enough margin tonight to pitch the Orioles to a 5-3 victory over Newark and tie the International League final play-off series at three games apiece before a crowd of 4,070.

In his special message to the Congress urging "immediate consideration" (on the day preceding a widely announced Congressional recess) of legislation proposing extensive development and control of the natural resources of the Missouri, Arkansas and Columbia River basins, the President "indicated" that the Governors of eight of the nine affected States in the Missouri River basin approved of this proposal.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Wednesday, Oct. 4 -- Sloshing through a chilly autumn drizzle, American First Army troops have sliced clear through concrete sections of the Siegfried Line north of Aachen into fields fortified only by tank ditches, newly dug earthen defenses and minefields, about forty miles from the great Rhineland arsenal of Cologne.

LONDON, Oct. 3 (U.P.) -- The Germans, threatened with entrapment by converging Red Army and Yugoslav Partisan drives toward their escape routes through Yugoslavia, have begun evacuating the Peloponnesus area of Greece and the island of Crete, dispatches from Cairo reported tonight.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Judge Gunnar H. Nordbye in Federal court here signed today an order granting a reorganization petition to the receiver for the Wisconsin Central Railway Company, which has been in receivership since Dec. 2, 1932.

Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for the Senate, accepting yesterday a challenge from his Democratic adversary, promised that in the remainder of the campaign he would devote his attention to Senator Robert F. Wagner's "legislative performances and lack of them."

ROME, Oct. 3 -- It was primarily Italy and to a lesser extent Germany that armed the French Cagoulards, I learned today. This is one of the minor discoveries made by the investigators of the assassination of the anti-Fascist Carlo Rosselli, in France in 1937.

ALBANY, Oct. 3 -- A State revenue surplus of $100,000,000 at the end of the fiscal year on March 31, 1945, was predicted today in a report by the Citizens Public Expenditure Survey, Inc., appearing in The State Taxpayer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Senator Truman, the Democratic nominee for Vice President, tonight declared that he favored a Constitutional amendment permitting a simple majority of both houses to ratify treaties. He added that he would vote to repeal the present requirements of a two-thirds Senate vote if "I ever get the chance."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 139:

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 3 -- British air troops made history by their epic stand at Arnhem were able to communicate with each other over Netherland pay telephones in the first few days, before the Germans learned their exact positions, it was disclosed today.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe issued yesterday a preliminary injunction sought by the Government to restrain the owners of an apartment and store building at 948 First Avenue from continuing remodeling operations in violation of regulations of the War Production Board.

Advertising plans for the Sixth War Loan Drive to begin Nov. 20 will be outlined to leading representatives of the advertising field by Treasury Department officials and members of the War Advertising Council at 2:30 tomorrow afternoon at The New York Times Hall.

NIJMEGEN, The Netherlands, Oct. 3 -- Faced with a large scale invasion of the Reich, German leaders have begun organizing their own underground resistance movement to help Germany's armed forces against the Allies, according to information obtained here today.

OF all the world's star-crossed lovers Romeo and Juliet had fewer troubles to contend with than most. What was a mere family feud and a certain amount of bloodletting compared to the gulf that has separated thousands of others? Romeo and Juliet were alike in nationality, religion, social class and even in being natives of the same small city.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Jackie Cooper, who became a Navy V-12 trainee at the University of Notre Dame soon after starring in a morals picture, "Where Are Your Children?" was acquitted today of contributing to the delinquency of two young South Bend girls.

Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic National Chairman, asserted yesterday in an interview at Democratic headquarters that Governor Dewey had already alienated the independent vote in this year's Presidential election by his "failure to explain or repudiate the record of his own party in the months and years prior to our entry into the war."

Morris Marcus, builder and operator, has purchased the six-story orty-eight-family apartment house at 55 Nagle Avenue from Jerry Dietz, who built the house five years ago on a plot 100 by 100 feet. Sale was subject to a mortgage of $129,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Representative Anderson of New Mexico, its chairman, reported to the House Campaign Expenditures Committee today that thirteen Republicans had mailed 3,116,000 copies of a speech at Government expense.

Net income of the Aviation Corporation for the nine months ended with August amounted to $3,199,871 after all charges, including Federal taxes, the report disclosed yesterday. The income is equal to 55 cents a share on 5,793,513 shares of capital stock and compares with $2,810,486 or 49 cents a share for the corresponding period of the previous year.
ROME, Oct. 3 (UP) -- A communique:

Declaring the City Planning Commission's proposed zoning changes would be entirely inadequate to control post-war building in the city, Edgar J. Nathan Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, urged the commission yesterday to grant a public hearing on an alternative zoning change plan offered by Irving V.A. Huie, Commissioner of Public Works and a member of the planning commission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting members in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 27, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Decreases of $129,000,000 in holding of United States Government obligations, $87,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted and $129,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

Increased need for nurses by the Army and Navy, veterans administration, public and industrial health services will result in a national shortage of 129,000 registered professional nurses by July 1, 1946, the National Nursing Council for War Service, 1790 Broadway, estimated yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- War spending of the Government fell below $7,000,000,000 in September for the first month since December.

Stockholders of All American Aviation, Inc., at their annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., elected the following directors: Halsey R. Bazley, Charles F. Benzel, W. Sam Carpenter 3d, Frank M. Donohue, Mrs. Richard C. du Pont and Charles W. Wendt of Wilmington, and Arthur P. Davis, George S. Leisure and David Rawson of this city.

The third volume in "The Story of Civilization" series by Will Durant will be released by Simon Schuster on Oct. 23. Having written of the East in "Our Oriental Heritage," which appeared in 1935, and of Greek civilization in "The Life of Greece," published in 1939, Mr. Durant now turns to Roman civilization.

In a recent radio forum on the subject "What to do with Germany after the war" several authoritative persons argued to the effect that Germany must not be destroyed or partitioned, that the destruction of German heavy industry would create an economic wasteland in the middle of Europe, with resultant unemployment of millions of Germans and a situation ripe for a future Hitler and World War III.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast by the Hungarian MTI Agency to the Hungarian press and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Communique 178:

The National City Bank of New York and the Bank of the Manhattan Company added their names yesterday to the long list of banks and trust companies that have issued this week condition statements as of the end of the third quarter.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 3 -- Rita Hayworth has been named for the starring role in "Lola and the Wolves," a comedy to be produced at Columbia by Sam Bischoff. The picture is to be based on an unproduced play by Hardie Albright and Eddie Emmerson, for which the company paid a reported $20,000.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3 -- It will be Mort Cooper, seasoned campaigner of many a crucial diamond struggle, against Dennis Galehouse, 32-year-old right-hander who has never seen a world series, let alone played in one, as the curtain rises tomorrow on the intracity classic between the mighty Cardinals, champions of the National League for the past three seasons, and the doughty underdog Browns, who have snared their first pennant in American League history.

WITH FIRST UNITED STATES ARMY, Near Uebach, Germany, Oct. 3 -- Uebach, a neat group of houses surmounted by thin steeples now black against the gray evening sky, has been stormed by American infantry. This whole sector of the offensive in the Rimburg-Palenberg area is grinding steadily forward, and what is officially described as a "definite break-through" of the Siegfried Line has been made around Uebach.

ROME, Oct. 3 (AP) -- American troops, slogging along in deep mud in their main drive through the northern Apennines, have captured Monghidor, an important road junction eighteen miles south of Bologna, Allied Headquarters announced today.

Women were characterized as the nation's "greatest purchasing agents" by James S. Adams, chairman of the sixty-sixth annual United Hospital campaign, at the fund's first women's division report meeting yesterday at the Hotel Pierre.
ALBANY, Oct. 3 -- Governor Dewey sharply criticized the tax policies of the Roosevelt Administration tonight and proposed a six-point program to reduce and simplify taxes in the post-war period.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 -- More than fifty representatives of the nation's largest financial organizations met here today with members of the Securities and Exchange Commission and adopted a program designed to protect post-war investors and principally the holders of $21,000,000,000 of Series E Government bonds against the loss of their savings through fraud.

Plans for a twelve-story apartment house at 4 East Eighty-ninth Street to cost $500,000 were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings by Eggers Higgins, architects, for the owner, the City Investing Company of 30 Broad Street.

At special meetings on Oct. 19, stockholders of both concerns involved will vote on a plan of merger and recapitalization for the obsorption of Sanford Mills into the Goodall Worsted Company, whose name then will be changed to Goodall-Sanford, Inc.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast by the Free Yugoslav Radio in Serbo-Croat and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
Volume of business and range of prices shrunk yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and final prices were 6 points higher to 2 points lower than on Monday.

It is a legitimate deduction that plans to carry out the decisions of the Quebec Conference were the principal business of the meeting in San Francisco of the United States Navy top command in the Pacific, from whose ranks was missing only Admiral Halsey. He was too busy fighting to attend.

LYON, Oct. 3 -- The moment the French coast came into view a French officer in the courier plane from Italy dropped to his knees on a mailsack and pressed his face against a little window. "France," he cried in a tremolo of excitement that heightened the emotion we all felt at seeing France again.

As a dozen persons watched in horror, Mrs. Carol Westcott, 26-year-old mother of two children, plunged to her death yesterday morning from the window of her seventh floor apartment at 149 East Fifty-fifth Street. Police, rushing through the building to her apartment, arrived too late.

Swayed between domesticity and a career, how can a woman pick up the threads of married life when her husband is invalided home from the war after several years of fighting? Rose Franken points the way in her comedy, "Soldier's Wife," which has its premiere tonight at the Golden.
LONDON, Oct. 3 (U.P.) -- The stork was taking a beating tonight in the battle of "the baby leave committee."

Declaring that the three overwhelming aims of the American people are victory as quickly as possible, a permanent and just peace and lasting prosperity for all the people, Senator Robert F. Wagner opened his campaign for re-election last night by asserting that "Thomas E. Dewey is not a big enough man to lead us toward these three aims in the critical times ahead."

While retail prices on slow-moving brands of rums, cane gins and whiskies in package stores have been cut to below cost in some instances, trade spokesmen yesterday declared there is little likelihood that a price war will develop as the public is making only nominal purchases of the lines.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Testimony indicating that Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota issued a letter of introduction warmly commending a man who is now accused of seditionist activities highlighted the appearance today before the House Campaign Expenditures Committee of Gerald L.K. Smith of Detroit, Presidential nominee of the America First party, to explain his failure to report campaign receipts and expenditures as required by law.

The City Vacancy Bureau proved its worth yesterday for a nearly blinded veteran of the South Pacific campaigns and found a three-room apartment for him adjacent to the Veterans Administration Hospital in the Bronx, where he is undergoing treatment.

A new wrinkle -- or a new fold -- in diapers was demonstrated yesterday with the aid of two babies, one smiling and one squalling, in a suite at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Thomas J. Skillman Jr. of Philadelphia, president of the National Institute of Diaper Services, which will hold its seventh annual convention this week at the hotel, showed the new method of folding a diaper and pinned it on the chortling baby.

With a thousand persons crowding their place of worship, the "Franciscan Fathers of Thirty-first Street" opened last night a five-day celebration for the 100th anniversary of their Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis of Assisi with the transitus ceremony, commemorating the saint's death and entrance into heaven, and solemn benediction.

Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, was elected chairman of the clearing house committee of the New York Clearing House Association at the annual meeting here yesterday. He succeeds Leon Fraser, president of the First National Bank.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Eighty-two of the 141 members of the National Citizens Political Action Committee had "voluntarily cooperated" with twenty-five organizations named by Attorney General Biddle in 1942 as "Communist fronts," J.B. Matthews testified today before a subcommittee of the Dies Committee.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 3 -- Aid for returned Negro Veterans was the principal plank in the platform of the National Urban League expressed in resolutions adopted at the closing session today. Equal help also is urged for the white veterans.
LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Although the tone of today's stock markets remained steady, business was very restricted and price changes were few.

MOSCOW, Oct. 3 -- Roman Catholics have the same rights as other religious groups in the Soviet Union and are permitted communication with the Vatican so long as it deals with purely church problems. This statement was made to the Religious News Service by Ivan Vasilievitch Poliansky, chairman of the newly established Soviet Council on Affairs of Religious Cults, which has jurisdiction in matters pertaining to non-orthodox churches in the Soviet Union.

The nations of the world must face the international problem of disease "not as isolated groups behind boundary lines, but as members of the human race projected suddenly into a frightening propinquity," Raymond B. Fosdick, president of the Rockefeller Foundation, said last night at the opening general session of the wartime conference and annual meeting of the American Public Health Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Asserting that "relaxation" orders which have already been issued by the War Production Board over the use of magnesium "have not meant what they seemed to mean," Dr. Willard H. Dow, president of the Dow Chemical Company of Midland, Mich., disclosed yesterday that "shortly all the magnesium controls will be removed."

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3 -- If you remember the story of Cinderella, her exquisite raiment turned back into shabby garments and her coach into a pumpkin at the stroke of midnight. The Brownies are the Cinderella team of baseball as they await the start of the world series at Sportsman's Park tomorrow. Puzzled fans and even more bewildered experts are wondering just when midnight will strike -- or if it will.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- Asserting that 32,500 fatal accidents in homes during 1943 represented an increase of 7 per cent over 1942, and warning that "more women are exposed to the hazards of life outside the home today than ever before," Margaret Culkin Banning, author, of Duluth, Minn., today appealed to the women of the country to re-establish "the conviction that life is valuable, that accidents are wickedly wasteful."

With the first real cold snap of the fall season yesterday came a flood of complaints over the failure of landlords to provide heat both for homes and business places. Altogether 279 complaints were registered in telephone calls and visits to the Department of Health.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Oliver Farm Equipment Company approved today acquisition by Oliver of the Cleveland Tractor Company and co-related financial proposals, as well as a change in the name to the Oliver Corporation.

Recent discussions of "utility" beef have brought to the attention of some consumers for the first time the fact that the Government grades meats according to quality. A similar system is used with certain other foods, and since the more householders know of such things, the better able they are to buy, a brief report follows of the standards and practices in effect.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- When the tide was high this afternoon a strong force of Royal Air Force Lancasters dropped their devastating 12,000-pound "earthquake" bombs on the dikes of Westkapelle on the German-held Netherland island of Walcheren, which controls the Schelde estuary to Antwerp, and in one great blow virtually neutralized this vital point.

Bedeviled by the gnashing shears of the censor during its try-out days in New Haven and Boston, "Men to the Sea" arrived at the National last evening presumably in its pure, or original, form. Regardless of Back Bay disputes over art, it seemed that the censor may have been overlooking the wood for the trees.

The dream pup that 13-year-old William (Bill) Traphagen Jr. wrote about to dog-loving Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley became a reality yesterday when the Cedar Grove, N.J., boy picked out a cocker spaniel at a pet shop here.

J. Louis Reynolds, chairman of the executive committee of Business Men for Roosevelt, declared here yesterday that the principal objective of his organization was to combat what he termed the highly successful whispering campaign carried on during the past four years against the Roosevelt Administration.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3 (AP) -- First and friskiest Cardinal to poke his head out of the Redbird dugout at today's workout was John (Pepper) Martin, 40-year-old "rookie," raring to go in his fifth world series.

After being leased to the Navy Department for use as a war factory and now returned to Westchester control, the $1,000,000 County Center beside the Bronx River Parkway in White Plains is being restored to cultural and recreational uses despite attempts by some residents to seize the opportunity for its conversion into an income-producing enterprise -- perhaps even a central produce market.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Oct. 3 -- The Pan American Airways local office outlined today a post-war plan to carry 40,000 passengers annually to the colony. The project is soon to be presented to the Civil Aeronautics Board.

Morris Reif, 147, Brownsville, added to his string of knockout victims Pat Giordano, 147, Toronto, in the main bout scheduled for eight rounds at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. A turnaway crowd of 4.100 persons, who paid $5,750, saw Reif stop the Canadian in 0:59 of the second round.

Victim of an unidentified hold-up man who snatched her bag on West End Avenue near Ninety-third Street, at 1:30 A.M. yesterday, Mrs. Dorothy Graham, 76 years old, of 200 West Ninetieth Street died at 9:30 A.M. at Knickerbocker Hospital.

Whether the uprising which began in Warsaw a little over nine weeks ago was or was not wise is now a question for the historians. Whether or not the lives of those who died were sacrificed to no strategic purpose: whether or not more aid could have been given by the Russians or by American shuttle fliers using Russian bases -- these also are questions to be examined in a future tranquillity.

Alex Rose, chairman of the administrative committee of the Liberal party, announced yesterday that Justice George Frankenthaler and the three other Liberal party candidates for the Supreme Court had received the endorsement of the Central Trades and Labor Council.

Trigger, trained Palomino horse featured at the nineteenth annual world's championship rodeo opening tonight in Madison Square Garden, was guest of honor yesterday at a cocktail party in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Astor, Broadway and Forty-fourth Street.

Conscious that American youth no longer looks to finance as a career and that the brokerage business has not been getting the kind of new blood that it wants since the slump of the early Thirties, the Association of Stock Exchange Firms has drawn up a program of education, designed especially for returning service men, Wymond Cabell of Richmond, Va., president of the body, announced yesterday.

BOSTON, Oct. 3 -- Led by the Governors of New England States, public authorities and industrial leaders lined up tonight against a Senate committee's plan to freeze reconversion in eleven Northeastern States to permit the West and South to expand their post-war industry.

In your issue of Sept. 28 you quote President Butler of Columbia University as saying in his speech of welcome to new students that progressive education is a "reactionary philosophy" and a "preposterous doctrine" which would place the child "back in the Garden of Eden to begin all over again the life of civilized man."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The Allies are entering Germany with military marks printed in this country and having a value, for Army bookkeeping purposes only, of 10 cents, the War and Treasury Departments announced today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, in the Southwest Pacific, Wednesday Oct. 4 -- Heavy American bombers, flying one of the longest missions ever carried out in this area, on Sept 30 made a large-scale assault on Balik Papan, vital fuel center of Netherland Borneo, General Douglas MacArthur's communique announced today.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 11.7 per cent in September, bringing volume for that month to a new high record, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

If the American and British publics are really to be save from complacency about the end of the war with Germany and a let-down in the war effort, something will have to be done about Field Marshal Sir Bernard L. Montgomery.

Four lengths, at the end of a long mile and a half, was the margin by which the Longchamps Farms' Donitas First won the $16,350 Ladies Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park, where 16,074 watched the races on a bright but chilly afternoon.
LONDON, Oct. 3 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 3 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 3 -- At least sixty persons were killed, several hundred were wounded and hundreds were arrested in Vienna during rioting that broke out in the city and spread to other parts of the country after a nation-wide announcement curtailing food rations roughly 10 per cent, reliable reports from neutral sources said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- President Roosevelt signed the recently enacted industrial reconversion and surplus war property disposal bills today, but with reservations and a request for further Congressional action to supplement both measures.

LONDON, Wednesday, Oct. 4 -- Russian troops, launching a three-way offensive to seize Belgrade, drove into Yugoslavia yesterday in two new invasion thrusts that outflanked the capital thirty-eight miles to the north and brought them within twenty-seven miles of the last railroad escape route for more than 100,000 German troops in the southern Balkans.

Responsibility for the welfare of thousands of city girls rests with the Young Women's Christian Association of New York, Mrs. Cleveland E. Dodge said yesterday at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel opening the group's campaign for $275,000 to meet the budget for work in 1945. More than 700 were present, including campaign workers, whose goal will be $25,000 higher than that of last year.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 -- A decrease of 250 per cent since January in the rate of discharges from Army hospitals because of physical disability was reported to night to the United States Chapter of the International College of Surgeons by Colonel Augustus Thorndike, director of the Surgeon General's reconditioning program.

Helen Keller, who has been deaf and blind for all but the first few months of her sixty-four years, yesterday called upon Congress to "revise the Social Security Act so that it may minister generously to the hardest pressed and the least cared for among my blind fellows."

Perhaps the war has had something to do with it, but the fact remains that time was getting short. It would hardly seem an authentic season unless a report came along. There was an unconfirmed rumor that a panther has made its appearance in a Northeastern State.

An attempt was made yesterday to learn whether fishing has settled down to normal after the hiatus caused by the hurricane. The answer was "yes and no," depending on the experiences over the week-end of those questioned.

The Brooklyn Savings Bank has sold the two-story business building containing ten stores and two lofts at 834-48 Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn, to the E-N-U Realty Corporation of New York City. The deal was closed for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $95,000 running for ten years.

"Portrait of America," it is called -- the new exhibition that opens to the public today at the Metropolitan Museum. Although the "portrait" may for some of us prove unrecognizable, and might therefore be dismissed with a briefish note, 3.216 American artists and 5,000 paintings are directly or indirectly involved in this matter, so the details concerning it should, after all, be set down.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Because of absenteeism among younger miners, coupled with exhaustion of the older ones, the output of British coal has dropped 100,000 tons a week, and Britain's fuel position during the coming winter will be no better than last winter.

New York University is back in football, not as a major power, which it once was, nor as a minor one competing with majors, which it tried to do with disastrous results, but on a modest scale more becoming to a Violet.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Chinese delegates to the talks on international security in progress at Dumbarton Oaks were received at the White House today and after a twenty-minute conversation with President Roosevelt expressed themselves as gratified with prospects for a new security system.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Production of long-range super-bomber types of combat aircraft in September was "the greatest yet in a single month," the War Production Board announced today. Although the month's output was slightly under schedule, officials of the war agency said that the total was 98 per cent of the mark aimed at and represented a "fine showing."
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Two square blocks of vacant land in the rear of the Concourse Plaza Hotel in the Bronx have been purchased by Joseph L. Ennis Co., Inc., operators, from the New York State Realty and Terminal Company, subsidiary of the New York Central Railroad.

General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein paroled James Blackwell, 29 years old, a Negro driver, of 2452 Eighth Avenue, from the Tombs yesterday and placed him in the custody of his lawyer, Mrs. Sara Pelham Speaks, to attend the funeral of his brother, Roger, 31, who last Wednesday was fatally shot when trying to escape from a detective after his arrest on a recent robbery and rape charge.

September's arrivals totaled 4,129, compared with 4,406 for the same month last year, a decrease of 6.2 per cent. Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,209, against 1,089 last week and 695 for the like period a year ago, according to the listing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

ROME, Oct. 3 -- Rome received today a report of mare German atrocities that followed the killing of nine Germans near Rosi in Tuscany by Partisans. Nazis rushed to Rosi, but all the villagers had fled so they butchered the residents of Santa Anna.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 3 -- Frank Strazza of Round Hill took a one-stroke lead in the annual Metropolitan P.G.A. championship with a 37, 35 -- 72 on the Huntington Crescent Club links today. A field of twenty-three competed.

Eastern Air Lines announced yesterday that part of the $25,000,000 it will spend for the expansion of its "Great Silver Fleet" will go into Curtiss Commandos. The rest of the purchase will go to Douglas in orders for DC-4s, the four-engine plane bought in large numbers by other airlines for post-war delivery.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- Mills, cash interests and the Northwest were aggressive buyers of December wheat today on the Board of Trade, and the price moved up 38 cent a bushel to a new high since May 11 and closed at the top, showing 18 cents above the low of less than a month ago.

ROME, Oct. 3 -- How Jacob Stalin, son of Premier Joseph Stalin, remained impervious to all the arguments of Reich Marshal Hermann Goering in a two-hour conversation after his capture three years ago was learned here today.
The ultimate participation of the British fleet in major operations in the Central Pacific against Japan apparently was one of the few final decisions reached at the Quebec conference.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 3 -- What appeared for several weeks as the positive prospect that Governor Dewey would win Minnesota's eleven electoral votes on Nov. 7 has turned in the last few days into a matter of real doubt in the minds of many political observers here, some of whom now see an uphill fight for the Republican nominee to prevent a "repeat" by President Roosevelt.

The Football Giants, a squad comprising twenty-nine well-conditioned men, worked out at their home field, the Polo Grounds, for the first time this season yesterday. Coach Steve Owen put his charges through a two and one-half hour workout, the opener of a series of intensive drills for the Giants' National League opener Sunday at Boston against the Yankees.

RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Two rival units of the University of North Carolina stood ready today to bid higher than ever before for high-powered coaching talent in preparation for whatever football wars may come.

Fifteen local public housing authorities yesterday announced that they would offer for sale on Oct. 11, short-term notes in the aggregate amount of $34,218,000. All the obligations will be dated Nov. 1, 1944.

The drive of the American First Army into the German Westwall north of Aachen has scored a major success. Despite strong German resistance American tank and infantry units have broken through the belt of concrete forts that constitutes the first hard crust of the so-called Siegfried Line, knocking out some forty of these forts and capturing several German towns, including Uebach.

Alfred Emanuel Smith, four times Governor of this State, who rose from the sidewalks of New York to eminence in public life and in the hearts of many Americans, died early today at the age of 70 in Rockefeller Institute Hospital.

Obtaining personnel to handle heavy Christmas retail trade, which is expected to develop early, was described yesterday as "the immediate and pressing problem" of merchants at the conclusion of the New York regional conference of the store management and personnel groups at the Hotel Commodore.

The 11,000,000 men in our armed forces who are now learning to eat a well-balanced diet will have a tremendous influence on our eating habits in a decade or so when they become the heads of families of 40,000,000 to 50,000,000 persons, the American Public Health Association, holding its annual conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania, was told yesterday by Lieut. Comdr. C.M. McCay of the Naval Medical Research Institute, Bethesda, Md.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 -- The Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and its intermediate holding company, the Buffalo Niagara and Eastern Power Company, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission separate but similar plans providing for the reorganization of Buffalo Niagara and its western New York subsidiaries into a new electric operating company and for the reclassification of its four classes of stock into two new classes.

The editorial in THE TIMES of Oct. 1, together with the powerful letter from William Church Osborn on the same page, will help to create a public opinion in favor of world cooperation to insure justice and prevent war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- President Roosevelt, stressing by implication the explosive nature of the Russo-Polish situation, flatly declined today to talk about the end of Polish resistance to the Germans inside Warsaw.

As the butter supply in New York City gets tighter and independent food retailers estimate that 60 per cent of their number are without supplies, the New York State Food Merchants Association announced yesterday that its 3,000 members had begun a survey to determine whether supplies were being diverted from this State.

The Waltham Watch Company has leased a large suite of offices in Radio Center at 610 Fifth Avenue for an executive and sales department in preparation for its post-war planning. The company, which has factories in Waltham, Mass., was established in 1849.

Because the first Tuesday of this month comes before the first Thursday, it befell that it was the Philadelphia Orchestra under Eugene Ormandy instead of the Philharmonic-Symphony under Artur Rodzinski which gave the first symphony concert of the winter season last night in Carnegie Hall.

The 2,200-ton super-destroyer Evans, named in honor of the late Brig. Gen. Frank E. Evans of the Marine Corps, was launched at high water yesterday at the Bethlehem Steel and Shipbuilding Company yard at Mariners Harbor in the presence of high-ranking naval officers, seventy-five invited guests and 500 shipyard workers.

"Gypsy Wildcat," which arrives at Loew's Criterion, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Produced by Universal and filmed in Technicolor, the picture stars Maria Montez, Jon Hall and Peter Coe. Nigel Bruce, Leo Carrillo, Gale Sondergaard and Curt Bois are among the supporting players.

Freight car loadings of the twenty-eight principal commodities in the fourth quarter of this year will approximate 9,531,701 cars, according to estimates just compiled by the thirteen Shippers Advisory Boards. This would be an increase of 0.9 per cent over the actual loadings of 9,442,744 cars in the final quarter of 1943.

The stock market operated yesterday over its previously established line, with the bulk of the trading centered in specialties and prices mixed at the close. Activity shifted between various groups during the session, and while a few issues managed to score major gains, alterations were generally confined to fractions.

LONDON, Oct. 3 (UP) -- Every Spanish ship outward bound from Europe in recent weeks has been compelled to submit to search by British warships to satisfy Allied authorities that no Nazi leaders or other Germans were aboard trying to flee to a neutral sanctuary, it was disclosed in the House of Commons today by the Ministry of Economic Warfare.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS. New Guinea, Wednesday, Oct. 4 (UP) -- A communique:

M.J. Markowitz has been named vice president of Alexander's Department Stores, Inc. He has been publicity director for more than ten years and will continue in this capacity in addition to his new duties.

KWEILIN, China, Oct. 1 (Delayed) (AP) -- Chinese commanders preparing the defenses of this strategic Kwangsi Province city, once the gayest in free China, spoke confidently today of Kweilin as China's Stalingrad. American observers expect the defense of the city to equal at least that of Hengyang, which held out for forty-nine days.

ALBANY, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Further streamlining of New York's income tax blanks will combine simplicity with a saving of more than twenty-five tons of paper, Rollin E. Brown, president of the State Tax Commission, said today.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- The problem created by the refusal of United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration help by the Yugoslav Committee of National Libera tion unless the committee rather than the UNRRA is allowed to distribute the relief supplies in the country will apparently be resolved.

The $100,000,000 issue of debentures of the American Tobacco Company is expected to go into registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission in time to become effective for public offering this month. In all probability the debentures will mature in twenty-five years and have the benefit of a sinking fund designed to retire most, if not all, of them by maturity.
