LAKEHURST, N.J., Oct. 3 -- Parachutists, blimp pilots and officers of the Navy's Air Rescue School here today assessed the results of yesterday's demonstration of life saving at sea off Manasquan Inlet with grim satisfaction. "The Navy," they said, "takes care of its own."

"We cannot build a curriculum for sex education; what we call 'sex education' has to be worked out in terms of total life experience," Dr. Lawson G. Lowrey told an audience of parents, teachers and professional workers yesterday at the headquarters of the Child Study Association of America, Inc., at 221 West Fifty-seventh Street.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 3 -- Rhode Island, Democratic in national elections since 1928, seems certain to give its four electoral votes to President Roosevelt again this year. Leaders of the Republican organization do not concede this. They believe that there is a fair but not an even chance that Governor Dewey, Republican nominee for President, will carry the State.

A syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will offer to the public today a new issue of $30,000,000 of Arkansas Power and Light Company first mortgage 3 1/8 per cent bonds, due in 1974, at 104 and accrued interest. The bonds were awarded to the Halsey, Stuart group at competitive sale on Monday.

Inning-by-inning scores will be included in the time announcements made every fifteen seconds from the New York Telephone Company's time bureau, MEridian 7-1212, during the world series games that start today in St. Louis. At the conclusion of the time announcements the operator will say, for example, "End of first inning, Cardinals 3, Browns 3."
LONDON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The six Allied armies in western Europe had captured at least 526,084 German prisoners by tonight.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Reversing its previous stand on horse racing in wartime, the Los Angeles Citizens War Manpower Commission today removed the barriers to Hollywood Park in Inglewood conducting a fall meeting.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The President's announcement today that former Justice James F. Byrnes will retire soon after Congress reconvenes, Nov. 14, from direction of the post-war reconversion agency which was established when Mr. Roosevelt signed the legislation was taken to mean that Mr. Byrnes intends at that time to resume private life.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The steel products industry will have 185,000 more tons of steel available in this quarter than in the preceding period, the War Production Board estimated today. Estimates of the quantity of steel to be made available in the current quarter fixed a total of 16,085,000 tons compared with 15,900,000 in the previous quarter.
ROME, Oct. 3 -- The Germans are dismantling the industrial equipment of northern Italy and shipping it to the Reich, the Italian Resistance Front communique said today.

The American Insurance Company of Newark has sold the large residential property at 35 Afterglow Way, Montclair, N.J., to Reginald Porter, associated with Titeflex, Inc., of Newark. The main building contains seventeen rooms and six baths. The grounds comprise more than three acres.

CENTRALIA, Ill., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Gov. John W. Bricker, Republican Vice Presidential candidate, said tonight that even with increased tax income the Federal Government has spent more than it collected. He declared that "continuation of deficit financing" would mean "an end to representative government and free enterprise in America."
Chester A. Alberts of C.A. Alberts Co. has become a member of the New York Security Dealers Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Gen. H.H. Arnold of the Army Air Forces announced today that Women's Air Force Service pilots would he inactivated on Dec. 20, in time for them to be home by Christmas, unless air combat losses in Germany should rise unexpectedly.

Protests against provisions of direction 1 to the War Production Board conservation order, M-379, will be made by the work clothing industry advisory committee at a meeting in Washington today with WPB officials, it was reported in the industry yesterday.
PARIS, Oct. 3 -- The first elections in France since 1936 will begin in February, for municipal and departmental councils, the Government decided tonight.

Fragments of a German robot bomb, reassembled and shipped front England, were put on exhibit in Time Square yesterday under the sponsorship of the New York War Fund. The display will remain there for the duration of the war fund's drive for $17,200,000 toward support of the United Service Organizations and thirty other local and national agencies and foreign relief groups.
LONDON, Oct. 3 -- After sixty-three days of bitter resistance, the patriots of Warsaw have been forced to surrender and the Germans again are in control of the shattered Polish capital.

Governor Smith was a born leader. His gifts of personality, his wit, humor, high spirits and instinct for friendship counted for much, but his mental and moral qualities were the chief factors of his success. He was sincere, truthful, honest and generous. He never made a promise that he did not keep.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 3 -- Meeting here to receive reports of the activities of the International Ladies Garment Workers campaign committee for the re-election of President Roosevelt, the general executive board of the ILGWU, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, with a membership of 310,000, issued today a statement declaring that a fourth term for the President was necessary "for a continuance of progressive government and for our objective of full employment."

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler is to be congratulated on his courageous speech which you reported recently. It is very true that family discipline has become entirely too lax and that boys and girls in their teens should be taught the foundations of discipline.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 3 -- Imperial headquarters in Tokyo announced today in a broadcast communique that Japanese troops were driving on Foochow, last big seaport in Chinese hands, after a "surprise landing" in Fukien Province.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- President Roosevelt today defended the aid the United States is giving China against an assertion made yesterday by a spokesman for the Chinese Military Council at Chungking that instead of being "lavish," as Prime Minister Churchill told Parliament last week, it was "pitifully inadequate."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Rural children receive an inadequate education, are taught by poorly prepared instructors, and attend school in tumbledown, badly equipped buildings, educators attending the White House Conference on Rural Education charged today.

This season's weekly fashion luncheons at the Ritz-Carlton got under way yesterday with Walter Florell showing his winter millinery collection. The hats were brilliant in color. Taking cognizance of women's desire to wear real creations again, he made "more" hats.

Owing to the continued shortage of newsprint, total advertising in all New York daily newspapers during September, amounting to 8,127,630 lines, showed a loss of 14.81 per cent under the corresponding month last year. Classified advertising, with a total of 1,020,325 lines, was down 38.64 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- A total of 11,000 members of the Army Air Forces has been killed in 5,600 fatal flying accidents in the continental United States since Pearl Harbor, the War Department disclosed today.

Mayor La Guardia will plead his case against rent-gouging landlords before the Joint State Legislative Committee Investigating Commercial Rents and will head the list of witnesses to appear at the opening of the committee's hearings today in the Bar Association Building at 42 West Forty-fourth Street, it became known last night.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- Apparently anticipating further serious incursions onto German soil, Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels and Heinrich Himmler, chief of all Nazi police, today called upon guerrillas to continue their struggle behind Allied lines.

ROME, Oct. 4 -- The Polish tragedy is the consequence of the old hostility of the Polish ruling class, composed of colonels and landowners, toward the Russians' socialistic principles, the Socialist paper Avanti said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 -- Thirty employes of the Philadelphia Transportation Company were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of violating the Smith-Connally Anti-Strike Act in connection with the six-day transportation tieup in August.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The text of President Roosevelt's address to the White House Conference on Rural Education was as follows:
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Eighty-two-year-old Connie Mack, picking the Browns to win the series, insisted today American League loyalty hadn't influenced his judgment.

As millions of Americans mourned his passing, arrangements were completed yesterday to have the body of Alfred Emanuel Smith lie in state tomorrow evening and night in St. Patrick's Cathedral, where a solemn pontifical mass of requiem will be offered for him at 11 A.M. Saturday.

Herbert B. Lewis has joined the Lukens Steel Company, Coatesville, Pa., and its divisions, By-Products Steel Corporation and Lukenweld, Inc., as machinery division manager, it was announced yesterday.

The New York Life Insurance Company has sold the eight-room house on approximately half an acre of land at 124 Pondfield Road West, in Yonkers, to Nathaniel M. Aycock. Elliott-Bates, Inc., was the broker, with the Raymond R. Beatty Organization representing the seller.
LONDON, Oct. 4 (UP) -- A communique,

Whether Emily Cunningham Myles, 18 years old, a member of the so-called "younger social set" of Long Island, shall be adjudged a youthful offender, subject to correctional procedure, as an alleged participant in recent thefts of $2,300 in wearing apparel from Lord Taylor, will be determined by Judge Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. in General Sessions after Oct. 27.

The report by Drew Middleton in your issue of Oct. 2, "Germans Obeying United States Army Rules," brings to the fore some peculiar facts which cause considerable alarm to those who know nazism from experience.
PARIS, Oct. 4 -- Paquin had his fashion opening today and his display was characterized by sharp contrasts. He mixes many fabrics and favors bloused backs.

Panic-buying of cigarettes by smokers here, which began two or three weeks ago and reached its most serious stage within the last two days, is largely responsible for the current shortage of all brands Patsy D'Agostino, former president of the New York State Food Merchants Association and operator of three retail markets, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The neutral Governments have been requested, in notes from the State Department, to institute measures to prevent enemy Governments and leaders and their collaborators from retaining their loot under neutral protection and from finding safe haven for their wealth in neutral territories, it was announced today.

Opening with a series of three meetings devoted to basic issues involved in the problems of returning service men, the 1944 season of the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, will be opened by THE NEW YORK TIMES at 8:30 P.M. next Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday with spokesmen reporting for Government, labor and industry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The War Production Board announced today it has authorized seven manufacturers to produce 664,500 pieces of aluminum cooking utensils, kitchenware and household articles during the fourth quarter and larger quantities in the first quarter of 1945, under Limitation Order L-30-E, which controls the output of these items.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The British Government has pledged its veterans of this war "gratuities by way of reward for service," in addition to a liberal and detailed program of immediate benefits for men to be demobilized after the defeat of Germany.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 4 -- The post-war elections promised by President Getulio Vargas at the beginning of the year and reiterated on Sept. 7 has created nation-wide interest. Today, for example, many persons are asking if the promised elections will be conducted by popular vote or otherwise.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- The British Government has decided, after much pressure, to set up a separate Ministry of Civil Aviation and the names of Lord Brabazon, a former Minister of Aircraft Production, and Viscount Templewood, formerly Sir Samuel Hoare, are among those mentioned for the new post.

On the occasion of his last visit to Albany, scene of his greatest triumphs, former Gov. Alfred E. Smith appeared with Joseph A. McGinnies, former Republican Speaker of the Assembly, in a surprise skit in the annual stunt dinner of the Legislative Correspondents Association last March.

" 99 Park," headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc., offers a partial list of free amusements available today through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M. Evening tickets after 4 P.M.

The Allegheny-Ludlum Steel Corporation has called for redemption on Dec. 1 at $110 a share and accrued dividends all outstanding shares of its preferred stock without recourse to outside financing, it was announced yesterday by E.J. Hanley, secretary and treasurer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The resignation of Will L. Clayton, surplus war property administrator, was accepted here today by James F. Byrnes, director of the new Office of War Mobilization and Re-conversion. The resignation will take effect when a majority of the members of the Surplus Property Board, authorized under terms of legislation signed by President Roosevelt yesterday, take office.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- American diplomatic and consular representatives assigned to liberated areas have been instructed to expedite reports on economic conditions and trends within the areas for the guidance of both the Government and business, the State and Commerce Departments announced tonight.

PARIS, Oct. 4 -- All activities of "one Philippe Petain, accused of treason and intelligence with the enemy," will be investigated by a Paris police commissioner who is empowered to gather testimony and issue search warrants under authority given him today by a military court.

The Winthrop Chemical Company pleaded guilty in Federal court yesterday to an information alleging violation of the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act, and was fined $18,000 by Judge Samuel Mandelbaum. The case involved the shipment in interstate commerce of adulterated distilled water and dextrose, or sugar, solution, for use in connection with atabrine dihydrochloride, phenarsine hydrochloride and neoarsphenamine neosalvarsan.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 4 -- Fred MacMurray and Leslie Fenton have formed Mutual Productions to produce "Pardon My Past," a published magazine story by Patterson McNutt and Harlan Ware. Under the plans, as announced, the actor will be starred in the picture, Fenton will direct it and McNutt will be the associate producer.

This department confesses to a friendly feeling for candy stores, perhaps dating from the days when we stood with nose pressed against a glass showcase, examining the sweets with childish concentration. Because of this disposition we are glad to welcome another confectionery to Manhattan -- a small shop just north of Fifty-seventh Street on the east side of Madison Avenue at No. 601.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- Retention of a larger share of earnings by individuals is essential as a means of providing the necessary incentive for investment of venture capital needed to inaugurate and expand industries in the post-war period, according to John L. Connolly, secretary and general counsel of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company of St. Paul and co-author of the Twin Cities post-war tax plan.

TO come late to the party is never very wise. The new-born are always doing it; they are always arriving late into a world warmed up by their elders, and not always finding the old jokes as good as their elders did. They have to pick up at a point where they are cold and where the old show is in hilarious progress. H. Allen Smith, for example, is as established as burlesque.

The news that the War Production Board was slackening its restrictions on the conversion of large dwelling units into small units, while an encouraging and necessary step, will not, in the opinion of practical real estate men achieve the results that some newspaper articles have presented.

Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 4 (U.P.) -- The guns fell silent and long lines of French civilians began evacuating the blood-soaked soil of Dunkerque today under a fantastic forty-eight-hour truce.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- About 8 per cent more Navy ships, planes and major ordnance items must be produced in the final quarter of this year than in the preceding quarter, Secretary Forrestal told his press conference today.

John W. Hanes, Undersecretary of the Treasury in the early days of the Roosevelt regime, told 400 persons at a meeting of the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, last night that there is no such thing as a Democratic party in this country today.
TORNEAA, Finland, Oct. 4 -- The Germans, bringing in reinforcements from Rovaniemi and possibly even from Norway, have made two desperate attempts to recapture Torneaa from the Finns.
" Of Smiling Peace" is the title of the new novel by Stefan Heym, who wrote "Hostages." Little, Brown will publish it Oct. 18.

It is probable that those who do not reach for the moon along with their copy of The Playbill may have a generally pleasant time at Rose Franken's "Soldier's Wife," which put in an appearance last evening. And it is not only probable but inevitable that those who attend the theatre when the moon is down -- the matinees being Wednesday and Saturday -- will find the John Golden's occupant considerably more than generally pleasant.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Orioles forged their way into the little world series for the first time since 1925 tonight by taking the seventh game of the final International League play-offs from Newark, 6 -- 3, in drizzling rain and fog before 14,747 fans.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Thursday, Oct. 5 (AP) -- A communique:

The nation's production of crude oil established a new peak last week when it averaged 4,762,300 barrels daily, an increase of 18,450 over the 4,743,850 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 6,100 barrels more than the recommendation of 4,756,200 daily for September by the Petroleum Administration for War.

In speculating on what lies ahead of reborn France it would obviously be of help to understand as clearly as might be what it was that brought about the fall of France. It is by no means certain that the most familiar versions take into account the whole story.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- His life was so crowded with usefulness and achievement, so steadily attended by the respect and affection of his fellow -citizens, that it is impossible to select one episode that completely illustrates what manner of private man and public leader was Alfred E. Smith.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 4 -- The Mound City closed it doors on the outer world today to concentrate upon its first exclusive world series in history, but some two hours later it was forced to throw them open again just to let in a little air.

In a comprehensive review of New York's aviation future John McKenzie, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, declared yesterday that the combined facilities of Idlewild and La Guardia airports would permit the handling twenty years hence of the city's statistical "point of airplane saturation" of 360 flights an hour.

Pearl Primus, who has managed to establish herself in the forefront of the younger dancers without ever making a Broadway appearance, last night rectified that anomolous situation by opening an eleven-day engagement at the Belasco Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Navy Department today outlined the procedure for which officers and enlisted members of the Waves would be selected for overseas assignments. Only those who volunteer for such duty are eligible for service abroad.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Joseph C. Rovensky, a vice president of the Chase National Bank of New York, declared today that the United States in the post-war era would be more important in world relations than ever before and that "our first job is to make the dollar worthy of the position it occupies."

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- Britain's role in world finance and the relationship between the Government and private enterprise were the subjects chosen by Sir John Anderson, Chancellor of the Exchequer, for his address today to the bankers and merchants of the City of London at a luncheon given by Sir Frank Newson-Smith, the new Lord Mayor.

To prevent "squandering or waste" of Great Britain's war-curtailed resources, the British Government "will find it necessary for some time to come to maintain close control over raw materials and capital" in international trade, Francis Edward Evans, British Consul General in New York, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The delegates at the Dumbarton Oaks security conference believe they have drafted an international organization which is different from the League of Nations in five important essentials. These may be defined as follows:
LONDON, Oct. 4 -- Business in today's stock markets was again subdued, prices moving in narrow limits with no decided trend.
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 4 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

" Builders of the World Ahead" will be the general theme of the annual Forum on Current Problems under the auspices of The New York Herald Tribune to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Oct. 16, 17 and 18, The Herald Tribune announced last night.

As important to the war program as combat duty -- and almost equally hazardous -- is the job of volunteers in the American Field Service, who drive ambulances on the fighting fronts, speeding first aid to the wounded and rushing them to hospitals.
Women in China have won their rights politically; now they must win them psychologically, Jean Lyon of the Chinese News Service said yesterday.

The outlines of a national program for medical care, designed "to make available to the entire population all essential preventive, diagnostic and curative services," and to fill the needs of "a large portion of the population" that now "receives insufficient and inadequate medical care," was adopted yesterday by the governing council of the American Public Health Association at the association's annual meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

FIRST UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Oct. 4 (U.P.) -- The "Galloping Ghost" of the Allied forces -- the Second Armored Division -- now is operating in the First Army area "somewhere in Germany." It was this organization that made headlines under the term "American armor" in the dash through France into Belgium.

PARIS, Oct. 4 -- The French Government will be financed for the present chiefly by borrowing from the Bank of France and transforming short-term into long-term government notes, it was said on high authority today.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 4 (U.P.) -- Gov. John W. Bricker accused the New Deal tonight of trying to buy the 1944 election with money collected by Sidney Hillman and his CIO Political Action Committee.

ALBANY, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Indications that Governor Dewey planned to direct a larger snare of his Presidential campaign appeals toward the "independent" voters developed today as the Republican nominee worked on an address scheduled for delivery at Charleston, W.Va., Saturday night.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- British shipyards will soon be allowed to switch over to the construction of small ocean tramps and troop carriers that will be as adaptable for post-war needs as they will be useful in the war against Japan, it was announced in the House of Lords today by Lord Leathers, Minister of War Transport.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Net profits before dividends of national banks of the United States and possessions for the six months ended on June 30 were $207,782,000, or at an annual rate of 10.11 per cent on capital funds, Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency, announced today.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Communique 179:
A supplementary communique broadcast domestically Tuesday from Budapest and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The stock market scored yesterday one of its best recovery efforts since the setback of early September. The share list emerged from its recent stalemate without the assistance of any major news development, and, although the averages failed to reflect the full scope of the rally, values in some cases were enlarged from 1 to around 3 points.

Capt. Stephen Stavers of the Marine Corps, one of the country's foremost exponents of bayonet and hand-to-hand fighting, was killed Sept. 18 by a Japanese sniper during the early stages of the Palau invasion, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- Wheat futures continued today their recent sensational advance. Prices on the Board of Trade rose 2 3/8 to 2 7/8 cents a bushel, with December selling at a new high since April. General buying was induced by revival of a report last week that the Office of Price Administration contemplated raising the ceiling price on cash wheat.

Frederick Marantz, New York pianist, gave a recital last night in Town Hall. The first half of his program was devoted to the sonata in E major, Op. 5, No. 5, of Johann Christian Bach; Beethoven's sonata, Op. 53, and Alban Berg's sonata, Op. 1.

Salvage of fats by civilians in the first seven months of 1944 increased 115 per cent over the same period in 1943, the American Fat Salvage Committee reported yesterday to the Association of American Soap and Glycerine Producers, Inc. The rise was credited to the ruling of the Office of Price Administration in December that two red points would be allowed for each pound of used household fat turned in to a meat dealer.

As a site for a large bakery, commissary and general office, Bickford's, Inc., restaurant chain, has purchased the plottage at 607-619 West Forty-fifth Street, running through to 604-12 West Forty-sixth Street, through John J. Reynolds, broker.

Thrills, spills and breakneck tricks by the carload flashed for two and a half hours last night in Madison Square Garden as the Nineteenth Annual World's Championship Rodeo got under way with 200 honest-to-goodness cowboys competing for the record amount of $110,000 in cash prizes.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 -- Surgery, instead of radium or X-ray, has the "real expectation of cure" in early cases of cancer as well as a means of relief in advanced cases, it was asserted today by Dr. William S. Bainbridge, surgical director of the Manhattan State Hispital of New York City, in a paper read before the United States Chapter of the International College of Surgeons.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- Calling the kitchen "one of the most hazardus spots on earth," Marye Dahnke, director of the home economics department of the Kraft Cheese Company, Chicago urged intelligent kitchen planning today as a means of reducing accidents.

Citations for "accurate and comprehensive reporting of the war news" and support of wartime activities on the home front were awarded to THE NEW YORK TIMES, The New York Herald Tribune, The New York Sun and The New York World-Telegram yesterday by Kiwanis International and the Kiwanis Club of New York City at a luncheon held in the Hotel McAlpin.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Gloriously happy, the exultant Browns yelled and screamed confidence in their ability to take their National League cousins, the Cardinals, in the world series after defeating them, 2 to 1, in the opener today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast by the Free Yugoslav Radio in Serbo-Croat and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

A UNITED STATES NINTH AIR FORCE FIGHTER BASE, France, Oct. 4 -- Yvette Hamel, a pretty 17-year-old French girl who was crippled in the Normandy fighting, has been adopted by the officers and men of a Thunderbolt fighter group commanded by Col. Bingham T. Kleine of Gonzales, Tex.

The City Planning Commission persisted yesterday in its refusal to hold a public hearing on the alternative plan proposed by one of its own members, Public Works Commissioner Irving V.A. Huie, for the regulation of height and density of new buildings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Nicholas Uncovic, counsel for Jones Laughlin and several other Pennsylvania steel companies, urged the National War Labor Board today to exclude from contracts between the companies and the United Steel Workers of America, CIO, provisions for maintenance of membership and check-off of union dues.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Two world records were shattered at the Lexington harness races today, one in competition and the other in a run against time.

After a listless market on the New York Cotton Exchange cotton futures closed yesterday 4 points higher to 4 points lower than on Tuesday. There was no feature to the trading, which was within a five-point range all day.

WITH FIRST UNITED STATES ARMY, in Germany, Oct. 4 -- A letter to the editors of THE NEW YORK TIMES, written "in the name of all the inhabitants of the city of Maastricht," the Netherlands, to thank the United States for the town's liberation, is on its way to New York, according to Het Parool, a Maastricht newspaper.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Oct. 3 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- A law prescribing death or life imprisonment and heavy fines for ten classes of war criminals was enacted today. It was estimated that between 3,000 and 4,000 persons, already arrested or being sought, would face a new court sset up to try their cases.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Senator Joseph H. Ball, Minnesota Republican, declared in a speech broadcast tonight over Station KSTP, that "I meant what I said" when he stated that he was unable at this time to campaign for Governor Dewey for President.

Plans for an eight-story addition to its bank building at 530 Fifth Avenue were filed yesterday by the Fifth Avenue Bank of New York with the Department of Housing and Buildings. This will be a post-war project.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Bernie Bierman, head football coach on leave from the university for duty with the Marine Corps, will leave the service on Oct. 15 and return to the school as coach "in an advisory capacity," he informed W.C. Coffey, university president, today.

The bright limelight played on a super-luxurious collection of furs yesterday, furs that recalled more festive days when big limousines were lined up on Broadway on the opening night of the Metropolitan Opera. The occasion was Jaeckel's presentation of its custom-made models at the Hotel Pierre.

Berlin, Ore., will change its name to Distomo on Oct. 28, it was announced yesterday by Maxwell Anderson, playwright and chairman of the Committee for the Rebirth of Distomo, 140 West Twenty-sixth Street.

I understand the record of the railroads in terms of handling military freight and troop movements is deemed admirable by the armed forces, but certainly the mere civilian passenger has due and sufficient cause for grumbling about service and discomfort. This it not, of course, the civilian's day, nor is deterioration of passenger service by itself any cause for surprise during a war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Addressing 200 educators, business leaders and Government officials attending the first White House Conference on Rural Education ever called, President Roosevelt today recommended a program of Federal aid for rural schools as being necessary to raise the educational standards in many communities.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 29 (Delayed) -- Prime Minister Churchill's harsh references to Bulgaria in his House of Commons address had a depressing effect on all members of the present Fatherland Front Government of Bulgaria. All Bulgarians appear to have been hurt.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 4 -- District Attorney Edward J. Neary began an investigation today into a complaint by Miss Frances Guzzo, 22 years old, of 96 Stone Street, Elmont, that a delegate of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union had forced eight women employes of the Marks Abraham coat factory in Elmont to contribute $1 each to the union's Roosevelt campaign fund under threat of taking up their union cards.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission disallowed today a proposed increase in rates for the Cabot Natural Gas Companies in New York State and criticized them for constructing "extravagant facilities * * * to reap quick profits from flush production."

WITH UNITED STATES THIRD ARMY in France, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Third Army troops broke into huge Fort Driant, main bastion guarding the city of Metz, and clung tonight to surface positions against German opposition rising in violence with assaults from countless tunnels and trapdoors.

LONDON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Up to 750 Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Fifteenth Air Force hammered Munich railroad yards and the Brenner Pass area today while Royal Air Force heavy bombers dumped thousands of tons of explosives on German U-boat pens at Bergen, Norway.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The presidents of four railroad unions and the head of the International Association of Machinists which has about 50,000 members employed on railroads, called on President Roosevelt today and assured him of their full political support.

Many of the charitable and humanitarian organizations to which Alfred E. Smith so freely devoted his time and energy paid tributes to him yesterday. The National Catholic Community Service, of which he was vice president and director, declared he was "respected by the entire nation, loved by the many who had the privilege of his personal friendship" and said that his death was an irreparable loss to that organization.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- A thirty-billion-dollar increase in equities of farm owners and tenant farmers during the war seemingly has placed agriculture in a strong financial position, the Department of Agriculture reported today.
PARIS, Oct. 4 (AP) -- A gorgeous gown draped on a cross-eyed manikin would be a shock to anybody u but that is actually the spirit of the Paris fashion openings this year.

Leaders of the city, State and nation, without regard to party or creed, joined yesterday in paying high tribute to Alfred E. Smith as one of the greatest Americans of this generation. Some of the innumerable expressions of sorrow at his passing follow:

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS in the Southwest Pacific, Oct. 4 -Lieut. Comdr. James E. Van Zandt, former Republican representative from Pennsylvania, received today the Legion of Merit Medal for "splendid performance of duty" as commander of assault waves and in "sustained operations against the enemy."

Acting after complaints by families of service men, the regional Office of Price Administration issued yesterday an order governing the price of gift packages. Savings of 15 to 25 per cent should result to consumers who buy ready-packed parcels containing any item of food, according to Daniel P. Woolley, the regional administrator.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 4 -- The parallel is not perfect but there is a strange similarity between the opening game of this series and the first one of the 1929 classic. Denny Galehouse, a part-time pitcher for the better part of the season and a man with a not too prepossessing won-and-lost record this campaign, stepped out from the shadows into the spotlight with a stunning victory over the Cardinals.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Thursday, Oct. 5 -- Tanks and mobile guns are now being driven into the American First Army's Westwall wedge behind the infantry that cut through the concrete crust of the German line north of Aachen and are spreading out against field defenses after fighting off three German tank and infantry charges.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, Oct. 5 -- Allied planes sank or damaged ten more Japanese freighters, pounded Japanese airfields and lashed at an important port in sweeps from the Philippines to Amboina, it was reported today by headquarters.

A stage production that will rival Broadway's most successful show in setting, lights and stage design with forty fashion designers cooperating to produce "acts" of the show will characterize the third annual fashion show to be produced by THE NEW YORK TIMES Oct. 24 to 27 at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

LONDON, Thursday, Oct. 5 -- Russian tanks and cavalry, smashing at least twenty-six miles across the Yugoslav plains, drove to within fourteen miles northeast of the capital city of Belgrade yesterday, while other Red Army forces south of the Danube River linked with Marshal Tito's liberation army and thrust toward the big Yugoslav rail hub of Nish.

HAVANA, Oct. 4 -- President-elect Ramon Grau San Martin said today that German industries that could make things useful for war should be suppressed and that the Reich should be broken up into separate states so Germany could not start another conflict.

Among the latest batch of Hollywood films sent abroad for the entertainment of American prisoners of war in Germany are "Arsenic and Old Lace," "Casanova Brown," "Saratoga Trunk," "In Society." "Step Lively," "Higher and Higher," "Devotion" and "Crime By Night," it was announced yesterday by the motion picture industry's War Activities Committee.

An industry-wide drive will be made for a floor-tax refund on liquor stocks following the end of the war, it was decided yesterday at a meeting of all levels of the industry at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Under the auspices of the Wine and Spirits Wholesalers of America, a gathering of association officials was held to consider post-war problems, with the floor tax refund question holding a predominant place in floor discussions.

Raymond B. Fosdick, president of the Rockefeller Foundation, made an unanswerable point against one species of isolationism in his address in this city at the conference of the American Public Health Association. Mr. Fosdick said we could no longer be indifferent to health conditions in China, where there is one hospital for each 700,000 persons, and one well-trained physician for each 70,000.

American education has come a long way since Abraham Lincoln had to walk several miles to borrow a book which he then studied by the flickering, unsatisfactory light from a log cabin fireplace. It still has a long way to go, as is made clear by the reports presented to the White House Conference on Rural Education.

In one of the tightest finishes in steeplechasing annals, Irish-bred Burma Road yesterday won the $16,950 Grand National Steeplechase Handicap by the scantest of noses from Rouge Dragon at Belmont Park. In addition to being of credit to Eire, none too large geographically, the score brought distinction to the tiny State of Delaware as the son of Link Boy is owned by Mrs. Esther duPont Weir of Wilmington.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, reported today that "progress" had been made under the intensified recruitment drive to meet manpower needs for critical war production, but James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization and Reconversion, pointed out that labor shortages still persisted in some of the "must" programs of the War and Navy Departments.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 4 -- Yale and Cornell meet in the Bowl Saturday, and that should be one of the best games the Ivy comes up with this year. A crowd of 25,000 or better is expected.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Joseph P. Kamp of New York refused today to give requested information to the House Campaign Expenditures Committee, as Dr. Edward R. Rumely, who was indicted after taking a similar stand, posted bond on a charge of "willful default" of a Congressional subpoena.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -Senator Truman, Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, completed plans today for a 7,500-mile campaign trip in which he will make major speeches in Los Angeles, Seattle, Peoria and Boston.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet and Chief of Operations of the Navy, issued a brief statement today seeking to clarify what he called "certain misunderstandings and misinterpretations which have arisen in the press and radio consequent upon the assignment of Vice Admiral Edwards to duty as Deputy Commander in Chief -- Chief of Naval Operations."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The text of Mr. Roosevelt's statement follows:

Radio Polskie, operated by the Russian-sponsored Polish Committee of National Liberation in Lublin, charged last night that Gen. Tadeusz Komorowski's "homeland army command" in Warsaw had violated an agreement to evacuate the Polish patriot forces across the Vistula to Russian-held Praga before General Komorowski [Bor] announced his capitulation to the Germans on Tuesday.

Formation of Women Volunteers for Roosevelt, an "independent voters' committee," was announced yesterday. Mrs. Edward C. Carter is chairman of the group, which has headquarters at 55 West Forty-second Street. She said it aimed to enlist 10,000 women to canvass their neighbors.
ROME, Oct. 4 (AP) -- American troops of the Fifth Army have reached a point within fifteen miles of Bologna in a drive slowed by mud and bitter German resistance, Allied Headquarters announced today.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 4 -- Herman Barron, Fenway; Frank Strazza, Round Hill, and Willie Goggin, Century, wound up all square at 215 for the fifty-four holes comprising the Metropolitan P.G.A. championship at the Huntington Crescent Club today.

Governor Dewey will deliver major speeches in his campaign for the Presidency at Minneapolis on Oct. 24 and at Chicago on Oct. 25, the Republican National Committee announced yesterday at its headquarters in the Hotel Roosevelt. Both addresses are to be broadcast over nation-wide radio networks.
LONDON, Oct. 4 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 4 (AP) -- A claim of foul and a victory by an outsider marked the $5,000 added Maryland Futurity before 7,500 fans today. Surviving the objection, R.A. Johnson's Petee Dee won by a nose from Gallorette, one of three representatives of William L. Brann.

BOSTON, Oct. 4 -- Although Massachusetts may be a doubtful State, President Roosevelt seems, at present, to have the edge over Governor Dewey and to be more likely to win its sixteen electoral votes in November.

Governor Smith was a born leader. His gifts of personality, his wit, humor, high spirits and instinct for friendship counted for much, but his mental and moral qualities were the chief factors of his success. He was sincere, truthful, honest and generous. He never made a promise their he did not keep.

Topics which were agitating the American public back in 1861 -- hoopskirts vs. bloomers, women's attempt to gain the vote and the underground railway for slave -- are woven into the story of "Bloomer Girl." Reports from Philadelphia, where the new musical has been practicing for the last three weeks, have been all to the good.

Many members of the American Retail Federation have complained recently that manufacturers of towels are requiring them to agree before making deliveries that the merchandise is subject to such price increase as may be authorized by the Office of Price Administration, Walter Morrow, acting president of the ARF, has informed Byres H. Gitchell, director of the Consumer Goods Division of the OPA.
LOUISVILLE, Oct. 4 -- This statement was made today by Senator Barkley:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- After two years of trying, the Government decided today that it could not make the American Federation of Musicians act in harmony with the recording companies, so President Roosevelt asked the union, on a personal basis, to follow Washington's order.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Japanese invasion forces are less than six miles from Foochow, last large East China coast port held by the Chinese, the High Command announced tonight.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 4 -- Pledging "to restore agriculture to the farmers," Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for the Senate, declared in a major campaign address tonight that the New Deal had followed up oppressive, meddlesome, bureaucratic handling of farm problems with a thinly veiled attempt to purchase farmers' votes.

Arguments by Representative Vito Marcantonio, J. Bertram Wegman and William Scott Stewart, defense counsel in the case of seven men convicted of using their former control over the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes to wrest large sums from the movie industry, were heard yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

Plans for intensive drives aiming to persuade everyone who is entitled to vote to register so that he can qualify legally were announced yesterday by Republican State headquarters, the Democrats, the Liberal party and several trade unions.

Immediate steps to correct the current situation in infants' and children's wear, in which the production of staple and popular price apparel "faces more serious curtailment than ever before" was urged yesterday upon the War Production Board in a resolution adopted at a special meeting of the Infants and Juvenile Manufacturers Association at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will offer today $31,500,000 of first mortgage, Series A, 3 per cent bonds of the Narragansett Electric Company. The bonds, due in 1974, will be priced at 105.08 per cent and accrued interest.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Dies committee was accused today by Nelsor Poynter, head ou Press Research, Inc., of applying "Gestapo methods of intimidation to the press."
ST. LOUIS, Oct 4 (AP) -- The play-by-play description of the first game of the world series at Sportsman's Park today follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The United States must be willing to import products of other nations as a means of providing a sufficient dollar exchange if it is to look forward to a healthy post-war trade in cotton, the Department of Agriculture said today.

Settlement of a strike that had halted grading and dredging work at Idlewild Airport since Friday was announced yesterday by John McKenzie, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, who said the strikers would return to work this morning.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 4 -- Immediate substantial help for Italy as part of a larger program to speed her economic rehabilitation was urged today by Luigi Antonini, vice president of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, as the sole means of avoiding a Communist upheaval in that country.

Robert Moses, New York City's Commissioner of Parks who has initiated and administered huge public works projects, lists seven major reasons for his opposition to the re-election of President Roosevelt in an article in The Saturday Evening Post, published yesterday. In the same article he enumerates also seven reasons for voting Republican.

The 25 per cent premium that had been permitted dealers up to now on less-than-box sales of hunting ammunition was revoked yesterday in an announcement from the Office of Price Administration in Newark. At the same time, ceiling prices on many types of ammunition recently released for civilian use were made public.

KANDY, Ceylon, Oct. 4 (U.P.) -The Indian Thirty-third Corps, in six months of fighting through northeastern India toward the enemy base of Tiddim, Burma, has killed 9,746 Japanese troops, taken 450 prisoners and, with the Indian Fourth Corps, occupied 1,190 villages and towns, it was _nounced today.

DETROIT, Oct. 4 -- A strike by some 4,000 maintenance workers halted or crippled war production of planes, trucks and weapons in twenty-five plants here today, and latest estimates tonight were that the walkout had forced 60,000 employes to be idle.

There are smoke banners in the sky these frosty mornings -- banners that tell of peace and quiet routine in the countryside. In the Northern States along main valley highways and along the secondary and country roads that wind and dip among the hills, the banners mark the trails men use.

LONDON, Oct. 4 (U.P.) -- British officers have arrived in the town of Tripolitza, in the heart of the Peloponnesus area of Greece, and have accepted the surrender of the German garrison, Greek Government circles reported tonight as Germany faced the threat of a major military disaster in the Balkans.

The Southern Pacific Company is reported to be giving consideration to a plan through which holders of the first refunding 4 per cent bonds of the Central Pacific Railway, an affiliate, would be asked to exchange them for new longer-term obligations.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- The question of what will be done with German war criminals was discussed again in the House of Commons today and drew from Prime Minister Churchill a hint that the United Nations' leaders might dispose of the Nazi hierarchy by a swift executive judgment rather than a trial.

Governor Dewey lays down two important requirements for taxes that have received little attention from Mr. Roosevelt. The first is that taxes must be designed not to act as a drag upon production or a barrier to jobs. High tax rates that help to bring about a low national income defeat their own purpose even as revenue raisers, to say nothing of their effect on the welfare of all of us.

Activity in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange continued slow yesterday with final prices 1 to 10 points net lower on active months. After starting with losses of 1 to 4 points, the market held steady for a short time and then eased. July particularly was under pressure at times, due because of the transferring of hedges from near months to that of position.

Preceded by approximately asI much fanfare as the elections, I "Bloomer Girl" moved into theI Shubert last evening. Let the elec-I tions be as satisfactory. Beauti-] ful to look upon, with a good score] and bright lyrics and an engaging] cast to sing them, the town's new-{ est musical show is what the town i has been awaiting for some time. I

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 5 -- Eleven hundred Flying Fortresses and Liberators, escorted by about 750 Thunderbolts and Mustangs, delivered a series of smashing blows today against German positions ahead of the American First and British Second Armies.

Supreme Court Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan ruled yesterday after a four-day trial that Chrystal Spencer Dunninger was the common-law wife of Joseph Dunninger, mentalist, and granted her a legal separation on the ground of abandonment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- President Roosevelt, broadcasting his second avowed political speech for re-election from the White House tonight, served notice bluntly that he did not want the aid of any individual or group committed to a foreign ideology in conflict with the American system.

KATAKOLON, Greece, Sept. 26 (Delayed) -- A British amphibious force that rode out phenomenal waterspouts on its course through the Ionian Sea landed here this afternoon in the Allies' first seaborne thrust at the Greek mainland. The landings were utterly unopposed and they were heart-warmingly cheered by the impoverished residents of this Peloponnesian village on the lee side of the little tongue of land twelve miles west of Pyrgos.

Loans of the sixteen reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $47,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, but investments were slashed sharply, so that the total of both categories fell $196,000,000, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for Senator, predicted yesterday that for the first time his party would poll more votes in New York County on Nov. 7 than the Democrats. Whatever margin New Deal nominees receive in Manhattan, he implied, will be furnished by the American Labor and the Liberal parties, each of which has nominated most of the Democratic slate.

Whiting Evans of Brooklyn, a member of the East End Surf Fishing Club, emphasizes a few things that have been done on behalf of Long Island fishermen recently and doffs his hat to Park Commissioner Robert Moses as the man responsible.

ROCK ISLAND, Ill., Oct. 5 -- Calling the record of the National Labor Relations Board "a national disgrace," Governor Bricker told a meeting here tonight that "common sense" demanded a resurvey of the whole field of labor relations to provide a program that would advance the "legitimate aims" of organized labor in this country.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- The $8,000,000,000 nation-wide building program may meet with serious delays unless post-war planners recognize the essential nature of builders' hardware and provide for at least a partial shift of an important segment of war work now being done by hardware manufacturers, it was revealed here today at the annual convention of the National Contract Hardware Association.

Roy Rogers, star of Republic Pictures and the annual World's Championship Rodeo at Madison Square Garden, will appear tomorrow morning on the "Cowboys and Indians" program, sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, in cooperation with the Association of Children's Book Editors, at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- As other sources of loot are dried up by the Allies' reconquests, plain extortion directed by the Germans against moneyed persons in the United States and elsewhere is on the increase, official sources said today.

Bailey Enterprises, Inc., has sold the six-story apartment house at 3300 Bailey Avenue, the Bronx, to a client of Taylor Company, broker in the transaction. The building contains ninety-six apartments and is situated on an irregular plot 150 by 140 feet.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission was asked today by the railroads to restore at the beginning of next year increases in freight rates which have been held in suspension since May, 1943. The step was necessary, according to their arguments, to enable them to take care of the great amount of deferred maintenance, which has been accumulated because of the war, and to provide improvements in service in the post-war period.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Lee Pressman, general counsel to the United Steel Workers of America, CIO, closed that union's case for modification of the "Little Steel" formula by appealing to the National War Labor Board today to redress the disparity which he asserted had existed between wages and living costs since 1941.

CHUNGKING, Oct. 5 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops, in a desperate struggle to retain their last major holding on the China coast, checked the Japanese six miles east of the port of Foochow after seven days of furious battles, in which both sides suffered heavy casualties, and Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek's forces in the interior have blocked the main enemy drive on Kweilin at a point about twenty-three miles northeast of the city, it was disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Chinese delegation at Dumbarton Oaks has approved the world security plan drafted by the American, British and Russian delegations in the first half of the conference.

BOSTON, Oct. 5 -- Full-time operation of the cotton industry for the greater part of 1945 and "indefinite postponement of conversion to a peacetime basis" were predicted here today by Russell T. Fisher, president of the National Association of Cotton Manufacturers.
LONDON, Oct. 5 (U.P.) -- German Heinkels carrying flying bombs caused damage and casualties tonight in a brief attack against southern England during the dark hours just before moonrise.

OUTSIDE PATRAS, Greece, Sept. 29 (Delayed) -- All sorts of persons make up the Elas-Eam in the Peloponnesus, and opinions of them held by the Allied officers who have been in Greece from a few days to more than a year vary widely.

PYRGOS, Greece, Sept. 27 (Delayed) -- This freed city of 24,000 jointly celebrated the third anniversary of the founding of the Elas movement and the arrival of the British task force en route from Katakolon last night.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles, forced to go the full fourteen games to win the International League play-offs, entrained tonight for Louisville, where they will meet the Colonels in the little world series opener tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- President Roosevelt promised that the rights of small nations would be assured in the peace-making when he received Martial Mora Miranda today for the presentation of his letters of credence as the new Ambassador of Chile.

ROME, Oct. 5 -- Italians, having received good news from President Roosevelt today about desperately needed shipments of goods and clothing, as well as industrial help, and bad news from British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden about their colonies, are naturally full of mixed feelings.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed increase in holdings of United States Government securities and note circulation for the system as a whole to be $159,046,000 and $210,106,000 respectively, while the ratio of reserve declined slightly to 53.0.

One by one the New York Football Giants are finding their way back to their old haunts which, as everybody knows, are the Polo Grounds. Latest to stray home is Ward Cuff, veteran wingback who, recently mustered out of the Army with a medical discharge, joined the squad yesterday for the workout preliminary to the Giants' opener with the Yankees in Boston Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- J.B. Matthews, research director for the Dies committee, stated today that 119 of 142 members of the National Citizens Political Action Committee have a record of 842 affiliations with "Communist front organizations."

Anticipating that men coming out of the armed forces next year will have immediate use for an all-purpose suit, Rose Brothers, New York, in cooperation with Pacific Mills Worsted Division will introduce a suit with accompanying slacks which they will make available for spring sales, it was announced yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 5 -- Baseball's incredible Browns ran out of miracles today with the result that the big fellow of this all-St. Louis world series finally caught up with the little fellow and deftly put him in his place.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- There will be no coal for heating private dwellings in Paris at least until January, Marcel Flouret, prefect of the Seine Department, said today. He said there were half as many trucks in Paris today as in 1940 and most of them lacked tires.
Following is the text of President Roosevelt's address last night, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Forces, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Communique 180:

Mayor La Guardia told the American Public Health Association at its annual luncheon-meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday that he expected to ask the Legislature in January for authority to include 165,000 city employes and about 50,000 transport workers in the New York City Health Insurance Plan, the city to pay half the costs.

The Grand Union Company reported yesterday for the six months ended on Aug. 26 net profit of $245,667, equal to $1.10 a share, compared with $238,465, or $1.07 a share, for the corresponding period of last year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 5 -- John Payne has been named by Twentieth Century-Fox for one of the four leads in the proposed film, "The Dolly Sisters." He will portray Harry Fox, the husband of Jenny Dolly. Production of the musical, "Waltz Me Around Again, Willie," which was to have been Payne's first picture since his discharge from the Air Forces, has been postponed.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Fighting forces in all parts of the world are getting the world series first hand from their representative correspondents here from every theatre of war.

Obviously it is Bonwit Teller's philosphy that women dress for men. Their program of fashions shown in the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel yesterday noon was headed "I'm dressing for my darling." The clothes were assembled with an eye to allure.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Friday, Oct. 6 -- An hour-long air battle developed over the great oil refineries of Balik Papan, Borneo, Wednesday as Japanese fighters and heavy anti-aircraft fire sought to prevent the methodical destruction of plants producing a large part of Japan's gasoline and oil.

The Americas Foundation, dedicated to the principles of inter-American unity, will confer its first award for the greatest contribution to inter-American friendship during the year to Juan T. Trippe, president of Pan American World Airways, it was announced yesterday at the foundation's headquarters in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Buffeted around from one movie company to another like a cork in a storm, the screen rights to "Junior Miss" finally have been sold to Twentieth Century-Fox for $400,000. The transaction was confirmed yesterday by a Fox official.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 5 (AP) -- Coming with a rush on the outside in a thrilling stretch drive, the Pine Tree Farm's Drudge, ridden by Willie Balzaretti, today won the Madison Allowance Purse of $2,000 at Rockingham Park.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Lord Keynes, economic adviser to the British Treasury, said today that he was in Washington this week for special talks with United States oficials related to extension and settlement of lend-lease.

The Council of National Library Associations, representing the United States and Canada, has established a Joint Committee for Books for Devastated and Other Libraries in War Areas, it was announced here yesterday.

OUTSIDE PATRAS, Oct. 1 (Delayed) -- The fall of Patras, the third city of Greece, appeared imminent early this morning as Maj. Ian Patterson, commander of the British forward troops, went into the city for another conference with Capt. Alexander Magnus, the German naval commander.
YENAN, China, Oct. 3 (Delayed) -- Here are some oddments from this corner of the world:

The closing sessions of the annual meeting of the American Public Health Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania listened yesterday to a recital of food and drug adulterations that have cost many lives, much illness, considerable discomfort, spoilage of foods and betrayal of the confidence of the buying public.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 5 -- Superb on the greens, with one-putt performances on seven of them, Willie Goggin, Century, won the three man play-off for the Metropolitan P.G.A. title with a 34 33 -- 67, at the Huntington Crescent Club today.
LONDON, Oct. 5 (Reuter) -- Polish Government in London communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- A "restricted" report of the Office of War Information which came to light today predicts that "dislocations in civilian life after V-E day (victory in Europe) are likely to be widespread and, in some quarters, serious."

The liberation of Greece, cradle of our civilization and symbol of man's eternal fight for freedom, has begun. After a long night of suffering and oppression under the heels of Nazi conquerors, who have outraged all that this land has meant to the Western world, Greek soil is again reverberating to the march of Allied troops.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Commodity Credit Corporation announced today an increase of 0.53 cent a pound in the cotton loan rate on the 1944 crop in compliance with provisions of the Surplus Property Disposal Act signed by President Roosevelt last Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Navy communique 547:

Pleasure-bent New Yorkers and visitors from out of town are taking the 20 per cent Federal cabaret tax with the same ease with which they consume the amber fluids served in the cabarets, a survey of the night club trade disclosed yesterday.

Conversion of Crookes Laboratories, Inc., of New York, to American ownership and operation through a purchase by a group of American pharmaceutical manufacturers, was announced yesterday by Justin Haynes, who as head of the group became the company's new president.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Political analysts seem in general agreement that, if the President "holds the line" on wages until after the election, he will lose to Governor Dewey very little of the union labor support he has now and retain a large segment of independent strength which may prove to be the deciding factor at the November polls.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 5 -- The witching hour of midnight finally struck for the Cinderella Brownies. Ken O'Dea, a handsome, square-jawed Irishman, rang the gong with his eleventh-inning pinch single and the Cardinals had broken Luke Sewell's uncanny magic spell. But it was a mighty close call.

KLOOGA, Estonia, Oct. 2 (Delayed) -- Foreign correspondents were shown today the scene of the German execution and cremation of an estimated 3,000 Jews, Lithuanians, Poles, Estonians and Russians on Sept. 19 -- an act that demonstrated most conclusively that the Germans are in full scale retreat and are capable of cold-blooded slaughter even when it will serve little, if any, military purpose.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Rochester was without a local daily newspaper today for the first time in twenty-six years as 177 printers of the two Gannett newspapers continued idle in a dispute which the management called a difference over a contract interpretation and the union said was "a lockout."

DETROIT, Oct. 5 -- At a special meeting today the stockholders of the Standard Accident Insurance Company of this city approved the investment of $2,500,000 in the stock of a new fire insurance company to be wholly owned and operated by Standard Accident.
LONDON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

BOSTON, Oct. 5 -- The Massachusetts Woman's Political Club called upon city officials today to prohibit the premier performance tomorrow night of a musical revue, reportedly satirizing Governor Dewey, at Symphony Hall under the sponsorship of the Communist Political Association of Boston.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Secretary Stimson reported today that Army casualties on all fronts were 351,293 on Sept. 21. The latest Navy casualty figure of 65,792 brought the total for the armed services to 417,085.
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 5 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Acting Capt. John Cronin of the Missing Persons Bureau spoke gently to the chubby, fair-haired little boy. "Jimmy," he said, "I want you to look around the room carefully and see if there is anyone here you know." Three-and-one-half-year-old James Rufus Tarvin Jr. did as he was told.
ROME, Oct. 5 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 30 were 912,999 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 14,332 cars or 1.6 per cent more than for the preceding week, 2,355 cars or 0.3 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 5,713 cars or 0.6 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Accompanied by the heaviest demand in a month, the stock market attempted yesterday a test of the August high levels. A better brand of leadership sparked the further recovery as a strong close revealed gains of major fractions to a point and more in certain cases.

PATRAS, Oct. 4 (Delayed) -- This city was liberated soon after dawn today after a day-and-night battle in which the German garrison, long entrenched around the harbor, was driven to a hurried evacuation that came to grief.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Functional fitness, flexibility, practical comfort and individual independence in decoration will be the average housewife's outstanding post-war desires in home furniture, Christine Holbrook, associate editor of Better Homes and Gardens, told the National Association of Furniture Manufacturers today.

A war bond drive will be started throughout the State by 500,000 men, women and youths to be known as the Blue Star Brigade during the Sixth War Loan campaign, which opens next month, it was announced last night by Frederick W. Gehle, chairman of the War Finance Committee for New York.

The American Presidential campaign is not being waged more closely on the issues of foreign policy chiefly because President Roosevelt and Governor Dewey have "a kind of mutually protective agreement" not to stir up disputes at this time against Russia and Great Britain, D.W. Brogan, British political scientist and author, declared here yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 5 -- In anticipation of early Allied occupation, the evacuating of the Ruhr and Rhineland is now proceeding apace, according to information received from Berlin through private channels today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- An unscheduled visitor at the White House conference on rural education made a dramatic appearance before the 200 delegates today, and succeeded in disrupting the serious business of the morning.

As a means of keeping fraudulent registrations for this year's elections to a minimum, Mayor La Guardia and Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein have arranged for close cooperation between the Police Department and the State Law Department, the two officials said yesterday in a joint announcement.

A one-day strike of 4,000 to 6,000 maintenance workers in the Detroit area has just forced immediate idleness upon some 50,000 to 60,000 workers. Because the men who keep the assembly lines and equipment in running condition refused to work, the production workers had to be sent home.

An error in THE TIMES is as rare as one in a bank statement. There is, however, a very important one in the obituary of Josef Buerckel in THE TIMES of Sept 30, and apparently from there it crept into your editorial regarding him in the same issue. Buerckel was indeed an energetic Nazi, and no doubt he was a war criminal.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- An Anglo-Belgian financial agreement, which the Belgian Minister of Finance said he "hoped" would prove preliminary to an economic understanding, was signed today and will be followed shortly by a similar Anglo-Dutch agreement.

Clamping down on illegal increases in the price of bread, which has been selling for as much as 2 cents a pound above ceiling in some bakeshops in this city, the Office of Price Administration obtained Federal Court injunctions yesterday against thirty-nine retail bakers, some of whom are alleged to have violated ceiling prices and others to have failed to post proper prices.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Finnish troops, pushing the Germans back along a line north of the Finnish "waist," have captured Rannu and Sima, and approached close to Livojaervi, a Helsinki communique announced today.

DETROIT, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Maintenance workers in Detroit area war plants called off their strike today after Walter P. Reuther had told them, "You can't pressure the War Labor Board into action through strikes."

Continuation of the present immigration laws was advocated in a resolution adopted unanimously by delegates to the forty-ninth National Encampment of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States at the opening session of its four-day convention in the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

ROME, Oct. 5 (U.P.) -- American soldiers today slashed through last-ditch resistance of the best German forces in Italy to within ten miles of the enemy's Po Valley lifeline and moved another mile closer to the valley's principal city of Bologna.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Witnesses from industry and Government, who appeared today before a hearing of the Federal Communications Commission on post-war policy to govern this country's participation in international broadcasting, united in condemning an agency proposal that broadcasts beamed directly to listeners abroad be dropped after the war.

ROME, Oct. 5 -- British forces landed on the Greek mainland by air on Sept. 24 and by sea on Sept. 26 and by yesterday they had driven across the northern part of the Peloponnesus and captured Patras, the country's third largest city, it was announced today.

The new war novel by Thomas Kernan, author of "France on Berlin Time," was written in a German prison camp in Baden-Baden. To elude Nazi censorship, Mr. Kernan gave his story a Spanish scene and Spanish characters. Once back in this country, he changed the scene to Germany and the characters to Germans.

The grand prize of $150 in War Bonds for the best picture in the news photo contest for 1944, conducted by the United Seamen's Service, was awarded yesterday to Matthew Black, New York Journal-American photographer, when the judging of 239 entries was completed yesterday afternoon at the Governor Clinton Hotel.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Chungking in English to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:
LONDON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Note circulation reached a new record high of 1,158,701,000, an increase of 4,138,000 for week ended Oct. 4, as reported by the Bank of England.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Joseph D. Nunan Jr., Commissioner of Internal Revenue, denied tonight that a Treasury Department agent entered the plant of the Lincoln Electric Company and announced that a man who worked with his hands should not receive as much as $5,000 a year.

Emphasizing that the War Department has grown increasingly aware of the need for research and development in connection with new weapons. Robert P. Patterson, Assistant Secretary of War, in a speech last night at the forum being conducted by the Standard Oil Development Company at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, said that in his opinion a single unified defense agency combining the Army and Navy would go far toward solving many post-war military problems.

George Baldanzi, executive vice president of the Textile Workers Union, Congress of Industrial Organizations, announced yesterday his resignation as a member of the board of directors of American Relief for Italy, Inc., on which he sat as CIO representative.

ROME, Oct. 5 -- Another and extremely serious case of German looting of art treasures and vandalism, this time from Florence, was divulged today by the Monuments Subcommission of the Allied Control Commission.

A white-whiskered, bespectacled, benevolent-looking old fraud named Mitsuru Toyama is dead in Japan at the age of 90. Hugh Byas, in his "Government by Assassination," quotes an editor of the Tokyo Asahi as saying: "Toyama is often represented abroad as if he were the chieftain of some secret society for political assassination."

WITH THE BRITISH SECOND ARMY in Nijmegen, the Netherlands, Oct. 5 -- Full details of the method whereby the Germans attempted to blow up the Nijmegen highway bridge over Wall Rhine River and a railway bridge about half a mile westward on the night of Sept. 28, were disclosed today.

Those familiar with Umberto Romano's painting in the past -- with even his painting of only a year or so ago -- will find themselves jolted when they enter the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue, where the artist is now having a one-man show.

LONDON, Oct. 5 (U.P.) -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today that a thorough investigation had failed to bring to light facts to support published reports that United States officers attached to Allied Supreme Headquarters in France had taken advantage of their military position to engage in private business.

The current meeting of the American Public Health Association watered down and then adopted a national program for medical care which had been prepared by one of its committees. Despite the dilution, the program marks an important step. Its statement of principles contains much that deserves the consideration of State Legislatures and of Congress, as well as some points which can be questioned in the light of experience here and abroad.

Wartime speculators and "chiseling" landlords out for a quick profit have created "a most dangerous and critical situation" in the New York business leasing field that must be met by prompt State action to prevent reduction in employment and production and the exodus of many manufacturers from the city and State, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday.

Police details numbering more than 500 men were assigned yesterday to handle the enormous crowds of mourners who are expected to visit St. Patrick's Cathedral tonight, when the body of former Gov. Alfred E. Smith will lie in state in that edifice, and tomorrow morning, when his funeral will be held.
The star atop the Christmas tree will shine more brightly in many homes this year as a direct result of the success of the United Nations arms in recent months.

If the United States has one game that is truly national, it is baseball. This is the hundredth year it has been played under accepted rules. The British say it is an adaptation of Rounders. One hundred per cent Americans know it is an evolution of One Old Cat, and will stoutly deny any foreign taint.
LONDON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Beleaguered, belt-tightening Germans got new cuts in food rations tonight from Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, total mobilization director.

Several of the investment banking firms that have been most active in the recent flood of offerings of new securities have encountered a purely mechanical problem which has necessitated part of the staffs of some of them to work virtually day and night to keep abreast with essential records.
Maj. Gen. Louis McC. Little, USMCR, and Mrs. Little have come to the St. Regis from Washington.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Americar Mission in Paris is now prepared to receive inquiries as to the whereabouts and welfare of American citizens who are believed to be in the Paris area, the State Department said today. Inquiries should be addressed to the State Department. For ,the time being, it was added, inquiries about persons who are not American citizens or are not residing in the Paris area cannot be accepted.

A scheduled meeting of the City Council was adjourned yesterday after adoption of resolutions eulogizing the late Alfred E. Smith, former Governor of New York, and the late John P. Nugent, Democratic Councilman of Manhattan.
PARIS, Oct. 5 -- Probably half the elementary-school children of Paris return to their classrooms this week.

The procedures of the United States Army courts martial in Great Britain have fully justified the authority given the Americans to try their own men by the Jurisdiction of American Forces Act passed in 1942, Prof. Arthur L. Goodhart of Oxford, declared here yesterday in a report on the conduct of American soldiers overseas.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically from Sofia and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Perry Faulkner, 56-year-old business man of Montpelier, Ohio, long active in American Legion activities, became today the chief Federal official assigned to assist veterans of this war in finding jobs after discharge from service.

The six-story apartment building at 16 East Eleventh Street, occupying a plot 56 by 94.9 feet, has been sold by the Cabari Realty Corporation to an investing client of H. Stanley Millyer, Inc., for cash above a mortgage of $69,000. The assessed valuation is $145,000.
ROME, Oct. 5 -- Brig. Gen. Benjamin W. Chidlaw, jet propulsion pioneer, has assumed command of the United States Twelfth Air Force Fighter Command, Allied Mediterranean Headquarters announced today.
LONDON, Oct. 5 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
