Ralph M. Wilby, 39 years old, a Canadian ex-convict, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions to the theft of $275,000 from the William T. Knott Company, Inc., at 128 West Thirty-first Street, accountants for a chain-store concern, but the total was revealed to be $387,000, most of which Assistant District Attorney George J. Hunter Jr. believes Wilby has cached in British Columbia.

MR. HOPEWELL was an economist and a writer, and a Socialist from his youth, when he had pored over the sacred writings of Karl Marx and had been exposed to the contagious idealism of men like Eugene V. Debs. He wanted deeply to "assure the social and economic security of every person without curtailing political freedom."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- An increase of 12 per cent in weekly department store sales for the week ended Sept. 30 compared with a year ago was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board. Sales increased slightly less than usual from August to September, the board added, but they continued to be about 13 per cent larger than a year ago.

DETROIT, Oct. 4 (U.P.) -- Two stock brokers went on trial today before Federal Judge Edward J. Noinet on charges of violating United States mail statutes in the sale of about 500,000 shares of stock in Devon Gold Mines, a Canadian company, after a third defendant had pleaded guilty to the Government's accusations.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- After sixteen months in the service of the Navy, Travers Island in Long Island Sound here, will soon be returned to the New York Athletic Club, it was learned today. The forty-acre island, attached to the mainland by a causeway, was the country home of the club from 1904 until the Navy leased it.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5 -- Medical insurance which will provide protection when the wage earners of a family are unemployed, as well as when they have steady employment, was advocated today by the United States Chapter of the International College of Surgeons at the closing session of the national assembly.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 5 -- Since the Arab inter-governmental talks on ways and means of attaining unity among the Arab countries of the Middle East first began in Alexandria a fortnight ago no inkling of what has been under discussion there has seeped out except a very full account of the lengthy formal opening addresses at the initial session.

This newspaper expects in the near future to receive a letter written "in the name of all inhabitants of the city of Maastricht," which lies on the left bank of the Maas River in that part of the Netherlands which is almost pinched off by Belgium on the west and Germany on the east. The text of the letter arrived by wireless on Wednesday.
PATRAS, Greece, Oct. 5 -- About three and a half years ago I fled from Greece a jump before the invading Germans. Now I am a jump behind the same enemy in retreat.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Secretary of War Henry Stimson presented an optimistic picture of the war situation in his weekly review at his press conference today.

The new season of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Artur Rodzinski, conductor, opened brilliantly last night in Carnegie Hall. The orchestra, a few slight slips to the contrary, showed its consistent development under Dr. Rodzinski's leadership.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Stockholders approved here today the Commonwealth Edison Company's $178,000,000 refunding plan, which Charles Y. Freeman, chairman, said was one of the "important initial steps of our post-war planning."

In a campaign speech broadcast over a State-wide radio network, Senator Robert F. Wagner who is up for re-election this year, urged last night the re-election of President Roosevelt on the ground that the Democrats had demonstrated better qualifications to finish the war and get the country back on a sound peace footing than the Republicans.

The Treasury Department procurement division will seek to purchase about 14,000,000 yards of woolens during the first quarter of 1945 for the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, it was learned yesterday following a meeting of Treasury officials and industry representatives at the Manhattan Club.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- The Polish Government-in-Exile announced tonight that Lieut. Gen. Tadeusz Komorowski (General Bor) had been taken prisoner, confirming an earlier German report that the leader of the Polish underground, for whose capture they once offered a reward of $2,000,000, had fallen into their hands on the surrender of Warsaw.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced today the terms of types of securities to be offered in the Sixth War Loan drive starting Nov. 20, and called for full support of the campaign for $14,000,000,000, which, he said, is "urgently needed."

A Brooklyn landlord who rented stores to "teen-aged" youths for use as club rooms was criticized yesterday in Coney Island Court by Magistrate J. Roland Sala, who told the defendant, Nathan Katz, 46 years old, of 3008 West Twenty-second Street, Brooklyn, his duty entailed more than collecting rents.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The War Production Board today lifted all its wartime controls from the use of magnesium in the manufacture of civilian products, thereby officially and finally ending the career of that metal as critical material.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Friday, Oct. 6 -- American tanks have driven their wedge into the Westwall another mile beyond Uebach, and the British Second Army, showing new aggressiveness in the battle to build up Allied bases for the coming offensive against Germany, has taken an equal amount of ground from powerful German forces guarding the vital bridge across the Lek River at Arnhem.

Dustman, from Greentree, 7 to 10 and your money back, rescued the form players in yesterday's Lenark Purse at Belmont Park, where he just made the grade in the last stride. Luck has been none too good for backers of favorites, so there was a general sigh of relief when this dark bay gelding eked out a nose victory under as strenuous a ride as Eddie Arcaro ever has given a horse.

Brig. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler will return soon to civilian life and will resume his duties with THE NEW YORK TIMES as vice president and general manager and with The Chattanooga Times as president and publisher. General Adler has been absent on active military duty in the field since Oct. 7, 1940.
LONDON, Oct. 5 -- The general tone of today's stock markets was cheerful, although business again was only on a small scale.
The National Society of Mural Painters was in a quandary last night about finding Corp. Frank Duncan and paying him $100.

Following are excerpts of a recent letter from the Misses Katherine and Anne Jeffries-Davis, 68 and 66 years old, who had a home in Croydon, England, and had lived there during the greater part of the war. Their reactions to a robot bomb attack might be of interest to your readers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The War Production Board outlined today the possibility of this country achieving a vast and virtually unrestricted "metal age" in the manufacture of civilian goods within a year after Germany has been defeated.
Friday's Southwest Pacific communique, as broadcast from Melbourne to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

In buying eggs this week-end, the best selection, both from the point of view of thrift and quality, is those of pullet size. These represent the freshest of the current production, according to an authority in the trade, who points out that Grade A pullets are on a par with the Grade A large variety in everything except weight of course.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Dr. John T. Fochtman, in 501 W 113th St; Diedrich Weidenhofer, in 157 W 105th St; George D. O'Connor, in 924 W End Ave; Ben Rosen, in 316 W 79th St; Sidney Horowitz, in 730 Riverside Dr; Charles Steiner, in 924 W End Ave; Harry Shay, in 310 W 79th St; Richard Strassburger, in 40 W 77th St -- Slawson Hobbs, brokers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Pope Pius XII, in a letter to Myron C. Taylor, President Roosevelt's personal representative at the Vatican, forwarded to the President today, gave his "fullest support" to the work and objectives of American Relief for Italy, Inc., a member organization of the National War Fund, that is obtaining and distributing clothing, food and medical supplies to destitute liberated Italians. Mr. Taylor is the chairman of the organization.

" Al" Smith was our first big political figure from the sidewalks of New York, but it would be a mistake to forget that before "AI" Smith the streets of New York, in more impersonal fashion, had asserted themselves vigorously in our national life.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- President Roosevelt received today a pledge of support on behalf of more than 1,000 artists, writers and scientists from a delegation which called at the White House and spent a quarter of an hour discussing politics and the work of the Independent Voters Committee of the Arts and Sciences for Roosevelt.

In adopting a record budget for the coming fiscal year, the Community Service Society, largest private family welfare agency in the United States, is seeking to meet increased needs arising from the war. Calling for an expenditure of $2,793,344, the new budget reveals the important role to be taken by this private social agency in the task of "human reconversion" ahead.

LONDON, Friday, Oct. 6 -- Red Army troops, sealing all escape routes out of Belgrade north of the Danube River, yesterday captured the big suburban road and rail hub of Pancevo, only eight miles northeast of the Yugoslav capital and within artillery range of the imperiled city.
PARIS, Oct. 5 -- French art now being free, painters, sculptors and engravers are opening a "liberation salon" in Paris tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (U.P.) -- Secretary Stimson said today that no "political or economic factors" entered into the Army's plans for partial demobilization of its forces upon the defeat of Germany.
With the Lions back in the winning column again, after a bleak 1943 season, Lou Little has an entirely new outlook on football.

Sooner or later "the axe must fall" on the New Deal way of thinking, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the board of General Motors Corporation, declared yesterday, and said that the election of Governor Dewey in November would change for the better the clouded outlook of the American system of free enterprise.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The surplus war property disposal bill which President Roosevelt signed on Tuesday contains a provision permitting the Commodity Credit Corporation to subsidize the export "of any farm commodity or product," and some officials regard this as a significant new step in the Administration's foreign economic policy.

Several west side apartment and loft properties were listed yesterday as having passed into new hands. Among the parcels changing ownership was the seventeen-story house at 114 West Eighty-sixth Street, sold by a client of E. Louis Gothelf to Stuyvesant Estates, Inc., for cash above a mortgage of $260,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The surplus war property disposal bill which President Roosevelt signed on Tuesday contains a provision permitting the Commodity Credit Corporation to subsidize the export "of any farm commodity or product," and some officials regard this as a significant new step in the Administration's foreign economic policy.

Several west side apartment and loft properties were listed yesterday as having passed into new hands. Among the parcels changing ownership was the seventeen-story house at 114 West Eighty-sixth Street, sold by a client of E. Louis Gothelf to Stuyvesant Estates, Inc., for cash above a mortgage of $260,000.

A COMMAND POST Before Fort Driant, France, Oct. 5 (U.P.) -- One of the biggest little battles of World War II continued through its third day today in the compact area, about 470 feet square, of Fort Driant, before Metz.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- The Government will discuss tomorrow the revival and enlargement of the Provisional Consultative Assembly transplanted from Algiers and will probably decide on its composition, official quarters said tonight.
Officials of the New Jersey State Teachers and Annuity Fund will offer for sale on Oct. 24, $7,365,900 of various issues of New Jersey municipal bonds.
While Topics of The Times usually displays intelligence and sound reasoning, the remarks on the Jewish Brigade Sept. 29 fell short of the broad understanding of a scholar.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- The new Schiaparelli collection opened today. Cloaks are nearly all in the form of a redingote. Some are doubled with fur, like the majority in all dress houses. This does not give the effect of a thin figure, but comfort comes first.

Plans for President Roosevelt's appearance in person at campaign rallies in New York and other States have been vetoed by a White House ruling that the President cannot appear at any scheduled "public gatherings," local Democratic leaders were informed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- A tentative "charter for rural education," containing an eight-point program designed to provide more educational opportunities for 12,000,000 rural school children, was presented today at the closing sessions of the White House conference on rural education, attended by 200 educators, school leaders and farm representatives.

The British "invasion" of Greece announced yesterday is more properly an "occupation" for politico-military objectives rather than an assault. The latest move in the Balkans follows similar small-scale operations at various points along the Dalmatian-Albanian coast, announced last week, and probably prefaces other British moves into Greece, the Greek islands and western Yugoslavia on the heels of the retreating Germans.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Crescent Public Service Company, its four subsidiaries and several affiliates filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan to comply with provisions of the Holding Company act by dissolving Crescent and distributing holdings in the subsidiaries among its security holders.

OTTAWA, Oct. 5 -- The Canadian Air Force to be used in fighting Japan will be composed entirely of volunteers, Air Minister C.G. Power said today. He added that he did not anticipate any trouble in raising as big a force as he wanted.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Electronic tubes and devices, which are hastening victory for the Allies, will open vastly expanded frontiers in the post-war world, 1,500 scientists and industrial leaders attending the first national electronics conference were assured today. Peacetime appliances in the field of radio, television, aviation, industry, medicine and science are ready because of the tremendous progress in electronics during wartime, the conference was told.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 5 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz stated today that in the last ten days of the operations in the southern Palau Islands the First Marine Division had lost another 191 men killed in action and 1,011 wounded in action.

WITH UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY in Germany, Oct. 5 -- American and German tanks are locked in the largest armored battle yet fought on German soil, in the area north and east of Beggendorf, crossroads village a mile and a quarter northeast of Uebach that was taken by a wave of American armor today.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The play-by-play description of the second game of the world series at Sportsman's Park today follows:
PARIS, Oct. 5 -- The death of Aristide Maillol, well-known sculptor, was announced today as the "liberation salon" of French artists staged a preview of its exhibition opening tomorrow.

WITHIN THE BORDERS OF PATRAS, Oct. 3 (Delayed) -- A bright moon shone down tonight on a strange scene that not only held the key to the resolution of the military problem of Patras but provided unmistakable evidence of the civil war now seething in Greece.
May it not be fitting at this time to call further attention to the great contribution that Governor Smith made to public education?

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 6 -- Bounding back with the resilience of a pre-war rubber ball, the Browns once more tossed baseball's outstanding academic minds into complete consternation today as they thrashed the supposedly infinitely superior Cardinals in the third game of this all-St. Louis world series and again moved into the lead.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in the Southwest Pacific, Saturday, Oct. 7 (U.P.) -- Allied bombers sank or damaged eight more Japanese ships, including a mine-layer, in sweeps over the Netherlands East Indies Tuesday and Wednesday, while other planes attacked airdromes on Halmahera Island with fifty-nine tons of bombs, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

The dispute between the Metropolitan Opera Association and the Association of Theatrical Agents and Managers, AFL, appeared to have reached a deadlock yesterday, when it was learned that all negotiations had been suspended and that Oliver M. Sayler, business agent for the union, had accused the Metropolitan of pursuing "an actively anti-union policy."

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Indications pointed tonight to a walkout of set designers, painters and machinists from one or more additional motion picture studios tomorrow. Two companies are already involved. A union representative said that "unless somebody does something pretty quick" the jurisdictional dispute which started yesterday might become a full-dress strike.

Retail trade was again active here this week. Demand for women's apparel and accessories was strong and active response to clearance offerings of some merchandise was reported. Estimates indicated department stores had increases of 20 per cent or more over the like week last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The National War Labor Board, by a vote of 6 to 3, with the industry members dissenting, decided today to send the issue involving Detroit maintenance workers to the automotive section of the Detroit regional WLB for immediate consideration.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State now offered by dealers:

The stock market's breakthrough in its recovery drive toward the high levels of August was furthered yesterday, but it was without sufficient force to solidify the previous run-up. Although the list definitely closed on the higher side, interest waned during the afternoon and the best strength appeared only in a group of selected issues.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 6 -- An unconfirmed dispatch to the Swiss Telegraphic Agency tonight said that the Hungarian Government, "finding it impossible to continue in the present grave national crisis," has handed in its resignation to Regent Horthy.

Under a slum-clearance policy emphasizing determination to keep strictly in the field of low-rent housing and out of commerce, the New York City Housing Authority has decided to provide no stores in its vast post-war building projects, and intends to reduce the retail space even in its existing housing centers to the "irreducible minimum," it became known last night.

Another conflict of ideologies may be expected to folow the war, Bishop Eugene J. McGuinness of the Roman Catholic Diocese of North Carolina said yesterday morning at a communion breakfast of the Anchor Club of the New York Police Department at the Hotel Governor Clinton.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 6 -- Senator Claude Pepper declared tonight that the coming election would mark the first time the American people will have a chance "to elect a President for a victory in peace as well as in war," and he described President Roosevelt as "strong in body and mind and ready to lead us into the prosperous days of peace which will be possible under another Roosevelt Administration."
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Communique 181:

The vanguard of what is expected to prove a heavy influx of retail buyers will arrive here beginning Monday when members of the Sportswear Guild will show their lines for the spring season. The showings will continue through Thursday, and will constitute the complete collections of the nine member firms for the entire season.

The total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $147,716,156 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the exchange. Average price per share of all listed stocks on Sept. 30 was $35.75 compared with $35.40 at the end of August.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast by the Free Yugoslav radio in English and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The board of directors of The Associated Press commended yesterday constructive steps taken in behalf of the principle of free interchange of news and expressed "its deep and abiding belief that the future peace and friendly relations between peoples of all nations will be advanced by worldwide acceptance" of this principle.

The letter of the President to James C. Petrillo, head of the American Federation of Musicians, illustrates once more the double standard of the Administration in dealing with disputes between unions and employers. Mr. Petrillo has defied an order of the War Labor Board. One cannot imagine the President's writing so gentle and friendly a note to an employer who had defied an order of the Board.

Earle H. Cochrane, 41 years old, who until last May had sole charge of the money order section of a postoffice at Beacon, received an eighteen-month prison term yesterday from Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum, before whom he pleaded guilty to making 237 false entries, erasures or alterations in his records.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Oct. 6 - -Jack Mitchell of Essex County today set a course record of 65 as he and Emery Thomas of Forest Hills defeated Percy Jarvis of Maplewood and Ralph Romano of Madison, 4 and 3, in the first of the New Jersey State P.G.A. pro-pro match play tournament at the Essex Fells Country Club.

Paying tribute to both the President's wartime record and his contributions for a permanent peace, Mrs. Kermit Roosevelt, widow of Maj. Kermit Roosevelt, son of President Theodore Roosevelt, called last night for President Roosevelt's re-election for reasons "fundamental in their simplicity."

New municipal issues scheduled for sale next week aggregate $61,214,000, compared with $5,602,125 for this week, according to the Daily Bond Buyer. The weekly average of offerings for the year to date now stands at $19,457,003.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Strangled with her own snood, the body of Dorothy Berrum, 17-year-old War Department clerk from Chippewa Falls, Wis., was found early today on Potomac Park golf course. A possible clue to the slayer was a man's belt lying about fifty feet from the girl's body.

ROME, Oct. 6 (AP) -- British forces in Greece advanced today toward the Isthmus of Corinth, gateway to Athens, and it appeared that the Germans had abandoned most of the Peloponnesus in getting out of all of Greece as rapidly as they could.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- A less aggressive demand for hard winter cash wheat here and in Kansas City, with reports that ceiling prices were not obtainable, led today to increased pressure on futures on the Board of Trade, and closing sales were about the bottom, with losses of 1 cent a bushel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Statements made by President Roosevelt in his castigation of "fear propaganda" in his second 1944 political campaign speech last night brought prompt repercussions today in political circles.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Importations of about 1,600,000 cases of Scotch whisky in the next twelve months are looked for by liquor importers, according to word received here today.
SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 6 -- Thirty-one "fundamentalist" cult members, twenty men and eleven women, were convicted by a District Court jury today of conspiring to preach and practice polygamy.

The budget plan proposed by converters to spread the cotton gray goods price rise among manufacturers and retailers as well as themselves has been received "coolly" by the Office of Price Administration, according to informed sources in the trade yesterday.

The issue raised by Lewis Mumford over Mr. Matthews' account of the Roman mob is of more than passing importance. He finds that account unctuous, self-righteous and a greater betrayal of morality than the acts of the mob itself, and attributes Mr. Matthews' perversion of moral judgment to mental confusion.

WITH AMERICAN THIRD ARMY, on the Moselle Front, Oct. 6 -- Fighting so close to the Germans that they can hear their conversations during lulls in the firing, American infantrymen tonight still have a toehold -- but only a toehold -- on Fort Driant, one of the key bastions standing athwart the approach to Metz.
LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Although dealings in securities today showed no expansion, the weekend having a restraining influence, the general tone throughout was steady.

Edward H. Gould's tears and plea that he was not aware he was violating terms of his probation on a stock fraud conviction six years ago brought him only censure yesterday in General Sessions, when Judge John A. Mullen ordered him back to Sing Sing for another ten years.

The Rev. Lucian Gallagher, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis of Assisi, 135 West Thirty-first Street, and guardian of the Franciscan Monastery, which adjoins, will be the deacon at a solemn pontifical mass for members of the armed forces in the church at 10 A.M. today.

State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi announced yesterday the formation of the Medical Practice Committee, which will have jurisdiction over all physicians and surgeons practicing in workmen's compensation cases in New York City with the exception of Richmond County.

WITH THE BRITISH SECOND ARMY, North of Nijmegen, the Netherlands, Oct. 6 -- The Germans around Arnhem and the area westward along the north bank of the Lek River appear to have adopted the same tactics they used in their stubborn attempt to hold Caen.

The Netmar Corporation has sold to Walter J. Everett the three- story residence at 165 East Eightieth Street, with a frontage of 18.9 feet. The purchaser expects to alter the house and occupy it. The M. Morgenthau-Seixas Company acted as brokers.

The people of the city of New York took leave yesterday of their beloved Al Smith. This morning at his funeral he will receive formal tribute from the nation and State that he so ably served and from the church of his abiding faith, but yesterday was reserved for a last farewell from the citizens whom he so proudly represented in his lifetime.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- Pierre Lefauchaux, industrialist, has been named provisional manager of the Renault company whose head was arrested recently and whose property was taken over by the state in a trusteeship, the Government announced today.

Because of the need for more time to investigate certain aspects of the case against Louis F. Weber, 45 years old, said by police to have been the head of the policy racket in Brooklyn several years ago, Magistrate J. Roland Sala, sitting in Coney Island Court, yesterday increased Weber's bail on a charge of disorderly conduct from $1,500 to $5,000 and adjourned sentencing to Oct. 18.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 6 -- It was reported from Haparanda, Swedish-border town opposite Torneaa, today that two Russian destroyers had appeared at Roeyttae off Torneaa. The report is unconfirmed so far. During the day a plane of Russian design was seen over Torneaa making attacks on the Germans.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- A program of severe deflation in Belgium to correct the situation left behind them by the Germans was announced tonight in a broadcast by Camille Gutt, Belgian Minister of Finance. A similar plan has been prepared for France, it is said, but there has been no sign yet of its being made effective.

Here are some fishing definitions that the National Association of Angling and Casting Clubs' committee on tackle terminology prepared for a world that undoubtedly could do without them. They are not guaranteed.

Henri Mondi, South African baritone, was heard in recital last I night in Town Hall. Mr. Mondi, who made his New York debut in the same auditorium in 1941, was heard there again the following year, and then entered the United States Army, from which he was honorably discharged.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Further evidence of improved industrial supplies was presented by the War Production Board today in a series of actions revoking or modifying its restrictions over several metals and materials to assure their unlimited use in the manufacture of new civilian goods under reconversion orders.

LONDON, Oct. 6 (U.P.) -- Canadian First Army troops were playing out the last bloody act of the drama of Dunkerque tonight under a sky turned dull red by the fires and explosions besetting the German garrison trapped in the French Channel port.

ROME, Oct. 6 -- Probably never before in this war has there been a permanent Allied landing in a new country in which there was absolutely no regular transmission or transportation facilities for the press. It is therefore worth recording that only the fact that Walter Lucas, correspondent for The London Daily Express, could ride a horse enabled the bulk of the correspondents' stories to get off after D-day in Greece.

Fluctuations in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange held within a 6-point range all yesterday, and final prices were 2 to 7 points net lower. The market started unchanged to 2 points down, and gradually eased, with distant months relatively weaker than the near contracts because of transferring of hedges from near months to deferred positions.

Five blind veterans, resolutely gay and determined to find out just what they will be able to do to earn their livings, spent yesterday at the Industrial Home for the Blind, 520 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, talking to 162 sightless workers and taking a hand at some of the organization's seventy-five types of machines.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission permitted today the modified plan of reorganization for the Midland United Company and the Midland Utilities Company to be submitted for final approval to the United States District Court for Delaware.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6 -- For the third consecutive week, business in the Pittsburgh district held approximately unchanged, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The volume of trade sagged somewhat, but the decrease was offset by moderate gains in industrial production and in shipments.

Today's Events: Don Cossack Chorus, Metropolitan Opera House, evenings; Nora Fauchald, soprano, and Spinoza Paeff, viola, in Victory Concert, New York Public Library, 5:30 P.M.; Erica Morini, violin, Washington Irving High School, 8:30; "La Traviata," Salmaggi Opera Company, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 6 -- Gen. George C. Marshall arrived in Paris today after a non-stop flight from the United States and conferred immediately with Gen. Dwight Eisenhower and his staff. There was no explanation for the unheralded visit of the Army Chief of Staff, nor for the presence of James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization, in his party.
ROME, Oct. 6 (AP) -- A communique:

Harvesting the best vegetable crop grown at the Thomas Jefferson Park gardens by 300 youngsters hasn't completely convinced 9 1/2-year-old Daniel Cappolo that he wants to be a farmer. "I seem to like it," he admitted, "but there's always baseball and the Yankees."

Bolingbroke, rated the country's top distance horse by his admirers, will have an additional chance at Belmont Park today to prove his ability, as he is entered for the two and a quarter miles of the $25,000 added New York Handicap against five others.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6 -- The Blaw-Knox Company will operate a War Production Board sponsored plant in Philadelphia for the production of packaged fuel that is expected to greatly benefit the anthracite coal industry, it was announced here today.

Letters urging the 186,000 enrolled members of the American Labor party to drop their party membership when they register for this year's election were mailed out yesterday by the Liberal party over the signatures of several former Right Wing ALP officials and others.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National Chairman, declared tonight that the New Deal has exalted to a place of national influence "the nation's most blatant exponents of political corruption and political degeneracy."
One episode in Al Smith's life can now be told, and it deserves perhaps not to go unrecorded.
PARIS, Oct. 6 -- The resistance movement tonight won most of the points it put forward regarding the constitution of the enlarged Consultative Assembly which will meet on Tuesday, Nov. 7.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Saturday, Oct. 7 -- In a second thrust toward the Cologne plain yesterday American First Army infantry pushed nearly one mile more through the forest of Huertgen, twenty miles east of Aachen, to within six miles of the communications center of Dueren, midway between the German border and Cologne.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- Some business men here are worried about what they regard as the risky financial policy of the Government in failing to apply the measures planned at Algiers to block all bank accounts and permit depositors to withdraw only a fixed amount, such as 5,000 francs a month.

Stricken by a streptococcic throat infection three days ago, Wendell L. Willkie, the Republican Presidential candidate in 1940, was still gravely ill last night at Lenox Hill Hospital, but his physician, Dr. Benjamin Salzer, said he could be considered "out of the critical category because he has shown marked signs of improvement."

The New Opera Company's production of "The Merry Widow," which achieved a notable run on Broadway last season, begins an engagement of four weeks this evening at the City Center. Jan Kiepura and Marta Eggerth will appear in their original roles of Prince Danilo and Sonia.

Lucien Carr, the 20-year-old Columbia University engineering school student who last August confessed the slaying of David Krammerer, 33, former teacher of English and physical education in Washington University, St. Louis, was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to Elmira Reformatory for first-degree manslaughter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Preliminary talks on world security were moving today toward a conclusion at Dumbarton Oaks, with a four-power accord on a 90 per cent program for a new international organization.

An appeal to carry the principle of freedom of the press "to every nation of the world" as the best guarantee against future wars was made yesterday by spokesmen for the newspaper publishing industry at the fall meeting of the New York Press Association at the Hotel New Yorker.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 6 -- Hotels throughout the country are in need of tax relief in order to be in a position to provide work in the critical reconversion period, Frank L. Andrews, president of the Hotel New Yorker, New York City, declared in an address before the wartime conference of the Pennsylvania Hotel Association at the Penn-Harris Hotel today.
A communique broadcast yesterday from Tokyo and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

Governor Dewey will devote his second successive major address to answering statements made by President Roosevelt. Just as he revised his Oklahoma City speech to answer the remarks of the President before the Teamsters Union nearly two weeks ago, he will devote his speech tonight to a reply to the President's address to Democratic party workers on Thursday night.

AT A BRITISH AIRFIELD, in the Western Peloponnesus, Oct. 4 (Delayed) -- Over a brooding mountain blocking off this new landing strip on the north, a C-47 transport, which the British call by its original name of DC-3, circled in the moonlight tonight and glided to earth.

Apropos modern variations on Mozart, Ruth Velikovsky wishes to know, "Whoever gave any man permission to sit over another's work and put his own touches around the theme?" Of course, her question cannot be answered; but whoever did give that permission gave it long ago.

Horace Mann launched its football campaign yesterday with a 26-0 setback at the hands of Power Memorial on the losers' gridiron. The visitors showed entirely too much strength along the ground and triumphed handily.

A mysterious yellow substance, present as an impurity in a yellow sodium salt of penicillin, has been found to exert a selective killing effect on mouse cancer cells grown in test tubes, it is reported in the current issue of Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 6 (AP) -- A new Chilean Cabinet, containing only four members of the Cabinet that resigned yesterday, was announced tonight by President Juan Antonio Rios.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Plans for establishment of commercial credit organizations in Latin-American countries to discount paper on United States exporters' sales there and collect from importers in local currencies over periods of a year or more are under discussion between foreign traders here and Latin-American bankers, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Vice, President Wallace is preparing to leave early next week on another and harder campaign trip on behalf of the Roosevelt-Truman ticket. It will keep him away from the capital until just before election day, he told a press conference.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Eric Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, today proposed to Secretary of State Hull that American business men be permitted to go into liberated areas of Europe as rapidly as possible.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 6 -- A new toxoid preparation for treating whooping cough and a method of recovering biotin from industrial fermentation wastes are among the 454 inventions listed in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 6 -- Flowers and horticulture as means of offsetting the grim experience of war was the theme here today at the first State-wide flower show held in New Jersey in recent years. The show, sponsored by the Garden Club of New Jersey, attracted more than 200 exhibits and 1,000 spectators to the Orange Lawn Tennis Club. It will be concluded tomorrow.

Active enforcement of New York State's Equal Pay law, which provides that no employer may discriminate in rates of pay because of sex, is now being carried out, following a three-month period of readjustment allowed to industries since the law became effective July 1, Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi reported yesterday.
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 6 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

ROME, Saturday, Oct. 7 -- Allied invasion forces were reported early today pouring into Albania, Greece and half a dozen islands far up the Aegean, threatening the German garrison in Athens with a pincers closing from the Peloponnesus and near-by Andros Island.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Pan American Airways, Inc., contended before the Civil Aeronautics Board today that its pioneering of air service in Latin America should entitle it to a post-war position as the exclusive American flag aerial carrier between North and South America.

More than half the babies now being adopted in New York City are the victims of short-notice, informal and sometimes commercialized adoption methods, experts in the field of child welfare said yesterday. Warning against the dangers, to mothers and foster parents alike, of the so-called "person-to-person" adoption, directors of several long-established agencies said that by no means all of the people who arrange these adoptions are engaged in a "baby trade."
DON'T be misled by the inconsequential title.* This is not an inconsequential book. It has imperishable stuff in it. No sensitive reader should miss it.
ALBANY, Oct. 6 -- Governor Dewey has appointed an advisory committee on technical industrial development to help bring information on new products, processes and materials to State business men.
In a discussion of gaps or gulfs there are two quantitative factors to be considered. One is the width of the gap itself. The second is what lies on either side of the gap.

More than 300 churches of all faiths in the Third Naval District, which includes the New York area, will receive tomorrow special honor certificates and messages from James Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy, for releasing their pastors to serve as chaplains.

Remember the old scissors grinder -- or was that before your day? There were several of them that used to come through our town when I was a small boy. One of them had an elaborate four-wheel cart with the machine supported inside, where he could see and work in comfort. The one I knew best was "Old Nat."

A memorial urging prompt repeal of the "greenback" law of 1933 and certain provisions of the Gold Reserve Act of 1934, which among other things gives the President the right to fix the prices of gold and silver, within certain limits, was addressed yesterday, to all members of and candidates for Congress by fifty-eight members of the Economists' National Committee on Monetary Policy.

The Appellate Division yesterday unanimously upheld the right of Mrs. Doris Duke Cromwell, tobacco heiress, to examine Frank Cadwell, a doorman of 969 Fifth Avenue, who had previously testified in a New Jersey divorce proceeding brought by her former husband, James H.R. Cromwell, that he saw her in New York in September, 1943, when she was supposedly in Reno, Nev., obtaining a divorce.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 (AP) -- A fast, alert Holy Cross eleven that Could do everything but kick points after touchdowns completely outclassed Temple University's youngsters tonight for a 30-0 football victory at Temple Stadium.

There will be more than passing interest in the recent demonstration off the New Jersey coast of the Navy's Air Rescue School, based at the Naval Air Station at Lakehurst. The development of sea-rescue devices in such variety and of such effectiveness, proceeding hand in hand with the development of combat weapons, points up the whole theory of our armed services with regard to personnel.

LONDON, Saturday, Oct. 7 -- Russian troops have invaded Hungary on a seventy-three mile front, pushing to within 102 miles of Budapest, the capital, and thirteen miles from Szeged, the country's second city, in a drive to knock Hitler's last big Balkan satellite out of the war, Moscow announced last night.

WILTON, Conn., Oct. 6 -- Miss Margaret Connors, Democratic candidate for the House of Representatives against Representative Clare Boothe Luce, advocated tonight an international peace organization comprising all the nations of the world and having power to use "military, political and economic force wherever necessary," and criticized her Republican opponent as a "pre-election" convert to the idea of a world peace organization.

Enthusiasts say that the personal aircraft is now like the 1919 automobile. It needs landing facilities, just as the automobile of 1919 needed good roads for mass development as an industry. If the New York metropolitan community invests in airplanes in the same proportion as it invested in automobiles, the problem will soon be acute.

LONDON, Oct. 6--The Netherlands is faced with the greatest disaster by flood and famine she has ever known, and the next few weeks will decide whether she will be able to continue to play her part in the world of the future as a modern civilized nation, Prime Minister Pieter S. Gerbrandy said today.
The following proclamation was issued yesterday by Governor Dewey:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Oct. 6 -- The Japanese have employed fighting dogs against United States troops, it was officially disclosed today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

TALLINN, Estonia, Oct. 5 (Delayed) -- The Soviet Estonian Government has no intention at present of collectivizing farming, but intends to carry out a program of nationalizing -- without compensation to present owners -- of all industries employing more than ten persons in its newest republic.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 6 (AP)--The triumphant Browns, leading the Cardinals 2 games to 1, in the world series, are about convinced they are over the hump, but they're not saying so.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Elizabeth Arden, Inc., 681 Fifth Avenue, New York City, was ordered today by the Federal Trade Commission to end discriminatory practices among retail customers of the firm's cosmetics, in violation of the Robinson-Patman Act, by offering certain purchasers demonstrator services which are denied to other retailers.

College football comes up with no less than three games in New York today on a program that includes two important Ivy League clashes at New Haven and Philadelphia, a heavy schedule for Western Conference teams and attractive listings throughout the nation.

BOSTON, Oct. 6 -- Sponsored by the Communist Political Association of Massachusetts, the musical revue, variously titled as "The People's Bandwagon," "F.D.R. Victory Bandwagon" and "New World A-Comin,' " opened tonight to a capacity audience of more than 2,500 in Symphony Hall.

Home canners are being warned by the United States Department of Agriculture not to pile glass containers of food double-deck style, since this weakens or breaks seals. Storing tin cans in this fashion is countenanced, however.

ROME, Oct. 6 -- In rain, mud and even snow that hampered their drive toward the Po Valley, Americans of the Fifth Army took Loiano, important big communications center fourteen miles below Bologna, and drove north of Mount Verene to capture Mozuno, three miles west of Loiano.

Lou Little's young Columbia football team, which opened its season auspiciously last Saturday with a one-sided triumph over Union, faces a much tougher task this afternoon at Baker Field, where it tackles Syracuse in a game scheduled to start at 3 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6--The final case in organized labor's assault on the national wage stabilization policy, which may affect 1,000,000 cotton textile and rayon employes, was argued before the National War Labor Board today.

The Citizens Union, in its Bronx section of the annual voters' directory, declared yesterday that all three State Senators from that county and four of the six Assemblymen who are seeking re-election had made commendable records in the last session of the Legislature.

" My Pale, Wolf," the story of a little girl and her dog, will open this morning at the Republic Theatre. Sharyn Moffett, a 7-year- old newcomer, is the girl, and the adult members of the cast are Jill Esmond, Una O'Connor, George Cleveland and Charles Arnt. The film was produced by RKO-Radio Pictures. . . .

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- More than 46,000,000 pounds of military cargo, including gasoline, munitions, trucks, jeeps and other war materials, were flown across the Himalaya "hump" in one recent month by the India-China Division of the Army Air Force Air Transport Command, the War Department announced today.

The extent of President Roosevelt's further personal participation in the campaign for his re-election became a matter of mystery and conjecture yesterday as the White House declared that he had scheduled no further speeches to follow the radio address he delivered from Washington to Democratic party workers on Thursday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Women are not as sure footed as men, and for that reason falls accounts for the largest number of accidents to women working for the air technical service command, Mrs. Ann M. Fox, safety director of the 100,000 women in that organization reported today.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- At a landing field fifteen miles southwest of Paris nine of us, including three French and three American officers, were squeezed into a military command car with six sacks of important mail and a huge pile of assorted luggage. In ordinary times we would have been an arresting sight.

Noramy Realty Corporation has purchased two plots of land on Meadow Lane, near Kenridge Road, Lawrence, L. I., on which it plans to erect one-family houses as soon as conditions permit. One parcel, of about four and one-half acres, was bought from the Riverhead Savings Bank, and the adjoining lot, of about two and one-half acres, from Emilie La Montagne.

PARIS, Oct 6 -- Eight American soldiers were hanged by the Germans in Compiegne Forest, northwest of Paris, according to officers of the French Forces of the Interior, whose patrols are still scouring that area.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 6 -- Count Friedrich Werner von der Schulenburg, the last German Ambassador to Moscow and one of the creators of the Russian-German nonaggression pact of August, 1939, has been liquidated, according to a report received here.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- Lucien Lelong's opening today revealed models differing widely from those of other couturiers. His coats and gowns are longer in back than in front; his belts are draped widely around the hips and are tied in back with long ends falling below the bottom of the frock.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Oct. 6 -- The Ranger Aircraft Engine Division of the Fairchild Engine and Aircraft Corporation announced here today the production of a 700-horsepower in-line air-cooled aircraft engine which officials claim to be productive of the largest horsepower per unit of weight and frontal area yet devised.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The strong fight made by German troops on the Western Front may force the War Production Board to revise its program for reconverting industry to peacetime activity.

Thomas J. Curran, Secretary of State and Republican candidate for the United States Senate, stressed in an address yesterday that religious intolerance and racial prejudice have no place in this country, now or in the future.

The number of cases of allegedly delinquent and neglected children handled by the Children's Division of the Domestic Relations Court still is on the increase, the monthly report of the division indicated yesterday.

The war in the Pacific for many weary months has been like a new business in which the profits have had to be plowed back. Only recently have the blood and sweat and tears expended begun to pay real dividends in the form of crippling attacks on the Japanese war potential of factories and oil resources.

The National Society of Mural Painters yesterday learned the address of Corp. Frank Duncan Jr., who won a prize of $100 in the exhibition of mural paintings at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street, arranged by the society in collaboration with Artists for Victory, Inc.

LONDON, Saturday, Oct. 7 (U.P.) -- Taking advantage of a late-rising moon in an effort to evade British night fighters, German pick-a-back planes launched two brief flying bomb assaults on London and other parts of southern England last night, the second in a row.

CHUNGKING, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Reinforced Japanese have reached the northwestern suburbs of Foochow, last Chinese-held major port on the east China coast, in their drive to forestall American landings from the Pacific, the Chinese High Command announced tonight. The fall of the city seemed imminent.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS,New Guinea, Saturday, Oct. 7 (AP) -- A communique:

Opposition to the reorganization plan of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad has developed among the holders of the company's 5 per cent convertible adjustment bonds. Recently the Interstate Commerce Commission ordered that the plan be submitted to the bondholders for acceptance or rejection.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Perfection of a 2,000,000-volt mobile X-ray machine which will take pictures through a foot of steel was announced today by Dr. Ernest E. Charlton of the research laboratory of the General Electric Company, who addressed the National Electronics Conference.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 6 (UP) -- Algiers, owned by E.J. Baker, St. Charles, Ill., won the feature $3,000 Lexington Herald-Leader Stake for 2-year-old trotters on today's Grand Circuit racing program. He scored in two straight heats.

Duell, Sloan Pearce celebrates its fifth anniversary today. Since its inception Oct. 7, 1939, the firm has published 295 books, 55 of fiction, 194 non-fiction, 46 mysteries. In addition it has distributed twenty-six titles issued by its affiliated house, Essential Books. The first book published by the firm was Archibald MacLeish's "America Was Promises."

Plans for a forty-five-story office building to be erected at 110-22 Broad Street, 16 Front Street and 15 Water Street were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings by Gerry Estates, Inc., of 270 Broadway, of which Robert L. Gerry is president.

FARGO, N.D., Oct. 6 -- With the State's underlying devotion to the Republican party label accentuated by a growing list of grievances against the New Deal, North Dakota seems all set to give its four electoral votes to Governor Dewey on Nov. 7, with a majority perhaps proportionately larger than it gave Wendell L. Willkie four years ago.

With the progressive liberation of Europe from the Germans, opportunities for aiding Jews there have multiplied, necessitating increased expenditures by the agencies of the United Jewish Appeal, 342 Madison Avenue. the organization reported yesterday.

WITH THE AMERICAN FIRST ARMY, in Germany, Oct. 6 -- American tanks fought their way down shell-torn roads into the outskirts of Geilenkirchen late today on the northern end of the six-mile front that Lieut. Gen. Courtney H. Hodges' American First Army has painfully hacked out beyond the Siegfried Line.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 6 -- Representatives of veterans' organizations have agreed to hold "no big parades in any downtown areas" of New Jersey cities on V-E Day, R. Graham Huntington, State American Legion commander, said tonight.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The play-by-play description of the third game of the world series at Sports-man's Park today follows:
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Governor Bricker, attacking "government by secrecy," declared tonight that "no one knows" how deeply President Roosevelt had involved this country in secret agreements.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 6 -- The possibility that Allied "procrastination" may throw Poland into the arms of the Reich is described as very real by neutral political and diplomatic observers in Berlin tonight.

No great consumer group is "more misunderstood, underestimated and neglected by some advertisers" than the farm market, Julian Snyder, vice president and director of Erwin-Wasey Co., said at a recent luncheon meeting of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Sheraton.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 6 -- Sonny Tufts has been set by Paramount for a co-starring lead with Betty Hutton in the proposed comedy, "Too Good to Be True," which will be based on a story by Harry Tugend about a showgirl who confesses to a murder in order to give her attorney-husband criminal court experience.
LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 6 -- After nearly a month of freedom from Nazi domination, Luxembourg now begins to return to a normality unknown in the small picturesque tourist country for four years.
LONDON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe Communique:

Financing for public utility companies featured offerings of new bonds to the public here this week. Of a total of $75,627,000 in five issues marketed, $61,500,000 was for two electric light and power companies, $10,000,000 was for an industrial concern and $4,127,000 was for two municipalities.

The two-story taxpayer building at 216 Westchester Avenue, Port Chester, N.Y., containing two stores and fourteen offices, has been sold by Morris Jones to A. Block. The property, assessed at $60,000, was purchased for cash above a ten-year mortgage of $38,500 held by the Home Life Insurance Company.

A survey of New York City butter receipts by the Regional Office of Price Administration shows that this community has been getting its proper share of the limited supply, Daniel P. Woolley, Regional OPA Administrator, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6--President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull hailed the beginning of the liberation of Greece today and paid tribute to the courage that nation has displayed under aggression and attempted enslavement by the Nazis.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Louisville battery of Pitcher Jim Wilson and Catcher Fred Walters defeated Baltimore, 5 to 3, tonight before 11,435 attending the little world series opener.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 6 (AP) - -Seven persons in an estimated crowd of 7,500 at Laurel Park today collected the daily double payoff of $2,908 for $2, largest in Maryland in nearly three years.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- In a cloudless sky over Berlin today the United States Eighth Air Force fought another great battle with the Luftwaffe while giving the battered German capital its 168th bombing as part of an operation that sent more than 1,200 heavy bombers and 1,000 escorting fighters to hammer German war factories and oil plants.

DULUTH, Minn., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Governor Bricker, Republican nominee for Vice President, said tonight that President Roosevelt had declared the existence of a "national emergency" fifty-nine times as reason for Government actions.

Brisk consumer demand for many items of seasonal merchandise featured retail trade here last week. Women's apparel and accessories, together with home wares, were active, while buying of gifts for servicemen overseas approached its peak. Estimates indicated department store volume ran 20 per cent or more ahead of last year.

LUBRICATING creams are true beauty creams. For the dry skin they, more than any other cream, make a real transformation in the quality of the skin -- smoothing out the lines caused by dryness, softening the tiny particles of loose skin that give it a rough, scaly appearance, substituting a soft, supple look for the drawn, taut look so common in dry skin conditions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- That the rural schools of this country are facing a crisis, suffering not only as a result of the war but from "chronic ills" of long standing, became apparent this week when 200 experts analyzed and explored the many problems in this area at an unprecedented White House Conference on Rural Education.
PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Marines and soldiers invading the Palaus have killed 12,211 Japanese and captured 224 since Sept. 15, day of the landings, the Navy announced today.

ROME, Oct. 7 -- Drive all night across the bleak spine of Italy en route from Bari to Rome and more than ever you sense the corrosive impact of the war upon the country that changed sides a year ago and is generally regarded to be doing its best in the inconclusive role of "co-belligerent" which it assumed last Oct. 13.

Dr. Theodore S. Wilder presented last week before the American Public Health Association the results of a twelve-year study of transmissible diseases in the Germantown Friends School, which numbers 600 pupils. He found that ultra-violet lamps in classrooms protected pupils markedly against cross-infection in cases of measles, mumps, chickenpox and colds.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Wheat broke 1/2 to 3/4 cent a bushel in the early trading today on the Board of Trade as the result of increased country offerings of cash wheat in the Southwest. Grain men here from Kansas City said buyers could get all of the grain that they wanted if they were willing to pay ceiling prices.

MR. HOPEWELL has recently been deeply perplexed. An early convert to the idea of collectivism, a conscientious student of "Das Kapital," long conversant with the nuances of Marxian dialectics, he has suddenly discovered that he has no clear picture in his mind's eye of what a socialist commonwealth would be like.

THE confusion which is normal to economics and politics expands to minor chaos in this novel of Canada's Government intelligentsia. The characters are all part of a huge disquiet. They open their mouths and gusts of rhetoric come howling out, they scream against each other like good friends in a madhouse.

The cherry bloom brushed wet aqainst my face, I swung the great door open and pushed deep Into the barn's hushed gloom, seeking A season's tool -- a trowel perhaps -- and there Waited the little car. Across the back In rollicking red letters, this: Excuse My Dust.

AFTER a somewhat casual early season, the theatre celebrated the arrival of last week's colder weather by letting fly with practically every arrow in the sheaf. Of course, five openings were nothing back in 1927, when once there were eleven on one day, but this is seventeen years later and five in a week is to all intents and purposes the millennium.

IN Portland, Me., a political worker goes from door to door leaving a few earnest words and a pamphlet or two at each stop. He is one of some 2,000,000 party workers enlisted under the banners of President Franklin D. Roosevelt or Gov. Thomas E. Dewey.

PARIS, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Countess Henri de Maublanc, a sister of Elizabeth Arden of New York, said today that she had taken many risks to aid Allied aviators shot down over France in the hope that some mother somewhere would also help her American aviator son if he should ever need aid.

What may become a pattern for work with veterans returning to college has been set by Colgate University in connection with its job of preparing men for midshipmen schools through its Navy Academic Refresher Unit, established recently as one of three in the nation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Guillermo Sevilla Sacasa, Nicaraguan Ambassador, denied today that there had been any recent uprisings, either small or large, within Nicaraguan territory.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Sunday, Oct. 8 -- American tanks and infantry bowled over German resistance yesterday in a further two-mile plunge through the Westwall north of Aachen, which is now threatened with isolation from the rest of Germany by the sweeping encirclement.

LONDON, Sunday, Oct. 8 -- Russian motorized infantry, racing across the sea-level Hungarian plains on a seventy-six-mile front, yesterday battled to within eighty-three miles of Budapest in a spectacular twenty-nine-mile advance through enemy defenses.

MR. BRAILSFORD, in articles which he wrote at the end of the last war, accused the Allies of basing their peace terms on moral, strategic, political, but not economic considerations, and the French of pursuing their goal of "hegemony" with ruthless logic.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 7 -- About 5,500 Allied planes from British and Italian bases struck the German war machine paralyzing blows today as the greatest air offensive yet launched carried through its third day without a pause.

A GENERATION ago there were a popular notion that a good piece of furniture must be made of solid wood. Veneer was scorned as a devilish invention of the early manufacturers of machine-made furniture, who did indeed make use of it to hide badly joined lumber.

BROADWAY last week had its premiere of "Bloomer Girl," with all the accoutrements befitting the town's newest smash, but over on a strange street called Madison Avenue there was an event that may be the longer remembered. It was the premiere on Station WABD of "The Boys From Boise," the first full-length musical comedy to be written especially for the burgeoning television art.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 7 (AP) -- A jurisdictional dispute between rival AFL unions drew more than 100 workers from the Paramount Pictures Corporation today, third major movie studio to be involved in the controversy.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The twenty-sixth annual fall golf tournament will get under way tomorrow with the playing of the qualifying round of eighteen holes of medal play. Match play will continue from Tuesday through Friday, with the finals on Saturday. All matches will be played on the Cascades Course.

STOCKING the pantry for the fall and winter should be a pleasant task this season. For even though such things as fresh butter, succulent steaks and pineapple juice may be scarce, delicacy shops have plenty of other enticing products to offer.

CARUTHERSVILLE, Mo., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Senator Truman, Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, accused the Republican standard bearers today of "demogoguery and chicanery" in current campaign speeches and said that it would be serious and dangerous "to take a chance on creating distrust with our allies by placing an inexperienced leader" in the White House.

THE Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Eugene Goossens, will open its Golden Jubilee season Friday afternoon and Saturday night in Cincinnati with a Beethoven program composed of the Eighth and Ninth symphonies. In the latter work the May Festival Chorus of Cincinnati will assist and the soloists will be Florence Kirk, Anna Kaskas, John Dudley and Gean Greenwell.

Columbia required some time to get started in its football game with Syracuse at Baker Field yesterday. Once the Lions got rolling, however, they had things their own way and went on to score a 26-to-2 triumph over their up-State rivals.

A NEW type of glass screen which is said to give third dimensional effect to ordinary motion-picture images without the viewer having to employ stereopticon aids, such as colored glasses, has been introduced in Moscow.

THIS vividly written hook reviews the history of nine major wars of the last 150 years, from the American Revolution to World War I, analyzing the factors which determined their end and brought about peace. It does not lead to any definite conclusions nor does it venture any prophecy as to when or how the present war will end.

APPARENTLY the picture "The Great John L." is going to introduce any number of novelties to the American screen. First, of course, it will introduce Bing Crosby as a producer and it will introduce Greg McClure as a leading man.

Last week it was revealed that Allied fighting men stood once more on the soil of Greece. British units, their movements screened at first by censorship, had landed at various points on the southern and western coasts of the mountainous peninsula and pressed rapidly inland.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Muhlenberg College, seeking revenge for two beatings at the hands of Swarthmore last year, pounded out a 33-6 decision over Swarthmore today for its first victory of the season.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 7 -- The big fellow in this 1944 world series finally got angry today with the result that our doughty Browns suffered what usually happens to the little fellow when he hasn't quite the class to make it an even battle.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Long runs and a supply of reserves led Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's football warriors today to a 27-14 victory over Union College.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 7 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. declared today that the Sixth War Loan, which will get under way on Nov. 20, definitely would not be the last, regardless of "extremely good" war news.

AMERICANS in seaboard cities have long been swiveling their heads around at the sight of unfamiliar uniforms. If they are alert enough and informed enough they may identify the dress or the insignia. Then the question that leaps to the mind is: "What in the world is the Norwegian Navy?" -- or the Belgian, or Polish or Netherlands Navy?

Retail trade was active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floor departments were busy and there was a good call for dresses, coats and suits.
ON THE ITALIAN FRONT, Oct. 7 -- Winter is back at the Italian battlefront where we left it last year, though the calendar only calls it fall.

Registration of voters in New York City, which starts tomorrow and continues all week, is being closely watched this year for a clue to the size of the national Presidential vote. In most other States registration is on a permanent or semi-permanent basis but in New York annual registration is required in all cities and villages of 5,000 or more and the results are a good barometer of the intensity of political feeling.

A converted jumper yesterday brought off another topsy turvy result at Belmont Park when the Brookmeade Stable's Caribou captured the $27,600 New York Handicap at the expense of Bolingbroke, star of the country's distance runners.

THE thirteen short stories of "Sea Duty" are by a magazine correspondent attached to various units of the United States Pacific Battle Fleet since the spring of 1942. They convey a vivid and unquestionably authentic picture of men, individual men, engaged in floating warfare in a vast area from which have come many terse communiques, occasional fragments of searing human drama, but few comprehensive interpretations of the total, day-to-day naval effort.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Pitt's Panthers, bouncing back from a 58-0 defeat by Notre Dame, shoved over touchdowns in every quarter today to trample little Bethany College of West Virginia, 50 to 13. Only 1,500 fans saw the game, perhaps the smallest crowd in Pitt football history.

With little more than a month of the Presidential campaign remaining, the minds of party workers and political observers last week were on the "independent" voter. One school of thought says the independent has already made up his mind, that no speeches or interjections of new issues are going to change it now.

DETROIT, Oct. 7 -- Detroit faced this week one of the most serious labor threats of the war -- serious not only because of the potential number of workers involved, but also because of its effect on the war effort at a crucial time.

ROME, Oct. 7 -- Mediterranean Allied headquarters put an official stamp today on what became increasingly obvious in the Peloponnesan campaign in Greece last week after the German garrison had been driven from Patras -- that "a great part of the Peloponnesus may now be considered clear of the Germans."

THE espalier or dwarf fruit tree, trained to grow in a specific shape, is well worth consideration for both amateur and professionally managed gardens. Their size recommends them for the small garden, and they are also decorative and useful in the large garden. Espaliers are beautiful when in flower and yield a good supply of fruit.

The annual Pulaski Day parade up Fifth Avenue today "will be a demonstration of protest against the unfair and un-American treatment which Poland is receiving from her allies," John A. Pateracki, president of the General Pulaski Memorial Committee of 287 Fourth Avenue, sponsor of the event, declared last night.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 7 -- The American-type breakfast, which a few days ago made the front pages of newspapers here, is another of those American institutions, like moving pictures, that will bring Brazilians and Americans closer together.

WITH AMERICAN FIRST ARMY, in Germany, Oct. 7 -- A series of hard-hitting American attacks broke the crust of German resistance north of Aachen today and the tide of battle rolled forward toward the Rhine after forty-eight hours of frustration and blood.

UNTIL Aug. 7, 1942, probably not more than a few hundred persons in the United States, in addition to Osa and Martin Johnson, ever had heard of the Solomon Islands or, if they had, were more than vaguely aware as to where they were, or what manner of people occupied them.

UNTIL frost comes the pink and white procession of autumn windflowers goes on. The inimitable grace of its blossom cups filled with shining gold stamens, swaying on two or three-foot stems, is enough to give pause for admiration. Though the actual planting of this Anemone japonica is best done in spring, now is the time to decide upon the kinds.

A "sky-hook," developed by the Material Command, Wright Field, floats to earth like the winged seed of the maple tree. When the sky-hook is released it begins to spin down without forward motion. Various models can drop loads of medicine and food ranging in weight from ounces up to 100 pounds.

IN or out of official life, birthdays have disconcerting habit of sneaking up on one. Because she is among the relatively few who view them with equanimity if not with glee, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt is characteristically undismayed by the sixtieth milestone which she will reach on Wednesday next.

HAVANA, Oct. 7 (U.P.) -- Gen. Fulgencio Batista, the President who gave Cuba her first clean elections in thirty years, pleaded today, on the eve of his retirement from the Presidency and his departure for a continental tour, that all peace-loving nations should not allow the emotion of victory to confound them in their efforts to establish a lasting peace.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Oct. 7 (AP) -- British West African patrols have made contact with reinforced Japanese who penetrated two miles inside Bengal in India, a headquarters spokesman announced tonight.

BOSTON, Oct. 7 -- No practice air raid warning or Federal post-war plan has alerted New England leaders so completely as has a Senate committee's suggestion this week to hold back industrial reconversion in Government-owned plants in eleven Northeastern States to permit the South and West to expand their post-war industry.

ALBANY, Oct. 7 -- Governor Dewey today designated Oct. 8-14 National Business Women's Week, issuing a proclamation in which he called on women to "assume a greater share in the duties and responsibilities of government."

The first touch of Indian summer favored New York yesterday, sending the mercury to a record high for the date of 83 degrees at 3:15 P.M. The day was decidedly humid, the reading at 8 A.M. being 100 per cent. By noon it had dropped to 70 and remained in the fifties throughout the afternoon.

HAVING conquered the land, Michael Todd is now preparing to tackle the water. His preparations were launched here the other day during a Teheran kind of conference with Billy Bryant, the showboat impresario.

ESTONIA, Tallinn, Oct. 1 (Delayed) -- Senior Petty Officer Oleg S. Myasoyedoff, 21 years old, skipper of the Red Fleet's smallest craft, sent a message of thanks to President Roosevelt today for his United States Distinguished Service Medal and then, turning his grease-stained back on correspondents, began to resume his preparations for an amphibious assault on German-held Oesel island commanding the Gulf of Riga.

According to War Shipping Administration statistics, 14,000,000 cubic yards of additional cargo space were obtained last year by the use of deck space for cargo and the filling of available under-deck space on vessels passing through this port for convoy assembly.

AS if in response not only to prospects of a longer war in Europe but also to forecasts of rather severe results upon employment and business activity if drastic cutbacks in war production are ordered abruptly, it became known at the close of the week that the War Production Board has apparently shifted to a new plan for reconversion.

A COMPARISON of the two extant versions of "Jacobowsky and the Colonel" such as that made by Winifred Smith in your column of Sept. 24 invites an answer and an argument. A line-by-line comparison of the two printed works might give weight to Miss Smith's concern, but a few actual performances of the present version make a strong case for Behrman's changes.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Oct. 7 -- Budda of Arden, Labrador retriever bitch, owned and handled by Mrs. Edmund W. Poor of Bay Shore, today won the open stake in the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club meet through the covers and adjacent waters of the estate of Charles L. Lawrance.

It is getting on to Columbus Day, a holiday which gains in popular observance with the passing years. This is rather odd, because with every year that passes, Christopher Columbus himself seems to be losing favor with the scholars who write popular histories of the United States.

With prospects of victory over Germany before the year's end dimming rapidly, the War Production Board's "spot authorization plan" will play a much more important part in the reconversion of industry to peacetime production than had been expected after the spectacular announcement early last month by WPB chairman J.A. Krug that virtually all controls will be lifted on V-E day, manufacturers stated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- President Roosevelt will speak at a dinner of the Foreign Policy Association in New York on Oct. 21. The function is to be held for the purpose of bringing "to the attention of the citizens of this country the important issues of foreign policy."

SOUTH AMERICANS, when they want to provoke their Argentine friends, sometimes refer to them as the Yankees of Latin America. This infuriates the Argentines no end; it causes them to go into long explanations of what they choose to call basic differences, most of these revolving around the idea that the Norteamericanos have no soul, while they themselves, being Latins, understand the deeper things of life.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- As weeks go by without a Russian answer to the Polish Government's memorandum for settlement of the "Polish question" the feeling is becoming stronger here that a solution cannot be reached by bilateral negotiation and will involve British and American intervention.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 7(AP) -- A new enemy landing southeast of Foochow, already the target of a swift advance of Japanese invasion forces from the northwest, was reported tonight by the Chinese High Command.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Bucknell's Navy and Marine trainees played amphiibous football on a rain-drenched field today to edge out Franklin and Marshall, 16 -- 13, for their third victory in four games.
