KWEILIN, China, Oct. 7 (U.P.) -- This ancient city, known as the Paris of China, has been turned into a sea of flame in the past twenty-four hours as Japanese forces advanced down the Hunan-Kwangsi railway.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Bob David's extra-point kick gave Villanova its margin of victory over the Sampson Naval Training Center before 10,000 at Shibe Park tonight. The score was 7 -- 6.

THE Mayflower boy was Giles Hopkins, big brother to that little Oceanus whom we remember from the first stories we ever heard of the Mayflower. It is through his 15-year-old eyes that we see that first year of the Pilgrims in the New World.

The campaign of the New York War Fund for $17,200,000 for thirty-one member agencies, including the United Service Organizations, the United Seamen's Service and War Prisoners Aid, will receive added impetus from the commerce and industry division, whose 5,000 volunteer workers have been assigned a quota of $12,130,000, it was announced yesterday by Richard W. Lawrence, president of the Bankers Commercial Corporation and general chairman of the campaign.

IN 1942 the Cortes Society began the publication of a new series of "Documents and Narratives Concerning the Discovery and Conquest of Latin America." The first dealt with the discovery of Yucatan; the second with that of New Spain. The present volume, the third, deals with the conquest of Mexico and the life of its Conquistador from birth to the moment when he has reached the summit of his power.

Gaining almost at will from its T-formation. Brooklyn College yesterday overwhelmed C.C.N.Y. by 37 -- 0, the most emphatic beating and the highest score in the fifteen contests the two interborough rivals have waged.

The West came to Forty-fourth Street yesterday, where for seventy-five minutes Roy Rogers, the Riders of the Purple Sage, and four other guest performers staged a "Cowboys and Indians" show for 500 youngsters.

The Pan-American Club and the Faculty-Student Political Committee at Smith College are sponsoring a two-day open forum on Pan-American affairs beginning Oct. 13. The forum will deal with the political, economic and cultural problems of inter-American relations.

MOST of the leading players have played bridge several thousand times and have encountered several hundred thousand different bridge hands. It would seem that with this vast experience they would never be unsure of the conventional meaning of any bidding situation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7 -- Farmers and ranchers along the Pacific Coast are beginning to hunt for post-war crops, just as industrial workers are seeking post-war jobs. A series of meetings has been held during the last few weeks by farmer-committeemen of the Agricultural Adjustment Agency.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 7 -- A game of "soldier" played with a sixty-year-old muzzle-loading shotgun that had not been fired in at least thirty years, ended this forenoon with the death of James Hayward, 6 years old, when the gun, held by Jimmy's brother, William Jr., 15, went off. The charge of 200 pellets struck the younger boy in the face, neck and left shoulder.

If Edward H. Bunnell, vice president of the Association of American Railroads, is a good prophet the day is not far off when a new machine will print railway tickets while you wait. Railway ticket offices will no longer have to keep racks of tickets on hand.

IT is hard for one who has lived through "The Saturdays" with the Melendys and helped them settle into "The Four Story Mistake" to say anything really new about those four brothers and sisters. Admiration and affection are now taken for granted and the best news is that they are still very much themselves, only more so, for these children really grow in their various interests.

SOMETHING in the nature of an esthetic portmanteau is called for to bring together the numerous group and one-man shows which arrived last week on Fifty-seventh Street and spread into its environs. Only sculpture seemed to be missing from the inventory.

ATLANTA, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Georgia Tech showed only spasmodic brilliance today, but four of the flashes led to touchdowns, three through the air, and a fighting North Carolina eleven went down, 28 -- 0, in a much better game than the score indicates.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 7 -- Louisianians still remain unusually apathetic toward the national election in November, and the same situation is reported to exist in adjoining States. Leaders of both major political parties seem unable to arouse interest in their candidates.

A WELL-WORN admonition often given hopeful authors is to write about what they know. The advice is still good, and given Feike Feikema's talent, his lean, prodding prose, his knowing feel for the land, you get a moving, well-done first novel like "The Golden Bowl."

WITH the publication of the third volume of "Lee's Lieutenants," Douglas Freeman completes one of the greatest individual achievements in the field of military biography. His scholarly four-volume "R.E. Lee" (1934), into which he put eighteen years of research and writing, did full justice to the commander of the Army of Northern Virginia.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Apparel merchants, through their trade associations, today threatened to carry their criticisms of amended OPA maximum price regulations 330 to the Emergency Court of Appeals, or before Congress, according to Joseph T. Meek, executive secretary of Illinois Federation of Retail Associations.

PIXYISH spikes of Wedgwood-blue bloom in April are what come of setting grape hyacinth bulbs three inches deep in the garden this month. For a preview of their spring performance a few can be started indoors to make February-blooming house plants.

On the side of a hill in Old Calvary Cemetery in Long Island City, Queens, just across the Brooklyn line from Greenpoint, Alfred Emanuel Smith was laid to rest yesterday afternoon under the warming rays of a benign Indian summer sun. His coffin was lowered into a simple grave beside that of his wife, Catherine Dunn Smith, in the family plot designated by a plain stone slab inscribed "Smith-Glynn."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Playing in spurts, Ohio State's Buckeyes racked up their second straight football victory and their first of the Western Conference season today with a 34-to-0 conquest of Iowa's badly outmanned Hawkeyes.

Much has been said about the post-war era. No world planners, those interested in fish and game conservation nevertheless are concerned in their own sphere and emphasize with logic that the pressure on forest and streams will be tremendous "when Johnny comes marching home."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- William H. Stanley's International Class sloop Bumble Bee, sailed by Arthur Knapp to the championship during the summer, today took her second race in the third post-season regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Judging from the advertisements, the country has gone diamond mad. Dealers plead for the stones, and presumably so much money is being made that everybody wants to prove it by wearing a sparkler. The truth is that, though we are buying more than the usual amount of gems (so are Canada, South America and the East), the market for what the trade calls "gem stones" is restricted.

Mozart: Quartet No. 16 in E-Flat (K.428). The Busch Quartet (Columbia, album M-MM-529, four twelve-inch records.) This is a satisfying performance which relies more on sturdy musicianship than on brilliance of tone and execution. It is strong, authoritative playing, though the emotional content of the work is, if anything, overstressed.

LONDON, Oct. 7 (U.P.) -- Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch, former War Minister in the Yugoslav Cabinet, has fled from Serbia, now virtually controlled by the Yugoslav Partisans or by Russian troops, into the Bosnian hills, a broadcast by the Free Yugoslav radio said today.

SINCLAIR marched stiffly away in that brisk manner, and he did not look back. Sinclair had gone; but chance had added Sinclair to his store of riches, anyhow, though no bank manager would look at that credit. Perhaps additions to good fortune were always so, imponderable, unaccountable, and of no use to anyone.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Officials of the Maritime Commission and War Shipping Administration spoke in highest praise today of the contribution made to the war shipping program of the United States by Henri Morin de Linclays, director of the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique, or French Line, in this country since 1933, who recently has been under criticism in New York by certain French officials.

LEOPOLD STOKOWSKI, who his made a specialty of concert-hall innovations, has several new schemes for the New York City Symphony Orchestra, which begins its season at the City Center tomorrow evening. First of all, the traditional first and second violin sections will be blended into one group of nineteen violinists who will sit together on the stage.

GUY BATES POST, a veteran of the stage and screen, a favorite even before World War I, is coming back to Broadway. Mr. Post and a group of friends have acquired the rights to a new play by Jack Preston of Hollywood, "Good Morning, My Son."

While the rapidity with which several of the French couturiers launched their collections so soon after the liberation of Paris both amazed and interested the women's apparel trades here, the styles shown possess little or no immediate significance to the American market, according to the consensus of trade opinion here.

IF the Japanese are reeling backward today under blows by Gen. Douglas MacArthur and Admiral Chester W. Nimitz much of the credit must go to a small man with crew-cut gray hair, leathery, wrinkled skin, blue eyes and a broad mouth which wrinkles frequently into a grin covering most of his face.

LONDON, Oct. 7 (Reuter) -- Field Marshal von Kesselring seems busy building a defense line along the north bank of the Adige, a special Reuter correspondent at Allied headquarters in Italy reported tonight.

PROBABLY the supreme test of a book for the layman on aviation is that it should be as intelligible to the uninstructed adult as to the generation which has, so to speak, been born with a stick in its hand. This dictionary is not only intelligible; it is readable.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- August saw the largest decrease in Federal employes in Washington in a year and a half, and that is viewed in some quarters as the ripple which, in time, will develop into a flood tide of an exodus from Washington.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 7 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey declared here tonight, in a nationally broadcast speech at the Municipal Auditorium, that the Communists were backing President Roosevelt because the New Deal was developing "its own form of corporate state."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- White Plains, opening its season on a smashing note, toppled favored Mount St. Michael from the undefeated class, 20 -- 12, with a fourteen-point last-period comeback at the Stadium today before 5,500 fans.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (U.P.) -- Police today charged Earl McFarland, a first class private of the Marine Corps and a veteran of Guadalcanal, with the murder of Dorothy Berrum, aged 18, whose brutally violated body was found under a willow tree in East Potomac Park yesterday morning.

Retention at the end of the war of the vast merchant marine fleet that has been built by United States shipyards to meet the demands of transporting troops and equipment to all the fighting fronts of the world was urged yesterday by Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Veterans Affairs and of Retraining and Reemployment.

HOLLYWOOD has reacted favorably to the plea from exhibitors and moviegoers alike for the elimination of over-length features. At the four major studios, where the outsize films have been produced in the recent past, an enthusiastic front-office effort is now being made to shorten all features and to set ninety to 100 minutes of theatre running time as a maximum for the general length of "A" pictures.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 7 -- The old-fashioned bulldog fight for which Yale football stood for years brought about the defeat of a favored Cornell team that seemed to be headed for a crushing victory in the Bowl today. The score was 16 -- 7.

World economic and political security and lasting peace will depend upon an international organization that will give security and recognition to all rather than upon new alliances and balances of power, speakers declared yesterday at an all-day forum on a program for security held by the Foreign Policy Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 7 (U.P.) -- The "track team" backfield from Illinois was light on its feet as usual today but its speed was nullified because of "butter-fingered" ball handling and Purdue capitalized on eight fumbles to turn in a 35-to-19 Western Conference victory before 15,210 fans.

As one who glories in the beauty of autumn I took a good deal of pleasure in George R. Stewart's article "The All-American Season." I was pleased, too, that he referred to our autumns as an American scenic wonder comparable to Niagara or Yosemite.

PATRAS, Greece, Oct. 6 (Delayed) -- Church bells rang from dawn yesterday in the villages and hamlets of the Peloponnesus to celebrate the return to Greek national rule. Flags flew from every building.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 7 -- Hard-hitting Notre Dame crushed game but untested Tulane, 26 -- 0, today with a show of explosive power that left little doubt the Irish will make a rugged defense of their national collegiate title this season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Dr. Alexander Loudon, Netherlands Ambassador, commenting on reports from London on the "dire extremity" with which the Netherlands is confronted, today expressed the belief that the Germans were bent on destroying not only the homes and people but also the land they live on.

" LONELY BOY BLUES" is the kind of book toward which it is almost impossible not to take a parental tone. Alan Kapelner, one gathers, is a very young man, raised in New York, devoted to jazz, and dedicated to Creative Art.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Representative Anderson of New Mexico, chairman of the House Campaign Expenditures Committee, said today he had received permission from the group to withdraw "from the permanent record of the committee" a statement he made Oct. 3 asserting thirteen Republicans in Congress had franked 3,115,000 copies of a single speech at Government expense.

AT the close of a week in which the surface of the entertainment screen hereabout was scratched but slightly by the passage of such new items as "Gypsy Wildcat" and "Dead Man's Eyes," it may be conceded that this corner has a reasonable cause to digress.
PARIS, Oct. 7 -- Confusion in apathy -- that was Paris in June, 1940. Confusion in activity -- that is Paris in October, 1944.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (U.P.) -- Adolf A. With a twelve-hit attack against three pitchers, the Cardinals defeated the Browns, 5 to 1, at Sportsman's Park, St. Louis, yesterday, again evening the world series between the intra-city baseball rivals at two games each.

Wendell L. The new committee is sponsored by the American Council on Education and is an encouraging sign of the broadening scope of the Council's activities and outlook.

That the concert given by the Saidenberg Little Symphony, under Daniel Saidenberg, last night in Town Hall won the hearty acclaim of the large audience present was only natural. For not only was the program stimulating in itself, but all of the music it contained was played for its own sake and not to display the qualities of the ensemble itself, a sufficiently rare phenomenon to merit stressed mention.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Oct. 8 -- Although outscored by the Garden City Country Club in the final round, the Hempstead Golf Club won the title in the second annual Long Island quadrangular team match with 186 1/2 points at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- Government efforts to advance wheat prices to parity are meeting with signal success, as prices have advanced 18 1/8 to 20 7/8 cents a bushel from the September low and cash wheat is selling at the Office of Price Administration ceiling level in many of the leading markets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (U.P.) -- There will be no easing of installment buying controls until after Germany and Japan have been defeated and until civilian production has been returned to normal, it was revealed tonight.

WILTON, Conn., Oct. 8 -- The chances of obtaining Senate approval of American adherence to a world security organization would be better if Gov. Thomas E. Dewey supplants President Roosevelt in the White House, John Foster Dulles, adviser to the Republican nominee on foreign affairs, here, told Mrs. S. Carter Hall of the Wilton League of Women Voters in a letter.

LONDON, Monday, Oct. 9 -- The Red Army, hurling about half a million men into a great offensive, has advanced sixty-two miles along a 175-mile front in Lithuania in a campaign to trap the remnants of Germany's Baltic armies and break into East Prussia from the north, Premier Stalin revealed last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Study of the main features of the proposals in the Dumbarton Oaks report today disclosed that none of the four blueprints, submitted by the delegations to the conference, has been followed closely in the plan adopted for the world security organization.

There has been a change in the buying attitude due to the change in the war situation, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. It was said that more buyers in the market were inclined to place orders where possible for next spring delivery.

ROME, Oct 8 -- The reinforced Land Forces of the Adriatic, under Lieut. Col. George Jellicoe, 26-year-old only son of Earl Jellicoe, naval hero of World War I, rushed on from Rion yesterday and are nearing the outskirts of Corinth, according to today's communique.

BOSTON, Oct. 8 -- Squeaking from disuse and lack of oil, the New York Giants still were good enough to beat the Boston Yanks in their National Football League opener in Fenway Park today, the score being 22 to 10.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Monday, Oct. 9 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (U.P.) -- Senator Burton, Republican, of Ohio, took issue tonight with Prime Minister Churchill's warning against hasty formation of a world-security organization, asserting that Senate "reservationists" would tear any elaborate plan apart.
LONDON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Last week's stock market was more active, reaching the million-share mark on Thursday. Prices advanced, notably toward the week-end; they reached the highest average since August. It was noticeable, however, that a day of inactivity followed each forward movement.

In his faithfulness to the cause of freedom, Wendell L. Willkie gallantly jettisoned personal political ambition to dramatize for the world "America's role in the future," Russell W. Davenport, who was personal representative for the candidate in the 1940 campaign, declared in a tribute broadcast yesterday afternoon over radio station WQXR.

WASHINGTON Oct. 8 (UP) -- A Senate inter-State commerce sub-committee has discontinued its hearings on the American Federation of Musicians recording ban and probably will make no recommendation, chairman Clark of Idaho, stated tonight.

The Army-Notre Dame game at this time looks to be the climactic event of the football season even though it is Navy for which Lieut. Col. Earl Blaik is gunning above all others and which may prove tougher to bring down than the Fighting Irish.

NANCY, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Manton S. Eddy of Chicago, Ill., an American fighting general who came up through the Army the hard way, was disclosed today as the commander of the United States Twelfth Army Corps, which is leading the new Third Army advance between Nancy and Metz.

"An American Program," by the late Wendell L. Willkie, will be published by Simon Schuster tomorrow. The book will include seven newspaper articles, two articles that appeared in Collier's magazine, and a new foreword by Mr. Willkie.
PARIS, Oct. 8 -- Writing in I'Aurore today, Paul Bastide, a Radical party member of the National Council of Resistance, called the American Presidential campaign "a miracle of democracy."

The death of Wendell L. Willkie brought expressions of deep regret not only from distinguished fellow Americans of every political belief but from leaders of Allied nations in all parts of the world. Some of them follow:

In mailing copies of "Handbook to Retailers" to member and non-member newspapers on behalf of the Committee for Economic Development, the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association included a memorandum taking issue with a Dun Bradstreet estimate of advertising expense which might be construed as normal for retail merchants.

WITH AMERICAN THIRD ARMY Beyond Nancy, Oct. 8 (U.P.) -- Screened by a friendly morning haze and preceded by a wall-like barrage from the American guns, infantrymen and armored forces of Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's Third Army opened a general attack on a twenty-mile front midway between Metz and Nancy at 6 A.M. today and by midafternoon they had captured at least eight towns.

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- The unexpected thing in France is that at first sight it appears rejuvenated by the ordeal of the last four years. In the years before the war it always seemed a middle-aged country. During the period of suspended hostilities that the French call "the white war," troops departing for the front looked worn and listless.

With the medical colleges of this country reporting a record enrollment this fall, and the outlook for 1945 equally promising, an adequate supply of physicians for the present and for post-war America appears assured, Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, dean of the Columbia University Medical School and chairman of the executive council, Association of American Medical Colleges, asserted yesterday.

A warning of the danger of intolerance in the post-war period was voiced by Willard Waller, associate Professor of Sociology, Columbia University, yesterday at the closing session of the four-day convention of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States, held in the Hotel Commodore.

Ballet Theatre opened a four-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night before the customary sold-out house, to the accompaniment of the normal number of decibels of applause and with the usual plethora of flowers for all and sundry.
Yesterday's communique as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
Prince and Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff have returned to 860 Park Avenue from Vernon Hall, their place in Southampton, L.I., where they spent the summer.

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- Between 4,000,000 and 6,000,000 persons in France are believed to be homeless as a result of the Allies' bombings during four years and the fighting of the past four months, which have destroyed or seriously damaged 1,500,000 houses.

Three hundred Third Naval District congregations were commended by Secretary of the Navy James Forrestal yesterday in messages recognizing their "patriotic sacrifice" in having released their pastors for service as Navy chaplains.
Before an altar forty feet high in centerfield at the Polo Grounds, 65,000 persons offered prayers yesterday afternoon for victory in the war and for a lasting peace.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 8 -- The plan of Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. for dealing with Germany after the war continues to draw violent criticism from the German press, which says President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill were responsible for the Secretary's proposal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The United States is getting 78,000 tons of crude rubber this year as reverse lend-lease from the British Commonwealth, the Foreign Economic Administration reported today. This is more than half of the total production of the empire territories participating in the operation.

Registration of voters for the November election will begin today in all boroughs of New York City, with the major political parties and various nonpartisan groups working independently for the common objective of persuading every potential voter to meet the legal requirements for casting a ballot.
ALBANY, Oct. 8 -- Governor Dewey proclaimed Oct. 9 today as Leiv Eriksson Day, by an announcement from the Executive Mansion. In his proclamation the Governor said:

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 8 -- Adding a four-under-par 68 to the 69 they scored yesterday, Dom Morano of Orchard Hills and John Dolan of the home club today won the ninth annual Crestmont Country Club best-ball invitation tournament by four shots.

A great American who served his country well is lost to us in the very prime of his active, useful life. Wendell Willkie in his early fifties, still young, still growing and still eager, was a tremendous asset in the hands of the American people. He had before him the prospect of long years of service to the fine causes on which his faith was founded.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- Domestic demand for cash lard continues fairly good, with sales almost entirely at ceiling prices, and some packers say they have little unsold product on hand owing to the light run of hogs and the necessity of filling Government orders.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (U.P.) -- Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney of Wyoming, chairman of the Senate Democratic Campaign Committee, declared tonight that Governor Dewey's West Virginia speech, "like all his speeches to date," was marked by "bad logic and spurious arguments."

Preceded by a parade of 3,000 marchers down Fifth Avenue from Seventy-eighth Street to St. Thomas Episcopal Church at Fifty-third Street the twenty-third annual Massing of the Colors was presented yesterday afternoon. Taking part in the parade were Army units, veterans of previous wars, women's auxiliaries, members of patriotic societies and groups from home defense organizations.
John D. Rockefeller Jr. has contributed $300,000 to the National War Fund, it was announced yesterday by Richard W. Lawrence, campaign chairman of the New York War Fund.
LONDON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- News of the death of Wendell Willkie was received today with deep regret in British official circles.

DETROIT, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Fireball Frankie Sinkwich passed and ran the Lions to a 19-14 victory over the Brooklyn Tigers before 15,702 spectators today for Detroit's first National Football League triumph. Sinkwich scored two touchdowns, one on a twisting 73-yard dash, and Bullet Bob Westfall, former Michigan fullback, plunged for the third Lion score.

Sharply critical of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office for its expressed intentions to confine salvage activity solely to education, Frank D. March, New York City Salvage Director, has submitted his resignation to Grover Whalen, chairman of the CDVO, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- Wet weather prevailed the fore part of last week in the main Corn Belt, but conditions improved materially later and the crop made considerable progress toward maturity. So far there has been no frost damage of consequence.

ROME, Oct. 8 -- An Italian partisan who was condemned to death by the Fascist police corps and saved by the Allies' entry into Rome has accused the noted tenor, Benjamino Gigli, of having assisted at his questioning and having called him a "criminal" and "murderer," it was announced today.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 117.9 on Sept. 26, compared with 117.7 a fortnight before, 117.6 a month before, 114.3 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The play-by-play description of the fifth game of the world series at Sportsman's Park today follows:
The United States Army has reached maturity on the battlefields of France.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The constitutionality of a New York statute that bars theatre owners from refusing admission to adults who hold admission tickets and whose conduct is neither abusive nor conducive to a breach of the peace will go before the Supreme Court for settlement tomorrow.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 8 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has bought from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer "Molly, Bless Her," a screen story by Frances Marion based on the life of the late Marie Dressler. Fox plans to use the scenario as a starring vehicle for Gracie Fields and Monty Woolley.

BRIAR CLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Dr. Joseph J. Arminio and his guest from Ossining, Frank Ciletti, scored 32, 33 -- 65 to win the member-guest best-ball tournament at the Briar Hills Golf Club today. Forty-five pairs competed, each player using a three-quarter handicap allowance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- President Roosevelt will not alter the National Wage Stabilization Policy before election day by modifying the "Little Steel" formula and granting the United States Steel Workers of America (CIO) a general wage increase, it was authoritatively disclosed today.
ROME, Oct. 8 (AP) -- A communique:
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 8 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

In the development of jet-propulsion planes it is evident that a forward stride for both military and commercial purposes, perhaps of revolutionary proportions, is in the making. Gas turbines represent the first true challenge to the conventional internal combustion engine in the four decades of its remarkable development.

ROME, Oct. 8 (U.P.) -- Fifth Army American troops have broadened their front below Bologna, rail and road center of North Central Italy, with advances that put them nine and a half miles from the Rimini-Bologna highway, it was disclosed today, and on the western coastal sector Negro infantrymen of the United States Ninety-second Division seized two mountains north of Viareggio.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- As an earnest of its serious intentions to look after the national interests of Britain in the field of civil aviation and of its determination to carry out its domestic program of economic security for all, the Churchill government announced tonight that two new Cabinet posts had been created.
Six new films, including a Mexican importation, are scheduled to arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Battling hotly on a frigid day, Baltimore had to go fourteen innings today to beat Louisville, 7 to 4, and take a 2-1 lead in games in the little world series. The clubs left immediately after the contest for Baltimore, where the series is to be resumed tomorrow night.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Posthumous award of the Congressional Medal of Honor to Pfc. John W. Dutko of Homer City, Pa., was announced by the War Department today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 143:
Sale of a large West Side holding by the Browning Estate, and of a Park Avenue corner as the site for a post-war apartment building, featured the Manhattan deals reported by brokers yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Water is spilling over the countryside from the big Kembs dam across the Rhine in upper Alsace ten miles southeast of Mulhouse and seven miles north of Basle, according to reconnaissance reports today on the effects of yesterday's heavy air attacks.

The path to a new world is the recovery of moral and spiritual worth and not in a political or economic blueprint, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo said yesterday in a sermon at the Collegiate Reformed Church of Saint Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Planes of the United States Fourteenth Air Force destroyed more than 163,000 tons of Japanese shipping and killed nearly 4,000 enemy troops in attacks during September, a communique from Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced today.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 8 -- Lack of strikes last week and a successful attempt to maintain steel output raised the ingot rate last week one point to 95.5 per cent of rated capacity. There is evidence that the rate this week will be equally heavy.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- Preliminary meetings were held today in connection with the biennial congress of the Cooperative League, and Murray D. Lincoln, executive secretary of the Ohio Farm Bureau, urged one session to seek a common understanding between urban and rural dwellers with a view toward greater cooperatives.

A thousand worshipers packed the Russian Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Virgin Protection to capacity yesterday, while a thousand more lined East Second Street, outside the cathedral, and waited to witness a service that was the climax of a two-day celebration of the 150th anniversary of the Russian Orthodox Church in America.

Following the sharp improvement recorded in the previous week, cotton prices turned easier last week in a comparatively slow market. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net declines of 9 to 47 points, with the sharpest recession in the distant July position.

Governor Dewey strongly implied yesterday, in an address from the reviewing stand of the annual Pulaski Day parade here, that he was suspicious of the Roosevelt Administration's attitude toward the future boundaries of Poland. He advised all Americans of Polish descent to "do everything in your power to bring discussions of Poland's fate from the dark to the light."

Where part-time jobs do not seriously interfere with school work and where they hold a particular interest for the 'teen-age boy or girl, they have been found to have a distinct educational value, according to a report of the Children's Aid Society's department of counseling and employment, released yesterday.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Oct. 8 -- Unless there are strange contradictory elements in the South Dakota political situation which the most competent observers here cannot detect, the Republicans will make a sweep of the State on Nov. 7.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- A conclusion that the average American's post-war pocketbook won't be as well filled as other estimaters have led him to hope is reached in a study made public today by the Brookings Institution.
One innocent pleasure within reach of all of us nowadays is the spending of money that we will have ready, tied up in great bags presumably, when the war is over.

OUTSKIRTS OF DUNKERQUE, Oct. 8 (Delayed) -- The German garrison at Dunkerque, virtually isolated from the rest of the world and holding grimly with little if any hope of escape, is systematically wrecking the harbor installations and burning the town.

During the past week individual price increases and decreases offset each other completely and thus caused the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices to remain unchanged at the previous week's level of 113.45.

Sidney Hillman, target for some of the heaviest Republican fire of the campaign, and Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic national chairman, took umbrage yesterday, in separate statements, at an announcement that the labor union leader would "represent the Democratic side" at a forum program on the Presidential election.

The Theatre Guild acknowledged yesterday that "Embezzled Heaven," starring Ethel Barrymore, would be presented Oct. 31 at the National, where "Men to the Sea" is now playing. Featured in Miss Barrymore's supporting cast are Albert Basserman (prominent Continental actor in his Broadway debut), Eduard Franz, Sanford Meisner and Martin Blaine.

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- The first two books published in France since the liberation are reprints of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's "The Edge of the Sword" and "Toward a Professional Army," written in 1934, when he was a major. The scarcity of paper is impeding the publishing trade.

The Republican and Democratic National Committees have accepted an invitation from Mayor La Guardia to use WNYC, the municipal broadcasting station, as a medium for correcting inaccurate or misleading statements by the opposition in the Presidential campaign.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Answering criticism that some airline advertising had encouraged travel, the Air Transport Association told J. Monroe. Johnson, Defense Transportation Director of the ODT, that many railroad displays were "subject to precisely the same criticism," it was learned today.

The New York metropolitan region, with 10 per cent of the nation's population, can provide 5,600,000 jobs, or 10 per cent of the national post-war employment goal, provided wartime high corporation taxes are drastically reduced and local obstructions increasing costs of production are eliminated, according to the findings of a study made public yesterday by the Regional Plan Association.

Premier Kuniaki Koiso told the Japanese yesterday that their armed forces were awaiting an opportunity "to crush the enemy forces with a single stroke," but warned this blow might be impossible unless Japan increased the output of war goods, particularly aircraft.

There comes a rainy Saturday in the fall which means a certain job to farm lads. It isn't a relished task. To avoid it, boys have been known to volunteer to clean out the old sawdust in the ice house or even to clean out the henhouse. But fate is inexorable, and the day arrives when the verdict is given. The harness must be washed and oiled before winter sets in.
PARIS, Oct. 3 (Delayed) -- "Coal for babies" is the appeal issued by the matrons of Paris maternity hospitals to the mines in northern France.

Governor Dewey, if elected President, would seek to keep Cordell Hull, for some period after the new administration took office, in charge of international affairs, either as Secretary of State or as a co-worker with John Foster Dulles, Mr. Dewey's eventual choice for that post, it was disclosed yesterday by the Republican candidate's intimate advisers.

The publication of Secretary Morgenthau's plan for dealing with Germany has disturbed me deeply. By its terms all manufacturing plants in Germany would be dismantled and the machinery destroyed or given to those countries of the United Nations which might desire it.

DETROIT, Oct. 8 (U.P.) -- CIO maintenance workers at the Packard Motor Company plant today ended their four-day strike after receiving assurances that the War Labor Board would give immediate consideration to their wage grievances.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Green Bay's newest aerial combination of young Irv Comp and old Don Hutson operated with deadly efficiency in the first half today to pace the Packers to their fourth straight National Football League victory, a 34-to-7 triumph over the Chicago Cardinal-Pittsburgh Steeler combine.

The above chart, prepared by Armour Co., should prove of considerable value to householders in view of the fact that beef is now the most plentiful variety of meat, and because the cuts most likely to be found in today's market are, for the most part, unfamiliar ones.

Several Westchester brokers made public yesterday long lists of residential sales they have just consummated. Among the properties listed by Fish Marvin as having passed into new hands was the home at 125 Cedar Lane, Bronxville, sold by the Kings County Trust Company to Arvid R. Nelson, and 1 Northway, Bronxville, for Fred P. Murphy of New York to Mrs. Paul P. Wrigley.

The air correspondent of The Times, London, said over the British radio yesterday that the results of Saturday's devastating bombing of Germany gave evidence that the Reich's power to continue the war may be brought to an end "some time much before Christmas."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Production of 100-octane gasoline by sixty-five refineries of the United Nations in October will exceed requirements for combat and training, according to a statement issued at the office of Secretary Ickes, Petroleum Administration for War.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The American Government is preparing to ask for post-war reforms in the world's cable and radio communications system which would give the person who wants to send a message to any part of the world a flat rate per word.
CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 8 (AP) -- King Farouk has dismissed the Cabinet under Mustafa Nahas Pasha.

ROME, Oct. 8 -- The night before embarking for Greece the British officers who were to direct the Peloponnesian expedition were reminded by their commander in chief that Greece was in the throes of civil war and that "all Greeks are politicians."

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Business on the Stock Exchange here remains at the low ebb to which it has fallen since Prime Minister Churchill's recent review of the war situation. From the market's point of view, the most important feature of that review was the Premier's warning that the end of the war probably was a matter of months rather than weeks.

Preaching yesterday on the "Vices That Mar Victory," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, criticized profanity and obscenity in conversation and current writing.

PATRAS, Greece, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Germans were reported fleeing from Athens today. Corinth, guarding the southern entrance to the Corinth Isthmus leading forty-five miles eastward to the ancient capital, was reported deserted except for several hundred Greek puppet troops.

American, British and Chinese troops in the Salween River district of southwestern China and Burma have reached a point where a junction of the new Ledo and old Burma Roads can be foreseen, General Joseph W. Stilwell said last night in a transcribed address broadcast over the Blue network.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Issuance of three new regulations to speed up the settlement of terminated war contracts was announced today by the Office of Contract Settlement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- In closing the conference at Dumbarton Oaks, Edward R. Stettinius, Undersecretary of State, predicted its work would be examined critically by the peace-loving peoples of the world. Drafts of the four-power report indicated today that this would be especially true among the middle powers of the United Nations.

Regulars at a London "pub" in one of the slum districts where Wendell L. Willkie played darts and talked with Blitz victims on his visit to England in 1941, last night drank a solemn toast to "a proper gent who made us feel that he was our friend," the British Broadcasting Company reported in a broadcast monitored by the National Broadcasting Company.

Financing higher education in the United States has now reached a point where 40 per cent of all operating funds come from Government sources while endowment funds yield capital totaling under 12 per cent, it was disclosed yesterday in a new study of college finances prepared for the American Council on Education by J. Harvey Cain, accounting officer of the New York City Board of Higher Education.

ALSDORF, Germany, Oct. 8 -- Two German tanks, survivors of six that led a bitter but beaten counter-attack this morning against American infantry holding this town, are being stalked through its streets this afternoon block by block by our bazooka squads.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- As an unavoidable consequence of the four-power reports on the Dumbarton Oaks conference, there appears on the political horizon another international consultation between Prime Minister Churchill, Marshal Stalin, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and the President of the United States.

Two museum exhibitions and one big annual group show head this week's list of new art attractions. The Museum of the City of New York has opened a show called "New York Between Two Wars," consisting of cartoons by Rollin Kirby. At the Museum of Modern Art paintings by Jacob Lawrence, Negro artist, will be shown beginning Wednesday.
LONDON, Oct. 8 (Reuter) -- The Daily Telegraph says of Wendell Willkie:

WITH AMERICAN FIRST ARMY in Germany, Oct. 8 -- Aachen is all but isolated. Late this afternoon veteran American infantrymen scrambled up the slopes of Crucifix Hill to bring the southern arm of Lieut. Gen. Courtney H. Hodges' pincer movement...

ROME, Oct. 8 -- Resentment against pleas for clemency from bankers in New York and other capitals on behalf of Vincenzo Azzolini, former governor of the Bank of Italy, was expressed by Count Carlo Sforza in an interview with me today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 8 -- A charge that Adolf Hitler faked the plot against his life on July 20 to provide an excuse for purging the army of defeatists was made tonight by Eero Petajniemi, former press attache in the Finnish legation at Berlin.

The Most Rev. J. Francis A. McIntyre, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, pontificated at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, commemorating the thirty-fourth anniversary of the consecration of the church after all debts incident to its construction had been cleared.

LONDON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- While industrial Germany still smoldered from yesterday's greatest aerial blow in history, Ninth Air Force fighter-bombers gave the Siegfried Line a super "buzz job" today, destroying 132 heavy gun positions that had been slowing the American First and Third armies.

When the Romans finally conquered Carthage they razed the city and sowed the soil with salt. It has been a desert ever since. The Nazis, beaten in battle, are sowing Holland with the salt of the sea in one of the cruelest efforts at mass destruction that history records. The scientific flooding of the Netherlands by 6,000 German demolition troops is not being done in defense but in revenge.

In an official interview reported today in THE NEW YORK TIMES by cable from Sofia the Bulgarian Premier, Kimon Georgieff, endeavors to reestablish a place for his people among the freedom-loving nations and he bluntly acknowledges "the inhuman behavior of some of our troops in Yugoslavia and Greece."
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Communique 183:
Oliver R. Grace of Sterling, Grace Co. has been elected to the board of United Chemicals, Inc.

Under a reorganization plan for Hearst-Brisbane first mortgage 6 per cent bonds which has received court approval, Midtown Enterprises, Inc., has just taken title to a group of midtown properties which had been held by the Hearst interests.

Despite bad weather, tremendous supply problems and stubborn German resistance, the Allied armies continue to close in on Hitler's "National Reduit," or innermost citadel, from all sides. WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (U.P.) -- Representative Daniel A. Reed of New York, chairman of the Republican Committee of the House which is studying post-war taxation stated tonight that his group would give serious consideration to a program for retiring the national debt at a rate of one per cent annually over a period of 100 years.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 28 Prof. John Hanna of Columbia University writes that common sense ought to be an antidote for Secretary Morgenthau's proposals about Germany. His letter is a warm plea in favor of the "crushed and impoverished Germany" that will be left when the war is over.

With ten, including Three Dots, entered in the $10,000 added Interborough Handicap, the fall race meeting will begin today at the Metropolitan Jockey Club's course at Jamaica. Post time will be 1:45 P.M., thirty minutes later than prevailed at the Belmont Park meeting, during which Three Dots performed so creditably.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The country's distilleries which received a month's holiday from production of industrial alcohol, produced about 50,000,000 gallons of spirits for beverage purposes in August, the United States Treasury reported today.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Oct. 8 -- Buddy Brown, a Chesapeake Bay dog, owned by Lieut. Comdr. E. Monroe Osborne of East Hampton, L.I., and handled in his absence in naval service by Paul Svane, tonight gained the highest honors in the open stake, featured event of the second day of the sanctioned retriever field trial meeting of the Long Island Field Trial Club held on the estate of Charles L. Lawrance in this village.

I have suggested to the chairman of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs and to a Republican member of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations that in the names of those two committees the word "international" should be substituted for "foreign."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Army nurses in Italy sometimes hunger and thirst after really feminine fall fashions, Dorothy Sutherland, overseas observer for the Army Nurse Corps, disclosed in a report to Army Nurse Corps headquarters here.

WITH AMERICAN THIRD ARMY Before Fort Driant, France, Oct. 8 (U.P.) -- At dusk last night the Germans counter-attacked at the southwestern corner of Fort Driant and with the aid of their heavy artillery they compelled our infantry men to move back about forty yards -- a long distance in this strange two-level battle in which the infantrymen are on top of the fort and the Germans are in their deep galleried defenses underneath.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- A big speculative trade was on in rye last week. An early upturn in sympathy with wheat was followed by a sharp reaction on profit-taking and talk that the order compelling distillers to use 10 per cent rye in making industrial alcohol might not be enforced early next year.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8 -- Campaigning for the re-election of President Roosevelt, Secretary Ickes charged at a dinner of the Hollywood Democratic Committee tonight that Governor Dewey was seeking to bring into Washington "a Trojan horse" full of "a prize group of isolationists and rabble-rousers."

Unless action is taken now to plan minutely the course of our peacetime economy widespread strikes and industrial chaos are in the offing for the nation after the war, Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, warned here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- With the ballot battle ending in four weeks, Republicans and Democrats are training some of their big guns this week on Midwestern States which many political analysts list as doubtful.

As a preliminary to further touring elsewhere, the New Opera Company's production of "The Merry Widow" dropped in upon the City Center on Saturday night. It will be on Fifty-fifth Street for four weeks, and the prices are low. Containing one of the most beautiful operetta scores of them all, "The Merry Widow" in this particular version also is pretty to look upon, well dressed and with attractive scenery.
BRUSSELS, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The ponies ran at Brussels' Boitsfort race course today and left in their wake a lot of sad sacks -- American officers and enlisted men.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Cardinals are reaching for the biggest share of the world series prize, confident they can defeat the Browns in the sixth game tomorrow. The Cardinals were a joyous lot when they ran into their dressing room. Every one of them congratulated the victorious Mort Cooper, who was puffing a cigarette.

The nation was thrown into mourning yesterday at news of the sudden death of Wendell L. Willkie. Thousands of telegrams of sympathy poured in on Mrs. Willkie, herself ill, at her apartment at 1010 Fifth Avenue -- many of them signed with noted names, others simply "A Friend" or "A Follower."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Any widespread effort by industry to cut prices by depressing wage rates after the war would confront the country with the dangers of "another disastrous depression," Chester Bowles, head of the Office of Price Administration, declared today.
LONDON, Oct. 8 (UP) -- A German communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
Gloves are an important part of the "costume" look this fall. Glove departments in leading stores now carry an assortment of dressmaker gloves that make for fashionable addenda in anyone's wardrobe.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 8 -- Ray Sanders, Missouri-born and reared, and Danny Litwhiler, transplanted from Ringtown, Pa., by way of Philadelphia, struck two lethal blows today before the admiring gaze of 36,568 onlookers that sent this all-St. Louis world series careening into the opposite corner from which it so persistently had been trying to go ever since the struggle began.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Clarence Doser of the Scarsdale Golf Club took the Westchester P.G.A. crown away from like Turnesa of Knollwood in their 18-hole play-off for the championship at Bonnie Briar today. All proceeds went to the Halloran Hospital golf-course fund.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- President Roosevelt, Governor Dewey, the Archbishop of Canterbury and the Bishop of London sent messages through which they joined today with members of all faiths in marking the 250th anniversary of the parish of St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church here, organized in the fifth year of the reign of King William and Queen Mary.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Cleveland's revitalized Rams gained their second National Football League victory in as many starts today by defeating the Chicago Bears, defending champions, 19 to 7.
Leading American fabric houses and twenty-two fashion designers will participate in one scene of "Fashions of The Times," dramatizing New York creative fashion design under wartime restrictions.

The Hill Realty Company bought the garden apartments at 200 West Merrick Road, in Freeport. L.I., occupying a plot 150 by 300 feet and reported to have an annual rent roll of more than $35,000. The sale was made for cash above mortgage of $152,900.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 8 (U.P.) -- Marine Corsairs plastered stubborn Japanese positions on Peleliu as Marines and soldiers made new advances against the enemy dug-in on Umurbrogol Mountain Saturday, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.
The four-story remodeled private home at 19 East Ninety-fourth Street has been sold by F. Sims McGrath to Louis F. Herman through the M. Morgenthau-Seixas Company and Malcolm E. Smith, Inc.

LONDON, Monday, Oct. 9 (U.P.) -- Germany early today proclaimed a military occupation of northern Finland as 100,000 Nazis dug in against a combined Russian and Finnish offensive along a 320-mile front from the Gulf of Bothnia to the Arctic Ocean.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Ship-hunting Allied planes sank or destroyed twenty-five Japanese coastal vessels and small craft in strikes around Ceram and Halmahera, headquarters reported today.

Small and medium-size business concerns throughout the nation that desire to take advantage of New York's pre-eminence as a business management center, will have at their disposal after the war the services of an expert coordinating agency, to be known as New York Office, Inc., Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.
The current season of the New York Times Hall will open tonight with the first of a series of meetings devoted to basic issues involved in the problems of returning service men.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The United States, Great Britain, Soviet Russia and China are expected to announce tomorrow the decision of the delegates at the Dumbarton Oaks conference to recommend creation of an international organization "to promote the establishment and maintenance of international peace and security with the least diversion of the world's human and economic resources for armaments."

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- The British people learned today that Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden were in Moscow. They were not surprised. It seemed a natural sequel to the Quebec conference.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 9 -- Former King Carol left Mexico City today by automobile for Vera Cruz, where, on Thursday, he will board the Argentine steamer Rio Tunuyan for Rio de Janeiro.
Two patrolmen were stabbed, one critically, at 1 A.M. today when they tried to disarm a sailor after he had molested a woman on East 125th Street and drew a knife when she rebuffed him.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The House committee investigating campaign expenditures received today records showing that $89,342 was donated to the American Democratic National Committee, a group opposing a fourth term for President Roosevelt, and decided to subpoena three of its officials.

St. Luke's Hospital has sold the five-story loft building at 104 Franklin Street to Continental Converters Corporation. The property is assessed at $29,000. The attorneys were Rodgers H. Bacon for the seller and Sidney Golding for the purchaser.

WITH AMERICAN FIRST ARMY, in Germany, Oct. 9 -- The northern arm of Lieut. Gen. Courtney H. Hodges' offensive, aimed at cutting off Aachen, has rolled up the rear of the Siegfried Line and has smashed its way into the outskirts of the key town of Wuerselen, reaching a point less than a mile and a half from the force driving northward from southeast of Aachen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -Federal control of commercial rent charges would be unjustified, the Senate Small Business Committee suggested today in a report saying that curbs were a matter for State and local action.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The question whether rules forbidding the solicitation of union members outside of working hours violate the Wagner act at the Republic Aviation Company, Babylon, L.I., will be reviewed, the Supreme Court decided today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Boston Stock Exchange's application to strike from listing and registration eighteen security issues of eleven foreign companies in countries which have been or are at war with the United States was granted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Trading in these securities has been suspended since Dec. 11, 1941.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The news of Wendell Willkie's passing will be a cruel shock to all American-loving Europeans.

In his first political address before a major labor group in his present campaign for re-election, Senator Robert F. Wagner denounced last night as without substance charges by Governor Dewey that President Roosevelt was courting the support of Communists in his fourth-term effort.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- The stock markets started the week on a cheerful note, with the outstanding feature the continued activity in shipping shares. Fresh buyers came for these, and, with the market short of stock, fresh gains were seen.
ALBANY, Oct. 9 -- Governor Dewey issued a proclamation today designating tomorrow Free China Day. In the proclamation he said:

The Regional Office of Price Administration announced yesterday that in accordance with standards established by rent control regulations it was "vigorously enforcing the requirements that landlords continue periodic painting and decorating of apartments in the New York metropolitan area."

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- The latest reports on conditions in the Channel Islands indicate that an acute food situation has arisen for the 70,000 persons still left on the only British soil occupied by the Germans.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- (AP)-- Following are the texts of documents released today outlining tentative plans for a world security organization as drafted at the Dumbarton Oaks conference:

In response to a resolution adopted unanimously by City College's Student Council, to "send letters to Mayor La Guardia and Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, demanding the opening of the board meetings to the public and press," Dr. Carmyn J. Lombardo, a board member, declared yesterday that he agreed "wholeheartedly with the students."

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 9 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops, battling to block the most imminent Japanese threat to the military center of Kweilin, continued to hold in check today tank-supported enemy units seeking to advance on the city from a point on the Hunan-Kwangsi railway twenty-three miles to the northeast, while the defenders of Foochow, on China's east coast, held their ground in the northeastern suburbs of the old treaty port.

QUINCY, Mass., Oct. 9 -- Several thousand workers in four key departments of the Quincy yard of the Bethlehem Steel Company walked out today in a wage dispute that seriously threatened constructional activity on warships at the plant.

Five main issues about which the American people are concerned, and the way welfare agencies may serve their communities through awareness of these problems were outlined yesterday by speakers at the luncheon meeting of the Second Autumn Study Course for Board Members, held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 9 -- Sidney Hillman told delegates at the Ohio State CIO convention tonight that "the people of Ohio, and we, the people of New York, each owe the nation an apology -- you for producing John Bricker and we for producing Thomas Dewey."

The millionth visitor from the armed forces was welcomed this month at the clubhouse of the National Catholic Community Service in East Fifty-first Street, opposite St. Patrick's Cathedral. The clubhouse, a finely appointed residence converted to wartime needs, has thus been "a home away from home" to one in every ten men, numerically, of our fighting forces.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9 -- With its keynote based on a sound economic system to assure steady employment, an International Religion-Labor Conference opened here tonight with representatives of three faiths giving the principal addresses.

Pointing out that the future economy of the Axis nations must necessarily play an important part in post-war trade, Eugene P. Thomas, chairman and president of the National Foreign Trade Council, attacked yesterday suggestions that enemy countries be reduced to economies primarily dependent upon agriculture.

Gounod's perennially popular opera, "Faust," has been chosen to open the Metropolitan Opera Association's new season, Edward Johnson, general manager, announced yesterday. The season will open on Nov. 27 and continue until April 1, for a total of eighteen weeks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- In an extraordinary formal statement Secretary Hull today objected to published reports that he would be asked to serve Governor Dewey as a foreign policy adviser should the Republican nominee be elected President.

At his induction yesterday as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, John F. X. McGohey promised to carry on the campaign against the black market that had marked the term in office of his predecessor, James B. M. McNally, who resigned to campaign for the Supreme Court bench.

Senator Taft predicts that the American people will make the final payment on the present war debt in the year 2245. He believes that the end of the war will find us with a national debt of 300 billion dollars and that this can be retired at the rate of a billion dollars a year.

The Childs Company and its subsidiaries showed for the first eight months of this year a gross income of $13,485,101, against $13,138,280 for the same period in 1943, according to an unaudited statement of earnings issued yesterday by the trustees of the restaurant chain.

Plans for the West Side Vocational High School, which is to be constructed at an estimated cost of $1,500,000, were among those filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The three-story structure will be built at the southwest corner of Columbus Avenue and 108th Street and will extend through to 107th Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- A child-welfare information service of country-wide scope, with a regular news letter paying particular attention to legislative developments affecting young people, is being organized, and will be formally put into operation in November.
ROME, Oct. 9 -- Vincenzo Azzolini, a former governor of the Bank of Italy, went on trial today for having turned over 117 tons of the gold reserve to the Germans.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Each St. Louis Cardinal will pick up approximately $4,334 for winning the world series, while each Brown player will receive about $2,842 out of the total player pool of $309,590.91, smallest since 1933.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Refusal by the Supreme Court to review lower court rulings resulted today in the high court sustaining the New York State law forbidding theatre owners to keep out ticket holders whose conduct is not offensive or conducive to a breach of the peace.

HENRIETTA BUCKMASTER'S "Deep River"* is the best historical novel I have read in 1944. It shows no evidence of the torrential literary talent that made Joseph Stanley Pennell's "History of Rome Hanks" so impressive a performance in spite of its grievous faults. It has little of the compressed melodramatic power of Howard Fast's vitriolic "Freedom Road."

Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for United States Senator, assailed last night the "consistently bad record" of his opponent, Senator Robert F. Wagner, in voting against veteran legislation, charging that the Senator's "new-found interest and effection" for the veteran stemmed from a desire to catch his vote.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Chief Justice Edward C. Eicher deferred decision on four defense motions for mistrial in the sedition case today pending further study of arguments that President Roosevelt's radio remarks last Thursday may have prejudiced the jury.

Word has been received from the Scotch Whisky Association in Edinburgh, Scotland, that although licenses have been granted, distillation has not been resumed, Harry L. Lourie, executive vice president of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers, Inc., told the annual meeting of that organization yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's statement on the plan for an international security organization:

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, speaking last night to 3,000 women in Carnegie Hall and to an overflow meeting in the street stressed the importance of women registering and voting in the coming election. She told her listeners that because of the unusual time in which they lived they must make it their business to vote.

In commemoration of its Silver Jubilee, the affluent Theatre Guild has earmarked a fund of $7,500 to be used for the sole purpose of giving aspiring talent a foothold on the ladder of success. As made known last April, that sum is being equally divided among five actresses, five actors and five playwrights.

Hope that the delayed program of Government loans provided under the "GI Bill of Rights" could be put into actual operation by the middle of this month, in so far as it applies to the purchase of homes, and by the end of the month for small businesses, was expressed last night by Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Veterans Affairs and also Administrator of Retraining and Re-employment.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The play-by-play description of the sixth game of the world series at Sportsman's Park today follows:

The Germans are not making a fighting withdrawal from Greece. They are in full flight "by land, sea and air." But they still have a long way to go through hard and hostile territory. If they are lucky, they may escape the trap being laid in their rear by the Russians and Marshal Tito's Partisans around Belgrade.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 9 -- Marcus Island, still one of the most important Japanese observation bases on the outer perimeter guarding approaches to the enemy homeland, was severely bombarded all day yesterday by units of the Pacific Fleet, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced early this morning.

DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Directors of the Independent Petroleum Association of America heard today a protest from the association's president against ratification of the Anglo-American petroleum treaty under consideration by the Senate.
Sixty thousand New Yorkers filed through the aisles of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday to pay their last tribute to Wendell L. Willkie.

A committee on demobilized women has been established at Barnard College to offer educational advice to women returning from the services and from war work, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve announced yesterday. The committee is intended, she said, to help women who may resume their education with Federal aid and will be under the chairmanship of Associate Dean Louise Gregory.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The War Production Board, in its final report on the supply of important industrial raw materials, today included cotton broad woven fabrics, tin, lumber, paper and its products, kraft-type container board, anthracite coal, natural rubber, sisal, manila hemp, corundum, cattle hides, kapok and pyrethrum in a "partial list" of materials which will continue to be scarce after V-E day.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday endorsed the plan of the Newspaper Publishers Waste Paper Committee to offer 2,300 scrap paper balers for sale at cost -- $2 -- to apartment house superintendents and janitors throughout the city. At the same time the Mayor again appealed to householders to be as careful as possible about separating waste paper from garbage and other refuse, when consigning it to the means of disposal available.

The production of steel ingots and steel for castings in the first nine months of this year established a record of 67,199,467 tons, compared with 66,395,130 in the similar period of last year, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Autograph manuscripts of American authors and the first printings of certain of these works will be exhibited at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East Thirty-sixth Street, until Dec. 9. Among the manuscripts are Mark Twain's "Life on the Mississippi," Thoreau's "Journal," Oliver Wendell Holmes' "Autocrat of the Breakfast Table," James Fenimore Cooper's "The Deerslayer," the only surviving fragment of Hawthorne's "The Scarlet Letter" and Whitman's "Ode to Washington" in three preliminary drafts.

MOSCOW, Oct. 9 -- Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, accompanied by the highest British military officials, arrived today for a series of war conferences with Premier Joseph Stalin and Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff that is expected to speed the final defeat of Germany and Hungary and iron out a number of political questions confronting the United Nations.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 9 -President Roosevelt's chance of winning Connecticut's eight electoral votes rests on the labor vote.

Coincident with the effectiveness of its registration statement, Liberty Aircraft Products Corporation offered yesterday to its common stockholders prior subscription rights to a new issue of 80,000 shares of $1.25 cumulative convertible preferred stock of $20 par value, at the rate of one share of preferred for each three and one-half shares of common held on Oct. 7, 1944.

WITH AMERICAN SIXTH ARMORED DIVISION, Near Jeandelaincourt, Oct. 9 (U.P.) -- The enemy violated a cardinal rule of warfare -- never dig a foxhole beneath a tree -- so tonight the tiny woods of Fouresse, northwest of battered Jeandelaincourt on the Metz-Nancy sector, are filled with dead Germans.

A Washington dispatch from Louis Stark to this newspaper declares that it has been "authoritatively disclosed" that President Roosevelt will not alter the national wage stabilization policy before election day by modifying the "Little Steel" formula and granting the United States Steel Workers of America a general wage increase.
BOSTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Boston Post said today in a copyright story from St. Louis that Delmar (Del) Baker, former manager of the Tigers, has signed to coach the Red Sox next season.

UNITED STATES NINTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, in France, Oct. 9 -- Hundreds of United States Ninth Air Force fighter bombers made a sudden devastating attack on the nesting places of the Luftwaffe Sunday afternoon slid left more than a score of the air strips wrecked.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 9 (AP) -Belief that Wendell Willkie would have "come out in favor of Governor Dewey" was expressed today by his elder brother, H. Fred Willkie, vice president of Joseph E. Seagram Sons Company.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9 (AP) -- For more years than you can shake a stick at, the big leagues have been claiming the baseball championship of the universe through the results of their annual world series -- but they have a "put up or shut up" challenge this season from the United States armed forces.

BOSTON, Oct. 9 (U.P.) -- The late Wendell Willkie recently indicated to friends that he planned to vote Nov. 7 for Governor Dewey for President, Senator Sinclair Weeks, Republican, of Massachusetts, said today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 9 (U.P.) -Minor disturbances broke out today in both Cairo and Alexandria over Egypt's sudden change of government yesterday, but extra police were believed to have the situation in hand.
The texts of the addresses delivered at the meeting on "Demobilization and rehabilitation" in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, last night, follow:
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- Fenway Golf Club's amateurs and pros almost scored a clean sweep as the club played host to the final one-day tournament of the Westchester P.G.A. season here today.
ROME, Oct. 9 (U.P.) -- American troops of the Fifth Army shoved the Germans northward from the town of Barbarolo and the heights of Mount Castellazi today and pounded within ten miles of Bologna.

LONDON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- A fleet of 2,000 United States heavy bombers and fighters resumed the aerial pounding of the Reich today, lashing at the Rhine city of Coblenz, fifty miles behind the Siegfried Line, and attacking military targets at Schweinfurt and Mainz.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 9. -Mrs. Job Taylor 2d of New York was indicted today by the Suffolk County grand jury on a charge of first-degree grand larceny in connection with the theft of jewelry from the summer homes of two residents of the Hamptons.

Influenced by a bearish cotton crop estimate and talk of an early peace in Europe, cotton futures prices closed yesterday 1 to 10 points lower than Saturday's final prices. The volume of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was small.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The United States, Great Britain, Soviet Russia and China today announced the decision of the Dumbarton Oaks Conference to recommend the creation of an international security organization, to be called "The United Nations" and to be empowered "to take such action by air, naval or land forces as may be necessary to maintain or restore international peace and security."
MELBOURNE, Tuesday, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Sydney, Australia's largest city, and the rest of the State of New South Wales virtually were without newspapers today because of labor difficulties.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Senator James M. Mead, Democrat of New York, urged today immediate convening of the State Legislature in a special session for the consideration of "exorbitant increases" in commercial rents in New York City.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- National Selective Service directed local boards today to abolish the limited service classification of 1-A(L) because the armed services are no longer calling for men qualified for limited duty only.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission denied today the Philadelphia Electric Company's application for exemption from the competitive bidding rule in its proposed sale of $130,000,000 of 2 3/4 per cent first and refunding mortgage bonds due in 1967 and 1974.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 -- A reorganization plan was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Indiana Service Corporation, a subsidiary formed by the trustees of the Midland Utilities Company.

OTTAWA, Oct. 9 -- A careful and earnest study by the people of Canada of the proposals made as the result of the Dumbarton Oaks Conference was recommended by Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The Supreme Court turned a deaf ear today to the plea that in deciding the insurance case by four to three last June it departed from a 110-year-old practice not to settle any constitutional question by less than a court majority.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 9 -- Dr. Albert Einstein declared tonight that even the most important domestic issues were secondary in the coming election to the problem of bringing about world security and a lasting peace, and on that account he urged the public to support President Roosevelt for a fourth term.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 9--Twentieth Century-Fox has named Michael O'Shea for the lead in the murder mystery story "Circumstantial Evidence." Preston Foster, who was previously announced for the part, has been withdrawn from the cast and lent to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to play the labor leader in "The Valley of Decision," the Marcia Davenport novel now in production with Greer Garson in the starring role.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 9 -- Attorney General Francis A. Biddle, in an address today before the annual convention of the New Jersey State Federation of Labor at the Claridge Hotel, accused the Republican party of resurrecting the "Red Bogey Man" because it lacked a major campaign issue.

ROME, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Allied command imposed a security blackout today over news of British troops who last were reported racing virtually unopposed across the Peloponnesus Peninsula of Greece and to be nearing Corinth, forty-five miles from Athens.

The fall meeting of the Metropolitan Jockey Club started at the Jamaica track yesterday, with the $10,000 added Interborough Handicap as the feature of the card. And the feature turned out to the satisfaction of the greater part of the crowd of 23,623 fans, for the popular choice won.
LONDON, Oct. 9 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Leopold Stokowski's conducting of the first of this season's concerts of the City Symphony last night at the City Center of Music and Drama was of a character which exhibited not only his sovereign command of the orchestra and his compelling temperament but also the thought and emotion of a great musician.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- Three former Ministers of the Vichy Government -- Pierre-Etienne Flandin, a former Premier of France; Marcez Peyrouton, former Minister of the Interior, and Gen. Jean-Makie-Joseph Bergeret, former Minister of Air -who are in the Fresnes prison are expected to be tried by courts-martial, official circles said today.

Despite long lines at many of the booths, registration in the five boroughs for voters who want to cast a ballot for the party candidates on Nov. 7 fell off on the first day for registration, according to the unofficial returns from the Board of Elections at 2 A.M. today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Tuesday, Oct. 10 (U.P.) -- Liberator bombers and Lightning fighters blasted the Japanese base at Zamboanga in southwest Mindanao in a heavy attack that spread explosions and fires through the waterfront area and installations and destroyed six enemy planes and three freighters, General MacArthur announced today.

John Stable, 85 years old, a homeless "cow milker," as he described himself, elected to spend ten days in the workhouse rather than pay a $20 fine in the Bowery Court yesterday, although he had $50 in his pocket, after he had pleaded guilty to sending in a false alarm of fire Sunday at the Bowery and Grand Street.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- One of the problems raised by the Dumbarton Oaks proposal today for creation of the United Nations charter is what is to become of the old League of Nations in Geneva.

Twenty-five hundred fires in New York City kitchens and bedrooms were recorded in the first half of this year, and an equal number may be expected before 1945 unless simple fire prevention suggestions are followed, Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh said yesterday in urging the cooperation of homemakers in the national fire prevention drive being held this week.
