WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today forecast this year's cotton crop at 11,953,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight, compared with a forecast of 11,483,000 bales a month ago, 11,427,000 bales produced last year and an average production of 12,455,000 bales in the ten years 1933-42.

ON THE OUTSKIRTS OF DUNKERQUE, France, Oct. 9 -- The British and French left behind at Dunkerque nearly four and a half years ago fought on against impossible odds for three days -- and never surrendered, it was learned today.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 9 -- Gertrude Lawrence, the English actress whose last extended American appearance was in "Lady in the Dark" two years ago, walked into the lobby of the Belvedere Hotel here tonight, glanced quickly about her and exclaimed:

MOSCOW, Oct. 9 -- A sharp attack on the Vatican's foreign policy was published today by the Soviet publication War and the Working Class, which said that the headquarters of the Roman Catholic Church had been a long-time friend of fascism and favored a soft peace that would let the Germans escape their just deserts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (U.P.) -The Democratic National Committee asserted today that a clause in the New York election laws prohibiting servicemen from betting on the election was the result of "Gubernatorial super-caution" against the probability that 80 or 90 per cent of the soldiers would vote for President Roosevelt.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9 (AP) -- There were lumps of emotion in the throats of Managers Billy Southworth of the Cardinals and Luke Sewell of the Browns as they met in the clubhouse after the Redbirds won the 1944 world baseball championship today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 -- A registration statement covering the proposed sale of $23,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, 3 per cent series due 1964, and $11,400,000 notes maturing serially over a period of ten years was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today by Koppers Company.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- Today it costs a French woman 10,000 francs to have a baby. This refers to the average middle-class woman who does not depend on charitable organizations. And what she may obtain with 10,000 francs is by no means sufficient.

Examiners of the Grace National Bank in Hanover Square on Saturday started to ask Kenneth Y. O'Neill, an assistant cashier, routine questions about payments from patrons on securities, of which he was in charge. O'Neill put them off with an announcement that he would make a complete explanation yesterday.

Strong buyer response marked the opening yesterday of spring dress lines of the Sportswear Guild and other producers. The tightest piece goods situation since the start of the war was the dominant factor as the new season got under way.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Taking the lead on the clubhouse turn and holding it over the mile and a sixteenth route, Mrs. L. Palladino's Tumult won the Plymouth Claiming Purse today at Rockingham Park.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The death of Wendell L. Willkie may intensify both Republican and Democratic efforts to cultivate the independent vote.

Tributes to the late Wendell L. Willkie and former Gov. Alfred E. Smith were paid by speakers yesterday at a "Get Out the Vote" luncheon sponsored by the newly formed Women's Division of the National Citizens Political Action Committee at the Hotel Commodore, at which $17,500 was raised for campaign work.
A meeting in Paris Saturday between Marlene Dietrich and Maurice Chevalier was reported yesterday by the American Broadcasting Station in Europe, according to United States Government monitors.

ROME, Oct. 9 -- The greatest single need in southern Greece today, according to British officers who worked in the country for months before the recent landing, as well as visual evidence and the pathetically expressed desires of the population, is not food.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. yesterday reiterated before the board of directors of the National War Fund that "the time to get agreement among the Allies on the principles and the framework involved in the peace program is now, while the fighting is going on."
The week-end's gridiron triumphs were celebrated and the wounds licked yesterday at the Football Writers' weekly luncheon at Toots Shor's.
LONDON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

KANDY, Ceylon, Oct. 9 (AP) -West African troops have driven the Japanese from a village northwest of Mowdok in the newly activated Arakan combat area on the Indian side of the India-Burma frontier, Allied Headquarters announced today.

More active campaigning by the American Legion to assure adoption of its recommendations on national issues was promised yesterday by Edward N. Scheiberling, newly elected national commander, who maintained that if the Legion program had been prosecuted more vigorously in the past "we might not have got into this war."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Among 377 casualties announced today by the Navy Department were the following from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- Simplicity and distinction proved the dominant features of Molyneux's opening today. It requires keen attention to note how every detail has been studied closely. There is no exaggeration at any single point.

GREAT FALLS, Mont., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Gov. John W. Bricker, Republican Vice Presidential candidate, declared tonight that President Roosevelt had exhibited a "violent antagonism to veterans' legislation," and added:
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Communique 184:

This week's financing will get under way today when officials of two railroads in the Pennsylvania System will consider bids for a total of $34,735,000 of bonds, proceeds from which will be applied to refunding outstanding obligations. The largest of these issues consists of $23,735,000 of Series E general mortgage bonds, due in 1975, of the Pittsburgh, Cincinnati, Chicago St. Louis Railroad.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 9 (AP) -Battling back for a 5-to-4 victory, the Louisville Colonels of the American Association squared the little world series tonight with the Baltimore Orioles of the International League at two games apiece before a record minor league crowd of 52,833 persons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Chairman Connally of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee issued a statement today saying that the Dumbarton Oaks agreement should receive "the support of the American people, irrespective of party affiliations."

In the first of a Monday night series of talks broadcast over a State-wide radio network, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State chairman, last night assailed Governor Dewey as a "do-nothing" Governor who is not "big enough to be President and whose every act has been aimed "to further his own self-centered ambition."

ALBANY, Oct. 9 -- Governor Dewey issued a statement today hailing the results of the Dumbarton Oaks conferences as a "fine beginning." The plan, as made public, was not a surprise to Mr. Dewey, his staff declared, since he had been kept abreast of the progress by John Foster Dulles, who was informed by Secretary Hull of important developments.

New England football fans are all aflutter this week. Notre Dame plays Dartmouth in Boston on Saturday, and that's something to get more excited about in the Hub than the return of George Preston Marshall and his Redskins to meet Herb Kopf's Yanks the following day.

HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 9 -The exchange of Russian and Finnish war prisoners, under the auspices of the Allied Control Commission in Helsinki, is now in full swing and should be completed next week when some 45,000 Russians will have been exchanged for 8,000 Finns.

At a ceremony yesterday in Coast Guard Headquarters, 42 Broadway, eighteen fire departments in the New York Harbor area, as well as five port agencies, received the Security Shield of Honor awarded by the Coast Guard for cooperation in protecting the harbor during wartime.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Federal Judge John P. Barnes dismissed today injunction suits brought by the Office of Price Administration against Swift Co., Armour Co., Wilson Co. and the Cudahy Packing Company.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- The Paris press republished today a Washington dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES forecasting an international security organization in which France would sit in council with Britain, the United States, Russia and China.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Four years ago last June at Philadelphia, after surely one of the oddest conversations anyone ever had with a full-fledged candidate for a Presidential nomination, this correspondent wrote a private account of it while the facts were fresh in his mind. The candidate was Wendell L. Willkie, who only a few hours before had bounced off the train that brought him from New York.

The first rabies fatality in the city in three years and the first in the Bronx in eight years was reported yesterday by Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins, Health Commissioner, who announced that Mrs. Josephine Tys, 53 years old, of 2024 Benedict Avenue, the Bronx, bitten by her own dog, died of the infection on Sept. 13.
MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands, Oct. 7 (Delayed) -- This has been book-burning week in this ancient city.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 9 (AP) -Courage equal to, or greater than, that shown in great world crises will be needed to carry on the work of the church after the war, C.C. Goodman of Dubois, Pa., told a panel meeting today at the biennial convention of 500 national leaders of the Brotherhood of the United Lutheran Church in America.

CHICAGO, Oct 9 -- Trade sentiment swung strongly over the week end to the bear side of the grain markets. For the first time in some weeks the Office of Price Administration and the War Food Administration failed to make any statements over the week end, much to the surprise of broker, many of whom covered short sales Saturday in the expectation that some new program would be announced.

Jerome Robbins' hit of last season, "Fancy Free," and Antony Tudor's already classic "Lilac Garden" provided the major substance of last night's program by the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House. They were set in between a fair to middling performance of "Les Sylphides" and a repetition of David Lichine's "Graduation Ball," which had received its premiere by this company the night before.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 17 per cent last week compared with the like week last year, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported a gain of 19 per cent over 1943.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Elements of the Eighty-first Infantry Division landed Sunday on Garakayo Island, two and one-half miles north of Peleliu in the Palau group, Admiral Nimitz announced tonight. They quickly established and secured a beachhead, advancing inland against light opposition, the Admiral said in a communique.

LONDON, Tuesday, Oct. 10 -- Russian troops, advancing eighteen miles in a great tank battle in which 4,000 Germans were killed, yesterday smashed to within twelve miles of the great Baltic port of Memel, while other Red Army forces drove across the Hungarian plains to reach the Tisza River fifty-three miles southeast of Budapest.

The rice harvest, now in progress, is beginning to gather momentum, according to representatives of the trade, who say that the grain will be moving to market in increasing quantities from now on. By mid-November supplies should be more than adequate in city stores.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9 -- Closing in swiftly on a foe who seemed to have run out his string and apparently knew it, Billy Southworth's Cardinals brought the first all-St. Louis world series in history to an end today by downing Luke Sewell's Browns in the sixth game of the set, 3 to 1.

Offering "democratic socialism" as the only answer to poverty, Norman Thomas, Socialist party candidate for President, urged the rolling up of a large Socialist vote this year as the best way to achieve "something better than the Tweedledum-Tweedledee, Republican-Democratic party setup."
Sixteen years may seem pretty young to be a 'cellist in Arturo Toscanini's National Broadcasting Company Symphony, but not to Bobby La Marchina of St. Louis.

Our Lady of Victory Roman Catholic Church has leased the five-story building at 23 William Street for use as temporary quarters pending the erection of its own building at the northeast corner of Pine and William Streets. Plans for the new building, which will be the first Catholic church in the financial district, were filed last week with the Department of Housing and Buildings.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9 -- The bubble burst today for the Brownies. Their admirable fight of the past three weeks was at an end, and it was a forlorn, bedraggled-looking ball club which lost out to the Cardinals in the final game of the world series.

Two special shows for the connoisseur of dolls were opened yesterday. With raw materials ranging from bread crumbs to beeswax, 100 exhibitors offered dolls of all sizes at the sixth annual display sponsored by the American Hobby Federation in Hearn's auditorium, and at Saks Fifth Avenue Bernard Rafca presented 2,000 of his "portraits."

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 9 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz gave war correspondents a useful lesson in weather today and in so doing staggered them with the reading of a communique that, until he came to the last few lines, sounded very much like the No. 1 story of the Pacific war.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 9 -- After reporting Sept. 17 that a breath of fresh air had begun to rush through Chungking this correspondent is obliged to report that the fresh air has stopped rushing. In three weeks the mood has changed from optimistic tolerance to gloomy resentment and reticence.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Tuesday, Oct. 10 -- The two arms of the American First Army attack around Aachen drove within a mile and a half of each other yesterday, severing all main roads leading to the east and virtually isolating the German garrison in the city.

Completing the assembly of a tract on which he plans to erect a new laundry building, James M. Elder, owner of the Community Pride Laundry, has purchased the plot at 10 West Thirty-third Street, Bayonne, N.J., from Adolph P. Klien.

" Wilson," Twentieth Century-Fox's film story of the first World War President, will start engagements at forty-four theatres of the RKO, Skouras and Randforce circuits here beginning the week of Oct. 23, it was announced by Fox. The film is slated to open on Oct. 20 at the Merrick Theatre in Jamaica and at the Rivoli Theatre in Hempstead.

Jeanne Therrien, 24-year-old Texas-born pianist, has won the Edgar M. Leventritt Foundation's fifth annual competition for young musicians. This year's contest was open to pianists from 17 to 25 years of age. The award consists of an appearance with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra on Sunday afternoon, Jan. 28, with Leonard Bernstein conducting, when the performance will be broadcast by CBS.
Food for emergency feeding in news liberated countries is included in the Army's procurement program, Lee Marshall, Director of Distribution, War Food Administration, declared here last night.

Bidders stood aside yesterday on the stock market and, the list, denied active support except for some specialties, gave ground under moderate pressure. Although losses were the widest in a month, the average decline held under a point despite greater inroads in individual cases.

Newspapers in many parts of the world will be used by Stix, Baer Fuller, St. Louis department store, to extend greetings on its fifty-third anniversary to American service men abroad, it was announced yesterday. Quarter-page advertisements, or smaller ones where space restrictions exist, will be run this month in newspapers in Alaska, the Bahamas, Barbadoes, Bermuda, Cuba, Hawaii, Jamaica, Newfoundland, Panama, Puerto Rico, Trinidad, France, India, Australia, New Zealand, Egypt, Iraq and China.

With the increasing number of European countries being freed from Nazi domination as the Allied armies drive towards Berlin, it is vitally important to American workers that a strong, free trade labor movement be rebuilt abroad, Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, declared yesterday.

OMAHA, Oct. 10 -- Despite intensive and apparently effective efforts of the CIO Political Action Committee and its associate, the National Citizens Political Action Committee, in registering and exciting the pro-Roosevelt vote in the industrial environs of Omaha, the State of Nebraska seems destined to give its six electoral votes to Governor Dewey, the Republican Presidential nominee.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 10 (AP) -- War Correspondents covering Supreme Headquarters wrote their stories closer to the scene of action tonight. Forty-five correspondents moved today from London to Paris -- virtually the last of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's official family to get across the English Channel.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 10 -- Mobilized for the people's war, the Rhineland population, the first witnesses of the first crushing defeat of the German Army on its own soil, was told by the Koelnische Zeitung and other publications in western Germany yesterday and today to go into action in the people's war and "let the Americans beware!"

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Miss Bertha Garcia, Cuba's first ranking woman player, and Miss Mary Arnold, sixth United States player, today showed some of the best tennis thus far of the third Pan-American tennis tournament. Miss Arnold defeated Miss Garcia, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The campaign to collect used clothing for Europe's liberated peoples, conducted by Catholic, Protestant and Jewish congregations the week of Sept. 24, will far exceed its 15,000,000-pound goal. Dan West, chief of the branch of contributed supplies of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, said today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in the Southwest Pacific, Wednesday, Oct. 11 (AP) -- A Japanese attempt to reinforce the little garrison still holding out against Gen. Douglas MacArthur's invaders of Morotai was largely broken up Monday night and early Tuesday by fighter planes and patrol-torpedo boats, which sank or damaged eighteen of the reinforcement barges.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 10 -- Howie Odell, whom Yale selected to lead the Elis back to football fame, is one of the most dynamic persons in today's coaching ranks -- young, forceful and trim -- three qualities that set him apart from the rank and file of present-day coaches.

New Year's Eve always has been considered the biggest night in the theatre. Prices generally are jacked up, especially for the successes, and the intake is enormous. This year, however, New Year's Eve falls on a Sunday. Showmen already are perplexed about the matter.
Hailing from the West and making light of Eastern opposition, Darby Dunedin yesterday captured the $7,500 Tambour Purse at Jamaica, a six-furlong test restricted to juvenile fillies.
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 10 (AP) -- A Fourteenth, United States Air Force communique:

LONDON, Wednesday, Oct. 11 -- All along the Western Front, where British, Canadian and American armies are struggling to force Germany to a decision before winter comes, the fighting was limited yesterday in a driving rain, mud, cold and fog.
MOSCOW, Oct. 10 -- Premier Joseph Stalin paid the highest tribute today to the British and American forces who have broken into Germany and thereby brought nearer Adolf Hitler's defeat.

A world series that set a record for strike-outs but left no other distinguishing mark has faded quietly into baseball's archives, where it doubtless will rest without ever causing any more disturbance.

Ever since Pearl Harbor the high-school enrollment of this country has fallen at a steady rate. In three years the high schools lost a million students. Alarmed at this trend, the United States Office of Education, the Children's Bureau, the Office of War Information and other groups cooperated to urge parents to send their children to school.

AT A REGIMENTAL COMMAND POST of the United States First Army near Aachen, Oct. 10 -- The German garrison and people of Aachen have received twenty-four hours to choose between surrender and "complete destruction" in an ultimatum that Lieut. Gen. Courtney H. Hodges conveyed to the commander of the enemy forces in and around the city and to a representative of the Buergermeister at 10:50 A. M. today.
The tribute paid to the late Wendell L. Willkie by the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell follows:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Wednesday, Oct. 11 (UP) -- A communique :

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Proposed transactions leading to liquidation of the California Public Service Company, a subsidiary of the Peoples Light and Power Company, will be considered at a hearing on Oct. 23, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today.
The monsoon season is approaching its end in southeast Asia and the slow and painful operations of the Allies in Burma will be freed shortly from the delay of mud and rain.

The way of the small nations in South America is a hard one. Especially when their larger neighbors are at odds. Such is the position now of Chile. It is bound to Argentine by many historic and economic ties. It was General San Martin of Argentina who made possible the successful revolt against Spanish tyranny in 1817 and with the Chilean patriot, Bernardo O'Higgins, established Chile as a nation.

Waldon E. Balcom, assistant sales manager of Pepsodent, who is moving with his family from Chicago, Ill., has rented the six-room dwelling at 90 Lockwood Avenue, Eastchester, N.Y., from Mrs. J.I.A. Voneschen through Finnerty's Real Estate.

Acquisition of the assets and business of the Owens-Illinois Can Company, a subsidiary of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company, was voted yesterday by the directors of the Continental Can Company, according to an announcement by Carle C. Conway, president of the latter concern.

Theatrical performances for 329,713 children have been sponsored during the last year by sixty-one Junior Leagues in various parts of the country, it was reported yesterday by Virginia Lee Comer, consultant on community arts for the Association of Junior League.
LONDON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Wendell L. Willkie sped west last night toward the final resting place he had chosen in his beloved Indiana, but not before New York, the State of his adoption, had accorded a last tribute that could be given only to one who had captured the admiration, the love and the respect of the common man.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 146:

How a political sub-freshman named Wendell Willkie came to Philadelphia in the early summer of 1940 armed with a shoestring and carried off the Republican nomination for President has never been better told than in Arthur Krock's column of reminiscences yesterday, quoting from his private memoranda of the time.

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- In recent months 3,500 persons suspected of collaboration with the enemy have been arrested in northern France, it was announced at Lille today. Despite the growing number of lists of this kind throughout France, protests are still heard that the purge is not being pressed with sufficient vigor.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- One of the first results of the conservations between Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin will be an invitation to Prime Minister Stanislaw Mikolajczyk of the Polish Government here to join them in Moscow, it was confidently expected tonight.

HAVANA, Oct. 10 -- Dr. Ramon Grau San Martin, physician and university professor, was sworn in as President of Cuba at noon today in the Presidential Palace as his followers throughout the republic celebrated wildly.
Former Gov. Charles Edison of New Jersey and Mrs. Edison are expected to come to the Ambassador today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (U.P.) -- The War Labor Board announced tonight that it would not attempt to define the authority of President Roosevelt to modify the wage stabilization policy when it made its report on whether the Little Steel formula should be changed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- As a result of increases in agricultural income and military payments, the Department of Commerce's index of total income payments to individuals in the United States climbed to a high record in August.

Havoc wrought by war upon missions in fighting zones has produced conditions calling for increased missionary activity, according to a letter from Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, who has written a letter from Rome to be read in churches of the archdiocese this Sunday.

The eighty-day duck season will open on Saturday in the intermediate zone, which takes in a considerable amount of the United States, including most of New York and neighboring States. Straws in the wind indicate that the early shooting will not be good

New training and refresher courses, designed to teach nearly 1,000,000 junior hostesses in 2,000 United Service Organization clubhouses to help service men become readjusted to civilian surroundings, will begin this month, it was announced yesterday at USO headquarters in the Empire State Building.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 10 (U.P.) -- Dr. Earnest A. Hooton, Harvard anthropologist, said tonight that the Allied victories in France had dispelled the last vestiges of the Nazi super-race myth.

Volumes 11 and 12 in "The Yale Edition of Horace Walpole's Correspondence'' were published yesterday by the Yale University Press. They consist chiefly of Walpole's correspondence with Mary and Agnes Berry, two young women he met when he was 70 and who became his neighbors.

An increase of 35 per cent in annual production and sales over 1940 to provide 550,000 more jobs here was announced yesterday as the post-war goal for New York City by Clarence Francis, vice chairman of the Committee for Economic Development and chairman of the board of General Foods, Inc.
Columbus Day will be observed here tomorrow by parades and other celebrations. The principal event will be a parade up Fifth Avenue from Forty-fourth to Eighty-fourth Street, beginning at 1 P.M.

Expansion of the Metropolitan Opera Guild's educational program and broadening of its war activities were announced yesterday at the Hotel Pierre by Mrs. August Belmont, founder of the organization, who has returned to active service as president.
WENATCHEE, Wash., Oct. 10 (U.P.) -- The New Deal "subsidy theory" of Federal dealing with State and local finances was condemned tonight by Governor Bricker as a threat to American home rule.

Denying charges in the Moscow publication War and the Working Class that the Vatican is pr-Fascist, the Rev. John LaFarge, S.J., editor in chief of America, national Catholic weekly, asserted in a statement to Religious News Service yesterday that the Soviet journal's "acid remarks" were inspired by the "unreasoning and needless fear of the unity of Protestants, Catholics and Jews in English-speaking countries."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 4:

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- The estimate of the Department of Agriculture that this year's corn harvest would be 3,196,977,000 bushels, an increase of 95,000,000 in the forecast in a month, was issued today after the close of business on the Chicago Board of Trade.

With the big guns of American warships thundering only 1,100 miles away and a great American carrier-plane raid striking 200 miles from the Japanese homeland, Premier General Koiso finds it expedient again to warn his people of the "very grave" situation confronting them and to promise that if they provide the weapons it may be possible for Nippon's armed forces "to crush the enemy with a single stroke."

Milton Karel was in Federal custody yesterday because, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, he tried too hard to convince too many people -- mostly young and feminine -- that he was an ultra-secret agent of the Army's Military Intelligence Division.

Governor John W. Bricker's qualifications to succeed to the Presidency if Governor Dewey should be elected and subsequently die were emphasized last night by Senator Albert W. Hawkes of New Jersey in a radio broadcast sponsored by the New Jersey Republican State Committee.
William D. Abeam, a member of the law firm of Clark, Carr Ellis, has leased a thirteen-room duplex apartment in 990 Fifth Avenue through Douglas Gibbons Co.

FOR a peculiar and powerful fusion of melodrama and political crusading you could not do better than investigate a startling novel by Margaret Shedd called "Inherit the Earth."* Miss Shedd, who is a daughter and granddaughter of missionaries and a niece of Charles G. Dawes, has lived long in British Honduras and in Mexico.

One of the important planks in the 1944 Republican platform stresses replacing Federal control by State controls wherever possible. The recent gathering of Western State Executives to discuss flood control and irrigation problems in the Missouri watershed, the largest tributary stream in the United States, was construed in many circles as an invitation for the formation of another TVA.

A public hearing, held yesterday by the President's Committee on Fair Employment Practice, in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street, brought forth a series of witnesses who told of discrimination by the Seafarers International Union of North America in referring seamen to certain ships and restricting men to certain departments aboard ship.

ROME, Oct. 10 -- Future Italian historians may write that a quarter-hour of bad humor on the part of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower on Sept. 8, 1943, changed the course of events in Italy. That will come from the account of Brig. Gen. Maxwell Taylor's dramatic visit to Rome to prepare for the American airborne division's landing that never took place.

LONDON, Oct. 10 (U.P.) -- Morning newspapers today generally approved the Dumbarton Oaks Conference program, but there were some points of criticism on what were termed shortcomings and gaps in the plan, and some editorialists, recalling the League of Nations, expressed the fear that the United States Senate would repeat its refusal to approve the proposed world organization.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- A new high record harvest for 1944 "now seems in reach," the crop reporting board of the Department of Agriculture said today. It called production "remarkable," considering farmers' labor-shortage and weather difficulties.

PARIS, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Trading in foreign securities was resumed today on the Paris Bourse amid bearish interpretations of a decree ordering all foreign securities to be listed and filed with the Government. It was the first trading in such securities since German occupation of the capital in June, 1940. No American issues appeared.

CORINTH CANAL, Greece, Oct. 9 (Delayed) -- The Germans retreating from the Peloponnesus blew up the sides of this most important waterway, sank ships at its entrances and threw in an enormous quantity of stolen property which they were attempting to carry away with them.

British-United States world controls on hides and skins not only have reacted to accentuate the shortage situation in this country but are defeating the purposes sought, according to a statement issued yesterday by the National Association of Importers of Hides and Skins.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- A "substantial proportion" of the 4,305 naval officers who returned to active duty from retirement since the war emergency began in 1939 are to be gradually released from service, the Navy Department disclosed today.

An investment banking group headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. and Drexel Co. as joint managers, will offer today $23,735,000 of general mortgage 3 3/8 per cent Series E bonds of the Pittsburgh, Cincinnati, Chicago St. Louis Railroad Company, affiliated with the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, at 102, to yield 3.27 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Presbyterian Church in the United States of America is opening a four-year campaign in which it will work for organic union with the Presbyterian Church in the United States (Southern), the United Presbyterian Church and the Reformed Church "as a first step toward Protestant unity," it was announced today.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 10 -- Secretary Ickes, speaking here tonight under the auspices of the State Democratic Committee, ridiculed Governor Dewey's charge that the West had been neglected under the Roosevelt Administration.

Harry A. Levy, national supervisor of sales to department stores for three candy companies, was appointed city salvage director for the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, chairman-director of the CDVO. Mr. Levy, who has been serving as salvage director for Manhattan, succeeds Frank D. March, who resigned, criticizing the CDVO for confining its salvage efforts to an educational plan.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 10 -Connecticut's corps of State and local policewomen, organized during the past year under the Social Protection Committee of the Connecticut War Council, was praised today for helping reduce wartime juvenile delinquency and venereal disease rates in the State.
LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Activity in today's stock markets was again on the small side, operators generally being inclined to await news regarding the purpose of the Prime Minister's visit to Moscow.

LONDON, Oct. 10 (U.P.) -- Adolf Hitler and Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels, attesting to their own fanatical faith in nazism, strove today to bolster the faith of the German people, asserting that endurance and a greater spirit of sacrifice would bring victory to the Reich.

Reporting on operations of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., and its subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended on July 29, Jack I. Straus, president, announced yesterday to stockholders that consolidated net retail sales, including those of leased departments, rose to a new peak of $169,897,774 from the $166,759,594 volume for the preceding fiscal year.
You will probably be interested in the following excerpt from a letter I recently received from a young Negro sergeant who is serving in the Army in Italy:

ROME, Oct. 10 -- Although at least one Italian commentator declared today that the political significance of Vincenzo Azzolini's trial was far greater than that of Pietro Caruso's, the public continued to show little interest in Azzolini's case today as the taking of witnesses' testimony began.
Excerpts from the addresses of the speakers at last night's meeting on "Labor and the Veteran" in the New York Times Hall follow:
Yesterday's communiqu, as broadcast in Serbo-Croat by the Free Yugoslav Radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Pressure on the stock market lifted yesterday, but under the handicap of the lightest volume in two weeks, prices did little better than become moderately firm. Buying in the air transport division gave the market a stronger appearance than was revealed by statistics, for the number of issues to decline exceeded those to rise by only one.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10 -- The Tide Water Power Company, Wilmington, N.C., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering the proposed issuance and sale by competitive bidding of $500,000 of 3 1/2 per cent first mortgage bonds and 10,000 shares of a new 5 per cent $100 par value preferred stock.

Mary, the wife of GI Joe who misses his advice on how to vote this year, and Tilly, who is electioneering for a candidate who has given her a ham, are puppets in a show, but they are also symbolic of many housewives whom the New York League of Women Voters hopes to reach in its campaign this fall through dramatizing the need for a large and educated voting public.

A large and diversified exhibition called "The Army at War" will be opened to the public today at the Roxy Theatre. It is presented by the United States Treasury and War Departments, and will continue here for three weeks before going on tour.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 10 (U.P.) -- The threatened general strike of 70,000 members of the Mechanics Educational Society of America in Cleveland, Detroit and Toledo, set for 10 A.M. Thursday, apparently hinged tonight on the union's objection to any arbitrator appointed by Cleveland's Mayor Frank J. Lausche.

Many large gifts, including several from anonymous donors, have been received by the United Hospital Campaign Committee for maintenance funds for city-owned and voluntary hospitals and the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday by James S. Adams, chairman of the organization, with headquarters at 370 Lexington Avenue.

The 1,062 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $101,398,754,393 of par value as of Sept. 30, had a total market value of $102,017,012,414, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of Aug. 31, there were 1,059 issues, aggregating $101,581,322,714 par value, which had a total market value of $102,328,885,992.

ROME, Oct. 10 (AP) -- American troops of the Fifth Army, toiling slowly forward through mud, rain and stout German positions, are within heavy artillery range of Bologna, Allied Headquarters disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Comparison of the United Nations charter, as issued by the conferees at Dumbarton Oaks, with the structure of the old League of Nations shows a similar framework but several essential differences aiming to make the new institution an instrument for checking wars before any hostilities rather than a combination to punish aggression.

QUINCY, Mass., Oct. 10 -- A conference of union and company officials will be held tomorrow in an attempt to settle the two-day strike at the Bethlehem Steel Company's Quincy shipyard after the Navy acted tonight to seek an end to the walkout that threatens warship construction.

Russell V. Cruikshank, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, in a prepared statement concerning the U.S. Senate's Small Business Committee's report on commercial rents, said yesterday that "most of the fanfare concerning this subject comes from those who have axes to grind."

Senator Claude Pepper of Florida charged yesterday that John Foster Dulles, and through him, Governor Dewey, Republican Presidential nominee, had broken an implied agreement with President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull to keep the making of the peace on a nonpartisan basis.

Charging that the Roosevelt Administration would make all insurance employes "Government clerks," Theodore M. Riehle, chairman of the National Insurance Committee for Dewey and Bricker, sent an appeal yesterday to insurance company employes and executives throughout the country to work for the election of the Republican national ticket.

Three new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Hollywood the new attraction will be "To Have and Have Not," Warners' screen version of the Ernest Hemingway story, with Humphrey Bogart starred. The topical drama features Lauren Bacall and Hoagy Carmichael, both of whom are making their film debuts, and Walter Brennan, Dolores Moran and Dan Seymour . . . .

Organized labor's grave dissatisfaction with existing legislation for returning war veterans and its resentment at Governmental interference with the free play of collective bargaining were forcibly expressed last night at a meeting in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, by spokesmen for the American Federation of Labor, the Congress of Industrial Organizations and one of the leading railroad brotherhoods.

Describing 1944 as "the most bitter year of the struggle on the mainland of Asia," Dr. Wei Taoming, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, declared last night at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, celebrating the thirty-third anniversary of the Republic of China, that the Chinese would continue to fight, regardless of the odds, until victory.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Strict control over a few key industries in Germany will enable the United Nations to prevent re-armament and at the same time permit a healthy economy to exist within that country, according to foreign traders and Government officials who discussed the problem here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The fact that no armistice convention with Bulgaria has taken shape points to some divergence between Britain and Russia. Fully one month has passed since Bulgaria surrendered and a new Government was set up in Sofia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- William H. Davis and other officials of the War Labor Board conceded today that the board could do nothing to force the American Federation of Musicians to reconsider its refusal to grant the request of President Roosevelt made last Wednesday to lift its ban on recordings for commercial use, as ordered by the WLB last June.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Communique 185:

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Complaining that "over caution" had already been carried too far in this war, Lord Vansittart today resisted on and obtained a government assurance to debate the broad terms of any peace treaty or provisional or partial settlement with Germany.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 10 -- Even in times of baleful adversity Chungking mechanically goes through the correct motions of public celebration. In honor of the Double Tenth [Oct. 10] anniversary of the 1911 revolution the gloomy, muddy capital of China was decorated today with national flags and everygreen arches with gold emblazoned characters and paper lanterns.

MOSCOW, Oct. 10 -- The Soviet Government is interested in developing economic properties outside its own boundaries and already has a mission in Iran negotiating with the Government there for a Kevirkhurian oil concession in the northern part of that country, it was disclosed today.

Asserting that the State Department has been "startled" to find business delegations approaching it for the retention of trade controls, Charles P. Taft, director of the department's Office of Wartime Economic Affairs, declared yesterday that "it is high time that private business got away from its liking for the security of Government distribution of business and began to justify the descriptive term 'enterprise.'"

The Morosco Realty Corporation has purchased the three-story store and apartment buildings at 640 Morris Avenue, corner of 149th Street, the Bronx, from Matthew Sullivan, Inc. Victor Morosco, president of the buying corporation, said he plans to demolish the present building and erect a new structure in which the Morosco Restaurant will occupy a major portion.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- A warning against "danger signals on the horizon of post-war planning" with regard to the employment of women was voiced today by Margaret A. Hickey, chairman of the women's advisory committee of the War Manpower Commission at a meeting of WMC women employes.

LONDON, Wednesday, Oct. 11 -- Red Army forces drove to the Baltic Sea north of Memel yesterday, cutting the last overland escape routes for an estimated 100,000 Germans in western Latvia, while in Yugoslavia the Russians severed the Belgrade-Athens railroad, the main Nazi lifeline from the Balkans.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- World Affairs, the bulletin of the American Peace Society, is about to release in its October issue statements by a Democratic and a Republican Senate leader which point identical ways to a bipartisan solution of the domestic political problems posed by the draft of the International Security League which has been submitted to the heads of the four great Allied nations by the delegates to the Dumbarton Oaks conference.

The statement in Topics of The Times in your Sept. 27 issue that "also on the way out, we imagine, are the revolutionary ideas on the teaching of foreign languages so hastily derived from the experience of the accelerated ATS language courses," is extremely unfortunate.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Martin (Slats) Marion, star shortstop of the newly crowned world champion Cardinals, and Bobby Doerr, Red Sox second baseman, today were named by The Sporting News as its selections for the most valuable players in the National and American Leagues, respectively, for 1944.

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- The striking point in Robert Piguet's opening today was his attempt to revive the bolero. His models were very Parisian but very restrained. In all there is gathered fullness at the front; the backs are straight and slightly bloused.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 10 (AP) -- China commemorated today the thirty-third anniversary of the Oct. 10 revolution that led to establishment of the Chinese Republic and was cheered by a prediction from Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek that "the coming year will not only bring us final victory but also will witness the success of our national revolution."

With cotton traders awaiting developments in Washington, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange finished yesterday 2 points lower to 9 points higher than on Monday. July was relatively the strongest month.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Susan B. Anthony 2d, great-niece of the exponent of woman suffrage, said last night that Representative Clare Boothe Luce. Republican, of Connecticut, had given "an exhibition of shallowness, derision and so-called glamour" in place of "the strength and the dignity and the powers of womanly statesmanship in the terrible tragedy of these days."

As a result of the "splendid response" received from distributors and dealers during the previous program which ended in August, the Norge Division of Borg-Warner Corporation has again released an extensive newspaper and magazine campaign throughout Latin America and South Africa, it was announced yesterday.

Presented with three possible methods of revising MPR 127 which governs pricing of finished cotton and rayon fabrics, the converters industry advisory committee meeting with officials of the Office of Price Administration in New York yesterday unanimously voted a motion urging OPA to adopt an interim regulation based on the "panel" plan.

Sales of E.R. Squibb Sons for the fiscal year ended with June rose 13.1 per cent in the twelve-month period to a new high record of $47,982,533, but increased taxes pared the net income to $2,389,816, or $4.01 a share on 495,606 shares outstanding on June 30, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Carleton H. Palmer, chairman.

LONDON, Oct. 10 (Reuter) -- Three British members of the International Olympic Committee today went on record officially as putting in a bid for the next Olympics to be held in the "scarred and battered" city of London.

Twenty thousand block leaders serving with the New York City Civilian Defense Volunteer Office will be incorporated into a division called the CDVO Neighborhood Representative Division, it was announced yesterday from CDVO headquarters at City Hall.

ROME, Oct. 10 -- A fortnight after landing at Katakolon on the western rim of the Peloponnesus, Lieut. Col. George Jellicoe's British troops have entered Corinth and thus completed a coastal sweep of almost 150 miles to conclude the lightly joined battle of southern Greece.

Complete endorsement of the United Nations organization outlined in the Dumbarton Oaks agreements was announced yesterday by the executive committee of the League of Nations Association, which also disclosed that it would change its name to embody that of the new United Nations body.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The War Production Board gave the foundry industry today a glimpse of its future after the fall of Germany, revealing a virtually unrestricted return to civilian production.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 10 (AP) -- The State Conservation Department, expecting more than 100,000 deer hunters to take the field this fall, predicted today that the 1943 kill of 22,368 bucks and does would be equaled or surpassed.

Last year, in the two months ended on Sept. 30, open-market commercial paper rose $20,000,000 to $169,500,000. This year the figure fell $2,000,000 to $140,800,000, showing a definite reversal of the normal seasonal trend. Bumper grain crops are said to be the answer.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,268, against 1,209 last week and 1,088 in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the lists appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 581, compared to 872 last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (U.P.) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, New York Democrat, charged today that the German Government was trying to have Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, former German Finance Minister, accepted with favor in this country, and called on Americans in high places who have had dealings with him to make his operations public.

LONDON, Oct. 10 (U.P.) -- Germany had extorted $26,400,000,000 from occupied countries in the form of "occupation costs" and unpaid-for goods until Aug. 31, the Ministry of Economic Warfare revealed today.

The Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House last night gave the season's first performances of Antony Tudor's "Romeo and Juliet" and Michel Fokine's, "Bluebeard." along with a repetition of Jerome Robbins' "Fancy Free."

One of the youngest men holding a master's license in the American Maritime Service received the first of the new Merchant Marine Meritorious Service Medals yesterday for his direction of a lifeboat during the storm that struck the French coast soon after the Allied invasion last June.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- President Roosevelt announced tonight his approval of a financial program viewed as marking a major step in making American markets available to the Italian Government and paving the way for a resumption of normal trade between the two countries by providing dollar backing for military lire issued as pay to American troops.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Charles (Red) Embree, ace of the Baltimore Orioles' pitching staff, tossed a four-hit shut-out at the Colonels tonight, while his mates pounded three Louisville hurlers for thirteen safeties and a 10-0 victory to put the Birds out in front of the Little World series, three games to two.

That overweight youngster whose classmates call him "Fatty" needs help, the nutrition division of the New York City Department of Health tells us. It says that parents have a way of dismissing extra pounds as not serious, when in reality they deprive the child of buoyant health and vitality, usually making him less active in sports and play, frequently sluggish in school, lacking in ambition and poor in social adjustments.

As might be expected by anyone who happened to see the New York Giants in their opener against the Boston Yankees in Fenway Park last Sunday, Coach Steve Owen devoted a considerable part of yesterday's practice, first since then, to a verbal expression of his disgust.

HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 10 (U.P.) -- Finland columns struck north and east of Torneaa, Swedish-Finnish border bridgehead at the top of the Gulf of Bothnia, in pursuit of retreating German forces, a Finnish communique announced today.

The swift pace of development in aircraft power plants is exemplified in the growth of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation, now celebrating its twenty-fifth anniversary. The company's early products, resulting from a combination of the designs of Charles L. Lawrance and its own engineers, began the extraordinary evolution of the radial engine in America.
LONDON, Oct. 10 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:...

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Thomas J. Curran, Republican Senatorial candidate, said 'to Dutchess and Orange Counties tonight "the New Deal has attempted to make a political football of agriculture in State and nation."

Two members of the "shirtsleeve gang" of ex-convict gunmen that perpetrated at least thirty holdups in the last year, usually minus their coats and hats and using pistols sometimes carried for them by a 19-year-old girl, were sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to State prison for twenty to forty years each.
ROME, Oct. 10 (UP) -- A communique:

A little older, a little heavier but a lot funnier and more loquacious than ever before, Staff Sgt. Joe Louis, heavyweight champion of the world, returned here yesterday and told all about his fourteen-month trip that covered this country, England, Scotland, Ireland, Italy, Africa and other points of interest.

Nicolas Kopeikine, veteran Russian pianist, who has made but few appearances in New York in recent years, gave a recital at Town Hall last night which was attended by a large and devoted gathering. His playing, like that of so many pianists trained in the exacting Russian school, is clear and forceful, and filled with genuine and thoroughly musical feeling for the music at hand.

BERLIN, Ore., Oct. 10 (U.P.) -- Residents of this town are not particularly proud of the name, which it got by accident in the first place, but if any changing is to be done, they want to do it themselves.

The Midwest dominates the first Associated Press football poll of the 1944 campaign -- just as that sector grabbed the honors in each of the previous eight seasons the nation's sports writers picked the leaders.

Complete returns from the five boroughs early this morning for the second day of registration indicated that New Yorkers were out much stronger at their polling places than they had been on Monday. Registration took a sharp spurt and the complete figures for the two days carried the total to 113,092 more than had registered for the first two days in 1940, the last Presidential year.
Manhattan property at a total assessed valuation of more than $1,397,000 was reported in realty transactions yesterday.

A banking group composed of the Harris Trust and Savings Bank, Chicago; the Chase National Bank, the Northern Trust Company, Chicago; the Bankers Trust Company and the National City Bank of New York and associates submitted yesterday the high bid for an issue of $12,000,000 city of Portland (Ore.) sewage disposal bonds.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 10 -- Milton Berle will return to Twentieth Century-Fox for his first film role in two years He will have the top comedy part, the fictional character of Professor Winud, a vaudeville performer and owner of a trained seal, in "The Dolly Sisters.''

SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The possibility of Australia's Labor Government's taking over newspapers to assure the people of news was mentioned today by the Information Minister during a discussion of a dispute that has left Sydney and the State of New South Wales virtually without newspapers.

The use of sulfadiazine prophylaxis in the Navy has been followed by "a marked reduction" in respiratory diseases, Comdr. Alvin F. Coburn of the Navy Medical Corps last night told the seventeenth annual graduate fortnight of the New York Academy of Medicine at 2 East 103rd Street.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 10 -The Ryukyu Islands, innermost guardians of the Japanese homeland, were attacked yesterday by carrier planes from Admiral William F. Halsey's Third Fleet. The enemy lost eighty-nine planes, fifty-eight ships were hit, and many shore defenses were left in flames by our carrier task forces' boldest venture of the war.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- The American Federation of Musicians, AFL, through its president, James C. Petrillo, informed President Roosevelt today that it would not grant his request to permit union musiicans to make phonograph recordings for commercial use unless all recording companies paid royalties on each disk into the union treasury.

Gifts totaling $240,451 have already been received by the women's division of the New York War Fund, Mrs. Vincent Astor, chairman of the unit, announced yesterday. This figure represents $9,000 more than had been contributed in the second week of the campaign a year ago, she told 150 volunteer workers at a report meeting at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.

Wilhelm Albrecht von Pressentin Gennant von Rautter of Brooklyn, 44-year-old former German count, escaped the death penalty for conspiring to commit espionage, and was sentenced instead by Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday to serve a prison term of twenty-nine years only because of the judge's fear that "revenge would be meted out to American citizens in Germany."

Because of the confusion apparent during the first day of registration, city officials moved yesterday to ease the congestion at the polling places so that all persons who want to vote in the November election may register before the deadline Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Under-Secretary of War Patterson declared today that a scheduled strike of skilled machinists in sixty-four war plants in the Cleveland, Toledo and Detroit areas would represent "a stab in the back of the American soldiers who are now locked in battle with the enemy in Europe and the Pacific."

The local office of the War Food Administration reported yesterday that meat receipts in New York City for the week ending Oct. 7 had dropped 2.5 per cent to 29,948,307 pounds from the preceding week's total of 30,711,873 pounds. Last week's receipts, however, were 1.1 per cent larger than those for the corresponding week last year, 29,621,870 pounds.

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- Arrival of the first plane to fly from the United States to France since the war is an event meaning more to the French than anyone can imagine who hasn't been cut off from outside contacts for years that seemed like decades. As a sign of liberation the resumption of direct communication with the American contingent stirs the French almost as much as the landing of the Allied armies.

College basketball at Madison Square Garden, where the court sport has flourished for a decade, will get under way there for its eleventh successive season on Wednesday night, Dec. 6, with C.C.N.Y. facing Detroit and N.Y.U. engaging Rochester, it was announced yesterday by Ned Irish at a luncheon at Toots Shor's.

Apparently as a result of the narrowing circle of battlefronts in Europe and the ever-lessening danger of air attack here, "a considerable part" of the Army's anti-aircraft protection for the New York area is being removed, it became known last night.

Thirteen, forming one of the best handicap fields of the season and with First Fiddle in the role of favorite, are entered today in the Continental Handicap at Jamaica, where the Metropolitan Jockey Club will conduct its second war relief day this year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -The Navy announced today that the French Order of the Legion d'Honneur had been awarded to eight United States naval officers by Vice Admiral Raymond Fenard, chief of the French naval mission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- A proposal that all young girls in the Government service be sent home came today from a social service expert as Washington debated the question of how to safeguard those who have come here from rural communities to take wartime jobs.

Among the many housing projects filed with the Department of Housing and Buildings yesterday in anticipation of stricter zoning rules for the city was a ten-story apartment house for a plot 161 by 100 feet at the southwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Nineteenth Street.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Thursday, Oct. 12 (AP) -- A communique:

Sarande is an Albanian town which even map followers may not recognize. Since the Italian occupation it has been known as Porto Edda, after the daughter of a man named Mussolini. At Sarande the British have just fought their first real battle since the Germans began their flight from Greece.

Federal stockpiling of raw materials and finished goods for any purpose other than military necessity will breed inflation both here and abroad, according to the Economists Committee on Reconversion Problems.
Eleven cases of diphtheria were reported last week in New York City, five more than the week before, and "they are unnecessary," Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins said yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Coach George Munger turned back the pages of the University of Pennsylvania's football history book today to impress his squad with the importance of battling over-confidence as they drill for Saturday's game with William and Mary.

Hitler is often referred to as a "corporal of the first World War." Even Mr. Churchill speaks constantly of him as of a corporal, thus conferring upon the man a rank to which not even he has ever laid a claim.

Successful in her self-conducted search, Mrs. Cora Haley left New York yesterday with her sister, Mrs. Annie Tarr of Roxbury, Mass., who had been missing from her home since Aug. 25. Mrs. Haley, also of Roxbury, came to New York last Friday and gave herself a week and a limited amount of money to find her sister.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Oct. 10 (Delayed) -- President Roosevelt wished to avoid large dollar debts that would burden post-war international commerce and final lend-lease settlement could be only on a world basis and must be judged in relation to the betterment of post-war economic and social conditions, Finance Minister Walter Nash assured New Zealanders in the House of Representatives last night in discussing a situation that has caused some misgivings here.

LONDON, Thursday, Oct. 12 -- Of all the fighting along several hundred miles of the front from the Netherland coast to the Swiss frontier none is more important, nor are the stakes higher, than in the sector where the Canadians in a series of complicated maneuvers are trying to clear up pockets of resistance and silence guns that deny the Allies the use of Antwerp's docks.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in Serbo-Croat by the Free Yugoslav radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ROSELLE, N.J., Oct. 11 -- The Nancy-Luzon Post of the Veterans of Foreign Wars has purchased the Macquoid property at Fourth Avenue and Chestnut Street for a war memorial and for use as a free lodging house for returning veterans of the present war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Production of half of the twenty types of Army planes now in service will continue on full scale after Germany surrenders, work on three new planes will be expanded and the output of ten models will be cut in varying degrees.
Notes on recent fishing operations:

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Troops of the Eighty-first Infantry landed unopposed Tuesday on Bairakaseru Islet, seven miles northwest of recently occupied Garakayo, strengthening the American grip on the southern Palaus, the Navy announced in a communique tonight.

All candidates for the Supreme Court in New York County, one candidate for the Court of Appeals and one for the Court of General Sessions, New York County, were found "qualified" by the board of directors of the New York County Lawyers Association, it was announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Don Hutson, who already holds a big handful of National Football League records, apparently is well on his way to break a couple of them with the season barely under way.

Registration in the five boroughs continued yesterday to keep ahead of the pace set for the Presidential election in 1940, but there was a falling off in the speed for the third day, compared with four years ago, according to figures compiled early this morning.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today set Nov. 8 for a hearing on a joint plan filed by the Standard Power and Light Corporation, and its subsidiary, the Standard Gas and Electric Company, in compliance with an order of the commission dated June 19, 1942, calling for the liquidation of Standard Power.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- A desperate situation is developing in the matter of nurses for the Army.

Senator Robert F. Wagner, Democrat, who is running for re-election in New York State, announced yesterday that he had drawn a bill providing for control of commercial rents which he would introduce in the Senate as soon as Congress reconvenes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- A Chinese relief and rehabilitation program under which the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration would be asked to contribute $945,000,000 to meet 37 per cent of the import costs was presented at a press conference today by Dr. Tingfu F. Tsiang, Chinese member of the UNRRA council.

Nicholas G. Lely, chief of the Greek Information Service in the United States, issued yesterday a statement cabled here by George Cartalis, Greek Minister of Information, which branded as fraudulent a reported agreement between Greeks and the Bulgarian Government that would permit Bulgarians to remain in Greek Macedonia and Thrace.

The lowly meatball and the plebeian hamburger have been advanced to places of prominence on the menus of Westchester and Long Island golf clubs and other swank places, the American Meat Institute reported yesterday.

OUTSIDE AACHEN, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Now Aachen is learning what the American Command meant when the ultimatum was sent in yesterday. Aachen is falling apart -- slowly, it is true, for this is a big target, but falling apart, nevertheless.

French radio stations yesterday gave the names of two more French villages to be remembered in the final settling of accounts, the Paris radio charging that German troops had massacred all butt ten of the 520 inhabitants of Comblanchien in Burgundy and the Brazzaville radio charging that Germans had hanged 120 Frenchmen in Tulle.

The principal security and commodity exchanges throughout the country will be closed today in observance of Columbus Day. Livestock markets will operate as usual, as will the security and commodity markets in Canada.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 11 (U.P.) -- Admiral William F. Halsey's carrier plane attack on the Ryukyu Islands was only the first of a series designed to crush enemy strength in a vital stretch of Japan's inner defense line, well informed sources believed today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 148:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Industrial alcohol requirements for the synthetic rubber program have been slashed to 22,000,000 gallons a month from a previous level of 30,000,000 gallons, according to word reaching the liquor trade here today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 11 -- High military and political circles and the mass of the people alike believe that Brazil's war effort is entitled to greater recognition, both now and later, at the peace conference.

LONDON, Oct. 11 (U.P.) -- Four hundred Flying Fortresses and fighter escorts of the United States Eighth Air Force groped through "soup" weather over the western front today to attack military targets at Coblenz and Cologne, just east of the First United States Army's Aachen offensive.

Well over 4,300,000 men and women in the armed forces have applied for absentee ballots and the best estimates of State election officials indicate that more than 2,300,000 of the ballots will be cast in the Nov. 7 election.
BERLIN, Ore., Oct. 11 (AP) -- This town is going to keep its name.

In an editorial printed in its first edition today, The New York Daily News announced the discontinuance of its political "Battle Page" with the explanation that some "below the belt" blows had been registered there and more might be expected.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- Extension of rural telephone service and application of new ideas in telephony were offered today by Walter S. Gifford, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, as post-war projects for the industry.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Coming from behind with three runs in the seventh inning, the Baltimore Orioles of the International League won the little world series, four games to two, tonight by defeating the Louisville Colonels of the American Association, 5 to 3, before a crowd of 23,536.

The first premiere of the ballet theatre season at the Metropolitan Opera House took place last night in the form of George Balanchine's "Waltz Academy," with music by Vittorio Rieti, scenery by Oliver Smith and costumes by Alvin Colt. Heading the crest were Nana Gollner and Nora Kaye and along with them Janet Reed, Albia Kavan, Miriam Golden and John Kriza, among others.

Samuel Okin, Manhattan lawyer and owner of 9,000 shares of common stock of the Electric Bond and Share Company made a determined last stand yesterday against the management of that huge utility company but came off second best as stockholders at their annual meeting adopted a resolution voicing confidence in the present management.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Governor Ogle Steeplechase Handicap marked the return of the jumpers to Maryland racing today and gave Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark's Boojum II the opportunity to score an easy four-length victory over the nearest of nine opponents, all of whom completed the two-mile course.

MADRID, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Spain has offered the French Government "all possible facilities" to bring under control the Spanish Republican Maquis forces that have been raiding Spanish territory from France since Oct. 4, it was announced here today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Oct. 11 (Reuter) -- Col. David Sarnoff, now on military leave of absence from duties as president of the Radio Corporation of America and chairman of the board of the National Broadcasting Company, received today the Legion of Merit for "exceptionally meritorious conduct in the performance of outstanding service."

Generoso Pope, publisher of the Italian language newspaper Il Progresso, announced yesterday plans for this afternoon's Columbus Day parade on Fifth Avenue, of which is to be the grand marshal, and also made public a message of good wishes from President Roosevelt.
The report of the Dow Chemical Company and subsidiaries for the quarter ended on Aug. 31, last, disclosed yesterday a net profit of $2,229,700, subject to renegotiation.

Since a unilateral attempt by the United States to control business and trade under foreign laws would be "ineffective and prejudicial," the thirty-first National Foreign Trade Convention called yesterday for a governmental policy which would allow "the standard of competition between Americans and foreigners, and thus also between competing American firms, to be determined by the requirements of the applicable foreign law."
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 11 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

The Flomarcy Company, steamship agents and operators for the Portuguese Lines, New York to Lisbon, publishes a "peace and good-will' advertisement today in New York, Philadelphia and Washington newspapers commemorating Columbus Day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- In the days when Dr. Arthur E. Morgan was still the Chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, before the President removed him for "contumacy," a Round Table at Princeton took up the issue of Government-owned versus private utilities.

LONDON, Thursday, Oct. 12 -The Red Army roared up to the East Prussian border west of Kaunas yesterday, reportedly isolated the great Baltic port of Memel, and on the southern front, with the aid of Rumanian troops, captured Szeged, second largest city in Hungary, and Cluj, capital of Transylvania.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace, opening a Midwestern Democratic campaign tour tonight, attacked what he called "Taftism" in the home town of Senator Robert A. Taft, declaring that policies advocated by Mr. Taft were "backed by strong newspapers, banks, and real estate," and added:

Lou Little drilled his Columbia squad against Yale's offense and defense yesterday in preparation for Saturday's game at New Haven. The third-stringers, armed with Eli plays, ran against the first and second teams for a half hour and then Little tried his own offense, with the third-stringers using the defense he hopes Yale will adopt.
LONDON, Oct. 11 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

QUINCY, Mass., Oct. 11 -- An agreement, under which workers' grievances will be submitted to the State Board of Conciliation and Arbitration if nearly 6,000 striking employes at the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipyard here return to work tomorrow, was announced tonight after a series of conferences brought about by Navy intervention.

LONDON, Oct. 11 (Reuter) -- Americans will soon dine from exotic china turned on famous British potters' wheels while battle raged in the skies overhead and most of the factories swung over to war production.

Two new pictures will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall, "Mrs. Parkington," Metro's adaptation of the novel by Louis Bromfield starring Greer Garson and Walter Pidgeon, will have its world premiere.

Recommendations for modification of the retail inventory control order, L-219, will be made to the subcommittee of the Retail Advisory Committee of the War Production Board if the order should still be in effect on Jan. 15, it was stated yesterday following a meeting of the Central Council of National Retail Trade Associations at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company has been appointed transfer agent for 82,000 shares of 4 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock of the Oliver Corporation. The National City Bank will act as registrar for the stock.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 -- Sidney Hillman, chairman of the CIO Political Action Committee, charged tonight that Governor Dewey was nominated as the Presidential candidate of the Republican party, not for his experience, ability or convictions, but because of his lack of convictions, his ability to confuse the issues and because the Republican Old Guard did not want to fight "an honest campaign in which they stood forthrightly upon the record of their party."
PARIS, Oct. 10 (Delayed) -- Of 350 members of the Union of French Women deported to Germany and interned in the Auswitz concentration camp, only four are alive today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Hungary's "fatal hour has struck," Senator Tom Connally said in a message broadcast to Hungary today through the OWI. The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee summoned Hungarians to shed the Nazi yoke and to ally themselves with the United Nations.

Post-war commercial shipping through the ports of the United States and Canada will have facilities equal to those provided in wartime, according to predictions yesterday at the opening of the thirty-third annual convention of the American Association of Port Authorities in the Hotel New Yorker.

Spokesmen for private industry estimated last night, at a meeting in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, that from 7,000,000 to 10,000,000 well-paid, productive jobs must be created to provide post-war full employment and prosperity.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Oct. 11 (U.P.) -- West African troops have captured Mowdok in the Sangu Valley two miles inside India, and have driven the Japanese back into wild hills to the northeast, ending the second officially announced enemy penetration of India, it was reported today.

LONDON, Oct. 11 (U.P.) -- A double Russo-Finnish offensive tonight threatened the entire German position in northern Finland with disaster as Finnish troops drove to within thirty-five miles of Rovaniemi and Berlin acknowledged that Russian forces were closing in on the key port of Petsamo from two directions after a landing on the Rybachi Peninsula.

For months after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor the American-educated woman announcer of Radio Tokyo, known to men of the Pacific Fleet and the marines and soldiers as "Tokyo Rose," would ask rhetorically in nearly every one of her daily broadcasts, "Where is the United States Fleet?" She has had many non-rhetorical answers since Dec. 7, 1941.
Bus operators in Manhattan and the Bronx, who have received no new tires since August, warned yesterday that they would have to reduce their service soon, possibly beginning within eight days.

LONDON, Thursday, Oct. 12 -Lieut. Gen. Courtney H. Hodges, commander of the United States First Army, had to begin yesterday to make good his grim threat to destroy the historic town of Aachen, Germany. The time limit for unconditional surrender of the German garrison inside the beleaguered city expired at 10:50 A.M. with no sign of compliance by the German commander.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Thursday, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Balik Papan, source of 15 per cent of Japan's aviation gasoline and lubricating oil, was bombed for four hours Sunday night by American Liberators. They attacked refineries and airdromes.

Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein announced yesterday that there had been "absolutely no evidence that any one party -- and that goes for the Republicans as well as the Democrats -- is responsible for delay or confusion" during the registration of voters the last three days in New York City.

ANTWERP, Belgium, Oct. 11 -The isthmus jutting from the Netherlands into the Schelde estuary and linking Zuid Beveland with the mainland has been sealed off and, it is estimated, 15,000 Germans have been trapped.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- A German radio-weather station in Greenland, believed to be the last clandestine outpost the Nazis operated in that barren territory, was captured and knocked out of commission last week, an Army Air Forces spokesman revealed today.
ROME, Oct. 11 (AP) -- A communique:

TRENTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- A survey today of fifteen of New Jersey's twenty-one counties disclosed that the total registration for the Nov. 7 election will be about 96.9 per cent of the 1940 total of 2,361,080.

Aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange fell slightly last month, going from 1,283,555 to 1,275,709 shares as of the Sept. 29 settlement date. Neither figure includes the short interest in odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers, which was 36,992 shares at the end of August and 32,213 shares at the end of September.

Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic national chairman, in a statement yesterday, called for an explanation from Governor Dewey on "the presence in the Dewey camp of men who are known to be diehard isolationists." The Democratic leader cited James Scott Kemper of Chicago, chairman of the Republican Finance Committee, as one isolationist whose support has been accepted by the Republican candidate.

Holders of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation's 6 per cent preferred stock, according to a notice received yesterday by the New York Curb Exchange, have received the right to exchange it for a new issue of 4 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock, subject to the terms and conditions specified in the Oct. 6 letter to shareholders.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The help of selected groups of farmers, food processors and others in forecasting food requirements of the United States next year has been asked by the War Food Administration. The agency must soon announce the 1945 production goals for the guidance of farmers, ranchers and other food producers, and to do so it must make an accurate appraisal of both foreign and domestic food needs.

Excerpts from the addresses of Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Administrator of the Federal Works Agency, and Paul G. Hoffman, chairman of the Committee for Economic Development, in the New York Times Hall last night, follow:
