The most fervid critic of secret diplomacy would not expect to be given at this time stenographic records of Prime Minister Churchill's conversations with Premier Stalin or Foreign Secretary Eden's with Foreign Commissar Molotoff. There does seem to be, however, much evidence of improvement in the relations between Russia and her allies.

Opening the way for a series of prosecutions in Brooklyn and Manhattan Magistrates Courts, which are expected to have nation-wide repercussions, Sheriff John J. McCloskey Jr. announced yesterday the issuance of 860 summonses against twelve leading processors of smoked fish.

Acting on widespread reports of rent gouging and other rent-law violations involving service men, Wacs and Waves and their relatives in Manhattan rooming houses land residence clubs, the Office of Price Administration has embarked upon a concerted drive to stamp out these illegal practices in the midtown district, in Chelsea and in the East Side and West Side neighborhoods from Sixtieth to Ninetieth Street, it became known last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Office of Price Administration announced three changes today in its regulation fixing ceiling prices for ethyl alcohol and high wines, two of which are designed to guard against increases in the cost of these products to the Government, and the third intended as a general precaution against "unreasonable and excessive" prices.

Charges that Sam Elkin, 44 years old, of 80 Clarkson Street, Brooklyn, had helped to perpetrate a $240,000 swindle involving the making of thousands of checks with false face values totaling $15,000,000 were placed before a jury in Federal court yesterday by Harold J. McAuley, assistant United States attorney.

Your account of the death of Toyama of Japan, "Terrorist leader, called one of the world's most evil men," who however, "once spoke gently to a dog that had bitten him" and "wouldn't even kill a mosquito," reminds me that in my student days in Spain we used to recite a poem by the great poet-philosopher Ramon de Campoamor (1817-1901), entitled "Antinomias del Genio' (Inconsistencies of a Genius).

The gap in the recovery effort of stocks due to the retreat on Monday was bridged yesterday by a new rally. Paced by a better brand of leadership, business snapped back at an increased tempo. Transfers on the Stock Exchange increased 717,150 shares, compared with 598,210 shares on Tuesday.

A syndicate operating in the name of Hotel Woodward, Inc., has bought the Hotel Woodward and annex buildings at Broadway and Fifty-fifth Streets in one of the largest midtown deals of the fall realty season.

A marked shortage of civilian supplies of many popular nickel candies and other low price confections looms for the country as the result of the 50 per cent "set aside" order for the armed forces issued by the War Food Administration, it was reported yesterday after a meeting of the National Confectioners Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

While smokers find it difficult because of the wartime rationing to purchase their favorite brands of cigarettes, Timothy Moriarty, 39 years old, a seaman of 25 South Street, revealed in the Bowery Court yesterday that there are plenty of all brands available to Tombs prisoners.
BYRON NELSON and Jug McSpaden have been on a golfing marathon since the first of the year. The two of them were caught between trains not so long ago in company with Ed Dudley and Freddie Corcoran.

ATLANTA, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Democratic leaders from four Southern States issued a joint statement tonight predicting that the South would "again lead the nation in sweeping President Roosevelt back into office."

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 11 -- The time for another Carnegie annual is at hand. "Painting in the United States, 1944," will be opened tomorrow night as part of the Founder's Day celebration at Carnegie Institute, when this year's prize winners will be announced.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 11 -- Sidney Kingsley, the playwright, has signed a contract with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to write one story a year directly for the screen during the next three years. The first is to be a drama dealing with the home front problems confronting returning service men with the central character a discharged medical officer.

An unconfirmed rumor that the Government would extend its buying program from June 30 to July 31, 1945, brought in covering yesterday in July cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange. That month advanced 23 points for the day, while other months gained 4 to 7 points net.

Every good citizen must wish the best of luck to Mayor La Guardia's experiment in keeping the record straight. Beginning next Monday representatives of the two major parties will have nightly facilities on the municipal radio station for the purpose of challenging wrong or misleading campaign statements.
Officials of sixteen local public housing authorities sold yesterday to various banks and investment firms $34,621,000 of short-term notes, all dated Nov. 1, 1944.

The Saturday Review of Literature announced yesterday that in a poll it had conducted among Washington correspondents, THE NEW YORK TIMES had received a vote of more than five to one as the newspaper which has maintained "the best all around Washington news service as measured by reliability, comprehensiveness and fairness."

New York's war cloud has a silver lining, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick told members of the Flatbush 12:45 Club at a luncheon yesterday at Oetjen's, Church and Flatbush Avenues, Brooklyn. One of the first cities to curtail expenditures for public improvements, New York has been able to retire $50,000,000 of its debts since 1941, he said, and to plan an integrated post-war improvement program.

LONDON, Oct. 11 (U.P.) -- It was election day today in England for American fighting men who began casting votes for the next President of the United States, and overseas voting will continue until Nov. 7. The service men flocked to offices, barracks and mess halls throughout the United Kingdom to cast their votes.

Just as civilians are reassured to know that men at the front are receiving adequate medical care, so the fighting man feels more secure when he knows that his family and friends are receiving the best medical care on the home front, Col. Arnold Whitridge, who has just returned from overseas, serving as intelligence officer with the Ninth Air Force, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- At a press conference on her sixtieth birthday, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt expressed the opinion today that the success of the Dumbarton Oaks world security plan depended on how strong was the determination of the peoples of the world to have peace.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in Serbo-Croat from Hungary and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

DETROIT, Oct. 11 (AP) -- With his skin heavily coated with oil and an artificial birthmark traced with cosmetics on his face, Bobby King, 4 months old, was returned unharmed to his parents today, ten days after he was abducted by a Negro nursemaid.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies in September increased 12.1 per cent over the same month of 1943, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES covering thirty-two companies. The increase is the second largest this year, the rise in August having been 13.6 per cent.

ROME, Oct. 11 (U.P.) -- British troops have captured Sarande, the fourth port of Albania, it was announced today. Five German divisions of perhaps 50,000 men were reported to be in full flight from Greece to escape an Allied trap closing around the Balkans from all directions.

Early relief is indicated in restrictive wholesale price ceilings of dry goods staples, according to sources in Worth Street yesterday. The Office of Price Administration has requested the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute to obtain 1939 net cost and selling prices of fifteen items including sheets, diapers, 5 per cent wool blankets and diapers, and the institute has sent out questionnaire for this information.

Wartime development in radio-electronics, including television and radar, have brought the American radio industry to the threshold of an era of expansion "even greater than the achievements of the last quarter of a century," Lieut. Gen. James G. Harbord, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America, said yesterday in a statement issued in commemoration of the RCA's twenty-fifth anniversary.

ALBANY, Oct 11 -- Governor Dewey, in his appearance at The New York Herald Tribune Forum Wednesday, Oct. 18, will deliver his second speech of the campaign devoted exclusively to foreign affairs, Paul F. Lockwood, his secretary announced today.

In his recent address Prime Minister Churchill spoke of the natural desire of Great Britain, the United States and the Soviet Union "to see emerge an entity which can truly be said to speak in the name of the people of France, the whole people of France," and suggested the possibility of the coming into existence of "an elected body" to achieve that result.

Fashions in flowers, such as a corsage of green Chinese lanterns with brightly colored Croton leaves designed for stadium wear instead of the conventional mammoth chrysanthemum, were exhibited yesterday at the annual flower "preview" held by the Florists Telegraph Delivery Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 11 (U.P.) -- Troops of the southern wing of the double-barreled Japanese offensive into southeastern China have driven deeper into Kwangsi Province, the Chinese High Command reported tonight in a communique which for the second day was ominously silent concerning operations in the Kweilin area and at the port of Foochow on China's east coast.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 11 (U.P.) -- The defending champions, Francisco (Pancho) Segura and Miss Pauline Betz, advanced to the semi-finals of the third annual Pan-American tennis tournament today, scoring victories in the day's play that saw all favorites win.

WHEN God the Father disappeared for the intellectuals, taking with Him "meekness, crucifixion and love," they were left groping for a substitute. That substitute, as Eric Russell Bentley sees it, becomes a Superman if hierarchy and respect for superiors are basic for them. This is perhaps the main argument in his lively and scholarly book, "A Century of Hero-Worship."*
Curly-headed Michael and his twin brother Joe were in solemn mood yesterday.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

When used with deftness such things as dried herbs, seasoned salts and herb vinegars can make culinary achievements of the commonplace. Among products of the sort available in the city are those of the Herb Farm Shop, Ltd., which had its origins in England and now has a factory here as well.
THE TIMES prints in its issue of Oct. 1 a delayed report from Helsinki which reveals the moral humiliation of ill-fated Finland and the human misery in the adjacent countries.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- A proclamation was issued today calling on the Jews of Palestine to lend active help against the growing terrorist activities in that country, while here in the House of Commons Earl Winter warned that both sides, Jews and Arabs, "are arming and preparing for a civil war after the war."

A new research program to determine the effects of toilet preparations and their ingredients on the skin, hair and nails, the first cooperative venture of this type in the industry, was announced yesterday by the Toilet Goods Association, Inc., a national organization of manufacturers of cosmetics and toilet preparations.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- Grain traders ignored today the estimate, issued by the Department of Agriculture late yesterday, that this year's total grain crop would be the largest on record, and although there was a little scattered selling early on the Board of Trade and a fractional recession in prices, the market turned upward later and showed good gains at the close.
LONDON, Oct. 11 -- The stock markets here generally were cheerful today on the latest war news, but business in most sections remained quiet.

The City Planning Commission made public yesterday a proposed capital budget of $198,317,593 for the calendar year 1945. Of this total $151,890,586 represents new appropriations, while $24,325,673 consists of funds already ear-marked in the 1944 capital budget.

Not since the departure of Orville Tuttle have the New York Football Giants had a "holler guy" in their midst to compare with Jim (Happy) Sivell, veteran guard, who worked with the Brooklyn Tigers at their Abilene camp and remained with them through the Green Bay game.

BOSTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Morris Litsky, 32, of New York's East Side, a stumpy-legged Jewish soldier with a sense of humor and an even bigger heart, has appealed to Americans, in the name of his dead comrades, to learn to be "a little kinder, a little more gentle and to love thy neighbor."

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- The World Security Council envisaged at Dumbarton Oaks was criticized in the House of Lords today by Lord Winster as an "organization for keeping small boys in order by prefects who would themselves be exempt from the rules they would administer."

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- Signs accumulated today that the municipal and departmental elections early next year, which are expected to end the arbitrary local regimes now existing, would prove a test of the incomplete political truce maintained since the liberation.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Senator Harry S. Truman, Democratic candidate for the Vice Presidency, is convinced the "Solid South" will remain solid despite anti-Roosevelt groups in some Southern States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The National War Labor Board, at a stormy meeting today, refused to recommend that President Roosevelt modify the Little Steel formula, holding that it was unable to say what effect a change would have on the price structure of the country.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Officials of the Mechanics Educational Society of America abandoned today plans to call 68,000 members out on strike at sixty-four Ohio and Michigan war plants and announced that the independent union would negotiate with the Cleveland Graphite Bronze Company to settle a long-standing dispute.

The two-seated democrat is a part of American tradition. It did not have the cozy intimacy of the top buggy nor the style and zip of the fringed-top surrey. But many a city man who drives a car with three- or fourscore horsepower magically concealed in a small space before him can remember the sturdy, utilitarian two-seated democrat.

The demand by Holland that she be given certain German territory to compensate for the destruction she has suffered is, perhaps, one of the most fortunate events of recent months. With it, the hard-headed Dutch have provided an answer to one of this nation's most perplexing questions -- namely, What can be done to prevent the Germans from ever again running amuck?

Bernard Shaw describes his new book, "Everybody's Political What's What," to be published by Dodd, Mead on Oct. 24, as a "detective story that tries to track down some of the mistakes that have landed us in two wars in twenty-five years." Religion, politics, money, education and government are his subjects.

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- Basil O'Connor, chairman of the American Red Cross, arrived here today to make a first-hand study of conditions in the field and of the progress being made with the French in solving their domestic problems. He expects to make two broadcasts to the United States, one devoted to each aspect of the work, in the course of his ten days in France.
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 11 -- Complaints against Chungking censorship of dispatches filed from the Communist area of China were voiced today by two correspondents at a government press conference.

ROME, Oct. 11 -- The third day of Vincenzo Azzolini's trial produced even fewer sensations than the first two, but it provided an explanation for the handing over of 10,000,000 lire to Vittorio Mussolini.

For the third time since the national amateur chess championship was inaugurated by the United States Chess Federation, the event, won last year by Dr. Ariel Mengarini of Washington, will begin this afternoon at 2 o'clock at the Manhattan Chess Club.

MOSCOW, Oct. 11 -- The future of Poland -- both her relations with Russia and the other United Nations and her own governmental organization after her liberation -- emerged today as a major world problem. A London broadcast said that Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk of the exiled Government, with which Russia does not maintain diplomatic relations, had left suddenly for Moscow.

Sumner Welles, former Under Secretary of State, declared last night that the Dumbarton Oaks plan for a world organization is "wise and desirable" and that "the United States should take part in it from the outset," with the understanding that it is to be amended and perfected as experience indicates the need.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- One of the questions Prime Minister Winston Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden went to Moscow to settle was the demarcation of the respective spheres of Russia and Britain in the Balkans with specific reference to the part played by Bulgaria in complicating them.

Coach Jack Weinheimer of New York University, acutely aware of the inadequate pass defense the Violets put up against Lafayette last Saturday, yesterday began the task of building a strong wall against the Temple aerial attack. The Owls, who invade Ohio Field on Saturday, work from both the T and single wing formations.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, In the Southwest Pacific, Thursday, Oct. 12 -- Maj. Richard Ira Bong, leading American ace in the Southwest Pacific, has run his string to thirty Japanese planes shot down.

ROME, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Wet and muddy American troops prodded the stubborn Germans south of Bologna today, but the enemy was far from being out of the hills before that big communications center and there were no signs that the Germans were ready to write off Italy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- President Roosevelt told a Polish delegation today that Poland "must be reconstituted as a great nation," and added that "it is very important that the new Poland be one of the bulwarks of the structure upon which we hope to build a permanent peace."

A proposed New York to London air service of seven round-trip flights weekly, which can be placed into immediate operation at the cost of only $263.80 a passenger for a one-way trip, was announced here yesterday by Jack Frye, president of Transcontinental Western Air, Inc.

TACOMA, Wash., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Governor Bricker declared tonight that the "New Deal dragged this country to the bottom of the list of nations" in industrial recovery and could not be trusted to provide productive peacetime jobs.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (UP) -- The Illinois Commerce Commission assumed today jurisdiction over the case in which eleven grain elevator companies and the Chicago Board of Trade are charged with "unjust, unreasonable and discriminatory rates and charges and the maintenance of discriminatory practices."

Mrs. Julia N. de Forest has sold the five-story store and apartment building at 132 East Twenty-third Street, southeast corner of Lexington Avenue, to an investing client of Gilliam McVay, Inc., brokers.

Staff Sgt. Joseph Louis Barrow, more generally known as Joe Louis, has just returned from a fourteen-month trip, during which he gave 196 exhibition bouts before 2,000,000 service men. He has one distinction which will give him a lasting spot in boxing history: he has held the world's heavyweight championship longer than any other man.

A three-month jail term and a fine of $4,250 were imposed by Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum yesterday on Isadore Aronin, 33-year-old partner in a coat-making firm, for what was described as "the most flagrant and calculating" violation of price ceilings to come to the attention of the Government.

On June 15 the National Labor Board, in its own words, "ordered" the American Federation of Musicians, headed by James C. Petrillo, promptly to withdraw its ban on the making of phonograph records and transcriptions. Mr. Petrillo ignored the order. When, a few months earlier, Montgomery Ward Co. had similarly refused to comply with an order of the War Labor Board, the Administration promptly sent in Federal troops and seized the plant.

MOSCOW, Oct. 11 (U.P.) -- The political commentator of the Red Star, in a three-column article today, criticized the alleged attempts of certain American and British circles to revive international cartels after the war.

Mary Ferguson, soprano from St. Louis, gave her first New York recital last night in Town Hall. Ably assisted by Edwin McArthur at the piano, Miss Ferguson was heard in a program which opened with a group comprising Mozart's canzonetta, "Ridente la calma"; the recitative and aria, "O, toi, qui prolongeas mes jours," from Gluck's "Iphigenie en Tauride"; and items by Scarlatti and Bishop.
SALEM, N.H., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Closing fast in the stretch, Sid Bernstein's Plane Spotter won the Unity Allowance Purse for $2,000 at Rockingham Park today, covering the mile and a sixteenth in 1:49.

Scorning the offer of mercy extended to his city, the German commander of Aachen has rejected the American ultimatum for surrender and elected to fight it out. Indeed, instead of surrendering, the Germans merely utilized the twenty-four hours of grace to rush up heavy reinforcements in a desperate and ill-fated maneuver.

OMAHA, Oct. 11 -- An attempt by the officially styled "Allied Drys of Nebraska" to restore prohibition in the State through a referendum has aroused more interest in the election of Nov. 7 than any contest or other factor in this anti-New Deal commonwealth.
ROME, Oct. 11 -- The investigation into the conduct of the Italian generals during the collapse at the time of the armistice last September has been blocked by the Allies, the Avanti asserted today.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Communique 186:

Stocks of all major oil product in the United States increased last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gasoline supplies at the close of the period week 78,554,000 barrels, an increase 526,000 over the 78,028,000 a week earlier. A year ago, they week 69,014,000 barrels.

Opera singer turns to the legitimate stage. We refer to Leon Rothier, a leading basso of the Metropolitan Opera for many years, who now is taking a fling at acting in "A Bell for Adano." He will not be required to do any singing.

WITH UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY, Outside Aachen, Oct. 12 -- The left flank of the American salient pressing Aachen from the north is being heavily counter-attacked by one of the finest divisions in Germany.

For nearly four hours yesterday, police emergency squadmen, sanitation workers and firemen tramped through the foot-deep water and slime of the sewers beneath the Stanley Avenue section of Brooklyn, searching vainly for the body of a young girl after four children had reported hearing her screams for help and seeing her floating by.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- President Roosevelt, a few pounds under weight but otherwise in perfect health, has become "proud of his flat -- repeat, f-l-a-t -- tummy," Vice Admiral Ross McIntire, the President's personal physician, revealed today.

The Italian Christopher who sailed under the Spanish flag and would have been equally willing to sail under a Portuguese or English flag would find some congenial thoughts in President Roosevelt's Columbus Day address. Not being a narrow nationalist he would understand the President's emphasis upon the international character of the armies now fighting to redeem Italy and other lands from the Nazi blight.

Lillian Evanti, Negro lyric soprano, returned to the local concert stage last night in Town Hall after an absence of twelve years. In a program which included arias by Handel, Mozart and Verdi; songs by Wolf. Negro spirituals and a group of lyrics of her own, Miss Evanti held the attention of her audience by her engaging personality and the communicativeness of her work as a whole.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Charlie Robbins, former distance ace for the University of Connecticut, and now of Chelsea Naval Hospital, captured the National A.A.U. and New England 20-kilometer crowns today, leading a field of thirty in a road race over the streets of Providence.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 12 -- Pat O'Brien and George Murphy, who recently completed "Having Wonderful Crime" at RKO, will be teamed again by the studio in another comedy murder story, "Blue Mist Mystery," by Eric Hatch. The novelette, which is scheduled for publication in January in a national magazine, will be produced by Robert Fellows.

Governor Dewey, after a conference yesterday with Dr. Abba Hillel Silver of Cleveland, chairman of the executive committee of the National Zionist Emergency Council, issued a statement "heartily endorsing" the Palestine plank in the Republican national platform.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The War Production Board authorized today the manufacture of 495,000 new shotguns and rifles, as well as the completion of some partly fabricated guns. Most of the weapons will go to law-enforcement agencies, farmers and ranchers.

Special 15-cent high school lunches, consisting of a variety of nourishing foods, are being offered by the Board of Education as a result of a further Federal subsidy, it was announced yesterday. The meals cost the cafeteria managers about 24 cents, but if prepared in the home would cost much more than that, the school officials pointed out.

Wounded and disabled war veterans do not want to be treated as heroes, they want to be normal human beings and live normal human lives, Maj. Gen. Norman T. Kirk. Surgeon General of the United States Army, said yesterday at a discussion of "The Veteran and the Community" in the conference room of THE NEW YORK TIMES, 229 West Forty-third Street.

A full-sized closet in the dining room should be considered a must for every post-war home or new apartment building, in the opinion of Carole Stupell, who described in an interview yesterday at her shop at 507 Madison Avenue her ideas for a coordinated storage unit for table accessories.

Believing the theme a timely one, R.H. Macy enveloped its fashion show yesterday at the luncheon hour in the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel in red, white and blue. The brightness of the color scheme was in the gay holiday spirit of Columbus Day.

MOSCOW, Oct. 12 -- An auspicious stage for determined unity talks was set today with the arrival of Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk of the Polish Government in Exile, Foreign Minister Tadeusz Romer and Dr. Stanislaw Grabski, Speaker of the Polish Assembly in London, just a day after the arrival from Lublin of Chairman Edward Osubka-Morawski, President Boleslaw Berut and Col. Gen. Michal Rola-Zymierski of the Polish Committee of National Liberation.

Hitler has written to the German 16-year-olds who are now volunteering for active service. They must be hard, steadfast and fanatical in battling for Germany, the Fuehrer tells them, because defeat means merciless destruction by the enemy.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The United Lutheran Church in America elected the Rev. Franklin Clark Fry of Akron president today to succeed the Rev. Frederick H. Knubel of New York City, who has been head of the church since unification in 1918.

It looks as though we shall have an abundance of fresh vegetables for the remainder of 1944. In an encouraging bulletin just issued by the United States Department of Agriculture, aggregate tonnage for the fall is set at 1,582,000 tons, which is 27 per cent more than the ten-year average (1933-42) and 2 per cent in excess of last season.

In a precedent-breaking proposal designed to round out the planned improvement of the downtown Brooklyn section, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick asked yesterday that the city spend $20,000,000 to buy up roughly eight blighted blocks bordering on Flatbush Avenue Extension for conversion into "super-blocks" that would be auctioned off to private interests for redevelopment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The board of directors of the Polish-American Congress took the position at a meeting today that eastern Poland "should not be taken by Russia" and that the eastern boundary should remain as it was prior to 1939.
LONDON, Oct. 12 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 12 (AP) Communique 187:

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Desperate as the Germans appear to be to prevent American capture of Aachen, they are fighting with even greater ferocity to prevent the Canadians from clearing them out of the Schelde River approaches to Antwerp, great Belgian port with its miles of deep-water docks for big ocean-going ships.

Nearly 2,000,000' New Yorkers have registered to vote in the four days the polling places have been opened throughout the city, according to the official returns made public early this morning. The total is 50,000 above the four-day figures for 1940, the last Presidential year.

Charging Governor Dewey with being an "isolationist at heart," Senator Claude Pepper, Democrat from Florida, forecast last night that the Republican Presidential candidate and the men around him "hate England for her national rivalry and Russia for her internal philosophy," and do not intend to work intimately with either after the war.

Whether there will be a post-war crime wave in this country depends on whether economic dislocations follow the peace, Lewis E. Lawes, prison consultant on the War Production Board and former warden of Sing Sing, said last night at the general session of the seventy-fourth annual Congress of Correction in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Germany actually lacks pilots, as well as gasoline, to keep her Luftwaffe in the air against the Allies' air forces Gen. Henry H. Arnold, Commanding General of the Army Air Force, asserted today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- A post-war career as coastwise merchant vessels, auto-carriers on the Great Lakes and as "cargo feeder" ships in some parts of the Caribbean, awaits many of the LST's (Landing Ship-Tanks) now in service with invasion forces in Europe and the South Pacific, according to shipping men here today.

Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday afternoon that he had been notified by Washington postal officials that the deadline for mailing Christmas packages and cards to service men overseas had been extended from Sunday to Monday.

Continuation of world hide and leather allocations after the war as a means of averting inflationary pricing, as well as to assure equitable distribution of available supplies, was advocated by industry and war agency speakers yesterday at the annual meeting of the Tanners Council of America, Inc., at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

While waiting for the impending shooting season to open in this vicinity (it's tomorrow for ducks and Monday for upland game in most of New York State), you may be interested in how the sport has been going in Maine.

ANTWERP, Belgium, Oct. 12 -- Canadian forces on the Schelde side of the Leopold Canal continued to fight fiercely today against ferocious German resistance and expanded their hard-earned bridgehead to a depth of 5,000 yards.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State chairman, who had announced that he had "shocking information" about an organized attempt to prevent qualified voters from registering, declined yesterday to turn his material over to Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- Balenciaga's opening revealed a collection of models on conservative lines, remarkable chiefly for painstaking attention to details. The principal features are narrowness in both frocks and skirts, all ampleness brought to the front, leaving the back straight; shoulders follow the natural line and many striped fabrics are used.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- A warning to tourists going to Florida and other resort areas that they might be stranded this winter and next spring was issued today by Col. J. Monroe Johnson, director of the Office of Defense Transportation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 149:

With its proposals for the organization and coordination of the world's economic life, the Dumbarton Oaks plan for peace realistically pioneers beyond the Covenant of the League of Nations, Dr. James T. Shotwell, chairman of the Commission to Study the Organization of Peace, declared last night in an address, "The Great Decision," at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Supreme Court took to its conference room today for decision one of the most complicated legal problems faced by the Government since Pearl Harbor, the constitutionality of moving and confining American citizens of Japanese ancestry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- An "interim" policy for the control of occupied Germany has been agreed upon by the Federal departments that have been debating the "long-range" policy for German occupation, it was learned today.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 12 -- The professional-amateur best-ball golf tournament held today over the Garden City Country Club links attracted a select field of thirty professionals from Long Island, Westchester and New Jersey. Each of the money players teamed with at least one member of the host club, some of the pros playing with as many as three.

Multi-colored kerchiefs, every size playing card and the hat that the rabbit had recently skipped from -- all raw materials for two hours of thrills -- were reclaimed from the floor of the stage on Central Park Mall late yesterday afternoon by a dozen new graduates of the College of Magical Knowledge.

BOSTON, Oct. 12 -- In a letter written seven days before his death Wendell L. Willkie said that he had "not finally decided" which Presidential candidate he would support in the 1944 campaign, according to a dispatch to The Christian Science Monitor from Washington.

The effort of business to secure post-war tax reserves has caused it to neglect, "in a great many instances," its review of existing opportunities within the law to prepare for the post-war period, J.K. Lasser, chairman of the New York University Institute on Federal Taxation, declared yesterday.

ROME, Oct. 12 -- In an effort to break the back of German resistance before Bologna, the Fifteenth Army Air Force cut loose this morning with its greatest attack of the war, greater even than the one that flattened Cassino. It was centered on German installations in the outskirts of Bologna, itself, with Liberators and Flying Fortresses dropping an immense load without air opposition and with few losses.

Two hundred and fifty employes of the Savoy-Plaza Hotel staged a sudden five-hour work stoppage that began shortly before noon yesterday. In a few minutes they had almost completely tied up all but the clerical services at the hotel.
This year it's just one doggone thing after another -- with the Tigers, the Brooklyn Tigers, that is. If it isn't injuries it's illness and vice versa.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, in New Guinea, Friday, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Five groups of heavy bombers, escorted by fighters, plastered the oil refineries at Balik Papan, Borneo, on Tuesday, headquarters announced today.

The spirit of the Italy that now fights with the United Nations was honored yesterday in Columbus Day ceremonies held throughout the city and with an impressive parade up Fifth Avenue in which the marchers bore aloft for the first time since the start of the war the tri-color of the House of Savoy.

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- The meeting of the regional commissioners from the south of France during the last couple of days has given the Government in Paris its first full and authentic report on conditions in that part of the country to which the authority of the Paris regime does not yet extend in any complete sense, it was learned today.

LONDON, Friday, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Moscow radio carried a Bulgarian announcement early today that Bulgaria's troops and administrative officials had been withdrawn from Greek territory in compliance with Allied demands established as a preliminary to armistice negotiations.
A RETURNING tourist from St. Louis found that the postman had rung more than twice while he was away. So here are a few gleanings from the accumulated mail.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Office of Defense Transportation today ordered heavy demurrage charges applied to freight cars held for loading or unloading beyond a fourth day and expressed the hope the action would make it "too expensive to be profitable to hold a box car for storage beyond a reasonable time."

Crowding close upon the Japanese report of a tremendous American carrier-based air attack on Formosa comes news of a heavy blow against the island of Luzon. Admiral Halsey is keeping his word to hit hard and often close to Japan. It is the fourth strike against Luzon in three weeks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Government and labor officials were concerned today over the possible effects on the national election that may result from the National War Labor Board's refusal to make any recommendations to President Roosevelt on labor's demand that the "Little Steel" formula be modified to permit upward wage adjustments.

The American Hungarian Social Club has repurchased its building at Sixth Street and Magnolia Avenue, Elizabeth, N.J. Built in 1927 at a cost of $62,000, the structure was lost in 1934 through foreclosure of a mortgage by the former Guarantee Building and Loan Association.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Oct. 12 -- "Dumbarton Oaks" was welcomed as a good beginning by Prime Minister Peter Fraser in a statement last night expressing his qualified approval of the security blueprint. The spirit of resolution back of proposals encouraged belief that the great powers were determined to lead in maintaining the peace by forceful action if necessary, Mr. Fraser said.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 12 -- At the Founder's Day celebration at Carnegie Institute tonight the Department of Fine Arts announced the winners of awards in the Carnegie annual "Painting in the United States, 1944," which opens to the public tomorrow.

LONDON, Oct 12 -- American, British and Canadian heavy bombers continued the strategical phases of the air offensive today, hammering German factories and oil plants. About 1,000 big bombers were involved, a far greater force than available to the Germans, but still only a small fraction of the fleet the Allies can put into the air when conditions are right.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Forces, Oct. 12 -- As confident and as smilingly tough as ever, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower told war correspondents here today that "we have a hard job ahead but victory is certain."

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- In a mesrage read today before the Cooperative Centennial Congress, Herbert H. Lehman, director of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, asserted that "application of the cooperative principles will facilitate relief and rehabilitation and promote enduring peace."
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 12 -- Aachen began to crumble today under furious American ground and air bombardment.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 12 -- Along the American First Army front today change in tactics was indicated in the assault against Aachen, first German city marked for destruction after its garrison refused to surrender.

You may hear him almost any time of the year, out in the deeper woodlands, but the barred owl seems to respond to autumn with particular vocal enthusiasm. Give him a chilly, moonlit evening and he will fill the air with inquisitive "whooing." But he won't hoot all night, which is decidedly to his credit.

The battleship Texas, 30-year-old veteran of two wars, pumped nearly 1,000 fourteen-inch, 1,500-pound shells into German positions on three bombardment missions since the invasion of France and was hit only twice by counter-fire, her skipper, Capt. Charles A. Baker disclosed in an interview yesterday.

Predicting that the United States is "headed on the road to a hell of chronic depression and new wars," Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, forecast yesterday a fascist movement in this country within the next decade. As an alternative he offered "democratic socialism."

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 12 -- Under the battle slogan, "No more quarter for a cowardly German than we give the enemy," the Nationalsocialistische Gaudienst of Cologne, an official party weekly out today, editorializes on the beginning of the "war of the German people."

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- A new relationship between France and her colonies is growing out of the liberation movement, Rene Pleven, Minister for Colonies, said today. It will take the form of a political and economic "integration" of colonies and broad programs for public health and education overseas.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 12 (AP) -- A crowd of 29,000 that jammed every nook and corner of rural Rockingham Park today broke the New England pari-mutuel betting record by wagering $1,697,467 during the fourteen-event War Fund horse racing double-header. The previous mark of $1,646,608 was set at Narragansett Park during a nine-race program on Labor Day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 7 were 877,942 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 35,057 cars or 3.8 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 28,415 cars or 3.1 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 31,308 cars or 3.4 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Some 25,000 crooner fans, most of them early teen-age girls clad in bobby socks and sweaters, created intricate traffic problems outside the Paramount Theatre in Times Square yesterday waiting their turn to see Frank Sinatra. But one police squad watching their antics was concerned with more serious problems than traffic snarls.
President Roosevelt declared last night that "to the people of Italy we have pledged our help and we will keep the faith."

As the initial response to the liberalized construction rules of the War Production Board and the National Housing Agency, permitting alteration of residential structures to provide additional suites to help meet New York's needs, the Federal Housing Administration has approved applications for conversion of 110 buildings to provide 541 additional dwelling units in the metropolitan area, Thomas G. Grace, New York State Director of the FHA, announced yesterday.

Harry T. Lubetkin, owner of the Trix Food Products Company at 16 East Twenty-third Street, was held without bail yesterday by United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter for return to Chicago, where he faces criminal charges.

LONDON, Friday, Oct. 13 -- Russian troops battled their way to within twelve miles of the big German raft center of Tilsit yesterday, hurling the enemy back across the East Prussian frontier on a 110-mile front in western Lithuania as they prepared for their first crossing in strength into pre-war Germany.

The first edition of Ernie Pyle's "Brave Men" will consist of 170,000 copies instead of 150,000, as announced previously. Being the December Book-of-the-Month, it will not be released by Henry Holt until Nov. 20. Copies may be purchased, however, before Sunday for mailing overseas as Christmas gifts for service men.

The War Labor Board is not, or ought not to be, a policy-making agency. It is, or ought to be, merely an administrative agency to carry out whatever national wage policy is laid down by the Administration and by Congress. It is the function of the latter, not of the Labor Board, to hold whatever hearings may be necessary to determine whether that policy is sound.
WASHINGTON, Oct 12 -- The Women's Land Army reported today 335,000 placements of women farm workers up to Sept. 1 as against 350,000 placements for the entire year of 1943.

Criticism of this country's "unilateral action" against Argentina and a plea for a policy that would regain Latin-American confidence, as well as prevent the growth of fascist doctrines in the Western Hemisphere, were emphasized last night in an address by Sumner Welles, former Under-Secretary of State, at the annual "Birthday of the Americas Dinner" in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Failure of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor to endorse the candidacy of President Roosevelt, despite what he asserts was support by a majority of its membership, is criticized by Daniel Tobin, head of the Teamsters Union, in the October issue of The International Teamster, official organ of the union.

As American troops began to move into doomed and burning Aachen the Berlin radio vowed vengeance "if the American hordes should carry out the threat to destroy this jewel of Kultur." It quoted the Nazi commander who rejected the ultimatum that would have saved the city as having replied: "Even an American cannot ask a city like Aachen, where thirty-seven German emperors were crowned, to surrender."

YONKERS, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- Isaac Young High School joined its city rival, New Rochelle High, and Mount Vernon's A. B. Davis High at the top of the Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association standings today by routing an injury-ridden Yonkers Central eleven, 32 to 6, at Gorton Field.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 12 -- The offensive by the American Third Army northeast of Nancy has come to an end, and around Metz Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's forces are still trying to clean the Germans out of Maizieres les Metz, six miles north of the city.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 12 -- Luzon, main island of the Philippines, was blasted on Tuesday afternoon, West Longitude Time, by a large force of carrier aircraft from "a task force of the Pacific Fleet," Admiral Nimitz said tonight. The American planes hit enemy air- bases and other installations, adding to the destruction begun on Sept. 20 and continued on Sept. 21 and 23.
The editorial "A Sense of Proportion." in a recent issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES was very much to the point.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (U.P.) -- Louis B. Mayer, movie executive, drew $1,138,992 for the twelve months ended Aug. 31, 1943, to top the nation's salary earners for the sixth consecutive year, the Treasury Department revealed tonight.
Wednesday's communique, as broadcast domestically from Sofia and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The War Production Board is undertaking sweeping simplification of its controls over production of farm machinery with the intention of removing individual quotas from more than 400 separate items of equipment, it was learned today.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 12 -- After a long day of competition on upland game and on ducks in the almost placid waters of Lloyd Harbor the judges announced their awards in the two field events held at Kilsyth Farms, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald M. Livingston, today.

Holding Power Memorial scoreless until the final seconds, Fordham Prep triumphed, 18 to 6, yesterday on Fordham Field. The Maroons dominated the issue all the way, playing almost exclusively in Power territory.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Opposing "wholesale and indiscriminate" vengeance on German people, the Archbishop of York, second ranking leader of the Church of England, declared today that "on the other hand we have no right to forgive them light-heartedly."

Somewhere on the road to Metz, Bing Crosby, the crooner, scored a beat on the American forces. Back in New York after an eight-week United Service Organizations tour of France and England, he told the story yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Earlier in the year the Germans began to flood island areas in Zeeland and parts of Polderland in the Netherlands. More recently Allied bombers have blasted dikes where German heavy artillery had been mounted. How far the flooding has proceeded it is hard to determine, but it is enough to arouse the concern of the outer world and of Dutch officials.

Ceremonies held simultaneously yesterday in New York and Zamorano, Honduras, marked the formal dedication of the Escuela Agricola Panamericana (Pan American School of Agriculture), a project founded and maintained by the United Fruit Company for the development of the agricultural resources of the Central American countries.

KANDY, Ceylon, Oct. 12 (U.P.) -- British patrols killed or wounded an undetermined number of Japanese in a series of attacks on units guarding the enemy's main escape route from their beleaguered Chin Hills base of Tiddim to Kalemyo, thirty miles to the southeast, as Allied artillery pounded the retreat road near Fort White, midway between the two towns, a southern Asia Headquarters communique reported today.

Major difficulties of terrain, weather, distance and supply, involved command relationships, red tape, the "inertia of the East," and some basic political, philosophical and strategic differences have accounted in considerable measure for the lack of definitive success in Burma in almost three years of war.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- The problem of sheltering and repatriating Europeans displaced by the war, which had been envisaged largely as a post-war complication, has arisen suddenly and in acute form in France. About 500,000 non-French persons are involved.
Ben W. McCreedy, Samuel Shapiro and Abe Turner tied at 1 1/2-1/2 in Group A as two rounds were completed in the national amateur chess tournament at the Manhattan Club last night.

Gains in sales volume over a year ago marked Columbus Day trade in the stores here yesterday, although the cool weather which normally spurs consumer demand for outer apparel was lacking. Merchants reported shopping crowds were heavy, and added that main floor, home furnishings and specialty food sales were large.
Uptown Manhattan properties figured in most of the real estate deals reported in the borough yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- President Roosevelt urged before the heads of diplomatic missions of nineteen other American republics, gathered at the White House today, the establishment "without further delay, and without waiting for the end of hostilities," of the United Nations peace organization agreed upon at the Dumbarton Oaks conferences.

Firm opposition to legislation for compulsory military training after the war was urged upon the New York Assembly of the Catholic Daughters of America at a luncheon yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Pennsylvania by the Rev. Dr. Cyril F. Meyer, dean of St. John's University, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- During the first week in October commodity prices in primary markets continued to edge gradually upward, having risen slightly for the last three weeks, to show a gain of 0.1 per cent during the week ended on Oct. 7.
The address by Maj. Gen. Norman T. Kirk, Surgeon General of the United States Army, before THE NEW YORK TIMES conference on "The Veterans and the Community" yesterday follows:
Lou Little is getting nervous and on edge, like a champion on the eve of a big fight, and that's a healthy augury for Columbia's chances against Yale in the Bowl at New Haven tomorrow.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast by the Free Yugoslav radio in Serbo-Croat and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Where will the "United Nations" -- the general organization for the maintenance of peace and security -- have its headquarters? The problem was not touched upon in the recent conference held at Dumbarton Oaks.

Count Carlo Sforza, in a Columbus Day radio address from Rome, rebroadcast here over station WOV, said yesterday that millions of Italian children were in peril of dying through hunger and cold and called for American aid as a sound investment in future peace.

In a campaign speech broadcast over a State-wide radio network, Senator Robert F. Wagner, who is up for re-election this year, called last night for the re-election of President Roosevelt on the basis of the Administration's foreign policy with which, he added, he is personally in accord.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Friday, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A communique:

NIJMEGEN, the Netherlands, Oct. 12 -- More than 2,000 Netherlanders, women as well as men, have been arrested in various parts of the liberated Netherands on charges of having been outright traitors or of having collaborated with the enemy during occupation or of having been war profiteers.

Yehudi Menuhin, the young violin virtuoso, returned to the United States yesterday after a six-week tour that included the first appearances by a foreign musician on the European Continent since the occupation. He arrived in New York by plane from London a day before he was expected.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in English to North America from Chungking and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 12 -- American planes, 1,000 of them, attacked Formosa, just north of the Philippines, concentrating on the island's three most important towns, all on the island's main railroad, the Tokyo radio announced today.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- The British Government, in the person of Lord Beaverbrook, its retiring Minister in charge of civil aviation, admitted in the House of Lords today that "in the factories and air routes of the world at present our future is not very bright."

A Russian program, arrestingly arranged and presented, was Dr. Rodzinski's offering with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. There were only two names upon his list. They were those of distinguished figures of the Russian musical past and present, whose works offered very suggestive comparisons and perspective of certain phases of the national art.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The Federation Bank and Trust Company, which filed this week plans for an eight-story and penthouse apartment building for postwar construction at 443-7 West Thirty-fourth Street, has sold the land along with the building plans to an investing client of John J. Reynolds.
Following is the text of President Roosevelt's Columbus Day address to the American Republics as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- J.A. Krug, chairman of the War Production Board, diclosed today that his agency had worked out "definite plans" with key industries which will determine the steps to be taken in reconverting war plants to peacetime operations.

ROME, Oct. 12 -- In his first speech in German since the liberation of Rome, Pope Pius XII told superiors and students of Collegio Germanico Ungarico this morning that he would "follow developments of post-war Germany with love and, if necessary, will give her his help."

Ballet Theatre last night presented Leonide Massine's "Aleko" for the first time this season at the Metropolitan Opera House, with Mr. Massine in his season's debut as guest artist, and Nora Kaye, Hugh Laing and Antony Tudor in the chief roles.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Three questions regarding the Dumbarton Oaks proposal for an international security organization were propounded today to the major Presidential nominees, President Roosevelt and Governor Dewey, by Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican, of Minnesota.

ROME, Oct. 12 (AP) -- More than 600 Germans and large stores of guns and material have been captured in the Allies' clean-up of the Sarande area of Albania the past two days, headquarters announced today.

Announcement by the War Production Board of removal of allocation controls over civilian uses of cellulose acetate, cellulose acetate butyrate, urea and melanine molding powders will have little immediate effect on output for civilians because of a suddenly developed shortage of urea compounds and others containing formaldehyde, molders stated yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 11 (Delayed) -- One acute problem facing the French Provisional Government is the practical application of its decrees restoring to Jews their possessions confiscated by Vichy under the orders of the German occupant. The intention is that the restoration should be "immediate," but there are many obstacles to surmount, so many that a legislative commission of the Consultative Assembly met today to consider the question in all its aspects.

The Army needs New York nurses. In the face of a growing need for nurses for overseas units and for professionally trained nurses in Army hospitals here, the recruitment of registered nurses within the Second Service Command is lagging far behind the quota. In addition, civilian nurses, asked to step in to help care for wounded men in Army hospitals, have failed to respond to the Army's appeal.

The Book-of-the-Month Club, Random House and Harper Brothers, whose purchase of the reprint publishing house of Grosset Dunlap was made public last week, announce that Little, Brown Co. of Boston and Charles Scribner's Sons of New York also have become joint purchasers of the reprint firm.

EUGENE, Ore., Oct. 12 (U.P.) -- Governor Bricker charged tonight that bureaucrats were stuffed to the suffocation point into cities all over the country, and demanded that "the patchwork of bureaus" be taken apart and the Government streamlined.

The Mayor's announcement that he is "going to bat" to reduce mortgage interest rates on city real estate to 3 per cent, as reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES, adds emphasis to the grave situation of the residential real estate industry resulting from inadequate returns on the money invested.

Before a crowd of 35,044, a new high for Columbus Day, A.S. Hewitt's Some Chance captured the $11,675 Continental Handicap, feature of Jamaica's second war relief day this season, which realized an estimated $125,000 and raised the New York 1944 total just short of the million-dollar mark.

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- Albert Lebrun, who was President of the French Republic at the time of its capitulation in 1940, called on Gen. Charles de Gaulle yesterday and told the General he was happy to see him take charge of the destinies of the country, according to a statement issued by General de Gaulle's office today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- No German cities may expect "immunity from destruction so long as they are maintained as part of the enemy's battle line," Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson warned at his press conference today.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- The chief feature today in a generally quiet stock market was the renewed strength of Canadian Pacific. The ordinary shares followed up yesterday's rise on the dividend announcement with a further gain. Among other dollar stocks both International Nickels and International Holdings were up.

The first analysis of newspaper advertising costs in relation to sales by the National Retail Dry Goods Association in cooperation with a large group of department stores throughout the country indicates that the figures range from a low of 1.20 per cent of sales to a high of 4.50 per cent with a general average of 2.25 per cent, the association reported yesterday.

BORDEAUX, France, Oct. 12 (AP) -- This city, France's second seaport, was again firmly in French hands today after its inhabitants had endured four years of martyrdom and blood-baths under the Germans.
TROY, N.Y., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Justice William H. Murray dismissed in State Supreme Court today indictments alleging conspiracy among three city of Albany officials.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Calumet Farm's Twilight Team fleet filly queen of the American turf, led at every stride today for the easiest kind of triumph in the $10,000 added Queen Isabella Handicap at Laurel Park.
LONDON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Swamped with more than three times the number of daily requests for household help than can possibly be handled, the United States Employment Service here announced yesterday that orders for maids and other types of domestic workers are now being received between 1 and 3 P.M. only.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- President Roosevelt said today that within a new days he would make a study of whether he could legally take further action to compel the American Federation of Musicians, headed by James C. Petrillo, to comply with his request to lift its ban on the making of recordings and transcriptions by some companies, as it was ordered to do by the War Labor Board in June.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Yale's hefty, experienced line is expected to power the Blue footballers to their third straight victory tomorrow when they battle Columbia in the Bowl for the first time since 1939. These Ivy League rivals met in New York last fall, however, and have been clashing on and off since 1872 with the Bulldogs in front, 17 -- 4.

Dumbarton is the name of a county in Scotland and also of its county town, which latter is fifteen miles away from Glasgow or about the distance of Yonkers from Mayor La Guardia's office facing City Hall Park.
Of 750,000 residents of New York City in military service, 585,000 or roughly 76 per cent are of voting age, Col. Arthur V. McDermott, director of Selective Service for the city, estimated yesterday.

The stock market maintained yesterday its position in the current recovery range, but aside from some strength in selected issues prices drifted narrowly and closed mixed. Buying was purely selective, individual stocks being singled out on the basis of dividend actions or news bearing on the not too far distant outlook for the issues involved.
Former Gov. Alfred E. Smith left his entire estate to his family, it was learned yesterday when Senator Robert F. Wagner offered the will for probate.

Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic national chairman, reported yesterday at a press interview that "apparently there is a whispering campaign going on and being intensified about the President's health." Mr. Hannegan, who saw the President last week, reported that Mr. Roosevelt was "very vigorous, the picture of health."

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- There was a notable lack of support in the grain markets in the late trading today on the Board of Trade and wheat and rye broke around 2 cents a bushel from the early high marks and closing sales were about the bottom.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Communique 188:

Registration in New York City took a sharp drop yesterday and as a result the total registration for a five-day period was 135,066 under the total for the comparable days in 1940, according to the complete figures for the five boroughs compiled early this morning.

College football comes up with a crowded program of interesting games today before the comparative lull of next week, when many teams will suspend action as their Navy personnel in the V-12 units take their exams. After today, the exodus of Navy and Marine students to advanced training centers will get under way and by November some of the teams will have to be appraised all over again.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace asserted tonight it was necessary "to take industry by the scruff of the neck" to place it into the war effort.
Armed bandits in the metropolitan area held up two taverns yesterday and robbed payroll carriers, making off with $4,400 in cash.

WITH AMERICAN THIRD ARMY on the Moselle, Oct. 12 (Delayed) -- The confused controversy among Government officials, politicians and private citizens in the United States as to what to do with Germany once she is defeated has its no less confused counterpart among American fighting men on this front.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 13 -- Eight men, who drank concoctions con raining 5 to 10 per cent of wood alcohol, died in Newark City Hospi tal within the last week, it was re ported today by Dr. Harrison S. Martland, Essex County's chief

After a six-week tour of France, Belgium and Holland that took him within six miles of Aachen, Fred Astaire, dancer, returned to New York yesterday with "souvenirs for the kids" and an "indelible impression of the unbelievable guts of those GI's."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The tripartite method of settling labor disputes is vindicated by the National War Labor Board's experience, according to Chairmah William H. Davis, who said today that the figures available to the board supported this view.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Recent abridgment of freedom of the press was condemned today by Carl Vitz, president of the American Library Association, as he announced a national Freedom of the Press Week to be observed by public, college and school libraries from Nov. 19 to Nov. 25.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 13 -- The first Allied airborne Army's attempt to bridge three great river barriers in the southern Netherlands, "the greatest airborne operation ever envisaged or launched," is estimated by Lieut. Gen. Sir Miles C. Dempsey, commander of the Second Army, to have saved his forces at least 25,000 casualties.

The Fishery Council reported yesterday that a supply of nearly 1,000,000 pounds of fish had arrived during the day on the New York market. The council appealed to City Markets Commissioner Henry M. Brundage to help move the great catch into the hands of consumers.

Carolyn W. Judson will become a limited partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Judson Co. on Nov. 1. Howard A. Plummer will become a limited partner in Pyne, Kendall Hollister on the same date. Francis X. Griffin will retire from E.W. Clucas Co. on Oct. 18.

During the Guadalcanal campaign in the fall of 1942 Admiral Halsey was talking with newspaper men in General Vandegrift's blacked-out tent near Henderson Field one hot November evening. He was asked how long he thought the war would last. "How long can they take it?" was his quick counter-question from the dim corner where he was sitting in a captured Japanese wicker chair, whose short legs didn't fit his long ones and always irritated him.

A "Service of Thanksgiving to Almighty God on the thirty-third anniversary of the founding of the Chinese Republic" will be held tomorrow at 4 P.M. in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. "Prayers will be offered for the Chinese people in their present great trials," an announcement yesterday from the cathedral said.

The German lieutenant who received General Hodge's demand for the surrender of Aachen last Tuesday morning is now an American prisoner. He and many other Germans in that town might have been willing prisoners three days ago if they had been able to consult their inclinations.

During the decade 1924-34 it was my privilege to serve as impartial chairman in the men's clothing industry in the City of New York; also as chairman of their Unemployment Insurance Fund. Thus I represented the manufacturers, contractors and Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America In that capacity, and later as chairman of the National Labor Board (Philadelphia region) I had intimate contacts with Sidney Hillman.

Butter dealers, recently enjoined in Federal court by the Office of Price Administration from violating price and other OPA regulations, appealed yesterday to Daniel P. Woolley, Regional OPA Administrator, to vacate the suits. He refused but promised to look into the dealers' contention that grading here is not satisfactory.
BUFFALO, Oct. 13 (UP) -- Buffalo's "400" was threatened with a wide schism tonight as the city's matrons chose sides in the "battle of the Twentieth Century Club."
LONDON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The official Soviet newspaper Izvestia in Moscow surmised today that Hungary "is going to blow up at any moment."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Continuing its internal "reconversion," the War Production Board today announced the abolishment of a division and a bureau, the departure of five dollar-a-year men from operating jobs and the resignation of another official.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 13 -- The Baltic situation is presenting an extremely confused picture. The underground movement in Latvia, for instance, is reported to be giving contradictory instructions, urging non-cooperation with the Germans but instructing Partisans to resist the Russians.

KANDY, Ceylon, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Allied forces have raided a Japanese post twenty-two miles south of the enemy's base at Tiddim in northwestern Burma and have beaten off an artillery-supported Japanese attack east of Tiddim, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's headquarters announced today.

The Nazi flag no longer flies over the Acropolis. After a little less than three years and a half it has been hauled down. The Nazi jackboots no longer tramp the streets of Athens. Their owners have business elsewhere. They are going on a journey. They are returning to their northern homes, as the Persians long ago returned to their eastern ones.

Six or seven million American males between the ages of 38 and 44 may be said to have bid farewell to their youth this week. The time is long past when they can have expected the Presidential greetings which call men to the front line, but not until last Monday did the order go out that this middle-aged group is now to be classified as "not acceptable for induction into military service."

ROME, Oct. 13 (AP) -- German troops before Bologna, like their predecessors at Cassino, came up out of their foxholes today after enduring what the Fifteenth Air Force described as the "greatest aerial assault of the war on a single target area" and rejoined the furious struggle for the final hills before the Po Valley metropolis.

I have been a nurses' aide since May, 1940, and have served about 1,500 hours. Last week I went to Red Cross headquarters in New York to arrange my winter schedule. On the streets were hundreds of well-dressed women shopping, going to fittings, or on their way to cocktail bars or luncheon engagements.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed increase in holdings of United States Government securities and note circulation for the system as a whole to be $355,474,000 and $201,784,000, respectively, while the ratio of reserve declined to 52.2.

New bond financing this week, most of it centered in one railroad loan, was the smallest for any similar period in two months. Aggregating $24,118,000, the week's two emissions consisted of $23,735,000 in carrier bonds and $383,000 in municipal securities and compared with $73,760,000 (revised) for four issues offered to the public last week and $8,500,000 in this week last year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 13 (U.P.) -- Charges made by the Army Newspaper CBI Roundup, that several movie stars quit entertaining soldiers in the China-Burma-India area because it was too tough, stirred up a storm in the film colony today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, warned today that the country would face its most critical post-war economic period when the various "pressures of inflation" reached a crisis four to eight months after the fall of Germany.
PARIS, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Several small clashes between Spanish frontier guards and Spanish Republicans of the French Maquis have been reported from the frontier region.

Throughout the United States the Catholic Church is planning to celebrate Mission Sunday on Oct. 22. It will be a day of appeal for funds to support the labors of devoted brothers in distant lands bringing faith and solace to humble peoples. It is an appeal in which Pope Pius himself has ardently joined.

ALBANY, Oct. 13 -- Governor Dewey indicated today that his next campaign speech, which will be given Monday night at St. Louis, would be in the same vein as the sharp attacks which he made at Oklahoma City and Charleston, W. Va., on President Roosevelt and his Administration.

Dave Wolper has decided to bring to a conclusion after tonight's performance the Broadway run of "Men to the Sea," the Herbert Kubly play which stirred the New Haven and Boston censors when it was done in those cities before arriving here.

LONDON, Saturday, Oct. 14 -- Russian shock troops captured the Latvian capital and big Nazi naval base of Riga yesterday, smashing seven miles through a strong maze of Axis defenses in a conquest that released many thousands of Soviet veterans for the battle of Germany itself.

Among the 4,000 Army nurses she had charge of abroad, not one was a "problem child," but the civilian nurses in this country who are not enlisting in the numbers needed present a real dilemma to the War Department, Lieut. Col. Bernice M. Wilbur, who has just returned after thirty-eight months in the Mediterranean area, declared here yesterday.

ANTWERP, the Netherlands, Oct. 13 -- The Germans continued to lose ground on the multiple fronts where they are facing the Canadian First Army today, but despite the discouraging outlook for them they fought like maniacs in some sectors.

BOSTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Razor-sharp, after serving fourteen months in the Army, Ray (Sugar) Robinson, 148 1/2, of New York, resumed his professional boxing career tonight by registering a two-round technical knockout over Izzy Jannazzo, 153, of Brooklyn, one of his favorite victims, in a scheduled ten-round feature bout at the Boston Garden.

I trust that Governor Dewey, or whoever else may have authority, will declare an emergency exists and extend the time of registration where necessary so that many will not practically be deprived of their right to register, and therefore to vote, at the next election.

The city of Miami, Fla., will be in the market on Oct. 26 with an issue of $7,600,000 of refunding bonds, series GM, for which bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 3 per cent. The bonds, dated July 1, 1944, will mature July 1, 1965, optional for call at various dates.

WITH AMERICAN FIRST ARMY ASSAULTING AACHEN, Oct. 13 -- Lean, hard-bitten veterans of one of America's most famous units fought their way into the ruined eastern section of Aachen today while to the northeast of the city the first wave of a German counter-offensive receded from unbroken American positions, leaving sixty-two of its tanks destroyed or seriously damaged on the shell-torn battlefield.

A study made for the Brookings Institution by Joseph Mayer places the probable net national income in 1947 at $127,000,000,000. This would compare with a national income of $80,400,000,000 in 1940; but it is considerably lower than most previous estimates of postwar national income.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- Though now far removed from the scene of major operations, various points on the Atlantic Coast, where the Germans are still holding out, report fantastic fighting conditions. When the American forces pushed south and then eastward the Germans entrenched themselves in several sectors along the coast, many of which have fallen by now.
Just returned from Pittsburgh, Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National Chairman, expressed confidence yesterday that the Republican national ticket would carry Pennsylvania.

The Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, president of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, issued yesterday a statement deploring reported "isolated" acts of desecration with respect to the bodies of slain Japanese soldiers and appealed to American soldiers as a group to discourage such actions on the part of individuals.

V-E day for the tanning and related industries will not coincide with the end of the European war, according to F. Albert Hayes, chief, leather branch, leather and shoe division, War Production Board, but only when leather cutbacks are sufficient to return to civilian production large supplies that now are channeled to war purposes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13--The Pacific Fleet's powerful air assault on Formosa was viewed here today by competent observers primarily as a blow to support our advertised plans to invade the Philippines and to harass Japan's supply lines between the homeland, China and conquered islands by destroying the enemy's air force in the Formosa citadel.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- The recent spell of cold wet weather at the front brought the realization that the men fighting on the rim of Germany were ill-equipped for winter. Within ten days the American troops have been "winterized"; 41 per cent of extra warm clothing was rushed to them by aircraft in a record operation.

MOSCOW, Oct. 13 -- Premier Joseph Stalin and Prime Minister Churchill met tonight with Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk in an effort to settle the knotty Polish political dispute -- one of the thousand problems confronting the United Nations, a solution of which is a necessary precedent to the establishment of a general Allied pattern for post-war Europe.

ROME, Oct. 13 -- Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York left Rome this morning for Naples and then the United States, from where he is expected soon to go on to the Far East to continue his visits as Roman Catholic military Bishop of the Armed Forces.

ROME, Oct. 13 -- Three proclamations announcing the approach of an Allied force and pleading for unity and order were broadcast by radio and planes tonight to the Greek people, whose capital, Athens, is reported now to be in the hands of patriots.

Leaders in the electric lamp and shade manufacturing industry warned city officials yesterday that their plants, long concentrated in New York, might be moved to neighboring States as a result of recent sharp increases in prices asked for loft and factory space here.

OTTAWA, Oct. 13 -- Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King announced tonight the appointment of C.D. Howe as Minister of Reconstruction, of Ian Mackenzie as Minister of Veterans Affairs and of Brooke Claxton as Minister of National Health and Welfare.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- President Roosevelt called on the War Production Board today to provide in its reconversion plans for increased supplies of agricultural machinery to help the farmers to continue their high rate of production to meet the heavy post-war demands for food both at home and abroad.

William Manus, 24 years old, an alleged bogus physician and the self-described "vice dean" and treasurer of the New York College of Psychiatry at 103 Park Avenue, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Special Sessions and was held in $5,000 bail by Justice Frederick L. Hackenburg on numerous charges of violating the State Education Law.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 13 -- The bridgeheads north and south of the German pocket on the south side of the Schelde estuary by the Canadian First Army were expanded further today and reinforcements reached the Allies in this sector.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Taking command in the opening furlong, J.L. Friedman's Which Ace led the remainder of the way in the Friendsville Purse at Laurel Park today. Under Jockey Buddy Root, the son of Case Ace forged to the finish line two lengths in front of J.W. Bowley's Flying Tartar, with Dr. G.T. Strother's Rocket Gal third in a field of twelve.

Ninety-year-old Judah David Eisenstein is a man of letters. When his family decided to celebrate his and his wife Rebecca's seventieth wedding anniversary on Oct. 22 Mr. Eisenstein prepared for the event in his own way -- by writing a treatise on longevity.

EN ROUTE WITH SENATOR TRUMAN, Oct. 18 (AP) -- A prediction that President Roosevelt would poll a minimum of 750,000 Texas votes was made today by three supporters who boarded Senator Truman's special car at Houston.
