A nation-wide counter-propaganda drive aimed at cementing German war morale, beginning in fifth grade classrooms and extending through the Army to the entire social framework, has been launched by the Nazis to combat the "thoughtless spreading of war-essential facts" and to drive home the line that the Allies are fighting all Germans and not just the Nazis.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, urged today that women receive due consideration in post-war employment. Speaking before the National Council of Negro Women, she also advocated extension of the social security system to agricultural and domestic workers, the self-employed, business and professional people and farm operators.

Approximately 100,000,000 square feet of storage space will be required by Government agencies for surplus material in the post-war period, Col. Albert B. Drake, Army Service Forces, said yesterday at the Conference of Termination and Reconversion, sponsored by the New York University School of Law and Division of General Education.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 13 -- The long dormant antagonism between Dr. Goebbels and Gestapo Chief Himmler came out into the open this week and Aarshal Goering was called in to "mediate," according to neutral observers just out of Berlin tonight.

Foster-Harris, an instructor in creative writing at the University of Oklahoma, whose students sold 1,000,000 words of fiction and earned thereby $10,000 in the last twelve months, has written a book called "The Basic Formulas of Fiction," published Tuesday by the University of Oklahoma Press.

Except for light shake-downs scheduled for today, the New York Giants and the Brooklyn Tigers have now completed their preparations for tomorrow's contest at Ebbets Field which opens the 1944 pro football season locally.
ROME, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- In presenting a request for allocation of additional frequency modulation channels for educational broadcasting, Dr. John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, said at a hearing of the Federal Communications Commission today that educational groups in twenty-eight States were planning State-wide broadcasts after the war.

" If cosmetics are taken too seriously they are a failure; they are not an end in themselves," agreed the reputedly unconventional Mr. John and Mr. Fred, owners of a newly completed cosmetic line and designers of hats, in an interview yesterday.

Heavy swings in their accounts made New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve system scramble last week to preserve their reserve positions. By Wednesday night they had increased actual reserves by $62,000,000.

With new designs in wallpaper ruled out by the War Production Board over a year ago, today's shoppers might well be amazed by the variety of fresh patterns on hand in stores. The answer, according to wallpaper dealers, is that when the design freeze went into effect, manufacturers had hundreds of patterns in stock that had never been shown in New York City.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- Jacques Duclos, secretary of the Communist party, in an interview with this correspondent, today said that the Consultative Assembly being formed by the Government could not serve as the alternative to the resistance groups as a legal basis for the regime.

The four-story Putnam mansion at 70 Willow Street, Brooklyn, which borough historians believe was built at least a generation before the Revolution, has been presented to the Brooklyn Chapter of the American Red Cross, it was disclosed yesterday at the organization's headquarters, 57 Willoughby Street.

ARMY vs. Pitt -- Ordinarily it is not easy to get back on a football fare after a steady diet of baseball. But games like this simplify matters immensely and even an inexpert doesn't have to peak through his blindfold to guess correctly. The Kaydets are a powerhouse which can grind out the points at will. Clark Shaughnessy's all-civilian squad cannot have much hope of stopping this array of military might.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 150:

Robert E. Healy, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, delivered last night an "off-the-record" talk before the New School for Social Research. It does not seem to have happened in this case, but luncheon clubs and other organizations continually advertise that their speakers will talk "off the record."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Department store sales for the week ended Oct. 7 were 16 per cent higher than sales in the corresponding period of last year. The following table shows percentage changes for like periods of 1943:

Gordon Manley, young Canadian pianist making his debut at Town Hall last night, showed many excellent qualities and at the same time, several unsatisfactory traits which prevented his playing from being completely successful. Most of his faults were faults of youth and of inexperience.

BOSTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Displaying a powerful running attack with Right-Halfback Johnny Rabbett setting the pace, Boston College's informal football team registered a 33-to-0 victory over City College of New York tonight at Braves Field.

The economic importance of cotton and its place in American fashion will be stressed in a special number in "Fashions of the Times," scheduled to start its run of eight performances on Oct. 24 at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The capitulation of Hungary is expected almost hourly in London, although there has been no official confirmation that her regent, Admiral Nicholas Horthy, has actually sought armistice terms.

The twelve-story and penthouse office building at 185 Montague Street, originally designed and built in 1929 for the National Exchange Bank, has been purchased by Webb Knapp, Inc., from the Bowery Savings Bank, which acquired it about six months ago through foreclosure of a mortgage of about $500,000.

The New York Society of Women Artists opened its twentieth annual exhibition with a preview last evening at the National Academy, 1083 Fifth Avenue. This show, containing more than a hundred paintings, water-colors and pieces of sculpture, will continue through Oct. 27.
OGDEN, Utah, Oct. 13 -- Returning to his home, on a farm, today, Boyd Borgstrom, veteran of the South Pacific, said he was enthusiastic over the battle he was prepared to fight on the home front.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad today announced acceptance, subject to Interstate Commerce Commission approval, of an offer of the manufacturers Trust Company of New York to make a 5-year $10,000,000 collateral loan at 1.745 per cent interest to be used with other funds to pay off $15,188,000 in the road's extended 3 1/2 per cent bonds, due Oct. 1, 1947.

Shozo Murata, who became Japan's Ambassador to the occupied Philippines when she granted paper "independence" to the occupied islands as a propaganda gesture exactly a year ago, declared in an anniversary statement yesterday that "American guerrillas" were harassing Japanese communications in the Philippines and that the puppet government's attempts to suppress the guerrillas had "not been very satisfactory," according to the Japanese News Agency Domei.

In a prompt resale, a client of Joseph Howard Katz, lawyer, has disposed of the four-story business building at 133 West Fifty-second Street through Rosner Brothers, brokers. The seller recently acquired the property from the Bank for Savings.

EN ROUTE WITH BRIOKER, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Gov. John W. Bricker's special train loafed through southern Oregon today while the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee stacked oratorical ammunition for the greatest venture of his Western campaign -- the invasion of California.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- President Roosevelt told his news conference today that he had been talking and thinking about making speeches beyond the one he is scheduled to make before the Foreign Policy Association in New York City on Oct. 21, but indicated that final decisions had not yet been made.

Observers agree that the duck season that opens its eighty-day run here at sunrise will not be good at the start because the great flights from the north have not begun yet, but it is possible that when freezing weather drives the birds southward the shooting will be the best in years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- President Roosevelt left in doubt today whether he would have another meeting this year with Premier Joseph Stalin and Prime Minister Churchill. In response to questions posed at his news conference, he said he did not know.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, Oct. 14 (U.P.) -- Allied night air patrols harassed the Davao and Tacloban airdromes on southern Mindanao and damaged two small freighters at Leyte and two ships at Zamboanga in sweeps over the Philippines Wednesday, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

Retail trade here continued active this week, with Columbus Day volume favorable and the week as a whole expected to show a gain of around 20 per cent for department stores. Gift buying for soldiers overseas reached its peak.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Edward Martin, Republican Governor of Pennsylvania, said today:

Samuel Shapiro, one of the younger experts of the Marshall Chess Club, led last night with a score of 2 1/2 -- 1/2 at the conclusion of the third round of the amateur championship of the United States Chess Federation in Group A at the Manhattan C.C. rooms.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 13 -- Vice Admiral Marc A. Mitscher's fast carrier task force, a part of William F. Halsey's Third Fleet, scored a tremendous victory against the Japanese in the Formosa area in a two-day attack Wednesday and Thursday, United States time. It destroyed 396 enemy planes and sank or damaged 100 ships and small craft, fleet headquarters announced today.

Reduced to a squad of thirty-three because of injuries and withdrawals, New York University clashes with Temple today on Ohio Field. The starting time is set for 2:30. The Violets have a manpower problem, especially in the backfield where they lost this week Frank Mangiapane, Murray Oringer and Joe Plentzas.

Some information about the nutritive value of commercially canned foods has come to this department from Allen L. Malone, director of the research department of the Continental Can Company. What Mr. Malone has to say is likely to interest most householders, especially in view of the fact that our consumption of tinned vegetables is likely to increase now that all varieties except tomatoes are point-free.
Mathieson Alkali Works, Inc., had a net profit in the first nine months this year of $828,801 after all charges, including $805,000 for Federal taxes, the report disclosed yesterday.

" Ninety-nine Park," headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc.,* offers a partial list of free amusements available today, through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M. Evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.
Julian Fleishman, formerly with the central buying office of Gimbel Bros., Inc., will join Charles Weill, Inc., resident buying representatives, on Monday.

Col. Arthur V. McDermott, city director of Selective Service, yesterday advised all men who expect to be inducted into the armed forces before election day to apply for absentee ballots. He pointed out that the State Election Law provides that any person qualified to vote may apply for an absentee ballot at his board of registry.
Connecticut University will help Brooklyn College open its home football season at 2:30 this afternoon at Brooklyn College Stadium. The game marks the first gridiron meeting between the two schools.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 13 -- Several developments in industrial and agricultural chemistry, including a shellac substitute and an improved method of vulcanizing rubber, and a method of predicting accurately the break-up of fog are among the 579 inventions listed as patented in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

ROME, Oct. 13 -- In words of greater bitterness than any yet uttered by an Italian public figure, Senator Benedetto Croce on the first anniversary of Italy's declaration of war against Germany today asked that this country's humiliation be brought to an end.

The Treasury Department, it was learned yesterday, is negotiating with the motion picture in dustry's War Activities Committee to arrange for the showing of Arturo Toscanini's film recording of Verdi's "Hymn of the Nations" in movie houses during the Sixth War Loan Drive, which opens Nov. 20.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The labor press gave prominence today to an Army circular discussing the subject of labor's production record and strikes.

Testifying yesterday at a hearing held by Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, in that body's office in the Woolworth Building on an application of the Consolidated Edison Company for approval of a merger of the financial structures of the light and power utilities serving the metropolitan area, Harold S. Sutton, executive assistant to the company's president, said such a merger would permit an annual saving of $4,626,761 in interest.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Sid Bernstein's Guerryton today won the $2,000 Peterboro Purse at Rockingham Park while the Donna Ray Stable's Marion Collins took the secondary feature, the $1,600 Wentworth Purse.
ROME, Oct. 13 (AP) -- General Wilson's broadcast indicated an Allied landing in force was imminent, contrasted with the comparatively small forces employed in the Peloponnesus.

Testifying yesterday at a hearing held by Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, in that body's office in the Woolworth Building on an application of the Consolidated Edison Company for approval of a merger of the financial structures of the light and power utilities serving the metropolitan area, Harold S. Sutton, executive assistant to the company's president, said such a merger would permit an annual saving of $4,626,761 in interest.

TOPEKA, Oct. 13 -- So certain are most political leaders and independent observers in Kansas that the State will go overwhelmingly for the Dewey-Bricker ticket for President and the Republican slate of State and Congressional candidates this year that they are wearily awaiting Nov. 7, when they expect a foreordained result to be made official.

The Regional Office of Price Administration has obtained injunctions in Federal court against forty-seven New York City retail bakers to prevent any inflationary rise in the price of bread and other baked goods, Daniel P. Woolley, Regional OPA Administrator, announced yesterday.
Governor and Mrs. Walter E. Edge of New Jersey are at the Ambassador.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Georgette Bauerdorf, 20, whose nearly nude body was found yesterday in the bathtub of her sister's apartment, was attacked and then strangled by someone who forced a folded washcloth down her throat, Lieut. Garner Brown of the Sheriff's office said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP)--Two Democratic Senators reported to President Roosevelt today on the political outlook, which they said they found good for their side.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Outlining a program for postwar America, Jonathan Daniels, administrative assistant to President Roosevelt, declared tonight at the opening of a three-day conference on "The Returning Service Man," sponsored by the Political Association of Vassar College, that victory must not become "a dead-end street for heroes."

Newsreels of the assassination in Rome of Donato Carretta on Sept. 18 and the execution by firing squad of Pietro Caruso have arrived in this country and will be released in the newsreel programs to be issued on Tuesday to theatres.

LONDON, Oct. 13 (U.P.) -- Strong forces of Italy-based American heavy bombers attacked rail and industrial targets in the Vienna and Budapest areas today, as adverse weather grounded the four-engined giants in Western Europe, leaving the attacks against German-held areas to light and medium bomber forces.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The stock markets here ended the week on a quiet but confident note. One of the best sections was home rails, in which buyers called for shares on news of the railway companies' scheme for participation in civil aviation, and prices advanced.

The first case of opposition to the lifting of War Production Board controls on V-E Day was made public yesterday when the Association of Pulp Consumers, Inc., announced that it had asked continuation of wood pulp allocations after the defeat of Germany "until such time as reasonable inventories have been restored and sufficient wood pulp is available to insure an adequate supply and a free and open market."

QUARTERMASTER BASE OF EIGHTH ROUTE ARMY, in Shansi-Suiyuan Military Area, Aug. 29 (Delayed) -- The writer is unable to give the location of this base except to say that to reach it he had to travel 250 miles horseback from Yenan in Shensi through mountainous country and that the main features of the vicinity are the Yellow River and the Great Wall.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 13 (U.P.) -- A Chinese military spokesman acknowledged today that the port of Foochow had fallen to the Japanese and that twin enemy offensives in southeastern China were within sixty-two miles of effecting a juncture that would split the country from north to south and give the invaders a continuous overland supply route from Manchuria to Singapore.

By paying more attention to the subject-matter of copy and the manner in which it is written and laid out rather than placing too much emphasis on size and position, grocery products advertisers can increase considerably the readership of their advertisements, Frederick Dickinson, sales manager of the Bureau of Advertising, A.N.P.A., told a recent meeting of the Newspaper Representatives Association.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Removal of substandard wartime buildings when peace has returned is the "solemn obligation" of the whole nation to the several communities which accepted them patriotically to serve the national effort, Herbert Emmerich of Chicago, said today.
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Government agencies have accepted recommendations of a special subcommittee of the advisory committee on Government questionnaires, comprising representatives of leading national trade associations, with regard to simplification of procedure for terminating war contracts, it was announced today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Saturday, Oct. 14 (AP) -- A communique:
CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Representative Clare Boothe Luce of Connecticut asserted tonight that President Roosevelt was "not only untrustworthy but also incompetent" in the field of statecraft.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 13 -- Warner Brothers has assigned Michael Curtiz to direct "Mildred Pierce," Joan Crawford's first picture for that company. The screen version of the James M. Cain novel is scheduled for production Dec. 1. "Night and Day," a musical based on the life of Cole Porter, which was to have been Curtiz' next venture, has been postponed until spring.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The War Production Board, in an effort to meet essential needs for important cotton fabrics, removed some restrictions but simultaneously imposed others today on the manufacture of men's work clothing made of denim.

LONDON, Oct. 13 (UP) -- Russian amphibious forces in a surprise landing have sealed off the Arctic port of Petsamo by capturing Liinahamari harbor, six miles to the north, Berlin reported today. The Soviet stroke, coupled with a swift Finnish advance from the south, appeared to have set a trap for 60,000 to 100,000 Germans in northern Finland.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the payment of $63,750 in fees to five persons in connection with the Utilities Employes Securities Company's plan of liquidation and dissolution.
Liquidation in distant deliveries of cotton in the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange brought about yesterday slightly lower prices and final quotations were down 2 to 17 points net.

BALZAC (and only a Frenchman would have dared) once said that woman's virtue is man's greatest invention. Anglo-Saxon moralists have denied this hotly, as an insult to both sexes; and yet Anglo-Saxon booksellers, if they are honest, will confess that few characters in fiction are more beloved by female readers than the successful harlot.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- As expected, the University of Pittsburgh was no match at all for the Army today, and the Cadets, adhering strictly to the script, went on a touchdown parade, the like of which had not been seen here at Michie Stadium since that November afternoon in 1929 when Dickinson was overwhelmed by an 89-7 count.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Sunday, Oct. 15 (AP) -- A communique:

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- The French are historically noted for being "frondeurs," as they put it, that is, rebellious against authority, suspicious of all ruling power and recalcitrant toward the State and its laws and regulations. Yet, paradoxically, they are among the most legal-minded of nations and illegality disturbs and even shocks them.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Tulane's flashy Green Wave pocketed its fumbles in the second and third quarters today to score a 21-0 victory over a game, but outclassed Rice Institute team.

The New York Giants vs the Brooklyn Tigers! That's the lineup for this afternoon at Ebbets Field. It will be the first clash of the year for local pro-football fans and what an opener! You couldn't ask for a better one and a capacity crowd is expected to be on hand when either Ken Strong (remember him?) or Bruiser Kinard plants his toe against the pigskin to get the interborough battle going.

John Wallace of Clayton, Mo., and Thomas Marshall of Fairfield, Conn., have been selected as judges for the annual licensed meeting of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club, which will be held at East Islip Saturday and Sunday, Nov. 4 and 5.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Folowing is the text of a White House analysis of statements made by Governor Dewey in his campaign speeches, and "the facts" presented in reply to each:

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 14 (AP) -- A budget of $1,790,000 for world action in 1945, nearly triple the $622,000 being currently expended, was approved today by the convention of the United Lutheran Church in America as delegates voted in favor of a new constitution greatly augmenting activities or the National Lutheran Council, which administers the funds.

Asserting that the basic issues of the Presidential campaign are not being met squarely, Dr. Eduard C. Lindeman, Professor of Social Philosophy of the New York School of Social Work, Columbia University, yesterday urged 150 members of the New York Women's Trade Union League to redefine the problems presented by both parties.

Formation of the Metropolitan New York Business and Industry Committee to study individual and group problems of smaller business, local, State and Federal legislation affecting it and to make recommendations to protect the best interests of smaller business was announced yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

CONGRESS too often suffers, in the public mind, from being considered in much the same category as the weather. We take it for granted that both are always with us; we occasionally remark that one or the other is "doing all right," but more often we express a wish that there could be a change.

THE third decade of the twentieth century has been called a lot of things, from the "Roaring Twenties" to the "Era of Wonderful Nonsense." Recently, however, this reviewer heard a well-known writer, in a broadcast, identify it as the era of H.L. Mencken.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Britain's greatest wartime sports crowd -- 90,000 -- watched a crack England team score six times in the second half to beat Scotland, 6 -- 2, in a thrill-packed international match at the Wembley Stadium this afternoon.

THE title of that new, forthcoming novel by John Steinbeck is "Cannery Row," which, as Californians at least will recognize, is the name of a street in Monterey, Calif. Like his "The Moon Is Down" and "Of Mice and Men," it will be a not very long book. . . .

Marking one of the most comprehensive steps it has ever taken, the board of directors of the General Federation of Women's Clubs voted unanimously yesterday to set in action a national program for the development of adequate post-war planning for the youth of the nation that would coordinate and integrate all public and private resources.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 14 (AP) -- A band of Iowa Pre-Flight School opportunists, who took advantage of two of their three scoring chances with quick thrusts in the second and fourth periods and then turned back Purdue's vaunted offense, handed the Boilermakers a 13-to-6 defeat today.

SAID the husband to the wife just returned from the hairdresser in a new, elegant coiffure, "Never put anything on your hair that keeps me from wanting to put my hand on it." His remark, aimed at the lacquered stiff curls and net she was wearing, is fairly typical of the normal male attitude.

THIS reviewer cannot see the name Marianne Moore without blushing, for it reminds him of the silliest critical blunder he ever made. Having come to share Mr. Eliot's conviction that "Miss Moore's poems form part of the small body of durable poetry written in our time," he remembers with shame that when, ten years ago, he first tried to read her, he could make very little of the poems.

MOSCOW, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Although still at loggerheads over the recent rising in Warsaw, the Polish factions have apparently decided to "let bygones be bygones" and exclude the capital's tragedy from their impending conversations.

The past week will be remembered in history not only for its battles but especially for the "statement of tentative proposals" issued at the close of the Dumbarton Oaks conference and signed by representatives of the United States, the United Kingdom, Russia and China.

LIKE any other manufacturing concern, the theatre pastes labels on its finished merchandise. There are musical shows, revues, dramas, comedies and farces. There also are hits and flops, gloomy turkeys and great smashes. And finally there is another one, used less often but with a connotation that is almost completely dismal -- the "matinee show."

A generation ago we thought we had reached the nutritional millennium because it was discovered that we live not alone by bread and meat but by calories. So we began to think of ourselves as living boiler plants and engines. Unless so much fuel (calories) were consumed we starved to death.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 14 -- The development of new cotton yarns of high strength by chemical treatment direct from roving, which will open vast new fields for the use of short staple cotton, was announced here today. The yarn will capture new markets for cotton both in the commercial and industrial fields, it was predicted, and will prove of great benefit to the economy of the South.

WHEN day is done Al Goodman seats himself at the piano for some relaxation. And, as the Broadway patron puts it, Mr. Goodman's relaxing moments at the piano mean "rocking the joint with a floor-splitting boogie-woogie."

THIS is a tale that was waiting to be told -- this story of the Lees of China. The Lees are a family who combine the best traditions of the old along with the progressive principles of the new generation. They are the kind of Chinese most Americans know little about, yet they are the same simple, hard-working, law-abiding people who are the pulse-beat of any nation.

ONE of Miss Graham's characters makes the interesting comment that the population of Montreal is divided into three social groups: the English Canadians, the French Canadians and the Jews, the English and French being united in ostracism of the Jews and the French and the Jews finding one common ground in their resentment of the political and economic dominance of the English minority.

The Allied liberation of Athens, "birthplace of democracy," and of Piraeus, its ancient port, was celebrated here last night at a gala program in Manhattan Center by several thousand Greek-Americans and civic leaders of New York who mingled with their joy a pledge to hold high the Hellenic torch of freedom throughout the post-war world.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (U.P.) -- The United States is preparing to call an international conference to formulate a comprehensive postwar world trade policy.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 14 -Reports that Reich Marshal Hermann Goering has been losing prestige and popularity as Adolf Hitler's heir apparent were rebutted tonight by confirmed declarations from neutral sources in Berlin.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Smashing to three touchdowns in the first nineteen minutes, Michigan rolled to a 27-to-0 Big Ten football triumph over Northwestern here today.

Holy Cross College Institute of Labor Relations has started its second year with a registration of more than 250 union leaders and representatives of management of manufacturing companies in central Massachusetts. It was opened last year to give the working man and his employer an opportunity to acquire a better understanding of industrial relations.

Bearing out Mr. Churchill's prediction that the Japanese will resume fighting in Burma as soon as the monsoon season ends, a small Japanese force has just made a reconnaissance thrust into Bengal to test the defenses of the Indian border. It was driven back, but the Japanese are believed to have concentrated considerable forces in Burma for more ambitious efforts.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 14 -- As part of her post-war reparations to the United Nations, Germany should be forced to contribute to the development of a Jewish national home in Palestine, Dr. Israel Goldstein of New York, president of the Zionist Organization of America, told 500 delegates tonight at the formal opening of the forty-seventh annual convention at the Steel Pier.

Holding itself bound by United States Supreme Court precedents, the Circuit Court of Appeals set aside yesterday an injunction and declaratory judgment of illegality that had been issued by the Federal District Court against an admittedly uneconomic boycott enforced by Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers against eleven major electrical manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Senate investigators have identified and obtained affidavits from members of the International Teamsters Union of the American Federation of Labor who came to blows with two Navy officers in the "battle of the Statler," Senator Green, Democrat, of Rhode Island, chairman of the Campaign Expenditures Committee, disclosed today.

DWARF ageratum grown from seed has a habit of producing plants that vary somewhat in height and flower form, and thus fail to carry out the neat ribbon border that was envisioned when the edging was planned. Even though seeds of the best dwarf strain are obtained, one cannot hope to have a uniform border if one uses this method of propagation.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Three methods of speeding the reconversion of war plants to peacetime production were offered today by Bernard J. Hank, president and chairman of the board of the Conlon Corporation, peacetime manufacturer of household laundry equipment and automotive parts supplier, now operating entirely on war work.

THIS one-man show by David Fredenthal bears the catch-title "Of Men and Battle." David Fredenthal, an artist familiar to gallery-goers, who has worked under Guggenheim and Museum of Modern Art fellowships and later as an Army war artist and for Life, made these sketches for the picture magazine during the attack on Arawa, New Britain, December, 1943.

WITH THE AMERICAN FIRST ARMY, in Germany, Oct. 14 -- Although military government officials of the American First Army have successfully solved the preliminary problems connected with the occupation of this small section of the Reich, it is apparent that they have not yet come to grips with the major problem, that of dealing with the SS, or Elite Guard, the Nazi state within a state.

ONE of the most popular short cruises before the war was the one to Bermuda. That coral island, with its giant hibiscus, snug coves and sandy beaches, offered the proverbial paradise for a few days' lazing in the sun -- days that went much too fast, since a considerable part of a week's holiday was consumed in the ocean trip.

Maj. I. Arthur Mirsky of the Army's medical corps states in Science that certain streptococci, which cause septic sore throat, one form of heart disease, erysipelas and rheumatic fever, may come from an anti-enzyme substance in beef sweetbreads and soy beans. The disease germs under investigation, known as beta hemolytic streptococci, are believed to owe at least some of their disease-causing power to the fibrinolysin they produce.

As we shifted from a peace to a war economy it was frequently pointed out that because of the bottlenecks of war production we were fighting a "battle of time." We will once more face a "battle of time" when we shift from war to peace. Time to clear plants of Government-owned machinery.

FIFTY years ago this past summer there appeared a curious little paper-backed volume entitled "Coin's Financial School" that was destined, as the staid Review of Reviews remarked a bit later, and with a trace of fear in its editorial voice, to "sway public opinion from the Alleghenies to the Pacific and from the Great Lakes to the Gulf of Mexico."

AHEDGE is a long-term garden investment. The place as well as the purpose of a hedge is usually well defined and common sense dictates, therefore, that even if the period for fall planting is getting shorter we take time to select the kind of plants that will be adequate and pleasing.

THE worst of being a playwright is that it is such a long time between ideas. I have heard of playwrights who know what their next five plays are going to be about, but I do not believe such stories. Rabbits, I have read somewhere, are the only members of the animal kingdom who can carry two litters at the same time; and your rabbit-playwright is, so to speak, a very rare bird indeed.
NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Coast Guard Academy scored a half-dozen touchdowns almost at will today as it beat Rensselaer Polytech, 38 to 6.

IN every novel Erskine Caldwell has published since "Tobacco Road," he has sought to probe more deeply into his material, and in none has he come nearer his objective than in "Tragic Ground." "Tobacco Road" will continue to hold the distinction of adding a new type to the gallery of American fiction.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, in the Southwest Pacific, Sunday, Oct. 15 (U.P.) -- More than 125 Allied bombers and fighters dropped 130 tons of bombs on Amboina and Ceram Islands in the southern Moluccas Thursday and Friday in a concentrated attack against enemy airdromes, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

CRISP, appetite-provoking days make fall a particularly good time for substantial macaroni dishes. They may be of several sorts, for macaroni -- the generic name for more than a hundred differently shaped flour-and-water pastes -- is so bland that it takes kindly to a variety of seasonings and may be combined with a number of foods.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 14 -- Francisco (Pancho) Segura of Ecuador put on a whirlwind finish today to defeat William Talbert of Indianapolis in the third Pan-American tennis tournament singles final in five sets. The score was 1 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 --2, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 1.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Events of the last seven days have gone far toward dispelling the apathy which for a time hung like an inert mist above the national political campaign.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S constant companion, unquestioning friend and admirer is Fala, the little black scamp of a Scottie that follows him about wherever he goes. Mr. Roosevelt made this relationship indelibly clear when he recently attacked some Republicans for making "libelous statements about my dog."
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Representative Clare Boothe Luce of Connecticut described President Roosevelt tonight as "the world's leading isolationist and appeaser" from 1933 to 1939.

Though American Airlines has been flying around the globe with the exception of the China-Australia gap, according to a summary of its wartime services for the Air Transport Command and Naval Air Transport Service made public yesterday by A.N. Kemp, American Airlines presilent, the company is asking for peacetime operation only across the North Atlantic.

CONTEMPORARY work with a decidedly modern slant took possession of the exhibition schedule last week, all but a few of the score of shows I visited being well within that category. At least three of the shows, were unquestionably American, and these we may take up briefly first.

In a special message broadcast yesterday from his desk at City Hall, Mayor La Guardia warned the families, relatives and friends of service men overseas to beware of "fake" Christmas gift packages now being sold at exorbitant prices.

RIGHT now, with European markets on the verge of opening up once more to American films, Hollywood is busy dubbing pictures in several languages. Most foreign audiences like to hear their own language spoken on the screen, but there is one country which would much rather take our actors as they are and depend upon subtitles to provide whatever language translation might be necessary.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14 -- Columbia had the first and last laughs in its twenty-second game with Yale in the Bowl today, but they did the Lions no good for the Elis continued their unbeaten record by downing the New Yorkers, 27 -- 10.
ROME, Oct. 14 -- British ground forces pushed on rapidly in Greece in an effort to take advantage of the German withdrawal, it was announced.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Outstanding among facts demonstrated in the past week by forums and round-table discussion of veterans' affairs conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES was the need for coordination of private organizations without whose work the benefit program cannot achieve the greatest success.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today the first volume in a new series of five statistical reports covering the years 1942-1943 and disclosing data on profits and operations of 1,530 American companies in 118 industry groups having total assets of more than $62,000,000,000.

IN 1940, at a national conference in Dayton, Ohio, the author of "Without Bitterness" -- then only 20 and straight from his native Africa -- was introduced by an American friend as "Prince Orizu of the royal household of Nnewi, Nigeria." The friend then added that the speaker was "also an Englishman."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 14 -- Brazilian and American businessmen intent upon developing trade opportunities after the war have appointed a joint committee of three Brazilians and three Americans to make recommendations to both Governments with respect to customs tariffs, freight rates and trade terms.

ALBANY, Oct. 14 -- Governor Dewey paid tribute to Theodore Roosevelt today in a proclamation designating Oct. 27 as Navy Day. The date will be the eighty-sixth anniversary of the birth of Theodore Roosevelt, who, before he was Governor or President, was assistant secretary of the navy and has been called the father of the modern American Navy.

The first football victory since the school adopted the game in 1939 was achieved by Lafayette High, 7 -- 6, over Poly Prep on Poly's gridiron in Brooklyn yesterday. This was Lafayette's twenty-third game. Not only had the school never won before, but it never had gained so much as a tie.

President Roosevelt has declined an invitation to deliver an address closing the annual forum of The New York Herald Tribune at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel next Wednesday night, according to an announcement issued from the White House yesterday.

A FIRST encounter with musical activities in the capital of Brazil is apt to leave one with mixed feelings. Rio de Janeiro is neither the jewel of musical culture that one may have been led to believe, nor is it as musically backward as it is sometimes depicted.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Among the smaller powers, members of the United Nations, which are now studying the tentative Security Charter framed at Dumbarton Oaks, it is a prevalent remark that, because it eliminates political and territorial guarantees, the proposed organization offers scant hope to the lesser nations unless it is to be coupled with broad world policies which will give those powers a chance.

SEVENTH ARMY AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, Central Pacific, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Truk, once the most feared Japanese bastion of the Pacific, has been 75 per cent neutralized by American air attacks. Seventh AAF headquarters reported today after an inspection of new aerial photographs.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 14 -- Although held in complete captivity and without a normally functioning government at his command. Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain is still designated by Berlin as the legal head of the French State.

Importers, shippers' agents, dealers and brokers attending the annual meeting of the Tanners' Council of America here last week were not seeing eye to eye with consuming industries and war agency officials with respect to the world hide and skin situation during the post-war period.

THE first brace of concerts by the New York City Symphony at the City Center was a success, reports Leopold Stokowski, the orchestra's conductor, but the orchestra itself is going to be "much better" in the future.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey was accused at the White House today of distortion, dishonesty and playing "fast and loose with the American people" in the charges he has been making against the Administration during his campaign as Republican candidate for the Presidency.

This country's merchant shipyards last month delivered 124 vessels, aggregating 1,195,997 deadweight tons, showing only a slight increase in tonnage over August, but faster vessels predominated, the Maritime Commission disclosed last week.

Wendell L. Willkie, who died suddenly last week at the age of 52, left an eloquent legacy of writings. On this page are quotations chosen to be representative of what he believed in and what he stood for. The excerpts have been taken from his books, his speeches and his magazine articles.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 14 -- Louisiana's ten Democratic electors will vote for President Roosevelt and Senator Truman, provided their party carries the State. This regularity was insured when the Democratic State Central Committee ousted seven electors who refused to pledge themselves to vote for the party's nominees.

ONE of the pleasanter aspects of "psychological warfare" is illustrated by an exhibit called "America Builds" presented for ten weeks last summer at the National Museum in Stockholm, now on display at the Rohsska Museum in Gothenburg, Sweden, and to be shown later, it is hoped, in other cities of Europe.

LONDON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Air Ministry announced tonight that the Royal Air Force had been breaking dams, seawalls, and submarine pens recently with a new type 12,000-pound "earthquake" bomb that it described as "undoubtedly the most destructive air weapon ever used."
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- Colgate's Red Raiders beat a favored Cornell team today, 14 -- 7, before 7,000 spectators.

HAVING been asked to say a few words about the book which won this year's Dodd, Mead-Redbook Prize Novel Competition, this reviewer will indicate its contents, and then move on to some sour remarks about prize-winning fiction.

The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has created a new position, that of director of libraries, and has appointed Prof. John E. Burchard, now director of the Bemis Foundation, to the post. Professor Burchard begins his new duties immediately but will continue to give a large portion of his time to important war work in which he has been engaged for the past four years.
ALBANY, Oct. 14 -- A stepping up of the Dewey campaign was indicated today with the announcement here that he would make a major address in Pittsburgh on Friday, Oct. 20.

In reply to Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce's Friday night Chicago speech, in which the Representative from Connecticut charged that President Roosevelt "lied us into war," Mrs. Mary T. Norton, Representative from New Jersey, yesterday issued a statement accusing Mrs. Luce of complete ignorance of the record, which, she said, completely disproved the charge.

EMERGENCY war work was almost halted in a New York factory recently when an important lathe broke down. The nearest replacement was at Battle Creek, Mich. Manpower might have been wasted and critical materiel might have been kept from our fighting men had not the replacement been rushed by air to New York.

AFTER the last pockets of resistance have been wiped out and General Eisenhower has announced the defeat of Germany, we shall have to face the fact that we are still engaged in fighting a war. A CONTEST among high school students throughout the United States is being sponsored jointly by the Pan American Union's Philatelic Section and the American Philatelic Society. "Pan Americanism in Postage Stamps" has been selected as the theme.

MOSCOW, Oct. 14 -- The fate of the Stalin-Churchill Polish unity negotiations hung in the balance tonight, but at least one participant. Boleslaw Berut, president of the Polish National Council of Lublin, expressed optimism that a compromise settlement would be arranged in the next few days.

MR. BARRETT writes with gusto of the early revolt of Texas-Americans against Spanish power in the Southwest. His writing has a fluency and speed which have lately seemed lacking in historical novels. Whatever his fast-moving plot does for the readability of the book, it seems to have somewhat limited his examination of Texas history.

ONE of the most overwhelming convictions held by Pope Pius XII is a belief in the desirability of peace. Yet all but seven months of his pontificate have been spent in the midst of a world war. From the time that Italy went to war against the United States, and foreign journalism on a free basis ended. the Vatican was partly cut off from the world.
PARIS, Oct. 13 -- A criticism of the American press, without the citation of a single American newspaper article to sustain it, appears in the newspaper Defense de la France today.

Telegraphic appeals to 200 hotels in the city requesting them to set aside up to 3 per cent of their rooms daily for service men and women, sent Friday by Rear Admiral William R. Munroe, commandant of the Third Naval District, and Maj. Gen. Thomas A. Terry, commanding general of the Second Service Command, met with a quick response yesterday.

Administration of two trust funds aggregating upward of $4,000,000 has been left by Henry K.S. Williams, retired lumberman, who died in San Francisco May 16, to the New York Community Trust, the organization disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Grain markets were unsettled today on the Board of Trade. They were fractionally lower early on scattered selling, but later, when shorts started to cover for the week-end, they found offerings limited and wheat, corn and rye rallied around 1 cent a bushel from the early lows and closed about the top.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14 (AP) -Secretary Morgenthau said today that the wartime increase in the public debt had been accomplished at an average interest rate of only 1 3/4 per cent, as compared with 4 1/4 per cent in World War I.

The Regional Office of Price Administration has obtained permanent injunctions in Federal Court against seven landlords in the New York metropolitan area restraining them from violating OPA rent regulations or charging more than legal ceilings.

The Treasury Department's failure to get strong business support for the Bretton Woods agreements last week at the thirty-first National Foreign Trade Convention was interpreted in business circles yesterday as an unexpected setback.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 14 -- A large number of Virginians in the armed forces have cast their election ballots with more than 26,000 already received here. This is well over 10 per cent of the Virginians of voting age in the services, estimated at 230.000. The total number of service men from this State may be as high as 270,000, but many are in the 17 to 20 age group.

Some 40 per cent of American voters are hopelessly Republican. Another 40 per cent are chronic Democrats. That leaves 20 per cent who, as independents, will decide the election. In going after the support of this small but vital group the party managers, it strikes us, aren't very complimentary.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 -- University of Pennsylvania defeated William and Mary, 46 to 0, to continue on its winning streak before a crowd of 32,000 at Franklin Field today.

A new Soviet offensive was pounding last week at the German East Wall. The invasion of East Prussia, land of the Junkers and traditional core of German militarism, seemed imminent. On a front of nearly 200 miles Russians were driving into the East Prussian system of fortifications which the Nazis had hastily built during the summer.

Leaders of educational institutions and organizations in various parts of the country joined yesterday in urging that subjects dealing with the Soviet Union, such as history, culture and language, be offered on a wide scale in American schools from the elementary grades up through teachers' colleges as a means of cementing a permanent bond between the United States and Russia.
Thomas Franklyn Manville Jr. has turned philanthropist, it was disclosed yesterday.

STORING a winter's supply of vegetables, either from the Victory garden or from the market when prices are down, or from both, gives all the pleasure of hoarding and has none of its unsavory connotations. The only critical note in the gardener's dream of impressing Christmas dinner guests with vegetables from his own backyard is the question how easy and how certain of results storing may be.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration, saddled with a complex lending problem, made public tonight an explanation of the basic interest and guarantee arrangements for loans to veterans under terms of the "GI Bill of Rights."

Three teen-age boys described as members of an upper West Side gang known as "The Dukes," appeared at last night's session of the American Prison Association annual meeting to detail their experiences in gangland and air their opinions about "cops, crime and criminals."

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 14 -- Ohio State's unbeaten Buckeyes, sparked by veteran Les Horvath, pounded over two last-period touchdowns to tumble Wisconsin from the undefeated ranks, 20 -- 7, in a bitterly fought Western Conference battle today.

A FEW months ago the sky over my office at Oxford Circus was filled, day after day, with majestic flights of Flying Fortresses, and, however familiar the sight, crowds never failed to stop and look at this demonstration of American power. Over Oxford I had seen a great rehearsal of gliders assembling from all points of the compass like giant birds in a Homeric simile.

ROME, Oct. 14 -- Dr. Vincezo Azzolini, former governor of the Bank of Italy, who did not say no when the Germans demanded the entire gold stocks of Italy, was sentenced today to thirty years' imprisonment, payment of civil damages to the bank and court expenses.

ANTWERP, Belgium, Oct. 14 -- A heavy counter-attack was launched today by the Germans at the base of the neck leading to Walcheren Island and, although the Canadians are firmly holding this vital strip, they are facing the heaviest artillery barrage they have seen in this war.

MINEOLA, Oct. 14 -- A touchdown in the second period enabled the Chaminade High Fliers to defeat John Adams of Ozone Park, 7 -- 0, for their second victory in four starts today. Adams suffered its first defeat, having tied New Dorp.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Virginia's swashbuckling Cavaliers held the North Carolina Pre-Flight eleven, rated second in the nation, to a 13-13 tie today and missed by six yards scoring the winning touchdown.

Reporting that never was it more difficult to get merchandise, Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers, in their special market report for THE NEW YORK TIMES, say that the phrase "it's darkest just before dawn" perhaps sums up present conditions in the wholesale markets.

Moscow was in a festive mood last week. Once again it was host to Premier Stalin's "fighting friend," Prime Minister Churchill, who had been secretly flown in from London with Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and two plane loads of staff members. It was their third meeting.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Syracuse University plowed through rain and mud tonight for five touchdowns and a 32-7 victory over Lafayette. The game was Syracuse's first victory in three starts land Lafayette's first loss in two starts.
ROME, Oct. 14 -- British and Greek troops, converging by sea and air today, occupied Athens and its near-by port of Piraeus and ended more than three years of German rule in the Greek capital.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Restrictions on the use of copper and zinc for printing plates, as established in Order M-399, were relaxed today and Order M-99, which required the scrapping of obsolete plates, was revoked, the War Production Board announced.

It was a far cry from the old days of Chick Meehan's violent Violets as a young and inexperienced N.Y.U. football team absorbed another shellacking at Ohio Field yesterday, this time at the hands of the Temple Owls by 25 -- 0.
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Three key up-State cities reported tonight that registration for the first two days fell far below comparable 1940 figures.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 14 (AP) -- The once-beaten Illini, striking with surprising suddenness in a hectic first period, momentarily demoralized a heavier Iowa Hawk-eye football team today and then rolled on to their second Western Conference victory, 40 to 6.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Nearly 20 per cent of the Netherlands has already been flooded by the Germans. True to their nature, they plan to surrender the country only to an older enemy of the Dutch than the Germans themselves -- the waters from which Holland was won by centuries of men's labor and ingenuity.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Indiana University strode home early and often in its homecoming football game with Nebraska today, romping through the Cornhuskers for a 54-to-0 victory.

WITH THE COMMUNIST EIGHTH ROUTE ARMY, in Shansi Province, Sept. 7 (Delayed) -For six days correspondents have been with operation units of China's Communist-led army in country that has passed many times from Chinese to Japanese hands and back again.

Who can enumerate all the sweet and pungent smells of a country woodshed? Who, for that matter, can describe a woodshed? They differ more widely than houses or barns: their chief similarity, in truth, is the fact that they shelter firewood, among other things. And their pungence varies with their homeland.

Boys and girls readily responded to his singlehearted determination when on the trail of a specimen or a scientific proof to his buoyant spirit of adventure, to his disregard of danger and never-failing ability to turn the light of humor on a situation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Another phase of the battle of airlines before the Civil Aeronautics Board for the control of post-war air routes made its appearance in the recent hearings, extending the conflict to stockholders of the same company.

After holding within a 4-point range during the short session, cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange finished yesterday unchanged to 3 points lower than on Friday. The market backed is awaiting developments from the conferences between the cotton trade and the Commodity Credit Corporation to be held in Washington tomorrow and on Tuesday.

Sooner or later, it seems, everyone who has worked on Roy Howard's journal gets a yen to write it out at length, and "The World Ends at Hoboken" represents Mr. Heimer's purgation.

And, since producers have been known to have short memories, such a time lapse could be expected to have a disastrous effect on the popularity of a singing star such as Kitty Carlisle.

TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 14 -- The first official estimate of the wheat crop in the Prairie Provinces this year is 423,000,000 bushels, compared with 227,000,000 in 1943, S.M. Webb, general manager of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, said today.

Do the Dumbarton Oaks proposals offer reasonable assurance for the realization of the basic purpose -- the maintenance of "international peace and security"? Or are they so deficient in principle and detail that they offer no such assurance, and should, consequently, be radically modified?

THE movie studios last week experienced their first major labor trouble in several years. It was occasioned by a series of "no strike" walkouts, which, on the surface, appeared as perplexing as any of Hollywood's "whodunit" concoctions.

A new medical college, to be known as the Essex College of Medicine and Surgery, will open in Newark on Oct. 23. This is the first time in 200 years that a college of medicine has received a charter to operate in New Jersey. Several attempts to create a medical institution failed in the past.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Gov. John W. Bricker declared tonight that the Federal Courts had been transformed into "conclaves of New Deal ideologies" in an effort to remake the nation along lines similar to State Socialism.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 14 -- As a means of building peace and better understanding in the post-war era, the Federal Government should subsidize the education in American colleges and universities of a "substantial number" of foreign students, Dr. C. Mildred Thompson, dean of Vassar College, declared today at the Political Association's conference on "The Returning Service Man."

A LINE on the front of the jacket tells us that "even from the grave Mrs. Camelot directed the investigation of her own murder." That is no more true of this than of any detective story in which the past of the murdered person plays an important part.

LIKE its unlamented predecessor, the second World War has become a vast siege operation, from the Alps to the North Sea. Four American armies, one British and one Canadian army are converging on the pillbox-studded defenses of the Reich for a last struggle with the Wehrmacht, a struggle which by the standards of this campaign will be long, bloody and difficult.
I LIKE the beautiful, sophisticated girls when they walk with grace on Fifth Avenue.
THERE were six stripes on the sleeve of the tough old sergeant who walked up to the information desk.

HERE Miss Ross brings together the stories of some of the women who helped make our Pacific Northwest. This reader is just a little head-shy of history presented on a divisionist basis, an arbitrary division of the participants; but Miss Ross makes it easy to forget such prejudices by showing that the overland journey to Oregon in 1836 did require greater resourcefulness and daring from the woman of that day than of the man.

HAROLD LLOYD, star of the silent movies, will make his radio debut at 10:30 P.M. on Sunday, Oct. 29, over NBC and WEAF when he assumes the master of ceremonies role for the "Comedy Theatre of the Air." The new show will present half-hour adaptations of comedy plays and motion pictures, with the premiere to be "The Palm Beach Story." starring Claudette Colbert and Robert Young.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 14 -- Navy fought its way out of trouble on no fewer than three occasions today and, in doing so successfully, the midshipmen managed to turn back the Duke eleven by 7 to 0 before a crowd of 30,000 in the Baltimore Stadium.

" Thirty-one on Parade," a display showing the services performed by the thirty-one agencies participating in the New York War Fund campaign for $17,200,000, will open today at 3 P.M. at the International Building of Rockefeller Center, 630 Fifth Avenue.

Dr. Oscar Schotte (Amherst) told a General Electric Forum recently that he is a member of a group of men "who have always claimed that regeneration of limbs in mammals, and therefore in man, belongs to the realm of scientific possibilities."

American engineering colleges are planning to add courses in the humanities and liberal arts fields, thus providing a more rounded education to the engineer of the post-war period a survey of sixty leading institutions has disclosed. In fact, many colleges have already started "liberalizing" and have introduced such courses as economics, sociology, history, English or psychology.

Asserting that the "master strategy" of the campaign for the election of Governor Dewey is "to preserve a graveyard silence about the Republican record," Senator Robert F. Wagner last night attacked this record on both domestic and foreign policies in a speech from radio station WOR on a State-wide hook-up.

Whirlabout looked more than ever like a filly of the top class when she captured the $11,150 Correction Handicap at Jamaica yesterday before 31,053 persons who had made her a 13-to-10 favorite in a field of seven. The victory, worth $7,525, pushed the earnings of the Louis B. Mayer 3-year-old past the $100,000 mark, a rarity for a filly, even in these days of lush purses and easy money.

GREAT LAKES, Ill., Oct. 14 (AP) -- With first stringers playing only a few minutes in the third period, Great Lakes used thirty-nine players to rout Western Michigan before 25,000 sailors at Ross Field today, 38 to 0.

Connecticut University spoiled Brooklyn College's home football opening by upsetting the Kingsmen, 10 -- 0, in a hard-fought game before 6,000 yesterday. Sparked by Leo Pinsky, the visitors capitalized on their two scoring opportunities.

The inventory control order L-219 is no longer needed in the home furnishings field to insure equitable distribution of available merchandise, according to a memorandum filed with the War Production Board by the National Retail Furniture Association, it was learned here last week.

Despite gloomy prediction of a continued shortage of cotton textiles after V-E day because of the tremendous quantities needed in the Pacific war, civilian consumers will get a greater share in 1945 than they enjoyed in any of the five years preceding World War II, according to Worth Street textile men last week.

Mrs. Roosevelt, in the course of a warm tribute to Wendell Willkie two days ago, made one puzzling statement in her column. It had no bearing on her main theme but it did bring to mind an interesting piece of American group behavior.

DURING the spring of 1942 the United States Government did something it had never done before in all our history and which there remains some doubt of its constitutional right to do: it removed American citizens, not accused of crime, from their homes and held them under guard in "relocation centers" which were really concentration camps.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Central Westerners in record numbers are apparently determined to have their say on Nov. 7 in deciding whether President Roosevelt is to serve a fourth term.

ANTWERP, Belgium, Oct. 14 -- Within the walls of Breendonck, the Gestapo torture center, which Belgium is to preserve as a museum of Nazi methods, the Belgian Government with ironic justice has imprisoned some of the men -- and one of the women collaborators -- responsible for betraying their compatriots to the German sadists.

Last week the Navy swung the deadly scythe of its fleet-borne air power back and forth across Japan's inner defenses. One great sweep slashed close to Kyushu, southernmost of Japan's main islands, down through the whole chain of the Ryukyu Islands, guarding the East China Sea, and found its chief target in Formosa, Japanese Gibraltar in the vital waters of the Asiatic coast.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Not the least among the legacies of ruin that nazidom will have bequeathed to Europe is the monetary inflation created by the German occupation. The first European country to grapple with it is Belgium, which this week took drastic action to restore the value of its currency and in the process to squeeze out of existence that part of Belgian inflation which represented the profits of collaboration.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Japanese troops, reinforced until they outnumbered the defenders four to one, have captured Kweiping in southern Kwangsi Province, after killing the Chinese garrison there to the last man, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

An objection or two was filed against the comparisons given here recently to show that corporation income in four Roosevelt years exceeded that of the famous Coolidge prosperity era. It was emphasized upon this occasion that business interests should not fool themselves about such facts because decisions of vast importance cannot be made soundly on the basis of distorted thinking.

A UNITED STATES SUPERFORTRESS BASE, in West China, Oct. 14 -- B-29 Superfortresses in their first nine attacks set the amazing record of not losing a single plane shot down by enemy fighters, Maj. Gen. Curtis LeMay of the Twentieth Bomber Command said today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Salable hogs received here today numbered only 300, not enough to make a market. Prices were nominally steady with the quotable top at the ceiling, $14.75 a hundredweight. Compared with a week ago prices were fully steady. Today's report of other livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follow:

THIRTEEN works by contemporary composers will be heard in the annual symposium of American Orchestral Music of the Eastman School of Music to be presented by the Eastman-Rochester Symphony Orchestra, under Howard Hanson, Oct. 17-19, in Rochester, N.Y.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Communique 189:

PRIVATE DETECTIVE LES IVEY wakes up with a hangover and goes a-sleuthing. He has no important case on hand, but he soon finds one in the murder of a bookkeeper. There is not much prospect of a fat fee in it, but Les takes it on just to keep his hand in.

" YANKEES WERE LIKE THIS" is in the school of books on life-with-father; but instead of going in for exaggerated hilarity and underlined quaintness, it deliberately takes a tone of excessive moderation. Wellshaven, Mass., on Cape Cod was a self-respecting American community.

MOTORISTS who can get lost on a well-marked State highway may well sympathize with the civilian fliers skimming over the country. For many of those motorists may be piloting their own planes from cloud to cloud in the decade after the war.

ALL the questions man asks about his life are multiplied by the fact of death: for man differs from all other creatures, it would seem, in being aware of his own death and in never being fully reconciled to sharing the natural fate of all living organisms.

LONDON, Sunday, Oct. 15 -- Russian and Yugoslav troops yesterday stormed into Belgrade, and heavy hand-to-hand street battles are raging in the center of the city, Marshal Tito announced last night. The fall of the Yugoslav capital appeared imminent.

In a tribute to Wendell L. Willkie, Rabbi Samuel M. Segal said yesterday in a sermon in Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street, that "all America is united by the memory of a great American whose role as an uncompromising liberal gained for him the respect and love due to an honorable statesman and ideal champion."

BOSTON, Oct. 14 -- A typical Notre Dame team that ran, blocked and tackled with all its normal pre-war speed, fire and zest for body contact buried Dartmouth today under the largest score the Fighting Irish have hung up since their 73-0 rout of Haskell Institute, an Indian school in Kansas, in 1932.

A FRIENDLY little story which mirrors accurately a little boy's feelings when he begins going to school. David, 6, and Timothy, 5, are living in South Carolina while their father is away at war and "First Grade" describes the daily happenings at school and at home. There is Halloween with its jack o' lanterns, an outdoor Christmas tree and, in the spring, baseball, gardens and a new boy in the class.

WHEN the icy fingers of frost have gathered the last blazing dahlia blooms and the foliage hangs limp and black, then it is time to dig the clumps of roots for winter storage. This year special care is taken because no one can forecast what the commercial supply of dahlias and other summer flowering bulbs will be in the spring.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 14 (Reuter) -- For three hours on the night of the Hitler assassination plot on July 20 Vienna was in the hands of rebel German generals, according to a member of the Austrian underground who has Just escaped to Sweden.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- With British troops in Athens, the Red Army and Marshal Tito's Yugoslav Army of Liberation fighting in the streets of Belgrade and Hungary's plea for an armistice reported in Paris and Ankara, Germany's Balkan position had become desperate tonight.

Sparked by Gene Rossides, the Erasmus Hall High School eleven swept to an 18-to-0 triumph over James Madison in the feature game of a schoolboy double-header before 8,000 at Ebbets Field yesterday. Tilden conquered Brooklyn Tech, 13 -- 6.

A REPORT on the relationship of one civilian theatre to World War II, will, perhaps, be of interest to mainland readers, if only because of the location of that theatre. This is not to say that the Honolulu Community Theatre is a war baby, as productions were seen by civilians and service men for years before Pearl Harbor.

The bang-bang of hunters' guns, already heard where sportsmen were lucky enough to find birds with yesterday's opening of the duck season, will mount to a greater pitch tomorrow at 1 P.M. in most of this State, when the upland game season starts.

American officers billeted in Paris apartments have found copies of well-known American magazines lying on tables where the Germans left them. Writers in these magazines were discussing such subjects as the possibility of revolution in Germany and the probable date for the war's end -- 1942.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 14 -- The frost is on the pumpkin and the farmer is calling loudly for corn pickers. From now until the middle of December, possibly the first of January, every resource of manpower and machinery that can be marshaled will be pushed to the limit to harvest the Middle West's third successive bumper corn crop.

Criticizing President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull for handling relations with Argentina "through the newspapers," Dr. Samuel Guy Inman, authority on Pan-American affairs, demanded yesterday that the United States seek to settle its differences through more direct discussion and according to an announced policy.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Bucknell fought a stubborn but losing battle today, yielding to Penn State by a 20-6 score in the thirty-fourth renewal of their traditional gridiron series before 8,000 homecoming fans.
LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Almost from the beginning of the Allies' bombing attacks on strategic targets in Germany there has been a sort of pendulum swing about the strength and extent of these attacks.

EN ROUTE WITH SENATOR TRUMAN, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Senator Harry S. Truman, rolling westward for a major campaign speech in Los Angeles Monday night, said today he was confident that the American people would elect a National Administration Nov. 7 which would make "a peace lasting long enough so that our grandsons won't have to do it all over again."

The $180,000,000 of financing by the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago, which is scheduled to reach the investment market on Wednesday, will be a milestone in utility financing, since it is the largest single issue ever to be registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission by a corporation in the electric power and light industry.

The Navy's first report on its administration of the conquered Marshall Islands is a happy augury for the island peoples of the Pacific. Here is being set the pattern to be followed elsewhere. Amid the exigencies of war a measure of self-rule that has not been known for over a century is being established.

THIS book is, in a very real sense, more than a Life of Philip II. It is even more than a study of sixteenth-century Spain. It is, in fact, a stimulating re-creation of all of western Europe and of England in an age of chaos and flux, an age in many respects not unlike our own.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The increasingly obvious preparations to invade the Philippine, the mammoth air assault on Formosa and the bold naval-air blow against the Ryukyu Islands. part of Japan's inner defense zone, this week pointed the way to the next major steps of American strategy in the Far East.

PARIS, Oct. 14 (AP) -- With bitterly worded reference to the lack of political single-mindedness among the Allies, Gen. Charles de Gaulle told the French people tonight they would have to depend "not on the benevolence of others" but on their own efforts to raise France to her former greatness.

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- Jefferson Caffery, United States representative in Paris with the rank of Ambassador, made a ceremonial entry today into the embassy on the Place de la Concorde. An American military band played "The Star-Spangled Banner" and then the "Marseillaise,'' while a company of military police stood at attention at the gates of the embassy.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 14 -- Busher, chestnut daughter of War Admiral, strengthened her hold on the 2-year-old filly championship at Laurel Park today as she ran away from nine others of her class in the nineteenth Selima Stakes.

MOSCOW, Oct. 14 -- Premier Stalin and Prime Minister Churchill shook hands tonight before a standing, shouting and applauding crowd of more than 2,500 persons in Moscow's huge Bolshoi Theatre in which the best artists of the Soviet ballet and the music world, including the famed Red Army choir and its Cossack dancers, gave a "command" performance.

What is this thing called fashion? An average man asks that question and receives an answer that takes his breath away in the third edition of "Fashions of the Times," to be presented by THE NEW YORK TIMES at the New York Times Hall, Oct. 24, 25, 26 and 27.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The largest number of B-29 Superfortresses ever used in an attack struck successfully today at Okayama on the island of Formosa, probably Japan's most important air target south of Japan proper, the War Department announced here.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 14 (AP) -- A North Carolina passing and running attack in the final minute of play enabled the Tar Heels to defeat the Cherry Point Marines today, 20 to 14, in a game that was a thriller throughout.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 14 -- The American First Army inched its way forward in the smoking rubble of Aachen today as Allied artillery battered the city continuously and German civilians began to straggle out. [Press services said the Americans were driving into the city from three directions, northeast, east and southeast.]

Applications for temporary and special gasoline rations for commercial automobiles should be made, beginning tomorrow, to local war price and rationing boards instead of the Office of Defense Transportation, Daniel P. Woolley, regional Administrator of the Office of Price Administration, announced yesterday.

THE role played by French women in the Resistance movement has entitled them, by popular acclaim, to share in the problems of liberated France. A B-29 BASE IN WEST CHINA, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Flames rising an estimated 22,000 feet over the town of Okayama on Formosa Island today marked the most successful Superfortress mission to date as the giant B-29's followed a mighty Nivy blow to add new wreckage to that major Japanese base.

Prize medals for the best essays on "Safeguarding the Home Against Fire" were presented by Mayor La Guardia yesterday to 200 children from the city's public and parochial schools at exercises held at City Hall. The Mayor complimented the children for "useful service to the schools and the city."

THE Ballet Theatre begins its second week at the Metropolitan Opera House with two performances today. The week's outstanding novelty is the first New York performance of Tamara Toumanova in "Giselle" which is scheduled for tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service director, wrote to President Roosevelt today that his remark of last August about demobilization, to which Governor Dewey has referred critically, was his "personal opinion in a field over which I have no responsibility.''

SINCE August, 1942, some 3,000 industrial plants in the United States have been honored with the E award for making outstanding records in the production of the tools of war. Ten years ago Oct. 1, the Securities and Exchange Commission came into being, taking over the administration of the Securities Act of 1933 from the Federal Trade Commission and administering the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, which created it.

POCONOS, Pa. -- The flaming foliage is now nearing its greatest brilliancy and is expected to reach its peak about the 18th; a record number of guests and cottage colony members are visiting resorts of this region to enjoy nature's fall show. Many of the resorts are holding Flaming Foliage Time Balls, while talking pictures, lectures, bridge parties fill indoor entertainment programs.

Affirming a majority opinion of the United States Tax Court, discussed in this column on May 21, the Circuit Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has held in a two-to-one decision that interest on the Port of New York Authority bonds is exempt from income tax (Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Estate of A.J. Shamberg, deceased).

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- The American Red Cross has 3,600,000 garments ready for distribution in Europe, Basil O'Connor, head of the Red Cross, said here today. One million of them are already in South France, the same number are awaiting shipment from Britain and the remainder are in warehouses in the United States pending assignment of shipping space.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- Under an alternating cover of scattered rain clouds and sunbursts, the seventh race of the post-season series was held today off the Larchmont Yacht Club and Corny Shields brought home his International sloop Aileen the winner, finishing 46 seconds ahead of W. H. Stanley's Bumble Bee.

THE Musical Digest, now in its twenty-fifth consecutive year of publication, announces important changes of policy. Its editor, Pierre V.R. Key, describes these changes as being in principle comparable to the procedure of the Reader's Digest in a more widely diversified field.

ROME, Oct. 14 (AP) -- British and American Armies shoved the stubborn Germans back along virtually the entire front in Italy today, and Canadian infantry and tanks struck brilliantly across the southern edge of the Po plain to within four miles of strategic Cesena.
