Two Brooklyn players, both undefeated, and with clean scores to their credit, qualified last night in Group C of the annual tournament for the amateur championship of the United States Chess Federation at Federation headquarters in Brooklyn.

Robert W. Fraser, former commodore and now race chairman of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, has been nominated for president of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound. He has been an active skipper for years with his Victory class sloop Black Jack.

Spring openings are being awaited by buyers, according to reports prepared exclusively for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Initial orders are expected to be larger than was anticipated a few months ago, when it appeared as if the war in Europe would end this year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- The new Government support program in wheat announced recently has not had the full effect expected by the trade, and although cash wheat is holding close to the Office of Price Administration ceiling level there has been some pressure on futures and the latter have lost a good part of the recent upturn.

In his letter to THE TIMES of Oct. 5 Nicholas G. Lely, commenting on the statement by the Bulgarian Premier, Kimon Georgieff, as reported by THE TIMES of the same date, expresses doubt concerning the sincerity of that statement and its author.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Signs of some revival of interest in stock markets have not been lacking in the last week. The turnover remains small, but recorded bargains show a moderate expansion. Appeals to Governor Dewey to call a special session of the State Legislature to extend voting hours on Election Day were made yesterday by the American Labor party State organization and the New York County Democratic organization, each acting independently of the other.

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle's radio speech to the nation last night, which caused varied reaction in the press here today, is regarded in Paris as the most important speech of his life, excepting only his appeal on June 18, 1940, urging the French to refuse to accept Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain's armistice.

Sidney Hillman, chairman of the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, declared last night that under President Roosevelt the American Negro "has made greater strides than in any other period in American history." He spoke at a meeting of the St. James forum, a religious group, at the St. James Presbyterian Church, St. Nicholas Avenue and 141st Street.
Notre Dame and Army go marching on at the head of the college football parade with their most smashing victories since 1932 and 1929, respectively.

MEGARA, Greece, Oct. 12 (Delayed) -- According to reports from Athens today, street fighting among the inhabitants, which has accompanied the Germans' withdrawal during the last four or five days, has grown more bitter, particularly in the area about Theseion.

DETROIT, Oct. 15 (AP)b -- The Cleveland Rams, fighting an uphill battle after failing behind, 17 to 0, in the first eighteen minutes of play, came back to beat the Detroit Lions, 20 to 17, today for their third straight National Football League triumph. A shivering crowd of 21,115 fans watched the Rams rally to score a touchdown in each of the last three periods.

Challenging the school of thought that holds many instinctive fears of modern man are remnants of his primitive existence in the evolutionary process, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer said in his sermon yesterday at the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, that most human fears, particularly those that seemed "un-nameable," were due to his having forgotted orignored his responsibilities to God.

New York City headquarters of the Selective Service System, commanded by Col. Arthur V. McDermott, marks today the fourth anniversary of the first registration of this war, on Oct. 16, 1940. In a statement reviewing events since 1940, Colonel McDermott revealed that 763,000 New Yorkers are with the armed forces.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 15 -- Margaret E. Connors, Democratic candidate for Congress in Fairfield County's Fourth District, charged last night that her Republican opponent, Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, lied herself when she said last Friday in a speech at Chicago that President Roosevelt "lied" the country into war.

Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, paid tribute yesterday afternoon to the city's firemen at the annual memorial services for members of the Fire Department at the Firemen's Monument, 100th Street and Riverside Drive.

The doctrine of goodness is the prime need today for salvation, the Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church, declared yesterday at the Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.

American service men and women all over the world are certain to have their Christmas stockings filled to overflowing on Dec. 25 if the mountains of parcels piled high yesterday in the Army and Navy postoffices in this city are any criterion.

A notable benefit and several museum exhibitions and one-man shows are on the art calendar this week. The Wildenstein Gallery will open a comprehensive Delacroix (loan) exhibition on Wednesday evening with a private preview, at which an admission of $5 will be charged.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 15 -Long Island Sound's prolonged yacht-racing season closed today at the Larchmont Club with two contests. The morning race was taken by Corny Shields' International Aileen and the afternoon one by Albert Marx's Alberta.

The moods of dejection and of fear that come upon many persons can best be dispelled by faith in God, the Rev. L. Wendell Fifield said yesterday at the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, Brooklyn, where he is pastor.

Your editorial of Oct. 8 "Traffic Accidents Again" very properly deplores the loss of 19,000,000 man-days because of automobile accidents. But the remedy you suggest -- that everybody think before acting and apply the rules of American sportsmanship to our behavior on highways -- leaves this problem right where it is.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 15 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey, Republican Presidential nominee, will come into this State tomorrow to face such an even contest with President Roosevelt for the fifteen electoral votes that they may go one way or the other on the reaction to his speech in the evening.
THE NEW YORK TIMES, which opposed Mr. Roosevelt in 1940, supports him in 1944.

BOSTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The Washington Redskins returned to their National Professional Football League birthplace to scalp the Boston Yanks, 21 -- 14, today at Fenway Park. A 42-yard pass from Pitching Frank Filchock to Winger Ted Lapka gave the victors their winning touchdown in the final period.

SOUTHEAST ASIA HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Oct. 15 (U.P.) -- British Fourteenth Army tanks, ferried across the swollen Manipur River eight miles north of Tiddim, have moved up hairpin turns to the top of the 5,600-foot "Chocolate Staircase," where they are poised for a final assault on Tiddim's Japanese garrison, already besieged by advanced Indian units, it was revealed today.

New York luxury goods merchants yesterday took all space available for private merchandise on the first air freighter of American Airlines to depart from La Guardia Field. The company's freight tariff is the first in the industry, with rates as low as 30 cents a ton-mile as against air express rates of better than 80 cents.

Today I heard a few times over the radio that more than 25,000 young people thronged sidewalks, streets and the entrance to the Paramount Theatre in order to catch a glimpse of Frank Sinatra. Some of them even grew hysterical and fainted.

Ballet Theatre restored four ballets to the repertoire in its week-end programs at the Metropolitan Opera House. "Peter and the Wolf," "Pas de Quatre," and "Barn Dance" received their first presentations this season on Saturday afternoon, and "Princess Aurora" on Saturday evening.

BOSTON, Oct. 15 -- Coordinated efforts by the United States Government and private philanthropic agencies were credited here tonight by John W. Pehle, executive director of the War Refugee Board, with having saved hundreds of thousands of persons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- A demand that American foreign policy be shifted away from the "imperial designs of Mr. Churchill" and "the Soviet drive for power of Mr. Stalin" is made by Senator Robert M. LaFollette of Wisconsin in an editorial in the current issue of the magazine Progressive.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 15 -- President Roosevelt today pledged his aid in initiating "appropriate ways and means of effectuating establishment of Palestine as a free and democratic Jewish commonwealth."

Old Hank Soar, who shuttles back and forth from a Pennsylvania Army camp to come to the aid of his sorely pressed old boss Steve Owen, on Sunday afternoons proved himself a trapper of the Dan'l Boone tradition yesterday when he caught himself a nice big fat Tiger right in Ebbets Field.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Communique 190:

Mayor La Guardia made his regular Sunday "Talk to the People" yesterday over WNYC, the municipal radio station, although he was in Chicago, fulfilling an engagement to make a campaign talk for President Roosevelt at a Democratic rally sponsored by Mayor Edward J. Kelly.

Ethel Elfenbein, young New York pianist who made her debut in Town Hall in 1940, was heard there again last night. Her program ranged from Bach and Scarlatti through Schumann and Chopin to Debussy, Anis Fuleihan, Alexander Lipsky, Dohnanyi and de Falla.

PANAMA, Oct. 15 -- The Government of Guatemala warned students today that it would take energetic measures to maintain order and told them they were being misled by a group of Fascists. The Government said that repeated complaints from parents and other reports indicated that unscrupulous and politically militant persons had penetrated schools and had been carrying the children along on paths entirely foreign to an educational function.
The problems connected with the return to civilian life of war veterans were the subject of sermons in several churches yesterday.

The question of what will be worn next spring -- and this winter at resorts -- will be answered in part in the third edition of "Fashions of the Times," to be presented by THE NEW YORK TIMES in Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, Oct. 24, 25, 26 and 27.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- Production of lard continues extremely light land the bulk of the free supply of that commodity has been sold for shipment, resulting in business being confined largely to sales of less than 5,000 pounds. Packers and other large handlers of lard say they are having trouble in convincing buyers that there is no large surplus despite liberal stocks in cold storage.

How the money New Yorkers are contributing to the National War Fund is aiding the 60,000,000 persons affected by war is graphically shown in "Thirty-one on Parade," an exhibit which opened yesterday in the mezzanine of the International Building of Rockefeller Center, 630 Fifth Avenue, sponsored by the fund's Women's Division.

Thomas Jefferson's prediction that it would take American civilization 500 years to reach the Pacific Coast was recalled yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, to counteract the "disheartened hours," which he said all thinking persons must have as they considered the obstacles in the way of lasting world peace.

The editorial "Our Hearts So Stout" that appeared in your paper in August tells of "Garryowen's" history and that it was played in the Marianas, but fails to tell who introduced it to this side of the world.

America's backlog of scientific knowledge is being burned up by the war, according to the National Association of Manufacturers, which is not stimulating research and invention, as is generally believed. In the current issue of Industry View, an article on "Inventions and Post-War Planning" states that not since the first decade of the century has the number of applications for patents and the total of patents granted fallen to the low point of today.

New York City registration for the general election, which closed Saturday night, totaled 3,216,613. This was 173,847 less than the record city registration of 3,390,460 for the last Presidential election in 1940.
ROME, Oct. 15 -- Today's newspapers tell how 100 Italians were slaughtered in reprisal for the killing of two German soldiers by Partisans in Meleto, Tuscany.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The natural increase in the population of the United States was 1,475,173 during 1943, the figure representing the excess of births over deaths, the Department of Commerce reports. It was the largest absolute recorded natural increase in the population since 1933, the first year for which data were collected from all the Sates, and brings the population of the country to a new record of well over 137,000,000.

Completely rested after a week in which there were no Broadway premieres, first-nighters will be called from refreshment to labor this evening. At the request of producer H. Clay Blaney, they will meet at the Forrest to examine a grisly mystery comedy. "Meet a Body --."
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The eleven-story apartment building at 190 Riverside Drive, at the northeast corner of Ninety-first Street, has been sold by the Union Dime Savings Bank to an investing client of Joseph H. Nassoit, Inc., and Nat Freedman.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Formal termination on Oct. 1 of the Combined Agency for Middle East Supplies, which was established by and operated under the jurisdiction of American and British authorities in Washington, was announced today in a joint statement from the State Department, Foreign Economic Administration and the British Supply Council.

For the second consecutive week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained unchanged at 113.45. Although a relatively large number of individual price changes occurred in the commodity market, the foodstuffs index was the only subgroup index which changed.

Your readers may be interested in knowing about the part the natives of the South Pacific islands have played in helping our American troops there. This is an excerpt from a letter I recently received from Pfc. Knox Mellon, a young American soldier, not yet 19, who has been fighting there for many months:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Relaxation of the rigid controls on lumber were announced today by the War Production Board, following reports that small mills might be forced into shutdowns by the regulations.

The recital of Roland Hayes last night in Carnegie Hall was in factual respects an old story -- a program upon classic and traditional lines, with a group by moderns and a group of Negro folksongs -- and one of the most intelligent and appreciative audiences that New York gathers at a song recital to profit by the entertainment.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Senator James E. Murray, Democrat, of Montana, chairman of the Special Senate Committee to Study Small Business Problems, declared today "now that the war is approaching a conclusion, a supreme struggle is on foot between big and little business."

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 15 (U.P.) -- A powerful Japanese drive on Kweilin from the northeast was turned back less than seventeen miles from the city, while Chinese troops in southeastern Kwangsi Province, supported by two days of attacks by the United States Fourteenth Air Force, blunted an enemy spearhead advancing north of fallen Pingnam on the West River, Chinese and American communiques reported today.

ABOARD THE DEWEY SPECIAL, Oct. 15 -- Governor Dewey replied today to the White House statement of yesterday and declared "Mr. Roosevelt confesses that every single statement I made in my Oklahoma City speech was exactly correct down to the last period."

PARIS, Oct. 15 (U.P.) -- Ballots for the election are being dropped by parachute to American airborne troops isolated in Holland, and along the entire western front the United States Army is making a strenuous effort to facilitate voting.

THE ticket sale for the Army-Notre Dame game should perk up today after the smashing triumph each of them registered on Saturday. They haven't sold a ducat at West Point since early in September and nothing has moved at South Bend since August. It's a mighty strange situation and -- what's that? Oh, the game's a sell-out.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Oct. 15 -- Three teams finished all square with identical scores of 34 -- 35 -- 69, in the annual pro-member tournament of the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today. They were Willie Goggin, Century, and Jack Mast; Henry Ciuci, Fresh Meadow, and Edward Ziegler and Clarence Doser, Scarsdale, and Robert Dixon.

Case histories of seventy-seven newspaper advertising campaigns in the past year have been compiled by the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, in its sixth annual "Blue Book." The reports selected for publication were taken from more than 250 entries by agencies and advertisers and include the following classifications: Industrial, food, transportation, financial, drug, insurance, housing equipment and supplies, public utilities and electrical appliances.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- Mayor La Guardia of New York, speaking today before the first major rally here in the 1944 campaign, made a stirring appeal for the re-election of President Roosevelt, whom he pictured as the leader to "win a war for justice in the world, a lasting peace and security in our country."

With butter supplies in New York reported by the War Food Administration to be the "shortest of the year," Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his weekly broadcast that he might find it necessary to call on hotel and restaurant operators to resume butterless luncheons.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Hopes confidently entertained that the Bank of England circulation would undergo some contraction when the Allies invaded Europe seem doomed to disappointment. It was reckoned that when the Anglo-American forces surged across the Channel their going would result in a considerable lowering of the demand for currency, even making allowance for the fact that the place of those going overseas might be taken to a considerable extent by new arrivals.

SIXTH ARMY GROUP HEADQUARTERS, in France, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Showing more power than at any time within recent weeks, both the United States Seventh Army and the French First Army won new ground over every section of the Sixth Army group front today with the exception of the Belfort sector.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- Interest in the grain markets fell off sharply last week, sales on the Board of Trade aggregating 96,672,000 bushels, or a daily average of 19,400,000, against averages of about 26,000,000 in the previous week and 11,000,000 a year ago.

The United States Government is curbing the rights of its wartime Allies to acquire unlimited quantities of food under lend-lease, it was learned yesterday. As a step toward shifting international shipments to a cash-and-carry basis, the Foreign Economic Administration is auditing lend-lease food demands.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15 (AP) -Senator Harry S. Truman, Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, told a press conference here today that he had heard nothing to make him feel "the least bit discouraged about Democratic prospects for victory."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Two hunter championships were awarded at the conclusion of the two-day Secor Farms fall horse show today after Mrs. Don Moore of New Rochelle had won her first jumper championship with her big aged chestnut gelding Thunder Boy.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 15 -- Even though the steel ingot rate advanced last week, the order volume declined, according to trade reports. The decline with some companies was severe and represented tonnages that have not been marked up more than a year.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NEW GUINEA, Monday, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur sent at least 150 planes -- and possibly far more than that -- at Japanese air and naval bastions south of the Philippines, while Navy air power was striking Formosa Friday, headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Full publicity on any post-war international supervision of cartels "would go far to correct some of the abuses with which the private industrial agreement now is charged," the Foreign Policy Association said today.
ROME, Oct. 15 (AP) -- A communique:

Hayes Industries, Inc., Michigan manufacturer of aircraft wheels and brakes and automotive parts, reports in its annual statement for release today, net profit for the fiscal year ended July 31 amounted to $817,323, equal to $2.45 a share, on 333,000 shares of common stock.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 15 -- The Japanese Imperial Fleet is reported steaming out of its anchorages to meet Admiral William F. Halsey's Third Fleet operating along the enemy's principal communication line below Japan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -The final responsibility for seeing to it that total investment -- private, municipal, State and Federal -- is sufficient to support full employment rests with the Federal Government, Chester Bowles, head of the Office of Price Administration, said today.

Juvenile delinquency, expected to increase in the post-war period, can be curbed only through intelligent community cooperation, John J. O'Connell. Chief Inspector of the New York City Police Department, and H.H. Clegg, assistant director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, declared yesterday before a joint session of the National Conference of Juvenile Agencies and the Committee on Crime Prevention of the American Prison Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Last week's financial markets were steady; especially bonds, which pressed forward every day to a new top-level price, by THE TIMES' averages, in more than thirty years. Transactions in the stocks were somewhat smaller; there was no million-share day, and trading only once passed 700,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The tentative four-power agreement of Dumbarton Oaks provides in Chapter IX for an Economic and Social Council which would form the "keystone" or "capstone" of the most all-inclusive international economic and social organization ever projected by the world's great powers, according to officials who took part in engineering the plan.

IN A B-25, Near Megara, Greece, Oct. 14 (Delayed) -- The sky over mine-pitted but gravel-plugged airfield near Athens bloomed with vivid-hued parachutes shortly before noon today as American transport planes under fighter escort dropped hundreds of British paratroopers on the Greek mainland.

Present community facilities to care for the city's veterans were described as "sadly lacking" yesterday by Stephen Sheriden, New York City area director of the War Manpower Commission. He spoke at a symposium on "Our Jewish Community and Its Post-War Problems" at the tenth anniversary celebration of the Council of Fraternal and Benevolent Organizations of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, at the Hotel Astor.

Glenn Davis, listed only as a substitute in Army's great array of backs, tops all the scorers of the eastern section, including colleges and service teams, after the first month of play, The Associated Press reports.

LONDON, July 1 (Released by censor Oct. 15) -- The romance of an engineering dream of grandiose proportions that partly failed of fulfillment but nevertheless was a venture unique in military history took shape and form off the French coast after D-day but has been kept a military secret since.

Lieut. (j.g.) Philip Herman Willkie, 24-year-old son of the late Republican leader, arrived home from convoy duty in the Atlantic early yesterday morning and made plans to leave tonight with his mother for Rushville, Ind., where his father will be buried tomorrow.
LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel, foremost Nazi soldier, who almost won Egypt for Adolf Hitler, has died, the German radio announced tonight.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- A 1945 budget of $1,520,340 for service to the armed forces, the returned veteran and youth at home, was voted today by the National Finance Council, budgeting and allocating body of the National Jewish Welfare Board.

World War II has again focused attention on one of the country's oldest problems -- what to do with the Indians --Mrs. O.A. Rosborough, chairman of the Indian Welfare Committee of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, said yesterday during the second day's session of the three-day meeting of the board of directors held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The opening performance of the Ice Follies of 1945 on the night of Nov. 21 at Madison Square Garden will be a benefit for the Musicians Emergency Fund, which for several years has sponsored the premiere performances of the skating show to raise funds for its philanthropic activities.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The champion Chicago Bears scored their first National Football League victory today, flashing some of their old-time form to crush the Chicago Pittsburgh team, 34 -- 7. Effectively mixing passes and a strong running game, the Bears scored in every period except the third.

Cotton prices in the domestic market fluctuated irregularly last week in a relatively narrow trading range. At the close of the market on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net changes ranging from an advance of 4 points to a decline of 7 points.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 15 -- All records for concentration and weight of bombs on a single target were broken when, in the concerted aerial campaign to destroy Germany's means of resisting the Allies' coming victory of-

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- The British Board of Trade index of commodity prices, based on 1930 as 100, stood at 167.1 for September, compared with 167.5 in August, and 162.9 in September 1933. The percentage decline for the month was 0.3, this being the first month since October, 1943, and the sixth month since the outbreak of the war for which a decline has been recorded.
Eight new films, including importations from France, Russia and Mexico, are scheduled to arrive this week. The programs follow:

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- Pierre ("Black Peter") Laval's financial operations are being investigated as a preliminary to legal process for the confiscation of his possessions. The inquiry, of course, is being conducted in absentia, since at present he is "somewhere in Germany." This investigation is distinct from an eventual charge of treason to be heard by a military court.

A nation-wide banker-dealer group headed by Harris Trust and Savings Bank, Chicago, and including the Chase National Bank, Bankers Trust Company, the National City Bank of New York, Northern Trust Company, Chicago, and the First National Bank of Chicago, will publicly offer today a new issue of $12,000,000 City of Portland (Ore.) 3 per cent, 1 1/2 per cent, 1 1/4 per cent and 1 per cent sewage-disposal bonds.

To make full utilization of changes in regional population and buying power, companies will have to set up new regional sales quotas and obtain new distributive outlets, according to a study of the war-caused shifts in the nation's industrial pattern made public today by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Mr. and Mrs. Howard L. Zacks won the husband-and-wife title in the metropolitan contract bridge championships which began yesterday at the Park Central Hotel. Second among the eighteen married couples were Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Jaeger.

A $10,000,000 program for the purchase of American agricultural and industrial machinery for shipment to Palestine as part of a postwar development plan was announced yesterday at the concluding session of the metropolitan conference of the Jewish National Workers Alliance at the Hotel Commodore.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 15 -- A debate as to whether women should be permitted to work in industry after the war if jobs become scarce took place at the final session today of the Vassar College Political Association conference on "The Returning Service Man."

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, Military Vicar of the Armed Forces of the United States, arrived at La Guardia Field at 2:40 o'clock this morning after a five-week tour of the western front and an extended stay at Rome.

It is not the decisions of leaders "made glittering and dramatic by much publicity" that shape the destiny of the world, but it is rather the spirit in which all the people carry out their individual responsibilities that determines the course of history, the Rev. Dr. Theodore Speers told his congregation yesterday at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- The Soviet press has made a sharp attack upon Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, Republican Presidential candidate, for his Pulaski Day speech, which Pravda's "reviewer" of foreign affairs said supported "the pretensions of Polish imperialists."
LONDON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 15 -- Only a few hours before the funeral of former President Ramon S. Castillo yesterday, a book was put on sale -- "La Politica Argentina y el Futuro de America" (Argentine Policy and the Future of America) -- by his Foreign Minister, Dr. Enrique Ruiz Guinazu.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 15 -Darryl F. Zanuck has announced that Peggy Ann Garner, the twelve-year-old actress who recently completed the role of Francie in Twentieth Century-Fox's "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn," has been chosen for the starring role in "Junior Miss."

LONDON, Monday, Oct. 16 (AP) -- More than 6,500 Allied planes, including 4,000 heavy bombers, gave Germany a violent hammering yesterday that left her main supply bases back of the Siegfried Line battered and smoking. Six-ton earthquake bombs dropped by RAF Lancasters scored direct hits on the already dry Sorpe Dam, twenty miles southeast of Dortmund in the Ruhr.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Holy Cross defeated a badly outplayed Villanova eleven today, 26 -- 0, scoring in every period except the opening quarter. Leo Troy scored two touchdowns for the Crusaders, with Ted Morasky and Joe Nester registering one apiece.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- Killing frost occurred last week in the more northern sections of the Corn Belt, but a large part of the crop matured ahead of the frost, except possibly in Iowa, where 25 per cent of the 600,000,000-bushel crop is expected to be chaffy and light in test weight.

The six-month quarantine now imposed on all unleashed dogs found on the streets of the Bronx soon may be extended to Manhattan or even to the entire city, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins indicated yesterday. The Board of Health will meet today or tomorrow to consider such an extension.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Publicly reported cash dividends in the United States amounted to $372,300,000 in September, an increase of 7 per cent over the $347,700,000 reported in September, 1943, the Department of Commerce reported today.
LONDON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

At long last the war in the Pacific moved to the very doorstep of Japan last week, as American carrier task forces struck at the Ryukyu (Nansei) Islands, and at Formosa and the Pescadores, enemy strongholds that bar off the coast of China and the East China Sea from the Pacific.

ANTWERP, Belgium, Oct. 15 -The two Canadian forces fighting to clear the east side of the Breskens pocket, where an amphibious landing was made six days ago, closed the pincers today and now are preparing for the main thrust toward the enemy's heavy gun positions guarding the Schelde Estuary.
LONDON, Oct. 15 (UP) -- A German communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
LONDON, Oct. 15 -- The western front flared with action Sunday from its northern end in the Low Countries to the southern sector in the Vosges Mountains.

A hard-headed educational campaign to teach America's true place in the world, what kind of a world it is and how we can best exist under such circumstances is the most promising avenue to the cure of war by means of education, says Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College, Columbia University, in his annual report made public yesterday.

WITH AN' AMERICAN INFANTRY COMPANY in Aachen, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The Germans are fighting here in Aachen with fantastically hopeless savagery, and this infantry company is moving forward literally only ten feet at a time in an attack that in more than two hours has gained only two blocks through one ravaged street.

The Bowery Savings Bank has sold through the Eugene J. Busher Company twelve buildings in the Bronx, including seven apartment houses and five three-family and four-family houses with an aggregate assessed valuation of $254, 000. The buyer was Samuel Hurwitz.

ROME, Oct. 15 -- About the most encouraging thing that can be said of the Italian campaign these days is that the Fifth Army has kept attacking and has been making repeated small gains. The distance to Bologna remains about eleven miles and there are other factors that suggest it will not be appreciably lessened overnight.

The Thurman H. Bane Award for the most important technical achievement by an officer or civilian of the Air Technical Service Command will be given for 1944 to Col. Donald J. Keirn of Wright Field for his part in the development and production in quantity of the turbo-jet engine now driving an undisclosed number of American and British fighter planes.

MOSCOW, Oct. 15 -- At a crucial moment in the Stalin-Churchill negotiations, the Polish Committee of National Liberation admitted today a significant failure in carrying out its agrarian land reform program in that part of Poland that already has been liberated.

Curtiss-Wright Corporation announced Charles W. France, vice president and general manager at Buffalo, returns to St. Louis as general manager; N.F. Vanderlipp, factory manager at Columbus, becomes general manager at Buffalo; Burton H. Witherspoon, general manager at St. Louis, director of business research at Buffalo, and Ralph R. Fuhrer, general superintendent of planning and tooling at Columbus.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- War-time paintings of planes in combat and the picturization of world-wide air activities by artists who are members of the Army Air Forces were placed on exhibition today at the National Gallery of Art.

American criticism of alleged "imperfections" in China's Government and lack of unity in her forces was declared "harmful to the cause for which we are fighting" by Bishop William T. Manning during services yesterday in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine honoring the thirty-third anniversary of the Chinese Republic.

When the history of the first half of the twentieth century is revised a hundred years hence more space may be given to the flowering of the adult education movement than to many other current developments.

A Japanese Imperial headquarters communique declared yesterday that the task force that had ibeen attacking Formosa was "fleeing eastward, with our units in full pursuit and subjecting it to heavy fire."
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 15 -Snow fell in some parts of New York State last night and today, and the Weather Bureau forecast below-freezing temperatures across the State before morning.

AACHEN, Germany, Oct. 15 (AP) -- American troops and guns smashed the greatest German attack of the battle of Aachen today, turning back strong forces of infantry and armor that for a time overran American positions in touch-and-go conflict.

LONDON, Monday, Oct. 16 -- After launching a record Arctic front offensive within six miles of the Norwegian frontier, powerful Russian amphibious forces have captured the key German-occupied Finnish port and naval base of Petsamo and have surged more than twenty miles southward along the main Polar Circle highway to split the German armies in Northern Finland, Moscow announced today.

MOSCOW, Oct. 16 -- Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden of Britain conferred at length today with Prime Minister Stanislaw Mikolajczyk and Foreign Minister Tadeugz Romer of the Polish Government in exile in an effort to round into final form a compromise settlement of the Polish political differences -- a resolution that is highly important to the United Nations.

Because the Navy foresees a reduction in its demand for air transportation to the European theatre of the war, agreements with Pan American Airways and American Export Airlines are being canceled effective on Dec. 31, it was announced yesterday here and in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Earl of Halifax, British Ambassador, and Archibald MacLeish, Librarian of Congress, opened the capital's Community War Fund drive tonight with addresses drawing a parallel between the unification of relief campaigns in the war fund, and the joint war effort of the Allies.
The War Food Administration has set aside 5,000,000 pounds of creamery butter for release to hospitals beginning today. Distribution will continue at frequent intervals through Feb. 15.

SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Gov. John W. Bricker, protesting what he called usurpation of State and local authority by the Federal Government, declared tonight that it was a trend which could lead to "political domination" of local governments.

The appointment of Russell M. Ergood Jr. as manager of the Philadelphia municipal bond department of Stroud Co., Inc., was announced yesterday. He is the Philadelphia representative on the municipal bond committee of the National Securities Traders Association, a member of the Investment Traders Association of Philadelphia and Municipal Bond Club of Philadelphia, of which he is a former secretary.

Pacific Mills earned in the first nine months of this year a net profit of $1,137,700 after all charges including provision of $8,315,000 for Federal taxes and S1,125,000 reserve for contingencies, the report disclosed yesterday.

Concerned about a post-V-E day inflationary threat in the form of competition among manufacturers and wholesalers in the building up of inventories as "hedges," the Office of Price Administration probably will seek the continuation of War Production Board inventory controls after victory in Europe, Chester Bowles, OPA Administrator, indicated yesterday.

Twenty-two corporations and eight of their officials, said to control 95 per cent of the ice distributed in the metropolitan area, were made defendants yesterday in a two-count Federal indictment alleging violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

Moderate pressure during the final hour yesterday produced an irregularly lower closing on the stock market. Business was the smallest in more than three weeks and the list drifted about in narrow circles until selling materialized in the closing period.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16 -- Senator Harry S. Truman, formally opening his West Coast campaign for President Roosevelt, asked an overflow crowd in the Shrine Auditorium here tonight to help elect a Congress to uphold the President's foreign policies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- This is the first Presidential campaign of modern times conducted while the nation is at war. But the reappearance of the most familiar type of political controversy, as the candidates bid for the national voting majority, demonstrates that circumstances do not alter cases -- even though the circumstances are without precedent.
ROME, Oct. 16 (AP) -- A communique:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Tuesday, Oct. 17 (AP) -- A communique:

Anton Dolin's version of "Giselle," always one of the brighter stars in Ballet Theatre's crown, shone again last night at the Metropolitan Opera House with considerable luster. In the title role was Tamara Toumanova for the first time hereabouts, with Mr. Dolin in his familiar place as Albrecht and Rosella Hightower as the Queen of the Wills.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- French officials today are watching with interest Belgium's application of drastic deflation by freezing bank accounts and exchanging existing currency against new notes printed abroad and brought into Belgium.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Bartley C. Crum, San Francisco attorney and once leader of Wendell Willkie's California committee, today announced the formation of a Republicans for Roosevelt Committee to support re-election of the President.

The Rev. Herbert Nelson Baird of the First Presbyterian Church at Whitesboro, N.Y., last night was elected Moderator of the Synod of New York of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America. His election took place at a dinner, which opened the sixty-second annual meeting of the Synod, at the First Presbyterian Church, 124 Henry Street, Brooklyn.
LONDON, Oct. 16 -- The stock markets here opened the week on a cheerful note and a fair amount of business was transacted as a result of an accumulation of week-end orders.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- A reconversion wage policy taking into account the inequities that will arise when incentive bonuses and overtime advantages are lost on V-E Day will be part of a report to be submitted by the public members to the National War Labor Board to their labor and industry associates.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 16 -- The American encirclement of Aachen was completed today.

Every member of the General Federation of Women's Clubs -- comprising 16,500 clubs with a national membership of 2,500,000 women -- will be called on to help the national program for post-war conservation of youth adopted unanimously as the chief project of the federation for the next five or ten years, Mrs. LaFell Dickinson, president, announced yesterday at a press conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ROME, Oct. 16 (U.P.) -- A United Press war correspondent who accompanied the Americans into Livergnano, reported that the five-day battle for the village, which straddles the important north-south highway leading into the valley, was more fierce than that at Cassino, and said casualties on both sides were heavy.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command announced today that heavy fighting was continuing twelve miles west of the Hunan-Kwangsi railway town of Hingan and twenty-five miles north of Kweilin, one of the main objectives of the current Japanese offensive in southeast China.

Details of a proposed advertising-free radio service, to be offered to subscribers at an estimated rate of 5 cents a day, were disclosed here yesterday by William Benton, vice president of the University of Chicago, who is in charge of the project.

What Gilbert Seldes described in his "program note" as "a little merry noise, and high spirits and liveliness" were provided last night at Carnegie Hall when Eddie Conlon and about thirty others gave a jazz concert there.

A syndicate headed by William Kaufman has purchased the four-story store and office building at 425 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of Thirty-eighth Street, from the estate of Robert E. Simon. The property, assessed at $1,045,000, fronts sixty-one feet on the avenue land 125 feet on the side street, and contains 8,500 square feet of floor space.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The War Department, reporting that it now is returning to this country about 30,000 men monthly, says it cannot increase the number substantially and continue to press the war "vigorously to an early conclusion."

AT AN AMERICAN INFANTRY COMMAND POST near Verlautenheide, Germany, Oct. 16 -- Three fierce German counter-attacks against American positions on Crucifix Hill, or "Dawson's Ridge," the mile-long tongue of land that is the key to the battle for Aachen, were smashed today by muddy and weary doughboys as the German counter-offensive continued.

ROME, Oct. 16 -- The Fifth Army drove closer to Bologna yesterday, capturing Livergnano on Highway 65, less than ten miles from that city. Livergnano guarded the approaches to the long escarpment to the east and its fall raised hope that, with the present improved weather continuing, Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's forces may soon master that obstacle.

LONG before the Good Neighbor policy stimulated American interest in all things Latin-American, Mexico had become fashionable in the United States. Tourists and romantic writers were enchanted by the beauty and the charm of a nation that was so near us in space and so far from us in culture and habits of mind and living.

Despite the runaway of the Cardinals, the National League in 1944 arrested a two-year downward trend in attendance and popped up with a 5 per cent increase over last season with an estimated 4,178,744 paying fans, unofficial figures compiled yesterday, show.

Ed McKeever, the Texan who fell heir to the Notre Dame coaching job when Frank Leahy went "down to the sea in a ship" and whose Fighting Irish are now rated at the top in the nation, according to the polls, was guest of honor yesterday at the weekly luncheon of the Football Writers at Toots Shor's.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- While last year the toy market was shady with only about 10 per cent of the Christmas toys properly priced according to OPA ceilings, this year at least 85 per cent of the toys will be properly priced, according to R.H. Greenwell, business specialist of OPA.

Because of infractions of rules set down by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for the 50,000 persons living in its Parkchester development in the Bronx 400 tenants were notified last July that their leases would not be renewed. Many tenants settled their differences, some moved, but seventy-two residents, supported by the Office of Price Administration, began a fight yesterday in Bronx Municipal Court to halt the management from abrogating their leases.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Former Magistrate Hulon Capshaw who was removed from his judicial seat and was subsequently disbarred as the result of charges by former District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, lost his fight to overcome his disbarment today, when the Supreme Court declined to consider his appeal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle, who is reported from Paris to be manifesting impatience at the delays in Allied recognition of his Government, has never made any formal request for recognition, it was asserted here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, called on the Interstate Commerce Commission today to reduce a 10 per cent increase in railroad passenger fares which it granted in January, 1942. The ICC said then that the rise would make for "adequate and efficient" transportation for the duration of the war.

LONDON, Tuesday, Oct. 17 -- Red Army forces, smashing across southern Yugoslavia to cut off the Germans fleeing from Greece, have driven to within 138 miles of the Adriatic, Moscow disclosed last night, while Berlin said the Russians had massed 1,000 tanks along the Vistula River for an imminent frontal assault on Warsaw.

I would like to tell you how much we appreciate your leadership in demanding repeal of the treaty veto power now held by a one-third minority of the United States Senate. Our foreign policy has been hampered by this clause for many years. It now threatens to take the spine out of proposals for the international security organization.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- The deposition of Admiral Nicholas Horthy as Hungarian Regent, the revocation, by an order of the day allegedly signed by Admiral Horthy, of his armistice proclamation of yesterday and the formation of a Hungarian puppet gov ernment of extreme rightist elements under the notorious Hungarian Nazi Ferenc Szalasi were announced by the Budapest radio today.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Niagara Hudson Power Corporation's board of directors said today the stock allocation in a reorganization plan filed by Buffalo, Niagara Eastern Power Corporation is "grossly inadequate and unfair" to Niagara Hudson's common and preferred stockholders.

Antwerp is the most tantalizing prize gained by the Allies since the invasion. We have the great port intact. It was captured in a sudden rush which prevented demolition of its vast harbor installations. They were never more badly needed than at this moment. Yet we cannot use them because we do not control the approaches to the harbor.

The theatre waited for the first frost of the season to start rivers of warm blood flowing through Broadway; H. Clay Blaney was the guilty party and "Meet a Body -- " was the play. It opened last evening at the Forrest, and it was not long before the use of the singular, "body," clearly became one of the season's major understatements.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 8 per cent last week compared with the like week last year, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported a gain of 17 per cent over 1943.

No other German commander in this war appealed to the imagination of his enemies as Field Marshal Rommel did. One fact they never denied was his capable generalship. Beginning as far back as 1936 he trained the later famous Africa Corps for tropical service, literally in hot-houses in which North Africa's worst conditions were artificially reproduced.

Declaring the city always goes "well over our quota," but urging New Yorkers to "give all you can," Mayor La Guardia opened the Manhattan home front mobilization for the New York War Fund drive at a ceremony on the steps of City Hall that was witnessed by a noonday crowd of 2,000.

The return to winning form of Bobby Permane, the spring and summer jockey sensation, was the most noteworthy performance in the racing at Jamaica yesterday. Admitted to the winner's circle only twice all last week, Permane satisfied his followers by scoring three times, booting one favorite home and winning twice on mounts that were far from heavily played.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board opened its hearings today on proposed air routes over the North Atlantic and received applications from eleven companies and exhibits from six cities, New York, Baltimore, Philadelphia, Boston, Norfolk and Miami, all asking for consideration as future terminals for such routes.

Notre Dame, garnering slightly more than half the first-place votes in The Associated Press second poll of the season, retained its rank as the No. 1 football team of the country in the opinion of 107 sports writers.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Communique 191:

Isn't it high time that the silly restrictions be removed from the tailoring of men's suits? Limiting suits to one pair of trousers has always seemed to me to defeat its own purpose. Through many years of experience I have found that a coat will outwear even two pairs of trousers.

President Roosevelt announces that he will begin a study of whether there is any legal action that can be taken to compel James C. Petrillo, head of the American Federation of Musicians, to comply with his request to lift the ban on recordings for the major recording companies.

Net assets of Tri-Continental Corporation at Sept. 30 amounted to $36,526,303, equal to $6.18 a share for the common stock after providing for bank loans, funded debt and preferred shares, it was announced yesterday by Francis F. Randolph, chairman. This compares with $32,760,010, or $4.63 a share, on Dec. 31, and with $33,703,831, or $4.61 a share, on Sept. 30, 1943.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 16 -- The first important cutback in Government war expenditures should be accompanied by a sharp reduction of excess profits-tax rates, a report presented today by the American Institute of Cost Accountants urged.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (U.P.) -- Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, chairman of the Senate Democratic Campaign Elections Committee, in an interview tonight called attention to Governor Dewey's declaration on Sept. 21 to the effect that "in agriculture, in labor and in money we are committed to some degree of Government intervention in the free workings of our economic system."

Dugan Brothers, bakers, have purchased the property at 611-13 Third Street, Newark, N.J., from the Bonded Building and Loan Association, in liquidation. The property has a frontage of approximately 77 feet and a depth of 200 feet to the bed of the old Morris Canal and is improved with two one-story buildings and one two-story structure.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Featherweight furniture and lawn-mowers you can push with your little finger will be features of the post-war market as a result of developments in light metals and alloys, a panel of metallurgists predicted today to the forty-sixth annual National Metals Congress.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- Distribution of a thirty-two-page booklet designed to demonstrate that the Republican Governors of New York, Ohio and Illinois have taken the lead in recognizing Negroes and appointing them to office, has been started by a committee of Negro State employes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The Treasury Department today opened the way for the ultimate resumption of American business relations with liberated Italy by lifting its restrictions under the Trading With the Enemy Act against commercial and business dealings with interests in the country.

A flood of Christmas gifts for United States service men and women overseas, constituting the greatest rush in the history of the postoffice, inundated New York mailing centers yesterday as hundreds of thousands of persons made a last-minute dash to get their parcels mailed before midnight.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 16 -- The Roosevelts "slugged it out" today over a Presidential choice. The "contenders" were the widows of Brig. Gen. Theodore Roosevelt Jr., who died in Europe recently, and Major Kermit Roosevelt, who died in the Aleutians in 1941.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission reaffirmed today the right of the Cities Service Company to retain all of its oil business rather than to be confined to a single integrated utility system and only a small portion of its nonutility business.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Stockholders of the APW Paper Company will consider on Thursday two plans to reduce the interest cost on its $2,000,000 of bonded debt. Under one plan the maturity of the first mortgage and collateral trust bonds would be extended from 1948 to 1965 and the interest reduced from 6 per cent to 5 per cent, the assenting bondholders to receive twenty shares of $5 par common stock for each $1,000 of debt exchanged.

WITH AMERICAN THIRD ARMY before Metz, Oct. 16 -- The airtight censorship clamped down last Thursday, for security reasons, on the news of the American troops attempting to take Fort Driant, was lifted today and it is now possible to reveal that the attack has been abandoned and the doughboys engaged in assaulting one of the key defenses of Metz were withdrawn under the cover of darkness late Thursday and early Friday morning.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Officials of the Commodity Credit Corporation said today that plans for putting the United States back into the world cotton market and for subsidizing sales of surplus cotton abroad at competitive world prices will be put into effect shortly after they are agreed on and will not await the end of the war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The Supreme Court today denied motions to force the release of Tyler Kent, the young American Embassy code clerk in London who was convicted in a British court on charges of delivering secret information to Axis agents.

Between the early American period when pewter was the common tableware and the later era of Staffordshire and Wedgwood American colonial tables from New York to Virginia were set with English delft, imported in large quantities from Bristol and Liverpool.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 16 -- In a major address attacking the New Deal on both the home and foreign fronts, Thomas E. Dewey declared here tonight that "our representation in the vital areas abroad is on the brink of chaos" and that the reason was "exactly the same as at home."

Fourteen-year-old Irwin Mohr, a student at the Seth Low Junior High School in Brooklyn, believes Argentina has a Fascist government. He said so in school the other day -- and this morning he is going to stand up in assembly to try to prove it.
ABOARD U.S. CARRIER, Off Formosa, Oct. 14 (Delayed) -- More than 100 Japanese planes crashed to their doom today in one of the war's greatest sea and air duels.

A panel of experts is being organized to make "a careful objective, technical investigation of the proposed amendments to the city's zoning laws," members of the Citizens Zoning Committee were informed at a meeting yesterday in the Adam Room, Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 16 -- Pacific Fleet carrier planes made a powerful attack yesterday against enemy bases in the Philippine Islands and fought off two more enemy air attacks directed against elements of Admiral William F. Halsey's Third Fleet task force.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The Dumbarton Oaks security proposals were explained today to representatives of eighty political, professional, church and other organizations of the country in the course of a question-and-answer session at the State Department.

THE football clan was assembled for its weekly exercises in fork-raising and storytelling, twin transactions these well-upholstered gents handle with considerable gusto and distinction. It was the regular meeting of the Football Writers Association at the Toots Shor Athletic Club, where the conversation runs the vitamins a close race for attention.

A committee of the National Association of Better Business Bureaus is revising the publication known as "A Guide for Retail Advertising and Selling," in which the association sets forth fair practice standards and definitions for retail advertising and selling, it was announced yesterday.

The resignation of William F. Carey from the $10,000 job as Commissioner of Sanitation, which he has held since 1936, and his appointment, at his own request, to a $5,350 job as Superintendent of Landfills within the department, was announced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia, who at the same time indicated that Mr. Carey would again be Commissioner tomorrow, or at least in a few days.
Lee Tressel of Baldwin-Wallace leads the nation's football scorers, according to yesterday's compilation by The Associated Press.
Holding within an 8-point range all day, the cotton futures markets on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday closed 6 points lower to 2 points higher than Saturday's final prices.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 16 -- Most of the political speculation one encounters in Iowa these days centers around the question of the majorities by which Governors Dewey and Bricker and the Republican State ticket are expected to carry Iowa on Nov. 7.

Joseph W. Frazer, chairman of the board of Graham-Paige Motors Corporation, announced yesterday that the company plans a lightweight passenger car of unconventional design, utilizing plastics, light metals and other recent developments of industrial research as its first product after the war.

HAVANA, Oct. 16 -- Some Cuban taxes that were considered unproductive by the new Administration have been canceled, according to an official note issued at the Presidential Palace today after the first Cabinet meeting.

LONDON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Royal Air Force bombers thundered across the North Sea before dawn today to carry out the fourteenth and fifteenth major British-American aerial attacks on the Reich in forty hours.

ROME, Oct. 16 (UP) -- George Exindaris, Greek member of the Allied Advisory Council, said today that 400,000 Greeks had died of famine during Axis occupation, and intimated Greece soon would press her claims for extension of her frontiers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Army B-29 Superfortresses returned to Formosa today for the second time within forty-eight hours to attack two military targets with "very good" results, Gen. H.H. Arnold announced today, disclosing, in a special statement, the significant fact that there was "an almost complete lack of enemy air opposition."
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in English to North America from Chungking and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

We were prominently reminded yesterday by our favorite papers that midnight was the deadline for Christmas mail to the boys and girls overseas. Somewhat less prominently we were reminded that midnight was the deadline for the third installment of the New York State income tax.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 16 -- Ingrid Bergman, who recently starred with Gregory Peck in the Alfred Hitchcock psychological film "Spellbound," will be starred by David O. Selznick in "Notorious." The post-war story was written directly for the screen by Lois Anderson, a magazine short-story writer.

LONDON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- A 30-year-old full colonel -- Hubert Zemke of Missoula, Mont. -- is the leading fighting ace now active in this theatre since Capt. Henry W. Brown of Arlington, W. Va., was reported missing in action Oct. 3.

Tokyo radio reported yesterday that Japanese naval and air forces driving home attacks on American carrier forces off Formosa and the Philippines had knocked out scores of United States ships and set back the "impending invasion of the Philippines by at least two months," The Associated Press said.

The fall conference annual meeting and election of officers of the Westchester County Realty Board will be held tomorrow at the Orienta Beach Club in Mamaroneck. Starting with a luncheon, the sessions will extend through the afternoon and evening.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 16 -- A simple attachment that an American sergeant thought up overnight and that was manufactured for 500 tanks in forty-eight hours largely out of captured enemy material, made a major contribution to the American breakthrough at St. Lo that led to the recapture of France.
Admiral Nicholas Horthy's Sunday proclamation to the Hungarian people, as transmitted from Budapest yesterday in German by Morse code and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Making his first appearance of the campaign in Queens last night, Senator Robert F. Wagner coupled a plea for racial and religious tolerance with an appeal for his own re-election to the United States Senate and for the re-election of President Roosevelt for another term in the White House.

" That's My Baby," a Republic film starring Richard Arlen and Ellen Drew, and "The Last Horseman," a Columbia Western, compose the week's double-feature program, starting today, at the New York Theatre. . . . "Kismet" today enters its ninth week at the Astor. . . . Revivals of "A Damsel in Distress" and "Love Affair" will begin a week's stand today at the Ascot Theatre in the Bronx.

WINNIPEG, Oct. 16 (Canadian Press) -- Manager Lester Patrick of New York Rangers, in a statement today said Phil Watson is ineligible to play for any National Hockey League club under a ruling made by N.H.L. governors at their meeting here last May.

Within a few hours of his return from a 19,000-mile tour of the European battlefronts, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman was in a pulpit here yesterday morning, holding up the "fortitude, justice and temperance" of this country's fighting men as an inspiration for all post-war planning.
An exhibition of photographs showing Nazi atrocities in Russia was opened with a reception yesterday afternoon by the Russian War Relief, Inc., at 461 Fifth Avenue.

ANTWERP, Belgium, Oct. 16 -- Enemy resistance in the Breskens pocket south of the Schelde River stiffened today, but the Canadians moved forward slowly, reducing the German-held area on the east and south and lessening the distance between their line and the German stronghold guarding the estuary.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 16 (AP) -- After the war, the level of unemployment will be about 2,500,000 persons, Brig. Gen. Leonard P. Ayres, Cleveland economist, predicted today in a report which asserted that "no very serious readjustments will be required in about half our economy, but very difficult changes will be required in the rest of it."

" Argentine Riddle," to be published Thursday by John Day, was written by a native of Argentina, Felix J. Weil. Dr. Weil has served as an economic adviser to his Government and has taught economics in universities in Buenos Aires. He is now a member of the Institute of Social Research and a director of the Latin American Economic Institute of New York City.

Walter S. Gifford, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, reported yesterday that, despite the fact that the Western Electric Company. A.T. T.'s manufacturing subsidiary, has been permitted to resume limited production of civilian telephones the Bell System would be able to furnish only one-third of the 1,350,000 telephone installations for which applications are pending because of a lack of additional central office equipment.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- The Russians' determination to stand on the Curzon Line as a minimum adjustment of Poland's eastern border -- an issue on which at the moment the Polish Government in exile is prepared to go under rather than accept -- is thought here to have snarled the negotiations in Moscow for the settlement of the Russo-Polish difficulties.

A recent bulletin of the Forest Service, United States Department of Agriculture, reveals disquieting facts regarding the dwindling forest resources of the nation. "Some Plain Facts About the Forests" is packed with figures and explanations regarding this vital resource.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Taking an early lead and holding it all the way, Miss Joan Beattie's White Hope ran away from the field today in the Laconia Allowance Purse for $2,000 at Rockingham Park, covering the mile and a sixteenth in 1:47.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in Serbo-Croat by the Free Yugoslav Radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Twentieth, Bomber Command communique 16:
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 16 -- Representative Clare Boothe Luce of Connecticut declared tonight that a small group of Communists had laid plans to "take over the Democratic party" after Nov. 7.

Ralph S. Geddes, Cleveland industrialist, was disclosed yesterday to have an interest representing 299,878 common shares in Hupp Motor Car Corporation as a result of the purchase in July of 336,726 shares of $1 par common stock of Hupp by the Globe Machine and Stamping Company of Cleveland. This gave the latter company 17.65 per cent ownership of Hupp Motor.

Four projects for schools and school children to undertake on behalf of children of war ravaged countries were endorsed yesterday by the National Advisory Committee of School Superintendents of the Save the Children Federation at a luncheon at the Town Hall Club.
LONDON, Oct. 16 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, in the Southwest Pacific, Tuesday, Oct. 17 (U.P.) -- Fighter-escorted Liberator bombers carried out the fourth large-scale attack on vital oil installations at Balik Papan, Borneo, on Saturday, dropping 140 tons of explosives in the refinery and storage areas that supply Japan with one-sixth of all her petroleum, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

Knize, in his tailleur show yesterday at luncheon at the St. Regis, sponsored smooth fabrics such as worsted and flannels for town; suits for country wear were sturdy tweeds. Those that emphasized beautiful fabrics and workmanship were shown unadorned or as a foil for accessories.

BOSTON, Oct. 16 -- Speedy distribution of civilian goods will be of the "utmost importance" to post-war recovery, President Roosevelt said in a message to the Boston conference on Distribution, opening here today. More than 1.000 business executives, a new high record, are attending the meeting, which concludes tomorrow.
LONDON, Oct. 16 (Reuter) -- The German people and troops are "not impressed" by recent "defensive victories," a German radio spokesman said tonight in a gloomy talk to the German forces.
A new cheese, called Dan-Dee and manufactured by the Kraft Company, has been introduced recently in metropolitan New York and Philadelphia.

ROME, Oct. 16 -- A German withdrawal from Greece was indicated by Berlin today as a strong British naval force reached Piraeus, port of Athens, carrying troops to reinforce Allied and Greek patriots liberating that country.

Unable to find a script containing the social significance generally associated with his productions, Herman Shumlin has turned for the moment to another form of mental entertainment in the psychological thriller. "The Visitor," which he is presenting this evening at Henry Miller's.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- Wheat made a firm start and a tame finish today on the Board of Trade, advancing around 1 cent early, but late in the session the market lacked support when the early buyers attempted to secure profits. Closing sales were 1/2 cent higher to 1/8 cent lower than Saturday's last quotations.
The Tokyo radio, reporting a statement by Sadao Iguchi, spokesman for the Japanese Board of Information, on the battle off Formosa, said yesterday:
Grant Field in Atlanta will hold the spotlight in college football this week on an abbreviated schedule that finds numerous teams idle while their V-12 Navy personnel take examinations.

In a drastic move to stem the spread of rabies, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins ordered yesterday that the anti-rabies quarantine on dogs in force in the Bronx since March 30 be immediately extended throughout the city.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Dillon, Read Co. will offer today $7,000,000 of Twin City Rapid Transit Company 4 per cent collateral trust bonds due on Oct. 1, 1964, at 101 1/2 to yield 3.89 per cent.
The letter of your correspondent Maurice Leon, relating to France and her Constitution, is enlightening but, it seems to me, misses the point.
Following is the text of Governor Dewey's speech, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

The National Tavern Association, at its semi-annual meeting yesterday at the Hotel Commodore adopted a resolution advocating the passage of legislation by the States which would withhold from all dry areas within a State any revenue derived from taxes or licenses on alcoholic beverages.

The demand that a special session of the Legislature be convened to extend the voting hours on Election Day gained new impetus yesterday as Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State chairman, sent a telegram to Governor Dewey advising this course "so that all who want to vote can be properly accommodated."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The Office of Price Administration eased its restrictions today on a wide range of textiles, apparel and related articles, exempting one type from price control, providing an adjustable pricing formula for another, and correcting regulations covering certain outerwear garments.

Declaring that even as he spoke American bombs and shells were continuing to burst on Japanese targets, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, said last night in a radio address from Pearl Harbor that the forces under his command had inflicted a series of "hammer blows" on the Japanese in the last ten days.

One of the briefest Special Sessions trials in years occurred yesterday when Justices Nathan D. Perlman, Frank Oliver and George B. DeLuca demanded individual copies of D.H. Lawrence's "The First Lady Chatterley" for perusal to determine whether it violated the State law against obscene literature.
Officials of seventeen local public housing authorities will offer for sale on Oct. 31 short-term obligations amounting to $29,828,000. The notes of all the authorities will be dated Nov. 29, 1944.

C.J. Marx, formerly district manager for the State of Missouri of the Frankfort Distillers Corporation, has been appointed manager of the central division. He will be in charge of sales in sixteen central division States.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The United Lutheran Church in America today refused to go on record against universal military service when it turned down a resolution calling for the ban in favor of one asking postponement of action by the Government for one year, or until after the war.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 16 -- Charging Governor Dewey and his associates with conducting a "slick, shady, insinuating campaign" for the Presidency. Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes tonight devoted a speech to exposing what he termed "falsifications and double talk" advanced by the Republican candidate.

Rumors were rife in professional football circles yesterday that Pete Cawthon, coach of the Brooklyn Tigers, was on the way out as a result of his team's defeat at the hands of the New York Giants at Ebbets Field Sunday, but according to Tom Gallery, general manager of the Tigers, they are entirely without foundation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Many defense motions for a mistrial or postponement of the mass sedition trial until after the election, based on President Roosevelt's recent joint reference to the Silver Shirts in America, the Black Shirts in Italy and the Brown Shirts in Germany, were turned down in United States District Court today.

WITH KING GEORGE VI AT THE FRONT, Oct. 16 (Reuter) -- In his tour of the battle areas, King George visited the British, Canadian and American fronts, held two investures in the field, and went to within three miles of the German frontier.

PARIS, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Gen. Henri-Honore Giraud and Gen. Charles de Gaulle conferred Saturday for the first time since the former French Commander in Chief returned to France, and there was speculation today that General Giraud might resume an active military or governmental role.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 -- Following a daylong series of conferences with State and city party leaders, Herbert Brownell, Republican national chairman, predicted today that Pennsylvania's thirtyfive electoral votes would be won by the Dewey-Bricker ticket by "an old-fashioned Republican majority."

While the Office of Price Administration announced yesterday that a "few tires" would be allocated to the Surface Transportation Corporation, operators of all Bronx buses, which has been forced to strip tires from thirty-four of its seventy-seven reserve buses, the Fifth Avenue Coach Company announced it had stripped tires from sixty-two of its 110 reserve buses to equip others and there would probably be a curtailment of service starting Monday.
ROME, Oct. 17 -- A pessimistic view of the Hungarian situation is taken both at the Vatican and in central European circles here. The situation is being watched closely.

Beating fighters from north of the border is fast becoming a habit with Morris Reif, the Broadway Arena idol. Last night in the scheduled eight-round feature he knocked out Johnny Price of Montreal in fifty-six seconds of the third round, the third successive Canadian he's beaten.

Clothes for all ages and types will be included in Fashions of the Times, opening next Tuesday. Epitomizing New York elegance will be one of Valentina's latest creations. A gown by Adrian has been flown from the Far West. Children and 'teen agers will appear in togs by Joseph Love and two newcomers, Emily Wilkins and Betty Betz.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 (UP) -Marine Sgt. Albert A. Schmid killed 200 Japs on Guadalcanal, was blinded in action and discharged from service. Today he put on his uniform, his Purple Heart, his Navy Cross and a gold medal awarded him by the city of Philadelphia and reported to his draft board for registration.

Jack Weinheimer was sitting at his desk up at University Heights yesterday, an hour before he was to direct his N.Y.U. squad through a long workout at Ohio Field. There was a faraway look in his eyes, and no wonder, because the Violet coach, at that moment, was glancing through a stack of old newspaper clippings. "How I could use those fellows now!", the mild-mannered Weinheimer exclaimed.

A night after "Meet a Body --" had distributed corpses over the stage of the Forrest in the active, or physical, melodrama, "The Visitor" knocked on the door of Henry Miller's last evening to display the semi-psychological melodrama. To be able to say this morning that the intellect had triumphed over brute force would be an agreeable task, but the age of full reason is not yet at hand.

France is now in the midst of a second revolution that will bring enlightenment to the rest of the world, members of the Town Hall Club were told yesterday by Robert Valeur, director of the French Press and Information Service, at a luncheon in celebration of the liberation of France.

The boards of directors of the Doehler Die Casting Company and of the W.B. Jarvis Company have agreed on a plan whereby the former company will offer one share of its no-par common stock for each 2 1/2, shares of Jarvis, which has 300,000 shares of $1 par value outstanding, it was reported in financial circles yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 17 -- More than 2,100 planes of the United States Eighth Air Force, 1,300 of them heavy bombers, attacked Cologne again today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- President Roosevelt will make a campaign speech in Philadelphia on the night of Oct. 27. This was disclosed at the White House today by David L. Lawrence, Democratic State Chairman for Pennsylvania, after a delegation representing Business Men for Roosevelt, Inc., a countrywide organization set up in August, had received formal acceptance of their invitation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 17 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has revived interest in "Miss Pilgrim's Progress," a story about the invention of the typewriter and the first woman typist, as a starring vehicle for Jeanne Crain. The screen play by Frederica and Ernst Maas, originally announced for Fox's 1940 schedule, is now being revised by Samuel Hoffenstein and Betty Reinhardt for production by William LeBaron.

John Stewart Bryan was a lean, kindly man who might have been equally at home in New England or Kansas but whom fate had placed in a strategic position in Virginia. He was president and then chancellor of the College of William and Mary, publisher of good newspapers, a scholar, an unpretentions man active in all good works.

A SECRET SUPERFORTRESS BASE, Western China, Oct. 17 (UP) -- China-based Superfortresses and United States Fourteenth Air Force planes have wiped out Japan's most important aircraft installations on Formosa and have sunk a Japanese cruiser and 32,000 tons of shipping, it was announced today.
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 17 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- Virtually everyone in France engaged in industry or commerce may be removed or suspended by decision of "purging committees" if collaboration with the Germans can be proved. This is the effect of a decree published today in the Journal Officiel.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 17 -- The system of priorities that has been evolved in the Surplus Property Act of 1944, which is "as complicated as a diplomatic protocol," may do much to hamper prompt and full utilization of surplus property, Capt. N. Loyall McLaren, chairman of the New York Division of the Navy Price Adjustment Board, declared today in an address before the fifty-seventh annual meeting of the American Institute of Accountants.
