HAVANA, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Cuba had ample advance warning that the worst blow in eighteen years was creeping slowly up from the Caribbean Sea and every precaution had been taken well in advance. Residents were evacuated from many exposed coastal points.

Describing the conference at Dumbarton Oaks as "only a good beginning," Bernard M. Baruch, special adviser to the Director of War Mobilization, warned last night, in an address before The New York Herald Tribune Forum on Current Problems at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, that "most of the work for peace still lies ahead."

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Newspaper advertising as a means of merchandising agricultural bank credit was advocated today by Albert L. Muench, secretary of the New York State Bankers Association.

The New York Building and Construction Trades Council an American Federation of Labor affiliate, went on record yesterday as supporting Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for Senator, in preference to the Democratic incumbent, Robert F. Wagner.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 17 (UP) -- Two reinforced Japanese columns in southeastern Kwangsi Province, roughly 100 miles south of Kweilin, have begun new attacks on Chinese positions fifteen miles northwest of Ping-ham on the bend of the West River.

Objections to the proposed zoning restrictions in amendments to be presented by the City Planning Commission to the Board of Estimate were raised yesterday by business and civic leaders at a meeting in the Brooklyn Borough Hall.
LONDON Oct. 17 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Gommunications Commission:
The long-sought and long-hopedfor "showdown" battle with the Japanese Fleet is still in the future, communiques from the headquarters of Admiral Chester W. Nimitz revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The black market in the distribution of liquor, with illegal transactions amounting to "millions of dollars," has been wiped out, Price Administrator Chester Bowles reported today.
Foreign dispatches during the last weeks seem to indicate that Paris fashions are again taking the lead. Paris creations were not intended for the women of France only, but "pour tout le monde."

Far be it from me to attempt to add a trace of luster to Hitler's very murky past, but in fairness to Mr. Churchill it should be pointed out that, according to British usage, he was apparently not inaccurate in referring to that strategical genius as a "corporal of the first World War."

MONTPELIER, Vt., Oct. 17 -- A heavy bomber plane which had been missing from the Westover Field Army air base in Chicopee, since Sunday night, was found wrecked today on Camel's Hump, 4,083-foot mountain, in Huntington, about five miles from Montpelier.

It's more than two and a half years since "Good Night, Ladies" emerged from obscurity to become one of the hinterland's most profitable ventures. With some misgivings, the old Avery Hopwood-Charlton Andrews farce, "Ladies' Night," reconditioned by Cyrus Wood, was quietly launched by Howard Lang and Al Rosen in February of 1942 in Santa Barbara. Calif.
ALBANY, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Governor Dewey dictated today the final draft of a foreign policy speech which he will deliver tomorrow night in New York City.
PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 17 -- The Japanese Navy refused combat with the Pacific Fleet in the Western Philippine Sea several days ago.

RUSHVILLE, Ind., Oct. 17 -- Wendell L. Willkie was buried in East Hill Cemetery here this afternoon after the simplest of ceremonies as requested by the widow of the Republican Presidential nominee of 1940.

ANTWERP, Oct. 17 -- In the drive westward through the Breskens pocket toward the all-important fortresses guarding the Schelde estuary on the south, the Canadians have pushed beyond Hoofdplaat and are now nearing the half-way mark to the primary objective.
LONDON, Oct. 17 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Central Pacific Railway Company, a leased line of the Southern Pacific Company, today asked authority of the Interstate Commerce Commission to issue $50,000,000 of its first and refunding bonds, Series A, and the Southern Pacific Company, as lessee, to act as guarantor of the principal and interest of the bonds.

INSIDE AACHEN, Oct. 17 -- Rifle fire is whistling down the empty streets, and a German 88 is bouncing shells down one avenue as a thin line of doughboys creeps from doorway to doorway and tunnels through shattered buildings to push their line farther west from the third of Aachen we now hold.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Seated before a panorama in a room filled with strange and secret scale models of naval craft and equipment, President Roosevelt showed news correspondents today how two artificially created invasion harbors had been moved from England to Allied beachheads in Normandy after D-day last June to aid the landing of 250,000 troops and the tanks, guns and supplies necessary for their operations.

THE letter was a long time in coming, so long that it didn't seem particularly important to answer it immediately. Now it never will be answered. It was from Capt. Steve Stavers of the Marines and Steve is dead, killed by a Japanese sniper in the early stages of the Palau invasion.

The shut-ins turned out en masse yesterday as the rodeo with its horses, steers, mules, trick ropers and cowboys carried them off to the "Wild West" for one and a half thrill-packed hours, during which they gaped, cheered, laughed and forgot the red brick walls of Bellevue Hospital that surrounded them.

An increasing number of war veterans need prompt social services. Walter S. Gifford, chairman of the board of trustees of the Community Service Society, reported yesterday in his annual letter sent to 9,000 contributors. Despite the adoption of a record budget of $2,793,344 for the coming year, the society will not have a formal drive for funds, Mr. Gifford said.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Wednesday, Oct. 18 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The War Production Board and the National Housing Agency jointly relaxed today several restrictions on the construction, design and equipment of dwellings and said that the changes would permit the building of houses of prewar standards.

The proposal to make conscription in peacetime a national policy was condemned yesterday by the sixty-second annual meeting of the Synod of New York of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America. The plan was called militaristic and lamentable in a resolution adopted unanimously by the 150 pastors and laymen attending the meeting in the First Prysbyterian Church, 124 Henry Street, Brooklyn.
This is the first year that I have been old enough to vote in the November elections. Naturally, while I was registering I was interested in observing others.

Until the Office of Price Administration is in a position to pass on any "rollback" savings to consumers, the rayon converting industry is opposed to any price ceiling reduction which would not be accompanied by similar cuts for manufacturers and retailers, the Textile Distributors Institute announced yesterday.

The letter of Nicholas Lely in regard to the claim of the present democratic Bulgarian Government to retain its hold as guardian of Greek Thrace calls attention to an undoubted threat to the new peace in Europe, which has only been partially allayed by the decision not to extend an armistice to Bulgaria until the new Government withdraws its troops from the territory seized as a satellite of the Nazis and Fascists.

Yankee horse-traders were no sharper than are New York housewives when it comes to making swaps. Figures compiled yesterday by the City Hall headquarters of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office indicate that the women may even hold an edge.

The Manhattan Savings Bank has sold the property at 3240-50 Broadway, northeast corner of 130th Street, to the Viden Realty Corporation. The property, assessed at $100,000, of which all but $5,000 is on the land, includes a one-story garage, a gasoline station site, a one-story shop and a two-story store and apartment building.

War sets thousands of people to drifting, even in a land that has not been invaded by hostile armies. There are thousands of drifters in America today, and their plight would often be grave were it not that one of our great humane agencies has foreseen their trouble and prepared to meet it.
The time and space given to your recent articles featuring Paris fashion shows, to say nothing of the theme of feminine styling, seem utterly shocking in these unhappy wartimes.

BOSTON, Oct. 17 -- Industrialization of China now a cardinal policy of the Chinese Government, will create a tremendous market for American goods in the post-war period, while defeat of Japan will open the way for China to sell cheap goods in world markets, particularly in the South Sea areas, to help pay for her imports.

A preview showing of the passenger and cargo plane to be operated by American Airlines, Inc., to London and continental Europe, six months after the end of the war with Germany, was hold at La Guardia Field last evening.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has agreed to relinquish a larger measure of control over civil affairs in France to Gen. Charles de Gaulle's de facto authority, it was learned today. The agreement was conditioned upon a pledge of full cooperation in the war against Germany.

Postmaster Albert Ooldman's office reported yesterday a record-breaking 17,474,830 Christmas parcels, addressed to soldiers overseas, had been turned over to the port of embarkation between Sept. 15 and midnight Monday.

In our judgment Mr. Dewey is making a mistake in continuing to pound away at the charge that the Administration is planning to keep young men in the Army and the Navy, after their services are no longer needed for military purposes, because it fears the problem of post-war unemployment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -Failure to act immediately on legislation setting up a "realistic and economically sound" plan for sale of the Government-owned merchant fleet to private operators would seriously handicap the American shipping industry in post-war competition for foreign trade.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 11, the Federal Reserve Bank announced today:

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, informed Senator Robert F. Wagner yesterday that he was urging his re-election to the Senate this year by an increased majority because "labor never had a more able champion or a more loyal and devoted friend in the Congress of the United States."

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17 (AP) -Senator Truman told the Commonwealth Club today that Governor Dewey had practiced "political chicanery" in his use in campaign speeches of "certain sentences" in the Truman committees reports.

Announcement of the election of new officers and the presentation of awards were features of the dinner dance last night of the Society of Motion Picture Engineers, which will close today its fifty-sixth semi-annual technical conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 17 -- The strategy of positional warfare as now applied by the Germans along the Western Front is halting the progress of the Anglo-American armies, Lieut. Gen. Kurt Dittmar, Nazi radio commentator, asserted tonight.

How John Giraffa, 41 years old, stole $11,855 from his employers, the Coca-Cola Bottling Company, at 625 East Nineteenth Street, and made three trips from the company's safe to a vacant house in Yonkers, where he lost the money in a dice game, came out in General Sessions yesterday.

There is something in the American environment that makes men handy with tools and ingenious in dealing with mechanical problems. This was true as far back as the Civil War, when almost any regiment on either side could produce privates able to build, repair and operate a railroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Cotton figured prominently in two separate developments in government agencies today, one of which raised the price for storing Government-owned stocks and the other of which sought to determine an export price satisfactory to both the trade and Federal officials.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 17 -- A vicious tropical hurricane isolated the Isle of Pines tonight, sent advance gales roaring over western Cuba and threatened the Florida Keys with their worst blow since the storm disaster of 1935. The raging winds knocked out the Government radio in Nueva Gerona, principal city of the tourist islet south of Cuba, and there was no word from the population of less than 10,000 persons.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- Adolf Hitler's grandiose plans for the annihilation of the Allies' invading forces on D-day, the late Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel's miscalculations and chaos in German communications as a result of air attacks were clearly pictured in German records that have been captured by the British.

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- French youngsters, who were encouraged to lie to the Germans and practice deceit against the enemy at every turn during the past four years, are showing no ill effects from this erratic upbringing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UP) -Senator Joseph H. Ball of Minnesota, who is "on the fence" politically until the Presidential candidates elaborate their foreign policy pledges, said tonight that he expected to announce next week which candidate he will support.

OMAHA, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Describing the current war as "more of a family matter than any previous war," President Roosevelt told American War Dads today that if "there is no diminution in the effort at home, with God's help, we shall not fail."

A high degree of selectivity characterized yesterday a moderate advance of prices on the stock market, although the expansion in business was too small for conclusive results. Activity was confined mainly to low-price issues, although a handful of medium-price stocks attracted sufficient attention to place them among the most active of the day.

Irving Stein, secretary of the Bronx-Empire City Chess Club, qualified yesterday for a place in the finals of tile national amateur championship at the Marshall Chess Club, when C.F. Tears Jr. resigned in their adjourned game from the first round.

The General Aniline and Film Corporation, 98 per cent of whose voting shares have been vested in the Alien Property Custodian since Feb. 16, 1942, took yesterday another step toward elimination of foreign connections when the directors voted dividends, part of which stockholders may take in shares of I.G. Chemic of Basle, Switzerland.

What we used to call "mad dogs" are now so much the concern of the Board of Health that it has authorized the Health Commissioner of the city to enforce a quarantine against rabies for six months. Dog owners have no good reason to protest. Since 1934 the Sanitary Code has directed that dogs be kept on a leash or under control.

ROME, Oct. 17 (U.P.) -- American stillerymen today turned captured and reconverted 88-mm, guns on the German defenders of Bologna at a renewed push northward from the totally destroyed village of avergnano, and hammered open a path to the rim of a three-mile edge above the town.

Warning that failure to extend voting hour on election day would force workers to take time off from war jobs to exercise their franchise, the Congress of Industrial Organizations Political Action Committee appealed yesterday to Governor Dewey to call a special session of the Legislature to authorize keeping the polls open until 10 P.M.

One of the most important Charles Dickens manuscripts in this country was sold at auction last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., for $17,000. It is the original manuscript of the novel "Our Mutual Friend," which had been offered for sale, with other valuable autograph material, by the Drexel Institute of Technology in Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- A special Navy board will be appointed soon to make a thorough investigation of the attitude of reserve officers toward the Navy and try to determine how many reservists actually will wish to transfer to the regular Navy after the war.

Charging that the Fascists and pre-war pro-Nazis in Greece are sponsoring misrepresentation of the facts in the country to Allied correspondents, Stelios Pistolakis, president of the Greek American Committee for National Unity, asserted yesterday that 95 per cent of the Greek people are united behind the National Liberation Front (EAM).

Because of final examinations at Columbia, the Lions' gridiron squad, with several members absent, went through a light but lengthy drill of two and one-half hours yesterday on the campus athletic field. Coach Lou Little and Ted Wieman, line coach, had their charges practice offensive plays and signal drills, contact work being sidetracked.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- although business on the stock markets was on a small scale today the general tone was firm Home rails held good and aircraft shares came in for further attention on post-war civil aviation prospects and some small gains again were recorded.
SAN DIEGO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Gov. John W. Bricker declared tonight that the leaders who represent "the so-called liberalism of the New Deal" were in reality "the arch reactionaries of this century."

One reader is troubled by the fact that on a certain day last week nine out of the fifteen books advertised in THE NEW YORK TIMES, plus the book chosen for comment by our book reviewer, were written by women.

Declaring that a gift to the National War Fund this year is "one way to show that there is no letdown in the spirit and unity of this country," President Roosevelt last night asked the nation to support the fund with its contributions.

A nation-wide investment banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and comprising more than 160 members will offer today to the public $155,000,000 of 3 per cent mortage bonds, due on Feb. 1, 1977, of the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago at 104 1/4.

One of the season's outstanding exhibitions, that devoted to work by Eugene Delacroix, the great nineteenth-century French painter, will open with a gala preview this evening at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street. It was organized as a benefit for the Quaker Emergency Service.

General Manager Tom Gallery of the Brooklyn Football Tigers made two things clear yesterday when he summoned the entire squad to luncheon at the Montauk Club, following the morning workout at Ebbets Field.

Commissioner of Health Ernest L. Stebbins appealed yesterday to the public to cooperate with the Health Department in its efforts to prevent a threatened rabies epidemic in the city. The disease has already caused the death of one woman.

Operations of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company during the first nine months of this year re-suited in net earnings of $5,513,719, or $2.16 a share, after giving effect to substantial reflections in the prices of various ar products, John D. Biggers, president, reported yesterday to stockholders.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 17 -- The Zionist Organization of America demanded today that representatives of that group be permitted "voice and status" when the Palestine question is discussed at peace conferences.
After the October position had expired at noon yesterday, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange held within a narrow range and closed unchanged to 2 points lower on the day.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Communique 192:

Two new films will open in first- run theatres today. At the Globe the new attraction will be "Sweet and Low-down," a musical produced by Twentieth Century-Fox. Heading the film's cast are Benny Goodman and his band, Lynn Bari, Linda Darnell, Jack Oakie, James Cardwell, June Haver and Allyn Joslyn. . . .
ALBANY, Oct. 17 -- Banking and utility corporations have reported to State Controller Frank C. Moore that on July 1 they held $3,777,393 in abandoned property.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- After an all-night search by 300 policemen, firemen and civilians and by bloodhounds of the State police, two children who wandered from their home here last evening were found by accident at 8:30 A.M. today huddled in a chicken coop four blocks away. The police said an outside latch on the door had trapped them in the coop.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Interesting sidelights on the Russian point of view on the question of the peace settlement with Germany, now one of the uppermost subjects in the debates of the Allied statesmen, are contained in an article, "Russia and Germany," printed in a new publication, Russian Affairs, and made available through the Soviet Embassy here.

MOSCOW, Oct. 17 -- The Soviet press disclosed today that the Iranian Government had turned down the Soviet Government's proposal for the immediate granting of a concession for the exploitation of oil deposits in northern Iran and had decided that nothing would be done about new concessions until after the war.

A.J. Cronin, author of "The Citadel," "The Keys of the Kingdom" and the forthcoming novel "The Green Years," has made approximately a half million dollars from film rights to his books. The new book, coming from Little, Brown on Nov. 13, was sold to the movies for $200,000 It has been put through three printings, totaling 150,000 copies, before publication.

Asserting that Governor Dewey has refused in his Presidential campaign to "make the fight on the issues," Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic national chairman, challenged him yesterday to answer four questions in his speech on foreign policy tonight before The Herald Tribune Forum.

Shipments of corrugated and solid fiber boxes during 1944 are expected to reach the second highest volume in the history of the industry, the Fibre Box Association reported yesterday. Volume is 1.1 per cent above last year's. Shipments through the end of the year are expected to amount to 49,300,000,000 square feet, compared with 51,500,000,000 in 1941.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- A solemn political law was broken at the White House today by Charles Edison, former Secretary of the Navy and former Governor of New Jersey. Not only did he inform the Presidential nominee of his own party, Franklin D. Roosevelt, that he would probably lose Mr. Edison's State; the unusual White House visitor also informed the press he had done this.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- Major Walter R. Metz of the Veterans Administration in Washington examined today Westchester County's 251-acre Crugers Park beside the Hudson River south of Peekskill and later informed County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach that he was "favorably impressed" with it as a possible site for a 2,000-bed veterans' hospital.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 17 -- Caught in the Hungarian Nazi government's fist and besieged by "dissident" elements of the First Hungarian Army which have surrounded the capital except for a corridor to the northwest, Budapest today began its first organized reaction to the new Szalasi regime, according to reliable information from Hungarian sources tonight.

Representatives of thirty-four separate groups of business and industrial firms, whose activities are more limited than those of large corporations, voted yesterday to develop "an immediate and long-range program" for the protection of their interests in metropolitan New York at a meeting called by the Commerce and Industry Association of this city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- A War Labor Board report dealing with the Little Steel wage formula stands a good chance of reaching President Roosevelt before the election under a modified procedure adopted by the board today with labor members assenting.

ATHENS, Oct. 15 (Delayed) -- This city is now free of German domination, which lasted more than three and a half years. The oppression, perhaps unequaled elsewhere and designed to humble and humiliate its citizens and rob them of every vestige of freedom and self-respect, is at an end.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 17 -- Dr. Earnest A. Hooton, Harvard anthropologist, would like to see a woman President in the White House.

" 99 Park," headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc.,* offers a partial list of free amusements available today, through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M.: evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 17 (U.P.) -- The Finns today announced the capture of Rovaniemi, German railhead and supply base in Lapland, after heavy fighting.
ROME, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Greek women and children are being used as hostages by German troops fleeing northward, authentic reports said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 156:

Aside from its purely musical values, Ruth Posselt's recital at Town Hall last night was a note-worthy affair. For this young American violinist deserves great praise for devising a program that was at once unusual and effective. Though the classics were represented by Handel's D Major Sonata and Bach's A Major work in the same form, the major portion was devoted to contemporary works, largely by composers whose reputations are firmly established.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 17 -- German forces that up until midnight yesterday were pounding furiously against the American ring around Aachen abandoned, for today at least, their frustrated attempts to smash open the trap enveloping the Westwall citadel.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York, meeting last night at 42 West Forty-fourth Street, approved the resolution of its committee on the judiciary in urging the election of Justice John Van Voorhis of Irondequoit, Republican candidate for a vacancy on the Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (U.P.) -The Navy is seriously concerned over a 25 per cent lag in construction of attack transports and attack cargo ships which are on rush order for a vital role in Pacific operations.

Fordham University which has been out of them intercollegiate athletic picture for more than a year, will be represented by a basketball team this winter. Jack Coffey, graduate manager of athletics, revealed yesterday. The Rams expect to engage in twelve contests, half of which probably will be played at home. No games are carded for Madison Square Garden.

Records will be established today in the field of corporate financing. In the first place, the largest single bond issue ever to pass through registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission and reach the public, namely, $155,000,000 of Commonwealth Edison 3s, will be offered by a nation-wide syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co.
Two former stable-mates, now running in different colors, captured yesterday's featured races at Jamaica, when Flaught and Light of Morn won in the presence of 21,227 persons who wagered $2,057,933.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- Bullish sentiment ran high in the grain trade today and prices on the Board of Trade here were on the upgrade from the start, with rye leading. December rye acted tight and advanced 2 3/4 cents a bushel to a new high since July 21 and closed at the top. Other futures gained 2 1/8 to 2 7/8 cents.

New York City's 500,000 passenger car owners will receive their new basic A gasoline ration books at Public Schools on Oct. 31, Nov. 1 and 2, Daniel P. Woolley, head of the regional Office of Price Administration, announced yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 17 -- Russian surface craft were reported today to be operating freely in the Baltic. Swedish fishing vessels reported that they had observed submarines and old naval units near the Island of Bornholm.

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- The GI in Paris is not the "free and easy" fellow he is in Rome. In Italy he is a conquering hero, Lord Bountiful, pal of the children. The poorest beg from him, shopkeepers and waiters defer to him, everybody smiles at him. To girls he is the most lavish, prodigious "ragazzo" they have ever seen.

Nearly 300 persons, including distinguished musicians, attended yesterday a luncheon in honor of Mrs. Edward MacDowell, widow of the composer, in the Music Room of the Biltmore Hotel. It was given under the auspices of the National Federation of Music Clubs, with Mrs. Guy Patterson Gannett, president of the Federation, as chairman. Walter Damrosch, conductor and composer, was toastmaster.
Amateur decorators usually count on bedspread and draperies to brighten up rooms that need color. Too often this role of obvious gaiety only calls attention to the dullness it is supposed to hide.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The dollars the United States is making available to the Italian Government under the plan announced last week by President Roosevelt, will be released as they are needed in the form of goods for Italian relief, it was learned from Treasury sources today.

Leo Krzycki, president o/ theI American Slav Congress, replied in heated terms yesterday to the l charge of RePresentative Clare Boothe Luce of Connecticut. made at a Republican rally in Pittsburgh on Monday, that "the All-American Slav Congress was hatched in Moscow on Aug. 10, 1941."

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- It was said on high authority tonight than an agreement had been reached between the Minister of War and the Committee of Military Action, Action, which heads the French Forces of the Interior, concerning the amalgamation of the FFI and the regular army.
SALEM, N.H., Oct. 17 (AP) -- A mysterious "woman in red" has plunged $25,000 to win $2,500 in show bets within a few days at Rockingham Park.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Representative Clare Boothe Luce, Republican of Connecticut, was accused today by R.J. Thomas, president of the United Automobile Workers (CIO) and treasurer of the National Citizens Political Action Committee with having once sought the support of the PAC, which she now attacks.

Esther Dorothy endorsed several changes in the silhouette during her showing of furs yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. Shoulders were rounder, necklines higher, and a new push-up sleeve was introduced. A high, cupped collar that framed the face up to the ears was featured in coats.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 17 -When Mayor Frank Hague read a report today of the visit of ex-Governor Edison to the White House and Mr. Edison's statement that Governor Dewey would carry New Jersey by a substantial majority, he made this comment:

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 17 (AP) -- A complaint demanding that Governor Dewey, the Republican Presidential candidate, his running mate, Governor Bricker, and Representative Clare Booth Luce of Connecticut retract alleged "defamatory and untrue utterances" against President Roosevelt was filed with the Federal Communications Commission today by William B. Rubin, Milwaukee attorney and former Democratic candidate for Governor.

Consolidation of the United States Brewers Association and the Brewing Industry Foundation into one organization to be known as the United States Brewers Foundation to integrate the industry's national activities and "to streamline them for more effective service to the industry and the public," was announced yesterday by Herbert J. Charles, of the Theo. Hamm Brewing Company, St. Paul, Minn., newly elected chairman of the new group.

LAUREL, Md. Oct. 17 (AP) -- J.H. Louchheim's Kopla won his second straight at this track and his third in a row by taking the Kossuth Purse, best offering on today's program. With Sterling Young doing the booting, the son of Okapi finished a length in front of Mrs. R. Feinberg's Blue Line.

Asserting that the "headaches" encountered in gearing for war work were nothing compared with what will probably be encountered when readjusting for peace, Lieut. Col. E. W. Reilley of the office of the quartermaster general, Army Services Forces yesterday urged business men to include an organization study as part of their postwar planning.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- President Roosevelt, analyzing the Dumbarton Oaks security agreements at a news conference today, declared that the proposal might not achieve peace forever, but that it could certainly serve to safeguard peace for our time.

The Regional Office of Price Administration obtained permanent injunctions yesterday in Federal Court restraining seventy-one window cleaning and building service concerns from violating price regulations, Daniel P. Woolley, Regional OPA Administrator, announced in opening a campaign to prevent inflationary increases in the cost of building cleaning and maintenance services.

Political prophets can't help speculating as to the probable effect of increased, diminished or stationary registration figures in any part of the country in a Presidential year. This year they will have to revise their methods to take in geographical shifts in the industrial vote and the unprecedented uncertainty of the service vote.

Party-minded persons, as well as those with weddings in the offing, will be interested in a new shop called the Ritz Plaza Caterer at 250 East Fifty-seventh Street, near Second Avenue, which opened its doors for business about a month ago.

Child victims of war in Normandy are receiving food, clothing and medicine directly from the United States, American Relief for France disclosed here yesterday. Two carloads of goods in 1,000 cases comprised the shipment, believed to be the first cleared by authorities for delivery to the French invasion country. This was in addition to goods being sent by way of London.

An alarming picture of food, health and mortality conditions in Italy, which he said offered "a challenge to the intelligent men and women of America," was described yesterday by Special Sessions Justice Juvenal Marchisio, president of American Relief for Italy, in his first public statement since he went to Italy four weeks ago as a representative of the State Department.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 17 -- By a decree published late this evening the Argentine Government forbids in the whole territory of the republic "any form of propaganda, direct or indirect, in favor of causes or regimes existing in countries with which Argentina has broken diplomatic relations."

Plans for thirty-six new buildings in Manhattan at an estimated cost of $19,389,500 were filed with the Department of Housing and Buildings during September, bringing the total for all buildings thus far this year far ahead in number and value of the corresponding period last year.

LONDON, Wednesday, Oct. 18 -- Russian troops yesterday drove to within two miles of the southern border of Czechoslovakia only thirty-one miles from a junction with Soviet forces in Poland, while Berlin said the Red Army had opened a great twin offensive against East Prussia from the east and south.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The French National Committee set up in southern Germany, probably in Baden-Baden, at the beginning of September, under Fernand de Brinon, formerly Vichy Ambassador to the German authorities in Paris, has a definite program to fulfill.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 17 -- A plan by Mexican Senator Alfonso Flores for the smaller nations of the Western Hemisphere to present a solid front and obtain recognition from the big powers in post-war settlement receives wide publicity in the local press.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The White House issued today, without comment, a second "factual analysis" of statements made by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, Republican Presidential nominee, in speeches attacking the Administration.

ARE American soldiers, gallant, resourceful and efficient though they are, just so many innocents abroad? Well-intentioned, kindly, unsuspicious, naively credulous, have they no understanding of the ancient evils, the duplicities and treacheries, the hatreds and moral quagmires that lie about them in Africa, Asia and Europe?

Irwin Mohr, a 9-B student at the Seth Low Junior High School in Brooklyn, who was challenged last Friday to prove his assertion at a student assembly that Argentina was a Fascist state, returned to the speaker's platform yesterday to reiterate his charge before 400 cheering schoolmates.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The role which Mayor La Guardia of New York will have in the administrative set-up of the Allied Relief Program in Italy remained a mystery tonight after he had spent about two and a half hours with President Roosevelt at luncheon and in conference at the White House proper.

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- The Paris press today is striving to get news instead of devoting all its attention to political polemics. This trend is laudable, but it reveals the gulf between the French and American conceptions of news.

Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Lehman Brothers head a banking group that won yesterday the award of $33,000,000 of electric plant refunding revenue bonds of the Department of Water and Power of the city of Los Angeles, Calif., on a bid of par for a combination of interest rates that represented to the issuer a net interest cost of 1.9289 per cent.
Swiss Insurance Company, to Parker-Aliston Associates, Inc., effective Nov. 1.

Butter trade delegations from New York City and Chicago went to Washington last night in a final effort to induce Federal authorities to modify trade restrictions that they declare make it impossible for many of their number continue in business.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Ira Hirschmann, vice president of Bloomingdale's in New York, who has just returned from the Balkans, where he represented the War Refugees Board, told a news conference today that the Bagrianov Government of Bulgaria called a special session of the kingdom's Parliament, at the suggestion of representatives of the WRB, at which it repealed the anti-Semitic decrees of the Nazis.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Wednesday, Oct. 18 -- Allied fighter planes surprised and destroyed a large Japanese motor convoy in a low-level sweep over northern Mindanao in the Philippines Monday, blasting sixty-two trucks and six staff cars, while night bombers struck airdromes near Balik Papan, Borneo, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

" They've gotta big line -- an awful big line," sighed Stout Steve Owen, as he relaxed in the comparatively tiny chair before his locker after winding up yesterday morning's drill of his Football Giants in the bright sunshine at the Polo Grounds.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- The British Government wants a new international air convention granting innocent passage and international traffic rights and eliminating subsidies. It envisages its enforcement by an international air authority with an operational executive subsidiary, regional panels and technical subcommissions that would fix quotas for international traffic, prescribe rates and establish technical standards.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The baseball fans of Detroit want their American League pennant races hot, and they showed it the past season by spinning the turnstiles to the tune of 923,176 paid admissions, an increase of more than 50 per cent over 1943.
ROME, Oct. 17 (AP) -- A communique:

Henry R. Ickelheimer, senior partner in the banking firm of Heidelbach, Ickelheimer Co., left a gross estate of $4,531,036 and a net of $4,414,853 at the time of his death on Dec. 8, 1940, according to an estate tax appraisal filed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- More than $86,000,000,000 was spent for new construction, machinery and equipment in the United States in the three and one-half years from July, 1940, to December, 1943, the Commerce Department announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 (AP) -The Third Federal Circuit Court of appeals took under consideration today a petition by the National Labor Relations Board to have the Weirton Steel Company, the National Steel Corporation, seven of their officials and five officers of a union adjudged in contempt of court.

A Paris newspaper has just sent a correspondent to London. The correspondent is sending back items that are news to Parisian readers. He is beginning with the Nazi blitz of 1940 and coming along down, and in the course of time will be current with each day's events.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 18 -- All six Allied armies on the Western Front made gains today in attacks against which Hitler has ordered mass mobilization of Germany's adult population.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- Santa Claus, minus his traditional robes, visited the House of Commons today and in the person of Col. J.J. Llewellin, British Food Minister, announced his intention of giving extra rations this Christmas, the sixth Christmas since the beginning of the war.

Lawrence Robinson of the World-Telegram was named chairman of the Sixth War Loan Drive Sports Committee at an organization meeting in the New York A.C. yesterday. Robinson succeeded Max Kase, sports editor of the Journal-American, who headed the Fifth War Loan Drive committee, which sold $16,730,170 worth of bonds.

When the Brooklyn Tigers move into Griffith Stadium to oppose the Washington Redskins on Sunday Pete Cawthon will present his newly found tailback in the well-proportioned person of Bob Trocolor. Yes, he's the same Trocolor who wore a Giants' uniform for three years and still was wearing one at the New Yorkers' training camp at Bear Mountain just before the current campaign got under way.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- To President Roosevelt was presented formally today the Four Freedoms Award of the Italian-American Labor Council of New York. The award had been accepted on behalf of the President at a dinner of the council, held in New York City on Columbus Day, by Francis Biddle, Attorney General.

HAVANA, Oct. 18 -- The hurricane which has been centered in the Caribbean Sea south of Cuba for several days swept northward across the island today, cutting a wide path of destruction. The first estimate of the authorities placed the dead in Havana at five, with some 200 injured.

Details of the plan to merge the Doehler Die Casting Company and the W.B. Jarvis Company, made public yesterday, were said to indicate that the directors of both companies have agreed on a merger as of Jan. 1, 1945, under the corporate name Doehler-Jarvis Corporation, subject to approval of the stockholders of both companies at special meetings to be held soon.

COVINGTON, Ky., Oct. 18 (AP) -Ten years of litigation involving the defunct Banco Kentucky ended today with a final judgment handed down by United States District Judge Mac Swinford by which stockholders must pay approximately $100,000.

A continuation of the present boom in movie theatre business after the war, provided there is no let-down in the quality of pictures offered the public, was predicted yesterday by Jack L. Warner, vice president in charge of production at the Warner Brothers studios, upon his arrival from Hollywood.

One-third of all babies born in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens last year -- 7,000 of them children of service men -- came under the care of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, 262 Madison Avenue, the service revealed in its annual announcement yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 -Adoption of a national policy whereby post-war assistance to foreign countries "would take into account as one of the major facts that the country under consideration accepts the concept of equality of all its nationals without regard to race or creed" is urged in a memorandum submitted by the American Council for Judaism to Secretary Hull and made public here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 159:

In determining how accurate are the observations and conclusions of J.M. Johnson, Director of ODT, and to what extent public cooperation has "permitted American transportation to do its job so effectively," I wish to call attention to the fact that thousands of servicemen on furlough to their homes are daily required to stand in trains hour after hour while civilians occupy the seats.

Steadiness prevailed yesterday in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange, and prices rose 2 to 4 points net. The market opened with gains of 3 to 4 points, eased to levels unchanged to 3 points lower than the previous close, but steadied again. Price fixing was sufficient to absorb light hedge selling.

ROME, Oct. 18 -- While the debarkation of Lieut. Gen. Ronald M. Scobie's forces continues at the damaged port of Piraeus and additional parachutists have landed in the Athens area -- and also with Patras now open to Allied shipping -- the first authoritative prospectus of Allied relief plans became available here today.

A constructive suggestion appears in THE TIMES editorial "Mr. Petrillo Says No." After again placing the blame for the mess in the musical recording industry on the shoulders of the President, it finally concludes with this sensible proposal:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Continuing reports Of declining prices for gold on the Egyptian and Indian markets in anticipation of peace were seen today as possibly thwarting an attempt by mining interests to have Congress permit the sale for export of gold and silver mined in the United States.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The Slovak patriots, who have liberated a good fourth of Slovakia from the Germans, are fighting under the auspices of the Czechoslovak republic. They intend that Slovakia shall continue to form part of a homogeneous republic after the war and are against federation, though in favor of decentralization on the lines already promised by President Eduard Benes.

The American Kennel Club, Inc., despite its recording of the births and lineage of some 1,500,000 purebred dogs since its inception in 1908 and its 4,000-volume library that includes works on "psychology and philosophy as applied to dogs," is not a scientific organization under the Federal income tax laws, according to a ruling yesterday by Federal Judge John W. Clancy.
Gov. J. Melville Broughton of North Carolina and Mrs. Broughton have come to the Waldorf-Astoria from Raleigh.

THE statement was typically British and couched in such appealing phraseology that the chances are that it will receive a favorable reaction in the minds, but particularly in the hearts, of those in authority. It came from Lord Aberdare, Lord Burghley and Sir Noel Curtis Bennett, the three British members of the International Olympic Committee.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- Shippers were assured today that there will be no serious shortage of railway freight cars, despite the fact that railroads are at present in greater difficulty in supplying needed cars than at any previous time in twenty years.

A quick turnover of a tall apartment building on the East Side featured realty activity in Manhattan yesterday when Frederick Brown resold the fourteen-story and penthouse structure at 956 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Seventy-seventh Street, which he bought last month.

President Roosevelt probably will make a campaign tour of Brooklyn, Manhattan, Queens and the Bronx on Saturday as a preliminary to the speech he had previously agreed to deliver on that evening at a dinner of the Foreign Policy Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic national chairman, said yesterday.

ATHENS, Oct. 17 (Delayed) -An order was issued yesterday morning, signed by the recently appointed Military Governor Spilitopoulous calling on the civilians to hand over their arms to the police and warning them to refrain from further demonstrations.

Never before were the results of a Presidential campaign so vital to American women, Governor Dewey declared yesterday at a press conference in the Hotel Roosevelt following his meeting with women sponsoring the "Double the Vote for Dewey Day," scheduled for State-wide observance next Wednesday.
ROME, Oct. 18 (AP) -- A communique:
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Pre-transfer furloughs took all but one marine trainee today as Penn State's football squad was leaving for its game with Colgate at Hamilton, N.Y., on Saturday.

Full employment is a phrase which post-war planners have been using to excess. The phrase would appear to mean that everyone would have a job. But this term is a rather ambiguous one. For example, in a recent Brookings study concerned with national income, the author made the assumption that there would be "reasonably full employment" in 1947.

Another Remsen Handicap dead heat resulted yesterday at Jamaica when the camera couldn't separate Great Power and War Jeep in the $12,250 stake which for forty years has been a feature of the Metropolitan Jockey Club's fall meeting. In the 1940 Remsen there was a dead heat between Mettlesome, belonging to Mrs. Dodge Sloane, who now owns Great Power, and Harvard Square.

Advertising linage in newspapers in fifty-two cities throughout the country was reduced 11.2 per cent in September, compared with the corresponding month last year, according to Media Records. Financial had the largest loss, or 19.3 per cent; general was next with 16.5 per cent, and classified third with 15.9 per cent.

Governor Dewey lashed out last night with the most inclusive and bitter attack he has yet made on President Roosevelt's handling of foreign relations. He charged that the President's "personal secret diplomacy" threatened to balk our efforts for a lasting peace and that "we are paying in blood" for the President's failure to have ready an intelligent program for dealing with invaded Germany.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- With buyers largely absent from today's stock markets, most sections had a neglected appearance and price changes were few and small. Gilt-edged issues held firm. Among the foreign bonds several Brazilian issues hardened.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- United States service men who have been prisoners of war for sixty days, or whose condition requires it, will have priority in returning to this country over all other casual personnel except sick and wounded.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- Despite adverse weather conditions, heavy bombers of the United States Eighth Air Force and the Royal Air Force continued today their offensive against communications and industries in western Germany, vital to the enemy's Siegfried Line defenses.

ROME, Oct. 18 -- The Vatican newspaper, Osservatore Romano, publishes today copious extracts from two strong sermons by Elia Cardinal dalla Costa of Florence in favor of the Allies and condemnatory of the Nazis, against which both German and Republican Fascist radios have inveighed.

Columbia's varsity basketball squad will engage in twenty games during the 1944-45 campaign, it was announced yesterday by Director of Athletics Ralph Furey. The Lions will open their drive on Nov. 29 in a game against Webb Institute at home and conclude their season by meeting Cornell in an Eastern Intercollegiate League test at Ithaca on Feb. 17.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Engineer Command of the United States Ninth Air Force built and restored more than 100 airfields in northern France between D-day, June 6 and Oct. 12, Col. George Mayo, Army Air Forces Engineer, said today. A small group of Air Forces engineers also built eight fields in southern France.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 18 -- In a last desperate effort to hold the Allied forces that have now arrived on the frontiers of Germany in the East and the West, Adolf Hitler decreed today the organization of a Volkssturm, or Home Army, into which will be mobilized all men of the Greater Reich between the ages of 16 and 60 not already engaged in actual military activity.
Miss Ann Helen Van Messel reflects again a lack of faith in the youth of America.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Until the votes have been counted, including those from members of the armed services, there will be no guide to the issues on which the American people will base their impending choice of a President. Even with the statistics in hand, and after careful analysis, the conclusions of one expert will be disputed by another.
Yesterday's Czechoslovak Forces of the Interior communique, as broadcast from the headquarters in Slovak to Europe by the British radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The energy that has been devoted to winning the war will enable this nation in the future to maintain peace in the world, Gov. Walter E. Edge of New Jersey told pioneers in the automobile industry yesterday at the fifth annual meeting and luncheon of the Automobile Old Timers, Inc., at the Hotel Roosevelt.

ROME, Oct. 18 (AP) -- British warships have seized Scarpanto Island, midway between Rhodes and Crete, in the name of the United Nations with landing forces meeting no enemy opposition, the Allied Command announced today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- A series of recent development is declared here to have materially narrowed the odds which, until two weeks ago, strongly favored Governor Dewey to win Illinois' twenty-eight electoral votes in the election of Nov. 7.

MIAMI, Oct. 18 (U.P.) -- Though the Florida West Coast appeared to be the most threatened area Miami Army air field men and women were being evacuated to Hialeah Race Track, which is on high ground fifteen miles inland. Married personnel and civilians were ordered to their homes, as Army and Navy planes took off in stiff winds for inland bases out of the storm's path.

The Nazi supermen in France had four years in which to get set for D-day, 1944. Being extremely methodical supermen, they doubtless considered every possible point of attack and every possible contingency. Just as the modified Schlieffen Plan had got them into France, so they must have had a super-Schlieffen Plan for staying there.

Two USO groups of Negro entertainers, recently returned from six-month tours of Italian and South Pacific theaters of war, gave vivid descriptions of their experiences in an interview at 90 Church Street yesterday. They were unanimous in their belief that the men at the front craved theatrical entertainment to break the ennui between battle action and said audiences showed their appreciation at all times by thunderous applause and laudatory remarks.
WITH UNITED STATES THIRTY-FIFTH INFANTRY DIVISION in France, Oct. 18 (AP) -- "I'll go; I have three kids at home myself," the sergeant said.

There will be legal shooting for deer in New York State starting tomorrow, the catch to this as far as metropolitan sportsmen are concerned being that they will have to travel to the Adirondacks to engage in the sport.

VENRAY, Netherlands, Oct. 18 -- This once neat town of 15,000 inhabitants presented many strange scenes early this afternoon, a few hours after the main German force that held the town had retreated after bitter hand-to-hand fighting in the streets and houses throughout the night and early this morning.

One of the most plentiful foods at present is the sweet potato, for this is the height of the harvest and the crop this year has been especially good. The total output is estimated at 73,435,000 bushels by the United States Department of Agriculture -- a gain of almost a million bushels over last season's yield, and a 9 per cent increase over the ten-year (1933-42) average.

Mrs. Bernard Goldman and Mrs. D.E. Kadison of New York won the women's pair championship in the metropolitan contract bridge tournament at the Park Central Hotel yesterday, with a score of 188.5 match-points. The winners overcame what had seemed to be a commanding lead assumed in them first session by Mrs. Helen Sobel and Mrs. Barbara Collyer Cook New York, who finished second with 187.6.

In his first recital of the season at Carnegie Hall last night, Sidney Foster, young American pianist, showed marked improvement over earlier efforts. In matters of tempi, his playing was more stable and more reliable; and the tone he drew from his piano was more pleasing than on previous occasions. His playing as a whole has taken on poise, authority and stability.

AMERICAN THIRD ARMY FRONT, Somewhere in France, Oct. 16 (Delayed) -- American ordnance is opening the way into Germany for the doughboys. Sleeping on straw in their foxholes they do not know whether they will march on Unter den Linden before Christmas or after Easter, but they are convinced that they have the weapons that will get them to their objective whenever the orders to advance come through from Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's headquarters.

Of all good men, it is the independent voter who most often comes to the aid of the party, strange as it may seem. That is to say, he comes to the aid of the party that is most in need of aid. This is the minority party.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Sale of the controlling interest in The Chicago Daily News to Knight Newspapers, Inc., for $2,150,000 was announced today by executors of the estate of Col. Frank Knox, late Secretary of the Navy and publisher of The News.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- Casualties at the rate of 4,000 a month are being returned to this country by air from overseas, Maj. Gen. David N.W. Grant, Chief Surgeon of the Army Air Forces, disclosed today at the annual meeting of the Inter-State Post-Graduate Medical Association of North America.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Post-war houses closely resembling those of 1941 in design but considerably higher in price, a continued rise in the value of old houses, a slump in prices on industrial properties and a doubling in the value of acreage suitable for development were forecast for Westchester County today at the annual fall conference of the Westchester County Realty Board, held here at the Orienta Beach Club.

The collaboration of designers and the press in promoting among American women the appreciation of new fabric and color combinations, was discussed yesterday during Alma Dettinger's morning broadcast "Other People's Business" over WQXR.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Gov. John W. Bricker asserted tonight that to credit the Roosevelt Administration for winning the war was an "insult" to industry, labor and the armed forces.

One of the most important existing American literary manuscripts was sold at auction last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., for $34,000. It was the original autograph manuscript of Edgar Allan Poe's "The Murders in the Rue Morgue," consigned for sale by the Drexel Institute of Technology in Philadelphia.

Jean Watson, Canadian contralto, was heard in recital last night at Town Hall. Personable, as well as the possessor of a fine and carefully trained voice, the singer already has a following of her own in this city, and at this third of her local appearances in this auditorium she was welcomed by a large and responsive gathering.

Three years of war have left grave new human needs in their wake -- needs that will increase till victory and remain long afterward. These needs are not readily visible. We see the conquering armies and navies advance. We shall see the fighting forces return triumphant.

The railroads, which have performed a "miracle in transportation" during the war, are ready to make their contribution to postwar readjustment and look forward with optimism to the future, Gustav Metzman, newly elected president of the New York Central Railroad and chairman of the Eastern Railroads Presidents Conference, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -Spokesmen for the Office of Price Administration today were adamant in refusing to alter present regulations governing the grading of butter. Herman Greenberg, chief of the war agency's enforcement staff, told a delegation representing butter dealers in New York, Chicago and Philadelphia that proposed amendments to the butter grading schedule would have to be submitted to an industry advisory committee for approval before OPA could consider making any changes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The question-and-answer session this week at which Edward R. Stettinius, Under-Secretary of State, explained the Dumbarton Oaks security program to representatives of political, professional, church and other organizations, was an example of recognition being accorded by the State Department to public opinion in foreign affairs.

ANTWERP, Oct. 18 -- After completing the "squeeze play" that forced the Germans out of the east side of the Breskens pocket, the Canadians advanced today from south of Ijzendijke toward Oostburg, which is directly in the center of the pocket. The fighting was heavy to the north, but elsewhere it slackened off.

To aid in satisfying civilian demands, cotton textile mills plan to purchase all goods in process at time of contract terminations, it was reported in Worth Street yesterday. Not only will reconversion to full civilian production be a comparatively simple matter, it was stated, but mills will have a very substantial volume of goods to begin full-scale normal selling.

In a proclamation which confesses his military and political bankruptcy, Adolf Hitler, self-styled Fuehrer of all Germans, who set out to conquer the world for the German "master race," has now appealed to the German people to rise in one last mobilization of young and old to defend the borders of their own land.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -Newbold Noyes Jr., war correspondent of The Evening Star, submitted to its business office today the following expense account, covering his first twenty-four hours in Athens, which is plagued by currency inflation:

The first of 2,000 tickets to be distributed among service men and women in this vicinity for the "Night of Stars" production, went yesterday to seven young women representing the Waves, Wacs, Spars and Marines. Mrs. Julius Ochs Adler, co-chairman of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, and Mrs. Leo Spitz, women's division chairman of "Night of Stars," made the presentation at the organization's headquarters, 99 Park Avenue.
NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 18 -- Former Gov. Charles Edison will not campaign for President Roosevelt, nor will he disclose how he intends to vote, he said tonight.

In recent months there has been a revival in American newspapers and magazines of the question, "Is there an organized anti-Nazi underground movement within Germany?" and much speculation regarding the reasons for the lack of Allied support of this movement.
Following is the text of Governor Dewey's speech as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WITH THE BRITISH SECOND ARMY, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The great decisive battles of the war in Europe may be fought this year west of the Rhine, provided the Allies get an even break in the weather, a British staff officer told correspondents tonight.

The New York City chapter of the Natonal Lawyers Guild, meeting last night in the Park Central Hotel, accepted a list of candidates for judicial offices drawn up by its board of directors. The meeting voted to raise a listing of "qualified" to "endorsed" in the case of Irving L. Levey, a Democratic and American Labor party candidate for the Supreme Court in New York County.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- Buying of rye futures by brokers who frequently act for cash interests and reports that further imports from Canada had been banned as the result of a scarcity of storage room at leading lake ports led today to an advance of around l 3/4 cents a bushel to a new high since last July.

Proceedings to deny probate to the will of Miss Josephine Lachat, who died at the age of 93, ended dramatically yesterday when Surrogate James A. Foley refused to accept an instrument that would have given virtually all of the aged spinster's $80,000 estate to Clyde Limbaugh, assistant manager of the Hotel Alexandria, 250 West 103d Street, where Miss Lachat was a guest at the time of her death last Dec. 23.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 18 -Sol Lesser, who produced "Stage Door Canteen" in conjunction with the American Theatre Wing, has announced that he will make a picture, "Canteen in Paris," based on the Wing's center for service men to be conducted in that city.

The North Atlantic Division of the Corps of Engineers has established an average record of settling termination claims "within two months and two days" after notice of termination has been sent out by the agency to war contractors, Maj. E.L. Story, chief of the department's contract termination branch, announced yesterday.

Impetus will be given to union organizational activities among office and clerical employes with the return of war workers into offices and plants engaged in civilian production, it was asserted yesterday by James P. Mitchell, director of industrial relations, R.H. Macy Co., Inc., at the office management conference of the American Management Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

This evening Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, long famous through their connection with musical hits, will enter the producing field when they present a straight comedy, "I Remember Mama," at the Music Box. As a composer-writer team they will not be forgotten for turning out "Oklahoma!"
LONDON, Oct. 18 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 18 -- The German-language Nazi newspaper Deutsche La Plata Zeitung, which, together the Italian-language Fascist newspaper Mattino d'Italia, was permanently closed by a Government decree yesterday, underwent a metamorphosis overnight and reappeared this morning in Spanish under the name Gaceta de la Plata.

The stock market bridged yesterday with a broad advance the gap that had separated it from the high levels of August. Noteworthy more for the scope of the rally rather than the size of the gains, the average price did not hold at the previous peaks, although the final level was so close as to be negligible.

Raymond Loewy, industrial designer, declared yesterday that "any designer can draw up plans for a post-war kitchen sink equipped with all kinds of fantastic gadgets that will cost a few thousand dollars and be limited to a strictly Park Avenue market."

At its annual meeting on Nov. 20 in the board of Governors room of the New York Stock Exchange the Association of Stock Exchange Firms will elect a board of governors and a nominating committee for the coming year. Nominations follow:

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- Two of the most urgent problems for the revival of French industry are transports and coal. They are closely related since the lack of an adequate coal supply is attributable chiefly to the lack of transports for mine props and for coal.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allies Expeditionary Force, Oct. 18 -- Boy still meets girl as the United States Army moves into Germany -- but not on a social basis. American soldiers are not allowed to go out with German frauleins.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Harry Woodring of Kansas, former Secretary of War, became a storm center in absentia today as Senators Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan and James M. Tunnell, Democrat, of Delaware battled over his non-appearance as a witness before the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The War Production Board has permitted 1,110 manufacturers to resume civilian production under the so-called "spot authorization" procedure since that measure was made part of the Government's reconversion program two months ago, it was learned today.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 18 (AP) -Roland W. Bush, Farm Credit Admininstration examiner of Houston, Tex., announced his resignation today and charged in a statement that an examination made of an unnamed Federal bank for cooperatives was being suppressed "until after the November election for political reasons."

As a result of an increasing number of complaints in recent weeks about failure of landlords during the fall season to comply with regulations governing painting and redecorating of apartments, the Office of Price Administration has reassigned 100 OPA rent employes in the seven area rent offices in the metropolitan district to supplement the regular staff processing tenants' protests on this score, Daniel P. Woolley, Regional OPA Administrator, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -Veterans of the present war will be able to obtain guaranteed loans for the purchase of homes after an appraisal of the property to determine its "reasonable normal value."

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- Every vestige of the Nazi state will be washed out of existence by the Allied Military Government in Germany under a program whose scope and complexity are without parallel in history. Germany will revert to her 1932 way of life, as it was before Adolf Hitler attained power, if the scheme works out as planned.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine and Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins issued a joint statement yesterday warning that the members of the Police Department have received orders to issue a court summons to the owner of any dog found on the street unleashed.

The nation's crude oil production last week averaged 4,726,550 barrels daily, an increase of 35,000 over the 4,691,550 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 18,050 barrels more than the recommendation of 4,708,500 daily for October by the Petroleum Administrator for War.

"Arsenic and Old Lace" will have played to a record attendance of more than 453,000 persons when it completes its seven-week engagement at the Strand tonight, it was estimated yesterday by the management. That film also holds the distinction of having played a longer stand at the Strand than any picture to have been shown there since the inception of the theatre's stage and the screen policy in 1938.

A national Educators for Roosevelt Committee consisting of sixty college presidents, deans, professors and school administrators was announced yesterday. The group, headed by Prof. Alonzo F. Myers of New York University, has arranged a meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania for the evening of Oct. 30.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 18 -- Campaigning in Bergen County today for the election of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, the Republican Presidential candidate, Gov. Walter E. Edge of New Jersey and Gov. Simeon S. Willis of Kentucky struck at what the New Jersey Chief Executive called "an unholy alliance" of New Dealers, Communists and city machine bosses.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Thursday, Oct. 19 (AP) -- A communique:

Russek's show of "Collection Caviar" yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel offered fashions that were glamorous but not too the-atrical for popular consumption. Colors were flattering, silhouettes were simple, and beaded trims showed restraint.
Following is the text of the decree by Adolf Hitler setting up a German Home Army (Volkssturm), as broadcast today and recorded by the Office of War Information:

The Johns-Manville Corporation and its subsidiaries showed consolidated net earnings of $3,911,076 in the first nine months of this year, equivalent, after preferred dividend requirements, to $4.55 a share of common stock, the report of Lewis H. Brown, president, disclosed yesterday.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 18 -- Pacific Fleet carrier planes roared over northern Luzon in the Philippines yesterday to attack shipping and installations in the ninth day of the war's most sustained carrier task force operation. Seven more ships were sunk or damaged and another nineteen planes destroyed, one of them in the air.

An investment banking group headed by Mellon Securities Corporation and the First Boston Corporation, as joint managers, won yesterday the award of $130,000,000 of first and refunding 2 3/4 per cent bonds of the Philadelphia Electric Company.

MONTREAL, Oct. 18 (U.P.) -- Asserting that the United States had imperialistic sentiments toward Latin-American countries, Vincente Lombardo Toledano, president of the Latin American Confederation of Workers, said at a press conference today that many Latin-American countries had been the victims of the "imperialistic aggression of the United States."
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 18 -In the same breath, Lieut. Col. Earl Blaik, Army football coach, said today: "We are sorely in need of opposition" and "we picked a tartar in Duke."

Recommendations were made from the bench in the Court of Special Sessions yesterday for an investigation of conditions in the Women's House of Detention, Sixth Avenue and Tenth Street, as well as a "house cleaning." This severe criticism of the jail management came after Sarah Moore, 30 years old, a Negro, had been convicted of attacking Mrs. Thora LeFevre, a captain of attaches there.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Asserting that "we cannot afford to install a new Commander in Chief at this stage of the game," Senator Harry S. Truman told a Democratic rally here tonight:

Manker Realty Corporation has sold the six-story apartment building at 731 Gerard Avenue, the Bronx, to Vogel Estates, Inc. The property contains seventy-two apartments and occupies an irregular plot approximately 239 by 144 feet.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The expanding requirements of the country's police radio service, the major importance of that service, and its claims to priority in the determination and provision of essential facilities were urged by chiefs of police and other law enforcement officers at the opening today before the Federal Communications Commission of hearings on this phase of the problem of post-war allocation of frequencies in the radio field.

The six-story loft building at 15-23 Waverly Place, at the northeast corner of Greene Street, has been purchased by an operating syndicate headed by Alexander Hirsch. The property, an old holding of the Wadsworth family, comprises a plot of 19,000 square feet.

Lieut. Van T. Barfoot, 25 years old, of Carthage, Miss., winner of the nation's highest award, the Congressional Medal of Honor, for outstanding heroism, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday on an Air Transport Command plane from Europe.

LONDON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Old men and boys -- and "if need be women and girls" -- were ordered to defend Germany with guns, swords, pitchforks, scythes and clubs as Adolf Hitler proclaimed tonight the formation of the Volkssturm or Home Army for a last-ditch defense of the Reich.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- By adoption, on a 5 to 1 vote, of the Anglo-Soviet Trade Union Committee report, the Trades Union Congress, which represents some 10,000,000 British workers, today linked the German people with their leaders in responsibility for atrocities committed by the Nazis.

Two youths, charged with the recent thefts of furs valued at $35,000 and men's clothing valued at $1,900, were held in $50,000 bail each yesterday in Bronx Magistrates Court, where they pleaded not guilty to a burglary charge. A further hearing will be held on Oct. 25.

ALBANY, Oct. 18 -- Declaring that Sidney Hillman and Earl Browder had taken over control of the Democratic party, Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, told two audiences here tonight that the future of America was at stake and the people must elect Governor Dewey and the entire Republican ticket if the democratic way of life was to continue.

The need for individual care and attention for babies and almost total lack of understanding of this need in group care is revealed in a three-month study of services to children under the age of 2 by the Child Welfare League of America.
AT RIFLE COMPANY HEADQUARTERS in Aachen, Oct. 18 -- Block by block Aachen is being wrested from the Germans in a bitter battle fought in the midst of the ruined city.

Joseph B. Elliott of Schick, Inc., Stamford, Conn., has been promoted to vice president in charge of sales and advertising. L.H. Simmonds has been appointed vice resident and general manager of Schick Service, Inc.

The Victor Metal Products Company has leased approximately 30,000 square feet of space in the ground floor, basement and second floor of 291-295 Greenpoint Avenue, Brooklyn, from the 295 Rockaway Avenue Corporation. Frank R. Fischer was the broker in the transaction.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (U.P.) -The Senate campaign expenditures committee voted 4 to 1 today to forego a formal investigation of the "battle of the Statler," deciding that nothing could be gained by delving further into the brawl between two naval officers and members of the AFL teamsters union.

An advantage that marks man-made fabric fibers is that their production can be controlled scientifically so that the quality remains the same every day, every year, Margaret Fuller of Textron, Inc., told an audience of women shoppers last evening in the drapery department of Wanamaker's.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Secretary of the Navy James V. Forrestal released today the following table summarizing losses inflicted upon the Japanese by the United States Third and Fifth Fleets, as reported in Navy communiques:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -Planes and anti-aircraft guns of the United States Third and Fifth Fleets in the Pacific have destroyed 3,080 Japanese aircraft in the past four and a half months, and 905 enemy ships, exclusive of small craft, have been sunk or damaged in the same period, Secretary of the Navy James V. Forrestal announced today in a roundup of the Pacific war.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically from Bucharest and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 18 -- Provisions of the Surplus Property Act which became effective this month were criticized today by Ernest L. Olrich, assistant to the secretary of the treasury in the Office of Surplus Property.
Tuesday's communique, as broadcast in English by the Free Yugoslav wireless and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, Thursday, Oct. 19 -- The Red Army, surging southward through seven passes over the high Carpathian Mountains, has entered Czechoslovakia on a 171-mile front and has battled across the country's eastern tip to link with Russian forces in Hungarian-annexed Transylvania, Premier Joseph Stalin announced last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Government officials and members of the cotton industry have reached an agreement, after two days of closed meetings, on the "guiding principles" to be observed in determining a "fair and equitable" post-war export price for surplus cotton under provisions of the Surplus Property Disposal Act, informed sources disclosed today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Statistics usually are dull reading, and evidently those amazing Cleveland Rams, a paradox in the National Football League today, don't bother to peruse them.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18 (AP) -Johnny Butler, left halfback of the Car-Pitts, National Football League team, was suspended, indefinitely tonight, the management announced, after he failed to report for practice.

The Federal Telephone and Radio Corporation, manufacturing affiliate of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, announced yesterday that it had received from the Columbia Broadcasting System an order to build and install a new television transmitter to be operated atop the Chrysler Building.

Concrete proposals for the disposition of surplus American merchant tonnage after the war were advanced yesterday at two of the ten round table panel discussions that comprised the opening day of the three-day eighteenth annual meeting of the Propeller Club of the United States and the American Merchant Marine Conference in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ON THIRD UNITED STATES ARMY FRONT, Oct. 18 -- This correspondent was present in the fire-control point in the cellar of an old French farmhouse this evening when a German battery five miles away got a taste of a new kind of American artillery fire.
What may be the first case of a serviceman successfully taking advantage of a provision in the GI Bill of Rights permitting an appeal of a dishonorable discharge was disclosed here yesterday.
