ROME, Oct. 18 (U.P.) -- American troops, in probably the most intense and concentrated fighting in all Europe, pushed today to within about seven miles of Bologna in the face of fierce artillery fire and fierce German resistance, while in the Adriatic sector Eighth Army forces began closing a pincers on the rich industrial Po Valley city of Cesena.

Bonwit Teller gave an audience of fashion writers a glimpse into post-war days when it exhibited yesterday morning a helicopter -one that has already made a record for itself in demonstration flights -- plus five costumes that the store recommends for women pilots.

Current high corporation taxes and incomes should not be the sole motive for installing employe-pension plans, as such plans are usually poorly conceived and are abandoned when income drops, C.P. Dawson, pension counselor of C.P. Dawson Co., said last night at the meeting of the Metropolitan Controllers Association at the Town Hall Club.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Mrs. R.H. Heighe's Adroit won the $10,000 added W.P. Burch Memorial Handicap at Laurel Park today, a length and a half in front of a three-way photo for second money. Col. C.V. Whitney's Big Push was second, William Helis' Salto third and Christopher T. Chenery's Hornbeam fourth.

The old Shattuck family home at 19 Washington Square North, the scene more than two decades ago of one of the most sensational robberies in the city's police history, will be converted into an apartment house, it became known yesterday.
BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 18 -The first organized military challenge to the Hungarian regime of Ferenc Szalasi in Budapest was issued to the Nazis this morning.

Winners in the twenty-sixth O. Henry Memorial Prize Story awards are: Irwin Shaw of Brooklyn, who won the first prize of $300 for "Walking Wounded"; Bessie Breuer of New York City, second prize of $200 for "Home Is a Place"; Griffith Beems of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, third prize of $100 for "The Stagecoach."

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Until Government "puts a speedy end to wasteful spending, deficit borrowing and excessive taxation," there can be no "sustained recovery," Gov. Dwight H. Green of Illinois said today to the Mortgage Bankers Association, now holding its annual conference on war and post-war problems here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -Abe J. Greene, president of the National Boxing Association, said today he had called upon Juan Zurita, lightweight champion, and Sal Bartolo, featherweight king, to "prepare for a proper defense of your titles -- and soon."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Maj. Gen. Julian C. Smith of the United States Marine Corps, who commanded the expeditionary troops, both Marines and Army, in the Palau invasion, today gave unstinted credit to the Japanese for having built up "unbelievably strong" fortifications and executing a "master plan of defense" in the Palau group.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 18 -- A tropical hurricane which ravaged Cuba today moved on to offer a dangerous threat to the southwest Florida coast tonight. Leaving a trail of death, injury and destruction in Havana and outlying areas, the hurricane whipped into the Gulf of Mexico, pursuing a northward course, and tonight was reported by the Weather Bureau to be centered about sixty miles northwest of Key West.

ATHENS, Oct. 18 (U.P.) -- The exiled Greek Government came home today to a rejoicing population, free again after three and a half terrible years of German occupation, during which 200,000 persons died of starvation and 15,000 were executed in Athens alone.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Communique 193:

The suppression of an Italian language newspaper and a German language newspaper by the Argentine Government undoubtedly will be pointed to by Government spokesmen as evidence of their intention to live up to their hemisphere commitments and as an implementation of Argentina's severance of relations with the Axis.
Two years ago last March, as he landed in Australia from the Philippines, Gen. Douglas MacArthur sent the Filipinos a message.

LONDON, Oct. 19 (U.P.) -- Bloody clashes tonight were reported sweeping all Hungary with a crisis gathering swiftly in Budapest where the Szalasi puppet government, supported by German troops using Tiger tanks in pitched battles with rebellious army units, struggled vainly to get control ninety-six hours after its Putsch.

A two-hour practice session was the lot of the New York Football Giants yesterday. They went through this grueling rehearsal at the Polo Grounds, where they will play their first home game of the National Football League season on Sunday, against the combined Chicago Cardinal-Pittsburgh Steeler eleven now known as the Car-Pitts.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 19 -- Dennis O'Keefe has been signed by Hal Wallis to play the fourth member of a quartet of suitors of Joan Fontaine in the comedy, "The Affairs of Susan." The picture, based on an original screen story, "Chameleon," by Lazlo Gorog and Thomas Monroe, will go into production at Paramount on Monday, with William Seiter directing.

Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was not very active yesterday, although the undertone was about steady and prices at the close were 3 points lower to 8 points higher than on Wednesday. The market held within a 6-point range.
GENERAL MACARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS in the Philippines, Friday, Oct. 20 (Army radio pool broadcast) -- American invasion of the Philippines was officially proclaimed today by Gen. Douglas MacArthur.

The Caterpillar Tractor Company, in its report covering operations for the nine months ended with September, announced yesterday a net profit of $5,546,986 on net sales of $167,226,700. Net profit for the first nine months of last year was $5,949,169 on sales of $125,777,471.
LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

Jan Karski's "Story of a Secret State," an account of the Polish underground, and George and Helen W. Papashvily's "Anything Can Happen," the story of a Russian immigrant, have been named the Book-of-the-Month Club's dual selection for January.

The stock market developed yesterday the push necessary to break through the August highs and to within striking range of the four-year peaks set last July. Activity diminished in the final hour, however, and the list backed away slightly from its top levels of the day.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 19 -- The State Department declared today that the United States Government took part "at all stages" in the formulation of the Armistice Agreement with Rumania and stated that Governor Dewey had omitted facts in discussing the surrender terms for Rumania in his speech on foreign policy in New York last night.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 19 -- On the eve of Navy's departure tomorrow to play Georgia Tech at Atlanta on Saturday, Comdr. Oscar (Swede) Hagberg expressed the opinion tonight that "if we can shake off the label of being an unlucky team we'll do all right."

Four fashionably dressed, middle-aged women and the husband of one of them were released in bail yesterday in Special Sessions to await trials on grand jury "informations" accusing them of being common gamblers and maintaining gambling establishments last summer in the upper midtown district. All had pleaded not guilty.

DETROIT, Oct. 19 (U.P.) -- The CIO United Rubber Workers cut short a strike of 500 members tonight when it levied fines totaling $6,000 on the group for engaging in a work-stoppage at the United States Rubber Company.

LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- British troops advancing southward from captured Venray ploughed 3 1/2 miles deeper into the German Meuse River bridgehead in the Netherlands today and, with a strong American force, converged upon the key town of Amerika, astride one of the main railroads leading eastward into Germany's industrial northern Rhineland.

A new campaign guide to advertisers and media for the 1945 American Red Cross fund-raising drive has been released by the War Advertising Council in cooperation with the Office of War Information and the Red Cross, it was announced yesterday.

Two exceedingly rare Greek marble statues of the late fourth or early third century B.C., showing something of the influence of the great Greek sculptor Praxiteles, have been acquired by the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
Due to manpower shortages and transportation problems, more than fifty New York and Brooklyn department stores have decided to open this year's Christmas shopping season on Nov. 8,

In its first request for textiles for the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, the procurement division of the Treasury Department asked yesterday for 8,288,000 yards of woolens for the last quarter of this year and 14,000,000 yards for the first quarter of 1945.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Miss Margaret Nichols of Hudson River, the organization's "duration" champion, won low-gross honors with 45, 45 -- 90 over Winged Foot's wind-swept east course today in the post-season one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association.

There is a well-authenticated story in Wall Street that, at a luncheon earlier this year, an informal investigator for the State Department asked financial leaders what steps would be necessary to induce American money to go into foreign countries to aid in world reconstruction.

Still seeking its initial victory, and its first touchdown as well, the New York University football team clashes with Boston College tonight in Fenway Park, the Hub. The Eagles have broken even in two contests.
The Philippine Islands, now under attack by American forces, are a key to the South China Sea and an island bulwark lying athwart some of the most direct approaches to the Asiatic mainland.

Followers of the football fortunes of the Tigers in the National League are hopeful that their favorites will still become a power in the loop, following the report released at the club's headquarters yesterday. It was revealed that the Tigers were trying to acquire Sid Luckman for the remainder of the season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Army casualties on the Western land front, from the invasion on June 6 through Oct. 3, numbered 174,780. Air Force casualties are not included in this figure as announced today by the War Department.

ANTWERP, Oct. 19 -- The fall of Breskens appears imminent. Canadian First Army troops who made a daring beachhead landing on the east side of the now famous pocket below the Schelde estuary are less than two miles from Breskens' guns guarding the entrance to the port of Antwerp.

PENNSVILLE, N.J., Oct. 19 -- Lieut. Col. Leslie B. Cooper, 50 years old, of Paoli, Pa., nationally known as a helicopter expert, was one of the five army men killed last night when a twin-engined training plane crashed and burst into flames in a field near here.

BUFFALO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today that American women should help prevent future wars and create the kind of government which "will meet the needs of those who fought the war and will furnish leadership and an example to other nations in the post-war world."

Ralph G. Ortiz has purchased the two-family dwelling with a store at 649 Prospect Avenue, the Bronx, which he contemplates using as a funeral parlor after extensive alterations. The property, assessed at $9,500, was bought from the trustees of the estate and property of the Diocesan Convention of New York. Henry Waltemade, Inc., was the broker.

New York member banks of the Federal Reserve System went through a most uneven and unsettled week, according to a report by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York on the period ended on Wednesday. For several weeks there has been a sizable outflow of funds from New York, but last week this was reversed and money began to flow back, possibly in connection with some of the big security flotations.

Federal legislation to make post-war home building easier, was predicted by United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, in an address last night before the Metropolitan League of Savings and Loan Associations at a dinner in the Hotel McAlpin.

A verbal bouquet to the "average housewife" for her skill as the purchasing agent of the American family was tossed yesterday by a Columbia University professor who said that college classes in economics could learn much from the housewife when it came to shrewdness and wisdom in buying.
Grocers throughout the city were again selling sugar in five-pound lots yesterday as a resut of replenishment of local stocks which had been depleted during the home canning season.
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 19 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for the United States Senate asserted here tonight that President Roosevelt was making a tour of metropolitan New York on Saturday in a "last minute attempt" to save New York for himself and Senator Robert F. Wagner on election day.

With 320 tons of spoiled Government-held prunes awaiting a buyer, the War Food Administration said yesterday that the loss of food through spoilage since the start of lend-lease in March, 1941, amounted to $1 out of every $5,000 worth of food handled.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- On the basis of experience in working on Government buildings, Miss Gladys Miller, interior decoration consultant for the Public Buildings Administration, thinks the household fabrics shortage is far more serious than most persons realize.
Wednesday's communique, as transmitted by the Swedish Telegraph Vews Bureau to the Swedish press and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Two General Staff committees have been appointed to study and prepare regulations and policies affecting reserve components of the post-war Army, the War Department said today.

The Tokyo radio reported yesterday that an Allied task force had launched an air attack and naval bombardment on an island in the Nicobar group in the Indian Ocean on Tuesday and that fighting continued through yesterday morning. The broadcast, directed in English to the United States was recorded by the Federal Communications Commission.

Describing the last year as the greatest in the organization's history, Lieut. Gen. James G. Harbord, chairman of the New York Chapter of the Red Cross, warned that Red Cross work must continue, however, after the defeat of Germany and Japan.
