ST. LOUIS, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The excess-profits tax on corporations appears to be headed for the scrap heap after the war, a Treasury official said today.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Army newspaper CBI Round-Up answered today criticism by Ann Sheridan, Joe E. Brown and Paulette Goddard, film stars, of a recent editorial asserting that they cut short their entertainment tours in "overseas theatres."

A while ago Jule Marshall of Larchmont read here about forest fires and sent along a booklet issued by the Wisconsin Conservation Department in which it was emphasized that 30 per cent of last year's fires were caused by smokers.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS N THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Oct. 19 -- What has at last become one of the most elaborate and best trained military precision machines in the world and one that is perhaps unique in the history of warfare was built up for the long, hard push into the philippines under the leadership of Gen. Douglas MacArthur.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The General Time Instruments Corporation, New York, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 38,380 shares of 4 1/4 per cent $100 par value cumulative preferred stock.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Oct. 19 (U.P.) -- Given up for dead, Flight Lieut. Arthur H. Ross Jr. of the Royal Canadian Air Force, came home today to the infant son he never expected to see again and his young wife who had never given up hope.

LONDON, Oct. 19 (U.P.) -- More than 1,000 American heavy bombers, flying through temperatures ranging to 50 degrees below zero, hammered Mainz, Mannheim and Ludwigshafen through clouds today in a 120-mile southward extension of an Allied air offensive apparently designed to paralyze all major rail centers of the German Rhineland.

Edgar Allan Poe copy which fetches four dollars a word and Charles Dickens' writings which bring in only four cents a word -- it is not the picture most people have of the relative earning capacity of the two men.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 19 -- The world premiere of the new American comedy, "The Late George Apley," written by John P. Marquand and George S. Kaufman and based on the former's 1938 Pulitzer prize-winning novel, took place in the Playhouse here tonight before a capacity audience.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- In a letter made public today Bishop Marcel Theas of Montauban expresses "painful emotion" aroused by sentences passed by military courts in France in connection with the "purge" now proceeding. In doing so he has drawn nation-wide attention to one of the most serious problems facing the Provisional Government.

Two merchant seamen, veterans of two years' service, were sent to prison yesterday by Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum after admitting the theft of two carbines from soldiers preparing to take part in the European invasion last June. According to Robert Mitchell, Assistant United States Attorney, the thefts forced two soldiers to go ashore without weapons.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in New Guinea, Friday, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur issued his regular communique today, describing a heavy aerial bombardment of Mindanao.

Expressing his gratification at the strengthening of the cultural relations between the Soviet Union and the United States, Andrei Gromyko, Russian Ambassador to this country, predicted last night, at a dinner of the American Russian Institute at the Hotel Commodore, that the tendency of the two peoples to study each other's national culture and scientific achievements would grow stronger and stronger.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Senator O'Mahoney of Wyoming, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, predicted today that a Democratic majority would be maintained in the Senate Nov. 7 and in a statement made this analysis of contests outside the South:

A program of exceptional significance for its values and contrasts in the most flexible and brilliant playing that the orchestra, returning to its former excellences under Dr. Rodzinski, has done since he took charge, and the presence of Yehudi Menuhin as soloist in the performance of the Mendelssohn violin concerto, distinguished the concert of the Philharmonic in Carnegie Hall last night.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The text of President Roosevelt's statement on the landing in the Philippine Islands:

ALBANY, Oct. 19 -- Before leaving tonight for a major address in Pittsburgh tomorrow, Governor Dewey issued a statement approving the State Department's warning to Germany against acts of terrorism and extermination of victims of Nazi aggression still held in German concentration camps.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Mrs. J. Borden Harriman, former Ambassador to Norway, asserted tonight that "it is surprising that Republican spokesmen like Mrs. Luce continue to insult the American people by misstatements and distortions of the records of the two parties on foreign affairs."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 14 were 898,650 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 20,708 cars, or 2.4 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 13,698 cars, or 1.5 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 2,601 cars, or 0.3 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- W. L. Clayton, Federal Surplus War Property Administrator, challenged in a speech tonight the ability of Governor Dewey, if elected, to carry out his personal pledge to continue Secretary Hull's reciprocal trade program in the face of historic and continued Republican opposition.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, called last night for the election of President Roosevelt, Vice Presidential candidate Harry S. Truman, and Senator Robert F. Wagner, but instructed 3,000 dressmaker union members to return them on the Liberal party ticket to strengthen the growth of a national liberal labor party.

Massachusetts Investors Trust in its report for the quarter ended Sept. 30, showed net assets of $152,541,277 or $21.97 a share against $140,643,966 or $20.64 a share last year. The number of outstanding shares rose from 6,813,108 to 6,942,970.

DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 19 -- James M. Cox, who was the Democratic nominee for the Presidency in 1920, charged tonight that the forces which directed the "conspiracy" against the League of Nations still control the Republican party and asked that all who desire security and peace support Franklin D. Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Department store sales in the week ended Oct. 14 were 16 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following table gives percentage changes from like periods of last year:

LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Churchill Government is aiding in a widespread campaign to boost sales of British goods in post-war markets all over the world, Harcourt Johnstone, Secretary of the Department of Overseas Trade, declared today.

Few could possibly have emulated your overseas correspondent Milton Bracker in making such a perfect diagnosis of the problems attending the liberation of Greece. He has pointed up succinctly and accurately the whole sorry story in his recent cables following the arrival of British troops in southern Greece.

I must take exception to one or two of the points made by the writer of your editorial "Mr. Whoo." I particularly object to the characterization of the screech owl's call as exemplifying merely "the enormity of the bird's lack of musical ability." The screech owl is a victim of an unfortunate association.

Something had to be done about it the telephone at Ballard School, 610 Lexington Avenue. Just about every night at dinner time it would ring and a masculine voice would ask in harried tones, "What's the best way to devil a crab?" or "How do I make horseradish sauce?"

The Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations "proved its worth" by helping to bring out what may be a larger registration than 1940 and its next big task is to translate this registration into votes for President Roosevelt on election day, Sidney Hillman, chairman of PAC, declared last night.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 19 -- Parallel columns of British and American tanks, driving through incessant rain and soggy Netherland fields, closed in today toward Venlo, on the great bend of the Meuse River thirty miles east of Eindhoven, and major junction of the main railway from the Ruhr and Rhineland industrial areas to Eindhoven.

ROME, Oct. 19 -- For the second time in five months, the Mediterranean staff of The Stars and Stripes has lost a man in action. He was Staff Sgt. Alfred M. Kohn of Miami Beach, Fla., and if it had not been for his own insistence on a front-line assignment he probably would still be holding down a desk job as managing editor of the Rome edition.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 19 -- The Gaceta de la Plata, successor to the suppressed Deutsche la Plata Zeitung, did not appear this morning. So far as is known, however, its non-appearance was not due to Government action, no measure against it has been announced.

A well-paced showing that covered a wide variety of tastes and needs was staged yesterday at the luncheon hour by Franklin Simon, in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. There were debonair things for the debutante, dignified styles for the matron and smart and wearable things for the average woman of indefinite age who can wear anything that is good looking providing it meets with the demands of her type.
PARIS. Oct. 19 -- It is expected that Gen. Charles de Gaulle will soon make another appeal against what some call the problem of "anarchy" in regions where the writ of government does not yet run.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Effective tomorrow clearing house members of the Board of Trade will have to report all net commitments of 25,000 bushels or more in December rye to the commodity exchange division of the Department of Agriculture.

FRESNO, Calif., Oct. 19 (U.P.) -- Gov. John W. Bricker closed his California campaign tonight with a blast at President Roosevelt who, he said, has violated almost every pledge in the 1932 Democratic platform during his twelve-year administration.

MOSCOW, Oct. 19 -- Leaders of the Soviet-sponsored Polish Committee of National Liberation have reached a tentative understanding with Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk of the London Government in Exile, and a spokesman for M. Mikolajczyk's delegation said: ...

ALBANY, Oct. 19 -- Beardsley Ley Ruml, treasurer of R.H. Macy Co., told educators at the closing session of the convocation of the University of the State of New York that Americans could easily turn their organizing and administrative talents to the inventing of a travel program for boys and girls.

In gratitude for his friendship in this "most tragic hour" of Poland's history, President Wladyslaw Raszkiewiez of the Government of the Polish Republic in Exile in London has awarded to the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, the Grand Commander's Cross with Star of the Order of Polonia Restituta, which was presented yesterday by Ambassador Jan Ciechanowski of Poland in its consulate, 149 East Sixty-seventh Street.

The four Commissioners of Elections, who divided on party lines on a proposal to ask Governor Dewey for a special legislative session to lengthen voting hours on election day, were invited yesterday to attend a special meeting of the City Council at which the same proposition will be raised.

The Atlantic Coast Line Company (holding company) announced yesterday the declaration of a year-end dividend of $2 a share, payable Dec. 12. This dividend will bring payments this year to the 1943 total of $3.50 a share.
LONDON, Oct. 19 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WOODBURY, N.J., Oct. 19 -- Mrs. Mary Fraley, 28 years old, the wife of Oscar Fraley, a sports writer on the staff of The United Press Association in New York, and a woman companion were injured fatally today in an automobile accident involving three machines near here.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed increase in holdings of United States Government securities and note circulation for the system as a whole to be $70,946,000 and $65, 114,000, respectively, while gold holdings decreased $9,000,000.

When Hitler brought "peace in our time" to a treacherous end in March, 1939, by invading the Czechoslovak Republic he set up the "independent" state of Slovakia, taking in a little over one-fourth of the republic's area and about one-sixth of its population. This was in accord with his policy of creating as much disunity as possible everywhere he could.

The Board of Estimate endorsed yesterday a proposal by the Board of Education to provide four bowling alleys as part of the recreational equipment of a new public school to be constructed in Queens and to operate them on a fee basis for the benefit of adults.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The important northwest Burma town of Tiddim has been captured by Indian troops after an air attack that smashed Japanese defenses covering the northern approaches, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's command announced today.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The Germans have gone back on their word to treat members of the Polish Home Army captured when Warsaw ceased fighting on Oct. 3 as prisoners of war and have begun mass executions of Poles in the Oswiecim and Brzezinka concentration camps, according to the Polish Government in London.

LONDON, Friday, Oct. 20 -- The Red Army has invaded East Prussia, capturing at least one German town in "one of the war's bloodiest struggles," Berlin said last night, while Moscow reported that other Soviet forces had cracked the German defense line south of Debrecen, Hungary's third city, and seized more than 11,000 prisoners.

The inductive train telephone has now been developed to the state where it should meet practically all railroad requirements, W.R. Triem, general superintendent of telegraph of the Pennsylvania Railroad, declared in an address last night before the New York Railroad Club in the Engineering Societies Building.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 19 -- Representative Clare Boothe Luce, critic of the Political Action Committee, gave her version today of an incident that led an official of the committee to charge that she had sought its support and was vexed because she did not get it.

Bringing up children is a common bond and basis for friendship, Mrs. Clara Savage Littledale, editor of Parents Magazine, said yesterday at the presentation of a child-care library to be sent to mothers and fathers of the Soviet Union by the Committee of Women of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship.

Department stores and specialty shops in Greater New York and Newark are cooperating with THE NEW YORK TIMES in contributing to the collection of typical American fashions shown throughout "Fashions of The Times," scheduled for presentation in The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, on Oct. 24, 25, 26, 27.

VENRAY, the Netherlands, Oct. 19 -- Amid the menacing bursts of German mortar shells and the roar of British artillery fire, 3,300 mentally deficient Netherland civilians, including 1,700 women, were taken out of harm's way today.

Asserting that liquid assets of individuals and corporations in the United States will amount to $189,900,000,000 by the close of 1944 and will reach a much higher level by the end of the war and the early post-war period, the Federal Reserve Bulletin for October declares that a decrease immediately following the war is not so likely as it was after World War I.

SEATTLE, Oct. 19 -- Senator Harry S. Truman pledged President Roosevelt tonight to sponsor private industry's use of the Government's $20,000,000,000 worth of war plants and to the completion of Government power projects to provide "the nucleus for a great prosperity for the entire nation."

An investing client of Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., has bought from the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company the apartment building at 53 West Seventy-second Street containing eight stores, several offices and fifty-six apartments.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Proponents of recognition of General de Gaulle were encouraged to believe today that his de facto authority would soon be recognized as the Provisional Government of France in view of reports that Prime Minister Churchill favors this course.

Eighty-five years old today, Dr. John Dewey, this country's foremost philosopher and scholar, will celebrate his birthday quietly with only a few members of his immediate family present. Essentially the day will be like any other, Dr. Dewey said yesterday, including a few more pages on his new series of philosophical papers.
ROME, Oct. 19 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Contributions of $25,000 each from H.R. Cullen, Texas oil man, and Senator E.H. Moore, Republican, of Oklahoma to the Common Citizens Radio Committee were reported today to the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee during an inquiry into the income and disbursements of the W. Lee O'Daniel News, published at Fort Worth, Tex.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Liquidation of the 2,000,000-ton food supply now held by the War Food Administration will start as soon as Germany is defeated, Lee Marshall, WFA distribution chief, today informed members of the National Association of Food Chains holding their annual meeting here.

LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Apparently anxious to avoid any accusation of interference in American politics, official Britain and the country's press -- with a few exceptions -- are guarding carefully against expressing a preference in the Presidential election.

ATHENS, Oct. 18 (Delayed) -- In his first public speech on home soil Premier George Papandreou today assured the people of their political liberty and democratic government, and announced that Greece was first on the list of war stricken countries to receive immediate aid from the larger powers.

Ten issues of outstanding securities of industrial corporations, aggregating $379,809,000, have been added to the legal list by the New York State Banking Board, making them eligible for investment by savings banks, it was announced yesterday by Elliott V. Bell, Superintendent of Banks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Assurance that additional facilities for police radio services would be included in the post-war reallocation of frequencies was given at today's hearing before the Federal Communications Commission.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 19 (AP) -- The hurricane swept north-ward tonight along the South Atlantic Coast after crossing Florida. causing two deaths in Miami and estimated damage of $20,000,000 to the citrus crop.

Doughty Jake Byer, a racing figure for a generation, fitted a chestnut 2-year-old filly named Head Smart so well for yesterday's Fairview Purse at Jamaica that the Max Slifkin color-bearer soundly defeated two heavily supported rivals who finished far behind.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Col. Robert R. McCormick's Chicago Tribune, which is supporting Governor Dewey for President, will say editorially tomorrow:

Calling for an early start on a comprehensive program of port facility improvement in this country, headed by a $2,000,000,000 project for "lifting the face" of the Fort of New York, Basil Harris, president of the United States Lines, warned yesterday that the United States faced the real danger that her ports may fall far behind those of many other nations in the efficiency of their facilities.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 19 (AP) - Representative Melvin J. Maas, Republican, of Minnesota, declared tonight that the Administration was withholding from the public a new report on Pearl Harbor prepared by an official Navy Board of Inquiry.

Hitler's creation of a Home Guard to wage a "people's war" against the Allies within Germany has again emphasized that, barring minor campaigns in foreign lands, American armies are now for the first time in their history invading the home territory of a major Power with a hostile population while the war is still in progress.

The brightest news in today's market report concerns meat, supplies of which are slightly better than last week. Beef of commercial and utility grade is plentiful, and there is also some steer beef of choice and good grade on hand, according to the War Food Administration, the New York Council of Wholesale Meat Dealers and the Meat Trade Institute.

From Kathryn Forbes' stories about Mama's legendary bank account, but not legendary character, John van Druten has fashioned a delightful evening for the theatre. He calls it "I Remember Mama," and, like its source, it is about a Norwegian-American family living in San Francisco, one that is complete with problems, children, cats and Uncle Chris.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 19 -- The political fortunes of the Wisconsin Progressives have soared and declined in the past generation, and one world war which they opposed has given way to another which they did not prepare to meet, but "Young Bob" La Follette, like "Old Bob" before him, is still trying to walk the knife-edge between the liberal and isolationist elements of the family political party.

AT A RIFLE COMPANY COMMAND POST IN AACHEN, Oct. 19 -- The long grim battle for Aachen is moving slowly but steadily toward a triumphant close. Over half of the city is now held by our infantry, supported by armored formations, and the German resistance, although still bitter, is on a smaller scale than hitherto.

Within the next three years the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York should have 1,500,000 subscribers and an annual turnover of $75,000,000, Mayor LaGuardia declared yesterday, after the plan's incorporators and its twenty-four directors had met in his office at City Hall.

Lieut. Van T. Barfoot, the "one-man Army" from Carthage, Miss., who holds the Medal of Honor, the nation's highest military award, is mighty proud of his citation, but says he is still prouder of having commanded a platoon in combat.

The president of the League of Women Voters, in her letter to THE TIMES of Oct. 17, presents capably the case for a change in our established method of treaty ratification and with due respect for the constitutional process, the importance of which cannot be too much emphasized.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 160:

AMERICAN THIRD ARMY FRONT, Oct. 18 (Delayed) -- Despite their sweep across France behind retreating German troops American Armies stand today before the frontiers of the Reich as mobile and as deadly in fire power as the day they went into battle.
LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Communique 194:

IN LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 18 (Delayed) -- With the help of fifty Russians, former slave laborers for the Nazis in France, Ninth Air Force engineers are rapidly completing an air strip for fighters. The volunteer laborers are former farmers and soldiers of the Soviet part of a colony of 200 men, women and children who were captured by the Germans on the eastern front and transported westward two years ago to work in French mines.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- J. A. Krug, chairman of the War Production Board, took public apathy toward war production as the subject for a press conference talk today, stressing that, while the program was being achieved in most respects, output was lagging in "a vitally important 10 per cent" which could delay victory in Europe "for months."

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 19 (AP) -An underdog Clemson eleven upset the University of South Carolina in their forty-second State Fair game in a steady rain today, 20 -- 13. The contest also settled the South Carolina championship.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Col. C.V. Whitney's Legend Bearer, 4-year-old daughter of The Porter and Motto, scored her third victory of the meeting today when she got up in the final strides to take the Staab Purse at Laurel Park.
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Although trading was extremely quiet, today's stock markets here were cheerful in tone.

ROME, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Additional troops and supplies were unloaded today at Piraeus for British and Greek expeditionary forces while the Germans admitted a withdrawal from Thebes, thirty-two miles northwest of Athens, which is already under Greek Government control.

De Pinna's presented a round-up of fashions for town wear at its show yesterday at the Plaza. Color prevailed for day, black took top honors in fashions for evening. This shop paid special notice to women who wear uniforms or functional clothes during the day with a group of "at-home" gowns that combined comfort with elegance.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine yesterday canceled all police leaves for Saturday and recalled all officers of the rank of captain or higher from vacations for that day to provide a police guard for President Roosevelt's campaign tour of the city that will be adequate for all emergencies.

ROME, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Allies hacked out new gains in northern Italy today against continued bitter German resistance. The British Eighth Army drove against Celincordia, less than a mile south of the fortress town of Cesena on the Rimini-Bologna highway, and the Americans captured additional positions south of Bologna.

As a result of allegedly runaway increases in Westchester rents during the last two months, the Office of Price Administration announced yesterday that all residential rents in the county would be frozen at the levels of last Aug. 1, effective Nov. 1. Landlords will be required to roll back by that date rents increased since Aug. 1.
LONDON, Oct. 19 (UP) -- A Japanese communique, as broadcast from Tokyo and recorded by The United Press:

HAVANA, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Surgidero de Batabano, a south Cuban port built on lowlands and over water, was destroyed by yesterday's hurricane, and its fishing fleet of more than twenty schooners driven as much as half a mile inland, reports from the hard-hit area said tonight.

IN the High Renaissance of the Tang dynasty during the first half of the eighth century a maiden called Winter Cherry dwelt in the palace of the Bright Emperor, Hsuan Tsung. Like many of the other hundreds of young women who gossiped and idled away their lives in the Pepper Rooms she had never seen her imperial master, so infatuated was he with Yang Kuei-fei, the favorite, whose beauty was celebrated throughout the celestial empire.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in English to North America from Chungking and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- Jeanne Lanvin's models, as shown today, manifest a marked desire to influence the mode -- her trend is to make both skirts and dresses longer and she admits that, at the moment apart from details, this is about the only novelty possible.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- Francois de Menthon, Minister of Justice, today justified the execution of Pierre Pucheu, former Vichy official, in Algiers last March by producing a letter of the sub-prefect at Chateaubriand saying that Pucheu had chosen Communists to be turned over to the Germans for shooting.

It is difficult to realize that John Dewey, philosopher and beloved teacher of two generations, is 85 today. Yet this vigorous fighter for democracy and the "common man," this kindly, gentle, modest scholar, has now been a "retired" professor for fifteen years. Fortunately, the years have treated Dr. Dewey graciously.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Henry J. Kaiser, industrialist, put before President Roosevelt today "an immediate specific pattern" for industrial reconversion to peacetime production which he and other manufacturers could begin to carry into operation "right away."

AACHEN, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Instances indicating a breakdown in the solidarity between German civilians and their military in this battered city were reported tonight by a senior American staff officer to be resulting from the harshness of military rules and the desire of some civilians to get out of the war.

A nation-wide underwriting syndicate headed by the Mellon Securities Corporation and the First Boston Corporation, as joint managers, and comprising more than 125 members, will offer today to the public $130,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage 2 3/4 per cent bonds of the Philadelphia Electric Company.

GROTON, Conn., Oct. 19 (AP) -- A Navy fighter plane glanced off a house rooftop today in a crash landing, tearing the blanket from the bed of a sleeping 2-year-old girl who escaped with only minor scratches.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The War Production Board directed cotton textile manufacturers today to utilize idle rope-making or cordbraiding machines for the production of "a minimum poundage" of twisted or braided cotton cordage or rope from 1/8 inch to 3/8 inch in diameter, provided labor or machinery is not diverted from more essential fiber ropes.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

A threatened strike of the city's sausage-makers, salami-stuffers and the rest of the delicatessen industry -- employers and workers alike -- in protest against present price ceilings was averted yesterday, for thirty days at least, at a conference in regional Office of Price Administration headquarters in the Empire State Building.

The Dry Dock Savings Institution sold to Jack Weprin and associates the nine-story apartment house for eighteen families at 101 East Seventy-fourth Street, near Park Avenue, for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $140,000. The property is 75 by 102 feet and is assessed at $345,000.

Champions in the various yachting classes compiled through the twenty-one regattas held last summer by the clubs in the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound were figured yesterday and only one 1943 ruler retained his laurels.

At special meetings held yesterday in Sanford, Me., stockholders of the Sanford Mills and of the Goodall Worsted Company approved by large majority votes the merger of Sanford into Goodall Worsted, whose name was changed to Goodall-Sanford, Inc.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Tokyo, in a broadcast recorded by the Federal Communications Commission, said American forces had landed on the small island of Suluan at the entrance of Leyte Gulf on the eastern side of the central Philippines.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Transactions leading to simplification of the Associated Gas and Electric System's capital structure were approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission on condition that the NY PA NJ Utilities Company does not reduce its open account indebtedness to the top holding company below $24,000,000.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, New Guinea, Friday, Oct. 20 (AP) -- A communique:

Mrs. Charles W. Weis Jr. of Rochester, member of the Republican National Committee, predicted yesterday the election of the Republican National ticket. She spoke at a luncheon of the Women's Division of the United Republican Finance Committee at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Acquisition of control of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., by the Hughes Tool Company of Houston, Tex., owned by Howard R. Hughes, was authorized today by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 17 (Delayed) -- If the political chaos now prevailing in Rumania is allowed to continue, that country will be faced with a civil war in the near future. Leaders of the four main political parties there are at loggerheads and fighting for ministerial portfolios.

As a means of eliminating disastrous "post-war" price-wars, the New York State Restaurant and Liquor Dealers Association announced yesterday that it would seek State legislation which would establish "floor" prices below which distillers would not be permitted to sell their products.
ALBANY, Oct. 19 -- Governor Dewey, in a nation-wide radio appeal for the National War Fund, described the fund tonight as "the American conscience in action."

BOSTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- After shooting for a knockout from the opening bell, Bobby Ruffin, 139 1/2, of Astoria, N.Y., finally managed to floor the rugged Vince Dell'Orto, 133, of Philadelphia, for the full count in the seventh round of their scheduled ten-round feature bout tonight at Mechanics Building.

Spencer Miller Jr., New Jersey State Highway Commissioner, will discuss post-war highways and airports at the dinner meeting of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards at the Stacy Trent Hotel in Trenton tonight.

Three new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Strand, the attraction will be "The Conspirators," Warner Brothers screen version of the Frederic Prokosch novel starring Hedy Lamarr and Paul Henreid. Peter Lorre, Sydney Greenstreet, Victor Francen and Joseph Calleia are featured in the topical drama.
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 19 (AP) -Cornell's football game with the Sampson Naval Training Center Saturday will be the 500th contest for a Big Red eleven.
Wednesday's communique, as broad cast by the Free Yugoslav radio in Serbo-Croat and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 19 -- A tropical hurricane which caused damage to Florida's rich citrus crop estimated in the millions, and at least twenty-five deaths since boiling up in the Caribbean more than a week ago, lashed at this shipbuilding and naval center tonight, plunging the city into darkness through power failure.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Seasonally lower prices for fruits and vegetables, together with a decline in the grain markets, caused the Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of commodity prices in primary markets to drop 0.1 per cent during the week ended on Oct. 14.

Regardless of Broadway's present state of prosperity, three plays are definitely shutting up shop tomorrow night. A fourth is hanging in the balance and may join the procession. Yesterday's additions to the outgoing list, which started off with "Pick-Up Girl," are "While the Sun Shines" and "The Odds on Mrs. Oakley."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The War Department's highest civilian honor, the award for exceptional civilian service, was presented today to John H. Ohly, 33-year-old attorney of New York City, by Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War.

LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Reports that rockets or robot planes were sighted over southern Sweden today caused speculation in London on the possibility that the Germans were developing a new long-distance vengeance weapon that could be launched against England from German soil.

B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., and associates were the successful bidders yesterday for $4,117,000 borough and school bonds of Fort Lee, N. J., receiving the award of $4,086,000 bonds on a bid that represented a net interest cost to the issuer of 3.082 per cent.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Spartans of Michigan State College maintained their undefeated record tonight by defeating the University of Maryland, 8 to 0, in mud and rain.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Distinguished Service Medal was presented today to Brig. Gen. Thomas Otis Hardin, commander of the Indo-China Division of the Air Transport command until recently, and Maj. Gen. John Cecil Persons, commander of the Thirty-first Infantry Division through two campaigns in the Southwest Pacific.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 20 -- An improved wind turbine for generating electricity, a method of making blue mold cheese of pasteurized milk and several developments in industrial chemistry are among the 511 inventions listed as patented in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, in the Southwest Pacific, Oct. 20 -- Forty men of the American Red Cross, some of them veterans of half a dozen New Guinea landings, went ashore with Gen. Douglas MacArthur's troops in the first day of the invasion of the Philippines and immediately began establishing clean canteens along the beachhead.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
ROME, Oct. 20 (AP) -- A communique:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- President Roosevelt brushed off his old naval cape today and polished up his speech in preparation for his "invasion" of New York City tomorrow.
GENERAL MacARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, in the Philippines, Oct. 20 (AP) -- A special communique:

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- The news was released here today that the United States Navy was leaving British Channel coast invasion ports for French bases from which it would operate for the remainder of the war in Europe.

Inquiries referring to Mayor La Guardia's recent campaign against housewives who shake dusty mops out the windows of city dwellings received a gentle brush-off from city departments yesterday in a survey conducted to ascertain where and how the daunted housewife may legally clean a mop.

Capt. Jan August Gauw of the Royal Netherlands Navy received the Legion of Merit award yesterday at ceremonies held aboard his ship at a naval base on Staten Island. The presentations was made by Vice Admiral Emory S. Land, U.S.N., on the deck of the big warship in the presence of the crew of 200 and a few invited guests.
SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Vadal Peterson, coach of the

Two informations of six counts each, charging diversion of vital war material into civilian use, have been filed in the United States District Court here against the Gemloid Corporation and the Albion Laboratories, both of 79-10 Albion Avenue, Queens, and their president, Joseph Frank, according to Albert V. DeMeo, assistant United States Attorney.

In so far as quantity was concerned, 15-year-old Joseph (Dolly) Catandella was a sure bet last night to capture first prize in the annual "contents of a boy's pockets'' at the Madison Square Boys Club, 301 East Twenty-ninth Street.

ARMY vs. Coast Guard -- The Cadets are beginning to reveal hidden weaknesses. In the past two games rival teams actually scored on the West Pointers. Of course, it also should be kept in mind that Army managed to squeeze through to victory in each instance by close counts of 59 -- 7 and 69 -- 7. Maybe the Kaydets can eke out another such triumph.
LONDON, Oct. 20 (UP) -- A communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

The advertising industry will be faced with the task of informing the country and the world what has to be done to insure post-war prosperity, Joseph D. McGoldrick, Controller of the City of New York, asserted yesterday. New York City is especially concerned, he said, because it has the greatest concentration of advertising brains, management executives, and graphic art facilities in the country.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Professional gamblers already have caused two boys to throw basketball games in Eastern intercollegiate tournaments, Dr. Forrest C. Allen, Kansas basketball coach charged today in predicting the betting fraternity would create a "scandal that will stink to high heaven" unless college presidents intercede to save the game.

GENERAL MACARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, Leyte, Philippines, Oct. 20 -- Two veteran United States battleships that were damaged in the Japanese sneak attack on Pearl Harbor -- the California and Pennsylvania -- are backing up the American landings in the Philippines. As these lines are written they are throwing 14 and 16 inch shells over our heads into enemy defenses in part repayment for Dec. 7, 1941.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 20 -- Recently given an honorable discharge from service in the United States Marine Corps, Louis Hayward will return to the screen as the romantic lead in Samuel Bronston's screen version of the Agatha Christie murder-mystery play, "Ten Little Indians."

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 20 -- As Aachen, a bastion of the Siegfried Line and an important forward base and supply center for Germany was completely overrun today, other Allied forces were thrusting north of Antwerp in a triple drive to beat back the German forces that have been menacing the Canadian First Amy

A new regulation for furniture wholesalers designed to bring ceiling prices for new jobbers under better control, to prevent pyramiding of margins in jobber-to-jobber sales and to protect long established jobbers in the field, is well along and is expected to be announced in the near future, it was revealed yesterday by Byres Gitchell, until recently director, Consumers Goods Price Division, Office of Price Administration.

A $100 War Bond and the promise of free dental care for the rest of his life was the reward Dennis McGillicudy, a trainman employed by the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, received yesterday for returning a $500 banknote to its owner.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 20 -- Four of the Ruhr district's most prominent industrial barons have been taken into Gestapo custody and accused of fostering defeatism and recommending surrender in the hope of saving their factories from complete destruction.

Earl D. Osborn, president of the Edo Aircraft Corporation, College Point, Queens, in a statement issued yesterday expressed grave concern over the impression created by a recent release by the Defense Plant Corporation listing Edo with plants as surplus available for purchase when present war contracts are completed.

Tony Janiro of Youngstown, Ohio, defeated Santa Bucca of Philadelphia in the feature bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. Boxing effectively at long range and checking his rival's attempts to score at the infighting, Janiro had little trouble earning the unanimous vote of the officials.

Two new films will arrive on Broadway this morning. Opening at the Gotham is "Summer Storm," an adaptation of Anton Chekov's story "The Shooting Party." The lead roles are played by George Sanders, Linda Darnell, Anna Lee, Edward Everett Horton and Hugo Haas. . . .

MOSCOW, Saturday, Oct. 21 -Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin achieved material progress in resolving the Polish question and agreed on coordinated military and political action in the troubled Balkans, including an attempted fusion of the Royal Yugoslav Government and Marshal Tito's Committee of National Liberation, it was made known early today.

Men of the United States Navy and the Marine Corps were impressed by finding hymn books, Bibles and New Testaments in English and native languages in the Gilbert and Marshall Islands, Lieut. Douglas Vernon, Navy chaplain, said yesterday in a luncheon interview at the Hotel Bedford, 118 East Fortieth Street.
ATLANTA, Oct. 20 -- The United States Naval Academy football team invades the deep South for the first time tomorrow to play Georgia Tech, pride of Dixie.

An exhibition of modern Dutch prints, assembled in conjunction with the forthcoming photographic show of modern Dutch architecture, opened yesterday at the Brooklyn Museum in the small print gallery and will be current through Dec. 3.

CLEVELAND, Saturday, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Thunderous explosions ripped a $6,000,000 liquid gas storage plant yesterday afternoon and spread the most devastating fire in Cleveland's history over a 50-block East Side area, causing many deaths and injury to at least 200.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Additional radio facilities for the protection from fire of municipalities, and for the control or suppression of forest fires were requested at today's hearing before the Federal Communications Commission in anticipation of the post-war reallocation of frequencies.

TEANECK, N.J., Oct. 20 -- Attorney General Francis Biddle tonight defined a bureaucrat as "somebody who holds a job that a Republican wants" and assailed Gov. Thomas E. Dewe as "a slick prosecutor" who does not tell the whole truth.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 20 -- Net earnings of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 were $8,543,471, compared with $9.431,147 for the preceding twelve months, William E. Levis, chairman of the board, announced today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- The scope of the Government's anti-trust suit attacking the legality of the licensing system under which the Wisconsin Alumni Research Foundation handles its vitamin D process patents was enlarged today with the naming of 17 more defendants, one individual and 16 food and medicinal products companies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Army's civilian supply program in Italy was defended today by Col. William C. Chanlor, deputy director of the Civil Affairs Division of the War Department General Staff, before the Women's Conference on International Affairs, a forum of about fifty national women's organizations, which was discussing the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The all-civilian football teams of Syracuse and Temple battled through mud, rain and the tail end of a hurricane to a 7-7 tie at Temple Stadium tonight. Only about 200 of an expected 15,000 spectators saw halfbacks Arden McConnell of Syracuse and Jimmy Wilson of Temple stage touchdown thrusts in the opening and closing periods.

A good deal more than mere nostalgia marks the activities of the Automobile Old Timers, an organization which has come to include more than 600 men of mark in the automotive field, all of whom have been associated with the industry in one or another capacity for more than a quarter century.

GENERAL M'ARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, in the Philippines, Saturday, Oct. 21 -- American ground forces have consolidated all beachheads on Leyte in the central Philippines and are moving inland, headquarters announced today in its second communique on the invasion. Ground casualties were reported comparatively light.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in a forty-seven-page decision unanimously reversed yesterday a decision of the Supreme Court requiring the Climax Molybdenum Company and certain directors of the American Metal Company to account to American Metal for profits and absolved Climax Molybdenum from charges of any improper use of the resources and facilities of American Metal for its own organizational development.

Three union leaders who demanded $1,800 under a threat to call strikes and slowdowns at the E. A. Laboratories, a war plant at 144 Spencer Street, Brooklyn, were convicted of attempted extortion early today by a jury in Kings County Court.

In response to a demand from physicians, public health officers, social workers and officers of the armed forces, Congress drew up an Emergency Maternity and Infant Care program of limited duration and entrusted the Children's Bureau with the task of carrying it out.

Fifteen including Bolingbroke and Devil Diver, are named for today's $50,000 added Gallant Fox Handicap, closing-day feature of the Metropolitan Jockey Club meeting at Jamaica. Those two have the most advocates for championship honors in the handicap division but they are up against a lot of lightly weighted horses for the long run of a mile and five furlongs.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- There is a curious parallel today between French opinion and French fashion. "Liberation" openings of the great dressmakers are now in full swing and they illustrate as well as anything the paradox wherewith the French mind is struggling as it swings uncertainly over the gulf between past and future.
The following books of a religious or inspirational nature have recently been published:

Contributions to the sixty-sixth annual United Hospital Fund Campaign for the support of seventy-seven volunteer non-profit hospitals have carried the drive beyond the half way mark toward its goal of $1,554,931 with total funds collected so far reaching $886,099, it was disclosed yesterday at the third report meeting of the Manhattan-Bronx Women's Division.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 20 -- Governor Dewey charged tonight that the Roosevelt Administration had been playing with the rights of labor for its own political ends and for the furtherance of the President's "one-man" rule.

A meeting of stockholders of American Airlines, Inc., has been called for Dec. 6 to consider recommendations of the board of directors that the authorized common stock be increased from 1,000,000 shares of $10 par value to 2,400,000 shares of $5 par value.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 20 -- Three members of a train crew were injured and traffic on the main line of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad was blocked here at 7:30 o'clock tonight by a collision of freight trains.

Reaffirming his belief in "democracy with a small 'd'" and in "liberalism with a small 'l,'" Senator Robert F. Wagner declared in a radio talk last night that he "utterly rejects the totalitarian systems -- be they fascism on the right or communism on the left."

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Notified by the War Department that her husband, Pvt. Thomas J. Kane, 34 years old, has been missing in action since Sept. 23, Mrs. May Kane of 45 Radford Street, here, said today that her plans go no further than caring for her four children on a Government allotment of $155 a month.

Dr. Samuel Weinrib, 55 years old, a dentist with offices in Manhattan and the Bronx, was freed on a suspended sentence yesterday by Judge Jonah J. Goldstein in General Sessions. He had pleaded guilty to shooting Miss Edna Dessau, 40, of 611 West 113th Street, on Dec. 30 last.

Governor Dewey, Republican nominee for President, said yesterday in Pittsburgh that he was waiting for a report from his counsel, Charles D. Breitel, before announcing his decision on requests for a special session of the Legislature to extend the voting hours in New York City on election day because of the large registration.
Following is the text of the address by Governor Dewey at Pittsburgh, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Charging that a "black market in nurses" exists in this city, Mrs. Frances P. Bolton, Representative from Ohio, warned last night that if the 10,000 nurses needed immediately for military and overseas duty with the Armed Forces did not volunteer their services Congress "would be forced to find means to make them do so."

A ruse carried out by radio correspondents with the United States Signal Corps attached to General MacArthur's headquarters was a factor in keeping the Japanese in the dark about the invasion of the Philippines, Arthur Feldman, Blue network correspondent, reported yesterday.

BUTTE, Mont., Oct. 20 (U. P.) -Senator Harry S. Truman, Democratic candidate for Vice President, pledged tonight that the Administration would extend rural electrification after the war if kept in office Nov. 7.

Cotton futures on the New York Stock Exchange held yesterday within a narrow range and closed unchanged to 6 points net lower than on Thursday. The market opened with losses of 3 to 4 points under some hedge selling and scattered liquidation. Trade buying was light.
PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 20 -- The full force of Pacific Fleet power in the Philippine Sea area blasted the enemy's reduced defenses in support of the landings yesterday under Gen. Douglas MacArthur.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 (AP) -Holders of securities of the Standard Gas and Electric Company protested the company's amended plan of recapitalization during oral argument today before the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The large plant for which war orders are only partly cut back represents one reconversion problem that has received too little attention. Many plants that find themselves in this position may be unable to convert to peacetime production because machines and floor space are still partly used for war goods.

GENERAL MacARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS in the Philippines, Saturday, Oct. 21 (AP) -- As reoccupation of the Philippines got under way today from beachheads in the heart of the archipelago, Gen. Douglas MacArthur summoned Filipinos to "rise and strike" the Japanese.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Oct. 21 (AP) -- A communique concerning the Moscow meetings of Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin:

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, accused President Roosevelt at a rally here tonight of usurping the authority of Congress with executive orders in order to carry out what Mr. Curran called the President's plan for one-man government under the New Deal.

From a tunnel deep in the heart of Corregidor Fortress, during the darkest days of the Philippine campaign of 1941 and 1942, each day was broadcast to all those Filipinos who dared to listen a plea for fortitude, for courage, for hope in the coming day of deliverance.

Edwin P. Banta 73-year-old former, German-American Bund "orator," Ku Klux Klan member and subsequent "investigator" for the anti-Nazi League, admitted yesterday in his Special Sessions trial for attempting to frame a rape charge against the author of the best seller, "Under Cover," that he had solicited the aid of Representative Hamilton Fish to induce Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine to listen to the rape accusation.

DETROIT, Oct. 20 (AP) -- A $150,000,000 post-war expansion program based upon a belief that the number of car owners in the United States after the war would rise from 30,000,000 to 40,000,000 was disclosed today by the Ford Motor Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- A market for $5,780,000,000 worth of new and used machinery, and other equipment from this country, will be found in the Latin-American republics in the ten years immediately following the war, according to estimates drawn up by the Office of Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs.
RENO, Nev., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Gov. John W. Bricker added Flint, Mich., and Detroit tonight to his Western capaign tour and said that he would make another swing into the East.

NEW RICHMOND, Ohio, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Judge John W. Haussermann, 76-year-old "gold king" of the Philippines, will follow General MacArthur back to the islands "soon" -- with a bankroll of millions to aid in restoring the Commonwealth to Western World prosperity.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals here reserved decision yesterday on appeals brought by creditors and stockholders of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company, from an order of the Federal court in Connecticut approving a plan of reorganization for the line.

Brig. Gen. Ralph K. Robertson, commander of the First Military District, Second Service Command, announced here yesterday the establishment of a joint Army and Navy disciplinary control board for closer coordination of the law-enforcement agencies of the two services.

An effort by a group of Argentine nationalists in the city of Tucuman to take reprisals against a group of fourteen attorneys, who had protested the dissolution of their bar association by President Edelmiro Farrell's Government, was successfully challenged last month by persons who were not parties to the original protest, it was learned yesterday.
GENERAL MacARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, Philippines, Saturday, Oct. 21 (AP) -- A communique:

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, in the Southwest Pacific, Oct. 20 -- Army medical contingents going ashore in the Philippines not far behind the first assault waves will face one of the most important public health tasks yet to confront their profession, the rebuilding of the magnificent system for the control of tropical diseases, which served as a model for the entire Orient.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- James V. Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy, disclosed tonight that the report by the Naval Court of Inquiry into the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor had been presented to him, but stated that careful inspection must determine whether any part of the document could be made public.

ROME, Oct. 20 -- While the Fifth Army is still held up by ten German divisions below Bologna -- as against three or four in the area when the offensive started on Sept. 10 -- British and Indian units of the Eighth Army have taken another step inland along Highway 9 by penetrating Cesena and clearing out the enemy from all of the town east of the Savio River.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- A three-column editorial in the Paris edition of the Stars and Stripes, United States Army newspaper, protested today against the "coddling" of German civilians at Aachen while American soldiers were living in the rain in open field, and eating cold food.

We are certain that Governor Dewey will accede promptly to the appeal that now comes to him unanimously from the City Council -- with the minority leader herself voting for the motion -- to call a special session of the Legislature for the purpose of extending the voting hours on election day.

To hear Mischa Elman play the Vitali-Charlier Chaconne and, with his pianist, Leopold Mittman, the Strauss violin and piano sonata last night in Carnegie Hall was for this listener not only a pleasure but a thrill. For this was Elman at his highest and most virile; Elman, as virtuoso and musician, at the splendid height of his powers.

A post-war shipping reserve of ten million tons and taking over Japanese trade routes was advocated by Secretary of the Navy James F. Forrestal last night in an address at the annual dinner of The Propeller Club of the United States and the American Merchant Marine Conference in the Waldorf- Astoria Hotel.

The Appellate Division unanimously dismissed yesterday an appeal of Frank Costello, from a Supreme Court decision which held him in contempt for his refusal to testify before Deputy Police Com missioner Cornelius O'Leary at the Copacabana night club hearings.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- The creation of a new military zone in France that leaves Paris and all but a narrow strip of the country exclusively under the authority of the French Government was announced tonight after a five-hour Cabinet meeting.

Forty-two persons were in court yesterday in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens to answer summonses for permitting their dogs to run on the street unleashed in defiance of the Police and Health Departments' city-wide quarantine ordered in an attempt to stamp out rabies.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt attended the opening yesterday afternoon of the "Tribute to President Roosevelt" art exhibition, sponsored by the Independent Voters Committee of the Arts and Sciences for Roosevelt in the American Fine Arts Society Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

With the characteristic enterprise which has brought it in a decade from a lowly position to that of the largest domestic air carrier, American Airlines has now instituted an all-cargo service known as Airfreight. This service is available in forty-three American cities and the communities which adjoin them.
AT RIFLE COMPANY HEADQUARTERS in Aachen, Oct. 20-- Aachen, the gate to the Rhineland, has fallen, the first German city ever to be taken by American troops.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -The Bureau of Agriculture Economics said today that a survey of representative farmers in twentyeight States disclosed that three out of four believed this country should participate in a world association of nations.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Under pressure of British troops, driving southward from captured Tiddim in northwest Burma, the Japanese have evacuated Falam, headquarters of civil administration in the central Chin Hills, thirty miles below Tiddim, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's command announced today.

Bailey B. Burritt, called the father of the family health movement in New York City, will retire on Nov. 1 as chairman of the Community Service Society's executive council, that agency announced yesterday.

Plans for the post-war construction of two large ten-story factory and storage buildings with offices for sites on West Forty-third and Forty-fourth Streets were filed by the Park Tilford Import Company yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The estimated cost is $1,080,00.

ROME, Oct. 20 -- All Italian eyes turned anxiously toward Sicily today to learn whether the "seditious demonstration" that cost nineteen dead and more than a hundred wounded in Palermo yesterday morning would be followed by new uprisings.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- Pierre Laval, who, as Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain's Prime Minister, initiated in 1940, the policy of collaboration with the Germans, was sentenced to death this morning by a special court of justice sitting in Marseille.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Communique 195:

An underwriting group headed by F.S. Moseley Co., the First Boston Corporation and Kidder, Peabody Co. will offer today to the public $5,950,000 of Eastern Massachusetts Street Railway general mortgage 4 per cent bonds, due in 1962.

BOSTON, Oct. 20 -- A 10-monthold black dog, Try Cob's Pinefair, owned and shown by Mrs. R. Kenneth Cobb of Nanuet, and bred by Mrs. H. Terrell Van Ingen of Greenwich, captured the Big 6 Novice Stake, first-day feature in the twenty-third annual specialty show of the Cocker Spaniel Breeders Club of New England, at Horticultural Hall today.

Operations of the Atlantic Refining Company and its subsidiaries for the first nine months of this year resulted in a net profit, subject to renegotiation, of $10,586,000 after all charges including interest, depreciation and taxes, but before minority interest.

Cameras and techniques for photographing the ocean bottom at a maximum depth of three miles were described yesterday at the annual meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania of the Optical Society of America by Dr. Maurice Ewing, who recently was appointed associate professor of geophysics at Columbia University.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt warned 400 members of the women's division of the Democratic National Committee at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday that unless women assumed the full responsibilities of citizenship all the war work they could do might be wasted.

Not one inclined to remain idle for long, Vinton Freedley, who has not been heard from since January when he sponsored "Jackpot," will be active again after the holidays, it is reported. This time, however, the musical comedy producer has selected a play as his new offering.

WITH MacARTHUR AT LEYTE, Philippines, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Under cover of devastating fire from Allied warships, American troops knifed ashore on Leyte ISland today, striking simultaneously at three points along the eastern beaches.

UNITED STATES NINTH AIR FORCE ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, Oct. 20 -- The Luftwaffe sent dwindling fighter forces into the German skies today in an attempt to ward off blows by the United States Ninth Air Force against vital military targets in the Reich.

Now that all cries of "fire the coach" will fall on deaf ears, so far as the powers-that-be in the Brooklyn Tigers' organization is concerned, a stand made perfectly clear by General Manager Tom Gallery, the Flatbush entrant in the National Football League will leave today for Washington, where tomorrow in the Redskins' wigwam -- Griffith Stadium -- they are to battle Slingin' Sammy Baugh Co.

DES MOINES, Oct. 20 -- Vice President Wallace declared in an address here tonight under the auspices of the National Independent Committee for Roosevelt and Truman that "on the score of international cooperation and world peace alone, the independent voters of America will stand by Roosevelt."

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 20 -- Although two months have elapsed since Rumania capitulated, there is little evidence that the Rumanian Government intends to purge the army and civil administration of the vast number of pro-Nazi officers and officials, who continue undisturbed.

Field Marshal Count Juichi Terauchi, identified by Gen. Douglas MacArthur as his adversary in the fight for the Philippines, is Japan's highest ranking active commander and one of her outstanding soldiers of modern times, according to The Associated Press.

Rear Admiral William R. Munroe, commandant of the Third Naval District, has designated today and tomorrow as Navy Church Week-end in this area. Navy chaplains will preach at synagogues today and churches tomorrow. Civilian clergymen will conduct services and other activities at naval training stations and schools in this State, Connecticut and Northern New Jersey.

BOSTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- With fleet Jim Elliott inspiring them with three touchdown dashes, Boston College's informal football Eagles romped to a 42-13 triumph over New York University tonight at Fenway Park.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Oct. 20 -- By jumping more than 600 miles beyond Morotai to the central Philippines with the largest armada ever seen in this area of the great Pacific, Gen. Douglas MacArthur went far toward splitting in twain Japan's newly conquered empire.

James S. Kemper, financial chairman of the Republican National Committee, was charged in a policy holder's suit filed yesterday in Broolyn Federal Court with administering the affairs of the American Lumberman's Mutual Casualty Company, of which he is president, for the personal enrichment of himself, his relatives and friends.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Oct. 20 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's landing was made on the northeastern part of Leyte, just south of Tacloban, the island's capital, which has a population of 20,000.

ALBANY, Oct. 20 -- The State Banking Department announced today that the affairs of the South Bay Building Lot Association of Buffalo had been liquidated and the corporation dissolved. Similar action was taken in the liquidation of the Goldwyn Loan and Investment Corporation of New York.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS in the Southwest Pacific, Oct. 20 -- It may now be revealed that the American Army and Navy have evacuated Australia completely, except for a few skeleton supply units after the friendly invasion that lasted two and a half years.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 20 (U.P.) -- Resurgent Chinese forces, heartened by the American invasion of the Philippines, smashed back Japanese columns driving into southeastern Kwangsi and blocked the enemy threat to Kweilin farther north, while Chungking military spokesmen hailed Gen. Douglas MacArthur's operations as having "tremendous effect" on the war on the Asiatic continent.

RALEIGH, N. C., Oct. 20 (AP) -- A death toll of at least 35 and great crop and property damage were recorded today in the wake of a West Indian hurricane which swept across the interior of the Carolinas with ever-diminishing force and headed into Virginia.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Britain's export trade has declined since the war by 51 per cent in value and by more than 70 per cent in volume, according to a White Paper issued today by the Board of Trade -- the first figures since March, 1941, when security silence was imposed.

Riboflavin -- a member of the Vitamin B family, which is essential to growth and to normal nutrition at all ages -- is the most important vitamin in milk. According to scientists of the United States Department of Agriculture, research recently conducted at experiment stations in Idaho and North Carolina shows that riboflavin is rapidly destroyed by exposure to sunlight and that darkness is therefore necessary to the proper keeping of milk.

GUATEMALA, Oct. 20 (U.P.) -- Young officers, aided by civilians and students and employing tanks, overthrew the provisional government of President Federico Ponce today in a revolt that began at 2 A.M. and that was reported to have resulted in more than 1,000 casualties after sharp fighting.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 161:

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Rye continues to be the outstanding feature in the grain markets and today it fluctuated nervously on the Board of Trade. Prices advanced as much as 1 3/8 cents a bushel early. December leading and going to 4 1/4 cents over May at one time, the widest difference so far this season.
