LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Week-end influences held today's stock markets in check, but the undertone remained steady.

German looting and vandalism is some parts of liberated Europe appear to have been less than formerely reported or expected. Paris emerges above the receding Nazi tide virtually untouched, and the loss of public art is said to be small.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 20 (AP) -Apprentice Dick Meade stole the riding show at Laurel Park before 5,000 spectators this dreary afternoon, riding his fourth winner in the Academy Purse. In a whipping, driving finish, Meade booted the M. M. Stable's Top Reward home a neck in front of Saboteur in a field of six going one mile and a furlong.

Grace Church, in the City of New York, has sold the five-story apartment house at 955 Sherman Avenue, the Bronx, to an investing client of Gilliam McVay, Inc. The property occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet, accommodates twenty-five families and is assessed at $58,000.

Department store sales this week jumped their gain over last year to 23 per cent, according to estimates made yesterday. This compared with an actual rise of 7 per cent reported for last week by the Federal Reserve Bank. Consumer buying was spread over many departments and early gift purchases of the more expensive types were noted.

ONCE Stephen Crane wrote books that were like a flash from a heliograph, and now half a dozen Southern novelists are doing it. There is an alertness about Hodding Carter in his first novel, "The Winds of Fear," which admits him right off into a brilliant company, but this time on a press ticket.

LONDON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- More than 1,750 heavy bombers from Italy and Britain laced German industries and communications with a series of shattering blows last night and today as official estimates declared German finished oil production had been cut 77 per cent below its May potential.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (AP) -- L.E. Mahan of St. Louis was elected today president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America at the organization's annual conference. He succeeds H.G. Woodruff of Detroit. Byron V. Kanaley of Chicago was elected vice president for the 1944-45 term.

Sweeping educational reforms for the post-war development of Poland, calling for compulsory public school attendance until the age of 18, universities open to all youth and a wide system of scholarships, have been formulated by the Polish Underground Labor Movement and the Polish Teachers Underground Convention, it became known yesterday.

The Sportsmen's Show, the heterogeneous exposition that contained all things for all men in the outdoor line before war interrupted its flamboyant career, will be revived in New York in February. It will be in the lower exhibition hall of Madison Square Garden instead of at Grand Central Palace, where it held sway until the Government took over that building. The dates will be Feb. 18 to 25.
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 20 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

The Japanese in the "decisive battles that are to come," will fight "until the enemy licks the dust," Gen. Kuniaki Koiso, Japanese Premier, declared yesterday at a "people's rally" in Tokyo, Domei, the Japanese news agency, reported in a dispatch to the press of occupied Asia.

WITH GENERAL MacARTHUR IN THE PHILIPPINES, Oct. 20 -- The Americans and Filipinos who died so gallantly in the dark days of 1942 will sleep easier tonight, for here on Leyte we are fighting the Japanese division that did the "dirty work" on Bataan.

Financial history has been established this week in the field of new security offerings -- a total of $346,450,000 in new bonds reaching the public. Although there remains a large volume of financing to be done, this record in all probability will stand for some time.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The War Production Board today further relaxed its controls over materials gaining in supply by removing all restrictions on the use of copper and copper-base alloys in the manufacture of a list of seventeen civilian and commercial articles, ranging from gears for can openers to watchcases.
Glix-Brand Company, girl's pajamas and house coats, to Glicksman Advertising Company, Inc. Newspapers, magazines and trade papers will be used.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- President Roosevelt opened his news conference this morning with assurances, direct from Gen. Douglas MacArthur that the Leyte invasion had caught the enemy "strategically unaware" and that all landings of his assault forces of 250,000 to recapture the Philippines were made on schedule and with "extremely light" losses.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- It is estimated in official and trade circles that if her communications were open France could export today women's dresses, hats, gloves and other articles worth many millions of dollars, some say as much as $400,000,000 at the high prices prevailing now.

A year-and-a-half dispute between authors Rex Stout and Dorothy Thompson over the type of peace that should be applied to Germany came to a climax yesterday when the former submitted his resignation as a director of Freedom House, asserting that Miss Thompson, its president, had made public "irresponsible and undocumented charges" against him.
Investors were active yesterday in the purchase of a theatre building and housing properties over a wide area in Manhattan. Institutions were the sellers in several of the deals.
Andrei A. Gromyko, Ambassador from the Soviet Union, and Mme. Gromyko have arrived from Washington and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

PANAMA, Oct. 20 -- A revolt against the provisional Government of President Federico Ponce broke out in Guatemala today, according to information received here from a reliable source. The details are meager but it is understood that junior officers in garrisons near the border of El Salvador revolted and joined forces with revolutionaries in El Salvador.

National Peanut Company, distributor of Planters Peanuts, has leased the forty-two-foot-front store at 1560 Broadway from the Bethlehem Engineering Company, through Albert M. Greenfield Co., Inc. The lease also includes the front portion of the second floor, which is utilized for the sixty-foot Planters Peanut display sign, which is to become a neon electric display as soon as conditions permit.

LONDON Saturday, Oct. 21 -Russian and Yugoslav troops yesterday captured the Yugoslav capital of Belgrade, annihilating its Axis garrison in savage street battles, while Berlin announced that other Soviet forces had penetrated twelve miles inside East Prussia, smashing across the German frontier on an eighty-mile front.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 20 - The New Jersey political scene assumed a bizarre aspect today, when a former Republican State Chairman endorsed the candidacy of the Democratic aspirant for the United States Senate.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Investigations of alleged gambling here, including a floating dice game reputedly run so openly that a player "wandered in" one night and lost $11,855, were being conducted today by City Manager William A. Walsh and two county officials, District Attorney Elbert T. Gallagher and Sheriff Edward J. Ganter.

New municipal financing scheduled for the market next week aggregates $36,048,375, compared with $63,096,500 for this week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The weekly average of offerings for the year to date is $21,441,562.

President Roosevelt's trip through four boroughs of Greater New York today cannot be compared, in its demands on his courage and physical stamina, with his journeys to Casablanca, to Cairo and Teheran, and to Pearl Harbor and the Aleutian Islands, all made within the past twenty-two months.

Operation of buses of the Surface Transportation Corporation in the Bronx will not be reduced for another week because thirty-two new tires have been received under a relaxation of Office of Price Administration restrictions on bus tires, Victor McQuiston, vice president of the corporation, announced yesterday.

The stock market experienced yesterday some difficulties at its new-found levels, and, although pressure failed to appear in force, prices backed down moderately. The process of consolidation, necessary when the market attempts to return to previous highs, did not materialize, and the list was left without a directional force.

Investment banking history was made here this week when underwriters offered to the public the largest amount of new corporate bonds for such a period on record. The flotations, which included the largest single issue of bonds ever marketed here, were principally for public utility companies, although municipal offerings, too, were larger than in recent months.

Federal Court injunctions against sixty-five Manhattan, Bronx and Westchester County eating places accused of ceiling overcharges ranging from $3 on a bottle of wine to 30 cents on an order of ham and eggs have been obtained by the Regional Office of Price Administration, Daniel P. Woolley, Regional Administrator, announced yesterday.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, in the Southwest Pacific, Oct. 20 -- The largest number of correspondents to cover any Pacific landing are reporting the Philippines operations. There are forty-five American press correspondents, exclusive of those with the Pacific Fleet, seven radio reporters and three still newsreel photographers, plus a large number of Red Cross, Yank, Office of War Information and other special writers, and representatives of British and Australian agencies and newspapers.

QUINCY, Mass., Oct. 20 -- A letter of protest against the strike last week of almost 6,000 workers at the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipyard here has been received by the company from forty men on a Navy patrol ship in the South Pacific.
Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National Chairman, said yesterday that he had received assurances that Governor Dewey would carry both Ohio and Michigan.

THE International Savings Congress, meeting in Italy in 1924, fixed Oct. 31 of each year as Universal Savings Day. Word comes from Buenos Aires that Argentina, on the twentieth anniversary, will issue a "Dia del Ahorro Universal" commemorative 5-centavos stamp.

Contrary to public opinion, the wartime drain on basic timber resources of the country is not excessive and is of such nature that it can be met gradually through new timber growth after the war, a canvass of lumbermen revealed last week.

CARDIFF, Wales, Oct. 21 -- The British Labor Party favors a postwar economic policy of partial socialization of industry supplemented by government partnership in large segments of private enterprise, according to Herbert Morrison, Home Secretary and Labor leader.

Two long marches and a blocked kick figured in the three touchdowns Brooklyn Prep scored to beat Fordham Prep, 19 -- 7, on Boys High Field in Brooklyn yesterday. It was the fourth straight triumph for Brooklyn Prep.
New York's garment district reached record-breaking heights yesterday in its reception for President Roosevelt.

IT would be gratifying, in any case, to announce that Mr. Nathan has another yearbook. It is gratifying, in addition, to report that the present volume lives up to its subtitle -- "A Record and an Interpretation" -- better than did its predecessor last year.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- Hotels here are well booked and members of the cottage colony are arriving earlier than usual. Both the Holly Inn and the Pine Crest Inn have opened after extensive refurbishing, and the Carolina, popular among those who annually spend the season in the Midsouth, will take down its shutters on Nov. 4.

SINCE successful spring and early summer gardens are created during the preceding autumn, now is the time to think of setting out new plants to achieve next year's color effects. In looking over our own garden, at least three perennials seem to be especially worth recommending for effecting spring color.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 21 -- Belgium is suffering acutely from the effects of her speedy liberation seven weeks ago. Grave maladjustments in the nation's economic and domestic life that have created a number of government crises remain.

WITH AMERICAN FIRST ARMY in Germany, Oct. 21 -- The campaign for the Rhineland has entered a new phase with the fall of Aachen, a phase in which, if the operations of the last nineteen days are any criterion, progress will be slow and difficult in face of bitter enemy resistance and adverse weather conditions.

THIS week's soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony will be none other than the genial French pianist Robert Casadesus, who will be making his 27th, 28th, 29th and 30th appearances with that orchestra. In all, Mr. Casadesus has been in the United States for nearly ten years, but in that comparatively short period of time he has won for himself an enviable place in the public's esteem.

Standing bareheaded and without a protecting topcoat in the chilling, driving drizzle, President Roosevelt told a cheering crowd of 10,000 yesterday morning at Ebbets Field in Brooklyn that he came to pay tribute to Senator Robert F. Wagner, who is standing for re-election.

GEN M'ARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, in the Philippines, Oct. 21 (AP) -- President Sergio Osmena, standing on the soil of his homeland, today issued a call to all Filipinos to rise and fight the Japanese invaders whenever the tide of battle reached their towns.

On the cold, rain-soaked, mud-floored Western Front the battle lines changed but little last week. Six great Allied armies were ranged along the frontier of the Reich, but only three of them were pressing actions -- two in the Netherlands, a third mopping up at devastated Aachen, first Reich city to fall to the Allies.

HOUSE plants herded indoors with the first autumn chills may be viewed with an eye to artistic placement. They offer many delightful possibilities varying with their colors, size and manner of growth. Singly or in groups they take the place of flowers which the garden will not supply after frost.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Citing practical steps taken thus far to achieve a world free press, Kent Cooper, executive director of the Associated Press, told the National Editorial Association in a luncheon address today that "none of the world organizations or systems now being discussed for the peace to come can possibly succeed unless the first basic step is taken to assure unhindered flow of information."

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21 -- California voters face once more the old-age pension issue in the Nov. 7 election. This time it is the so-called 60-60 plan, an initiative constitutional amendment providing $60 a month for citizens 60 years old or more, the recipients to be prohibited from gainful occupation and to be compelled to spend the pension each month.

Charles H. Goren of Philadelphia and Mrs. Helen Sobel, George Rapee and Samuel M. Stayman of New York won the metropolitan contract bridge team-of-four tournament at the Park Central Hotel by default early this morning after their thirty-two board final match with George Kennedy of Brooklyn and Jack Cushing, Ambrose Casner and Ralph Hirschberg of New York had ended in an exact tie.

AS a participant in and observer of the cinema scene from the inside since the advent of talking pictures, I have found so many things wrong with Hollywood that I can understand those who prefer to leave it severely alone.

William T. Simpson chairman of the State War Ballot Commission, said yesterday that so far 334,375 men and women in the armed services had returned ballots and that most of these had been sent to the boards of election throughout the State.

CORP. MAURICE GORDON has been doing gouaches of the Gulf States region and the exhibition at Georgette Passedoit's proves that he has been working intelligently and effectively in his chosen medium. Gordon has depicted types of a South that is rapidly passing away and both the beauty and the desolation of landscape in Mississippi and Louisiana.

With the three most heavily played horses out of the money, the chestnut horse Some Chance, covered with a chocolate mud coating, yesterday won the $55,150 Gallant Fox Handicap at Jamaica as 28,195 watched under difficult weather conditions.

One of the longest vigils of the day was kept yesterday at Washington Square, where a crowd soaked by rain waited more than two hours to see the President end his morning tour here at the Roosevelt apartment at 29 Washington Square West.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- The Court of Justice in Marseille today passed a third death sentence in a newspaper racket case in which Pierre Laval, former Chief of Government in Vichy, figured so prominently that he was sentenced to death yesterday in absentia.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- That the future of France lies in an economically united Western Europe, which will be the link between Russia on the one hand and the United States on the other, was the contention today of Andre Istel, financial adviser to the French Government.

The main ballroom of the Plaza will be the setting Thursday afternoon for the annual White Elephant Cocktail Party and Tea Dance, one of the largest fetes of its kind given here each autumn. As in past years the event will benefit the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

Dr. Maurice Ewing temporarily left his professional chair at Princeton a few years ago to conduct experiments at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution. Purpose? To make photographs of the ocean's bottom at great depths and thus to gather facts badly needed by geologists and salvagers of sunken cargoes.

On the periphery of a tropical-born storm, New York City was lashed yesterday for the second day by winds and heavy rain. The Weather Bureau said the storm was subsiding last night and that there would be sunny skies and cool temperatures today.

A second reading of your editorial "The Choice of a Candidate" confirms the opinion that it is a persuasive statement of the case for the re-election of the President. Your fairness in recognizing the weaknesses and down-right mistakes of the Administration and the ability and accomplishments of Mr. Dewey prepares the ground for an honest consideration of the paramount issue -- foreign policy and international relations.

PASSAIC, N.J., Oct 21 -- Charles A. Lindbergh shot down a Japanese plane during his recent trip to the south Pacific war zone, The Passaic Herald-News said in a copyrighted article today. The newspaper said that it had submitted its article to Mr. Lindbergh through business associates and that the flier sent back word that he had no comment to make.

To even casual observers the highlight of the three-day eighteenth annual meeting of the Propeller Club of the United States and the American Merchant Marine Conference, which closed Friday evening in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, was the active participation of American ship owners who, at former meetings were content to sit back and listen.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Oct. 20 (Delayed) -- A group of colorful military and naval personalities, most of whom played leading parts in the early stages of the Pacific war, are serving as commanders under Gen. Douglas MacArthur in the return to the Philippines.

BOSTON. THE Boston Symphony, entering its sixty-fourth year and its twenty-first under Serge Koussevitzky, is attracting a new segment to the public, and indications are that new attendance records will be set. Season subscriptions are above last year's, but individual concert ticket sales are startling even the almost imperturbable box-office overseers.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The all-civilian Iowa eleven taunted Purdue with a game-leading second period touchdown today, and then lived to regret its challenge as the Boilermakers turned on the steam to win in the last half, 26 to 7.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On the issue of foreign policy you state that "the scales tip heavily in favor of the Democratic party" because its platform is more forthright. The last three Democratic platforms have been magnificent, but how have they been performed? They are known more in their breach than in their observance.

HERE is a mystery story told chiefly through the medium of gossip at a boarding house table in a Vermont village near the Canadian border. The most persistent gossiper is Mrs. Clapp, who knows everything that ever happened in the village and a great many things that never happened anywhere.

Reading this, you know just what it is like to cultivate corn under a blazing sun or to try contour plowing for the first time behind a pair of mules.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Tailback Billy Jones' field goal from the 7-yard line in the dying minutes of play gave Tulane a 16-13 victory over an inspired Auburn eleven in a bitterly fought game today.

What was described as "a fundamental advance in microscopy" that makes it possible to see certain internal structures of living cells, tissues, bacteria and industrial material, thus opening up for exploration a world of life hitherto unseen, was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the Optical Society of America at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- With the liberation of western Europe and the Russian occupation of Hitler's former Balkan satellites, the United Nations' machinery for punishing Axis war criminals has begun to turn. There is to be no repetition of the farcical Leipzig trials foisted on the world by the Germans after the last war.

NOT all eyebrows need eyebrow pencil. Only if the brows are too thin, too short, or too light is a pencil really necessary. If a woman has the pale, sandy-colored brows of the blonde or red-head she should use a pencil in one of the many shades of brown.

At the beginning of that period in the New World a Catholic colony in Maryland was enjoying peace and the freedom to worship as it chose.

PARTY plans for campaign buttons are demure this election, as compared to the deluge in 1940. Republicans are sponsoring two conservative pin-ons: one red-white-and-blue, saying "Dewey-Bricker," and one blue-and-white, saying "Dewey."

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- Nell Brinkley, widely known as the creator of a distinctive type of elaborately sketched boy and girl drawings formerly syndicated throughout the United States, died tonight at New Rochelle Hospital. She was 56 years old.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read and reread your important editorial in this morning's NEW YORK TIMES and I am profoundly disturbed. I am convinced of the sincerity of your long and studied exposition and have every reason to believe that you are trying to be fair. I am disturbed by the fact that you have chosen to ignore the most important new influence in our American political life.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- U-boats have reappeared in the Atlantic shipping lanes, Albert V. Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, warned today. At the same time he disclosed that in the Pacific a part of a "vast British fleet" that will be capable in itself of fighting a general action with the Japanese Navy was on its way.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 21 -- Argentina contemplates large scale dehydration and withdrawal of bones from meats to maintain exports in spite of shipping difficulties recently imposed, Ignacio Zuberbuhler, president of the Argentine Rural Society, said today while visiting Chile after having attended its annual cattle exhibition here.

The Riverside Community House, 239 West Sixty-ninth Street, will sponsor three plays for boys and girls by the Clare Tree Major Theatre for Children. The first in the series will be a performance of "Old King Cole" on Saturday morning at the Hunter Playhouse, Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Arguing that the trend of living costs has risen steadily since 1942 despite efforts of the Administration to halt the move, organized labor has pressed its demands for modification or abandonment of the Little Steel formula with renewed vigor here this week in the hope of getting a favorable decision before election day.

The RAF is now using a thirty-pound incendiary parachute bomb filled with methane in gasoline under pressure. The bomb emits a jet of flame about 15 feet long and 2 feet wide. On impact a detonator is fired. The flash touches off the priming in a central tube. This in turn ignites thermite, which heats the interior of the bomb and thus raises the internal pressure.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- High on the list of legislative topics being discussed for the near future is consideration of hundreds of thousands of young men who are serving in the Merchant Marine.

President Roosevelt, openly campaigning for re-election in the usual partisan sense and bidding particularly for New York's forty-seven electoral votes, came from a rain-drenched Washington to an equally wet and wind-swept New York City yesterday to let the people see him as he looks at the moment and judge his physical fitness with their own eyes.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Julius Davis, an 18-year-old naval aviation cadet without any college football experience, powered St. Mary's Pre-Flight to a startling 21-to-12 upset victory over the U.C.L.A. Bruins today.

THE old machine which has been retired and then makes a magnificent comeback to a life of usefulness is fast becoming a folk hero in the literature of this mechanical age. Jenny is the latest newcomer to that group and, in spite of her title, one of the most lovable.

Emperor Hirohito, in the course of commending three top-ranking Japanese officers for their part in the Formosa "victory," yesterday took occasion to declare that "the was situation was daily becoming more pressing," according to a Tokyo domestic radio broadcast.

FROM the popular pastime of guessing about national income billions and figuring out pent-up demands, interest now seems to be shifting in business to more practical considerations. Creeping into this trend is a move toward appraising more clearly the part distribution must play in attaining post-war goals.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Workers added to factory payrolls during August fell behind those who quit, entered the armed forces or were laid off, the Labor Department reported today.

An ambulance and kitchen trailer to be used in devastated French villages was presented yesterday to the French Provisional Government in ceremonies at the French Hospital, 330 West Thirtieth Street. The ambulance which was donated by Mrs. Archibald McKay was accepted on behalf of the French Government by Guerin de Beaumont, Consul General of the Provisional Government.

The bank-credit group formed recently by twenty-four banks in this city is but the foundation stone of a comprehensive, nationwide system of regional groupings which together will provide a credit structure which may well equal, and perhaps supersede, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

With the United States Army asking for many million pounds of flowers, pyrethrum has become a strategic war crop for the Americas. Recent developments have made it highly effective in combating the insect enemies of our troops-flies, fleas, body lice, and the yellow-fever and malaria-carrying mosquitos.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: For several years we have received in our home no daily newspaper except THE NEW YORK TIMES, and particularly recently have I been pleased that we have a great newspaper, perhaps our greatest, which was playing the role of a Wendell Willkie in newspaperdom; in other words, was sitting on the sidelines and watching with critical eye the activities of both sides in this important Presidential election.

As a climax to a fifty-one-mile campaign tour of New York City, made in an open car through a chilling rain, President Roosevelt last night declared himself in favor of establishing world-security machinery before hostilities cease and of having Congress authorize American participation in the application of force against an aggressor without specific approval in each case.

College graduates are engaged in a wider variety of industries than ever before, a recent survey made by Hunter College, to prepare for post-war changes, reveals. A comparison of a pre-war class with one of last year indicates an increase in the employment of women in new positions, which can be attributed to manpower shortages arising from the war situation.

HONOLULU, T.H., Oct 21 -- One of the signs of war disappeared in the Pacific today, a significant move that means the American offensive has reached such speed and assurance we need worry no longer about disastrous counter-attacks.

LONDON, Oct. 21 (U.P.) -- Some 250 Italy-based American heavy bombers, cooperating with Russian armies driving on Budapest, bombed the Gyoer and Szombathely rail yards in western Hungary today.

The eighty-eighth graduating class of the New York State Maritime Academy, numbering 184, yesterday afternoon heard Vice Admiral Emory S. Land, War Shipping Administrator, call their wartime education at the academy "something that will endure long after the ships we've built and bragged about are forgotten."

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 19 (Delayed) -- The Russian Army's behavior in Rumania has been excellent. It has surpassed all expectations. Considering the crimes and atrocities perpetrated by Rumanian troops against the populations of the Ukraine and Crimea, observers are amazed by the Soviet soldiers' self-control.

American colleges and universities this fall show substantial increases in civilian enrollments, compared with registration a year ago, although many of these institutions still face considerable financial peril, according to a survey of 454 colleges conducted by President Raymond Walters of the University of Cincinnati.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is impossible for me to comprehend the considerations which dictate your present stand for two reasons. First, I can't reconcile the position you now take with that which you took and so ably supported by powerful arguments four years ago. If those reasons were valid then, they are doubly so now.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 21 -- Argentina's Vice President, Col. Juan Peron, announced to the press today that the gradual return to their military duties of all officers who at present hold civilian posts had begun yesterday and would be completed by Jan. 1.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 21 -- It is obvious, as an officer here remarked the other day, that if the Allied armies at Germany's gateways had everything they wanted at the front -- everything in the way of supplies and terrain -- there would be an all-out offensive against the Reich at this moment.

Citing his record during eighteen years in the Senate as proof of his sincerity of purpose and will to work, Senator Robert F. Wagner in a State-wide radio broadcast last night listed development of "ever- increasing opportunities for American business" as his first objective in seeking re-election.

FIVE more guest artists will make their appearance with the Ballet Theatre during the current week at the Metropolitan Opera House. Four of them -- Argentinita, Pilar Lopez, Jose Greco and Manolo Vargas -- are by no means newcomers to these programs, but Igor Youskevitch is.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 21 -- Occupy, sleek sprinter from the stable of John Marsch, Chicago sportsman, scored a spectacular photo-finish decision over J.H. Rouse's Three Dots to capture the inaugural Autumn Handicap at Churchill Downs today.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 21 -- The death toll in Cleveland's disastrous explosions and fire climbed toward the 100 mark late today as a systematic search was made of the half-mile square ruins in the East Side north of St. Clair Avenue between East 55th and East 65th streets.

GENERAL MacARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, in the Philippines, Sunday, Oct. 22 (U.P.) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur issued a warning today to the Japanese military leaders in the Philippines that he would hold them immediately responsible for any failure to accord to prisoners and internees the proper treatment to which they are entitled.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 21 -- The combination of a 130-pound impost and a muddy track proved too much for Twilight Tear today, and the Calumet Farm filly finished fourth, out of the money for the first time in her career, as Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Dare Me splashed to victory in the thirtieth Maryland Handicap at Laurel Park.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- As Gen. Douglas MacArthur's strong ground and air forces, backed to the hilt by powerful naval surface and air support, launched the long-expected invasion of the Philippines this week, military and naval observers in Washington indicated their belief that the battle of the Philippines might well be considered the opening phase of the coming battle of Japan.

ABOARD A BRITISH AIRCRAFT CARRIER in the Indian Ocean, Oct. 21 (AP) -- British Eastern Fleet units operating in long-range liaison with the Americans in the Pacific have just completed their most prolonged mission of carrier-borne air attack and inshore bombardments, a bold foray into the Nicobar Islands group in the Bay of Bengal.

RUSHVILLE, Ind., Oct. 21 -- Mrs. Wendell L. Willkie made a fervent appeal today that all conjecture be ended as to whether her husband would have supported the Presidential candidacy of Governor Dewey of New York or President Roosevelt at the coming election.

SUNDRY vagaries of mood and behavior apt to turn up between ages 9 and 13 were long ago conveyed by Booth Tarkington in "Penrod," as they are depicted for a new generation in such a comic strip as "Our Bill." It is a phase of growing up, as Dr. Fritz Redl was quoted as saying here some time ago, when "the nicest children begin to behave in the most awful way."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The "secret" label attached to a Navy court's report on Pearl Harbor added new heat tonight to the political controversy over the disaster, with Representative Maas, Republican, of Minnesota, contend-this was "an alibi for not giving it to the public."

The election of Colby M. Chester as chairman of the New York Red Cross Chapter's board of directors, and of J. Harrison Heckman, now serving as Red Cross commissioner for the Central and Pacific areas, as executive director, was announced yesterday by the chapter's chairman, Lieut. Gen. James G. Harbord.

Retail stores in the week announced an earlier Christmas shopping season to start Nov. 8. The week's business for department stores ran about 23 per cent above the same week last year. MOSCOW, Oct. 21 (U.P.) -- A report by the official Tass news agency on the reactions of the Lublin press also was displayed prominently by the Soviet newspapers today.

ON THE LEYTE BEACHHEAD, Oct. 21 -- The Filipinos are mad with joy at having the Americans back after the years of Japanese occupation and brutality, which drove many of them in Leyte into the mountains. Despite the heavy naval barrage the natives lined the hills.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Field Marshall Gen. TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 21 (AP) -- An immediate increase in the price ceilings of both fresh and processed citrus fruits to compensate growers for their storm losses has been asked by directors of the Florida Citrus Exchange.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 21 -- Wendell Willkie would not have supported President Roosevelt's campaign for a fourth term, Gov. Raymond E. Baldwin declared today, in discussing a talk with Mr. Willkie on the day that Governor Dewey was nominated for President.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Three Navy trainees playing their last football game for Villanova combined their efforts in a scoring thrust late in the second period today to give the Wildcats a 7 -- 0 victory over Muhlenberg at Shibe Park today.

COLUMBUS, Oct. 21 -- Ohio State made its bid for this year's national college football championship today. In a wild last-quarter, played before a record war-time crowd of 73,477, the Buckeyes pushed over 20 points in the last fifteen minutes to beat the Great Lakes team, 26 -- 6, and spoil the homecoming of their former coach, Lieut. Paul E. Brown.

The first performance of Walter Piston's "Fugue on a Victory Tune" featured last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Artur Rodzinski conducting, at Carnegie Hall. The work is one of seventeen commissioned last season by the League of Composers, the Philharmonic-Symphony and the Columbia Broadcasting System, each to commemorate some aspect of the present war.

ORSON WELLES is coming back to radio in his own regular weekly show scheduled to begin at 7:15 P.M. on Friday, Nov. 17, over the Columbia Broadcasting System and WABC. Tentatively entitled "The People's Request," the fifteen-minute shows will have no established format, and Mr. Welles, according to reports, will do just about as he pleases.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial seems to condemn the candidate, Dewey, because he approves of some of the measures instigated by the New Deal. We all realize that many social changes are desirable, and that in many lines Government help for the underprivileged may be necessary. Why condemn a Republican candidate because he realizes that?

LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Dr. Forrest C. (Phog) Allen said today he had sent a telegram to Ned Irish, acting president of Madison Square Garden, New York, furnishing him with the name of at least one basketball player who was alleged to have "sold out" to gamblers during an Eastern basketball tournament last year.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- The creation of military and civil zones in France, which extends the authority of the French Government over a wide territory and increases that authority in civil areas, was generally considered today, in both France and Allied circles here, as the harbinger of early recognition of the de Gaulle Regime as the full de jure Government of France.

About sixty manufacturers of upholstered furniture spent an anxious twenty-four hours last week, with some already picturing themselves behind bars, following a meeting with Office of Price Administration representatives.

In an effort to solve the many problems of the high school curriculum and to modernize it to meet the changing needs of students, a cooperative study has been begun by the Rochester public high schools in conjunction with the University of Rochester. The enterprise has been given general approval by the State Education Department at Albany.

THE Presidential campaign has to a certain extent developed into a contest between the older and the younger generation. Governor Dewey has denounced his opponent and other members of the present Administration as being too old and too tired.

MOSCOW, Oct. 21 -- Going beyond the terms of the Stalin-Churchill communique, the Soviet press reported that today the two war leaders had reached real unanimity on political and military questions affecting Rumania, Bulgaria, Yugoslavia, Hungary and Greece and greeted with relief the "disappearance of the Balkan powderkeg" from the European political scene.

MENLO PARK, N.J., Oct. 21 -- The 131-foot Edison Tower of Light, visible for many miles when illuminated, ended its wartime blackout briefly tonight when former Governor Charles Edison, son of Thomas A. Edison, operated the switch to turn on the beacon in commemoration of the sixty-fifth anniversary of the invention of the first commercial incandescent electric light.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 21 -- Senator Byrd's failure to say anything publicly on behalf of the Roosevelt-Truman ticket, or to put a stop to efforts being made outside Virginia to obtain votes for him, at the expense of that ticket, is causing considerable comment.

Brooklyn College's football team battled an informal eleven composed of Coast Guardsmen from the U.S.S. Lorain to a 7-7 tie yesterday in an exhibition contest on the Flatbush gridiron. The game was marred by a steady downpour which slowed both squads' offenses and kept the ball very slippery.
LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Ever since 1896 Kansas has been taking it on the chin when the Nebraska Cornhuskers came to Lawrence.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Large cutbacks in war production, which were foreseen as an employment and morale problem this fall, have failed to materialize in anything like the expected volume, and no major cuts are now in sight before victory in Europe.

LONDON, Sunday, Oct. 22 -- Red Army troops, in a twenty-mile advance, yesterday reached the Danube River eighty-four miles south of Budapest and reopened a great offensive to win the Hungarian capital, while Berlin admitted that massive Russian tank columns had driven twenty miles inside East Prussia to within fifteen miles of the great German rail hub of Insterburg.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (U.P.) -- First an enemy submarine hit the Liberty ship George Ade. Then the mid-September hurricane with the sea lashed into mountainous waves, tried furiously to sink the ship. But she survived both ordeals.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 21 (AP) -- A group of service men, aroused by a work stoppage which paralyzed the huge North American Aviation Company's bomber plant, stormed its entrances today, dispersing pickets and tearing up union placards.

The National Music Council has conducted a survey to ascertain to what extent music is at present used in leading nervous and mental hospitals throughout the country, and what the results have been. BOSTON, Oct 21 -- Voter registration in the New England States has pushed to record figures as the election campaigns head into their final two weeks with all signs indicating that President Roosevelt and Governor Dewey are running a close race in the pivotal State of Massachusetts.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., announced today the winners in its annual aviation writing and photographic contest.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 -- Many small companies attempting to raise capital through sale of equity securities have been compelled, on the average, to sell a dollar's worth of stock to obtain a net return of 80 cents, according to the results of a survey made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

MOSCOW, Oct. 21 -- The keynote to the conception, execution and results of the Churchill-Stalin conference can be found in Prime Minister Churchill's vivid phrase that only Anglo-American and Russian friendship in war and peace can save the world and avert future bloody sacrifices by yet unborn generations.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 21 -- Admiral Nicholas Horthy, former Regent of Hungary, accompanied by his immediate family, the chief of his military staff, Lieut. Gen. Anton Vattay, and Maj. Gen. Gyvergy Brunssik, commander of his personal bodyguard, are "enjoying the right of asylum" granted at Admiral Horthy's personal request somewhere in the Reich, according to an official German review of the Hungarian affair put out by the Berlin DNB agency tonight.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- The Germans' parting shots at Britain with their flying bombs are growing fewer. The attacks are small and scattered and are of the hit-and-run variety.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 21 -- The chances of President Roosevelt to repeat on Nov. 7 his feats of 1932, 1936 and 1940 in capturing the twelve electoral votes of Wisconsin are said here to rest squarely on the ability of his labor supporters to amass sufficient strength in Milwaukee County to offset the large vote by which he is expected to lose out-State.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 21 -- Chile contemplates the early establishment of diplomatic and commercial relations with the Soviet Union and Italy, informed sources said today.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Stanley Orr, chairman of the Cleveland Red Cross unit, in a message to Washington Red Cross headquarters today expressed the fear that fire fatalities might reach 200.

GENERAL MacARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS ON LEYTE, Sunday, Oct. 22 -- United States invasion forces have captured Tacloban, capital of the central Philippine Island of Leyte, with its airdrome and a second airfield, while advancing an average of four miles on all sectors through strong Japanese pillbox defenses with only light casualties, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced in a communique today.

STORRS, Conn., Oct. 21 -- In a cold, driving rain that kept a crowd of 1,000 spectators huddled throughout the contest, the University of Connecticut Huskies defeated City College of New York today, 21 to 0. It was the Huskies' fourth triumph in five starts.

Fifteen years ago Dr. Kenneth C.D. Hickman of Rochester, N.Y., began to experiment with high vacuums to dry photographic film for tropical shipment. Now he is using the same method to wring vitamins out of raw materials. Out of his work, an industry has grown which is now the largest producer of vitamin A concentrates and the only large-scale producer of vitamin B.

Last week construction work on New York City's Brooklyn-Battery vehicular tunnel got a "green light" from the War Production Board. CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Buell St. John, a veteran of the war in the Pacific, kicked a field goal from the 8-yard line with seven seconds left in the game and gave North Carolina Navy Pre-flight a 3-to-0 decision over the Georgia Pre-flight eleven today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- The hardwood industry, considered a month ago to have passed its peak in production, now finds it necessary not only to equal 1944 output, but to increase production nearly 7 per cent in 1945.

A NEGRO with wartime wages in his pocket (along with a pistol and a pint of gin) loses his bus seat at the Carvell City rest-stop, and is tossed to the sidewalk when he protests. Later old Hendricks, the town's bumbling marshal, drives up, bored with the duty of jailing yet another uppity black boy.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 21 (AP) -- The mysterious lady in red who has been getting in the hair of New England horse tracks by plunging on favorites to show returned today to Rockingham Park. The woman, who has created several minus pools by her transactions, showed up just as track officials believed that publicity had scared her away.

The world championship three-cushion billiard tournament will be held at the Hotel Capitol starting on Dec. 3, it was announced yesterday by Charles C. Peterson, president of the Billiard Association of America. It will be the first time in ten years that the competition will be held in this city.

IT is a foregone conclusion that war will leave in its wake a host of staggering problems. Peace will not be a mere matter of signing a lot of treaties at the conference table. There will be no real and lasting peace until the wreckage of conflict has been cleared away and we resume our normal occupations.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Kentucky bounced back to the victory road today by defeating a scrappy Virginia Military Institute eleven, 26 -- 2.

The American forces plunging ashore on Leyte Island found themselves 2,500 miles from Milne Bay, on the southeastern tip of New Guinea, where they started their advance sixteen months ago: about 600 miles from Manila; about 1,000 miles from Hong Kong; about 2,000 miles from Tokyo.

The reproduction of the painting illustrating the article "Six Delusions About Germany" was displayed for the first time at the opening of the House of German Art at Munich in 1937. Time seemed to roll back when I saw this picture again, farther back than 1937, well into the Nineteen Twenties.

MR. MERGENDAHL wrote his novel "between engagements at North Africa, Tarawa, the Marshalls and elsewhere," and even if for reasons no less fortuitous it would be pleasant to praise his book. There are other reasons: he appears to be quite as attractive as his hero, Harry Trexler, from whom he is indistinguishable; as young, as bewildered, as awkward, and as angry.

Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, Republican nominee for United States Senator, will start tomorrow on the most intensive phase of his campaign. Mrs. Curran, the former Miss Margaret Farley, will accompany him during part of his schedule.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- In a dramatic finish that had the deciding touchdown pass in the air when time ran out, Cornell's injury-ridden Big Red team snatched a 13-to-6 victory over Sampson's powerful blue jackets on rainswept Schoellkopf Field before 3,000 sturdy fans today.
BOSTON, Oct. 21 -- German prisoners of war, who once risked their lives to destroy Americans, now are getting a large measure of credit for saving New England farmers a heavy crop loss this year.

This country has no intention of attempting to establish a postwar maritime monopoly, Basil Harris, president of the United States Lines, asserted yesterday. The United States wants only a fair share of its export and import business handled by an active American merchant fleet, capable of operating on a basis of competitive equality with foreign-flag shipping throughout the world, he added.

THE recent fruitless attempt by the Committee for Rebirth of Distomo to induce at least one of the twenty-four Berlins in the United States to change its name to that of the Nazi-obliterated Greek city shows that Americans generally are quite satisfied with home-town names, no matter how queer or ill-favored.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- One of these autmunal afternoons -- it might be next Saturday at the Polo Grounds -- the prolific point-producing juggernaut that is the Army football team will receive a true test, truer, at least, than the one the cadets faced today at Michie Stadium, where a virtually weaponless Coast Guard Academy eleven went the way of all West Point opponents thus far.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 21 -- Farm communities are beginning to regard as practical possibilities in the not-too-distant future things which a few years ago would have been brushed off as fantastic ideals, or at best remote hopes. Among them are an electric power line and a surfaced road to every farm home.

LILY BULBS, which for the most part must be planted during November and December because they arrive so late in the market, provide a wealth of exotic color and fragrance in the summer garden without sacrificing hardiness or vigor.

The National Association of Manufacturers is alarmed at the fall in the number of patents issued since this country declared war. On a per capita basis, invention is 45 per cent below the pre-depression level. Why? One reason is that most of the good scientists and engineers are working on war projects.

Sugar shares and securities of Marshall Field Co. and the Texas Pacific Land Trust were outstanding performers yesterday in a generally dull two-hour session of the New York Stock Exchange. As a whole, the list drifted narrowly and closed a shade firmer.

With a pair of victories to his credit, Edward S. Jackson Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., got off to a good start in the first two rounds of the United States Chess Federation amateur championship play at the Marshall Club yesterday.

ON D-day the Anglo-American invaders of Europe found that the Luftwaffe had been broken. From the beaches of Normandy to the Siegfried Line, our armored divisions and infantry have thrust forward under skies almost empty of the once-dreaded Nazi aerial armadas.
For quite some time I have been scanning your editorial page for an editorial in support either of Mr. Dewey or Mr. Roosevelt, for I, too, have been undecided as to which would be the wiser choice.

The Republican campaign to gain control of the White House is now entering its final phase, with Governor Dewey attacking, attacking, attacking. This will continue until election, with only one more speech scheduled to be devoted to Mr. Dewey's own remedies for the things he thinks the New Deal has done wrong.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle has cemented and is expanding his control over civil affairs in France to the point that it would come as no surprise if Great Britain and the United States before a much longer delay recognized his de facto authority as a provisional government.

ONE of the Barrymore freres, who shall be first-name-less since the avenging arm of Hollywood is long, once replied, when asked his opinion of the cinema, that it was the Woolworth of show business. The wit of this appraisal is apparent when one contemplates the magnitude, product, popularity, prosperity, ubiquity and countless other facets of both institutions.

Walter Soltow, New Utrecht High's unbeaten harrier, repeated his conquest of last year when he captured the Brooklyn title in the P.S.A.L. borough championships at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. Soltow finished about 200 yards in front of his team-mate, Howard Hehn, in 13:04 for the three-mile test.

JUST one hundred years ago appeared what was possibly the most sensational novel produced in nineteenth-century America. The novel was "The Quaker City, or the Monks of Monk Hall, a Romance of Philadelphia Life, Mystery and Crime," and its author was George Lippard.

I THINK that all ambitions are lawful except those which climb upward on the miseries or credulities of mankind. All intellectual or artistic-ambitions are permissible, up to and even beyond the limit of prudent sanity. They can hurt no one.

The impact on sales of the War Production Board's recent decision permitting men's trousers to be made with pleats is causing concern among men's clothing manufactures and merchants, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

A NEW and important member is about to be added to the ranks of octogenarians in the musical profession. This time it is Alexandre Gretchaninoff, the veteran Russian composer, for the last few years a resident of this city, who is celebrating his eightieth birthday next Wednesday.

LONDON (By Wireless). THOSE who imagine that the supreme German crisis at home and on the battlefronts must find the Fuehrer prostrate do not know Hitler. An analysis of his reactions, based on a close study of his personality, in the last two decades suggests a different picture.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I thoroughly agree with you when you say: "* * * the fact remains that in the single greatest crisis of our times, when Britain stood alone as the outpost of civilization against the dark forces that threatened to engulf us. Mr. Roosevelt saw the issue clearly and met the issue boldly."

NORTHFIELD, N.J., Oct. 21 (AP) -- A chilling northeaster failed to dampen the enthusiasm of the golfers in the James E. (Sonny) Fraser invitation tourney today at the Atlantic City Country Club as Sonny Fraser, the club president, blasted his way into the semi-final round with a pair of decisive victories over Bert English, 8 and 7, and Harry Elwell, 5 and 4.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Vice President Wallace declared tonight that farmers could expect their income to be cut in half "within a few years" if a Republican administration was elected.

LAST Thursday Toscanini started rehearsing for his next batch of broadcasts that begins this afternoon, and already the atmosphere around the National Broadcasting Company is a good deal tenser than it ordinarily is. Not that the boys in the NBC orchestra are a timid lot.

ROME, Oct. 21 (AP) -- British Eighth Army troops advanced into the eastern Po Valley in two directions today, capturing the coastal town of Cesanatico, eighteen miles below Ravenna, in a drive up the Adriatic coast and making what was described as "considerable progress" northwestward along the Rimini-Bologna highway.

Sugar shares and securities of Marshall Field Co. and the Texas Pacific Land Trust were outstanding performers yesterday in a generally dull two-hour session of the New York Stock Exchange. As a whole, the list drifted narrowly and closed a shade firmer.

With a pair of victories to his credit, Edward S. Jackson Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., got off to a good start in the first two rounds of the United States Chess Federation amateur championship play at the Marshall Club yesterday.

ON D-day the Anglo-American invaders of Europe found that the Luftwaffe had been broken. From the beaches of Normandy to the Siegfried Line, our armored divisions and infantry have thrust forward under skies almost empty of the once-dreaded Nazi aerial armadas.

The wit of this appraisal is apparent when one contemplates the magnitude, product, popularity, prosperity, ubiquity and countless other facets of both institutions.

Walter Soltow, New Utrecht High's unbeaten harrier, repeated his conquest of last year when he captured the Brooklyn title in the P.S.A.L. borough championships at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. Soltow finished about 200 yards in front of his team-mate, Howard Hehn, in 13:04 for the three-mile test.

The impact on sales of the War Production Board's recent decision permitting men's trousers to be made with pleats is causing concern among men's clothing manufactures and merchants, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

A NEW and important member is about to be added to the ranks of octogenarians in the musical profession. This time it is Alexandre Gretchaninoff, the veteran Russian composer, for the last few years a resident of this city, who is celebrating his eightieth birthday next Wednesday.

LONDON (By Wireless). THOSE who imagine that the supreme German crisis at home and on the battlefronts must find the Fuehrer prostrate do not know Hitler. An analysis of his reactions, based on a close study of his personality, in the last two decades suggests a different picture.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I thoroughly agree with you when you say: "* * * the fact remains that in the single greatest crisis of our times, when Britain stood alone as the outpost of civilization against the dark forces that threatened to engulf us. Mr. Roosevelt saw the issue clearly and met the issue boldly."

Norman Thomas, five times Socialist candidate for President, said yesterday at La Guardia Field on his return from a speaking trip in Michigan that he had no preference as between President Roosevelt and Governor Dewey.

Registration in sixty-five up-State and Long Island cities and villages where voters must register in person showed a loss of 9.2 per cent from the registration in 1940 for the last Presidential election, a tabulation of figures furnished by correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES disclosed yesterday.

MOSCOW, Oct. 22 -- A sharp attack on the policies of Mohammed Said Maraghei, Iran's Premier and Foreign Minister, as harmful to the best interests of the Iranian people and injurious to Iran's relations with the Soviet Union, Britain and other Allies was published today in Trud, Soviet trade union newspaper.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Detroit Lions, sparked by Frankie Sinkwich, who last week was hospitalized with appendicitis, fought off a last-period drive that reached the shadow of their goal posts and held the favored Chicago Bears to a 21-21 tie before 23,835 fans at Wrigley Field today.
LONDON. Oct. 22 [AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 20 (Delayed) -- Brazil has not made soundings, or at least diplomatic quarters deny that soundings have been made about Argentina's rejoining the American bloc of nations in policies. It is understood that Brazil will not interfere directly in the Argentine situation but will indirectly, as she did for instance, in the recent statement of Minister of the Exterior Pedro Lean Velloso Netto.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- Almost before there has been time to digest the Churchill-Stalin communique on the Moscow discussions, the Lublin press of the Polish Committee of National Liberation, backed by the most influential sections of the Russian press, has renewed the campaign against the Polish Government in London.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Excellent weather conditions for drying out the new corn crop have prevailed for about three weeks, and moisture content in the grain is decreasing steadily. Although a large part of the available freight cars are being used for the movement of soy beans, considerable new corn is commencing to move, and late last week about 25 per cent of the receipts represented 1944 crop grain.

Protesting the premature publicity that she said Rex Stout had given his resignation as a director because of her leadership, Miss Dorothy Thompson, newspaper columnist, in a letter made public yesterday, offered her resignation as president of Freedom House.

ROME, Oct. 19 (delayed) -- Here is the text of the prize winning essay "What Victory Means to Me," which has just won a $500 war bond for Pvt Isadore Rubin of 1030 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, Fifth Army tank destroyer battalion, in a theatre-wide contest:

MOSCOW, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The magazine War and the Working Class in an article today cited American statistics showing that the United States controls 57 per cent of the world's oil resources, Great Britain 27 per cent and the Soviet Union 11 per cent.

Prices of cotton for future delivery fluctuated irregularly within a very narrow trading range last week. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net declines of 5 to 10 points.

While Notre Dame, Army, Ohio State and Georgia Tech added to their string of conquests and Penn took the week off for exams. Navy suffered a second checkmate to what was fancied its most lustrous football campaign of all.
LONDON, Oct. 22 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (U.P.) -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced tonight that four new types of Treasury bonds and notes will be offered during the Sixth War Loan drive beginning Nov. 20.

LONDON, Monday, Oct. 23 -- Russian troops, in a new, twelve-mile-deep invasion of German soil, yesterday reached the Niemen River immediately opposite the East Prussian rail city of Tilsit, and two Soviet armies launched a pincers assault to seize the great fortress of Insterburg, Berlin announced last night.

LONDON, Monday, Oct. 23 -- Russian troops driving the Germans out of the valuable nickel mine country in northern Finland have smashed to the Norwegian border along an eighty-mile front and stand within three miles of Kirkenes, Nazi air and U-boat raiding base on the lend-lease Arctic supply line to Murmansk, a Moscow communique announced tonight.

KANDY, Ceylon, Oct. 22 (U.P.) -- British West African troops in the Arakan region of lower Burma have pushed the Japanese eastward to the Kaladan River after driving them from the narrow Sangu Valley, just inside India, across the 3,000-foot jungle-covered Arakan hills.

Nearly 1,000 persons thronged historic Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, yesterday for the twenty-third annual observance of the British Harvest Festival. All British societies in the metropolitan area participated in the service, which was preceded by a parade from Vesey Street to the church, in which their representatives carried British colors.

ROME, Oct. 22 -- British forces sweeping the Germans out of the Aegean have hopped to the northern extremity with a landing on the strategic island of Lemnos, guarding the entrance to the Dardanelles.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 22 -- A maritime mystery reminiscent of that which for a long time involved the Marie Celeste is recalled in the finding of a Cuban cargo ship adrift in the Gulf Stream with a dog the only living thing aboard.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- There was further evidence last week of a tighter situation developing in cash lard as the result of the small output incident to a light run of hogs, and the fact that the bulk of the stock in cold storage is owned by the Government.

Mack Trucks, Inc., was back in the bus business today after getting the "go ahead" signal from the War Production Board for resumption of output after twenty-one months in war work following requisitioning of the company's Allentown, Pa., plant by the Navy for production of airplanes.

Dr. Shuster, president of Hunter College, in the course of a talk on "What Shall We Do With Germany?" before Kiwanis International Oct. 18, said that all parts of Europe will look ideologically alike at the conclusion of the war.

Three and one-half floors containing 70,000 square feet of space in the financial district have been leased by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for the purpose of grouping its subsidiaries. The agency, which occupies the entire sixth floor in the Federal Reserve Bank Building, has rented the fifth, sixth and half of the seventh floor in Pine Street and the entire sixth floor in 60 Wall Street.

Devoid of the spectacular, but interesting and exciting in an orthodox sort of way, the home opening of the New York Football Giants before a crowd of 40,734 at the Polo Grounds yesterday was everything for which Stout Steve Owen could ask.

A Swedish newspaper reported yesterday that Austrian partisans had occupied several regions of Austria, including the "mountainous parts of Styria, Carinthia and the areas near the Tyrolean frontier.'' There were new reports of sabotage by the Partisans and Gestapo counter-measures aimed at Austrian Catholics.

President Roosevelt used his speech before the Foreign Policy Association on Saturday evening to add to the blue-prints of Dumbarton Oaks a recommendation of very great importance. This was his proposal that the American representative on the Council of the new league of The United Nations "be empowered in advance by the people themselves, by constitutional means through their representatives in Congress, with authority to act."

After remaining constant at 113.45 for three consecutive weeks, the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices (1926=100) rose fractionally to 113.47, a change of about 0.02 per cent. There was, however, more activity in the individual indexes.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- The American and British air forces claimed the skies over Germany for their own today as they attacked vital communications, transport and industrial centers of the Reich with some 1,400 heavy bombers, without a single bomber being lost.

Dogs to the number of 466 strutted yesterday in the Fourth Regiment Armory, Jamaica, most of them handsomely, a few indifferently. It was during the Staten Island Kennel Club's seventh annual exhibition held for the benefit of the American Women's Hospital Reserve Corps.

A "great oratorical meeting," staged in Fukuoka yesterday as another of Japan's current series of "Crush Anglo-America" rallies to spur the Japanese people to greater war production, heard Seizo Kobayashi, president of the Imperial Rule Assistance Political Society, warn that "the enemy with great military strength and numerical superiority is attempting to wipe us out."

In his regular Sunday broadcast from City Hall yesterday afternoon, Mayor La Guardia announced that in the next six months every man, woman and child, exclusive of infants, in this country, would have little more than half a pound of meat daily. The Mayor based his forecast on allocation figures released by the War Food Administration.

Asserting that there is "only one issue in this campaign -- the issue of peace." Russell W. Davenport, the editor who ran Wendell L. Willkie's campaign for the Presidency in 1940. declared last night that Governor Dewey, the Republican candidate this year, has disrupted efforts of statesmen "to reach mutual decisions" by his "ignorant misuse of minor issues for temporary political advantage."

Manufacturers of nationally advertised food products and pharmaceuticals who desire to repurchase their own trade-marked brands of surplus goods to meet post-war demands are awaiting with interest appointment of the four-man board to administer the Surplus Property Act of 1944, according to advertising men here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The American Red Cross has sent 5,000 tubes of penicillin by air express to the International Red Cross committee in Geneva to be used in treatment of American prisoners of war held by Germany.

Although producer Dave Wolper did all he could to keep "Men to the Sea" on the boards, the Herbert Kubly play was withdrawn on Saturday night from the National after its third week, or twenty-third performance, thereby increasing the number of week-end closings to four.

PARIS, Oct. 22 -- Persistent reports of unrest in Spain seep across the frontier, although it has been closed to international traffic. The general tenor of these reports is that Republican forces are rising against the Franco government and that several thousand are already armed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Senator Joseph Hurst Ball, 38-year-old Minnesota Republican, will risk party censure tomorrow by formally calling for the re-election of President Roosevelt on the premise that he is better prepared than Governor Dewey to steer the nation along the vital road to permanent peace.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- Of Wendell Willkie it can be said that "he being dead, yet speaketh," The Times of London says in an editorial it is publishing tomorrow morning about the election in the United States.

United States Plywood Corporation has appointed Fred B. Smales manager of their California sales division; Don L. Braley, manager of the San Francisco distributing unit; Don L. Kesselring, manager of the Oakland, Calif., distributing unit, and John D. Patriguin, resident manager in Fresno.

WITH AMERICAN RANGERS in the Philippines, Oct. 17 (Delayed) (AP) -- A tragedy of the Pacific war in which an American civilian guerrilla fighter killed his sick wife and child to keep them out of the hands of the Japanese and who was slain himself after he had shot many of the enemy was disclosed today by Ranger Lieut. Leon Tinnell.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (U.P.) -- One picture, an old proverb says, tells more than 10,000 words. With this in mind, an Army officer is carrying on experiments in the Senate chamber which may save a lot of talk.

ROME, Oct. 22 -- A problem of the American Red Cross in occupied Germany before the German surrender will grow out of the increased needs of troops for "on post" facilities, it was brought out here today at a conference of Basil O'Connor, chairman of the American Red Cross, and his principal aides.

Twenty-five additional spot authorizations for production of specific civilian products, including one to the Long Island City, Queens, plant of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., to make 52,000 innerspring mattresses within the next year, have been approved by the War Production Board, Region 2, it was announced last night by Lewis S. Greenleaf Jr., regional director.

WESTON, Conn., Oct. 22 -- Franklin P. Adams, scrivener and "Information Please" luminary, rides to the hustings these autumn nights as Democratic candidate for State Senator from Connecticut's Twenty-fifth District.

Nineteeen young men received yesterday afternoon from the Jewish Theological Seminary of America degrees that gave them the right to be rabbis and teachers of their religion. The commencement was attended by 1,200 persons in the seminary quadrangle at 122d Street and Broadway.

TACLOBAN, Philippines, Monday, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Against a background of aircraft fire, Gen. Douglas MacArthur today announced establishment of the temporary seat of the Philippine Commonwealth Government in this recaptured capital of Leyte.

Ambrose Casner and Miss Ruth Sherman won the metropolitan contract bridge mixed pair title in two sessions of play at the Park Central Hotel yesterday. They scored 388 1/2 match points. Second, with 383 1/2 points, were Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Jaeger, while George Rapee and Mrs. Vivian Hanson were third with 368.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically from Sofia and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

AACHEN, Germany, Oct. 22. -- The American flag went up in Aachen today and officials of the Allied Military Government began their rule in the first large German city to be conquered by our arms. The governing officials had little real business to do today, however, once they had set up shop. There were no local customers. Aachen is shattered and dead beyond description.

If the old electric iron will not heat up or the toaster develops a short circuit, the housewife stands a better chance of getting it repaired today -- and in shorter order -- than she did six months ago, according to reports received from electrical appliance service centers yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y. Oct. 22. (AP) -- In a telegram sent to President Roosevelt tonight Frank Gannett, publisher of the Gannett newspapers, criticized the Chief Executive for the latter's description of the Gannett papers as "isolationist" in an address last night in New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Assurances to employes in war plants that their positions have not been jeopardized by the inclusion of the names of their concerns in a catalogue put out by the Defense Plant Corporation, a Reconstruction Finance Corporation subsidiary, was given here today by Jesse H. Jones, Secretary of Commerce and head of the RFC.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 22 (AP) -- J. Louis Reynolds, vice president of the Reynolds Metals Company, replied tonight to a statement by Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican national chairman, by saying that "Mr. Brownell is skating on thin ice when he attempts to attribute my support of Mr. Roosevelt to favors received."

The Museum of Modern Art will open two exhibitions to the public on Wednesday, presenting comprehensive views of the work of Lyonel Feininger and the late Marsden Hartley. Another outstanding event of the week will be the memorial exhibition of paintings by the late Anne Goldthwaite, which opens today at Knoedler's.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 22 -- A sustained steel rate, a drop in net order volume and an easier delivery situation were highlights in news of the steel industry last week. Indications are that the steel ingot rate this week will be close to the 97 per cent figure for last week which was up one point from the week before.

In an atmosphere of high anticipation on both sides of the footlights, "Fashions of the Times," third edition, will go through final rehearsals today in preparation for the premiere tomorrow afternoon at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

The record-breaking volume of new corporate bond offerings reaching the market in the last month or so has provided a real test for the principle of competitive bidding for securities for re-offering to the public. The results so far have not established definitely the principle as a cure-all for or a solution of the problems of corporate financing.
LONDON, Oct. 23 (Reuter) -- In today's editorial, The London Times welcomes the reassurance that American foreign policy will not be involved in the coming Presidential election.

Mayor La Guardia, in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall yesterday, joined with the City Council in appealing to Governor Dewey to call a special session of the Legislature in order to extend the voting hours on Nov. 7.

On few subjects is there more confusion of thought in all countries than on the role and effect of foreign trade. But this confusion of thought seems to be particularly evident today in Great Britain, which has traditionally seen the foreign-trade problem with greatest clarity.

If there was one passage in Mr. Roosevelt's address before the Foreign Policy Association that evoked an especially warm response from his audience, it was the passage in which he paid tribute to an outstanding Republican, sitting at his table, who has been for four years a member of his Administration-Henry Stimson.

The regional office of the Solid Fuels Administration for War announced yesterday that twenty-two coal dealers and eighty-three coal consumers in New York City and suburban areas had been penalized between Sept. 1 and Oct. 15 for violations of anthracite coal regulations.

On all the fronts in Europe, as in the Far East, the tide of battle continues to roll in our favor. Aachen, the "impregnable" bastion of the Siegfried Line, which Hitler proposed to make the German Verdun and Stalingrad that the Americans should not pass, has fallen after a siege of thirteen days.
ROME, Oct. 22 -- A Roman audience that did not know whether to laugh or cry saw the first performance in a former Axis country of Charles Chaplin's movie, "The Great Dictator," today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Trading in oats and barley remains relatively slow on the Chicago Board of Trade, although December oats acted tight last week as the result of buying induced by a belief imports from Canada would be curtailed owing to a desire to put as much wheat in Eastern lake ports as possible before the close of lake navigation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Foreign Economic Administattion intends to follow a policy of relaxing export controls to the extent compatible with war-time exigencies and reconversion possibilities, Leo T. Crowley, head of the FEA, announced today.

There is a tendency in this modern world to "pigeonhole" Christianity in "an altogether secular civilization spreading around the globe," with religion in general and Christianity in particular playing no dominant part in it, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, said in his sermon yesterday at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive at 122d Street.

Employing the term "deliberate falsification" and even stronger words, Edward J. Flynn, former Democratic National Chairman yesterday replied to Governor Dewey's assertion in his Pittsburgh speech on Friday that the $25,000 fee received by Mr. Flynn's law firm from the five operating railroad brotherhoods was "political cash."

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 117.9 on Oct. 10, compared with 117.9 a fortnight before, 117.7 a month before, 113.9 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

Selma Reyes, Australian violinist now living in Toronto, made her New York debut last night in a recital at Town Hall. She played an exacting program, consisting of Tartini's Sonata in G minor ("The Devil's Trill"), with arrangement and cadenza by Fritz Kreisler; the Brahms violin and piano sonata in G major; Dvorak's A-minor concerto, and two pieces by Joaquin Nin: "En el Jardin de Lindaraja" and "Rhapsodia Iberica."

OTTAWA, Oct. 22 -- On the eve of the British Commonwealth talks in Montreal on post-war civil aviation, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King announced tonight that the Canadian Government had leased from the Newfoundland Government the air base at Goose Bay for ninety-nine years.
LONDON, Oct. 22 -- There has been a lull in activity while the stock market awaits knowledge of the results of the Moscow conference.
Ernie Pyle, whose "Brave Men" is the Book-of-the-Month Club's December selection, will receive the degree of Doctor of Letters from New Mexico University at its commencement exercises on Friday.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Philip Murray, CIO chairman and president of the United Steel Workers of America, today told 2,000 Political Action Committee workers that he "assumed full responsibility'' to the CIO for the formation of the PAC.

DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 22 -- At least ten major aviation war plants have been busily engaged for the last ten weeks in turning out exact replicas of the German V-1 robot bomb, it was made known tonight by Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers, deputy director of the Army Air Forces Technical Service Command.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The National Association of Manufacturers said today that governmental disagreement over disposition of the lend-lease program, coupled with "intense secrecy," is causing American companies dependent on foreign markets to "rely on rumor and conjecture" in mapping their post-war programs.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he would make a series of campaign addresses for iPresident Roosevelt.
