The Mayor will speak at the Carnegie Library auditorium in Pittsburgh tomorrow night, at Symphony Hall in Boston on Friday and in Paterson, N.J., next Monday under the auspices of the New Jersey League of Independent Voters.

SEATTLE, Wash., Oct. 22 -- A Roosevelt victory in this State next month is expected by competent observers. They predict, however, that Washingtonians will split their ballots to re-elect Gov. Arthur B. Langlie, Republican.

The La Mur Realty Corporation, represented by Harold L. Strauss, attorney, bought from the Central Savings Bank the four-story loft building at 107 Wrest Forty-sixth Street in a deal arranged by Malcolm M. Slaughter Co.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- Governor Dewey, refraining from comment on President Roosevelt's foreign policy talk of last night in New York, worked at the Executive Mansion today on the farm speech he will deliver at Minneapolis Tuesday night on a tour of Minnesota, Wisconsin and Illinois.

The American service men fighting all over the world were described yesterday afternoon as "crusaders for ideals that have made our country great, for all that is best and highest in government," by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman in St. Patrick's Cathedral at the celebration of Mission Sunday.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Communique 197:

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 22 -- Harry (Hippity) Hopp's 66-yard return of a punt by a substitute back, George Pryor, in the fourth period gave the Bainbridge Naval Training Center eleven a 7-0 victory over the Camp Peary Pirates today before 12,000 blue-jackets on William and Mary College's Cary Field.
Fourteen, including the stake winner Price Level, have been named for the $10,000 added Autumn Day Stakes, main event today as the Empire City Racing Association opens its fall meeting at Jamaica.
AT GENERAL MacARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Oct. 22 (Delayed) -- A communique:

The Park Department announced yesterday that on Wednesday it would be compelled to discontinue the work of straightening and removing street trees that were destroyed in the last hurricane, because the $400,000 appropriated for these contracts by the Board of Estimate would be exhausted.

ATHENS, Oct. 22 (U.P.) -- Greek guerrilla forces have captured the island of Andros and the Germans have abandoned the neighboring islands of Tinos and Syros [Syra], clearing the entire Cyclades group fringing the southeastern coast of Greece, it was reported today.

Gustaf Gustafson of the Hawthorne C.C. wrested the lead from Edward S. Jackson Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., in the national amateur championship finals of the United States Chess Federation at the federation headquarters in Brooklyn last night when he won from Andrew Erdos in 53 moves in the fourth round.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, France, Oct. 22 -- The British Second Army joined today in the concerted campaign to isolate and eventually annihilate the German forces holding sway over the water route to Antwerp, the most valuable port in western Europe.

In an effort to help solve the problems confronting the members of their race in this country, 400 Negro leaders yesterday approved plans to form a national Post-War Planning Coordinating Council to study economic and social issues and to draw up a comprehensive program.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 22 -- American citizens should not evade their responsibility in the public debate and discussion upon the report of the Dumbarton Oaks conversations, the Rev. E.A. Conway, of the social action department of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, told the delegates to the biennial convention of the National Council of Catholic Women here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A 38-yard field goal by Joe Aguirre midway in the final period today gave the Washington Redskins a 17-14 victory over the Brooklyn Tigers before a capacity crowd of 35,000 fans in the opening game of the season here.

ROME, Oct. 22 (AP) -- British tanks manned by New Zealanders have speared seven miles into the Po Valley north of Cesena in Italy while other Eighth Army troops using boats and bicycles in pursuit of the retreating Germans on the swampy Adriatic coast sector are approaching Cervia, six miles north of captured Cesenatico, Allied headquarters announced today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 22. -- Members of the clergy, both Catholic and Protestant, are included in the draft for the German people's Home Guard army, beginning today, Catholic church officials in Stockholm have been informed. Only Jesuits will be exempted.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Order is being re-established slowly in Guatemala following the revolution Friday, when the Government of Acting President Gen Frederico Ponce was overthrown.

Net earnings of the Hercules Powder Company for the nine months ended with September amounted to $3,527,948, after $8, 755,469 Federal taxes and $200,000 provision for contingencies, the report disclosed yesterday.

One of the most difficult questions confronting us today is how to adjust our bill of rights and our bill of responsibilities, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman declared in his sermon yesterday at Christ Church (Methodist), Park Avenue at Sixtieth Street.

SANITY fled from the football scene on Saturday and lunacy took charge. There were crazy results, crazy plays, crazy decisions and an atmosphere of sheer madness. In fact, one doesn't have to go beyond the Georgia Tech-Navy game to find all the demented ingredients tucked into the same package.

Miliza Korjus, Polish coloratura soprano, made her first New York appearance last night in Carnegie Hall, assisted by an orchestra composed of fifty-eight men from the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, who were conducted by Paul Breisach.
Rent control for residential accommodations in Westchester County will become effective on Nov. 1, Daniel P. Woolley, Regional Office of Price Administration Administrator, reminded yesterday.

Whatever may have been the inherent deficiencies of the "Little Steel" formula, it has become a fixed point in labor relations. Labor and management have accepted its limitations as an existing fact and have sought to improve the economic value of the jobs by means other than direct wage increases.

Home-made bread lends an interest to meals that is hard to match. The recipes given here, all of which have been tested in THE NEW YORK TIMES kitchen, are for cereal loaves that are quick and easy to make because they do not require yeast.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- Fresh from the task of disentangling some of the skein of the British policy toward Russia, Prime Minister Churchill returned to London by plane today without Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, who debarked somewhere en route, to find that in his absence relations between the Conservative and Labor wings of his coalition Government had become snarled.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ABOARD ADMIRAL KINKAID'S FLAGSHIP at Philippines Beachhead, Oct. 20 (Delayed) -- For 900 miles the great American convoy that carried the American flag back to the Philippines stretched over the Pacific. But at A-hour, with battleships' shrieking shells hitting Japanese positions and swarms of carrier-based planes striking relentlessly, each of about 600 vessels reacted in its role like clockwork.

The chief novelty of the weekend at the Metropolitan Opera House where the Ballet Theatre is in residence, was the first appearance this season of Argentinita and her little Spanish company -- Pilar Lopez, Jose Greco and Manolo Vargas -- in the Ravel "Bolero" last night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 22 -- Randolph Scott has been named by Twentieth Century-Fox to portray Irving Netcher, the husband of Roszika Dolly, in the biographical musical, "The Dolly Sisters," which, according to plans, will be put into production late next month by George Jessel.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Green Bay's Packers held their position at the top of the National Football League's Western Division today by conquering the surprising Cleveland Rams, 30 to 21, in a rousing battle. The victory was the Packers' fifth straight in league competition, and the setback was Cleveland's first in four games.

A fire of undetermined origin in the organ loft of the Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, was quickly put out by firemen yesterday afternoon. Bringing into play several eighty-five-foot aerial ladders to hose the flames from outside the church, the firemen extinguished the blaze before it swept up into the 150-foot steeple of the ninety-year-old edifice.
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The undefeated Eagles, launching a brilliant running attack that accounted for three touchdowns in the first half, turned back the Boston Yanks, 38 to 0, on the Shibe Park gridiron today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Although wheat prices averaged higher last week, there was no snap to the buying except for a brief period, and when shorts had covered and additional mill buying failed to appear the market reacted quickly and the close yesterday was around the low point.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $51,278,654,397. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, non-interest-bearing discount bills and notes as follows;

On the eve of his departure for a major campaign swing up-State, Senator Robert F. Wagner announced last night that, in answer to his inquiry, Lieut. Comdr. Julius A. Krug, director of the War Production Board, had reported that eighty-one applications for conversion to peacetime production had been granted in New York State.

AT GENERAL MacARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Monday, Oct. 23 -- American invasion forces, in full control of the Leyte coastal road, are driving the Japanese toward the wild hills of the interior behind their path-blasting flame-throwers, tanks, artillery and dive bombers, Gen. Douglas MacArthur disclosed today.

ROME. Oct. 22 -- Ten leaders of the Sicilian separatist movement were arrested yesterday in Palermo during a day of considerable agitation. A bomb was thrown at them. Crowds of strikers went parading and shouting through the streets and at one time the police had to charge them.
AT GENERAL MacARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Monday, Oct. 23 (UP) -- A communique: ...

The Bureau of Intercultural Education, 119 West Fifty-seventh Street, announced yesterday that 111 educators and interfaith leaders in twenty-five States have endorsed the book "Probing Our Prejudices," by Prof. Hortense Powdermaker of Queens College, as a timely and realistic blueprint for building mutual understanding among America's religious and thnic groups.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 22 -- After a scoreless first half in which the tide of battle continually shifted, the St. Cecilia's eleven buckled down and tallied a touchdown in each of the remaining two quarters to down St. John's Prep of Brooklyn, 13 -- 0, today.

Retailers were able last week to clarify their buying policy for spring as a result of the announcement of lend-lease clothing requirements and of the Treasury Department's buying program on woolens, according to reports prepared exclusively for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Hopeful signs of more flavorful food in the near future were given today by A.L. Kalish, Chief of the Essential Oil Section, War Food Administration.

One thing we need not worry about overmuch is the dire eventuality that our language will become too greatly simplified. All human nature is set against such a trend, and this is true even of those who deplore the long word and the abstruse phrase.
Yesterday's communique as broadcast in English to North America from Chungking and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, Monday, Oct. 23 (Reuter) -- President Roosevelt's foreign policy statement that enslavement does not await Germany is welcomed today by two of Britain's leading provincial papers. The Manchester Guardian and The Yorkshire Post, which stress the importance of the statement on the German home front.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Food and agricultural products under lend-lease shipment to the Allies in September totaled 541,872,551 pounds, according to the announcement of the War Food Administration today.
On Oct. 16 a cable from W.H. Lawrence from Moscow endeavored to explain the admitted failure of the Lublin Committee in Russian-occupied Poland to carry out its program of land reform.
Four new films, including an importation from Mexico, are scheduled to arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

A Presidential election in the United States is a historical event in the strict sense of the term, the unforeseen political consequences of which will influence the course history takes. Every election has its foreign political aspect and hence is closely studied and observed in all countries whose policy brings them into contact with the United States.

Irving S. Olds, chairman of the National Gifts Committee of the National War Fund, announced yesterday that contributions totaling $5,507,600 have been paid or pledged by thirty-nine large national corporations to the fund in its nation-wide campaign.

MOSCOW, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Pope Pius XII and the Franco regime were targets today for an article in the publication War and the Working Class that said the Pope might be called the "godfather" of the Spanish dictatorship.

Broadway stars came out for President Roosevelt last night at a fund-raising dinner party of 1,700 members and guests of the Independent Voters Committee of the Arts and Sciences for Roosevelt in the Astor Hotel.

Families of American prisoners of war were warned yesterday not to accept enemy broadcasts of socalled prisoner messages and lists as authentic, in an "Army Hour" broadcast. Above all they were warned not to be victimized by unscrupulous persons who attempt to sell this information and at the same time encourage listening to enemy propaganda broadcasts.
LONDON, Oct. 22 (Reuter) -- A tribute to the great armored strength of American battleships was paid in a Tokyo message to1 the German Transocean Newsl Agency today.

The first public demonstration in the city of a blood donor's making a contribution to the armed forces will be staged tomorrow at noon on the steps of the Sub-Treasury Building, Wall and Nassau Streets, marking the opening of an intensive drive for volunteer blood donors among employes in the financial district, the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross announced yesterday.
ROME, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A communque:
Mr. and Mrs. William Goodwin Renwick of Tucson, Ariz., and Boston have come to the Pierre for a stay of several weeks.

Little Kenneth Barry Maloney arrived at La Guardia Field from England yesterday, the youngest passenger ever to cross the Atlantic in an Army transport plane unaccompanied by any member of his family.

WITH AMERICAN SECOND ARMORED DIVISION in Germany, Oct. 22 (AP) -- "Old gravel voice" is back in the saddle again as boss of this famous "Hell on Wheels" Division, and he has speared it into the Siegfried line.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 22 -- One might walk the streets of Brussels all day without finding a person with a good word to say for the Cabinet of Premier Hubert Pierlot, and the critics of the Belgian Government find plenty of support in the local press.

Lenore Engdahl, pianist from Minneapolis, who gave her first Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon, invested her playing with a sensitiveness of feeling, a wealth of poetry and imagination that made her performance uncommonly appealing and communicative.

On a somewhat larger business last week's stock market advanced nearly up to the week-end, then lost the gain. Highest average of the week, though not at the best July figure, had recovered the greater part of the August and September decline from the top level of midsummer.
British forces captured the enemy base of Tiddim in western Burma last week and wrote the final and decisive chapter to the Japanese invasion of India.

Post-war plans of Mount Sinai Hospital call for erection of a maternity pavilion and buildings to house research and routine laboratories, expansion of post-graduate medical education and an enlarged program of fellowship grants, according to the biennial report for 1942 and 1943 made public yesterday.

Peace threatens to cause "inflationary enrollments" in all colleges and universities, now in distress because of the virtual elimination of male undergraduates, Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, warned yesterday in his annual report to the university council.

WITH AMERICANS near Thionville, Oct. 23 (U.P.) -- Hidden deep in the rugged and heavily wooded hills overlooking the Moselle Valley, American troops in a German fort are hurling $1,000,000 worth of German shells from German guns into German strong points.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- The "Polish problem" will have to be resolved on the issue that has stood in the way of rapprochement between Russia and Poland all along -- Poland's eastern frontier. Prime Minister Stanislaw Mikolajczyk apparently has not brought back any new formula from Moscow, and tomorrow the Polish Government will begin a series of Cabinet meetings to settle the dispute one way or another.

The text of the statement issued by the Soviet Union on Russian recognition of the Provisional Government of the French Republic, as transmitted in English by the Soviet Tass agency and recorded by the Federal Comunications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Jack Frye, president of the Trans-continental and Western Air Lines, said today that the United States was "large and powerful enough in relation to other countries in the world, to support a relatively greater number of international airlines."

AT GENERAL MacARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, Leyte, Oct. 23 (U.P.) -- The names of eighty-three American officers and men rescued from the Japanese several weeks ago after two and one-half years" imprisconment, and now safe in Australian hospitals, were announced today.

AFTER every major military conflict since the Peloponnesian War the veterans, the men who have known the hardships and regimentation of army life and who have known the imminence of death in battle, have felt themselves to be a class apart, separated from the great mass of mere civilians by a gulf of strange experience.

ABOARD DEWEY TRAIN, Cleveland, Oct. 23 -- Governor Dewey in his appearance at Minneapolis tomorrow night, will answer President Roosevelt on foreign policy instead of making a farm speech, as he had planned.

PARIS, Oct 23 -- In the first treason trial held by the Court of Justice of the Seine Department, Georges Suarez, 53, managing director of the Parisian newspaper Aujourd'hui, was sentenced to death after a trial lasting about six hours. The court also ordered the confiscation of all Suarez's property. When the verdict was delivered, the entire court room cheered.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Oct. 24 -- Premier Stalin announced last night that the Red Army had driven nineteen miles into East Prussia on an eighty-seven mile front, capturing more than 400 populated points on both sides of the main railroad leading to Insterburg and Koenigsberg.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- In his speech at the Foreign Policy Association dinner Saturday night the President took a position on the current argument over the authority which the American member of the proposed Council of the projected world security league shall exercise when the question before the Council is whether the league shall employ force to put down a threat to peace.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Dr. I. Keith Tyler, director of Radio Education at Ohio State University, tonight received the award of merit presented for outstanding service in educational radio by the School Broadcast Conference. Dr. Tyler is director of the Institute for Educational Radio and president of the Association for Education by Radio.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 23 -- Irvington High School presented another strong claim for Group 4 high school football honors in North Jersey by defeating East Orange High, 21-0 today at Ashland Stadium. Previously Irvington had disposed of West Orange, Garfield and Thomas Jefferson.

Although the people of Norway hope that they will suffer no new invasion and that the Germans will be forced to withdraw without battle, they are fully prepared to wage war beside the Allies, if necessary Dr. Carl J. Hambro President of the Norwegian Parliament and last President of the League of Nations Assembly reported yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Senator Joseph Ball, Republican, of Minnesota, said tonight that unless all nations in an international peace agency pledge in advance the forces necessary to put down aggression, the organization "will be simply a debating society, without power to act, and future aggressors will sneer at it just as Hitler sneered at the League of Nations."

BUFFALO, Oct. 23 -- In the first of a series of campaign talks in key industrial centers up-State Senator Robert F. Wagner charged tonight that Governor Dewey, Republican candidate for President, put forward a social security program which did not go "half as far" as the one he himself already introduced and fought for in Congress.

Buyers and merchandise managers from Boston to San Francisco, from Atlanta to Montreal began arriving in New York yesterday, the start of their fall buying trips scheduled to coincide with the opening at 2:30 this afternoon of "Fashions of the Times," third edition.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The War Department acknowledged late this afternoon that the report of the Army Board which has investigated the Pearl Harbor disaster now is in the hands of the Secretary of War, but, as in the case of the Navy report, there was no indication that the information would be made public at an early date.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 23 -- Senator Harry S. Truman tonight challenged Governor Dewey to demand the defeat of eight Republican "isolationist" Senators to back up his "strong foreign policy" assertions or "the people must assume he is another Harding."

Thomas Crawford, trustee for certificate holders, has sold the twelve-story loft building at 31-33 East Thirty-second Street and the adjoining three-story at 29 East Thirty-second Street to investors represented by Arthur Shinder. The taller building, fully rented, occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet between Madison and Fourth Avenues.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 23 (AP) -- A group of soldiers, several of them wearing overseas service ribbons, seized a placard from a union picket today near the busy downtown intersection of Twelfth and Baltimore Streets and removed an American flag which had been attached to the sign.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Cruttenden Co., which headed an investment bankers' syndicate in the recent marketing of $885,000 of Utah Radio Products Company 4 1/2 per cent subordinated convertible debentures of 1954, today offered to repurchase the debentures.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Senator Joseph Ball, Republican, of Minnesota, formally declared today that he would actively support the re-election of President Roosevelt in recognition of the Chief Executive's pronouncements and achievements in the field of foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The National Labor Relations Board today ordered seven collective bargaining elections be held within ninety days among employes of the Western Union Telegraph Company from coast to coast. This is the most extensive plebiscite yet designated by the board.

Ambitious young men and women, confident in their own star and setting no limit to their hopes, are hereby warned against one serious danger. They must not set out to win international fame as scientists or authors.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 23 (UP) -- The Chinese High Command announced today that Chinese troops, fighting desperately to prevent the Japanese from splitting China in two, had stalled both the northern and southern prongs of the Japanese pincer drive and gone over to the offensive.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Associated Press filed with the Supreme Court today a protest against a lower court decision which it said would have the effect of "transferring the press from the field of private enterprise to the status of a regulated public utility."

JERUSALEM, Oct. 23 -- The General Council of Palestine Jews today decided on the necessity of mobilizing the Jewish population of Palestine to combat terrorist activities. The decision was reached after representatives of most of the Jewish parties had debated all day whether adoption of active measures by the Jewish community might provoke strife within its ranks.

ROME, Oct. 23 -- Great interest was stirred here today by a frontline story by Sgt. Bob Fleisher of the Army newspaper Stars and Stripes which makes the flat charge that jubilant interpretations and what might be called a "hopped-up" style of recent stories about the fighting in Italy have tended to widen a breach between civilians and soldiers and to destroy the latter's confidence in the press.

Add to the list of new films arriving this week, "Murder in the Blue Room," a melodrama with music produced by Universal, which will open at the Rialto on Friday. Anne Gwynne, Donald Cook, John Litel, Grace McDonald and June Preisser are among the featured players.
ROME, Oct. 23 (AP) -- A communique:

Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Under-Secretary of State, received last night the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws from New York University. In accepting it he warned that "in this interdependent world of the twentieth century the freedom and well-being of nations and peoples, hand in hand with security itself, must be advanced by international cooperation rather than by national action alone."
A mighty roar went up at 3:45 P.M. yesterday as 15,000 youngsters hailed their heroes in Madison Square Garden. It was at the rodeo, of course, and the heroes were Roy Rogers and Trigger.

The major powers of college football, and they include Navy even though beaten twice, head into rough opposition this week as operations are resumed on a full scale, with examinations over for most V-12 naval trainees.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 23 -- Unconfirmed reports said tonight that Ferenc Szalasi, Hungarian Nazi puppet Premier and Regent, had been killed last Friday in Budapest along with members of his general staff during a "coup d'etat" staged by troops loyal to Admiral Nicholas Horthy, patriots and Budapest police.

Little by little the pressure of war on men's suits is being lifted. In many cases, in fact, there is no outward evidence that pressure of any sort, whether by war or by the tailor's flatiron, has ever been applied. Cuffs on pants have been legal for some months, though creases remain optional.

Erasmus Hall's unbeaten eleven added to its prestige yesterday when it rode roughshod over a Lafayette High squad, 33 -- 7, in the feature game of a double-header at Ebbets Field. In the other contest, Brooklyn Tech vanquished Madison, 24 -- 6.
DENVER, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Governor Bricker tonight cited what he called a "consistent pattern of contradictions" in President Roosevelt's utterances.

Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, whose historic and palatial home at 640 Fifth Avenue recently was acquired by the William Waldorf Astor estate, has purchased the large stone house at 1048 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Eighty-sixth Street.
LONDON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

AT GENERAL MacARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Tuesday, Oct. 24 -- American liberation forces made new gains along the entire Leyte Island front today, tightening their squeeze on the strategic Leyte Valley, after a Japanese counter-attack in one sector was beaten off in bloody fighting.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 23 -- The formation of a "Chilean Commission of Solidarity with the Argentine People" and the publication of the first issue of the Gaceta in Argentina, a widely distributed publication printed here, reveal the reaction of groups unfavorable to the present Argentine military Government, informed circles said today.

A new post-war planning committee, designed to help service men and their families to become readjusted after the war, has been formed by the Jewish Social Service Association, it was disclosed yesterday at its headquarters, 113 West Fifty-seventh Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 23 -- RKO-Radio is planning to make "Portrait of a Lady," an unproduced play by Alexander King and Chester Erskin, as a starring vehicle for Rosalind Russell. She will do the picture after her appearance in the lead of "Sister Kenny" for this company.

Portraits of eight military leaders of World War II -- de Gaulle, Gamelin, Wavell, Rommel, Montgomery, Timoshenko, MacArthur and Eisenhower -- and of three "soldier-politicians" -- Churchill, Chiang Kai-shek and Hitler -- are set against a background of military events in "Great Soldiers of World War II," to be published Oct. 30 by Norton.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 23 (AP) -- E.N. Ayer of San Francisco, president of the National Apartment Owners Association, declared today that men "whose adult years have been spent in association with Communist front organizations" occupy top positions in the rent department of the Office of Price Administration.
DETROIT, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Striking employes of three Kelsey-Hayes Wheel Company plants voted tonight to return to their jobs tomorrow.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- One-third of Rotterdam's port facilities have already been destroyed by the Germans in preparation for their eventual evacuation of the Netherlands' greatest commercial city and charges have been placed in the remainder ready to be set off at the press of a button, it was learned today.

ALBANY, Oct. 23 -- Governor Dewey made public today a report of the emergency food commission which he named last year to find ways and means for everyone in the State to have a good diet and to maintain agriculture on a prosperous basis.

The spectacle of Mrs. Luce's pretty "American" head rolling in the basket on election day, as described by her in your news column of today, is an affecting one. But let me say to her, a one American head (dating from way back before the Revolution) to another that Mr. Sidney Hillman's head, in spite of what she says about it, is pretty American too.

ATHENS, Oct. 23 (AP) -- British troops pushed today through ancient Thermopylae to Lamia, about 100 miles northwest of Athens and fifty miles south of Larissa, as they pursued the Germans retreating in northern Greece.

Reporting on operations of the Shell Union Oil Corporation for the nine months ended with September, R.G.A. van der Woude, president, informed stockholders yesterday that the consolidated net income had increased to $22,538,000, or $1.67 a share, from the $18,209,223, or $1.35 a share, earned in the first nine months of 1943.

Among the seasonal foods to be found in city shops is an unusual confection, a so-called Vienna-style fruit cake, which we discovered recently at the Vendome, 415 Madison Avenue. Made by a Long Island woman, according to a recipe which she brought here from Austria, it is actually not a cake but a large, filled pastry.

Theodore Perez's letter calls attention to the lack of social and welfare provisions for the 160,000 Americans now serving aboard our merchant vessels. Though publicly acclaimed as heroes, these men are as yet without the benefit of legislative measures that will protect their rights and secure for them a status similar to our servicemen.

WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 23 -- Glaring inconsistencies -- "talk on one side, contradictory action on the other" -- were attributed to Representative Clare Boothe Luce last night by her opponent, Miss Margaret E. Connors, in a speech before the Independent Connors for Congress Club here.
Hospital Week will be ushered in today by a large group of women volunteers, representing seventy-seven voluntary hospitals participating in the sixty-sixth annual United Hospital Campaign.
We read about post-war shortages of trained personnel -- chemists, for instance. Men who would ordinarily be studying chemistry are now in the services.

ROME, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Despite German reinforcements, American Fifth Army troops today consolidated newly won positions in bitter fighting eight miles south of Bologna in Italy. The British Eighth Army enlarged its grip on the Adriatic sector by capturing Cervia, twelve miles below Ravenna.
LONDON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Organized guerrilla warfare is spreading throughout Spain, Spanish Republicans declared here tonight.

MONTREAL, Oct. 23 -- Delegates from eight British Commonwealths and countries in the five continents of Europe, North America, Asia, Africa and Australia began an informal and exploratory conference here today on the problems of postwar civil aviation within the Empire and with a view to reaching some measure of agreement among themselves before they all go to the international conference to be held in Chicago next month.
LONDON, Oct. 23 (UP) -- A German communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- With liberation, extravagant hats had had their day in France. During the occupation women, especially Parisiennes, delighted to exasperate the Germans by wearing contraptions of huge size and made of the most fanciful materials.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Rye was decidedly active and sharply higher in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, July advancing 3 1/4 cents a bushel at one time and September going to a new seasonal high on buying attributed to general commission houses which uncovered stop-loss orders.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 23 -- Air transport facilities that follow into conquered atolls and islands on the very heels of victorious American forces have already been expanded in the Pacific to include the southern Palau Islands, it was disclosed today, despite the fact that the last resistance on Angaur and Peleliu has not been eliminated.

LONDON, Oct. 23 (U.P.) -- Clarification of historic Allied diplomatic decisions taken at Moscow was expected within twenty-four to forty-eight hours from both Prime Minister Churchill and the Polish Government in Exile, as Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, en route home from Russia, was reported engaged in important conferences in the Middle East.

Park Commissioner Robert E. Moses endorsed yesterday the candidacy of Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, declaring that Senator Robert F. Wagner, Democratic candidate for re-election, "has became more and more a stooge of the New Deal."

The Committee for Economic Development, representing major private industries in planning for post-war economic and industrial reconstruction, announced yesterday formation of a committee to estimate the volume of construction and the number of workers to be required in all branches of the building industry in New York City after the war.
CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- "Mac killed instantly yesterday while assaulting enemy positions in France."

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 23 -- Until the Russian Government does something substantive to change its policy of persecution and discrimination against religion there is no use continuing with the international pretense that the Soviet Union is a democracy, Mgr. Michael J. Ready of Cleveland declared in a prepared address before delegates to the convention of the National Council of Catholic Women here tonight.

Billy Arnold, Philadelphia high school student, halted Ernest (Cat) Robinson of Jamaica in 2 minutes and 44 seconds of the second round at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The knockout was the twenty-seventh for Arnold, who has engaged in twenty-nine pro contests.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

As unconcerned as when he flew from England with a Red Cross nurse to meet his grandmother here, Kenneth Barry Maloney, six months old, the youngest transatlantic passenger ever carried by the Army Transport Command, started last night for the home of his paternal grandparents, in Grand Rapids, Mich.

DENVER, Oct. 23 (U.P.) -- A 2,000-mile telephone call smoothed the differences between father and son today, and Maj. Horace Dodge Jr., heir to one of America's largest motor-car fortunes, promised to be best man at his son's wedding, which he originally had opposed.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, France, Oct. 23 -- Whatever happens on the ground along the Western Front, Germany is in for her worst winter of bombing if she chooses to continue the war. Even if the weather should in some measure hamper our ground operations, air warfare may still provide the blow that will wreck the Reich's will and capacity to fight.

Redecorating of apartments under OPA regulations includes papering as well as painting, it became known yesterday. Although an official order to this effect was transmitted to deputy rent directors under date of Sept. 26, last, it was not given any publicity and the general public has been unaware of its provisions.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, accused the New Deal administration tonight of "sabotaging our traditional form of government." He declared that President Roosevelt, as the country's Chief Executive, had sought to take over the judicial and the legislative branches of the Federal Government.

WITH BRITISH SECOND ARMY at Schijndel, the Netherlands, Oct. 23 -- Smashing steadily northwestward toward's Hertogenbosch British troops liberated Schijndel this morning after having subjected the town to a fierce artillery barrage throughout the night as a preliminary to wresting the community from the Germans.

After Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney, commanding general of the United Nations Air Forces in the southwest Pacific, had surveyed the airfield near captured Tacloban on Leyte Island in the Philippines, he was asked his opinion of it. "It's a fairly typical Jap airdrome," he said, "which means it's not nearly good enough for us.

While he may have been speaking with tongue in cheek, George Munger, the University of Pennsylvania's head coach, told the Football Writers Association, at its weekly meeting at Toots Shor's yesterday, that his unbeaten lads were in for a tough afternoon against the Navy's twice-beaten eleven at Franklin Field on Saturday.

Two new New York Stock Exchange firms will be formed on Nov. 3. Harold M. Iseman, Alfred Bruno Wolfe and John W. Schulz will form Iseman Co., and J. Eldridge Scheffmeyer and John E. Scheffmeyer will form Scheffmeyer Co.
A-memorial exhibition of work by Anne Goldthwaite, who died in January, opened yesterday at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street. It will remain until Nov. 4.
Plans for two apartment buildings, one twelve stories high accommodating 154 families and the other six stories in height, were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Communique 198:

Among the major league highlights of 1944 were the generally overlooked feats of Johnny Lindell of the Yankees, Whitey Kurowski of the Cards and the Phillies' Ron Northey, each of whom made homers in every park of his league.

The city's second annual outdoor chysanthemum display of 2,000,000 multi-colored flowers reached its peak yesterday, according to Park Department officials who had watched the plants anxiously through the hurricane and Saturday's storm.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Twenty-five additional industrial plants have been selected to receive the Army-Navy "E" award for outstanding performance on war work. They are:

A soldier in the line finds it hard to think of victory "as meaning anything but an end to fear, to loneliness and death, and a chance to go back to pick up the strands of interrupted life." This is the testimony of Pvt. Isadore Rubin of Brooklyn, who has just won an essay prize contended for by men of the Fifth Army's front in Italy.

The city of Akron, Ohio, awarded yesterday to Fox, Reusch Co. and associates an issue of $844,000 of refunding bonds at a price of 100.978 for 1 1/2s. The bonds will mature serially Nov. 1, 1946 to 1952.

ATHENS, Oct. 22 (Delayed) -- Travelers from the Peloponnesus report clashes between Communists and the Security bands recruited during the Nazi occupation to safeguard life and property against alleged leftist extremists.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- In disclosing that Lieut. Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, Deputy Chief of Staff, often referred to as Gen. George C. Marshall's "right arm," has gone to the Mediterranean as Deputy Supreme Allied Commander, the War Department said today that before his departure he had received the Distinguished Service Medal and Legion of Merit.

Leopold Stokowski chose to conduct an all-Russian program with the New York City Symphony at the City Center last night. Like the first concerts, last night's affair showed conclusively that a new orchestra need not by any means be a bad one; and that Mr. Stokowski's reputation for being able to weld a group of musicians into a fine orchestral organization is not undeserved.

Mike Jacobs, president of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, said yesterday at La Guardia Field that he expects Heavyweight Champion Joe Louis and Billy Conn will be released from the Army after the European war ends, and held out the possibility that they would fight for the title as civilians in the Yankee Stadium by next Summer.

ATHENS, Oct. 23 (U.P.) -- Followers of the Eam, the Greek National Liberation Front, forced entry into the Athens Stock Exchange today and assaulted persons whom they accused of speculating in foreign exchange. Order was restored by Greek police.

The Joint Legislative Committee Investigate Commercial Rents, through its chairman, Assemblyman D. Mallory Stephens, announced yesterday that the committee would discuss with Chester Bowles, National Administrator of the Office of Price Administration, in Washington today what plans OPA has developed for controlling commercial rents.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- Recognition of the French Provisional Government was hailed in Britain tonight as a measure long overdue, and its unanimity was regarded as partly a triumph for British foreign policy, which has long pressed for such a consummation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- A nation-wide scientific sampling of the housekeeping population shows that, from a dietary standpoint, a far better family table was being set in the spring of 1942 than in 1936, when a first sampling was taken.

In one of the most serious reverses of the year, the stock market was subjected yesterday to two hours of intensive selling which wiped out the recovery efforts of the last two weeks. Unleashed first by weakness among the motors during the fourth hour, the pressure increased in the final hour to such a pitch that prices were reduced around 2 points in a long list of issues.

AACHEN, Germany, Oct. 23 -- German authorities have rescinded their order, issued just before our forces entered Germany, calling for the mass evacuation of civilians from the Rhineland. This order, though accompanied by threats of severe punishment, was disregarded by large sections of the population, as we have found on entering Aachen and smaller German communities.

Release of Government surpluses of consumer goods at ever-increasing rates from now on would go far toward enabling distribution to move into the high gear necessary during reconversion and would likewise be the healthiest kind of price-control action, B. Earl Puckett, president of the Allied Stores Corporation, said yesterday.

A collection of window treatment ideas suggesting possibilities for the decorator who is untrammeled by considerations of price and practicality went on exhibit yesterday at W. J. Sloane's. Ten water colors accompanied by generous samples of the fabrics, represent the conceptions of twenty Sloane decorators working together in two-man teams.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- Registration figures in Westchester County for the November election, with 27,129 distributed soldiers and sailors ballots included, showed a grand total today of 316,567. The record high of 1940 was 317,931.

LONDON, Oct 23 -- Quiet ruled in most sections of today's stock markets here. Attention centered in the Kaffirs, which weakened on forced selling for Cape account in an unwilling market, and many prices were cut.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Railroads have not outstripped industry generally in war profit benefits, a railroad spokesman said today, and will need a post-war net operating income of a billion dollars a year in order properly to rehabilitate war-worn properties.

TACLOBAN, Leyte, Oct. 23 -- The citizens of liberated Tacloban, capital and largest seaport of Leyte Province, told today how their Japanese "masters" forced them to march in a parade through the streets of the town in honor of the "victory" over Admiral William F. Halsey's fleet off Formosa last week.

WITH AN AMERICAN INFANTRY DIVISION in Germany, Oct. 19 (Delayed) -- Some Pennsylvania soldiers fighting along the Siegfried Line have met some Germans speaking a language they know -- Pennsylvania Dutch.

Repeal of the Hatch Act in so far as it forbids Federal employes from engaging in political activities and full rights for Government employes to organize for collective bargaining was demanded at the opening session of the convention of the United Federal Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, at the Hotel Capitol, Fifty-first Street and Eighth Avenue, yesterday, in the report of the union's offices presented to the 800 delegates.

The furniture manufacturing industry is considering the development of a cooperative advertising program, it was learned yesterday. If and when such a campaign is started, it probably will emphasize the greatly increased value which a purchaser of furniture now obtains for his dollar due to the difference in costs between machine-made and handmade furniture.

The reorganization committee of the Seaboard Airline Railway Company yesterday requested holders of fourteen of the railways bond issues to deposit their securities in support of the plan that has been approved by the United States District Courts and by committees representing all but two of the issues called for deposit.

Mr. Malinowski, in his letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 19, questioning the existence of an underground anti-Nazi movement in Germany, makes at least one mistake in fact and another by implication. Without wishing to give the impression that a strong and highly organized resistance movement now exists in the Reich, I should like in fairness to correct these two errors.

An underwriting syndicate of 167 members headed by Blyth Co., Inc., will offer today to the public $115,000,000 of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company's first and refunding mortgage 3 per cent bonds, series L, due on June 1, 1974. The bonds will be priced at 104 to yield 2.80 per cent.

WITH THE CANADIANS IN NORTH ANTWERP, Oct. 23 (Canadian Press) -- In the push to Esschen on this sector two youthful Canadian dispatch riders went out with forward infantry looking for excitement and German souvenirs. They got both and forty-nine German prisoners.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 163:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 23 -- The Germans are becoming alarmed over the possible fate awaiting their occupation troops in northern Norway as Russian forces, cutting across from the Finnish town of Petsamo, prepared to penetrate Norwegian territory.

Despite the heavy volume of corporate financing currently making its appearance, there came yesterday a reminder from Canada that the war is still going on and tremendous sums of money are needed to bring it to a victorious conclusion. Our neighbor to the north yesterday began its seventh and largest war loan campaign, calling for the sale of $1,300,000,000 in Canadian Government securities.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 23 -- The assumption which grew out of the 1940 election that President Roosevelt would be opposed by a majority of Indiana voters in any bid for a fourth term persists today among seasoned and competent observers who view the political scene from the Hoosier capital.

ON LEYTE BEACHHEAD, Oct. 20 (Delayed) -- American troops went ashore this morning in the Philippines with the precision of a well-trained football team and the power of a giant steamroller. As seen from the bridge of the flagship of Rear Admiral Daniel E. Barbey, commander of naval forces that struck the northern beaches on Leyte Island just south of Tacloban.

Conditions of aerial warfare over Germany and Japan were reproduced with all the realism possible to the Navy's Special Device Division of the Bureau of Aeronautics at the Museum of Science and Industry in Radio City yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- President Sergio Osmena of the Philippines has advised President Roosevelt in a message from the island of Leyte made public at the White House today that he had called upon the Filipino people to give their "complete and determined support" to the armed forces of the United States and to "rise to the cause of democracy and liberty."
Yesterday's communique as broadcast in Serbo-Croat by the Free Yugoslav Radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Jurisdiction was released today by the Securities and Exchange Commission over terms and conditions to the sale of United Gas Corporations $100,000,000 of 3 per cent first mortgage and collateral trust bonds, due 1962 to sixty industrial investors.

Barracks buildings and other installations erected on leased lands for military purposes in public parks in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island are to be sold to the public, the division real estate officer of the United States Engineers, at 270 Broadway, announced yesterday.

Clothing manufacturers are catching up on deliveries of Army field jackets, due to technical progress being made in their production, it was stated yesterday by the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U.S.A. It was said that the procurement, totaling some 5,000,000 jackets, is being turned out as fast as possible by the industry, but that problems that have come about have made it impossible for some manufacturers to meet delivery dates.

It is reassuring to note that not all of the finer endeavors of civilization have been brought to a halt by the gruff demand of war. Scholarship in many a field tightens its belt and carries on through all distractions, knowing that life will some day be normal again and have need for the gifts that only scholarship can provide.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 -- A group of CIO union members in the harbor area arc forming a committee to fight what they call the misuse of unions for political purposes, especially for pro-Roosevelt and Communist purposes, it was said today by Harold Haskill and Ray T. Trent, shipyard workers.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Harold G. Olsen, Ohio State University basketball coach and chairman of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Tournament Committee, said today he did not know of a single coach who would listen to gamblers attempting to "fix" a college basketball game.

Corp. Harold L. Cross Jr., son of Prof. and Mrs. Harold L. Cross of Harlaine Farm, Skowhegan, Me., and formerly of 571 Prospect Street, Maplewood, N. J., was killed in action on the western front in Europe on Sept. 27, according to word received here yesterday.

A 62-year-old motion picture projectionist with a history of service with both the United States and German armies, and his 26-year-old foster daughter, were arrested yesterday by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who accused them of having served Germany as spies between 1939 and the fall of 1941.

The Ballet Theatre last night gave the season's first presentation of Leonide Massine's "Three-Cornered Hat" at the Metropolitan Opera House. This ballet can be either very smart or very dull, depending entirely upon how it is cast, and last night it was cast to the hilt with Mr. Massine, of course, as the miller, Tamara Toumanova as his wife and David Lichine as the corregidor.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Southern California crushed Washington's hopes of being the Western nominee for the New Year's Rose Bowl game by inflicting a 38-to-7 beating on the previously undefeated Huskies tonight.

LONDON, Oct. 23 (U.P.) -- Paris dispatches tonight reported sizable skirmishes along the French-Spanish frontier between Spanish guerrillas and regular army troops of Generalissimo Francisco Franco, but Spanish Republicans were quoted as minimizing the importance of the fighting or its significance in any attempt to restore a republic.
A jitterbug's penchant for a two-toned tweed sports jacket with a glen plaid design led to his arrest on a grand larceny charge early yesterday morning in a crowded Broadway dance hall.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The text of the State Department announcement of recognition of the de Gaulle regime as the Provisional Government of France:
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically from Sofia and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

President Roosevelt and Senator Robert F. Wagner have been endorsed for re-election by the Empire Typographical Conference, representing 16,000 union printers in New York State, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State chairman, announced yesterday on the basis of a telegram signed by Basil Hillman, secretary-treasurer of the conference.
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 23 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday, active months closing 3 to 10 points net lower than Saturday's final quotations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Official American recognition of the French Provisional Government, raising France to a high place among the United Nations and preparing the way for rapid reconstruction, was accorded today to the de facto authority under Gen. Charles de Gaulle.
Baron C.G. Willem H. van Boetzelaer, the Netherlands Minister, and Baroness van Boetzelaer have arrived from Washington and are at the Ritz-Carlton.

Hollywood does not mind scraping the surface of its vast resources to lend Broadway a helping hand. To be sure, there is nothing altruistic about these excursions in the domain of the legitimate stage. The attachment each art has for the other again is demonstrated by "Violet," opening tonight at the Belasco.

IT was the weekly gathering of the Football Writers Association and the men of muscle from the coaching ranks braced themselves for a heavy attack on the vittles. They all handle themselves deftly in the grocery department.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Capt. Patrick McHugh, president of the Atlantic Fishermen's Union, opposed today any proposal to remove "ceiling" prices on fish.

WITH THE TWENTY-FOURTH DIVISION, on Leyte, Oct. 22 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- A battalion of American infantry led by 48-year-old Lieut. Col. Robert Straveins of Chicago captured the city of Palo yesterday almost without opposition, wiping out the last Japanese stronghold on the twenty-mile section of Leyte's coastal road between Tacloban and Dulag.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 7 per cent last week over the like week of 1943, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The figure was unchanged from that of the preceding week.

ROME, Oct. 23 -- The return of the Allies to Greece and the Aegean Islands and the steady drive northwest of Marshal Tito and the Russian Army are giving the Italians much food for anxiety these days.

The astonishing performances of Shura Cherkassky, pianist, last night in Carnegie Hall were singularly uneven in their merits and defects. He gave a discouraging indication of the athletic methods that were to be employed in a harmless piece by Handel when he led off with the most clangorous delivery of "The Star-Spangled Banner" that we have heard from any pianist, however muscular, in these war years.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, France, Oct. 23 -- The German positions between the Nijmegen salient and the North Sea began to disintegrated today under the firm, steady pressure of a series of British and Canadian advances, the latest of which were undertaken just after midnight.

One of the largest antiques exhibitions New York has seen for some years opened yesterday at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue. Attractively displayed in 150. large booths, the exhibits of colonial and European furniture, porcelain and silver emphasize furnishings and decorations useful today as well as rare collectors' items.
PALO, Leyte, the Philippines, Oct. 23 -- This invasion boom town got its old Mayor back today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- How to make women happy and get the most work out of them in the transportation field, especially in jobs such as driving street cars and buses, is the theme of a new seventeen-page report by the Office of Defense Transportation, written by Miss Dorothy Sells, chief, and Miss Cornelia Edge, assistant chief, of the personnel supply section.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 23 -- A brilliant round of 66, five strokes under par, enabled Ernie Catropa, Salisbury, to win the annual Long Island P.G.A. championship with 71, 66 -- 137, at the Garden City Country Club today.

ON BRITISH FRONT in the Netherlands, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The British Second Army advanced more than five miles and captured four key towns today, moving within two and a half miles of the key Dutch rail and road city of's Hertogenbosch.

Two weeks from today 3,227,751 persons will he entitled to vote in the City of New York. The percentage of actual voters to eligible voters will probably be unusually high. So high, indeed, that there is grave doubt whether it will be physically possible for all would-be voters to register their choices on the available machines in the existing districts between the hours of 6 in the morning and 7 at night.

ON BOARD DEWEY TRAIN, Oct. 23 -- The likelihood of a special session of the New York Legislature being called to extend the voting hours on election day in New York City from 7 P. M. to 9 P. M. increased today as Governor Dewey at a press conference said that he had instructed his counsel, Charles D. Breitel, to confer on "requirements" with the Board of Elections.

William F. Carey, a director of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, Chicago Great Western Railroad, General Aniline and Film Corporation and other companies, who has been, at his own request, a Superintendent of Landfills at $5,300 for the Department of Sanitation since last Monday, was restored yesterday to his former position of Commissioner of the Department at $10,000 a year by Mayor La Guardia.

A reasonable prosperity for all nations, resulting from increased interchange of goods and services, will assure peace better than the "grandiose" peace plans that are now in the making, Eric A. Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, declared yesterday.

Both the Giants and Tigers emerged from last Sunday's National Football League encounters in fairly good physical condition and this morning at the Polo Grounds and Ebbets Field, respectively, will begin preparations for next Sunday's games.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today the issuance of orders directed against what it termed "collusive and fraudulent bidding" on contracts for supplying materials to rehabilitate facilities of the Cramp Shipbuilding Company, Philadelphia.

LONDON, Tuesday, Oct. 24 (U.P.) -- Elsewhere on the 1,500-mile Eastern Front, Russian troops were continuing their advances in northeastern Hungary. Marshal Rodion Y. Malinovsky's Second Ukrainian Army advanced eight miles to within eight miles of the southern border of Czechoslovakia by capturing Dombrad, nineteen miles southwest of the important Czechoslovak rail junction of Cop.

The final regularly listed meeting of the New York season got under way yesterday at the Jamaica track, where the Empire City Racing Association inaugurated its twelve-day program. The card, headed by the Autumn Day Stakes, attracted a crowd of 22.950.

The rebirth of France as a Great Power was formally signalized to the world yesterday when the leaders of the United Nations extended recognition to General de Gaulle's de facto regime as the Provisional Government of the French Republic, with sovereign authority over the larger part of French soil.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle's greatest diplomatic victory, one for which he has striven more than a year, came today when the Allies formally and fully recognized his regime as the Provisional Government of France.

GUATEMALA, Oct. 23 -- The new Government requested all students, merchants and workers in public services to carry on their activities today to help to stabilize the situation. However, there are still some disturbances, part of which were caused by Indians urged on by ousted members of the former regime, some of whom are attempting guerrilla war on a small scale.
KANDY, Ceylon, Oct. 23 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Senator Johnson of Colorado, an anti-New Deal Democrat, in commenting today on Senator Ball's announcement said: "Ball is taking himself too seriously. His statement probably will put Minnesota definitely in Dewey's bandwagon."

An attack on the Roosevelt Administration and the Congress of Industrial Organizations Political Action Committee was suddenly canceled yesterday morning by the Advertising Men's Post 209 of the American Legion shortly before it was to be made in an address by Eugene W. Castle, president of Castle Films, Inc., at the post's weekly luncheon meeting at the Hotel Lexington.

LONDON, Wednesday, Oct. 25 -- The Red Army, battering ahead against a desperate defense bolstered by four fresh German tank divisions, dug deeper through the East Prussian forests yesterday, conquering at least fourteen heavily fortified strong points on an expanding front more than thirty-five miles wide and pressing within six miles of the big rail and road hub of Gumbinnen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that those on the East coast and in the Middle West who converted their heating equipment from fuel oil to coal or wood could have fuel oil if the equipment were changed back to use it.

CORP. JOHN SCOTT of Morris Field in North Carolina beguiles his reader in the beginning with reference to Jimmy Conzelman and then deftly slides into a plea for greater recognition of service football teams in general and his own Third Air Force Gremlins in particular. He writes:

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- Vast numbers of the American people are carrying over to the present days of high wages the bad eating habits they acquired of necessity on reduced incomes during the depression, Miss Mazina Moore, president-elect of the American Dietetic Association, said at its annual meeting today.

BOSTON, Oct. 24 -- The First Circuit Court of Appeals upheld today an injunction issued by the Supreme Court of Puerto Rico restraining the island's treasurer and members of the Insular Emergency Relief Council from distributing a $16,000,000 emergency relief fund to unemployed and needy Puerto Ricans.

Some manufacturers of building materials and equipment are giving thought to the possibility of aiding through advertising better municipal building codes to permit wider use of modern materials, according to advertising circles here. Others, it was pointed out yesterday, are looking into the matter of aiding campaigns or slum clearance and better housing as a means of increasing possible outlets for their products.

WITH THE UNITED STATES TWENTY-SIXTH DIVISION, Beyond Athienville, France, Oct. 23 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The home front talk about stern treatment for a defeated Germany has inspired fanatical, bitter-end resistance among German front-line troops, in this sector at least, and the GI's are a little bitter about it.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 24 -Combativeness, team work, resourcefulness, excellent morale and a good engineers corps were attributed today by Maj. Gen. Ralph H. Wooten of the United States Army Air Forces to the Brazilian Expeditionary Forces fighting on the Italian front. General Wooten returned yesterday from Italy.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 24 -- A plea to help parents face facts when they have a mentally retarded child was made today to physicians, psychiatrists and educators by Dr. Henry C. Schumacher, director of the Cleveland Child Guidance Center, at the institute on the education of exceptional children, sponsored by Woods Schools of Langhorne. Pa., in cooperation with the Western Reserve University.

Australia's geographical position and her economy will not permit any relaxing of war restrictions until victory in the Pacific is won, Dr. Douglas B. Copland, Prices Commissioner of Australia, declared yesterday.

An extra dividend of $2.50 in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 63 cents a share was voted yesterday on the common stock by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company of Canada, for payment Dec. 31. On Dec. 31, 1943, the company paid an extra of $1 a share.

Braids, huge chignons and center parts were the predominating features of the coiffures worn by the models at the opening of "Fashions of the Times" yesterday. There was a wide variety of hair styles, with the costume or the features of the model often determining how the hair was arranged.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company reported yesterday that production in the first nine months of this year set a new high record, with billings for war equipment of $612,099,591, an increase of 22 per cent over the figure for the 1943 period.

DETROIT, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Senator George D. Aiken of Vermont brought to Detroit business leaders today messages from President Roosevelt and Governor Dewey reiterating their support of the St. Lawrence seaway and power project.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Publishers Association protested to the Supreme Court today that a lower court had entered the legislative field in ruling that The Associated Press must change its membership by-laws.

Young children who have enjoyed comparative safety after being bombed and shelled when caught in the war's path have not suffered the severe after-effects that many experts predicted, Emily Hahn, the author who was repatriated from Hong Kong on the Gripsholm last year, declared yesterday at a luncheon at the Beekman Hotel.
PARIS, Oct. 24 -- The purge of collaborators with Germany has reached such proportions that in Paris alone the Minister of Justice today ordered what amounts to general mobilization of the judiciary.

Mme. Germaine Schnitzer, former concert pianist, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal court to a charge of conspiracy to violate a Presidential freezing order and to making false statements to a Government agency. Her counsel's plea that she be sentenced immediately, however, was rejected when the court was informed that Mrs. Schnitzer was expected to testify against her alleged fellow conspirators.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 24 -- The Curtiss Commando, ordered by Eastern Air Lines and National Airlines for the New York-Florida run, was shown in its civilian form today. The plane will carry thirty-six or more passengers at from 235 to 242 miles per hour.

Outlining its plans for reconversion to appliance manufacturing, the Proctor Electric Company, a division of Proctor Schwartz, Inc., announced yesterday that it will not seek any price increases for its line of traffic appliances but will market its products at 1942 prices.

LONDON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The first open call for a new civil war in Spain has been issued by the underground newspaper, Conquest of Spain, which urged that officers of the Spanish Army take up arms against Generalissimo Francisco Franco and the Falange, Spanish Republican headquarters here announced today.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., Lehman Brothers, Phelps, Fenn Co. and associates submitted yesterday the high bid for $14,000,000 city of Houston, Tex., water revenue bonds, due on each Oct. 1 from 1947 to 1969. The offer was 100.069 for $2,344,000 as 4 1/4s and $11,656,000 as 2s, representing a net interest cost to the city of 2.12134 per cent.

There is really no such thing as an "expensive" color, according to Dorothy Liebes, California fabric designer, who discussed in an interview here yesterday, her favorite theory that color is the most important thing esthetically in home furnishings, and described some of the designs she is working out for post-war production.
George R. Le Sauvage president of the National Restaurant Association, opposed yesterday a proposal that because of increased patronage restaurants limit the number of their customers.

LYNN MONTROSS was once known to an entire generation of high school and college boys and girls as the creator of an ineffable undergraduate hero called Andy Prothero. With the collaboration of his wife, Lois, he wrote a series of stories about Andy, smoothie, cheer leader and "big man on the campus," that appeared in College Humor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- A declaration that Governor Bricker was one of the signers of an appeal for establishment of temporary refugee havens in the United States was made today by the War Refugee Board in connection with a speech delivered by Mr. Bricker in Denver last night.

The first day's auction of the effects of the late Pierre Laval (we may say late because, though he still walks, his countrymen have sentenced him to death) brought in the equivalent of $20,000. Some of the antique furniture was described as not genuine, the wormholes apparently having been put in by hand, and late.

The first public demonstration of how the Red Cross obtains blood for the armed forces from patriotic donors took place yesterday when a 47-year-old veteran of the first World War gave his twelfth donation of one pint on the steps of the sub-Treasury Building at Wall and Nassau Streets to mark the beginning of an intensified drive for blood donors from the financial district.

Basil J. Vlavianos, editor of the Greek-language newspaper the National Herald, announced yesterday that he had received a letter from President Roosevelt pledging all possible American aid for Greece and expressing the hope that Greece soon would be able to choose its own form of government.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Encouraged by the progress of the American attack on the Philippines, buying of rubber shares was in good volume in today's stock markets. While gains were not large, many classes of shares improved.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 24 -For the first time since the Democratic political machine of Mayor Frank Hague came into control of Hudson County in 1917, a political lieutenant of Mayor Hague and two of his fellow-workers in the Jersey City tax office were named today in indictments returned by the Hudson County grand jury.

LONDON, Oct. 24 (U.P.) -- More than 400 American fighter planes, attacking German transport between the Western Front and Berlin today, hit 150 locomotives and destroyed or damaged 483 railway cars along a 200-mile line extending from Hanover to below Kassel, the United States Eighth Air Force reported.

Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. and Joseph E. Davies, former Ambassador to Russia, will be the principal speakers at a fund-raising dinner Friday night under the auspices of the Business Men for Roosevelt, Inc., which has bought the radio time for the broadcast of President Roosevelt's speech from Philadelphia that same evening, it was announced yesterday.

Dr. Martha M. Eliot, associate chief of the Children's Bureau, denied yesterday that the bureau was seeking to carry over into the post-war period the Emergency Maternity and Infant Care program, through which free medical care is given to wives and babies of service men in the four lowest pay grades of the armed forces.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 24 (UP) -- Chinese forces, fighting with support of the Fourteenth United States Air Force to extend their offensive in southeastern Kwangsi Province, have launched attacks against strong Japanese positions around Kweiping, along the West River bend 120 miles south of Kweilin, Chinese and American communiques disclosed today.
As a bacteriological laboratory worker it has struck me that some recent statements about rabies have drifted toward the twaddle side.

Two events shared the spotlight on the racing card presented by Empire City at Jamaica yesterday. They were the Storm King, a $3,500 race for 3-year-olds at six furlongs, and the Patroon Class D Handicap, run over a mile and three-sixteenths by 3-year-olds and upward, and worth $3,500 added.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, France, Oct. 24 -- The lights have gone up again in parts of Germany. While London is still thoroughly blacked out and most other British cities still require a considerable dimout, two major German cities have turned on their street lights for at least two nights recently.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Oct. 24 (UP) -- A communique: ...

The twelve-story apartment building at 305 Riverside Drive, southeast corner of 103d Street, has been sold by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to Paul S. Hitlin, builder and operator, for cash above a first mortgage of $352,500.

WITH BRITISH FORCES, North of Lamia, Greece, Oct. 24 (U.P.) -- Thousands of tramping, footsore German troops, accompanied by a strong armored formation, were reported today by Allied scouts to be retreating northward from the area of Phersala, 120 miles northwest of Athens, toward Salonika.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- William Sherry, chairman of the legislative committee of the National Association of Independent Tire Dealers, today warned tire manufacturers his organization would seek prohibitive legislation unless they discontinued their retail operations.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 24 -- Governor Dewey declared here tonight before an audience of 18,000 persons that the American delegate on the proposed United Nations Security Council should not be required "to return to Congress for authority every time he had to make a decision."

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, France, Oct. 24 -- Germany is "desperate" for rail transport and is making frantic effort to defend her railroads and rolling stocks with guns and planes and a variety of tricks, according to Maj. Harold Sparks of Frankfort, Ky.

Deploring the growing turnover among civil service employes of the Federal Government as an obstacle to the war. Arthur S. Fleming, member of the United States Civil Service Commission, appealed yesterday to the employes "to stay on the job" until victory and outlined the commission's program for improvement of wages and working conditions.

On the third day of the Battle of Midway, June 6, 1942, an American admiral talking with his staff said, "Well, it looks like we've stopped them again. But where will they hit us next?" His comment was pertinent to our side then. The question now must be on some other minds; those of the Japanese admirals whose battleships and cruisers are reported under attack by American carrier planes in the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Oct. 25 -- Strategic targets on the Japanese island of Kyushu were attacked today by a task force of B-29 Superfortresses of the Twentieth Air Force, Gen. H.H. Arnold, in his capacity as commanding general of the Twentieth, announced early today.

The implication that "springs so readily" from necessary post-war planning that an end of the war is in sight was denounced here last night by Under-Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson, who declared that "winning the war is still the No. 1 job."

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt writes in the November issue of The Ladies Home Journal, released yesterday, that despite criticism she prefers a life of service to the role of Dresden doll "when the world is rocking on its foundations."

The New York Stock Exchange will suspend from dealings tomorrow old securities of the Minneapolis, St. Paul Sault Ste. Marie Railway Company, including the 5 1/2s of 1978, the guaranteed 5s of 1938, the consolidated 4s of 1938, the consolidated 5s of 1938 and the 6s of 1936, and will admit the new securities to dealings.

Ben W. McCready of the Queens Chess Club drew his adjourned game from the fourth round with Thomas Mahon of Brooklyn at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday and tied for second place with Dr. Siegfried Werthammer of Huntington, W. Va., in the annual tournament for the United States Chess Federation amateur championship.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 24 -- For the first time since the war began. Fleet Headquarters have permitted some cautiously hedged disclosures on what Admiral Chester W. Nimitz frequently refers to in his off-the-record press conferences as one of our greatest secret weapons.

WASHINGTON, Oct 24 -- Recent discussions in Moscow by Russian, British and Polish representatives went very well, President Roosevelt reported at his press conference today upon the basis of a luncheon conference with W. Averell Harriman, American Ambassador to the Soviet Union.

Yesterday was movie day in the clubhouse at the Polo Grounds, with the audience restricted to coaches and players of the football Giants and a few curious newspapermen. The feature film, which might have been called "Rolling Up the Car-Pitts," enlisted the earnest and sometimes embarrassed attention of the younger and huskier spectators.

After having opened at the lows of the day unchanged to 3 points below Monday's closing quotations, the cotton futures markets on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday near the best levels of the day with net gains of 2 to 13 points.

The ingeniousness of a salesman in installing a loud burglar alarm in his car to protect its contents of valuable furs landed him in the Downtown Traffic Court yesterday on a summons for disturbing the peace. The gadget went off last Thursday noon in front of 411 Fifth Avenue and shrieked for sixteen minutes, a traffic patrolman told Magistrate J. Roland Sala.

BOSTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Secretary Forrestal was asked today by counsel for Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel, naval commander at Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941, to release immediately the findings of the Court of Inquiry as to his client's innocence or guilt.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 24 -- Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for the Senate, told an enthusiastic audience here tonight that when the voters sent him to Washington he would work for a world organization in which all peace-loving nations, great and small, would be represented at the peace table.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- Bruyere's collection shown today reflects a military tone, in contrast to the general lines of winter attire. Dresses are called "Jeep," "Liberation," "New York," "Los Angeles," "Paris," "Renewal" -- names recurring in the military and political news here.

The New York Women's League for Animals, which has seen much of stray dogs in its operation of the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals at 350 Lafayette Street, wishes to urge dog owners of Greater New York to obey implicitly the order of the Board of Health to leash their dogs when out of doors.
