Lieut. Col. Stanislaw Skalski, Polish ace, said in an interview here yesterday that the robot bomb, because its terrific destruction can be attained with great economy of men and materiel, would be the long-range artillery of the future.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Retention of radio frequencies now assigned for television, press relay and motion picture services, with opportunities for experiments and development of additional facilities, was requested at today's hearing before the Federal Communications Commission.

In your issue of Oct. 8, 1944, is an item captioned, "Challenges Willkie on Newton Baker," in which James M. Thompson challenged Wendell Willkie's statement published by John Temple Graves as to Newton D. Baker's activities in support of a League of Nations plank at the 1924 Democratic National Convention.

Provisions of the Investment Company Act of 1940 were invoked yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission for the filing in Federal court of a complaint accusing Edward V. Otis, Curtis Franklin and other directors of British Type Investors, Inc., of deriving improper profits through their alleged domination of that corporation and two others controlled by it.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- There was a good deal of drama, latent and obvious, in the scene at the Quai d'Orsay when four Ambassadors arrived together to announce to the Foreign Minister that the Allied Powers had recognized the de Gaulle Government as the Provisional Government of France.

Field Marshal Montgomery, speaking this week at a celebration of the second anniversary of the battle of El Alamein, gave way to what was perhaps a natural sentimentality about his old foe, the late Marshal Rommel. "He was a worthy opponent," he said, "and I always respected his military tactics." Military men will understand.

The victory guns of Moscow roared and its wintry sky was ablaze with myriads of colored flares as Marshal Stalin announced to the Russian people that their armies are now fighting on German soil. It was tremendous news, and the Russians, who take their disasters with stoic calm, like to celebrate their victories as they come.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Invitations for a full dress United Nations security conference in this country to endorse the tentative charter framed at Dumbarton Oaks may be sent out in December and the conference itself may be conveed in early winter.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 24 -- Governor Dewey declared here today that he enjoyed the "acquaintance and friendship of most of the members of the United States Senate, but unfortunately I never had the pleasure of meeting Senator Ball."
Following is the text of Governor Dewey's speech last night, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

New York University's football outlook brightened yesterday when it was learned-that Jim Donovan, regular right end, who missed the Boston College game last Friday, will be available for the remainder of the season. Donovan rejoined his mates at practice yesterday.
American forces in the Philippines pushed farther into the interior of Leyte yesterday as our foothold in the islands was secured in less than a week of fighting.
ROME, Oct. 24 (UP) -- A communique

FLORAL PARK, L.I., Oct. 24 -- Sewanhaka provided an upset in holding the unbeaten Hempstead High football team to a 7-all score today, the tie being the second in four games for the visitors. The game was keenly fought all the way.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 24 -- Women in industry, and particularly working mothers, is resulting in a definite lowering of the moral tone of the nation, according to the Rev. Albert J. Murphy, director of Catholic Charities in Cleveland, at today's session of the National Council of Catholic Women's Convention.

"Fashions of the Times," since its first presentation, has taken the pattern of everyday life as its background. On the stage, as in actual living, clothes of all types appear side by side. The third edition of the show, which opened yesterday afternoon in Times Hall, was true to the established form.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Alied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 24 (UP) -- Communique 199:

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 24 -- Women in industry, and particularly working mothers, is resulting in a definite lowering of the moral tone of the nation, according to the Rev. Albert J. Murphy, director of Catholic Charities in Cleveland, at today's session of the National Council of Catholic Women's Convention.

"Fashions of the Times," since its first presentation, has taken the pattern of everyday life as its background. On the stage, as in actual living, clothes of all types appear side by side. The third edition of the show, which opened yesterday afternoon in Times Hall, was true to the established form.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Alied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 24 (UP) -- Communique 199:
Relative to the extension of hours of voting, there is one fact that is never mentioned. How long does the public think grossly underpaid inspectors of election should work?

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- An attempt by this city to force merchants to remove signs that hang over public sidewalks came closer to fruition today through a decision of the Appellate Division validating the plan. Cities throughout the State contemplating similar sign removal laws are watching the case, which may yet go to the Court of Appeals.

At last night's fashion pageant a new shade was introduced -Limelight. For four months top members of the fashion industry have been working with this shade. It belongs in the lime family. A radiant green, it is more crystalline than lime or chartreuse.

Asia will develop as an export market faster than Europe can get back into a normal type of trading, Col. C. Warren Boulton, managing director of Machine Tools (India) Ltd., told a meeting of the Export Managers Club of New York yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

For the thirteenth consecutive time over a two-year period the Notre Dame football team rates as the country's No. 1 eleven in The Associated Press poll, but this time the Irish margin is a mere eight points.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 24 (U.P.) -When patrol planes sighted the Japanese fleet steaming through the Sibuyan Sea -- at the closest point only 140 miles from the west coast of Leyte -- and the Sulu Sea to the west, and flashed the news, Hellcat, Helldiver, Avenger and Corsair planes from Admiral Halsey's Third Fleet went immediately to the attack.

DENVER, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Senator Millikin, Republican, of Colorado says he does not want to "trade epithets with Senator Truman, for that would be like wrestling with a cipher," but he added that he objects to the "isolationist" label the Democratic Vice Presidential nominee has pinned on him and seven other Republicans seeking re-election.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- The ten counties of the Sixth Judicial District, Broome, Chemung, Chenango, Cortland, Delaware, Madison, Otsego, Schuyler, Tioga and Tompkins, are expected to give Governor Dewey, Republican nominee for President a greater plurality than the 78,706 margin given to Wendell L. Willkie in 1940 and considerably more than Mr. Dewey's 1942 majority of 74,941 over John J. Bennett Jr. and Dean Alfange, his two opponents for Governor.

EN ROUTE WITH BRICKER, Oct 24 (AP) -- Governor John W. Bricker of Ohio, deciding to make a strong bid for the home State of his Democratic rival for the Vice Presidency, tonight added six speeches to his Missouri program.

Roy M.D. Richardson, Republican candidate for Congress in Brooklyn's Seventh District, may falter a bit in turning a neat souffle, but he is pretty sure that the cook books that his Democratic opponent, Representative John J. Delaney, has sent to 10,000 women in the district will do little or nothing to ease current wartime food shortages.

ATHENS, Oct. 23 (Delayed) -- More than 800 armed members of the Edes, whose Greek initials stand for National Democratic Revolutionary Union, have obeyed Prime Minister George Papandreou's orders to leave Athens, and in most cases complied with his suggestion to join their warrior chief, Gen. Napoleon Zervas, whose circumscribed area lies in Epirus.

Dealers feel that the security markets are getting into excellent shape for the Sixth War Loan drive. Bank loans to others than brokers and dealers for carrying Government securities provide an excellent index of this condition. Before the Fifth War Loan these were down to $266,000,000.

As he was imposing what may prove to be a ten-year sentence on 20-year-old Helen McEniry, former inmate of orphanages, with a police record, General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein demanded yesterday that the State establish institutions where offenders of her type could be rehabilitated after leaving prisons or correctional institutions.
The Rev. and Mrs. Walden Pell 2d have arrived from Middletown, Del., and are at the Biltmore.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Sixty miles of rainy Saturday in New York last week was duck soup for Fala, who improved the campaign hours by catching on to a new trick, Mrs. Roosevelt reported to her press conference today.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 24 -- Endorsed for United States Senator by every major labor group, Wayne Morse, Republican liberal, is charging all over Oregon these days calling for the ousting of the Roosevelt Administration, which is supported by the same labor factions as he is.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 24 -- Anchor towns at both ends of the yielding German line between the Nijmegen salient and the North Sea in the Netherlands came within range of Allied field guns today.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Wednesday, Oct. 25 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's invasion troops, killing more than 3,000 Japanese, have captured at least twelve Leyte towns and villages on an expanding twenty-five-mile front and have fought their way into the outskirts of San Pablo, only seventeen and a half miles from the west coast of the island, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (U.P.) -Whole blood flown daily directly from this country to Paris is being transfused to wounded soldiers in France, sometimes within twenty-four hours after it is given by donors in Washington, New York and Boston, the War Department stated tonight.

In an expansion move, the Maron Confections Company, candy manufacturers, bought from Frederick Brown the two-story building at 321-43 West Fifty-fourth Street, 200 by 100.5 feet, now occupied as a garage. Irving Dorf was the broker.

WITH THE BRITISH SECOND ARMY at 's Hertogenbosch, the Netherlands, Oct. 24 -- British forces captured about half of 's Hertogenbosch today in unspectacular fighting that followed an almost night-long barrage in which British light, medium and heavy guns blew the Germans from the surburban village of Hintham and the northeastern outskirts of the city.
HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 24 -Under heavy political odds, Vaino A. Tranner, leader of the FinnishSocial Democrat party, won the first round in the struggle for party hegemony during the last few days.

The Navy permitted the Grumman factory at Bethpage, L.I., to announce yesterday some of the improvements and some of the achievements of a new version of the Grumman Hellcat, now in both the Pacific and European theatres. By refinement in detail the F6F-5 is reported to be twenty knots faster than its predecessor, the F6F-3, which was in the 400-knot category.

Bailey B. Burritt, known as "the father of the family health movement,'' was the guest of honor last night at a dinner at the Hotel Plaza, arranged on the eve of his retirement as chairman of the executive council of the Community Service Society, with which he has been connected for thirty-one years. He will retire on Nov. 1.

The possibility that the scope of any special session of the State Legislature that might be called by Governor Dewey to extend voting hours would be widened to embrace the subject of commercial rent control was emphasized yesterday by realty and political observers on the basis of the latest developments in the business rental situation here.
